column2: Your editorial of Jan. 7 "On the Production Front" is a succinct and admirable summation of the accomplishments and problems of American industry in the current national crisis.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 37 to 42 points net lower on the active months than on Saturday.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The State Liquor Authority told the Legislature tonight that there had been a marked change in the drinking habits of the state's residents during the last ten years.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations in Prime Minister Churchill's Cabinet, said today that he was confident that the meeting of Commonwealth Finance Ministers beginning in London tomorrow would demonstrate to the world both the determination and the ability to overcome the difficulties that confront Britain and the sterling area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced changes today in its 1952 crop goals which call for a 6 per cent increase in production over last year instead of the 4 per cent previously announced.
The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., announced yesterday that it was donating $609,000 to thirty-six philanthropic and labor causes in the United States and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman asked Congress today to extend for two years the Government's authority to own and operate all-purpose synthetic rubber plants but suggested that efforts be made to encourage private capital to construct additional plants producing butyl, a specialty product.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 14 -- Two Navy pilots stationed at the United States Naval Air Station at near-by Pomona are missing and assumed to be lost after their Skyraider attack bombers collided at sea during a flight off the Carolina coast yesterday afternoon, authorities at the base announced today.

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Joe Adonis, metropolitan gambler who is serving a prison term on charges of operating a gambling enterprise in Bergen County, asked the State Supreme Court today to relieve him of paying a $15,000 fine and serving five years probation.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 14 -A heavily escorted French convoy was fighting its way today from Hanoi to beseiged Hoabinh over a mountain road harassed by pro-Communist Vietminh troops seeking to block the land route between the two points.
Coffee and cocoa moved against a down-trend pravalent in most commodity futures markets yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The three major Western powers proposed formally today that the Soviet Union's new atomic control proposals be forwarded to the United Nations Disarmament Commission for its consideration.

New internationally inspired prints and a new crease-resistant process for cottons have made Altman's fabric customers anxious to get working on summer fashions. In the first of a week-long series of fashion shows, the store presented yesterday eighteen styles of Bates fabrics.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 14 -- After holding a 30 -- 27 lead at half-time, the Fordham Rams outplayed St. Peters College to record their sixth basketball victory of the season, 80 -- 46.

Trapped by a fire from a detective oil heater, Walter H. Farrar Jr., 28-year-old victim of polio rolled from his wheel chair out the window of his bedroom on the second floor of 941 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday. He died in Greenpoint Hospital at 5:10 A. M.
STELLARTON, N. S., Jan. 14 -- Death and disaster struck this Nova Scotia coal mining town today following an explosion and fire in the McGregor mine. Nineteen workers in the mine were killed.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A new hand took hold of Pitt's wavering football fortunes today as Lowell (Red) Dawson obtained the head coaching job at the sky-scraper university.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- United States military aid to Iran has been suspended, at least for the time being, as a result of the Teheran Government's failure to meet terms of the Mutual Security Act.

The Terminal Warehouse Property, occupying the entire block between West Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Street and Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, has been acquired in a joint purchase by the Hemmerdinger Estate Corporation and the Lefcourt Realty Corporation from Irving Geist. The property comprises twenty-five adjoining seven and nine-story buildings. It has an assessed valuation of $3,100,000, of which $980,000 represents land value.

Benjamin Franklin's idea that an education should include both cultural and practical studies is evident in the curriculum of public schools in New York, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools for the city, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A resolution to dismiss the Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs from further jurisdiction over House-approved legislation designed to give undisputed ownership of rich oil lands beneath the marginal sea to coastal states was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas.

Illinois topped the college basketball ratings of the United Press board of coaches for the fifth week in a row yesterday and St. Bonaventure and Duquesne gained places among the top ten for the first time this season.

The Audubon Artists, celebrating a decade as a national exhibiting organization, will open the largest show in its ten-year history on Thursday at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at Ninetieth Street.

The type of cases considered by the National Labor Relations Board reflects the changing social and economic aspects of industrial relations. Now, for the first time in its sixteen-year history, the board has been asked and has consented to direct an election among employes of a labor union.

The second day of the winter New York Lamp Show in the New Yorker Hotel ended yesterday, with the buying tempo accelerated appreciably. The show, open to the trade only, will run through Friday. Hours are 9 A. M. to 7 P. M. through Thursday and 9 A. M. to 3 P. M. Friday.

The Musicians' Guild presented one of its finest concerts last night. It was an event that had not only some of the most exhilarating performances in recent memory, but possessed shape all of its own.

The reinforced plastics industry, now relatively small, is bound to become large, according to the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc. These materials, the society said last week, do not compete with other plastics but rather with metals, wood, glass and other structural materials.
An "edible" paint for baby's furniture and some new paints for woodwork, walls and floors are available here now.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue submitted to Congress today:...

Net operating earnings of the Irving Trust Company last year amounted to $7,778,924, equal to $1.55 a share, compared with $7,406,412, or $1.48 a share, in the previous year, according to the bank's annual report, just issued. The report, signed by William N. Enstrom, chairman, and Richard H. West, president, is being mailed to stockholders in advance of their annual meeting to be held on Jan. 30.

A wage increase of $3 a week retroactive to Jan. 1 for 12,000 employes in Manhattan loft and office buildings was announced yesterday by David Sullivan, president of Local 32B, Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L.

A two-engine Northeast Airlines Convair, inbound from Boston with thirty-three passengers and a crew of three, just missed making a radar-guided landing at La Guardia Airport through the drizzle and fog yesterday morning and plunged into the East River.
LONDON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, hero of the Flying Enterprise, said today that he was not entitled to a big ticker-tape welcome in New York because he had failed to save his ship.

The five-member Board of Health, at its regular monthly meeting yesterday, angrily denounced a recent decision by the United States Department of Agriculture that allows meat processors to double the amount of saltwater pumped into corned beef in the curing process.

As the 1952 fund appeal for The Salvation Army in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens opened yesterday, its chairman, Joseph H. McConnell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, announced that a volunteer corps of famous persons in the creative arts would participate.

Saudi Arabia Airlines, with routes extending from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to Cairo, Egypt, Lebanon, and Karachi, Pakistan, has become an important part of Saudi Arabia's transportation and communication system. The company was started in 1946.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Salary increases for the forty-five Westchester Supervisors and the County Clerk, Sheriff and District Attorney were advocated here today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach in his annual message to the Board of Supervisors.

Under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the New York Foundling Hospital, a luncheon and fashion show will be given today at Sherry's in behalf of the hospital. Mrs. Helmuth Kranich Jr. was recently elected president of the auxiliary, and Miss Betty Johnson is chairman of the junior committee aiding in the plans for the fashion show.
Dr. Courtnay Pitt, vice president-finance, has been named to the top-level management policy committee of the Philco Corporation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 14 -- Menachem Begin, head of the extreme right-wing nationalist Herut party, said today in an interview that he was bending all his energies toward bringing about a plebiscite on the question whether Israel should engage in direct negotiations with Germany for reparations.

The adoption in the city's new master zoning plan of the special regulations designed to eliminate the carnival type of enterprises in the "Great White Way area" was called for by the Broadway Association yesterday.

Known and loved by people of all races and creeds in all walks of life in the city, the Salvation Army is now completing its seventy-second year of service to the troubled, the sick, the aged and the young.

On the occasion of its centennial the Young Men's Christian Association finds itself, despite its rural units and far-flung semi-missionary activities, essentially an urban organization. The Y. M. C. A. now embraces some 1,700 branches with nearly 2,000,000 members, but most of these branches are established in city areas.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 14 -- The Association of Argentine Writers has asked academicians of Argentina and Spain to introduce officially two "isms" into the Spanish language. The words are peronism and justicialism.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The United Nations has agreed to purge itself of any association with a report titled, "The Refugee in the Post-War World," which it published recently under a grant by the Rockefeller Foundation.

Capt. Franklin B. Weaver, 30-year-old master of the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Trader, voluntarily surrendered yesterday to United States Attorney Myles J. Lane to face a charge of murder on the high seas.

From organizations that had as their principal purpose the maintenance of institutions providing a minimum of food, clothing and shelter for needy youngsters, the nation's child welfare agencies have become today specialized services offering help with mental and emotional difficulties as well, Spencer H. Crookes, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America, said yesterday.

Colonial Airlines, Inc., filed a $500,000 damage suit yesterday in Federal Court against three of its former executives and an advertising agency. The suit alleged false expense accounts and general misuse of funds.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Former heavyweight boxing champion Joe Louis today termed his battle with the Professional Golfers Association the "biggest fight" of his life. Despite the ban of Negro entrants, he expects to play in the San Diego invitational open golf tournament which starts on Thursday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 14 -- Interior Minister Alexander Rankovic reported, several days ago to the fourth annual conference of the Communist party organization of the state security police [UDBA] that there had been a noticeable decline of enthusiasm for their party work among Yugoslav Communists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -European-American Airlines, Inc., asked the Government's permission today to set up an "air freight bridge" between the United States and Western Europe.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 -- British Prime Minister Churchill declared tonight that the United States, Britain, Canada and Western Europe stood united "to defend the cause of freedom with all our strength" and he called the North Atlantic Treaty the surest guarantee of victory should war be forced upon them.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Mayor Impellitteri's legislation to provide actual functioning for the New York City Parking Authority was introduced in the Legislature tonight by Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo and Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens of Brewster, the Republican fiscal leaders.

Three hundred and nine gifts, ranging from $1,000 to $1 and including $267 from 209 members of THE NEW YORK TIMES Chapel of Local 6 of the International Typo-grapical Union were acknowledged yesterday on behalf of the Neediest Cases Fund.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Tuesday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The United States Navy said today that all twelve crewmen died when a big patrol bomber crashed and burned late yesterday in a rice field near Atsugi air base.

SAN FRANCISCO Jan. 14 -- The westbound City of San Francisco streamliner with 226 passengers and crewmen aboard was stranded in a blizzard without heat at the top of the High Sierras tonight as the worst storm in half a century swept California and Nevada.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman today nominated William H. Draper Jr. of New York to be his special representative in Europe, with the rank of Ambassador, to act as the senior United States civilian official concerned with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the economic and military aid program under the Mutual Security Act.

Ed Hickey's St. Louis Billikens, who beat Kentucky in the Sugar Bowl recently, tackle Howard Cann's New York University team and St. John's faces Manhattan in an interborough battle on the collegiate twin bill at Madison Square Garden tonight.

THE National Collegiate Athletic Association hasn't quite made the bold, firm leap toward Utopia but it has finally got off the treadmill and taken a cautious step in the right direction. Ever since the N. C. A. A. started to flex its muscles on that treadmill, it has been annually decrying sin but never hitting the sawdust trail toward redemption.

Johnston, Lemon Co. and underwriting associates will place on the market today an issue of $1,400,000 of convertible subordinated debentures of the Southern Oxygen Company, producer of gases and chemical products in Maryland, Tennessee and North Carolina.
DOTHAN, Ala., Jan. 14 (UP) -- A dynamite explosion wrecked the home of a witness in the 1951 Alabama parole Scandal early today.

After seven hours' deliberation, a jury of ten men and two women reported last midnight to Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan in Federal Court that it had been unable to reach a verdict in the case of Frank Costello, the gambler, on trial for contempt before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee last March.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,129, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

For three years one of the most important phases of the cold war between Russia and the United States has been the contest over German youth. Russia has exerted herself to the uttermost. She has appealed in every possible way to the pride and prejudice of those within her orbit.
BOSTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- A rookie's first major league penalty helped Toronto's second-place Maple Leafs to beat the Boston Bruins, 1 -- 0, before 8,224 fans at the Boston Garden tonight.

This country's privately owned, ocean-going tanker fleet increased only slightly in size during 1951, but on Jan. 1 of this year was still the world's largest under a single flag, according to a report released yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 15 -- An investigating committee announced today that it had found no violation of the principles of academic freedom in the dismissal by the University of Minnesota of Dr. Forrest O. Wiggins, Negro philosophy instructor.

NEW BRUNSWICK, in opening up more than 100 miles of salmon rivers previously leased to private individuals and groups, is making a strong bid for popularity among visiting salmon fishermen, many of whom have protested what they term "high license fees and restricted angling."

GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan 15 (UP) -- An angry father said today he was ordering a special letterhead with a tombstone on it for use when he sent his dead marine son's Purple Heart Medal back to President Truman.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., Jan. 15 -- A study of tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike to effect possible reductions was pledged by turnpike authority officials today as the final nine-mile section of the 118-mile road was formally dedicated and placed in operation here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The National Science Foundation reported to Congress today its general plans for speedily placing the nation's research and development programs in a state of "operational readiness." for possible war or an extended period of preparedness, perhaps lasting many years.

The most important change in education in this generation has been "the rapid development of parent participation in the planning and operation of school programs," Dr. Howard Lane, Professor of Education at New York University and specialist on youth problems, declared last night.

ROME, Jan. 15 -- The fine hand of Italian fashion showed itself for the first time in 1952 today as specially invited buyers and members of the press previewed the spring collection of Countess Simonetta Visconti.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Louis Budenz told the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities today that Grace Maul Granich served as an aide to one of the Communist party's top operators in 1935.

SEATTLE, Jan. 15--The SeattleFirst National Bank had one of the most profitable years in its history last year, with earnings topping those for 1950, Lawrence M. Arnold,, clairman and Albert R. lV[unger, president, reported at the bank's annual meeting today. The stockholders elected Volney Richmond Jr. to the board of directors to succeed P. E. Harris of Seattle.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of Mrs. Isaac Gilman as president of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations will be celebrated today at the group's thirty-second annual convention and luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

Pending clarification of a Board of Education regulation, only parent groups and the Boy and Girl Scouts will be permitted to use public school buildings for after-school meetings free of charge, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Under the Arc de Triomphe, France's monument to her military glory, President Vincent Auriol tonight placed a marshal's baton before the flag-shrouded coffin of Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, who died Friday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Representative Hale Boggs and Carlos Spaht, rivals backed by politically split members of the powerful Long family, raced ahead in early returns from today's Democratic primary for Governor.

MOASCAR, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- A new Egyptian guerrilla attack was launched in the Tel el Kebir area today against the British road-block near the filtration plant. Heavy fire was exchanged between British troops and a small party of Egyptians.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 15 -- Communications along the single highway route linking Hanoi with the French-held mountain post of Hoabinh, forty miles west of here, have been re-established, a headquarters spokesman said here today.

Two bookmakers who were key witnesses at the recent State Crime Commission public hearings in Staten Island received stiff jail sentences yesterday for refusing to cooperate with the special grand jury now investigating crime and official corruption on the island.

Budget Breakdown Submitted to Board -- Refinancing of Transit Deficit Studied Realization of the city's goal to obtain from the State Legislature in increased state aid and new taxes about $200,000,000 above current revenues to finance the city's 1952-53 budget would mean salary increases of about $300 a year for 100,000 city employes, Mayor Impellitteri said last night.

The Baroness Tweedsmuir, Member of Parliament and leader in British activities from films to advertising, at the first monthly luncheon of the Woman's Advertising Club of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday said great advances have been made through advertising and public relations in affecting British thinking at all levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today an expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty to admit Greece and Turkey and thus to throw the Eisenhower defensive line eastward across the whole of the Mediterranean.

Stockholders of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation at a special meeting here yesterday authorized a $5,000,000 issue of convertible preferred stock to meet the working capital requirements of the expanding volume of operations.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Russell L. Snodgrass, financial vice president of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, said today the railroad "has no outstanding loan with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation."

Ralph E. Ablon of Luria Brothers Co., New York, was elected president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel yesterday at the closing session of the organization's three-day annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. David C. Holub of the Holub Iron and Steel Company, Akron, Ohio, was elected first vice president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to increase by 10 per cent the basic pay and allowances for quarters and subsistence of all members of the armed forces, as well as the pay of all retired personnel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- Handsome word portraits of four "first-rate winning candidates" pictured as capable of beating anybody the Democrats might enter in the fall Presidential contest were painted for Republican women leaders here today.
YONKERS, Jan. 15 -- The tangled affairs of this city's civilian volunteer services became slightly less tangled today.

The hearty New York welcome that had been prepared for today in honor of Capt. Kurt Carlsen, heroic skipper of the Flying Enterprise, has been postponed until tomorrow. The freighter captain's plane, carrying him from London to New York last night, developed mechanical trouble over the Atlantic Ocean, jettisoned some of its extra fuel tanks and then put back to Shannon Airport in Ireland.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- A controversy regarding the control of atomic research in Britain arose again today in a symposium in the Journal of the Atomic Scientists Association, a small but influential newsletter in which five leading scientists have been arguing whether the atomic plant should remain under ministerial supervision or become a semi-independent project like the Atomic Energy Commission in the United States or the British Coal Board.

The resignation of Joseph K. Carson Jr. as executive vice president of the Propeller Club of the United States was accepted "with regret" yesterday. Mr. Carson will leave the organization on Feb. 1 after nineteen months with the club.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- General Headquarter communique 1,130, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- A strike of twelve cargo checkers for higher wages today shut down three of the busiest piers on the Delaware waterfront here and kept more than 1,000 other dock workers from their jobs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Office of Price Stabilization said today that the ceiling price on coffee will not be raised despite Brazil's decision to increase its price above the ceiling.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- The United States Weather Bureau office in Los Angeles found itself caught in a Hollywood rumor today.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Jan. 15 (AP) -- College football rulemakers tried to make it clear today that they wanted unnecessary roughness stopped.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets carried the air war deep into North Korea yesterday, damaging two out of 190 Communist MIG's encountered in two sky battles.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 15 -- Anticipating new and perhaps more enticing East German moves for reunification, Western Allied and German officials say they are planning some moves of their own.

Inability of commercial banks to participate in the earnings of the Federal Reserve System constitutes "a special tax on banks," N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, asserted yesterday. Speaking at the bank's annual meeting of stockholders, Mr. Jackson emphasized however that Chemical believes fully in a strong independent Federal Reserve System.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Payment of price differentials in "distress" cases and the use of whatever flexibility is possible in awarding Government contracts are two means by which the Small Defense Plants Administration is endeavoring to help small business in this emergency, Telford Taylor, head of the Small Plants Administration, said today.

ALBANY, Jan 15 -- Two political deals involving the creation of additional judgeships in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn and their division on a bipartisan are under discussion among Republican and Democratic legislators and party leaders.

Events tonight: Verdi's "Rigo-letto," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Ernest Ansermet, conductor, Bernard Zighera, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Ernst Wolff, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet and Nadia Reisenberg, piano, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; Sylvia Marlowe, harpsichord, and Luigi Silva, 'cello, Mannes Music School, 8:30.

Zachary Solov, choreographer and ballet master of the Metropolitan Opera, has been named first winner of the Capezio Dance Award of $500 to be granted annually for important achievement in dance in the United States.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly completed a unique session today during which the small nations took the initiative and carried a series of resolutions on dependencies that at best are unwelcome to the Western Powers.

Turning to the paintings of the early nineteenth century for inspiration, Erik Braagaard and Adolfo Sardinas turned forth a hat collection yesterday at their salon on East Fifty-sixth Street that was enchanting in its delicacy and air of romantic femininity.
MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- The curling rink at the historic St. Andrews Golf Club presented an unfamiliar scene today.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The conference of Commonwealth finance ministers called to discuss the balance-of-payments crisis in the sterling area began here today. Chancellor of the Exchequer Richard Austin Butler, leader of the British delegation, presided.
Nicholas DeFalco has been appointed manager of the receiver quality control department of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A New York business man and a Texas lawyer and oil man today won control of the Illinois Zinc Company in a stockholders' proxy contest.

The most important word in this report for 1951 is "taxes," Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, told stockholders yesterday in presenting his annual statement of operations. Earnings before taxes, he said, amounted to $47,027,000, or $6.36 a share, an increase of $1.52 over 1950.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 3,668, compared with 3,624 last week and 3,611 in the similar week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,427 arrivals yesterday against 2,128 last Tuesday.

The price of milk, which ordinarily shows a seasonal decline in late spring and early summer, is not expected to drop as much as usual this year, according to the local office of the State Extension Service in Marketing. Rising cost of farm production plus heavier operating expenses for milk dealers are the reasons for this recent prediction.

Eight witnesses, including Al Weill, matchmaker of the International Boxing Club, testified yesterday before a grand jury investigating the slugging of Mr. Weill and an attempted assault on a referee after the fight last Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Shortages of the three basic metals -- steel, copper and aluminum -- will continue at least through June and probably September, John D. Small, chairman of the Munitions Board, Department of Defense, declared here today.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- A new campaign to terminate the costly and exasperating Communist-led guerrilla war in Malaya was announced here today. Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, a distinguished and dynamic soldier with considerable political experience, was put in charge of it.

Ruggiero Ricci played a new sonata for unaccompanied violin by Bernd Alois Zimmermann at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Zimmermann, born in 1918 in Germany, was a pupil in composition of Philip Jarnach. His sonata is in three movements of a somewhat improvisational nature, a "Praeludium," "Rhapsodie" and "Toccata," the latter based on the famous four notes of Bach's name in the German spelling -- B flat, A, C, and B.

LYNBROOK, L. I., Jan. 15 -- A nail driven into a section of armored electric cable last Friday was found to have been the origin of a $200,000 fire that swept through a store and office building here yesterday.

Next week has been dedicated as Mrs. Warburg Tribute Week by the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York in honor of almost four decades of effort by Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, an honorary chairman of the division, in behalf of underprivileged persons.

Increased participation by trade unions in community social services was reported yesterday at a luncheon conference here in celebration of the fifth anniversary of the Labor Participation Department of Community Chests and Councils of America. The meeting was held at the New Weston Hotel.

Back in 1908 a dignified, sharp-eyed Italian named Giulio Gatti-Casazza came to New York to become general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, a post he held for twenty-seven years. At that time he pointed out that the Opera House, built in 1883, had a handsome auditorium but that in many practical respects it was poorly arranged and improperly equipped.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 15 -- A motion picture designed to orient boys and girls of high school age for future military service brought forth protests here today from delegates at the opening session of the annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

Combined net asset value of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation and its affiliate, last United States and International Securities Corporation, on Dec. 31, last, was $121,240,953, compared with $96,720,710 at the end of 1950.

Before flying back to England last evening, Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, expressed himself as "very much encouraged" by his conversations with United States and Canadian leaders. He said the "wide-ranging and successful" talks had produced "close agreement," between Britain and the United States, bringing world peace closer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Making full use of a height advantage, the Cornell basketball team defeated Yale, 60 -- 52, tonight to move into a three-way tie with Penn and Princeton for the Eastern Intercollegiate League lead.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Paul L. Fischof, a private detective employed last July by Billy Rose to recover stolen jewelry, lost his license today for playing off an estranged husband and wife. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Mason, against each other and collecting fees from both.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Ada C. Stable's Jaco, a staunchly-backed favorite, made a show of a field of seven 3-year-olds that met in the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association today cleared the way for Joe Louis to play as an invited amateur in the San Diego open tournament Thursday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Connecticut highway, motor vehicle and police officials told the Legislative Council today that the Merritt Parkway was inadequate to handle the present traffic load in Fairfield County and submitted several solutions for consideration.

Jakob Gimpel, Polish pianist who began playing in this country in 1939, gave a recital at Town Hall last night which was his first solo program here in four years. His return was impressive, for his playing had an emotional depth that was lacking in earlier appearances.

Premier Willem Drees of the Netherlands visited the garment district yesterday cloaked in secrecy. This circumstance arose when the genial statesman was in fact isolated by order of the State Department in Washington without his knowledge or desire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Charles W. Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today that there would be a substantial increase in unemployment when the defense drive hit its peak in the second quarter of this year but it would not be serious.

The Frank Costello jury, hopelessly deadlocked 11 to 1 for conviction of the gambler on contempt charges, was dismissed at its own request by Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan yesterday after it had deliberated just short of twenty-four hours.

The fact that there is an increasing number of variations on the style called contemporary will be emphasized by two series of model rooms opening today. This was also apparent at last week's wholesale home-furnishings market in Chicago.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- Dispersion of defense plants, a policy that has been condemned by labor leaders as a prime cause of unemployment in Detroit, remains a key objective in Government planning, Maj. Gen. Francis H. Griswold, military director of the Munitions Board, said here today.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Hamilton Richardson, United States junior tennis champion, said today he planned to go home before the Australian championships finished in order to register at college.

The stock market ran into sufficient selling yesterday to reverse a trend to the higher side prevalent in the four preceding sessions. The drift to the easier side came in spurts with quiet profit-taking evident whenever bidding relaxed. The sharpest retreats appeared in a long line of selected issues.

Talented St. Louis defeated New York University's basketball team by 75 -- 66 before 14,938 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. Then St. John's, held in check for one half, scored an easy victory over Manhattan, 63 -- 53, in the second game of the last double-header until Feb. 7, as the ice show takes over the Arena.

The first larceny indictments in the holdover Brooklyn rackets grand jury's current investigation of the waterfront were handed up yesterday against a dock checker and a salvage dealer. Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz asserted a "new day " in law enforcement had arrived.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- The elimination of private insurance companies from the field of workmen's compensation insurance was urged today in a legislative program adopted by the State Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

First Army Headquarters, Governors Island, announced yesterday that 25,300 students were enrolled in the Army's Reserve Officers Training Corps at colleges, universities and secondary schools in New York State, New Jersey and New England.

The Board of Education's budget estimate for 1952-53 was praised yesterday at a public meeting for containing some improvements over previous budgets, but was criticized generally for failing to go far enough in attempting to meet the needs of the city's pupils.

Manufacturing chemists warned yesterday that no useful purpose would be served by proposed legislation that would require "affirmative" permission by the Food and Drug Administration before the introduction of new chemicals for processing and packaging foods.

The letter of a correspondent printed in your issue of Jan. 7 in which he cites Article III, Section 2, of our Constitution as a basis for the American Government attaching Hungarian funds in this country as a counter-measure of reprisal for the $120,000 fine imposed and paid by our Government for the release of four American fliers seems to me to contain a lot of pure nonsense, with all due respect to the writer.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 15 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be notified formally by cablegram Thursday that his name has been entered for the New Hampshire Presidential preference primary, March 11. The New Hampshire primary is the nation's first.

SEATTLE, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A lone lifeboat, overturned and tossing amid some debris believed to be from the hold of the missing freighter Pennsylvania, told today of the probable fate of the crew of the ship.

Four of six unlicensed seamen, who were rescued on Dec. 29 when all but Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen abandoned the sinking American freighter Flying Enterprise, praised the master yesterday as a "good seaman and skipper," with whom they would not hesitate to sail again.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 15 -- The Israeli Government received a green light from the Knesset (Parliament) today to "act in the matter of reparations from Germany in accordance with the needs of the hour."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The National Labor Relations Board reinforced today its doctrine that it could not rule on the merits of a union jurisdiction dispute when the parties had an agreement on methods for private arbitration of their disputes.

Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings at the Pierre for the forty-third annual Blue Ridge Ball in behalf of the Blue Ridge School in Bristol, Va., to be held on the night of Jan. 25 in the main ballroom of the hotel.

Controller Lazarus Joseph's independent statement of views on city economy, budget and tax problems is a welcome and healthy sign that someone within the Board of Estimate is reaching out for a policy other than drift.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Two general officers and two enlisted men became today the first Army recipients of the Armed Forces Reserve Medals. The medal was established last fall by executive order to honor members of Reserve organizations for ten years of "honorable and satisfactory service."

Joseph E. Boland, assistant corporation counsel of Yonkers, asserted yesterday that "traffic losses would be tremendous" if the New York Central Railroad won its petition for higher rates. He testified at a hearing before the Public Service Commission on the railroad petition asking for 30 per cent increases in the prices of restricted and unrestricted monthly commutation tickets and 21 1/2 per cent on twenty-six trip multiple-ride tickets.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Stringent legislation subjecting members or supporters of organizations judged "subversive" by the courts to fines, jail sentences and occupational restrictions was introduced in the Assembly today.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 16 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida has assured the United States that Japan will not recognize Communist China and hopes to conclude a peace treaty with Nationalist China, it was officially disclosed today.

The wreck of the twin-engined Convair that crashed and sank Monday morning in shallow water off Rikers Island was hoisted out of the East River yesterday by a giant crane and taken to the Marine Terminal at LaGuardia Airport.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur received yesterday the Gold Medal of Achievement of the Poor Richard Club of Philadelphia in a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Jackie, a brown and white chow-and-shepherd dog, went home from Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday with Mrs. Inocencia Feliciano and her 11-year-old son, Hector, after Magistrate Harry G. Andrews had accused another claimant to the animal of telling lies in support of his claim.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Charles E. Wilson, defense mobilization director, warned today that the props would be knocked from under price billings if the C. I. O. is successful in getting a wage boost breaching the Government's wage increase ceilings.

Joseph C. Grew, chairman of the board of directors of the National Committee for a Free Europe announced yesterday the election of Read Admiral Harold B. Miller, U. S. N., retired, as president, effective March 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Blames Hidalgo, one-time undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation working in the Communist party, said today that no amount of money could compensate for the suffering he underwent during his years as a counterspy.

Was it a mere whim of nature or was it an invasion from Europe or the Orient that sent scientists from the American Museum of Natural History and the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine of the Department of Agriculture scurrying recently to the lake at Central Park to examine an army of snails?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation had to be "forced" to take action on multimillion dollar irregularities in its grain storage program, Controller General Lindsay Warren told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged in the Senate today that David Demarest Lloyd, an administrative assistant to President Truman, obtained his $17,500-a-year job after White House "pressure" had been applied to the Loyalty Review Board to clear his record.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Edgar Faure, Minister of Justice, tonight told President Vincent Auriol that he would decide finally tomorrow as to whether he would try to form a Cabinet. It was believed probable that he would try, and if so might ask the National Assembly to endorse him as Premier Thursday.

NORWALK, Ohio, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A freight train rammed the rear of a New York Central passenger train twelve miles southeast of here today, injuring more than thirty passengers. Only one was hurt seriously.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The Arab members of the United Nations won at least a temporary victory today when the General Assembly's special Political Committee approved a resolution enlarging the Palestine Conciliation Commission and expressing the Assembly's regret that Arab refugees had not been readmitted to Israel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Maj. Robert J. Barrett acknowledged today that "eight or ten men" grew rich operating numbers rackets in Washington while he was superintendent of police here.

AGNES DE MILLE, creator of the celebrated ballet "Rodeo," choreographer of "Oklahoma!," "Carousel," "Bloomer Girl" and "One Touch of Venus," feels about dancing the way Belmonte felt about bull fighting, the way Gauguin felt about painting, the way the ancient martyrs felt about their holy faith. She first discovered her vocation as a child when she was taken to see the great Pavlova.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- An important part of the foreign trade of most countries is subject to restrictions imposed because of balance of payments difficulties, the governments adhering to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade conclude in a report published here today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 15 -- A grief-stricken mother and father were found unconscious in their home tonight beside the body of their only child, a 7-year-old girl, which the father had taken from Norwalk General Hospital earlier today.

Life in department stores will be characterized in fact and fiction by two books to be published soon. Ernestine Gilbreth Carey's "Jumping Jupiter," to be issued by Crowell next Tuesday, is a humorous story about work in a giant department store as seen through the eyes of a toy buyer.
The steel shortage has hit the nation's schools a terrific wallop.

The American Bankers Association has filed a formal protest against a proposed amendment of Securities and Exchange Commission regulations to permit directors of commercial banks to serve as directors of registered holding companies and their subsidiaries but prohibiting bank officers from holding such directorships.

COLFAX, Calif., Jan. 15 -- A highway department snowplow and two trucks bored through huge drifts tonight to within five miles of the snowbound streamliner City of San Francisco in 7,200-foot Donner Pass.

THE longer a fellow lingers on the baseball sidelines the less he is able to understand the way big leaguers totally disregard the very fundamentals on which their sport is based. Comparatively few of them even know how to bunt, but lunge frantically at a ball like your maiden aunt trying to swat a bee with a canoe paddle at a church picnic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The 31,000 military and civilian personnel staffing the Pentagon held their first air raid drill since the end of World War II this afternoon. It appeared for the most part to have gone off without more than the average Pentagon confusion.

Thick fog yesterday morning closed four airports in the New York metropolitan area and slowed harbor traffic to a creeping pace. Although the mists lifted considerably in the afternoon and transportation resumed operations, the murky curtain closed in anew at 4 P. M. and did not start to rise again until after 10 o'clock last night.

The extortion conspiracy trial of former First Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran bore out its promise of high-level ramifications yesterday when Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti told prospective talesmen he could not say why Frank J. Sampson, assistant to Mayor Impellitteri, was not a defendant in the case.

The Perspective plan of coordinated furniture and accessories is the central attraction of the midwinter model rooms opening today of Abraham Straus. In five room-settings, complete to the last are combined with Milo Baughman's furniture to show that rooms using this complete correlated scheme need not look as though they had come off an assembly line.
Cocoa and coffee were the only commodities showing pronounced price movements yesterday. Others moved little and were generally irregular.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and closing prices were 8 to 17 points net higher than on Monday.

Neither fog, plane "stacks" nor lack of taxicabs prevented Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, from arriving at the Astor Hotel last night for his speech before the New York Economic Club -- even if a half hour late.

Peddlers and those manufacturers who flout the American rayon industry's "ban" on the use of highly inflammable brushed rayon in sweater-making continued yesterday as the villains in the nation-wide "torch sweater" scare. And it was learned that they faced possible action by the Federal Trade Commission, which has begun an investigation of probable violation of its rules on the labeling of rayon products.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Williams College students voted down by 509 to 390 today a plan to admit all Williams students to Greek-letter fraternities.
I have just read the article concerning the proposed increase in fines for speeding and weaving on the Long Island parkways.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Cost savings that can be made in factories by planning and scheduling maintenance tasks may be equal to as much as a company's entire annual net profit after taxes. This was asserted here today by Gilbert I. Ross, president, Ross Co., Inc., New York management consultants, at conference sessions of the Plant Maintenance Exposition, which is being held at Convention Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Jaywalking and unrestricted pedestrian movement were described today as factors in traffic delay and as hazards almost equal to parking in some congested areas of New York and London. The descriptions were made at the opening session of the thirty-first annual meeting of the Highway Research Board here.

If the Supreme Court rules that weekday religious education in school hours is unconstitutional, Protestants must consider whether they can give enthusiastic moral support to schools where no such instruction is given, the Rev. James A. Pike, dean-designate of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said last evening.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Sir John D. Cockcroft, Nobel Prize winner and director of the British Atomic Energy Research Establishment, has been ordered to fly to Washington immediately to join Prime Minister Churchill and Lord Cherwell, the Prime Minister's chief scientific adviser, for talks on atomic energy later this week.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Reports of big export sales of wheat in prospect for this week caused some early buying of that grain here today, but there was no great enthusiasm in following the bulge, and prices reacted from the top levels.

CAIRO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Egypt has suggested that oil companies operating on Egyptian soil -- now paying a 15 per cent royalty -- split their profits with her on a 50-50 basis. Two companies expressed readiness to enter negotiations.
PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 15 (AP) -- A Federal judge approved a compromise plan today for reorganizing the huge American and Foreign Power Company.

On a January day just one hundred years ago a venerable philanthropist named Sampson Simson and eight other distinguished members of the Jewish community in New York gathered together to sign the papers of incorporation of a new and badly needed hospital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today handed Federal wage stabilizers their first test on a vital labor issue -- the union shop.

Dr. Alan T. Waterman, director of the National Science Foundation, established by act of Congress on May 10, 1950, has issued his first annual report. The law in accordance with which the Foundation was created states that search is to be conducted for specific military purposes, as well as for other ends.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A plan to tie charges for restaurant meals to the ups and downs of wholesale food prices is under consideration in his office, Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, said here tonight.
The election of W. J. Murray and James F. Hoge as directors of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., was announced yesterday by Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president

An application was filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate by the Stuyvesant Town Corporation for permission to raise the average rental ceiling in the large East Side housing project by $7.87 a room a month.
I recently read a letter in your columns from an individual who questioned the reason for penalizing quantity purchasers of postal cards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The President's Commission on the Health Needs of the Nation today agreed to enlarge its membership to include a doctor "who was familiar with the policies of the American Medical Association."

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Increasing dullness of industrial shares was the main feature of the stock markets here today. This weakness was increased by the announcement of big new capital issues by Imperial Chemical Industries and Associated Electrical Industries. Most other shares apart from oils and coppers also tended to weaken but British Government securities remained firm.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 15 -- A conference to discuss the liquidation of the two-year old Netherlands - Indonesian Union opened here today with special Ambassador Raden Supono, head of the Indonesian delegation, declaring his Government would reject any agreement that "infringes on her sovereignty."

Thoughtful Americans must find it shocking to read of American Medical Association opposition to President Truman's establishment of a commission to make a survey of the nation's health. Equally shocking is the refusal of an American physician, a trustee of the A. M. A., to accept an appointment to that commission on the ground that he considered it "an instrument of practical politics."
OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- Prime Minister Churchill left Ottawa by train this afternoon for Washington where he is due to arrive shortly after midday tomorrow.

Handicapped by the loss of two players, Allan Stanley and Eddie Slowinski, Coach Bill Cook of the Rangers has shuffled his lines for tonight's meeting with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden, the Broadway Blues' final home game preceding nine on the road.

A three man Presidential fact finding board began investigation of the contract dispute between Pan American World Airways and the air transport division of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday after a brief off the record session marked by procedural wrangling and resolute pessimism on both sides.
Apartment house incinerators are the primary air-pollution problem in Manhattan, Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell (retired), deputy director of the city's Bureau of Smoke Control, declared yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 15 -- Jean Van Houtte took over the premiership of Belgium's Social Christian (Catholic) Government today from Joseph Pholien. Apart from the change of premier, two new ministers were appointed to the key posts of economic affairs and finance.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 15 -- Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj has made an urgent appeal to the United States, British and French Ambassadors for an early reply to the Yugoslav Government's request for $86,000,000 in grants to cover the trade deficit during the first six months of this year.

Forty-eight young Norwegians who make up a choir known as the Singing Boys of Norway arrived in New York yesterday for a cross-country tour on which they will give eighty concerts. The singers, 11 to 27 years old, are scheduled to perform six nights a week.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Scandal Sheet," a newspaper drama presented by Columbia and featuring John Derek, Donna Reed, Broderick Crawford and Rosemary De Camp, is at the Paramount. Phil Karlson directed and Edward Small produced the Motion Picture Investors production from a screen play by Ted Sherdeman, Eugene Ling and James Poe and the novel, "The Dark Page," by Samuel Fuller.
Another warm mid-January day attracted more big crowds yesterday to the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Secretary Brannan said today that there were possibly no more than eleven or twelve cases of shortages in Government-owned farm commodities, and predicted there would be only nominal, if any, loss to the Government.

Oklahoma County, Okla., sold yesterday $5,900,000 of bridge, road and school bonds to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers. For $5,000,000 of the issue the bid designated a cost of 1.9132 per cent, and for $900,000 the interest cost was 1.9151 percent.

Long before the British elections of last October it was clear that the British pound was heading toward a new crisis. Realization of that fact was, indeed, generally assumed to have played an important part in the Conservative victory at the polls. Mr. Churchill perceived that if the tendencies then in the ascendant continued to prevail action by Britain alone, however drastic, would not of itself suffice.

The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, in behalf of its 161 affiliated groups, gave notice yesterday to the 262 other agencies sharing in collections by the Greater New York Fund that it disapproved of a fund committee proposal to abandon the solicitation of privately owned concerns and partnerships.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today dropped its $15,500,000 civil law suit against Carl G. Strandlund, former president of the defunct Lustron Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Government announced today it is going to pay higher than ceiling prices to the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company of Calumet, Mich., for the output of four "high cost" Michigan copper mines.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 -- Consumer goods will be plentiful in the years ahead, with the result that business will be confronted with a competitive situation, members of the American Management Association were told today at the second session of their four-day general management conference here.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 16 -- The headquarters of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway acknowledged this afternoon that United Nations aircraft were in the general vicinity of Kangdong, North Korea, Monday night when, the Communists asserted, Allied warplanes bombed a prisoner-of-war camp, killing ten United Nations prisoners and injuring at least sixty others.

Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation elected Thomas J. Watson Jr. as president yesterday. Formerly executive vice president, he succeeds John G. Phillips, who was elected vice chairman of the board and chairman of the executive and finance committee.

George Britton, heretofore a minor player in "South Pacific," suddenly finds himself co-starred with Martha Wright in the Pulitzer Prize musical. The unexpected jump to stellar heights came about this way.

Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, State Director of Civil Defense, declared yesterday, after returning from a conference in Washington with other state defense chiefs, that civilians had to be prepared for a "front yard" version of what happened in Hawaii on Dec. 7, 1941.

Rebecca Hosias has purchased the four-family house also containing two stores at 5324 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, from Roll Reslek. The property occupies a plot 20 by 85 feet and is assessed at $16,500. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

From the New York Giants yesterday came the announcement that "Manager Leo Durocher will be assisted during 1952 by the same coaching staff as in previous years" -- Freddy Fitzsimmons, Frank Shellenback and Herman Franks.
GREENWOOD, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Bank of Greenwood, which has served this rich northwest Florida peanut and livestock community for forty-three years, is going out of business.

Despite increased costs, maintenance of high quality is essential for effective commercial printing, it was emphasized yesterday at two main events marking continuing observation of Printing Week in New York.

CAIRO, Jan. 15 -- Extended midterm vacation ended in the Cairo secondary schools today but instead of returning to their classes the pupils went on strike, staged anti-British demonstrations, upset a street car and clashed with the police, who at one point were forced to use tear gas and clubs.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York unexpectedly refused last night to reaffirm the stand it had taken in 1948 when it recommended to Congress that a ban be placed on the televising or broadcasting of public hearings of Congressional investigating committees.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Senator Samuel Greenberg, Democrat of Brooklyn, introduced a bill today to repeal a law passed in 1950 that excused children from health and hygiene instruction in conflict with the religious beliefs of their parents.
The C. B. S. Television Workshop tilted a camera at "Don Quixote" in its debut at 4 o'clock last Sunday, but its art got caught in the studio windmill.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The West German Government will call for 60,000 volunteers from the former Wehrmacht as soon as a treaty providing for a European Defense Force has been approved by the six governments now preparing for such a supranational army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- New York City's construction industry, hard hit with the defense effort drawing heavily on structural steel, got assurance today of a measure of relief from Henry H. Fowler, National Production Administrator.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Harry Hopman, captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, said today that he didn't think any of the world's first ten tennis players abides strictly by the rules of the International Lawn Tennis Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman today offered Senator Estes Kefauver no objection to his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Delegates to the United Nations were told today that sacrifices caused by the defense program in the United States would be shared by all sectors of the population -- workers, farmers and business men.

Urging shirt manufacturers to be realistic in pricing and in giving values, Sidney Rosenblum, president of the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers, said last night that consumers would buy garments at prices below last year.

With taxes taking $15,215,371 more than in the previous year's period, net profit of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries was reduced to $17,284,891 in the six months ended with last November from $20,143,810 for the 1950 period.

General Templer, newly appointed British High Commissioner for Malaya, said here yesterday that he had been assured of "fullest support" by Prime Minister Churchill, and would do his best "to do a job" cleaning up the Communist guerrillas.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A simple method by which companies can measure the morale of their workers and pinpoint trouble spots and conditions has been developed by the University of Chicago.
A gift of twenty shares of General Motors Corporation stock, worth $1,012.61, topped yesterday's list of twenty-four contributions to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman's reorganization plan for the Internal Revenue Bureau was assured today of a hearing befor three Congressional committees, but prospects of favorable consideration remained in doubt.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Soviet Russia made a preliminary move today that may lead to participation of its ice hockey team in the winter Olympic Games here starting Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Prominent religious leaders opened a three-day meeting at the Pentagon today at which they will be informed of defense progress and hear discussions of the religious and morale problems of the armed forces.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, said today he welcomed the new Soviet proposals on atomic control but warned the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly that it should not expect them to result in a "sudden or dramatic solution" of the East-West tension.

MADRID, Jan. 15 -- Arab nationalist leaders who were expelled or forced to flee from Spanish Morocco because of their anti-Government activities will be allowed to return to their homes, according to Mimbar Eshaab, an Arabic newspaper published in Tetuan.

Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, said last night that the 143-group Air Force recommended by the Defense Department would not give the United States full war strength but should be regarded as "a deterrent and as a readiness force."
BOSTON, Jan. 15 -- Boston longshoremen began today the unloading of the Isthmian Line's freighter Steel Flyer, which had been tied up in port since Dec. 3, because of a picket line.

The machinery set up for marketing the new-type public housing bonds backed by the Federal Government worked smoothly yesterday, with the result that thirty-one local authorities issuing $133,786,000 of bonds incurred borrowing costs substantially below those of the first two big sales of the new bonds last year.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The United States Army is training its troops in Europe to defend themselves against the assumed possibility that the Soviet Union is capable of employing atomic weapons tactically against soldiers in the field.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The State Attorney General said today The Jockey Club was engaged in business for profit and therefore must pay the state's corporate franchise tax.
Three lads from South Carolina presented half a bushel of yams yesterday to Bernard M. Baruch at his office at 597 Madison Avenue.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Bills to remove the threat of eviction now faced by several hundred tenants in Knickerbocker Village and other limited - dividend housing projects were submitted to the Legislature today by Senator Elmer F. Quinn, Democratic minority leader of the Senate, and Assemblyman Louis De Salvio, Manhattan Democrat.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, largest corporate enterprise in the nation, and its principal telephone subsidiaries, achieved the highest net income in its history, with $376,784,730 for the twelve months ended Nov. 30, last.

Monsanto Chemical Company announced yesterday plans for the issuance of 400,000 new shares of common stock in early February through an underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co. No prior offering will be made to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- James W. Wadsworth, chairman of the National Security Commission, told the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives today that Universal Military Training could be substituted for the draft, provided world conditions got no worse, during a transition period of two or three years, and that the country would save billions of dollars a year by doing so.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today a civil anti-trust suit against The Mansfield (Ohio) News-Journal had been ended with acceptance by the newspaper of a judgment regulating its advertising policies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Dartmouth's Billy Biggs scored on a push shot as the buzzer rang ending a five-minute overtime period to give the Big Green a 60-59 victory over Harvard in an Eastern League game before 1,200 tonight.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., Toledo, will use 1,500 daily and weekly newspapers, covering all markets in the United States, today and tomorrow to announce public introduction through dealers and distributors of the company's new passenger sedan.

Sweeping changes in its merchandising policies and a wide-scale modernization program to bring about profitable operations for D. A. Schulte, Inc., were announced yesterday by N. C. Earl Jr., president, who heads the management group that on Dec. 23 took control of the 161-store chain.

Because of the increasing shortage of teachers for elementary schools four or five positions are being offered seniors upon graduation from the Teachers College of Connecticut at New Britain. Thirty school superintendents have been interviewing prospective elementary school teachers.

A most distinguished musician, a modern conductor who ruled the orchestra and secured effects of wonderful subtlety and color by virtue of his brains and his extremely sensitive perceptions, and not by semophoric gesticulations or other contortions as we were trying to listen to music, led the Boston Symphony Orchesetra as its guest conductor last night in Carneigie Hall: Ernest Ansermet.

An apparatus that is useful in teaching high school pupils to drive a car many miles without leaving the classroom could be the answer to the problem of providing hazard-free, behind-the-wheel training in schools, William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The nation put ten soldiers on its roster of most honored dead today in presenting Medals of Honor to their families.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range all day yesterday and closed 4 points higher to 2 points lower than on Tuesday.

The substantial capital of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York makes it unnecessary for the bank to increase its capital funds under present conditions, as so many other banks have done, J. Luther Cleveland, chairman, told stockholders yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Dewey set the stage today for the first political contest of the Presidential year with national significance in New York by ordering a special election on Feb. 19 to choose a member of the House of Representatives from the Fifth Congressional District in Queens.

Representatives of Pan American World Airways and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., reached agreement on three out of seventy-five issues raised in the contract dispute being investigated by a Presidential fact - finding board here yesterday but bogged down on the question of a $1 payment for meals missed on overtime.

Questions on the germ theory of disease will be included in forthcoming State Regents high school examinations in biology, but pupils will not be required to answer them if the theory conflicts with their religious principles, it became known yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 16 -- The Mexican Government's intention to nationalize the country's civil aviation industry, in which United States investments run into millions of dollars, was announced today by Angel Martin Perez, Director of Aeronautics.

The Public Service Commission ended its investigation of the purchase of a private water company by the Suffolk County Water Authority with a finding yesterday that the price paid was excessive and the proceeding was irregular, but that there was no proof that the members of the Water Authority had personally benefited.
PARIS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Total casualties of United Nations and Republic of Korea forces in the Korean war have reached 414,945, an Associated Press survey showed today.

SEATTLE, Wash. Jan. 16 (UP) -The Coast Guard cut down its air search for survivors of the freighter Pennsylvania today and officers held little hope that any of her forty-six crew men would be found alive in the Pacific Ocean.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 -- British troops raided two villages in the Sweetwater Canal region today in their most extensive operations to date to clear out the lairs of Egyptian snipers. The villages were el Hamada and Tel el Kebir south.

The Salton Manufacturing Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it would discontinue sales to distributors and dealers in New York State known to resell its products below minimum retail "fair trade" prices. The concern is a medium-size local manufacturer of hot trays and hot tables.

Sweden has been the proving ground repeatedly for many new ideas in modern finance, especially in the use of depreciation acceleration as a means of capital formation. Consequently it is no surprise that the first major issue of prime-risk bonds bearing a cost-of-living redemption value should come from Sweden.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- Walter Ulbricht, Deputy Premier of East Germany and Secretary General of the Soviet zone Communist party, said today that a United Nations commission to investigate the possibilities for all-German elections would "certainly not" be allowed to enter the Soviet zone.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 16 (UP) -- An official spokesman said today that the Argentine Government would be asked to reconsider an order closing sections of the border with Chile, leaving 2,500 residents of two Chilean border towns without a food supply for five days.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has given unanimous approval to the expansion of the North Atlantic alliance to include Greece and Turkey as full-fledged members. The same committee was equally unanimous in approving the alliance itself, and the Senate ratified the treaty by an over-whelming majority, but only after long debate and over determined opposition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In the third such challenge from the Republican right wing within eight days, Senator James P. Kem of Missouri demanded today a Senate investigation of the Truman Administration's "suicidal" foreign policy.

The first crackdown on violators of wage and salary controls in the metropolitan area may result in pay rollbacks for 7,000 workers in 267 New York and New Jersey companies, Frank J. Muench, regional director of the Wage-Hour and Public Contracts Division of the United States Department of Labor, warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States and Britain have broken the deadlock over the exchange of information on atomic energy.
Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said last night that the only way to improve the health and life expectancy of the Negro people was through a program of national health insurance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that its investigators were combing the nation in search of evidence against manufacturers and interstate sellers of inflammable sweaters.

New York City has its eyes on only one man today. Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen is home from the sea, a hero already weary in his modesty of hearing "Well done!" but ready to take on one more ordeal, the march up Broadway. Montaigne said that "there are some defeats more triumphant than victories."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Wage Stabilization Board announced today the appointment of a six-man committee consisting of two each from the public, industry and labor to act on petitions for approval of health and welfare plans.

An agreement has been worked out by Governor Dewey and Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, on the best method of using Federal and state military forces in combined operations in an emergency, it was announced yesterday at First Army headquarters on Governors Island.

The first conventional-type passenger car line to be built by Willys-Overland Motors since 1942 was announced yesterday by the company. Designated the Aero Willys, the new models will go on display tomorrow in dealer showrooms throughout the country.

A sale of 5,867 Breath of Spring silverblu skins by the New York Auction Company for the Mutation Mink Breeders Association yesterday brought a top of $87. Stewart silverblu platinums brought a top of $54 and dressed silverblu platinum a top of $48.50.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (UP) -- A country judge appeared tonight to have given Louisiana's leading politicians a practical vote-getting lesson in yesterday's Democratic primary to select a candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Winston Churchill, a stanch champion of the British Empire, today became a full-fledged member of the Society of the Cincinnati -- men whose ancestors helped to wrest the United States from Britain's grasp 175 years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Government announced today that retail prices for white potatoes would be rolled back Jan. 28 to reflect the lower ceilings at the farm-shipper level.

A grant of $7,000,000 toward the endowment of a graduate school at Emory University of Georgia, one of the largest it has ever made, was announced yesterday by the General Education Board -- an affiliate of the Rockefeller Foundation.
ROME, Jan. 16 -- American buyers found the suits they have been looking for in Italy today in the collection of Alberto Fabiani, second generation Rome couturier.

Penn's basketball team brought the long Columbia victory string of twenty-seven games on the Morningside Heights court to an end last night. The Quakers conquered the defending champions, 66 to 64, in a stirring Eastern Intercollegiate League test.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company produced and sold more paper, paperboard and chemicals during the fiscal year ended last October than in any previous year, but earnings declined $2,000,000 under the pressure of higher taxes.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- If any of the nations from which Britain is seeking aid to keep the Suez Canal in operation send warships to Egyptian waters, Egypt said today, she will consider it an act of aggression and bring the matter before the United Nations.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,131, for Wednesday's operations:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Finance Minister Horacio Lafer told representatives of the local American Chamber of Commerce today that the Government is ready to consider any legitimate suggestions regarding present restrictions on repatriation of foreign capital and profits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 9:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The military budget for the coming fiscal year has been held to a total of $48,000,000,000, about $11,500,000,000 less than this year, despite strong pleas by the Air Force that more funds be requested of Congress for working toward the air arm's new goal of 143 wings.

The withholding of loans or grants to Brazil by United States or international governmental financial agencies was urged yesterday by a major American business group in protesting the retroactive restrictions that Brazil recently placed on foreign capital earnings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Truman urgently recommended to Congress today tax law changes to increase Federal revenues by about $5,000,000,000 annually, but there was little likelihood the legislators would approve his program in an election year.

Central-Illinois Securities Corporation, New York City, a large stockholder in the City National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, has launched its opposition to the bank's plan to split its stock four to one and to increase capital by selling additional shares to stockholders.

An enduring concept of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a permanent body equally indispensable to "a cold war" or "a real peace" was outlined here yesterday by Premier Willem Drees of the Netherlands.

IT isn't entirely a one-way street down which big league stars have been traveling in answering calls into the armed services. Art Houtteman, who never should have made the journey in the first place, already has returned and will report to the Detroit Tigers in Lakeland next month. He can make quite a difference to Bengal pennant hopes, although he alone is not the complete cure for manifold Detroit ills.

While public officials and newspaper men swarmed outside on the airfield strip, Mrs. Agnes Carlsen was reunited at 1:20 o'clock this morning with her hero husband, Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, inside a Pan American clipper at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- State Senator James Fitzgerald, Democrat of Queens, offered a bill today to outlaw professional, boxing and wrestling in New York State because, he said, they were under "hoodlum control."
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Manly Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator, declared here tonight that no widespread relief from metals shortages might be expected this year.

Plans for pressing action for a new and larger New York School of Printing were considered yesterday at a Printing Week meeting by members of the city's industry-labor advisory group on vocational education in printing. Necessary action was discussed as the group attended the annual Wayzgoose -- good fellowship hour -- held by the Apprentice Schools of the school, in its main building, 461 Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON Jan. 16 -- Nathan P. Feinsinger, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, said without reservation today that wage increases based on productivity would be permitted as soon as the board could write a regulation.

VIENNA, Jan. 16 -- Plain speaking from official sources on the subject of Austria's highly cartelized economy was heard tonight at a meeting of the League of Austrian Industrialists. The speakers were Austrian business men and members of the Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 (AP) -The worst storm in decades was abating in California tonight but more rain and snow was heading down the coast from the Gulf of Alaska.
