ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 16 -- Navy poured 59 points through the hoops in the last half today to defeat Johns Hopkins, 97 -- 58, and establish an Academy scoring record.

ATHENS, Jan. 16 -- John Skoulikaris, 28-year-old Athenian, who was captured and mutilated while fighting in Greece's war against Communist guerillas, will leave for the United States by plane tomorrow on President Truman's personal invitation.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The North Atlantic allies extended by two weeks today the deadline for the completion of plans for a European army with West Germans in it.

Paolo Silveri, Italian baritone who joined the Metropolitan Opera last season, sang Rigoletto last night when Verdi's opera of that name was presented for the eighth time since its revival last November. It was his first appearance of the season and his first local assumption of part of the doomed jester.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 16 -- The British Government today rejected, on the basis of the Anglo-Persian (Iranian) treaty of March 4, 1857, the Iranian Government's demand for the closing of all British consulates in Iran. The demand was in a note last Saturday accusing British officials of interfering in Iranian affairs.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, American Zionist leader, asserted last night that Western European and American Jewish communities never had asked or desired "any special status as national minorities." He said such a concept was "alien to the political structure of these countries," in which, he said, "Jews desire equal rights of citizenship and freedom from all forms of discrimination."
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 16 -- Fordham's smooth-passing quintet fought off two Princeton rallies to notch its eleventh victory in thirteen starts, downing the Tigers by 72 -- 66 in Dillon Gym tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the working capital of corporations rose by $200,000,000 in the third quarter of last year. In its quarterly analysis the agency estimated the net working capital of corporations at $79,200,000,000, reflecting a growth of $3,900,000,000 in current assets, which was almost entirely offset by the increase in current liabilities.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (UP) -- Fifteen starters were named today for the $10,000 Hialeah Inaugural Handicap that sends South Florida's racing season into the rich middle days of the Gold Coast tourist season.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 3,124,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, they amounted to 128,333,000 barrels, compared with 125,209,000 a week earlier and 121,209,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Attorneys for minority stockholders of the Boston and Maine Railroad asked a special Federal court here today to send back to the Interstate Commerce Commission an I. C. C.-approved plan for financial reorganization of the road.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16 -- In a circular note to all foreign embassies in Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Office advised that, effective yesterday, restrictions had been placed upon travel by diplomats to twenty-two Soviet-cities and new regulations had been issued affecting travel in the immediate vicinity of Moscow.

OTTAWA, Jan. 16 -- The Canadian Government is expected to nominate a Canadian-born Governor General to replace Viscount Alexander of Tunis. The King will appoint the new Governor General, who will be his personal representative, but it will be the Canadian Government that will make the selection.

Within the next few weeks the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd lines will resume, for the first time in twelve years, regular direct cargo services between United States Atlantic and West German ports. The runs will be made by new, or recently rebuilt, craft capable of making the crossing in eleven days.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- Diplomatic circles in Japan are making considerable efforts tonight to assess the declaration of Premier Shigeru Yoshida that his Government has no intention of concluding a bilateral treaty with Communist China after the peace treaty restores Japanese independence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Congress received President Truman's Economic Report today with marked indifference, especially his recommendation for revenue increases to bring in about $5,000,000,000 through plugging loopholes and eliminating special privileges in the existing law and through "some" tax rises.
The current operating expenditures of the public schools compared with cost a year ago are estimated by states as follows:
The Giants "expected it," Charles Feeney, vice president of the club, declared yesterday. "He's just like everybody else. The whole country is making sacrifices now, and naturally he must make his."

Books by and about two important figures of the Civil War will be published by World in the next three months. Scheduled for Feb. 11 is the American edition of Brig. Gen. Colin R. Ballard's "The Military Genius of Abraham Lincoln." Originally published in 1926 by Oxford University Press in England, the book is an analysis of Lincoln and his generals and of Lincoln as an unconventional military strategist.

When the final accounts are tallied, "Desire Under the Elms," may turn out to be the greatest play written by an American. To a theatregoer who has just come from the Anta Playhouse, Mr. O'Neill's harsh tragedy of New England is not something to feel temperate about.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquenfort, France, Jan. 16 -- The United States Government has now agreed with Britain, France and four other countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that West Germany should be allowed to have a tactical air force of more than 1,000 planes by midsummer 1954, according to Allied sources.
Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday, with volume light to moderate.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Revisions in the route of the State Thruway through Rockland County were presented today to two township supervisors and mayors of two villages affected. The changes aroused dissatisfaction in Suffern; some county officials were piqued because they had not been invited to the meeting and there was general annoyance because the Thruway engineers failed to provide the interested parties with maps.

The Hanover Bank's annual stockholders' meeting yesterday was one of the briefest in the institution's history, lasting a little over twelve minutes. William S. Gray, chairman of the board, who presided, answered a number of questions raised by one stockholder, completed official business, and the meeting was adjourned.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 16 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Ridgley Gaithers took command today of the Eleventh Airborne Infantry Division, quartered here for the Army's biggest winter maneuvers.

Few things in life are quite so satisfactory as having a working place beside a window which faces the woods. Seated so, full satisfaction can be safely guaranteed. To be sure, the great novel cannot be written there, nor the play.
THE TIMES recently printed a letter urging the introduction of fluoridation of the city's water supply.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Dr. John D. Clark, of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, today sharply criticized Administration monetary policy which, he said, was "based upon the principle that the financial world must be kept in great uncertainty about future interest rates and the availability of credit."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Monsanto Chemical Company of St. Louis applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to issue 400,000 shares of its $5 par common stock to be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets tangled yesterday with Communist jet in three battles involving almost 140 planes and damaged two of the swift red-nosed enemy MIG's.
Increased competition to American privately owned shipping is coming not only from maritime nations active before World War II but also from fourteen countries not listed then as shipowning nations.

The tenth annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists will open to the public today in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Prizes and awards were officially announced last evening at the preview reception.

THE New Brunswick salmon fishing is making news these days, for the Province has just announced that the public auction of angling leases on several of its famous rivers will be held on March 12, each lease to run ten years.

Terms of a private bond placement and a bank-loan agreement aggregating $122,500,000 were announced yesterday by the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation as it completed its financing for a substantial increase in productive capacity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 -- Presidential campaign directors for Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower clashed today in "first-ballot" nomination claims and provided a colorful backdrop for a pre-convention meeting of the Republican National Committee opening here tomorrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Reports that many passenger trains of the New York Central Railroad were failing to reach destinations at scheduled times led the Public Service Commission today to reopen a 1942 proceeding dealing with the carrier's "on-time" performance.

Walter Vincent, president of The Actors' Fund of America, announced yesterday that sums collected during the week proclaimed by Mayor Impellitteri as Actors' Fund Week have exceeded $73,000, with contributions "still coming in."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Following is the text of President Truman's annual Economic Report, presented to Congress today: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES:

ROME, Jan. 16 -- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, speaking as "an American citizen" at a press conference here today, expressed his personal regret that the United States had no diplomatic representative at the Vatican and described this situation as "most unfortunate."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Corporate profits before taxes were the highest on record in 1951, reaching an estimated total of $44,800,000,000, but combined Federal, state and local taxes took about 60 per cent of these profits, the Council of Economic Advisers reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, introduced a bill today to put the country's "disciplined Communists" immediately into concentration camps. He estimated their number at 50,000, including 20,000 actual agents of the Kremlin who are working night and day as the vanguard of those who would destroy us."

Net earnings of Institutional Securities Corporation, wholly owned by the savings banks of this state, registered their fourth successive annual increase in 1951, reaching $203,690, or $2.04 a share, Robert E. Pratt, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- A bill to provide a mandatory jail sentence for bookmaking on a third conviction was introduced today by Senator John M. Braisted, Democrat of Staten Island, to strengthen the hand of law enforcement officials in dealing with gamblers.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 -- The Cleveland Trust Company approved an increase in the capital stock, ratified a formal pension plan for employes and officers, elected Adrian D. Joyce a director and promoted three officials at the bank's annual stockholders' meeting today.

The City of Nashville, Tenn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Feb. 5 on an issue of $2,500,000 of electric power and revenue refunding bonds dated Jan. 1, 1952, and due Jan. 1, 1955 to 1971.

Two major proposals of the Strayer - Yavner report -- that the city schools receive fiscal independence and that members of the Board of Education be elected rather than appointed -- were rejected yesterday at a conference of community and education representatives.
LONDON, Jan, I6 -- Industrial shares were progressively weaker on the stock markets here today. Many leaders fell 2s or more.

Although cocoa now costs from 2 to 5 cents a pound more than last January, it is still readily enough available to assure plenty of that favorite hot beverage for winter. And, surprisingly, the home cook who prefers the short-cut instant cocoa mixes will find prices on these unchanged in most cases.

Writing from the supposed viewpoint of 1956, Soviet propagandists have indulged in one of their most imaginative efforts: a description of the semi-paradise that they say the world would enjoy by then it current Soviet "peace" proposals are adopted.

The captivating yacht harbor on four indoor floors of Grand Central Palace and known as the National Motor Boat Show has passed its midway mark, with only three more full days to go before closing late Saturday night.

" Viva Zapata!" the Darryl F. Zanuck production for Twentieth Century-Fox starring Marlon Brando as the Mexican bandit, Emiliano Zapata, under the direction of Elia Kazan, has been scheduled for its world premiere on Thursday, Feb 7, at the Rivoli, it was announced yesterday by the company.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 16 -- Thirty - one hundred shipyard workers are toiling on three shifts here to finish the nation's first superliner, the S. S. United States, which is to make her maiden voyage on July 3.

The local campaign for the nomination of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for President on the Republican ticket will have an unusual start on Feb. 8, with a rally and entertainment at Madison Square Garden, arranged by Citizens for Eisenhower and Youth for Eisenhower.
John L. Colmar, national chairman of the Taft Clubs of America, said here yesterday that he expected to name a New York chairman of the Taft Clubs soon.

The Coast Guard's super ice-breaker Eastwind arrived here early yesterday from Boston and was dispatched immediately up the Hudson River to take over the task of clearing the ice from the channel as far as Albany.
Fleet-footed seamen who "ran away" with two relay races for mariners in New York port received their awards here yesterday aboard their vessel, the Norwegian America liner Oslofjord.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the period Dec. 2 to Dec. 29 averaged 35,406 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 41,297 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and 37,478 for November.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- A Foreign Office spokesman expressed disapproval today of the declaration by Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida of his desire to make peace with the Chinese Nationalists. Objection was taken here to such statements being made before the Japanese treaty came into force.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to consider any further increase in Railway Express rates at this time.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 16 -- Vince Bailey and Bill Rutter shared scoring honors with 19 and 18 points, respectively, as Army defeated Dehigh, 62 to 51, in basketball at the field house today.

The stock market pulled out of an early slump yesterday and, in resisting selling pressure, rallied almost a point. The character of the market was not unlike those of the sessions before the Tuesday slump, with no major show of strength.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Max and Grace Granich, identified as "Communist functionaries" by two former party members, refused today to discuss their alleged Red activities because they might be self-incriminating."

EMIGRANT GAP, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Passengers and crew of the snow-bound streamliner City of San Francisco, marooned since Sunday in the blizzard-swept high Sierras, resumed their westward journey on a relief train tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Drexel Tech won its fifth game in six starts tonight with a 77-54 verdict over Stevens Tech, gaining revenge for a defeat suffered at Hoboken last season.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- Federal Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. today dismissed three of nine indictments against Denis W. Delaney, ousted Boston Collector of Internal Revenue. Delaney originally was charged with accepting $12,500 to influence his action on tax matters and of falsely certifying that $180,000 in tax liens had been paid.
Representative Carl Vinson is quoted as stating on Jan. 6 that the preliminary vote of the Congress on U. M. T. in June "clearly indicated that the nation wants universal military training."

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Although export sales materialized in a big way, as predicted, they did not incite any great amount of buying interest in wheat futures trading here today. There was some short covering which gave wheat initial strength with fractional gains, but after that the trade was devoid of any important feature.

The election of Thomas D. Neelands Jr., 40 Wall Street, as a director of the Silex Company, Hartford, Conn., was announced yesterday. Mr. Neelands, who is a member of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., is also a director of the Beech Aircraft Corporation and Capital Airlines, Inc.

Ten years ago Henryk Erlich and Victor Alter, intellectuals, leaders of Polish-Jewish labor and of the world Socialist movement, were executed in the Soviet Union. Today memorial observances for them are being held in twenty countries.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 16 -- Dutch universities, with centuries old traditions of schooling technicians and administrators for the Netherlands' former empire, have banded together to make their reservoir of experience available for the world's undeveloped territories.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced last night that it had decided to postpone the eviction of nineteen tenants from Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Truman's nomination of Harry A. McDonald to be Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation hit a snag in the Senate today, and some doubt arose over the prospect of his confirmation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Jan. 16 -- There is an interesting story behind the decision of Darryl Zanuck to purchase "My Book and Heart," a novel by Corra Harris, as a sequel to Twentieth Century-Fox production last year, "I'd Climb the Highest Mountain."

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Poland told delegates to the United Nations Economic and Financial Committee today that she was suffering shortages in some foodstuffs and consumer goods, but insisted it was because the Warsaw Government refused to institute "rationing by purse."

Representatives of the Citizens Committee to Control Itinerant Street Peddling, composed of sixty-three civic, community and consumer groups, asserted yesterday that they would press for legislation in the City Council to curb street peddlers in major shopping areas.

In his Economic Message to Congress at this time last year President Truman predicted that before 1951 was over defense spending, then running at an annual rate of around $20 billions, would reach a rate of between $45 billions and $55 billions. Nevertheless, he took that occasion to announce that in the increasingly lively debate over the financing of rearmament he stood with those who advocated a pay-as-you-go policy. He said:
The perennial spring color favorites -- navy and white -- were high-lighted in the costumes presented by Russeks yesterday afternoon at the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Luther Rawlings of Chicago tonight clinched a title match with Jimmy Carter, lightweight champion, by scoring a fifth-round knockout over Enrique Bolanos of Los Angeles in the Chicago Stadium.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The Budgetary Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today to give a 7.5 per cent increase to all employes of the world organization stationed at headquarters in New York.

Despite a plea by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson that city departments keep their 1952-53 requests down to their actual 1951-1952 budgetary appropriations, fifty-nine city agencies have asked for a total of $27,877,591 above the current fiscal year.

Whether the city would ask the 1952 Legislature for authority to renew the 3 per cent sales tax by local law was in doubt yesterday. At the close of its third successive executive meeting to discuss the city's financial program to be sent to Albany, the Board of Estimate had not yet settled the issue.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The 31-year-old King Farouk instructed his Government to announce to "both parts of the Nile Valley, north and south, and to the rest of the world the birth of Crown Prince Ahmed Fuad."

It had to be the Rangers that the Chicago Black Hawks picked on to snap their losing streak. Defeated in their seven previous National Hockey League games, the Windy City skaters came out of it last night at Madison Square Garden by handing the Blues a 6-to-4 defeat.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee announced plans today for a "vigorous investigation" of multi-million-dollar shortages in Government-owned grain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson denounced today the new Soviet proposal on atomic controls as a "paper" prohibition with no assurances of agreement on effective controls. He said he could not now see how the proposal could advance the cause of disarmament.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 16 -A pair of skiers braved the blizzard at Donner Pass early today to find J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County executive, and his wife, Mary, cold but safe in a compartment of the stranded City of San Francisco in the Sierra Nevada Mountains in California.

The rising costs of industrial accidents, owing to changes in workmen's compensation laws, have made it necessary for employers to increase their efforts for medical rehabilitation of employes after injuries, it was emphasized here yesterday in a discussion of the subject at the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.

In reference to a letter from A. Philip Randolph, may I suggest that you (for printing it) and A. Philip Randolph (for writing it) refer to the Tenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, wherein it is stated that "the powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved to the states respectively, or to the people."

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, intrepid skipper of the sunken Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Enterprise, landed at 1:02 A. M. today at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a flight from Ireland.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 17 -- The United States chairman of the Allied Council to Japan today told the Russian member that Japan was increasing expenses for defense forces because of the threats of Communist external aggression and to meet Communist "machinations" within Japan calculated to overthrow the Government "by violent and revolutionary means."

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The Peruvian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly plans to submit a resolution calling on all applicants for membership in the United Nations -- with the exception of the four Soviet satellites in Eastern Europe -- to submit proof of their qualifications to the Assembly as well as to the Security Council.

Lieut, Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, retired, Director of the State Civil Defense Commission, told fifty fire chiefs yesterday that New York was "way ahead" of the rest of the country in preparations for a possible enemy attack.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, called on the Senate today for early action on Universal Military Training as the only means of reducing heavy military budgets, which he said the United States could support only "for two years, for three, or five."

In his letter to you the First Secretary of the Polish Embassy in Washington makes a clever use of statistics in order to prove how much Poland produces. Statistics, however, in Communist hands always serve their own peculiar purposes. The figures quote by him do not give any real picture of conditions under which the Polish worker is asked to produce, nor of where the products of his work are going.
Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, recommended yesterday a return to religion to lessen corruption in government.
Mount Sinai Hospital of New York at Fifth Avenue and 100th Street opened a year-long centennial celebration yesterday with a glimpse into its medical past and a forecast of its medical future.

One more Brooklyn mother and her new baby took the sun in Prospect Park yesterday. Wendy, one of four llamas in the zoo, introduced her five-day-old, fawn-colored daughter, Bonnie Lee, to the public and to the baby's father, Peter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A special pamphlet advising small business men on the steps they should take to obtain loans to help them in defense or essential civilian production has been prepared by the Small Defense Plants Administration.

Tallulah Bankhead, who admits to loving music and grows especially voluble in discussing it, will be one of the more interested listeners at tonight's Philharmonic-Symphony concert. Guido Cantelli will conduct the premiere of Alan Shulman's "A Laurentian Overture," which Mr. Shulman has dedicated to Miss Bankhead.

GENEVA, Jan. 16 -- It is regarded as by no means impossible in international financial circles that the upshot of the present crisis in the sterling area's economic relations with the rest of the world will be re-establishment of the convertibility of the pound sterling some time during 1952.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 16 -- A projected reorganization and "streamlining" of the Methodist Church, designed to reduce overlapping and duplication among the denomination's sixty - three boards and agencies, was vigorously opposed here today by delegates attending the annual meeting of the Board of Missions and Church Extension.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, United States Ambassador to Denmark, said tonight that the Communists' concern for the American Negro was "false and hypocritical." She charged Russia with enslaving 10,000,000 persons in labor camps.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The church and the army joined today in a glittering spectacle to honor Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny who died last Friday and who was elevated to a Marshal of France yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Tropical Park's successful meeting -- in which attendance and betting records were shattered -- ended today with a sparkling speed performance by Lot-A-Brass in the featured $5,000 Tropical Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Willis Smith, Democrat of North Carolina, introduced a bill today to give the District of Columbia back to Maryland. He made the move in an effort to beat a pending bill to grant limited self-government to the nation's capital.

Because of growing tax complications, both individual and business, planning for distribution of estates has become an increasingly involved matter and now calls for the careful consideration of a team of experts, including attorneys, accountants, bankers and life insurance underwriters.

CAIRO, Jan, 16 -- A Crown Prince was born to King Farouk and Queen Narriman of Egypt at 8:20 A. M. today. The infant was named Ahmed Fuad, after his grandfather, the late King, and received the title Prince of Said (Said is the Arabic word for Upper Egypt).

Backed by Mayor Impellitteri, Frank J. Sampson denied "absolutely" yesterday that he had had "anything whatsoever to do with any Fire Department shakedown," as intimated Tuesday by Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti.

WALSALL, England, Jan. 16 (AP) -An engraved silver punchbowl bought seven years ago to be presented to a United States Army colonel has the town fathers in a dither. They don't know what to do with it.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 16 -- The Iranian Women's Organization has dispatched to the secretary General of the United Nations a protest against Iranian regulations that bar women from voting.
An organization designed to obtain a larger share of Government contracts and subcontracts for small manufacturers and for regional pools of small plants was organized here last night.

Dr. Willem Drees, Socialist Premier of the Netherlands, who is here on a visit at President Truman's invitation, is spending a substantial part of the time making first-hand observations of housing, trade unionism and industrial relations and visiting manufacturing plants.

Boxing follower will honor some of the sport's distinguished figures tonight in the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight. Roof on the occasion of the fourteenth annual dinner of the Boxing Writers' Association of New York. Close to 400 guests will attend the affair.
A merger of the Welfare Council of New York City and the Health Council of Greater New York has been approved by the Greater New York Fund and will become a reality in several weeks.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The non-Communist areas of the world during 1951 scored gains over 1950 in the production of every major commodity except two -- tin and lumber.

Philip Godfrey, newly elected director of Continental Bank and Trust Company, indicated yesterday at the bank's annual meeting that legal proceedings might be started soon to accelerate settlement of claims delaying the bank's liquidation.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- A Republican agreement that neither legalization of pre-colored oleomargarine nor permanent personal registration of voters would be made party measures was reached today at a conference between Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Senate majority leader, and Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck.

GENEVA, Jan. 16 -- Tremendous increases in heavy-industry output will be demanded of the Czechoslovak economy in 1952, according to a report by Dr. Jaromin Dolansky, new head of the Czechoslovak State Planning Office.

Ernest Wolff returned to Town Hall last night to give a recital that consisted, in the main, of lieder by Schubert, Schumann and Wolf. Some older German and Italian composers also were represented. Paul Meyer was at the piano.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Ernest A. Gross, United States representative, said today that the power of world opinion was responsible for the Soviet Union's decision to come forward "with atomic control proposals it denominates as 'new.'"

A suit challenging the right of the New York City Housing Authority to raise rents without a hearing on the tenant's "ability to pay," and to act as a commercial agent in determining rentals and imposing rises on already existing rentals, will be heard by Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein at 10 A. M. today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Jan. 16 -George J. Eising, a New York stock broker, was killed by a bullet here today in the workshop of his home on Taylor's Lane. A rifle was at his side and Dr. Victoria A. Bradess, assistant county medical examiner, listed the death as a suicide.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 16 -- The nation's wholesale grocers today called for an immediate suspension of ceiling price regulations on all food products handled by their industry which are certified by the United States Department of Agriculture to be in ample supply.

Having found that one-way avenues on the periphery of congested Manhattan can speed travel substantially, the Department of Traffic now intends to extend that method to the core of the city and early next month will restrict Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way movement.

The Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., announced last night that fifty-one companies with 68,500 workers had notified the union they wanted to terminate their contracts or seek pay cuts when present union agreements expire March 15.

It costs a lot of money to run the country's school system. More buildings, more teachers, more equipment, more supplies and more children give school administrators a continuous headache as inflation diminishes what available funds can accomplish.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Coaches and officials have contributed to "undesirable trends" in the game of football, the National College A. A. rules committee declared today. It called upon them to teach and enforce the spirit as well as letter of the regulations.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 17 -- The Chinese Communists will "fight to the end" in Korea rather than permit any of their prisoners in United Nations hands to elect to join the Nationalist forces of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on Formosa, Allied truce delegates at Panmunjom were warned yesterday.

By far the largest contribution received by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in the 1951-52 campaign was listed yesterday and it amounted to $16,821.76, the previous day's market value of 330 shares of General Motors Corporation stock.

Divergent views on retention of price-wage controls were expressed yesterday by leading educators in the industrial management and economic fields at a meeting of the Trade and Industry Law Institute in the Roosevelt Hotel. They did agree, however, that administrative power must be retained for economic controls in the event of an emergency.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 16 -- The West German Government has embarked on a new program for regaining the German place in the European sun. In this, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer again has appealed to the Socialists for cooperation in a bipartisan program and there were signs today he might get it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A continuing downward trend in Federal grants to states for the four public assistance programs under the Social Security Act was reported today by the Federal Security Agency.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16 -- The Yugoslav Government appears to be seriously concerned about growing public discussion in the United States over the American policy to support Yugoslavia with substantial economic financial assistance.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Jan. 16 -- This township, home of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, heroic skipper of the Flying Enterprise, will welcome back its famous citizen on Saturday with a Captain Carlsen Day celebration of its own.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The United States and three other nations presented to the special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today a $250,000,000 plan intended to make almost 1,000,000 Arab refugees who have fled from Palestine to neighboring states self-sufficient within three years.

Members of the New York Committee of the Frontier Nursing Service will give a reception and tea on the afternoon of Jan. 24 at the Cosmopolitan Club for Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, director of the organization. Mrs. Seymour Wadsworth is chairman and Mrs. Samuel H. Ordway, vice chairman, of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, charged today that a reported shift in the Republican membership of the Senate Elections subcommittee would be "like changing the jury half way through a trial."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Chester Bowles, the United States Ambassador to India, gave a personal and coldly received recommendation to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that this country put in a $1,000,000,000 program in aid to India.
Men and women in this city are slightly older than their suburban neighbors and a few years older than people in the rest of the country, according to Census Bureau figures.

The first issue of House Home, the first number of the home-building edition of The Magazine of Building, will appear today. It is published by Time, Inc., and is designed to help Americans "find a better way of living by giving them better homes at prices they can pay."
A possible solution to the problems presented by Ted Collins' New York Yanks emerged yesterday as officials of the National Football League teams began gathering here for their annual meetings.

Capt. Peter Terranova, head of the Police Department's narcotics squad, yesterday asked a group of child welfare workers associated with private agencies to cooperate with the police in their drive to track down the "pushers" of narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In comments critical of the proposal that General Eisenhower be elected President this year one recurring note has been that his stand on domestic issues is unknown. Yet these are broadly the same as they were on Labor Day, 1949, when the General spoke to the American Bar Association, meeting at St. Louis.

A higher rate ceiling on thrift account interest-dividends "would cause vibrations throughout the banking structure," William A. Lyon, State Superintendent of Banks, declared yesterday. Speaking at a luncheon meeting of the Savings Banks T rust Company, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Mr. Lyon said any action by the Banking Board to lift the present 2 per cent rate would apply equally to all institutions of deposit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Cardinals can pay Stan Musial $85,000 and the Dodgers can pay Jackie Robinson $40,000 provided they do not exceed a maximum annual salary budget for all the ball players on their clubs, the Salary Stabilization Board announced today.

On Monday, three days before her daughter was to be married, Mrs. Charles Goldstein of 630 Coster Street, the Bronx, was operated on at Memorial Hospital at 444 East Sixty-eighth Street. Yesterday the wedding took place as scheduled, but it was held at the hospital.

Young women headed by Miss Kirby Smith and including Mrs. Albert Perry-Miller are aiding in the plans for the dinner dance in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association to be given tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Proceeds will be donated to the needs of the beneficiary, which for the last thirty-five years has provided vacation periods in summer camps for boys and girls from crowded districts of Greater New York.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Assistant Secretary General Byron Price angrily denounced today Soviet "insinuations of crookedness" in the handling of funds for the construction of the United Nations headquarters in New York.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 17 -The New Year speech made by President Getulio Vargas concerning repatriation of foreign capital investments, the freezing of all amortization after five years and setting a limit of 8 per cent on remittances of profits and dividends will be another subject for heated discussions in the present session of Congress.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Sharp declines were registered in all grains today, the market being adversely affected by the fact that heavy export sales to Germany had failed to stimulate any considerable outside support in wheat. On the contrary, there was heavy long liquidation, and the declines in wheat unsettled the coarse grains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- With the constant increase in urban traffic congestion, the parking problem throughout the country requires more attention than any other public need, delegates were told here today at the thirty-first annual meeting of the Highway Research Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Representative Louis B. Heller, Democrat of New York, accused Senators today of trying to "coerce" a House investigating subcommittee that he heads "into violating its sound rules of procedure."

Defense and "defense supporting" loans reversed the downward trend of business borrowings from New York banks last week, expanding commitments $96,000,000. The rise in the week ended on Wednesday partly offset the decline of nearly $150,000,000 in the two previous weeks, and was the largest since Dec. 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A limited Universal Military Training program could be put into operation, without adding to defense costs, six months after Congress gave its approval, Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, told the House Armed Services Committee today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today its agents had confiscated 6,000,000 pounds of contaminated foods in the last six months of 1951.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen came home to his, white frame cottage at 65 Alwat Street this afternoon, and told a handful of neighbors that the measure of his joy "cannot be put into words."

The New York Boxing Writers Association held its fourteenth annual dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Headed by the world heavyweight champion, Jersey Joe Walcott, most of the notable figures of the sport were present.

The Board of Estimate, with Controller Lazarus Joseph dissenting, voted in executive session yesterday to cut the 2 1/2 per cent franchise tax on gross receipts of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System to 1/2 of 1 per cent and permit the company to retain 10 cents instead of 7 out of the present 15-cent fare for a combination ride on its Bronx buses and the city subways.

Rooms in which simple, flexible, contemporary pieces form a new grouping set against backgrounds of sharp primary color accented by black and white are the feature attractions at Macy's midwinter furniture show that will open Monday.

Extensive grants for social research, education, law reform, agricultural programs in Latin America and medical studies were included in $9,884,000 appropriated by the Rockefeller Foundation in the last quarter of 1951, it was announced yesterday.
The total of patients at Presbyterian Hospital during the last year makes it "the largest of all voluntary hospitals in the country," Charles P. Cooper, hospital president, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Federal District Judges in Chicago issued temporary orders today to restrain six meat packing companies from violating an Office of Price Stabilization rule limiting the amount of fat that may be left on pork loins. Hearings on whether the temporary orders should be canceled or replaced by permanent injunction will be held on Jan. 25 before Judge Michael L. Igoe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Bill Mosienko counted two goals tonight to become the twentieth player to score 200 goals in the National Hockey League as the Chicago Black Hawks and the New York Rangers fought to a 6-to-6 tie in the Chicago Stadium.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- With tears in his eyes, Denis W. Delaney took the witness stand in Federal District Court today and recited the story of his life. He defended his acts as Collector of Internal Revenue.
MOASCAR, Egypt, Jan. 17 -Five young Egyptian terrorists sat in a row. They were the college commandos.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Harold E. Stassen's name may be on the April 8 Illinois Presidential preference ballot only because of the courtesy of the Cook County (Chicago) Republican Organization, whose members overwhelmingly favor Senator Taft.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- In this space were published today extracts from a Labor Day speech, made by General Eisenhower at St. Louis in 1949 to the American Bar Association. They were offered as precise guides to his thinking on domestic issues that still confront the nation in 1952 without change of substance.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 17 (UP) -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt's mud-loving Whither splashed to an easy four-length victory in the sloppy going today at Santa Anita in the 15,000 added Los Feliz Stakes for 3-year-olds.

GRAND JUNCTION, Col., Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it had contracted to buy uranium produced at an ore-processing plant that the Anaconda Copper Mining Company will build near Grants, N. M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman has approved a plan for a "real expansion" of the atomic weapons program, Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, reported today.

The trustees of the Queens Borough Public Library elected Charles Margett as president of the library last night. Mr. Margett, a resident of Jamaica and former president of the Queens County Bar Association, succeeds O. G. Alexander, also of Jamaica.

The recital season reached a high point last night when Adele Addison, soprano from Springfield, Mass., made her debut in Town Hall. The young singer was warmly greeted by a large audience, for her history of success with the Boston Symphony, the New England Opera and on tour had been well published.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17 -- The present Government of Mexico does not intend to nationalize commercial aviation, the Ministry of Communications, which is responsible for aeronautics, announced today.

Completion of a seven and one-half mile wooden pipeline to pump nickel-copper ore concentrate from its concentrator plant to reduction plants at Copper Cliff, Ont., was announced yesterday by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- John D. M. Hamilton, Eastern manager of the National Taft Committee, objected today to efforts by another group to collect funds for the Ohio Senator's Republican Presidential candidacy.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Court of Appeals today upheld constitutionality of the state law requiring Public Service Commission authorization before a bus company enters into a conditional sales contract.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A Congressional investigation into alleged "improper practices" among scheduled airlines was demanded today by the Independent Military Air Transport Association, an organization that says it represents the majority of nonscheduled airlines.

The American Institute for Imported Steel urged the Federal Maritime Board yesterday to turn down an increase in freight rates proposed by the west bound conference steamship lines that would mean a rise in ocean transport costs for steel of about 80 per cent in two years.

Henrik Kurt Carlsen has finally arrived home in this country and been met with the kind of public enthusiasm which was inspired by Charles A. Lindbergh in 1927. Like Lindbergh's, Captain Carlsen's courage and determination have captured the people's imagination, and the people have rewarded him. He has received the welcome due a hero back from the wars.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The United States and other sponsors of a three-year plan to make Arab refugees self-sufficient at a cost of $250,000,000, have reached a preliminary agreement with the Arab states on the proposal.

The stock market was torn yesterday between diverse news developments which left final prices selectively higher. Prime Minister Churchill's address before a joint session of Congress certainly was not considered as painting a peaceful picture of world affairs, and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky threw cold water on any possibility of an early termination of the Korean fighting.
To encourage the writing of letters to our service men in distant stations, especially Korea, the Veterans of Foreign Wars has initiated a project, the slogan of which is, "Be Sure to Write Today!"

Three new productions, including Alban Berg's controversial opera, "Wozzeck," will be presented during the spring season of the New York City Opera Company. The season will start Mach 20 and continue for six weeks, through April 27.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The worst run of storms in sixty-two years brought floods and washouts to California today, but partly paid for the damage in benefits to drought-parched farmlands and dwindling city water reserves.

Fish prices are a nickel a pound lower on a number of species this week-end, a cut that brings them to the lowest level in more than a month. Eggs, too, took another dip, a mark-down of 6 cents a dozen bringing the large Grade A to 65 cents, the City Department of Markets announced yesterday.

According to Mario da Camara, delegate of the Brazilian Treasury here, the regulations barring earnings of more than 8 per cent on non-Brazilian capital from being remitted abroad or from being used to swell the non-Brazilian capital investment base "do not change in any way the laws concerning fair treatment of foreign capital."

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, told the City Affairs Committee of the City Council at a public hearing yesterday that his department had received only fifteen complaints about inadequate ambulance emergency service out of 327,000 calls last year.

We are opposed on the strongest grounds of principle to any law that, while making officially disclosed facts available to the public, forbids newspapers and other mediums of public information to publish such facts. It is an abridgment of freedom of the press to say by law what the press shall or shall not publish, when facts are freely put on the record (and not military secrets, for instance).

A group of young designers with new ideas joined with a will in a fashion presentation at Altman's yesterday. The occasion was a preview of M. W. Thomas cottons in clothes from the Young Colony Shop. These will be modeled for the public on Monday between 11:30 A. M. and 3 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, in a Senate speech today denounced as un-American the use of the lie detector in testing Federal job applicants. He disclosed that Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, had prohibited the use of the device in his department after the Senator had protested.
Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday his opposition to a possible increase of one cent a quart in the price of milk in the city.

The rigid limitations on the activities and movements of foreign diplomats as well as other foreigners in the Soviet Union have been substantially increased by the latest Soviet order on this subject. In the area about Moscow diplomats now can travel outside the city for only about twenty-five miles, though even within this radius there are substantial forbidden areas.

The Chevrolet and Buick divisions of the General Motors Corporation yesterday announced their 1952 car lines. The cars, which incorporate many new advances and improvements, will go on display tomorrow in dealer showrooms here and over the country.

Many dinners will be given at the thirteenth annual White Elephant Party, which will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
The body of Francis Poultney Clark, socially prominent actor whose stage name was Owen Lamont, was found yesterday in a locked closet of his two-room suite at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Minister of Justice Edgar Faure, a Radical, was swept into office as the new Premier of France tonight by the National Assembly by an exceptionally heavy vote of 401 to 101.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 17--Pointing out that the textile industry currently is going through a serious deflationary period, The American Cotton Manufacturers today lodged formal protest with Mobilization Director Charles E. Wilson against continuation or extension of price controls.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 6-to-1 decision, today affirmed for the second time the first-degree murder conviction of Bernard Stein of New York City. His execution was set for the week of Feb. 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 -- A move to throw out Guy G. Gabrielson of New Jersey as chairman of the Republican National Committee was beaten down today by an overwhelming vote of confidence in him as members of the committee opened a three-day meeting here to plan for the national convention in July.

The chap who once said "there's nothing new under the sun" never saw a National Motor Boat Show. Plenty of new ideas and commendable new wrinkles are on every floor of the Grand Central Palace, where this extravaganza of outdoor fun will end its run tomorrow night.

The way officials of such Point 4 prospects as Brazil and Mexico are talking about stopping the "bleeding" by foreign capitalists and about "nationalizing" investments brought up with the aid of foreign private enterprise must mean something, but what is not clear.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The Soviet Union moved into the 4-year-old Kashmir controversy for the first time today with charges that the West was trying to grab control of the princely state to turn it into a military and strategic base.

I have done jury service for many years. The last time I served was during the December term, 1951, in the Supreme Court. It has been a revealing experience and one which is not easily forgotten. From the vantage point of the jury box I have watched the dynamic spirit of American democracy at work.
The Giants yesterday announced the signing of Charles (Chuck) Diering, light-hitting outfielder and Sheldon Jones, right-handed pitcher.

Because they seem to us to refute various unfounded assumptions about college athletes we note with pleasure and interest some facts developed in a study at Columbia University. The varsity football squad of the college (which, by the way, won five games and lost three last fall for the best record since 1947) had forty-one men on it.
International Selling Corp, importers and exporters of chemicals and machinery, in the Chanin Building, 122 E 42d St -- Hudhattan Corp, broker.
ROME, N. Y., Jan. 17 (AP) -- A four-engined bomber roared out of an overcast sky, narrowly missed a home and a cluster of apartments and crashed in flames near Griffiss Air Force Base today.

GENEVA, Jan. 17 -- The World Health Organization announced today that fifty countries had agreed to discontinue the medical use of heroin. For some reason the names of the countries were not mentioned.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 (UP) -Five defeated opponents pledged their support today to Robert F. Kennon, a country judge and "poor man's candidate," who beat seven opponents Tuesday in a Democratic gubernatorial primary and won a place in the run-off Feb. 19.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Submarine Command," a Paramount war melodrama with William Holden, Nancy Olson, William Bendix and Don Taylor, is at the Globe. John Farrow directed and Joseph Sistrom produced from a story and script by Jonathan Latimer.

MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 17 -- Harry C. Hawkins, an international trade expert and career diplomat, has been named as the first appointee to the William L. Clayton Chair of International Finance at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Dean Robert Burgess Stewart said today.

A quiet young matron from Woodbridge, N. J., whose chief interests outside her home are her church and the Parent-Teacher Association, rode up Broadway yesterday in a new hat ornamented with lacy drifts of confetti and ticker tape.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly refused today to vote on the new Soviet atomic proposals or any others submitted by the Soviet Union regarding the question of disarmament, and instead referred them to the United Nations Disarmament Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (UP) -- J. Russel Sprague, Republican National Committeeman from Mineola, N. Y., and Nassau County Executive, and his wife arrived today after being trapped for three days on the snowbound City of San Francisco.
Benrus Watch Company will spend more than $3,000,000 in advertising and sales promotion this year, according to Harvey Bond, director of advertising.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Destruction of three Communist MIG jets and three Red tanks in air actions highlighted the Korean war yesterday. Ground fighting was sporadic and generally light.

A recent intimation that Courtney Burr and his confederate, Malcolm Pearson, were thinking of doing "The Willows" turns out to be correct. Don't misconstrue this as one of those long-range projects. Not according to unimpeachable sources.
Almost every Soviet city having major industrial facilities important for military purposes has been closed to foreign diplomats as a result of the latest Soviet restrictions on diplomats' movements.

The old dissension between Rear Admiral William S. Maxwell, retired, deputy director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, and two of his colleagues on the Smoke Control Board, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings Bernard J. Gillroy and William G. Christy, bureau director, flared into the open yesterday at a City Hall public hearing.

Passengers on two westbound Long Island Rail Road trains were delayed two hours last night, and eighty-four other Long Island and Pennsylvania Railroad trains either were canceled or were delayed up to an hour and a half when an empty train struck and killed an unidentified man near Pennsylvania Station.

The city gave Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, a reluctant hero, the traditional confetti - and - tied - down-whistle salute yesterday. It dropped riced paper in his freshly combed hair as he rode up lower Broadway with his blond wife and two daughters, Karen and Sonja, just before noon.

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, the shipmaster from Woodbridge, N. J., whose brave, losing fight against the sea for his ship is being retold all across the Western world, yesterday added to his adventures the rare thrill of a formal welcome at City Hall.

Seven firemen pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conduct unbecoming a member of the Fire Department and failure to discharge their duties in connection with irregularities in the signing of a logbook for Gerard W. Purcell, a dismissed fireman.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican of Manhattan, renewed his fight today for the creation of "watchdog" grand juries to keep a constant eye on the activities of public officials in the five counties of New York City.
Following is the text of the address by Prime Minister Churchill in Washington yesterday to a joint session of Congress, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, said today that Dr. Philip C. Jessup, whose nomination as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly has not been confirmed by the Senate, was "a most arrant defender to the American way of life * * *"

WASHINGTON, Jan. l7 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Jan. 12 declined 13 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1951:

In outlining operations and hindrances in Korea due to the restrictions on strategic bombing, Maj. Gen. Roger L. Ramey, operations chief of the Air Force's general staff, yesterday entered the controversy over which is the better plane -- the American F-86 or the Russian MIG-15.

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen declined yesterday to accept a gold wrist watch offered by a Pennsylvania admirer and reiterated his determination not to cash in on the fame resulting from his heroic attempt to save the Flying Enterprise.
Apartment buildings and multiple dwellings were involved in Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Office of International Trade authorized today the export of 25,000 tons of iron and steel scrap and another 2,500 short tons of pig iron for the first quarter of 1952.

CAIRO, Jan. 17 -- British military authorities in the Suez Canal zone continued today their interrogation of Egyptian policemen and suspected terrorists captured yesterday in the course of extensive clearing operations in the area just south of the Tel el Kebir ordnance depot.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Jan. 17 -- In a speech critical of New England textile productivity, Francis W. White, president of the American Woolen Company, asserted tonight that his company was "giving serious consideration" to moving all its operations out of the region.

Presentation to Mrs. Douglas MacArthur of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Medal of the Women's Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Association, Inc., was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sherman Haight, president, at the annual meeting of the association at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

Local members of the Tri-State Council on Family Relations were urged yesterday to write their state senators and assemblymen urging action on the so-called Gordon bill, which would provide for appointment of a commission to study New York laws affecting family life.

AN ailment which has been diagnosed as "blue marlin fever" is entering the epidemic stage in the Bahamas, for these blue and silver torpedoes are luring hopefuls from the mainland to Bimini, where the run seems to be approaching a peak.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A clearly stated, long-term foreign policy and a single Chief of Staff for the armed forces were among the basic elements of an integrated mobilization program outlined by W. Stuart Symington in a report to President Truman nearly a year ago.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. l7 -- Modern management has a new conception of the word profit, according to Lawrence A. Appley of New York, president of the American Management Association. He explained the point in an address at the final session of the association's mid-winter general conference here.

A minimum of shoe with a well defined silhouette was predominant in the Saks Fifth Avenue spring designs previewed by the press yesterday. Strippings that formed flattering patterns on the foot, vamps that were cut away to reveal all the toes, and completely backless shoes were shown in flat and high heel interpretations for daytime as well as evening.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Congress gave to Prime Minister Churchill today a more affectionate reception than ever it has given in late years to the President of the United States himself.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 -- The rescue yesterday of 226 persons from the snowbound streamliner City of San Francisco in the high Sierras came just in time, some passengers reported today.

Federal supervision of the issuance of driving permits was urged in Traffic Court yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh as he levied a $338 fine on a 19-year-old New York University student who had pleaded guilty to ignoring sixteen traffic tickets.

One of the city's worst week-end and holiday traffic bottlenecks will be eliminated early in April when the Port Authority's new $9,000,000 tunnel under West 179th Street and the city-state $4,600,000 Highbridge Interchange are opened.

It is inevitable that sooner or later another ice storm will slide down upon the suburbs. It is inevitable that an afternoon drizzle will turn, when the sun goes down, into what the weather bureau somewhat unromantically calls a freezing rain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Grace Granich told the House Un-American Activities Committee today that she was "a very loyal citizen of the United States." But she joined her husband, in refusing to tell the committee whether she was or ever had been a member of the Communist party.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Veteran Sid Abel rammed home two goals tonight to lead the front-running Detroit Red Wings to a 5-to-0 victory over the Boston Bruins before 10,241 fans at the Olympia Stadium.

Events today: Philharmonic - Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; "Der Freischuetz," Cooper Union, 8:15; Dessoff Choirs, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Barbara Custance, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Herma Menth, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Juilliard Orchestra, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30; Tann Williams, contralto, and William Hain, tenor, West End Presbyterian Church, 8:15; Boston Symphony. Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.
Despite crew shortages and some delays resulting from short supplies of bunker fuel, 150 sailings were made by National Shipping Authority vessels during December, the agency reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the United Gas Corporation of Shreveport, La., to sell $50,000,000 worth of its first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, series due 1972.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 17 -- A 172-word cablegram formally notified General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Paris today that his name had been entered in this state's March 11 primary as a Republican candidate for President.

Investment assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation hit a record high of $155,130,269 at the end of 1951, according to the investment company's annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday by Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president. Net assets of the concern at the year-end were equivalent to $22.17 a share on the outstanding common stock, a gain of 29.8 per cent over the $17.08 a share reported at the end of 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -The Government today invited the steel industry price advisory committee to a meeting Jan. 29 to discuss a proposed order under which the industry might apply for price adjustments.

General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen yesterday adjourned the extortion conspiracy trial of James J. Moran until 10:30 A. M. Monday after only ten jurors had been chosen from an original special panel of 300 talesmen.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Joe Louis broke into the big league of golf today as the first Negro to compete in a tournament co-sponsored by the Professional Golfers Association of America, and Ted Kroll broke the course competitive record with a 7-under-par 65 in the opening round of the $10,000 San Diego Open.

Benn Barber, district general counsel of the Waterman Steamship Corporation, was re-elected president yesterday of the Security Bureau, Inc., at the organization's annual meeting in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. This will be Mr. Barber's third term as head of the bureau, a maritime industry organization formed to fight theft and pilferage on the port's waterfront.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Government indicated today it had already begun to use secretly part of the $100,000,000 appropriated to aid the escape of men from behind the Iron Curtain who wished to join combat units for the ultimate liberation of their homelands.

The Franklin Award for Distinguished Service of the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc., was presented last night to Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, head of the Central Intelligence Agency. General Smith was wartime Chief of Staff to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union from 1946 to 1949.

IT just didn't seem to make any sense when Willie Mays flunked the first aptitude test that his draft board gave him. Willie the Wonder is no Einstein. But he's no dope either. Not only is he a high school graduate but he finished in the upper half of his class. Obviously something was wrong when he failed and the feeling was overwhelming that he'd pass on the second try.

Assailing price controls in the livestock and meat industry, John Holmes, president of Swift Co., asserted yesterday that "the greatest benefits of price control go to unscrupulous violators who cash in on the black market."
PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The United States delegation produced evidence today that United States aid to a famine-stricken Russia after World War I was received gratefully in 1923.
Operations of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation in the six months ended with last December resulted in net earnings of $3,971,018 after taxes and all charges, the report revealed yesterday.

The reports of Jack Raymond from Germany do not, in my opinion, give to the uninformed sufficient information on which to base an unprejudiced opinion with respect to the Allies' policy for the decartelization and decentralization of the Ruhr steel and coal industries under Law 27.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- With a mixture of admiration and dismay thousands of Britons heard the recorded voice of Prime Minister Churchill addressing the United States Congress, broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation tonight.

Factory workers in this state earned an average of $66.08 a week in November, a rise of exactly $4 over the weekly average for November, 1950, according to figures made public yesterday by the State Labor Department. The rise was 6.1 per cent, slightly less than the 6.9 per cent increase in living costs in the twelve-month period.
For the first time this winter, Eastern skiers will have to be careful before deciding where to do their trail or slope running this week-end.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The body of Marshal Jean de Lattre de Tassigny came home today to the little village of Mouilleron en Pareds in the Vendee Department after a 200-mile stately procession across western France.
Federal wage inspectors reported yesterday that one-quarter of the New York and New Jersey employers whose payrolls they had examined in the last two months were violating Government wage controls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republican Presidential nomination are intent on beating former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota as badly as possible in the Wisconsin, Illinois and Ohio primaries.

The use of the antibiotics -- including penicillin, streptomycin, chloromycetin, aureomycin and terramycin -- to control infections may seriously interfere with the normal bodily process of immunity development, it was emphasized yesterday at a conference on antibiotics.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 17 -Shocked by the vote of the United Nations General Assembly's Special Political Committee not only retaining the Palestine Conciliation Commission in an enlarged form, but reaffirming past United Nations resolutions on the subject of Palestine, the Israeli Foreign Ministry was today seeking to mobilize friendly nations in an effort to change the situation in the final Assembly vote.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 17 -- "Ordvac" passed its final examinations with perfect grades today at the University of Illinois. The electronic brain, which has 2,720 vacuum tubes, will be used by the Army at the ballistics research laboratories, Aberdeen, Proving Ground, Md.

A new era of high speed wool goods production has begun at the main plant of the Bachman Uxbridge Worsted Corporation in Uxbridge, Mass., it was learned yesterday. Louis Bachmann, vice president, revealed that the company now has in operation a battery of twenty-four new Sulzer looms, with a hundred more to be installed when finished.

A committee of sixty union leaders representing both the American Federation of Labor and the Committee of Industrial Organizations was organized yesterday to solicit funds for the Red Cross among the 1,000,000 union members in New York.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for sixty-three families on plot 52 by 100 feet at 33 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Tenth Street, has been purchased for investment by the Salmos Corporation, represented by Lawrence I. Gerber, in a deal negotiated by Pearce, Mayer Greer, brokers, for cash over a mortgage of $341,763.
One of the most delightful figure-skating shows ever presented at Madison Square Garden opened last night when the Arthur M. Wirtz Hollywood Ice Revue made its nitial appearance at the big arena.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Rose Valois calls her line "sea shell," which is an apt description of her small shallow berets and toques that are slightly convex on top and sweep a little forward into an undulating or scalloped edge shadowing the brow. The back of the head is entirely uncovered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- During the week ended Jan. 16, member bank reserves increased $119,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

More parents are voluntarily seeking assistance in the solution of problems concerning relationships that do not necessarily stem from neglect or abuse, the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children reported yesterday at its seventy-first annual meeting.

Twenty-two contributors gave $340.30 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to make the 1951-52 campaign total $345,447.01. The Community Service Society reported two gifts amounting to $82 while the remainder, $258.30, was sent direct to this office.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Governor Dewey's forces in the Republican state organization are mobilizing for an all-out primary battle with backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in two Congressional districts of Erie County and one district in the lower Catskill area.

" The Diary of George Templeton Strong," a four-volume work edited by Allan Nevins and Milton Halsey Thomas, has been scheduled by Macmillan for April 15 publication. The diary, begun in 1835, covers forty years of American life, with news of the theatre, concerts, fads, scandal in high society, political battles, the events of the Civil War and details of the expansion of New York City.

A "sweep toward Christianity" among North Korean prisoners of war was reported yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, stated clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

A spokesman for the Kuomintang (the Chinese Nationalist party) denounced yesterday as "absurd and groundless" the charge by Li Tsung-jen, Chinese Nationalist Vice President, that President Chiang Kai-shek was a dictator and had illegally given control of the Kuomintang to a committee appointed by himself.

UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., is seeking a court order to restrain the Utica and Mohawk Cotton Mills, Inc., from moving to South Carolina, pending trial of a $400,000 suit brought by the union.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 17 -- A 34-year-old self-employed auctioneer today refused to pay the Government his $88 Social Security tax for 1951 because he believed he could provide for his family "better than the Government can."
BONN, Germany, Jan. 17 -- The Western Allies have rejected proposed legislation by the West Berlin Government that would have implied the integration of the city with West Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill gave Congress today a solemn but fairly hopeful report on the state of the universe.

A pattern of air freight traffic between the United States and Europe in which the eastbound loads predominated was reversed last year for the first time in the history of international air freight, Seaboard and Western Airlines announced yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, declared today that "unreasonable demands presented by the American command can give no hope for a successful conclusion" of Korean armistice talks at Panmunjom.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- A $250,000,000 program for Korean relief and rehabilitation, prepared by J. Donald Kingsley, United Nations Agent General for Korea, has been approved by a five-member advisory committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- The National Council of Farmer Cooperatives urged today "immediate termination of price controls on agricultural commodities" because "consumers' food costs can be held at present levels only by effective control of costs, other than farm production costs, which are reflected in consumer prices."
The Chicago International Trade Fair, originally schedued for March 22 through April 6, has been postponed to Aug. 2 through 17, it was learned yesterday from foreign trade sources here.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 17 -- A forum panel of six Long Island high school students agreed here today that American civil liberties were being threatened, but they disagreed as to the magnitude of the threats.

HONG KONG, Jan. 17 -- An emergency regulation is scheduled to take effect here tomorrow giving to the Hong Kong Colonial Government the power to clear existing squatters camps and resettle their Chinese inhabitants in new areas under Government supervision.

Your editorial "Electricity for Subways" was pleasant reading to one who as chairman of the smoke abatement committee of the Lexington-First Avenue Association has for years maintained that the city would not only save money on the purchase of its power requirements but would increase its income through taxing the privately owned utilities that could supply all of the city's requirements.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The stock markets were mainly dull here today with the exception of British Funds, foreign bonds and copper mining shares. A late rally in the industrial leaders canceled most of the early losses and left one or two prices slightly higher.

I WISH that some statistically minded individual with nothing else to do would make a survey of the locale of modern American novels. It would be interesting to know whether the numerical preponderance of Southern novels is really as great as it seems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee decided today to ask Secretary of State Dean Acheson for a full report on the "ransoming" of four United States airmen whose plane was forced down in Hungary.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Spartan Valor outbattled Jumbo in a thrilling stretch duel today to capture the $10,000. Hialeah Inaugural Handicap, opening day feature of a meeting that may see a $60,000,000 betting record established at the Florida track.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 18 -- The Communists charged yesterday that Allied planes again had violated the neutral area set aside for the Korean truce conferences, dropping a bomb on the outskirts of Kaesong, headquarters of the Chinese and North Korean armistice delegation.
Pacific Coast players were the first choices of both local clubs in the National Football League as the professional circuit's annual draft of collegians got under way yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Jan. 12 totaled 742,757 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 129,977 cars, or 21.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 40,258 cars, or 5.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 113,214 cars, or 18 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
" Studio One," which has done so much fine pioneering in television, contributed a distinctive hour of video this week (10 P. M.

Cocoa stood out against the general down trend of commodity prices yesterday. There appeared little domestic news to account for its strength, which apparently, followed the higher prices being quoted by producers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation of Richard M. Bissell Jr. as Deputy Director for Mutual Security, effective tomorrow.

F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., and Zuckerman, Smith Co. will offer to investors today 325,000 shares of common stock of International Resistance Company, manufacturer of resistors used in electronic and electrical devices. The stock is priced at $5 a share.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- William H. Draper Jr. of New York was confirmed by the Senate today to be special representative in Europe for the Mutual Security Program with the rank of Ambassador.
TOKYO, Jan. 17 -- The expected criticism of Premier Shigeru Yoshida's announced policy on post-treaty relations between Japan and the two Chinas has now begun to crystallize.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Capt. Jim Dilling's foul shot with only one and a half seconds left in an overtime period gave the Holy Cross basketball team a 66-65 victory over St. Louis tonight at the Boston Garden before 8,771 fans.
DENVER, Colo., Jan. 17 -- The famed Teapot Dome oil field of Wyoming has resumed production for the first time since it was shut down 25 years ago following the notorious lease scandals.

As never before in the past, the citizens of this country are concerned about their public schools. Throughout the national local citizens' groups are being founded to work for better school facilities for all the children.

A bitter inside struggle for the presidency of the Board of Education resulted yesterday in the adjournment of the board's election meeting until 11 A. M. Monday, when Andrew G. Clauson Jr. of Richmond, a former president, is expected to win the post.
