If the operating rate of the nation's steel mills this year should average a flat 100 per cent of present capacity, they would turn out 108,587,670 net tons of raw steel, a new record quantity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today approved a merger of the broadcasting interests of R. H. Macy Co. of New York City and General Tire and Rubber Company.

The current abundance and reasonable cost of eggs suggest frequent use of this nutritive food not only at breakfast but also as a basis for lunch and supper dishes. Especially economical now as an alternative to high-cost meats are the large Grade A eggs.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 17 -- Although local Communist efforts have made little impression on the elections held here last week, Marxism's chief attempts to court Indian intellectuals and other higher circles appear to be funneled through this city, the traditional "gateway to India."
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 17 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Allied Supreme Commander in the Far East, was commended tonight by two Methodist Bishops for his churchly qualifications.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 18 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,132, for Thursday's operations:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that the "extravagances" of United States representatives in Germany "stink to high heaven."
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs, a tiny Georgian, shot a two-under-par 72 today to lead the Tampa women's open golf tournament -- an event she has been trying for six years to win.
The National Soccer Coaches Association opened a three day convention at the Hotel Paramount yesterday by designating its All-America selections.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 17 -The Hercules Powder Company is entering the field of chemicals produced by hydrocarbon oxidation, it was announced yesterday when plans for the erection of an $8,000,000 plant were described. Using a new process, the company will make phenol, para-cresol and acetone.
For more than fifty years the Salvation Army has taken to its heart the forgotten men of the Bowery. Today these men receive comfortable, clean lodgings in the Bowery Memorial Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- President Truman has chosen a veteran diplomat, Robert D. Murphy, now Ambassador to Belgium, to be this country's first post-war Ambassador to Japan.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., Jan. 17 -- The new fare increase that the Long Island Rail Road will seek amounts to only a cent a day for commuters and a cent a ride on one-way tickets, William Wyer, trustee of the railroad, told members of the Suffolk County Village Officials Association at a meeting here tonight.

A plan to add a national theatre in conjunction with the new opera house proposed for the site just off Columbus Circle has reached the point where it will be taken up today at a board meeting of the American National Theatre and Academy, known as Anta.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Jan. 17 -- A Chinese Communist general brusquely pushed aside two representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross who tried today for the second time to enter North Korea on a humanitarian mission.

The impact of the November, 1950, hurricane carried over into 1951 with the result that last year's underwriting earnings of the five companies comprising the America Fore Insurance Group were adversely affected to the extent of about $5,000,000, Frank A. Christensen, president, reported yesterday in the annual condition statement of the group.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Salary Stabilization Board made it clear today that its new baseball wage policy removed ceilings from the pay of individual players, such as Stan Musial of the Cards, for both this year and last. But the board added that it was up to the clubs to work out ways of paying Musial, and those in the same class, without violating overall pay ceilings.

The American Arabian Oil Company announced yesterday the election of F. A. Davies, executive vice president, as chairman and chief executive officer of the company. This action followed the resignation of W. S. S. Rodgers as chairman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Ben Hecht, one of the most prolific writers serving the movies, is discussing a deal with Snader Telescriptions, Inc., which would put him into the video field in a big way. In fact, it is a two-way deal, because some, if not all, of the proposed television shows to be done on film may be packaged in groups of three and marketed first to theatres.

Protests will be made to the Federal Trade Commission on several points of the recently promulgated revised rules for the identification of rayon fabrics and garments made of rayon, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed at or close to the lows of the day, 35 to 55 points net lower on the active months than on Wednesday.

The last tense moments before he jumped into the raging Atlantic seas from the deck of the doomed American freighter Flying Enterprise were recounted here yesterday by the vessel's chief engineer, George Brown of Baltimore.
DUDLEY, England, Jan. 17 -On the wrought iron gates at the entrance to Himley Hall one would almost expect to see a sign saying, "Men wanted."
A proposal that separate gas rates be established for consumers in Westchester County was put before the Public Service Commission yesterday.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 17 -- French capture of Hoabinh two months ago completely disrupted a Vietminh plan to seize the western end of the Tongking delta, Gen. Raoul Salan, Acting French Commander in Chief for Indo-China, said here today in an interview.

Today's events: Children's concerts: Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman, conductor, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 o'clock, and Mannes Orchestra, Carl Bamberger, conductor, Mannes Music School, noon.
Three of the exhibitions of abstract painting on view this week make good foils for one another.

The board of the American National Theatre and Academy, known as Anta, voted yesterday to accept in principle the invitation of the Metropolitan Opera to join in a new cultural center to be constructed just off Columbus Circle.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Preston Sturges is returning to Paramount to write the screen play for Betty Hutton's next musical, "Look, Ma, I'm Dancin'," based on the 1948 Broadway success. There is more than an even chance that Mr. Sturges also may direct the picture, but that has yet to be officially announced.
The number of new housing units started this year will probably reach 800,000, and possibly higher, according to the Housing Letter, publication of the International Statistical Bureau.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Industrial shares weakened in late business in the stock markets here today after having been reasonably firm. Their early improvement was stimulated partly by the tone of Prime Minister Churchill's address before Congress, but the effect wore off.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 18 -- Jacob A. Malik's Security Council speech supporting the Indian-sponsored Kashmir Constituent Assembly came as a surprise to Pakistan. It was not expected that the Soviet Union would side so strongly with India in the dispute.

Eugene Hairston of the Bronx knocked out Al (Red) Priest of Cambridge, Mass., in the sixth round of their scheduled ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 2,176 saw Dr. Vincent A. Nardiello, State Athletic Commission physician, order Referee Harry Kessler to stop the bout at the end of the sixth session.

Thirst for that particular brand of culture known as opera is widespread. Proof of this, together with a partial quenching of it, is to be found in a series of English-language one-nighters at the Cooper Union Forum and, on the following evenings, at Walton High School in the Bronx.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Don Gehrmann, the uncrowned king of American milers, tonight reasserted his sovereignty over the eight- furlong realm.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 -- City firemen began today taking over traffic duty at school crossings. Veteran policemen showed them the "tricks of the trade," and on Monday morning the firemen will be on their own.
Joseph R. Holahan asserted yesterday that "glory and greed" were the motives for the murder of his brother, Maj. William V. Holohan, while on a secret mission in Italy in World War II.

I am sorry Lincoln Diamant feels I flew in the face of facts in the incident of the "silver bullet," as he terms it, which was swallowed and brought up forcibly during the Hudson Highlands campaign in the Revolution. I omitted details in my first letter, as the overall story is just as effective without them.

Today's new film is "Peace Will Win," a Polish-made documentary, directed by Joris Ivens in collaboration with Jerzy Szelubski, dealing with the second World Peace Conference held in Warsaw, at the Stanley. The Artkino Pictures release is narrated in English.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Organized labor split today over the issue of permanent personal registration for voters in the state's cities and villages with populations above 5,000.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 18 -- The Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church, the United States' largest single Protestant denomination, unanimously went on record today as opposed to the appointment of "anyone, at any time, in any place" as an Ambassador to the Vatican.

Visiting buyers have placed many orders in the last two weeks for women's apparel, a survey of New York's wholesale markets revealed yesterday. Total volume, however, was not large owing to the fact that caution was being taken to avoid new build-ups of inventory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin announced today that the railroads and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen had agreed on procedures for settlement of disputes over introduction of the forty-hour week for yard service employes.

The 2,500 animals at the Bronx Zoo had their day at city budget hearings in the Municipal Building yesterday when Budget Examiner John J. Carty, sitting in the absence of Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson, was told that hay, fish and horseflesh for the zoo's tenants would cost $9,300 more next year.

A good deal has been said and written about automobile accidents and the mounting death toll resulting from these accidents. Special emphasis has been laid upon the human element involved -- recklessness, insobriety, indifference, etc.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 18 -- So long as the Soviet Union exercises absolute control over its economy and foreign trade, there is hardly any scope for trade expansion between India and Russia, in the opinion of authoritative Indian official and political circles.
The following round-up of new products for use about the house may be of interest to the homemaker.
The fund-raising drive of the New York City Cancer Committee has obtained $22,000 toward the 1952 goal of $1,394,327, William E. Hutton, co-chairman of the men's committee, said yesterday.

The apartment house accommodating seventy-two families on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 28-28 Thirty-fifth Street in Astoria, Queens, has been sold by a client of the Harris Block Company to the Thirty-fifth Street Company. Joseph E. Nelson was the broker and the attorneys were Sidney Schwamm for the seller and Saul Mildworm for the buyer.

WHEN you go to lunch with a small group of dog fanciers it pays to make certain before the event that all favor the same breed, or select a restaurant where you are not known or which is not on your list Of favorites.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said today he hoped President Truman would seek re-election and he added that "I think he is by far the strongest candidate the Democrats could put up."

One day, along about here, a gentle but firm voice will suggest it is about time to dismantle that railroad empire which, since last Dec. 25, in the dim past, has been causing serious pedestrian traffic problems in the living room, or in the dining room, or in both.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A Senate subcommittee received today a long-awaited report from its staff investigators dealing with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and then adjourned in an atmosphere of indecision.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Egypt warned today that if the United States, France or Turkey sent troops to the Suez Canal zone, as requested yesterday by Prime Minister Churchill, Cairo would regard this as a hostile act, and probably would bring the matter before the United Nations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- President Truman's Point Four program for world economic development loosed "an avalanche of hopeful blueprinting in even the remotest capitals," but in three years of operation failed to achieve one of its two basic purposes, George A. Sloan, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense said today it expected a 5,000,000 to 6,000,000-barrel shortage of fuel oil on the East Coast north of Norfolk, Va., by the end of March.

For his part in the disorder that followed Ernie Durando's seventh-round knockout of Rocky Castellani in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 11, Thomas Eboli, better known as Tommy Ryan, yesterday suffered revocation for life of the licenses issued by the State Athletic Commission to him as a manager and second of boxers in this state.

Many New Yorkers, on the momentary impulse of high resolve, make an appointment with the Red Cross blood-donor center, and then fail to appear. According to a recent statement by Frank W. Lilley, acting administrator of the regional blood program, approximately one-fourth of those making appointments cancel them or do not come in.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A shortage of gravel threatening important road building projects in some Western and Southern States was reported here today at the closing session of the Highway Research Board.

HONG KONG, Jan. 18 -- The Chinese Communist radio in Canton hurled a salvo of sharp threats at this British colony tonight in a broadcast in which five deported "cultural workers" declared one after another that Hong Kong belonged to Red China.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 18 -- Establishment of a framework of workable controls which provide such merchandising flexibility as is possible rather than decontrol of prices will better solve problems of the food industry in the year ahead, the nation's wholesale grocers were advised here today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 18 -- As a substitute for Saturday night parties a group of serious-minded Stamford High School students have organized weekly Bible reading and discussions. Their aim is to pass on their beliefs to fellow-students.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday the downward course it started earlier in the week and closed 8 to 21 points net lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- John L. Colmar, national chairman of the Taft Clubs of America, said today that criticism of his organization by a manager of Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination was based on a misunderstanding.

Seeing "profound and widening cracks behind the Iron Curtain," Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennesse, declared in a radio address last night that if Americans were to take the fullest advantage of these weaknesses in the Communist regime "we must convince the peoples behind the Iron Curtain, as distinguished from their leaders, that we are their real friends, not their enemies."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The State Department reorganized its foreign information and education staff today in an effort to compromise with advocates of a fully independent United States agency for carrying the "campaign of truth" abroad.
Two pitchers and a catcher signed for the Dodgers yesterday, raising to ten the number of players now under contract.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The State Banking Department announced today it had approved a certificate of increase of capital stock of the Empire Trust Company, 120 Broadway, from $4,000,000, consisting of 80,000 shares of the par value of $50 each to $4,500,000, consisting of 90,000 shares of the same par value.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The Union of South Africa returned to the plenary meeting of the United Nations General Assembly today to deliver an hour-long attack on the Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, whose activities caused the South African Premier, D. F. Malan, on Dec. 12 to order the delegation to boycott the Assembly plenary sessions.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A subcommittee of the United States House of Representatives has ended its hearings here and at St. Croix on proposals to give the Virgin Islands a greater measure of self-government.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 18 -- The snow was falling hard today, lifting the spirits of 100 skiers, who will compete in the fifth annual Capt. Vic Constant Memorial Alpine races this week-end. The foremost downhill and slalom racers, including ski instructors, took a last-minute crack at the Lord and standard descents today to mark their straightest lines for tomorrow's downhill test, opening phase of the combined event.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Jan. 18 (AP) -- State's Attorney Robert C. Nelson of Lake County said tonight that new documentary evidence "involving a vast organization and huge sums of money" had been uncovered in the horse-meat investigation.

PORT SAID, Egypt, Saturday, Jan. 19 -- The British cruiser Liverpool opened fire from her anchorage off Port Said yesterday after a four-hour gun battle in the city between British troops and Egyptian guerrillas, Egyptian port police reported today.

New ways to keep books and magazines in order are constantly being considered by today's designers. Many desks and tables are now designed to incorporate storage space for reading matter, but many other pieces are planned with the sole intent of holding books or periodicals.

MADRID, Jan. 18 -- Spain is willing to place at the disposal of the United States naval and air bases necessary to strengthen the Western defense system as her contribution to a policy of military collaboration in exchange for United States military and economic aid.

This year's National Motor boat show, which will close its run tonight with a final toot of whistles, horns and pipes in Grand Central Palace, is helping to make a nation of carpenters and boat-building artisans.

Aggregate short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchgnge hardly moved in the month to Jan. 15, dropping only 11,278 shares to 2,439,306, according to a compilation released by the Exchange yesterday.

NATHAN STRAUS is in favor of the Declaration of Independence's hope of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness to the degree that he thinks every man, woman and child in America should have a decent place to live in a decent landscape. The former administrator of the United States Housing Authority devotes his existence to that humane endeavor.

VIENNA, Jan. 18 -- Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner, told a press conference in Linz today that he was touring the American zone of Austria before returning to the United States to discuss Austrian problems in Washington.

Joseph W. Heimsoth, chairman of the citation committee of the Lutheran Society of New York, presented its first annual citation for distinguished service last night at a dinner at the Astor Hotel to Mrs. Susan K. Schaefer, president of the Lutheran Women's League of New York and Vicinity, Dr. Ethel J. Alpenfels of the New York University School of Education spoke.
Possibility that Sugar Bowl sponsors would tie up with some college conferences for New Year's day football bowl games was seen yesterday by The Associated Press.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- Feuding between Presidential campaign forces of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, even as spokesmen for each warned against verbal barbs that might carry seeds of party disunity, overshadowed business sessions of the Republican National Committee today.

Diseases that have ravaged domestic animal population in South Africa have been checked in some instances by modern antibiotics, but the drugs now available will not serve to increase the meat supply there, it was reported here yesterday at a conference on the use of antibiotics in tropical diseases.
BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The following New England winter sports conditions were reported today:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Rui Gomes Almeida, president of the Coffee Trade Center, said today that recent rises in coffee prices are due to the "unavoidable fact" of production shortages and that no United States ceiling prices or other artificial measures can prevent them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Office of Alien Property announced tonight that 215 patents of German origin held by the Schering Corporation, Bloomfield, N. J., would be made available to the public on a non-exclusive, royalty-free basis.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 18 -- Authorities in the French protectorate of Tunisia today countered a wave of nationalist demonstrations that had left four dead and fifty-six wounded in the last week by arresting a dozen Nationalists and Communist leaders and mobilizing security forces at trouble centers.

The number of suppliers of metal products willing to accept orders for near-by delivery has substantially increased in January, compared with December, it was learned here yesterday in a can- vass of members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder created a new post today over his department's far-flung activities against international narcotics peddlers, smugglers, tax evaders and counterfeiters.
Something new under the academic sun was described yesterday as representatives from twenty-one colleges met at Barnard College for the annual meeting of the Women's Placement Bureau.

May I be permitted to refer to statements contained in an advertisement published in your paper of Jan. 16 by the Zionist Revisionists of America. The advertisement purports to deal with the "truth" about the demonstrations in Jerusalem on Jan. 7, for which the Herut party in Israel has accepted responsibility.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals today set aside a Civil Aeronautics Board certificate to Capital Airlines for nonstop operations between Cleveland and New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.4 per cent in the week ended on Jan. 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, at 176.5 per cent of the 1926 average, was 12.5 per cent above the pre-Korean average, but 1.9 per cent below the level of a year ago. The largest declines occurred in the farm products and foods groups. Smaller decreases were noted for textiles and chemicals.

A proposal that the Government permit creation of an industry-union shipping corporation to assure European industry lower coal prices has again focused attention on a sore point in the European economy -- its coal shortage and its reliance on American coal at high prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- General Motors Corporation was authorized today to raise wholesale price ceilings from 4.4 to 6 per cent on its five passenger car lines to reflect higher production costs.

In decisions affecting eleven Fire Department members accused of shakedowns in air compressor and oil burner inspections, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet ordered yesterday the retirement of a first-grade fireman and a civilian inspector and imposed on them maximum fines estimated to exceed $500.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Starting a week from tomorrow, the ration of fresh beef, mutton or pork will be reduced by nearly 20 per cent, but the bacon ration will be increased from three to four ounces a week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, who probably will become the first Supreme Allied Commander in the Atlantic, is a 56-year-old veteran submariner who now commands the United States Atlantic Fleet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Truman and Prime Minister Churchill announced today that they had agreed to the appointment of an American supreme commander for the North Atlantic Treaty Navies in the Atlantic.

The turn of events in the case of Bermuda's venerable House of Assembly versus The Royal Gazette has Gilbertian flavor. The Assembly has approved the report of a select committee condemning The Gazette for a breach of privilege in publishing details of a public debate that the House had voted to suppress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department gave thirty-day dismissal notices today to 280 Federal meat inspectors. A spokesman said the department had run out of funds to pay their salaries. Most of the 280 were hired since July 1 in anticipation of record meat production this year.

Repercussions of the report of the men's ranking committee and the Davis Cup campaign that ended in defeat in Australia are expected to enliven the seventy-first annual meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association today at the Vanderbilt Hotel.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Edgar Faure, whom the French National Assembly last night endorsed as Premier by an overwhelming vote, said today that he hoped to present his Cabinet to the Assembly by Tuesday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 18 -- The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty allies have now established a radar warning net across the entire length of the command area of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, which stretches nearly 2,500 miles from Norway across Central Europe down to Italy.

In response to obvious weaknesses and to persistent criticism the State Department has now put into effect a major reorganization of its foreign information services, including Voice of America, libraries, films and educational exchanges. At the heart of the new plan is a separation of policy-forming from operational functions of the program, which heretofore had headed up in one man, the Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- John W. Gibson, chairman of the United States Displaced Persons Commission, disclosed here today that this country's German-ethnic refugee immigration program would be completed by May 15, a month and a half ahead of schedule.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Marshal Jean de Lattre de Tassigny was buried today in the presence of a few intimates in the cemetery of the tiny village of Mouilleron-en-Pareds in western France, where he was born not quite 62 years ago.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 -- The Socialists have introduced a constitutional issue that, if decided in their favor, would make it nearly impossible to obtain West German participation in the defense of Western Europe over their opposition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Charlie Comiskey's resignation as an executive of the family-owned White Sox was accepted today, and though both sides maintained the "door was open" for negotiations, neither apparently was willing to start discussions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Using powers remaining from the Trading With the Enemy Act of 1917, the Treasury Department today barred the sale or other disposition of a steel mill manufactured for Czech interests and now in storage in this country.

LITTLE VALLEY, N. Y., Jan. 18 (UP) -- A nonscheduled airliner that crashed near here Dec. 29 with loss of twenty - six lives made the flight in violation of Civil Aeronautics Administration weather regulations, a Government weather observer testified today.

GALVESTON, Tex., Jan. 18 (UP) -- The last operating shipyard in Galveston was shut down today when workers at the Kane Shipbuilding Corporation walked off their jobs. The strike brought to more than 2,300 the number of workers idle in nine shipyards.

A Manhattan housewife asked representatives of milk producers yesterday why a quart of milk costs 12 cents in Youngstown, Ohio, where she visited her children last month, and about twice that much in New York.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 19 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom charged yesterday that the Communists planned to withhold 50,000 South Korean prisoners during an armistice in the Korean war.

Steel shares came in for belated recognition yesterday in the stock market and, bolstered by the rails gave the list an irregularly higher rating at the close. However, prices were unable to maintain their best levels under pressure of offerings in the final hour.
Housing and commercial realty changed hands in Manhattan deals reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- The defense rested today in the trial of Denis W. Delaney, former Boston Collector of Internal Revenue. He is charged with accepting $12,500 to influence his decisions on tax matters with falsely certifying that more than $180,000 in tax liens had been paid.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- "Bafflegabb" -- a new word to describe Government jargon -- received official recognition today alongside the now-familiar "gobbledegook."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 18 (AP) -- An all-male jury acquitted Mrs. Dorothy Binger tonight of charges that she had hired a young truck driver to kill her husband in a murder - for - insurance plot. The jury deliberated a little more than an hour. Its verdict, not only sets Mrs. Binger free, but makes her eligible to collect on three insurance policies on the life of her husband, Richard Binger, 30 years old.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence and Miss Jeannette Burr, two pert ski queens, added to the United States' Olympic stock today by taking first and third places in the giant slalom of the international meet which attracted stars from six nations.

The first annual Advertising in Action Award (a gold trophy) for the best sales promotion and advertising campaign of the year in the investment field was presented yesterday to Dreyfus Co., New York Stock Exchange concern. The award, sponsored by the Standard and Poor's Corporation, was made to Jack Dreyfus, senior partner of the investment concern, at a one-day conference on promotion and advertising for the investment business in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- David J. Guy, natural resources expert, today was elected executive vice president of the American Watershed Council, Inc., national association of local, state and regional watershed organizations.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,133, for Friday's operations:

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- International Harvester Company is arranging a $125,000,000 five-year loan with the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and an associated country-wide group of banks, William R. Odell Jr., vice president and treasurer of Harvester, announced today.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 18 -- Adelphi, paced by Jim Grant, handed Wagner its first setback, 76 -- 57, in sixteen Greater New York College Basketball Conference games over a two-season span tonight.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 18 (UP) -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, suggested today that Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, had been wrong when he had described United States "extravagances" in Germany.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Inflation will outrank Russia as a threat to the United States for the next year or two, Philip D. Reed, chairman of General Electric Company, said today. He told the Executives' Club of Chicago at a luncheon meeting that the six rounds of wage hikes since World War II constituted the biggest single cause of the country's inflationary trend.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., already beset by a bitter intraunion feud that first manifested itself in the crippling dock strike last fall, appeared yesterday to be facing additional dissension as Local 968 threatened to renew its ten-year fight for recognition.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The British people are beginning to wonder what it is that the Americans do to British statesmen. Is it hospitality, or the blandishments of mass receptions? In any case, they are wondering what happened to Prime Minister Churchill after he got to Washington.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Miss Louise Suggs, steady as a machine, forged three strokes ahead of the field at the halfway mark in the Tampa women's open golf tournament today. For the second day in a row the little Georgian posted a two-under-par 72 for a 144 total.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder today backed President Truman's proposed reorganization of the Internal Revenue Bureau. Mr. Snyder called it a plan to free the tax collection system "of any hint or suggestion of favoritism and influence."
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets and about 120 Russian-built MIG jets exchanged brief firing passes over Northwest Korea yesterday. There were no damage reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, suggested to the House Armed Services Committee today that Universal Military Training be kept on a volunteer basis until the present draft law expired in 1955.
Mayor Impellitteri reiterated yesterday his belief that continuation of the retail sales tax at 3 per cent was essential to a sound fiscal program for balancing the city's 1952-53 budget.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- One or more prominent lawyers will be used in the job of cleaning up corruption in the Federal Government, Attorney General J. Howard McGrath announced tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee voted today to strengthen the voice of the Far West in allocating delegates to the 1952 Republican Presidential nominating convention.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The United States Government has lost its $8,449,973 tax case against the old Cold Metal Process Company of Youngstown and Federal attorneys must now decide whether to appeal the decision. Court attaches say the interest alone on the huge fund the Government now owes Cold Metal already amounts to more than $1,000,000.

There was little cheering in domestic metal circles yesterday when terms of the United States-British metal exchange announced in Washington were disclosed. The general reaction was that Britain had fared relatively the better from the deal.

" Leopard in the Grass," a novel by Desmond Stewart, is the only book published today. It is about a young English archaeologist caught up in Middle East politics. The author, a young English writer, is assistant professor of English at University College, Baghdad.
The sun shone on the seventeen acre United Nations enclave along the East River yesterday, but there was lots less sunshine in the hearts of most of the people across the street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The National Production Authority revealed today that a new open hearth furnace will not open on schedule at Peoria, Ill., because of a lack of iron and steel scrap.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Hollywood's "Quo Vadis" will be banned to all children by the British film industry's movie censor, unless it is cut, The London Daily Mirror said today.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- According to Maud et Nano's opening, the hat for summer 1952 is a small cloche worn straight and just concealing the hairline. The spring classic navy blue is abandoned in favor of paillassons in coral pinks or Capri blue which is a soft turquoise.
Hyman N. Furman has acquired the stock and assets of the Criterion Shirtband Company, Inc., 392 Lafayette Street. Plans are under way to enlarge and modernize the plant.

An industrial site on the south side of Route 29 in Springfield, N. J., has been purchased for immediate improvement by the Hanovia Chemical and Manufacturing Company, a unit of Engelhard Industries. The property, acquired from the Lubern Realty Company and Monterey Estates, fronts about 700 feet on the highway.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 -- Floods from new torrential rains forced thousands of persons from their homes in southern California lowlands today and caused damage running into millions of dollars. A warm sun broke through the clouds just before darkness, but a new storm bearing southward from Alaska threatened more rain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Representative Alfred D. Sieminski Democrat of New Jersey, today urged President Truman to see re-election and quoted the President as replying that he had "never quit under fire or ran away from anything."

Although sales of the Caterpillar Tractor Company last year rose to a new high record, its net profit declined to $15,732,141 from the peak of $29,264,285 reached in 1950, according to the annual report for 1951, issued yesterday by L. B. Neumiller, president.
Two resolutions urging more stringent legislation on narcotics were unanimously adopted yesterday at the ninety-third convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs at the Statler Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Officials were quoted tonight as having said that the French Resident General in Tunis had banned M. Beurguiba and other nationalist and Communist leaders from large urban centers in Tunisia because they caused disorders and incited the populace to armed struggle in the last four days.

Although nothing concrete was accomplished in the National Football League's "star chamber" session at the Statler Hotel last night, the executive meeting, called at the request of Ted Collins, terminated amicably.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and local officers seized more than 3,230 gambling machines valued at nearly $900,000 in a surprise state-wide round-up today.

Mrs. Quintina Rizzo, until recently a partner with her husband, Joseph, in a dress manufacturing business, reported to the police yesterday the loss of a brown paper bag containing $36,000 in $50 and $100 bills.

Although the demand for steel ran considerably in excess of the available supply last year, more finished steel was shipped in the first eleven months of 1951 than in all of 1950 or any previous year, and only two of the twenty major consuming classifications received less metal in the 1951 period than in the first eleven months of the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today a 40 per cent decline in the nation's potato supplies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A full investigation of shortages in the Agriculture Department's grain-storage program was voted today by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

Mr. and Mrs. William Paul Hoffmann gave a supper party last night in the Oak Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Basil Harris after the performance of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Carroll Club and the Carroll Vacation Club, of which Mrs. Harris is president.
The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation announced yesterday that it has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of 630,000 shares of its common stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The House Agriculture Commitee announced today that public hearings will be started Tuesday on the Government's method of forecasting the annual cotton crop. The group said it is particularly interested in the Department of Agriculture's "wide margin of error" in estimating the 1951 crop.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Jan. 18 -- Workers at two divisions of the Fairchild Plane and Engine Company here went on strike early this morning, threatening the output of guided missiles and cooling equipment for high speed jets and bombers.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 18 -- During its first twenty-four-hour operation as a complete unit, the 118-mile New Jersey Turnpike was used by 27,543 vehicles whose drivers paid a total of $23,000 in tolls.

SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 18 -- A move to merge the Central and Lincoln Young Men's Christian Associations, the latter with a Negro membership, was revealed today in a letter to members of the Summit County Interracial Committee, Prentice C. Ford chairman, disclosed the proposal and urged action by the Lincoln group.

One good carload of commuters met late yesterday afternoon in the Commodore Hotel and organized a militant group under the name of Citizens Commuters Committee. It will be devoted to fighting rate increases requested by the New York Central Railroad.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Jan. 18 -- As Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen and his family rested at home behind a police guard today, local officials prepared for a homecoming celebration tomorrow afternoon that will be the biggest in the township's 238-year history.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 18 (UP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People this week-end will make a posthumous award to Harry T. Moore, Negro leader Who was bombed to death. At an "emergency" regional meeting here, the association's Council Against Intolerance will honor Mr. Moore with its annual Jefferson Award for "outstanding contributions to furtherance of the principles of democracy."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee investigating Capital crime was told today that Theron Lamar Caudle, ousted Federal tax prosecutor, had delayed for two years a criminal case against Emmitt Warring, big-time Washington gambler.

The indoor track season is now in full swing, and with 1952 another Olympic year the winter races will measure the athletes who will represent America at Helsinki. In this respect New Yorkers are fortunate. Five of the biggest meets will be held here, starting with the Millrose Games in late January and ending with the Knights of Columbus Games in early March.

Expenditures for kitchenware this year by new families establishing their first homes will run from $100,000,000 to $150,000,000, John G. Brooks, vice president in charge of housewares sales for Ekco Products Company, predicted in Chicago yesterday.

The Netherlands Government will place three reconverted Victory ships in low-cost trans-Atlantic passenger service, it was announced yesterday by the Holland-America Line, general agents for the Netherlands Directorate-General of Shipping.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Dr. Victor Belaunde of Peru warned the Soviet Union today that the General Assembly would eventually elect qualified applicants to membership in the United Nations if the Security Council acts "unjustifiably" -- in other words, if the Soviet Union continued to exercise its veto.

The insigne of a fish, the symbol by which early Christians secretly identified themselves in greeting one another so as not to reveal their identities to persecutors, has been adopted in the form of small blue metal coat lapel pins by the National Council of Presbyterian Men.
SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Harvey L. Carey resigned today as a United States Attorney here, even though a jury had cleared him of charges of soliciting a $60,000 bribe.

Dressed in similar tan gabardine coats and tan fedoras and wearing false rubber noses attached to lenseless spectacles, three armed young thugs invaded the second-floor offices of the Petrone Travel Agency, 654 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, early yesterday afternoon, held up seven persons and escaped with $6,300 in cash.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Army said today it would like to retain unit designations and the organization framework of National Guard divisions even after individual Guardsmen were released from the Federal service.

The mystery of the disappearance of traffic summons record book No. 34 from the West Sixty-eighth Street police station last Dec. 4 was no nearer solution last night after a captain, two lieutenants, two sergeants and three policemen had completed testimony at their departmental trial.
The war mobilization program has left its impact upon the nation's public schools.

Carly Wharton's musical presentation, "A Month of Sundays," will close for repairs at the conclusion of its pre-Broadway engagement in Philadelphia next Saturday evening. After the necessary book revisions are made, Miss Wharton hopes to start production activities on it in the spring.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Soviet authorities clamped new restrictions on traffic between Berlin and the West today, apparently as a reminder of their power to cut the isolated city's surface lifelines at will.

Six guards and three civilian employes of the city penitentiary on Rikers Island were indicted by the Bronx Grand Jury yesterday for the alleged sale and smuggling of narcotics to prisoners. The jury, which has been investigating alleged traffic in narcotics in the penitentiary, is scheduled to continue its inquiry on Tuesday.
Commodity prices drifted generally lower again yesterday, with cocoa futures the sole important exception in the New York market. Sugar held about even.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The traditional offshore trawling grounds of the English Channel Were so over-fished during the war that marine biologists are now trying to help fishermen to find new grounds, not far from their home ports, by undertaking yard-by-yard surveys of the sea floor in the most likely places.
Shrimp was the subject for discussion as well as the piece de resistance at a recent luncheon given for food editors by the newly formed Shrimp Association of the Americas.

BOYNE CITY, Mich., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Kent Freeland, who spent nearly 50 cents for postage while corresponding with the Government concerning a nickel, closed the books today on his 1950 income tax return.
STAFFORD, England, Jan. 18 -- It was snowing hard in Stafford and on the Lichfield Road the heavy truck plying between the mills and mines of the West Midlands splattered through thick slush.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The traditional offshore trawling grounds of the English Channel Were so over-fished during the war that marine biologists are now trying to help fishermen to find new grounds, not far from their home ports, by undertaking yard-by-yard surveys of the sea floor in the most likely places.
Shrimp was the subject for discussion as well as the piece de resistance at a recent luncheon given for food editors by the newly formed Shrimp Association of the Americas.
Commodity prices drifted generally lower again yesterday, with cocoa futures the sole important exception in the New York market. Sugar held about even.

A complaint frequently heard from Americans who havebeen surveying European progress in rearmament is that those countries are not working nearly hard enough, that they show little enthusiasm for Eisenhower's program.

A report praising shipments by Roman Catholics of clothing to Arab refugees in the Near East has been received by Msgr. Edward E. Swanstrom, executive director of War Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference, he said yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 18 -- As part of the build-up for large - scale maneuvers next autumn, Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe will station war-seasoned missions in West European countries to help get their forces battle-ready.

A resolution opposing the proposed appointment of an envoy from the United States to the Vatican was adopted at a rally of Brooklyn Baptists last night at Hanson Place Baptist Church, at South Portland Avenue.
MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Jacodema, making her first start of the winter, raced to a notable victory in the Hibiscus Purse at Hialeah Park today.

Over the vigorous protests of defense counsel who sought a longer adjournment, Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan yesterday set Feb. 25 for the re-trial of Frank Costello for contempt of the United States Senate.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- French financial experts fear an acute dollar crisis in the next few months.

MONTREAL, Que., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A Belgian count whisked his 14-month-old son off to Europe on a plane today, foiling the efforts of his estranged wife -- an American heiress to Manville asbestos millions -- to gain legal custody of the child.

Young persons of today have had to "grow up in such a hurry" and have so many pressures upon them that there is danger they may miss the humorous aspect of life unless adults help them to see it, Miss Margaret Scoggin, acting superintendent of school work for the New York Public Library, said yesterday.

The first American performance of the oratorio "Golgotha" by the well-known Swiss composer, Frank Martin, was given by Paul Boepple and the Dessoff Choirs last night in Carnegie Hall under the honorary sponsorship of Dr. Fred Cygax and with the cooperation of Mme. Marguerite Staehelin, director of the Swiss Music Library, the non-profit institution created by the Swiss Composers' League, whose purpose it is to make known contemporary Swiss music in this country.

An elderly Brooklyn landlord, who sampled the facilities offered at the Brooklyn City Prison and apparently found them to his liking, was sent yesterday to Kings County Hospital for observation by Magistrate Charles Ramsgate, sitting in the Brooklyn Municipal Term Court.

OMAHA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Union Pacific Railroad has announced plans to construct a new forty-two-mile line between Cheyenne and Dale Creek in southeastern Wyoming at a cost of $16,000,000. The railroad described the project as the biggest line change since the driving of the golden spike eighty-two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission took jurisdiction today over the proposed sale of the Washington Water Power Company's common stock, asserting:
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 18 -- A new edition of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" is on sale here. The newspaper Magyar Nemzet told its readers that "in Truman's America they try to hide this book."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, insisted today that Senate committee hearings on mine safety legislation proceed as scheduled for next Thursday and declared the soft coal operators were seeking a delay.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Under the leadership of corn, grain futures on the Board of Trade here showed a stronger undertone today. Active covering by shorts was a factor in corn, and there seemed to be a much broader demand, on the theory that the pressure of high moisture corn from the country had been discounted.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Playing brilliant golf despite wind and rain, Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., kept the lead at the half-way mark today in the $10,000 San Diego open tournament.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 18 -- The "Alert America" exhibit, a graphic illustration of the destruction caused by war and of the best civil defense techniques, was opened at the Hempstead Armory here this evening at a ceremony attended by state and local defense officials.

Department store sales here this week began to revert to "nor- mal" levels as consumers followed an easier pattern in their buying. Trade observers, comparing current volume with the "scare" levels of the 1951 week, put the decline yesterday at 16 per cent.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 18 (UP) -- Playing brilliant golf despite wind and rain, Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., kept the lead at the half-way mark today in the $10,000 San Diego open tournament.
HERE is the story of Jonathan "Pony" Rivers and Little Vic, the racehorse he watched over and loved from the first time he saw it as a wobbly legged colt to its triumph in the Santa Anita Handicap.

A graduate-studies program which is of great significance in the area of American history and culture is to begin at the opening of the second semester on Feb. 5 at the University of Delaware. The project will be conducted in cooperation with the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, said tonight that in about three years America's air armada should be built up to "a striking power no nation has ever had."
BECAUSE of Laszlo Halasz's record for novelty, the new powers-that-be of the New York City Opera Company know they will be carefully watched. They are taking no chances of not leading from strength.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Despite a communique and formal speeches by Foreign Secretary Eden and Primes Minister Churchill on matters of high state policy, the British people are still somewhat puzzled concerning what decisions have been made by Mr. Churchill and President Truman in Washington.

" THE purpose of this book," A. L. Rowse writes, "is to bring together a number of evocations of persons and places," and "to see the people through the places where they live or which their lives touched, and the places through them and their eyes."
I am a little disturbed by the contents and by items omitted in Senator Brien McMahon's "Russia's A-Bomb: A Speculative Survey" (Dec. 30).

PEOPLE without land and land without people -- that is the twentieth century's cruel paradox and at the same time its great challenge. Some 60,000,000 people are refugees in hostile lands or surplus to their nation's economies. On the other hand, vast areas of the world urgently need immigrants.

IT often sadly turns out that the very man who fought most ardently in his youth for the new, experimental ideas of his time clings so tenaciously to these pioneering efforts that he is unable to welcome succeeding ideas and becomes in his later years the most die-hard of reactionaries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Safeway Stores, Inc., has lost the suit in which it attacked the validity of pork and lamb ceiling prices.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Count Ivan du Monceau de Bergendael arrived here today with his 14-month-old son, Tommy Manville du Monceau, after a flight from New York, where he had eluded his estranged American wife, who is an heir to the Manville asbestos fortune.

SANDSPIT AIRPORT, B. C., Jan. 19 -- A crippled DC-4 transport plane, homeward bound from the Far East with forty servicemen and three crew members aboard, undershot this Canadian airport early today and crashed into the sea.

THE Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra has used an electronic tuning device for the past three years. Our first oboist, Robert Sprenkle, had got tired of the general feud between string and wind players over the correct basic pitch and he felt that only a neutral agency for establishing the pitch would do.

HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that the Korean war was a "blessing" because it had awakened the free world and inspired it to organize strongly enough to "knock down" the Communists and, if necessary, to wipe them out.

FOR the past five years home owners have been buying garden tractors at the rate of over a hundred thousand a year. But with a hundred or more different models on the market, choosing the one that's best suited to a particular job is no easy task.

GRANTS, N. M., Jan. 19 -- The Santa Fe Railroad said today an Indian's discovery of uranium on its land, which caused a price boom this week on the New York Stock Exchange, also made him the railroad's highest paid employe.

MICHELANGELO'S exploration of the human figure as a vehicle to express the whole cosmos of emotion can be seen with intimate insight in his drawings. His restless, protean talent bursts through in chalk, lead-point, pen-and-ink -- in tireless studies relating to his painting and sculpture and in more complete drawings (such as those presented to the beloved Tommasso de' Caviliere), provocative with allegorical meanings which are clues to his ardent and ever-troubled soul.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L., opened a campaign today against the Communications Workers of America, C. I. O., and announced a nation-wide drive to take over representation of Bell Telephone System employes.

BONN, Jan. 19 (AP) -Herr Blank, 45, who fought against the Allies from start to finish of World War II, heads what is officially called "The Service Office of the Federal Chancellor." It is expected to become Germany's defense ministry.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., Jan. 19 -- The Old Whalers' Presbyterian Church here is now out of the red after a year's drive for $28,000 to make the church safe for services, but it still needs $60,000 to restore its steeple, once a mariners' beacon.

THE panorama of contemporary American art has been enlivened by two huge group shows, one in New York and another in Philadelphia. The latter opened last evening with a preview reception at which prizes were announced in the galleries of the Pennsylvania Academy, whose 147th exhibition includes 342 paintings and ninety-seven pieces of sculpture.

THOUGH the title of Osbert Lancaster's newest work is "The Alarms and Excursions of Lady Littlehampton," the innocent, brittle and indomitable Lady is not the hero of the book. Neither is she the heroine. Both hero and heroine are the superbly deft, lucidly imagined landscapes the author has drawn and tucked into the middle of the book -- landscapes, perhaps falling a bit short of Turner and Cezanne, but having distinct virtues of their own.

THIS is a lucid and sober account of political and constitutional development in Iraq since it was admitted to the League of Nations in 1932 as a nominally independent state with special treaty obligations to Great Britain, the former mandatory power.
GENEVA, Jan. 19 -- There is a real fear in Europe that the United States, because of its tremendous industrial power, will grab too much of the world's raw materials.

Physicians, personnel specialists and industrial hygienists attending the twelfth Annual Congress of Industrial Health here the last two days have discussed problems about which the average citizen gives little or no thought -- the provision of on-the-job health services for American workers.
Soccer coaches and college officials yesterday brought to a conclusion their three-day series of meetings at the Hotel Paramount.

PHOTOGRAPHS of the designs of the next two United States commemorative stamps were made available last week by Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson. They are 3-cent items for the 125th anniversary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's charter and the semi-centennial of the American Automobile Association.

A major problem that confronts the engineers who are trying to design a power plant that will be driven by what is loosely called atomic energy is the effect of radiation on metals used in the reactor and other parts. The reactor is the "furnace" where heat is generated.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Four-power talks on an Austrian independence treaty, slated to resume here Monday after a lapse of several months, may be delayed by Soviet insistence on discussing Trieste and Austrian demilitarization.

MIAMI, BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A new two-year contract for Hollywood musicians, including a 15 per cent wage increase, was adopted last night at a meeting of James Petrillo with several top movie industry executives.

While the volume of business loans made by banks in 1951 was larger than in 1950 and was transacted at higher average interest rates, profits of the banks did not increase proportionately because of the drain of heavier taxes and operating expenses, this is disclosed by the condition statements for Dec. 31, just published.

TWELVE years of research have gone into the creation of the new airpower carburator which has been installed in Buick's 1952 Roadmaster models. The carburetor was designed to distribute fuel more evenly and accurately to the engine so as to produce more power and greater economy in gasoline consumption, according to Ivan L. Wiles, general manager of the Buick division and vice president of General Motors Corporation.

HOPES for the establishment of a permanent all-professional Gilbert and Sullivan company in this country are taking on a rosy hue, indeed. Within the last fortnight S. M. Chartock signed Martyn Green, erstwhile star comic of the D'Oyly Carte Company.
The 1952 national championships were split between Worcester, Mass., and Philadelphia at the meeting of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

A SUPERIOR work in the current class of precious fiction, "Fire in the Sun" reveals the essential meagerness of novels written about exquisite little half-people. Veronica Demeade, the heroine, is one of select group of English poets and artists.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 19 (AP) -- United States men Olympic skiers could do no better than seventeenth place today in an international slalom race in which Austrians captured the first three places.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The old issue of national health insurance, a "must" element of the Truman Fair Deal, has been revived explosively just as Presidential campaign politics are coming to a boil.

Two of Italy's leading tennis players arrived yesterday from Milan on their way to California for coaching and play in a series of winter tournaments there. They were Fausto Gardini, 21 years old, a student at the University of Milan, who holds the 1951 Italian national singles championship, and Giuseppe Merlo, 24, of Bologna, runner-up to Gardini.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Already anxious regarding the import of British pledges of prompt, resolute and effective measures if a Korean armistice were broken or if Communist China attacked elsewhere in Southeast Asia, an important part of British opinion is beginning to worry over what will happen if the cease-fire talks fail completely to produce an armistice.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 19 -- One of the largest shipyards in the country, with one of the most important construction programs, may not be able to meet its ship delivery dates later in the year unless steel allocation scheduling is improved.

When Millard G. Gamble as a youngster delivered well water each day to the neighbors in his home town of Louisville, Ga., it probably never entered his mind that one day he would be directing the transportation of oil products to the far corners of the earth by the largest privately owned shipping fleet under the American flag.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath will appoint a prominent lawyer who will have the power of subpoena and all other Justice Department resources available to him to clean up Government corruption.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19 -- Although it was described as being too early to serve as a definite indication, orders received by the big soft goods manufacturing and distributing companies here in the ten days ended Jan. 18 showed a pick-up of more than seasonal proportions.

Retailers were warned last week that they soon will be faced with the issue of sales tax at the manufacturer or retailer level. In a special report issued last week by the American Retail Federation's headquarters in Washington, Rowland Jones Jr., president of the group, urged merchants and their organizations to unite in presenting a common stand on the question to Congress.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly declared formally today that South-West Africa -- German territory before the first world war -- should be placed under the trusteeship system of the world organization.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Flood victims of Southern California's biggest storm since 1938 straggled back to their homes today and began scraping off the mud.

THE last of Harold J. Laski's comments on the British Constitution have appeared as a posthumous publication. They were presented in a series of lectures given at the University of Manchester early in 1950, less than two months before his death.

MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Holy Cross Crusaders started slowly tonight but spurted to trounce Tufts College, 79 -- 47, on the losers' court. It was the eighth straight victory for Holy Cross, which now has an 11-1 record.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., and most of the other favorites, including Frank Sedgman, advanced today in the Australian national tennis championships.

If New York has not enjoyed June in January, it has had, at least, early April. Instead of the "normal" six inches of snow during December and seven inches in January, it has had no "measurable" snow at all this winter.
The season's fourth orchestral concert for young people at Hunter College, with Thomas Scherman conducting the Little Orchestra Society, was presented yesterday morning.

MANY of us have dreams of an island paradise where nature smiles and men live close to the soil in peace and harmony, with the futilities safely set aside. Guy Morrison, a Brisbane reporter, and his wife, Kay, lived with their dream until Paul, an artist, came along to tell them about Moan-ahra, a mile-square island within the Great Barrier Reef of Australia.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- There used to be a time when this historic Tidewater town settled down in winter to the leisurely pace of other Southern resorts during the off-season. But the opening of the completed New Jersey Turnpike has started a new cycle and Florida-bound motorists are re-discovering Williamsburg as an ideal stop-over point on the route south.

Members of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution have arranged their annual card party for the afternoon of Feb. 5 at Sherry's for the benefit of the Tamassee Scholarship Fund and other philanthropies of the organization.

THERE has always' been cause for suspicion that the B. in the name of Cecil B. DeMille stands for either Barnum or Bailey -- or possibly for both -- although the books still insist it initials the prosaic name of Blount. But henceforth there will be no doubt about it.

WHEN the Kefauver committee hearings were making their remarkable televised penetration of American thinking and emotion, no small part of the impact came from the little sermons preached every so often by Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire. Senator Tobey was the old-fashioned conscience of the American people, speaking like a Greek chorus.

THE author of this lively as well as substantial volume is a professor at Ohio State University who has written before now about goings-on at the court of the not-so-merry monarch, Charles II. At first blush -- and blushes are of course appropriate -- it might seem unlikely that another book about Nell Gwyn was really called for.
English director and critic and author of a book of dramatic criticism, "He That Plays the King."

ASIDE from the continued comparative decline in retail sales figures, the business and industrial picture showed little basic change last week. Plant expansion in defense and allied lines continues at a rapid pace, inventories in consumer goods fields are being slowly reduced, and prices for the most part are holding at levels which existed at the close of 1951.

In "The Diamond Retains Its Ageless Gleam" (Dec. 30), E. W. Kenworthy used the phrase, "whether it be a three-karat gem of purest crystal from Tiffany's or a little yellow melee from a mail order house." I would like to believe that this was not an aspersion cast on a number of reputable mail order houses throughout the country.

Competition among banking institutions for thrift funds and the need for leadership among bankers in the fight against inflation will receive the attention of New York commercial bank executives at their annual mid-winter meeting tomorrow. The one-day session, to be held at the Commodore Hotel, is sponsored by the New York State Bankers Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The two major labor federations have rejected a legislative approach to the problem of Communist-dominated unions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Three alternative methods of deferring college students from compulsory military service were proposed today by the Educational Policies Commission of the National Education Association and the American Council on Education.

THE conduct of the younger generation, as it has from time immemorial, provides fuel today for countless arguments -- in and out of the newspapers. Critics of the youngsters say too many of them are weak and undisciplined, a result of current "soft treatment." Their champions hold the young are now, more than ever before, wiser, soberer, more aware of the world around them and their responsibility to it.

MONTREAL, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk scored his second straight shutout tonight, turning aside forty-six shots to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 4 -- to -- 0 National Hockey League triumph over the Montreal Canadiens before a near-capacity crowd of 14,443 at the Forum.

The new year has brought with it a number of new atlases which raise a question as to the principle map-makers should follow in drawing political boundaries. Most of the new atlases appear to accept unilateral Soviet annexations as faits accomplis and mark their lines accordingly.

MARY ANDERSON, who was to climb high in American labor politics, was one of the thousands of nineteenth-century immigrants to the New World. She was born a Swedish farmer's daughter, and because high taxes lost her father his lease on a royal farm she found herself at 16 on the way to Michigan.

The operating rate of iron foundries in the greater New York area is now about 10 per cent above rates prevailing in November and December, it was reported here yesterday by members of the Gray Iron Founders Society, national trade organization.

Although more than 1,000,000 European refugees have been resettled since World War II, there still exists a large-scale refugee problem that requires immediate attention, Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, asserted in an address read last night at the opening session of the two-day meeting of the United Service for New Americans at the Roosevelt Hotel.

FOR the first time in the history of commercial air transportation, passengers aboard an international flight (American Airlines flight 758 from Toronto, Canada), landed at New York last week and completely "ignored" United States Customs inspectors.

A NEW picture of Liszt as a creative musician is emerging, thanks to the efforts of such activities as those of the recently founded Liszt Society. The society, which made an important contribution in furthering wider acquaintance with the composer's late piano works in its initial publication, will follow this up with a second book of his keyboard pieces to be issued shortly.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Undefeated St. Bonaventure, ranked sixth nationally in The Associated Press poll, registered its tenth victory tonight by trimming Cincinnati, 77 -- 58, in Memorial Auditorium. Niagara beat John Carroll, 77 -- 62, in the first game of the double-header.
Frank McGuire's St. John's University basketball team easily defeated its Brooklyn rival, St. Francis College, 54 to 36, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday.

A a result of recent incidents in San Diego the Professional Golfers Association is trying to work out a program that will at least begin to attack discrimination against Negroes in P. G. A.-sponsored tournaments. Joe Louis is co-chairman of a committee taking up details with the P. G. A. president, and as a result of the progress that has been made Bill Spiller has decided to drop his threatened suit against the association.

Professional football in New York, a two-team proposition for years, will belong exclusively to the Giants hereafter -- and "forever." For at 10:50 last night at the Statler Hotel, Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League revealed that Ted Collins had sold his gridiron assets and franchise to the league for $100,000 and that the league in turn would turn over the franchise to Dallas, Tex.

In a move designed to provide 40,000 tons of scrap steel, the Maritime Administration asked yesterday for bids for the scrapping of six vessels now in the Government's Reserve Fleet. Bids will be opened in Washington on Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The debate over extending the G. I. Bill of Rights to Korean war veterans will fined the American Legion urging "the same break the veterans of World War II got."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 19 -- The Federal Government disclosed plans tonight for selective service affecting young men aged 19 to 21. Western Germany, it was stressed, was being called upon to contribute 300,000 to 400,000 men in a European army.

Steel, oil, rail and gold shares showed strength yesterday as the stock market extended gains selectively and closed irregularly higher in moderately active trading. Sales totaled 730,000 shares, compared with 740,000 on the preceding Saturday. Of the 884 issues traded, 407 advanced, 225 declined and 252 closed unchanged. Twenty-seven reached new highs for 1951-52.

Quick thinking and swift action by a 30-year-old taxicab driver was credited yesterday with saving the lives of four members of his family and three neighbors living next door to him in veterans' housing in the East Bronx.

WHEN the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra visited the United States and Canada just a year ago both the reviewers and the public deplored the scarcity of original music from Israel in the programs, and the question was asked whether perhaps there was not enough symphonic music in the young community to warrant inclusion in the orchestral concerts.

THIS is a top-heavy week, with nearly everything crowded into today's program. Of especial interest is the appearance of Angna Enters this afternoon at the Lexington Avenue "Y," where she is bringing back many of the old favorites of her repertoire.
" A NEW era in television dawned today." -- N. B. C. statement.

OUT of a movement which began as an effort to sustain national spirit and morale in the last war by bringing music to young people of invaded Belgium there has developed an organization of impressive proportions known as Jeunesse Musicale.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When we are faced for the first time in the history of our country with such wholesale corruption in public office as has never been known before it seems to me that it behooves us to consider how we may prevent, at least in the future, such violations of public trust.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The Defense Department wrestled today with the question whether a gift or gratuity included acceptance of a free lunch or a box of cigars as well as a free automobile.

As Prime Minister Churchill winds up his mission to the United States it is interesting to recall his remarks to his fellow-citizens shortly before he left London. He said on Dec. 22: "I do not want any exaggerated hope or importance to be attached to my visit to Washington.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The British of late have become uneasy about some recent examples of shirking on the part of some of their workers.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 20 -- The Communists agreed yesterday to establishment of a military staff committee to work out safeguards for prisoner of war encampments to secure them against attack during continued fighting in Korea.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- Merchants are reconciled to poor comparative sales figures with a year ago for the first two months of 1952 because of the wild buying at this time last year. They hope by March to have closed the gap with a year ago and then begin to show gains.

THE lengths to which television will go to achieve an end or a "first" have perhaps never been so perfectly exemplified as in the arrangements set up for what the C. B. S. television network claims is the first telecast from a submarine running submerged at sea. There has been a previous pick-up from a submarine, C. B. S. concedes, but in that case the craft was surfaced and tied up to a dock.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Bentley Kassal's letter to you, published on Dec. 29, illustrates several misapprehensions about the situation in Germany which I have found to be too prevalent in the United States.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The F. B. I.'s biggest state round-up of slot machines was extended swiftly into new Kentucky areas today. By nightfall, 4,079 of the gambling devices valued at $1,129,500 had been seized.

SOME radicals become such through hate and some through love. Communism, Moscow style, is first-rate for the haters. Dorothy Day, who follows her "From Union Square to Rome" with this autobiographical record, hated nobody, though she could hate the evil things people did.

N attempt to aid the amatelr who wants to be his own iterior decorator was presented here this week. Involved in the cpoperative project are a single uurnitqre manufacturer-- Drexel-- ind an even dozen fabricators of various types of accessories for the home.

COCOA, Fla. -- This east coast town in the heart of the Indian River country, about midway between Jacksonville and Miami, annually attracts thousands of winter visitors who seek only the quieter pursuits of bathing, fishing and boating.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- New Jersey legislators will receive on Monday Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's annual budget message, in which he is expected to propose a balanced budget without new taxes.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 19 -- Richard Remsen of the University Club and Germain Glidden of the Harvard Club, the top-seeded team, gained the semi-final round in the annual invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today.

New York City's custom of confetti-and-ticker-tape parades up Broadway -- the traditional greeting to distinguished visitors -- dates back to 1910, when ex-President Theodore Roosevelt was showered from downtown windows and sidewalks in a tour of the city.

THIS department was recently lamenting the lack of distinction in the numerous first mystery novels of 1951; but the first "first" of 1952 starts the year off with a resounding bang, and offers gratifying evidence that vivid fresh talents are still being attracted to the field.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Americans saved $14,900,000,000 in the July-September quarter of 1951, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Systematic thefts of television components by servicing company employes, who used the stolen parts to set up in business for themselves, have forced the Conlan Electric Company to file a petition in Brooklyn Federal Court for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act, it was disclosed yesterday.

The aircraft industry is not only getting around the shortages of Kirksite metal for dies and tools, but is actually saving money and getting more efficient results through the substitution of phenolic plastics. Kirksite, made of lead and zinc, is proving almost unobtainable, due to the shortages in the latter material.

Like every other aspect of American life, education has been affected by the nation's program of mobilization for defense. Educators and informed citizens generally have been aware that the schools were beginning to suffer. Just how much they have not known.

E. J. Tracy, superintendent engineer of the Ward Line, was elected president of the Society of Marine Port Engineers yesterday. He succeeds C. N. Guckert, of the Seas Shipping Company, who headed the society for two years.
SNEEDVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 19 -- Tennessee's famous child bride, who married a 6 - foot farmer when she was only 9 years old, marked her fifteenth wedding anniversary today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Maurice Braverman, Baltimore attorney now under Smith Act indictment, was arrested today after a police patrol car chase when his companion was allegedly observed pasting pro-Communist posters on a building wall.

CHICAGO, Jan 19 -- Local 347, United Packinghouse Workers of America, C. I. O., charged today that the State Department had lowered an "iron curtain" on American trade unionists by "prohibiting trade unionists to travel abroad."
