Since the publication of my article on Pearl Harbor, "Ten Years Ago This Friday --" (Dec. 2, 1951), I have received a number of letters from readers demanding, with varying degrees of vehemence, to know why I did not point out that General Marshall "muffed" the last-minute warning to General Short in Hawaii of the impending disaster.
HEAVILY laden streamliners continue to converge on Florida from the North and the Midwest and the movement also is brisk to the more distant sun-lands of Arizona and California.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 19 -- Exterior and interior work on the $250,000 nursery for foundlings operated by St. Vincent's Hospital here was completed this week. Contractors were finishing the landscaping in preparation for the dedication next month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Two members of a House investigating subcommittee demanded today that Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, be subpoened to tell what, if anything, he knows about international profiteering on United States war surplus material.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said today he hoped to send to Congress soon his plan for free hospitalization for 7,000,000 persons.
I read with a great deal of interest Dorothy Barclay's article "Training for Happy Family Living" (Jan. 6).

OF sensitive young men, the dislocated poets with grenades, there can be no end. The American army off novelists has already produced its share. "Dead Men Rising" proves that Australians also knew the frustrations of command, unheeded counsel from the Other Ranks, short leaves and improbable death.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Jan. 19 -- A one-man police force, waging war alike against narcotics peddlers, automobile thieves, and other criminals, and with a sharp eye for stray children -- that's Patrolman Dominick P. Meatto of Hoboken, a member of the Hudson County Police Department since 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Although the employment situation as a whole is good -- 61,000,000 men and women are working and only 1,500,000 are looking for jobs -- there are some black spots in the picture. A number of industrial cities, caught in the lag between the transition from all-out civilian production to limited defense production, have labor surpluses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A threat of possible criminal action by Federal prosecutors today hung over some of the Southwest grain and elevator men named in Senate testimony as being involved in shortages of Government grain. The shortages are now estimated at nearly $4,000,000.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 19 -- Arkansas, the wonder state, is wondering whether a barefoot mountaineer, a jug of liquor and a razorback hog are complimentary symbols of the state.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A nation-wide strike of some 35,000 aluminum workers early next month was threatened today as no progress was reported in contract talks among two unions and two big companies. Federal mediation teams were ordered to try to break the deadlock.

A PROFESSOR of English at the University College at Baghdad has added his name to the vanishing band of fiction writers whose imagination has become committed to life on the Asian mainland. "Leopard in the Grass" is Desmond Stewart's first novel.
The second of the New York Assemblies for this season will be held Friday night in the ballroom of the Plaza, under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller.

BY the time a bridge player has played the game for a few years and in a few hundred games, he becomes aware of the fact that bridge hands fall into patterns. A certain holding translates automatically into a particular bid -- you have seen the same hand so often before that no thought is necessary.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- A rocket ship to the moon would cost about $200,000,000 to build, according to a Philadelphia astronomer.

Steady buying on a small quantity basis is expected to feature the local winter furniture market opening tomorrow in the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue and adjacent showrooms. Both manufacturers and retailers feel that success of the just-concluded Chicago market will be repeated here.
In the Far East last week, two ominous situations confronted the West.

MOASCAR, Egypt, Jan. 19 -- The murder of a Catholic nun, believed to be a United States citizen, was reported by the British today amid continued violent attacks in which a British soldier was killed and five others wounded, one so seriously that he may die.

Al Parsells, eight-goal star, was able to notch only one marker as Jack Ivory led his Detroit Ivory Rangers to a 9-6 victory over the Ramapo Polo Club in the feature match of the indoor double-header at Squadron A Armory last night.

Every broadcasting studio has at least one so-called "electronic organ," an instrument that has a keyboard with which the performer controls the oscillations of tone-producing electron tubes. Because of the effects that can be produced, the instrument deserves to stand on its own feet as a new creation.

Tenants of Amsterdam Houses, the city-owned project on Amsterdam Avenue between Sixty-first and Sixty-fourth Streets, took up posts of vigil last night to protect their children from assault by strangers.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 19 -- The French-Vietnamese forces were engaged today in two major offensive sweeps against the pro-Soviet Vietminh troops in Tongking. One is thirty-five air miles west of Hanoi, in the Hoabinh region, the other fifty air miles southward, in the southern reaches of the Red River delta.

AS a man who spied for his country, Great Britain, for three years during World War I while attached, with grisly convenience, to the German Intelligence Service, Bernard Newman may be said not only to have seen it all but to have done most of it.

Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, warned yesterday that corruption in public office was a "far more dangerous enemy" to America today than was communism yesterday. Mr. Rickenbacker spoke to 200 members of the International Benjamin Franklin Society, and proposed a spiritual rearmament to strengthen American leadership.

DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 19 -- A 350-acre industrial district, to be served exclusively by the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad, is being developed in the Farmers Branch Area, adjoining the northern city limits of this city. The land is owned by A. Webb Roberts, Dallas business man.
" All American business is now public business -- and it had best describe itself clearly and honestly."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Washington, Paris and Tokyo agreed this week that the truce talks in Korea had reached a new stalemate, and there was increasing discussion of what was to be done about it.

COMMERCIAL airline crashes in the last three or four years usually have been so violent and the wreckage so complete as to leave no survivors to explain what happened. Even though skilled and experienced investigators eventually came to decisions about the probable causes of the accidents by studying the wreckage, the report of a single surviving crew member would have contributed materially to airline safety.

News of trains and towns buried in Sierra snows and of floods sweeping southern California with tragic loss of life may make some persons wonder what has become of the Golden State's celebrated climate. Nothing has become of it. It is going to extremes this year, but it is not doing anything that it has not done before.
TAYLORSVILLE, Ind., Jan. 19 (UP) -- A sycamore tree blamed for thirteen traffic deaths was fenced off today to keep it from killing more.

Dr. Alan Waterman, director of the National Science Foundation, submitted his first annual report to the President last week, and the President in turn passed it on to congress. Since the foundation was not established until May 10, 1950, there was nothing to present in the way of scientific accomplishments.

HOW to present his material most artistically and effectively is a major problem which faces an author. Lonnie Coleman, in his fourth novel, has chosen to tell, in the words of a south Alabama girl with a commonplace, selfish nature, the thirty-year story of relations among three families, two white and one Negro.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A Senate subcommittee's long and so far largely secret investigation of Democratic charges looking toward an attempt to expel Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, reached a major turning point this week.

The so-called purchasing power bond -- that is, one whose value at maturity would be adjusted to compensate for a decline in the buying power of money -- may still be only a subject for ivory-tower economic debate in the United States, but in Sweden it is a reality.

The use of betatron equipment in factories for commercial inspection of heavy metal sections is the newest technique for checking quality, it was reported here yesterday by Charles W. Briggs, research director of the Steel Founders Society of Cleveland, national trade organization.

YES, said the experts, without a doubt cooking in America is changing. Ben Irvin Butler, president of the Society of Amateur Chefs (men only), even went so far as to observe that this period in food history is one of the most important "since the Medici girls first became wives of French kings and took their personal chefs to France, thus influencing the latter's cookery and establishing its pre-eminence."
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 19 -- A disabled Air Force bomber crash-landed today atop a crowded guardhouse at Mather Air Force Base and exploded, burning to death six men and injuring sixty-one.

FIFTY-TWO years ago Gelett Burgess introduced us to the Goops. That term for excessively bad-mannered children has since become a part of our language (with the blessing of Webster's New International Dictionary) although it isn't heard quite so frequently as a generation ago.

PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Gene Melchiorre, former All-America basketball star at Bradley University, pleaded guilty yesterday and asked for probation for failing to report a bribe for helping rig the score in a game with Oregon State College.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Negro leaders declared tonight they would not be intimidated in their fight for equal rights in the South by recent terrorism and the slaying of their Florida champion.
Representatives of sixty-one labor, civic and political groups organized yesterday to avert what they foresaw as an imminent fare increase on the city's transit lines.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 19 -- Tunisians clashed with French security forces here and in the inland city of Mateur today as Nationalist demonstrations supporting a Tunisian appeal to the United Nations for home rule and protesting the arrest of popular leaders continued for the sixth day.

SOMETHING of a mystery surrounds the presentation of "Come of Age" Wednesday at the City Center. Why should this "play in music and words" about a young poet and a worldly woman, which did not go particularly well in 1934, be revived?

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today adopted a United States-Chilean resolution urging a cooperative international attack on the problem of famine. The vote was 42 to 0 with the five members of the Soviet bloc abstaining.

ANDRE GIDE spoke for millions of others when he said, "The fear of ridicule causes our worst cowardice. How many youthful impulses that were full of courage have been suddenly deflated by the word 'Utopia' applied to their conviction.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Edward M. O'Connor, United States displaced persons' commissioner, reported today that the November-December conference of twenty-three nations in Brussels had agreed upon the principle of "first asylum" wherein countries bordering on the Iron Curtain bloc would be encouraged to assist refugees in their initial period of freedom.

Bismarck once said that the supreme fact of the Nineteenth Century was that Britain and the United States spoke the same language. Let us make sure that the supreme fact of the Twentieth Century is that they tread the same path.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- A portrait of Gen. Robert E. Lee, wearing the grey uniform of the Confederacy, was unveiled in the post library at the United States Military Academy this afternoon.

CAIRO, Jan. 19 -- The Egyptian Government formally accused the British military authorities in the Suez Canal Zone today of subjecting recently captured Egyptian "patriots" to atrocities, including torture and cold-blooded murder.

Captain Henrik Kurt Carlsen is expected to describe, at a luncheon here on Wednesday, the method he used to secure a tow line to the Flying Enterprise. Sponsors of the luncheon, to be held in the Commodore Hotel, will be the Propeller Club of the United States, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York and the New York Board of Trade.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 -- A last-minute rush of appeals from the city's new assessment list was expected today to swamp the Board of Tax Review at the last of its nightly hearings in the early part of next week. The final hearing is scheduled for Wednesday.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market here last week placing orders in normal quantities for all ready-to-wear spring merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

Gertrude Samuels' "Court of First Resort for the Family" (Jan. 6) concerning the Home Term Court was well done. It gives a good picture on the functions of the court and points out what it tries to accomplish and what it hopes to accomplish in the future.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Air Force reported yesterday that ten Allied planes, two of them Sabre jets, were shot down during the last week in fights with Russian-built MIG-15's. Communist ground fire accounted for the eight other Allied losses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today the United Nations "apparently would have no choice but to fight an all-out war" with Communist China if the Korean truce talks failed.

TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- Once more jet fighting in Korea has subsided and United Nations pilots and Air Force strategists wonder if this lull will be followed by the stepped-up air conflict that has concluded earlier breathers. How much more the MIG pilots can accelerate their campaign is not known, but so far the enemy has not used anywhere near the total air strength that he can hurl across the Yalu River into North Korea.

Prime Minister Yoshida of Japan appears to have stirred up some opposition at home and to have evoked some apprehension abroad with his statement last week that Japan was ready to push forward a bilateral treaty with Nationalist China. Mr. Yoshida's letter on this point to John Foster Dulles was explicit and happily free from some of the familiar equivocations of diplomatic correspondence.

Magnolias and fig trees and a lilac hedge at Twelfth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, and pastures full of cattle at Charleton Street will be seen by New Yorkers in a pictorial exhibit of more than 100 country homes on Manhattan from Tuesday until July 31 at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

WHEN pussywillows are in bloom along a snowbound Adirondack-road and the mercury flirts with zero, who can doubt that winter is a remarkable season -- at least, in the country. For winter belongs in the country.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 -- The late Sir Malcolm Campbell's Bluebird, the world's most famous racing car, will return next month to Daytona Beach, where it traveled at 276.82 miles an hour seventeen years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, disclosed today that he was considering a plan to put his name into the April 8 Illinois primary as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The danger of the Korean war's spreading to a conflict directly involving Communist China was cited yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, United States Ambassador to Britain, as a possible result of Prime Minister Churchill's promise of prompt action to oppose any Red violation of a projected Korean armistice.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Portsmouth today retained its lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League by holding the Wolverhampton Wanderers to a 1-1, draw. Manchester United tied Manchester City, 1 -- 1, while Arsenal defeated Derby, 2 to 1.

ALL day, every day, through all four seasons above and below the Equator, merchant ships of all kinds and sizes, of all degrees of paint work and boiler scale, plow their workaday paths. Except for the luxury giants and speed queens they seldom make the front page and perhaps not even the back.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 19 -- Does world communism, from bases in Russia and mainland China, plan stepped-up aggression, perhaps an outright military invasion of other areas in Asia besides Korea?
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Violence in Tunisia, coupled with the confused political situation there, caused Premier-elect Edgar Faure today to hasten preparations for formation of a new French Cabinet.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 19 -- Iran accepts President Truman's contention in a message to Congress that she can best realize her aims and objectives through cooperation with other nations of the free world, Javad Bushehry, official spokesman for the Government and Minister of Communications, stated today in answer to a question.

ON the banks of the sacred Jumna River, near the memorial where Mohandas K. Gandhi was cremated, half a dozen men in nondescript dress debate a momentous question. They are the panchayat, or council, of Delhi's informal guild of dhobis, or washermen, who do the city's laundry on flat rocks in the holy stream.

OF all the television programs that have come and gone, one of the longest running is a one-man show about drawing and sketching. Jon Gnagy, a self-taught commercial artist, started in television nearly six years ago to teach people how to improve their doodling, and he's still doing business over Channel 4 on Sundays at 11:45 A. M.

Cruise wear, spring sportswear and dresses, home furnishings and new spring coats and suits were stressed in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, New York, Jan. 19 -- United States leadership has been weakened and governmental policy on international cooperation, which has been distorted by withdrawal of support for the migration policy of the International Labor Organization, the American Association for the United Nations asserted today in a statement advocating reversal of the move.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Congressional antagonism to President Truman's recommended tax increase program was growing today just two days before the President hands Congress his budget for the coming fiscal year, beginning July 1.

There are some self-dumping lakes in Alaska. One of them, Lake George, has drained every year for thirty years. Kirk H. Stone, University of Wisconsin Geography professor and authority on Alaska, spent part of last summer studying such lakes and found that in eight to ten days the water level of Lake George, which is normally about 120 feet deep, drops so that only three small shallow lakes remain.

Accused of trying to ship slot machines to Italy without clearly marking the contents of the cases and the name of the shipper, as required by law, Jack Anthony Marraffa, 31 years old, of 387 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, was held yesterday in $1,500 bail for hearing Feb. 1 by United States Commissioner Edward E. McDonald in the Federal Building.
Two of the brightest prospects of 1952 for the Giants, champions of the National League, signed their contracts yesterday.
A new approach to medical education, emphasizing "revolutionary" teaching methods, will be offered by the new Yeshiva University medical school when it opens in the fall of 1953.

TO THE EDITOR: HOWARD P. VINCENT'S. satisfying review of three new works on Herman Melville includes the statement that "Leyda's ['The Melville Log' by Jay Leyda] is a new biographical technique in America * * * this impersonal presentation of documents (letters, diaries, news clipping, quotations from novels, Melville's markings in book margins)."

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 19 -- Doug Burden, 20-year-old Middlebury freshman, today hurtled down Mount Mansfield in record time to top a talented field of sixty in the down hill phase of the fifth annual Capt. Victor Constant Memorial Alpine ski competition. The 6-foot 3-inch speedster was at his best in negotiating the mile-and-three-quarter course, which drops 2,000 feet, in the remarkable time of 2:39.4.
It would seem that Justice William O. Douglas is unduly perturbed in "The Black Silence of Fear" (Jan. 13) and that his proposition is paradoxical.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 19 -- Arnold Wolfers, Sterling Professor of International Relations, announced today the establishment of four Overbrook Fellwships in International Relations at the Yale University Graduate School.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Harry Ellwood Paisley of Philadelphia, a church worker for seventy years and a railroad man for fifty-four, was named Protestant "layman of the year" yesterday by the Division of Christian Education of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

EL CAMINO REAL, the King's Highway or the royal road, was formed by the plodding feet of the Franciscan padres who sought and gradually selected the best route between their southernmost mission in San Diego and the one in San Francisco.

The vacuum tubes used in radio go back to Edison's discovery of the "Edison effect." Vice Admiral Harold G. Bowen, executive director of the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation, comes out with a short, simply worded, little book on the history of electronics based on the "effect." Edison had sealed in the bulb of an incandescent lamp a plate near the filament.

I quite agree with Dr. Lionel Sinclair regarding the depravity of the bulk of the radio fare; however to those living in New York and environs there is the blessing of such stations as WNYC, WQXR, WABF and WFDR, whose sendings of the best in music sans objectionable commercials are a delight.

The police of the Coney Island station at 2951 West Eighth Street, Brooklyn, came to the rescue yesterday of thirty-eight persons who had been made homeless by a fire that had swept a three-story frame building at 2971 West Twenty-fifth Street.

THE new and critical problems now before the nation, and likely to persist for several years at least, present a new challenge to economic thought and action. To meet this challenge successfully does not involve recasting the classical "theory of value" or rechecking the mathematical formulas of Keynes.
In the months immediately ahead, Wall Street will see the most selective stock market in its history, in the opinion of five economists for New York Stock Exchange firms.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 19 -- Norwegian speed skaters won brilliant victories today over tough American and Dutch competition in a pre-Olympic international meet at Bislett Stadium. Meanwhile snow started piling up in Oslo in the wake of several blizzards and everything pointed to perfect conditions for the opening of the winter games Feb. 14.

IN London, a month or two ago, I listened to two full programs of American verse read aloud. The experience crystallized for a certainty the differences between American and British verse. What strikes an English writer as most alien in the poetry that is most typically American, from Pound and the Imagists to poets like Richard Wilbur, is the extent to which the universe of reference is the physical, sensible world.

Prime contractors with defense orders are sometimes handicapped in obtaining reliable and competent sub-contractors. One way this bottleneck may be broken is pointed up by a campaign now under way in Minnesota where the Minnesota Federation of Labor (A. F. L.) is working in cooperation with chambers of commerce and civic associations to stimulate registration of plants that are prepared to take on sub-contracts.

" Tannhaeuser," the second in a series of ten lectures by Dr. Curt Sachs on the operas of Wagner, will be held at 8:30 P. M. tomorrow at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

THE playwrights are the whipping boys of the Soviet theatre these days. They've been assailed from all sides in recent weeks as the knaves responsible for the unsatisfactory conditions behind the footlights in Stalin's realm.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- With his invincible stretch sprint, Don Gehrmann cut down Fred Wilt again tonight. Spurting into the lead just twenty yards from home, the slender Wisconsin graduate won the O'Reilly Mile by one yard in 4 minutes 9.3 seconds as 12,000 spectators in the Boston Garden for the Massachusetts Knights of Columbus games thrilled to the suspense of another absorbing contest between the arch rivals.

CALIFORNIA photographers won the first two prizes in Ansco's $10,000 color photography contest. Glen Fishback of Sacramento took the top award, a 1951 Ford; Ralph S. Kemmerer of Castro Valley won the second prize of $750 in cash.

Entries for the Westminster Kennel Club show, to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12, closed last week with 2,451 dogs. They closed short of the 2,500 maximum for the first time in the decade that the limit, imposed because of benching limitations, had been in effect.
Prime Minister Churchill stopped off in New York late yesterday afternoon on his way home after his two-week diplomatic mission to Washington and Ottawa.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- A new chemical compound for the treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis, called aldinamide, has been developed by the Lederle Laboratories Division of the American Cyanamid Company here.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Jan. 19 -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service intervened today in an attempt to end a strike by workers at two divisions of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation here.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- Philadelphia women's apparel stores' sales last week were 6 per cent below a year ago. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 110,671, against 115,898 a year ago, decrease of 4.5 per cent Thus far this year Pennsylvania carloadings total 201,027 to compare with 216,579 last year, decrease of 7.2 per cent.

The wide blue sky of winter, when nature is less visibly busy, invites mental excursions. It is a very different sky from that of, say, July or August when every tree is in full leaf at every ridge is fringed with trees. Boundaries are everywhere then; in winter the boundaries are all here on the ground and the sky itself is boundless.
" ABADABA One, this is Gruesome Four. The beeper says he hears babble."

You have wronged an illustrious New England family by misspelling the name of the sea captain, Jacob Crowninshield, who was responsible for bringing the first elephant to this country, as reported in "American Firsts" (Jan. 6).

Fritz Reiner was the conductor on two nation-wide broadcasts yesterday. In the afternoon, he directed Strauss' "Salome" at the Metropolitan Opera, which went out on the network of the American Broadcasting Company, and between 6:30 and 7:30 he led the N. B. C. Symphony in a concert over the National Broadcasting Company.

THE barberries comprise one of the largest families of shrubs. About 125 varieties are hardy in the vicinity of Boston, and there are a number of tender kinds grown farther south. In spite of this, few are available generally, for the shipment of barberry plants from state to state is strictly regulated by the U. S. Department of Agriculture.

Net income of Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation for the six months ended Nov. 30, last, were $6,005,321, or $1.75 a common share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $6,622,000, or $1.93, for the corresponding six months of 1950.

NOT to be outdone by Hollywood, the dancers now have an Oscar of their own. The Capezio Dance Award has been established by Ben Sommers, president of Capezio, Inc., "to focus attention on meritorious work in the dance field," and the first recipient of the honor is Zachary Solov, young choreographer and ballet master of the Metropolitan Opera.

THROUGH the frosty windows of his Johnny Appleseed Bookstore on the common, Walter Hard, the lean, lined proprietor, as weathered and gray as a locust fence rail, gazes out at the line of cars with skis racked on top rushing northward on U. S. 7.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 -- The report that the Canadian Government intends to recommend to the King the appointment of a Canadian as Governor General in succession to Viscount Alexander has roused a surprising amount of opposition.
The Visiting Nurse Service of New York will be the beneficiary of "Portraits of Personalities-Past and Present," a loan exhibition, opening Tuesday afternoon at Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue.

TODAY'S children are apt to know a good deal more about aeronautics than their parents ever will, but it is doubtful if many of them realize how recent is the airplane and how old is man's dream of flying.
Importers were disappointed last week over delay of Senate enactment of the Customs Simplification Bill, which was approved by the House last year.
The United States Weather Bureau yesterday issued the following forecasts and reports of winter sports conditions in New England:

LOTTE LEHMANN'S Farewell Recital is completely documented in a new Pembroke Album. Her touching farewell speech, and her whole performance -- including the final An die Musik, which the soprano broke off and left Paul Ulanowsky to finish on the piano -- is contained on one twelve and one ten-inch disk.

THE proper study of mankind is dogs. That is something which dog owners have long understood, but recently this enlightened group learned that science is coming around more and more to their view. A group of psychologists who deal with the effects of childhood experience on mental health report that dogs are ideally adapted to experiments that explain all sorts of human behavior.
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,134, for Saturday's operations:

AFTER a long period of neglect Eugene O'Neill is represented on Broadway with two productions. The City Center put on "Anna Christie" on Jan. 9 with Celeste Holm, Art Smith, Kevin McCarthy and Grace Valentine. After the final performances at the Center this afternoon and this evening it will move into the Lyceum on Wednesday.

NEWARK, Jan. 19 -- A slum-clearance and redevelopment program that will cost $40,000,000 was approved by the Newark Housing Authority today at a special meeting. Tentative approval by Federal agencies has been received, the Rev. Thomas J. Finnegan, chairman of the housing authority, said.

Two professors of agricultural economics, both former members of the New York Milkshed Price Committee that set the present formula for the price of fluid milk eighteen months ago, went on record yesterday against a proposed upward revision in the price.

AT the moment Julien Gracq is the most talked of writer in Paris. An obscure professor of geography and history named Louis Poirier with three novels, a play, and two essays to his credit under a pseudonym, he has achieved this position simply by being the first to reject the coveted Goncourt Prize.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 19 -- Otis H. Smith, a former Brooklyn attorney who reversed the usual procedure by leaving a big city to make good in a small place, will start his second term as Mayor of this Delaware Bay community on his return from a business trip to Venezuela. Lewes has a population just under 3,000.

AT the age of 28 Jean Stafford came out with her first novel, "Boston Adventure," and in so doing walked through the door marked literature with almost alarming suddenness. That was 1944. Miss Stafford started on it in 1940; during some of those four years she was on the staff of The Southern Review.

A warning that Asians were skeptical of the intentions and democratic claims of the West because of the "persistent racialism in some parts of the United States" was given last night by Dr. Maurice L. Perlzweig, the World Jewish Congress' consultant to the United Nations, who recently returned from India and Southeast Asia.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Harry Hopman, non-playing captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, today named five United States tennis players on his world's "Big Ten." Veteran Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., was not among them.

LIKE many another youngster, Flip the colt was just too early a riser. His joyous racket was a nuisance to all the other animals of the barnyard, so old Willie Goat spun a yarn calculated to keep Flip afield for many a peaceful dawning. When the joke backfires on old Willie, Flip winks one great, soft eye at his young readers.

Al Schoenig of Manual Training, winning the second section of the mile run in 4:28.2 at the 102d Engineer Group Armory last night, established a new meet record in the third Cardinal Hayes High interscholastic games. A 157-pounder who stands 6 feet 1 inch, Schoenig achieved his fastest time in a meet, although he had done 4:24 in practice on Columbia's board track.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- Izvestia and Pravda, bulwarking the rapidly growing Soviet drive for international trade expansion, charged today that anti-United States feeling was rising in Britain because of the "economic insanity" of United States policy and that Western Europe generally was astir with the desire for renewing East-West trade.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Department store sales for the ten months ended Nov. 30 were up 0.6 per cent compared with a year ago in the Chicago area, the Federal Reserve Bank reported. Main store sales rose 0.1 per cent while basement store sales were up 1.2 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much of the United Nations debate on atomic control has been focussed on false issues. The removal of two of these is perhaps the principal contribution of Vishinsky's recent "concessions." Indeed, the question of "periodic inspection" was in all probability coined with the expectation that it would later be abandoned with a propagandistic flourish.

The New York University swimming team defeated Fordham in the latter's pool last night, 48 to 36. Cromey took the 220-yard free-style and the 440-yard free-style, while Silverstein won the individual medley and the 200-yard breaststroke.

THE weather this winter has not been the best for gardens in the vicinity of New York City. Mild and rainy days followed abruptly by cold and windy ones, then a change back to almost balmy weather can cause a lot of damage to pants.

Young women, including Miss Ann D. Miller and Mrs. Louis L. Stanton, are aiding members of the executive committee in the sale of tickets for "Aida" Saturday night, Feb. 2, at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over for the twenty-seventh annual opera benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Vassar Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, said today that Republican Senators were exploring ways of forcing a vote on a resolution of "no confidence" in Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States delegate to the United Nations Geenral Assembly.
The National Committee of the Progressive party met yesterday 13 Astor Place to make plans for placing its candidates for President and Vice President on the ballot in as many states as possible.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 19 -- The tournament committee of the Professional Golfers' Association today voted to approve participation by Negroes in P. G. A.-co-sponsored golf tournaments.

It's a dreary life -- lying in a hospital bed. And it's even drearier lying in a public ward where visiting hours must be strictly controlled. Many hundreds of patients in New York hospitals look forward to the visits of Lassies of The Salvation Army to brighten otherwise dull days.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Price changes in grains were neither large nor of any real significance on the Board of Trade today. Dealings proceeded at a routine pace, with the local trading fraternity accounting for a large part of the turnover.

Plans to extend medical service to a larger percentage of the 500,000 American children and adults afflicted with cerebral palsy were disclosed yesterday at a meeting in the Statler Hotel to prepare for the annual campaign next May.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- A three-year port development project has been launched by the Indian Government to tap the resources of a 270,000-square-mile area comprising five states surrounding the Gulf of Cutch on India's northwest coast.

TORONTO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs skated to an easy 6-to-2 triumph over the slumping Boston Bruins tonight before 13,003 fans to tighten their grip on second place in the National Hockey League. Howie Meeker led the winners with two goals and an assist on a third.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 19 -- The horse of the year of 1951, C. V. Whitney's Counterpoint, had to run one of the greatest races of his career today to score a nose victory over Phil D. in the $23,600 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita.

Highlighted by some brilliant Knickerbocker play in the late minutes and an incident involving Warrior Coach Eddie Gottlieb and Referee Stan Stutz near the end of the second period, the Knicks scored a 94 -- 88 triumph over Philadelphia in a National Basketball Association game at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory last night before 4,500 booing and cheering fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor said today that Senate investigators had found a "decided reluctance" among our Allies to stop the flow of strategic materials to Iron Curtain countries.
IS there a lack of writing and directing talent capable of artfully combining education and entertainment for broadcasting?
MIAMI, Jan. 19 -- Greek Ship, the Brookmeade Stable's "Mighty Mouse," outlasted six hard-driving opponents in a close, touch race today to capture Hialeah's $10,000 added Royal Palm Handicap.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Two teams from the Bronx came past the bastions of the United States Military Academy today and the invasion was an all-out success as Fordham defeated Army in basketball, 74-70, and Manhattan turned back the Cadets at track, 67 1/3 to 41 2/3.

The year 1951 was one of sharp contrasts for the nation's drug and pharmaceutical trade, it was reported last week. While good gains were made in sales and product improvement, ground was considered to have been lost in the legal sphere.
MADRID, Jan. 19 -- Generalissimo Francesco Franco was reported today to be discussing with Caliph Muley Ben Hassan of Spanish Morocco a far reaching plan to grant wider autonomy to that protectorate.

IT was Tocqueville who first observed that all those things which in Europe are normally done by Government are done in America by private individuals or organizations. Certainly from the days of the founding of the Boston Latin School and Harvard College private initiative and generosity played a large role in American society, and throughout the nineteenth century most American colleges, libraries, hospitals, museums and similar institutions were created by private contributions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Truman's announcement that J. Howard McGrath would remain as Attorney General and that the Department of Justice, which Mr. McGrath heads, would have the job of cleaning up corruption in the Federal Government did nothing to take that issue out of politics.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 19 -- Two Swiss representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross said here today they would go back to Panmunjom Monday, despite an official Communist protest against their presence in the neutral truce talk zone twice this week.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19 -- The Government's assertion that Argentina's present difficulties were caused by increased local consumption were challenged today by the Union Civica Radical, President Juan Peron's only important nation-wide opposition.

An old guide once remarked, in paraphrasing a Continental axiom, "that if you scratch a woodsman you find a catamount," and after going through some of the mail in response to a recent column on the proposed "managed cutting" of the Forest Preserve we are convinced that the same transformation could be reached by scratching conservationists, hunters, hikers and anglers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Prime Minister Churchill left here for New York on the noon train today with a tribute to forty-nine Ko rean war veterans for their roles in "a memorable act of resisting tyranny and aggression."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- While the uninhibited Republicans at San Francisco were listening to claims of electoral potency by and in behalf of four of their availables for national candidacy this year, the Democratic shut-ins -- those Presidential aspirants whom Mr. Truman still restrains from taking to the wide-open spaces of party politics -- were being agitated by a new set of rumors about his attitude toward another nomination.

The Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry, a labor-management group, has broadened the terms of its scholarship program at Columbia University to enable the daughters as well as sons of electrical construction workers to attend a liberal arts college.

WHAT in the world are we coming to when an author uses his pen name to draw attention to his real name? Ordinarily, the purpose of a nom de plume is to conceal identity, but the publishers of A. A. Fair are now advertising the fact that he is none other than Erle Stanley Gardner.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- From here it appears as though people in the United States were prone, whenever there is a French Cabinet crisis, to regard it as evidence of an unaccountable French taste for instability and for interference with the work of the world.

THE usually talkative motion picture industry is about as communicative as a sphinx when it comes to technical developments still in the experimental stage. Right now Hollywood is full of rumors and reports about new scientific advancements being just-around-the-corner which will help cut production costs and improve pictorial quality.
HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A geologist with a sense of humor took a map of the United States, drew two narrow lines from the Texas Panhandle to Calgary, Canada, and labeled it "Texans' Corridor."
Victor Seixas of Philadelphia was moved up from No. 2 to No. 1 in the revised national tennis rankings adopted yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association at the Vanderbilt Hotel.

AS is well known, Charlie Chaplin's "The Great Dictator" was one of the top political satires of pre-war times. It was perfectly natural, therefore, for United Artists to consider showing the picture in Germany once the subject of the story had been safely removed from the scene.

ALTHOUGH grown-ups held a poor opinion of the Catnip Man, Nancy and Bob thought this shabby old character one of Gloucester's finest attractions. Loving him, they felt no surprise at the good turns he did, as when he coaxed Mrs. Thompson's frightened cat out of a tree.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 7 to 18 points yesterday.

IF you are in the market for a recording of Tosca, there are two new performances of Puccini's opera. One comes from Westminster, and the other from Remington. Both albums contain three twelve-inch disks.

A DECADE ago the available literature on "top management" consisted of less than a dozen disconnected works. Within the last decade this literature has expanded greatly, although much of the "new" material has actually been a rediscovery or rewording of ideas previously expounded.

SARASOTA -- The Chamber of Commerce modestly maintains that there is everything here that a tourist could wish for. Right now the community is showing real foresight in acquiring beach front property on the Gulf of Mexico so that -- unlike Miami Beach, where the waterfront is largely chopped up into tiny parcels owned by hotels -- Sarasota will always have good beaches open to all residents and visitors.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 -- The International Association of Firefighters will send a representative here Monday to discuss the use of firemen as traffic policemen at school crossings.

AMONG the choice species of polygonums are found climbers, groundcovers, shrubs and rock garden plants. In midsummer, both annual and perennial species display similar spikes of minute flowers in ivory, pale and deep pink, rose red or red purple.

The Government of Western Germany announced yesterday plans for a selective service program for youths in the 19-to-21 age group to help train 300,000 to 400,000 soldiers in Germany's contribution to a Western European army.

The Catholic Centre for the Blind will be the beneficiary of the Feb. 7 performance at the Radio City Music Hall, where the film, "The Greatest Show on Earth," is playing. A section of the mezzanine on that night has been taken over to raise funds for the Centre. Tickets may be obtained from Mrs. William F. Cogswell at 22 East Seventy-first Street.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Al Watrous, the leader all the way, scored a ten-stroke victory in the first P.G.A. National Senior Open golf tournament today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Penn preserved its unbeaten Eastern Intercollegiate League Basketball record tonight with a 72-55 victory over Dartmouth. A crowd of 6,544 watched Villanova lace North Carolina State, 86 -- 71, in the opener.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Jan. 19 -- The neighbors of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen opened their hearts to the doughty skipper today with the most tumultuous welcome-home celebration this township of 42,000 has seen in its 238-year history.
Arrogance and egoism have taken the place of self-dedication among our leaders of the people, Rabbi Jacob Polish said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Hebrew Tabernacle, 605 West 161st Street.

THERE is much more than skiing to attract the winter sportsman to Canada at this time of year. In addition to ice skating and tobogganing, outdoor lovers will find a variety of spectator sports crowding local calendars, from curling bonspiels and hockey games to dog racing and skating shows.

The railroads in the Eastern territory will receive about $60,000,000 additional revenue annually if the examiners are upheld by the Interstate Commerce Commission on their recent recommendation with respect to the division of joint inter-territorial freight rates.

Having read with great interest the recent discussions in these columns based on Mr. Wilson's book "How to Help Your Child With Music," I realize that the League of Composers' Children's Concerts may have more than intramural interest.

BOONVILLE, Ind., Jan. 19 (AP) Ever since Oct. 21 John Sturgeon has lived with an automobile "parked" halfway in his living room and halfway in his front yard. It came roaring in off a sharp curve on Highway 62.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19 -- Retail trade in general continued to lag in the Southeast last week. Thirty-seven proposed building projects which would have cost upward of $5,600,000 have been disapproved by the National Production Authority to conserve materials in scarce supply for the national defense program.

" I HAVE always been interested in the subject of history," writes Jeff Selleck, "though I have never had the time to pursue it. But as an indication of the turn of my mind I will list the publications our family subscribes to. We take Life, Time, U. S. News and World Report, The Saturday Evening Post and Reader's Digest.

INDICATIONS are that this year New Orleans' Mardi Gras will be one of the gayest to be held in several years. Tuesday, Feb. 26, will be the day of the big parades, but during the week preceding, the city will be busy with private balls and civic committees will be preparing floats and costumes for the wind-up celebration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Twenty-three major areas, including New York City, now have a surplus of workers, but the outlook is for absorption of the surplus as defense production gains, the Department of Labor reported today.

Mr. Ansermet began his Boston Symphony concert of yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall as he had begun the program of Wednesday night, with a classic. In this instance the classic was Mozart of the G minor symphony, as the Fifth Symphony of Beethoven was the classic of the earlier concert.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Soviet Union's proposals on disarmament, including its last-minute proposals on atomic control that, according to Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, constituted acceptance of the Western position on two essential points, were referred by the General Assembly today to the new United Nations Disarmament Commission.

An ancient method of bronze casting with a modern twist, which made possible quantity production of precision parts during World War II, has opened a new avenue to sculptors as well as to manufacturers of war material. It is known as the cire perdue, or lost wax, process.

GOING to the post for the sixteenth time, Colonel North is an older, wiser and less agile man than the Captain North who first starred in these vehicles back there in 1930. Once more the famous G-2 sets out on a mission of counter-espionage and contemporary international intrigue.
LAWRENCE, Mass., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Pacific Mills and the Textile Workers Union, A. F. L., renewed a contract today covering 3,500 worsted workers without changing work loads or wage rates.

" PAINT YOUR WAGON," the Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical currently rolling briskly along at the Shubert Theatre, shows signs of veering toward the West's film factories. According to a spokesman for Cheryl Crawford, the producer, no less than three companies -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the Warner Brothers and Paramount -- are serious enough about the work to have made offers.

FROM Pretoria come the designs of the five stamps which Union of South Africa will release on March 14 for the tercentenary of the landing of Jan Antony van Riebeeck at Kaapstad (Cape Town) on April 6, 1652. The colors are to be announced.

Department store sales continued well below the corresponding 1951 figures as a consequence of the heavy scare buying recorded last year. Trade observers put the decline from 1951 at as much as 16 per cent, but remarked that current buying might be considered "normal." Most of the declines for the latest week were recorded in the hard lines.

Grandmother would never recognize her button box the way a hundred or more men and women members of the New York State Button Society, meeting in state convention here this week-end, have dignified and systematized the accumulation of the fascinating little fasteners.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Louise Suggs slipped over par today for the first time but clung to a three-stroke lead at the three-quarter mark of the Tampa Women's Open Golf Tournament.
Domestic producers of sulphur are mapping plans to increase their output in line with an enlarged production rate sought by Washington, it was learned last week.
ODESSA, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP) -- State police voiced fear tonight that a Cornell University junior, his younger brother and sister and two other young children had drowned in Cayuta Lake.
ALPE D'HUEZ, France -- Nobody at Alpe d'Huez talks about skiing once they come in off the slopes. Thus, unequivocally, this becomes the finest ski resort I have ever known.

It was with great emotion that I read Helen Keller's stirring tribute to a long-neglected hero, Louis Braille, in her article, "Light-Bearer to the World of Darkness" (Jan. 6). Whether by chance or Providence, Jan. 6 also provided a television tribute to Braille worthy of that great man.

SOMEWHERE in the back of every writer's mind is a book about his boyhood, and for better or for worse he usually writes it. At best he may produce a "Huckleberry Finn" or a "Look Homeward, Angel"; at worst he will probably offer up a haphazard stew over-spiced with egotism and watered with nostalgia.

IN a seasonal anthology one expects to find poems suitable for Christmas, Easter, Arbor Day and similar holidays. Miss Sechrist, however, doesn't stop there. In this outsize collection of about 300 poems she has thoughtfully included selections for such occasions as May Day, Candlemas, State's Day, Book Week and Fire Prevention Week. There is even a poem for Moving Day!

TO THE EDITOR: FRANK SULLIVAN'S article on humor is very appropriate to these days and he may be interested in the following short passage from the Talmud, written in a "grim age" too. It came to me in a letter from my father and read:

PHOTOGRAPHERS who witnessed the program of abstract films at the Museum of Modern Art last week seemed more concerned over the abstract's validity as a photographic medium than appreciative of its unique qualities as a new and distinctive graphic form.

Efficiency experts, who now go by the less crisp but more dignified title of management engineers, have wound up a six-month study of workings of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Two fellowships in family life education of $2,500 each, given by the Grant Foundation, are available at Cornell University. The fellowships also include free tuition toward the Ph.D. degree. Those who wish to apply should write to the Department of Child Development and Family Relationships at Cornell, Ithaca, N. Y.

NEWARK, Jan. 19 -- Plans for a one-day work stoppage by members of American Federation of Labor locals in nine northern New Jersey counties, as a gesture of sympathy for striking district agents of the Prudential Insurance Company, were abandoned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- In the old days the best political advertisement a politician could have was that he was born in a log cabin. A better political bet today, statistically at least, is a war record.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- By a minor twist of irony, one of the Southwest's most complex and least understood features is at the same time perhaps its best known and most symbolic feature: the cactus. Saying "the cactus," however, is as indefinite as saying "the human."

President Truman has worked out a system of giving Congress his program each year by easy stages. First, in a State of the Union Message, he outlines in broad strokes America's national and international role. Second, in an Economic Report, he presents a picture of the U. S. economy and a large part of the legislative agenda ahead.

GARY, Ind., Jan. 19 -- (AP) Gary steel union officials accused the Wage Stabilization Board today of permitting a stall in their wage talks and declared they would strike Feb. 22 unless the dispute was settled.

Jersey Joe Walcott, world heavyweight champion, will be compelled to sign not later than March for a defense of his title or run into difficulties with the State Athletic Commission, it was learned yesterday from a source close to the boxing governing board.

AMONG the stories which Paul Chavchavadze (ne Tchavchavadze) scattered with prodigal hand through his "Family Album" two years ago is one reputed to have interested Alexandre Dumas. With nothing to go on but an item from the Paris newspapers, this alien brashly applied to the chief personage involved, an illustrious Georgian princess, for the private details to put in a book.

BLIND abuse and undiscriminating enthusiasm have for so long been simultaneously lavished on Picasso that a dispassionate judgment on his torrential output is near-impossible. But the selection of his paintings, 1939-45, now at Louis Carre's gives us some idea, at least, of the sort of art in which he took refuge during the atrocious years of the German occupation.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland chose Robert E. Lee's birthday tonigth to urge Southerners to follow the example of the general and rebel "against the threat of tyranny from the national capital."

TO go on with what I was saying last week about the cheap reprints and their impact, past, present and future, on the business-profession of book publishing: I said that I would return to the history of Penguin Books because I thought we might find in the nature of that history some guideposts to the future.

A major development in the current meeting of the U. N. General Assembly in Paris is that the West has taken a firm lead in the propaganda struggle with communism. The West seized this lead last November when Britain, France, and the U. S. presented a comprehensive plan for reduction of atomic and other armaments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- North Carolina withstood a 32-point effort by Temple's Bill Mlkvy to hand the Owls a 70-65 defeat in the second game of a Convention Hall basketball double-header tonight.

Supporters for Senator Robert A. Taft for the Republican Presidential nomination will make no fight for national convention delegates in this state in Congressional districts where the Republican county chairmen are not for the Ohio Senator, District Attorney Lindsay R. Henry of Suffolk County, said yesterday.

Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo sat down in his chambers in the Brooklyn Federal Building one afternoon last week recalling old days with Alfred Jerome Loring, the foreman of the January Grand Jury. They had been schoolmates nearly forty-eight years ago and were holding their first reunion.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Princeton was knocked from the ranks of the unbeaten in Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League competition tonight by bowing to Cornell, 67 to 51.
Hunter College will again be the site of United Nations activities starting next Sunday, when a five-day meeting will be held in the building at 695 Park Avenue.

Old masters and a large group of paintings of nineteenth century schools will be auctioned at 8 P. M. on Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The pictures, now on exhibition, are the property of Mrs. Ogden L. Mills and Herman G. Lane of New York, Stephen Ames of Hollywood and other owners.

PLANT CITY, Fla. -- This tight little community of 10,000 supplies 95 per cent of the winter strawberries shipped to the North and Middle West. It is well worth a visit by tourists not in too much of a hurry to reach the beaches.

The year-long effort of a private United States group to foster a coalition of Soviet exile organizations for a well-financed propaganda war against the Soviet regime has run into serious difficulties that may force a change in tactics.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Russia's application for provisional membership in the International Ice Hockey Federation was found faulty today at a special meeting called by Dr. Fritz Kraatz, president of the organization.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the nineteenth annual Polka Ball, to be held on the night of Feb. 1 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Kosciusko Foundation for the benefit of the organization's Chopin Scholarship Fund.

The influence of European style ideas, color combinations and cloths will be strong in American sportswear this year, leading manufacturers reported last week. Several companies sent representatives on European tours to find adaptable products for home consumption.

ADOLF HITLER danced his jig of joy in the presence of his generals and his admirals. It was June 17, 1940. His dreams of conquest seemed to be coming true. Poland was partitioned and occupied. Denmark, Norway, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, had succumbed.

NO clinging ivy dims the walls of Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College. The school is only seventy-five years old and an infant compared with some of the nation's great institutions; but it opened its ambitious door when Texas still had raw frontiers, and it has grown up, robustly enough, with the state. As George Sessions Perry points out, the college comes close to epitomizing the Texas spirit of vastness, readiness, brashness.
Ninety-two aliens were deported yesterday aboard the Italian liner Saturnia, which sailed for Gibraltar, Portugal, Fance and Italy.

THE first of these handsomely produced volumes is devoted to an account of Italian early Renaissance painting during one of its few lulls, the decades which elapsed between the death of Giotto and the birth of Masaccio. Art historians have tended to hurry through these middle years of the trecento feeling, not without reason, that Florentine and Sienese painters of the time were treading water between one great wave of creativity and the next.

One fact distinguishing the latest report to Congress by President Truman is that he has not lost any of the enthusiasm for more taxes which he displayed so repeatedly in 1951. In requesting a tax increase of more than $5,000,000,000 this year he jolted the Congress, many of whose members believed that another increase in this election year would be political suicide.
New York's fabulous, usually extravagant, mid-January excitement known as the National Motor Boat Show departed last night at 11 o'clock after an eight-day anchorage in Grand Central Palace.

ONE of the most useful and yet neglected plants is the old - fashioned impatiens (Impatiens sultani). It is difficult to know why it has fallen from popular favor, for it produces a wealth of blossoms almost all year round without any special care.

THE incursion of the State into film production makes for some odd results. If anybody had told the average English taxpayer a few years ago that his money would find its way into making a movie of a Broadway musical comedy very roughly deriving from Shakespeare he would have been alarmed, incredulous, or both.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Pakistan called on the United Nations Security Council today to meet at an early date to consider Libya's application for membership in the world organization.
UNION CITY, N. J., Jan. 19 -- A 12-year-old Bayonne schoolboy, helping his father photograph a house-wrecking job here, uncovered two well-preserved copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES of the Civil War era.
Building work estimated to cost $347,425,000 was started in New York in 1951, according to figures made public yesterday by Robert R. Behlow, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Worth Street commission houses are preparing to welcome hundreds of wholesale dry goods buyers who are coming to New York this week. The arrival of the wholesalers, it was pointed out, will set the pace for spring and summer buying of textiles and help to activate a quiet primary market.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The newspaper El Siglo reported today that twenty-six bandits were killed by police in a nine-hour gun fight on Thursday in a rural area near Lerida municipality, sixty miles northwest of here.

COMPLETION last week of the final nine-mile stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike brings the 118-mile express highway directly to New York City's western doorstep. With easy access supplied by interchanges connected to the George Washington Bridge, Lincoln Tunnel and Holland Tunnel, the pike is now directly useful to travelers from the city, northern Jersey, upstate New York and New England.

The New York Film Critics yesterday presented awards to winners of the seventeenth annual poll for outstanding achievements in the preceding year at a reception in the Rose Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Bosley Crowther, motion-picture critic for THE NEW YORK TIMES and chairman of the group, made the presentations.

The Danish State Symphony Orchestra will make a six-week tour in this country next fall, it was announced yesterday by the American Scandinavian Foundation and Columbia Artists' Management, who will sponsor the orchestra on its first visit to the United States.
Associated Hospital Service, New York's Blue Cross Plan, will raise subscription charges May 1 to meet increased hospital costs.

Erna Berger, soprano, gave the first of a series of three recitals yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her winning personality and the sincerity and refinement of her work won a ready response from the audience.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 20 -- There are many people who work in complete anonymity in motion picture studios, doing odd jobs that contribute importantly to the making of pictures. One of them is Vera Mordaunt, whose name has become synonymous with "magic" at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer during the last twenty-one years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- A huge oil painting, familiar for a century at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, will be presented Saturday to the Netherlands Government during ceremonies marking the 100th anniversary of the issuance of the first Netherlands postage stamp.

FLORENCE, Jan. 20 -- From corks embroidered on an evening gown to umbrellas tucked in special coat pockets, Italian inventiveness marked today's showing of haute couture under the auspices of G. B. Giorgini of Florence.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 20 -- A United States Atomic Energy Commission engineer today urged the National Canners' Association to cooperate with the A. E. C. in developing industrial applications of fission products in the food industry and to proceed with commercial exploitation of these developments.

JUAREZ, Mexico, Jan. 20 -- Blond Patricia McCormick was wildly cheered and won two ears after she had killed both bulls in her world debut today as North America's only professional woman bullfighter.
Leroy Randle Grumman, pioneer aircraft designer and builder, will receive the 1951 Honorary American Fellowship of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences on Jan. 28, it announced yesterday.

The late Harry T. Moore, Negro leader killed last month by the explosion of an assassin's bomb in his home at Mims, Fla., has posthumously received the Jefferson Award of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for his "furtherance of the principles of democracy."

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Louise Suggs won her first Tampa women's open golf championship in six starts today, with a closing round par 74 that put her five strokes ahead of second place Babe Zaharias.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 -- Picket lines at the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation's huge Aliquippa works were withdrawn suddenly late today, ending a one-day wildcat strike that had completely shut down the mill.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence of Rutland, Vt., cemented her position as a pre-Olympic favorite and the American men's team made its best showing in the wind-up today of the international ski festival here.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 20 -- Clergymen of nine denominations are going to pray in relays throughout tomorrow night that "God may intervene" to stop building of a horse race track at West Memphis, Ark.

Ground action in Korea was limited Sunday as United Nations forces repulsed an enemy probe in the east-central sector of the front. Elsewhere along the battle line friendly forces reported only scattered light contacts with small enemy groups.

ODESSA, N. Y., Jan. 20 (UP) -- A mitten of one of the dead helped searchers today to recover the bodies of a Cornell University student and four children who broke through the ice while skating and sledding on Lake Cayuta.

ZURICH, Jan. 20 -- In a confidential circular going out this week to a restricted group of customers the Swiss Bank Corporation of Zurich draws attention to the existence of considerable differences between New York and Zurich market quotations of certain foreign government bonds, the circular indicating which bonds might be sold advantageously and which others should be bought with the proceeds.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 20 -- Beneath the rather glittering surface of Western Germany's economic strength, its sound currency and its favorable trade balance, lies a serious strain of poverty and hard times.
Here is a bedtime story that mothers might like to tell their children to illustrate what happens to naughty little boys.

At the Saturday evening concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony, conducted by Guido, Cantelli, the only change of program was the Dvorak Piano Concerto in G minor, played by Rudolf Firkusny. Shulman's "Laurentian" Overture, Schubert's Second Symphony and Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler" were carryovers from the Thursday-Friday concerts.

If Mayor Impellitteri and his fellow-members of the Board of Estimate are as seriously concerned with new sources of revenue as they profess to be it does not make sense that they have pigeon-holed the request of Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley for 15,000 parking meters, which would add a minimum of $2,500,000 a year to the city's depleted treasury.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A ten-minute exchange of fire on the central front was the only clash reported along the entire 145-mile Korean ground front Sunday.

The composers whose music was played Saturday night at the Composers' Forum were fond of using a great many notes in busy and sometimes nervous patterns. This was true of Charles Mills' instrumental music more than his songs. In Halsey Stevens' works, it was practically unrelenting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Grain futures worked sharply lower last week, although the trend was irregular, punctuated by frequent rallies, which, however, failed to hold. At times there was a little independent strength in corn and oats.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Although not assured of unanimous Arab support for their revised Palestine refugee plan, the United States and three other sponsors of the proposal have decided to lay it before the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 22 -- In a note delivered to the United States Embassy shortly after 1 A. M. today the Soviet Government charged the United States with collaborating with German and Japanese war criminals in seeking to make propaganda from allegations that Russia still held prisoners of war of Germany and Japan.
Newsprint production in North America set records last December fort he month and the full year of 1951, it is reported by the Newsprint Service Bureau.

Form displayed in last weekend's meets at Philadelphia and Boston established Don Gehrmann, George Rhoden, Roscoe Browne, Horace Ashenfelter, Arthur Bragg, Harrison Dillard and Bob Richards as solid favorites in their respective specialties at Saturday's Millrose Games, first of the five 1952 track and field extravaganzas at Madison Square Garden.

The Coast Guard's civilian Auxiliary gave assistance to more than 2,000 boats involved in accidents last year, Capt. Nathaniel S. Fulford Jr., U. S. C. G., chief director of the Auxiliary, reported yesterday.

Five distinguished musicians joined yesterday afternoon to provide the tenth program of the New Friends of Music's season at Town Hall. The result was a series of first-class performances, even though the program did not hang together well as an entity.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Russians said publicly today that their efforts to build a "little Ruhr" on the German-Polish border had been unsuccessful. They blamed the East German bureaucracy.

British sterling forwards sunk to new low discounts last week for the first time since exchange regulations were altered in mid-December when a free market developed on the withdrawal of the Bank of England from posting official buying and selling rates in those deliveries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- The impact of the rearmament program, with resultant increases in prices of imported goods, adversely affected the economy of most Asian countries during the second quarter of 1951, the United Nations Commission for Asia and the Far East reported today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Republicans in Congress challenged the Truman Administration from two quarters today on the way it is meeting the issue of corruption in government.
ZURICH, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Russia's application to participate in the Olympic ice hockey tournament was turned down today by the International Ice Hockey Federation.

In carrying out the aims of the American National Theatre and Academy to exhibit distinctive stage art as it did last March by sponsoring the local stand of Louis Jouvet and his French company in "L'Ecole des Femmes," the board of the Congressionally chartered organization voted on Friday to consider the importation of the Greek National Theatre in October for a fortnight's run on Broadway.

Ceremonies marking the Feast of the Epiphany according to the Julian calendar were held here yesterday by two self-governing Greek churches. Gold crosses were thrown into the waters of New York Bay and the East River, doves symbolizing the Holy Ghost were released and swimmers retrieved the crosses in accordance with age-old tradition.
KEARNY, N. J., Jan. 20 -- The Newark Portuguese, erasing a three-goal deficit, turned back the Philadelphia Nationals in an American Soccer League game at Washington Oval today, 4 to 3.

The All-American Amateur Baseball Association will seek support of the major leagues in expansion of its program, Glenn L. Martin of Baltimore said yesterday. Martin, chairman of the association's board of directors told the annual meeting that the amateur association could take over part of the majors' farm work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Estes Keufauver let the cat out of the bag today.

CAIRO, Jan. 20 -- The United States Embassy in Cairo confirmed today that Sister Anthony, a United States citizen, had been killed at Ismailia yesterday. The announcement said that she had been shot through the heart at 4 P. M. and had died instantly.

The important effect of the individual on the moral and ethical climate of this country, on international and interracial relationships and on the fulfillment of the world mission of Christianity was stressed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frank T. Cartwright, associate secretary of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- In the Canadian wilds 140 miles north of Duluth what is believed to be one of the continent's richest iron ore deposits rests beneath a lake and 70,000,000 tons of mud, clay and gravel -- glacial residue. In one of the biggest and most hazardous dredging jobs on record, a Chicago company is removing both the lake and the lake bed to clear the way for full scale mining operations.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Premier-designate Edgar Faure of the Radical party, after having worked through the night, succeeded early today in forming an emergency coalition Cabinet, whose first tasks will be to deal with an outbreak of anti-French agitation in Tunisia and with an increasingly critical financial situation in France.
Night owls were the worst sufferers yesterday as the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System began economy cuts in service on its Bronx bus lines.

The New York Infirmary, 321 East Fifteenth Street, presented yesterday its annual Elizabeth Blackwell awards for outstanding contributions in the field of medicine to five distinguished woman physicians.

WALTER BRIGGS was more than just another owner of just another ball club. Primarily he was a baseball fan who wanted the best of everything. He came pretty close to getting it, too. To start, he owned the Detroit Tigers, a franchise most diamond men consider the best in baseball. Then he enlarged and beautified Briggs Stadium until it became one of the finest ball parks in the land.
McCHORD AIR FORCE BASE, Wash., Jan. 20 -- A B-17 plane homeward bound from a search mission crashed on an Olympic Peninsula peak last night, but five of its crew escaped alive. Three were missing.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 21 -- Communist delegates negotiating at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war yesterday warned the United Nations to change its stand on an exchange of prisoners or give up hope for a truce.

A chill wind, bustling over the Harlem River and sweeping up University Heights to the stony open spaces of the Hall of Fame, lent a touch of the sea yesterday to the first meeting of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen and Capt. Neils Olsen, who rescued thirty-two persons from the Flying Enterprise on Dec. 29.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 53 more battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 15 killed, 31 wounded, 1 missing in action and 6 injured. It also lists 24 killed who were previously carried as missing.

Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday that he was "inclined to think the reason more have not returned to the true fold is because we Catholics have not given good enough example."

The arts and industries in the United States consumed 110,000,000 ounces of silver last year, which was 10,000,000 ounces below that of 1950, acocrding to annual review of the silver market by Handy Harman, fabricators of precious metals, released for publication today.

Citations for bravery and meritorious acts by 373 policemen were listed in general orders issued yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan. The list covered recommendations by the honor committee of the Police Department since November.

If the Federal Reserve System's activities were to be rigidly restricted, Government intervention in the lending and investing decisions of commercial banks is likely to be substituted, S. Sloan Colt, president of Bankers Trust Company, warns in his annual report to stockholders.

"Henry Irving," a biography of the great Victorian actor by Laurence Irving, will be published by Macmillan on March 25. The author, Sir Henry's grandson, in the telling of the actor's life, also presents a study of the Victorian stage and its relationship with society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Hiram Bingham, Chairman of the Federal Loyalty Review Board, said tonight there had been no evidence "of any deliberate whitewashing of any case reviewed by this board."

Nine young persons who were awaiting transportation home after they had attended a church social in St. Albans, Queens, were injured early yesterday morning when a city-owned bus swerved into a group of fifteen to twenty persons at the intersection of Linden and Merrick Boulevards, Jamaica.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan 20 (UP) -- Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., playing a brilliant brand of golf over a water-logged course, won the most important golf victory of his career today as he captured the $10,000 San Diego open from a fast closing Jimmy Demaret.
The Metropolitan Opera's twelfth week, which starts on Jan. 28 the second half of the season, will be highlighted by a new production of "Carmen" Thursday evening, Jan. 31.
Building permits in 215 cities in December declined to $266,210,510, the smallest monthly total since February, 1949, and 37.6 per cent under $426,607,027 in December, 1950, Dun Bradstreet reports.

The policy committee of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, representing twenty-one major Jewish organizations in eight Western nations, including the United States, yesterday pledged support of the $1,500,000,000 claims of the Israeli Government against Germany.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- In the past week the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares has broken through last year's low point of 115.5.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Jan. 13 to 19 are given in the following tabulation:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 20 (UP) -- A Negro leader blamed the South's "Talmadges" and "Byrneses" today for racial prejudice and for terrorism such as the recent wave of bombing in Florida.
