The Citizens Budget Commission, unofficial watchdog of the city treasury, predicted yesterday a basic real estate tax of $3.19 on each $100 of assessed valuation for the fiscal year beginning July 1. This would be a rise of eleven points above the current rate of $3.08, which has stood for the last two years as the highest in the city's history.

A warning that 200,000 automobiles might be locked in or out of 900 Manhattan and Bronx garages after next Monday as the result of a labor dispute was sounded yesterday by the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade.

On Tuesday of last week the financial representatives of eight British Commonwealth nations that are members of the so-called sterling area met in London to consider ways and means of protecting the pound, in which they have a common interest with Britain and which is facing its third major crisis since the war.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee today endorsed the Administration's "guns and butter" approach to the rearmament program.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, Jan. 20 -- Forty-one persons, including some believed to be guerrillas from Cairo universities, were detained today for investigation after British troops had cordoned off this city and cleared inhabitants from an Arab section.

Fear of a national aluminum strike receded last night when it became known that the White House was prepared to certify the dispute to the Wage Stabilization Board if Federal mediators failed to effect a peaceful settlement this week.

Arthur Godfrey, who happens to be one of the more likable and gifted individuals in show business, is also broadcasting's perennial bad boy. The comedian already has had one serious brush with the Federal Communications Commission for his lapses in taste, but last Friday in his morning radio program he really outdid himself.

About this time of the year every wardrobe needs pepping up. Sometimes a little item can do wonders. The early spring tonic we suggest today is the extra jacket. We offer you the spencer, the bolero and the little high-waisted Directoire toppit, all designed to make your between-spring-and-winter dressmaking problems easier, and all fashioned for easy sewing.

Many buyers were in the wholesale market here last week and more are expected this week to complete spring purchases, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Although a substantial volume of orders were placed, store budgets remained in an open-to-buy position.

Wild rice, always expensive, is exceptionally so today -- about $2.25 for twelve ounces. Since this robustly flavored accompaniment to pheasant, other game and poultry is not controlled by the Office of Price Stabilization, it is bound to be hit by inflation.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 20 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh won again in his uncompromising determination to avoid anything vaguely resembling the assumption of obligations on the part of Iran toward the United States, when the $23,000,000 Point Four United States technical aid program was brought into effect today without the signing of a technical implementation agreement.
BADMINTON, England, Jan. 20 -- In spite of wars, austerity and high taxation, fox hunting, which is almost synonymous with the name of England, is still flourishing mightily in this country.
America has many outstanding defense weapons, but one of the most valuable is its vast network of communications.
Outright hijackings are on the increase and there is a tendency toward indiscriminate thefts, it is reported by the Cargo Protection Bureau in summarizing trends in truck cargo theft losses.

City Councilman Charles E. Keegan, Bronx Democrat, announced yesterday his intention to introduce in the City Council tomorrow a bill to establish a uniform labor relations policy for city employes, which would operate through a nine-member board to handle grievances and wage and hour problems.

PELHAM, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Overlapping police work in Pelham Township's independent villages of Pelham, North Pelham and Pelham Manor was complicated enough for commuters and housewives before two brothers became rival chiefs of police.
Robert Baron and Nolan Thrope have formed a partnership to act as mill agents to national chains and buying syndicates on women's swimsuits and knitted outerwear. Their offices are at 1441 Broadway.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 -- Talk of softer steel demand (measured against record-breaking output) has gained ground in recent weeks. Not with producers alone has this theme been played but with some customers as well. Even if that were not enough it was clear that 1952 will not go down as a hectic steel shortage period because:
Rain and snow chased by a cold wave moved east yesterday in the wake of devastating West Coast storms, The United Press reported.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, landed at Logan Airport here this morning at the end of a thirty-two day aerial journey that had covered 28,000 miles and had included an eight-day visit to the front lines in Korea.

The arguments of the education and church groups who oppose U. M. T. seem to be based on the premise that its operation will be poorly done. Everything can be done wrong, even education and religious observance. To be fair, the educators must admit that recent scandals have shown that college athletics if poorly handled can be "fantastically expensive, educationally undesirable, morally hazardous."

Two young thugs who liked to use stolen Mercury cars in their hold-ups were captured yesterday morning by the police in Queens after their car crashed into a tree while they were being pursued. The men, according to the police, admitted eight hold-ups, using and later abandoning a stolen Mercury in each robbery.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, president of the Clergy Association of New York and Neighborhood, preached his first sermon yesterday morning as pastor of St. Paul's Lutheran Church. South Fifth and Rodney Streets, Brooklyn. He will be installed at a later date, succeeding the Rev. William G. Boomhower, who now has a pastorate in Troy.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 20 -- The Iranian Foreign Ministry disclosed tonight some of the documents that, it maintains, prove that British consuls in Iran have interfered with Iranian affairs. It was on the basis of this charge that the Iranian Government demanded a week ago in a note to the British Embassy that all British consulates in Iran be closed tomorrow.

DALLAS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Giles Edwin Miller, president of vast textile interests who got into professional football because he was such a keen fan, said today he foresaw immediate success of the game in Texas.

Among the suggestions made by the City Controller, Lazarus Joseph, for economies in our city government was the "non-filling of vacancies on the regular city payroll." As a lay visitor in one of our municipal hospitals I would like to state that this policy, which has been practiced for some time, has had an effect on the work of the Department of Hospitals that is nothing short of disastrous.

Greater use and better coordination of the nation's monetary powers is urged by seventeen prominent economists to prevent excess money demand for available goods and services while the defense program is being pushed.

The first of three upgrading schools for members of the Seafarers International Union is operating with a class of fifteen men undergoing intensive training preparatory to examinations for able seaman and other deck ratings

Within the next few months, according to the Soviet press, the Soviet Government will put into operation the Volga-Don Canal, Russia's equivalent of the Panama Canal. This waterway will permit continuous passage of sea-going vessels through the heart of the country and between the southern and northern seas bounding the Soviet Union.
Lonnie Ellison, a 26-year-old unemployed laborer, was arrested by Brooklyn police yesterday and charged with assault, robbery, burglary and rape.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 20 -- While Indian officials have resolutely declined to comment on the statement by Jacob A. Malik, Soviet delegate to the United Nations Security Council, backing India's claim to Kashmir, there is concern in informed circles here that Moscow should have chosen the Kashmir dispute for having a fling at the Western powers.
A special campaign for the enlistment of 300,000 volunteers needed for the city civil defense medical emergency division was begun yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 20 -- Congress appears to be veering from the idea of a law to deal with Communist domination of certain labor unions where their functions concern national security.

The manner in which Joseph Curran, national president, and other top ranking officials of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., have administered the affairs of that organization over the last four years was praised here yesterday in a report made public by the American Civil Liberties Union.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan, 20 -- A northwest blow, carrying puffs to thirty-five miles an hour, cut short today's dinghy regatta at Indian Harbor Yacht Club after two races had been staged. Three capsizings and one dismasting convinced the committee the little Dyer Dhows could take no more of the weather.

As a means of overcoming a shortage of engineers and scientists, this country's first course in the classroom use of radio-isotopes will be given to New York high school science teachers, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

Barkev Vartanyan, baritone, made his New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Despite the relatively minor nature of the event, it attracted newspaper photographers, for in private life Mr. Vartanyan is one of a clan that seldom gives song recitals.

Prices of cotton futures declined last week in response to unfavorable reports from the goods market anal reports of further mill curtailments. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week with net losses of 69 to 81 points, or $3.45 to $4.05 a bale.

COVINGTON, Ky., Jan. 20 (AP) -- George Remus, the "king of bootleggers," who was reputed to have piled up a $20,000,000 fortune during prohibition days, died at his home here today. The 78-year-old former Chicago attorney suffered a stroke Aug. 9, 1950.

The largest and most varied art exhibition of the week is that of "Portraits of Personalities, Past and Present," organized for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Presented at Portraits, Inc., it will open tomorrow afternoon with a preview, admission to which will be $2. Thereafter the charge will be 60 cents.

A collection of new furniture described as representative of the "American trend," together with two new groups that are contemporary in style, highlight the mid-winter show that opens today at Bamberger's in Newark.
Two importations from England comprise this week's new films. The programs follow:

The major effort on last night's League of Composers program -- at least in length -- was Vincent Persichetti's "Harmonium." The series of songs, settings of twenty-five poems by Wallace Stevens, lasted an hour and five minutes. Walter Piston's twenty - minute Quintet seemed a model of brevity by comparison.
HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 20 -- French-Vietnamese forces continued today their attacks against the strong pro-Soviet Vietminh concentrations along the highway northeast of Hoabinh.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt became today not only a citizen of honor but "the first citizen" of the little town of Lannoy, in the north of France. from which one of her late husband's ancestors departed in the seventeenth century to join the earliest settlement in New York.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 20 -- Although their girls built up a lead of ten seconds, the ski team of New York City Ski Council lost by 22 seconds to the team representing the New Jersey Council in the first annual intercouncil race at Mad River Glen today.

QUANTICO, Va., Jan. 20 -- Evidence has accumulated at the Marine Corps base here that the grades a man makes depend to some extent upon whether he is living in a comfortable steam-heated barrack or a cold, drab-looking, crowded Quonset hut.

The hundredth anniversary of the death of Louis Braille will be observed throughout 1952 in France, his native land. The world owes much to M. Braille for the invention of the system of reading and writing for the blind by the use of raised dots. The blind are ever in his debt, for through his efforts they were released from their narrow world.

THOMAS JEFFERSON SELLECK, 55 years old, forced into unwelcome retirement and complete physical inactivity by a coronary occlusion, asked himself serious questions for the first time in his busy life. His good friend, Doc Crocker, had told him that he must think differently as well as live differently if he wanted to go on living. "Why don't you write your memoirs?" the doc had asked.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Democratic legislators have been told that Mayor Impellitteri and his associates on the Board of Estimate have decided unanimously to ask the Legislature for a $63,000,000 increase in state aid to New York.

If the earnings of an insurance agent were satisfactory and secure, why should over 15,000 agents have gone out on strike for an assured take-home basic pay of $55 a week for fifty-two weeks a year? This basic rate, in addition to the commissions earned, would mean a living wage.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 20 -- Violent weather over much of Tunisia and the liberal deployment of force by French protectorate officials appeared today to have checked the series of outbursts of the last week by Tunisian nationalists demanding home rule and protesting the arrest of their leaders.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Most official and private circles connected with foreign trade are convinced that, at the present level of French prices, France's exports are doomed to stagnation if not to a sharp decline.

Two kinds of men live in American homes -- the handy and the unhandy. The first group look with calm understanding on every piece of machinery and gadgetry in the home, from broken window batches, leaking faucets and blown fuses on to burned-out toasters.

In your editorial "A $257,000 Daily Loss" you again came out for a subway fare raise "that will cover operation cost." Yet never in your many editorials on the matter have you explained how such a raise will solve, more than temporarily, the growing deficit of the rapid transit system.

If, as had been reported from Texas, Giles Miller, the textile man, who heads the Dallas syndicate about to take over the New York Yanks National Football League franchise, is en route here with legal papers and a $100,000 check to seal the deal, he will find no commissioner in this town.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 20 -- The National Council Against Conscription charged today that the proposed universal military training program was designed not for the development of trained soldiers, but for the "indoctrination of civilians to insure their support of national military policy."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- With wind creeping up to twenty-five miles an hour, but only half that force to begin with, the dinghy fleet at the Larchmont Yacht Club went out today and managed to get in two races.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, tonight reproved the supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a Republican Presidential candidate for an inability to take their own medicine.

The Korean negotiation drags on. There is no real meeting of minds, no approach, as yet, to the underlying issues. It is increasingly apparent that there is some master plan behind the repeated tactic of obstruction. If that plan is essentially a Communist play for time, it is only natural that one should ask to what use the time gained will be put.

God's great enunciations of birth, purpose and sacrifice are too often misunderstood by Christians and by not accepting them in the proper spirit we are "failing elaborately where we might succeed simply," the Rev. Quintin Warner, Canon of St. Paul's Cathedral in London, Ont., said yesterday at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.
Americans write five billion checks a year, or fourteen million a day, and these checks cover 90 per cent of the exchange of money in this country.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- British track and field athletes, both men and women, are training more systematically than ever before in the determination to make a good showing at the Helsinki Olympic games -- if funds can be raised to pay their fare.

Artcraft Hosiery Mills is planning an extensive campaign of local newspaper advertising in ten major cities, including New York, to inform consumers of the quality land styling of its product. The company's appropriation is $300,000 for advertising of an institutional nature to run twice weekly in newspapers.
New York has "a more efficient" Department of Welfare than it has had for many years, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy declared yesterday in issuing his department's annual report.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks' experiment with Sunday afternoon hockey paid off with 13,614 fans today, even though the last-place home team lost, 3 -- 1, to the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Paul Ronty's freak unassisted goal in the third period carried the New York Rangers to a 3-to-2 victory over the league-leading Detroit Red Wings tonight in a rough National Hockey League game at Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Truman's budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, expected to run to more than $82,000.000,000, reaches Congress tomorrow with the prospect that despite economy moves it will fare better than the accompanying request for about $5,000,000,000 in new taxes.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 20 -- A breathtaking second run down the thirty-gate slalom course that dropped 400 feet in its 2,000-foot length enabled Tommy Corcoran, Dartmouth's 20 - year - old Canadian sophomore, to take major honors today as the fifth annual Captain Victor Constant Memorial Alpine ski competition ended.

Last year the Salvation Army gave individual counseling and provided comfortable, low-cost lodgings in its centers to 292,404 men and 230,094 women. Some 4,732 New York families who found themselves in difficulty brought their troubles to the Army's family service bureau and received much-needed guidance and assistance.
Prime Minister Churchill will give a farewell address to the nation "on matters of importance" at 1 P. M. tomorrow from the steps of City Hall, the Mayor's Reception Committee announced last night.

City Council President Rudolph Halley announced yesterday that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company had agreed to drop eviction proceedings against nineteen tenants of its Stuyvesant Town housing project whose leases expired last October.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 20 -- Continued improvement in the external monetary position again was shown by last week's return of the Netherlands Bank which recorded a further rise in foreign exchange and gold reserves of 71,000,000 to 1,753,000,000 guilders.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20 -- A marriage counseling clinic, under the joint sponsorship of the Department of Psychiatry and the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of the Yale School of Medicine, will be opened here this spring.

Two bonding companies that guaranteed thousands of television service contracts may soon find themselves in the TV servicing business as the result of thefts by servicing employes of the Conlan Electric Company. The losses are said to total more than $400,000 over a five-year period.
On the night of his sixty-first birthday, and in the forty-fourth year since he first played in the United States in 1908, Mischa Elman gave an anniversary recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

Four years ago both major parties went into the Presidential campaign pledged to statehood for Alaska and Hawaii. The Democratic platform used the adjective "immediate," whereas the more cautious Republicans preferred "eventual." These pledges have not been kept.
DALLAS, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Giles Miller, youthful textile executive, had professional football in Texas today, but was busy denying offers he was reported to have made for Doak Walker and other stars.

A new 190-horsepower engine is among improvements offered in the 1952 "Golden Anniversary" line presented yesterday by the Cadillac Motor Car division, General Motors Corporation. The engine is of V-8 design, has a compression ratio of 7.5 to 1 and is described as the most powerful ever installed in Cadillac cars.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman announced plans today for a $5,000,000,000 to $6,000,000,000 expansion of atomic energy facilities over a period of about five years.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The touring New York Metropolitan ice hockey team, spurred to a special effort by the presence of Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway as a spectator, scored a stirring 5-to-4 victory over the all-Japan team tonight, sending in the deciding goal in the final 26 seconds.

Broken homes -- broken lives -- too often they take their toll of children to whom no blame can be attached. In 146 Salvation Army-investigated and supervised foster homes, love and peace are provided for young victims of family tragedy.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art was visited by 2,263,336 persons in 1951, the sixth successive year that attendance has exceeded 2,000,000, the trustees announced yesterday at the eighty-second annual meeting of members of the Corporation of the Museum.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 21 -- A Vietminh counter-attack failed to dislodge French troops from an important hill commanding the Hoabinh highway yesterday as fighting continued for control of the single road linking the French-held Hoabinh pocket to Hanoi. The latest battle along the high-flanked western end of the highway went into its fourth day today with strong Communist-led Vietminh forces still menacing the route from bases in rugged territory to the south.

The Joint Distribution Committee agreed yesterday to provide a minimum of $850,000 for the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, the principal agency offering vocational training to Jews overseas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Following is the text of President Truman's budget message:

A general reduction in refined sugar prices was a bullish factor on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. With several leading refiners cutting their prices from 8.25 to 8.15 cents a pound, both sugar contracts gained 3 to 5 points.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan, 22 -- Discussion of terms for an armistice in the Korean war reached a state of virtual suspension this morning when, for the third successive day, the United Nations and Communist delegates adjourned after a ten-minute session in which neither had anything new to propose.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Members of the State Board of Regents will meet this week with representatives of the State Commission on co-ordination of State Activities to protest certain aspects of the proposed reorganization of the board.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- One hundred exiled diplomats from ten eastern European countries met here today to express a common aspiration for closer European cooperation when conditions in their homelands permit.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- At the end of a twelve-hour meeting with only a half-hour break for lunch, the Cabinet announced tonight that military appropriations would be increased by $200,000,000 in the coming fiscal year 1952-53, and by a like amount in 1953-54.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower told an audience of France's leading statesmen and savants today that the "challenge of our time" was to win the peace. At the same time he warned that the search must be conducted simultaneously in every field of human activity.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, Jan. 21 -- A pitched battle between British troops and Egyptians was fought in a Moslem cemetery here today. One British officer was seriously wounded, one Egyptian was killed and another wounded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- It is regrettable but true that the long-range programs directly and collaterally related to the military security of the non-Communist world, invoked by the President and approved in principle and detail by Congress, make it almost impossible for Congress at this point substantially to reduce the executive budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman's budget request for 7,400 additional employes for the Bureau of Internal Revenue came under scrutiny today in House hearings on the Presidential plan for reorganizing the agency.

ON Feb. 2, 1650, a girl child was born in the city of London who was destined to achieve one of the most celebrated rags-to-riches success stories of all history. Her father was nameless. Her mother was the drunken proprietor of a bawdy house. Her childhood was spent in the foulest slums of seventeenth-century London. Her first job was as a barmaid in her mother's establishment.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 21 (UP) -- Dock strikes paralyzed Puerto Rico's principal ports today, halting both incoming and outgoing shipments.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- For the first time in five years, the Soviet Union declined today to attend a meeting, to discuss the peace treaty for Austria.

Harry Gross finally told his own story yesterday of his short-lived flight from police custody last fall just before he wrecked the state's case by refusing to testify against eighteen present and former plainclothes men accused of taking gambling graft from him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- The International Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners has notified Local 644 of the Painters Union that its charter has been revoked and has advised the membership, believed to number about 300, to seek new affiliation with other American Federation of Labor craft locals in the motion-picture field.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Murder, torture and bloody riots in this island prison camp of the United Nations have created what officials here call one of the toughest prison administration problems of modern times.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Meeting with reporters on Saturday to discuss in advance the contents of the 1,222-page document, known in Washington Government parlance as the "Telephone Book," President Truman said he was convinced as in the past that the budget was in every way correct.

Depositors in savings banks of this state may soon receive as much as 2 1/2 per cent interest on their money instead of the present 2 per cent to which they are limited by current state banking regulations.

Cardinal Spellman returned here early yesterday morning, completing a round-the-world trip that included a Christmas visit with the troops in Korea, and troops at Rome and other points. He arrived here by train from Boston, and was met by his brother and sister-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. John W. Spellman; James Tynion, secretary of the Knights of Malta, and three members of the clergy.

OTTAWA, Jan. 21 (Canadian Press) -- A new method to find oil fields may result from experiments being conducted with the airborne scintellometer, the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy was told today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- Speaking in the presence of Premier Stalin and members of the Politburo, Peter Pospelov, high Communist party theoretician, declared tonight that Asia was aflame with a revolution that "no force whatsoever can stop."

Immediate placement of small orders with a minimum of first day shopping by small store owners and buyers featured the opening yesterday of the winter furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange. Several low-priced bedroom furniture factories exhibited with prices 8 to 10 per cent lower than those quoted at the national market in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Premier Willem Drees of the Netherlands saw President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson today in the first of a series of conversations that may have an important, and perhaps even a decisive, effect on the formation of the six-nation European army.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Representative Peter F. Mack Jr., flying a little plane he had borrowed from the Smithsonian Institution, landed here today to complete the final ocean hop of his goodwill flight, around the world.

Financing effectuated by issuers of securities privately during 1951 totaled $5,033,098,837, according to a preliminary report yesterday by the Investment Dealers' Digest, trade publication. This is an increase of $1,487,666,322 over the Digest's final total for 1950, and the first time that private placements have exceeded $5,000,000,000 in any one year.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Legislature approved unanimously tonight Governor Dewey's proposal for a joint legislative committee to study the state's chaotic Sunday "blue laws" with a view to bringing them into line with modern customs.
The continuing climatic feud between the Sunshine State and the Golden State has produced a new scene in the hundred-year-old play that has featured Florida and California in the two starring roles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Lieut. Gen P. T. Mow and Col. V. S. Hsiang, former Chinese Air Force officers, asked libel damages amounting to $4,000,000 in an answer filed in United States District Court here today to the suit brought against them by the Republic of China.

A City Hall reception, to have been held at 1 P. M. today in honor of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, has been canceled because the visiting 77-year-old British statesman is suffering from a "slight" head cold.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- The stage was set for a resumption of trade between the East and West zones of Germany as responsible officials, both here and in Bonn, today indicated agreement is now possible on the key issue of unrestricted trade to and from West Berlin.

Secretary Acheson has urged upon the Senate the prompt ratification of the Japanese peace treaty and the Pacific security pacts. We concur heartily in this recommendation. There is much to be gained by early and decisive action. There is something to be lost by delay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The country's highest diplomatic and military authorities asked the Senate today to approve the Japanese Peace Treaty and the three accompanying defense pacts arraying the democratic world in the Far East.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Three pessimistic volumes printed in 1659 entitled "New-England, a Degenerate Plant" brought 460 ($1,288) when another part of the Harmsworth collection of Americana, considered the finest outside the United States, was sold at auction today was at Sotheby's.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Members of Loyola University's defunct football squad will begin a mass exodus next week to other colleges around the nation. Following final examinations on Friday, at least fifteen football players will start moving to schools where they can continue participating in the sport. Loyola canceled its football program last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A Government agency told Congress today that the railroad-airline labor law faced a "complete breakdown" if strikes in the two industries continued much longer at recent rates.

Through the door, left ajar by the bearer of the morning mail, came a familiar, and not altogether pleasant, aroma and a wheezing sound which suggested that someone was having difficulty with the draw of a pipe.
A Brooklyn Union Gas Company official testified yesterday that by 1956 the utility would have increased its output of gas for heating purposes by 221 per cent over 1950.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- The influential London Times charged today that the United States has been carrying on a private price war with the tin producers of the world.

The Celotex Corporation realized a net profit of $3,497,371 after taxes and all charges from net sales of $59,241,634 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, according to the annual report to stockholders issued yesterday by O. S. Mansell, president.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Over the opposition of the United States, the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly adopted today a resolution declaring that a definition of aggression was possible and desirable.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the Burlington County Bridge Commission today to continue operation of two Delaware River toll bridges purchased in a transaction described by the court as "fraught with fraud and corruption."

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Allied night raiders attacked a Communist hill position on the Korean western front twice yesterday, but withdrew after a two-hour battle with Chinese Reds. The raiding patrol disengaged at 4 A. M., after it had received a "heavy concentration" of Red machine-gun fire, hand grenades and small arms, according to a United States Eighth Army communique.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Dewey urged the Legislature tonight to increase the maximum statutory benefits payable under the sickness compensation law from $26 to $30 a week, putting them on a par with unemployment insurance benefits.

A proclamation designating the period beginning today and ending Jan. 30 as Salvation Army Week was issued at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri. He urged the people of the city to support the Salvation Army's program of humanitarian service.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Reliable sources report from Cairo that Abd-el Krim, former Emir of the Riff and hero of the Moroccan independence war in the early Nineteen Twenties, who is now a politcal refugee in Egypt, doubts there has been a basic change in policy in Spanish Morocco on the part of Madrid authorities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman's $85,444,000,000 budget for the fiscal year to start next July prompted a bipartisan chorus in Congress today to demand sharp cutbacks in nondefense requests and a tough scrutiny of military items for a weeding out of waste, duplications and "frills."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- State Department officials expressed surprise today that the technical assistance program of about $10,000,000 for Pakistan had occasioned disappointment in Karachi Government circles.

The appointment of F. S. Elfred as executive vice president, B. E. Bassett as vice president for production and M. W. Acker as a vice president of Olin Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday by John M. Olin, president.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 (AP) -- C. W. Winters' Whirla Lea, a fleet filly out of the Midwest, showed her heels to a small but select field of 3-year-old misses in the $5,000 Orange Blossom Purse before 16,907 at Hialeah Park today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The Defense Production Administration reported today that it had granted more rapid-tax write-off certificates to railroad companies than to any other industrial group.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 21 -- The Indian Government has entered into partnership with the Scindia Steam Navigation Company, a leading Indian concern, for expanding the shipbuilding industry as a joint enterprise, the Ministry of Works Production and Supply announced today.

A 39-year-old Israeli diamond dealer was held in $25,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Edward McDonald, charged with smuggling $25,000 worth of gold bullion into this country from Canada.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 21 -- Having been host the past week-end to the Captain Vic Constant Memorial races, this skiland is looking forward to staging the national downhill, slalom and combined championships on March 22-23.

The Pine-Thomas producing unit at Paramount has a new picture lined up for Arlene Dahl after "Caribbean Gold." The title is "Jamaica Run," and it is based on a book by Max Hurray titled, "The Neat Little Corpse." Lewis R. Foster is writing the script and also will be the director.

The recent TIMES editorial endorsing Permanent Personal Registration amazed me. This piece of legislation has been fought by the enlightened citizens of our state for many years. It is a monstrosity that will not increase the number of citizens voting, but will enhance fraudulent voting and strengthen political machines.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 21 -- An examination of the Government's statistical analysis of the 1952 economic plan showed today that Yugoslav planners had allocated 41.3 per cent of this year's estimated national income to defense and capital investments.
PISA, Italy, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- The leaning tower of Pisa will lose its balance and topple over in the year 2151, according to an official calculation made public here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- President Truman, asking new billions for foreign aid, told Congress today the United States was about to speed up its arms deliveries to Western Europe, and other areas threatened by the Communists, under a new allocations policy.

A "self-portrait" of William Randolph Hearst, culled from his memoranda, letters, cables and telegrams compiled over a fifty-year span, is planned for late spring publication by Simon Schuster. Edited by Edmond D. Coblentz, publisher of The San Francisco Call-Bulletin and a close associate of the late publisher for more than fifty years, the book also will contain some of Mr. Hearst's verse, prophecies and candid cvomments on friends and enemies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Because of past confusion over budgetary terms, the Budget Bureau issued a six-page statement today explaining the difference between such things as "expenditures," "appropriations" and "obligational authority."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Representative E. E. Cox, Democrat of Georgia, assured Congress today that at least eight investigations were under way into charges that subversives had infiltrated the Army Signal Corps' top-secret intelligence agency.

Exhibitors representing seventy-five concerns throughout the country set up exhibits of $100,000,000 in both old and new Governmental and industrial surplus items yesterday in preparation for the First National Trade Show of Surplus Dealers, which opens today at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today supported a United States move initiated last December to split the proposed covenant on human rights into two, one covenant setting forth the long-established political rights and the other containing the more controversial economic and social rights.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter made his first Philadelphia appearance as world lightweight champion by scoring his second ten-round split decision in less than six months over Mario Trigo of Los Angeles tonight at the Arena. The New Yorker's title was not at stake.

A four-day series of luncheon meetings honoring Mrs. Felix M. Warburg was opened yesterday by the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York at the Tavern-on-the- Green. An overflow gathering of 500 Bronx women attended and pledged $41,000 toward the federation's campaign goal of $20,000,000 for its 116 affiliated institutions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Louis E. Heindel, advertising director of the Madison, Wis., newspapers, today urged the pooling of all newspaper advertising groups into a united front to launch a "strong newspaper selling front." He addressed the annual meeting of the Newspaper Advertising Executives' Association here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Seafarers' International Union, A. F. L., criticized the Government's handling of the manpower problem at a meeting called by the Maritime Administration today.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- Mr. Griffis commented that he was resigning because he felt his main task "to develop the beginning phase of new Spanish-American relationships and understanding has been completed."

The three January Presidential messages to Congress -- the message on the State of the Union, the economic message and the budget message -- have come to overlap at so many points that by the time the last of them appears it is unlikely to contain many major surprises for the public.

Cash dividends on common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange held virtually even last year. The decline from the record payments of 1950 was only 0.1 per cent. Fourteen of the twenty-seven industrial classifications showed gains. Twelve paid less. One held even.
TORONTO, Jan. 21 -- A return to thrift by Canada's 3,000,000 housewives is the goal of a campaign by women's organizations across the country, led by the National Council of Women.

WHENEVER professional baseball discovers that it owns a white elephant, it is stuck with it. The price of feeding and caring for the beast is high but there is always the hope that some new mahout will arrive with the proper formula for changing the pigmentation.

The functions of several agencies now financed by the city -- notably the Supreme, County, Municipal and City Courts and the Department of Hospitals -- would be designated as county services and charged to the yield of the proposed separate 1 1/2 per cent county real estate tax under a plan outlined to Democratic legislative chiefs yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

HAVING been subject to arbitrary regulations, which did not always coincide with conservation requirements, wildfowlers are a rather pessimistic group. Judging from comments received they do not expect much in the way of immediate relief as a result of the projected organization of wiidfowlers of the Atlantic flyway states.

A bride of three days and her husband were overcome by illuminating gas early yesterday morning as they slept in a furnished room at 159 East Eighteenth Street. The bride, Mrs. Jovina Gonzalez Chevore, 36 years old, died, but her husband, Israel, 26, was resuscitated and taken to Bellevue Hospital in a critical condition.

BELOIT, Wis., Jan. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that the pro-Communist policies of the State Department had "fully justified" the demands of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for an investigation of conditions in the department.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 -- All factors point to an outstanding year for the apparel trades, Max E. Weinstock, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, asserted here today.

While the Brooklyn Dodgers came up with three players agreeing to terms for 1952, the world champion New York Yankees undoubtedly stirred more interest in baseball circles yesterday with the signing of Joe Collins, first baseman-outfielder, for 1952.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 22 -- Emperor Hirohito told the Diet (Parliament) today that Japan faced difficulties and great responsibilities with restoration of national sovereignty under the peace treaty.

FREEPORT, Ill., Jan. 21 (UP) -- A Federal indictment today accused two brothers of converting 1,105,307 bushels of Government corn to their own use. The authorities said they had used false bins to deceive the Commodity Credit Corporation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 21 -- Assurances of a large demand for canned foods plus a growing labor shortage in the canning industry as the result of the defense effort is being reflected in the large number of orders being placed at the annual exhibit of the Canning Machinery and Supplies Association at Convention Hall here.
Open opposition by various factions in Congress to President Truman's budget request produced yesterday a sizable rally in the stock market.
The rapidly changing and expanding economy of South American countries offers a bright prospect for United States trade and business, according to A. V. Moore, president of the Moore-McCormack Lines.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the largest independent operating public utility west of the Mississippi, had a net income of $36,876,000 in 1951, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $2.14 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding in the year, and compared with $37,846,019, equal to $2.62 each on fewer shares in 1950. Gross revenues increased to $279,863,000 from $237,437,291.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The production of 3,800,000 passenger cars this year was forecast today by advisers to Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson. They also said that output curbs on other consumer goods might be eased.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Doubles platy again occupied the stage today as fans keenly awaited the resumption of singles and a possible meeting between Frank Sedgman and Dick Savitt in the Australian national tennis championships.

The Government filed yesterday in Federal Court a civil anti-trust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation, world's largest manufacturer of tabulating machines and tabulating cards, charging unlawful restraint and monopoly of the tabulating industry in the United States.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 21 -- The real reason for the Arabs objections to the United Nations project under John B. Blandford Jr. for the resettlement of Arab refugees in the opinion of Israeli Government officials, is that the Arab Governments do not really want to solve the refugee problem.

Evidences of the smoldering behind-the-scenes battle that has been going on for the presidency of the Board of Education were discernible in the voting yesterday, as Andrew G. Clauson Jr. of Richmond was elected to the post at a short but bitter special meeting.

Three former members of the Fire Department, scheduled to testify against James J. Moran, were held in protective custody yesterday by detectives of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's staff as a jury was completed in General Sessions to try Moran on charges of extortion and conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A program under which Federal attorneys throughout the country will investigate complaints of anti-trust violations more speedily and thoroughly than before was announced today by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath.

Differences of opinion over the proposed change in the Greater New York Fund's operating methods, to eliminate solicitation of funds from privately owned concerns and limit it to solicitation from publicly owned organizations developed yesterday among major agencies supported by the fund.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Union rejected today any compromise on the admission of new members to the United Nations, and announced it would not permit the admission of the new state of Libya unless the majority agreed to the Soviet proposal for en bloc admissions, including the election of five nations backed by Moscow -- Albania, Bulgaria, Hungary, Outer Mongolia and Rumania.

CAIRO, Jan. 21 -- British Embassy officials said tonight that an inquiry "of exhaustive nature" was in progress into Saturday's incident in Ismailia during which Sister Anthony (Bridget Anne Timbers), 52-year-old nun and a United States citizen, was shot dead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman submitted to Congress today a budget calling for $85,444,000,000 of expenditures to finance what he called the fight for security and peace in the 1953 fiscal year, which begins next July 1.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Queens County Republicans served notice tonight that they would not support a request from New York City to authorize a county real estate tax.

Father James Keller, founder and director of the Christopher movement, announced yesterday the plans for a new $10,000 Christopher contest, open to all individuals, including non-professional writers, which will begin on Ash Wednesday, Feb. 27.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman called on Congress today for another increase in postal rates to reduce the ever-rising deficit of the Post Office.

Paul Felix Warburg has been re-elected vice president of the National Jewish Hospital, nonsectarian free medical center for needy tubercular patients at Denver. Mr. Warburg also is chairman of the hospital's New York office.

The University of Illinois basketball team, which has been threatening for some time to take over the No. 1 spot in the weekly Associated Press poll, finally made it yesterday and dropped Kansas to second.

The Vocational Advisory Service will be the beneficiary of the performances of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet on the night of March 27 at the Warner Theatre and of "Don Juan in Hell' on the night of April 1 at a theatre to be announced. Mrs. Walter E. Beer Jr. and Mrs. L. Emmett Holt Jr. are co-chairmen of the executive committee for both events.
A threat by American Federation of Labor drivers to slow down operation of city-owned buses on Staten Island yesterday caused only minor interference with normal service.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Commonwealth Finance Ministers, who have been struggling for the last week to find a way out of the economic crisis that confronts them wound up their deliberations here today with a promise to spend less and earn more and to aim at the early restoration of the gold reserves in the hope of ultimate return to free convertibility of their currency.

There is no comfort in the monotonous regularity with which one has to say of French politics: "The more it changes the more it stays the same." Change -- real change -- is what France needs. The cards have been shuffled again, the same old pack of cards, and this time Edgar Faure, a Radical Socialist, has come out on top of the deck.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan inspected yesterday the Central Plan Reporting Desk set up in the Communications Division at Police Headquarters on Jan. 14. Similar desks are being placed in operation in each of the borough police headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman is expected to issue soon an order authorizing the deferment of apprentices from military service. The Selective Service System and the Department of Labor have jointly recommended the policy to the President.

A two-week institute on cerebral palsy, under the sponsorship of the Coordinating Council for Cerebral Palsy in New York City, Inc., opened yesterday at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

Many tables have been reserved for the thirty-second annual card party under the auspices of the Republican Committee of 100 to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Main Ballroom of the 'Plaza. Mrs. E. Dudley Haskell is general chairman of the benefit committee and Miss Isabel N. Atterbury heads the Republican Committee.

Arthur W. Wallander, director of civil defense here, announced yesterday that his office was preparing to present a new bill to the City Council for the protection of all volunteers. The measure would insure them while engaged in training, mock raids or on duty in actual enemy attacks.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Arab delegates to the United Nations General Assembly met twice with top representatives of the Soviet Union over the week-end and were reported to have made a new bid for Soviet support in their efforts to reduce Western influence in the Middle East.

The advisory council of the American Nurses Association asked yesterday for a clarification by its board of directors of its non-strike policy in instances where employers refuse to sit down in good faith to discuss working conditions.

The Riverdale Country School contributed $487.50 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to bring the day's total to $746.50 received from twenty-seven donors. The 1951-52 total has now reached $347,002.84.

Photographic impressions of classic marble heads, the Manhattan skyline, tulips, a ship's log and early American engravings make up some of the patterns on decorating fabrics designed by Miss Leize Rose Stewart, and now available on order at her studio, 80 West Fortieth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 -- Acquittal on nineteen counts of contempt of the United States Senate was ordered today for Stanley Cohen, former San Francisco head of the Continental Racing Wire Service, by Federal Judge Michael J. Roche.

Public Service Company of North Carolina, Inc., has borrowed privately $7,200,000 from institutional investors on 4 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1977, it was announced yesterday. The First Boston Corporation negotiated the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Three Kansas and Missouri officials protested today an application by the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company to abandon gas sales to the Gas Sehvice Company in the two states.

Ease of preparation, wide selection and quality usually are cited as reasons for buying frozen fruits and vegetables rather than the fresh or canned. But the State Extension Service has just prepared a chart on comparative costs of vegetables in these three forms that illustrates several instances in which the frozen item also is the most economical.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 21 -- The United States Government has agreed to grant Pakistan between $8,000,000 and $12,000,000 in technical assistance for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1952. The agreement for the Point Four help will be signed here within the next few days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senate Republicans moved today to force a debate in their attempts to have Dr. Philip C. Jessup, Ambassador at large, ousted as a member of this country's delegation to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A three-point legislative program of aid for service men and war veterans, including readjustment benefits for veterans of the Korean conflict, was outlined by President Truman today in his budget message.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Pentagon officials are discussing a successor to take over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's European command if the general comes home to promote his Presidential campaign, Representative Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The possibility of an atomic attack on the United States was not overlooked by President Truman in his budget message.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Corn was again the leader on the bull side of the grain market here today, although there was a strong tone also in other grains. Buying of corn was on a broad scale, and profit-taking sales were absorbed easily on the recession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman asked Congress in his Budget Message today to authorize for the 1953 fiscal year an additional $52,359,014,000 to build the nation's military strength, including $14,000,000,000 for planes.

Products that have been described as an answer to many a jet pilot's prayer were displayed yesterday at the Governor Clinton Hotel. There the Dow Corning Corporation of Midland, Mich., showed insulation materials, boots for the actuators of cowl flaps and deicers and other material that worked just as well at 100 or more degrees below zero, Fahrenheit, and 1,000 or more degrees above.

Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois warned last night that race clashes "could take place, given a little encouragement, in scores of American communities." Governor Stevenson was among the speakers at a dinner of the National Urban League at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, called yesterday on Government and industry to work together now on inventing and planning "the weapons of 1960 and 1970."

The net income of the New York Central Railroad last year was between $14,000,000 and $15,000,000 after charges and taxes, Gustav Metzman, president, told newsmen yesterday. This would equal between $2.17 and $2.33 a share, and would compare with $18,315,170 or $2.84 each on the 6,447,410 capital shares outstanding in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Two bankers told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the low earnings and shrinking revenues of railroads are making securities of the carriers unattractive to investors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, introduced in the House today a bill to create a Department of Overseas Information, to be headed by a Secretary with Cabinet rank.

Ira A. Hirschmann, who founded the New Friends of Music with Hortense Monath sixteen years ago, has resigned his position as its president. Miss Monath will carry on as program director for the remainder of the season, and the chamber music programs will run as previously scheduled.

An editorial in THE TIMES of Jan. 15 contains a sharp attack on a report entitled "Measures for International Economic Stability" recently submitted to the United Nations by a group of five economists, of whom I was one.

Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that as part of his drive for severe economy in municipal operations to help balance the 1952-53 expense budget, he would ask all city departments and agencies to justify the provisional employes on their payrolls.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Two Jews accused of being members of an alleged Zionist underground were hanged here today on public gallows.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday sent official notice to Jersey Joe Walcott, world heavyweight champion, that unless he agreed within fifteen days to defend his title against a legitimate challenger the board would withdraw recognition of the Camden (N. J.) veteran as champion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today temporarily blocked a proposal to increase the all-water rates on freight moving out of Sacramento, Calif., to Atlantic Seaboard ports.

Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, who played at Town Hall on Sunday for the New Friends of Music, played there last night on his own behalf. It was his first New York recital in two years. He repeated the Sonata he had played the day before, Beethoven's Op. 69. Only this time he had his accompanist, Artur Balsam, as his partner instead of Karl Ulrich Schnabel.

Encouraged by the wide public demand for tickets to "Desire Under the Elms," which auspiciously launched the American National Theatre and Academy's 1952 Play Series last week, Robert Whitehead, managing director of the program, decided yesterday to extend the run of the Eugene O'Neill classic for two weeks.

The return of the gear and personal effects of thirty seamen, withheld when they quit the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Trader at Kobe, Japan, last October, was ordered yesterday by the United States District Court, according to the National Maritime Union, C.I.O.

Sales volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended last Saturday was 15 per cent below the corresponding week of 1951, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 21 -- Colonial Williamsburg, the ever-growing restoration of a historic past in this small community, once the capitol of the Virginia Colony, opened today the latest addition to the reconstructed community.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Desperate for scrap steel with which to meet the 38,000,000-ton quota fixed for this year by the National Production Authority, the Government has turned to possible sources of high grade scrap represented by disused trolley and railroad track in the country. According to unofficial estimates by the N. P. A., the tonnage of scrap available from obsolete trackage throughout the country will run into hundreds of thousands of tons.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,136, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):
The Congress of Industrial Organizations established a special committee yesterday to oust leftwing unions from the social service field in this city.
TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- A balanced budget of $198,150,862 without resort to new taxes was proposed today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to the New Jersey Legislature.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 21 -- Gov. Frank J. Lausche said today he had urged Michael V. DiSalle, Director of the Office of Price Stabilization, to be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in Ohio's May primaries.
As an old-timer in the Boy Scout movement whose interest has never lagged I hope that you will find space for this message to all graduate Scouts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Truman asked Congress today to raise the Voice of America to a shout.

A report recommending that the city approve plans of the Port of New York Authority for construction of the proposed $85,000,000 third tube for the Lincoln Tunnel was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- New standards for public mental hospitals were set today in the official "Standards for Psychiatric Hospitals and Clinics," sponsored by the American Psychiatric Association and released by its president, Dr. Leo H. Bartemeier of Detroit.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 44 to 62 points net higher yesterday than on Saturday, with volume of business moderate.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 21 (UP) -- Australian Jim Ferrier, shooting some of the finest golf of his brilliant career, carded an eight-under-par 64 for the first day leadership in the $5,000 Palm Springs invitational tourney.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett said in the Knesset (Parliament) tonight the Government had reliable information that two Iraqi Jews hanged in Baghdad today for an alleged bomb plot were innocent. "It was judicial murder," Mr. Sharett declared.

Legislation to transfer title of little known Mill Rock Island in the East River from the Federal Government to the city was introduced in Congress yesterday by Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Emanuel Celler. The Park Department wants control of the irregular eight-acre tract off Ninety-sixth Street to bar possible commercial exploitation, but it has no intention of developing the property.

The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city set up a joint committee yesterday to end jurisdictional raids, cross-picketing and other destructive competition between rival unions.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 21 -- Three Tunisian nationalists were killed and thirty wounded today in Tunis and other cities in new clashes between French security forces and crowds demonstrating against continued French political control of Tunisia.

The budget presented to Congress yesterday by President Truman is based on the assumption that there will be no general war before the end of the next fiscal year, July 1, 1953, and on the hope, which is only a hope, that the Korean war will end before the fiscal year starts July 1, 1952.

Byron Janis gave his third Carnegie Hall recital last night and dazzled his numerous listeners into long applause. He is a performer of rare dexterity and control of the keyboard for his years, and a musician who knows how to search out the real shape of a composition.

A suit to prevent License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey from banning the newstand sale of Sunshine and Health, and Sun Magazine, nudist publications, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by O. John Rogge, counsel for the publishers and distributors of the periodicals.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The main interest on the stock market here today was centered on foreign issues, while home industrials sagged slightly from neglect.

A tract of twenty-seven acres on the west side of Glen Cove Road, about 200 feet north of Roff Avenue, in North Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by Jerrold R. Golding and Margaret Dilliard to Birchwood Park Homes, represented by David Holman.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Tim O'Connell bunched all four of his field goals during the last minute of overtime play to give Boston College a 64-51 victory over Dartmouth tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The White House announced the imminent retirement of Stanton Griffis as Ambassador to Spain today and the appointment of Henry S. Villard of New York as the first United States Minister to the United Kingdom of Libya.

Judge Leo F. Rayfiel, in Brooklyn Federal Court, received assurances yesterday from representatives of two bonding companies that 20,000 television set owners would continue to get service despite the bankruptcy of the Conlan Electric Corporation of 1042 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. The Massachusetts Bonding Company and the Manufacturers Casualty Company Will handle the contracts through a servicing unit.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Arab spokesmen accepted today a revised $250,000,000 plan for aid to Arab refugees, but Syria and Lebanon implied that their support was conditional on Western concessions regarding the basis for continuation of the Palestine Conciliation Commission.
Sculpture-like shapes distinguish some of the four new ceramic lamp bases designed by Margot Kempe, ceramicist and metal worker. They are available at Ernst Schwadron, 757 Madison Avenue.

The original tempera picture for the American Red Cross 1952 fund campaign was unveiled yesterday in a brief ceremony at the New York Red Cross Chapter headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue. The picture, work of Joseph Binder of 100 Central Park South, will illustrate virtually all campaign material -- billboards, window posters, leaflets, and newspaper and television advertising.

In the struggle for peace and national security the United States is being called upon to spend $65 billions during the coming fiscal year for major defense projects. Of this sum $52.4 billions are earmarked for our own armed forces and $10.5 billions to bolster up -- politically, morally and economically -- a free world large enough for us to breathe in.
MIAMI, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Paul L. Kelley's Ignition ran the fastest six furlongs of the meeting as he easily captured the featured $5,000 Indian Creek Purse at Hialeah Park today.

Dr. Dryden L. Phelps, missionary, whose enthusiasm for the Chinese Communists led to his recall from West China, presented his resignation yesterday to the board of managers of the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society.

Fifty-three young mothers in wheelchairs, one with a sidecar seat for her 16-month-old son, all recent victims of infantile paralysis, started yesterday the final week of recruiting for the Mother's March on Polio by promising to enlist proxies to do their fund raising on the evening of Jan. 30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report strongly endorsed today President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 22 -- A million-dollar plan to overhaul student living conditions at Williams College, including broad changes in campus fraternity life, was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- John Foster Dulles, the Administration's Republican foreign policy adviser, called on the United States today to take up a "positive" policy in Asia.

Prime Minister Churchill sailed at 1:10 A. M. today aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary for his homeland after a seventeen day visit with Government leaders in the United States and Canada. Even in his final hours here the statesman was preaching British-American unity against Communist aggression.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- A conciliatory reply received today from the Belgian Government was considered by other delegations meeting here as providing, at last, the basis for an agreement on a European army when the Foreign Ministers of the six negotiating countries reassemble Saturday.

Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati Negro who formerly held the title, yesterday was established by the New York State Athletic Commission as the first challenger of Jersey Joe Walcott, the world heavyweight champion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, sole importer and seller of tin, advanced its price 18 1/2 cents a pound today to $1.21 1/2 on dock, New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Truman asked Congress today to act on mine safety measures at once.

During the third annual Children's Dental Health Week, beginning Feb. 4, free dental examinations will be given to selected groups of children from the Boy Scout, Girl Scout and Camp Fire Girl organizations, it was announced yesterday by the Oral Hygiene Committee of Greater New York, an affiliate of the American Dental Association.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,476, against 3,668 last week and 2,181 in the corresponding week of last year, according to the listing appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,167 arrivals yesterday, compared with 1,427 last Tuesday.

The glut of citrus fruit in Florida, particularly oranges, threatens all but the frozen orange concentrate markets, it was said here yesterday. One report said that growers were offering the fruit free to anyone who would pick it.

Leading New York Democrats, whose first choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination is President Truman, have nevertheless been assaying other possible candidates in the event that he should decide not to run.

The pilot of the ill-fated twin engine American Airlines Convair that crashed yesterday in Elizabeth, N. J., was making a bad weather instrument landing, officially known as I. L. S. (instrument landing system). It is essentially a radio type landing aid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Truman Administration supporters were reported tonight to be planning a decisive effort in Illinois to set back, if not wreck, the Presidential aspirations of Senator Estes Kefauver, Tennessee Democrat, whose formal announcement of his own candidacy is expected at a press conference here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- David Perlman, 33 years old, a writer for The San Francisco Chronicle, was named winner tonight of the second William the Silent Award for the story "most conducive to an appreciation of the democratic affinity between the Netherlands and the United States."
Gross operating revenues and net income of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation in 1951 were the highest on record, Earle J. Machold, the president, reported yesterday.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 22 Nationalist demonstrators and French troops clashed in a two-hour battle tonight in the seaport city of Sousse, 100 miles south of here. Nine Tunisians and the senior French Army commander in the area were killed and twenty-six persons were wounded.
CAIRO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- British troops herded Egyptians behind rolls of barbed wire and widened their hunt for snipers and arms in Ismailia today.

Both the O'Dwyer and Impellitteri city administrations were involved in a Fire Department shakedown racket, a prosecution key witness testified yesterday. He said the racket was headed by James J. Moran under Mayor William O'Dwyer, and by Frank Sampson in the current administration.

Your editorial of Jan. 12 on U. M. T. effectively answers the arguments against U. M. T. advanced last week by the Association of American Colleges. However, your editorial contains a fallacy, a common fallacy, unfortunately. It is that "the creation of a large reservoir of partially trained citizens" is the principal aim and end-result of U. M. T.

Directors of United Air Lines, Inc., yesterday announced a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a common share, payable on March 15. The airline distributed dividends of 75 cents a share in December and July, 1951.

It can hardly have escaped the notice of readers of this newspaper in recent weeks that much optimistic information has been coming out of Madrid concerning relations with the United States, while a deep silence is all that emanates from Washington. Since the contrast is calculated to bewilder readers it will be of service to set the record straight.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP) --The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following winter sports forecasts and skiing conditions:

Harry Gross denied under oath yesterday that he had been paid to scuttle the state's case against eighteen present and former policemen accused of taking gambling graft by refusing to testify against them last September.

A home away from home is what an average of ten women students find each semester in the Placement Bureau of Hunter College. Students who would be unable to continue with their studies because they could not afford to commute to the college, have no parents, or come from broken families are placed by the bureau in "opportunity homes" in midtown Manhattan.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Orator Francis Woodward, 66-year-old heir to the Jell-o millions, fell eight floors to his death just before daylight today from his $1,600-a-month hotel suite here. A coroner said it was suicide.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- After a confidential plan for the demilitarization of Kashmir, drawn up by Gen. Jacob L. Devers, had been made public here today, Indian delegates to the United Nations immediately denied that it ever had been presented to New Delhi officials.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Jan. 22 (AP) -- West Germany, Italy and Japan today offered to collaborate with a United Nations investigation of the fate of hundreds of thousands of World War II prisoners they believe are still held in the Soviet Union.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Moonrush, winner of the 1951 Santa Anita handicap today took the $7,500 Santa Monica Palisades purse. It was Moonrush's first victory of the Santa Anita Park meeting.

BONN, Germany Jan. 22 -- The United States High Commissioner's Office disclosed today the results of a survey on the attitude of Germans toward German Unity. The study revealed that less than half of those questioned believed the West was more favorable than the East to reunification of the country.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 22 -- A woman, pulled screaming from her suddenly flattened kitchen, was the only person in the house saved this afternoon when a twin-engined airliner with twenty-three aboard plunged out of the fog and rain and embedded itself in the heart of her frame house, dragging the roof and walls down around it.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- "Wozzeck," the controversial opera by Alban Berg which Hitler once ordered suppressed, was presented tonight for the first time in England at Covent Garden and was received with the usual mixed reactions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UP) -- A Republican move to investigate Attorney General J. Howard McGrath was backed today by the second-ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- John C. Lynn, legislative director of the American Farm Bureau Federation, warned the House Armed Services Committee today that full implementation of the Universal Military Training plan would mean that 11,900,000 men would be in Army training camps during the summer of 1959, even though no general war was in progress.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 22 -- Despite the increase in competition among manufacturers, observance of fair commercial practices in the relationship of the nation's retailers and the billion-dollar coat and suit industry has been fully maintained, it was asserted here today by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- President Truman described Robert P. Patterson tonight as "a great American and a great public servant."

The International Business Machines Corporation has arranged to borrow $115,000,000 from the Prudential Insurance Company on 3 3/4 per cent notes to mature on Jan. 1, 2052, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the accounting mchine company.
CASABLANCA, North Africa, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- Little hope was held today for the salvage of the United States freighter Newberry Victory, aground in the outer harbor of Casablanca.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22 -- Sol Lesser, who has been turning out the assorted adventures of Tarzan since 1943, is on the trail of a new series dealing with primitive life. This time the producer intends to use a girl as the central character.

The four-story apartment house accommodating forty-four families on a plot about 100 by 112 feet at 3420 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Eva Farber and Minnie Gussoff to the 878 Driggs Avenue Realty Corporation, represented by Irving Waxman, attorney. The Title Gurantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $135,000.

The bodies of two men of a seven-man riding crew aboard the Liberty ship Jesse Applegate were removed by a Coast Guard cutter as the ship passed her second day at anchor in the open sea ten miles off Montauk Point.

VIENNA, Jan. 22 -- Prospects for the conclusion of a peace treaty having been pushed into an indefinite future by Russia's negative attitude, Austria's coalition government tonight reorganized itself for the problems it believes lie ahead.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- A series of ten State Banking Department bills and a group of sixteen bills proposed by the State Insurance Department were introduced into the Legislature today, most of them removing inconsistencies in the present law or making technical changes to cover contingencies not foreseen when present provisions were enacted.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- As the North Atlantic Treaty Organization prepares to streamline its own structure it is fully conscious of the progress the Allies have made in the past year in improving their collective defenses against the Soviet threat. The Russian bloc still has an admitted edge, but it is gradually diminishing and it is believed that within a year this edge will have been blunted.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 22 -- Southern furniture, a neglected subject that has of late engrossed antiquarians and students of early American history and artifacts, proved an absorbing topic last night and today for registrants attending the Fourth Annual Antiques Forum at Colonial Williamsburg.

Early in the spring of each year, hundreds of boys and girls in the city streets begin to think longingly of woodland lakes and sunlit beaches. Providing vacations for these youngsters in camps and in the mountains is a happily anticipated event in the Salvation Army.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Santa Anita's director of racing, Carleton F. Burke, tonight virtually invited Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt to withdraw his stable from the track after the noted horseman criticized its stewards and racing strip.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Prices improved moderately on the stock markets here today, with the infusion of a little more confidence after the Commonwealth Finance Ministers' conference.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., and Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., survived a four - set struggle in 105.8-degree heat today to reach the doubles semi-finals in the Australian tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The House of Representatives was told today that the Executive Department of the Government was "much concerned" and was seeking to negotiate for relief in the amount of taxes levied by foreign Governments against huge expenditures made by the United States for the mutual defense of Europe against aggression.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 22 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, urged here yesterday that the countries of Europe officially call a constitutional convention to "examine and actually cope with" the problems of a "greater political and economic unity" and that such a convention report its findings "within a year or a year and a half."

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Grain futures generally showed a strong tone on the Board of Trade here today most of the session, but there was considerable profit-taking in the late trading, with prices receding a little from the early high spots but closing strong on commission buying.

The Canadian dollar rose to parity with the United States dollar yesterday for the first time since August, 1939. Lowest quotation of the day was 99.968 cents, shortly after the opening, but this was followed by the jump to par for a net gain of 1/16 cent over Monday's final level. Business was in good volume.
