EASTON, Pa, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Lafayette College today appointed Steve M. Hokuf as head football coach, succeeding Maurice (Clipper) Smith.

MONROE, Wis., Jan. 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, bidding tonight for the support of Wisconsin's farmers, denounced Federal regulation and control of agriculture and declared, "the Government's place in agriculture, as in other fields of activity, is advice and assistance, but such advice and assistance need not involve and must not involve Government regulation and control."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Federal Trade Commission took action today against the sale of inflammable sweaters by filing against a Philadelphia concern a complaint accusing its two owners of manufacturing sweaters that were "highly inflammable and dangerous and unsafe to wear."

The adaptability of soup -- which may be not only a course in itself but also an ingredient in meat, fish, egg or even dessert dishes -- is demonstrated in a recipe booklet just released by the H. J. Heinz Company. The leaflet emphasizes the use of that firm's canned condensed soups.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner said today he had found no reason for reducing the 48,000-pound maximum take-off load of the C-46 airplane.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Textual excerpts from General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's statement issued today covering highlights of news conference held Monday:

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 22 -- Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and at least thirty other persons died at 3:45 P. M. today when an American Airlines Convair crashed at South and Williamson Streets in the South Elizabeth residential district. The accident occurred in thick fog and rain.

Small farmers in the Brazilian state of Minas Geraes will be benefited by a program of supervised credit and assistance on which $930,000 will be spent in the next three years, the American International Association for Economic and Social Development announced yesterday.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 22 (UP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison won a major share of the money in the $5,000 Palm Springs invitational golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Lincoln MacVeagh, United States Ambassador to Portugal and a career diplomat for nearly twenty years, will succeed Stanton Griffis as Ambassador to Spain, it was reported on good authority today.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- Premier Edgar Faure won a heavy vote of 396 to 220 in the French National Assembly today in approval of his new Cabinet and of the policy of conciliation he proposed for dealing with the Tunisian crisis.

There is no doubt that much is wrong with charity and other philanthropic fund-raising in New York, in duplication of appeal, competition for the given dollar, inadequacy of central organization, multiplicity of agencies, public relations failures. Furthermore, a change of course must be charted, for the situation seems in danger of growing worse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- President Truman today nominated Earl Wayne Beck of Kansas City, Mo., a Negro, to be Recorder of Deeds for the District of Columbia.

A new collection of comparatively inexpensive tables and stools, together with a new group of fabric designs by Interior Trend Associates, are displayed in the newly decorated showrooms of Reilly-Wolff Associates, Inc., 50 East Thirty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Legislation enabling state-approved research groups to obtain for medical experiments stray dogs and cats that would otherwise be destroyed was reintroduced today by two upstate Republicans.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Walter Hoving, chairman of the New York Anti-Sales Tax Committee, urged Republican legislative leaders today to undertake a state investigation of New York City finance for the primary purpose of requiring the city to put into effect economies recommended by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey.

The stock market made another bid yesterday to match the high levels of last year but missed the mark again by a narrow margin. The list managed to reach into better ground despite profit-taking in the final hour, which moderated the increase in the composite rate to 0.15 point. This average gain was not indicative of the strength in stocks not included in THE NEW YORK TIMES index.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,137 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- "I go to Berlin to be cheered up," said the young American officer in the Frankfurt railroad station. He was not referring to the pleasant wooded suburb where Americans are segregated in surroundings which even in this gray season are reminiscent of the most prosperous sections of Westchester County.
Snow, sleet and rain glazed thoroughfares in the metropolitan area yesterday, but as the mercury climbed in the early evening road conditions became less hazardous for motorists and pedestrians.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 22 -- Iran refused today to accept the British Government's nomination of Robert Hankey as Ambassador to Iran to replace Sir Francis Shepherd, who is being transferred.

The seven television stations in the metropolitan area now provide 11.3 per cent more program time than they did a year ago, according to the preliminary results of a survey released yesterday by the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, reported to Congress today that the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps had lived up to their promises that virtually no man would have to face a second winter of combat in Korea.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Communist MIG's took up the Allied challenge today in a renewal of the air war in Northwestern Korea.

A loan exhibition, "Portraits of Personalities -- Past and Present," opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

An American Federation of Labor slowdown affected 40 per cent of the 55,000 riders on city-owned Staten Island bus lines yesterday. Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced last night that the board had received union assurances that the interruption would be called off pending negotiations between the union and the board today.
An open break has developed between the New York State Banking Department and Federal authorities in the savings and loan field as a result of the latter's policies on establishment of branches.

Joseph Rosenstock, who was named acting director of the New York City Opera Company after the dismissal of Laszlo Halasz, has been named general director. Yesterday he announced his roster of artists for the spring season. It shows that the company has not been split, by the controversy over Mr. Halasz.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- Israel withdrew from all participation in the United Nations General Assembly today "as an expression of grief and protest" against the hanging of two Jews in Baghdad, Iraq, yesterday. The Israelis are expected to return to their seats in the Assembly tomorrow.

First permit me to express my complete endorsement and concurrence on your editorial entitled "Against Public Welfare." It is splendid. It should have the desired effect upon the members of our Legislature, and the obnoxious bill permitting the publicizing of names of recipients of welfare will, I am sure, be defeated.

Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told 600 Girl Scout volunteer workers yesterday that "we must show patience and kindness" toward the reconstruction of democracy in Europe. He recently returned from Bavaria, where he was United States Land Commissioner.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Max Zaslofsky and Harry Gallatin led the New York Knickerbockers to an 82-78 victory that ended a ten-game home winning streak of the Philadelphia Warriors tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Rio Grande Southern Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to abandon its 172-mile narrow gauge line between Ridgway and Durango, Colo.

The Ward Baking Company will discontinue operation of its Brooklyn plant soon and has contracted to sell the land and buildings for $950,000 cash, which is considerably in excess of its book value, Faris R. Russell, chairman of the board, told stockholders in the annual report issued yesterday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22 (UP) -- A Coast Guard warrant officer seized at a show here admitted he was the dice-shooting paymaster wanted for slipping away with about $46,000 in Government money and a waitress, the police said today.

Twenty-five teachers have been called to the Board of Education in the last six months to answer questions concerning alleged membership in the Communist party, it became known yesterday. Of the twenty-five, six have resigned and one has retired rather than submit to questioning.

Wholesalers have failed to keep pace with "soaring" retail sales of men's outerwear and sportswear, Lester J. Handelman, secretary-treasurer of the California Manufacturing Company, St. Louis, declared yesterday. He spoke at second-day sessions of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute's twenty-fifth annual meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

With its parlay of Bob Hope, Fred Allen and Jerry Lester finishing out of the money, N. B. C. television has hopefully substituted "Royal Showcase" in the 7 o'clock niche Sunday evenings. So far it has not shown a very promising early foot.

A center mall for railway rapid transit on the automobile expressways of the future was suggested yesterday as one way of easing traffic congestion in the New York metropolitan area and other centers of population. The proposal was advanced by E. E. Kearns, manager of the General Electric Company's urban traffic division, at the winter meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the Statler Hotel.

British shipyards in 1951 experienced their greatest boom in thirty years and at the end of the year had under construction 40 per cent of all the world's new building. The tonnage laid down in Great Britain and Northern Ireland, as of Dec. 31, totaled 2,209,012 gross tons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A member of Congress from Mississippi asserted today that estimates of cotton acreage and production made by the Department of Agriculture should properly be called "guesstimates."
The Korean situation was rapidly reaching a crisis yesterday as the truce negotiations continued stalemated after seven months of effort.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved without opposition today a $250,000,000 program to make Arab refugees in the Middle East self-sufficient within three years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- In a joint statement, Harry P. Wurman, president of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., and Everett Meyer, president of the Webster Tobacco Company, announced today the signing of an agreement under which Bayuk would acquire certain operating assets of Webster.

HONG KONG, Jan. 22 -- The Communist controlled newspaper Ta Kung Pao announced today that new job opportunities had opened up on "collective farms" in the rice-producing Canton delta for overseas Chinese deported from Malaya.

Eight of the ten riders who will form the United States equestrian team in the Olympic Games at Helsinki next summer were chosen yesterday. At the same time it was disclosed that the team's training center would be transferred from Fort Riley, Kan., to Camden, S. C., about Feb. 1 and that the fund-raising campaign for expenses still was about $64,000 short of its goal.

It would give this writer pleasure, particularly in view of the very favorable impression Victor de Sabata made upon him when he first heard him conduct, to say that his concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall represented his best and most musicianly attributes.

A city financial aid program under which the State Legislature will be asked to approve a county real estate tax estimated to yield $100,000,000 and increases in eleven categories of state aid totaling $63,800,000 was announced at City Hall last night by Mayor Impellitteri.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 -- The Chinese Communist Government, denouncing today the proposed treaty between Japan and the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa as a "military threat to China, inferentially threatened to call into operation the Chinese-Soviet pact for joint action against a revived Japanese "imperialism."

Net sales of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company last year rose 7.1 per cent to a record high of $814,216,968, an increase of $54,360,967 over the previous peak of $759,856,001 set in 1950, but earnings declined $8,140,701 under the pressure of heavier taxes.

The United States Olympic Nordic ski squad of fourteen, Coaches Harald (Pop) Sorensen, Colorado Springs, Colo., and Leif Odmark, Sun Valley, Idaho, and Manager Hjalmar Hvam, Seattle, departed yesterday aboard a Pan-American Airliner for Oslo, Norway, where the sixth winter games will be held, Feb. 14-25.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The United States flatly turned down today any "package deal" with the Soviet Union that would open the doors of the United Nations to a spelled-out list of Communist and non-Communist applicants.

CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- The Ministry of Interior tonight listed for publication a series of complaints against the British forces in the canal zone, charging them with various acts of brigandage, kidnapping and pilfering of property. The governate of Ismailia was reported to have detected the bodies of two Egyptians in a British military hospital.

Fifteen hundred persons gathered yesterday on the floor of the New York Produce Exchange to witness the presentation of a framed scroll to Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, skipper of the ill-fated ship Flying Enterprise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Home rule for the nation's capital, which has been handled by Congress like a Government department since the District of Columbia adopted a commission form of management in 1874, was approved by a scattered voice vote in the Senate today.
Blood collections in the New York metropolitan area so far this month continue to lag behind the quota, the Red Cross announced yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- Two United States Navy experts were among fifty technicians who cruised up and down the English Channel today on the world's first merchant ship to be powered by gas turbine.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Conservative Government is to do away with the limit on the number of houses to be built. Instead of the old system of fixed building allocations, local authorities and builders are to be encouraged to get as many new homes as possible out of limited supplies available, Harold Macmillan, Minister of Housing, announced tonight.

On Jan. 12, 1934, the late Delos Chappell brought "Come of Age" into Maxine Elliott's Theatre with a cast starring Judith Anderson. There it tarried for thirty-four performances. Despite its untimely fate, the Clemence Dane play, with music by Richard Addinsell, made such an impression on those who saw it that people have wondered through the years why it didn't receive another chance.

Ralph Kirkpatrick is one of America's most interesting artists and last night, in his annual Town Hall recital, he gave another of his absorbing programs in which he revealed unexpected facets of the composers, in which he specializes.

For the person seeking some gleam of light in the President's gloomy budget figures for 1952 and 1953, at least a meed of encouragement might be found in the fact that these figures represent the "bookkeeping" budget rather than the so-called "cash budget," and that the latter offers a slightly more hopeful picture.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 22 -- A stealthy war by night, still being fought along Israel's borders between Arab infiltrators and the Israeli Army and police, cost the lives of 133 Arabs and twelve Israelis in the last three months of 1951, Israeli Army sources disclosed tonight

Cerebral palsy specialists agreed at the New York Academy of Medicine yesterday afternoon that treatment for the crippling affliction should begin just as early as cerebral palsy was diagnosed -- probably about six months after birth.
Careful planning on British lines can safeguard New York's food supply in case of bombing, Markets Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli reported yesterday to City Defense Director Arthur W. Wallander.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Salary Stabilization Board announced today that a hearing would be held in New York on Feb. 6 at which owners of baseball clubs or their representatives may present objections to or proposals for the modification of the order issued last week setting up a formula under which salary increases may be given to ball players.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky left for Moscow tonight with a furious parting charge that all the decisions of the current United Nations General Assembly had been for the preparation of a new war.
ROME, Jan. 22 -- Italy expects to spend 612,600,000,000 lire ($980,000,000) on defense during the fiscal year 1952-53, Finance Minister Ezio Vanoni said in a press conference today.
Indiana and Michigan Electric Company borrowed $23,000,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of first mortgage bonds and serial notes sold at public sealed bidding.

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, master of the ill-fated American freighter Flying Enterprise, told a Coast Guard board of inquiry yesterday of the last days of struggle and heroism before his vessel slipped beneath the waves only fifty miles from the safety of a British harbor.

John Fox, former bond salesman who was born in the tenement district of South Boston, emerged yesterday as the largest single stockholder in the world's biggest telegraph enterprise, the $300,000,000 Western Union Telegraph Company.

It has taken one parent quite a while to wake up to changes in school customs from the time when he was a boy. Ever since one 11-year-old entered school the parent has heard of a subject taught in all the grades called "social studies."

A prizefight manager and his brother were charged yesterday with third-degree assault as a sequel to an attack on Al Weill, matchmaker of the International Boxing Club, in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 11.

The Board of Inquiry named by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi to investigate the costly twenty-five-day wildcat strike of longshoremen in the Port of New York last fall has submitted a valuable, painstaking report which should go a long way toward building up constructive labor-management relations in this major port.

The "double-duty" product, as represented by clothing and home furnishings, took first prizes for eight manufacturers yesterday, when the winners in the first annual Hess Brothers Award Competition for Versatility in Design and Use were announced at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The disputed waterfront contract that sparked the record twenty-five-day dock strike in the Port of New York last fall was "validly" ratified despite the presence of vote fraud, according to an official finding made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Travel restrictions against Soviet diplomats here may soon be put into effect in retaliation for new bars against diplomatic movement recently ordered in Moscow.
In a downpour of rain, the first neighborhood drill of about 100 such exercises scheduled for the civil defense forces of the city in 1952 was held here last night.
Through the second World War and the years that immediately followed Robert Porter Patterson, who died in yesterday's plane crash in Elizabeth, N. J., played a key role in the nation's affairs.

Governor Dewey called the proposed medical center of Yeshiva University an "inspiring project" in a telegram read last night at a dinner honoring Isidore Leviton as a founder of the school. The dinner, spearheading Brooklyn's $1,000,000 drive for the school, was held at the Brooklyn Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway.

The consolidated debt of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority was offered to investors yesterday in a new form -- $215,000,000 of general revenue bonds to be secured by the pooled revenues of five bridges, two tunnels and the Authority's other toll facilities.

Active cotton futures lost 3 to 35 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The market opened 9 to 18 points higher, and was steady early on price-fixing and reports of a firm spot basis in the South.

Joseph Anastasio, one of the Anastasia brothers (he spells his name with a final o) active on the Brooklyn waterfront, asked for and obtained a certificate of good conduct in a visit to Police Headquarters yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 23 -- The Communist radio this morning made a new charge that United Nations planes had violated the neutral area set aside for the truce conferences in the Korean war and Communist liaison officers at Panmunjom renewed an old accusation that one of their delegation's convoys was strafed on the road last week, with two men wounded and vehicles damaged.
PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The United States Government had spent $168,140,631 up to last Nov. 24 in its wartime Korean civil assistance program, the United Nations announced today.
Thirty-four tenants of a fashionable apartment building off Riverside Drive at 321 West Seventy-eighth Street won a $9,000 treble damage award yesterday in Federal Court from their landlord.

ONE of the oldest of all catchlines is this: "If you can't beat 'em, join 'em." That's how George Weiss happens to be general manager of the Yankees. It wasn't exactly that Weiss joined the Yankees. In effect, they joined him.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- Denis W. Delaney, former Massachusetts Collector of Internal Revenue, was found guilty tonight on all six counts in two indictments charging that he had accepted $7,500 to influence his decisions in tax cases and that he had falsely certified that more than $180,000 in tax liens had been paid.

The main issue behind the cleavage of agencies over the proposed change in operations by the Greater New York Fund is whether leaders here should work toward a more united fund-raising or decentralize fund-raising activities because of the complexities involved, according to authorities interviewed yesterday on the controversial Brunie Report.

Travel on the trolley lines of the Yonkers Railroad Company is becoming increasingly dangerous and may become worse, company officials testified yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing at 233 Broadway.

Angered by the second big airplane crash in his municipality within six weeks, James T. Kirk, Mayor of Elizabeth, N. J., demanded last night that Newark Airport be relocated "regardless of cost," to remove an "umbrella of danger" from low-flying planes.
For an hour yesterday the Henry Street Settlement Music School at 8 Pitt Street echoed with the voices of former stars of the Metropolitan Opera.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- A warning that higher corporate taxes would encourage monopolies, and a suggestion that a retail sales tax be adopted as a substitute, were issued today by H. Stanley Marcus, president of the Neiman-Marcus specialty store, Dallas, Tex.

The American Nurses Association is continuing its opposition to the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution, Miss Janet Geister, first vice president of the group, declared yesterday following adjournment of the association's advisory council after a two-day meeting at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Business activity registered only minor changes in the closing weeks of last year, and national output continued at a peak rate of 4 to 5 per cent higher than a year earlier, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Another Congressional showdown on whether the Federal Government or the states shall have the profits from any oil or other deposits beneath their offshore seas was virtually assured by a 9-to-2 vote of the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee today.

Howard Henig, counsel to Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore, charged yesterday that much of the city's current financial difficulties could be traced to a lack of courage on the part of present and former city officials in meeting their responsibilities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The State Department again urged the Soviet Union today to take part in prisoner-of-war discussions that began yesterday in a United Nations committee in Geneva.
Most New York Commodity Exchanges registered relatively heavy volume yesterday. Prices showed no definite pattern. Cocoa alone was pronounced in strength.

Three months after its completion the seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy-three families at 750 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-second Street, has been sold by 750 Park Avenue, Inc., Francis Kleban, president, to Felomer, Inc., for investment. The seller was the builder of the house, which was sold through L. V. Hoffman Co.
BOSTON. Jan. 22 (UP) -- New York's fighting Rangers overcame a two-goal deficit tonight and held fourth place in the National Hockey League by tying Boston, 3 -- 3.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Governor Dewey recommended today that the starting salary of State troopers be raised from $1,680 a year to $2,250 and that all present members of the force receive a pay increase of $570 a year.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 22 -- Denying that any Communist could get or keep a job on its faculty, Sarah Lawrence College disclosed tonight the torment that veiled charges of communism were causing there.

Issues of public utility stock priced at more than $32,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings include outstanding as well as new common stock of Pacific Power and Light Company, and a preferential offering of common stock to shareholders of Kansas City Power and Light Company.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 22 -- A short, stocky 45-year-old blonde couturiere broke down and wept today as competitors in the fashion world came forward with embraces and congratulations on her overwhelmingly successful display of sports and play clothes.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- About 15,000 workers were made idle here today in a walkout at the Briggs Manufacturing Company, which supplies automobiles to the Chrysler Corporation and other car manufacturers.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Assemblyman Elisha T. Barrett, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation, said today that he had called a tri-state conference in New York for Feb. 1 to discuss the wisdom of an interstate compact on smoke control. The meeting will be held at the Roosevelt Hotel.

American Colonial furniture fashioned of maple is dashingly treated with modern decorative tricks in five new model rooms just opened at Stern Brothers. Almost all the furniture in these rooms is Consider H. Willett's "Lancaster" collection, which reproduces Pennsylvania Dutch motifs, and is finished in a pleasantly warm, not too light honey tone.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 22 (UP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur declared himself out of the Illinois Presidential preference primary today, but Mid-Western supporters refused to give up the fight to win the Republican nomination for him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Production expansion programs already laid out for the steel industry will provide a sufficient quantity of that metal to meet all military programs, as now defined, with a surplus available for other purposes, a special task group of steel mill officials told the Office of Defense Mobilization today.

THIS is the drowsy season along the Outer Banks, now that the ducks are protected, and there will be little to relieve the monotony until the first channel bass appears off Oregon Inlet, except for the brief respite offered by the annual Nags Head Fox Chase on St. Valentine's Day.

Tragedy has struck again in the air over New Jersey, and this time its sorrow-laden list of casualties includes the name of an American who has served his country with extraordinary distinction. Robert P. Patterson was one of the great and gallant figures of the times in which we live.

O. C. Holland has been named director of advertising and sales promotion of the Interchemical Corporation, printing ink division. He succeeds the late George Welp, with whom he served as assistant director five years.

The thirty-three local municipal hospitals effected more care to more patients in 1951 than in any other year in the city's history, an annual report released yesterday by the Department of Hospitals showed.

The importance of ceramics -- both decoratively and functionally -- in the contemporary home is highlighted in "Living with Ceramics," opening today at the Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street, and continuing through Feb. 9.
Whitey Lockman signed his 1952 contract with the Giants yesterday, duly rewarded with a pay increase for having helped the Polo Grounders to the pennant last season.
The State of West Virginia announced yesterday that it would offer for sale next Tuesday an issue of $6,000,000 of road bonds dated Feb. 1, 1952, and due Feb. 1, 1953 to 1977.

" Duveen," by S. N. Behrman, the author's first venture in literature outside the theatre, will be published March 24 by Random House. It is a story of the spectacular career of Joseph Duveen, art connoisseur, promoter and "super-salesman," describing the devices he used in selling masterpieces for fabulous sums to the richest collectors of Europe and America.

The board of directors of the New York City Center of Music and Drama voted yesterday afternoon against reconsideration of its dismissal of Laszlo Halasz as director of the New York City Opera Company. Because of the action, Frederick F. Umhey, executive secretary of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, walked out of the meeting and said he would resign his position on the board.
Esther Fernandez, pianist, and Richard Sharetts, bass-baritone, winners of the Town Hall Debut Award offered by the New York Madrigal Society, were heard jointly yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston, Tex., asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to construct new facilities to cost about $128,216,000 to increase capacity of its natural gas pipeline system to 1,515,000,000 cubic feet daily.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 23 -- Senator Robert A. Taft wound up his two-day stumping tour of southern Wisconsin early today with the assurances of his backers that he would have the support of twenty-two to twenty-four of Wisconsin's thirty delegates in his bid for the Republican nomination at the party's national convention in Chicago starting July 7.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Congress has been asked to approve construction of the first of several new-type escort aircraft carriers, designed to combat Russia's growing submarine fleet.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The major Dutch reservations to the European army plan, which were cited as obstacles to an agreement in Washington Monday in connection with the visit there of Netherlands Premier Willem Drees, have been removed in negotiations here, according to officials taking part in them.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The State Thruway Authority announced today it would suspend for the duration of the acute steel shortage the ban against the use of foreign-produced steel in state public works projects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- Rep. Frank E. Smith, Democrat, of Mississippi, charged today that the government is forcing cotton farmers to "subsidize" rayon and nylon producers -- their direct competitors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Earl J. McGrath, Federal Commissioner of Education, reprimanded an aide today for criticizing the opinions of an Indiana school teacher.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet Union told United Nations delegates today that by paying a $120,000 fine for four United States airmen who landed in Hungary in November the United States had conceded that the fliers were spies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois was being mentioned prominently among influential Democrats here tonight as a leading candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Truman appealed directly to the Senate today to repeal a provision of the Defense Production Act of 1950 which, he said, threatened "serious complications" in American foreign policy.

TRENTON, Jan. 23 -- A more thorough automobile driver's test to disclose physical defects and "undeveloped mental attitudes" was advocated today by Acting Director William J. Dearden of the State Motor Vehicles Division.
Underwriting syndicates will offer to investors tomorrow new issues of public utility and railroad debt securities totaling $31,850,000. The offerings are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP)--Fifteen Senators and four Representatives sponsored legislation today to have the Federal Government pay extra unemployment compensation to workers made jobless by cutbacks in civilian production.

The experience of European countries shows that an increase in the interest rate is an integral part of a sound credit restriction policy, Per Jacobsson, economic adviser of the Bank for International Settlements, declared yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 23 -- Vlajko Begovic, director of the Yugoslav economic planning staff, said today at a press conference that his Government would be able to balance its international payments sometime in 1954, provided it was able to complete its capital investment program in industry on schedule.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 23 -- A 66 2/3 per cent stock dividend was declared at the annual meeting here of stockholders and directors of the First National Bank of Portland.

Higher interest rates on both long and short term borrowing this year were viewed as a possibility yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company. Responding to a question at the annual stockholders' meeting, Mr. Colt said that he believed "the pressure from the point of view of the demand for funds would be for higher rates on both long and short term money."

Florida Expansion The Tampa Electric Company, serving the largest city on the west coast of Florida will spend $52,000,000 for construction and extension of its facilities in the next five years. This is double the amount of expenditures for the same purposes in the last five years, Francis J. Gannon, president, told some 200 in attendance at the New York Society of Security Analysts luncheon meeting at Schwartz Restaurant yesterday.

ADELAIDE, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Defending Champion Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., was forced to come from behind at 0 -- 3 in the fifth set to defeat Ian Ayre of Brisbane, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 5 -- 7, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4 , in the quarter-finals of the Australian tennis championships today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Charges that the home-building industry had been treated unfairly in the allotment of materials and in enforced cutbacks under the emergency mobilization plan were denied here today by Manly Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 2,977,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 131,310,000 barrels, compared with 128,333,000 a week earlier and 123,782,000 a year ago.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The United States and eleven other sponsors presented a resolution to the General Assembly today hailing the emergence of Libya as an independent state and urging her admission to the United Nations.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,138, for Wednesday's operation:

Events toinght: "Gianni Schicchi" and "Salome," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, conductor, Cantelli, violin soloist, Isaac Stern, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Isabel Mourao, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Adelaide Van Wey, folk singer, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

With his usual forthrightness General Eisenhower has again stated the case for European unity simply and directly. He is as conscious as are the statesmen of Western Europe of the difficulties in the way of the kind of unification necessary if the free half of the Continent is to stand without external support.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Two New Yorkers were among residents of eleven states cited tonight for heroism by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission. Bronze medals were awarded to Mrs. Jane E. Mason, 33 years old, of Cloverdale, Warren County, and Earl L. Zimmerman, 23, of Cheektowaga.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman predicted yesterday that 1952 would bring "the worst crisis in home-building as well as in unemployment in the building trades" in state and nation since the end of World War II.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 23 -- The greater part of Plum Island, which the Federal Government contracted to sell to Suffolk County for $85,000 in May, 1950, has been withdrawn from the Government's surplus property list and a $17,000 down payment has been returned.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Mayor Ernst Reuter said today that he had received assurances that the Allies would reconsider, in six months' time, their decision to retain West Berlin's special status outside the Federal Republic, reaffirmed last week. He added that some progress had been made in the city's efforts to be included as the twelfth state of West Germany.
The Board of Transportation announced last night that a settlement had been reached in the union dispute that had slowed bus service for 55,000 Staten Island riders in the last three days.

Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, vice president and acting head of Columbia University, called on Americans yesterday to spend less time in idle criticism of their allies in Western Europe and more time in trying to understand the basic requirements "of an association which is as indispensable to us as it is to them."

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- A silver cup nearly two feet high, standing on a bar at the Olympia Exhibition Hall here, awaits the winner as 375 bartenders from all over the world submit their prize original cocktail formulas in a contest for the world's championship that began today.

For the first time since repeal, a whisky ad in a national magazine will contain consumer prices when full-page copy on Park Tilford Reserve appears. The ad has been released for Park Tilford Distillers Corporation by Storm Klein, Inc.

Approximately 135 American feature-length motion pictures will be released in Spain during the twelve-month period after March 1 by the terms of an agreement approved yesterday by the Spanish Government and the American motion-picture industry, it was announced jointly by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Export Association, and Ellis Arnall, president of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 23 -- Religious-minded young women in Israel, who now are exempt from the two years national service that other unmarried women 18 to 26 years old are tendering, will lose their special privilege this year, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion told the Knesset (Parliament) today.

Many supper parties will be given at the second annual Animal Kingdom Ball for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals to be held tonight in the main ballroom suite of the Pierre.

Bobby Clark confirmed a report yesterday that he may appear in a revival of "Sally," first on the West Coast and then on Broadway, under the auspices of Edwin Lester. "The chances are pretty good," he said, adding that he intends to get in touch with Mr. Lester soon "to find out what his deadline is on the project."

Increased over-all car length and roomier luggage compartments are offered in the 1952 line presented yesterday by the Oldsmobile division, General Motors Corporation. The models will go on display today throughout the New York metropolitan area.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Thursday, June 26, 1884, a young reporter, fresh from a tour of an elaborate new structure in downtown Manhattan, wrote: "For commercial uses, it is perhaps the finest building in the country.

President Truman's announcement Monday of plans for a five to six billion expansion program of atomic energy facilities, beginning July 1, 1953, marks the third major expansion program in the field since 1949, and the largest so far. When it is completed by July 1, 1958, it will more than quadruple the present capital investment in atomic-energy plants.

The strange story of a Harvard graduate of fifty years ago who apparently lived in squalor for nearly thirty years came to light yesterday with the disclosure that Harry Chapin Smith, 84 years old, had died last Oct. 24, leaving an estate of at least $400,000.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 24 -- The United Nations Command intimated yesterday that an armistice in the Korean war might be impossible to conclude because of the Communist refusal to agree on the terms for a cease-fire.

A test of strength is brewing in the port of Philadelphia between major martime concerns and the International Longshoremen's Association. The contest is being watched by New York shipping men for its crucial bearing on future Atlantic Coast operations.

Cross-examination of a fire lieutenant testifying for the prosecution at James J. Moran's extortion conspiracy trial boomeranged yesterday when the prosecution witness linked Moran with a new phase of "gratuities" that had not been specified in the indictment against him.
Western Union engineers yesterday described a foot-square telegraph machine designed for the desk top of a busy man that is to be installed in 10,000 offices by the end of 1952.

A Senate labor-management relations subcommittee is exploring the thorny question of how to deal legislatively with Communist-dominated unions. It has received from the Atomic Energy Commission an answer to a questionnaire which shows how this sensitive agency has sought to meet the problem.
" Time for Beany," a film series of puppet adventures, will be presented over Channel 2 on Mondays through Fridays at 5:30 P. M. and on Saturdays at 1 P. M., beginning Monday.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr. again takes up the heavy responsibilities of president of the Board of Education of New York City. He has proved his worth through years of experience on the board, and we congratulate him heartily as meriting the confidence of his colleagues.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The dissemination of British scientific information is being handicapped by the rising costs of paper and printing. The difficulty is being experienced to a marked degree by the Council of the 300-year-old Royal Society, which now spends more than 20,000 a year on publications, compared with 10,000 before the war.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 23 -- Premier Urho Kekkonen said today Finland hoped her Scandinavian neighbors would "establish and secure neutrality" to avert even the threat of an attack on Russia across Finnish soil.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Legislation to entitle nonresident income taxpayers to the same deductions that are allowed residents was reintroduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican of Manhattan.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, which already has won a $3,120,743 judgment against Otis Co., today filed a new $2,588,919 action against the investment concern's principal owners.

The Massey-Harris Company, Canadian agricultural equipment maker, had consolidated net earnings of $15,378,721 or $2 a share in the fiscal year ended with October, James S. Duncan, president and chairman, reported yesterday. In the previous year the net was $17,540,803 or $2.28 a share.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- The Orange County Republican Committee endorsed two regular organization candidates tonight for delegate to the Republican National Convention from the Twenty-ninth Congressional District.

Our park system moves steadily forward, in spite of many obstacles, and yesterday the Park Association of New York City took note of some of that progress. William M. Chadbourne, president, bestowed the association's 1951 annual award on Frank D. Schroth, publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle, for his civic leadership in initiating and promoting to recent completion the Brooklyn War Memorial, with its additional park facilities in S. Parkes Cadman Plaza.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, renewed today his demand for a Universal Military Training law to eliminate the "uncertainties" of present draft policies.

MADRID, Jan. 23 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spanish Chief of State, said today in an interview that if the proposed aid agreement with Washington were enacted, Spain would welcome the stationing here of United States military missions for the purpose of instructing this country's armed forces in the use of new weapons and in new techniques.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan dismissed yesterday the $2,100,000 damage suit brought by Paul Robeson, singer and left-wing figure, and twenty-nine others, against Westchester County officials and two veterans' organizations as a result of two Peekskill riots in 1949.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Swiss Federal police said today that they were holding a man, believed to be a Rumanian, in connection with the mysterious death of Capt. Eugene Karpe, former United States naval attache in Bucharest. Captain Karpe fell or was pushed from a train in Austria on Feb. 24, 1950.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Prices started today with a follow-through to yesterday's slight improvement, but later retreated under the lead of British Government securities and closed dull on the stock markets here. An exception was building material issues which rose in response to the Government's plans to speed the housing program.

Weaving, woodworking and piano-playing classes for parents and children and several courses designed for mothers and fathers ranging from infant care to the health needs of children will be offered for the first time at local colleges and centers beginning early next month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Truman sent to the Senate today the nominations of Abbot L. Mills Jr., a Portland, Ore., banker, and James L. Robertson, Deputy Controller of the Currency here since 1933, to be members of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.
For the second time this month a local hospital and the Red Cross collaborated to save a life by replacing a patient's complete blood supply three times over, the Red Cross announced yesterday.

I read your editorial and the letter from Max M. Tamir published on Jan. 21 -- both concerned with the problem of the heavy deficit resulting from the operation of our city transportation system. He feels, as I do, that a blanket increase in fares charged is not the proper solution.

Back in 1845 when New Yorkers picked blackberries along what is now Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, and deer cavorted on the rock at Bowling Green, the city directory reported house numbers were "in a regular state of beautiful confusion."

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- A constitutional change to strip the Legislature of power to authorize projects in the forest preserve for the regulation of the flow of streams was introduced in the Legislature today under the sponsorship of the Joint Legislative Committee on River Regulation.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Raymond K. (Buddy) Parker, who almost coached the Detroit Lions to a divisional pro football title last season, signed a new one-year contract today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23 -- Jacob S. Potofsky of New York, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers' Union, C. I. O., today called for immediate action by the Department of Defense in allocating contracts to areas where high unemployment exists in the clothing industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Truman Administration is campaigning for extension of an international wheat agreement on the ground that it helps thwart communism in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Defense Production reported today that inadequate expansion of the machine tool industry had created "the most serious bottleneck" now existing in the rearmament program.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, the British High Commissioner in West Germany, speaking before the Foreign Press Association today replied to critics of Britain's unwillingness to join the European army by pointing out his country's military investment in the defense of Germany.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Crafty Admiral, 4-year-old son of Fighting Fox, today blazed around the Hialeah Park racing strip in record time to win the $10,000-added Palm Beach Handicap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Truman today nominated Eric A. Johnston, Washington State Republican and former Economic Stabilization Administrator, to be chairman of the International Development Advisory Board, succeeding Nelson Rockefeller of New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran has asked Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein for a ruling on whether the old or new Congressional district lines should be used in electing delegates to the Republican and Democratic national conventions.

A study by Ellsworth Barnard of Edwin Arlington Robinson's views on the nature and function of poetry wil be published Feb. 11 by Macmillan, entitled "Edwin Arlington Robinson." The work analyzes the religious and philosophical views of Mr. Robinson, his attitude toward American democracy and capitalism and an explanation of the symbolism in the poet's works. Mr. Barnard is the author of "Shelley's Religion."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- House investigators who dug into the Internal Revenue Bureau scandals threw their support to President Truman's reorganization plan in a surprise move today.

The King's County District Attorney's office began last night an investigation into what County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz described as an "apparent attempt to fix a juror" in the perjury trial of a former policeman.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- Two last-period goals broke up an even contest and enabled Middle-bury College to defeat Army, 4 to 2, in hockey at Smith Rink today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the United States fully supported suggestions by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for a constitutional convention for speeding plans for economic and political unity in Western Europe.

Montclair, N. J., borrowed $1,985,000 yesterday in the public market on issues of bonds maturing Feb. 1, 1953 to 1977. The obligations were bought at public sealed bidding by Phelps, Fenn Co. and associates at a bid of 100.049 for interest of 1.8 per cent. Reoffering was at prices to yield from 1.05 per cent to 1.95 per cent.
Two important players yesterday signed their contracts with the world champion Yankees.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Erie Railroad Company announced today that its net income for 1951 was $13,487,837, equal to $4.68 a share, before deductions for capital and sinking funds. This compares with $13,455,493 and $4.67 in 1950.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Donald O'Connor has signed a three-picture contract with Paramount, and there are indications that he will co-star in the dancing role opposite Betty Hutton in the musical "Look, Ma, I'm Dancin'."

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 23 -- The American Airlines crash that took twenty-nine lives here yesterday -- twenty-three of plane crew and passengers, and six tenants in homes hit by the plane -- has touched off the most intensive multi-pronged investigation in commercial aviation annals.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Governor Dewey of New York is going to make a speech tomorrow night on how to defend Asia from the Communists.

The Korean armistice negotiations continue to drag along into what looks more and more like a stalemate. It may be that failure of the Soviet attempt in Paris to extort a political settlement before a cease-fire and the departure of Mr. Vishinsky for Moscow will put new life into the discussions at Panmunjom.

VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- The Socialist half of Austria's coalition government today introduced into Parliament a bill designed to nullify the recent decision of the Austrian courts restoring to the former leader of the Fascist Heimwehr, Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, properties confiscated by the Nazis.

VIENNA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The "good Russian" who was to emigrate to the United States with his family as a reward for trying to help Robert A. Vogeler, American business man, escape from a Red Hungarian prison will not be leaving just yet, and maybe not ever.

CAIRO, Jan. 23 (AP)--An Egyptian newspaper correspondent said today that Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, had told him that Russia would assist all Middle Eastern peoples "to free themselves of Western economic domination."

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 23 -- Clashes between Tunisian nationalists and French forces reached a new peak of deadly violence today, with no sign that the statement made before the National Assembly in Paris yesterday by Premier Edgar Faure had had any conciliatory effect.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Michael V. DiSalle, Director of the Office of Price Stabilization, announced today he would be a Democratic candidate for United States Senator from Ohio.
Apropos your editorial "Moving Toward U. M. T.," it would seem that the current program for a complete militarization of the United States is proceeding under a program of falsification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee announced formally today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination and immediately criticized the Truman Administration for not doing enough to clean up corruption in Government.

Permanent personal registration of voters here would "create a new crop of Dutch Schultzes all over the city," bring back "colonization" of voters and probably permit the names of thousands of persons to remain on registration lists long after they were dead, David B. Costuma, secretary of the Board of Elections, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Senate Rules Committee approved the use of nearly $700,000 today to finance Senate investigations into mobilization, subversive activities, elections laws and government grain shortages.

HASTINGS, Neb., Jan. 23 -- A special committee has started to work on the draft of an interstate compact for the ten Missouri River Valley states and the Federal compact for the unified management of the water, soil and related resources of the basin.

Federal Judge John C. Knox said last night that the Federal Court calendar in the Southern District of New York was so clogged with anti-trust suits that lesser litigants were "daily being deprived of the rights of simple justice."

CAIRO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Egypt's Interior Minister denounced tonight a British search set off in Ismailia by the slaying of a United States nun and declared that Suez Canal zone matters had gone beyond the stage of "mere protestations."

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Ambassador Bruce, first as head of the Marshall Plan mission for France and then for two and a half years as Ambassador in Paris, has made a remarkable record in the period characterized by United States aid for European recovery and by French leadership in moves for unification of Europe.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida in his first major policy address before the new session of the Diet today invited the Nationalist Government of China to accept the proposal for a treaty of amity with Japan "as soon as it is legally possible."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, on its own motion, ordered today an investigation of the Norfolk Southern Railway Company and the Norfolk Southern Bus Corporation, with certain associated companies made respondents.

The Department of Parks has a "scandalously undermanned and underpaid staff" and "the vicious practice of not filling vacancies has made this situation infinitely worse," Parks Commissioner Robert Moses charged yesterday in a letter to Mayor Impellitteri.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Defense Department identified 261 more United States battle casualties today, bringing the total to 104,644 since the outbreak of the Korean war.

Eleven contemporary composers have received commissions from the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress, the Library announced yesterday. The works were commissioned in connection with the observance this week of the second anniversary of the inaugural concert sponsored by the foundation, which is dedicated to the memory of Natalie Koussevitzky, the late conductor's first wife.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The National Production Authority granted an increase today in the quantity of cans that may be used to pack four low-cost basic food products and two essential nonfood products. Food items receiving a more generous allocation were spaghetti and macaroni, chili with beans, nonseasonal soups and dried soaked beans.

Retail hardware sales so far during January are about 15 per cent below the same period last year, it was reported here yesterday by large retailers. Decreases were attributed to public fears that predicted shortages of "hard goods" may not actually occur, retailers said.
DESFORD, England, Jan. 23 -- Britain's first two "people's houses," built in twelve weeks for 970 (about $2,700) each, were opened in this Leicestershire town today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Truman sent a special mission to Tokyo today to negotiate with the Japanese Government agreements governing the disposition of the United States armed forces to be left in Japan when the Japanese peace treaty goes into effect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A series of important shifts in diplomatic assignments was touched off today by the resignation of James E. Webb as Under Secretary of State and the nomination of David K. E. Bruce, United States Ambassador to France, to succeed him.
VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- Ladislav Kopriva, Czechoslovak Minister for National Security, has followed Rudolf Slansky into disgrace, according to an annuoncement tonight by the Prague radio.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23 -- Asserting that the third World War already is a fact, President Juan D. Peron, in his weekly newspaper column appearing tomorrow, again calls for the prompt establishment of a confederation of Latin-American states.

The visit of Winston Churchill, which has just ended, the things he said and what Foreign Secretary Eden also said in his notable address at Columbia University have given us a sharp and disturbing reminder on the Middle East. We should not let it slip easily from our minds or permit other vital problems to distract us from its importance.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Jean Barthet's minute hats may be described as plateaux or pancake berets spanning the top of the head and dipping down slightly into elongated sides. Uncovering the head high in back, they are very narrow from front to back.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 23 -- A decree just issued reorganizes the National Supply Institute, changing its name to the Agricultural Products Protection Corporation, and defines its functions.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and France met in London today to consider what action the Western powers should take if the Soviet Union declined to enter into negotiations this week on the Austrian state treaty.
Insufficient attention was given to certain portions of the Eisenhower and Truman statements issued recently on the Eisenhower candidacy. The General said:

Having completed arrangements for a meeting in Miami among the principals involved in the confused heavyweight title situation, James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, yesterday returned to Florida to resume his vacation there.
ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Governor Dewey appealed to farmers tonight for continued support of his pay-as-you-go policy for financing highways and other capital improvements.
FORT DIX, N. J., Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Fort Dix civilian worker killed three women members of his family with an automatic pistol tonight and then committed suicide, the state police said.

The five-story store and apartment building on lot 25 by 110 feet at 425 Third Avenue, near Thirtieth Street, has been sold by the Church of the Incarnation to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, in a deal negotiated by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers.
Shortly after the close of trading today the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange will tackle once more the question of whether to change trading hours.

The port got its first view yesterday of the new cruise ship Silverstar, which arrived here late Tuesday from Hamburg, Germany. Three hundred travel agents inspected the 6,000-gross-ton vessel yesterday afternoon.

Barry Jones, the British stage and screen actor, who impressed American audiences with his portrayals of the atomic scientist in "Seven Days to Noon" and, more recently, the murderer in "The Clouded Yellow," has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for his American film debut in "Plymouth Adventure," the company's forthcoming version of the Ernest Gebler novel about the Massachusetts Pilgrims.

No one needs to be told now that Judith Anderson is a great actress. But it is gratifying now and then to have a chance to see her quality proved, and "Come of Age," which was brilliantly put on at the City Center last evening, is her occasion.

EACH winter about this time, when the snow approaches the eaves and the thermometer drops, Eldred Bailey, up on New Brunswick's Miramichi River, sets out the records and sends a report on the salmon fishing of the past season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A bill to create Federal judgeships was introduced today by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. The judgeships follow the recommendations of the Judicial Conference of the United States at its meeting last September.

The stock market encountered its first serious setback in a week yesterday as bidders stepped aside when moderate profit-taking appeared at intervals. It was not a one-way market, despite the weakness in most of the key divisions. Losses were not of serious proportions except in some of the recently favored oil issues, with the decline in the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index limited to 0.47 point.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Allied tanks poured more than 1,600 shells on Chinese Communist troops on Korea's central front yesterday as sharp fighting broke out.
State Department agents seized the passport of William L. Patterson, executive secretary of the Civil Rights Congress, as he returned to this country yesterday by plane from London.

Dr. Paul C. Aebersold, chief of the isotopes division of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, Oak Ridge, Tenn., demonstrated to more than 1,000 executives of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, how radioactive products can be used to improve industrial production.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., shooting the day's only sub-par golf, won medal honors today in the qualifying round of the Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 23 -- With defense production going into full swing this year, price controls must be retained to prevent undue dislocation of the nation's economy, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association of New York, asserted here today.
Prices in commodities futures markets were generally lower yesterday but coffee and wool resisted the trend.

The General Foods Corporation had the highest fourth-quarter sales in its history and the second largest quarterly volume on record, Clarence Francis, chairman, reported yesterday. Sales for the three months through Dec. 31 amounted to $168,226,313, compared with $130,892,539 for the same period of 1950.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Jan. 23 -- For the third time in his long career, Dr. Arthur J. Leonard resigned today as Public Safety Commissioner of Saratoga Springs while under fire in connection with investigations of gambling.

A two-for-one split of the Bell Aircraft Corporation's stock and an increase in its total authorized $1 par common shares to 1,250,000 was voted by stockholders at their special meeting held in Buffalo yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Last Greetings, flashy daughter of the good California sprinter, With Regards, captured the $15,000 Santa Barbara Stakes today at Santa Anita. She breezed home with a head to spare over Season's Best, Rex Ellsworth's consistent 3-year-old filly, in the seven-furlong feature. A long-shot, Wild Glory, was third, beaten six lengths.
Somebody in the advertising business is looking into the future these days. A poster in the library of the city penitentiary on Rikers Island suggests: "Fly to Bermuda."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Potential Presidential candidates backed up General Eisenhower's call for a European convention.
Another out-of-town college -- the University of Cincinnati -- was linked yesterday to the eleven-month-old inquiry into the fixing of basketball games.

Henry Matter, executive vice president of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, urged wholesalers yesterday to intensify their efforts to educate manufacturers and retailers on the vital role played by the wholesaler in the economy. He spoke at closing sessions of the institute's twenty-fifth annual convention in the New Yorker Hotel.
Prices of edible fats and oils, which have been decreasing gradually since early last year, slipped into a new series of declines on Jan. 11.
Singling out black and white as a color theme not to be overlooked, Bonwit Teller provided attractive glimpses at the Pierre Hotel yesterday of holiday fashions for those vacationing in the South.

Annie Kalish has purchased the fifteen-family apartment house at 309 Sea Breeze Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Karsh Realty Corporation. Gold Star Realty was the broker in the transaction, in which a purchase money mortgage of $17,000 was executed at the closing. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Governor Dewey paid tribute yesterday to former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, who was killed in Tuesday's plane crash at Elizabeth, N. J., and termed his death "a tragic loss to the state and nation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, the author in 1950 of a "Declaration of Conscience" against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, formally withdrew today from a Senate subcommitee that is investigating him.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--The program proposed by Mayor Impellitteri and his associates in the Board of Estimate for solving New York City's revenue needs for next year was described in Republican quarters here today as an unrealistic political gesture.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23 -- While Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party has obtained an absolute majority in the states of Bombay and Madhya Pradesh, the Communists are steadily gaining in the southern states of Travancore - Cochin, Madras and Hyderabad.

Owing to lack of coordination and planning by social and welfare agencies and failure to understand "the real causes of need," America's vast welfare program, for which the nation annually spends $13,000,000,000, is not as efficient as it ought to be.

Frank D. Schroth, publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle, received the 1951 citation of the Park Association of New York City yesterday for his "example of unselfish civic leadership" in promoting the Brooklyn War Memorial dedicated last Armistice Day.

The Irving Trust Company has made a leasehold mortgage loan of $2,628,000 on the second section of the Beech Hills cooperative apartment colony under construction on a forty-acre tract in Douglaston, Queens. The cooperative is spsonsored by a group headed by Bernard Silverman.
TORONTO, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored three goals while the Toronto Maple Leafs were serving penalties tonight to beat the Leafs, 4 -- 2, before 13,329 fans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of the statement issued by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee today, announcing his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination:
The biennial fashion show given by John Walther to exhibit his fine worsteds to the press was held yesterday at Hampshire House.
A triple threat faces this country's liberties and freedoms today -- "aggression from without, subversion from within and self-destruction" -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman said here yesterday.

Formal Action by the Board of Estimate on granting to the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System $407,000 of financial relief for the three months ending March 31 was postponed last night until this morning because of the absence of City Council President Rudolph Halley from the city.

THE novel about the future -- a phenomenon of our time -- takes a turn toward cheerfulness with the publication here today of A. P. Herbert's "Number Nine, or the Mind Sweepers."* This is an exuberant spoofing of prestige-haunted pomposities that is valid wherever the stuffed shirt raises its billow. It stings specifically some fatuous British bureaucrats
The Philadelphia Athletics yesterday purchased the Ottawa franchise of the International League from the New York Giants. The deal was completed at the Hotel Commodore.

The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange 38 to 63 points net lower than on Tuesday. The market opened 5 points higher to 5 points lower, and went early to levels 29 points higher on trade support to 12 points lower.

Thousands of IND subway passengers stood on overcrowded stations for nineteen minutes at the start of the rush hour early last night when a Queens-bound train stalled four times in the Fourteenth Street station because of mechanical difficulty in the closing of doors on two cars.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Heavy realizing sales by longs swamped the demand for grain futures here today, although export trade news in wheat was more bullish. After a firm opening all around, a sharp price recession occurred. The buying broadened somewhat on declines and steadied the market, but there was still an absence of any extensive outside support.

Military honors will be paid to former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson at the 107th Regiment Armory here today, and funeral services will be held tomorrow at the National Cathedral in Washington. Burial will be in the National Cemetery at Arlington, Va.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was asked today to put aside personal objections to the extent of allowing a committee vote on United States participation in construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

If the Wage Stabilization Board lacks the courage to say no to organized labor, why must it insult the intelligence of the public by trying to justify wage increases with fancy double-talk? It is now planning to stoke the fire of inflation higher by "productivity increases."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A witness before the Armed Service Committee of the House of Representatives suggested today that Universal Military Training and other "relatively useless military steps" might actually be "Russian-inspired plans to take our attention and strength away from the present conflict she is promoting."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 23 -- The uncertainties and doubts that have surrounded rearmament in Western Germany for nearly a year and a half have been swept away in the last few days and the Germans have come face to face with the harsh truth that rearmament means conscription and conscription means major changes in the Federal Republic's social structure.

WASHINGTON, Jan 23--All military aid to Iran is being "held in abeyance" until that country can meet requirements of the Mutual Security Act designed to block further Communist aggression, W. Averell Harriman, foreign aid coordinator, told Congress today.

The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday receipt of a "multimillion-dollar contract" from the Air Force for the construction of a building at Reynolds' Phoenix, Ariz., plant and the installation of two giant extrusion presses "to produce improved aluminum parts for our super-bombers and other aircraft."

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen sketched once again yesterday his heroic but vain fight to save the American freighter Flying Enterprise -- this time to an audience of professional maritime officials, many of whom had personally experienced marine disasters or played a part in a sea rescue.

A fleeting reunion with the mother he had not seen since 1908, and with three of seven American sisters he had never seen, was 48-year-old George Augustus Romanos' reward yesterday for twenty-two days of lonely travel. The tearfully happy meeting on the Hudson River pier at West Forty-eighth Street lasted only a moment and then the Lebanese visitor was led away to Ellis Island.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Harvard's future intercollegiate football schedules will be lightened without regard to gate receipts, President James B. Conant informed the university's Board of Overseers in his annual report made public tonight.

From an artificial creation along the banks of the Potomac, Washington has grown to be the ninth largest city in the country, with a civic and commercial life befitting a population of more than 800,000. But because of custom and prejudice Washington's citizens have no vote, and the District is still governed by Congress, as it has been for over seventy-five years.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli, conductor, Isaac Stern, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Singing Boys of Norway, Ragnvald Bjarne, conductor, Eivind Bull-Hansen, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30.
HELENA, Mont., Jan. 24 -- Montana public schools will receive more than $3,000,000 as a result of an oil boom in the Williston Basin of eastern Montana and western North Dakota.

Six years have passed since New York City's Eye Bank for Sight Restoration was established. In that Brief interval it has probably done more for the restoration of sight lost by reason of damage to the cornea through disease or injury than any other single agency in the United States.

The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday the sale of $53,574,000 in short-term notes of twelve local housing authorities, including that of New York City. The notes, which will come due Aug. 29, were sold at interest rates ranging from 1.10 per cent to 1.19 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, told Congress today that stiffer criminal penalties should be added to a pending Federal mine inspection bill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, today ended a long-standing controversy by abandoning a set of proposed regulations that would have allowed the Commissioner of Indian Affairs to impose discretionary restrictions on lawyers representing Indian tribes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Office of Price Stabilization today authorized immediate increases in basic retail prices of 1952 automobiles made by General Motors and Hudson.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 24 -- Connecticut's thirty - eight - mile Merritt Parkway, the "Gateway to New England," finally has a speed control system that is reducing accidents without infringing on normal rights of motorists. The State Police said today that the system, modifying drastic measures of last October, would be permanent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Truman and a host of other distinguished officials and citizens will attend the funeral service tomorrow for Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War and a hero of World War I, in the National Cathedral of the Protestant Episcopal Church at 3 P. M.
White-haired Mrs. Evyleen Cronin gasped and wept yesterday as Judge Harold A. Stevens gave her a suspended sentence for stealing money from Tallulah Bankhead by raising checks the actress had signed.

Joseph F. O'Brien, a recently discharged policeman, was found guilty of perjury in the first degree last night in Kings County Court, as the District Attorney's office successfully initiated its follow-up drive to punish policemen linked with Harry Gross' bookmaking empire.
Joseph E. Pridday resigned yesterday as president of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn department store, as a new wave of difficulties enveloped the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The State Department was understood today to have given its blessing to the dispatch to Spain of a new United States military group that would explore further the possibility of air and naval bases in that country.

Scientists have a pretty exact set of measurements for most things in the universe, but, as any parent knows, one simple measurement still eludes everybody: that is, the precise length of time expressed by the word "jiffy," as used by an eleven-year-old boy in a variety of sentences which include "I'll be dressed in a jiffy," or "I'll be down in a jiffy," or "It'll only take me a jiffy."

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Coincidental with a forecast that the recession in the American textile industry would soon end, warning was given today of the possibility of short time working in a number of Lancashire mills during coming months.

Fifty per cent of all young persons in rural areas gravitate to urban areas, Dr. Richard P. Saunders, president of the Save the Children Federation, said yesterday. Dr. Saunders, who assumed the presidency on Jan. 1, addressed the federation's New York women's council at its luncheon meeting in Christ Church Parish House to outline the federation program in sponsoring schools for children in rural areas.

Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Stall of the Army, "made his peace" with the Army's newest combat arm -- armor -- last week, but the problem of creating a powerful armored force, equipped with the best tanks in the world, still loomed as one of the major jobs of United States rearmament.

TRIVANDRUM, Travancore-Cochin, India, Jan. 24 -- Discontent flourishes like tropical verdure on the humid Malabar Coast of India, a region that is as poor as it is beautiful. This disaffection found its outlet in recent elections in the state of Travancore-Cochin, which produced what amounted to a humiliating defeat for Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party and a thumping victory for the Communists

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Widespread speculation as to the future status of Col. Earl H. (Red) Blaik at West Point was ended today when Maj. Gen. Frederick A. Irving, superintendent at the United States Military Academy, announced that Colonel Blaik would remain as both director of athletics and football coach.
CAIRO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- British troops continued to comb the Suez Canal zone city of Ismailia today in search of Egyptian snipers and guerrillas who touched Off the recent bloody violence there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Small Defense Plants Administration disclosed today that it has received a total of forty-one applications for loan assistance totaling approximately $33,000,000 in the two and one-half months it has been in existence.

Frederick F. Umhey, executive secretary of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced yesterday his resignation as a charter member of the board of directors of the New York City Center of Music and Drama.
