PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Although most United Nations delegates know no more about the Panmunjom armistice negotiations than they read in the newspapers, it is now the general opinion that if there is to be an armistice it will not be concluded in time for the General Assembly to take up a permanent settlement in Korea during the Paris session.

FOR thirty-seven years no really important British murder trial seemed complete if Sir Bernard Spilsbury did not testify. A tall, extraordinarily handsome man, immaculately dressed, with a flower always in his lapel, he would express his opinions with laconic force and an overpowering air of conviction. "That incomparable witness." one of England's most distinguished lawyers called him.

The training for self-protection in case of atomic bombing now being given to school children here in monthly drills soon will be supplemented with showings of a new film, "Duck and Cover," produced by a local film company in cooperation with the Federal Civil Defense Administration and the National Education Association.

Chester Bowles, United States Ambassador to India, suggested yesterday that American private capital go into partnership with India in an effort to make that four-year-old democracy economically self-sufficient, and thus present to the world a concrete counter-argument to Communist propaganda.

DUBLIN, Jan. 24 -- Statements from Washington by W. Averell Harriman, Mutual Security director, and Ambassador Francis P. Matthews that Ireland might be cut off from all aid under the Mutual Security Act have been received with concern here. Any rift in relations between this country and the United States, especially at this juncture, is something everybody is worried about.
Changes in commodity futures prices were varied yesterday. Cocoa again made strong gains. Wool rose moderately. Coffee lost ground. Sugar and vegetable oils were mixed.

MUNSAN, Korea, Friday, Jan. 25 -- The Allies made a new attempt today to get the stalled Korean armistice talks moving again by proposing that staff officers begin drafting at once an agreement for policing a truce.
One answer to the $30,000,000 question posed in your editorial of Jan. 21, "Riding in Public Transit," is to bring together all transportation facilities in metropolitan New York.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The possibility that the Soviet Union would enter the men's and women's speed skating events at the winter Olympics in Oslo appeared strengthened today by the fact that five new world records in men's events have just been established by Russia's top skating stars.
Anthony Mascagnone, a healthy 12-year-old who takes cooking -- and eating -- seriously, wore a Grand Prix chef's hat yesterday.

Former shareholders of the Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company are being notified today that they will forfeit all rights to recover from the Transamerica Corporation under a court order of last Aug. 8 if they do not file proof of claim by April 25. E. Ennals Berl, special master appointed by the United States District Court of Delaware, is mailing notices to shareholders whose names are available to him.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 4-to-3 decision, ruled today that efforts by the State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles to prevent unsafe driving on the highways did not justify "loose and informal" action in revoking a driver's license.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Administration has accepted what President Truman once called "the terrible Capehart Amendment" in its version of a Defense Production Act to replace legislation that will expire June 30. The bill to be sent to Capitol Hill within a few weeks has been put together to allow ample time for debate before the expiration date.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The International Raw Materials Conference today awarded to the United States 77 per cent of the crude sulphur the free world expects to have available during the first six months of the year. Canada is to share in the United States allocation, but no specific breakdown was given.

Platers Stampers Ltd. has increased its sales volume ten times since it began operations sixteen years ago and is now the largest producer of housewares and kitchenware in England, Arthur Wellesley, a director of the company, declared here yesterday. The company is a subsidiary of Ekco Products Inc. of Chicago.

President Truman, in a letter to the American Jewish Committee, asserted that the United States must assume "the responsibilities of moral and spiritual leadership" of the world, particularly in the field of human rights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, suggested today that Congress let the armed services start Universal Military Training now with men deferred from the draft -- students, farmers and others.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman gave notice yesterday that he would liquidate the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System unless Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., signed a new contract giving the company a free hand on economy lay-offs and cuts in bus service.
OMAHA, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Armour and Company filed a Federal court suit today charging the United Packinghouse Workers Union, C. I. O., with violation of its contract and asked damages of $2,756,600.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, dean of the Graduate School of Public Health at the University of Pittsburgh, told a national conference on the retirement of older workers here today that chronological age alone was "deficient" as an index fox retirement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- American diplomats were ordered today to say good-bye to slow boats to China, Tasmania or anywhere else their official duties carry them.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Industrial prices continued to be depressed today by the stock markets' preoccupation with the sacrifices that the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Robert Austen Butler, is expected to demand next week. A late rally left them still dull but helped British Government securities and foreign bonds to recover or to reduce their losses.

Successful treatment of young narcotics addicts depends on the help given by the community to integrate them fater their release from hospitals, Dr. Murray Diamond, clinical director of the United States Public Health Service Hospital in Lexington, Ky., said yesterday.

Many dinners will be given at the forty-third annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School at Bristol, Va., tonight in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. James F. Hoge and Mrs. John D. Baker Jr. are co-chairmen of the dance committee.

Anti-Semitism can best be combatted by encouraging prejudiced persons to "talk out their prejudice under competent guidance and proper environment," Rabbi Henry E. Kagan of Sinai Temple, Mount Vernon, N. Y., declared here yesterday. Rabbi Kagan, who also is an instructor in psychological guidance at Teachers College, Columbia University, spoke at a luncheon given by the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Theron Lamar Caudle, ousted Assistant Attorney General, said today that he ha dsent a check for $999.32 to the Internal Revenue Bureau here in full payment of his 1950 income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Andrew N. Overby was sworn in today as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, succeeding William McC. Martin Jr., who resigned the post last year to become chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Overby has been deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund since February, 1949.

Market value of all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $3,174,874,842 in December according to a compilation by the Exchange yesterday. Aggregate value was $109,483,613,065 on Dec. 31, against $106,308,738,223 on Nov. 30.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet proposal that the United Nations admit fourteen countries -- five Communist states and nine non-Communist states -- received support today from Scandinavian and Arab delegates.

The Panama Line, operators of passenger and cruise service between New York and Cristobal, C. Z., has decided to continue its operations from here after surveying the feasibility of removing its terminus to another Atlantic port.
Three more Giants and two Dodgers returned their signed contracts yesterday, raising the Giant total to fifteen and the Brooks' to sixteen.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Kenneth Younger, Minister of State in the Foreign Office under the Labor Government, said today that Prime Minister Churchill in his address to the United States Congress had given an impression of encouraging Far East policies that Britain considered "dangerous and futile."

The United States Golf Association yesterday made public the dates for the 1953 Walker Cup matches at the Kittansett Club, Marion, Mass., and for the 1953 championships. The championship sites had been set previously.

Orin Lehman, nephew of Senator Herbert H. Lehman, whom he succeeded as a member of the public advisory board for the Economic Cooperation Administration, was designated last night as New York City's "Outstanding Young Man of the Year" by the Young Men's Board of Trade and the Junior Chamber of Commerce.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- A proposed amendment to West Berlin's law for compensation of Nazi victims would extend benefits to persons who were nominally Nazi party members but later suffered damages as a result of opposition to the Hitler regime. An estimated 1,200 to 1,500 persons here and abroad would be affected.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 24 -- United States tin production in November was the lowest since August, 1943, and tinplate output reached a two-year low, the International Tin Study Group reported today.

Sales promotion practices and procedures for smaller stores are outlined in a new publication, "Sales Promotion Manual for Smaller Stores," issued jointly yesterday by the sales promotion and smaller stores divisions of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Tunisia became the uppermost topic in French politics today. When the National Assembly discussed the admission of Greece and Turkey to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, many sections of opinion voiced their discontent that Tunisia and Morocco had not been included in the Nato area of defense.

There are many indications around the country that manufacturers and wholesalers are "loaded with merchandise inventories" which eventually they will have to sell, New York City Commissioner of Purchase John Splain, told more than seventy-five participants in the fourth annual economic seminar of the Department of Purchase yesterday, in sessions held in the Municipal Building.

Estes Kefauver has formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. The ambitious and able young Tennessean -- not yet 50 -- first leaped to national prominence when he administered a sound licking to Boss Crump of Memphis; and now, while still a freshman Senator, he has become a familiar figure to every television household in the land as a result of his famous crime investigation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Admiral William M. Fechteler, Chief of Naval Operations, said tonight that the Navy expected to have an atomic-powered supercarrier by about 1960 that would be able to cruise at top speed "almost indefinitely."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- In a move that may have great political significance, President Truman signed an executive order late today authorizing the Senate Rules Committee to inspect tax returns in connection with any of its pending investigations.
SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 24 (AP) -- A special master in bankruptcy today ruled the 1937 sale of the Williamsport (Pa.) Wire and Rope Company to the Bethlehem Steel Company for $3,300,000 was a fraud.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -- New Yorkers did less drinking last year, although they imbibed more heavily in hard liquor than in 1950. The over-all drop in consumption of alcoholic drinks was attributed to a decline in beer sales from 23.3 gallons a person in 1950 to 22.75 gallons last year. Sales of hard liquor (over 24 per cent alcohol) were up from 1.6 to 1.7 gallons a person.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The City of London agreed today to lend to the British Government its Chief of Police, Col. Arthur Edwin Young, for a year, to reorganize the Malayan police force. Colonel Young will leave next month and will serve under Gen. Sir Gerald Templer, the new High Commissioner.

Almost since the first day of television there has been a widespread assumption in both musical and TV circles that fine music does not lend itself to visual treatment by the cameras. What appealed to the eye, it was feared, would prove only distracting to the ear. With the exception of Arturo Toscanini's conducting of the N. B. C. Symphony, the fear often has been amply justified.

Although defense credits were expanded last week, seasonal influences reduced business borrowings from New York banks $31,000,000. The reduction, third to be registered in the last four weeks, brought the decline in such borrowings since Dec. 27 to $83,000,000, in contrast to an increase of $78,000,000 in the same period a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Government, which has spent more than $500,000 trying to discharge one $5,450-a-year employe, finally made the dismissal effective today.

A Federal statute that forbids the transfer of American-flag ships to foreign purchasers without the prior consent of the Maritime Administration is assailed in the latest issue of The Shipping Survey as unfair and discriminatory.

ROME, Jan. 24 -- Negotiations are far advanced to take the La Scala Opera Company to America this summer for a two-month opera season at Jones Beach, L. I. Producer Michael Todd, who is in charge of the American end of the negotiations, expects the La Scala board of directors to reach a definite decision on Saturday.

New orders for machine tools moved up sharply in December from an index level of 330.5 in November to 416.8 in the last month of the year, it was disclosed here yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders Association, a national trade organization.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 25 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,139, for Thursday's operations:

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Gilbert Orcel's horseshoe coifs are just about the briefest hats that have appeared to date, and among the most enchanting. Flat and clinging to the front of the head more or less in a horseshoe curve, they leave the back and half of the top of the head uncovered.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 24 -- Complete confidence in his ability to win a majority in the Bundestag for conscription and rearmament over a clamorous but disparate opposition was expressed today by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

The Board of Estimate blocked yesterday, by a vote of 13 to 3, a move by Controller Lazarus Joseph to impose upon it the duty of approving all appointments to fill city job vacancies. First Deputy Controller Lewis F. Lang, sitting for Mr. Joseph, who was unavoidably absent, forced a roll-call on the proposal and cast the three affirmative votes.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The controversial question of the state's strict divorce law was raised in the Legislature again today with the introduction of a bill to create a twenty-three-member commission to study all phases of the problem.

OTTAWA, Jan. 24 -- At the same time as Vincent Massey's appointment as Governor General was announced here, it was made known that at his own request Viscount Alexander's term would end on Jan. 28 and that until the new Governor General assumes his duties an administrator, usually the Chief Justice, would perform the duties of the office.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman, Australia's top tennis player, reached the final of the Australian national championships today, beating his countryman, Mervyn Rose, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Cases of alleged favoritism and influence in the Justice Department, some "personally" involving Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, were given to the House Judiciary Committee today behind closed doors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A strong endorsement of the four Pacific treaties now before the Senate has been given by Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson Week was bound to come and here it is in full spate. It was bound to come about this time in 1952 if President Truman was still silent as to his intentions toward seeking another term because:

President Truman has asked Congress to pass a mine safety bill with teeth in it. Secretary of the Interior Oscar Chapman told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that if the Government had had authority to enforce its mine safety regulations it could have prevented the disaster which cost 119 lives in Orient Mine No. 2 at West Frankfort, Ill., last December.

The National Production Authority is preparing the first end-use limitation order on zinc and is contemplating a further diversion to consumers of supplies of the metal due for the national stockpile of critical materials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Truman refused again today to disclose whether he would be a candidate for re-election or whether he might leave the Presidency and seek his old Senate seat from Missouri, but he said he probably would announce his intentions before the deadline for filing for office in his home state. The deadline in Missouri is April 29.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Will Rogers Jr., with only four days' experience behind him as a professional actor, has no desire to pursue Thespis beyond "attempting," as he said today, to portray his late father in "The Story of Will Rogers."

MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Eatontown, Mrs. A. Roberts' stakes-winning gelding who survived a serious intestinal operation last year, again proved that he retains all of his speed and class when he captured the $4,000 Seminole Purse at Hialeah Park today.
A proposed civil defense mutual assistance pact between New York State and the Provinces of Ontario and Quebec was discussed at a meeting of Federal, state and Canadian defense officials here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) -- The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives today approved a bill aimed at shutting off the flow of Mexican laborers who cross the border illegally to do farm work in the United States.

The first break in beef prices since last fall was reported yesterday by the city Department of Markets. General declines of 1 to 3 cents a pound on five cuts were attributed to an improved supply and price reductions at wholesale.

An audience of 1,200 high school boys and girls, participating in the New York Times Youth Forum yesterday at Benjamin Franklin Junior High School in Yonkers, hailed Jackie Robinson of the Brooklyn Dodgers, guest on a panel with six students who discussed the subject: "Does Youth Understand Moral and Spiritual Values?"

When Isabel Mourao reached the last quarter of her program in Town Hall last night one listener felt that she was Just hitting her pianistic stride. It was the attractive Brazilian performer's North American debut, and she was probably -- and understandably -- nervous.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Senate was notified today by Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, that, before the appointment of Harry A. McDonald, a fellow Republican, to head the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was submitted for confirmation, he would move that the Senate first act on a long-pending bill designed to abolish the R. F. C. itself.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has changed the base period for its indexes of department store sales and stocks, it was announced yesterday. Previously it used the 1935-39 average as a base; under the revision it will use the average of the three years from 1947 to 1949.

Three books about South Africa written by South Africans are scheduled for publication in the next three months. Houghton Mifflin will publish on Feb. 4 Daphne Rooke's new novel, "Mittee," a story about life in a farming community.

HASTINGS, Neb., Jan. 24 -- Officials of Nebraska's Public Power System expressed fear today that the Department of the Interior might force the liquidation of the country's only statewide public power set-up through marketing methods of Federal power.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 -- After a fierce battle with rebel forces all of yesterday, Nepalese Government troops have the situation under control in Katmandu, the capital of Nepal, according to latest reports reaching here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Disability will become a major obstacle to national strength unless determined efforts are made to cope with it, a task force appointed in June to develop plans for the effective use of handicapped workers has reported.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Julius Boros of Mid Pines, N. C., starting his second year on the professional golf trail, scored a five-under-par 66 for the first-round lead in the $10,000 Phoenix open tournament today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 24 -- A dissident group of Caodaists, and not the Communists-led Vietminh forces, is held responsible here for the latest outbreak of terrorism in Saigon. Twelve persons have been killed and more than eighty-five injured by delayed-action explosive charges set off this month.

Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue has a subtle way of charming with her designs. In her spring collection of ready-to-wear shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, she delighted her audience with prettily molded bodices, skirts cut and stiffened to flare with grace, soft shoulders, wool suits with dainty blouses of gossamer silk and lace -- always a signature of this designer -- and such other familiar touches as her ombre evening nets.

The war in Korea, which started with a long-prepared and Soviet-supported Communist assault on June 25, 1950, enters its twentieth month today. The Korean armistice negotiations, which began with the Malik broadcast of June 23 1951, are now in their eighth month. During this time the United Nations, supported by the proffered aid of forty-six nations and the armed forces of seventeen, has succeeded in throwing aggression back beyond the line from which it started.
As a journalist and student resident in the Middle East I present to the people of the United States an open plea for justice and a calm reconsideration of our policy there.

The stock market stumbled around yesterday in erratic fashion, with interest shifting through various sections and ending up in a mixed pattern. There was no definite trend during the session, a few more issues advanced than declined, business operated at a slower pace and the composite rate showed a net fall of 0.58 point.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 (UP) -- Sid Abel's third-period goal enabled the league-leading Detroit Red Wings to tie the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 2, tonight before 15,102 fans, the largest week-day crowd ever to see a National Hockey League game in Detroit.

TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United Nations commander, announced today that the Imperial Hotel here, one of the most famous buildings in Japan, would end its career as billeting quarters for ranking United Nations military personnel and civilian very important persons on March 31 and that Japan would regain control of other hotels and office buildings as soon as possible.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Since the Bey of Tunis did not join with the French Resident General in his appeal to the Tunisian population for a return to order, a French ministerial conference here tonight decided to rush parachutists and military reinforcements to Tunisia.

Preliminary plans for the appeal for $2,414,522 by the Catholic Charities of New York, as approved by Cardinal Spellman, were announced yesterday by Msgr. James J. Lynch, archdiocesan director of the organization. The announcement was made following a meeting of the district managers for the archdiocese's 386 parishes.

The Shell Oil Company, the United States unit of the Royal Dutch-Shell Group, had estimated net earnings in 1951 of $97,000,000, according to the preliminary annual report of H. S. M. Burns, president, released today.

Regarding Berthold Wyler's letter published in THE TIMES of Jan. 1 on the subject of Switzerland's stand, the gentleman, although writing in the first person plural, is speaking strictly for himself as far as most Swiss are concerned. In history, in international and constitutional law as well as in current affairs, Swiss neutrality is a matter considerably more complex than Mr. Wyler would have you believe.

" Saint Joan," starring Uta Hagen, will reach the end of its run at the Century on Feb. 2 instead of a week later. Presented for the second time by the Theatre Guild, the revival opened Oct. 4 at the Cort, where it stayed until Jan. 5.

Further testimony that James J. Moran profited as First Deputy Fire Commissioner from payments extorted from oil burner installers up to Nov. 10, 1950, and that Frank J. Sampson, assistant to Mayor Impellitteri, received the payments thereafter, was produced by the state yesterday at Moran's extortion conspiracy trial in General Sessions Court.

Miguel Roldan, 44-year-old former New York night club owner, credited with popularizing the Conga, a Cuban dance, in this country, was booked at the Simpson Street Station in the Bronx early today on a charge of homicide in the fatal stabbing of his 11-year-old son in the apartment of his estranged wife, Mrs. Marie Louisa Roldan, 30, at 1117 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, late last night.

Another promising week-end of skiing is in store for Eastern enthusiasts, who have been enjoying one of the best seasons in years. New snow was reported at many points and with the prospect of additional cover followed by cold weather tomorrow, the outlook is favorable.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 24 -- The disorders in Tunisia began to assume the appearance of an insurrection in some parts of the country tonight with at least fourteen more persons killed during the last thirty-six hours by assassins or in open clashes between nationalist crowds and French security forces.
C. E. Graham Reeves has resigned as a director and vice president of Reeves Brothers, Inc., textile house.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 24 -- Grants totaling $17,500 in scholarships, prizes and awards in the fields of labor-management relations, race relations and meritorious public service were made here tonight by the trustees of the Sidney Hillman Foundation at their animal dinner.

Establishment of a College of School and Teacher Services at Wesleyan University, in Middletown, Conn., was announced last night by Victor L. Butterfield, president of the 121-year-old institution. He said the college would open in the fall.

The first three winners of the Clarke F. Ansley Dissertation Awards were announced yesterday by Columbia University. The prizes, to be given annually, make possible the publication in book form of three outstanding dissertations submitted for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at the university.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- During the week ended Jan. 23, member bank reserves increased $172,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 25 -- The Peiping radio charged this morning that United States planes had flown over Manchuria and had dropped bombs in Lioatung Province, north of the Korean border on the Yalu River.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Governor Dewey's executive budget slated for submission to the Legislature next week, will make $155,000,000 available for highway and parkway construction. This is twice the amount provided for this purpose in the budget submitted last year.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 -- The police raided a Communist Youth club today as three days of balloting in Teheran came to a close.
Johnny Saxton, undefeated welterweight from Brooklyn, will appear in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. His opponent will be Livio Minelli, veteran from Bergamo, Italy.

With regard to the very interesting editorial, "Wood and Point Four," in your Jam 12 issue, I note that the American Geographical Society is alarmed at an estimated unsatisfied demand of 700,000,000 cubic meters of round wood.

THAT extravaganza of the open spaces which annually is crammed into the confined acres of Grand Central Palace, known as the Sportsmen's Show, is scheduled to open for its nine-day run on Feb. 16 and advance reports indicate that the exposition will include a number of new displays designed to vibrate the aesthetic as well as the sporting chord of sportsmen.

Governor Dewey called upon the United States last night to serve notice on the Soviet Union that further Communist aggression in Southeast Asia would be met by "every weapon at our command and every weapon we may develop in the future."

Though it is in summer that the bees gather nectar for honey, most of the liquid sweetening comes to market in winter. This year, supplies are the largest ever for the 1951 crop of 249,000,000 pounds broke all records. Here are some recipes that owe their distinction to honey.
" Ribbons and Laces and Old Fashioned Faces," an exhibit opening today in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum recreates life in early America.

A demonstration of the functioning of a civil defense first-aid station after an enemy attack on the city was held yesterday at the Kips Bay-Yorkville Health Center, 411 East Sixty-ninth Street, as part of the city defense organization's drive for 300,000 Medical Emergency Division volunteers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 -- A statewide campaign committee to push the candidacy of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for the Democratic Presidential nomination now is being set up, it was announced here today by David L. Foutz of Los Angeles.

Trustees for the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System informed Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday that they were negotiating with "several groups" of private investors for purchase of the company's bus and trolley lines in lower Westchester County.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 24 -- Public indignation over eighty-five deaths in two airplane accidents here within the last six weeks boiled over tonight at a mass meeting called by municipal officials in City Hall.

Major changes in top executive posts of the Cities Service system, effective on Feb. 1, were announced yesterday by W. Alton Jones, president of the parent Cities Service Company. The moves are part of a program to gear the executive staff to the growth of business and expansion of facilities.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Money for 250 tickets sold to white persons for a Marian Anderson recital here last night was refunded because of a clause against segregation in the Negro singer's contract.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Political emigres from Eastern European dictatorships completed a four-day conference here today by announcing progress toward blueprints for closer cooperation with other European nations following liberation and more democracy at home than ever before.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Britain, France and the United States today once more asked the Soviet Union to come to the conference table and complete a treaty for Austria s independence.

Guido Cantelli began his final week as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night and impressed one anew with the clarity, precision and predictability of the response he got from the ensemble.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $6,290,246 for 1951, compared with $5,927,114 in the preceding year. The balance of net income available for the utility's outstanding common stock was $2.18 a share based on the 2,396,950 shares outstanding at the year-end.

Vincent Massey had the honor of being the first Canadian Minister to the United States. Now, as was announced in London yesterday, he will be the first Canadian-born Governor General of Canada. His many friends here will welcome this new distinction, and one presumes the appointment will be received in Canada as a happy solution of a question which has stirred up some controversy north of the border.
Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to make no change in present trading hours.
A "safety" drive by American Federation of Labor drivers and mechanics that has slowed bus service for Staten Island bus riders since Monday spread to Queens yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Miss Pat Garner of Midland, Tex., beat Miss Polly Riley of Forth Worth 1 up today for the biggest upset of the day during the first round of match play in the Helen Lee Doherty golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Railway Express Agency to go ahead with plans to apply a special 6-cents-a-shipment surcharge on the bulk of its business.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, Jan. 24 -- The Egyptian Government's implied threat to oppose British troops by force, coupled with yesterday's statements by Fuad Serag el-Din Pasha, the Interior Minister in Cairo, has led to a change in atmosphere in the Suez Canal zone.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- The Port of Philadelphia, extending from Trenton on the north to Wilmington on the south, was tied up today by what union leaders called a "lockout" of longshoremen.

A "modern-living-perspective" promotion, in which Lincoln-Mercury dealers have combined with the Drexel Furniture Company and many home accessory manufacturers, is expected to result this year in one of the biggest campaigns in department store history.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard Austen Butler, declared today that the cooperation of the non-sterling countries, notably including the United States, was needed for speed and completeness in the British Commonwealth's efforts to maintain and strengthen sterling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 747,662 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 4,905 cars or 0.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 32,088 cars or 4.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 128,499 cars or 20.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Dr. Leopold Stieglitz, family doctor to many of the city's great merchants, editors, artists and writers, will begin without ceremony today his sixty-first year of general practice under the State Board of Regents' medical license No. 1.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- A leading steel producer served notice on the Wage Stabilization Board today that the steel industry would not go along with any Government recommendation for higher wages that failed to provide "an equivalent increase in steel prices."
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Windy City II, the European juvenile champion of 1951, was easily beaten at Santa Anita today in his first start on the American turf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Truman reiterated today, in the face of a protest pilgrimage to Washington by more than 500 Protestant clergymen, that he was standing by his intention of sending an Ambassador to the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales in the United States during the week ended Jan. 19, declined 14 per cent below sales in the same period of last year.
TRENTON, Jan. 24 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll announced today he intended to nominate Maj. Russell A. Snook of Trenton as Superintendent of the State Police succeeding Col. Charles H. Schoeffel.

Philip Loeb, the actor who was dropped from the television cast of "The Goldbergs," has received a financial settlement to cover the remainder of his contract with Gertrude Berg, owner and star of the program.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The appointment of Vincent Massey as Governor General of Canada in succession to Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, who will assume "other responsibilities," was announced from Buckingham Palace tonight.
Alger Hiss, former State Department official now serving a five-year sentence for perjury, filed in Federal Court yesterday a motion for a new trial based on "newly discovered evidence."

A goal of $150,000 in contributions to the National Conference of Christians and Jews from the motion-picture industry was announced yesterday by Henry A. Linet, publicity chairman for the industry's participation in the 1952 drive for funds, according to a statement from the organization.
The American Radio Association, C. I. O. yesterday urged the responsible Government agencies to require that portable lifeboat radio equipment be placed on all American ships in the future.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 24 -- Approximately 200 industrialists, business men and civic leaders of Connecticut today expressed opposition to the Federal Government's advocacy of decentralization and dispersal of manufacturing plants.
McCreery's Big Top restaurant was host to the press and "the greatest girl on earth" -- she who balances budget, a job and home life -- at a luncheon-fashion show yesterday.

Plans were advanced at recent meetings held in the Tea Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria for the sixtieth annual New York Wellesley Club luncheon, which will be given on Feb. 2 in the Starlight Roof of the hotel. Mrs. Robert Nias West is chairman of the executive committee for the event, and among her aides is Mrs. Valentine Zahn, president of the New York Wellesley Club.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 24 -- Premier Willem Drees of the Netherlands said today that the Dutch people were prepared -- although somewhat reluctantly -- to ally themselves with Germany in forming a European army.

Stockholders of the Chain Belt Company at their annual meeting yesterday authorized an increase in capital stock to 1,000,000 shares of $10-par value from the now outstanding 500,000 shares of no-par value. The new stock is to be exchanged for the old on a share-for-share basis, leaving 500,000 authorized but unissued.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick upheld today the constitutionality of the state's weight-distance tax on heavy trucks. He rejected the truckers' arguments that the law was unreasonable, discriminatory and violated the Federal and state Constitutions.

WHEN Gilbert Dodds missed the boat for the 1948 Olympics because he couldn't run fast enough with his injured tenden to catch it, the United States lost whatever chance it had to win the 1,500-meter event, the classic metric mile. As usual, the Olympic Committee was scratching hard for contributions to finance the expedition and it almost seemed like a needless expenditure of scarce funds to send any 1,500-meter men abroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Army stood firm today on its ruling that motherhood outranked majorhood.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The Wage Stabilization Board's Michigan Enforcement Commission today imposed two penalties upon a construction company that had paid forty Ann Arbor bricklayers 25 cents an hour more than the lawful rate for that area.

FONTAINBLEAU, France, Jan. 24 -- A shortage of spare parts that has seriously hampered United States-equipped European air forces in General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's command may be ended soon, according to well-informed air experts here.

Clarence H. Staples, Los Angeles representative of the firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, yesterday presented to Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, a "broker's medal" from eighteenth century London. Under a 1696 act by King William III, stockbrokers in London were required to produce on demand a silver identification medal, with the royal arms on one side and those of the City of London on the other.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- General selling forced grain future prices down sharply today, with the weakness attributed in part to recent sharp declines in soybeans, lard and vegetable oils. Commission absorption was sufficient to check the declines and bring about fair rallies in wheat, corn and oats, while rye showed a relatively strong tone throughout the session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue virtually cleared the House of Representatives today when the House Expenditures Committee unanimously rejected a resolution of disapproval.

Indications are that "higher-cost money" will continue at least for some months, Nugent Fallon, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, told the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday. The meeting was attended by about 700 savings institution executives representing 409 member savings and loan associations and savings banks.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 24 (UP) -- Fatalities in the big Northern blizzard rose to twenty-one today as rescuers dug the bodies of two South Dakota ranchers out of fifteen-foot snowdrifts.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 -- A United States mission is expected here soon to begin conversations with the Mexican Government on an agreement that would qualify this country to receive military aid under the Mutual Security Assistance Program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 24 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said today that his views on Universal Military Service should not be confused with the Universal Military Training program under consideration by Congress.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 -- A United States mission is expected here soon to begin conversations with the Mexican Government on an agreement that would qualify this country to receive military aid under the Mutual Security Assistance Program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 24 -- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said today that his views on Universal Military Service should not be confused with the Universal Military Training program under consideration by Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- Dr. Clark Kerr, a 40-year-old economist and arbitrator of labor-management disputes, was elected chancellor for the Berkeley campus of the University of California today by a unanimous vote of the Board of Regents.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan 25 (AP) -- Nepal's Government today outlawed the Communist party in that strategic Himalayan kingdom. The Nepalese Embassy here said that the action was taken because the Communists abetted a revolt earlier in the week.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- A citizens' movement of ground-swell proportions is bringing more support to the public schools than ever before in the country's history.

THE great justification of the novelist is to show us that there are no ordinary human beings. The orators may spend half their time speaking of the common man, the other half speaking of the uncommon one -- always letting us know, sooner or later, that they mean the same thing. They are on the side of human dignity, all right.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- One thousand paratroopers of the 188th Regimental Combat Team of the Eleventh Airborne Division jumped in formation here today before 2,000 persons. Forty-one of the men suffered injuries, all minor except for one broken leg and a dislocated shoulder.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- The "battle" in American education would end abruptly if persons would concentrate on developing schools and colleges best suited for all the children rather than fighting for special philosophies, Mrs. Millicent Carey McIntosh, dean of Barnard College, told the Westchester County Federation of Women's Club today.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 25 -- Tunisia passed through a day of nervous calm today, with the two major trouble spots of the country under conditions that represented martial law, in fact if not in name.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged the maker of Imdrin, a patent medicine, with "falsely" advertising that it would cure or serve as an effective treatment for arthritic or rheumatic conditions.

Retail prices of many toys will be reduced this year to slightly above the 1950 levels. Some toy manufacturers, anticipating rising costs in raw materials that did not develop, increased prices early in 1951. During this period, retailers bought almost everything produced and manufacturers felt the higher prices were justified.
Protestant young people in New York and vicinity will join hundreds of thousands of others in the United States and Canada next week in answering a "Call to United Christian Youth Action."

The tragedy of Egypt flared up luridly yesterday in the Suez Canal zone town of Ismailia when the British attempted to disarm a force of Egyptian auxiliary police and ran into a pitched battle in which some forty-five men died. Before the five hours of fighting were over the British had brought up tanks and armored cars.

Ambassador Binay Ranjan Sen of India said yesterday his country had thrown its doors wide open to foreign capital in an effort to obtain adequate long-term assistance in a "close race with time." India's aim, he said, is to solve domestic problems of hunger and economic insecurity.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Barbara Romack, 19-year-old from Sacramento, Calif., eliminated defending champion Claire Doran of Cleveland, Ohio, in the third round of the twentieth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers:

TOKYO, Jan. 25 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Japanese Parliament today that he had agreed to limited recognition of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's regime on Formosa as the legitimate Government of China at the request of the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Michael Moretti, a suspended policeman for the State's Attorney, was convicted today of murder and his punishment set at life imprisonment.

HILLBURN, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- Mayor Charles Banker of Hillburn, civil engineer for the American Brake Shoe Company, has turned over to James s. Bixby, regional director for the State Department of Public Works, an alternate route that would permit the New York State Thruway to bypass the incorporated villages of Hillburn, Suffern and Sloatsburg.

The necessity for the continued existence of voluntary community relations agencies so that civil liberties can be safeguarded and intergroup relations promoted more effectively was stressed yesterday by Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, which opened its forty-fifth annual meeting at the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Military action to disarm the Egyptian auxiliary police in Ismailia was approved by the British Government but it was not expected here that such a deadly battle as occurred today would be the result.
Except for cocoa, which reacted from its recent gains, and sugar, which marked time, commodity futures prices were generally firm to strong yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The shutdown of dry cargo facilities in the Philadelphia port area blocked the loading today of Army supplies on three freighters. Twenty other sea-going vessels were diverted from Delaware River piers between Trenton, N. J., and Wilmington, Del.

Two armed hold-up men escaped with a payroll of almost $27,000 yesterday morning from a contractor's shanty at a Queens housing project after disarming three guards and keeping at bay five construction employes. The money had arrived only fifteen minutes before the hold-up.

Ernest K. Halbach, former president of General Dyestuff Corporation, was found innocent by a jury in Federal Court last night of Government charges that he conspired to divide world markets in a cartel agreement with a German concern. The verdict was returned at 11:15 P. M. after a deliberation of ten hours.
TOKYO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The North Korean radio reported tonight the Communists hold forty-seven foreigners who were not named in prisoner of war lists delivered to the Allies.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The State Department of Taxation and Finance moved today to collect the distance-mileage tax on heavy trucks which went into effect on Oct. 1. Letters will be mailed tomorrow to the owners of 240,000 trucks advising them that back taxes would be regarded as delinquent after Feb. 5.
Thomas Eboli, 40-year-old fight manager, and his brother, Patsy, 27, appeared yesterday in court on assault charges for the second time this week, this time on the complaint of an Iranian official.

The Department of Sanitation will be forced to reduce the frequency of waste collections throughout the city unless its full complement of 9,800 men can be restored in the 1952-53 budget, Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, in a surprise decision, withdrew today from the Illinois Democratic Presidential preferential primary, declaring that he could not in good conscience campaign for support for himself "when in my own mind I prefer someone else -- Harry S. Truman."

MADRID Jan. 25 -- In an effort to facilitate European defense planning, Spain is preparing to accommodate her national railway network to that of the rest of the Continent and has already begun working out a system of standardizing her military weapons more nearly along American lines, according to Lieut. Gen. Agustin Munoz Grandes, Minister of the Army.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The Sun Oil Company and subsidiaries reported today that their consolidated net income in 1951 amounted to $45,353,974, compared with $36,291,498 in the previous year.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 -- The American Woolen Company, which produces one out of every seven yards of woolen cloth turned out in the United States, agreed today to extend its present contract with the Textile Workers Union of America from the expiration date of Feb. 1 to March 1 in order to negotiate completely new agreements.

Some first-rate choral singing was done by the Singing Boys of Norway in Carnegie Hall last night. There were three or four dozen of them, dressed in white, long-trousered suits with blue capes falling down their backs, and they stood in a rising semi-circle about their director, Ragnvald Bjarne, who founded the group twenty-five years ago.

Pork, now the most attractively priced item at meat counters, probably will continue plentiful through next month. Supplies coming to market currently are from the bumper pig crop last spring. The second largest on record, it totaled close to 62,000,000 porkers.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- An official of the Textile Workers Union predicted here today that labor soon would seek legislation to compel newer industries to employ a minimum proportion of older workers.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The annual meeting of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association heard today it was not unreasonable to expect, between 1951 and 1955, a total new capital investment in pulp and paper facilities of more than $600,000,000.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Measures to give the Church of England greater freedom from parliamentary control, while retaining its status as the "established church" of the realm, were recommended today in a report to the Church Assembly.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A livestock specialist said today a reduction in hog numbers this year would be sufficient virtually to wipe out all of the increase in the last three years. Higher prices will result, he predicted.

Last represented on Broadway as co-producer of "Bathsheba," the Jacques Deval play that featured James Mason and Pamela Kellino in 1947, Maximilian Becker hopes to resume his producing activities this season with a new script called "The Happy Ant Hill."

Fred J. Emmerich of Read Emmerich, imports and exports, has been elected chairman of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade, succeeding John A. Zellers, who becomes honorary chairman.

A resolution "unanimously condemning" the report of state fact-finders on last fall's twenty-five-day dock strike was adopted by the strike committee of members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., last night.

David H. Murray and Donald C. Heath have been elected vice presidents of Wm. B. Remington, Inc., Springfield, Mass. Mr. Murray, an account executive, will supervise all agency copy. Mr. Heath, also an account executive, will supervise development of all marketing plans for agency clients in addition to his other duties.

Terminating an ownership of I fifty years, Marie Bzata has sold the five-story apartment house [with two stores at 302 East Seventieth Street to a client of J. Lemle i Sons. S. Sason was co-broker in the transaction. The property, on :a plot 26 by 100 feet, is seventyfour feet from the southeast corner of Second Avenue.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 -- Discussions to decide how many United States troops and bases would be retained in Japan as garrison forces after the signing of the Japanese peace treaty were begun today shortly after the arrival by air of a State Department - Defense Department mission headed by Dean Rusk, President Truman's personal representative, and Earl D. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of the Army.

In this period of steel scarcity, many interests have wrestled with the problem of getting stagnant steel and idle equipment into use or moved to steel mills as scrap for melting into new steel. Credit for the latest new idea to spur that effort goes to Joseph T. Ryerson Son, Inc., of Chicago, one of the nation's largest steel distributors.
My attention has just been called to a dispatch by Jack Raymond under the heading "Exiles' Alliances Disturb Officials," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 27, 1951.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Connecticut's small manufacturers were assured today by Federal officials that larger supplies of critical metals such as copper, steel and aluminum will be available for them in coming months.

With emphasis on conservation because of material shortages and the need to curb spending, the Hooker Electrochemical Company has developed a cleaning agent which has so far salvaged $20,000 worth of materials at a cost of only $3,000.

Today's new film is "Mrs. Drake's Duck," a comedy starring Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Yolande Donlan, at the Embassy Guild Theatre in Rockefeller Center. Val Guest wrote and directed the offering, which was produced by Mr. Fairbanks and Daniel M. Angel and is being released by United Artists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency postponed its decision today on President Truman's appointment of Harry A. McDonald, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, as administrator of the reorganized Reconstruction Finance Corporation with intimations that it first might subject the S. E. C. to a full-scale investigation.

Lower air and ground losses in Korea may result from use of the new Fairchild Rapidyne aerial camera shutter. The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, which developed the unit, said that the device permitted more accurate photography at higher flying speeds than was possible previously, thus aiding the photographers to avoid attacking fighters and ground fire.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,140, for Friday's operations:

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Claude Saint Cyr's opening confirms an important trend in spring hats: side emphasis. But it is slight, for hats are small, merely plateaux curving downward and a little outward at each side. In fact, they are half hats, the front half, with the coiffure exposed up to the top of the head in back.

Cultured Japanese pearls valued at $35,000 were stolen from the cargo area of the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, sometime between their arrival on Monday and 10 A. M. yesterday. The pearls were of the white variety, said to be the more expensive types.

The three-day stand of the thirty-first annual Middle Atlantic figure skating championships, held under the auspices of the Skating Club of New York, started at the Iceland rink yesterday and, after a long session, four titles were decided.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- February allocations of refined copper by the National Production Authority are nearly 14,000 tons smaller than for January, it was disclosed today. Sharpest cuts were made in allocations for brass mill products and wire mill products.

Senator Robert A. Taft sat through three and a half hours of lampooning by the Circus Saints and Sinners yesterday, grinning widely at the satirizing of himself, a coterie of other Presidential aspirants and President Truman.

ROME, Jan. 25 -- Unusual optimism prevailed in Italian official circles today as Premier De Gasperi left for Paris to attend the conference of the six Continental European Foreign Ministers, which will attempt to remove the last technical difficulties stnading in way of creation of a European army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Senator Brien McMahon said today that "the very large expansion" in the atomic program to be recommended soon would put the United States in a position, for a few years at least, where the Soviet Union would not dare attack.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Confusion over a court action temporarily halted today a reopening of the Communists-in-Hollywood inquiry by the House Un-American Activities Committee.

ROME, Jan. 25 -- The Government of Premier Alcide De Gasperi was defeated by seventeen votes in the Italian Chamber of Deputies this morning when a majority of Deputies, overriding protests by Finance Minister Ezio Vanoni, voted to increase the salaries of state employes beyond the limit that the Government considered acceptable.

The manager of a Manufacturer's Trust Company branch in the Bronx and three other men were arrested early today on charges of forgery, grand larceny and conspiracy after a series of check-kitings and fraudulent loans that may result in a $50,000 loss to the bank, the police reported.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 25 -- Congress and the State of New Jersey moved today for more effective air-ground safety measures, spurred by two recent air crashes here that killed eighty-five persons, including six Elizabeth residents whose homes were struck by an American Airlines plane in rain and fog last Tuesday.

" The Geography of Hunger," by Josue de Castro, executive chairman of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Commission, has been scheduled for Feb. 28 publication by Little, Brown. It is described as a "refutation" of William Vogt's "Road to Survival" and other treatises on the relationship between overpopulation and hunger.
The New York State Optometric Association urged defeat yesterday of the Neddo-Brady bill that would allow ready-made eyeglasses to be sold in this state by others than physicians or optometrists.

Dean Young B. Smith of Columbia University's Law School asserted yesterday that because of the "difficult financial situation" facing the nation's major universities the Government might "in the not too distant future have to take over" these institutions of higher learning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The House Interstate Commerce Committee today called hearings Monday on the possibility of a fuel oil shortage on the East Coast.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 26 -- Communist representatives discussing an armistice in the Korean war told the United Nations today to wait a little longer for a decision whether or not the Chinese and North Koreans would accept an Allied plan to speed up the deadlocked conversations at Panmunjom.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, said today that the steel industry could pay its workers a "considerable" wage increase without raising prices.

No sale of Frederick Loeser Co., Brooklyn department store, has been consummated as yet, but negotiations are still in progress, and if they fail the store is likely to be closed and its inventory and real estate liquidated, it was learned yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 25 -- Iran is working on a deal with the West German steel industry that may bring her nearly moribund seven-year plan for national development to life again and bring the West German state a long way toward resuming Germany's position just before World War II as by far, the most important Iranian commercial partner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Office of Price Stabilization today rejected proposals for price increases in kerosene, home heating oil and Diesel oil that would average more than 1/2 cent a gallon to consumers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has added to its active production schedule a chase-type melodrama and a multiple husband-wife comedy drama.
Unlike Hansel and Gretel, real people don't leave an obvious trail when they are lost. It takes a lot of digging and often several years to locate missing persons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today it was investigating a report that messages from Korea that might have prevented a break between President Truman and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur never reached the President.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Ninth United States Court of Appeals today issued an order prohibiting the Securities and Exchange Commission from taking any further action on a proposed sale of common stock of the Washington Water and Power Company to public utilities districts of the State of Washington.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- Pravda declared today that the Soviet Union honestly and disinterestedly sympathized with Egypt's struggle for "freedom and independence," and sharply denied that Russia in any manner constituted a threat either to Egypt or the other Middle Eastern countries.
The following round-up of household "hints," gleaned from various sources, may be of value to homemakers.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Jan. 25 -- Forty cooking housewives besieged City Manager James Pollock today and forced him to apologize for hinting they were poor money managers if they could not feed, clothe and house their families on $45 to $50 a week.

The annual New York Book Week in behalf of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will open on Feb. 4, to replenish the libraries of Coast Guard Stations, Merchant Marine Lighthouses and Lightships.

The Investors Control Corporation, of which Henry C. Black is president, has purchased the three four-story apartment buildings at 337 to 347 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, from Samuel Weinberg. Walter Scott Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Reuben Lesser for the buyer and George Ittleman for the seller.

An article on your financial page of Jan. 6 ("Freight Rate Rise Held No Panacea," by J. H. Carmical) sets out many of the reasons why continuing rate increases cannot be a cure for the ills of the railroads, or even a satisfactory means to accomplish higher net revenues.

Robert Grant 3d and Clarence C. Pell Jr., seven times winners of the title, and Kenneth Wagg of England and John Rolland of Canada reached the final round of the national amateur racquets doubles championship yesterday. They will meet today at 1:30 P. M. at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

The resignation of Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson, effective Feb. 29, was announced last night by Mayor Impellitteri. Mr. Patterson, a veteran of forty-five years of city service, filed a retirement application Wednesday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25 -- The Yugoslav Government has repealed its regulations concerning the direction of manpower and has restored the free labor market. This decision marked another important break with the policies and practices of the Soviet and satellite Governments, which use manpower direction as one of their favorite instruments of labor exploitation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Choppy fluctuations with irregular price movements within moderate limits featured the grain market here today. Early bulges met free selling, while on the recessions the demand broadened enough to steady the market, but there was heavy pressure again near the close.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Egypt complained today against United States establishment of Air Force facilities in Libya through the influence of military occupation and introduced a resolution by which the United Nations Assembly would ask withdrawal of all foreign troops from the new state within six months.

VIENNA, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet Union's contention that Austria cannot expect a state treaty until she has been "demilitarized" formed the subject of some bitter exchanges between the Russian and United States representatives at today's meeting of the Allied Council.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The stock markets here were disturbed today by news of fighting in Egypt. Virtually all prices drifted lower except for foreign bonds which held firm, with German bonds receiving particularly strong speculative support.

The President sent to the Senate this week two nominations for membership on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. They are Abbot L. Mills, Portland, Ore., banker, and James L. Robertson, a career Government employe since 1933 and at the time of his selection first deputy controller of the currency.

It is a pleasant irony of history that we Americans -- such relative newcomers on the world's stage -- should be congratulating one of the most ancient of all countries -- India -- as if we were the oldsters. Today is the second anniversary of the founding of the Republic of India, which to us old-timers with more than 175 years of republicanism behind us is mere infancy.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet Union's demand for Security Council reconsideration of the membership applications of thirteen countries that have been unable to get into the United Nations was approved today by the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee over bitter United States opposition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The consumers' price index edged its way up to another record between mid-November and mid-December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Democratic party regulars, determined to prevent another bolt from the national party, met here today to plan ways of barring rebellious candidates from the primaries in Alabama this spring.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A price stabilization official told critical Congressmen today that changes in the order setting prices on Irish potatoes would be made whenever inequities were disclosed.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared last night that in view of the "grave and immediate" threat of aggression hanging over the world, the security of the United States depended largely on the maintenance of maximum stability in many of the areas served by the Point Four program of assistance in under-developed countries.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Wallame S. Gourley named an Erie manufacturer trustee today for the bankrupt American Bantam Car Company of Butler.

New steel lightweight passenger cars, introduced last year for commutation service by the New York Central Railroad, have withstood the impact of wrecks better than the old type they replaced, a witness for the line testified yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Government's three big bookkeeping agencies announced today they had "streamlined" the Treasury system Alexander Hamilton set up in 1789 for taking in and paying out money.

With droves of Oympic-conscious athletes on the floor and the galleries packed close to their 15,000 capacity for the non-televised show, track and field will make its 1952 debut in Madison Square Garden tonight. The occasion is the forty-fifth annual games of the Millrose Athletic Association.
BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- Soviet authorities have agreed to drop their demands for certificates of origin on goods shipped from West Berlin to West Germany, a West German trade representative said today.

CAIRO, Jan. 25 -- A military operation by 1,500 British troops in the Suez Canal zone to disarm Ismailia auxiliary police today resulted in the announced killing of forty-two members of the Egyptian force and the wounding of fifty-eight others, while the British lost three killed and thirteen wounded.
The New York State Bar Association overwhelmingly adopted resolutions yesterday advocating a code of procedure to govern all Congressional and executive department hearings.

Bartholomew Nicastro, a 50-year-old retired New York City policeman, of 79 Brook Street, Garden City, L. I., was adjudged in contempt of court yesterday by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz for having refused to fill out a financial questionnaire as requested by the Kings County rackets grand jury.

The city is in the midst of a measles epidemic, the Department of Health announced yesterday. This month 2,722 cases have been reported -- 1,224 in Manhattan, 1,003 in Brooklyn, 257 in the Bronx, 236 in Queens and two in Staten Island.
Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that New York, a city of diverse racial and religious groups, "is the best example of what moral rearmament tries to achieve."

Museum-goers and Fifth Avenue window shoppers more often than not are two dissimilar sets of people but, to mark the week-long conference of the United States National Commission for Unesco, opening today, thirty museums have come to the avenue.

High selectivity characterized trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and the market failed to establish any definite pattern. Operating quietly through a routine session, price changes generally held within a fractional range although there were wide swings in both directions.

To capture the independent voters in this year's Presidential race the Republicans must have a candidate with glamour, "and that is why Eisenhower is our boy," Mrs. Walter S. McNab, first vice president of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs, told women party workers yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this report of winter sports conditions and forecasts:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it has amended its rule U-70 under the Holding Company Act with respect to the connections with financial institutions of officers and directors of registered companies and subsidiaries thereof.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, Jan. 25 -- The clash between British troops and Egyptian police began today after Ali Helmi Bey, deputy Governor of Ismailia, had been notified that the British authorities had decided to expel the auxiliary police from the canal zone.
New prices for General Motors and Hudson automobiles based on the recent Office of Price Stabilization regulation permitting retail increases, were announced yesterday by dealers in this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Truman and a host of highest officials in the armed services, the judiciary and the legislative branches of the Government paid final respect today to Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War.
Bob Cerv, batting champion of the American Association last year, yesterday turned in his signed contract to the Yankees, and may be either the world champions' right fielder or first baseman.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The New York section of the American Society of Foresters today endorsed the Conservation Department's proposal for a re-examination of the state policy with respect to the forest preserve.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 (AP) -- An average 6 per cent cost-of-living pay increase aggregating about $10,500,000 for the state's 80,000 employes was proposed today by Governor Dewey's administration.

The cornerstone of a six-story addition to the parish school building of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, will be laid at 84 Fourth Avenue at 11 A. M. Friday. It will stand by the side of school quarters at 86 and 88, which are to be remodeled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- The Army has upheld the conviction of six Wac sergeants for beating another woman soldier but has reduced their prison sentences, it was disclosed today. Dishonorable discharges and forfeiture of all pay and allowances were approved by the Judge Advocate General's office.

Another step in the growing organization movement among parents of retarded children was taken last night when the Parents Association for C. R. M. D. held its first general meeting at Junior High School 118, the Bronx. "C. R. M. D." is a designation used by the schools for "children with retarded mental development."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The House Armed Services Committee was told today that the great majority of members of the National Education Association believed Congress should either postpone starting Universal Military Training or abandon the idea altogether.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 25 -- The Labor Revolutionary party, founded by Victor Manuel Gutierrez, Communist Deputy and secretary of the Labor Federation, has been dissolved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Dick Todd, a square-jawed Texan who likes to be boss, agreed today to return as head coach of the Washington Redskins for the 1952 season.

The forthright speaking of Governor Dewey on the menace that confronts the free world in Southeast Asia is timely and welcome. There is good ground for his grave apprehension for the safety and future of the entire East Asian area if the Associated States of Indo-China are swept by a Chinese Communist invasion.

Normal service on city-owned bus lines in Staten Island will be restored on Monday, Winfield Jensen, superintendent of the Staten Island division of the Board of Transportation, announced at 9 o'clock last night. This announcement was confirmed by William Magnus, president of Local 726, Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway Employes, A. F. L.

Four commercial installers of fuel oil equipment testified yesterday at the extortion conspiracy trial of James J. Moran that between 1948 and Nov. 15, 1950, they had paid $16,650 to Fire Department inspectors.

ELWOOD, L. I., Jan. 25 -- Leaders of all faiths have come to the support of a 58-year-old Polish nun who will be deported unless a special bill is passed to give her sanctuary in the Long Island convent she has chosen.

The news about last night's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera concerned the young American soprano, Genevieve Warner, who sang the role of Gilda. It was her first major effort at the house; she previously had been heard in minor roles, such as Barbarina in "The Marriage of Figaro."

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Jan. 25 -- General James A. Van Fleet, United States Eighth Army commander, had to hitchhike back to headquarters yesterday after his plane was forced down on an abandoned frontline airstrip during a blinding snow storm.

ADELAIDE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Dick Savitt, the storm boy of international tennis, created a scene local fans will long remember as he lost to Ken McGregor, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the semi-final round of the Australian championships today.

LAUSANNE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Rene Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, said today if the Olympic committees of East and West Germany failed to reach agreement at their Copenhagen meeting Feb. 8, the international committee "may reconsider the whole question of Germany's participation in the Olympic games at Helsinki."

The mysterious ways of drifting bottles and their unpredictable journeys over the waters of the oceans are a challenge to the imagination. A recent United Press dispatch from Nag's Head, North Carolina, reports that a bottle containing a distress message dated July 16, 1942, was found along the beach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee announced today that John Carter Vincent, a career diplomat, would receive a public hearing on Jan. 30 and the opportunity under oath to defend his loyalty to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A countrywide campaign to increase public understanding of education and its aims, national and international, was started here today by the American Council on Education.

Ever since the trial of the eighteen New York policemen last September when Harry Gross upset the state's case by refusing, at the last moment, to testify, nothing much in the way of praise has been written or spoken about the members of our city's police force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, suggested tonight that an army of "full-time missionaries of democracy" be sent to under-developed areas of the world to aid in the free nations' struggle for men's minds.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- France will send a new note proposing to reopen negotiations with Tunisia over reforms to give that protectorate wider autonomy in local affairs, according to a decision of the Cabinet taken here today.

In his "Italian Journeys" William Dean Howells referred to Naples as a dirty city and then hastened to add that New York was dirtier. Just so, when I was in Istanbul not so long ago I spoke of it as dirty and then, in simple justice, hastened to add that of course New York is dirtier.

Herb Scherer, former Long Island University star, will be wearing a Knickerbocker uniform tonight when the New York professional team meets the Indianapolis Oympians in a National Basketball Association test at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

A dispatch from Moscow reports that still another Soviet economist has taken a look at the American economy through dark glasses and sees an economic crisis bearing down upon us inexorably. For him, at least, analyzing and forecasting the American economy's movements are simple.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee called tonight for the establishment of state and local crime commissions throughout the nation as a means of backing up "courageous, honest officials."
District qualifying rounds will be held for the first time in this year's Empire State amateur championship, executives of the New York State Golf Association decided here yesterday.

Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and author, has agreed to appear in a thirty-minute film to be produced by the National Broadcasting Company and televised later this year, possibly in the early spring. The network said it had asked Mr. Russell to talk to the television audience "about the things he has learned in a long, thoughtful and active life and about the things he feels he will never learn."

A super-streamlined sports Buick convertible, built on "car-of-the-future" lines and insured for $1,000,000, will be exhibited Monday at the Monarch Buick Company's showroom, Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to recommend Senate confirmation of four Presidential nominations, including that of Jack Gorrie to be chairman of the National Security Resources Board.

Charges of "stalling" and "cold indifference" were made yesterday by shipyard workers' representatives following a brief and fruitless negotiations session in the McAlpin Hotel with the Bethlehem Steel Company.

Robert P. Briggs has been elected executive vice president of the Consumers Power Company and James H. Campbell, vice president, made a director to fill a vacancy left by the late M. W. Arthur. Justin R. Whiting, board chairman, also announced yesterday the election of H. Stanley Richmond and Donald E. Herringshaw as vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 175.9 per cent of the 1926 average, 12.1 per cent above the pre-Korean average, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

JEFFERSON CITY, Jan. 25 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley became ill tonight after making a speech here, but said he would be able to go to Kansas City, Kan., tomorrow to attend the Midwest Democratic Conference, which opened today.
