WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A $69,000,000 machine tool subcontract held by the General Motors Corporation has been suspended because of revised requirements for jet aircraft engines, the National Production Authority disclosed today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 25 -- The French Government must take every precaution against the possibility of a Chinese Communist invasion of Indo-China, Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Indo-Chinese states, told a press conference here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Justice Department decided today against prosecution of Republican Gov. William S. Beardsley of Iowa for income fax deficiencies.

A pattern of a large, fern-like plant, done in pale blues and arranged at intervals on paler blue, won the first award in a fabric design competition offered to third-year students at the Parsons School of Design by Scalamandre Silks, Inc.

A gang of six men who were said to have specialized in stealing Cadillac automobiles "to order," was rounded up by the police yesterday. The men were charged with having altered the motor numbers of more than 100 stolen cars in the last year.

A gap of 6,000 miles and forty-four years between a mother and her son was closed yesterday afternoon on the South Street pier of the Ellis Island ferry. Few of the hundred-odd persons who disembarked at 3:30 o'clock were aware of the emotion-filled reunion.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Britain will get the bad news next Tuesday afternoon. As soon as Parliament reassembles after its long Christmas recess the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard Austen Butler, the Conservative Sir Stafford Cripps, will announce, the second installment of his austerity program.

The Preakness, which will have its seventy-sixth running in May, has attracted eighty-seven eligibles, an increase of 26 per cent over last year. In making known the list of candidates, the Maryland Jockey Club announced that the value of the race has been fixed at $75,000 added, with various nominating and eligibility fees making the gross about $100,000.
Among events in this week's art program are four one-man exhibitions of paintings that demonstrate once again how varied the approaches of contemporary artists can be.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 19 to 25 points yesterday, closing strong.

The twenty-three-day strike of Local 138, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., against the Greater New York Wholesale Grocers Association, Krasdale Foods, Inc., and Bernice Foods, Inc., ended last night when the union voted to accept a settlement.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 -- For the present Burgomeister Ernst Reuter is resigned to the Allied decree that West Berlin cannot be attached to the Federal Republic as a twelfth state. Although it has two distinct governments this means that the whole city remains under nominal four-Power control.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Tio Ciro, an Argentine-bred owned by the Cherry-Oca Stable, was a surprise winner of the $5,000 Spanish Moss Purse, feature of the card that drew a crowd of 14,849 to Hialeah Park today. The race, at a mile and a furlong, was run on the turf course.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 25 -- In a letter to the Democratic Conference of Midwest States, President Truman laid down today what he apparently considered the campaign pattern for the Democratic party in the 1952 elections. It embodies the theme that the party has brought an expansion of domestic prosperity and progress and has held the free world together against communism.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Caribbee, a sleek 57- foot yawl skippered by Carleton Mitchell of Annapolis, Md., led the fleet tonight in the sixth annual Fort Lauderdale to Cat Cay ocean sailing race. The winner of last year's Nassau Cup was first across the starting line, a second ahead of her nearest competitor on the starboard tack.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee finished its hearings today on the Japanese peace treaty and the three associated pacts creating a democratic defensive alliance in the Pacific.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of a message sent by President Truman to the Midwestern Democratic Conference here:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 25 -- Jonathan Bingham of New York, acting administrator of the Point Four program, said today that tremendous expansion of the activities in prospect demanded far more technical experts for field work than the Technical Cooperation Administration had been able to locate.

ALTHOUGH the Eastern big-game hunter, possibly because of the competition for the available game supply, is inclined to try for the first head of legal game that passes within range, there are still a few areas where the hunter may hold out for a "trophy," and apparently a lot of them are doing it.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- A call for a constitutional convention to meet this year to draft a plan for a European federation is being discussed by Western European leaders.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Julius Boros, the 210-pound professional from Mid Pines, N. C., shot sub-par golf again today and retained the lead in the $10,000 Phoenix open tournament at the end of the second round.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the nation's stocks of wheat declined rather sharply during the three-month period ending Dec. 31, reflecting a record rate of export.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 26 -- Pilots of the United States F-86 jet planes scored one of their major air victories of the Korean war yesterday. In four savage encounters with Communist jet fliers, they destroyed ten MIG-15's, probably destroyed another and damaged three.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The motion picture industry has asked the Federal Communications Commission to set aside for its use a "highway in the sky" over which it can bring televised entertainment to the movie theatres of America.
Operating revenues of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore increased last year to $83,820,535 from $79,434,133 in 1950, but earnings failed to reflect the improvement.
Johnny Saxton kept his string of ring victories intact last night with his twenty-fifth triumph in a highly unsatisfactory bout in Madison Square Garden.

A plan for merging Braniff International Airways and Mid-Continent Airlines has been approved by directors of the two companies, subject to approval of stockholders and the Civil Aeronautics Board, according to a joint announcement by the airlines yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 25 -- Discovery that the B vitamin known as pantothenic acid is needed by the body to manufacture cortisone, the famous arthritis medicine, was announced today by Dr. George R. Cowgill of Yale University at the opening of the International Conference on Vitamins.

In spite of continual protests on the part of our citizens this "richest country in the world" has about the worst postal service. One of our members of Congress, recently returned from a European trip, told over the radio of his feeling of humiliation when he saw what excellent postal service there was in Paris and in other large cities of Europe.

Coal exports during January will probably exceed those of December, it was estimated here yesterday by members of the Coal Exporters Association of the United States, Inc. Larger shipments to Japan are expected to continue, and if the current rate holds throughout the year, the 1952 total should exceed that of 1951 by a substantial margin, it was stated.

In a move to break the deadlock over admission of new members the General Assembly's Political Committee has adopted two resolutions with contradictory intent. Both resolutions repeat previous Assembly calls on the Security Council to reconsider the applications for membership submitted by various nations, including Italy, Ireland, Finland and five others heretofore barred by a Soviet veto.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The State Thruway Authority said today it had ordered a study of an alternate route proposed by a citizens' committee for the cross-state highway in the vicinity of Suffern, Rockland County.

Attendance at the local furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange had set a new record for a winter event by 5 P. M. yesterday when 11,436 retailers had registered, according to J. J. Melniker, exchange president. The market closes at noon today.

ABOUT 300 orchestral compositions by seventy-seven European composers are described by twenty noted annotators in this volume. Mr. Biancolli, scholarly music critic for The World-Telegram and Sun. reduced them from reams of program notes written for America's important orchestras; some of his own writings for the Philharmonic-Symphony are included.

The concept of freedom tends to be obscured when illiteracy keeps hundreds of thousands of people from reading their own rights under the law or even from understanding a traffic sign, Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, declared here yesterday.

Japan's professional baseball league has invited young Americans to come to Japan. They can't bring back any dollars after training and playing there but the Japanese will pay for their travel, give them spending money and take care of their living costs. There is no idea of "raiding" American baseball and all would be done with the full sanction of the American organizations.
CAIRO, Jan. 26 -- The last moments of Cairo's historic Shepheard's Hotel were fiery and dramatic.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- All ships bearing Army cargo were ordered diverted from the port of Philadelphia today until settlement of a dispute that had tied up the water front since Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- An estimate of $4,250,000, described as "every conservative," was offered today as the damage and loss figure in the Sierra Nevada region of northern California and Nevada resulting from the blizzards, snow and rock slides in recent weeks.

A SPECIAL flavor has always distinguished Theodora DuBois' picaresque yarns. Her whimsical and adventurous people prefer the world of small sailing craft and our coastal waters for their often outrageous doings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A nation-wide aluminum strike scheduled for Feb. I apparently was forestalled today when President Truman certified the dispute to the Wage Stabilization Board.

IT is certainly reflective of something that the most profound and sobering picture yet made on the subject of race discrimination -- on tensions between blacks and whites -- has not been made in this country, where the problem has been widely clarified.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- A new French note addressed to the Bey of Tunis in the hope of ending the conflict with the Tunisian Government was sent by air today, with Jean Laloy, a high official of the Foreign Office, as the Government's messenger.

The Curtis Cup team of women golfers that will represent this country in the series against the British in Scotland next June was named yesterday at the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association.

SOME hypothetical historian writing a hundred years from now about the ballet of our own times will undoubtedly note certain trends in its use of music, and the chances are that he will find very convincing but quite erroneous reasons for them. Maybe it is worth while to give him the right ones here and now, for they are fairly important.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt may not like Santa Anita's track, but his top-flight mares, Bed o'Roses and Next Move, showed a special liking for it today as they ran one-two in the $50,000-added Santa Margarita Handicap.

LANGUAGE experts with time on their hands will be able to prove by the record that the sixth session of the United Nations Assembly here set a new mark for the cultivation and use of proverbs. As is well known, proverbs are old snappy sayings, very pithy, invented in Russia.

The performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on the night of March 26 at the Warner Theatre will aid the Youth Consultation Service, the Katy Ferguson House and the Girls Service League. The entire orchestra of the theatre has been taken over in behalf of the three organizations.

BONN, Jan. 26 -- The great mass of the German people were jolted out of their customary political apathy this week. The jolt was administered by a Government announcement which told them that Germany was going to rearm as a member of the European Defense Force and that conscription would be necessary to find the men.

A TELEPHOTO lens for the 35mm Argus C, C2 and C3 miniature cameras has been developed in Munich, Germany, and will soon be available on the American market, according to announcement by the importer and distributor, Geiss-America, Chicago 45, Ill.

That is perhaps a harsh way of putting it; but there is no doubt that when critics violently disagree about a composer, that composer, however long he may have been dead, is still very much alive.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 26 (UP) -- Lestor L. Lapham, 51 years old, was arrested today for embezzling $15,202 in Brown University funds, but the former university assistant treasurer pleaded innocent to the charge.

But the Warner-Hudnut Corporation would like to believe that the genesis of the phrase stems from the bottled liniment first sold by Earl S. ("Doc") Sloan seventy-five years ago to relieve rheumatism and other ailments.
The Federal Government is about to investigate the recent acquisition by an individual of a major, but not controlling, stock interest in the $300,000,000 Western Union Telegraph Company.

THE distinction between amateur and professional painters is a touchy one, especially to those of the first category who have moved themselves into the second and maintain heatedly with Emerson that every professional was once an amateur.

In a score of novels (only a half dozen of which have been published here) he has developed a rotund, coldly exact style which seems perfectly tailored to his blend of morality play and Welsh Gothic.

Hunter College, founded in 1870 as a school for women exclusively, will partly revert to type in February when five men, the last of the specially admitted veterans, leave the day sessions of the Park Avenue division.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 26 -- Sophomore John Clune of Jersey City set a new Naval Academy basketball scoring record of 33 points today as the Middies scored a 69-54 victory over Virginia Military Institute. It was the third time this season that Clune had cracked the Academy mark. He hit eleven of twenty-two field goal attempts and eleven of thirteen tries from the foul line in thirty-three minutes of play.

SHARING is hard for young children, although it looks easy to parents. When Randy's mother says, "Let Jimmy have your truck for a little while," she wants him to be generous. All Randy wants is his truck.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Three coal industry leaders joined this week in a prediction that coal consumption would reach new high levels in the next quarter of a century.

Cal Abrams and Don Thompson, utility outfielders, and Clarence (Bud) Podbielan, right-handed relief pitcher and occasional starter, yesterday brought the announced total of Dodger signings to nineteen.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 26 -- The position of 2,000,000 Europeans in French North Africa and the security of the southern flank of the North Atlantic Treaty powers are jeopardized in the current struggle in Tunisia between the Moslem nationalists and the French protectorate authorities over the issue of home rule.

ONE of the few persons around Broadway who has not read the critical raves about Carol Stone's chillingly tragie portrait of a lustful New England housewife in the magnificent Anta revival of "Desire Under the Elms" is Miss Stone herself. Demonstrating a will power truly incredible for an actress in such matters, she never reads her first-night notices until the run of the play has ended.

IN its relatively short life the Haydn Society has proved that it is not afraid to think big and that it does not hesitate to go ahead with its grand ideas. Since Alexander Schneider is a musician with a similar philosophy and with a driving capacity to act on his convictions, it was inevitable that he and the Haydn Society would join forces on some large-scaled project.

THREE years ago Ernestine Gilbreth Carey, in collaboration with her brother, Frank, wrote in "Cheaper by the Dozen" a gay and good-natured account of the Gilbreths out of the ordinary home life. Now, in "Jumping Jupiter."

CAIRO, Jan. 26 -- United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery was received by King Farouk tonight amid reports that the United States was attempting to intervene to prevent a final diplomatic break between Egypt and Britain.

The piano recital given by Clifford Curzon yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was distinguished not only by his admirable art but by the interest and unconventionality of the program that he offered his audience.

FROM 1935 to 1944 Admiral Wilhelm Canaris was chief of the "Abwehr," the intelligence section of the German General Staff. In July, 1944, after the unsuccessful bomb plot against Hitler, he was arrested and on April 10, 1945, just two weeks before the Americans reached his prison, he was hanged.

ANYONE attempting to identify "the trend" at the semi-annual wholesale home furnishings markets held here and in Grand Rapids earlier this month would find not one but many trends. For the diversity of designs that were new was overwhelming -- more, it was claimed, than at any similar event since the war.

Gonzales, or the incomparable serologist of the M. E.'s office, Dr. Alexander S. Wiener, are completely unknown to the general public and even to many avid murder-readers.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Virtually every major newspaper in Moscow turned attention today to the unrest in North Africa. emphasizing the degree to which events in Egypt and Tunisia were coming to the forefront of Soviet interest.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 26 -With the avowed intention of giving local public school teachers a larger part in selecting textbooks while preventing the use of subversive materials in the schools, the Board of Education here has been considering the adoption of a set of rules and regulations on use and selection of textbooks.

ALL remaining stocks of Egypt's regular stamps from 1 millieme through 1, together with airmail items, a 40m special delivery and seven postage dues, were overprinted "King of Egypt and Sudan" in three lines of Arabic type and placed on sale at post offices last Sunday, according to word received by International Stamp News in New York. There are about thirty-five varieties.

IN its three and a half years of statehood, Israel has been as much written about as many much older and much larger countries. But thus far, it has been primarily a subject of giddily partisan or brightly superficial literature.
BONN, Jan 26 -- German indignation over the latest French action in the Saar territory, a perpetual irritant to French-German relations, is unexpectedly strong.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Preparations for the main phase of Exercise Snowfall, when simulated atomic weapons will be introduced into the Army-Air Force maneuver, were completed this week at this Jefferson County military reservation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -Retail activity in the Twelfth District fell off heavily again during the week ending Jan. 19. Retail food prices in San Francisco reached a new high level in mid-December and were still going up at the end of the month, according to the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WHEN the State of Pennsylvania submitted the question of a soldier bonus to its citizens in 1949, Lucian J. Ciletti, a veteran of service in North Africa and Italy, voted against it. In his words, "the country and the State of Pennsylvania owed him nothing."
TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 27 (AP) -General Headquarters communique 1,141, covering Saturday's operations:

Myra Hess, the English pianist, devoted the program of her recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall to three sharply contrasted sonatas. The eminent artist provided her hearers with an exhibition of real music making, in which she was always absorbed in unfolding the meaning of the works under consideration, with no thought of superficial display for its own sake.

JANUARY is an important month gardenwise. The catalogues with their flurry of new varieties anticipate the new season, and inevitably stimulate a certain amount of stock-taking on the old. It seems appropriate, therefore, to report on how 1951's introductions fared when they left the catalogues for a career in the garden.

THE British social scientist, Gordon Rattray Taylor, has chosen an ironic question for his title -- his premise being that management too frequently fails to consider the attributes distinguishing men from machines.

The New York meat trade is worried over shortages which it is feared may develop before this year's corn crop is available for feed in late summer and to an even sharper degree next year unless the 1952 crop is increased.

THERE is always something impressive about beginnings, a feeling manifest in the awe felt by the traveler who gazes at a still pool, the ultimate source of a great river. The tides of Constructivism, the supremely anti-naturalistic art of this century, will not probably ever sweep all before them.

More efficient use of engineers in industry and public projects could increase their availability for engineering tasks as much as 50 per cent, it was asserted here last week by H. Gregory Shea, president of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers, with offices at 393 Seventh Avenue.

IN his review of Bertrand Russell's -- latest book, "New Hopes for a Changing World," Prof. T. V. Smith does well to quote Socrates' definition of courage as the "knowledge of the grounds of fear and hope." But what are the true grounds of fear and hope? Professor Smith does not answer that question, but merely assumes that there is no reason for placing hope in God's Providence, or for fearing the consequences of sin.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 26 -- Neither for nor intermittent rain and sleet prevented a field of sixty-seven 12 to 17-year-old American skiers from taking off from the 3,260-foot summit of Bromley Mountain in the giant slalom today.

THE ASSOCIATED PRESS United Nations correspondent, Francis W. Carpenter, does a workmanlike job in this somewhat opaque picture of the glass house and men in it, at the lower end of Forty-second Street, facing the big soft-drink sign across the East River.

Leon Keyserling, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, yesterday attacked as "prophets of doom" business men and economists who have voiced fears of a slump after the peak of rearmament spending has been passed.

High prices of corn, the Southern drought, bumper oil crops around the world and faulty price calculations in the Department of Agriculture's price support plan for cottonseed oil have developed an unusual situation in the futures market for that commodity on the New York Produce Exchange.

THE problem posed in this book is the larger crisis of our time. Beneath the immediate disturbances of war and revolution Andre Siegfried finds a fundamental transformation in Western society. Mechanization has disrupted the old "basis of Western civilization," the tripartite balance among knowledge, the individual and techniques.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Administration efforts to get a system of Universal Military Training started this year are being made in the face of a predicted shortage of manpower comparable to the deficits in critical materials that will plague the manufacturers of automobiles, dishwashers, radios and plumbing fixtures.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Prices of grains rose on the Board of Trade today, largely because of one sudden burst of large-scale buying near the end of the first hour. After that the market proceeded at a normal pace, slipping back only slightly from the earlier highs.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Baloma, a 2-year-old filly, set a new quarter-mile Fair Grounds record in the $9,500 Johns Joy Purse today, finishing eight lengths ahead under a tight rein after her jockey broke a stirrup.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26 -- Sources in the National Front, Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's ruling party, said today that the Tudeh (Communist) party had split on the issue of the list of candidates that it had presented in the Teheran elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -The Senate Preparedness subcommittee has asked the Army Engineers and Air Force to explain why more than $100,000 was spent before construction of an "underwater" air field in North Africa was abandoned.

OF all the piano disks recently released, few are as satisfactory as the Arthur Rubinstein performance of the Brahms Sonata in F minor (Victor). Rubinstein is a heroic pianist, and it takes that kind of artist to vitalize the music. Musicianship and good intentions are not enough, as witnessed by the plodding recital performances that one so often hears.

NEW and improved turf grasses are on the way. Although much is expected of them, they will be unspectacular in the sense that regular mowing will still be necessary, as will other routine care. The best of the new grasses will not accomplish the impossible, despite their promising qualities.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 26 (UP) -- Some United States officials took the view today that the Egyptian Government was primarily to blame for the Egyptian-British clashes. It was reported that little hope was held here that Cairo could control the rioters.
SHELTON, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP) -- A skidding truck and an automobile collided on the icy pavement of Route 8 here early today, killing a Mount Vernon girl and three Bronx young men.

The performance of Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra," with Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh on Feb. 7 at the Ziegfeld Theatre ha sbeen taken over by members of the Chapter Number One of the Berkshire Industrial Farm to raise funds for the organization.

Many well-known women, among whom are Mrs. H. Nelson Slater Mrs. Ralph J. Hines and Mrs. Archibald M. Brown, are furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," with Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh in the leading roles, on the night of Feb. 4 at the Ziegfeld Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Schola Cantorum of New York.

SATINS and laces from great-grandma's day will be fetched from rosewood chests for the annual Spring Pilgrimage opening in Natchez on March 1 and continuing through the month. Thirty homes known for their distinguished architecture and rare furnishings, will be open to the public during the Pilgrimage, which is sponsored by the two Natchez garden clubs.

A LITTLE less than a year ago twenty kits crammed with examples of the best toys and books and play equipment available to American youngsters in the 2 to 6 age group were shipped abroad for study and use in Education Service Centers and teachers' training schools throughout the American zone of Germany.
Senator Robert A. Taft pressed his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination here yesterday by denouncing the Administration's foreign policy as the most "calamitous" in history.

Members of the Manhattanville College Alumnae Association have taken over the performance of "Madama Butterfly," with Licial Albanese and Giacinto Prandelli in the leading roles, on the night of Feb. 16 at the Metropolitan Opera House to augment the college Scholarship Fund.

Many jewelry stores that based their reputation on branded merchandise face bankruptcy this year as a result of the Supreme Court's decision ending fair trade pricing, it was asserted last week by Leo Weisfield, a director of the Office of Price Stabilization in part of the State of Washington, chairman of the board of the Diamond Council of America and president of Weisfield's, a West Coast jeweler chain.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky left for Moscow this week with the dark statement that decisions at this session of the Assembly would lead to war. Reasons for his pessimism are not far to seek. Not only did the Soviet Union fail to block the principal proposals sponsored by the United States and other Western powers, but Mr. Vishinsky himself was not up to his usual form and committed several costly tactical mistakes.

FIRST impressions whether of persons, art or things are not necessarily the true ones, and it goes without saying that often they have to be revised even to contradiction when time and experience have yielded greater knowledge. But a reaction to any experience however brief is inevitable.

Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N. J., will be the beneficiary of the matinee performance of "The Constant Wife," with Katharine Cornell, Grace George and Brian Aherne on Feb. 9 at the National Theatre.
My heart is heavy at the news of the death of Robert P. Patterson; heavy because of my loss, and heavy because of the great loss to the public.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis, seeking his third straight national outdoor speed skating title, breezed to victory in opening events of the annual meet today.
HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 26 -- Dartmouth's basketball team scored its seventh victory tonight, defeating Army by 60 -- 55. Fred Gieg led the winners with 20 points.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The United States, Britain and France introduced a resolution today declaring that it would be premature for the United Nations General Assembly to take up the question of a permanent settlement in Korea during the current session in Paris.

NEWARK, Jan. 26 -- A resolution condemning the Englewood Board of Education and its superintendent of schools for setting up rules and regulations "fostering anti-democratic practices and placing all teachers on a plane of suspicion by questioning their loyalty to our nation," was adopted today by the executive council of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The Foreign Ministers of six countries met today to continue negotiations for a European army. They agreed tentatively that the defense board to administer the joint force should have nine members, the same number as the high authority of the Schuman plan for pooling Western Europe's coal and steel resources under a fifty-year pact.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, representative of Nationalist China, attacked the Yalta agreement today as a "disastrous mistake" and said that President Roosevelt's part in it was "hard to explain or justify."

One of the most important world causes with which this country has aligned itself has been the U. N. International Children's Emergency Fund. It is a cause which has quite logically stirred the hearts of mankind everywhere for the simple reason that children must not die.

May I add a word to what has been called out by the tragic death of my friend and former colleague, Robert Patterson? I shall not speak of those qualities which were apparent to all: the purity of his spirit; his matchless courage; his directness and penetration; the pungency of his speech; his scorn of sham and evasion; his long dedication to public service; his almost fanatical obsession with any cause he espoused.

WILLIAMANTIC, Conn., Jan. 26 -- Harold E. Stassen, Republican Presidential aspirant, urged tonight a return to the gold standard as the only way to beat inflation and establish a "solid American dollar."

MADRID, Jan. 26 -- The leaders of the Western world are convinced that Soviet foreign policy, in its ultimate aspirations, is bent upon global domination. This assumption, based on a careful study of Moscow's actions and Stalinist dogma, does not forecast Russian efforts to conquer the world in a physical sense.

Jacob Blaustein, Baltimore industrialist and president of the American Jewish Committee, warned last night that the unity of the American people and the nation's prestige in international affairs were being endangered because of intolerance toward differing opinions.

More military output throughout industry has occurred in January and more new orders for defense products have been placed, but they were far below the volume of new business needed to offset the decline in civilian orders and production.

JOHN STEINBECK'S "The Wayward Bus," which has been moving slowly toward the cameras since 1947, will reach that goal in April, it was revealed last week by Charles K. Feldman. The producer, who departed for the coast the other day gratefully clutching the New York Film Critics' Award for "A Streetcar Named Desire," also divulged that none other than William Saroyan had turned in "a wonderful" script from the Steinbeck novel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -The controversial issue of sending an American Ambassador to the Vatican was sidestepped today by four avowed Presidential candidates. They also put off direct answers to the question: Do you think it will be a campaign issue?

DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- Michigan Republicans, united only in the hope of unseating Gov. G. Mennen Williams and Senator Blair Moody, are sharply divided between supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- An emergency board recommended to President Truman today that the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen end its two-year dispute with the railroads by accepting the 23 1/2-cent hourly increase for road service and 38 cents for yard work accepted long ago by the majority of railroad workers.

New York's intricate building industry did not have a jurisdictional stoppage of any consequence in 1951, and -- what's more -- found it unnecessary for the first time since 1910 to use its management-run arbitration machinery for the settlement of inter-union controversies.

LIBBY lived in a Greenwich Village apartment with her husband, Peter, and came to learn that -- whatever had brought them together -- as of now they had little mutual understanding. When Peter left on a business trip she had a brief encounter with Tom and discovered the joys of true communion of mind and spirit.

The New York State Bar Association advocates a code of procedure for all Congressional and executive department hearings and a uniform system of rules for Congressional investigating committees and subcommittees. In both cases the association would ban photography, radio and television, except in the case of public hearings on pending legislation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- St. John's University pulled away in the final quarter to win its thirteenth basketball game in fifteen starts tonight, defeating Temple, 53 -- 44, in the opening contest of a double-header at Convention Hall.

Arthur J. White, chairman of the New York Regional Wage Stabilization Board, reported yesterday that the board was being blocked from making speedier decisions on wage rise applications by the failure of unions and employers to supply essential facts.

As British Commonwealth statesmen weighed last week the chances of the sterling area holding together with Britain as its banker, financial markets here came up with an appraisal of values suggestive of a somewhat more optimistic future for Canada, the first British dominion to quit the sterling trading area and to run her international trade and banking affairs herself.

Income tax reform which brings about corrections in the determination of what constitutes taxable income is ordinarily accomplished by slow stages. This is especially true where the United States Supreme Court, in resolving conflicts between findings of the lower courts, has rendered an unpopular decision. As a general rule the remedy is to be found only in new legislation.

A petite blonde in the seventh grade of grammar school held the spotlight yesterday as the second day of competition in the thirty-first annual Middle Atlantic figure skating championships was completed at the Iceland Rink yesterday. She was Miss Carol Heiss of the Junior Skating Club of New York.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 26 -- Alabama Democrats loyal to the national Democratic party moved decisively today to gear the state party machinery to support the national party's Presidential nominee next fall.

Don Gehrmann, the Snapper Garrison of footracing, last night provided his distinctive finishing touch to another mile-racing masterpiece. Getting up in the last few strides, the slim Wisconsin graduate beat Fred Wilt for the third straight year in the Wanamaker Mile, showpiece of the forty-fifth annual Millrose Games, before a standing-room-only crowd of more than 15,000 at Madison Square Garden.

In a new circuit for fluorescent lighting developed by John H. Campbell, General Electric lamp division engineer at Nela Park, Cleveland, Ohio, a "magnetic converter" steps up frequency much as a transformer steps up Voltage. Two converters are now installed in the plant Industry Station at Beltsville, Md., where the lighting installation converts 60-cycle current to one of higher frequency without the use of rotating equipment.

THERE was one aspect of President Truman's budget message which sounded good to the movie industry. This was his indirect forecast that the nation's film theatres would do a gross business of roughly $1,464,000,000 during the fiscal year, starting July 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 -- Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore carded a one-under-par 74 today to beat California's darling of the fairways, Barbara Romack, 2 up, and gain the final of the twentieth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The United Nations General Assembly approved today a $250,000,000 program designed ultimately to make the Arab refugees from Palestine self-sufficient, and it also adopted a compromise plan for continuation of the Palestine Conciliation Commission.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -- The Miami Fashion Council, a group of fifty-one of the leading makers of men's, women's and children's apparel in this Southern resort, has just completed its most successful market week. More than 1,600 visiting buyers have viewed the exhibits of the manufacturers in the Casablanca Hotel, and orders placed have given the apparel producers a backlog that will keep them busy eight weeks on spring and s-miner merchandise.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida unveiled this week his plans to implement the San Francisco peace treaty and the security pact between the United States and the soon-to-be-independent Japan. In so doing, Mr. Yoshida opened for himself a Pandora's box of troubles.

SIX workshops in photography by five leaders in the field will start the first week in February at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Berenice Abbott offers an advanced workshop specializing in technical problems that will run fifteen weeks from 5:50 to 7:50 P. M., Monday (fee $50).
DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- The Detroit Symphony Orchestra today announced the signing of Paul Paray, French musician, to a three-year contract as permanent conductor.

WITHIN the next twelve months, the 57,000 employes of the Bureau of Internal Revenue must collect more than $65 billions in taxes. No other agency, with the possible exception of the Department of Defense or the Atomic Energy Commission, has a greater task in this defense build-up period than this bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Americans may be 180,000,000 strong in 1960, and California will have nosed out Pennsylvania as the second most crowded state in the union before 1955, the Census Bureau said today.

IN vegetable gardening, as in other fields, there are rightists, leftists, conservatives and liberals. There are those who treasure the old standbys, and those who can't wait to try the new varieties. But, as usual, there are more middle-of-the-roaders than extremists -- people who plant some of the fine, old varieties but who also like to try the new and improved offerings.

Department store sales continued last week at about the same level as the week before, which was characterized by trade observers as "normal." Volume was estimated at about 15 per cent below the 1951 week, when "scare" buying sent volume high.

On the night before Judge Patterson's death I sat with him and a group of friends gathered to wish Ambassador Draper well on his departure to Europe. In speaking of Ambassador Draper, Judge Patterson commented on the ability of the Republic in times of crisis to find devoted and able citizens willing to accept the responsibility for major public service.

RICHARD FREY and Howard Schenken, the bridge columnists, who once were partners and team-mates (and won the masters' pair championship together), recently circularized all the "life masters" of the American Contract Bridge League, asking each for his favorite bridge hand.
The national amateur racquets doubles championship was won yesterday by a foreign team for the second successive year, the first time this has ever happened.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26 -- To improve the free public school system in this country it will be necessary to more than double the money now spent for education, Edward M. Tuttle, executive secretary, National School Boards Association, declared here today.

Ending last week of the various home furnishings markets throughout the country which began with the national event in Chicago on Jan. 7, brought out the fact that women are beginning to dominate the actual business operation of the $10,000,000,000 - a - year home furnishings industry.

ADELAIDE, Jan. 26 -- Frank Sedgman, world's top-ranking amateur tennis player, and his partner Ken McGregor retained their Australian doubles crown today, but most of the tennis talk still centered around American Dick Savitt's 13-minute sit-down strike yesterday.

BUYING activity in most of the wholesale markets here eased off last week from recent levels. In the women's apparel and accessory lines, the early peak of buyers' arrivals had been passed, although large contingents of store representatives again will visit suppliers here next month on their secondary trips.

MIAMI -- Starting this week Mexico will be added to the list of countries which sun seekers wintering in Florida can reach on short ocean trips out of Miami. The 6,000-ton Silverstar is scheduled to sail from here on Tuesday on the first of a series of seven-day cruises across the Gulf to Veracruz.

In cooperation with meteorologists of the United States Navy, the Rev. J. Joseph Lynch, S. J., director of Fordham University's seismic observatory, has been making a study that indicates a relation between changes in the weather and small ground waves.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- An aroused De Paul team that trailed at one time by fourteen points, battled to a last-quarter lead and hung on tonight to hand mighty Illinois its first defeat of the season, 69 to 65.

Federal agents on Friday caught up with Rosario (Frank the Sheik) Tornello, 53-year-old member of a French-Italian narcotics and counterfeiting combine, it was disclosed yesterday. He had been sought over the country since last summer.

Although the Senate Interior Committee approved a bill last week to establish Federal title of submerged land beyond the United States coastline, the measure will probably be drastically revised before it passes the Senate.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 27 -- The Communists accepted today the United Nations plan for speeding the armistice talks in the Korean war. The Allies then proposed a dramatic meeting between Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway and the Communist high command to sign a partial truce pact.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A stirring fourth-quarter comeback by Seton Hall's thirteenth-ranked basketball team gave the Pirates a 68-66 decision over Villanova tonight. A crowd of 6,737 looked on at the Palestra as the Pirates gained their fifteenth victory against one loss in the second game of a double-header.

Bob Patterson had many friends, but, generally speaking, his were not the friendships of leisure hours or lighter pastimes. They were rather the solid friendships of similarity of aim, grounded on mutual interest in the accomplishment of some worth-while objective.

SOLDIER SUMMIT, Utah -- Teletypes and telegraph sounders are busy with "special situation reports" and mammoth wedge plows, flangers and rotary plows are digging through yards of snow as the railroads in the mountains of the West work to keep their trains running through one of the toughest winters in recent history.

BEFORE a new rose becomes a new rose -- way, way back -- it's nothing but a gleam in some hybridizer's eye. Consider this year's triple-threat All-America winner, the floribunda Vogue. In 1943 it was just an idea. Today it is a staggering reality of some 450,000 plants.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 -- Among the developments of more than ordinary note in the breed judging that began the two-day run of the Maryland Kennel Club dog show today were victories by a boxer and a whippet.

IN writing this novel, with its vivid scenic effects, careful dialogue, well-tailored plot and smooth sequences Dymphna Cusack has employed all her playwright's skill She has created a number of attractive, likable characters, given them a tragic dilemma and moved them inexorably to a fine dramatic conclusion.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 -- Lloyd Mangrum, leading money winner of 1951, took over the three-round lead in the $10,000 Phoenix Open golf tournament today as he fired a 4-under-par 67 for a 54-hole total of 204 strokes.

For pictorial thinking was so prevalent among the entries that it amounted practically to sabotage of what started off as a splendid idea full of rich patentials.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The period of political calm that has prevailed in Britain since the general election last October returned Winston Churchill and a Conservative Government to power will he shattered when Parliament meets again next Tuesday after nearly eight weeks of recess.

Mrs. Walter Schiffer is president of the guild. Mrs. E. Wood Gauss heads the benefit committee.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Superior speed and experience proved the deciding factors as Dartmouth's hockey team defeated Army, 3 to 1, at Smith Rink today.

Restoration of a Manhattan landmark that was a subject of dispute between Federal and city officials a decade ago will begin next month in Battery Park when masons and bricklayers scale the scaffolding around the old Aquarium.

The first marked upturn in six months for metal stamping plants in the New York district was reported yesterday, marking the end of the slump in the last half of 1951. Jack Keinoder, general manager of the John Volkert Metal Stampings Company, and a trustee of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association, declared that orders for some plants in January increased about 20 per cent from the volume of the last quarter of 1951.

THERE has been some trepidation expressed by many rifle and pistol shooters concerning the prospects of the United States teams scheduled to compete in the I. S. U. and Olympics matches, as it is felt the huried selection of team personnel will reflect unfavorably on our scores.

BIZET'S "Carmen" will be given a production new from the ground up next Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. For this purpose Mr. Bing has invited, as guest stage director, Tyrone Guthrie, director of London's Old Vic, who has distinguished productions both of opera and of drama to his credit.

IN San Quentin Prison in 1939 there occurred an exhibition of cruelty that would be hard to believe if it were not on public record. This bit of barbarity took place when the prison authorities subjected forty-six men to what can only be called deliberate torture.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- Mate, sailed by Robert Lippincott of the West New Jersey Fleet, crossed the finish line first today in the opening Bacardi Cup race of the twenty-first international Star. Class Regatta. The victor's time was 2 hours 8 minutes 48 seconds.

OSLO, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Oslo's snow-overed peaks and treacherous bob-run slides were being readied today for the sixth winter Olympics while the question of possible Russian participation remained an important issue.
JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 25 (UP) -- Vic Toweel of South Africa retains his world bantamweight title tonight defeating Scotland's Peter Keenan on points in fifteen rounds at the Rand Stadium.

JODHPUR, India, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -The Maharaja of Jodhpur, one of India's richest princes, was killed in a plane crash today about sixty miles from here while campaigning for a seat in the new Indian Parliament.

Mr. Churchill in his address to Congress recalled that saying of Bismarck's about the supreme importance of the fact that Britain and America speak the same language. While he was telling us this, at the same time he was impressing upon us the fact that, although Britain and America speak the same language, they speak it quite differently.
MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (UP) -- The surging Canadiens, red-hot all week on the road, kept up the pace at home tonight as they pinned a 5-3 National Hockey League defeat on Boston's sagging Bruins.

JOHN GUNTHER has prudently refrained from calling this sympathetic biography "Inside Ike," although the general facetiously suggested that he should. It's just as well, because there doesn't seem to be any "inside story" on Eisenhower, and so this book is simply a useful and interesting collection of the known facts about an apparently uncomplicated man.

PHYLLIS FENNER is quite right when she says: "It isn't easy to know what youngsters think is funny." This book, however, offers a good cross-section of juvenile opinion. Under Miss Fenner's directions cartoons from juvenile and adult magazines were submitted by "several hundred" children, from 9 to 14 years old, then selected by a jury of classmates.

TUCSON, Ariz, -- Advance notes of fiesta, rodeo and gay pageantry are filtering through the sunlit atmosphere of Tucson as the winter season starts to unfold, Optimistic predictions are borne out by advance reservations which are a notch above last year and are still climbing.

COCHIN, India, Jan. 26 -- India celebrated the second anniversary of the republic today in the context of warning portents for the organization that obtained this country's independence -- the Indian National Congress party.

A nation-wide political survey indicates that more than half the necessary delegate-votes to win the Republican nomination for President have been promised to Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, but that supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower are pressing him hard, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States and Britain are so much closer in their views on the conduct of the Korean war as a result of the Truman-Churchill talks that no protests from the British Foreign Office are expected should the United Nations commander be forced to resume full-scale land and air operations against the enemy in Korea.

Fewer buyers were in the wholesale market here last week and, with the pressure off, manufacturers were offering good values to encourage additional spring purchases, resident buying offices reported. Summer lines are expected to open during the next two weeks and many buyers will return to the market early in February.

New York is more than just "a state of mind" to one resident, who adopted the city as her home fifteen years ago. To Miss Maud Suman, now 80 years old, New York spells romance -- "The world is right here at the curbstone." It is a mural of towering spires framed in her bed-sitting room window and a vision of endless inspiration.

CAIRO, Jan. 26 -- The Egyptian Government declared martial law throughout Egypt tonight after a day of terror in Cairo. The army, with the sharp crack of its rifles, began to quell rioters who burned, pillaged and smashed tens of millions of dollars worth of United States, British and French property.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26 -- Vincent Massey's appointment as Governor General of Canada has been marked in the press and among Canadians by a good deal of emotional and sometimes confused opposition. It is not likely, however, that it will become a controversial political issue.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Manchester United took the lead in English soccer today in a program marked by upsets on frosty grounds and a near riot at Chelsea.

WASHINGTON. IN the severe white stone building at 1901 Constitution Avenue, where the American-British Combined Chiefs of Staff worked in lonely splendor during the late war, the post-war civilian managerial class has reached the summit of power.

The excellent arguments cited by Benjamin Fine in opposition to homework ("No More Homework? The Pros and Cons," Jan. 13) will be most welcome to many parents who have long deplored this unnecessary burden on their youngsters.

THIS latest addition to the How-and-Why Series (formerly entitled the Chanticleer Wonder-Story Books) is a companion volume to "How the First Men Lived" and "The First Great Inventions." Similar in approach and format, this traces one aspect of man's development --exploration, since prehistoric men searched for new pastures and hunting grounds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Adjusted average hourly earnings for production and related workers in manufacturing increased about 3.3 per cent in the nine-month period from Feb. 1 to Oct. 31, 1951, the Wage Stabilization Board said today.

In reply to the charges made by the New York State Social Welfare Department that the city's Welfare Department was inefficient, Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy declared yesterday that the state, by this attack on the city administration, was defending itself "in advance" of surveys that would put it "in an extremely bad light."

ASIDE from the interest attaching to the depiction of highly diverse celebrities as recorded by outstanding artists of the last seventy years, the current exhibition, "Portraits of Personalities -- Past and Present," at Portraits, Inc., reflects in sketchy outline the changing approach to the portrait during a lifetime.

WAYS of cooking rice are almost as many as the cooks who prepare it. Which is saying a good deal when one considers how widely the white grains are consumed. As an example: The Territory of Hawaii imports more than 5,000,000 pounds monthly: rice may be served two or three times a day and as much as a cup and a half eaten at a sitting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) - Bigger and faster ocean-going oil tankers have plied the sealanes since the outset of World War II and the Maritime Administration now is developing plans for further improvements, particularly in speed.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur spent his 72d birthday yesterday nursing a mild case of laryngitis in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. In the evening he was guest at a dinner in the hotel given by forty of his former staff officers.

When Myrtle Ehrlich left high school in Brooklyn, her classmates would hardly have classified her in the yearbook as the girl "Most Likely to Succeed." This she admits. Yet today, Myrtle "Tillie" Lewis -- twenty-five years later -- is president of the largest independent cannery in the world with a $20,000,000 annual business.

VIENNA, Jan. 26 -- Austria will receive only $120,000,000 in economic aid from the United States during the fiscal year ending June 30 -- instead of the $190,000,000 she had requested -- it was officially announced today by Clarence E. Meyer, chief of the former Economic Cooperation Administration mission here, now renamed the Special Mission for Economic Cooperation.

NOT since the days of "Little Egypt" has so much emphasis been placed on movement as it is today by television program producers. If a variety or musical show wants to do a production number about the Rock of Gibraltar, someone has to decide how to get motion into the act.

Mr. Fine's article has prompted me to submit the following carefully considered recommendations. These, if enforced, would do much to haul education up from the black well of ignorance and superstition, where it has been confined since inception:

TO the uninitiated the job of a laboratory soil analyst might well appear to be rather routine. What could be more boring than running samples of the "good earth" through a chemical mill day after day? As a matter of fact, it's a pretty fascinating business.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A ten-year program for the improvement of 12,500 miles of town roads -- nearly a quarter of the town-road mileage in the state -- will get under way this year, with the state financing a little more than half the cost.

THE seed and nursery catalogues for 1952 preface their pages of familiar wares with a greater number and a wider assortment of new varieties of plants than ever before. This year something new may be found all the way from a waterlily to a tree.

Used tin cans, the collection of which was something less than a rousing success as a source of scrap for steelmaking during World War II, are being called again to active duty in the present emergency.

This was the political picture on Jan. 27, 1948 -- four years ago today: Henry A. Wallace was in the Presidential race as the avowed candidate of a third party on the left. Harry S. Truman clearly intended to run but his prestige was low and he was headed for a battle over the Democratic nomination.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A former city editor of The Los Angeles Daily News testified today that he had belonged to a Communist group of newspaper men in Los Angeles about 1937 or 1938.

IDEALLY, this book represents the vade mecum we have all. artists and laymen who care about art, been waiting for. It is a cookbook of the craft of painters and sculptors. written by forty-three practitioners.

Three years ago six hundred contractors affiliated with the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry and Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (A. F. L.) agreed upon a plan whereby sons of union members who are high school graduates would be eligible to compete for six-year scholarships at Columbia University and its School of Engineering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The new-born United States had to borrow from the banks to pay the first installments on the salaries of the President, the Vice President and members of Congress. The Treasury has not been out of debt since, except for one fiscal year, 1835-36.

THE pleasure that comes from neighborliness and friendship is implicit in this picture-story of boys and animals. Here are the vacation adventure of the twins, Tippy and Gil, at Grandpa's farm. They frolic with the animals, search through the green woods for a turtle to give to their lame friend Kenny and accidentally find an old Indian trace.

SHORTAGES of materials and the possibility of further Federal controls which may also affect automobile production are among the principal problems under consideration at the thirty-fifth annnal convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association here.

Directors of the Pacific Fire Insurance Company, Bankers and Shippers Insurance Company of New York and the Jersey Insurance Company of New York, all affiliated, have approved an amendment to reduce the par value of the capital stock of each company to $10 a share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The United States, although despairing of playing anything like the role of mediator, was reported today to be urging moderation on both parties in the violent Anglo-Egyptian dispute.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 26 -- Consultation and inspection services and an educational program in sanitation and health problems will be offered to business, industry, hospitals and similar institutions on a fee basis by the Orkin Institute of Industrial Sanitation, a new group, formation of which was announced here today by experts in sanitation and allied sciences.

MANCHESTER, England, Jan. 27 -- Russian plans for a big export drive in textile machinery and textile goods are being watched closely by Lancashire traders, but the machinery and the goods are so crude by British standards that it would be "fantastic" to offer them in Britain, they say.

SINCE almost everyone these days is taking a whack at the Federal Government and the way it operates, it may come as a surprise to learn that Government employes also have ideas on how to improve the biggest business in the country.

THE great city is built like fortress against the heavens Wherever the heavens are above, below on the earth there are the walls of the houses; everywhere city against heaven. It is only between the edges of the roofs that gaps remain; these are embrasures, look-out posts, from which to watch the enemy.

I APPROACHED a revisit to the Far East with considerable foreboding. The trip, from which I have just returned, took me through Japan, Korea, Formosa, the Philippines, Indonesia, Singapore, Indo-China, India and Pakistan -- all familiar places, with memories for me of happy years, but all changing.

Bloodmobiles visiting military installations and a public utility company in Brooklyn are expected to add a minimum of 850 pints of blood to the total collected during the coming week, Hugh H. Cuthtell, chairman of donor recruitment for the Brooklyn Red Cross chapter, announced yesterday.

AS THE giddy throng snake-dances down the Avenida Rio Branco in Rio de Janeiro during Carnival week next month, television cameras will catch the whole scene -- or as much of it as the undulating merrymakers with their ether spray-guns permit.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 26 -- Reports that the Air Force has rescheduled its requirements to carry fighting - aircraft production into 1955 instead of 1953 whetted the appetites of manufacturers this week as they strove to outline their production programs over the coming six to nine months.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Jan. 26 -- The Army Signal Corps announced today the successful development and operation of a robot-controlled weather station that formerly required the services of seven men.

Taking a major step to improve and make more available family counseling for marital, parent-child and personality problems, Jewish Family Service, one of the country's leading family service agencies, will consolidate three of its Manhattan offices in one centrally situated at 29-31 East Twenty-second Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 -- Cain Hoy Stable, owned by Harry F. Guggenheim of New York, scored its first stakes success of the year at Hialeah today when Anchors Aweigh led all the way in the six-furlong Jasmine Stakes for 3-year-old fillies.

LONDON. JUST over a year ago, I announced in the House of Commons the suspension of Marshall aid to Britain. It was a proud moment for us. Marshall aid had been planned to continue until 1952, yet we were able to manage on our own two years ahead of schedule.

The current disorders in the French protectorate of Tunisia have resulted in new arrests and in increased political tension in Morocco, Mohammed Laghzaoui, one of the leaders of the Moroccan Istiqlal (Independence) party, said here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The United States Weather Bureau in response to inquiries, described today the various geographical areas involved in its forecasts and country-wide summaries.

Relief in New York City is not being handled any more efficiently today than it was four years ago, an atmosphere of poor morale and "confusion and desperation" exists in the welfare centers and turnover of both investigators and supervisors in the Department of Welfare is "excessively high," it was charged yesterday by the New York State Department of Social Welfare.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- B-29 Superforts flew into northwest Korea last night and dumped seventy tons of bombs on Sinuiju in their first attack on this fighter base just across the Yalu River from Manchuria.

THE National Broadcasting Company television network's projected series on the United States Navy, entitled "Victory at Sea," has now reached the stage where N. B. C. says it definitely will get under way in September of this year in what the network calls "prime" listening time, since the joint venture with the Navy represents an outlay of some half a million dollars.

Judge Marvin R. Dye of Rochester, a member of the State Court of Appeals, urged last night that the courts and bar associations make greater use of their powers of contempt and disbarment to punish lawyers who turn courtrooms into hippodromes.

WITH careful planning, home-grown small fruits may be had from the first strawberries of early June to the last late-keeping grapes of January. It is mainly the development of early and late-ripening varieties that has made this possible. In some cases, too, the ripening period may be changed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A conference of members of the American Council on Education called on the Council's executive board today to review its recent recommendations for student draft deferment A continuing study of Universal Military Training, on which the Council so far has taken no position, also was asked.

A young Israeli with a Cockney accent was stopped at a midtown bank last week as he tried to change a $50 bill that he had bought the previous week for 18 pounds at a "black" exchange in London. He had bought the bill, a counterfeit from a French plant, illegally, but under the impression that it was good.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- There is a frenetic quality about the Eisenhower-for-President movement at this stage that is strikingly reminiscent of the Willkie pre-convention campaign of twelve years ago.
The "evils" of low earnings by banks were noted officially here last week.

The word "budget" derives from an old French word, bougette, meaning "little bag." It came into use in Government finance in Britain, where the Chancellor of the Exchequer was said to "open" before the House of Commons his receptacle of documents on receipts and expenditures for the coming year.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 (UP) -- William Steinberg, director of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra and former associate of Arturo Toscanini, will take over the post of permanent conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony.

George Black (Dod) Orsborne, the small and assertedly dauntless adventurer who set out from here last May on a World cruise, may learn this week whether he will be able to continue from Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, where he ran afoul of the British laws.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Jan. 26 -- Seventy-five experts in industrial relations, medicine, labor and education, admittedly groping for a solution to problems of retirement, agreed here today that the Government and industry should abandon chronological age as the sole basis for retirement.
Helen Keller appealed yesterday for the return of an unusual Swiss gold watch she lost when she left her green crocodile leather overnight case in a taxicab on Jan. 17.

CAT CAY, Bahamas, Jan. 26 -- Caribbee won the sixth annual Fort Lauderdale to Cat Cay ocean sailing race today with a triple first, unusual in blue water racing annals. The trim 57-foot yawl sailed by Carleton Mitchell of Annapolis, Md., was first to start, first to cross the finish line and first in corrected time results.

THE common rhubarb (Rheum rhaponticum) is a fine, deep-rooted perennial that is ornamental as well as useful. The foliage alone is worthy of the garden, and there are sturdy spikes of bloom that are seldom considered because of the luscious, edible stalks. It is ideal for low boundary lines, vacant corners or wherever there is a need for a coarse, leafy background.
TORONTO, Jan. 26 -- The New York Rangers widened their fourth-place lead in the National Hockey League race tonight by battling the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-3 tie in a hard-fought game.

VIVID scenes of action contrast sharply with tiresome discourses about the totalitarian state in this novel of flight and pursuit. The pursuer is Konnr, a minor police officer from a monolithic (and strangely mythical) state; the quarry is Willy Bryo, an escaped prisoner; the chase covers land and sea at breakneck speed, then bogs down on an idyllic island where both men are washed ashore.

THE College in "The Masters" is a microcosm set up to show us how men act in society. Whether Mr. Snow meant his dons to be full-scale humans, capable of pathos and muted tragedy, or to be Lilliputians, utensils of satire, I didn't claim in my review to know.

TWO things are new at Old Sturbridge Village in Massachusetts. One is its recently announced program of remaining open to visitors throughout the year. The other is the withdrawal of its founders and sponsors. Albert B. and J. Cheney Wells, from personal or financial participation in its affairs.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Walter O. (Spike) Briggs Jr., once a college second baseman, took over as president of the Tigers today. He succeeded his father, who died nine days ago.

HARRISBURG, Jan. 26 -- The Democratic State Committee endorsed President Truman for re-election today, pledging him "unwavering and enthusiastic support" and named twenty delegates at large and twenty alternates to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next July.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, told Congress today that production of more and better "fantastic new weapons" would result from stretching out for twelve months the defense build-up, as recently disclosed.

UNTIL Joseph Kramm's "The Shrike" opened at the Cort on Jan. 15, Jose Ferrer, the protean theatre man, had not been acting on Broadway since he stepped off the "Twentieth Century'' last spring. But don't imagine that Mr. Ferret has been brooding.
The New York Knickerbockers whipped the Indianapolis Olympians, 99 to 93, in a National Basketball Association battle at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- Shipowner and stevedore industry members of the Pacific Maritime Association, who have grown accustomed over the years to hearing charges of unstable labor relations on the waterfront, have been informed by the association that man-day work losses from maritime strikes and work stoppages during the last three years have been six times as great on the East and Gulf Coasts as on the Pacific.

The report last week of the state fact - finding panel that investigated the October-November dock strike was a compromise which highlighted virtually all of the primary causes of waterfront unrest. A summary of the more significant problems, the panel's conclusions in respect to them, and what observers feel can be done to solve them appears below:

THERE is a mercurial quality to the French mind that is best caught on very fast film. Like French cabinets, their salon conversation is touch and go; now it is amour -- everyone tells his anecdote -- then it flashes to Xenophobie. Each subject shines brightly and momentarily; the only thing avoided is ennui, which is international for boredom.

Each subject shines brightly and momentarily; the only thing avoided is ennui, which is international for boredom.

PANMUNJOM, Jan. 26 -- The United Nations negotiators who have been meeting with Communist representative at this mud-hut village in the middle of no-man's-land would not be at all surprised if their half-year attempt to bring about an armistice should suddenly succeed tomorrow -- or should suddenly collapse in a prelude to all-out war again.

President Truman's budget message to Congress caused little surprise in financial circles last week. Calling for the expenditure of $85,444,000,000 in the next fiscal year, or $14,500,000,000 more than at present, the message sets some marks to be considered -- record expenditures, receipts, and a deficit in peacetime.

Great Lakes steamship owners, together with certain railroads and railroad labor union interests south of the Canadian border and certain North Atlantic port cities in the United States, were named yesterday by Lionel Chevrier, Minister of Transport of Canada, as among the "powerful minority interests" that have tried to sidetrack the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

As a major convention city, Atlantic City has been the scene of many medical and scientific meetings over the years. No session, however, has been more unusual nor promised greater dividends than that being held here this week-end.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Two men died and a third was injured today when a B-26 attack bomber crashed, exploded and burned in the mudflats less than half a mile from a Navy ammunition magazine.

HERE is a story warm and simple, frequently moving, sometimes chucklesome, often eloquent. The Josephite Father Murphy, Salem-born Irishman of parents poor in money but rich in faith, looks back on his life and reminds us again that an ecclesiastical career can have drama, tragedy and salty comedy in equal parts.

ERICH MARIA REMARQUE is a handsome, sophisticated connoisseur of good living. Meet him in Paris or New York, his friends will tell you, and you will find him a gay companion who knows just where to find the best in wine, food, entertainment. Remarque disdains conventional closing hours, and if the champagne is cold and the company stimulating he sees nothing incongruous about ending the evening at eight or nine the next morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A Senatorial committee is about to begin a comprehensive investigation of the Department of Agriculture's "bank," an institution with $100,000,000 of capital stock and borrowing authority of $6,750,000,000 -- which is still operating in high gear although it has lost something more than $1,000,000,000 since its establishment in 1933.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Kansas State upset the Kansas Jayhawks, 81 to 64, to take over the Big Seven basketball conference lead tonight.

In the budget that he sent Congress last week, President Truman included a request for a record sum of $688,000,000 for Federal educational expenditures in the fiscal year 1953. This is more than three times the amount that was appropriated for schools and colleges and for other educational purposes for the current fiscal year, which ends next June 30.

LOS ANGELES -- Exceptionally heavy precipitation, notably in the southern part of the state, has gotten California off to a flying start in snow sports this winter. Last year, while the northern high-altitude sections enjoyed seventeen "skiable" week-ends during the season, southern California snow fans basked most of the time in unwanted warmth and aridity.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 9 points yesterday. Weekend liquidation canceled part of the earlier gains.

Extensive restyling is offered in the 1952 Mercury line presented yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company. The cars, which will be displayed here on Wednesday, will be available in eight body designs, with a choice of twenty-two solid or color combinations.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Everything went off all right last night at Marian Anderson's first recital in Miami before a non-segregated audience. Police gave the noted Negro contralto the greatest protection ever afforded a singer here during her program in the Dade (Miami) County Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate's provisional and tentative investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was never a very enthusiastic enterprise. Now the prospect for any action has become even more remote.

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning that President Truman convene a conference of religious leaders of the three major faiths to discuss the question of naming a United States ambassador to the Vatican.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- The appeal by General Eisenhower this week for a "constitutional convention" to prepare the way for economic and political unity of Europe brought various comments. One was that it seemed incongruous for an international military chief to advise a political revolution.

GOING directly from a convent school to Broadway, Jessica Dragonette made her first stage venture as the Angel Voice in Max Reinhardt's "Miracle." Not long after that she made her radio debut on NBC when that pioneer network, then a month old, contained only nineteen stations. She was soon singing weekly to an audience of many millions.

The Mills College of Education, 66 Fifth Avenue, which recently was granted authority to conduct courses leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Education, last week made known its plan for expansion and changes in its liberal arts and teacher- education program.
An informal dinner honoring the captains and crews of the sunken Flying Enterprise and the Navy Transport Gen. A. W. Greely will be held on Tuesday at the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 26 -- A battle was fought sixteen miles east of Hanoi today as French and Vietnamese troops attacked a Vietminh force that had penetrated the north delta defense line of the French north of Kesat.

WITH Hollywood embarked upon a cycle of preposterous pictures in its newest attempt to lure more patrons into movie houses, actors with dimensions enough to fit the unusual demands of current scripts are hastily being summoned to the sound stages from all parts of the world.

Stevenson "won't lift a finger" to seek the party's Presidential nomination but would accept it under two conditions. Jacob M. Arvey, Democratic national committeeman from Illinois, said in his opinion the state's Governor would consent to be a White House candidate:
