WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Marine Lieut. Gale C. Buuck of Fort Wayne, Ind., has been reprimanded privately for his published criticism of President Truman's conduct of the Korean war.

THIS collection of twenty-nine essays by as many different writers on various phases of the dance ranges from history and philosophy through mechanics and technology to personal artistic approaches. It is a rich and provocative symposium in which individual opinions are freely expressed.

Al Parsells, one of the leading players in indoor polo, accounted for nine goals as his Ramapo trio routed the New York Athletic Club, 14 -- 4, last night in the feature of the double-header at the Squadron A Armory.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 27 -- Japanese parliamentarians advised Premier Shigeru Yoshida yesterday to seek a pledge from the United States that Jajan would not be used as a base for atomic bombings, should a third world war break out and Japan be subjected to Communist attack.

A bill to cancel the $190,000,000 debt owed to the United States by India for wheat shipped to that country since last June will be introduced in Congress this week, Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. declared yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Preparations were being made in London today to meet a worsening of the diplomatic situation in Egypt.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 26 -- Midwestern Democratic leaders called upon President Truman today to accept renomination at the National Convention in Chicago in July.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Iron scrap collections at naval shipyards have increased 97 per cent in the last six months, Vice Admiral C. W. Fox, Chief of Naval Materiel, said today.

A program for the improvement of school district organization in Midwestern states has been initiated by the Midwest Administration Center of the University of Chicago in cooperation with the University of Nebraska. The center hopes to provide better evidence than is now available as to what constitutes the most desirable type of district organization in relationship to community development, population distribution and other factors.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UP) -- George Gee, a former Red Wing, scored once and set up two other goals tonight to lead the last-place Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-to-2 victory over Detroit, his former team.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- American military authorities, particularly the United States naval command, have turned formation of the United States Olympic team into "their monopoly," the newspaper Soviet Sports charged today.

Last Friday some of the world's leaders in nutrition research presented their findings at an International Conference on Vitamins and Hormones held in Havana, Cuba. The old saw that "we are what we eat" was confirmed. The papers read also made it clear that food is more than food; that the right food promotes and maintains health, and that the wrong food often causes disease.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The International Materials Conference provided 6,150 tons of newsprint today to six countries otherwise unable to obtain supplies, but said that such "emergency allocations" would have to be replaced in the near future by "normal commercial transactions."

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has said of the Middle East: "As far as the sheer value of territory is concerned, there is no more strategically important area in the world."

RICHMOND, Va. -- James Crumbley of Norfolk, debarking in his home town after a thirteen-day cruise through, the Caribbean on the Holland-America liner Ryndam, said: "It was like I never left home." This was scarcely odd because Mr. Crumbley's fellow-passengers, about 500 of them, were Virginians almost to the last colonel and lady; he had been on a Virginia cruise, a Caribbean trip of, by and for residents of the Old Dominion.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Siena College scored a 61-58 victory over Manhattan tonight, coming from behind in the last minutes of play to nip the Jaspers.

THE reappearance of Story Magazine in book form is something of a literary event for those of us who mourned its passing several years ago. Begun with great courage and faith in the dark days of the depression (1931).

NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla. -- Construction work is under way on three new bridges connecting this resort city of 7,200 with the beach, at a total cost of about $875,000. The largest structure, a causeway, to cost $686,500, will provide an extension to the ocean of State Route 40.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee issued a formal announcement here today that he would be a candidate in the May 6 Ohio Democratic Presidential primary and declared, "I expect to win."

Wise Old Herbaceous, who came on the scene some months ago, thanks to Reginald Arkell, has collaborated with his creator, though Herbaceous apparently thinks little of his friend as a gardener, thus:

A. P. HERBERT once helped change Britain's antiquated divorce laws by burlesquing them in a book called "Holy Deadlock." Now -- eighteen years and about as many books later -- he has got the wind up about psychiatrists, especially those who infiltrate the Government as personnel experts.

Because sin "leaves its effect upon our senses" and affects body, mind and soul, the sick are beset by fears and insecurity that can be allayed only by prayer and by "the healing oil of extreme unction," the Rev. Charles J. McManus of St. Patrick's Cathedral clergy declared at solemn mass yesterday. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 27 -- There are indications that the Dutch Government will take advantage of the greatly strengthened monetary position to put its financial house in order.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Trade volume in grain future operations on the Chicago Board of Trade dropped moderately last week. Purchases of leading grains were substantially smaller than the preceding week, but were balanced in part by more active trade in soybeans, purchases of which increased about 17,000,000 bushels compared to last week.
CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 27 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in effect gave his approval today for the first time to the entry of his name in a Presidential preference primary.
More persons than ever before are covered by retirement programs in the United States, but inflation is diluting the benefits.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Sharp divergence between the partisans of deflation and those who propose a relaxing of controls on credits are now showing their effects within the highest government organizations.

Cotton prices were firmer last week, except for the rather sharp setback that occurred around midweek. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the period with net advances of 15 to 28 points, following declines of 69 to 81 points in the preceding week. A belief that the crop would fall short of Government expectations, based on the ginnings report to Jan. 16, encouraged buying last week.

Twenty books that are believed to be among the oldest post-Talmudic works and that were written between the tenth and eleventh centuries have come to light through research done at the Jewish Theological Seminary, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis Finkelstein, its chancellor.

The thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace. Since new car production for 1952 is expected to be on-third below last year's output, clinic discussions were held on the methods of keeping in servicable condition all automobiles now in use.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 26 -- The Israeli Cabinet is expected to announce soon measures to deal with the threatening wave of inflation.

BERLIN, N. H., Jan. 27 (AP) -The combined profits after taxes of the Brown Company and its Canadian subsidiary, Brown Corporation, reached a record high of $7,430,040 in 1951, Laurence F. Whittemore, president, announced today.

Four adjoining and interconnecting buildings occupying the block-front at 321-41 Rider Avenue, 322-42 Canal Place and 221-27 East 140th Street, in the Bronx, have been sold by the James Arthur Corporation, represented by Louis Teitleman, to the G. A. Realty Corporation, represented by William Kapelman and Samuel Edelstin.
A forty-hour week for 8,000 drivers and mechanics on nine privately owned bus lines was made contingent yesterday on city action to raise fares or provide other financial help to the bus companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Americans have donated 1,225,000 pints of blood through the American Red Cross for our military forces since the outbreak of war in Korea eighteen months ago, E. Ronald Harriman, president of the organization, reported today.
Ten new films, including English, Italian, French and Austrian-made importations, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:...

BONN, Germany, Jan. 27 -- The Government of Federal Germany announced tonight that it would not agree to any form of treaty binding the Republic to a European defense force until the Saar question and other related issues had been discussed by the Bundestag (Parliament).

Life in the Arctic is the subject of two books to be issued next month. On Feb. 25 Atlantic-Little, Brown will issue "People of the Deer" by Farley Mowat. It is an account of the Ihalmiut Esikimos who live in the Great Barrens Land, northwest of Hudson Bay.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 27 -- Americans in charge of the United States effort to help Iran avoid a Communist revolution are in an increasing quandary as to how far to go in supporting the Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's mammoth land reform experiment, which is the only thing now going on here directly concerned with correcting the conditions that lead to communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Senate investigators demanded to know today why the Army still was keeping a "secret" label on a United States Air Force base in Greenland that had been publicized by newspapers and magazines and used in propaganda by "Moscow Molly."

DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- Clarence Mitchell, director of the Washington Bureau of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, today assailed what he said were the racial stands of three Presidential candidates, Senator Robert A. Taft, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Estes Kefauver. President Truman drew both praise and criticism.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, golf's leading money winner last year, took his first 1952 victory here today in the $10,000 Phoenix open tournament.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- For the first time since the end of World War II several states are collecting more tax revenue than they are spending.

The Rev. Leopold Braun, only American Roman Catholic priest in Russia from 1934 to 1945, charged yesterday that "organized State Department stupidity" in the war years had led to the present tension between the United States and the Soviet Union. He urged a "reciprocity of force" in any future dealings with Russia.

Beginning today the R. C. A. Exhibition Hall in Radio City will become a place of pilgrimage for a large and devoted sect. It is the sect of Carusophiles. They will be journeying there not, indeed, to touch the hem of costumes the immortal tenor once used to wear, because these, while on view, will not be quite so approachable as that.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Legislation to outlaw professional boxing in New York -- or to investigate it -- will be smothered in committee, Republican leader Arthur H. Wicks of the State Senate indicated tonight.
MOUNT HAMILTON, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -- A star that flares up brightly eighteen times a day has been found by a University of California astronomer working in Australia.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The second-place Toronto Maple Leafs scored in every period tonight to shut out Boston, 3-0, before 8,242 National Hockey League fans, who at times jeered or stomped to show their disapproval.
Instructions to the public in the event of an enemy gas attack were announced yesterday by Arthur W. Wallander, City Director of Civil Defense. He emphasized self-aid.

The New York State Department of Social Welfare, in its report calling the New York City Welfare Department inefficient, has resorted to "deliberate distortion of facts, obvious misstatements of fact and the use of crafty and tricky language," City Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 (UP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today it made a profit of $8,000,000 in the last six months of 1951, compared with $7,500,000 in the last half of 1950.

A resolution condemning a tendency to segregate Negro doctors into a "few municipal hospitals" and urging all municipal and voluntary hospitals to open places on their staffs for qualified Negro physicians will be put before the Medical Society of the County of New York tonight, at a monthly meeting at 2 East 103d Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said today in two addresses here that moral integrity must be restored to national Government and organized crime suppressed in this country as a prerequisite to United States leadership in world affairs.

The United States Constitution wisely forbids our Government to grant titles of nobility but does not prevent the President from pinning a medal on persons he thinks deserve it. The Distinguished Service Medal is one such, and every fair-minded individual familiar with the circumstances will welcome its bestowal last Saturday on W. Stuart Symington.

Former President Herbert Hoover urged yesterday that the United States withdraw all its ground forces from Europe except those needed to protect our air bases outside the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Mezzy Barber, 33-year-old competitor from the Brattleboro (Vt.) Outing Club, today gained his third triumph of the season as he topped the Class A field in the twenty-first annual Norsemen Ski Club ski jump.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 28 -- Staff officers of the Communists and United Nations Command began sessions yesterday in an attempt to reach agreement on terms for an armistice in the Korean war that a military subcommittee at Panmunjom had proved unable to conclude in almost a month's discussion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The privately owned merchant fleet in the United States was increased by 113 vessels totaling 1,309,344 deadweight tons during 1951, the National Federation of American Shipping reported today.

HANOI, Indo-China, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- The main railroad linking the Tongking capital of Hanoi and its supply port of Haiphong has been damaged for the third time in two weeks by Communist-led Vietminh saboteurs, French sources reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 -- By stretching itself far beyond its normal pattern the steel industry last week was able to boost its steel ingot rate one full point to 99.5 per cent of capacity. That figure was based on new steel capacity recorded as of Jan. 1, 1952.

" Porgy and Bess" finally has been wrapped up -- quite a saga in itself -- by Blevins Davis and Robert Breen. They will join hands in what appears to be an ambitious future for the second revival of the famous Negro folk musical by George Gershwin, DuBose Heyward and Ira Gershwin.

Having begun with Mozart's Requiem and shorter works three weeks ago, the Robert Shaw Chorale continued its "Choral Masterwork Series" last night when it presented Bach's B minor Mass in Carnegie Hall. The work drew an audience of 2,700, which applauded the achievement in no uncertain terms.

Performances of Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas" do not come up too often, and Town Hall therefore was filled to capacity yesterday when the amazing and prophetic opera was presented in concert form by the New Friends of Music.

Three busloads of architectural historians, including Ryuichi Hamaguchi of Tokyo, toured Manhattan Island between Sixtieth and Wall Streets yesterday, giving a collective expert's eye to buildings selected, in advance for their scrutiny.

Although total sales of International Harvester Company and subsidiaries for the year ended Oct. 31, last, were 36 per cent above the volume attained in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1950, net income was 6 per cent less than a year before.
MARIETTA, Ohio, Jan. 27 -- A "sneak" flood rolled down the Ohio River today, driving about 2,000 persons from their homes.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 27 -- The response of the German public to the America Houses and reading roooms is described by United States officials here as one of the signs of democratic growth often overshadowed by other events.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Overcast skies and zero temperatures all but stalled the Korean war yesterday on the ground.
MATTOON, Ill., Jan. 27 -- series of gas explosions ripped the center of this town of 18,000 at 12:45 P. M. today, causing an estimated $1,000,000 damage.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Poland moved a step closer to the Soviet way of Government today with publication of a new draft Constitution patterned closely on the Soviet Constitution of 1936.

Each year before the President sends his annual message on the budget to Congress the Administration's high fiscal command holds a "seminar" for newsmen. Since the questions and answers at these sessions deal entirely with the interpretation of the budget message and the budget figures, they do not normally produce any news stories of consequence.

To George Rhoden yesterday was voted the Rodman Wanamaker International Trophy as the outstanding performer of the tumultuous Millrose Games, best-attended and most absorbing Madison Square Garden track spectacle of the post-war era.

Caging the disk three times before the game was eight minutes old, the Canadiens of Montreal defeated the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night Bill Cook's skaters fought valiantly to erase this early deficit, but the Flying Frenchmen managed to carve out a 5-3 victory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Economic leadership and mass production methods of the United States are cited by the United Nations statistical yearbook as major factors in tremendous advances registered in world output of important commodities over the last two decades.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 27 -- The bell in the tower of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church heralded this morning the beginning of the church's 250th anniversary celebration.

This is no time for recriminations. When anything happens as serious as the Egyptian conflict, law-abiding citizens there and everywhere have a clear duty. The fires that burned in Cairo's rioting, the fires that blaze all through the Middle East, threatening to destroy the freedom and security of the area, must be quenched.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis won his seventh senior men's national outdoor speed skating title since 1939 as the fifty-third annual event concluded today. It was his third consecutive crown.

A ten-year agricultural plan for Israel, involving a cost of $840,000,000 and designed to make the fledgling state as nearly self-sustaining as possible in food production, has been started by the United Palestine Appeal in conjunction with the Israeli Government.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- In the last few days a vast amount has been written and talked about the results of the recently held commonwealth finance ministers' conference in London but the effect on the markets of the decisions so far reported to have been taken has been slight and fleeting,

Lloyd Ailsby's New York Rovers had beaten the New Haven Tomahawks only once in eight games before yesterday. Then the Red Shirts, apparently playing inspired hockey, blanked the second-place Tomahawks, 5 -- 0, in a rough-and-tumble Eastern Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden.

A committee representing the rank and file of Local 968, International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., has written to Governor Dewey, it was learned yesterday, requesting his aid and that of other state officials in ending what they describe as discrimination against their organization by top union officials and management.

In a cash deal, the four-story private dwelling in Colonial style at 117 East Thirty-first Street has been sold by Mrs. Alice B. Davis to the Audubon Management Corporation, a subsidiary of Walter Scott Co., for investment. It occupies a lot 21 by 98 feet between Fourth and Lexington Avenues and was sold through Gilliam Murphy, Inc., in conjunction with Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The West German Government made today its first formal claim to participate in the North Atlantic Treaty. It did so at the conference of the Foreign Ministers of the six nations proposing to merge their land and air forces in a European army.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- "The United States can no longer afford underemployment of some two million families on American farms, while manpower shortages exist and the demand for farm products grows." This is the thesis of a report issued today by the National Planning Association.

ZURICH, Jan. 27 -- As Swiss banking in 1951 enjoyed an exceptional year, publication of the first bank balance sheets last week has stirred wide speculation here as to how the five great commercial banks intend to utilize net profits.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 -- By way of demonstrating that he was in peak condition and at the height of his showing prowess for a defense of the Westminster crown a fortnight hence, Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest took best tonight in the two-day Maryland Kennel Club event.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will examine another aspect of Nazi Germany's wanton bid for world conquest in "The Arms of Venus," to be produced by Otto Lang with Michael Rennie playing the lead role.

Buttons play a dual role in fashion. They are both decorative and functional. There are countless button styles, of which we have selected six for illustration in today's Patterns of The Times suggestions. Directions for ways of using them may be obtained by writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Away with the Van Hornes, Crosbys, Rosens and Goulds, mere children all. Long live Ruby Goldstein!

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- David B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, and an eighteen-member negotiating committee spent today studying the recommendations of a Presidential emergency board for ending a two-year dispute with the railroads.
TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,142 for Sunday's operations:

At the corner of the Bowery and Third Street, the Salvation Army is building a new opera tion to be known as a "drying - out" center. Its four floors will provide private rooms, dining facilities and lounge for men of the Bowery needing a place to stay during the days when they are attempting to overcome alcoholism.

In the Paris meeting of the General Assembly the representative of the free Chinese, Dr. T. F. Tsiang, has again presented the case against the Soviet Union. It is a grave series of charges, gravely presented. It has nothing of the fireworks of a Vishinsky or the dogged dullness of a Gromyko or a Malik.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that he had told President Truman that sentiment in Minnesota was strong for Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee for the Democratic Presidential nomination if the President himself was not a candidate.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Gov. Earl Warren of California said today he might challenge Harold E. Stassen in the Wisconsin - Republican Presidential primary.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Voters of the adjoining villages of Dobbs Ferry and Ardsley yesterday decisively defeated a proposition to consolidate their school districts. The proposal was intended to effect economy and improve the scholastic, athletic and extra-curricular programs of both educational systems.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Jan. 27 -- Blitz, a 100-pound St. Bernard who roams the estate of Herman Berman on Kings Point Road here, had an experience this morning that he won't soon forget.

ERICH MARIA REMARQUE'S new novel, "Spark of Life,"* is published today, six years almost to the day after the publication of his "Arch of Triumph." Mr. Remarque is not a writer who can be hurried into producing an annual novel. His first, "All Quiet on the Western Front," appeared twenty-three years ago. "Spark of Life" is only his sixth.

The American home rates second only to the motor vehicle as the source of accidental deaths in this country, according to figures published in the January issue of National Safety News, a publication of the National Safety Council.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 27 -- Nationalist agitation in Tunisia had subsided tonight to a handful of scattered acts of sabotage and even "mischief," but its leader asserted that this was a temporary lull that would end if France did not make concessions toward home rule.

MUNSAN, Korea, Jan. 27 -- Rear Admiral Ruthven E. Libby, spokesman for the United Nations command during the talks on prisoners of war at the armistice negotiations, expressed his personal belief tonight that most Communist prisoners captured from the Chinese and North Korean Armies would elect to return to their own countries under the plan of voluntary repatriation proposed by the United Nations.

The advance of the Canadian dollar to parity with American was the biggest single event in the foreign exchange market last week. At this new peak, Canadian stands at its highest since August, 1939, when it sold at par.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- An unexpected break, the change in Government, occurred in the tense situation in Egypt tonight as British authorities were taking precautions against more bloodshed and destruction there.

CAIRO, Jan. 27 -- King Farouk ousted the Government of Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha tonight because of its failure to maintain "security and order," and appointed an independent to head the new Cabinet.

A centennial exhibition of work by a noted American painter; a group of outstanding modern works at the Museum of Modern Art; and numerous one-man and group shows make up this week's program in the art world.

The Morningside Citizens Committee, formerly the Morningside Citizens Committee on Schools, announced yesterday that it had broadened its activities to include other problems affecting the area between Morningside Avenue and the Hudson River from 108th to 125th Streets and to support the efforts of the city and private sponsors to build new housing units.
MUNSAN, Korea, Monday, Jan. 28 -- The United Nations Command submitted to the Communists today a detailed draft of a prisoner-of-war exchange plan for inclusion in a Korean truce agreement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Washington Times-Herald said yesterday that when General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was 19 years old he made a speech at a Democratic rally in Abilene, Kan., attacking the Republican party.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 27 -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh today gave Sir Francis Shepherd, the retiring British Ambassador, what appeared to be a suggestion that he was ready to negotiate British-Iranian differences, the most important of which is the oil question.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A collection of New Orleans bon vivants who bandied words with Senator Estes Kefauver last year on the subject of crime and corruption will go after Mr. Kefauver's skin tomorrow night. Mr. Kefauver's coonskin cap, that is.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Jan. 27 -- The Parker House, a Newtown landmark dating back to Revolutionary War days when it served as a tavern and stage coach station, has been sold by its owner, Mrs. Edith G. Parker, to Nicholas Tamburri of Stamford, Conn., and his brother, William A. Tamburri of Fairfield, Conn. Frank Gillespie of Norwalk was the broker.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 27 -- Within six months the members of the North Atlantic Lobster Institute hope to have ready for New York tables quick-frozen lobsters packed in rockweed and ready to pop into the boiler, plastic bag and all.

The Westinghouse Electric Appliance Division is planning to spend more than $12,000,000 in advertising and promoting the sale of its products this year, it was made known over the week-end in Mansfield, Ohio. The expenditure, a record budget, was detailed following a two-day planning session for distributor executives.

Honors conferred by the United States Government for the people of the United States, through the office of the President, upon military personnel are not conferred as personal honors by any particular individual who happens to be President of the United States.

Aly Maher Pasha, the new Premier of Egypt, was interned by the British for thirty-one months during World War II for allegedly having turned over to the Italians a British military plan for the defense of Egypt.
LAKE ALFRED, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Henry Shakeshaft of Mount Kisco, N. Y., set a new world record for Class C outboard hydroplanes in the annual Valencie Regatta today.

A 7-year-old boy fell last night through the window of a Brooklyn apartment, landing in a muddy courtyard, five floors below. After starting to crawl away, he got up and walked. Apparently he was uninjured.

A plea to help National Chinese intellectuals survive, pending a possible return to the mainland, and a call for an educational program in Korea against communism marked the opening here last night of the third national conference of the United States National Commission for Unesco -- the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

The Bulova Watch Company and City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses announced yesterday that construction of the company's new precision instrument defense plant on a twenty-five acre "garden-type" landscaped site in Queens had been started.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Between fog and a following mere gasp of breeze, the sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club today was threatened with a black-out.
Nicola Moscona, one of the Metropolitan Opera's bass-baritones, last night gave his first Town Hall concert since 1945.

The shipping industry, led locally by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, is pressing for the passage of legislation providing for round-the-clock quarantine service in this harbor and other important points of entry in the United States.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Jan. 27 -- The future seemed brighter for Fred Bixby, his wife and their four young children when he found a job recently as a laborer after a long period of unemployment. But today the 42-year-old father and two of the children were in a critical condition and the other two youngsters were dead as a result of a flash fire last night in their home here.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- Robert Lippincott of Riverton, N. J., sailed his yacht Mate to a second successive victory this morning in the Bacardi Cup series of the twenty-first international Star Class regatta. He has a total of 48 points for the two races. The third will be sailed tomorrow afternoon.

The rise of the Canadian dollar to full parity with the American dollar on the foreign exchange market last week was more than merely another fluctuation on the financial exchanges. Economically it represented a well-justified recognition of the enormous productive gains made by our great northern neighbor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Commodity Credit Corporation, a major unit of the Department of Agriculture, has been robbed and Congress is about to undertake a full-scale investigation to find out how it happened.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 27 -- The widespread Communist election successes in this huge State of Madras may be attributed more to successful Leftist exploitation of sectional interests than to ideological persuasion, according to objective observers here.

OTTAWA, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- The Government is planning to invite certain industrial and other companies and organizations to keep in close touch with Chalk River's attempt to harness atomic energy for power purposes.

Regarding your editorial of Jan. 23, "Castles in Spain," let me assure you that the American people on the whole are not "bewildered" because of the optimistic information coming from Spain, nor are they fearful of the prospective decision about to be reached by the various missions assigned to study the Spanish question.

UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The last shot of the match, by Del McTavish, gave Lachute, Que., a 15-14 triumph over Kingston, Ont., today in the final of Mitchell Medal curling competition at the fifth international bonspiel.

Storage space to order, in the form of unpainted units or storage walls, may be found in some new versions designed to take care of a variety of objects, from a television set to a toaster. Especially useful in small quarters, the units are comparatively inexpensive.
The Board of Estimate will begin this morning a new series of executive meetings at City Hall in an effort to hammer out a program of new or heavier local taxes to help balance the 1952-53 budget.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Republican state leaders, following a quiet canvass of county chairmen, have decided to abandon any attempt to write a legislative reapportionment law until after the fall election.

In a sermon at the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Eighty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, the Rev. Frederick Schalow warned yesterday that "the spread of godless ideals so prevalent today in Asia will affect us all in the form of wars and struggles and corruption in government."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Union employes of the Baltimore Transit Company voted acceptance tonight of a three-year contract, ending a seventeen-day tie-up of the city's bus transportation. The vote was 2,461 to 100.
I was pleased to read the editorial in your issue of Jan. 20 on the subject of maps and boundaries. Public attention needs to be turned to such matters.

The Protestant Episcopal Church has not been caught up in the "prevalent hysteria" over the international situation because its clergy have been trained in religious history and "are not nervous about God's reputation," Canon Edward N. West, sacrist of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Detroit's goalie, Terry Sawchuk, scored his tenth shut-out of the season today as the Red Wings defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 0, before the largest National Hockey League crowd of the season in the Chicago Stadium, 13,904 fans.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Federal, State and local law enforcement authorities in Illinois intensified last week their investigation of racketeering in the illegal sale of millions of pounds of horse meat as beef in Chicago and elsewhere.
Following is the text of former President Herbert Hoover's address yesterday to a nation-wide radio and television audience:

The American Jewish Committee, ending its forty-fifth annual meeting yesterday at the Commodore Hotel, unanimously endorsed a decision of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims to reach a settlement with the West German Government on reparations for the Israeli Government and for Jewish people over the world.

Verdi's "Otello," which has been out of the Metropolitan Opera House repertory for the last two seasons, will be revived Saturday afternoon, Feb. 9. Eleanor Steber, who will sing the Desdemona, will have two major roles that day, for in the evening she will appear as Fiordiligi in the season's sixth presentation of "Cosi fan tutte."

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- While sentiment in the grain market seemed to have been predominantly bearish last week, with long liquidation heavy at times in all pits, there was persistent commission absorption on the declines, and to the surprise of many operators prices were higher than a week ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- Longshoremen and stevedoring companies ended a five-day work stoppage in the Philadelphia port area today by implementing a clause in their contract that called for a "small joint committee" to negotiate disputes.

A 48-year-old farmer, who fled from Rumania a decade ago before the advancing Russian armies, was singled out yesterday on his arrival here as the 25,000th displaced person of German ethnic origin to come to this country under a program instituted in 1950.

A small electronic device that can be applied to home television receivers to test and reactivate the picture tube without removing the tube from the set, resulting in renewed brightness in many and considerably longer useful life, has been placed on the market for the first time by a New York manufacturer.
Bob Hogue, a right-hander who aspires to the role of the chief fireman's job that once belonged to Joe Page, signed his 1952 contract with the world champion Yankees yesterday.

Robert Jenkins Clark, in a letter published in THE TIMES of Jan. 17, states that "the persecution of Negroes, Catholics, Jews * * * is, unless it violates some provision of the Constitution, a matter for each state to deal with as its own conscience (and voters) dictate."

Even the novice in cookery now can whisk together a Spanish-style rice dish in a matter of minutes at a price kind to frayed budgets. Piquantly spiked with saffron, powdered onions and garlic, "Yellow Rice Brand Dinner" is a gastronomic find of Joseph Victori, 164 Pearl Street.
An athletic police lieutenant and an opportune red light resulted early yesterday morning in the capture of two men charged with impersonating police officers.

LEFTY GROVE was mad and Lefty had a king-size temper. He had just lost a 1-0 game to the St. Louis Browns because Jim Moore, substituting for the absent Al Simmons in left field, had misjudged a fly ball to let in the run.

Former Judge Learned Hand of the United States Court of Appeals, who was 80 years old yesterday, said he'd like to set the record straight about the part he did not play in Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy's rejection of President Truman's offer to Judge Murphy to head an investigation of corruption in the Federal Government.

The Loewenguth Quartet, which appeared earlier this month for the New Friends of Music, played under its own auspices on Saturday night at Town Hall. Since its debut here three seasons ago, the quartet has won some ardent followers and enthusiasm ran high at its latest appearance.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Miss Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., today won the twentieth annual Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf championship with a 2-and-1 victory over Miss Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore in the 36-hole final.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The largest electric motors for marine propulsion in the world are being built in this country for Russia. They weigh about 100 tons each.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for construction of a West Side Airlines Terminal on the southeast corner of Forty-second Street and Tenth Avenue. Its location is expected to help cut bus travel time to and from Newark Airport by as much as twenty minutes.

Two make - believe dragons roamed the winding streets of Chinatown yesterday, chasing away evil spirits and bringing good luck to the Chinese settlement as it ushered in the year 4650, known in the Confucian calendar as the Year of the Dragon.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The price average for burley tobacco sold in Kentucky last week declined to $43.98 a hundred pounds as the volume of business also decreased.

I. E. Cruse has been appointed division sales manager in charge of the newly created Gerber division, which includes metropolitan New York, Long Island and northern New Jersey. The appointment is effective Feb. 1.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that he was "highly gratified" by the increase in 1951 in the number of arrests of sellers of narcotics. He added: "If this continues we will have the situation well under control."

Two make - believe dragons roamed the winding streets of Chinatown yesterday, chasing away evil spirits and bringing good luck to the Chinese settlement as it ushered in the year 4650, known in the Confucian calendar as the Year of the Dragon.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The price average for burley tobacco sold in Kentucky last week declined to $43.98 a hundred pounds as the volume of business also decreased.

I. E. Cruse has been appointed division sales manager in charge of the newly created Gerber division, which includes metropolitan New York, Long Island and northern New Jersey. The appointment is effective Feb. 1.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that he was "highly gratified" by the increase in 1951 in the number of arrests of sellers of narcotics. He added: "If this continues we will have the situation well under control."

The birthdays of two former parishioners, Gen. Robert E. Lee and Maj. Gen. Thomas J. (Stonewall) Jackson, were marked yesterday in a commemorative sermon by the Rev. Theodore H. Winkert, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church (The Church of the Generals), Fort Hamilton Parkway and Ninety-ninth Street, Brooklyn.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan was honored as "Citizen of the Year" last night by Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith, Jewish fraternal organization, for exposing corruption in public office and prosecuting college basketball "fixers." Max Kase, president of the lodge, presented a citation to him at the first annual awards dinner of the organization in the Astor Hotel.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 -- The first of an estimated 10,000 Mexican families whose land has dried to dust have begun a forced exodus northward to escape what the capital's newspapers describe as "imminent starvation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, called today for a $7,000,000,000 cut in Federal spending as a demand went up in Congress for budget economies that would spare neither the military nor foreign aid programs.

The only change in the Saturday evening Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall was the presence of Nicole Henriot as soloist in Liszt's E flat Piano Concerto. Otherwise the program, conducted by Guido Cantelli, adhered to the Thursday-Friday pair of concerts, with Rossini's "Semiramide" Overture, Busoni's "Berceuse elegiaque" and the Mussorgsky-Ravel "Pictures at an Exhibition."

Your recent front-page headline "West Germans Set Selective Service for Men Aged 19-21" gave me a shock. It sounded like German mobilization. But as I read down farther into the story I saw that it dealt principally with a radio speech by the West German State Secretary for Security, Theodor Blank, in which Mr. Blank merely announced his Government's plan to institute a draft at some later date.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A syndicate headed by Larry MacPhail, who led the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Yankees to baseball pennants, contracted today to buy a controlling interest in the Bowie race track.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 28 -- Capt. Dod Orsborne, author, adventurer and master of the sketch Argosy, and his mate, Edwin Hoskins, were cleared today of charges of unloading here three rifles and 3,000 rounds of ammunition.

An agreement under which 6,500 employes in Manhattan office and loft buildings will receive an increase of $3 a week was announced yesterday by David Sullivan, president of Local 32B, Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The main cause of reading retardation, in adults as well as children, is a past history of "inappropriate instruction," Dr. Emmett A. Betts, director of the reading clinic, Temple University, declared today. Although emotional difficulties, personality factors and vision problems may play a part, he said, poor teaching methods are the prime cause.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- A bill to set up a six-member court of review to hear appeals from decisions of the State Workmen's Compensation Board was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Leo P. Noonan, Republican of Cattaraugus County.
Trading in the New York commodity futures markets was dull yesterday and volume was low. Cocoa and sugar were stronger in price, but others showed losses.

SURAKARTA, Java., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Indonesian Army command here reported 1,400 casualties and the capture of 1,000 prisoners in a bloody seven-week campaign to purge fanatic Moslem terrorists of the Darul Islam sect from central Java.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, with 52,000 workers on the nation's railroads, rejected today a Presidential emergency board's recommendations for settling a union-management dispute over wages and hours.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The United States, Britain and France served notice today that they would call for United Nations action to meet any new Communist attack in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A Supreme Court ruling on segregation of white and Negro children in public schools was postponed today when the court asked for further details on the matter.

Richard Kimball, architect, in a purchase for occupancy, has acquired the five-story dwelling at 138 East Seventy-first Street from Mrs. S. H. Kronthal. The sale was negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co. as brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, accused the administration today of putting "terrific pressure" on Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee in an effort to "head off" a proposed investigation of J. Howard McGrath, Attorney General.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- How Italian Communists were duped into circulating an American slap at Moscow's "peace" campaign has been brought to light in an order issued from Communist headquarters in Rome.

Several dinner parties will be given before the performance of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," with Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh, tonight at the Ziegfeld Theatre for the benefit of the Academy of American Poets.

A syndicate of forty-three investment houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and W. E. Hutton Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $15,000,000 of the Dayton Power and Light Company first-mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds due in 1982 at 102 1/4 to yield about 3.13 per cent to maturity.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Hard-hitting Ken McGregor won the Australian singles championship today when he upset Davis Cup star Frank Sedgman, 7 -- 5, 12 -- 10, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, in the all-Aussie final before 6,500 surprised spectators.

The State Athletic Commission's recent action in serving notice on all ring champions that the six-month title defense regulation would be rigidly enforced, resulted yesterday in a renewal of overtures by the National Boxing Association for at least a working agreement between the N. B. A. and the Empire State body.
The shipping industry in New York is disturbed by sharp increases in the premium cost of workmen's compensation approved by State insurance authorities and made effective on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota introduced a bill today to permit the Maritime Commission to award medals to members of the merchant marine for distinguished service.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Cain Hoy Stable's 3-year-old colt Armageddon, racing for the first time since he won the Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park last October, did fairly well in a six-furlong sprint at Hialeah today, but he didn't do well enough to suit those in the crowd of 16,987 who had backed him into 6-to-5 favoritism.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Soviet industry as a whole exceeded 1951 production targets by three-fifths of 1 per cent, said a report by the Council of Ministers of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics broadcast early today by Moscow radio.

The innovation of raising the curtain at "South Pacific" at 7 o'clock and ending the show at 9:55 proved successful last night. An audience of 1,599 persons, including the maximum allowance of thirty standees, was present at the first of a series of early Monday night performances at the Majestic Theatre.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Robert J. Christenberry, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, will be asked by the State Senate tomorrow how much time he will need to clean up boxing in the state. His interim appointment by Governor Dewey is slated to be acted upon by the Senate tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Brig. Gen. Harry H. Semmes, a patent attorney of Washington, has been appointed executive director of the National Security Training Commission, it was announced today by James W. Wadsworth, commission chairman.

Three new pilot classes for retarded children, which have been organized and are conducted under the auspices of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, were formally dedicated yesterday at a ceremony at the Young Women's and Young Men's Hebrew Association, 178th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- A four-point program for settling by arbitration law suits growing out of motion-picture industry disputes was proposed today by the Theatre Owners of America and will be offered for acceptance on an industry-wide basis.
Details of the 1952 truck line were announced yesterday by the Ford Motor Company. The vehicles will go on display Friday.

Notice was served in Paris yesterday that the United States, Britain and France will call upon the United Nations to act in the event of further Communist aggressive action in Southeast Asia. The occasion for the warning was the statement of Andrei Vishinsky on Jan. 3 in which he referred to United States attitudes "whenever events begin to take their course on the southern borders of China, in Thailand, Burma and Yunnan Province."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Mr. DiSalle declared today that no one would suffer in the Northeast this winter because of fuel oil shortages, but he reiterated his refusal to grant a price increase to suppliers.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 28 -- Sir Francis Shepherd, the British Ambassador, left by air today on his way to his new post as Ambassador to Poland.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Allied Sabre jets damaged one Communist MIG-15 jet in a brief clash over "MIG Alley" today. Allied losses, if any, were not reported by the Fifth Air Force.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 29 -- Communist truce negotiators at Panmunjom rejected today the wording of the United Nations blueprint for prisoner of war exchange, but agreed to some points of the document aimed at speeding a Korean armistice.
Business men in many lines have more cash, and they are paying more invoices on a cash discount basis, a survey disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Nervousness over what measures the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Robert Austin Butler, might announce to combat the country's balance of payments crisis kept business low on the stock markets here today. Most sections finished dull.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The following ski conditions at New York

DETROIT, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Basic retail ceiling prices for the Ford Motor Company's 1952 models in all lines -- Ford, Mercury and Lincoln -- were announced tonight. The company said they were granted by the Office of Price Stabilization.

When a federal peacetime budget reaches $85 billions, of which about 60 per cent is directly connected with defense, this budget comes to differ in kind as well as in magnitude from budgets that we are used to. People accustomed to spending billions of the public funds can hardly help becoming billion-dollar-minded.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A House Agriculture subcommittee began today looking into methods by which the Department of Agriculture assembles data for its monthly cotton crop estimates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, has threatened to try to induce advertisers in Time magazine to withdraw their business because of what he calls "a smear attack" made on him by the publication.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UP) -- The Un-America Activities Committee of the House of Representatives voted today to cite Sidney Buchman for contempt of Congress after the Hollywood writer-producer again failed to appear at a hearing on Wast Coast communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The not surprising announcement by Senator Maybank of South Carolina today that he opposes another term for President Truman and favors Senator Russell of Georgia as the Democratic nominee this year promptly followed a huddle of Southern Democratic Senators with Governor Byrnes of South Carolina, a week-end visitor to Washington.

The five New York chapters of the American Red Cross will ask residents and workers of the city to contribute $6,700,000 to the organization in March, Leroy A. Lincoln, chairman of the 1952 fund campaign, announced yesterday.

Asserting that the nation was still suffering from the attack of "budgetitis" that broke out last week when President Truman requested $85,000,000,000 for the coming fiscal year, Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, declared last night that the lion's share would be spent to safeguard the United States against attack or to prevent a third world war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Michael V. DiSalle, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, broached to a Congressional committee today a plan his agency has long studied for decontrol of consumer items no longer needing governmental action to keep them within proper price bounds.

The opening of formal hearings yesterday on the career and salary plan for municipal workers drafted by Griffenhagen and Associates, consultants, brought a heavy turnout of city employes, largely opposed to the recommendations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a proposed immigration and naturalization law designed to codify, clarify and at many points to liberalize or toughen hundreds of piecemeal enactments and thousands of implementing regulations adopted in 154 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today approved a plan for splitting Loew's, Inc., into two companies, one devoted to motion-picture production and distribution, the other to owning movie houses.

Ever since the Soviet Union decided to grace the forthcoming Olympic Games with its presence there have been propaganda rumbles out of Moscow. The latest, loudest and funniest is a blast in the newspaper Soviet Sports about how United States military authorities, and especially the Navy, are taking over the whole "direct control of the sports life of the country" and will, of course, direct the selection of the Olympic athletes.

Compensation totaling $6,700,000 has been paid to date to the injured and to the families of those who lost their lives in the two 1950 train wrecks of the Long Island Rail Road at Rockville Centre and Kew Gardens, Queens, it became known yesterday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Reports on what Japan's Premier told the Diet Saturday about a proposed treaty with Nationalist China had a disquieting effect today in this Nationalist capital.

THREE weeks after General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower announced that he would accept the Republican nomination for President if it were offered him, John Gunther's "Eisenhower: The Man and the Symbol"* is published. This example of Mr. Gunther's celebrated nose for news is even more convincing than his "Riddle of MacArthur," which appeared last year more than three months before the five-star general's recall.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 28 -- Burmese Army units have launched a campaign against a strong force of Chinese Nationalist troops in the mountainous frontier country of northern Burma, the Government announced tonight.

Of 5,974,865 tons of newsprint consumed by newspapers in 1951, a total of 2,610,000 tons were recovered and used by paperboard, roofing, wallboard, paper and specialty mills. This was reported yesterday by the Eastern Conservation Committee of the Wastepaper Consuming Industries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a resolution providing for a "full and complete examination and review" of the Office of Alien Property, which controls and operates all property seized during World War II from nationals of enemy countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- In a decision growing out of an explosion in the Holland Tunnel under the Hudson River in May, 1949, the Supreme Court sustained today an Interstate Commerce Commission regulation commanding truck drivers transporting inflammables to avoid heavily traveled routes so far as "practicable and feasible."
BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The demotion of shortstop John (Buddy) Kerr to the Milwaukee American Association farm club was announced today by General Manager John Quinn of the Boston Braves.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At Loew's State, the attraction is "Invitation," a Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer drama featuring Van Johnson, Dorothy McGuire, Louis Calhern and Ruth Roman. Gottfried Reinhardt directed and Lawrence Weingarten produced from a screen play by Paul Osborn and a story by Jerome Weidman. Ray Collins, Michael Chekhov and Lisa Golm are among the supporting players.

The stock market moved ahead yesterday but on a selective basis, and it recovered a small part of the ground lost late last week. In many respects, the session duplicated those of the preceding few days, with stress laid on certain sections rather than on the market as a whole.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 28 -- Tunisian nationalists called a temporary halt today in the strike that has kept most Arab shops closed the last ten days, avowedly to contribute to an atmosphere in which a political settlement with France could be achieved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's proposals for a Pacific security pact have been criticized adversely here because they did not deal with the difficult questions his old friend and former associate, John Foster Dulles, ran into when he tried to negotiate precisely such a pact.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The New York State Catholic Welfare Committee urged support today for legislation "which will strengthen the marriage bond and safeguard the family."

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 28 -- United States ships now unloading in Saigon will increase the amount of United States military supplies delivered to forces fighting the Communist-led Vietminh insurgents to 100,000 tons since August, 1950, a United States Legation spokesman revealed here today.

Joseph Ruggiero, described as a Brooklyn waterfront hoodlum, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to an indictment charging him with the operation of a lottery and possession of policy slips.

Of the several bad features of last year's Defense Production Act among the worst was the so-called fats and oils amendment. This pernicious piece of special-interest legislation, which slithered through Congress without hearings, may seem to be a small matter to most of the people of the United States but it is a grave matter to many people in Europe who thought they could rely on consistency and common sense in American trading policies.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Nearly 1,400 families have signed a petition protesting a 15 per cent rent increase notice sent out Saturday by the management office of the Shanks 1,467-family public housing installation here.
" Chiselers" who '"build monstrosities of "low-cost" homes received a scolding yesterday from a leader in the construction business.

In choosing poultry as an alternative to high-cost meats, the economy-minded shopper does well to consider fowl, or, as it is sometimes known, stewing chicken. Currently 49 cents a pound, the bird contains a larger proportion of meat than the more popular broilers and fryers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Air Force headquarters announced tonight a forthcoming reorganization of the Air Defense Command designed to conserve manpower and funds.

A supplemental city fiscal aid program calling for new taxes and increases in existing taxes that, if enacted in full, would give the city a net increase of at least $89,000,000 in its yearly revenues, was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate at the last of a series of executive sessions dealing with city finances.

The highest sales and earnings in its history were achieved by the Dayton Rubber Company in the fiscal year ended with last October, A. L. Freedlander, president, informed stockholders in the annual report mailed yesterday.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Jan. 28 -- Rain-swollen rivers sent muddy flood-waters rolling over 1,000,000 acres of rich farmland in five Midwestern states, driving at least 8,000 persons from their homes and taking the lives of at least nine persons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, resigned today as chairman of the Senate Democratic Campaign Committee for reasons of health. Senator Earle C. Clements of Kentucky, was named to succeed him.

HUNTERS seem to be confronted with all sorts of problems these days, other than the comparatively uncomplicated one involving "where" and "what" to hunt, which the majority seem to have solved by chivvying foxes or rabbits through the winter covers.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,143, covering Monday's operations:

NEVE ILAN, Israel, Jan. 28 -- On a rock-strewn, sun-swept slope of one of the highest hills between Jerusalem and the sea, representativs of Israel, the United Nations and Sweden gathered today to plant the first tree of what is to be a pine forest dedicated to the memory of Count Folke Bernadotte, who was assassinated in September, 1948, while serving as United Nations mediator.
Contemporary Protestantism is gradually returning to a more formal type of worship service, Dr. Cyril C. Richardson, Professor of Church History at Union. Theological Seminary, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Repeated outbursts by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers Union, injected a note of drama today into a Senate Labor subcommittee hearing at which leading coal producer associations opposed Federal safety regulation of the mines.

Having laid the ghost of year-round Saturday closings -- at least for the next three or four weeks -- the governors of the New York Stock Exchange are now studying proposals to cut down on the need for back-office help on Saturdays, so that more firms may have effective five-day weeks.

Mrs. Henry LeRoy Finch gave a buffet luncheon yesterday at the headquarters of the New York City Mission Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, for members of the board of managers of the women's branch, of which Mrs. Finch is treasurer, and the junior board.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott broke out with an angry tirade today against the "fight-or-else" ultimatum of the State Athletic Commission.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Following the change of Government in Cairo, new instructions reportedly were sent today to Britain's diplomatic and military chiefs in Egypt.

The Phillips Petroleum Company last year had a net income of about $73,700,000, or $5.45 each on the average of 13,534,118 shares outstanding after adjustment for a two-for-one stock split, K. S. Adams, chairman, and Paul Endacott, president, reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- Although gross operating revenues soared to a new high in 1951, the net income of the Pennsylvania Railroad dropped to $26,697,717, equal to $2.03 a share from $38,420,677 or $2.92 a share in 1950.
CAIRO, Jan. 28 (UP) -- Maher Pasha told the Chamber of Deputies that Parliament would not be dissolved, as many quarters had expected, unless it opposed the Government's policy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Former President Herbert Hoover's proposal that the United States withdraw most of its ground force from Europe drew varying Republican comment in the Senate today. The Democrats generally were silent.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Norman Hayes, 20-year-old Boston Negro, outslugged ex-middleweight champion Jake Le Motta of New York, the favorite, for a split decision in their ten-round bout tonight at the Boston Garden.

In the name of the free world our gallant allies the British are engaged in using tanks and cannon against the civil police of another ally, Egypt, equally gallant but less powerful. Will a new Dr. Johnson arise with a new dictionary, with new definitions of "freedom" and "democracy"?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today urging approval of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project:
BONN, Germany, Jan. 28 -- The West German Government intends to ask the United States, Britain and France to begin disccussions aimed at final settlement of the Saar's status.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Judith Coplon, former "Government girl" who was convicted twice of attempting to spy for the Soviet Union, won the right to a new trial today as a result of the refusal of the Supreme Court to review decisions on three appeals from rulings of lower courts.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that district delegates to the Republican and Democratic national conventions next July should be elected on the basis of Congressional districts as they existed prior to the enactment of the reapportionment law last December.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- No importance was attached here today to the appeal for a change in British policy toward Iran that Iranian Premier Mohammed Mossadegh made to the retiring British Ambassador, Sir Francis Shepherd, before the Ambassador's departure from Teheran.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- Shipping returned to normal here today when stevedoring companies resumed hiring longshoremen under an agreement guaranteeing "job-site inspection" of all damaged cargoes.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 -- The Atomic Energy Commission, in haste to prepare its Nevada test site for the recent atomic bomb explosions, paid plumbers as much as $756 a week and common laborers as much as $250 a week.

CEDAR GROVE, N. J., Jan. 28 -- A twin-engine Lockheed Lodestar airplane, carrying only its pilot, crash landed on a golf driving range at 12:45 P. M. here today after running out of gas in a snowstorm. The craft smashed into a shed over the tees of the golf range, pinning the pilot in the shattered nose of the ship for an hour and a half.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The United States granted Britain $300,000,000 today "to support its defense program and contribute to maintaining the strength and stability which are essential to that program."

In an effort to stimulate another great debate over our foreign and military policies in this Presidential election year Ex-President Hoover has returned to his basic theses of a year ago, with some significant modifications. He is still as determined as ever to resist Communist expansion, and he agrees that peace can be preserved only through strength.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Free selling lowered prices for grain in all pits in the early trade here today, but on declines there was a stiffening in the demand, with part recoveries from the low spots. The selling influence early was the more reassuring tenor of the Egyptian news. Pressure automatically contracted on the declines, while commission-buying broadened.

Samuel I. Rosenman, compiler of "The Public Papers and Addresses of Franklin D. Roosevelt," has written an account of the part he played as the late President's ghost-writer, and Harper plans to publish it in May. Titled "Working With Roosevelt," the book describes the circumstances under which Judge Rosenman wrote or helped write speeches and messages and what Roosevelt was like among his closest friends.

The declarations by the United States, Britain and France in Paris yesterday that they would demand urgent United Nations action in the event of Communist aggression in Southeast Asia is so far the only tangible result of the recent three-power Southeast Asian military conference in Washington.

Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti announced yesterday that the state would rest its case in General Sessions Court today after ten trial days spent in seeking to prove the fifty-two counts in its extortion-conspiracy indictment against James J. Moran, former First Deputy Fire Commissioner.

A strong trend for accessories that echo the color or fabric of hats ran throughout recent spring millinery collections. Besides the popular stole, there were many novel ideas to enliven spring costumes, both in accessories and fabrics.
The Giants, Yankees and Dodgers all were in the baseball news yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (UP) -- A Capitol Airlines DC-4 carrying twenty-three persons through clear skies more than a mile high plunged 2,200 feet in a nose dive today, tossing passengers from their seats and injuring five.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- A bill empowering magistrates to require adolescent narcotic addicts to undergo hospital treatment and other rehabilitation courses was approved unanimously tonight by the State Senate and sent to the Assembly.

CAIRO, Jan. 28 -- The Egyptian Parliament met tonight in a regular session and unanimously gave support to Premier Aly Maher Pasha, 68-year-old political independent, and his Cabinet, who were sworn in before King Farouk earlier in the day.

Harvey Koslow has been named divisional merchandise manager of the downstairs fashion store of the New York, Brooklyn and Jamaica units of Roaman's. He formerly was buyer of downstairs dresses and daytime cottons and street floor classic dresses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that an increase of 10 per cent "across the board" in the pay and allowances of members of the armed forces "is very necessary and long overdue."

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 28 -- Walter Maynard, president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, said tonight that capital gains taxes now acted as transfer taxes and therefore impaired the mobility of capital.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Virtually all members of the United Nations except the Soviet bloc went on record today in favor of Libya's admission to the United Nations. The resolution, adopted by the Special Political Committee of the General Assembly, also contained a proposal for the establishment of a special international fund to aid Libyan development.

HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- Robert Lippincott of the West New Jersey fleet sailed his yacht Mate to a third straight victory today to capture the Bacardi Cup, top prize of the twenty-first annual international Star Class regatta here. Robert Levin was his crewman.

The Medical Society of the County of New York, largest county medical society in the country, at a regular meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine last night, adopted a resolution condemning racial discrimination in hospital staff appointments, with recommendations on positive action to help eliminate the problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court ruled today that the United States could seize all rights under enemy-owned negotiable bonds even though the bonds themselves could not be seized because they were outside the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Truman gave Congress today a last opportunity to authorize United States participation with Canada in constructing the long-delayed, controversial St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project.

The prospect of existence in a bagel-less city seemed destined yesterday to continue indefinitely for New Yorkers when forty members of Local 802 of the Teamsters' Union, A. F. L., demanded back pay in full for the time that 300 members of the Bagel Bakers Union, Local 338, have been on strike.

A wave of hope has been spreading from Egypt around the free world since the news was flashed that King Farouk had dismissed Nahas Pasha and installed a new Government. Premier Aly Maher Pasha has already won a unanimous vote of confidence in Parliament and has the assurance -- for the present -- of the Wafd party's support.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- United States Army officers in Japan have rejected a request to admit an American Federation of Labor representative to that country, A. F. L. sources said today.
That once familiar particular of New York's winter landscape, snow, fell in abundance on the city yesterday.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 28 -- Eighty-four personal and two technical fouls were called tonight as Manhattan College defeated Le Moyne College, 79 -- 71.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Navy has awarded a $30,000,000 contract for converting two heavy cruisers into guided missile ships, Rear Admiral Homer N. Wallin, Chief of the Navy Bureau of Ships, said today. The 13,600-ton cruisers Boston and Canberra will be converted at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, Camden, N. J.

The National Biscuit Company, in its preliminary annual report yesterday, announced an increase of 11 per cent in sales for 1951, but rising operating costs reduced its net profit to $16,202,212 from $21,110,431 earned in 1950.

A soft-voiced young robber with a five-inch knife blade stole $100,000 in jewels yesterday afternoon from Mrs. Scott Scammell, an attorney's wife, in her eleventh-floor, thirteen-room apartment in a cooperative house at 1125 Fifth Avenue, near Ninety-fourth Street.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 28 -- The contest in this Midwest area between supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the Republican Presidential nomination is growing in intensity. While it is most noticeable in Kansas, where politicians gathered today on the eve of the annual Kansas Day celebration, a big Republican rally, it also is to be found in surrounding states.

Who has the best right to the $90 back interest scrip which the Republic of Peru proposes to issue to holders of certain of its $1,000 bonds formerly in default? Are former bondholders who assented to the Republic's debt adjustment plan in 1947 entitled to the scrip? Or should it be issued only to persons now holding the new bonds issued under the debt settlement plan?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified 179 additional battle casualties in Korea in a new list that reported 39 killed, 114 wounded, 5 missing in action and 21 injured in accidents. It also listed 26 known dead who were previously reported missing.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh's basketball team not only broke a four-game losing streak tonight but came through with an upset by rallying to beat Notre Dame, 62 -- 55.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were slightly easier yesterday, closing 19 to 32 points below prices on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, announced today that the United States and Canada had exchanged atomic information within the last three weeks -- the first time such an exchange had taken place with a foreign country under the amendment to the Atomic Energy Act adopted at the last session of Congress.

Total net assets of the Wellington Fund, one of the country's largest mutual funds -- open-end investment companies -- reached a new high of $193,930,722 at the end of 1951, it was reported yesterday by Walter L. Morgan, president, in his annual statement to stockholders.

A new, fast cargo service between New York and London, Hamburg and Le Havre was started yesterday with the sailing of the Cunard Line freighter Alsatia from pier 92, North River with 8,500 tons of general cargo.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Prime Minister Churchill lost no time on his return from the United States today in tackling the problems, domestic and foreign, that beset his Government.

A few days ago, upstate, the zero cold broke without notice. The man who stepped out-of-doors bundled up in advance for the usual chill blinked in surprise and opened his coat. It was warm, with a warmth not felt since last October and long forgotten.

Government and private leaders urged here yesterday that the nation make room for more surplus Europeans and refugees for the sake of world peace, American foreign policy and the country's own economic future.

Young women, including the Misses Mary Hicks Edson and Iris Miller, will act as manikins in the fashion show that will be a feature of the entertainment at the tea and cocktail dance for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York on Thursday afternoon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
A play based on five short stories by F. Scott Fitzgerald printed in The Saturday Evening Post during 1930 and 1931 is in the making for a Broadway presentation this spring.

DECATUR, Ill., Jan. 28 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen charged tonight that the foreign policy views of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, would lead to "probable war." He said President Truman's policies could have the same effect.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 28 -- As the third national Italian high fashion show concluded a few days ago with a rush of buying, there still was no question of Rome replacing Paris as the world fashion center.

All 440,000 shares of the no par value common stock of the Schering Corporation, its sole capitalization, are due to go on the auction block this week. The company, once controlled by German pharmaceutical interests, was seized by the Attorney General's office in 1942 under the terms of the Trading With the Enemy Act.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The first four collections from London's "top ten" designers show a sharp swing to the romantic trend in styles and to soft, muted colors.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Governor Dewey was requested this evening by the executive committee of the Westchester Republican Committee to appoint John E. Hoy of Yonkers as sheriff of the county to succeed Sheriff Fred W. Ruscoe, who died last month.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 28 -- The new German twelve-division army and tactical air force that will eventually become part of the European Defense Force under command of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will not wear the once famous gray-green uniforms of the old Reichswehr and Luftwaffe.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The State University is being denied legitimate freedom of operation and being hamstrung by unrealistic limitations imposed by state fiscal officers who have no training in education, the institution's trustees charged today.

A device permitting the user to reduce the width of a wheelchair so he can pass through doorways easily was demonstrated yesterday at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The State Federation of Labor renewed its opposition to permanent personal registration today by submitting to Governor Dewey and the Legislature a 40,000-word study that it said showed that the new registration system would be costly, increase the opportunity for fraud and fail to encourage larger turnouts for elections.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Highways Department said today that "unlimited quantities" of scarce construction steel had been offered from foreign sources, but that the offers were rejected because of the "excessive price."

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 28 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold E. Stassen will be entered in the March 11 New Hampshire Presidential primary against General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, it was announced tonight.

Flying conditions were a bit rugged in New York yesterday and even the English sparrows and starlings were having some difficulty flitting from sidewalk to window ledge as clouds hid the Statue of Liberty's torch. But as aviators they had it all over a big bird that came down from north of the border, failed in attempts at an instrument landing and went home without seeing the big city.
