WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Government's power to deport Germans as enemy aliens ended when the war with Germany was declared officially over, the Supreme Court ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Norman Thomas, veteran Socialist leader, said today that adoption of Universal Military Training would make it much harder for the United States to crusade for world disarmament and peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The United States has agreed to purchase $28,000,000 worth of crude natural rubber for its stockpile, the General Services Administration announced today. The purchase, already closed, is part of a deal arranged by Government officials with Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of Great Britain, on his recent visit here and is expected to bring an early benefit to the balance of payments of the sterling area.

New and higher ocean freight rates between Italy and this country will price Italian wines, liquors, tomatoes, tomato paste and other products out of the American market, it was asserted yesterday by E. L. Sozzi, who for many years was president of the American Chamber of Commerce for Trade with Italy.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Prof. Walter Hallstein, chief German delegate to the European army conference here, visited General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander, today, and it was understood that the general had expressed the hope that the Bonn regime would not complicate the negotiations for a combined army by linking them to the unsettled question of the future of the Saar.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 -- A test of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's support in the labor movement was initiated today at the opening session of the sixth national convention of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., by the circulation of a resolution criticizing his domestic policies.

YOU'D better quit now, Bill Corum. You're wasting your time, George Widener. Flee to the hills while you still have the chance, Messrs. Vanderbilt, Whitney, Field, Parr, Strub, et al. Here comes the Redhead!
CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 22 (UP) -- Federal Judge J. Waties Waring acclaimed by many for trying to equalize racial rights but shunned by his neighbors here, said today that he would retire Feb. 15.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, First Army commander, approved yesterday the conviction of seven privates court-martialed at Governors Island last month for mutiny and riot at the Fort Jay guardhouse last September, but he reduced their sentences.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee told the National Cotton Council today that in order to meet the Government's 1952 quota, cotton growers would have to produce 4 per cent more than they did in 1951.

The eightieth anniversary of the founding of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee was marked yesterday as its oldest member, who has served more than fifty years, was honored at reception at the Barclay Hotel.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- The New Jersey Legislature moved today to permit voters to express their Presidential preferences at the April 15 primary election.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- The Eastern Air Defense Force announced today plans to streamline its administrative and support units. The reorganization is slated to go into effect on Feb. 6.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- Three resolutions inspired by two recent airplane crashes in Elizabeth were adopted by the State Assembly here today.

Fear will reduce the volume of motor vehicle traffic and curtail the sales of cars unless highway accidents are curbed, delegates were told yesterday at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association.

Dr. Ludwik Gross, in his letter printed in THE TIMES on Jan. 17 urging caution in the consideration of fluoridation of municipal water supplies, has apparently overlooked certain facts based on the records of responsible national organizations.

With its sights set on the International Wolfe-Noel Challenge Cup matches in Boston on Feb. 24, the British women's squash racquets team arrived here yesterday on the Cunard liner Mauretania. Seven players, headed by Mrs. Sheila H. McKechnie, captain and manager, made up the visiting contingent.

Following its unusual and commendable custom, the Little Orchestra Society introduced two new compositions to its audience last night. Both were solo pieces, and each had its share of warmth and appeal, one quite typically English, the other in what is known as the "international" idiom, though its composer is French.

The Greek Army now consists of ten well trained and fully equipped divisions that could be placed in the field at a moment's notice in the event of Communist aggression, John E. Peurifoy, United States Ambassador to Greece, declared here yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 -- One man was killed today and eight were injured when a heavy steel lifeboat broke loose during a dockside drill on the liner Lurline and plunged twenty-five feet to the the water in Wilmington Harbor.

A sharp letter went to State Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale yesterday from City Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy, charging that the state had withheld from the city Welfare Department the names of the 280 cases that the assistance contends received public assistance to which they were not entitled.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The Republic of Korea warned here today that the Communists would strike again whenever they considered themselves ready.

A two-bedroom apartment with a living-dining area and a library alcoye is being shown furnished with French provincial pieces in a group of model rooms at McCreery's. There is also a second series of rooms, these using contemporary styles.

HICKORY, N. C., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Hundreds of tiny white plastic bottles carrying messages of goodwill from college students in the United States to the Chinese people are being released off the China coast this month.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Russia has protested again the proposed Middle Eastern defense command as planned by the United States, Britain, France and Turkey, the Moscow radio announced early today.

Two hundred weather forecasters shook unexpected snow from their shoulders and stamped wet shoes in the lobby of the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday at the first session of the American Meteorological Society's four-day annual meeting.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 28 -- Munawar Jehan Begum, 50-year old senior begum of the Nawab of Junagadh was arrested here today on a charge of beating to death her 13-year-old maid servant Bano.

Aluminum, Limited, of Montreal, a leading factor in the aluminum industry outside the United States, has started a 150 per cent expansion of its bauxite-alumina production facilities in Jamaica, B. W. I., through an additional investment of at least $20,000,000, Nathanael V. Davis, president, announced yesterday.

Immigration officials, waterfront detectives and plainclothes men of Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's special waterfront racket squad swooped down on Pier 1 at Columbia Street, Brooklyn, yesterday in a search for aliens here illegally.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The Senate approved unanimously today two bills that would make mandatory a minimum sentence of fifteen years for persons convicted three times of felonies involving the sale or possession of narcotics.

The economic report for 1951 just issued by the Soviet Government presents comparatively little that is new when compared with the disclosures made by Politburo member L. P. Beria in his speech last November. One feature of this report can be welcomed, however.

St. John's University's string of triumphs against local court foes may strike a snag tonight when the Redmen engage the strong Fordham quintet at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The junior varsity teams of the two schools meet in a preliminary at 7:30 o'clock.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Archie Moore of Toledo, the No. 2 light-heavyweight title challenger, gained a ten-round decision tonight over Harold Johnson of Philadelphia.

The cruel truth of the matter is that polio is more prevalent now than it has ever been before. In the three-year period from 1939 through 1941 there were 26,255 cases reported. In the three-year period just ended there were 104,217 cases. Within the span of ten years the number of polio cases has quadrupled.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- Dr. George H. M. Lawrence, Professor of Botany at Cornell University, has been appointed director of the Bailey Hortorium, Deane W. Malott, university president, announced today. Dr. Lawrence succeeds Liberty Hyde Bailey, dean emeritus, who established the Hortorium and gave it to the university in 1935. Dr. Bailey has resigned as director, but will continue in an advisory capacity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The letter of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur yesterday to New Hampshire admirers, requesting the withdrawal of his name from the primary, was regarded as significant in the capital today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Signing of a $130,000,000 electric power contract today assured construction of a new Reynolds Aluminum plant in Arkansas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Government announced plans today to reclaim several million dollars worth of machine tools turned over to educational institutions as surplus property after World War II.

Aided by celebrities of stage, screen, radio and television, the eigth annual March of Dimes fashion showing was held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The Couture Group of the New York Dress Institute presented the spring fashions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate ratified today an expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to admit Greece and Turkey into the Western defensive alliance as full partners.

A larger amount of merchant shipping is being employed on the world's trade routes than ever before in a normal peacetime year, Walter L. Green, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, asserted yesterday.

In an unexpected rebuff to Mayor Impellitteri and Construction Coordinator Robert Moses, a City Council committee withheld yesterday approval of amendments to the Parking Authority Law. The action came in executive session of the Committee on State Legislation after a two-hour public hearing that ended with the charge that the Mayor had "gagged" Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley, conspicuous by his absence from the proceedings.

Members of the Youth for Eisenhower Committee set up their headquarters in an Army tent yesterday to assist the Eisenhower Bandwagon Committee in preparing for the midnight "Serenade to Eisenhower" rally to be held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 8.

A few hours after Governor Dewey's 1952-53 state budget had been published, containing none of the $63,800,000 additional state aid for which New York City had asked, Mayor Impellitteri announced that he would go to Albany Monday to confer with state legislative leaders.
The temperature in the city fell to 8 degrees above zero at 3 A. M. today, setting a record for the year. The previous low temperature for 1952 was 17.3 on Jan. 8.

In this writer's estimation, the program given by Nathan Milstein, violinist, with Arthur Balsam, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall, came very near to the ideal contents of what a program of such an occasion should be. Its most important music, admirably chosen and contrasted for an evening's entertainment, took the lion's share of the time and was presented before the intermission, when the audience was in the best frame of mind for such communication.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 30 -- The Communists at Panmunjom today expressed some interest in the detailed plan of the United Nations for an exchange of prisoners after an armistice in the Korean war, but gave no indication of yielding on the crucial issue of voluntary repatriation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The National Fuel Gas Company of New York asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell $18,000,000 worth of sinking fund debentures due in 1977. The debentures are to be sold at competitive bidding.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 29 -- Additional pier and warehouse facilities at the Camden Marine Terminal to handle the increasing ship-borne cargoes to industrially expanding south Jersey were recommended today by the South Jersey Port Commisison.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Bert Bell, National Football League commissioner, and Giles E. Miller, Texas textile manufacturer, today signed the papers completing the sale of the New York Yanks and the shift of the franchise to Dallas. Miller said that the club would be called the Dallas Texans.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Movements on the stock markets here today were largely precautionary in advance of the statement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard Austen Butler, which came after business had finished. Bear covering at the end of the current bookkeeping account helped many sections to gain, including British Government issues and industrial shares.

Weather or Not The book reviewers of the land have a tough job keeping up with the stream of writing that continually pours off the printing presses. It is unlikely that they will get around to reviewing a lot of harmless fiction that appears regularly at this time of the year, chiefly on calendars and in almanacs: the weather forecasts for the year ahead in all America.

MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Development of the vast Ungava iron ore deposits would be impossible without United States capital, Dr. J. A. Retty, geologist who made the first geological map of the area in 1936, told a chamber of commerce luncheon today.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Addressing the annual legislative conference of the American Legion here tonight, Governor Dewey urged veterans organizations to intensify the efforts they are taking to have Congress vote universal military training.

THOSE who are trying to decide on the breed of bird dog best suited to their type of shooting may find an answer at the Sportsmen's Show, which is scheduled to open at Grand Central Palace on Feb. 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The United States is using its "good offices" to bring the British-Egyptian dispute to an end, but it has no plans to mediate "in any formal sense," the State Department announced today.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East voted today to admit Japan as an associatae member, subject to the approval of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey's support appeared likely today for the proposed program to allot $650,000 more in state aid to county and city library systems, which has been approved by the State Education Department.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 29 (AP) -- A Federal jury today returned a verdict for $35,000 in favor of Jorge Pasquel, Mexican baseball team owner, in his breach of contract suit against Mickey Owen of Springfield, former major league star.
The work of more than twenty persons is being shown this week at the third annual art exhibit by residents of Hudson View Gardens, 183d Street and Pinehurst Avenue.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Boston's inspired Bruins hung a 3-1 defeat on the league-leading Detroit Red Wings tonight to climb back into a fourth-place tie with the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League. The Bruins played their best game in weeks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Grain futures gained considerable momentum on the buying side of the Board of Trade here today. The strength developed after a moderate downturn immediately after the opening. As had been the case for some time, the early selling in all pits was cushioned by persistent commission house absorption, which had the appearance of being investment accumulation.

PARIS, Jan 29 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, chief of staff of the Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe, expressed hope tonight that in the event of a general war the forces made available under both the United Nations and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would be merged under a "coordinated system."

BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- "Kommiss," the popular word for military service, has bounced out of Germany's martial past to awaken a debate more vigorous more widespread than any started by such earnest platform phrases as "European unity."

Recent news of purges in the Soviet republics of Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan gives additional evidence that the 15,000,000 Moslems under Kremlin rule share the same growing nationalistic spirit that is causing current difficulties in the Middle East.

The Associated Hospital Service of New York increased its enrollment 259 per cent, and its payments to hospitals 530 per cent between 1940 and 1950, the Hospital Council of Greater New York reported yesterday.
Public utility companies borrowed $55,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of bond issues at public sealed bidding to syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 29 -- The 1951 Maine lobster catch, valued at $7,010,000, will be the largest in more than fifty years, the State Sea and Shore Fisheries Commissioner, Robert L. Dow, said today.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Hardy Amies, who has designed many clothes for Princess Elizabeth's Australian tour, introduced today the widest-based pyramid coat yet seen. Built on a stiffened lining, it is seen at its best in corded white silk or grosgrain, with asymmetrical black button fastenings.
Mrs. Matilda E. Heppenheimer was guest of honor yesterday at a party in her home, 64 East Ninety-first Street. Four generations helped her celebrate her 100th birthday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- James G. Lyne of New York will be chairman of the organizing committee of the eighth Pan American Railway Congress to be held in the United States in the summer of 1953. The appointment was announced today at a meeting of the United States National Commission in the Pan American Railway Congress Association.
Parents who entrust their children "to just anyone" were urged to practice more caution by Magistrate Phillip B. Thurston in Felony Court yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Robert K. Christenberry, after his appointment as chairman of the State Athletic Commission was confirmed today, reiterated his warning that Jersey Joe Walcott would be stripped of his heavyweight title in New York unless Walcott signed by Feb. 5 for a title defense.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- For six days no meals were prepared by stewards aboard the freighter Alaska Bear of the Pacific Far East Line during a recent voyage to the Middle East, Capt. Doan E. Noble related today at a Coast Guard hearing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Any change in steel prices to reflect requirements of the present Defense Production Act must wait for at least a month to give agency officials an opportunity to work out an equitable schedule, spokesmen for the industry were told today by representatives of the Office of Price Stabilization.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- This is a winning week for Jockey Ira Hanford -- on and off the racetrack. On Sunday he shot a 73 at the Miami Springs Country Club and led the qualifiers in a racetrack golf tournament. Today he rode his first winner of the Hialeah race meet.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29 -- The Mexican Government has published in the Official Gazette recently decreed regulations governing uranium and other fissionable ore mining. The reaction of the country's private mining interests is one of disappointment.

Fines totaling sixty-eight days' pay and several reprimands were meted out yesterday by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan to a police captain, two lieutenants, two sergeants and seven patrolmen in three major cases involving neglect of duty.

The extortion-conspiracy trial of James J. Moran was adjourned yesterday in General Sessions Court because of the illness of Judge John A. Mullen, confined to his home at 530 East Eighty-sixth Street with a cold. The trial is expected to go on today.

Assistant District Attorney James P. McGrath proved by demonstration yesterday to a jury in Queens County Court, Long Island City, that a three-quarter length fur coat could be hidden inside a woman's girdle. After that the jurors, all men, took only an hour to find the women involved guilty of stealing the coat.

Theodore W. Kheel's recommendation that nine private bus lines set up a forty-hour week on July 1 -- provided the city allows them a higher fare or other financial concessions -- appeared doomed yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- New capital construction projects estimated to cost $173,000,000 were recommended to the Legislature today in Governor Dewey's annual budget. He proposed $63,500,000 for such work in the present fiscal year ending March 31.
Lanvin division of Sanson Hosiery Mills, Inc., to Dorland Advertising, Ltd. National fashion magazines and local newspapers.

The nation's largest open - end investment company or mutual fund, the Massachusetts Investors Trust, reported yesterday that its number of shares outstanding in 1951 increased 694,991 to the record total of 11,583,925 at the year's end.

A 60-year-old cashier at the Paris Theatre died last night soon after a patron had found him bound and gagged on the empty orchestra floor of the motion picture house. Before he collapsed he mumbled that he had been robbed and authorities found later that $250 was missing from the box office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, asserted today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had found Philleo Nash, a White House assistant, to have been a past member of the Communist party.

The ideal playground should have, first, a swimming pool and, second, a refreshment stand, according to a committee of young "experts" on the subject, who met yesterday to present a model of a playground to Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- An air of fatigue hangs over the closing sessions of the United Nations General Assembly. To one who witnessed the drama and expectancy of the opening days, when the United States launched its sweeping disarmament plan, and comes back for the wind-up, the contrast in the mood of the delegates, reporters and hangers-on is very striking.

A 59-year-old exporter and his wife were found dead last night in their two-room suite at the Marlton Hotel, 5 West Eighth Street, in Greenwich Village. Health Department inspectors said the couple had died of carbon monoxide poisoning, apparently accidentally.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- The complicated financial background of the defunct Empire Tractor Corporation of this city was related today by Frank Cohen at a reopened hearing in the corporation's bankruptcy case.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Christopher Fry's play, "The First - Born," which he wrote before the war, opened here tonight at the Winter Garden Theatre. Most of the London reviewers were deeply impressed with the simple Bible story of Moses and Pharaoh, The Daily Telegraph's W. A. Darlington calling it "Fry's strongest play so far."

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey's interim appointment of Robert K. Christenberry as chairman of the State Athletic Commission was approved unanimously by the Senate today after the chairman had appeared for an hour before a closed session of the Senate Finance Committee.

For the first time since he ordered abandon ship in the icy North Atlantic a month ago, Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen last night greeted half of his crew from the sunken Flying Enterprise and extended his "profound gratitude" to Capt. Neils Olsen and five crew members of the rescue ship, the Navy transport Gen. A. W. Greeley.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 29 -More than 32,000 troops and airmen, supported by almost 200 planes, continued winter and airborne training today in Exercise Snowfall while temperatures reached 12 degrees below zero.

John Sinclair, national chairman of the American Red Cross fund-raising drive recommended yesterday afternoon that the humane aspects of the organization be stressed in the campaign rather than its statistical features. He addressed several hundred volunteer women workers in the New York chapter headquarters at 315 Lexington Avenue.

Our refusal to stop aid to Nationalist China in its struggle against the Japanese imperialist invaders of China after 1937 was one of the main reasons for the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. We were faithful to our traditional policy of cooperation with Free China -- the greatest pool of manpower and natural resources -- and won.

A public offering of $125,000,000 of twelve-year sinking fund debentures of Aluminum Company of America was placed on the market yesterday by a nation-wide syndicate of 172 underwriting houses, headed by First Boston Corporation, and by a selling group of 302 investment houses.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- Preceded by glowing reports from London, Emlyn Williams, English actor-author-director, made his first American appearance at the Plymouth Theatre last night in his program of scenes from the novels and stories of Charles Dickens.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Following is a digest of Governor Dewey's Budget Message to the Legislature today:

Americans should begin to plan for profitable private investment in India, her Ambassador, Binay Ranjan Sen, said here yesterday. Speaking at the ninth annual luncheon of the Far East -- America Council of Commerce and Industry, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, he outlined two types of joint Indian-American corporate organizations that would lead to profitable employment of United States capital, once passing of the defense emergency finds American industry looking for outlets for surpluses.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,144, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- With a new Government in office in Cairo, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden renewed today his offer to enter into negotiations for a revision of the 1936 British-Egyptian treaty, which is the cause of the bloody dispute between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Lawrence K. Rosinger, New York writer and Far Eastern affairs specialist, declined to answer today when Senate investigators asked if he ever had been a member of the Communist party.
Hundreds of off-duty firemen picketed offices of borough presidents in various boroughs yesterday in the biting cold to continue their demand for "adequate pay increases."

The eighty - fourth Belmont Stakes, banner offering of the Westchester Racing Association's annual spring meeting, has attracted the record number of 125 nominations from seventy-six owners for the 1952 running. Date of the classic, third jewel in the sport's triple crown, has not been set officially, but if tradition prevails, it will be held on June 7, the last Saturday of the session.

During 1951, 598 bounties were paid on eagles in Alaska, according to a letter received from the Treasurer of that Territory. I was referred to this official by the Fish and Wildlife Service, which I was informed kept no records of the matter, though it is the federal bureau responsible for the protection of the native animals and birds of Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -The International Cotton Advisory Committee reported today that cotton production this season in Russia and China combined was about 1,000,000 bales larger than had been estimated.
PARDON me while I roll up my sleeves for a swing at this one.

The National Mediation Board, in its current annual report, is gravely concerned at the growing tendency of railroad labor unions to reject emergency board recommendations and says that if continued this "can only result in a complete breakdown" of the carefully constructed machinery of the Railway Labor Act.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 -- The Brazilian Government has ordered all state and territorial Governors to prevent a meeting of the allegedly Communist "Continental Peace Congress" anywhere in the country.

A series of television programs offering authorities medical information on various diseases will be produced by the New York County Medical Society in cooperation with the National Broadcasting Company. "Here's to Your Health" is the general title of the series.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- A celebration of the 215th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Paine opened here today with a campaign to enlist the 375 families living on what was once his farm to be come "Paine farmers." As members of the clan they would contribute to a fund for buying a bronze bust of the patriotic writer for New York University's Hall of Fame.

Governor Dewey's proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1 passes the billion-dollar mark for the first time, with recommended appropriations of $1,092,760,887, an increase of $93,636,954 over the current year. The increase is caused largely by inflation, and the budget is balanced without an increase in tax rates because this same inflation has swollen revenues from income and other taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- John L. Lewis called on Congress today to give the Federal Government power to close down unsafe coal mines and end a "most abominable record of slaughter, unequaled in the civilized world."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida yesterday ruled out the possibility of establishing "friendly relations" now between Japan and the Soviet Union because of "unpleasant" issues separating the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate Rules Committee, long under pressure from "minority groups," approved today a resolution designed to make it easier for the Senate to break filibusters.

A quiet and mild-mannered clerk, the father of two children, went out to lunch yesterday from the Brooklyn bank where he is employed and hasn't returned yet. The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are looking for the man because when he left the bank he apparently took $38,224.06 in cash with him.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was dull yesterday, but closing prices were steady, 15 to 24 points net higher on active months.
Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan inspected yesterday a new system for making oxygen available for the department's emergency service division.

The average price of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange dropped last December from $97.82 to $97.43; a decline of 39 cents, the Exchange reported yesterday. In the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, 1951, they had declined by $3.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Olympians stretched their "home" victory streak to fifteen games tonight by taking a 100-72 National Basketball Association decision from the New York Knickerbockers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today was named as one source that will oppose the motion-picture industry's request to the Federal Communications Commission for a closed "highway in the sky" in order to develop large-screen theatre television on a nation-wide ba1sis. Commission hearings will start on Feb. 25 in Washington.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The swollen Ohio River crested tonight at near-by Parkersburg, W. Va., and rolled on to the little towns of Pomeroy and Middleport, Ohio, leaving 8,000 to 10,000 flood refugees and at least ten dead or missing.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 29 -- French policy and activities in the Saar violate an agreement reached between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the West German Federal Republic and Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France, the Bonn Government charged today.

Internal explosions in high-speed jet fighters, a new problem for designers and an additional hazard for the pilots who fly them, were discussed publicly for the first time yesterday at the twentieth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Astor Hotel.

Careless and discourteous driving are among the outstanding factors in sabotaging highway safety efforts, M. R. Darlington Jr., managing director of the Inter-Industry Highway Safety Committee, said yesterday. Other causes cited were lack of driving instruction, inadequate roads, lack of uniform traffic laws and the general belief among drivers that protective rules are designed for someone else.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey is pinning his hopes of balancing his record-breaking billion-dollar budget on predictions that the state will collect $64,000,000 more taxes in the 1952-53 fiscal year than in the one now drawing to a close.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today accused Samuel R. Beard, Washington gambling figure, of trying to evade payment of more than $1,660,000 in income taxes for 1945 to 1947.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- What is popularly known here as the Chancellor's "axe" fell today, and for the second time since the Conservatives returned to power last fall it lopped off more of the good things of life that still had existed.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 29 -- A man who saved his dog from a tenement house fire may have unintentionally fanned the blaze into a holocaust that took seventeen lives, a fire investigator said today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 29 -- A 952 "minimum goal" of $2,900,000 or emergency relief and rehabiliation work throughout the world was approved here today by the National Lutheran Council.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (UP) -- Count Turf, whose owner didn't think he was far enough along on his comeback to be nominated for the Maturity, raced to a clear-cut victory in the $7,500 Salton Sea Purse at Santa Anita today.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Dewey submitted to the Legislature today the first state budget to top $1,000,000,000. It calls for $1,092,760,887 in appropriations, an increase of $93,636,954 over the final total for the present fiscal year, which ends March 31.

Net sales of the United States Steel Corporation last year jumped $568,572,381 to a record $3,524,978,527, but net income declined $31,510,940 from the 1950 level to $183,953,202 under the impact, principally, of sharply increased taxes and employment costs.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Criticizing the military's allegedly excessive demands for scarce materials, the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor called today for the establishment in the Department of Defense of a civilian board on military requirements and allocations.

Nearly 20,000 procrastinators paid the penalty for lateness yesterday when they spent long periods lined up at the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, 80 Centre Street, in the last-minute rush to obtain 1952 license plate tabs. The 1951 registrations expire at midnight tomorrow.

A report by a city-employed real estate expert to the Board of Assessors yesterday at a Municipal Building hearing held that the property and building of the Woodstock Tower Hotel, 312-24 East Forty-second Street, had increased in value since regrading of the street a year ago.

Russell L. Fish, president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, declared yesterday that some banks must bear part of the responsibility for "fleecing" of buyers of poorly built low-cost homes. He made this statement in a press conference on the second day of the group's fifty-eighth annual convention, in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Army said tonight that Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's headquarters in Tokyo turned down a request by the American Federation of Labor for permission to set up an office in occupied Japan.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 -- Some workers on the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site last fall were able to triple their wages by jumping between construction companies working for the Government on different contract bases, it was testified at a commission hearing today.

GIBRALTAR, Jan. 29 -- There is no doubt that the Spanish Government needs United States aid to bolster its sagging economy and modernize its armed forces. There is also no doubt that the Madrid regime is prepared to cooperate to a considerable degree with Washington both economically and militarily.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 -- Walter M. Pechart and David N. Kessel, described by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee as leaders in gambling activities in the East Bay area, were acquitted of contempt charges today by Federal Judge Louis E. Goodman.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 29 -- The Navy contemplates taking possession by March 1 of about 4,500 acres of land in the Calverton-Manorville-Wading River areas of Riverhead as the site for a proposed $22,000,000 jet plane plant, according to information received from Washington from Representative Ernest Greenwood, Democrat of New York.

TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- Speakers before the State Agricultural Convention today warned New Jersey farmers against "the allure of price-fixing" and "reliance on political power and pressure" to aid the farm industry.

A comfortable bed, cleanliness, kindness and friends! Those mean heaven for women without a place to sleep, stranded and alone in New York. At the Women's Emergency Lodge operated by the Salvation Army, these women find a shelter until they are able to obtain employment and a permanent residence.
CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 29 -- Petitions to enter the names of Harold E. Stassen and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio in the preferential part of the March 11 New Hampshire primary ballot were filed today.

The world's "free peoples" fear that American concern with military preparedness "may lead to war," that American policies mask "an urge to expand" and that American economic programs win trade advantage, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Howland H. Sargeant warned here yesterday.

Today's new film is "The Las Vegas Story," an R. K. O. romantic melodrama with Jane Russell, Victor Mature, Vincent Price and Hoagy Carmichael, at the Paramount. Robert Stevenson directed and Robert Sparks produced from a screen play by Earl Felton and Harry Essex and a story by Jay Dratler.
A blind athlete will be an outstanding competitor in the sixty-fourth annual Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 16.

A 13-year-old Bronx boy accused of the fatal shooting Monday of another boy, 11, in a vacant Bronx lot, and the earlier stabbing of a second boy, 15, admitted yesterday that he had bought his .22 caliber rifle with his part of the proceeds of a recent $1,000 liquor store robbery, the police of the Morrisania Avenue station reported.

Late selling yesterday disturbed a stock market that earlier seemed about to break the irregularity pattern recently prevalent. The afternoon selling developed principally in the oils, with the market sustained by bidding for the railroad stocks.

Net sales and operating revenues of the Hercules Powder Company rose 35 per cent last year to a new high of $216,848,692 from the previous peak of $160,230,774 made in 1950. Earnings before taxes were up 50 per cent, while the net income was down 6 per cent, with taxes taking $15,588,517 more than in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A bipartisan demand was made today in the Senate for pressure on Britain and other allies of the United States to agree to participate in "extreme sanctions" against any further Communist aggression in Asia.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29 -- Republican ranks in Kansas, home of the Eisenhower-for-President boom, split sharply today as backers of Senator Robert A. Taft accused leaders of the campaign to make General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower the party's Presidential nominee of "steamroller tactics" in the selection of national convention delegates.

After reading opinions voiced in your paper about transit riding falling off it strikes me that no one has mentioned the obvious cause. Riding hasn't decreased as much as chiseling has increased. This I know from personal observation.

It has become a popular sport to snap at the medical profession. Just as racial minorities have been the scapegoat on many internal problems of the nation, so has the medical profession become the target of many persons who either do not think problems through, or who have ulterior motives for their criticisms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman may be heading for the whistle stops, but you could never tell it from some of his recent speeches and appointments. If he had to finance the forthcoming Presidential campaign on the funds gathered or anticipated from his recent appointees, he could scarcely progress to the frontiers of the District of Columbia.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., unanimously and without debate, today adopted a resolution holding support for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a Presidential candidate in abeyance "until and unless" he expressed himself on domestic issues.

For a club supposedly heading into difficulties satisfying the salary demands of an array of spectacular pennant winners, the Giants seem to be doing quite well, thank you. They brought their total of 1952 contract signers to twenty yesterday with the announcement that four more players had come into the fold.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Western European leaders expect that by the time the North Atlantic Council meets in Lisbon Feb. 16 the six governments concerned will be ready to initial a draft treaty for a European army unless serious parliamentary resistance should develop meanwhile.

The Rockcliffe Ice Wagon, a Royal Canadian Air Force laboratory plane, landed yesterday at La Guardia Airport, where her pilot confirmed what already had been proved in Monday's snowstorm. "This is no all-weather plane," he said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Without a dissenting vote, the House Judiciary Committee ordered a full-scale investigation of the Department of Justice today as House tax scandal investigators, balked by the stubborn silence of a key witness, initiated contempt proceedings against him and his attorney.

Several subway stations in Manhattan and Brooklyn, which the city plans to improve for use as air-raid shelters if the necessary funds are made available, were inspected yesterday by Federal, state and city defense officials.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The London News Chronicle today quoted Egypt's new Premier, Aly Maher Pasha, as saying he was prepared to discuss the formation of the Middle East defense command proposed by the United States, Britain, France and Turkey.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Two high French officials who returned from Tunisia without delivering a French note to the Bey of Tunis reported to the French Government on their mission. It was considered likely that steps would be taken soon to deliver the note and, possibly, to resume negotiations with the Tunisian Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -Memphis and Philadelphia received a joint award today for being the cleanest cities in the country. The Ernest T. K. Trigg Award was presented to the two cities by the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, which conducts an annual "national cleanest town contest."

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of The Chase National Bank, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the idea of "uniting" with the Bank of the Manhattan Company is still "a wise one." His interest in bank mergers, the chairman explained, is that "I would like Chase to have a city-wide branch bank system.''

WOODBURY, L. I., Jan. 29 -- Another of the fine old estates developed about forty years ago and fitting into the pattern of gracious entertaining in the early part of this century is to be made into a home development.

A petition protesting "exorbitant" water rates was presented to the Public Service Commission yesterday on behalf of 2,200 families in Levittown. Representatives of the Wantagh Levittown Civic Association asserted that the rates had made it difficult for some home owners to meet carrying charges.

There is a blue moon, it was reported at the meeting of the American Meteorological Society here yesterday afternoon, every time there is a blue sun. The last blue sun and moon were observed in Europe in September, 1950.

Blair Bolles, former head of the Washington Bureau of the Foreign Policy Association and author of "Tyrant From Illinois," has a new book on Norton's list. "How to Get Rich in Washington" is a discussion of "the basic economic and political causes which underlie the current spate of graft and influence-peddling in the capital."
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 30 -- Ambassador Dean Rusk opened United States negotiations with Japan today to permit United States troops and bases in this country after the peace treaty goes into effect.
Net income of the world's largest public utility system, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., last year aggregated $39,211,827, an increase of $5,202 over the 1950 net of $39,206,625.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 29 -- The use of United States weapons by the French and Vietnam forces in Indo-China has "added to the hope and confidence of the free world," United States Minister Donald R. Heath said today in a speech marking the arrival of the 100th shipload of supplies under the United States military aid program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today, in response to questions, that the 10 per cent pay increase for the armed forces the Administration was seeking might cost as much as $880,000,000 in the fiscal year 1953, instead of $832,000,000 as previous estimates have had it.

For reasons best known to him, Herman Shumlim has dedicated himself this season to espousing plays of British origin. "Gertie" is his third consecutive offering of the present term (the other two were "Lace on Her Petticoat" and "To Dorothy, a Son") hailing from Albion.

Senator Robert A. Taft was assured yesterday of at least eight delegates from New York to the Republican National Convention when Frank J. Kenna, Queens County Republican leader, announced the organization designees for delegate from his county.

Most Americans know more about ancient Egyptian history than they do about contemporary conditions there, a young Egyptian student told the high school Unesco conference yesterday. Consequently, he asserted, many persons here do not understand what is happening in the Middle East.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 29 -The January panel of the Nassau County grand jury finished its month of duty today with a strongly worded presentment condemning the increase of serious crimes committed by youth after they had been drinking in bars.

The United Nations made its first approach yesterday to open condemnation of Soviet aggression when the Political Committee of the General Assembly found Soviet Russia guilty of aiding and abetting the Chinese Communists in their conquest of the Chinese mainland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Attacks on the public schools add to the tensions of childhood, said the yearbook "Growing Up in an Anxious Age," published today by the Association of Supervision and Curriculum Development of the National Education Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Dr. W. C. Hueper, chief of the Cancerigenic studies section of the National Institutes of Health, advocated today a provision in the Food and Drug Act requiring that all new chemicals added to food and cosmetics be previously tested for both toxic and cancer-producing substances.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 29 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Daniel Malan warned leaders of the Negro population here today that they would be "dealt with" if they carried out threats to call demonstrations against the Government's color legislation.
The Federal Narcotics Bureau called yesterday for compulsory hospitalization of all narcotics addicts, not just minors as provided in the bill that passed the State Senate on Monday night.

Mrs. Terese Arvay, a 73-year-old former ballerina who performed "all over Europe" for two decades, and her sister, Mrs. Feni Kiss, 94, patted and straightened each other's ensembles into final perfection yesterday at the Sirovich Day Center for Older Persons, 203 Second Avenue.

GENEVA, N. Y., Jan. 29 -- Presidents of eleven state liberal arts colleges agreed today to form the Empire State Foundation of Independent Liberal Arts Colleges, to solicit, receive and distribute corporate gifts in support of independent liberal arts colleges in New York.

Union rivalry sometimes leads to the picketing of concerns which, despite union contracts, are caught in the middle of jurisdictional rows. To end cross-picketing by rival unions and to ban jurisdictional raids against each other the A. F. L. and C. I. O. in this city have set up a joint committee to formulate rules of the game.

CAIRO, Jan. 29 -- Parleys between the new Premier of Egypt, Aly Maher Pasha, and members of various political parties with the object of broadening the base of the present Cabinet and presenting the nation with a national front at a time generally considered as one of national emergency, took place today.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A million-dollar fire in Cincinnati's congested west end nearly destroyed the Cincinnati Sash and Door Company tonight before being brought under control.

" Town Meeting of the Air," which has been around practically since Marconi first started to tinker with sparks and coils, has turned up on television with a new liveliness. If on radio the forum show has been done in three-quarter time, in TV it is strictly swing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A Senate Small Business Subcommittee decided today to investigate a contract awarded to General Motors Corporation for making parts for F-84 and F-86 jet fighters.

That old picture of John Bull as a portly, beefy, jolly specimen of humanity needs revising. He is lean and hard today, and while he hasn't lost his rollicking humor there is a wry touch to it as he thinks on former beefsteaks and today's weekly chop.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors sponsored legislation today to have a "daily verbatim public record" made of proceedings in the State Senate and Assembly. The bill was introduced by Senator George T. Manning, Republican of Rochester.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 29 -- Maj. Gen. Dean C. Strothers said today the United States Twelfth Air Force would transfer most of its tactical planes to France because German airfields along the Iron Curtain "don't have enough elbow room."

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 29 -- Maj. Gen. Dean C. Strothers said today the United States Twelfth Air Force would transfer most of its tactical planes to France because German airfields along the Iron Curtain "don't have enough elbow room."

ROME, Jan. 29 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today condemned the "campaign against Catholicism" that it said was being carried on in Yugoslavia "more violently there where the Catholic faith is strongest" and results in such episodes as the attack on Jan. 20 on Msgr. Anthony Vovk, apostolic administrator of the Diocese of Ljubljana.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 29 -- The Yugoslav Government of Premier Marshal Tito has decided to replace its military attaches in several of the leading Western capitals with ranking generals of the Yugoslav Army as a preliminary move toward establishing closer liaison, chiefly with the United States and British commands.

Reflecting improved operating results for 1951, directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., increased the quarterly dividend on its stock with the declaration yesterday of 50 cents a share for payment March 10. Last year shareholders received quarterly dividends of 30 cents in March and 40 cents each in June, September and December, with a year-end extra of 30 cents, bringing the total to $1.80 a share.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The nation's money supply increased by almost nine billion dollars to a new record high in 1951, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Fresh truffles, epicurean fare that in this country formerly was available only to chefs in a few hotels and restaurants, this week will be offered at retail. Bloomingdale's Delicacies Shop is the innovator, bringing the succulent fungi here by Air France from Perigueux in the heart of the French truffle region.
PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The Greek Government is beginning to have misgivings about the possible return to Greece of several thousand children evacuated from northern Greece to Cominform countries in 1947.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- The Soviet Union was found guilty today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly of having failed to live up to Moscow's 1945 treaty of friendship with Nationalist China.

Venetian blind manufacturers were told yesterday to cease lamenting Government materials restrictions. The big trick lies not in maintaining production but in selling the reluctant consumer, according to A. F. Waltzinger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Truman presented Medals of Honor, the nation's highest military award, to two infantry sergeants today. He commented that it would be "a wonderful thing" if in civilian affairs "we had fighters for the right like these two young men."

ALBANY, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's legislative fiscal leaders today introduced bills to give the state's 80,000 employes an across-the-board pay increase of 6 per cent on base salaries effective April 1.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,411, compared with 2,476 last week and 1,166 in the similar week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 576 arrivals yesterday against 1,167 last Tuesday.

The State of West Virginia sold yesterday $6,000,000 of road bonds, due Feb. 1, 1953 to 1977, to a banking syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago at a bid of 100.049 for interest of 1 3/4 per cent, an interest cost of 1.746 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at tax-exempt yields ranging from 1 per cent to 1.90 per cent.
Vegetable oils made substantial gains in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Other lines were irregular or weak.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -- The organization of a new production group designed to provide greater opportunity for young people engaged in all aspects of movie making to display their talents is well under way at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 -- The H. J. Heinz Company's new vinegar building has been put in operation here, embodying novel structural and processing features and increasing the company's vinegar production capacity by half. It is part of a $15,000,000 plant expansion program.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Minority stockholders of the Radio Voice of Springfield, Inc., which operates Station WIZE, today sued Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer; his wife, Elizabeth, and other company directors.

New rules compelling motorists to drive with low-beam headlights at night and barring the use of parking lights on city streets were promulgated yesterday by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. The regulations, effective Monday, are aimed at reducing night traffic accidents and the Commissioner predicted that they would save at least fifty lives a year.

Uta Graf, who made her debut here three years ago as a virtually unknown soprano from Germany, returned to Town Hall last night for her second local recital. This time she came with more heralding, for in the meantime she has sung three seasons with the San Francisco Opera and last season she sang with the Royal Opera at London's Covent Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Witnesses before the United States Tariff Commission today pictured the American tuna fishing industry as on the verge of collapse from the weight of Japanese and Peruvian imports.

A middle-aged German couple, who sailed 8,500 miles in a thirty-foot sailboat to reach this country, looked hopefully yesterday for the immigration door of the United States to be thrown open to them. They said that developments of the last few weeks had given them hope.
Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, called yesterday for greater effort by editors, educators and Government leaders in the creation of a more enlightened public opinion.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A drastic program drafted by the Conservative Government to avert national bankruptcy was outlined to the House of Commons today by Richard Austen Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

An exhibition, which at the same time pays tribute to the generosity of a very progressive trustee, opens today at the Museum of Modern Art. In the third floor galleries have been installed major modern paintings and sculpture acquired by the museum through the Mrs. Simon Guggenheim Fund -- and a decidedly impressive collection the works form by themselves.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29 -- The Iranian Government announced today it had agreed to export oil to Communist Hungary under a new barter trade agreement.

James Jones, Rachel L. Carson and Marianne Moore yesterday won the third annual National Book Awards. The honor involved a protracted television, radio and press interview, a speech by each winner and the applause of 600 persons crowding the Century Room of the Commodore Hotel.

A "large portion" of foreign traders have failed to comply with basic requirements of price-control regulations, a meeting of exporters was informed yesterday. An official of the Office of Price Stabilization said later that approximately 40 per cent of dealers subject to specialized export and import price rules have failed to file reports of ceiling prices and related information.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Nearly 25,000 aluminum industry workers will forego scheduled strikes to give the Wage Stabilization Board a chance to work out a recommended settlement in their contract dispute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -The Senate agreed today to limit debate, beginning at noon tomorrow, on a bill to repeal curbs on imports of fats, oils and dairy products.

DENIS LETERRAND was only 14. He lived at home with his kind, conventional and stupid mother and father, who ignored completely their duties as parents to understand and guide their son. Denis spent the hours from eight in the morning until seven in the evening in a Jesuit school, where he was a noisy and refractory pupil.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- After he had made a tearful plea for mercy, Denis W. Delaney, former Massachusetts Collector of Internal Revenue, was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $10,500 in Federal District Court today for bribery and falsely certifying tax lien payments.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- After he had made a tearful plea for mercy, Denis W. Delaney, former Massachusetts Collector of Internal Revenue, was sentenced to two years in prison and fined $10,500 in Federal District Court today for bribery and falsely certifying tax lien payments.

The ubiquitous woman's touch is becoming a factor in lumber yard operation. Edith Ramsay, an editor of American Home and the daughter of a lumberman, told the Northeastern Retail Lumbermans Association yesterday that many lumber yards are making displays in their offices so attractive that women drop in and buy.

Women can clean up corruption in Government and change the political picture any time they wish, because they have more votes than men, Senator Estes Kefauver, candidate for the Democratic Presdential nomination, told a group of women's organization leaders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Paul Creston, a 45-year-old composer of New York, heard his fifty-second musical work, his Fourth Symphony, performed for the first time anywhere tonight in Constitution Hall. The performance was by the National Symphony Orchestra under Howard Mitchell at a regular midweek concert.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30 -- The threatened shutdown of 3,000 retail gasoline service stations in the state, scheduled for Friday, has been postponed for ten days, it was announced today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The British-owned Bank of Iran and the Middle East announced today it would close its doors in Iran by July 30, after sixty-three years of operation, because of Iranian Government restrictions.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today $50,000,000 of first-mortgage and collateral-trust bonds of the United Gas Corporation, due in 1972, at 102.17 to yield 3.35 per cent. The bonds, which bear interest of 3 1/2 per cent, were bought by the bankers at competitive sale on Tuesday, with a bid of 101.52999.

Three five-story buildings and a taxpayer on plot 100 by 95 feet at 233-35 Lafayette Street and 59-61 Spring Street have been sold by the Spring Realty Company, Abraham J. Schecter, president, to Edgar L. Cooper and Ernest Landers for investment in a deal negotiated by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers.

NEWARK, Jan. 30 -- The strike of 6,800 bus drivers and maintenance employes of two Public Service transportation companies, which was scheduled to begin at midnight tomorrow, was postponed for at least five days today after Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll ordered the companies seized under the State Public Utility Anti-Strike Act.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- New York City's income from pari-mutuel betting at flat race tracks, now scheduled to expire in 1956, would be retained by a bill introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Fred Preller, Republican of Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, recommended to the Senate Armed Services Committee today the enactment of a bill already passed by the House to raise the pay, housing and subsistence allowances of the armed forces by 10 per cent.

VIRGINIA WOOLF drew two singularly contrasting portraits of her father, Sir Leslie Stephen. One is in her novel, "To the Lighthouse," where he appears as a rather joyless humbug, a pedantic old despot. The other is in "The Captain's Death Bed and Other Essays," where the hundredth anniversary of her father's birth seemed to stir a belated mellowness in her appraisal of that most eminent Victorian.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 30 -- French and Vietnamese troops improved their control of the mountain-flanked Hoabinh end of the Hoabinh-Hanoi highway yesterday by pushing out north and south of the road and consolidating outer defenses of the highway strong point of Dong Ben.

The Giants reported three more contract signers yesterday to bring their total to twenty-three. All are rookies, the group consisting of Rudy Rufer, shortstop: Ronnie Samford, a second sacker, and Hoyt Wilhelm, a young right-hander.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- A divided Labor Opposition decided today to attack the economic policy of Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative Government as enunciated yesterday by Chancellor of the Exchequer Richard Austen Butler. The Laborites will carry the issue to a vote tomorrow.

UPTON, L. I., Jan. 30 -- Exposure of corn kernels to atomic radiations has led to a 17,000-fold increase in the rate of changes (mutations) in their hereditary characteristics, it was announced hero today at the Brookhaven National Laboratory of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Your editorial on "A Healthy Controversy" is the best statement that has been made since the committee headed by Henry C. Brunie proposed (on Dec. 17, 1951) that the Greater New York Fund abandon solicitation of privately owned firms and their employes.

More suits with two pairs of pants will be found on clothing racks this year than has been the case in recent times. Manufacturers plan to increase their dollar volume through this move, it was learned in a survey of the industry yesterday.

Allie Reynolds, brilliant right-hander who cashed in an elbow full of chips for two no-hitters and a world series victory last year, will call at the Yankee offices today to discuss his 1952 contract. Also present will be Manager Casey Stengel, freshly arrived from his home in California.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 -- About $20,000 worth of good lumber was deliberately burned by a "cost-plus" contractor at the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site last fall, Bruce McNeil, also a contractor, testified today at a commission hearing.

" A Trip to Mercury" will be presented at the Hayden Planetarium, Eighty-first Street at Central Park West, tomorrow through March 31. The imaginary journey will be made in the large star dome, which will be converted by special effects projectors into the interior of a space ship.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- The Government of Premier Alcide De Gasperi, which was defeated by seventeen votes last Friday, suffered another defeat, this time by six votes, in the Chamber of Deputies today, over the question of salary increases to state employes.

The weather over the eastern two-thirds of the United States was partly regulated, or timed, during the eighteen-month period that ended last July by silver iodide smoke poured into the prevailing eastward winds from smoke generators in New Mexico, Dr. Irving Langmuir reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Roger L. Putnam as Economic Stabilizer. The vote came after Mr. Putnam testified he believed he could "hold the line against inflation * * * in the very dangerous year" ahead.

A price reduction of about 8 per cent on all kitchen cabinets supplied to Eastern and Midwest distributors was announced yesterday by the General Electric Company. Harold T. Hulett, general manager of the electric sink and cabinet department of the company's major appliance division, said the cut is the direct result of a corresponding reduction in production costs.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 30 -- In a dramatic finish, the name of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee was entered twenty-nine minutes before the deadline for filing today to challenge President Truman on March 11 in the New Hampshire Democratic Presidential preference primary.
Those who were abroad on the city's streets at 5:05 o'clock yesterday morning enjoyed the passing distinction of having experienced this winter season's coldest temperature.
A man who is temporarily down can become permanently out of society if he doesn't get a chance. The Salvation Army is daily giving that chance to hundreds of men in this city.
SEOUL, Thursday, Jan 31 (AP) -- Allied planes yesterday rained bombs and flaming napalm on a big Communist supply center, churning it into blazing rubble.

Chester I. Barnard, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said yesterday that the foundation had no responsibility for the contents of a recent report on refugees that had aroused criticism on the part of some United Nations members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Going counter to Administration wishes, the Senate shelved today, by a vote of 47 to 39, a bill to repeal curbs in the Defense Production Act on imports of agricultural and dairy products.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A 55-year-old woman whose feud with the Government over taxes has resulted in several suits and counter-suits was sent to jail for contempt of court today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Powers in Europe, Rocquencourt, France, Jan. 30 -- A reorganization of Allied tactical air forces supporting General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's command in West Europe is now nearing completion and will be announced soon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and John L. Lewis staged an impromptu, catch-as-catch-can debate on the Taft-Hartley Act at a Senate hearing today, with inconclusive results.

The character of Sinclair Lewis -- exuberant and questing in his younger days, assured and testy at the pinnacle of his success and lonely and confused toward the last -- traces itself through an exhibit of Lewis memorabilia opening tomorrow at the museum of the Academy of Arts and Letters near 155th Street and Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 23, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Freshman Jesse Arnelle, Penn State's lanky center, scored 18 point -- 5 during a fourth-period rally -- to lead the Nittany Lions to a 53-49 victory over Navy's quintet today. It was Penn State's ninth-straight triumph.

Safety should be served by the new rules requiring motorists to use their low-beam headlights at night in the city streets. Even experienced drivers have been handicapped by the anomalous and vague regulations, differently interpreted in different parts of the city, and by different police officers, which have forced them to drive with too little illumination.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill informed the House of Commons today that when he told the United States Congress that Britain's response to any breach of a Korean armistice would be "prompt, resolute and effective," he was expressing "frankly and fully" the spirit in which Britain and the United States face their difficulties together.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The prospect that the House of Representatives will get the opportunity to vote at this session for joint construction by the United States and Canada of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project brightened today.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Australian Lawn Tennis Association, disturbed because only two members of the United States Davis Cup squad remained here to play in the nationals, left undecided today whether to permit its Wimbledon team to compete in the United States championships this year at Forest Hills, N. Y.

The tradition has it that actors yearn to play Hamlet, actresses to play Juliet and most sopranos to play Carmen. But Ljuba Welitch has been eager for an opportunity to play Musetta in "Boheme" ever since her arrival at the Metropolitan three seasons ago, and last night she had her wish.

Airplane landings under zero-zero conditions (when fog is flat on the runways and there is no forward visibility) are not possible with the equipment used now in planes and on the ground. Such landings will not be made possible by further refinement of the equipment.

A group of women, headed by Mrs. Richard P. Connette and including Mrs. James Gibbons and Mrs. S. Hazard Gillespie, are advancing plans for the Valentine tea dance, to be held Feb. 8 in the Chanteclair Room of the Sherry-Netherland under the auspices of the Thrift Shop Committee of the Union Settlement Women's Auxiliary.

Preliminary instruction for boys 10 to 12 years old who will take part in the first sewing classes ever to be offered at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, was given at the club yesterday. Regular sessions will begin next Wednesday at 4 P. M. and will continue each Wednesday for three weeks with Miss Ann Necchi, a sewing specialist, as teacher.

Improved educational systems for the young people of the world and a universal language that would make textbooks of all countries available to students everywhere were put forward as means of bringing about world peace last night by a panel of six high school students, three boys and three girls, at a New York Times Youth Forum held at Hunter College in conjunction with the third national conference of Unesco.

In testifying before the Joint Economic Committee this week Michael V. DiSalle was probably making his last public appearance as price boss under the Defense Production Act. Sometime early next month the rotund former Mayor of Toledo will return to his home state, where he plans to enter the primary race for the United States Senate.
ALLAHABAD, India, Jan. 30 -- A rarity in politics -- a candidate sworn to silence -- is challenging India's loquacious Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for a seat in Parliament.

In a move to coordinate and unify activities in the field of social work education, delegates from leading social work agencies over the nation have adopted a constitution setting up a strong, permanent National Council on Social work Education.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The newt Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law will concentrate during the current legislative session on correcting minor inequities regarding amateur sports and recreation and leave more controversial issues for further study.

The Poetry Society of America awarded seven prizes totaling $1,900 last night at its forty-second annual dinner at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue. In addition, the gold medal of the Alexander Droutzkoy Memorial Award for "services to poetry" was bestowed upon A. M. Sullivan, the retiring president of the society.
BRITISH HEADQUARTERS, Suez Canal Zone, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Egyptian rioters literally tore British victims of Saturday's Cairo riots limb from limb, official British reports received here revealed today.

The United States Customs Inspectors Association of the Port of New York, dissatisfied with the present upgrading and retirement plan provisions under Civil Service, will meet on Feb. 20 in the Statler Hotel to consider what advantages could be gained by joining a nation-wide labor organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices dipped 1.6 per cent between mid-December and mid-January, ending a three-month advance. Reporting this today, the Department of Agriculture said declines in the prices of eggs, turkeys, cotton, cottonseed, most meat animals and citrus fruit caused the downturn.

The fact that stark, sleek uncluttered furniture can be handled in such a way that the final effect is one of luxury is neatly demonstrated in a new showroom. At Laverne Originals, 160 East Fifty-seventh Street, where assorted objects for use in the home such as fabrics, furniture, wallpapers, baskets and even a wire composition may be purchased through decorators, the total impression is one of restrained elegance.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 30 -- The Brazilian Government has decided to intensify its drive against communism by enforcing the anti-Red laws to the hilt and seeking new means to get at secret Communists and fellow-travelers, Justice Minister Francisco Negrao de Lima said today.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- One paratrooper was killed and twenty-seven injured today as some 1,000 men of the Eleventh Airborne Division leaped from C-119 "flying boxcars" into the icy fields of Camp Drum.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Walter S. Doxsey of Cleveland, president of the American Steel Warehouse Association, said today that "despite the continuing cries from Washington, the steel situation is definitely easing."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30 -- The Yugoslav Government has authorized collective farms to expropriate any holdings of independent peasants that are situated between strips owned by collectives.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Representatives of New Jersey seashore counties decided today to ask the state to raise its share of beach erosion funds above the $1,000,000 now proposed in the budget for 1952.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce called today for further study of the pending universal military training bill on the ground that it would cost an estimated four billion dollars in the first year and might mean "a waste of manpower and a waste of money."

The directors of Youth House, a shelter for delinquent boys located at 331 East Twelfth Street, will withdraw on Feb. 7 their resignations submitted to Mayor Impellitteri late last month. The resignations were sent to City Hall when it appeared that the city would not renew its lease on the premises.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 30 -- The motion-picture industry today lost its first battle in Texas to strike down censorship by city ordinances.

The New York State Crime Commission started yesterday the first all-inclusive attack on New York waterfront crime, including "many murders," kickbacks, "loan-sharking" and evils inherent in the hiring system.
A college for adults that has been a more or less neglected child at Columbia University since 1904 will come of age tomorrow.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 30 -- France is unwilling to return the Saar to Germany under any conditions and is equally unwilling to accept any solution of the Saar issue that affects French economic interests in the tiny industrial state, a highly placed French source declared today.

GIBRALTAR, Jan. 29--In his last interview as United States Ambassador to Spain, Stanton Griffis said he thought United States military and economic aid to Spain would be the best "investment" the United States could make in Europe and predicted that such assistance would influence Madrid's governmental philosophy in the direction of freedom.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Jan. 30 -- The overflowing Ohio River coursed through main streets in two cities today, but near-zero temperatures and floodwalls lessened the hazard of further serious damage to sections of the Ohio Valley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the United States was pleased by the way King Farouk and the new Cairo Government had taken firm steps to end the disorder in Egypt.

CERTAINLY you remember the Mexican League and the fabulously wealthy Pasquel brothers. They scared the daylights out of organized ball a half dozen years ago by flaunting vulgar wads of folding money before the fascinated eyes of major league players. The entire business was too ridiculous for belief and it causes snickers now.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A schedule of requirements by which the Defense Production Administration will judge the competence of applicants seeking to enter the aluminum production field was set up today by Manly Fleischmann, Administrator of the D. P. A.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 30 (UP) -- Two cracks, one of them a mile long, appeared in the earth's surface here today in the wake of a series of rumblings and flickering lights which frightened some residents.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 -- The Mexican Government has prohibited the exports of certain essential commodities "until the domestic market is saturated and enough stocks have been accumulated to assure against any price rise."
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Justice Christopher J. Heffernan of the State Supreme Court restrained the State temporarily today from enforcing its new weight-distance tax on big trucks.

The process by which the skins of animals and fish are converted into fashionable products, such as purses, shoes and othes wearing apparel, is the theme of the February exhibit of the American Craftsmen's Educational Council at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

New types of communications equipment that are being issued to troops in Korea and Europe were demonstrated yesterday at Fort Jay, Governors Island. Weight-reducing improvements and a shift-over from AM to FM in portable radio sets were among the notable innovations.

The sanity of your editorial "Waiting at the Gate," favoring the proposed statehood for Alaska and Hawaii, applies just as well to giving constitutionality to the Equal Rights Amendment. "Four years ago both major parties went into the Presidential campaign pledged to" such constitutional progress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Investigators of the House of Representatives accused a group of West Point graduates today of a "cheap and tawdry" attempt to put pressure on 10,000 business men with a hint that they could help them to get Government contracts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that a loose binding tape flapping from the left elevator had been the probable cause of a sudden 2,200-foot dive by an airliner over Pennsylvania earlier this week.

The general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., meeting in bi-monthly session at the Commodore Hotel yesterday morning, adopted a statement opposing permanent Universal Military Training. The vote was 39 to 8 and followed a period of spirited debate.
