CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Clarence Henry of Los Angeles, No. 3 contender for the world heavyweight championship, tonight scored a technical knockout over Bob Satterfield of Chicago in 1 minute 41 seconds of the first round of their scheduled ten-round bout in Chicago Stadium.

After having called sixteen witnesses to testify on twenty-four of the fifty-two extortion and conspiracy counts against James J. Moran, Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti rested the state's case against the former First Deputy Fire Commissioner at 12:51 P. M. yesterday.

CAIRO, Jan. 30 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech in the House of Commons in which he expressed a wish for agreement with Egypt on the defense of the Suez Canal Zone that would "meet Egyptian aspirations" appeared to have been well received in Government circles and was headlined in the day's press, with the references to the incidents of Saturday deleted.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 2,551,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum institute. At the week-end supplies were 133,861,000 barrels, compared with 131,310,000 a week earlier and 126,261,000 a year ago.

Governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, meeting in Hartford. Conn.. have reopened the question of higher commissions on Stock Exchange deals. The matter has been under study by the exchange staff since early fall and was noted in the quarterly report to members issued in October.

There were only a few inhabitants in blackened Rivington Street, between Lewis Street and Baruch Place last night, and they were embittered folk and hopeless, affrighted of the future. Their homes and shops have been condemned for the Baruch housing development.

The quota for the advance gifts committee of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, in the 1952 Red Cross Fund campaign beginning March 1 was announced yesterday as $625,000 by Mrs. Loyall F. Sewall, chairman of the committee.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers moved a half-game ahead of Rochester to lead the Western division of the National Basketball Association by defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 77 -- 65, tonight.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 -- James B. Carey, Secretary-Treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told the national convention of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., today that "there needs to be a corporate morality as well as a political morality" in the United States.
Plans for raising around $50,000,000 through a new financing program early in March were approved yesterday by directors of the Inland Steel Company.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- With the reluctant consent of that "former naval person," Prime Minister Churchill, Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, commander of the United States Atlantic Fleet, was appointed today as Supreme Allied Commander of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Koppers Company, Inc., Pittsburgh, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for 250,000 shares of its $10 par common stock, to be offered for public sale through an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation.

With $4,500,000 at stake, the battle between Duane Jones, head of the advertising agency of that name, and nine of his former executives will continue with renewed energy, and the court case is headed for early trial, it was learned yesterday.
Earle H. Daniel, a man who has helped tens of thousands of amputees to walk again, is leaving New York today for Florida to continue his work there.

Neither Congress nor the public has been satisfied with President Truman's decision three weeks ago to let his own Attorney General conduct the inquiry into charges of corruption within his own Administration. While the principal target of the allegations has been the Internal Revenue Bureau of the Treasury Department, the Justice Department itself has also been prominently mentioned.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Dr. Lawrence A. Kimpton, chancellor of the University of Chicago, has joined with three faculty members in a letter of protest to Secretary of State Dean Acheson urging amendment of the McCarran subversive activities control act.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that the Legislature had power under a constitutional amendment approved by the voters last November to force local units of government to supplement the pensions of retired public employes. In addition, the Attorney General held that the amendment also removed any obstacle to the provision of supplemental pensions by the Legislature for retired state employes.

Redesigned bodies, increased visibility, horsepower and riding comfort are listed as outstanding features of the 1952 line announced yesterday by the Ford division, Ford Motor Company. The models go on display tomorrow in dealer showrooms here and throughout the country.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, 52-year-old Governor of Illinois, said today that he was not a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Ministry of Economy and Commerce announced last night approval of a project for construction of Chile's first big newsprint mill.
The election of two vice presidents and the reassignment of two vice presidents of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, effective tomorrow, have been announced by Gwilym A. Price, president.

Irving Trust Company held a "town meeting" on the problem of taxes yesterday. Officially scheduled as the annual stockholders' meeting, the hour-and-a-half session was devoted largely to an airing of views on the topic. William N. Enstrom, the bank's chairman, who presided, answered occasional questions and offered a few comments, but for the most part he listened with patience.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today approved a resolution that renewed the annual plea by the Assembly that the Cominform states hasten the repatriation of children removed from combat areas in northern Greece during 1947.
YONKERS, Jan. 30 -- The Central National Bank here put some of its money out in the lobby today and invited its clients to make their own change without supervision.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr. was nominated by President Truman today to be Commandant of the Marine Corps for four years beginning Jan. 1.

To see Enid Bagnold's "Gertie," which opened at the Plymouth last, evening, is to realize again that the British are admirable people. They are solid. They are intelligent, observant and civilized, and they also have a sense of humor. But why is there no bounce or sparkle in this comedy of manners by a woman with an original mind and a shrewd understanding of other women?

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today authorized the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation to raise its electric rates by $2,500,000 in south central and eastern New York.

Prime Minister Churchill gave a good demonstration yesterday of how to say the same things in two different ways. What he told the House of Commons about Korea, Formosa, the Middle East and the cold war did not differ in substance from what he told the American Congress and President Truman a few weeks ago.

May I be permitted to comment on the letter by Avraham Harman, Director, Israel Office of Information, published on Jan. 19, and attempting to refute the facts stated in the advertisement of the Zionists-Revisionists of America which appeared on Jan. 16.

Two teen-age boys have been in police custody since Jan. 23, when they were caught robbing a parking meter in Brooklyn Heights, the Traffic Department reported yesterday. The youths, 14 and 15 years old, were apprehended in front of 166 Remsen Street with burglars' tools and a parking meter coi nbox containing $6.60, the department said.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- The United States laid before the United Nations today a detailed account of the trial of William N. Oatis, former correspondent of The Associated Press in Prague, as an "indictment" of the Czechoslovak Government.

Completely in charge after the first period, St. John's routed Fordham, 69 -- 56, before 4,500 spectators at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. By their triumph, the Redmen strengthened their claim to Metropolitan basketball leadership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The rush of Presidential candidates into the New Hampshire primaries, scheduled for March 11, testifies to the great importance political managers of these candidates attach to the outcome in a state that ranks forty-third in the Union in population and has only four electoral votes to cast in the selection of a President and Vice President out of the minimum of 266 required for a choice.

Valuable limestone sculptures from ancient Egypt and a limited number of marble specimens of early Roman and Greek art from the collection of M. A. Mansoor of Cairo and Heliopolis were sold at auction here yesterday. The collection covers the period of Egyptian art from prehistoric times to the early days of Christianity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Motor carriers operating in New York State and those operating in New England and between New England and New York were under criticism before the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 -- The gravest sign of Argentina's economic plight was given by the Government today when it ordered all restaurants and other public eating places to observe a meatless day each week.

The late Jo Davidson's original plaster model of Walt Whitman was presented yesterday to the Walt Whitman School by Mrs. Leonard J. Trilling. This long-term loan of the over-life-size plaster, from which the bronze in Bear Mountain Park was cast, was made possible by the interest of the sculptor's widow; of his close friends, Mr. and Mrs. Ely Jacques Kahn, and of Nathan Bienstock, administrator of the estate.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A Federal judge has blocked the Government's attempt to protect the movie industry from foreign competition saying "free competition" was the best way to spur the Mexican industry to make better films.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- An appeal was carried to the Supreme Court today against the new Federal gambling tax, which requires gamblers to buy a $50 occupational stamp and pay the Government 10 per cent on all wagers. It was the first time the issue had been taken to the highest court.

The swing from hard goods to soft not having developed as expected, the apparel industry finds itself with high inventories all along the line, according to a report yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Victor Moore, a resident of California since 1947, may come out of semi-retirement to take up again the role of the hapless vice president, Alexander Throttlebottom, in the forthcoming revival of "Of Thee I Sing." He created the part in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Government will appoint a group to study whether controls on sheet steel -- widely used for making automobiles, refrigerators, washers and many other home appliances -- should be removed.

CAMDEN, N. J., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Acceptance of an agreement for a 32-cent-an-hour pay increase ending the 191-day strike at the Todd-Johnson Shipbuilding Corporation yards in New Orleans was announced here today by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the indictment of three men, including a one-time basketball star at Long Island University and an Altoona gambler, on charges of bribing a New York University player to "shave points" in a game played on New Year's Day in 1951.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30 -- The Protestant churches of America were called upon here today to revise their chaplain procurement programs in the face of an "alarming and critical" shortage.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Louisiana Republican leaders who favor Senator Robert Taft of Ohio for President made a surprise move in the State Central Committee today by voting to declare null and void a Jan. 15 Republican primary.

A seventy-four-page report to the State Superintendent of Insurance, called "The Problem of the Uninsured Motorist," which is made public this morning, provides enough information for New York legislators to proceed at this session to a decision on the question of making automobile liability insurance compulsory in this state.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Bold, the 1951 Preakness winner, wasn't of any help to Brookmeade Stable in Hialeah's $13,750 Bougainvillea Handicap today, but Brookmeade took most of the money. Picador, the other half of the entry that carried the white and blue silks, fed all the way in the mile-and-three-sixteenths race over the grass course.

A brash advertising agency executive (no rare species) walked into a stiff argument yesterday by suggesting to a group of pharmaceutical manufacturers that brand-name promotion of ethical drugs could raise prescription sales.

WASHINGTON, Jan 30 (AP) -- Italy has formally asked the United States for permission to try two former American soldiers on charges of slaying their commanding officer during a secret wartime mission behind enemy lines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- The Theatre Owners of America, representing about 9,000 movie houses, are formulating a campaign to attempt to seek tax relief, it was reported by Gael Sullivan, executive director, after a closed meeting this morning of the executive board.
Hal Dietz has been appointed general manager of Emerson-New York, Inc., distributor of Emerson television and radio receivers in this city and in Nassau and Suffolk counties.

A syndicate headed by Murray Rubinstein has sold the six-story building at 37-06 Seventy-second Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, containing seven stores and fifty apartments, to David Gold of Jackson Heights. Frank Benjamin of Queens Hub Realty, agent, reported the buyer paid cash above mortgages of $180,000.

Three young robbers, carrying out an elaborate conspiracy, tricked their way yesterday into an apartment on upper Park Avenue, where they drew weapons to intimidate their victim, her secretary and two servants, and escaped with $114,800 in jewels and $1,500 in cash.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Bill Hannon of Westville, Ind., enjoyed the best day of his college career by scoring 36 points to lead Army to an 83-to-64 basketball victory over Brown University in the field house today.

H. E. Humphreys Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, recommended yesterday that the Government offer immediately its GR-S synthetic rubber plants, including feedstock facilities, for leasing by private industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Federal government will help serve a record billion and a half cut-rate but nourishing meals to 9,400,000 United States school children this year, the Agriculture Department predicted today.
New York State will accept no new tenants after Friday in any of the emergency housing provided here six years ago for war veterans in barracks, old school buildings and abandoned tenements.

The twenty-one-story Master Printers Building at 406-16 Tenth Avenue and 460-78 West Thirty-fourth Street has been purchased by Bruno-New York, Inc., which plans to increase the space it now occupies there. The property asssessed at $2,850,000, of which $500,000 represents land value, occupies the entire block on the east side of Tenth Avenue between Thirty - third and Thirty - fourth Streets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Doctors at Presbyterian Hospital reported today that they had shocked a student nurse back to life with electricity after her heart had quit beating for an hour and forty-five minutes.

GENEVA, Jan. 30 -- Fluctuations in international trade and payments of kind that have given Europe two acute dollar crises in two years must be expected as a normal feature of the present world economy, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe warns in a study of 1951 economic developments.

The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier toward the close yesterday in sympathy with the dip in the stock market, and final prices for active months were down 9 to 22 points on the day.
Recovery of ground water levels in large areas of Brooklyn from below to above sea level between 1947 and 1950 was reported yesterday by the United States Geological Survey.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 30 -- Some 9,000 men of the Eleventh Airborne Division, participating here in Exercise Snowfall, are being screened and examined in the first large-scale attempt in this country and probably in the world to "conquer" frostbite, the crippling injury that causes so many casualties to troops fighting in winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A tentative agreement was reached today to match Heavyweight Champion Jersey Joe Walcott and Harry Matthews in a title bout sometime in May. No site was announced for the proposed match.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30 -- Syria's reformist military regime, which is scheduled to announce soon decrees providing for major land reform, is faced with the necessity within two days of either committing a major breach of the Syrian Constitution or abandoning in mid-career its efforts to remake Syria.

HYDERABAD, India, Jan. 30 -- Fractional differences within the Congress party in this state lost many voters to the better-organized Communists, who maintained closer contact with the electorate than their rivals for several years, according to well-informed election analyses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A reconsideration of the vote of six Senators in the Senate Tuesday night that sent to the White House a ratified protocol designed to admit Greece and Turkey as full partners to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was asked by Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, today.

Today's new film is "Sailor, Beware," a comedy with music produced by Hal Wallis, released by Paramount and starring Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, at the Mayfair. Hal Wallis directed from a script by James Allardice and Martin Rackin, an adaptation by Elwood Ullman and a play by Kenyon Nicholson and Charles Robinson.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The Board of Health today closed two Loop restaurants, including the Blackhawk, in an investigation of alleged horsemeat sales in the city.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 30 -- Returning to action after a two-week lay-off for midyear examinations, Yale checked a late rally to beat a tenacious Amherst quintet, 58 -- 55, on the Payne Whitney court tonight.

Thousands shivered in the cold outside the Motor Vehicle Bureau offices in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens yesterday in a belated effort to purchase 1952 automobile license tags. There was reason for their fortitude. Last year's registrations expire at midnight today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 30 -- With Walter Dukes and Richie Regan setting the scoring pace, Seton Hall University subdued St. Francis of Brooklyn, 70 -- 60, tonight before 3,000 at the victor's gymnasium. Dukes scored 23 points and Regan 22.

The first major blow against alleged "pirates" and "bootleggers" in the record industry was struck yesterday. Columbia Records, Inc., and Louis Armstrong, jazz musician, filed a complaint in New York Supreme Court against Paradox Industries, Inc., for the alleged re-recording of Columbia's Armstrong "Jolly Roger" series and the sale of it under misleading brand labels.
The January quota of 30,000 pints of blood here is short 6,764 pints, the Red Cross announced yesterday. The 1,026 pints donated Tuesday brought the month's total to 23,236.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- As they approach the completion of a draft treaty for a European army, European leaders are discussing the vital question of the United States reaction to this project in a Presidential election year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- The Government today granted Chrysler, Studebaker and Kaiser-Frazer wholesale ceiling price increases ranging from 3.75 to 11.68 per cent on their 1952 model passenger automobiles.
The New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation paid honor yesterday to William J. McNulty, a special agent for the last twenty-eight years.

The Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association assailed the Defense Production Authority's 40 per dent cutback of materials critical for home building and asked yesterday that the question be reconsidered by the agency. The action was in the form of a unanimous resolution at the group's fifty-eighth annual convention in the New Yorker Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The British will take as a hopeful sign the reported statement tonight by the new Egyptian Premier. Aly Maher Pasha's statement to a reporter that he was ready to consider any proposal for an understanding seemed to be a sign of that willingness to negotiate that the British have been waiting for.

As twelve more city departments went to budget hearings in the Municipal Building yesterday with their requests for operating funds in 1952-53, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson said that ninety-four agencies reporting so far out of a total of 111 had asked for $152,074,319 more than was appropriated for them in the current year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- In a gamble for high political stakes, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio decided today to test his vote-getting ability against that of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Harold E. Stassen in the nation's first Presidential preferential primary on March 11 in New Hampshire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Two novelists and a songwriter asked Congress today to tear down the "little iron curtain" they said this country had erected against foreign writers and publishers. They told a House Judiciary subcommittee that many foreign nations might "retaliate" unless copyright laws were changed.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Windy City II, an expensive importation from Ireland, whipped the Calumet Farm's twosome of A Gleam and Hill Gail in that order today in the $15,000 San Gabriel Stakes at Santa Anita Park.

Another appraisal of General Eisenhower is planned for April 9 publication of Doubleday, entitled "Dwight David Eisenhower: A Study of Growth in Leadership." The author is Kevin McCann, who served with the general as his assistant in the Chief of Staff's office from 1946 until Eisenhower left to become president of Columbia University.

Commuters are taking to the warpath in Croton, Brewster, Ossining, Bronxville, Scarsdale, Harmon and Yorktown Heights. Other parties are to be formed for combat in White Plains, Tarrytown, Yonkers, Mount Kisco and Peekskill.
CAIRO, Jan. 30 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha said today he was ready to listen to any peace move that Britain would make.

Lily Pons gave her first New York recital in six years last night at Carnegie Hall. An audience of 2,700 turned out to hear her and her assistants were those standbys of other years, Frank La Forge, who has been her accompanist since 1936, and Frank Versaci who traditionally provides the flute obbligatos.

To New Yorkers who have feasted on enchiladas, tacos or tamales, the very mention of the words puts appetites on the alert. But to savor such Mexican fare need not involve a trip south of the border. A recent bit of scouting by this department has revealed sources here for the foods that are common fare in Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The House of Representatives approved by a voice vote today President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

The most important single factor contributing to crime on the waterfront of the Port of New York is the so-called "public loading racket," John F. Gehan, executive vice president of the American Export Lines, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- There was relatively little response by the stock markets here today to Chancellor of the Exchequer Richard Austen Butler's statement other than by a further contraction of business. Indeed, the business turnover is expected to remain small until announcement of the Government's third installment of its austerity program on Budget Day, March 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Bills to liberalize existing old-age pensions for veterans and to provide new pensions for widows and orphans of some World War II veterans were rejected by the House Veterans Committee today for economy reasons.

Hernando Torres of Medellin, Colombia, is blind, but he has ambitions to be a radio advertising expert in his native land. His chances for success appear excellent, for he has been in this country since last September studying advertising at Columbia University and gaining practical experience at the studios of the National Broadcasting Company.
PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Pakistan flatly denied today Soviet charges that the West was trying to turn the princely state of Kashmir into a military base.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein upheld yesterday the right of the New York City Housing Authority to raise rents in middle income non-subsidized projects without first holding a hearing on the tenant's "ability to pay."

An exhaustive report that favors compulsory automobile insurance was submitted yesterday to every member of the State Legislature by the State Insurance Department. The document emphasized that in 1952 uninsured, financially irresponsible motorists will be involved in accidents causing losses of about $14,500,000 to residents of the state.

This week marks the twentieth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences. It has brought together in technical sessions leading engineers concerned with the extraordinary diversity of problems which have developed with the advent of jet power plants, with the fantastic extension of electronic controls and protections, and with the early steps of atomic application to aircraft power and armament.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina, declaring that the situation "stinks to heaven," denounced yesterday deals between Republican and Democratic leaders on nominations for judgeships. In an address before the Kiwanis Club, Judge Medina said he was "absolutely opposed to the whole system."

Allow me to differ strongly with your editorial of Jan. 26 on "Tragedy at Ismailia." You imply that the present trouble in Egypt concerns the safety of shipping in the canal. Since Egypt never threatened traffic in this international highway, this implication, also referred to in Mr. Churchill's speech before Congress, is without foundation.

The New York State Insurance Department has just completed a routine examination of the affairs and business activities of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, third largest insurance concern in the country. While its report is not being made public, Alfred J. Bohlinger, superintendent of the agency, said yesterday that it "can be stated unequivocally that the Equitable was found by the examiners to be in a strong financial position."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Truman has declared that Congressional delving into State Department papers could endanger the safety of the United States by making its Foreign Service officers afraid to report objectively what was going on in the world.

THE reason behind the increased interest in such big bores as the .300 and .375 magnums is finally becoming apparent, and recent correspondence ties it closely with a lot of projected "dream trips" to Alaska for the big brown bear. Not next year, nor the year after, but this spring.

Martin G. Olsen, the 36-year-old bank teller who went out to lunch on Tuesday from his post at the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, 50 Court Street, Brooklyn, and failed to return, was still missing yesterday, according to the police.

The sailing of the American Export liner Constitution for Mediterranean ports was delayed forty-five minutes yesterday when 405 unlicensed members of her crew staged an impromptu and unauthorized strike. The men, shouting about "unsatisfactory conditions," walked off the ship five minutes before she was to have sailed and remained ashore until ordered aboard again by a union official.

The Voice of America is preparing to put on a television look for the rest of the world. It was estimated here yesterday that the foreign television audience had grown to more than 12,500,000 regular viewers in seventeen countries and was likely to double this year.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Jan. 30 -- A note redefining the French position on the home-rule demands of Tunisia was delivered to Sidi Mohammed el-Amin Pasha, Bey of Tunis, and the Tunisian Government today by Jean de Hauteclocque, Resident General in the French protectorate.

ROME, Jan. 30 -- Riotous scenes occurred at Rome University this morning and later had an echo in the Chamber as a result of an attempt by some students, believed to be neo-Fascists, to prevent Umberto Calosso, Democratic Socialist Deputy, from delivering a lecture on Italian literature.

Cocoa futures trading here underwent violent changes yesterday as traders attempted to evaluate reports and rumors of a proposed purchase of the commodity abroad against a $12,000,000 credit established in Germany for the purpose.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) -- Representative Robert L. Doughton of North Carolina, the oldest member of Congress, announced today that he would "reluctantly" run again this year.

Now and then a person who has a reasonable familiarity with the English language comes on new words. If they seem to be general and not hyphenated scientific terms he may look them up in a dictionary and thus add to his vocabulary.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Jan. 30 -- Seven University of New Mexico students, departing in secrecy to avoid unwanted helpers, have started into the Northern Mexico mountains in search of "buried gold," which they hope was hidden there by Pancho Villa.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 31 -- Communist negotiators tried yesterday to stake out a claim to five islands in the Yellow Sea south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel and proposed to limit United Nations naval activities after an armistice in the Korean war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Grain futures lacked the buying force to move prices upward after the substantial gains of yesterday, and there also was some profit-taking by recent buyers in all pits. Deferred deliveries of wheat were relatively strong, but rallies were not extensive.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Long lines of housewives formed early today at groceries throughout the country in a rush to buy canned goods before they disappeared under the new import restrictions announced yesterday by Richard Austen Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
General Headquarters communique 1,145, for Wednesday's operations:

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Even Charles Creed, noted for his classical tailoring, has moved away from the severer lines to more gentle roundness in his new spring silhouette. His jackets are shorter and very waisted, and seams, lapels and necklines are all curved.

HEADQUARTERS, Fifth Air Force, Korea, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Communist anti-aircraft fire is a growing menace to United Nations air power, which is trying to throttle the Communist armies in Korea by choking off their supplies. The Fifth Air Force said today that Red ground gunners had knocked down 111 of its planes since last Oct. 1.
Unionized Northern hosiery workers will have their wages cut by as much as 25 per cent next Monday because their employers cannot compete with unorganized, low-paying plants in the South.
Austin, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Feb. 21 on issues of general obligation bonds totaling $6,300,000.
Support of the United Nations as the primary instrument of achieving world peace, was voiced yesterday by 1,000 students attending the Board of Education's high school Unesco conference.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey's record-setting $1,092,760,887 state budget for the next fiscal year appeared headed today for ratification by the Legislature despite efforts of some groups to obtain a reduction in personal income taxes.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 30 -- A spokesman for the organized city firemen of New York appealed to the American Federation of Labor Executive Council today to aid the firemen's campaign for a pay rise and warned that the state of the men's morale might produce undesirable actions.

Two Harlem fires caused much trouble on land and over the Harlem River yesterday morning. One blaze made sixteen families homeless and drove many more persons to the icy streets; the other delayed more than fifty rush-hour New York Central and New York, New Haven and Hartford trains, mostly bringing commuters from Westchester County and Connecticut, for from six to twenty-five minutes.

Secretary Acheson can point to a good deal of evidence to support his statement that Western Europe has made great political, military and economic progress toward strengthening itself in the last few years. There is, first of all, the economic recovery of Western Europe under the Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Plans are being made for the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France, and the Chancellor of the West German Republic to meet in London on Feb. 13 to work out a Western Big Three agreement for bringing Germany into the European defense organization.

The stock market yesterday underwent its sharpest shaking out in almost three months as a late selling wave produced losses of as much as 3 points. The offerings were so abundant in the last hour that the ticker tape could not keep abreast of actual floor transactions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that the search after nuclear energy of all kinds had cost the taxpayers of the United States a net sum of $2,805,411,139 from its inception in June, 1940, to June 30, 1951.

PARIS, Jan. 30 -- Svend designs a bewitching little half-hat, a mere band that arcs over the brow, then curves into a sculptural volute on the right temple and another in back on the left side. He makes it in untrimmed black lacquered straw, in daffodil pique almost covered with white feathers and in white pique piped in black grosgrain.

DETROIT, Jan. 30 -- Automobile industry leaders today told the Federal task force assigned to find jobs for Detroit's 105,000 unemployed that defense contracts on the present limited scale could not absorb the number of idle auto workers. The only immediate solution, they said, was for the Government to allow increased production of passenger cars and trucks.

TOKYO, Jan. 30 -- The Japanese Government indicated today that passports would not be issued to a dozen prominent business men and former public office holders who have been invited to Moscow for an international economic conference there next April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's letter to Admiral Lynde D. McCormick informing him of his appointment as Supreme Allied Commander of Naval Forces in the Atlantic:
The ACF-Brill Motors Company has a backlog of orders approximating $17,000,000, Charles W. Perelle, president of the eighty-one-year-old concern reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Supreme Allied Naval Command for the entire Atlantic, with headquarters at Norfolk, Va., was described here today as "rigged to go."

The Johns-Manville Corporation for the second successive year attained new high records in sales, production, payrolls and profits in 1951, L. M. Cassidy, board chairman, informed stockholders in the ninety - third anniversary report mailed yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The State Council of Churches today said that administration of New York's divorce law was "fraught with fraud and perjury" and recommended the drafting of equitable legislation. The council, representing 4,700 Protestant churches in the state, adopted the resolution at its annual one-day meeting.

The Aluminum Company of America is installing the nation's largest extrusion press at its plant in Lafayette, Ind. The new press will permit production of larger, lighter and more intricate aluminum shapes for aircraft and other industries which are working on defense orders.

Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois. warned yesterday of the "throttling effect" of Federal controls on private business. He spoke at the closing session of the National Automobile Dealers Association's convention at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The State Power Authority asserted today that the interests of the state in the hydroelectrical potential of the St. Lawrence River had been kicked around very thoroughly" by Congress at the behest of public power exponents in the Department of Interior.

By agreement of both sides, General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen dismissed twenty-eight of the fifty-one extortion counts against James J. Moran yesterday, leaving the former First Deputy Fire Commissioner to face twenty-three counts of extortion and one of conspiracy.

For the second in its series of designer showings, presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Saks Fifth Avenue selected the spring collection of Jo Copeland of Pattullo. Miss Copeland works with a crisp fresh feeling. She likes the starch white of collar and cuffs or gilet insets tied with big bows.

Weaver of silken phrases and contriver of double-edged retorts, S. N. Behrman finally will have the satisfaction of escorting "Jane" into the Coronet this evening. His twelfth play for the Theatre Guild land the group's fifth subscription offering of the season, the comedy will be presented at eight o'clock with Edna Best and Basil Rathbone starred.

Four thousand workers in 350 retail and small wholesale bakery shops throughout the metropolitan area went on strike early today. In another phase of a contract dispute in the bakery industry here, a threatened strike against a major wholesale group was averted temporarily last night.

A scarcity of meat in Argentina is as anomalous as a shortage of beans would be in Boston. And yet the impossible has happened -- there is insufficient beef in Buenos Aires. Now the Peron regime has gone on to make the impossible ridiculous to boot by attempting to conceal the lack of meat behind a campaign for a more varied diet.

WASHINGTON, Jan 31 (UP) -- Italy was authorized today to go into the United States courts to seek the extradition of two former G. I.'s accused of the war-time slaying of Maj. William V. Holohan of the Office of Strategic Services.

Recent financing by the International Harvester Company appears to have been a major influence in the net reduction of $59,000,000 in business loans from New York banks in the week ended on Wednesday, Jan. 30. The decline, fourth to be registered in the last five weeks, brings the total decrease in business commitments since the end of last year to $142,000,000 contrasted with a gain of $130,000,000 in the same period a year earlier.

It is not too early, even now, to begin thinking of Feb. 29. If General Eisenhower, Senator Taft and others can be starting now to think of faraway November it is not too early for an average citizen to begin considering Feb. 29.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)--Freebooter, winner of the Grand National Steeplechase in 1950, and two French horses drew top weight of 175 pounds today for the famed jumping classic at Aintree April 5.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The American Federation of Labor may take sides in the Presidential contest this year, contrary to historic practice.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Exercise Snowfall, dubbed by some "Exercise Snow Fail" because of the scarcity of snow in this "North country," probably marks the end of an era and the opening of a new one in military history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A drop in the rate of casualties in Korea and an increase in the number of voluntary enlistments have made it possible to reduce the number of men it was originally planned to draft in the first half of the year, Selective Service said today.

Anthony Anastasia 45-year-old Brooklyn waterfront boss, was arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on a two-count indictment accusing him of assault in the second degree and resisting a public officer. He entered a plea of not guilty and was continued in $2,500 bail for trial, no date for which was set.
GIBRALTAR, Jan. 30 -- Legend has it that when the last of the little colony of Barbary apes dwelling on Gibraltar has died or quit the Rock, Britain will be driven out.

I Should like to commend your timely editorial in support of the Metcalf-Hatch pound bill. There are no doubts in the minds of informed people as to the value of this legislation. Peculiarly enough, this group comprises 85 per cent of the population, as determined by nation-wide and state-wide polls and the recent referendum in Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- All grains were under heavy selling pressure for the greater part of the session today, but there were fair rallies at times on short profit-taking, while commission absorption broadened moderately on the setbacks. Long liquidation was heavy in all pits, however, and outside buying was not much in evidence except on the extreme declines.

CAIRO, Jan. 31 -- No formal proposals on basic issues, meaning the evacuation by British forces of the Suez Canal Zone, or the unity of the Nile Valley -- have been made since the change in government, a British Embassy spokesman declared today.

Thus far the painfully obvious attempts of the Soviet Union to woo the Japanese have met with icy rebuffs. Premier Stalin's fervent New Year's greeting to the Japanese people received the raised eyebrow when it didn't get the Bronx cheer. Similarly the Russian attempts to hold out the bait of trade with Red China and with the Soviet Union itself have not provoked the right sort of flutter in Japanese breasts.

LOS ANGELES, Jan 31 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today denied implications at a commission hearing here that there had been laxity in security precautions during the construction of its Nevada test site last fall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--President Truman said today that he would have his name taken off the ballot in New Hampshire's March 11 Presidential preferential primary, but emphasized that this action did not mean he would not be a candidate for re-election.

Build a half dozen ships in the same exact design, on the same shipways and with the same marine architects and workmen and each one of the six will respond differently in any given condition of loading, speed and reaction to wind and wave.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31 -- American Protestants were warned today to formulate a "uniform" definition of the much-debated principle of the separation of church and state or suffer the consequences of serious misinterpretation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31--More than 1,000 dock workers returned to their jobs on the Delaware waterfront's three busiest piers today after an agreement had been reached in the fifteen-day strike of twelve cargo checkers.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 1 -- The United Nations Command proposed yesterday to speed negotiations for an armistice in the Korean war by appointment of a new committee to discuss the last remaining point of the agreed agenda, recommendations to be made by the military leaders to the Governments concerned for a final settlement in Korea.

" Carmen" was restored to the Metropolitan repertory last night in more ways than one, and with a final effect that was a sensation. As a whole this was a memorable performance. Exception could be taken to the details of scenery or stage business.

I. Miller Sons, Inc., will open a new shoe store at 715 Fifth Avenue near Fifty-sixth Street today under the name of the "Ingenue Shop." The store will slant its ideas to suit the young career girl and matron in the selection of styles as well as prices, which range from $7.95 to $17.95.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- West German police raided the national and state headquarters of the Communist party and the neo-Nazi Socialist Reich party at dawn today

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Saturday totaled 727,933 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,729 cars or 2.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 56,233 cars or 7.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 91,999 cars or 14.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

KALIMPONG, India, Jan. 31 -- The Chinese are developing Chamdo, an important Tibetan fortress on the eastern frontier, as the main administrative center of Tibet, outrivaling Lhasa politically, according to reports from Tibet, Lhasa remains as the religious center.

An appeal for elimination of price controls as a step toward ending "the killing blight of deflation" in the textile industry was urged last night by William H. Ruffin, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The arrests of eleven men after three investigations by the Immigration and Naturalization Service were made public yesterday. They included seizure of an alleged former comrade of an Italian bandit leader and a well-known British boxer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- Robert E. Mayer, executive vice president of the Pacific American Steamship Association, trade organization for American Flag steamship operators on the Pacific Coast, was elected president of the association today, succeeding D. N. Lillevand, vice president of Grace Line, Inc. Mr. Mayer has been on the association's staff since 1946.

A 73-year-old woman recluse, who didn't trust banks and carried $60,000 on her person daily for eleven years, has reported to the police the disappearance in a cafeteria of $17,800 in cash, $20,000 in jewels and $14,700 in stocks and bonds.

Wall Street's sunless canyon reverberated with the strains of hymns and martial music during the noon hour yesterday as the Salvation Army opened the "booth-canvass" phase of its 1952 appeal in an open-air ceremony on the steps of the Subtreasury Building.

Dimitri Mitropoulos returned to his Philharmonic-Symphony last night with one of the new compositions he so valiantly -- and so commendably -- champions, in this case Leon Kirchner's Sinfonia in Two Parts. The Conductor placed it strategically in the program just before the romantic Bruch Concerto which was played by that peerless violinist, Zino Francescatti.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- An allotment of $100,000,000 to Italy from economic aid funds of the Mutual Security Program was disclosed by officials today in the wake of published reports in Rome newspapers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 31 -- Getulio Vargas completed his first year as the popularly elected President of Brazil today under fire from his opponents over the skyrocketing cost of living while his supporters praised him because prices had not gone even higher.

An old-fashioned fluffy sponge cake -- the last crumbs as delicious as the first slice -- has much to say for itself. The current low price of eggs and a new quick-mix recipe, cutting mixing time to one-third, make this family favorite a delightful and wise dessert choice now.

Most areas of the Soviet economy made substantial progress last year, but bad weather cut the grain crop 3,000,000 tons below that of 1950, analysis of the Soviet Government's 1951 economic report reveals.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP) -- West Germany's bid for a major share of the world's postwar chemical market was reinforced today by the newest company carved from assets of I.G. Farben.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Legal experts were at work in London and Paris today on the relationship that will be established between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European defense community when the latter comes into being.

Eight teachers who refused to say whether they were Communist party members were suspended without pay yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and will face departmental trials soon. Last year, eight other teachers were dismissed after similar hearings.

The Red Cross has contributed 14,000 vials of gamma globulin, a saline solution used to counteract measles, that have been administered by hospitals and private physicians since shortly before the current epidemic began, Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Prompt Government action to create more jobs in Detroit and other Michigan industrial centers was promised today by members of the Federal Distressed Areas Task Force as the group concluded a three-day survey here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Truman denounced Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, today as a pathological character assassin who needed no information to make accusations against others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The motion-picture industry has filed with the Federal Communications Commission a list of witnesses it will call in support of its application for a channel of the radio spectrum to bring televised entertainment to motion-picture theatres.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., unanimously adopted today a resolution inviting back into membership any of its former elements that had renounced the left-wing political ideologies for which they were expelled in 1948.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Settlement of an eleven-day dock workers' strike paralyzing Puerto Rico's principal ports appeared nearer today as the International Longshoremen's Association reduced its wage-increase demands from 35 to 20 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- L. G. Cox, director of technical projects for the Beech-Nut Packing Company, told the special House committee investigating the use of chemicals in food products today that his company had spent $668,000 in the last six years keeping residues of new pesticides out of baby foods and peanut butter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- During the week ended Jan. 30 member bank reserves decreased $647,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The State Crime Commission's preliminary inquiry into conditions on the waterfront has already uncovered sufficient evidence of illicit activity to warrant expansion of its scope and staff, according to Chairman Joseph M. Proskauer. As an indication of its determination to do the best job possible in the state's first all-out attack on waterfront crime the Commission has obtained the volunteer services of Theodore Kiendl, distinguished trial attorney.

An affiliation agreement, bringing the teamwork approach to providing every service needed by the disabled, was signed yesterday by Columbia University, Presbyterian Hospital and the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled in the latter's building at Twenty-third Street and First Avenue.

YONKERS, Jan. 31 -- The six winners of a 1,000,000-lire "Pierce the Iron Curtain" contest were named today by Ambrose P. Salmini, a ship's chandler who advertised the contest in Italian newspapers last fall in a private propaganda war against the Cominform.

YONKERS, Jan. 31 -- For the second successive day the Central National Bank here put the honor system to work by placing bowls of small change in the lobby and inviting its depositors to make their own change. The system succeeded today as it did yesterday.

The stock market found it difficult yesterday to find a firm footing. Prices were alternately higher and lower and, despite a creeping rally in the last hour, the list finished irregularly lower. Gains and losses were magnified at various stages of the session with the composite rate off 0.26 point at the close.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, appeared slated tonight for the post of Price Administrator which Michael V. DiSalle is expected to vacate around Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Truman said today that it was the privilege of a Congressional committee to investigate anyone it wanted to in commenting on the House Judiciary Committee's decision to conduct an inquiry into the Justice Department.

While fulfilling week-end competitive engagements in Milwaukee and Boston, Fred Wilt, Curt Stone and Horace Ashenfelter will be keeping their ears cocked for results of the deliberations of the Olympic track and field committee in Chicago tomorrow.

Despite increased operating expenses and higher taxes, the American Gas and Electric Company's net earnings for 1951 exceeded those of 1950, according to the utility's annual statement, released yesterday. Net earnings for the year were $24,637,194, compared with $24,191,232 in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Truman made a four-and-a-half-hour flying tour of the Ohio Valley's flooded areas today and returned to praise the effectiveness of control projects installed in the drainage basin since the disastrous flood of 1937.

Safety on land, on sea and in the air is so urgent these days that no proposal to advance it should be overlooked. In a letter to the Federal Communications Commission, the Coast Guard and the Maritime Board, the American Radio Association, a marine communications union, urges that portable lifeboat radio transmitters be placed on all United States merchant vessels for use in abandoning ship.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 31 -- Reliable information reaching here indicates that the Chinese Communists may have reduced their forces somewhat in the provinces of Kwangsi and Yunnan, bordering Indo-China and Burma, during the last month or six weeks.

Another labor crisis on the city's nine private bus lines was in the making yesterday. Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., informed the companies by letter that he was "disappointed" and union members were "furious" over a recent recommendation by Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, to put a forty-hour week in effect July 1.
Mrs. Anne S. Hutchins is the only known recipient of a Valentine from the two stone lions that guard the Fifth Avenue entrance of the New York Public Library.

Mayor Impellitteri and Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens were at odds yesterday over the proposal to raise $100,000,000 for the city's 1952-53 budget by imposing a special tax on county real estate.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Legislation aimed to strike the pocketbooks of Communists and fellow travelers and at organizations they support was introduced today by Senator William F. Condon and Assemblyman Malcolm Wilson, Republicans of Westchester.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A small freight rate war was touched off today when the Baltimore and Ohio and the Pennsylvania Railroads served notice they will cut charges on some grain shipments from Buffalo to Philadelphia and Baltimore.

The five local borough offices and several suburban units of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau were swamped yesterday by a record last-day rush to beat the deadline for the renewal of automobile licenses.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Allied planes added 132 cuts in Communist rail lines yesterday to the 13,000 the United States Fifth Air force estimated they had made in five and one-half months of "Operation Strangle." This campaign, which has largely succeeded the ground war, was continued last night and early today by light bombers.

A nation-wide drive by the American Heart Association to raise $8,000,000 to fight heart disease, was officially opened last night in a coast-to-coast broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System from Los Angeles by Bruce Barton, national campaign chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) -- The Senate, having involved itself in a diplomatic tangle over admitting Greece and Turkey to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, asked President Truman today to let it approve the matter all over again.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- With the backing of President Truman, three Democratic Senators asked the Senate today to go on record for early establishment of a European political federation within the North Atlantic community.

The widow of Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, who was killed in a plane crash last month at Elizabeth, N. J., appealed to the public by radio last night to stop blaming the pilot of the aircraft for the tragedy and give their "moral support" to his widow.

Commodity futures markets yesterday were generally under pressure from selling engendered by Korean peace talks. Wool and vegetable oils closed near their lows for the day but late rallies limited losses in most other commodities.

A special panel of the Wage Stabilization Board will resume hearings here today on demands by the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., for a wage rise of 15 cents and a like amount in other benefits.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the Anti-Sales Tax Committee, cited yesterday Federal Reserve Board figures on business trends in this country as proof of his contention that the sales tax was hurting business here. Mr. Hoving, who is president of Bonwit Teller Inc., expressed his views at a press conference held in his offices at the store.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Tighter restrictions on bad-weather landings at Newark Airport were recommended today by the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Although volume continued to decline on the Stock Exchange here today, prices continued to improve in most sections until the industrial shares became dull in the late dealings. Nevertheless, the industrial shares closed with many net gains, reaction not having extended far beyond leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Nine girls and thirty-one boys have been selected in the eleventh annual Science Talent Search among high school seniors on the basis of promise for careers in science. They have been invited here for five days, Feb. 28 through March 3 with expenses paid.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 1 -- United States troops will remain in Japan after the conclusion of the peace treaty as "considerate guests" on a mission of the highest importance to both countries, Dean Rusk, special Presidential envoy, told the Japanese today.

PARIS, Friday, Feb. 1 -- Replying to a United States contention that Associated Press correspondent William N. Oatis had been imprisoned by the Czechoslovak Government for carrying out normal functions of a newspaperman, the Soviet Union charged yesterday that spying was inherent in the accepted American concept of journalism.

Your editorial of Jan. 27 captioned "Pointing Up Point Four" states the categorical answer "Of course we can't" to Senator Lehman's rhetorical question "Can we afford not to do it?" i. e., not to continue our colossal expenditures under Point Four and other foreign - aid programs.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 31 -- State and Federal military officials today reported that they would prefer the shoreline side of the Merritt Parkway as the route of a proposed expressway through Fairfield County to the New York state line.

Three persons connected with a crooked gambling ring that bribed basketball players at the University of Kentucky and Bradley University pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to indictments growing out of the widespread plot. Two others accused as bribers were granted one-week adjournments by Judge Saul S. Streit.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Federal Judge J. Sam Perry denied freedom on a writ of habeas corpus today to Mrs. Irene B. Whetstone, 55-year-old income tax rebel, and sent her back to jail.

The centenary of the birth of the distinguished American artist J. Alden Weir is being celebrated with an exhibition of his work that opens today at the American Academy of Arts and Letters. Weir was a member of the Academy and its Art Committee, headed by Barry Faulkner, has rounded up 113 of his oil paintings, not to mention a generous selection of drawings and etchings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Sales by manufacturers increased 16 per cent in 1951 over 1950, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Agreement to merge Northwest Airlines, Inc., and Capital Airlines, Inc., was announced here last night by the heads of the two companies. Croil Hunter, president of Northwest, and J. H. Carmichael, president of Capital, jointly described the consolidation as providing a new international and domestic line of 26,000 unduplicated route miles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Senate passed today by voice votes two House bills suspending import duties on lead and zinc until March 31, 1953. Both measures had been urged by defense authorities because shortages of the two metals were hampering the mobilization program.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Norwegian sports circles were in a whirl today after the nation's Olympic Committee barred one of its speed skaters from participation in the winter games next month on grounds of war-time collaboration with the Nazis.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 31 -- With the polling for India's first national elections completed but not yet fully counted in all but five Himalayan hill districts, the Congress party, led by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, is well in the lead on a party basis all over the country but has lost a number of provincial leaders and lags slightly behind the combined opposition in the popular vote.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 (UP) -- Eddie Arcaro booted home Reighs Bull in the featured $7,500 County Museum Purse at Santa Anita today to complete a riding triple.

In meting out fines of $12, $24 and $36 to ten firemen found guilty in the Gerard W. Purcell spurious signature case, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet said yesterday that he would "deal more severely with persons who get in trouble in the future."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Nowhere in the world is there a larger and freer press than in the Soviet Union, says Pravda, official organ of the Soviet Communist party, which then proceeds to scold the 4,000 Soviet provincial newspapers and calls on the party to improve their content.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The El Paso (Texas) Natural Gas Company has asked the Federal Power Commission for permission to expand its system's capacity at an estimated cost of $108,882,686 to provide more gas service in New Mexico, Arizona, California and Nevada.

Royal Little, president of Textron Incorporated, announced several changes yesterday in key executive officers in two subsidiary companies. James E. Robinson has been elected president of Textron Puerto Rico and of Textron Mississippi, Inc., to succeed Mr. Little, who will continue as chairman of both subsidiaries.

The late Harry Edwin Heilmann, regarded by many as one of the diamond's least appreciated stars of the past, and Paul Glee Waner, an outstanding hitter, are the latest to move into baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N. Y. They are the sixty-first and sixty-second players to be so honored.
More money will be spent by industry this year on new plant and equipment than ever before.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- President Truman has expressed the view that to try to get along without another tax increase would not be "safe."

Increased vegetable production in winter-growing areas has resulted in generally lower prices this week-end, the Department of Markets announced yesterday. For the first time this winter it reported not a single mark-up at vegetable markets. Price reductions brought costs down from half a penny to a dime on over a dozen items.

ROME, Jan. 31 -- The Syndicate of Dramatic Authors, in a recent resolution, has asked the Government for legislation to protect Italian playwrights. The organization urged that prizes for the best Italian plays be reserved for plays that had been performed at least ten times in a season, including two showings in a city of at least 300,000.

Three armed and masked men held up Max Spelrein and his wife last night as they were entering their fourth-floor apartment at 2110 Westbury Court, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, and robbed the apartment of $200 in cash, as well as furs and jewelry valued at $20,000.

Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia charged here yesterday that President Truman's "socialistic" policies were aiding Communist aims to undermine the American free enterprise system and thus destroy our "best insurance against war and Russian aggression."

New securities offered publicly in January by investment concerns here increased sharply over a year ago. Flotations of bonds were the largest for the month since 1950 and stock offerings since 1946, with the total of stocks nearly four times the amount floated in 1951.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra will sail from New York on April 28 on the Ile de France for its three-week tour of Europe. George E. Judd, the manager, who has returned from a trip abroad to arrange itinerary and programming, announced the plans, which are now in their semi-final stages.

Your editorial entitled "The Abuse of Nationalism" fails to mention that present developments in the Near East and North Africa are the logical outcome of the seeds that we planted in the pronouncements of the Western Powers in the Atlantic Charter and the Charter of the United Nations.

LONDON, Jan. 31--The Conservative Government's program for saving sterling from further devaluation--attacked by the Labor Opposition as "irrelevant, unnecessary and unfair"--was upheld in the House of Commons tonight by a margin of 31 votes.

Five new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Phone Call From a Stranger," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama featuring Bette Davis, Gary Merrill, Shelley Winters, Keenan Wynn and Michael Rennie, is at the Roxy. Jean Negulesco directed and Nunnally Johnson produced from Mr. Johnson's script and a story by I. A. R. Wylie.

New prices for 1952 Ford and Mercury automobiles, based on the recent Office of Price Stabilization regulation permitting retail increases, were announced yesterday by Ralph Horgan, Inc., 1842 Broadway, Ford dealer, and Mezey Motors, Inc., 241 Park Avenue, Mercury dealer.

The program that Helen Lightner sang last night in Town Hall was the compilation of a serious and tasteful musician. In some respects it was a little too ambitious for the singer, but at her best she was able to handle it with finesse and a good measure of vocal beauty.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 -- Stanley Kramer today acknowledged through a spokesman that he had refused an offer made by the Wage Earners Committee of the U. S. A. to cancel his libel action against the organization in exchange for a retraction of its accusation that he was "notorious for his red-slanted, red-starred films."
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Paulette introduces turbans of straw in a diversified collection based on gold tones, black and white, interspersed with dark greens, reds, sapphire blue and violet.

Kooperativa Forbundet, which is now floating an issue of about $19,500,000 of "purchasing power bonds," is not, strictly speaking, a "parent" of the Swedish co-operatives, but rather their "big daughter," explains Dr. Hermann Herz, in a comment on the financing just received here from Sweden.

An American library will be established this fall at the University of Dijon, France, in memory of John Erskine, educator, author and musician. Mr. Erskine, long connected with Columbia Uiversity, died last June 2.

TRENTON, Jan. 31 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll questioned today the adoption of compulsory automobile liability insurance in New Jersey, predicting that general acceptance of the principle eventually would force state governments to enter the insurance field.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Normal economic and social reasons are bringing about a natural dispersal of industry and will continue to do so at an accelerated rate without military pressure.
Elaborate preparations to mark the signing of a Yankee contract by Allie Reynolds yesterday proved in vain. The chief rejected the terms.

The recent proposal of the New York State Board of Regents for daily prayer in the public schools promises to be hurtfully divisive among religious groups while it destructively threatens the basic American doctrine of the separation of church and state. For it is not only an opening prayer that is proposed but also the implementation of this by "specific programs" for "intensifying in the child" certain "religious" attitudes.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- All clubs affiliated with the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs were urged to sponsor an Over Sixty Club in the year ahead by their public welfare chairman, speaking today at the midwinter board meeting at the Gramatan Hotel.

Favorable dividend action was taken yesterday by directors of two oil companies. Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) declared an extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents, both for payment on March 13.

Too many advertising campaigns are planned on the basis of psychological and other studio instead of on conditions in the marketing field and in the stores in which the products are sold. This charge was made yesterday by E. B. Weiss, director of merchandising for the Grey Advertising Agency.

A cost-of-living wage rise, an increase in food allowances and more life insurance will go into effect today for approximately 3,500 men employed aboard New York Harbor tugboats, self-propelled lighters and oil barges.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- A belief that copper would be the only limiting factor in the automobile materials situation in 1953 and a hope that this could be dealt with through more copper imports were voiced today by Ernest R. Breech, executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company.

For housewives whose kitchen duties include considerable canning, the United States Department of Agriculture has announced a new raw pack method for canning meat and vegetable stew. Described as safe, easy and timesaving, the procedure was developed by the department's home canning specialists.

A collection of Interior Trend Associates' decorating fabrics, which for a year have been available in Chicago, may now be found at Reilly-Wolff Associates, 50 East Thirty-fourth Street. The materials, which may be ordered through decorators, come with designs hand printed in various colors on two fabrics.
The Army Nurse Corps had a small party at the Vanderbilt Hotel yesterday for the following reasons:

MONTREAL, Jan. 31 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard returned to action after an absence of five games and scored a third-period goal which gave the Montreal Canadiens a 1-0 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers tonight at the Forum.

Explaining the contradictory public views about welfare, Charlotte Towle, a leading social work educator, declared yesterday that society had "mixed feelings" of "conscience" and "fear" about social work.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- A Democratic program to improve living conditions on farms was announced today by Senator Elmer F. Quinn and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, minority leaders of the Legislature.

HONG KONG, Jan. 30 -- Official details of plans for the establishment of a new All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce became available here today as the Peiping Government continued to call on Red China's harassed middle class to wash away its "capitalist sins" by the process of individual confession and mutual accusation.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31--West Germany has asked the Western Big Three ministers to insure conditions for a free election in the Saar this autumn as the first step toward settling the future of the territory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- In the speech of Prime Minister Churchill to Congress on Jan. 18 three passages impressed some British and Americans in Washington at the time as rather lacking in his usual deftness of phrase and soundness of judgment, and likely, therefore, to arouse criticism here and apprehension at home.

Lillian Gish came on stage yesterday in the role of canine health adviser and told ninety-eight women and four men members of the New York Women's League for Animals how they might contribute to the longevity and health of their dogs.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh left by air for Kenya Colony in East Africa today on the first stage of a five-month visit to the Dominions of Ceylon, Australia and New Zealand.

To get the best skiing this weekend, metropolitan enthusiasts will have to go to Vermont, New Hampshire and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada. The Poconos of Pennsylvania, the Berkshires of western Massachusetts, the Catskills and such near-by points as Bear Mountain and Fahnestock have little to offer but base.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Government today offered for sale -- to American citiens only -- all of the capital stock of the Schering Corporation, a concern with assets of more than $14,000,000 which manufactures pharmaceutical products at Bloomfield, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The rescheduling of armament production, including aircraft, will enable the return of about 35,000,000 pounds of aluminum to the Defense Production Administration in the second quarter of this year, according to authoritative estimates made today.

IN Peking in the Nineteen Thirties George Kates experienced "the most rewarding adventure of my life" and enjoyed "riches of life surpassing anything I had elsewhere known." His book about the seven good years he spent there from 1933 until 1940 is called "The Years That Were Fat." It is another book about China by an American.

Senator McMahon's Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, which has just begun an inquiry into the causes that permitted some workers on the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site to draw triple wages and receive pay for as much as 206 hours a week, has a difficult but not impossible task before it if, as the Senator says, it is to "explore the situation thoroughly and completely."

Operations of the Ohio Oil Company last year resulted in a net income of $41,600,000 after taxes and all charges, according to the preliminary annual statement issued yesterday by J. C. Donnell 2d, president.

There is a striking -- and rather heartening -- agreement that Egypt wants and should receive satisfaction for her "national aspirations." Foreign Secretary Eden first used the phrase in the House of Commons on Monday. Yesterday a Foreign Office spokesman in Cairo, and some newspapers there, said the nation was seeking a settlement that would "satisfy Egypt's national aspirations."

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Miss Kathy McKinnon of Lake Worth, Fla., and Mrs. H. V. Stone of Ware Shoals, S. C., scored an upset victory over the co-favorites in the opening round of the seventh annual women's four-ball golf tournament today.

Further studies on the nature of positronium, a recently discovered new element composed of a positive and a negative electron, were described yesterday at the annual New York meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.

SEATTLE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Immigration officers said today that they had stopped Paul Robeson, singer, and Vincent William Hallinan, an attorney for Harry Bridges, labor leader, from crossing the border into Canada.
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- The United Nations Security Council today asked Dr. Frank Graham to make another on-the-spot attempt to end the Indian-Pakistani controversy over the political future of Kashmir.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie said today the ferment in the Middle East, Asia and Africa could be settled only by respect for law and order and a recognition of legitimate national aspirations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Government officials and members of Congress have been receiving lessons this week in the techniques of thwarting Communists from Jean-Paul David, a French expert in the field.

Recommendations that weather minimums at Newark Airport be raised to 500 feet ceiling and one mile visibility were described as "just plain stupid" yesterday by more than a dozen airline pilots and representatives of the Air Lines Pilot Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Jan. 26, declined 14 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by cities follow in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

A Chicago manufacturer who is also an art collector acquired several valuable specimens of ancient Egyptian art at auction yesterday by reliance upon a perusal of the catalogue and by a novel method of bidding.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Extension of the state's unemployment insurance law to make 500,000 more wage earners eligible for benefits when they are out of work was unanimously recommended to the Legislature today by the Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Dick Savitt bade farewell to Australia today after adding new sting to the bitterness that has developed between him and the Australian tennis public.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat easier yesterday and closed 3 points higher to 17 points lower than on Wednesday.

An overflow audience of 1,800 persons, including Vice President Alben W. Barkley, filled the ballroom of the Commodore Hotel last night in tribute to Eddie Cantor on the occasion of his sixtieth birthday and in recognition of his activities in behalf of Israel.

Dr. C. W. Mayo, surgeon at the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., has been elected a director of Mutual of Omaha, the world's largest exclusive health and accident insurance company, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Did Prime Minister Churchill really make any new decisions in Washington on British policy toward the war in Korea?

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 -- Steve Nelson, western Pennsylvania Communist leader, was found guilty today on twelve counts of violating the state's Anti-Sedition Act of 1939. The jury deliberated for twenty-one hours in Allegheny County Criminal Court.

In a "revolutionary" approach to easing commercial traffic congestion around the Chelsea docks, Eleventh Avenue under the West Side Highway between Twenty-second and Thirteenth Streets will be restricted to one-way southbound operation within two weeks.
BUFFALO, Mo., Jan. 31 (AP) -- A Missouri farm couple is thinking about buying a house in town and taking a trip after receiving a check for $100,000.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 -- A shortage of money for investment purposes may block efforts to increase West German production over the present levels and to make Ruhr industries the bulwark of the Western defense economy, Allied and German experts disclosed today.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,146, for Thursday's operations:

New issues of public utility and railroad securities valued at more than $19,000,000 will be offered to investors today, in line with the award of underwriting contracts to banking syndicates at competitive bidding. The offerings are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- An Internal Revenue official said today that the new Federal gambling tax had choked off 90 per cent of the country's illegal gambling business, which has been estimated at $20,000,000 a year.

THE annual Valentine fox hunt at Nags Head, on the North Carolina Outer Banks, a three-day event during which hounds are-followed by jeep, beach buggy and even shank's mare, will get howling on Feb. 14. The advance reservations indicate that there will be a reccord turn-out for the big run.
