The Columbia Broadcasting System, which for a couple of years has envied the number of television stations owned by the National Broadcasting Company, has elected to achieve video parity in a rather odd way. It has hired the first electronic gigolo, a weary wolf, played by Renzo Cesana.
OTTAWA, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press) -- A total of 286,600,000 bushels of Prairie wheat, oats, barley and flaxseed remained to be harvested on Dec. 31, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Leaders in finance, philanthropy and international relations were among the 600 persons who attended a funeral service yesterday for Miss Anne Morgan, philanthropist, at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- William M. Boyle Jr., former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Guy George Gabrielson, present head of the Republican country-wide organi zation, were accused by the Senate permanent investigating subcommittee today of conduct in Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan matters that invited ugly charges.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 31 -- Sir Hubert Rance, the Governor of Trinidad, has refused to hand the ketch Argosy back to Capt. George Black (Dod) Orsborne, who pleaded guilty in court recently to a charge of landing arms without permission, was fined $500 and was ordered to forfeit the ketch.

After a delay of nearly a year the question of a unified direction of the navies of the North Atlantic alliance has been settled with the appointment of Admiral McCormick, commander of the United States Atlantic Fleet, as Supreme Allied Commander of the Atlantic.

" My Life's History," the autobiography of Grandma Moses, will be published Feb. 27 by Harper. The author, whose full name is Anna Mary Robertson Moses, describes her life as girl, wife, mother, grandmother and painter, covering ninety-one years of American life.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that the Russians should be able to estimate this country's atomic bomb stockpile within 15 per cent.

Supplies of scientific instruments and laboratory apparatus are low and manufacturers' stocks of raw materials are nearly gone, according to reports just received by the Scientific Apparatus Makers Association, Chicago. The group is asking customers to apply priority ratings to all orders.
CUBA, N. Y., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Three children and their grandfather died today when their home was leveled by fire as firemen from ten communities were fighting another blaze only three miles away.

VIENNA, Jan. 31 -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber has scheduled a radio speech for Saturday intended to prepare the Austrian people for a new and stronger line that Austria is prepared to take to procure her freedom.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council announced here yesterday that it is protesting formally the act taken last year by the Saarland to require American and foreign holders of Saar bonds to deposit them for validation by July 11, 1952, under penalty of having the bonds declared invalid.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- President Truman's request that his name be withdrawn from the New Hampshire primary posed a problem for California Democratic leaders who are scheduled to meet this week-end in Los Angeles.

Larger jet commercial airliners than the public is now thinking of, bigger turbo-propeller transports and multi-engine helicopters were predicted for the future yesterday by Peter Masefield, chief executive of British European Airways.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Few times if ever has the refugee problem haunted this weary center more than it does today. Economically, East German refugees alone, of whom there are more than 100,000 here, now drain the equivalent of $56,000 daily from the hard pressed city government.
ROME, Jan. 31 -- Pope Pius XII today urged management and labor to be guided by "human sentiments" in their mutual relations and to work together in harmony for the common welfare of mankind.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis and Jimmy Clark of Laguna Beach, Calif, tied for the lead at the end of the first round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament today. Both shot five-under-par 65's.

Long-haul truck drivers in thirteen Southern and Midwestern states went on strike for higher wages at 12:01 A. M. today and Southern carriers slapped embargoes on freight shipments to prevent spoilage, The United Press reported.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Herbert M. Woolf of Kansas City is a man who likes to take a little flutter on his Woolford Farm race horses. Today he must have made a couple of perfectly delightful visits to the Hialeah mutuel windows.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 31 -- St. Francis Hospital, a Roman Catholic institution, has demanded that seven Poughkeepsie physicians sever their connections with the Dutchess County League of the Planned Parenthood Association or resign from the hospital's medical staff.

City assessors have placed an aggregate valuation of $19,483,891,881 on taxable realty in New York for the next fiscal year, carrying the official estimate of the worth of privately owned properties here back near the record high mark.

Net income of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the fourth quarter of 1951 established a record for the company, but the full year's earnings dropped 15 per cent below the record profits earned in 1950, despite a 25 per cent gain in the volume of business last year, E. G. Grace, chairman, reported yesterday.

For nearly half a century the Mills School of New York has been recognized among the outstanding institutions in the preparation of young women as teachers for nursery, kindergarten and primary grades. The recent action of the State Board of Regents elevating Mills to college status is a fitting tribute to the school's unique place in teacher education.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month expanded to the largest volume since October, but was the smallest for any January since 1949. The turnover was above the million-share mark in every full day's session, the largest of which was 1,918,560 shares on Jan. 22.

Larger jet commercial airliners than the public is now thinking of, bigger turbo-propeller transports and multi-engine helicopters were predicted for the future yesterday by Peter Masefield, chief executive of British European Airways.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Few times if ever has the refugee problem haunted this weary center more than it does today. Economically, East German refugees alone, of whom there are more than 100,000 here, now drain the equivalent of $56,000 daily from the hard pressed city government.

A moderate recovery was staged by the stock market yesterday. But the marked contraction in business and high selectivity which characterized the gains made it not too convincing. Brokers were still divided as to the immediate course of the market.
The land of opportunity is today the goal of millions of people in Europe and Asia, but it also carries with it a certain amount of bewilderment and confusion.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Amateur Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, barely missed equaling the P. G. A. scoring record today as he tied with Skee Riegel, Tulsa, Okla., at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament. Both have eight-under-par 132s for the thirty-six holes.

Three Harlem thieves who took $114,000 in jewels and $1,000 in cash late Wednesday forenoon from Mrs. Leon J. Livingston in her ten-room duplex on the ninth and tenth floors at 812 Park Avenue were arrested yesterday. Most of the loot was recovered.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1 -- With the return of Adolfo Ruiz Cortinez, Government candidate, to the capital yesterday after an intensive tour of the southern states, the first phase of the Presidential election campaign has ended.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Richard D. Searles, Under Secretary of the United States Department of the Interior, called today for "close cooperation between Government and industry" to enable the nation to meet current defense demands and emerge still stronger basically.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- The publication here today of a letter from Francis W. White, president of the American Woolen Company, to Emil Rieve, head of the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., setting forth the basis on which the company proposed to negotiate for new contracts, brought swift union reaction.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 1(AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta and Miss Barbara Romack of Sacramento, breezed through the second round of the women's international four-ball golf tournament at Orange Brook today.

CAIRO, Feb. 1 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha believes that negotiation with Britain is the "only normal way to attain Egypt's aims" and that the only question now is on what basis to open the talks, it was announced tonight.

As the result of a "drastic" change in the construction of street lamp-posts, dark and semi-dark streets in the city will soon have their full complement of illumination, Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, disclosed yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in January declined in the aggregate to 18 per cent below abnormal scare-buying peaks of the same month last year, according to a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Drastic reductions of French imports, similar to and partly in consequence of British cuts in overseas buying, are imminent, according to officials here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Jack L. Warner, happily counting the profits coming in from "A Streetcar Named Desire," has worked out another picture deal with the writing-directing combination of Tennessee Williams and Elia Kazan.

Victory in the 200-yard relay gave Andrew Jackson High School the team title in the annual P. S. A. L. indoor swimming championships at the Columbia University pool last night. The team finished with 21 points to 19 for Evander Childs, the runner-up.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- An unexplained but striking change has been made in the Byelorussian flag, including an alteration in coloring that will make it easily distinguishable from the customary Soviet banner.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Joe Dobson denied today he had signed his 1952 contract to pitch for the White Sox, "despite what the club announced the other day."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Tilden H. Edwards, presiding at a Coast Guard hearing, refused to dismiss charges today against eight messmen accused of misconduct for abstaining from work for several days on the freighter Alaskan Bear during a voyage to the Middle East last year.

Four showings of sculpture are among the numerous exhibitions of art this week. Three members of the group at the Sculpture Center are showing new work at that gallery and Charles Stevens makes a first one-man appearance at the Ganso Gallery.

Production of canned meats has increased 500 per cent in the last fifteen years, according to the American Meat Institute. Final figures on the 1951 production showed a total of 1,500,000,000 pounds, or 18 per cent more than in 1950.

A shortage of about $24,000 from ticket sales during the 1951 season of the Brooklyn Dodgers Baseball Club was reported on Tuesday by Walter O'Malley, club president, to the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, it was learned last night.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- Four non-Catholic physicians on the staff of a Roman Catholic hospital here declared today that they would not resign from the Dutchess County League for Planned Parenthood in the face of a demand from hospital authorities.

The leadership that the nation needs can be provided through the ability of the Young Men's Christian Association to overcome "the poor attitudes and careless habits" in the present generation, Herbert H. Schwamb, vice president of the J. C. Penney Company, declared yesterday.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 1 -- Describing the organized military reserve systems of the North Atlantic pact countries as "little more than a skeleton," General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, called today for the "muscles and sinews" needed to give Western defense an efficient readiness.

Prof. Enrico Fermi, Nobel Prize winner in physics and one of the principal architects of the atomic bomb, described yesterday before a large gathering of physicists and physics teachers at Columbia University his latest explorations on the nature of the cosmic forces within the hearts of atoms.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- A wide field of agreement was declared to have been reached by French authorities and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in talks today that centered mostly upon questions for discussion by the Western Big Three soon in London and by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization council when it meets in Lisbon.

Leaders of the perishable foods industry in the city foresaw yesterday the industry's early exodus to New Jersey unless Mayor Impellitteri's proposed increase in the gross business tax from one-fifth of 1 per cent to one-half of 1 per cent is dropped immediately.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Nationalist China won from the United Nations General Assembly today a softened version of the condemnation of the Soviet Union that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Government has been trying for three years to get.

CAIRO, Feb. 1 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha today put the finishing touches upon his "national front." In its present form this is a committee that will advise the government mainly upon the three important issues confronting Egyptian foreign policy today -- evacuation of the British forces from the Canal Zone, unification of the Nile Valley and the projected Middle Eastern defense system.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 1 -- Supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, who won the Republican primary Jan. 15 in New Orleans, went to court today to prevent backers of Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio from denying them the fruits of victory.
The following is a round-up of new products that might be of use in the home.

Margaret Scoggin, librarian, teacher and editor, has been named winner of the 1952 Constance Lindsay Skinner Award. The award, given annually by the Women's National Book Association to a woman for outstanding service in the book world, will be presented to Miss Scoggin on Feb. 15 at a dinner at the Town Hall Club.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Tiger Lillet, an amber-colored drink, today made John Jones, thirty-seven-year-old London bartender, the world's champion cocktail mixer.

ROME, Feb. 1 -- The Chamber of Deputies, which twice in the last seven days defeated the Government of Premier Alcide De Gasperi by slim margins, voted its confidence in it this evening by 285 to 233, with three abstentions.

Newbold Morris, who was named yesterday by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath to head the investigation of corruption in Government, was president of the City Council in the La Guardia Administrations. He has been active in New York politics for twenty years as a Republican often allied with Liberal, Fusion and Independent forces.
Army aviation, the prodigy of the armed services, is growing up fast.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Two of the best indoor performances of the year -- in the mile run and the pole vault -- spiced the second annual Milwaukee Journal Games tonight.

Joseph Molfetto has purchased forty-one lots in the Flatbuch section of Brooklyn in a transaction negotiated by the Bulkley A. Horton Company, broker. He bought a plot 456 by 90 feet at the southwest corner of Feniman's Street and Brooklyn Avenue from the Substantial Homes Company, and an adjoining interior plot of ten lots from the Charles Bennett Estate.

A FEW weeks ago we devoted several columns to a discussion of the types, trajectories, velocities and so-called "killing power" or energies of several of the popular big game calibers, and since then have received a number of letters calling attention to the omission of the small caliber, high velocity weapons from the discussion.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Union is pressing forward with what appears to be its greatest post-war effort to convince nations of the West, and in particular Britain, that their present ties with the United States constitute an economic cancer that will prove fatal unless large-scale East-West trade is restored.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Hinting at new developments in the production of atomic implements of war, Gordon Dean, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said here today that "there is a proud and encouraging story" in the Los Alamos scientific laboratory, the commission's weapons research center in New Mexico.

Net sales of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company last year reached a new high of $489,305,162, substantially exceeding the previous peak of $409,898,010 made in 1950, but earnings declined $9,972,202, according to the preliminary annual statement issued yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A Government spokesman denied today that Iran had decided to close all foreign cultural centers outside Teheran. He said the shutdown orders issued yesterday to United States, British and Soviet information offices were a result of a "wrong handling by local authorities."

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Fifteen Arab, Asian and African members of the United Nations charged today that French military intervention in Tunisia and the arrest of local political leaders there had constituted "a threat to international peace and security."

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1 -- Dismissing reports that Argentina's economic situation was perilous as "political maneuverings," President Juan D. Peron declared yesterday that the republic was financially sound, but faced a mild austerity program.

The editorial in THE TIMES of Jan. 27 "A Broader Scholarship Plan" wisely asks support and commendation of the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry and Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, as well as of other industry-union educational schemes, for the parts they are playing in recognizing that "knowledge in a complex world is the key to improving the lot of the individual and of society."

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A Federal District Court judge dismissed today indictments charging ten pro-Truman Democrats with conspiring to sell Federal patronage, but overruled motions to dismiss indictments charging four with actually selling Federal jobs in Mississippi.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 1 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur were entered in the Minnesota Republican Presidential primary today, but the former Pacific commander was expected to withdraw.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday extended by about two weeks the time limit at the disposal of Jersey Joe Walcott before he must enter into articles of agreement for the defense of his world heavyweight title against the ex-champion, Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A bill to revise and clarify the British law of libel and slander, which is one of the most straitlaced in the world, was approved on its second reading in Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A diplomatic authority expressed as his "personal opinion" today the view that the prudence and historical sense of Joseph Stalin was the main bar to the initiation of an all-out war by the Soviet Union.

The Bank of New York Fifth Avenue Bank, as trustee for the estate of A. P. Winthrop, sold the four-story dwelling at 256 West Seventy-fifth Street, near the southeast corner of West End Avenue, to an investing client of Irving Shapiro, attorney.

A new type of food promotion, involving three different food products, will open March 1 under the auspices of the National Macaroni Institute. Described in all advertising and merchandising materials by individual manufacturers as the Winner Dinner Combination, the unbranded product promotion will feature macaroni, Blue Lake green beans and canned tuna.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 26 points higher to 23 lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Conflicting views on the proposal to restrict new one-family dwellings built this year to a maximum floor space of 1,500 square feet, delayed issuance of such an order by the National Production Authority tonight.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Immediate favorable action on President Truman's recommendation for increased Federal revenue was demanded of Congress today by the American Federation of Labor.

In the last thirteen years, 72-year-old Joseph Walter Martin says he has played bit parts in 500 motion pictures and at times has worked as an interpreter. But the Federal Bureau of Investigation is concerned with only the last four years, in which, it says, Martin cashed forged checks over the country at the rate of $1,000 a week.

Plans have been completed for the showing in suburban areas of a series of foreign-made films heretofore restricted to art theatres in New York, it was announced yesterday by the Walter Reade Theatres, owners of the Carlton in Red Bank, N. J., and the Para mount in Plainfield, N. J., where the initial screenings will take place beginning on Feb. 13 and continuing on successive Wednesdays.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 1 -- Paul Ginsberg, national commander of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, said today that he would be opposed to sending United States land forces to Indo-China should the Chinese Communists invade the area.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- The arrival in Paris of William H. Draper Jr. as United States special representative in Europe and deputy administrator of M. S. A. highlights the transition from the Economic Cooperation Administration to the Mutual Security Agency as the organ of American aid. E. C. A., for four years the best-known initials in Europe, vanished as quietly from the scene as the fadeout in a movie screen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Paul Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, told a Senate Banking subcommittee today that "it would be a catastrophe for the nation" if the Federal Reserve Board should succumb to the "easy-money" policy of the Treasury Department in managing the public debt.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The stock markets here remained buoyant today despite further contraction of business before the week-end. In fact, industrial prices, after wavering during the morning, resumed their advance in the afternoon and closed firm, with tramp shipping shares doing particularly well.
United Air Lines announced yesterday sale of $10,000,000 of debentures to two insurance companies to help finance purchase of equipment.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The bleak, snow-mantled Korean battlefront was so quiet yesterday that the Eighth Army took note of an attack by thirteen Reds on the eastern front. Seven of the Communists were killed by United Nations troops as the enemy tried a nuisance raid under the crags of Heartbreak Ridge, in the Mundung area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- John Carter Vincent of the State Department, turning on his Senate interrogators for the first time in three days of cross-examination, accused them today of deliberate unfairness.

Soviet Russia has in effect served notice that it regards all American correspondents working abroad as spies who may face death for reporting on "political, economic and military matters" in countries behind the Iron Curtain. This bald threat was voiced before the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly by Soviet delegate Pavlov.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 1 -- Bartenders here had a half-holiday today as a result of a short-lived strike called by Local 488, Bartenders and Hotel Workers Union, A.F.L., against 550 taverns in this city and Bayonne.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh filled a heavy program of engagements today in the heat of a Kenya summer -- only twenty-four hours after leaving London's bitter cold.

DENVER, Feb. 1 -- Asserting that Government price-fixing has been responsible for the shortage of lead and zinc, Felix E. Wormser, vice president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, recommended here today that price controls be removed from the two metals.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Ohio River was stationary here tonight at 56.8 feet, which is about five feet over flood stage. A crest will not be declared officially, however, the Weather Bureau said, until the water begins to subside.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- A spokesman for New York religious groups told the Supreme Court today that parents feared the public schools were pushing religion into the "backwaters of life."
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A grubby little painting, recently cleaned and found to be by Pieter Breughel, was sold today at Christie's, London art dealers, for $31,000.
A strike of 20,000 long-haul truck drivers in fifteen Southern and Midwestern states, which began at midnight Thursday showed every indication of a speedy end yesterday.
AMANA, Iowa, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Stockholders of the ninety-eight-year-old Amana Society voted unanimously today to continue their corporate life as a capitalistic group for twenty more years.

Trust investments under current conditions will be the major consideration of banking executives at the Midwinter Trust Conference of the American Bankers Association here on Monday. Approximately 1,800 trust executives from all sections of the country are scheduled to attend the three-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -The Senate Agriculture Committee announced plans today for a detailed investigation of private warehouses where up to $7,000,00 worth of Government-owned grain was reported to have disappeared

This day, Feb. 2, 1952, New York enters upon its 300th year as an incorporated municipality. Giovanni Da Verrazeno, the Florentine navigator, is said to have sailed into the harbor in 1524. Henry Hudson came along in 1609. But the settlement of New Amsterdam dates from 1626 or somewhat earlier, depending on definition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia and head of the House Armed Services Committee, advanced a new plan today to start a "real" Universal Military Training program side by side with the draft in a few months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Legal arguments marked a Federal Trade Commission hearing today on charges that three large soap companies engage in unlawful discrimination in their sales.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Kerngold Eising changed its name to Korngold Co. yesterday.
BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 1 (UP) -- The United States Olympic hockey team defeated the Swiss team, 4 to 3, today in an exhibition game at Margarethen Rink.

Harassed camp directors, recovering from the headaches of last season and not yet concerned with the 1952 crop, were relieved to learn yesterday that there can be no way of determining what is normal behavior for a boy or girl in camp.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Negotiations to end the thirteen-day-old dock strike here recessed tonight without agreement.

Dr. Gilbert Grosvenor, president of the National Geographic Society, has won the Morse Medal of the American Geographical Society for his work in "spreading the awareness of the practical value of geography," it was announced yesterday.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 2 -- Communist delegates at Panmunjom negotiating for a truce in Korea proposed yesterday severe limitations on inspection behind the lines during the armistice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- It appeared tonight that the almost perennial. Administration drive to get Congress to approve full statehood for the Territories of Alaska and Hawaii was headed for trouble again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -Following is the text of today's announcement by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath concerning the appointment of a special assistant to conduct the Government's "clean-up" program:
David Schwartz has been appointed general manager of the retail fashion store division of Spiegel, Inc., Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -Newbold Morris, President Truman's new broom" for the Government clean-up campaign, has a role in a Senate investigation of a "get-rich-quick" deal in surplus Government oil tankers.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad said today it would ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to stop the New York Central from cutting its rates on export grain shipments.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today he did not have tim eto sue President Truman for calling him pathological character assassin.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 1 -- The severe repressive measures taken by the French against the nationalists in this protectorate have angered Tunisian officials and have sharply reduced the chances of conciliation in the current dispute over Tunisian demands for internal autonomy.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 -- German faith that France genuinely desires a partnership for the defense of Europe has been shaken by French actions in the Saar, Chancellor Adenauer declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Government plans for the expansion of nickel supplies envisage a flow of 132,000 short tons from foreign and domestic production by 1954, the Defense Production Administration disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Newbold Morris, New York attorney and former President of the New York City Council, accepted today the task of directing President Truman's program for cleaning out corruption in the Federal Government.

Today is "groundhog" day. Legend and tradition say that on this day the groundhog -- or Marmota monax if you are meeting him formally and for the first time -- crawls out from his winter burrow, looks about him, and if he sees his shadow decides that spring is still six weeks off.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) -- It will be a heavily favored Counterpoint against the field tomorrow when nine 4-year-old thoroughbreds compete in the Santa Anita Maturity, the world's richeset horse race with a gross value of $183,750.

Turbo-propeller aircraft, which some American plane builders and airline operators consider the intermediate step between the piston-engine plane and the turbo jet, are five to ten years away, in the opinion of experts at the twentieth annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences in the Astor Hotel.

The Interstate Sanitation Commission, a tri-state agency regulating pollution in local coastal waters, indicated yesterday it would study the feasibility of dealing with smoke control and air pollution if requested by legislative officials of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

The death of Anne Morgan completes a life of such large and unusual service as to command like remembrance. Born to vast wealth and social pre-eminence at a time when her compeers gave little or no thought to the condition of human beings outside the golden curtain of their self-centered pleasures, she, while yet a young girl, opened her heart, her hands and her purse to the needs of others less favored.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- A House subcommittee will begin hearings next week on complaints that builders have been allowed to sell defective housing to veterans and others under Government-insured mortgages.
CAIRO, Feb. 1 -- Egypt's new Government appears to have come awake to the danger inherent in the discontent of the poverty-ridden Oriental masses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Bruce K. Brown, Deputy Petroleum Administrator for Defense, said today that estimates indicated there would be a world-wide shortage of bunker, or No. 6 residual fuel oil, in the first half of this year of about 150,000 barrels a day. He said some persons put the estimate as high as 175,000 barrels daily.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The temporary State Commission to Study Federally-aided Welfare Programs recommended today an amendment to the Federal Social Security Act that would prevent the withholding of Federal aid from states in the absence of a court order.
Sunlight broke through an over-cast sky to bring a brief interval of warmth yesterday for the cornerstone-laying ceremonies at Grace Church School, 84 Fourth Avenue.

The Army Nurse Corps will take advantage of the celebration today of the fifty-first anniversary of its founding to place additional emphasis on the current campaign to recruit 2,000 new members. The quotas are not yet filled and there is still opportunity for properly qualified persons to be admitted.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- A Soviet resolution that in effect called for en bloc admission of fourteen applicants for membership in the United Nations, including five Communist countries, failed of adoption by the General Assembly today as a result of strenuous United States opposition.

A commuter on the Harlem Division of the New York Central Railroad contended yesterday that its patrons should be exempted from fare increases the company is seeking and asserted that the division was actually operated as a separate railroad.
HAMBURG, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Oil strikes north and south of the German-Danish border have raised geologists' hopes that the North Sea coast still carries rich deposits.

A bakers' strike early yesterday morning closed 250 neighborhood bakeries after wage negotiations had failed to replace the contract that had expired at midnight. One hundred other shops in this class signed new contracts, however, and remained open.

Much contemporary table glassware from Europe now available in shops here depends almost entirely on form for its interest although some shows evidence of restrained ornamentation. Germany, Holland, Sweden and France are among the countries from which recent shipments of the glass have arrived for use on American tables.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Jacques Heim inaugurates his Paris openings with the low waistline of the 1920's running straight through his collection. Sometimes it is merely indicated by a low back, belt or, in the case of frocks, by a long fitted sweater bodice terminating in a fold or drapery about the hips.
Realty groups offered varied comments yesterday concerning the Tax Commission's valuation of taxable realty in New York for the next fiscal year, which was increased tentatively to $19,483,891,881.
A blind approach "to our criminal problem is the crime of New York City," John M. Murtagh, Chief City Magistrate, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer declared today that the question of ethics in Government could not be solved by the creation of agencies or commissions and that "a certain sense of propriety should govern Congressional investigations just as it should govern the actions of administrative officials."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 1 -- Indonesia's drive to win a foothold in Dutch New Guinea by renewed negotiation ran into a stone wall today when the Netherlands refused even to discuss any plan that would involve yielding of authority over the last remnant of her colonial empire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) -- Two 17-year-old youths have confessed stealing $33,750 in jewels from the 23-year-old daughter of former Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy in the belief that they were only costume jewelry, the police said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A Dewey Administration leader cautioned the Board of Trustees of the State University today against "wrecking" the development of the University with "super-charged ambition."
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The California Fruit Growers Exchange, citrus marketing cooperative, was sued for $2,400,000 damages under the anti-trust laws today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 1 -- A reduction of expenses and a general tightening of administrative procedures in the overseas airbase construction program was indicated today by William Huggins, newly named United States Assistant Secretary of Air for materiel, procurement and overseas aid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Foes of increased tariffs and restrictive quotas on tuna imports asserted today that the domestic tuna industry was seeking a monopoly. The assertion was made by Burt Nesow, representing the B. N. Trading Co., New York importers, before the U. S. Tariff Commission.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Conservative Government's new bill imposing charges for the National Health Service was published today.

Coley Wallace, 197, Harlem, knocked out Aaron Wilson, 192, Birmingham, in the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. It was Wallace's fifteenth victory in sixteen bouts. The crowd was 3,681.
A new Bruennhilde, one with a rich, clear and dramatic voice, was born on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

Retail sales volume here this week fell 4 per cent below that of the comparable week of 1951, trade observers estimated yesterday. During the week last year adverse weather brought stores' volume well below the highs that prevailed throughout January, 1951.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 1 -- A Department of Interior investigation into Indian timber sales was under way here today after The (Portland) Oregonian, in a week-long series of articles, had charged that Indian wards of the Government had been short-changed more than $120,000 in sales approved by the Portland area office of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
Theodore Belzner is just ending twenty-eight years as a high-level catwalker.

At knife's point a hold-up man took a $6,000 diamond ring, a wedding ring and $10 from Mrs. Morris Lewittes in the self-service elevator of 585 West End Avenue, near Eighty-eighth Street, shortly after 11 A. M. yesterday and escaped.

To meet the demands made by impending changes in social work education, teachers in schools of social work will have to re-examine their functions, Grace L. Coyle, professor in the School of Applied Social Sciences, Western Reserve University, declared yesterday.

In your editorial "Constructive Dock Report" of Jan. 23 you mentioned that the Board of Inquiry named by Commissioner Corsi found that one trade union local "which collects $25,000 a year in dues failed to have a bank account for the last sixteen years." This is a shocking but, of course, extreme case.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1 -- The National Lutheran Council today appealed to President Truman "not to impair national unity" by precipitating the issue involved in the proposal to establish a United States Embassay at the Vatican.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade had several sinking spells today, with further long liquidation in evidence, but buying appeared to broaden on the declines, with brisk rallies at times. Fluctuations were of the choppy order, with some buying by export interests in both wheat and corn, while actual export sales reported were of sufficient volume to check selling.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- The artist and what his relationship to industry can and should be was discussed here last night by the Institute of Contemporary Art. The discussion was launched by Dr. Walter Gropius, founder in 1919 of the Bauhaus, a forward-looking and experimental German school of design, and now professor of architecture at Harvard University's School of Design.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- The suspension of several "unprofitable" week-end trains on the Jersey City-Butler runs of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad was sanctioned today by the State Public Utility Commission. Schedule changes are effective March 1.

Newbold Morris shows his sense of a citizen's responsibility by accepting appointment as a special assistant to Attorney General McGrath to investigate "misconduct by employes of the Federal Government" and to "make recommendations to strengthen the integrity and efficiency of the entire administration of governmental functions."

The Cunard liner Britannic, which left Pier 90, North River, yesterday on a sixty-six-day Mediterranean cruise, was delayed three hours last night when an injured passenger was removed in Gravesend Bay and sent back to a hospital.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 1 -- The Army Counter-Intelligence Corps and the Federal Bureau of Investigation moved swiftly today to seize classified World War II papers after a weekly newspaper reported that two business men had found them in a war surplus Army field safe.

Bond men never die. They just make rumpus. Anyway, that's the report from the St. Regis Hotel after the annual meeting yesterday of the New York Chapter of "Kappa Beta Phi," the fun auxiliary of the Bond Club of New York. At yesterday's affair William G. Laemmel, vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, succeeded Wickliffe Shreve of Hayden, Stone Co. as "Grand Swipe."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- J. P. Shields, Grand Chief Engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, announced here today that strike ballots had been sent to some 60,000 active members of the brotherhood on all railroads in the United States.

Allie Reynolds put in another pleasant afternoon lolling around in the Yankees' Fifth Avenue office yesterday still firmly saying "no" to General Manager George M. Weiss' latest salary terms for 1952.
The career and salary plan for municipal workers prepared by Griffenhagen Associates, consultants, continued under sharp criticism yesterday from unions representing city employes.

A greater volume of Government procurement will be channeled soon to small business by field directors of the Small Defense Plants Administartion, according to Telford Taylor, administrator of the S. D. P. A. He was interviewed at a conference marking the installation of Casper H. Citron as regional director for New York and New Jersey in new offices at 512 Fifth Avenue.

Jaywalking, long a habit and a form of irrational entertainment for most New Yorkers, has now been officially branded the danger that it obviously is. T. T. Wiley, Acting Traffic Commissioner of New York, and Geoffrey Grimes, chief of the Road Research Laboratory of London, agreed in Washington the other day that their respective cities had costly and unsolved problems created by pedestrians refusing to obey the obvious rules of street-crossing safety.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 1 -- A net grand list of $255,313,869 was announced today by Assessor Fred W. Dawless after the Board of Tax Review had completed work on more than 1,500 property assessment appeals. The 1951 grand list, on which taxes for the fiscal year 1952-1953 will be based, represents the first complete revaluation in Stamford since 1932.

The 26,000-ton liner Empress of Scotland took on a capacity contingent of 425 passengers last night for departure during the early morning hours for a fourteen-day Caribbean cruise. It is the first of a series of three cruises out of New York scheduled for the ship by the Canadian Pacific Line.

The Rumanian Government has virtually wiped out the savings of its people in a Soviet-style monetary reform aimed at ending rampant inflation caused by farmers' withholding of their produce from the Government, the Bucharest radio revealed.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP) -- C. G. Sparkman of Detroit, deploring what he called "secrecy" in the leadership of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., opened a new fight for the union's presidency today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, rejecting President Truman's notion that Presidential primaries are merely eyewash, announced today that he would enter the Massachusetts primary, to be held in April. It is the sixth primary he has entered or said he would enter.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 1 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina today spurred the South's anti-Truman revolt with renewed advocacy of the MacArthur views on the Far East and a blanket condemnation of major pending Fair Del domestic programs.
Arthur Moran opened the defense of his older brother James J. Moran in General Sessions yesterday by contradicting the testimony of ex-fireman James F. Smith, a key prosecution witness.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The irregular and "haphazard" worship practices of nominal Christians and Jews are reducing major faiths to the level of "festival" religions, the Rev. Dr. James W. Clarke of St. Louis, declared here today.

Major hosiery manufacturers joined yesterday in support of a program to correct present depressed conditions caused by overproduction. Distress has bean chiefly due to excessive plant expansion in making women's full-fashioned hosiery.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court Justice today restrained the state from enforcing collection of its weight-distance tax on big trucks pending decision by the Appellate Division on the levy's constitutionality.

Dismissal of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company as one of twelve railroads and railroad associations named as defendants by the Seatrain Lines, Inc., in its anti-trust suit asking $186,000,000 damages was announced yesterday by Graham M. Brush, Seatrain president.

For the past three years the American International Association for Economic and Social Development (A. I. A.), a non-profit rural rehabilitation organization, has been dramatically translating our good-neighbor policy into action for two close neighbors -- Venezuela and Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent over the week ended last Tuesday to 176.3 per cent of the 1926 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 3.2 per cent below the level of a year ago and 2.8 per cent below that of Jan. 23, 1951, which was the pricing period immediately prior to the effective date of the G. C. P. R.
Kirsten Flagstad gave her farewell recital last night in Carnegie Hall. She announced her retirement to the audience of 2,700 after, she had finished the scheduled portion of her program.

Special ceremonies will be conducted today in many Roman Catholic dioceses in America at which children under 12 years of age, who are members of the Pontifical Association of the Holy Childhood, will meet to renew pledges of support of missions among abandoned and helpless children in foreign lands.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 1 -- An assembly of solemn and determined public officials, and spokesmen for business and organized labor pleaded today with a five-member Congressional subcommittee to direct the relocation of Newark Airport as the only effective measure to prevent plane disasters in this area.

Many dinner parties will be given tonight in Sherry's Opera Restaurant at the Metropolitan Opera House before the performance of "Aida," which has been taken over by members of the Vassar Club of New York as their annual opera benefit for the organization's Scholarship Fund.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Canadian province of British Columbia filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for $30,000,000 of securities to be offered for sale to the public through an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation, A. E. James Co., Inc., and seven other concerns.

The establishment of the Anta Department of Community and Industrial Showmanship, designed to service civic and industrial theatrical projects as well as community organizations, was announced yesterday by Robert W. Dowling, chairman of the American National Theatre and Academy.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- The United Nations General Assembly congratulated Libya today on her achievement of independence and recommended that she be admitted to the United Nations. Fifty-three nations voted in favor of such a resolution, with none opposed, although the Soviet bloc refused to participate.

HONG KONG, Feb. 1 -- Gen. Yeh Chien-ying, Communist Governor of Kwangtung Province, called on the people of Canton yesterday to "rise up and strike a strong counter-blow against the capitalists" in a speech that brought the Peiping regime's rapidly developing "quadruple opposition" campaign all the way down to China's southern borders.

A high level of realty activity was maintained in Manhattan last year, when 3,448 bone fide property transactions were completed for a price total of $347,546,165, the Real Estate Board of New York reported yesterday in its regular market analysis.

The United Steelworkers of America, C. I O., presented its case yesterday for a guaranteed annual wage of about $3,000 and said this particular phase of its demands would cost the steel industry 6 1/2 to 7 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Some 29,000 tons of zinc will be withdrawn from the stockpile to be diverted to defense production in the next six months, the Office of Defense Mobilization disclosed today. In addition, 3,000 tons of rutile, critical material used in the manufacture of welding rods and other items of the defense program, will be released from the stockpile.
HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- Robert Lippincott of the West Jersey Fleet sailed his Mate to victory in the first two races of the Cuba Cup series today in the twenty-first Star Class regatta.

The Hudson Wholesale Grocery Company has sold its property at 100 Larch Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., to the American Stores Company of Philadelphia which will use it to expand its warehouse and distribution facilities in the New York metropolitan area.

Miss Gloria Rosky of the Ohrbach A. A. won the metropolitan A. A. U. senior 200-yard backstroke championship last night in the first major women's meet of the season at the Brooklyn Tech High pool. She beat Miss Carol Giardine of the Women's Swimming Association by seven yards in 2:48.6.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 -- William Schneiderman, reputed acting head of the Communist party in the United States, and fourteen other party functionaries in California went on trial in United States District Court today on charges of conspiring to teach and advocate the forceful overthrow of the United States Government.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Checks totaling $7,000, the gift of the Isbrandtsen Company of New York to Capt. Dan Parker, Chief Officer Kenneth Dancy and the crew of the tug Turmoil, which went to the aid of the American freighter, Flying Enterprise, which sank in the Atlantic on Jan. 10, were handed over by Ambassador Walter S. Gifford at a luncheon here today.

Strictly speaking, any New York State motorist found driving yesterday without a 1952 license tag affixed to his last year's plates should have received a summons for violation of the State Motor Vehicle Law, punishable as a misdemeanor.

By raising irrelevant issues regarding such matters as Trieste and the Italian Peace Treaty the Soviet Union has forced the postponement of the proposed four-Power meeting scheduled to discuss an Austrian treaty which would permit withdrawal of American, British, French and Soviet troops from that country.
BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following forecasts and skiing reports for New England:

There appeared in a recent issue of THE TIMES a news item headed "United Nations Assailed" which dealt with the country-wide committee that would have the United States withdraw from the United Nations. As a citizen interested both in peace and in the prestige of our country I read the article with considerable alarm.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,147, for Friday's operations:

MIAMI, Feb. 1 -- The favorite in today's seven-furlong main event at Hialeah race course was Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' Yildiz, a non-winner since he collected $50,000 in the Flamingo Stakes here last March.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 1 (AP) -- Safeway Stores. Inc., complained today that the Government's retail beef regulations do not set prices high enough to allow the big food chain its pre-Korean profit margin as required by law. Safeway's protest called on Price Stabilizer Michael V. DiSalle to rescind the retail beef order.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Maj. Gen. G. J. Nold, deputy chief of engineers, told the Senate Preparedness subcommittee today that New York workers were not recruited for building military bases in Arab countries because the contractors believed a large number of them would be of Jewish origin and would be resented by the Arabs and be in personal danger.

An estimated $30,000,000 to $50,000,000 will be spent this year in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada, in oil and natural gas exploration and development, D. H. F. Black, director of the Province's Industrial Development Office, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday at a luncheon-meeting at Schwartz' restaurant here.

Early next month, customers of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company will begin using natural gas almost as it comes from Texas, Hugh Cuthrell, president, said in his annual report issued to stockholders yesterday.

The inability of the National Broadcasting Company to clear air time on a minimum number of its affiliated television stations has caused one of three sponsors to drop "The Goldbergs" program. Sponsorship by another of the clients is "indefinite" at this time for the same reason.

Twenty-eight boys and girls whose physical handicaps prevent their attendance at regular classes received high school diplomas yesterday in what Board of Education officials said were the first graduation exercises made possible by television.

Heavy German purchases of cocoa over the last three days were reflected in Cocoa Exchange futures trading yesterday. Prices rose 1 to 31 points on 249 lots, of which thirty-two were exchanges. According to private cables to cocoa trade houses, the purchases have all been confirmed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The key tariff covering railroad class rates east of the Rocky Mountains was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission, bringing the regulatory agency within sight of the end of its long effort to obtain uniformity in the classification of railroad freight and in the rates applied to freight moving under class rates.

In 1941 the United States and Canada reached an agreement, still to be approved by Congress, that the two countries were to undertake the construction of a St. Lawrence seaway and of a great hydroelectric plant. Weary of waiting eleven years, Canada has now served notice that she will build the seaway alone and rely on the Province of Ontario and some agency of the United States to proceed with the hydroelectric plant.

The New York Port Authority which supervises operations of Newark irport, said yesterday it! I was ready to Cooperate with the Senate Committee on Luterstate and Foreign Commerce on its suggestions regarding air and ground !safety,

The annual Polka Ball of the Kosciuszko Foundation was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the organization's Chopin Scholarship Fund. Mrs. Nevil Ford was chairman of the executive committee. Serving with her were Mrs. Casimir Jarzebowski, co-chairman, and Mrs. William H. Draper Jr. and Adam B. Lyczak, vice chairmen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The State Department was showing acute impatience with both France and Germany tonight for introducing the Saar problem and the issue of German membership in the North Atlantic alliance into the current European defense talks in Paris.

IMAGINATION, handmaiden of the culinarian as well as the poet or composer, can be invaluable in planning a supper to be served after the theatre or perhaps after an evening of skating. Necessarily, the menu for such an occasion should involve only dishes that are quick and easy to do; the hostess does not want to spend too much time in the kitchen. But the dishes need not be prosaic.
Safety standards for domestic gas appliances have been raised sharply in the last quarter-century, it was reported yesterday by the American Gas Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- House Repubilcans produced dismissal records today in an effort to prove that President Truman's plan to take tax collectors "out of politics" by putting them under Civil Service would not be the answer to corruption.

Wars and political upheavals exact a heavy toll in human suffering. In the case of the United States we have been made richer through the individuals who have elected to make this their home when they have been forced by hostilities or their concomitants to flee their native lands.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Indiana slapped a suspension on heavyweight champion Joe Walcott today for skipping an exhibition match and ignoring a $200 fine, but his manager, Felix Bocchicchio, protested hotly tonight that the action was all a mistake.

PORT STANLEY, Falkland Islands, Feb. 2 -- An Argentine shore party fired shots over the heads of a British group landing from the survey ship John Biscoe at Hope Bay, on the tip of the Antarctic's Palmer Peninsula (Graham Land) yesterday, this British settlement reported today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 2 -- One hundred and fifty letters of sympathy have been received by Mrs. Thomas J. Reid, the widow of the pilot of the American Airlines plane that crashed here on Jan. 22, killing twenty-nine persons.

AMONG the various styles of bridge play, the simplest and often the most effective is the one that the leading players call "bang-bang." In this type of hand you take everything in sight and assume that in the course of the play you are going to get enough tricks to make the contract.

Recorded selection from "Das Rheingold," the first of Wagner's opera cycle, "Der Ring des Nibelungen," will be played tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street at the fourth in a series of ten lectures on the operas of Wagner. Dr. Curt Sachs, music historian and consultant to the library's Music Division, will be the lecturer.

THE Kashmiri gentleman had suggested a quit cup of coffee at the India Coffee House. The coffee is much better than at the hotel, he explained. Also, the place is quieter and there are fewer people to check on whom you are with and what you are talking about. And talking was to be done.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Hardy Williams' quarter-court set shot with fifteen seconds remaining gave Penn State a 61-60 victory over West Virginia tonight in a clash of once-beaten basketball powers.

ONE of the nation's most remote and spectacular short-line railroads, the Laramie, North Park and Western, has become a part of the far-flung Union Pacific system. Shorn of its sonorous name, it is now known simply as the Coalmont Branch of the Union Pacific.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Reports from Cairo that Abdul Fattah Amr Pasha might soon be returning to his post as Ambassador here encouraged hopes that a solution of the difficulties with Egypt over the British garrison in the Suez Canal zone might not be so far distant as had been feared.
KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 2 (UP) -- A Connecticut hotel owner was beaten to death on the waterfront today and the police said a young sailor was the last person seen with him.

Senator Paul H. Douglas' analysis of the major problems facing the United States ("The Four Challenges to the Nation," Jan. 6) is deficient in one point. The most important problem faced by our country -- and the world -- is peace.

WORK by outstanding modern European artists played a considerable role in the exhibitions of the crowded week just closed. The Museum of Modern Art has assembled in its third floor galleries the various paintings and sculptures which it has been enabled to acquire since 1937 through the Mrs. Simon Guggenheim Fund -- an impressive array which pays tribute to the generosity and catholicity of taste of that retiring and progressive trustee.

HOLLYWOOD has finally returned the most famous aunt in the world -- Charley's of course -- to Oxford, England, the lady's original stamping ground. And now, after sixty days of location filming, Warner Brothers' version of "Where's Charley?" the last Broadway streamlining of Brandon Thomas' beloved antique, is in studio hands.
Your review of "Cry, the Beloved Country" appealed to me very much. Part of its appeal lay, of course, in the happy memories I have of the book. But your appreciation put it into words again for me.

EDDIE BRANNICK was suspicious when he heard the news. He practically toppled backward off his chair the instant he was told that he had been voted a plaque by the Baseball Writers Association for distinguished service to the game. Then he gulped hard and said weakly, "Gwan! You're kidding!"

JEWISH music is as difficult to define as the Jewish people itself. There are those who deny the reality of a Jewish music. They say that what is called Jewish music is really Slavic or Balkan, Babylonian or Egyptian.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Soybeans and lard showed a little firmness on the Board of Trade today in a market which, while steady, could not make a great deal of progress on the upside. Export houses gave soybeans support, and there also appeared to be some short covering.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- John Carter Vincent, career diplomat, completed a four-day appearance before the Senate Internal Security Committee today with testimony that in his opinion a Communist could not represent this country abroad "without being a traitor."
COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes reported today that South Carolina would not oppose a Negro request for an early court hearing in the public school racial segregation case.

ONCE it was possible to distinguish the creative writer from the pamphleteer in the works of Howard Fast. Unfortunately for his success in the field of the novel, his steady shift to the left has cast an increasingly hectic fever-flush on each of his recent production.

THE industrious Paul Nettl has this time set out to "recapture the memory of a number of musicians who have fallen into oblivion today." He has divided his book into two sections. One deals with men like Biber, Abt, Stamitz, Tomaschek, Vorisek and others.

THE cynical reviewer who once defined the "modern" historical novel as the fireworks created by the collision of an irresistible force with an immovable object would find the works of Rosamond Marshall case in point.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -- A Congressional drive began today to patch up fair trade laws and prevent a repetition of the spectacular 1951 price wars.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP) -- A pre-dawn mine explosion 300 feet underground killed six men near here today. Sixty-five other members of the night shift fought their way to safety through choking gas. Four of these were injured but only three seriously enough to be hospitalized.

THE social geography bf one country is always slightly mysterious to the inhabitants of another, and I doubt if every foreign critic surveying the English scene as it has developed during the past 200 years takes into account the long and distinguished history of the English upper middle class.

We Americans have such a droll sense of humor. We adopt "Inflation Controls" which guarantee to business men that if wages or other costs go up their prices will go up (Act of Congress); to workers that if living costs go up wages will go up (administrative decision of the President); to farmers that if prices of things they buy go up food prices will go up.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 -- Relations between Argentina and Britain appeared today to be undergoing new strains after Rinehard Allen, British Charge d'Affaires, had held two conferences with Foreign Minister Jeronomo Remorino and Navy Minister Anival Olivieri.
A Government spokesman declared here last night that the "most dangerous obstacle" to the nation's defense program was "American industry's lack of a sense of urgency."

The installation of a comprehensive two-way frequency modulation radio-telephone network for the Fire Department, placed under contract late in 1950 at a cost of $586,000, is 95 per cent complete and should be in service within a few weeks, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet announced last week.

FORTY years ago the Mexican revolutionist Emiliano Zapata, a tenant farmer of almost pure Indian blood, recruited a peasant army from the plantations and villages in the south under the banner of "Land and Liberty." The legendary leader held the field against successive federal governments; later joining forces with Francisco Villa in the north, Zapata occupied Mexico City three times in 1914-15.

I ENJOYED reading Barbara Berch Jamison's profile last Sunday of James Justice -- the colorful 250-pound movie character actor from Scotland who played parts in three American films last year. But what's that she said about Hollywood's "cycle of preposterous films"?

THE late Dr. John C. Ferguson, adviser to former President of China Yuan Shih-kai, once made an interesting remark to me: "There are two classes of Sinologists -- one class understands everything but knows nothing, the other knows everything but understands nothing."
The International League Baseball Writers Association elected three former standouts to the circuit's Hall of Fame yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Ambassador at Large, said here today that the Soviet Union suffered its "greatest defeat" in postwar conference history when moral law joined forces with technical skill to fashion the Japanese peace treaty.

THE surprise and delight of American audiences at the sudden flowering of Italian films since World War II, manifested in such compelling dramas as "Open City," "Shoe Shine" and "The Bicycle Thief," have generally been accompanied by only dim remembrance of the fact that it was in the earliest studios of Italy that the "flickers" found their first artistic range.

Richard Shepard's "Egypt, N. Y. C." (Jan. 13) is a charming vignette of a minority group in our city. It brings a fresh viewpoint to those of us who deal with children of varied national backgrounds in our schools.

In a hearing tomorrow before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard in New York an attempt will be made to discredit the typewriter evidence given in the second trial of Alger Hiss, former State Department official who is serving a five-year sentence for perjury.

Stunned by the impact of taxes on banks, stockholders of these institutions were comparatively subdued at their annual meetings completed last week. In previous years the gatherings sometimes appeared to attract stockholders whose major interest was to badger management.

The City College swimming team handed Fordham its sixth straight defeat of the season yesterday at Fordham, 46 to 38. Although the Beavers won six of the ten events, they did not seal the outcome until they took the 440-yard free-style relay, the final race on the program.

English and French furniture, Oriental rugs and decorative accessories of many kinds will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The property comes from Louis Effingham de Forest and Stewart B. Hopps of New York, among other owners.

In 1867, a few years before he launched a united Germany on the path that led to World Wars I and II, Otto von Bismarck told the North-German Reichstag, "Let us set Germany, so to speak, in the saddle. It will soon know how to ride."

St. Francis snapped a four-game losing streak by defeating Manhattan, 82-70, at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory yesterday. It was the first quadruple overtime basketball game ever played in New York by collegians or professionals.

Cairo last week was calm, partly from exhaustion after the bloody riots of the week-end, partly as a result of strong measures ordered by the King. For twenty-four hours a day armored cars patrolled the streets; hundreds of agitators were arrested.

DETROIT, Feb. 2--Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said here today that he would urge President Truman to leave his name on the ballot in New Hampshire's March 11 preferential primary.

MIAMI, Feb. 2 -- Surprise followed surprise in the two divisions of the Bahamas Handicap for 3-year-olds at rain-drenched Hialeah today. The winners, in the order of their appearance in the unsaddling enclosure, were Apheim Stable's fifth-choice Quiet Step, who paid $18.30, and Mrs. Vera S. Bragg's ninth-choice Trick Pilot, who paid $35.50.

Dr. George H. Gartlan, who for forty-eight years has made sure that the city's pupils received the three B's--Bach, Beethoven and Brahms--as well as the three R's, will retire as director of music for the Board of Education at the close of the current school term. Dr. Gartlan will be 70 on July 19, the compulsory age for retirement.

WE have a way of thinking that all the writers of the past are already known to us. But one of the greatest poets of the nineteenth century (the century of Blake, Whitman and Rimbaud) is still relatively little known in his native Italy and practically unheard-of elsewhere.

The steel industry will begin its arguments tomorrow before a special panel of the Wage Stabilization Board that is mediating the contract dispute between the United Steel workers of America, C. I. O., and the producers.
The fourth annual Columbia College Forum on Democracy, to be devoted this year to a study of "Leadership in a Democracy," will be held at the school for three days beginning on Feb. 21.

OF all contemporary composers, the late Bela Bartok was perhaps the best able to give his listeners an immediate sense of the inevitability of his music. And this despite the fact that his materials were most dissonant and atonal.

A variable star with the shortest period ever discovered has been found by Dr. Olin J. Eggen of the University of California, now working in Australia. He says the new star varies in brightness from its dimmest to its brightest over a period of only eighty minutes.

Afrikiya, the Arabic name for Tunisia, recalls the fact that this small, feverish French protectorate was the original Roman Africa which gave a name to a continent. Here was Carthage, already an ancient city, Virgil says, when Aeneas arrived, fleeing the wrath of the Greeks and the fires of Troy.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 2 -- The executive committee of the Cincinnati Bar Association, instructed its Committee on Judiciary and Legal reform today to investigate the circumstances of the appearance of Representative Pat Sutton, Democrat of Tennessee, as a defense attorney in a recent Army court-martial here.

Guido Cantelli, who conducted the N. B. C. Symphony in three concerts earlier this season, returned to the podium late yesterday afternoon and directed it in the first of a new series of five concerts. The Carnegie Hall program was broadcast over a nation-wide network.

Sol Bauman, a perennial Broadway character who, according to the police, has spent 50 of his 72 years in jails as a pickpocket, "had a feeling" yesterday that "something was going to happen." And it did.

THE recent accidents which have befallen the commercial airlines in this country again stress an old and irksome fact of aviation and add new emphasis to a frequently asked question. The fact is: Bad weather is the greatest single obstacle and hazard in aviation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 2 -- By outlawing football betting pools and professionalism in sports, the Central Committee of the Yugoslav Communist party has started a campaign against thousands of unemployed, long-haired young blades who congregate in Belgrade, Zagreb and other principal cities of Yugoslavia.

MOST of the short stories in Frances Gray Patton's collection, "The Finer Things of Life," appeared originally in The Hew Yorker. This automatically indicates that they are detailed as to setting, slight as to plot, beautifully written and presented from a civilized point of view.

Late Friday night an unshaven youth upset the routine of the Clymer Street police station in Brooklyn by pulling a sawed-off rifle from the side pocket of a thin coat. The barrel of the weapon had been shortened and the stock sawed away.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- Bach, Beethoven and Wagner are helping East Germany's campaign for unification in a subtle phase of the Communist propaganda war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- Department store sales were again down sharply throughout the West last week. San Diego was the only bright spot on the Coast. Inflation continued its cycle in the last few months, figures just released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed.

Benjamin R. Shute's letter published on Jan. 20, evaluating the efforts of our occupation policy in Germany, has left me with an uneasy feeling. Such evaluation must fail if limited to "accentuating the positive."

KING POINT, L. I., Feb. 2 -- Capt. Hendrik Kurt Carlsen, skipper of the ill-fated Flying Enterprise, was guest of honor today at the United States Merchant Marine Academy as "Carlsen Day" was observed at the Point.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan, the bolo punching Cuban Negro, will risk his world welter-weight boxing crown at Miami Stadium Monday night against a tough, hard-hitting, but unrated hometown challenger, Bobby Dykes.

Another compliment has been paid to Red Bank and the National Sweepstakes Regatta. For 1951, the New Jersey Outboard Association, which annually picks an honorary commodore, has selected Joseph C. Irwin of Red Bank, the veteran chairman of the annual Sweepstakes affair on the Nave-sink River.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Britain is in the midst of another economic crisis, the third since the war. It affects not only the United Kingdom, but the whole sterling area. The pound sterling, which finances roughly half of the world's trade, is in greater danger than at any time since devaluation in September, 1949.

The old struggle between the hardness of the cutting tool and that of the material to be cut is reaching a critical stage, according to a statement from Detroit by the American Society of Tool Engineers. The crisis, says the society, has been brought about by the increasing hardness of the alloys required in jet engines and other materiel for defense.
A national survey to plan a "sound" development of this nation's schools of social work was suggested yesterday by Dr. Helen Wright, president of the American Association of Schools of Social Work.

CAIRO, Feb. 2 -- Commenting upon reports that Egyptian Premier Aly Maher Pasha had sought new talks with London in the hope of ending British-Egyptian tension, a British Embassy spokesman tonight recapitulated the British Government's position, saying that the "return to normal security conditions in the canal zone is an absolute prerequisite to the resumption of conversations between the two Governments.

Completely new body styling and a substantial price reduction in one model and an increase on another are offered in the 1952 Lincoln line presented yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company.

THE cause of educations telecasting on a non-commercial basis in New York State, which has won the enthusiastic endorsement of countless educators and civic leaders, today hangs in the balance. It has run into the paralyzing grip of inertia and timidity.

In a letter printed in the theatre section of THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 13, Mr. Boris Marshalov declares that, "Miss Perry was consciously or unconsciously teaching Stanislavsky" in the acting classes of the Perry-Mansfield School of the Theatre which included Julie Harris and Leora Dana.

Following a raid on an apartment at 1287 Bronx River Avenue, the Bronx; shortly before last midnight, about forty men were questioned at the Westchester Police Station in the Bronx in connection with a floating dice game which, the police said, is known to have had as much as $20,000 available for play at previous gambling sessions elsewhere.

Opportunities for American college students to spend a year in France were announced last week by the Institute of International Education Approximately eighty grants are open for study or teaching in France next year. Forty of the grants are for young Americans interested in teaching conversational English for one year in a French school.

ATLANTA, Feb. 2 -- Retail trade in the Southeast last week continued to fall below levels of a year ago but merchants pointed out that the decline was no more than expected. Georgia almost doubled its tax collections this January over January, 1951.

WITH the coming of February many greenhouse plants that have seemed dormant or nearly so suddenly spring forth with a new zest. To the greenhouse gardener, it is the advent of spring and the beginning of a busy season of planting, planning and feeding.

A radical change in the thinking of manufacturers and their advertising people in view of the upheavals that have occurred in marketing practices, particularly in the retail field, was urged last week by E. B. Weiss, director of merchanding, Grey Advertising Agency.

HONG KONG, Feb. 2 -- Accused of obstructing the Government's march toward socialism and subverting backsliding members of the Communist party with their "sugar-coated capitalist bullets," the middle class economic groups in China are now being subjected to intensified "ideological remoulding" under a "quadruple opposition" movement.

MORRIS Germain, popular New York teacher and lecturer, was honored for his forty-five years in photography at the Annual Awards Dinner held here last week by the staff of the Germain School of Photography, of which he is the director.
THE electrical industry has extended to the nation's railroads an invitation to greater electrification of transport by developing new locomotives of improved performance and economy.

THE stories in this anthology edited by Paul Jensen, who is a good pilot among other abilities, have only one thing in common -- they are all concerned with flying and the air. Fictional entries alternate with fact.

IN a recent NEW YORK TIMES article on this years Music Critics Circle Awards, Mr. Downes was kind enough to commend the Mannes Music School on its performance last May of Bohuslav Martinu's prize-winning one-act opera, "Comedy on the Bridge."

When Dr. T. F. Tsiang, Free China's representative in the United Nations, offered his resolution to the effect that the Soviet Union had violated its 1945 treaty of friendship with China he was trying to get the world organization to face the facts of Asiatic aggression. He may not have been too optimistic about bold and forthright United Nations action, since the complaint had been carried along since 1949.

THE wise have spoken and their decisions have coincided, for a change, with the verdict of the multitudes. "From Here to Eternity" and "The Sea Around Us" have won the National Book Awards in fiction and non-fiction.

WE'VE heard it said somewhat ruefully now and then by certain leaders of parents' groups that about the only sure way they have found to get full attendance at a meeting is to schedule a discussion on sex education.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet representative in the United Nations General Assembly, declared in another bitter attack on the United States and Britain tonight that not only was "the Anglo-American bloc" preparing a third world war, but "this world war has in fact begun."

DETROIT, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Senator Kefauver, in his first political speech since becoming a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, tonight called Republicans people who "stand for yesterday."

VIENNA, Feb. 2 -- Dr. Karl Gruber, Austria's Foreign Minister, told his people in a radio speech today that they had better give up all hope of obtaining a state treaty from the Foreign Ministers of the four occupying powers and should turn instead to the United Nations.

THE recent establishment by President Truman of a new Missouri Basin Survey Commission could be a step of major importance in the long struggle to evolve a satisfactory program for the proper conservation, development and use of the land and water resources of the Missouri Valley.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP)--Jet bombers, flying almost three times as fast as World War II bombers, can drop their missiles with even greater accuracy by using a new automatic pilot, the Air Force said today.
