ONE Sunday last fall, shortly after the United Nations General Assembly opened in Paris, millions of families in Western Europe were listening uneasily to the evening news broadcasts. Western delegates, they heard, had warned of "evil" men who plan "aggression."

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Kentucky, No. 1 team in The Associated Press national basketball poll, erased an 8-point, third-quarter lag, to outlast ineligibility-weakened Notre Dame, 71 -- 66, before 15,965 at the Chicago Stadium tonight. It was the twelfth straight victory for Kentucky's Wildcats, who now have a 17-2 record.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Feb. 2 -- Three union free school districts -- Glen Head, Glenwood Landing and Sea Cliff -- are considering a proposal to merge into one district and build a central high school to serve the adjoining communities. Glen Head and Glenwood Landing have only elementary schools, while Sea Cliff has a high school in the same building with its grade and junior high classes. Each is overcrowded.
City College's fencing team handed Brooklyn College its second defeat of the season, 17 to 10, in the Beaver's gym yesterday. The victory was City's second in two starts.
The oldest fire insurance company in the United States -founded in 1752 by Benjamin Franklin and a group of his friends -- is preparing to observe its 200th anniversary.

DAVE GARROWAY, a former low-pressure master of ceremonies content to live and let live, suddenly has set out to change the rise-and-shine living habits of television families in thirty cities from Boston south to Jacksonville, Fla., and west to Omaha, Neb.

ARTHUR HONEGGER was not quite 30 when he composed the music for King David, which has the offificial designation of "a symphonic psalm in three parts" but which could also be described as an oratorio.

MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (UP) -- Floyd Curry and Billy Reay scored last-period goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens rallied to tie the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game at the Forum.

Warmth and love bind a family into a circle -- but often the circle is broken by problems that, to the family, seem insurmountable. A wage-earning member of the family may be sick, or the children taking wrong paths, or the budget may be too difficult to figure out.
For the second successive month, the New York Regional Blood Program of the American Red Cross has fallen short of its goal, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William M. Markel, administrator.

Plans to merge General Instrument Corporation into Standard Coil Products Company, Inc., through a stock exchange have been announced by Glen E. Swanson, president of Standard Coil, and Abraham Blumenkrantz, chairman of General Instrument. The two companies have agreed to an exchange of stock at the rate of five shares of General Instrument for four shares of Standard Coil.

Bills giving the city power to impose by local law new or increased special taxes to yield an estimated $122,100,000 of additional revenue will be introduced in the Legislature this week, Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday. The measures are intended to effectuate a tax program approved by the Board of Estimate in executive session last Monday.

KAY BOYLE, H. Allen Smith, Martha Gellhorn, Arthur Kober, Kenneth Fearing, Henry Steig and a lot of other people liked Manhattan radio writer Robert Paul Smith's first novel, "So It Doesn't Whistle" (1941). But the cocky Saroyan cheerfulness that made this haphazard little Greenwich Village story appealing failed to hide the plotless, pointless barrenness of Smith's second novel, "The Journey" (1943), the sketchy history of a love affair that flopped.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 2 (AP) -- St. John's of Brooklyn, No. 15 nationally in the Associated Press basketball poll, defeated thirteenth-ranked Indiana tonight, 65 -- 55, in its first invasion of the Western Conference. Bob Zawoluk, St. John's big center, made 25 points.

THE main proposal in answer to both the monopoly and decay of Broadway theatrical enterprises has been the cry of decentralized theatre, theatre off-Broadway. This call has been answered with a renewed enthusiasm for the Community and Little Theatre movement from Texas to Maine, Soda jerks, social climbers, would-be Hollywood hopefuls have joined the endless parade in honor of Thespis, all with that irresistible urge to "belong to the world of theatre.

IT is an interesting commentary on the strengthening bonds of the Western World that the son of Italy's first republican President, who is now lecturing as a Professor of Government at Cornell, should have taken the lead in preparing this excellent study of communism in Western Europe.

HAVANA, Feb. 2 -- The Cuba Cup of the competition twenty-first international Star Class regatta was won this morning by Robert Lippincott of the West New Jersey fleet when he sailed his yacht Mate to a third successive victory for a perfect 39-point score.

THE subject of this novel -- a love affair between a schoolboy of 14 and a nun twice his age -- might easily have been treated in a distasteful way. One might fancy that only an experienced and consummate craftsman could have avoided all the ugly pitfalls which such a plot opened, and composed a small masterpiece of restraint and delicacy.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Six unidentified planes bombed and strafed Allied lines in east-central Korea yesterday, while United States jets shot up three enemy jets and two tanks, and killed or wounded more than 100 Red soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Truman is in the curious position of getting and, up to now at any rate, ignoring the same advice from both his political friends and foes. Inside and outside the Democratic party, his supporters and opponents are clamoring for an immediate and clear-cut statement as to whether he will be a candidate for re-election.

Young women headed by Mrs. Edwin Anthony Heard Jr. and including Miss Rosamond Clifford and Miss Elisabeth Reed, are serving on the junior committee for the performance of "Venus Observed" on the night of March 18 at the Century Theatre to assist the Finch Junior College Building Fund. Mrs. Randolph Lawson, a trustee of Finch, is general chairman of the benefit committee.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2 -- A community-wide effort to better relations between racial and religious groups in this resort city is under way in the wake of the recent series of unsolved terror bombings and other evidences of civic tension.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 2 (UP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, said today that he "feared" that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower" had become the victim of a "trap" set by Republicans who were "afraid he would become an unbeatable Democratic candidate."
Contents of this country's canapes may be altered in coming months by the growing success of "special" business interests in restoring imports of foreign products.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- A serious erosion of the ties of the American Federation of Labor to the international labor movement was manifest today in a firm statement of policy issued by the executive council.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Cornell defeated Pennsylvania, 64 -- 51, in a battle of undefeated Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League teams today before 8,000 in Barton Hall and took over first place from the Quakers with a record of four victories and no setbacks in the Ivy circuit. Penn has taken four of five league games.

The prospect of a succession of ring matches with a "double-champion" flavor developed yesterday, following the State Athletic Commision's abrogation of the old rule which required a champion in a lower class, fighting for a title in a heavier division, to surrender his championship immediately upon signing for the heavier title match.

INDIA EDWARDS is on the road again. Kansas City lately saw her, so did New York. Name a city -- for instance, Detroit or Albany, N. Y. -- and she has just been there or is momently expected. As vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee she is busier than she has been in four years at her dedicated task which, in three words, is -- Votes From Women.

University of New Hampshire FERTILIZERS may be more difficult to obtain in 1952 because of the heavy demand from farmers who are being urged to produce more crops. Furthermore, superphosphate, which goes into all mixed fertilizers for both farm and garden, is in short supply.

With the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company and the Iranian Government still miles apart on agreement, a tentative compromise plan has been proposed by government and private interests friendly to both parties which could result in Iranian oil again becoming available in the international market.

More than 85 per cent of the orders for supplies bought by Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its North American affiliates during 1951 were filled by small business concerns, described as those having fewer than 500 workers.

As home televiewers absorb illusion from their cushioned chairs, watching the rain beat down on a lonely farmhouse where our young hero is held captive by gangsters, a TV camera man is frantically pushing his 800-pound camera on wheels around a chaotic set to get to the kitchen scene in time for the coffee to boil.

Wisconsin Democrats who had been determined to unseat Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, even if a Republican had to do it, now are striving to agree on one strong Democrat since Gov. Walter J. Kohler, a Republican, who they thought could turn the trick, has dropped out.

The Army was charged yesterday with trying to back out of a $250,000 overpurchase of tomato paste. The charge was made in a statement by James B. Herzog, president of Stern, Morgenthau Co., Inc., 510 Sixth Avenue, food importers.

A letter addressed by President Abraham Lincoln to his friend, Henry J. Raymond, founder and editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, suggesting that Mr. Raymond reconsider his objections to compensated abolishment of slavery, was sold at auction for $1,100 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, last week.

THE sign over the theatre will read simply "Emlyn Williams as Charles Dickens." No play-title, no cast, no director. Backstage it will be unnaturally quiet and the 46-year-old Welsh actor-author will admit to an occasional slight chill of loneliness, a feeling that he is not so much working in a building as haunting it.

SAUL STEINBERG, who uses line to satirize the complacencies, authoritarianisms and inflated vanities of our time with the same bite and purpose as Voltaire used the written word, is a smallish man with a large, ovoid head on which thinning, blondish hair is plastered as slickly as that of a dancing school-bound teen-ager.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 2 (UP) -- St. Bonaventure, one of the nation's two remaining undefeated college basketball teams, breezed to its thirteenth straight victory tonight with a 79-48 victory over Loyola of Chicago before a crowd of 10,357.

Plans are being advanced at meetings and teas for the luncheon and fashion show to be given for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop on March 27 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Miss Louise Edgar, president of the beneficiary, is general chairman of the committee for the event. Among her aides are Mrs. William H. Husted and Mrs. Paul L. Franken.

News that Yale University is increasing faculty salaries and has established a minimum of $3,500 for beginning instructors is welcome information. Like other universities that have made similar moves in the past year, Yale's action in this matter represents an effort at least partially to protect the real incomes of its faculty in this period of rising prices and taxes.
Price increases on raw aluminum and its products, as well as on steel, will be sought promptly once the current wage controversy in the two industries is settled.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- All during the brief parliamentary recess Premier Edgar Faure has been working with experts to draft a compromise on the budgetary and financial issues that would be acceptable to the Cabinet Coalition parties and could at the same time keep the Socialists' support.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 2 -- Fishermen and sailors for nearly a century have ridiculed the existence of an albino sperm whale, as portrayed by Herman Melville in his novel "Moby Dick." Now they can cease their scoffing.

THE mysterious Orient will no longer be mysterious if American producers continue using Shinto shrines and geisha girls as backdrops for their films and Japanese directors enlarge their search for Western faces.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A barrage of criticism from Capitol Hill was directed today at Newbold Morris two days before he was to come to Washington to head a drive on Government corruption.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 2 -- A coal town doctor, a hero of a 1945 mine explosion that took twenty-three lives, is the target today of union miners, who seek to oust him from his hospital and practice.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 2 -- The parties of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government coalition have agreed that Federal Germany cannot progress further toward membership in the European defense community until France modifies her stand on settlement of the Saar's future.

FOR THIS WEEK: Dislodge snow from evergreens with a rake or broom and protect shrubs and trees from roof slides or drip. . . . Tramping down snow around young fruit trees keeps mice and rabbits from nibbling unprotected bark. Cylinders of small mesh wire netting or plastic guards safeguard the lower eighteen inches of trunks. . . .
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 2 -- Henry Williams Jr. shot a par 70 to take the lead in today's windy third round of the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament with a fifty-four-hole total of 203.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- That mythical character, the Average Voter, was in the capital this week seeking a progress report on the latest "Great Debate."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Army's basketball team made an afternoon of athletic rivalry in seven sports extremely pleasant for those at the military post today with a thrilling uphill victory over Colgate.

THE podium of the Boston Symphony is a powerful lure. When Charles Munch became ill Ernest Ansermet was willing to drop the book he was writing in Switzerland, while on sabbatical leave from his own orchestra, in order to come to Boston to conduct.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The increasing support for Aneurin Bevan and his followers among the members of the Labor party in the House of Commons is making Clement R. Attlee's task as leader of the Opposition increasingly difficult. The former Prime Minister already is having to modify his chosen course to suit the demands of the extremists within his own party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Representative Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, announced today that he would seek election to the Senate to unseat Kenneth McKellar, the Senate's senior member in point of service and chairman of its Appropriations Committee.

FONTAINEBLEAU, France, Feb. 2--Before 1,000 officers and men representing six of the nations whose forces he commands, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, warned here today that "we seem to approach a crisis" in the struggle between those who stand for dictatorship and those who stand for freedom.
The cotton futures market opened irregular yesterday and closed 15 points higher to 4 points lower than on Friday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb, 2 (AP) -- Winnie Ruth Judd, trunk murderess, escaped from the State Hospital for the Insane tonight for the fifth time.

Department stores are beginning to approach the sales figures set a year ago in the buying rush that followed the intervention of the Chinese Communists in Korea. Trade observers put the decline from the 1951 week at only 4 per cent. Affecting the comparison, however, was the fact that adverse weather in the 1951 week held sales down.

Edward J. Donovan, chairman of the New York State Correction Commission, said last night that the temporary phase of a project for rehabilitating female narcotic users was being carried out successfully at the Westfield State Farm, in Bedford Hills, N. Y.

IN replying to Prof. William Kilpatrick's letter I should say first of all that I realize my reference to the ideas of Professor Dewey was in some measure hasty and ill-considered. Those ideas were misunderstood, misinterpreted and misapplied, and only in that sense, perhaps, can it be said that they were inherently destructive.

DR. MERRILL MOORE, the Boston psychiatrist - sonneteer, is with us again and, as always, very welcome company. His latest volume carries on the marathon production that should by now bring Dr. Moore well into his second hundred thousand of efforts in this medium.

IT is a tribute all around -- to Melville's inexhaustible genius, to the passionate teachers and perceptive critics and intelligent readers -- that books by Melville, as well as about him, are now received with enthusiasm and even pleasure.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- An immediate Federal grand jury investigation to determine if The San Francisco Call-Bulletin printed news stories that obstructed justice was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Oliver J. Carter.

A well-known resident of Washington, D. C., whose remarks in press conferences are ordinarily not quoted verbatim, described the Presidential primaries last week as "eyewash." He added, in his customary indirect discourse, that these primaries don't mean a thing when the nominating convention meets.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- A threatened delay in the sailing of the Pacific Far East line's freighter Alaskan Bear was dissipated today as a result of Coast Guard subpoenas.

William Vogt, national director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., asked the American Medical Association yesterday to support doctors facing ouster from the staff of St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

New Hampshire -- forty-third of the forty-eight states in area, forty-fourth in population -- has sent one native son to the Presidency (Franklin Pierce, Democrat, 1852), and another to the Vice Presidency (Henry Wilson, Republican, Grant's ticket, 1872).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Congress is about to undertake an investigation of the largest law office in the world, headed by a Cabinet officer, staffed by about 33,000 persons and with only one client.

HOUSE-TRAILER manufacturers, unwilling to let well enough alone, are planning to offer further demonstration of their ingenuity at the National Trailer Coach Show in Cleveland from Feb. 13 to 17. Among the 150 new trailers to be put on display will be models boasting such wonders as radiant heating, split-level layouts of rooms and closets with sliding doors, to say nothing of novel versions of the already familiar porches and sun- decks.

Jack Collins will be continued on the payroll of the Brooklyn Baseball Club, but not as business manager, to cooperate with the Brooklyn District Attorney's office in its investigation of a shortage of about $25,000 in club finances.

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- While Canada has been a strong supporter of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization from the outset, and was in large part the originator, it has become clear that she intends to remain among the countries that control that organization and will not consent to being controlled by it.

NEWARK, Feb. 2 -- Mayor Ralph A. Villani denounced today a bill introduced in the Legislature for compulsory local referendums on all slum clearance, urban development and public housing projects. He termed the bill a "most serious threat" to rebuilding programs in progress with funds provided under the Federal Housing Act of 1949.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 2 -- Education costs and the number of pupils enrolled set records during the 1950-51 school year in Connecticut. The Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, a privately financed research organization, reported today on its survey of educational spending in the 169 towns of the state during the last academic year.
Parents who teach their children to read in the belief they are helping them with their schoolwork may actually be doing more harm than good, according to the Board of Education.

When the college joins forces with the social agency, the business office, the laboratory and the church in the training of its students, the process of education is substantially improved. This conclusion was emphasized last week by officials of Keuka College, a women's college at Keuka Park, N. Y., in a report on the school's nine-year experiment with a work-study program.
Black and white are highlights of the spring fashion news. This dramatic color contrast is seen in fashions for all occasions.

The Port of Baltimore, aided by an accelerated promotion campaign and constant diversions of commerce from other major, ports, particularly New York, has become for the first time in more than half a century a major competitor of the Port of New York on the Atlantic seaboard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, disclosed today that Government investigators on three occasions last year had found "violations" of the Federal mine safety code at the Carpentertown coal mine, and so had informed its owners.

In his speech of Jan. 24 Governor Dewey advocated the formation of a general Pacific Alliance and the declaration by the signatories that an invasion of Southeast Asia by Communist forces would immediately bring the signatories into war with the aggressor.

How schools and colleges can promote greater public understanding of world affairs was explored here last week when 2,300 of the nation's foremost educators, scientists, artists and community leaders met at the third national conference of the United States National Commission for Unesco -- the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

GARDENERS are often as familiar with the names of their roses as with those of their intimate friends. "Mme. Gregoire Staechelin," "Charlotte Armstrong," "General Jacqueminot" fall glibly from their lips as they proudly show blooms of these top performers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--As an applicant for an entry visa into the United States, Graham Greene, British author and prominent Roman Catholic layman, is under investigation by the State and Justice Departments in conformity with the requirements of the Internal Security (McCarran) Act.
Geologists of the California Institute of Technology headed by Dr. Robert P. Sharp find that much of the Malaspina Glacier in southern Alaska flows uphill.

A NEW approach to nature and science photography, in which living matter rather than dead or otherwise immobilized subjects are photographed, was discussed last week by Dr. Roman Vishniac. Dr. Vishniac, well-known nature photographer, who has been experimenting along these lines for some time, prepared an illustrated report on his findings for the monthly meeting of the Biological Photographic Association, New York Chapter, last Thursday.

A guerrilla army of 370,000 men could be organized immediately with United States equipment and encouragement to block Communist aggression in Southeast Asia, General Li Tsung-jen declared in an interview here last week.

Public attention is focused on diamond smuggling not only because of the large amounts of money involved in the traffic, but also because of the adverse effect on world trade and production, import circles pointed out last week.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 2 (AP) -The commonly accepted uses for oil are heating and transportation, but there's a new branch of the industry that has created and furnished a thousand uses for oil. They call it "petrochemical."
Four of the six dogs that were in the final of the Westminster Kennel Club show a year ago have been entered in the event again this year. The show will be in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- A 33-year-old woman was shot dead this afternoon when a New York detective's service revolver was discharged accidentally in an automobile traveling northward on the Taconic State Parkway here.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Two official world records for outboard motorboats -- B stock runabouts and C racing hydroplanes -- were set in the Orange Cup Regatta today.

The belief of United States Government officials that the Soviet Union partly converted its economy for greater military production last year has been strengthened by close study of the 1951 economic report of the Soviet Government, issued last week.

Taking command in the fourth quarter on fast breaks, the New York Knickerbockers won their eleventh straight home contest in the National Basketball Association by halting the Boston Celtics, 91 -- 83, in an Eastern Division battle before 5,200 fans at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory last night.

The recently released report to the Office of Defense Mobilization from the Task Force on the Handicapped, which it appointed last June to recommend methods for more effective use of handicapped workers in defense production, is one of the most significant documents on rehabilitation published to date.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- The immediate future of the truck dock hands strike, which is tying up Chicago's loading and unloading facilities, will hinge on the outcome of a union meeting tomorrow morning. Members of Local 710, Teamsters Union, A. F. L., will discuss terms with their representatives, who have been in contact with the truck operators.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2 -- Plans drawn in 1922 for a "General Pershing" military highway across Connecticut were "apparently overlooked" By state and national military officials in their Thruway survey, John S. Dole, chairman of the Fairfield County Traffic Council, said today.
DESPITE a couple of unfortunate crashes, which always depress the air travel business for a short period, the scheduled commercial airlines appear to be heading for an even better year than 1951.

The publication last week of the Atomic Energy Commission's semi-annual report and the President's recent prosaic announcement of another major expansion in the nation's atomic energy program masked current and impending developments in the atomic field almost as revolutionary as the first A-bomb.

In spite of the fact that many of the major orchestras in this country are relying on guest conductors for their regular subscription series, to bolster public interest and box office, we find that little is being done to give an opportunity to young American-born conductors.

SOME of the new insecticides that have appeared on the market recently are highly effective for certain pests and relatively ineffective for others. For the home garden, those of low toxicity to man and animals should be chosen.
The question whether fair-trade pricing is to be put back in business will be taken up by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee tomorrow.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 2 (AP) -The chairman of the board of Kingan Co., Indianapolis meat packers, urged stockholders today to remove H. Frederick Willkie as company president Feb. 21.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Pravda, organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party, devoted nearly one-quarter of its space today to Herbert Hoover's address of Jan. 27, which it characterized as prime evidence that "alarm has seized a wide stratum of Americans" over present United States foreign policy.

THE war of 1812 is finding increasing favor as a setting for historical romances. Myron David Orr has used as background for his novel of the period the struggle for Mackinac Island, the Citadel of the Great Lakes.
IN three current exhibitions of landscape, artists show that there are as many different ways of paraphrasing nature's appearances.

Arthur M. Tode, honorary president of the Propeller Club of the United States for many years, has been elected president of the Circumnavigators Club. Mr. Tode succeeds the well-known explorer Lewis N. Cotlow. At the same time, the Circumnavigators named Lowell Thomas as honorary president; William D. Ryan, vice president, and Raymond M. Dinsmore, secretary.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 2 -- The Netherlands' "Bells for America" campaign got under way today. Three truck-mounted carillons, festooned with Dutch and United States flags, started from different parts of the country to cover every hamlet, pealing out a message of the national gift Queen Juliana will present in Washington in April.

ONE reads, as though resuming a conversation with an old friend and a delightfully informed lover of music, the book of program annotations selected from those which Lawrence Gilman contributed from 1921 to 1939, the year of his death, to the programs of the New York Philharmonic and the Philadelphia Orchestra.
Al Parsells scored with less than one minute to play to give the Ramapo polo team a 13-12 victory over New York last night in the feature of a double-header at the Squadron Armory.

WITH all the fanfare and the wreaths of praise that indirectly are attributed to the original author, Margaret Landon, who wrote "Anna and the King of Siam" on which "The King and I" is based, I thought I might acquaint you with a story whereby, had it not been for the advent of a missionary there might never have been a Miss Owens in the capacity of teacher to the Siamese court.

EQUIPPED with a new high-compression V-8 engine of 160 horsepower, which is designed to provide increased power and economy of operation, the 1952 Lincoln presented here yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company comes in five body types. These are the Cosmopolitan custom four-door sedan, the custom hardtop sport coupe, the Capri special custom hardtop coupe, the special custom convertible and the special custom four-door sedan.

Procrastination in meeting personal and community obligations in parent-child relations and in municipal and international planning for the elimination of delinquency and war was condemned by Rabbi Morris N. A theory explaining for the first time the mystery of supernovae, giant stars that suddenly explode in the depths of interstellar space with a force of ten billion billion billion atomic bombs, in a flash that equals the light of a hundred million suns, was presented yesterday at the meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.
TORONTO, Jan. 30 -- Six Canadian oil companies, after a long fight for the Dominion Government's approval, will build this spring the first oil pipeline in North America to cross the Rockies.

MAYBE we have had enough of first ladies. Maybe Marianne Moore isn't, or shouldn't be (and certainly wouldn't want to be) the first lady of poetry. She is indisputably a poet of the first rank. The one trouble with Marianne Moore is that she doesn't write enough.

WHITE PLAINS -- A new state park less than twenty-five miles from Times Square and another parkway exit from the city are contemplated by the Taconic State Park Commission, but execution of the plans depends on the transfer by Westchester County to the state of a tract for the park.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 2 -- The largest list of candidates for Ohio delegates to the Republican and Democratic national conventions in twenty-eight years is expected to be filed by next Wednesday's deadline for qualifying for the May 6 primary.

CURRENTLY setting the pace in the off-Broadway play-producing field is a non- Equity outfit bearing the rather Euclidean title of "Circle-in-the-Square." Last Thursday the group began an eight-week run of Garcia - Lorca's "Yerma" which moved the project into its second year of operation at its Greenwich Village home.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, arriving by air from his Paris talks with Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, said tonight that their discussions covered a wider range of topics than had been thought likely.
CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 2 -- The national political spotlight is on the nation's first Presidential preference primary, which will be held March 11 in New Hampshire.
Justice Douglas, in "The Black Silence of Fear" (Jan. 13), wrote: "Once we had confidence in each other. Now there is suspicion."

TANGIER, Feb. 2 -- The sad and violent occurrences in Egypt and Tunisia are in fact merely the latest manifestations in an Islamic revolt that has been taking place by fits and starts ever since World War I.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Feb. 3 -- The Communists agreed today that all prisoners of war on both sides should pledge not to fight again in Korea. Earlier, the Reds had refused repeatedly to accept this proposal by the Allies.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- When Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, left Paris today after two days of talks with Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, French officials professed to be assured that Britain would support them on the immediately pending German issues.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Feb. 2 -- Plans to build a $22,000,000 hexagonal Army Signal Corps research and development center here to consolidate all scientific work now carried out in four widely separated laboratories have been announced by authorities here.

The Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital, 29 Greene Avenue, making a general appeal for contributions, reported yesterday a steady increase in clinic attendance with clinic patient visits last year averaging 2,010 weekly.

BONN, Feb. 2 -- The long irregular semicircle of nations that stretches from the toe of Italy to North Cape and which is called Western Europe was under a half-forgotten pressure this week. It was not the familiar pressure of the Soviet Union with its insults and incidents but the lighter but still insistent pressure of renascent Germany.

As the first month of the new year ended some of the problems to be faced in 1952 have come into focus. The Administration in several messages to Congress has stated the issues, which range from heavy expenditures to new taxes.

Mathes of Los Angeles. The entire decision (Warner Bros. v. Columbia Broadcasting System) is a distinguished document well worth the perusal of those readers who have access to a law library.

Bail of $10,000 each was set in Felony Court yesterday for three youths accused of stealing $114,000 in jewels and $1,500 in cash last Wednesday from Mrs. Leon J. Livingston in her apartment at 812 Park Avenue.

This will do them no good -- it will continue to be winter. But what sort of winter? In 1875 the mean temperature for February in New York City was 23.2 degrees, which, even in those robust times, was considered cold.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 2 (AP) -An optimistic Senator Robert A. Taft proposed today to hammer on "corruption in Washington" during his campaign for the Republican nomination for the Presidency this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) -Guy George Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, defended Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Communists - in - government campaign today and said the American people "should be proud of what the Senator has done."

SINCE the film sleuths are aware of a good thing when they see one, it should not come as a surprise if "The Shrike" is snagged for the screen soon. At the moment, three major studios -- Paramount, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Twentieth Century-Fox -- are on the trail of the psychological melodrama, produced and directed by and starring Jose Ferrer, which opened to fine notices at the Cort Theatre on Jan. 15.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Three veteran players and a newcomer stroked their way into the final of the women's international four-ball golf tournament today. Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., and Miss Bea McWane of Birmingham, Ala., will meet Miss Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., and Miss Pat Garner of Midland, Tex., in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final.

It has been generally accepted that home conditions, a feeling of security and emotional balance are important factors in the scholastic achievement of school children. Now we have scientific proof of the relationship between these and similar factors with the grades that pupils get in the classroom.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 2 -- Frank Thomas, football coach of Alabama's Crimson Tide for more than fifteen years, resigned today as athletic director at the university because of ill health.

Reduced prices of British goods, plus the new "super-austerity" program aimed at raising export earnings, should soon produce a rise in unit volume of United Kingdom products selling in this country, traders predicted last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- It's the budget-cutting season on Capitol Hill again, evidenced, as usual, by public vows of big reductions and private misgivings over the anticipated results.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Finance Ministry announced today that Indonesia would revalue her currency Monday. Other sweeping changes are expected to restrict imports from dollar areas and encourage exports.

The first alcoholism clinic in the Metropolitan area to specialize in the treatment of problem drinkers employed in local industries will open tomorrow, Winthrop Rockefeller, chairman of the board of trustees of New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, announced yesterday.

Apathetic New Yorkers were asked yesterday to show greater interest in the city's Civil Defense program. Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commissioner of Health, urged wider response to a recent appeal by Grover A. Whalen, Coordinator of Recruiting and Public Information, for 74,000 volunteers to man 400 first aid mobilization points in the five boroughs.

HONOLULU, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Governor of Hawaii, the Mayor of Honolulu and civic leaders joined today the campaign to restore white crosses to graves of war dead in the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific.

A paraplegic veterans' wheelchair basketball team, known as the Flying Wheels, is scheduled to arrive in New York today on a sixteen-day tour of the nation to show that "ability, not disability, counts."

NEW DELHI, Feb. 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and the Working Committee of his Congress party are meeting here over the week-end to discuss the political situation arising out of the serious reverses in India's first national elections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, plans to issue a new order Monday aimed at easing growing unemployment in widely scattered parts of the country, mobilization officials said today.

The Chopin Sonata was, to these ears, the climax of the piano recital that Nikita Magaloff played yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. It was a strong, masculine performance with big lines and a spacious quality, buttressed by a clear, singing tone that never sounded forced, even at moments of greatest intensity -- and Mr. Magaloff did not stint his attack.

SHUQUALAK, Miss., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Warhoop Jake, a nimble-footed pointer owned by a New Jersey dog fancier, today was named, for the second straight year, champion of the National Field Trial Club's free-for-all stake.

By using radioisotopes as markers, the Communicable Disease Center of the Public Health Service has demonstrated that the vagabond common house fly occasionally travels as far as eight miles in search of food. In six recent tests, more than 200,000 radioactive flies were released.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Midwinter rains came to the Ohio valley, flooding Marietta, and to southern California, inundating some of Los Angeles. Eighteen feet of snow fell over the Sierra Nevadas, marooning a passenger train for two days at Donner Pass.

The New York University swimming team defeated Manhattan College in the former's pool yesterday, 46 to 38. Each team had a double winner, Manhattan's George Gross taking 50 and 100 yard free-style events and New York's Bob Cromey scoring in the 220 and 440 yard free-style races.

Conflict of court decisions in the administration of Federal income tax laws is inevitable under our decentralized court system. ACCORDING to the records of the professional theatre, Franz Lehar's Gypsy Love has not been heard in this city since the thirty-one performances it had in 1911, when it was brand new. MANCHESTER, Vt., Feb. 2 -Boston College placed skiers sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth to win the Asa Osborn Trophy giant slalom on Bromley Mountain today. The Terriers tallied the low time of 7:39.7 to beat six-man teams from American International College, Brown University, Boston University, New England College and Northeastern University in the New England Intercollegiate Ski Conference competition.

THE first of the spring flower shows here in the East is now less than a month away. On March 1 a nine-day exhibition opens in Cleveland, Ohio, and one in Washington, D. C., overlaps it to run from March 6 to 12.

FEBRUARY has little to recommend it here in the North, where snow and ice and cold winds are likely to prevail. And yet, in a way, it is a pleasant month, for it marks the time when branches of flowering trees and shrubs can be brought into bloom indoors.

SAN FRANCISCO. Feb. 2 -- After preliminary investigation! lasting weeks, a long-heraldedi public hearing of charges and L counter-charges involving operatJons of the Internal Revenue Bureau in the Northern California District is scheduled to open here Monday.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 2--Possible opposition to the proposed deepening of the Delaware River channel from Philadelphia to Trenton developed this week. Mayor George E. Brunner of Camden requested Congressional aid in blocking recommendations of Army engineers until Camden was assured the project would not imperil its water supply.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Maryland's unsung Intent stepped up in class in the Santa Anita Maturity today and rang out a knockout victory over the champion, Counterpoint, and the rest of the field in the world's richest horse race.

A "best - favored - treatment" clause commonly found in offers of foreign Governments to resume interest payments on defaulted dollar debt is complicating the effort of the Republic of Peru to clear her international credit status so that she may apply with clean hands for a substantial loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

THE National Broadcasting Company, apparently, has been dissatisfied with the sound of gun shots on television. It seems that studio acoustics and stage settings combine to have an adverse effect, making them sound like toy cap pistols instead of the actual thing.

C. S. FORESTER, who wrote "The African Queen," the novel -- I make this point because Jim Agee and I did the screenplay, and if the picture isn't as fine as the book the blame ought to be put where it belongs -- has never been to Central Africa.
DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 2 -- The impending introduction of natural gas to New England is causing unrest among the men who till the soil in northern Fairfield County.

A new Catholic Center at New York University, housed in a four-story red brick structure at 69 Washington Square South, will be dedicated on Wednesday at 3 P. M. by Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York. The twin buildings were recently combined and restored at a cost of $50,000 by the Archdiocese of New York for Roman Catholic student activities.

By this time the name of Otis Barton ought to be familiar to thousands who follow the news of science. He is the man whose scientific interests and yearning for adventure prompted him to invent and build a benthoscope -which is what Would have been called a diving-bell in the last century.

Jose Iturbi accomplished the unusual feat of performing four piano concertos at his postponed concert given Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The artist also led the R. C. A. Victor Symphony from the keyboard in the presentation of these works, which were heard by a responsive capacity audience.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 3--Communist delegates negotiating for a truce in Korea rejected yesterday any form of international control over the repatriation of civilian populations displaced in the war.
A home and training school for sixty young girls is being acquired by Girls Town, Inc., a private welfare agency.

PUBLIC interest in Judith Anderson's performance in "Come of Age" has persuaded the City Center to extend the engagement one more week. That will conclude the Center's winter drama season. Although critical opinion has varied about the artistic merits of the productions, all three have been enormously successful at the box office.

TORONTO, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins opened a 2-point lead in their battle for the fourth and last National Hockey League playoff spot tonight by holding the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs to a 1-1 tie before 13,400 fans.

Franz Pick's 1951 Black Market Yearbook, published last week, is a work that opens the door to a field about which the average business man knows little -- a door that most Governments -- anxious to preserve public confidence in their currencies -- have tried to keep closed.

THE cry of "Woodman spare that tree" has been resounding from several sections of New York during recent weeks, as the result of a suggestion by the State Conservation Commissioner that the present forestry management methods employed on stats forests might be studied with the view of making such changes as scientific forestry required.
The Navy Purchasing Office at the Norfolk Naval Supply Center, said to be the Navy's biggest, likes the response of small business concerns to orders.

As the first major step toward an "atomic city of the future," Brazil plans to construct a pilot nuclear reactor in the inland mining state of Minas Geraes, Admiral Alvaro Alberto, chairman of the Brazilian National Research Council, said here last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 2 -- The growing importance of strategic materials in the world situation has stirred two bitter controversies in Brazilian Congressional circles over petroleum and rubber. Basically, economic nationalism on one side is pitted against a group on the other that feels that the vital point is to assure supplies and think of economic factors later.

ALTHOUGH American audiences have, since the war, met or become reacquainted with such outstanding European conductors as Munch, Cantelli, Paray, Ansermet. de Sabata and Kubelik, the coverage is far from complete.

IN his first public statement upon his return to Washington Senator Tom Connally, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, expressed the opinion that foreign aid should be cut. If by "foreign aid" he weans gifts to foreigners by our Government, I will go further than the Senator; I will say that "foreign aid" should be eliminated entirely.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 2 -Navy eked out a 76-74 victory over Yale's quintet in a thrilling game on the Payne Whitney court tonight.

WHEN anti-British mobs set fire to Shepheard's Hotel in Cairo eight days ago, something of Egypt itself disappeared into the night. For here, going up in flames, was an institution that symbolized an era and a way of life, a crossroads hostelry that came to mean sanctuary for some, comfort and friendliness for others.

Yesterday the United States had been fighting in Korea for 584 days -- the same number of days that it fought in World War I. U. S. casualties in Korea are now over 105,000. In World War I, U. S. casualties were 364,800; in World War II, 1,143,873.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and winter sports reports for New England:
PANA, Ill., Feb. 2 (AP) -- A Pana justice of the peace today upheld State Senator John Fribley's contention he could hunt foxes without a license.

A liberal arts education can give men and women a more constructive outlook and a better understanding of all types of people, according to alumnae of Wellesley College who joined yesterday in a panel discussion on the subject.

A plan to unite and develop on a nation-wide scale all research for helping the mentally retarded was announced last week by Nathan Feder of New York, new research chairman of the National Association of Parents and Friends of the Mentally Retarded.

AMERICAN industry has been given the job of making thousands of planes and guns and tanks and jet engines to arm ourselves and our democratic partners in Western Europe. Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson reported recently that orders for 60 billion dollars of military goods had been placed since the Korean invasion. How soon will these contracts be translated into armament rolling off assembly lines?

LEBANON, N. H., Feb. 2 -- Cooperative action of the type in action here would help considerably to cut down inroads by the South on New England's industry, it was asserted this week by Merrill J. Teulon, director of the industrial division of the New Hampshire Planning and Development Commission.

In those areas of the country where small game abounds the beagle hound, a floppy-eared, usually brown and white colored breed, has earned his laurels as a tracker. One beagle scored yesterday in Brooklyn, but his quarry was bigger game -- a burglar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The State Department announced today the conclusion of a new Point Four agreement with Pakistan that will make $10,000,000 in United States technical assistance available to the Karachi Government.
CAIRO, Feb. 2 -- The Egyptian Constitution drawn up in 1923 grants powers to the Crown. By the Constitution the Crown is the deciding factor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- More and more narcotics addicts are stealing and forging Government checks to get money for illicit drugs, the Secret Service reported today.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- The New England textile industry is currently face-to-face with the greatest crisis in its history. At least 56 cotton and rayon mills, employing 45,000 workers, have notified the union they will press for a wage cut when the current contract expires.

COUNTRY-WIDE retail sales seem to be stabilizing for the time being at around 16 per cent below 1951 levels. For two weeks running the Federal Reserve Board has reported a drop of that amount after declines of more than 20 per cent when the year began.

IN 1943 sudden death from pneumonia brought the career of one of the outstanding orientalists of modern Germany to an untimely stop. When Heinrich Zimmer died -- just after beginning his work at Columbia University -- he left behind him a prodigious collection of notes which included outlines of lectures and plans for books which he had intended to write in the twenty or more years that should have remained to him.

NEWARK, Feb. 2 -- The Port of New York Authority opened at noon today a new 2,000-foot taxiway at the airport here that officials believe will eliminate about 35 per cent of the low flying over this area.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UP) -- California's track coach and athletic director, Brutus Hamilton, an Olympic star thirty years ago, was named today to coach the American men's Olympic track team.

OSLO, Feb. 2 -- Cornzl Pajor, a former world champion speed skater from Hungary who left his homeland to escape from Communism and became a Swedish citizen, was barred tonight from competing in the Winter Olympic Games starting Feb. 14.

A coronation dinner to raise funds to pay off a $400,000 mortgage on the Regina Pacis Votive Shrine, Sixty-fifth Street and Twelfth Avenue, Brooklyn, was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania Athletic Commission "cannot go along" with the suspension imposed on heavyweight champion Jersey Joe Walcott by the State of Indiana, Commissioner John (Ox) DaGrosa said tonight.

HONG KONG, Feb. 2 -- Intensive tree planting will take place in Western Manchuria under an expanded ten-year Communist plan for establishing a long forest shelter belt to protect vulnerable Manchurian farmland against floods, drought and the sandstorms of the encroaching Mongolian desert.

SOUTH AFRICANS of Boer descent often bemoan the fact that the beauties of their young but sturdy language are inaccessible to the outside world. They will tell you, and with justice, that there is a music and a vigor in their tongue that merits a wider audience.

WOMEN enjoy finding a man embroiled in domestic difficulties, and in consequence, Albert Toombs will probably build up a following equivalent to Mario Lanza's, (among the older girls, that is). In "Raising a Riot" (1949) he certainly described the Life Complicated.
I want to congratulate you for having published some weeks ago the letter of Harvey Stevenson, president of the Fine Arts Federation of New York, urging the use of public funds for art work.

THERE will be five premieres instead of four, after all, in the forthcoming season of the New York City Ballet. George Balanchine will create something called "Divertissement Classique" to Mozart's Divertimento No. 15, with costumes designed by Christian Berard for an earlier Mozart ballet.

Pollution of many of the city's principal beaches, including Coney Island, the north shore of Queens and Jamaica Bay, will be ended by June 15 when three new large sewage disposal plants will go into operation, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen said yesterday.

THE renaissance of Mexican art that occurred after the 1910 revolution is a fascinating subject, for Mexican artists broke away from the European tradition and cast back for their inspiration to the work of their Aztec and other tribal ancestor's.

OF interest 'to cross-country motorists who like to take a busman's holiday and watch automobile races is the announcement of the 1952 season of competitions sponsored in various parts of the country by the American Automobile Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, refused today to cut the United States sugar quota below its present limit of 7,700,000 tons, saying it was low enough to help domestic producers for the year as a whole.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Feb. 2 -- Four service men fled almost naked from their burning barracks in the Alaska wilderness and survived thirty-six hours in 20 below zero weather and a 50-mile gale.

FOURTEEN selections from the works of ten prominent Russians are made available in "Soviet Legal Philosophy." The translation by Hugh W. Babb, Professor of Law at Boston University, is admirable; its English is significantly better then the Russian of the majority of the original texts.

AN impressive Centennial Exhibition of paintings, drawings and etchings by the American artist J. Alden Weir, has opened at the American Academy of Arts and Letters. Every period of his career is represented and the fact that a generation has elapsed since his death in 1919 should enable him to settle within a historical perspective.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 3 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,148, for Saturday's operations:
PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The United Nations General Assembly turned down today a Soviet-bloc demand for the repatriation of Eastern European refugees now living in Western Europe.

TELEVISION, once anathematized by movie interests, is being looked upon as the miracle invention which, properly harnessed, will put new life into the film business. That theatre operators, like the producers, are dreaming sweet dreams of potential new riches in the electronics era became more apparent last week at the annual mid-winter executive board meeting of the Theatre Owners of America.

Both the alcoholic beverage and the broadcast and television industries are assembling their forces to oppose the Johnson-Case bill in Congress which would legally bar spirits advertisements from the air. The distillers already have their own code, self-enforced since the repeal of Prohibition, against the use of radio or television for liquor advertising.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- Don Gehrmann, no longer inclined to cut it so fine, let loose with his lethal kick in the last backstretch tonight. The result: A ten-yard 4:08.9 victory over straining Fred Wilt in the Hunter mile. A near-capacity crowd of 12,541 watched this recurrent foot-racing drama at the sixty-third annual Boston Athletic Association Games in the Boston Garden.

The observation in Justice Panken's letter to THE TIMES Magazine (Jan. 20) that "nine out of ten high school graduates will never make use of their studies in botany," and his doubt as to the value of teaching higher mathematics make me indignant.

The fiftieth anniversary number of the Literary Supplement of The Times of London, which has just reached this country, is fittingly majestic. Nothing less would become so authoritative, so pre-eminent a literary organ. A brief history of its conception and contributors and some thirty pages of reprints of criticisms provide a proper monument to the occasion.

Elwin (Preacher) Roe, slim, trim southpaw who, with huge Don Newcombe heading for the Army, could very well be regarded at the moment as the Dodgers' front-line mound staff in toto, has signed his 1952 contract, it was disclosed yesterday, and that must have brought about a great sign of relief in the vicinity of Montague Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A last-minute change in strategy to save the Alaska and Hawaii statehood bills from defeat raised the prospect today of an early Senate filibuster by opposing Southerners.

MUNCIE, Ind., Feb. 2 (UP) -- Dr. Jules F. La Duron, physician who has been a "man of mystery" in this community since his second wife disappeared in 1937, was cleared of manslaughter today in a fatal shooting that he said resulted from a blackmail case.

SAXTONS RIVER, Vt., Feb. 2 -- Kimball Union Academy from Meriden, N. H., today won Vermont Academy's forty-fourth annual winter carnival, the oldest scholastic event of its kind in the country. Coach Billy Robes' charges rolled up 374.502 points to remain unbeaten and to lead Vermont Academy, Deerfield and Cushing Academy in that order.

Elwin (Preacher) Roe, slim, trim southpaw who, with huge Don Newcombe heading for the Army, could very well be regarded at the moment as the Dodgers' front-line mound staff in toto, has signed his 1952 contract, it was disclosed yesterday, and that must have brought about a great sign of relief in the vicinity of Montague Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A last-minute change in strategy to save the Alaska and Hawaii statehood bills from defeat raised the prospect today of an early Senate filibuster by opposing Southerners.

MUNCIE, Ind., Feb. 2 (UP) -- Dr. Jules F. La Duron, physician who has been a "man of mystery" in this community since his second wife disappeared in 1937, was cleared of manslaughter today in a fatal shooting that he said resulted from a blackmail case.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- Don Gehrmann, no longer inclined to cut it so fine, let loose with his lethal kick in the last backstretch tonight. The result: A ten-yard 4:08.9 victory over straining Fred Wilt in the Hunter mile. A near-capacity crowd of 12,541 watched this recurrent foot-racing drama at the sixty-third annual Boston Athletic Association Games in the Boston Garden.

The observation in Justice Panken's letter to THE TIMES Magazine (Jan. 20) that "nine out of ten high school graduates will never make use of their studies in botany," and his doubt as to the value of teaching higher mathematics make me indignant.

The fiftieth anniversary number of the Literary Supplement of The Times of London, which has just reached this country, is fittingly majestic. Nothing less would become so authoritative, so pre-eminent a literary organ. A brief history of its conception and contributors and some thirty pages of reprints of criticisms provide a proper monument to the occasion.
OSLO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Norwegian speed skaters dominated the two-day international meet which ended today. Olympic competitors from six nations competed.

The long-standing controversy between Hoboken and the Government over three city piers, which were seized from German interests in World War I, may be revived by Mayor Fred M. DeSapio's most recent effort to get control of the docks.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 3 -- French "hunger" for the Saar has confirmed the decision of the Socialist Opposition to oppose a West German contribution to European defense, Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, declared today.

Cash awards and citations were presented last night in absentia to three chaplains of the armed services for "concentrated service and idealism" devoted to interfaith and goodwill during the year. This was done at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel given by the Chaplain Alexander D. Goode Lodge B'nai B'rith.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The retirement age for British civil servants has been raised from 60 to 65, it was announced tonight. Retirement at 60 is optional, but those who undergo tests proving "an acceptable standard of efficiency" may remain at work.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Eight-year-old Jacqueline Mea of Berkeley Heights is ordinarily obedient to her parents' wishes except in cases of emergency and especially if the emergency involves a dog. She disobeyed yesterday and was almost drowned in Seeley's Pond.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Prof. P. A. M. Dirac of Cambridge University, a Nobel Prize winner and one of the most original mathematical physicists in Britain, has stirred up speculation in scientific circles here by producing a series of equations to demonstrate a new theory of electrodynamics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Henry H. Fowler, administrator of the National Production Authority, has suggested that the building industry blueprint new construction projects even in the face of present scarcities in materials.

ZURICH, Feb. 3 -- Coming at a time when concern was growing over the increasing difficulty of keeping the European Payments Union solvent, the drastic measures taken last week by Britain to square her balance of payments have won cordial approval here despite the severe blow dealt to Swiss tourist business.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 3 -- The Dutch capital market has been suddenly flooded by numerous municipal loans for housing construction. Municipalities so far have been prevented from obtaining such funds by the Government's cheap money policy, which barred them from paying interest above 4 per cent.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (Reuters) -Slick continental operators are snatching thousands of dollars right from under Britain's nose with a complex system of trafficking in silver between London and New York.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Ian Mikardo, a member of the Bevanite wing of the Labor party in the House of Commons, charged tonight that the United States had decided on war against Communist China and that Prime Minister Churchill knew of the decision and was not resisting it.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 3 -- Sharp and divergent reactions erupted from the pulpits of Roman Catholic and Protestant clergymen here today in a controversy over birth control.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, demanded again today that President Truman say where he, the Senator, misquoted from loyalty reports on Philleo Nash, Presidential aide. He offered to lend the President what he said were his copies of Federal Bureau of Investigation files on Mr. Nash.

After reading Dr. Arthur M. Master's letter in your columns I am impelled to make the following comment on one item without intending to reflect in any way upon the many other admirable performances of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

Louis E. Yavner, former Commissioner of Investigation under the late Mayor F. H. LaGuardia, has been invited to head a staff of investigators in the new checkup on Federal corruption by Newbold Morris, former President of the City Council.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Long liquidation was heavy on the Board of Trade last week, resulting in substantial declines. At times, rallies developed but failed to hold. The pressure on high moisture corn has weakened the spot markets, and made for at least temporary weakness in futures.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 3 -- In a major bid for world trade and water commerce, the $20,000,000 Savannah state docks and warehouse system of the Georgia Port Authority will be completed and formally opened for business in November, 1952.

GEITHUS, Norway, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Art Tokle of Brooklyn, N. Y., today registered the longest jump in the international ski tournament here, but finished fourth in the final standings because he failed to score enough points on form.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3 -- The steel industry last week was again on the trail of a new production record. In the past, on an upward trend, the month of March has been a peak month. This year will be no exception unless a steel strike should interfere.

A huge, white Department of Sanitation truck sat all day yesterday athwart the sidewalk at 1742 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, its nose buried in a wooden dwelling. The police were afraid to move the truck lest the three-story structure collapse.

One woman was killed and her sister critically injured when they were struck by a single-decker Fifth Avenue Coach Company bus while crossing Fort Washington Avenue at 180th Street at 10:40 o'clock last night.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3 -- Mexico's wilderness of mountains and jungles is more of a deterrent to an invasion of North America through this country than is her military strength. This situation satisfies neither the United States nor Mexican military chiefs.

Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Joseph are scheduled to present New York City's financial problem to State Legislative leaders today in Albany. The city's need for more revenues is conceded by such reputable and impartial expert consultants as Professors Haig and Shoup, who, under Dr. Gulick's direction, studied the question exhaustively for the Mayor's Management Survey.

HERBERT A. PHILBRICK, son of a railroad trainman, father of five pretty daughters, Baptist Sunday School teacher, is in many ways a typical American citizen. He got his college education by night study while he supported himself with a full-time job. He is energetic, extroverted and gregarious, a modestly successful advertising man.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 3 -- The possibility of a Congressional inquiry loomed today in lower Delaware, following regional investigations of an uncompleted housing project at near-by Delmar.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver's Presidential ambitions are receiving the cold-shoulder treatment from many of the Tennessean's fellow Southerners in the Senate.

TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Feb. 3 -- The Riff is so quiet nowadays that one hardly can hear a ghost. Only the echoes of the wind moan through the cruel mountains from which Abd el Krim's warriors shelled this city twenty odd years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Today was a red-letter day for three girls -- two of them little, one grown. They all met the President.

In the big city, where most power lines are hidden underground and hence protected against storm and wind, it is rare that the supply of electricity fails, leaving the citizen in a darkness all the more black because its arrival is sudden.

Irregular price movements prevailed last week in the domestic cotton market. On the New York Cotton Exchange, the nearby March and May deliveries registered net gains of 21 and 7 points, respectively, for the week, but other active contracts had declines of 20 to 57 points.

Manufacturers' shipments of passenger tire casings fell sharply last year, the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc., announced yesterday. The total for the year was 61,811,110 units, a decrease of 26.78 per cent from the 1950 total.

A number or display messages have been prepared by the Office of Price Stabilization in answer to requests from business men who want to assure their customers that they are cooperating with the program.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 3 -- A plea for more active participation in Jewish temple activities was made this morning by Sidney Roos, president of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, at the cornerstone-laying ceremonies of Temple Emanu-El of Long Beach at Neptune Boulevard and East Chester Street.

SAARBRUECKEN, The Saar, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Hermann Roechling, 79, "Krupp of the Saar," is on the verge of selling to United States interests the remnants of his multi-million dollar iron and steel kingdom, Saar industrial circles reported today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (UP) -- The United States Olympic hockey team defeated Switzerland, 6 to 4, today as angry Swiss fans tried to storm the penalty box to fight with American players who, they thought, were guilty of excessive rough play.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- A spectacular second-round flight of 149 feet, the longest of the day, enabled Bernhard Blikstad, 27-year-old Norwegian from the host Telemark Ski Club, to upset Sigurd Sorensen of Norway in the New York State Class A ski-jumping championship today.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Reaction of the City, particularly the stock markets, to the further proposals of Richard Austen Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, for dealing with Britain's economic situation, has been slight but favorable.

Approximately forty-two characters selected from the ageless works of Charles Dickens will be re-animated by Emlyn Williams himself, starting at 8 o'clock this evening at the Golden. A word of caution: latecomers will not be seated during the first scene.

Bald-headed men will have reason to be proud of their lack of hair if the plan of a Waltham, Mass., lumber dealer is successful. Donald B. Hyde, whose own hair line has receded, is enlisting their aid to save from extinction the bald eagle, symbol of the United States.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Boston's Celtics made good on 42 of 50 foul shots as they came from behind to beat the New York Knickerbockers, 100 -- 95, in a National Basketball Association contest today.
The selection of eight delegates at large from this state to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago has been virtually completed by party leaders.
Miss Kate Wollman, who gave $600,000 in 1949 for a skating rink in Central Park, has decided to make New York children the beneficiaries of another substantial gift.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Prison Association of New York, in its annual report to the Legislature, urged the establishment of a division of research in the Corrections Department today as one means of improving the rehabilitation of prisoners.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Heavyweight Champion Jersey Joe Walcott, eager to accept a lucrative offer to fight Harry (Kid) Matthews, apparently made little progress today in an attempt to postpone meeting former champion Ezzard Charles in a return bout.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 3 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar has been meeting with members of the Government, including the Defense, Finance and Foreign Ministers, to define Portugal's attitude toward questions that will be discussed during the conference of the North Atlantic Treaty organization that will open here Feb. 16.
Milton S. Greenebaum has been appointed metropolitan New York sales manager for Gibson's Diamond Eight Blended Whisky, which is marketed by Melrose Distillers, Inc. He joined Melrose in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -The National Foundation for Consumer Credit announced its intention today to make a finish fight for repeal of "Regulation W," which controls the buying of household goods on time.
" Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea" now has been done on television. But even Jules Verne could have foreseen the results.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- The signing of an agreement between Armour Co. and the United Packinghouse Workers of America, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, granting a 6-cents-an-hour wage increase for more than 30,000 workers in twenty-six plants as well as other adjustments in the union's contract with the packing company was announced today.
The New York City Cancer Committee, 7 East Fifty-second Street, will begin today three new projects to ease the suffering of cancer patients and one to detect cancer.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Henry Williams Jr., a pro who looks like a professor, played it safe today and won the $10,000 Tucson open golf tournament. His one-over-par 71 gave him a 72-hole total of 274 and his first major victory.

The fundamental issue in the difficult evolution of the European army was at last raised last week by the West German Government when it staked a claim to participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Bob McAllister of Ventnor, N.J., set a world record in the second heat for 48 cubic inch Z Class runabouts today after being spilled in the first heat.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Danny Thomas is about to close a deal to acquire screen rights to George Jessel's autobiography, "So Help Me," which was published in 1943. Mr. Jessel today admitted that negotiations had reached the contract-signing stage and said he couldn't think of anyone better qualified than Thomas to portray him.

MOREHEAD CITY, N. C., Monday, Feb. 4 (UP) -- A disabled freighter with twenty-six men aboard was driven aground off North Carolina's outer banks last night in the path of a freak off-season "cyclonic storm" heading in from the Atlantic.

There is no little significance in the overwhelming vote by which the General Assembly resisted the Soviet attempt to bring up a discussion of Korean issues and supported the resolution providing for a postponement of such a discussion until after an armistice had been reached in the field.

DETROIT, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay's last-minute goal enabled the Detroit Red Wings to defeat the New York Rangers, 4 to 3, tonight in a hard-fought National Hockey League game before 13,134 fans at Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund announced today that it had dropped Dr. Frank V. Colombo, owner and operator of the Dragerton Hospital in Utah, "because of certain practices and the size of fees collected from the fund for minor services."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Harold L. Ickes, who was Secretary of Interior throughout the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, died tonight in Emergency Hospital, where he was under treatment for complications of a former arthritic condition.

Plans for the erection of a one-story industrial building were announced in connection with the sale of a plot of vacant land containing 21,000 square feet between Forty-third and Forty-fifth Streets, in Astoria, Queens, by R. A. Weisner to a client of Harold Hirstein, attorney, Louis Landsman was the broker.
An increase in dollar volume in the first half of the year over the 1951 period is expected by a majority of 131 manufacturing companies surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board.

In your columns of Jan. 26 Whitney N. Seymour, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, is reported to have said that the Communists have had trouble finding reputable lawyers to represent them because the Communists refuse to let lawyers have the customary freedom of action to conduct the defense as they think best.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Canada has stopped all shipments of beef into the United States and has drastically cut the movement of cattle, while this country is sending cattle to Canada for the first time in many years, the Canadian Department of Agriculture disclosed today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A chunky gunman in United States Army uniform kidnapped the red-haired 18-year-old step-daughter of a United States Army sergeant near Hanau tonight while she was riding in a car with two American soldiers.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Mayor Impellitteri has arranged to meet separately with Governor Dewey tomorrow while he is in Albany to discuss New York's financial problems for next year with leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Big Ed Sandford, back after two weeks in sick bay, teamed with Goalie Jim Henry tonight to give Boston a 1-0 victory over Montreal. As a result the Bruins strengthened their grip on fourth place in the National Hockey League.
Manhattan's great mile relay team came up with the show-stealing performance for the second straight week at the Boston Athletic Association games last Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Following are tributes on the death of Mr. Ickes:

The Gracie Square Theatre, a 2,200-seat motion-picture house at the northeast corner of First Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, has been sold by the trustees of Columbia University to Evan M. Frankel, designer and builder, who plans to alter the building for occupancy by television or motion-picture companies.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The police were without a major clue today in the search for Winnie Ruth Judd, trunk murderess who broke out of the State Hospital for the Insane last night in her fifth escape.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- United States Air Force F-51 Mustangs set fire yesterday to a large Communist troop and supply area on the west coast of North Korea with rockets and jellied gasoline.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- General Headquarters Communique 1,149, for Sunday's operations:
Residents of the city were warned yesterday that they were "risking death" if they kept their windows closed with gas-flame appliances in operation.

BEDFORD, Pa., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Representative Vera Buchanan of McKeesport, Pa., was injured in an auto wreck on the Pennsylvania Turnpike tonight a few hours after she had been endorsed as a candidate for re-election on the Democratic ticket.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Plans were reported under way today for construction of a $25,000,000 horse racing track in the metropolitan New York City area.

TULLAHOMA, Tenn., Feb. 3 -- Unions and management have signed a contract that rules out strikes, lockouts and work stoppages in operation of the $157,500,000 Arnold Engineering Development Center here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- The National Council of Presbyterian Men ended its three-day annual meeting here today with a plea by Thomas E. Whiteman, newly elected president, to begin a campaign of civic righteousness to "shock" the nation out of its "blissful siesta."

Mayor Impellitteri, in calling attention to the serious political situation in the Middle East, asserted yesterday that "Israel is our ally in that troubled part of the world," and that "in the clash between tyranny and freedom, the United States needs helpful allies."

How to make machine tools readily available to manufacturers will be discussed by the board of directors of the Machinery Dealers National Association at a meeting in the Statler Hotel, St. Louis, on Wednesday.

To count on Turkey "to persuade the Arab nations to join in the Middle East defense system" is scarcely the realistic approach which THE NEW YORK TIMES usually brings to its editorials. Not only did the United States, Britain and France fail to engage in any consultations with these nations prior to the announced proposal of the new defense plan but Turkey was added as one of the original inviting Powers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona, Senate majority leader, declared tonight he would oppose any effort to displace debate and a vote on Alaskan statehood as the pending business of the Senate.

Although most of us have been nourished on the idea of being "on our own," our personal strengths and abilities cannot find full expression without the support of higher authority, the Rev. Dr. James A. Pike declared yesterday morning in his first sermon as Dean-designate of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
At lunch time the Beau Brummel restaurant that Daniel Belmont recently opened at 65 East Fifty-fourth Street caters principally to men. Women are allowed only if they have escorts.
