PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Britain's position in the European Payments Union deteriorated further in January. E. P. U. statistics show that the British deficit for the month was about $150,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Billy Graham, the evangelist, told a crowd from the steps of the United States Capitol today that "if I would run for President of the United States today, on a platform of calling the people back to God, back to Christ, back to the Bible, I'd be elected.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- Support of Israel was urged tonight by Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, at the concluding session of a national planning conference on aid for the new state.

THE actors get older but the acting gets worse every year at the Baseball Writers Show, a stirring production which plummeted to new depths at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. It must have set back the dramatic art at least a full century before these temporary disciples of the sock-and-buskin profession departed from the stage, unwept, unhonored, unsung -- and still unrehearsed.

Quoting the inscription on United States coins, "In God We Trust," the Rev. Harry J. Wolff of St. Patrick's Cathedral clergy deplored yesterday materialistic Americans whose "outlook and actions demonstrate they trust in the coin and are completely oblivious of God's existence and our dependence on Him."

Mario Del Monaco will sing the role in Verdi's "Otello" for his first time in the Metropolitan Opera's fourteenth week, which begins next Monday. During the week, Paolo Silveri will sing his first Escamillo with the company.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 3 -- Miss Charlotte Mills, daughter of one of the victims in the sensational Hall-Mills murder case here in September, 1922, died on Friday in the Middlesex Nursing Home, in Metuchen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee declared today he was confident he could win the Democratic Presidential nomination even if President Truman should run again.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Under a consistent instead of a spattering and puffy wind, twenty sailing dinghies had a marathon in the way of racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Feb. 3 -- Edi Mall, 27-year-old Austrian ski professional, and Miss Virginia (Jimmie) Snively, a 1951 graduate of Middlebury College, today won the Harvey Gibson Memorial Trophy ski races.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations will start today a campaign for elimination of all profits to private insurance companies and brokers in workmen's compensation coverage.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Burmese Government forces have launched large-scale offensive Operations against Communist insurgents, and first reports from official quarters said today that at least 130 Communists had been slain.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Britain has been experimenting with a form of traffic control that is a compromise between the rights of pedestrians and the necessities of modern urban life.

PANAMA, Feb. 3 -- The disruption of oil production in Iran, the trouble at Suez and the east coast longshoremen's strike were reflected in traffic changes in the Panama Canal during the last quarter of 1951, according to a study published in the Canal Review here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (UP) -- Mid-winter college graduates can practically take their pick of jobs, with engineering students getting as many as ten to twenty offers, a survey of colleges across the country showed today.
The Giants disclosed yesterday that Wes Westrum, their first-string catcher, had accepted terms for 1952.

Mrs. Rosa Caruso, 50-year-old mother of five children, brought the fatalities in the Elizabeth, N. J., American Airlines crash of Jan. 22 to thirty when she died at St. Elizabeth's Hospital there yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 3 -- Further evidence of the strain between the American Federation of Labor and its chief world allies appeared today in a declaration by its executive council calling for abolition of the 1936 treaty between Egypt and Britain and for immediate home rule for Tunisia as part of the French Commonwealth.
With pennies, nickels and dimes marking his trail, a 9-year-old boy led a Brooklyn patrolman on a three-block chase yesterday after having allegedly broken into a five-and-ten-cent store.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Trading on the Board of Trade increased moderately last week, purchases of wheat, corn, oats and rye futures all being larger than last week. Volume, however, was much lighter than last year despite free long liquidation which usually spells increased activity.

Members of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship observed the ninth anniversary of the battle of Stalingrad yesterday at a luncheon in the Brevoort Hotel, Fifth Avenue at Eighth Street, at which speakers praised Russia's peace efforts and condemned "warmongering" in America.

To give real, lasting help to unmarried mothers it is necessary to do more than merely provide a solution to their immediate difficulty -- they must be helped to understand themselves and know why they got into the difficulty in the first place, Mrs. I. Edwin Goldwasser, civic leader, declared yesterday.

MADRID, Feb. 3 -- Entering an unknown country for the first time is always an exciting adventure. When the unknown land is as controversial and complex as Spain, the eyes and mind of the most jaded traveler are sharpened by an intense curiosity. It is like opening a book read in translation and trying to spell out the original text for oneself.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein reported to the Legislature today that the State Law Department had collected a total of $4,228,908 for the state in litigation last year and that it had shaved $13,192,034 off the amount of claims filed against the state.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Measures invoked by European governments failed throughout 1951 to halt the inflationary spiral and prospects are that 1952 will confront them with even greater difficulties, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.
The theory that people can be "equal but separate is a myth,", Dr. Leland S. Cozart, president of Barber-Scotia College, Concord, N. C., declared yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Abandonment of hope that the United Nations would admit any new members during the current session of the General Assembly was reflected today in publication of a working schedule that virtually precluded such action.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 (UP) -- Kid Gavilan, shaken by a sleepless night in a storm, makes the second defense of his world welterweight crown tomorrow night against Bobby Dykes of Texas.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- Donald R. Wilson, national commander of the American Legion, today called on the 4,000,000 men and women of the legion "to spearhead a movement for the spiritual reawakening of all Americans."

Germany is making altogether too much fuss about the Saar. Putting the worst possible construction on the French action in raising the status of its High Commissioner to Ambassador, it was a slight turn of the screw in the tenacious effort to separate the Saar permanently from Germany.

Mayor Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph, who will confer in Albany this afternoon on the city's $285,900,000 program for fiscal aid, contend that the city must have at least $200,000,000 of additional revenue to produce a balanced budget for 1952-53 without curtailing vital city services and denying pay rises to its employees.
Lily Dumont, Berlin pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Shunning shorter pieces, she confined her program to four well-known works of considerable length.
CAIRO, Feb. 3 -- The Cairo rioting of Jan. 26 has presented to Britain and the United States a wholly unexpected opportunity to bring back to life the proposed Middle East Command alliance.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Under actions pending in the courts, millions of acres in the United States and its possessions are being taken from private owners for public use.

The United Advertising Corporation has elected a woman as an officer for the first time in the agency's history. Mrs. Edwina Cavanagh, who joined the finance and auditing department ten years ago and has been in charge of accounting for the agency and its divisions, has been chosen assistant secretary and assistant treasurer of the corporation and its affiliated companies.

" Growing up" might be a lot less painful for American young people -- and their parents -- if a national referendum could be arranged to settle such thorny points as at what age a girl may start dating and how old a boy should be to take the family car alone.

GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- In an analysis made public today of Soviet economic statistics, the research division of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe demolished most of the picture of a peace-loving country devoting its resources to furthering the welfare of its people that Soviet spokesmen have presented to the rest of the world.
Six new films, including importations from England and South Africa, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 3 -- The Nassau County unit of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn department store, will open here late this month. The new store, located at Fulton Avenue at Hilton, will be the largest and most complete suburban department store operation in the Northeastern United States, according to an A. S. announcement.

On last night's continuation of the Choral Masterwork Series Robert Shaw is giving in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Shaw conducted the Hindemith and Brahms works. Helen Hosmer took over after the intermission to lead the Des Pres "Miserere" and the New York premiere of Norman Dello Joio's "Psalm of David."

TURIN, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- Andy Tommy, Canadian skier representing St. Lawrence University, came careening down the slopes of Snow Ridge today for a sweep of the slalom and downhill events of the Army's Exercise Snowfall ski meet.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 3 -- The vast majority of the 2,400 cadets at the United States Military Academy here would resign in protest if ninety cadets, discharged for cheating during examinations, were "allowed to remain in the corps," according to a statement in the alumni magazine, Assembly.

The Blood Donor program during the war was carried on in the old Tiffany building when the jewelry firm moved into its new store on upper Fifth Avenue. No precious ruby that had ever graced the windows of that place was ever as priceless as the crimson stream of America's life-blood which was given there by loyal and patriotic citizens.
A large number of group exhibitions and one-man shows make up the customary variety of this art week in New York.

Motion picture theaters would be excluded from the provisions of a proposed change in the zoning law requiring large buildings used for retail, wholesale, manufacturing or storage purposes to provide off-street berths for trucks. The change is among new zoning proposals slated for early consideration by the City Planning Commission.

The five-story dwelling at 22 West Fifty-fifth Street, formerly the home of the late Vernon C. Brown, has been sold by the Castle Operating Corporation, Mrs. Ruth Axe, president, to the Institute of Effective Speaking and Human Relations, which plans to convert it into a school building from plans by Joseph Casale, architect.

Southwestern Public Service Company is offering today to its stockholders 251,540 shares of additional common stock at $17.50 a share at the rate of one share for each thirteen held. The offer expires on Feb. 14. A banking syndicate, headed by Dillon, Read Co., is underwriting the transaction.

The Canadian dollar last week suffered its first setback since itq climbed to parity with American, begun about a month ago. London selling which set in on Thursday and carried into Friday, dumped the rate to 90.28 cents from par; the week's final of 99.625 cents, represented a loss of 11/32 cent from the preceding week.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 3 -- Problems connected with the building of the Vietnamese Army by the Government of Vietnam were understood to be one of the chief topics of the discussion over the week-end between Jean Letourneau, French Minister for the Indo-China States, and Bao Dai, Vietnam's Chief of State.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- In a stimulating spring collection, Jacques Fath abandons the excessively full skirt for one of restrained or moderate flare, dropped to fourteen and a half inches for daytime and to ten for dancing. He calls his new line "The Round."

An investing client of G. Wartels, attorney, bought the five-story building housing twenty-five families on plot 63 by 120 feet at 2607 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, from the Hegra Realty Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $25,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Representative Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, charged today that Newbold Morris, President Truman's new investigator of corruption in Government, had let himself be used by Communist front organizations and should therefore "disqualify" himself from any Federal service.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- To overcome a rising deficit in the balance of trade and to defend the franc, the French Government announced tonight it had decided on a drastic cut in imports by the re-establishment of quotas for goods from the other countries of the European Payments Union.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A decrease in net income for the fiscal year ended last Nov. 30 was announced by the International Shoe Company today despite an all-time sales record of $223,317,150.

When Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation and member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, died on March 15, 1944, the Government lost one of its finest career men and the nation one of its wisest counselors in the field of public administration.

A plaque honoring the rescue role of the towboat Bill Endter in a recent East River airplane crash will be presented to the vessel's captain and crew tomorrow morning, in a ceremony at the Barber, N. J., plant of the California Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee reported today that the Government could recover most of the millions of dollars lost through unscrupulous practices of grain warehouses, but declared that other millions had been wasted by a faulty grain storage policy.

Hearty congratulations to THE TIMES and Milton Esterow for the story on missing house numbers in the city. The loss in time (and business) among those who search for the right address is incalculable. With enough official pressure the condition can be corrected.

Two United States Olympic teams left from Idlewild International Airport yesterday for the Winter Games at Oslo, Norway, which start on Feb. 14. The figure skating squad, complete except for Dick Button, the defending singles champion who is in Europe, was headed by its coach, Harry E. Radix of Chicago.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 4 -- The Communists made some concessions yesterday in the negotiations at Panmunjom for an armistice in Korea.

The marines at Quantico, Va., who made better grades when they lived in drab mud - surrounded Quonset huts than their buddies who lived in comfortable barracks, probably had greater motivation and incentive, prominent educators and psychologists suggest.

Eliot Hearst of Columbia, still undefeated in the annual title tournament at the Marshall Chess Club, gained an additional half point yesterday in a drawn game with Edmar Mednis, who played the two knights defense. The match involved only 19 moves.

" When I started in business I did not think about women's fashions," said the creator of today's garments in the American Designer Series of the Patterns of The Times, as he and the writer lingered over luncheon.

Harold Ickes' severest critics would have to admit that he added to the interest and zest of life in America, and that his death leaves us all a little duller. The Ickes personality and the Ickes achievements were artistically mingled, but there can be no doubt that the personality helped to draw public attention and support to the Ickes program.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 3 -- United States aid to Israel assumed tangible form today with the arrival in Haifa of the freighter Laurentian Valley carrying the first cargo of food ordered under the terms of the United States grant-in-aid for 1951-52.
MOSCOW, Feb 3. -- Why did Pravda, organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party, publish the speech by Herbert Hoover that was broadcast throughout the United States on Jan. 27?

The American student in France is often confused at first by the precision of French university thought as contrasted to the casualness of French university life, but if he can stick it out he can acquire an enormous respect for French education, a Columbia University professor reported yesterday.
An exchange of letters made public yesterday disclosed that I. Howard Lehman, one of the two trustees of the Third Avenue Railroad System, had resigned as one Saturday.

The backing and filling and stalling that has gone on in Congress over the bills to grant statehood to Alaska and Hawaii is no credit to the United States or to the elected representatives of its citizens. It has been established for some considerable time that a substantial majority of Americans and their representatives believe that the two new States should be added.

Judge J. Waties Waring of Charleston, S. C., has just resigned his seat after ten years of good and faithful service on a Federal district bench. Judge Waring was born in Charleston, of a family which has been in South Carolina for ten generations. His father served in the Confederate Army.

To keep man from "constantly jumping out of spiritual windows" personal and spiritual security should be fostered in youth, the Rev. Laurance I. Neale said yesterday morning at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., has served notice on Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley that it intends to "use all its strength" to block his plan to convert Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way operation.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 3 -- While Government newspapers maintained silence, all Opposition elements celebrated today the 100th anniversary of the overthrow of Juan Manuel de Rosas, an Argentine tyrant.

To some 1,400 baseball enthusiasts, including most of the game's outstanding figures, the world must have appeared completely upside down and inside out for a few hours in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.
Rayon and acetate yarn and staple-tow production set a record in this country last year.

Victor Moore has agreed to the terms of a contract to portray Alexander Throttlebottom, the vice president who is always ignored, in the forthcoming revival of "Of Thee I Sing," which Chandler Cowles and Bennett Segal are producing. The comedian created the part in the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical satire in 1931.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The International Materials Conference allocated 22,951 metric tons of primary nickel to the United States today for the first quarter of 1952.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- The production of a feature-length color film in three dimensions will be undertaken shortly by Arch Oboler, the independent producer, writer and director announced today. Thus Mr. Oboler will be the first Hollywood producer to put to practical test the advances in movie photography the Natural Vision Corporation demonstrated here last June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the constitutionality of New York State laws under which the showing of the Italian motion picture, "The Miracle," was banned on the ground that it was sacrilegious.
After living in constant fear of execution or deportation during the last thirteen years, members of the persecuted Psittacine family have been restored to citizenship in the local avicultural world.

The State Department of Social Welfare and the New York City Welfare Department are again engaged in one of those public exchanges of acrimonious charges that seem regrettable and unnecessary. The state starts it with a broadside carrying the implication that comparatively little progress has been made in improving the efficiency of the city department since the expose of four years ago, the hotel-and-mink-coat era.

TWO years ago the committee on whose behalf we write asked Robert P. Patterson to act as counsel for the committee and to present the case for United States Senate ratification of the convention to outlaw genocide adopted in December, 1948, by the United Nations.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Two Communist MIG jets were damaged in a brief fight over Northwest Korea yesterday, the United States Fifth Air Force reported today.
O. D. Rice has been named manager of operations for the Rust Furnace Company, Pittsburgh. H. Hayward Dinneen has been named chief engineer, succeeding Mr. Rice.

Documents antedating 1935, bearing on the way defendant investment bankers in the current anti-trust suit did business decades ago, reappeared in the trial at the Federal court here yesterday following a formal ruling by Judge Harold R. Medina admitting a limited number of pre-1935 documents as Government evidence.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- Congress was urged today to restore the legality of state fair trade laws to protect small business men and prevent "a new out-break of vicious price wars."
BRISTOL, Va.-Tenn., Feb. 4 -- Civic leaders said today that the national Red Cress has refused to collect blood here because of a policy fight with the local chapter over how to collect money.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,150, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

The announcement by the Arab-Asian bloc of its intention to carry the Tunisian case to the Security Council means that the United Nations is going to have to struggle with this problem after all. This is regrettable, but it is the sort of development that has to be expected in the contemporary world. "Colonialism" or "imperialism" in Africa, the Middle East and Asia is one of the most dynamic and urgent problems of our times.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that Sidney Smith, an official of its Production and Marketing Administration's Kansas City office, had been suspended. The action was taken pending an inquiry into the circumstances under which about $84,000 of storage fees was paid to the V. M. Harris Grain Company after an order had been issued stopping any further disbursement of storage fees to that concern.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission met for the first time today and the United States announced that it was preparing "specific proposals" on the job of planning balanced arms reduction and atomic control.
A 6-year-old child, playing with matches, set off a four-alarm fire at 8 A. M. yesterday in the Manhattan Beach Veterans Housing Project that left thirty-two families homeless.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A left-handed hook shot by Frank Kudelka with six seconds remaining gave the Baltimore Bullets an 82-81 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers tonight.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that beginning March 14 service on most of the Third Avenue elevated line would be shut down during the night hours daily and throughout Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. The board members said they took the action on the recommendation of Edward T. McNally, general superintendent of the New York City Transit System.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel company, disclosed today it had entered for the first time the small group of "billion dollar" American companies.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The subdued elegance of nut brown, putty, beige, soft yellow, charcoal gray, white and black -- but no navy -- runs through the Jean Desses models. Stripped of any trimming, they have a cut that is eminently couture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Because of Congressional differences, the State Department has deferred again the selection of the director of the new International Migration Committee. This became known today as George L. Warren, United States delegate, departed for the Feb. 18 meeting of the committee in Geneva.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 4 -- Federal Chancellor Konrad Adenauer demanded tonight that the Allies meet West Germany's wishes on the future of the Saar and representation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as the price of the Federal Republic's cooperation in the defense of Europe.

Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that to grant the wage demands of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., without a price rise would set a pattern that would cost the Government $11,000,000,000 in tax revenues from industry in general.

Because of the general unwillingness of banks to face cost-realities, many trust departments and their customers may become the victims of the "economic hurricane" likely to follow the "current inflationary cyclone," Harry M. Bardt, vice president of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, declared yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -- The Iranian Cabinet, meeting at the bedside of ailing Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, decided tonight to close down certain foreign "cultural institutions" in Iran.

The stock market was hammered down yesterday to the lows of 1952 as sellers found no opposition. In a volume of trading approximating those of last week's sessions, the list suffered its worst setback in more than three months, the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index retreating 2.17 points.
Trustees of St. Joseph Lead Company voted a cash dividend on the common stock yesterday and recommended that the capital stock be increased.
CAIRO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha said today that he was working actively for a better understanding between Egypt and "all the powers of the free world."

On Jan. 22 THE TIMES printed letter from Abraham Wisotsky, assistant business representative of the New York Typographical Union No. 6, expressing his amazement at a TIMES editorial endorsing Permanent Personal Registration. Mr. Wisotsky described P. P. R. as a "monstrosity" opposed by "the enlightened citizens of our state for many years."
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 4 (AP) -- St. John's of Brooklyn completed a two-game conquest of Western Conference basketball teams tonight by beating Purdue, 64-53, on a 25-point performance by Bob Zawoluk.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 -- Public Service transit workers won today a 17-cent hourly wage increase and a reduction of their work week from forty-four hours to forty hours. State Treasurer Walter Margetts, who arbitrated the long wage dispute between Public Service Coordinated Transport and the union ruled that further increases in pay during the next two years would be governed by the cost of living index.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The United Nations General Assembly approved today a resolution asking the Economic and Social Council to reconsider its decisions regarding the Commission on the Status of Women so that it could be convened once a year.

Governor Dewey has at last gotten around to a consideration of the billboard nuisance. Governor Lehman wanted the whole nuisance studied and controlled, and so recommended. Until now Governor Dewey, in spite of appeals, has ignored the matter.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Assembly passed by a vote of 134 to 12 tonight and sent to the Senate a bill aimed at preventing such Communist picketing demonstrations as those during the Federal trial of eleven top Communist officials in New York City in 1949 and 1950. Opposing the bill were one Republican and eleven Democrats.

The simulated use of atomic weapons in Exercise Snowfall, the current Army-Air Force winter exercise at Camp Drum, N. Y., has underscored the need for a vast program of military education in atomic capabilities and limitations.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 4 -- The need for high echelon leadership emerged from the conferences between French and Vietnamese leaders last week-end as one of the early requirements for the new military forces being created under the Bao Dai Government of Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Col. John H. Van Vliet, author of a long-missing secret report on the Katyn Forest massacre in World War II, testified today that he believed the Russians themselves slaughtered upward of 10,000 Polish soldiers in a Soviet prison camp in 1940.
James J. Moran, former First Deputy Fire Commissioner, rested his case yesterday without taking the stand in his trial in General Sessions on charges of extortion and conspiracy.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- Fifty - three Archbishops, Bishops and apostolic administrators either are "in prison for the faith" or have been deported or impeded from carrying out their pastoral mission in European Communist-dominated countries, including Yugoslavia, according to an official statement issued by the Vatican today.
Brooklyn pupils, who may have wondered whether scientific principles taught in class have any practical value to the average individual, will have an opportunity to find out for themselves.

Maine Public Service Company is giving to its common stockholders until Feb. 25 the right to subscribe to 35,000 additional shares of common stock at $15.25 a share on the basis of one additional share for each five shares held Feb. 4.

A recommendation that the city have a code of standards and ethics, "which would be a guide and yardstick to every employe -- beginning with the Mayor himself," was made to Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, yesterday by Stanley Kreutzer, Honorary Commissioner of Borough Works.

The need for spiritual planning to match municipal planning in this city was stressed yesterday by Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church (Methodist), in an address at a luncheon marking the opening of the annual fund raising drive of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill's Government is calling a meeting next April to decide whether a big new African federal state can be formed.

Everybody is getting into the contest act. Until recently only the consuming public received prizes for participating in radio quiz shows or struggling fiercely to develop the right soap powder slogan. Now an important element of business -- the retailer -- is receiving contest rewards.

THE sport of hunting still has its growing pains. A report of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service indicates that 12,660,993 persons paid $37,840,791 for licenses during the year which ended June 30, 1951.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 -- Ford's theatre, the only one in Baltimore still booking available Broadway attractions, has dropped its policy of Negro segregation, in effect since its opening in 1871.

" Reckless and misleading," "unbelievably phony" and containing "a tortured effort to mislead" -- this was the way the New York State Department of Social Welfare's recent survey of the city's welfare department was described yesterday by Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare during the period covered by the survey.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Senate was told tonight that Republicans would oppose permanent personal registration because it would necessitate an additional expenditure of $10,000,000 on New York City to put it into operation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved legislation today to make it easier for the Government to seize Mexican wetbacks who entered the country illegally in search of work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- New safety standards for commercial airplanes, effective March 5, were issued today by the Civil Aeronautics Board following an annual review of air safety by its experts and interested parties.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Jersey Joe Walcott, who wants to sidestep a return match with Ezzard Charles because of its dubious cash value, offered today to meet Rocky Marciano for the heavyweight title in May or June.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The National Production Authority today limited the use of copper in the manufacture of electric lighting fixtures.

John Lindsey's biographical study of Sir Christopher Wren, the English architect, will be published March 5 by the Philosophical Library, entitled "Wren: His Work and Times." Although Wren is known as designer and rebuilder of St. Paul's Cathedral and builder of fifty-two churches in London, he was also an astronomer, an anatomist, a scholar, a scientist and a politician.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Charles T. Myers has been named commander in chief, United States Northeast Command, and commanding general, North East Air Command, the Air Force announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The British frigate Burghead Bay has left Port Stanley, the Falkland Islands, for Hope Bay, Palmer Peninsula (Graham Land), in Antarctica, where last week a British landing party from the survey ship John Biscoe was prevented from landing by fire from an Argentine Navy group.

For four years Dettmar Otto, a German who worked as a ship's radio officer, tried to gain admittance into the United States for himself and his wife, Inga, 25, but his efforts were without success because he could not get a sponsor.
Allie Reynolds and Bobby Thomson, two of the top heroes of last season, signed their 1952 baseball contracts yesterday.

Asserting that they were not opposed to the principle of one-way operations on avenues, six civic groups insisted yesterday that it should not be extended to Seventh and Eighth Avenues until all other possible alternatives had been considered.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein ordered trial yesterday of a dispute arising from the manner in which certain proxies were tallied in the October election of directors of the Segal Lock and Hardware Company, Inc.

Just a year ago Gunther Jaeckel opened a "fashion-at-a-price" department. So important has this become that it has now developed into a larger one for coats and suits. Here the merchandise is kept at a not-too-extravagant price level, the cost of the merchandise ranging from $39.95 to $115.

In the last fiscal year Puerto Rico shipped more rum here than all other Caribbean producers combined. Final supply figures for that period are not available but are expected to exceed those for 1950, when Puerto Rico sent 645,000 cases of rum here, compared with 320,000 from the Virgin Islands and 97,000 from all other areas combined.

BILOXI, Miss., Feb. 4 (UP) -- Twelve hundred civilian construction workers struck in protest to an open-shop order here today, halting all work on a $35,000,000 expansion program at Keesler Air Force Base.

A survey of thirty key industrial cities in the nation, made more than six months by the National Urban League, showed widespread discrimination against Negroes, especially in the skilled or white-collar classes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Thousands of Republicans whooped it up tonight at their traditional $1.20 Lincoln Day box supper at which party leaders predicted that an informed electorate would make a sweep in the November balloting.

A new series of ads is being distributed by the Advertising Council for use during Brotherhood Week, Feb. 18-24. Copy will stress that "Communism thrives on dissension." According to Lee Bristol, president of Bristol-Myers ComPany, the anti-Communist approach is being played up because it was found that one of last year's mats, using this appeal, drew 50 per cent more newspaper orders than its nearest rival.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- A libel suit strongly reminiscent of the one that Victor Kravchenko, author of "I Chose Freedom," brought successfully against a Communist publication here in 1949 began here today in the same courtroom with some of the same participants.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that "there is no immunity here" as he began an address dealing with his previous charges of communism in Government.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 4 (UP) -- Puerto Rico's new "home rule" Constitution was approved tonight by a vote of 88 to 3 in the constitutional convention after a disputed clause defining the island's relationship to the United States had been stricken from the preamble.

Some hints for the home laundress who has an automatic laundry machine were given in a talk yesterday by Miss Margaret Doughty, director of the Bendix Home Laundry Institute. She spoke at a meeting of representatives of publications at Bruno-New York, 460 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Worthington Miner, producer of "Studio One," which for years has been one of the leading drama programs on television, has virtually completed negotiations that will transfer his services from the Columbia Broadcasting System to the National Broadcasting Company.

Low-beam headlights became mandatory for night driving on city streets at 5:38 P. M. yesterday and spot checks by personnel of the Traffic Department and volunteers from other city agencies at hundreds of strategic locations in the five boroughs showed about 75 per cent compliance, Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley declared.
PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Fifteen Asian and African members of the United Nations announced today that they had decided to present a joint appeal to the Security Council for action in the Tunisian case.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The Tunisian Government will demand that France release imprisoned nationalist leaders and will pose other stiff new conditions as the price for withdrawing its complaint to the United Nations Security Council against French internal rule of the protectorate, according to Tunisian sources here.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- The Navy announced today that it was taking steps to reclaim the lease of the Old Cramp shipyard on the Delaware River because the American Foreign Warehouse Company had failed to keep up maintenance obligations.

The Texas and Pacific Railway Company at the close of last year had long-term debt outstanding of $82,247,556, of which $23,391,556 consisted of equipment obligations. W. G. Vollmer president, said yesterday in a preliminary report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Howard Hughes, the wealthy airplane and motion picture leader, need not dispose of 929,020 shares of stock in the New Theatre Company by Feb. 20, 1955.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The dissatisfaction which Republicans in Congress have expressed at the choice of Newbold Morris, to discover the depth and scope of official misconduct and recommend preventive measures for the future, springs from obvious causes, the plainer in a Presidential election year.

CAIRO, Feb. 4 -- Britain responded to Iraqi Premier Nuri es-Said's offer of mediation in the British-Egyptian dispute with a proposal to withdraw her Suez Canal garrison from its present base, leaving only a group of British experts to cooperate with a similar Egyptian contingent, it was reliably reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The Secret Service announced today that agents masquerading as hoodlums had broken up a counterfeiting ring that printed fake bonds and $3,000,000 worth of counterfeit money in four years. Three men were seized and arraigned, while a fourth man accused of being a minor figure in the ring was held for questioning.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak yesterday and closed 36 to 55 points net lower than on Saturday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Grain prices suffered substantial losses today as the result of another wave of long liquidation in all pits. The selling was augmented by local sales, while the buying demand was sluggish until the market had dropped sharply, when there was a moderate rally on short profit-taking.

Another indication of the growing interest throughout the world in all kinds of handicrafts is the opening of an exhibition at Rockefeller Center today. Previewed yesterday, the display, which will remain on view through March, is under the sponsorship of the Department of Trade and Commerce of Canada and includes a wide range of articles from the Provinces of New Brunswick, Quebec and Nova Scotia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Tomoya Kawakita, California-born Japanese sentenced to die for treason, won a review of his conviction from the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Newbold Morris, appointed by the Attorney General as a special assistant to scourge wrongdoers from the Government, took the oath of office today and settled down to a task that he acknowledged would not be completed for many months.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- As violence continued in the strike of the Insurance Agents International Union, A. F. L., against the Prudential Insurance Company today, six striking agents were arrested by police for threatening a non-striker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican of Wisconsin, announced today that he and Representative O. K. Armstrong, Missouri Republican, were calling a conference on psychological warfare to be held here Feb. 22-23.
Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- Members of the House subcommittee investigating the Internal Revenue Bureau spent most of today "getting the picture" of the San Francisco tax scandals and fixed tomorrow at 10 A. M. for the start of the first formal, open session in this city.

Under the Government's price-support program the Commodity Credit Corporation has had to hold vast amounts of grain and other commodities off the market. Apart from the economic problem that this has created it has involved a major physical problem as well. It has meant arranging for the warehousing of commodities totaling anywhere from $2,000,000,000 to as much as $4,000,000,000.

Newbold Morris took over his new post as special assistant to Attorney General McGrath yesterday under not too promising auspices. In the first place, he was being accused of having associated at one time or another during the past decade and a half with organizations subsequently listed as subversive or suspicious.

MOREHEAD CITY, N. C., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Twenty-six crewmen abandoned their storm-broken freighter today only to be pitched into the Atlantic by the splintering of their lifeboat fifty yards off shore. They survived both pre-dawn ordeals without injury.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- H. Frederick Willkie today urged stockholders of Kingan Co., who have been asked to oust him as president of the Indianapolis meat packing company, to be patient and learn the "truth."

A "new" violin concerto by the 12-year-old Felix Mendelssohn had its first public performance last night by Yehudi Menuhin at his concert in Carnegie Hall. Another new work, an unaccompanied violin sonata by the Israeli composer Paul Ben-Haim also had its premiere on this occasion.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 4 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio predicted today that he would win 40 per cent of the votes cast by union members in a Presidential election and would be "just as strong with labor as any other Republican candidate."

GALVESTON, Tex., Feb. 4 (UP) -- A shrimp boat captain said today he would let the courts decide his reward for risking his life in a borrowed boat to haul in a runaway oil barge estimated to be worth $80,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Prof. Abraham H. Fraenkel, president of B'nai B'rith in Israel, said today that the organization in his country "supplies the only platform where people of different political parties can meet and discuss major problems in a spirit of unity."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- A charge of misconduct was preferred by the Coast Guard today against five members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., in connection with the recent voyage to the middle east of the freighter Alaska Bear of Pacific Far East Line.

Kansas City yesterday got one date, March 29, for the Olympic basketball trials. This compromise move was disclosed by Asa Bushnell, secretary of the executive committee, at the weekly luncheon meeting of the basketball writers at Leone's.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 4 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, will challenge Senator Robert A. Taft for all of Ohio's fifty-six delegates to the Republican national convention.
Except for domestic sugar and wool tops, most commodity futures markets were lower yesterday.

The Government filed yesterday in Federal court a $328,000 treble damage suit against the National Lead Company of New Jersey, charging Office of Price Stabilization violations. The violations, according to the suit, totaled $109,657 in over-the-ceiling sales of paints, pigments, lead and lead oxides.

The Christian Rural Overseas Program, which has been sending farm commodities to needy countries throughout the world, is dissolving the partnership under which it has operated and will henceforth function under the sole sponsorship of the Department of Church World Service, National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Favorable action by the Senate Banking and Currency committee on the nomination of Harry A. McDonald as administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation appeared in prospect tonight as a showdown vote was set for tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- In a letter to the New York Building Congress, Inc., Henry H. Fowler, administrator of the National Production Authority, today promised the earliest possible relaxation of building restrictions for nondefense areas but said there was little hope for an early improvement in the present "tight" building supply situation.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- To compensate for the rising costs in the New York area, the United Nations General Assembly approved today the expenditure of an additional $3,000,000 for the construction of the United Nations headquarters on the East River and an extra $1,330,000 for the cost of a living allowance to its staff members there.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 4 -- Speaking with an air of assurance that was lacking in his manner before the Communist party of India rang up solid victories in this country's current national elections, Ajoy Kumar Ghosh, General Secretary of the party, declared today that elected Reds would bend their energies toward scrapping this nation's present constitution and substituting what he called a "democratic document."
TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- Around-the-clock helicopter service between the battleline and a hospital ship has been tested successfully for six weeks in Korean waters.

High winds of an Atlantic storm buffeted the city early yesterday morning with gusts that registered up to forty-four miles an hour. The winds diminished as the day wore on and at nightfall the Weather Bureau reported that the city had been spared the brunt of the storm.

Up in the Adirondack hamlet of Sugarbush, where Virgil Lissom's rocky acres are piled with snowdrifts, Virgil is starting on his annual job of budget balancing. In recent years, as a way of passing the time, he checks the arithmetic in each federal budget as soon as it appears.

The plywood industry has taken the first step on the long road to recovery from the slump it fell into last year. Coleman R. Curtis, Eastern sales manager of the Mengel Company's plywood division, reported yesterday that his organization's North Carolina hardwood plywood mill would operate at capacity in the next four months.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Ohio River flood threat ended in Louisville today after the river reached a crest five feet above flood level. The weather bureau said that, barring unforseen heavy rains, the river would start falling late tonight. The forecast called for colder weather, with no rain in sight.

This country must maintain sufficient military power to safeguard its liberties and its position of world leadership, Francis P. Matthews, United States Ambassador to the Irish Republic and former Secretary of the Navy, declared here yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The unwillingness of the Irish Republic to sign the revised bilateral agreement required by the United States Mutual Security Act emphasizes a basic difference between this act and the Marshall Plan, from which it grew.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 4 (UP) -- Counterpoint suffered no bone injury when he hurt his right hind leg during the running of the $183,750 Santa Anita Maturity last Saturday and Trainer Sylvester Veitch said today the 1951 "horse of the year" would be put back into training in a day or two.

An innerspring mattress 10 feet square is being used by the Civil Aeronautics Administration as a means of determining what happens beneath an asphalt pavement when a heavy airplane taxis over the surface. The Federal agency is trying to find out what causes gradual deformation beneath flexible paving like asphalt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- An order which mobilization officials hope will ease serious unemployment in some sections of the country will be issued tomorrow night, the Office of Defense Mobilization said today.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 4 -- The 6,000 employes of the Mexican Light and Power Company went on strike today, and tonight the country's capital, normally a gaudy neon-lit blaze of color, lay in darkness with industry and transportation badly disrupted.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Protestant and Jewish clergymen of Dutchess County adopted a resolution today rebuking a Roman Catholic hospital for telling seven doctors they must either quit the hospital staff or resign from a birth control group.

Meeting for an hour and a half yesterday in the offices of the Third Avenue Transit System in an effort to lay the basis for a contract to avoid liquidation of the city's largest private bus system, top officials of management and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., apparently failed to make any headway.

A consultation alcoholism clinic, devoted to the treatment and rehabilitation of problem drinkers employed by New York business concerns, opened yesterday at University Hospital, 303 East Twentieth Street.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -- The Institute of London Underwriters today announced reductions of up to 50 per cent in war and civil strife insurance rates for certain Chinese ports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, told the Senate today the Department of State is "selling our standard of living down the river."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Statehood for Alaska, an issue that has been before Congress intermittently through thirty-six years, went to debate again in the Senate today, with emphasis on the strategic importance of the Territory in the fight on communism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives made certain today that no women would be called for training under the Universal Military Training bill.
The following article is by Gayle Talbot of The Associated Press, who recently returned from Australia.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Former Assemblyman Harry A. Reoux of Warren County has been dropped as counsel of the special Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment. He had been at odds for some time with Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Westchester, the committee chairman.

Cardinal Spellman presented the Catholic Youth Organization's Club of Champions Medal last night to Arthur J. Morris, financial vice president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, for thirty-seven years of active interest in youth work.

ANYONE who thinks that enthusiasm for murder, madness and degeneracy as fictional themes is a peculiarly American and Southern literary fashion just hasn't been reading enough novels from other countries. Consider the novels of Daphne Rooke, prominent member of our modern Gothic school and undisputed leader of its South African division. Miss Rooke is the author of two novels and it's a tossup which is the more gruesome.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 5 -- Communist negotiators at Panmunjom agreed today to an exchange of prisoners in the Korean war "as rapidly as possible" after an armistice started, but failed to reach a definite agreement with United Nations delegates on how soon the captives could be returned.

A first issue of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development payable in Canadian dollars will be offered in Canada today by an underwriting syndicate of Canadian investment interests headed by Dominion Securities Corporation, Ltd.; A. E. Ames Co., Ltd., and Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation attained a new high record in sales last year, but earnings were reduced to $103,889,711 from $124,111,851 for 1950 because of heavier taxes, Fred H. Haggerson, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

MIAMI, Feb. 4 -- Kid Gavilan, the Cuban Negro who holds the welterweight boxing title, floored Bobby Dykes of Miami for a count of nine in the second round in the Miami Stadium tonight and appeared to have the situation under control for most of the rest of the way.
With more than $1,000,000 worth of exhibits displayed in 575 booths the twenty-fifth annual exhibition of the Automotive Accessories Manufacturers of America opened yesterday at Grand Central Palace.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Dewey has been tentatively chosen by Republican leaders to head New York's ninety-six-member delegation to the Republican national convention in Chicago July 7. He would be one of six delegates at large.
Behind iron gates and gray walls, the Salvation Army has brought encouragement and hope to thousands of prisoners through its Men's and Women's Prison Bureaus.

The recent NEW YORK TIMES editorial titled "The U. S. A. and India" came to my attention an hour after completing my 1951 tax return. Suffering from a dollar shortage (as does England), I was shocked.

In the six months after the United States stopped shipping gold abroad in mid-1951, $1,005,000,000 of the metal was received from foreign countries. This was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review of credit and business conditions. It added that United States gold stocks rose by another $236,000,000 in January, indicating further heavy purchases abroad.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- A United States delegate to the United Nations General Assembly declared tonight that the willingness of the United Nations to postpone a discussion of a permanent settlement in Korea until an armistice was reached constituted "quite a remarkable demonstration of solidarity behind the effort in Korea."

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- John L. Train, president and general manager of the Utica Mutual Insurance Company, took issue tonight with a recent statement by Louis L. Hollander, State C. I. O. president, that the elimination of private insurance companies would save $90,000,000 in the cost of workmen's compensation insurance.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders promised Mayor Impellitteri today they would give prompt decisions on various proposals New York City has made for state help in solving the financial problems it will face in the next fiscal year.

The Democratic party's suit to invalidate the Republican Congressional Reapportionment Law in this state was discontinued yesterday in Supreme Court and the party was left without a clear course of future action.

The Municipal Broadcasting System, operator of the city's radio station WNYC, would be authorized to apply for Federal sanction of television facilities under a resolution forwarded to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan.

Reporting on operations of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation for the fiscal year ended with last November, Floyd B. Odlum, board chairman, gave special attention to the allegedly devastating effect of rising taxes on America's system of free enterprise.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The United States Army and the German police are hunting a United States soldier, absent without official leave, as a suspect in the kidnapping of an 18-year-old American girl.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- A Government ban of the export of "immature" Scotch whisky, defined as aged less than three years, came into effect today. The Board of Trade's decision had already touched off a dispute among Scottish distillers.

Mortgages totaling $1,049,000 were filed yesterday in the Richmond County Clerk's office at St. George, S. I., by Michael, John and Alexander D'Alessio, top figures in gambling activities on Staten Island, to secure funds for the payment of Federal income taxes due since 1946.

Legal steps will be taken to prevent the city from putting into effect the Griffenhagen career and salary plan, Howard McSpedon, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council, American Federation of Labor, said yesterday.

Mortgages totaling $1,049,000 were filed yesterday in the Richmond County Clerk's office at St. George, S. I., by Michael, John and Alexander D'Alessio, top figures in gambling activities on Staten Island, to secure funds for the payment of Federal income taxes due since 1946.

CAIRO, Feb. 4 -- A committee of fourteen is being formed here to work toward the transformation of Egypt into a country of small peasants with about five acres of land each as the basis for economic and social regeneration.

The General Assembly of the United Nations, meeting in Paris for the last three months, is expected to adjourn today after demonstrating again that it now plays an indispensable role in world affairs both as a parliament of man and as an instrument for the preservation of peace and resistance to aggression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Advertising claims that Philip Morris cigarettes are not irritating or are less irritating than other brands would be barred under a Federal Trade Commission examiner's decision issued tonight.

A saving of 89 per cent in the use of steel in the construction of Manhattanville College's new dining and assembly hall at Purchase, N. Y., was made possible through the use of pre-stressed concrete girders, Eggers Higgins, architects for the building, said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- German non-Reich bonds attracted most attention on the London stock markets today, when dealing in them was resumed. Most of these issues finished higher than they were three months ago, when dealings were suspended.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 4 -- Federal Security Administrator Oscar Ewing denied tonight that he got his present job because he was backed for the post by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, New York State Democratic chairman.

The "outstanding fact" revealed by the President's budget message to Congress is the abandonment of the principle of meeting the cost of the defense program on a pay-as-you-go basis, and the acceptance of a policy of deficit financing. This is the view of the National City Bank, as expressed in its monthly letter, just issued.

Graciela Rivera, the first Puerto Rican singer to be engaged by the Metropolitan Opera, scored a personal triumph last night when she made her debut with the company in the title role of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- "Let the Republicans and Democrats alike cauterize their noisome sores lest each be overcome by the stench of its own corruption." These were the last words from the pen of Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, who died last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Robert A. Lovett, Secretary of Defense, warned a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today that any substantial cut in the $52,000,000,000 defense budget estimates would shrink the military establishment below the minimum safety level.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The State Thruway Authority reported to the Governor and Legislature today that planning was under way on all sections of the 535-mile super-highway and that barring a worsening of the international situation the project would be completed by 1954.

The East Asiatic Company, after a seven-month absence from the trade, will reinstitute regular passenger service between New York and Copenhagen, Denmark, in April. The service will be maintained temporarily by the liner Falstria, which was withdrawn from the Atlantic run early last summer and placed in the Far East trade.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- The suddenly stiffened attitude of the West Ger man Government toward the Allied powers was regarded by high French officials tonight as a maneuver likely to jeopardize the Western defense program and the accompanying policy of integrating West Germany into the Atlantic community.

Although Charles Dickens fancied himself as an actor, Emlyn Williams is an actor. On account of the capriciousness of human life, it is impossible to prove now that Mr. Williams' readings from Dickens, which opened at the John Golden last evening, are superior to the readings Dickens gave in New York in 1867.

The more parents will "let their children go" as they grow up, the more they will actually "keep" them, Dr. Robert Goldenson, Professor of Psychology at Hunter College, told a group of parents last night. He spoke at a meeting of the Parent-Teachers Association of the East Side branch of the Bentley School, 112 East Seventy-first Street.

TANGIER, Feb. 4 -- Morocco was divided up when outright colonialism was still in fashion. It was the last unclaimed segment of Africa and the European powers managed to work out an agreeable solution. France, by making concessions elsewhere on this continent, received the major share.

The Louisville and Jefferson County Metropolitan Sewer District, Kentucky, announced yesterday that it would receive bids Feb. 19 on an issue of $4,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds dated March 1, 1952, and due March 1, 1953 to 1977.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A plane load of American Olympic team members arrived from New York tonight, bringing the U. S. contingent here to more than half strength.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved legislation today that would guarantee that a valid divorce granted in one state would be legal in any other state provided certain minimum standards were met.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, introduced a bill today to forbid evport controls on cotton and other farm products unless they fall more than 85 per cent below government production goals.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- The scandal in which hoodlums sold millions of pounds of horse meat as beef continued to spread today as several official investigations continued. There were these developments:

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- State and city moves were begun today to investigate charges that the Rugo Construction Company, owned by three brothers, had set up a fund to pay bribes and to make political campaign contributions.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 -- Eva Peron returned to the official limelight today when she accompanied her husband, President Juan D. Peron, to the opening meeting of the conference of Argentine Governors. It was her first public appearance since she underwent a major operation Nov. 6.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- In the Soviet Union for the last fourteen months recovering from a stroke that partly paralyzed him, Maurice Thorez, head of the French Communist party, has reassumed an active role in directing the party's affairs at home, the Communist official newspaper L'Humanite said today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Organized opposition of truck operators to contract demands of Ohio over-the-road drivers ended tonight and a quick end to the four-day-old strike was predicted.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 4 -- After a two-year study, the Westchester Board of Supervisors rejected today a proposal for merging the county park and recreation commissions and the creation of a maintenance division to serve the Park Commission and Department of Public Works.

Department stores must recognize the importance of teen-age buyers and adopt some of the variety store and super-market techniques to capture a greater share of that market, according to speakers at the annual notion clinic held yesterday in the Statler Hotel.
Hunter College will confer degrees upon 577 graduates this evening at 8 o'clock at its 101st commencement exercises in the Assembly Hall of the college, 695 Park Avenue at Sixty-eighth Street.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 -- With unanimous endorsement of Republicans and Democrats, the New Jersey Senate passed a measure today to provide voters with a Presidential preference poll at the April 15 primary election.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Arleigh A. (Thirty-one Knot) Burke, a central figure in the Army-Navy unification controversy, was nominated today for a permanent appointment to that rank.
MIAMI, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Pincher, owned by Henry H. Hecht of Baltimore, was an easy winner of the Summer Skies Purse, a $5,000 allowance event that topped Hialeah Park's stakeless program today.

The missionary captain of a two-masted schooner, who navigated it without mishap among the tricky coral heads and reefs of the Marshall Islands, is home on furlough, her white sailing dress and visored cap replaced by a smart spring outfit. She is the Rev. Eleanor Wilson, a Congregational Christian worker of solid landlubber ancestry.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 4 -- Rumors that preparations were being made for the retirement of William Green as president of the American Federation of Labor met their usual fate today after a week of meetings of the federation's executive council.

Alexander Uninsky's piano recitals have been the subject of alternating praise for his sensitivity and criticism for his cool virtuosity ever since his debut here in 1943. Last night in Town Hall, the Russion-born artist mated the various elements of his musical personality to produce as complete a communication as one could ask.
VIENNA, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Hellmut Seibt of Austria, despite a fall during the free skating tonight, won the European men's figure skating championship for the second consecutive year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- Ingrid Bergman and Marlon Brando are said to have expressed more than passing interest in a proposal by Sam Spiegel to co-star them in a contemporary drama entitled "The Witness."

On the premise that liquidation of the Third Avenue Transit System was inevitable in the present contract impasse over economy layoffs, the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., has decided to press for early dissolution and the taking over of the bankrupt bus lines by the city.

Appliance retailers were asked yesterday to "stop committing mass economic suicide" by continued indiscriminate price cutting. The request was made in a letter to all Hotpoint appliance dealers and was signged by E. R. Taylor, vice president for marketing at Hotpoint, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Louis E. Yavner, executive assistant to Rudolph Halley, President of the New York City Council, declined today an appointment as principal aide to Newbold Morris, New York Republican who took office yesterday as an Assistant Attorney General assigned to clean up corruption in the Federal Government.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Frank Sedgman, Australian star of the recent Davis Cup tennis victory over the United States, won't defend his American title at Forest Hills next summer for purely financial reasons.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 10 points higher to 5 points lower than on Monday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- City Collector William T. Prendergast said today that a survey by his office showed ninety-one motion-picture theatres went out of business in Chicago during 1951. These theatres represented 25 per cent of the 366 theatres in operation at the beginning of the year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Federal Judge James W. Morris today dismissed a second suit by the Communist party to halt current proceedings of the Government's Subversive Activities Control Board.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Christian Dior brings suppleness and ease to the fashion silhouette. The key themes of his important collection are the sweater bodice and bloused backs, particularly those on boleros.

The M. B. C. Realty Company has purchased for investment from Jacob Glass Sons, operators, the sixteen - story apartment house for eighty-one families at 785 West End Avenue, at Ninety-eighth Street, which is assessed at $520,000.
We knew last night, the instant Thomas Beecham stepped upon the platform at Carnegie Hall as guest leader of the Philadelphia Orchestra, that he was in top form. This would mean an exciting concert.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor said today that labor would cooperate in the certification of disputes to the Wage Stabilization Board only as long as consideration on the merits was assured.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Yale defeated the Springfield College quintet, 76-71, tonight in an experimental game during which proposed rule changes were tested.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) Miss Grace De Moss of Corvallis, Ore., set the pace today in qualifying play of the twenty-eighth annual women's championship of Palm Beach when she toured the 6,008-yard Palm Beach Golf Club course in women's par of 35, 37 -- 72.

The unfortunate experiences encountered by three young men in their efforts to enroll for civil defense, as outlined in their letter which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Jan. 15, are very regrettable. However, it must be admitted that most of their difficulties were avoidable.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge, in a radio address tonight, announced his support of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, for the Republican Presidential nomination.

Two employes of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York were killed by asphyxiation and four others who went to their rescue were overcome by ammonia fumes yesterday in a by-products building of the company's gas manufacturing plant at Hunts Point Avenue and the East River, the Bronx.

PARIS, Feb. 5 - Eighty - one countries, including twenty - one not seated in the United Nations, will meet here tomorrow to announced publicly how much money they intend to contribute to the United Nations technical assistance program for 1952.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- Charging that the United States central intelligence agency has organized a special bureau with the designation "I" to carry out anti-Soviet and anti-Communist plots, the Soviet Army organ Red Star today called for new intensive vigilance by all Soviet Army officers and men against American "spies and diversionists."

Today's new film is "When Worlds Collide," a science-fiction adventure in Technicolor, with Richard Derr, Barbara Rush, Peter Hanson, John Hout and Larry Keating, at the Globe. Rudolph Mate directed and George Pal produced the Paramount presentation from a script by Sydney Boehm and a novel by Edwin Balmer and Philip Wylie.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll made known today his long-expected intent to appoint State Senator Edward J. O'Mara, Jersey City Democrat, to the state Supreme Court.

Two graduates of high schools "south of Fourteenth Street" received yesterday the annual Fleurette Morris Memorial Prizes of $65 each. The recipients were Vivian Ida Maller of Seward Park High School and Allan Kaye of the School of Performing Arts of the Metropolitan Vocational High School.

Relatively light volume and irregular trends characterized commodity futures trading in New York yesterday. Cocoa broke sharply with only 141 lots traded. Coffee was weak on fifty-five trades. Vegetable oils showed a little strength but sugar and wool prices were mixed.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- In debate on the European Army plan next week Foreign Minister Robert Schuman is expected to explain how the Government proposes to link the European defense community with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to make the treaty cover West Germany.

Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves retired, wartime head of the atomic bomb project, declared here yesterday that the security of the United States lay in the atomic bomb and the nation's technical skills rather than in large ground armies.

A resolution asking the State Legislature to set in motion governmental and legal machinery that eventually might lead to sanction of off-track horserace betting in New York State was adopted yesterday by the City Council by a vote of 21 to 3.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Allied warplanes destroyed four Communist ammunition and supply bases in heavy attacks Tuesday, touching off giant fires that lighted the night sky for miles.

Prof. James Angell's objections to your editorial "Economics and Stardust" are based largely on its alleged misunderstanding of the content and purpose of the U. N. report signed by the professor and four colleagues. He stresses such rather formal points as that the report is not intended to deal with the full employment problem.

The nation's lagging military aircraft program has a new set of wings. Freshly clipped by President Truman'a budget knife, the new wings will not carry the program so fast or so high as was originally contemplated, but defense officials feel they are more realistically fitted to the country's capacities in a period of limited mobilization.

A wiry ex-convict who was paroled from Elmira Reformatory last year after serving time for burglary was arrested yesterday morning for attempted burglary after he allegedly let himself down a rope from the roof of an apartment house at 111 West 106th Street and climbed through a window into a top-floor apartment.

Public utility and railroad companies borrowed $22,110,000 yesterday in the public market through the sale of bonds and equipment trust certificates at competitive bidding. The awards were as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Sharp fluctuations in German bonds on the reported statement by the West German Chancellor regarding the Saar were the main feature of the Stock Exchange here today. Movements in other markets were usually of a minor order in quiet conditions.

Rumors were flying around last night that "Three Wishes for Jamie," the new musical comedy with a cast headed by Anne Jeffreys, John Raitt and Bert Wheeler, would be brought into the Hellinger on March 5 and that the house's present tenant, "Two on the Aisle," would pave the way by being shifted to the Broadway on March 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- Five sailors attached to the crew of the freighter Alaska Bear during a recent turbulent voyage to the Middle East pleaded innocent to twenty-three counts of "misconduct" at a Coast Guard hearing today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 -- The Government asserted today that the fifteen California Communists who are defendants in the nation's second major trial under the Smith Act were "professional revolutionaries" bent on destroying every vestige of constitutional democratic government in pursuance of the doctorines of Karl Marx.

Defense lawyers in the investment banking anti-trust suit disagreed with each other yesterday in Federal Court over whether or not the financing effectuated by bankers for the American Telephone Telegraph Company thirty years ago could be squared with present-day legal notions.

The Keystone Mariner, first of thirty-five similar vessels now under construction for the Federal Government in seven of the nation's shipyards, will be launched Feb. 29 at the yard of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Chester, Pa. Mrs. Edward L. Cochrane, wife of the Federal Maritime Administrator, and a native of Chester, has been invited to be the sponsor of the ship, which is being built at a cost of $8,530,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Complex new instruments of war were displayed by Defense Department officials before members of the Senate today as evidence of the tremendous rise in military costs.

Adoption of three-color signal lights -- red, yellow and green -- as standard for future traffic installations and a radical experiment on existing two-color signals were announced yesterday by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

A barber shop and a shirt hospital where former barbers and retired tailors clip and stitch to keep other members trim-looking were among the new services introduced last year at the William Hodson Community Center.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 -- The motion-picture industry's sanctions against the "unfriendly ten" Hollywood figures who in 1947 declined to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities came to a second legal test today.

Mrs. Peter McDonnell heads the committee for the luncheon and card party for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter to be held on Feb. 14 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many reservations have been made for the event.

HONG KONG, Feb. 5 -- Ho Chi Minh, Vietnamese Communist leader of the Vietminh dissident forces, delivered a radio speech recently in which he hailed the "good progress" made last year by the insurgent "Democratic Vietnam Republic."

Forty-six men were arrested late yesterday afternoon in a raid on an East Harlem dice game said by police to have been run by "a powerful mobster." Ten thousand dollars was said to be involved in the game.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- The Free Democratic party, the second largest group in the Bonn Government coalition, joined today the growing bloc of West German "intransigents" when it declared in its press service that the Federal Republic could agree to a defense contribution only if West Germany received equal rights in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate temporarily shunted aside today the controversial Alaskan Statehood Bill to pass a measure designed to halt or curb the steady illegal entry of Mexicans to take farm jobs in this country.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Competition for the Hovey Trophy, emblematic of the newly established Northeastern District women's curling championship, opened at St. Andrew's Golf Club today. All three Utica (N. Y.) Curling Club rinks won first-round matches.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Col. James B. Leer, public information officer at the United States Military Academy, said today that a quotation yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the "cribbing" scandal here was incorrect. The story was about an article written by Cadet D. C. Ahearn of Winthrop, Mass., for the alumni magazine, Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- To speed Congressoinal action on economic controls, Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, today introduced a bill extending the Defense Production Act until June 30, 1953.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 5 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahome announced today he would permit his name to be entered in the Nebraska Democratic Presidential primary in opposition to Senator Cstes Kefauver of Tennessee. Backers of Senator Kefauver had reported earlier they had permission to enter the Tennessean in the April 1 primary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today the peace treaty with Japan and the three associated pacts that will raise a democratic defensive alliance in the Pacific.

The stock market sank yesterday to new low levels in a continuation of the general decline in prices, before meeting support that cushioned the decline. The fact that moderate bidding was able to stem the setback inspired the comment in financial circles that this week might see the conclusion of the downward movement.
