ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- State support was requested today for a proposal to deepen the canal system linking the Hudson and St. Lawrence Rivers via Lake Champlain so that it could handle vessels of 2,500 tons capacity. The present canal system can only handle barges up to 250-ton capacity.

Despite the abnormal operating conditions arising directly or indirectly from the nation's rearmament program, the Avco Manufacturing Corporation earned the second largest income last year, with its net of $10,089,214.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 6 -- The Communist delegates at Panmunjom today launched their long-awaited proposal for recommendations to be made by the military field commands to the Governments concerned in the Korean war after an armistice is signed.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 5 (UP) -- Isidor Bieber's Palestinian, a leading candidate for the $100,000 added Santa Anita handicap, suffered a fracture of his right hind shin today and was declared through with racing.

Parents who are serious about wanting their youngsters to grow up free of prejudice against individuals and groups must do more than talk about tolerance and brotherhood, a group of parents were told this week. They must make a conscious effort to include individuals of other races, religions and nationalities among the friends who come to their homes.
TORONTO, Feb. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Shareholders of the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., approved today an increase in the company's ordinary shares from 15,840,440 to 20,000,000.

Members of the Women's Century Fund Committee of the American Museum of Natural History held their second Portrait Room luncheon for this year yesterday at the museum, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden indicated today that Britain would enter into negotiations with the new Cairo Government for a settlement of their treaty dispute and that in the beginning Britain alone would deal with Egypt.

The Katyn Forest massacre of more than 10,000 Polish soldiers in World War II, about which Col. John H. Van Vliet testified Monday before a special House committee, is the subject of the only book issued today. The author of "The Katyn Wood Murders" is Joseph Mackiewicz, a journalist of Vilno, who went with the leave of the Polish Underground to Katyn Wood in 1943.

Helen Keller's "appeal to the public" for help in recovering a cherished timepiece has been answered, and today she will come into the city from Westport, Conn., to regain the specially constructed watch. It will be returned to her by Richard Weaver at the pawnshop at 594 Ninth Avenue where it was pawned four days after Miss Keller lost it.

Many customers of manufacturers and wholesalers will find themselves in a weaker cash position this year as a result of higher income taxes, extension of accounts receivable totals, expanding operating costs and lack of outside funds, according to a report of the Credit Research Foundation Inc., released yesterday.
Rear Admiral Charles F. Behrens, medical officer of the Navy's Eastern Sea Frontier, was among the 400 Navy and civil service employes of 90 Church Street who donated blood on Monday.

NEWARK, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A quick-thinking father who learned to give first aid when he was in the Army was credited today with preventing his 2-year-old son from bleeding to death from a cut jugular vein.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Truman reconsidered today and agreed to leave his name on the ballot in New Hampshire's Democratic Presidential preferential primary on March 11, in which he will be opposed by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

MADRID, Feb. 5 -- Two reports on Spain, one on its military potential and the other on its economic problems, are now being studied in Washington. The study is going slowly -- too slowly for the Spaniards, who have been given to understand that the missions of Maj. Gen. James W. Spry and Sidney C. Sufrin were a prelude to a defense agreement between the United States and Spain.

New York perishable food dealers, who are fighting Mayor Impellitteri's proposal to increase gross business taxes from $2 to $5 on gross sales of $1,000, said yesterday they would carry the battle to Albany Monday with a bill to exempt their industry from the tax.
The steel industry turned a critical eye yesterday on the wage demands of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., and said that they were costly, unjustified, unnecessary and inflationary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Government today set an expansion goal to provide 940,000 tons of lead from domestic mines and imports in 1955. But it said even this supply will fall considerably short of demand.
OSLO, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A movement to boycott the Olympic slalom ski course because of a lack of snow has made them too dangerous was reported under way tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, disclosed today that he had tried without success to interest the National Research Council, Veterans Administration and Public Health Service in the cancer-treating methods of Dr. Robert E. Lincoln of Medford, Mass.

Nearly 20,000 persons were delayed coming into the city during the rush hours yesterday from Long Island and northern New Jersey points after two cars of a mail and baggage train entering Pennsylvania Station became derailed. The mishap, at 2:48 A. M., blocked one of the four East River tunnels that serve the station, as well as six of the terminal's twenty-one tracks.

An issue of more than $39,000,000 worth of new common stock of the expanding Monsanto Chemical Company was successfully marketed by the nation's investment banking machinery yesterday in a transaction likely to go down in underwriting annals as one of the most daring and delicate post-war equity financing deals.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- An attempt by James G. Smyth, former Collector of Internal Revenue for Northern California, to obtain the quashing of a conspiracy indictment led to drama in one Federal courtroom today, while in another a House subcommittee began a long awaited public hearing on San Francisco tax scandals.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 5 -- Authorities here have taken precautions to insure that this capital will not face the destructive price riots that caused heavy damage in the provincial capital of Belo Horizonte in the mining area of Minas Geraes over the last week-end, General Cyro de Rezende, this city's chief of police, told the press today.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The United Nations Assembly ended its 1951 session this afternoon with another clash between the United States and the Soviet Union over the decision not to take up permanent settlement of the Korean question now. As its final action the Assembly voted overwhelmingly to hold a special session at its headquarters in New York if an armistice is reached or if "other developments" make it desirable.

CHANDLER, Ind., Feb. 5 (UP) -- Students picketed Chandler High School today protesting that one of the teachers was a drinker. School officials attributed the strike, however, to dismissal of two basketball players.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce today fixed an export quota of 2,000,000 pounds of nylon yard for the first quarter of this year.

The National Council of the Boy Scouts of America made public last night, the eve of Boy Scout Week, a message to the Boy Scouts from President Truman. The message endorsed the organization's three-year program, which will start today. The program will seek to train Scout leaders better, make Scouting available to more boys,
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Following is the text of the official call for the Democratic National Convention, approved today by the party's Executive Committee:

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Even a new assurance by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today that the Conservative Government under Prime Minister Churchill was still following the cautious policy of former Prime Minister Clement Attlee in the Far East failed to allay entirely the fears of the Labor Opposition that Mr. Churchill had led the United States to expect more from Britain than this country is ready to deliver.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman today furnished to the press an unusually long list of her engagements -- twenty in the next two weeks.

Young matrons, headed by Mrs. William A. Chisolm and including Mrs. John O. Ross and Mrs. Conrad G. Hurlimann, are serving on the junior committee for the St. Valentine's Day luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Windham Children's Service to be held in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Mrs. Alfred Ogden and Mrs. Arthur Talbot are co-chairmen of the executive committee.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Woody Dumart scored his 200th National Hockey League goal tonight and Jim Henry racked up his second consecutive shut-out as the Boston Bruins beat the cellar-dwelling Chicago Black Hawks, 5-0, and took a firm hold on fourth place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Russian propaganda is flooding the United States through the mails, express, the Soviet Embassy and smugglers' activities, a Senate subcommittee on Communist propaganda disclosed today. The State and Justice Departments were blamed for policies that encouraged it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Army said today it had discharged about 100 veterans of the Korean war without paying them in full because their pay records were not in this country.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 5 -- There were fewer absentees than usual among Westfield's high school students yesterday -- perhaps because they attended classes for the first time in their new $2,700,000 building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A program aimed at putting special governmental services on a uniform "pay-for-what-you-get" basis will save taxpayers an estimated $48,000,000 in the 1953 fiscal year, which starts July 1, according to the Budget Bureau.
The anticipated changes in the Brooklyn Dodgers' front office personnel were announced by President Walter O'Malley at the Montague Street offices yesterday, along with the signing of four players.

The Security Council has asked Dr. Frank Graham to return to his efforts to find a solution to the deadlock between India and Pakistan on the disposition of Kashmir. Dr. Graham had been able to report some progress but not as much as he had hoped for and not as much as many persons had anxiously awaited.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that he had authorized the diversion of $478,160,000 of military aid funds under the Mutual Security Program to provide economic help to Britain, France, Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique No. 1,151 for the twenty-four hours ended at 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday. Eastern standard time):

If the opponents of statehood for Alaska and Hawaii ever had any really convincing arguments time and events have long since passed them by. Both Territories want statehood; both Territories morally, economically and politically deserve statehood; both Territories are prepared for statehood, and sooner or later both Territories are going to get it.

Major league baseball, professional football and basketball representatives will file their exceptions, if any, to the Salary Stabilization Board rulings at a hearing at the Veterans Administration Building, 252 Seventh Avenue, at 10 A. M. today. John Kieran will preside.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The Assembly gave final approval and sent to Governor Dewey today a bill empowering the courts to require the detention of adolescent narcotics addicts for hospital treatment and rehabilitation.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger will be asked to approve on Feb. 20 contracts for sale of the 82-year-old bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway Company to two syndicates for approximately $7,000,000.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Despite the unanimous opposition of the Western powers the United Nations General Assembly voted today that one of the two proposed covenants on human rights must contain a provision that states flatly that "all peoples shall have the right of self-determination."

Charles F. Robbins will retire as president of A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., on July 1 under the company's retirement plan, he said yesterday after the annual meeting of stockholders in the Vanderbilt Hotel. As a large stockholder, he will continue his interest in the company and could become chairman of the board, an office which has not been filled since the death of Julian W. Kurtis in 1945.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- The Mayor of Tuckahoe and two other defendants were placed on trial in County court here today before Judge John P. Donohoe on a charge of conspiring to violate gambling laws. The selection of a jury was begun and will be resumed tomorrow.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Feb. 5 (UP) -- Thomas Keen, dog-racing figure and former associate of Al Capone, was killed today when he stepped on the starter of his automobile and touched off an explosion that blew him through the roof of his garage.

Some of our friends were induced to sign the Japanese peace treaty on the basis of the compromise that Japan would be left free to make a treaty with either Nationalist or Communist China. Now the United States is putting pressure upon Premier Yoshida to sign a treaty with the Nationalists.

New York University's new chancellor, Dr. Henry T. Heald, said, yesterday, he thought his 68,000-student school was "a university that I suspect is not fully appreciated by the community." He added that it spends "more money than it takes in," and "needs to spend more money than it is spending."

The influence of television already has been made manifest in so many different ways that the future course of the medium necessarily is a matter of both public interest and concern. Great as have been the strides in the use of the invention, too little still is known about television's ultimate powers to warrant any step which might impede its broadest possible development.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Under Republican sponsorship, a resolution was introduced in both houses of the Legislature today calling for an investigation of the state courts with a view to recommending legislation and constitutional changes to eliminate the congestion in court calendars.

TRENTON, Feb. 5 -- Guy George Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, was re-elected to the National Committee today by the State Committee, assuring his continuance on the national body during the coming Presidential campaigns.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 5 -- Princeton withstood a third-period Temple rally and outlasted the Owls to notch a 59-56 basketball triumph in Dillon Gymnasium tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Ned H. Dearborn, president of the National Safety Council, indirectly accused three Cabinet officers today of a "callous" attitude and a "neglect of responsibility" for their employes' safety.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- A selling wave struck the grain market again this morning, causing sharp declines all along the line, but there was a demand for the offerings today which was not in evidence yesterday. Prices for all grains, and soybeans as well, moved up sharply from the initial low spots, which were the lowest registered on the downturn.
A new shipment of imported wares is now on display in the antiques and gift shop at Bergdorf-Goodman, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

An indictment of the way New York is taking care of the 6,500 dependent and neglected children who annually need temporary shelter was made yesterday in the conclusions of a two-year study of this city's temporary shelter program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Next to the Washington Monument and the Potomac River on an April evening, the most impressive sight in the Capital of the United States is the annual Pentagon offensive against Congress.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 5 -- Four appointments to unfilled or newly created positions in the Public Safety Department were made here today by the majority bloc of the City Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The Assembly today passed a bill empowering the State Racing Commission to banish from horse racing any person who had associated with a convicted criminal. The bill now goes to the Senate.

A Federal Court jury was deliberating last night the case of four men, including three former Office of Price Administration agents, accused of diverting 3,500,000 pounds of rationed sugar into the black market in 1946, for a $150,000 profit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing today issued proposed regulations to carry out the new Durham-Humphrey amendment to the Food and Drug Act, together with the new rules on labeling required as a result of the law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The State Department today denied charges by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, that the International Materials Conference was responsible for shortages of critical commodities in the United States.

That William Heard Kilpatrick should object strenuously to the pledge of allegiance to the flag of the United States and to the suggested school prayer should come as no surprise. The discovery of the harm implicit in the pledge of allegiance and a non-sectarian prayer, practiced for generations in our schools without evil effects, is one of the remarkable discoveries of recent origin of the "liberal" minds. The stated reasons have little substance.

Robert D. McLellan has sold the office building at 27-16 Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, to the Eye Gate Realty Corporation. The City Title Insurance Company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet.

When the Russians applied for recognition of the International Olympic Committee to gain admittance into the Olympic Games, they made none of their usual reservations on rules and promised to give up the practice of awarding cash prizes to athletes, Avery Brundage told the Track Writers Association at Leone's Restaurant yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) -- More than 15,000 actors, actresses and musicians -- or one in three in the British entertainment industry -- are out of work today. Their plight is blamed on a big slump in the entertainment world.
American business men wishing to sell their products in Japan were advised yesterday to concentrate on licensing their manufacture in that country, rather than attempt uncertain direct export.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Jack Cowart, former assistant to the United States Production and Marketing Administrator, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of accepting payment from a private concern to help it recover a claim against the Government.

BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Feb. 6 -- A widespread plot against the Peron Government has been frustrated by the police with the arrest of Col. Francisco Suarez, retired, a former Army Chief of Staff, and more than 100 other alleged conspirators, it has been learned on good authority.

A major wave of embezzlements, automobile thefts and similar crimes in Soviet Georgia has resulted in a wholesale purge of top Communist party and Government officials in that area, diplomatic sources report.

PARIS, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The United Nations announced today that 306,070 men in the United Nations forces had been killed, wounded and captured or missing in Korea from the beginning of the war to Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A House Armed Services subcommittee sat down hard today on the Air Force for planning to buy 20,156 "super de luxe" upholstered typist chairs at a cost of more than half a million dollars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The House of Representatives today unanimously voted a contempt citation against Sidney Buchman, Hollywood producer of "The Jolson Story" and an admitted ex-Communist who twice disobeyed a summons to appear before the House Un-American Activities Committee.
Advancements in the spinning, weaving and finishing of cotton textiles were show yesterday by the Swiss Fabric Group, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The House passed today and sent to the White House a bill to admit to this country a 13-year-old Korean boy who had been unofficially adopted by the First Marine Division.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Prime Minister Churchill indicated today that Britain's rearmament program would cost 500,000,000 ($1,400,000,000) more than originally estimated and acknowledged again that it could not be completed in the scheduled three years.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Gas meters in Westchester County that behaved correctly when manufactured gas was in the mains now are occasionally going on temperamental rampages to register incorrectly the flow of Texan natural gas, the Consolidated Edison Company reported today.

Art criticism and rebuttal departed from the esthetic plane yesterday at Haaren High School, Fifty-ninth Street and Tenth Avenue, when a 16-year-old student wielding a seven-inch hunting knife stabbed a classmate in the chest for ridiculing his talents.

Arbitragers in the international financial markets dismiss as "absurd" certain London press reports about a "racket" traffic in British silver yielding "rake-offs" to international traders at the expense of Britain's dollar earnings.

Carrying out the instructions of Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, United States Attorney Frank J. Parker moved in Brooklyn yesterday for an additional grand jury in the Eastern District to look into corruption and organized crime.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Government has decided to try Judith Coplon, former "Government girl," a third time on charges of spying for the Soviet Union.

Despite discouraging reports that the cost of salvaging steel from abandoned trolley tracks was $35 a ton higher than the market price of $80, an experiment to see if the cost could be cut was started yesterday.
James J. Moran, First Deputy Fire Commissioner in the administration of former Mayor William F. O'Dwyer, was found guilty last night on twenty-three counts of extortion and one of conspiracy.

Leadership of the American Merchant Marine Institute changed hands yesterday for the first time since 1938, as the organization's board of directors unanimously elected Walter E. Maloney as president for the next year.

The difficulty encountered by the well-known British author Graham Greene in meeting the non-Communist test required of all alien visitors to this country illustrates again to what depths of puerility our immigration laws have been allowed to sink. We never were really worried about Mr. Greene, whose transgression apparently was that he belonged to the Communist party for about a month some twenty years ago, prior to his conversion to the Catholic faith.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission, after referring to the "moral obligations" surrounding a return bout between Heavyweight Champion Joe Walcott and Ezzard Charles, said today that it would recognize Walcott as the champion "until he loses his title in the ring or retires."

Unanimous endorsement of the prospective merger of the Health and Welfare Councils of New York was given yesterday by member agencies. However, sharp disagreement was voiced at a hearing in the Statler Hotel on specific phases of the skeleton operating plan for the merged councils, which member agencies had been asked to analyze.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath has ruled that Graham Greene, prominent British novelist and Roman Catholic layman, is eligible for a United States visa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee put off a vote again today on the nomination of Harry A. McDonald, present chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, as Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- United States diplomates stationed behind the Iron Curtain will discuss in Paris next month the possibility of withdrawing representatives of this Government from the Soviet Union's satellites, the State Department announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 5 -- Following is a summary of the major decisions taken at the sixth session of the United Nations General Assembly in Paris:

MIAMI, Feb. 5 -- An apprentice named Jimmy Breckons scored for the tenth time at the meeting and players of favorites did some ticket-cashing for the first time during the afternoon, when the Cherry-Oca Stable's Argentine-bred Tio Ciro held on for a tip-of-his-nose decision in Hialeah's best race today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 5 -- A locked World War II Air Force strongbox turned over to the First Army Headquarters Counter Intelligence Corps today by George E. Burtsche, contractor of Red Coat Road, in the belief that it might contain secret Air Force papers. The box, however, was empty.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The State Association of Election Commissioners avoided any direct action today on the controversial issue of permanent registration today. This represented a slight retreat from the organization's former militant opposition to such proposals.

As self-possessed as if he were in uniform and pounding a beat, Patrolman Joseph A. Kelly, 27-year-old World War II veteran, marched last night into Hunter College, Sixty-eighth Street and Park Avenue, in a long procession of young women and received a degree as a member of the graduating class.

The elections going on in India since December are so vast and so long-drawn-out that they are hard to grasp, either realistically or imaginatively. Yet, enough results are now available to provide for first judgments, pending the final results, which we should have in a month or so.

NEWARK, Feb. 5 -- Financial operations of 450 enforcement officers, politicians and business men in Bergen County, whose names cropped up during the investigation of gambling there by Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler, have been made available to United States Attorney Grover C. Richman.

CAIRO, Feb. 5 -- The Minister of the Interior, Ahmed Mortada el Maraghy Bey, told the foreign press tonight that a thorough investigation was in progress to ascertain those responsible for the rioting and burning of buildings that took place Jan. 26 in Cairo.

The way was cleared yesterday for the State Legislature to consider amendments to the Parking Authority law when after heated debate the City Council adopted a Home Rule resolution by a vote of 21 to 4.

IF living consists of a perpetual succession of decisions, big ones and little ones, conscious and unconscious ones, it follows that the really big and painfully conscious decisions are the true touchstones of character. When such decisions hinge upon issues which are moral and emotional as well as practical, they can seem nearly impossible to make.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,582, against 1,411 last week and 1,430 in the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 874 arrivals yesterday, compared with 576 last Tuesday.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- The wandering tribe of Genghis Kahn settled down in America today, hoping their days as nomads are over.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Premier Edgar Faure asked the French National Assembly tonight for a formal vote of confidence on the discussion of the Government's proposal for a sliding scale in setting the minimum wage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- A special House committee investigating abuses of the G. I. Bill of Rights sponsored legislation today, to extend free schooling provisions to veterans of the Korean fighting -- but under strict new controls.

Probably the greatest convenience of Macy's street-floor Take-Home Food Center that opened officially yesterday is the meat department. A wide choice of Government-graded prime and choice fresh meats, as well as table-ready varieties, is offered. Shoppers spending the day in town -- and working housewives, too -- may make their purchase early in the day and pick it up just before going home.

Trailed for months wherever he went, Irving Nitzberg, former member of the notorious Brooklyn gang known as "Murder Inc." who had twice escaped death in the electric chair, was arrested at Fifty-third Street and Lexington Avenue last night on charges of grand larceny and receiving stolen property.
Arthur W. Wallander has resigned as City Director of Civil Defense and will soon resume his position with Consolidated Edison Company.

Round one of the "battle of the pocket lighters" was ended yesterday. In St. Paul, Minn., Brown Bigelow, remembrance advertising concern, won a patent infringement suit over its automatic compressed gas lighter, brought by Ronson Patents Corporation of New York.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The New York Central Railroad was warned today that it should expect "second-class fares" for "second-class service" unless it ran its trains on time.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 (AP) -- George P. Mahoney, Maryland's Democratic National Committeeman, entered today the race for his party's nomination to the United States Senate. He made his announcement in a statement distributed to state newspapers.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- The Allies announced today they again had issued a deconcentration order against the Robert Bosch combine, manufacturers of electrical goods, which once was cited as "a prime example" in the Occupying Powers decartelization program.

Plans for large-scale entry of Dow Chemical Company into the export market were outlined yesterday. Clayton S. Shoemaker, recently appointed president of two new Dow export companies, said the development would aim immediately at areas free of severe currency exchange and tax barriers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Congress today began an inquiry to determine whether the Government is guaranteeing loans on jerry-built dwellings which may become "the slums of tomorrow." A house banking subcommittee headed by Representative Albert Rains, Democrat of Alabama, is conducting the investigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today called a halt to a freight rate war among the major Eastern railroads in the handling of export grains. It told the carriers involved to stop a progressive cutting of charges on such shipments until it could review the situation.
Central Park is an amazingly popular center for migrating birds, Roger Tory Peterson, an American bird expert, told the Garden Club of America yesterday.

One of the finest television dramas of the season -- the poignant story of a writer who fought his way back from an attack of infantile paralysis -- was presented on Monday evening by Robert Montgomery in his hour-long program at 9:30 over N. B. C. video.

Virtual assurance that the Bureau of Customs will be able to continue its vital function of expediting and processing foreign trade on the present scale at least for the fiscal year 1952-53 was given yesterday by Representative J. Vaughan Gary, Democrat of Virginia.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The Republican-controlled Assembly struck a strong blow for the much-abused mink today, unanimously passing a bill that would prevent hunters from shooting them.

The outlook for bank earnings is good, according to Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at the New York University. A speaker yesterday at the midwinter Trust Conference of the American Bankers Association, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Dr. Nadler asserted, however, that the net earnings prospect for corporations in general was "not particularly bright."
VINELAND, N. J., Feb. 5 -- Citizens of Landis Township and Vineland Borough voted by a large majority in a special election today to join forces and become one city -- Vineland -- on July 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Truman said tonight that early signs indicated great interest in the forthcoming Presidential campaign. He pinned his remarks humorously onto last night's Republican Lincoln Day box supper here.

As everyone knows, the people upstairs constantly are pounding. They are banging away up there through the days, the nights, the weeks, the months and years. Sometimes they themselves do the pounding, at other times they get in professionals to do it for them, but always there is pounding.

THE world ended for Ralph Branca in the late afternoon of Oct. 3, 1951. Bobby Thomson had just hit THE home run and life no longer was worth living for the broken-hearted youngster from Mount Vernon. His sensitive soul was whipped by the fires of regret and despair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Government today certified its willingness to pay a premium of 10 to 15 per cent in order to channel defense contracts to areas where unemployment is a critical problem and to small business threatened with disaster by defense production programs.

THE pace is approaching the "break-neck" phase in the Silver Sailfish Derby, now just past the middle of its four-week run at the Palm Beaches in Florida. Although the fish do not always cooperate in these marathons, this derby is proving to be an exception, for 171 fish were entered during a recent three-day period.

HYDERABAD, India, Jan. 31 (By Airmail) -- The Nizam of Hyderabad, who once was reputed to be the wealthiest man in the world, and indisputably was one of the most powerful rulers on the globe with absolute dominion over 16,000,000 subjects in an area the size of Minnesota, is a political nonentity today.

In her spring and summer custom collection, viewed yesterday at the Savoy Plaza Hotel, Tatiana of Saks Fifth Avenue championed the little hat, those that curve snugly across the head and then dip low at one side. For variety she interspersed small shallow silhouettes in brims and berets worn level on the head, dashing sailors tilted backward or to one side and romantic bonnet brims.

Secretary Lovett's testimony in behalf of an adequate defense budget must be read in the light of two series of reports which provide both an explanation of why we must arm and a warning to all Western nations to be on guard. One of these reports is the latest economic survey by the United Nations Commission for Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Sixteen focal housing authorities today awarded $24,027,000 in short-term loan notes at competitive bidding, the Public Housing Administration announced.

MARCH AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 5 (UP) -- An Air Force B-29 bomber approaching this base clipped telephone poles and crashed in flames on a highway today, killing at least three of the eleven men aboard.

WFDR, the only remaining frequency modulation radio station of three originally owned by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, will cease operations Feb. 15 because "operating costs are so high that we can't continue."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee agreed today on the main points of a bill under which all qualified 18-year-old youths would be called up for six months of universal military training.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Democratic opposition to a renewal of the enabling act giving New York City the right to impose a 3 per cent sales tax appeared today to have receded slightly in the wake of Mayor Impellitteri's conference with Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders on the city's financial problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The nation's stockpiling of strategic materials for a full emergency has met serious setbacks as a result of the demands of mobilization, strikes, high prices and world shortages, the Munitions Board said in a semi-annual report to Congress today.

A $3,730-a-year plumbing inspector for the Department of Housing and Buildings was named yesterday in a criminal information containing seven counts of second-degree perjury and, in addition, charging violation of the City Charter.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The State Board of Social Welfare informed Governor Dewey and the Legislature today that it was opposed to the enactment of any law opening relief rolls to public inspection at this time.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- The problem of what is funny -- or what constitutes comedy from the Soviet viewpoint -- is a very serious one, the newspaper Soviet Art reported today.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 7 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,152, for Wednesday's operations:

This morning's new film is "Viva Zapata!" Twentieth Century-Fox's dramatization of the career of the Mexican revolutionary, with Marlon Brando in the title role, at the Rivoli. Elia Kazan directed and Darryl F. Zanuck produced from a script by John Steinbeck.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Frank E. Gannett Rochester, N. Y., publisher, received an award of merit and honorary fellowship from the George Washington Carver Memorial Institute tonight for "outstanding contributions to the betterment of race relations, human welfare and Americanism."

Growing signs of irritation between the American Federation of Labor and the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions were noted at the recent meeting of the A. F. L. Executive Council. The international confederation, a little over two years old, is undergoing the usual growing pains of such organizations.

Reading in THE TIMES that several doctors are being dropped from the staff of St. Francis Hospital because they are on the medical advisory board of Planned Parenthood of Dutchess County, I am amazed at such undemocratic action.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Two Democratic legislators from Brooklyn today introduced a bill aimed at lessening the danger of crashes in heavily populated metropolitan areas by aircraft on instrument approaches.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- The new tension between France and West Germany will be reflected in the unsolved problems that will be passed to the forthcoming meeting of the North Atlantic Council by its Temporary Council Committee under the chairmanship of W. Averell Harriman, which resumed its meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Truman and the nation paid tribute to King George VI today in extending this country's sympathy to the British people on his death.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ernie Beck set a new Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League individual scoring record of 45 points tonight while leading Penn to a 82-48 victory over Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The State Department suggested today that the United States allow not less than 25,000,000 pounds of fresh or frozen tuna fish to be imported duty free each year, with a duty of 3 cents a pound to apply to further imports.
St. Francis College defeated Iona College of New Rochelle, 64 -- 58, at the Second Corps Artillery Armory in their second consecutive overtime basketball contest.

Parisienne inspired coats for children, designed by Pierre Balmain for Bambury, highlighted a fashion show at the Pierre Hotel yesterday. Even the tiny toddler can boast a French designed fashion, as sizes ranged from one to fourteen. Featured along with these designs were other selections of spring Bambury coats and suits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today took a firm stand, in its annual report to Congress, against the progressive reductions it had suffered in its appropriations over a period of years.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 6 -- Fordham's basketball team ran into a sharp-shooting Seton Hall squad tonight in the Pirates' gymnasium and bowed, 60 -- 41, before a capacity crowd of 3,500 fans. The victory was the eighteenth in nineteen games this season for Coach John (Honey) Russell's team.
The tall, blond 30-year-old naval officer who is expected to be designated Prince Consort Philip is the new Queen Elizabeth's complement in personality, upbringing and experience.

The stock market barely made the grade yesterday, either in business or in rallying power. In the third dullest session of the year, prices negotiated a limited recovery from the decline of the two preceding days which had brought quotations close to the lows since December.

Exporters are becoming increasingly interested in proposed price decontrol on textile soft goods and shoes, because such suspension of ceilings would call for parallel lifting of export price curbs, trade sources pointed out yesterday. Exporters, who traditionally sell at prices varying according to markets, would be most likely to benefit from such decontrol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Business concerns piled up almost $10,000,000,000 in additional stocks during 1951, the Department of Commerce reported today. The Office of Business Economics said inventories at the end of December aggregated $69,400,000,000, compared with $59,400,000,000 a year ago.

Professional baseball had its day in court yesterday when representatives of both major and minor leagues appeared before John Kieran in a two-hour hearing at the Veterans Administration Building, 252 Seventh Avenue.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Sixty flagstaffs lining the driveway of the Palais de Chaillot were stripped of their banners today in tribute to King George, and above the building the blue and white flag of the United Nations flapped at halfstaff.

Companies must take active leadership rather than wait for directions from official quarters to plan for the protection of personnel in wartime, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday in its report on how British and continental companies minimized the effects of air attacks on employes and installations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Old Senate opponents of the North Atlantic Treaty opened today an effort to put Congressional limitations on President Truman's freedom to commit troops to carry out its common defensive obligations.

Men and women in normal health between the ages of 18 and 59 can give blood painlessly and harmlessly as many as five times a year, Dr. William M. Markel, administrator of the New York regional blood program declared yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Queen Elizabeth's accession will change many features of everyday life in Britain. Some of these changes may be profound. In many others, Britons will be reminded closely and immediately of the influence of monarchy on modes and customs.
ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Republican legislators from Suffolk County took steps today to strip W. Kingsland Macy, former State Republican Chairman, of his last source of patronage.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

VIENNA, Feb. 6 -- The office of the Australia Chancellor stated today that no proposals had been made to the Western occupation powers regarding measures with which Austria would counter a Soviet attempt to partition Austria and added that nothing of the kind was feared by the Austrian Government.

Two youths, who turned out to be narcotics addicts, were arrested last night and charged with snatching a woman's purse containing $200 last Sunday. The youths were traced after one of them had dropped his withholding tax statement at the scene of the crime on the upper West Side.

MUNSAN, Korea, Feb. 6, (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by North Korean Gen. Nam Il at Panmunjom today introducing Communist principles for recommendations to the Governments of countries involved in the Korean war:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Air Force has awarded a contract to McDonnell Aircraft Corporation of St. Louis, to prepare for production of a new twin-jet fighter plane.

Early ratification of the Japanese peace treaty has been assured by the fact that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has approved it unanimously and thus paved the way for like action by the Senate as a whole. This action, strongly recommended by Secretary Acheson and General Bradley, is first of all a tribute to the handiwork of Mr. Dulles, the chief architect of the treaty.

Joint action by European countries to promote exports to the dollar areas was advocated yesterday by a West German publisher at a world trade meeting of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, 233 Broadway.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- A group of 175 corporation executives, manufacturers, lawyers, clergymen, clubwomen and housewives rose in protest today against barbed inquiries concerning "communism" aimed at Sarah Lawrence College by the Americanism committee of the Westchester County American Legion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Joseph P. Kamp was acquitted today of contempt of Congress for allegedly failing to provide records demanded by the House lobby investigating committee.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today new issues of public utility bonds totaling $12,000,000. The securities were acquired by the bankers on Tuesday at competitive sale. The offerings are as follows:

Federal judges have an arduous and vexing judicial post, particularly in the Southern District of New York, where sixteen jurists are called upon to be economists, business men and experts on seamanship, literature and music. Twenty-two per cent of all civil litigation in federal courts is now pending in the Southern District.

Jim Hearn, the righthanded pitcher the Cardinals couldn't use but who helped to win a pennant for the Giants, returned his signed contract to Charles (Chub) Feeney at the West 42d Street offices yesterday.

Miami Beach, Fla., sold yesterday $2,399,000 of bonds, due Aug. 1, 1952 to 1971, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 99.002 for interest of 2.60 per cent, an interest cost of 2.673 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at yields ranging from 1.50 per cent to 2.70 per cent.

A new industry which has been developing in the last decade around a new raw material -- glass fiber -- will make its first major bid today for direct participation of private investors in its ownership.

THE wildfowlers of New York, as well as a good showing of enthusiasts from neighboring states, will be well represented tonight at the annual dinner of Ducks Unlimited at the Hotel Roosevelt, at which these coot-shooters, duck-callers and goose-honkers will be certain of finding kindred spirits.

HANOI, Indo-China, Feb. 6 -- French and Vietnamese troops engaged Vietminh forces at three different points within the Red River delta yesterday as Communist - led contingents continued their efforts to widen their areas of control and influence inside the perimeter of the main French and Vietnamese defenses in Tongking.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 2,033,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted 135,894,000 barrels, compared with 133,861,000 a week earlier and 129,700,000 a year ago.

Miss Anne Morgan, daughter of the late J. Pierpont Morgan, who died Jan. 29 at the age of 78, bequeathed 80 per cent of her estate to employes and the remainder to charitable organizations with which she had been associated for years. Her will was offered for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Satterlee, Warfield Stephens.
EASTON, Pa., Feb. 6 -- Lafayette College hung up its seventh straight victory by defeating the City College five by 58 -- 49 tonight. It was the Maroon's eleventh triumph in sixteen games.

Two waitresses, both stabbed to death, were found at 5 P. M. yesterday in the ground-floor apartment of one of them at 1580 Metropolitan Avenue, Parkchester, the Bronx. The body of Mrs. Jean Mitchell, 36 years old, the apartment lessee, was discovered in the foyer.
Blackie, a frisky mongrel from the "other side of the tracks," returned from the other side of the Atlantic yesterday with a somewhat smug air befitting the hero of a canine escapade.
In commodities futures trading here yesterday cocoa was strong, others were mixed or lower.
The new Queen Elizabeth, second of her name and fortieth in line of succession from William of Normandy, inherits a throne that is the most enduring political institution of modern history.

The re-election of all eighteen incumbent officials of Local 333, United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., became official last night with the issue of a formal report by the elections committee of the tugmen's local.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- William L. Pfeiffer, Republican state chairman, said today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's early return to the United States was essential to win him the Republican nomination for President.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 7 to 27 points net lower than on Tuesday. Near months showed the most weakness.

Cooperation rather than competition among trust men, lawyers, insurance underwriters and investment advisers is essential for effective estate planning, Mayo A. Shattuck declared yesterday. Mr. Shattuck, nationally known trust authority, a member of the firm of Haussermann, Davison, Shattuck Field of Boston, was the principal speaker at the closing session of the mid-winter trust conference of the American Bankers Associa tion at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Bureau of Mines reported today that many operating rooms in the nation's hospitals contained a deadly combination of explosive gases and equipment that easily generated static electricity. Even the shoes and clothing that some operating-room attendants wear, the bureau said, have a tendency to "manufacture" static electricity.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 7 -- The United Nations Command began today a detailed study of the Communist proposal for a top-level political conference three months after the armistice in the Korean war to deal with related issues in the Far East.
ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 6 -- In a placid creek just behind the Old Mill on Main Street here is a buoyant colony of nine families who have solved the housing problem in a romantic way.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The State Commerce Department said today its inventory of plant facilities had assisted the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale in starting an intensified program of parts and sub-assembly sub-contracting necessitated by stepped-up schedules for the production of jet fighter planes.

James J. Moran, political protege of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, spent his first day in City Prison yesterday as the search went on to learn who, if anyone, succeeded him as top man in the $500,000 extortion racket in the Fire Department.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A chubby little prince scrambled across the nursery floor today, unaware that the death of his grandfather had made him one of Britain's richest boys -- with a legacy of grave responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Truman was quoted today as having said he was prepared to run the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by Executive Order himself if the Senate did not confirm Harry. A. McDonald, his nominee, as Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator Pat McCarran, the Nevada Democrat who heads the Senate's Internal Security investigating subcommittee, shocked proponents of statehood for Hawaii today when he announced that his group was preparing for a protracted inquiry into communism in the islands.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 -- Marxism is not based on any "necessity" of overthrowing existing Government by violence, fifteen California Communists on trial under the Smith Act argued today in the defense's opening statement in United States District Court.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the state-aided Frederick Douglass Houses low-rent housing project to be erected on a 22.5-acre site bounded by Manhattan Avenue, Amsterdam Avenue and West 100th and 104th Streets.

Burlington Mills Corporation held the first public inspection of its new $2,000,000 warehouse at Teterboro, N. J., yesterday. This fabric distribution center covering an area of 247,000 square feet will provide Burlington's apparel customers in the New York area with spot deliveries on more than 5,000 styles and patterns of goods.

About 10,000,000 pounds of strategic copper was freed for vital defense production in the General Electric Company last year by using aluminum and other metals as substitutes in company products, Harry A. Winne, vice president of engineering, disclosed yesterday.

In his seventeen seasons at the Metropolitan Opera, Charles Kullman has made a reputation for the variety of roles he has sung, and last night he assumed still a new part, his twenty-eighth to date. It was that of Herod in the season's fifth and final performance of Richard Strauss' "Salome."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A new policy dispute in the Veterans Administration has brought the resignation of Dr. E. H. Cushing as assistant chief medical director.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio picked up two more delegates to the Republican National Convention today in his struggle with the Eisenhower-for-President forces in Oklahoma.

The nation's aircraft industry is not strong enough financially to support the requirements of the Air Force, Roy T. Hurley, chairman and president of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, warned yesterday. He charged that the industry's profits and expansion plans have been severely restricted by Government policy, while the aluminum, oil, airline and other important industries have been accorded consideration enabling them to develop necessary strength in the present emergency.

THIS is the Olympic year and it's a lead-pipe cinch that at least one Olympic champion will be competing at the New York A. C. games in Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. But even a fellow blessed with powers of clairvoyance would have difficulty in identifying him -- or them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, describing the United States and its European allies as indispensable to each other, said today that North Atlantic pact members would be ready at their meeting in Lisbon later this month to announce their contributions to the free world's defense program.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Navy staged an 11-point spurt in the final quarter today to defeat Pittsburgh's basketball team, 54 to 44.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 5 -- A sharply written student editorial condemning school authorities for mixing politics with the pulpit was hailed as "a healthy sign" today by Dr. Allan B. Heely, headmaster of Lawrenceville School, one of the targets of the blast.

Some of Britain's history has been most glorious when a Queen held the throne, although not all the women proclaimed rulers of the monarchy and empire added to its prestige. So averse was the first of them to wearing a crown that she fainted on hearing the news. She was Lady Jane Grey, a girl of 16 caught in the meshes of a plot to change the succession from the Tudors to the Dudleys.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Feb. 6 -- Communist reporters covering the Korean armistice talks for the enemy side in this mud-hut village have entered into a jealous competition to exploit this "propaganda bonanza" they are convinced they have discovered in their daily liaison with the Western press.

Many seats have been purchased for the pre-opening performance of "Venus Observed," with Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer in the leading roles, Monday night at the Century Theatre for the benefit of The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind. Among the well-known women who are furthering the success of the benefit are Mrs. R. Thornton Wilson Jr. and Mrs. Robert H. Ellinger.
New York's thrifty received a new incentive yesterday.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 6 -- Young Queen Elizabeth II left hurriedly for home by plane tonight only a few hours after her husband had broken the news to her of her father's death.

The sixteenth annual awards of the Press Photographers Association of New York were announced yesterday. Thirty-six pictures out of 646 submitted by photographers working on newspapers and picture agencies in the city were chosen by a panel of editors for prizes or honorable mention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The White House confirmed late today that President Truman had written a letter of praise to Theron Lamar Caudle less than a month before the President had removed Mr. Caudle as Assistant Attorney General for outside activities believed incompatible with his duties. Mr. Caudle was dismissed Nov. 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Officials of the Department of Defense underwent a period of criticism before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today and did not seem to like it. They were appearing in support of defense budget estimates of more than $52,000,000,000.

Bungling thieves took cheap furs and inexpensive fountain pens valued at $4,500 from the cargo area of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday but overlooked $32,000 in mink under their noses and $500,000 in imported watch movements, cameras and laces in a locked cage near by.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Under a charter of 1337, Prince Charles Philip Arthur George, as the sovereign's first-born son, became Duke f Cornwall and also received the titles of Duke of Rothesay, Earl of Carrick, Baron of Renfrew, Lord of the Isles and Great Steward of Scotland.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Restoration of a Revolutionary War landmark in the area of old Fort Lee between Hudson Terrace and the edge of the Palisades Cliffs south of the George Washington Bridge is under study by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.
Conversion of Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way operation has been decided upon by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley despite objections of the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

James J. Moran, holder of various important offices under former Mayor O'Dwyer, has been found guilty of extortion and conspiracy in a $500,000-a-year Fire Department shakedown. A General Sessions jury brought in the verdict; Judge John A. Mullen declared it "amply supported by the evidence."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 6 -- United States and British diplomats are trying earnestly to cool the passions awakened in the Federal Republic by the dispute over the Saar to the point where West Germany and France can negotiate on the issue of the territory's future.

Stockholders of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation at their meeting here yesterday, approved a plan granting officers and 160 key employes, options to purchase an aggregate of 100,000 shares of the company's authorized unissued $5 par capital stock.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The news of the death of the King brought business to a standstill on the Stock Exchange here today. Members stopped dealing before official decision was taken to close at noon. There was little business with only a few changes in prices. Prices were mostly lower. Nowhere was there any sign of disturbance.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 6 (UP) -- A battle-seasoned "invasion" force of 5,000 soldiers stole into the rugged northern New York mountians today to prepare for an "atomic attack" scheduled as the climax of Exercise Snowfall.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- Following is the text of the British Privy Council proclamation tonight:

The New York University basketball team will oppose Syracuse at Madison Square Garden tonight. The game will be the second half of a double-header, with De Paul of Chicago slated to oppose Manhattan in the opener.
SANDRINGHAM, England, Feb. 6 -- This tiny hamlet of Sandringham mourned deeply tonight the loss of a beloved squire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 30, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan, Democratic leader of the State Senate, said today that he would oppose the amendments to the New York City Parking Authority law that Mayor Impellitteri has requested.
Soviet airpower and Soviet atomic developments probably are primarily geared to the support of Russian ground armies, in the opinion of some close students of the Soviet Union.

The fury of the German air blitzkrieg over Britain in 1940-41 failed to shake King George's resolve to maintain his residence at Buckingham Palace, in the heart of London. The palace was bombed, yet he steadfastly refused to find a safer home, preferring instead to share danger with his people.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- A strong last-half rally enabled Army to overcome Swarthmore, 56 to 46, on the Field House court today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 6 -- A proposal that may prove to be a cause of discord was placed before the parents of Greenwich today by the Board of Education. The idea, which seems designed to rob smoking among high school students of its "forbidden fruit" quality, is to let sophomores, juniors and seniors of Greenwich High School smoke on the school grounds.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The Board of Regents announced today the appointment of Mrs. Harper Sibley of Rochester and Bruce Bromley of Brooklyn to the new commission that will investigate charges of subversive material in the state's public school textbooks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -- A House subcommittee heard today that James G. Smyth, now under indictment, was appointed Collector of Internal Revenue for Northern California in 1945 despite three intelligence reports "distinctly unfavorable" to him.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Italy's application for membership in the United Nation's was vetoed by the Soviet Union tonight for the fifth time. Ten of the eleven members of the Security Council voted for a French resolution recommending the admission of Italy.

" CAPTAIN HORATIO HORNBLOWER" stands beside "Candide." "For Whom the Bell Tolls" is followed by "The Forsyte Saga." George Meredith's "The Egoist" faces the "Electra" of Euripides; Pope's "The Rape of the Lock" takes alphabetical precedence over "Rasselas," by Samuel Johnson. And though there are five books by Hugh Walpole, there's not one by Ring Lardner.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- From the medical point of view the death of King George VI today was a surprise to the nation and apparently to his family and his doctors as well.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- This was an afternoon of minor league horse racing at Hialeah. Perhaps the least minor leaguish of the nine guessing contests was a $4,000 sprint for 3-year-olds that never had succeeded in winning $5,000 in a race. Those in the crowd of 18,731 who guessed right were the ones who backed a colt named Brian Boru.

CAIRO, Feb. 6 -- A palace announcement late tonight said King Farouk wished to have no celebration of his birthday next Monday because of the situation in the Suez Canal zone. Instead of gifts, the King suggested, well-wishers might contribute to relief for those made destitute as a result of the rioting in Cairo on Jan. 26.

Federal taxes last year of $95,000,000, an increase of $33,900,000 over the 1950 tax bill, reduced the net income of the National Steel Corporation to $45,287,093 from the record $57,814,974 earned the year before, according to the preliminary annual report of Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board, issued for publication today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6 Four candidates, including Michael V. DiSalle, Federal Price Stabilizer, filed petitions here today as candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in Ohio's May 6 primary.

Persons living in modern houses but preferring traditional: 'furnishings may be interested in two model' apartments just installed at Riverview South, 55 East End Avenue. The interior design. team of Muller-Barringer are responsible for selecting the eighteenth century furnishings from Macy's and arranging them against the contemporary backgrounds of this just-completed house.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A wreath of yellow daffodils tossed tonight from the Pennsylvania Railroad commuter train the Broker was marked "In Memoriam" for eighty-five persons killed here in a train wreck a year ago.

A recent announcement by the Swiss Mount Everest expedition that it will use oxygen tanks in its attempt to scale the mountain this spring brings into focus again the compelling challenge, the thrilling adventure, past-present-and-future, of Mount Everest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Grain futures carried on the recovery which set in yesterday in the early trade today, but, as shorts covered, the demand was found to be thin and prices reacted sharply from the early highs. Later, there was a brisk final rally on commission support.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Former Gov. Ellis G. Arnall of Georgia was reported today to have agreed to take over the Office of Price Stabilization from Michael V. DiSalle, who is leaving Feb. 15 to seek the Democratic Senatorial nomination in Ohio.

President Truman's decision to slow down the nation's aircraft production timetable will ward off a squeeze on the civilian economy that has threatened to force many small manufacturers out of business for lack of materials and to cause increased unemployment in the second half of this year.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Except for one match, first-round results in the Palm Beach Women's amateur golf tournameht today ran true to the form established in the qualifying round.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6 -- The first public protest over widespread arrests made by the Government during the last three days was issued late last night by local leaders of the Radical party, whose president was among those arrested.

Mayor Impellitteri's estimate that the city needs at least $200,000,000 of additional revenue to balance its 1952-53 budget is at least $91,000,000 too high, according to an analysis made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.
George VI reigned over Britain through one of the most troubled periods in her long history.
OSLO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic committee, arrived by air today carrying a large glass wassail bowl etched by Sidney Waugh as a gift to the city of Oslo.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Paris went into mourning on receiving news of the death of King George VI. The public first learned of the King's death when the flags on the French Foreign Ministry, the President's residence, the Elysee Palace, and dozens of other public buildings were placed at half staff.

A policeman was shot in the neck yesterday morning in a struggle with a male patient in the psychiatric ward of Bellevue Hospital. The police said the patient seized a policeman's pistol during the struggle and fired six shots, one of which struck Patrolman William Kennedy, 30 years old, of 94-58 239th Street, Bellerose, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee formally approved a "bona fide" Universal Military Training bill today under which all able-bodied 18-year-olds would be called up for six months of training. The vote was 27 to 7.

Louis Armstrong, famous jazz trumpeter and band leader, received $1,000 damages in Supreme Court yesterday and a consent injunction in his fight against "pirates" and "bootleggers" in the record industry.

Fresh in appearance and original in design are new contemporary drinking, smoking and table accessories by Karl Aubock of Vienna, now available at Lord Taylor. Black iron, shiny brass and copper, clear glass and walnut wood form the basic shapes.

The steel industry told a Wage Stabilization Board panel yesterday that the board would hamper the country's defense against atomic attack, undermine our foreign economic policy and introduce "totalitarianism" in the United States if it recommended that Southern steel workers get the same pay as Northern steel workers.
OSLO, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A heavy snowfall stilled complaints about the condition of the ski courses today but curtailed most of the winter Olympic practices.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Feb. 6 -- Penn State ran its victory streak to twelve tonight to equal a Nittany Lions basketball record with a 66-52 victory over Rutgers. The Lions won twelve in a row ten years ago.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 6 -- Big-time gambling in Bergen County was made possible by the "active cooperation" of police and public officials, it was charged here today in a presentment handed up by a special grand jury. The jury has been investigating gambling and corruption in this county for more than a year.

GENEVA, Feb. 6 -- The project for coordinated world action to aid migration from overpopulated, Communist-menaced regions of Central Europe, launched by sixteen Governments at the recent Brussels conference, has been made uncertain by word or a campaign in some United States circles to take over the whole program as a strictly American operation.

Only two of the four New York City concerns that arrange for the import of more than $50,000 worth of books, magazines and newspapers annually from the Soviet Union and other Communist Countries are registered as foreign agents, a survey disclosed yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 6 -- Columbia's Jack Molinas celebrated his return to basketball this season with a 27-point performance as the Lions defeated Brown, 95 -- 75, tonight.

There will be sadness among all of America's Indians at the news that Harold L. Ickes has died. Across more than ten years before he became President Roosevelt's Secretary of the Interior he had cared for the Indians and understood them and fought their battles for and with them.

Relations between Eugene O'Neill and the American National Theatre and Academy have been strained because of differences over procedure in connection with the current revival of Mr. O'Neill's drama, "Desire Under the Elms," at the Anta Playhouse.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 (AP) -- George Rhoden racked up his sixth straight cup victory of the season tonight as he won the 600-yard run in record-equaling time of 1 minute 11.4 seconds in the sixth South Atlantic Association track and field games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Seven speakers from Congress and elsewhere will move into New Hampshire starting next week to urge General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for that state's fourteen delegates to the Republican Presidential nominating convention.

DUBLIN, Feb. 6 -- The news of King George's death was received here today with unfeigned sorrow. Despite the Irish Republic's constitutional separation from the Crown, its people always had shown deep admiration for the King.

Firmenich, Inc., manufacturer of aromatics and food flavors, to Calkins Holden, Carlock, McClinton and Smith, Inc., effective April 1. J. Sherwood Smith is account supervisor and Walter B. Geoghegan account executive.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- As messages of sympathy from all over the world poured into London, the reaction of the British Commonwealth showed how closely linked in grief over the death of King George were peoples of the Dominions and colonies and of the mother country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Cushing said today that "I have no loyalty for the VA as such, butI have a great deal of pride in the very good department of medicine and surgery developed in the last five or six years. That is slipping. It is hoped that this [his resignation] will call attention to the weaknesses."

Having returned from Germany only recently -- after various assignments there during the past five years as press officer of the United States occupation authorities which took me to many West German towns -- it might interest your readers to know some of the thoughts which usually come to me when I hear a discussion of the topics "neo-nazism" and "democrats in Germany."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 6 -- News of King George's death spread in Karachi with rapidity and general and genuine grief was discernible among all groups. Places of amusement and most business houses closed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- The Defense Department identified today 270 more United States casualties in Korea in its weekly report, bringing the total to 105,271.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A masked man, identified as a former Polish soldier, testified today that he saw 200 Polish Army officers slain by Soviet soldiers in Katyn Forest, near Smolensk, Russia, one night in October, 1939.

Charles A. Wiggins, sales and advertising manager of the Calumet division of the General Foods Corporation, has been given added responsibility of sales and advertising manager for the company's Minute Division. Principal products of the division are Minute Rice and Minute Tapioca.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Three irregularly operated airlines asked the Supreme Court today to review their $100,000,000 damage action against the Air Transport Association, Inc., and twenty major airlines.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Important diplomatic changes may follow in the wake of the death of King George VI and the accession of Elizabeth II to the throne.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 6 -- Six military police -- three British and three United States -- under the command of a British sergeant marched stiffly down the gravelled drive before this international headquarters at noon today and lowered in turn the flags of the twelve North Atlantic treaty organization Allies and of Allied Supreme Headquarters itself as a sign of respect for Britain's dead king.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A personal note of reassurance by Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson failed today to stem a storm of Congressional protest against his order, issued yesterday, directing that premium prices be paid, if necessary, to get war contracts to critical unemployment areas.

King George VI ascended the throne because of an unprecedented event in English history -- the abdication of his oldest brother, King Edward VIII. Never before had a British monarch given up the crown of his own free will.

Boy Scout Week began here yesterday at a luncheon attended by 1,000 persons, who heard speakers praise the Scouting movement for its positive influence on the moral and democratic ideals of the world of tomorrow.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 6 -- Within a few hours of the news of the death of King George VI, his daughter, Elizabeth was today proclaimed Queen in Canada. This action was taken at a fifteen-minute Cabinet meeting, followed by a sitting of twenty-three members of the Privy Council, who approved the proclamation.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- This was a silent city tonight, with bright lights dimmed and all places of entertainment closed, as Londoners went home shocked by the death of their King.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House Republican Policy Committee unanimously endorsed today a resolution that would direct President Truman to submit a new, balanced budget to Congress within thirty days.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 6 -- A deadlock among members of the local Board of Education was broken early this morning by a vote cast by a member of the board from her bed in Norwalk Hospital and sped to a meeting of the board by a police car.

Rallying from an 11-point deficit at the start of the last period, the New York Knickerbockers scored a last-minute triumph over the Baltimore Bullets, 73 -- 70, before 1,500 spectators at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. Their last-ditch effort gave Joe Lapchick's charges their twelfth straight home victory and put them back at the .500 mark in the National Basketball Association standings.

Pending hearing on a petition for a jury trial of charges that they assaulted Referee Ray Miller and Matchmaker Al Weill of the International Boxing Club in Madison Square Garden Jan. 11, the trial of Tommy Ryan, known also as Tommy Eboli, and his brother, Patsy Eboli, yesterday was adjourned until March 5 by Special Sessions Justice Joseph V. LoScalzo.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Eugene (Silent) Hairston of the Bronx and Robert Villemain of France battled to a draw in a ten-round middleweight bout tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Britain entered a new Elizabethan era today. Upon the death of King George VI, Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, his elder daughter, automatically became Queen of the United Kingdom and the Dominions Overseas at the age of 25.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- The Motion Picture Industry Production Code Administration, headed by Joseph I. Breen, has abandoned its traditional policy of silence in the face of criticism and henceforth will reply to all attacks upon its actions from sources within and outside of the business.

Gina Bachauer gave a piano recital at Town Hall last night that was almost feverish in its brilliance. For marksmanship and sheer bravura her performances were breath-taking. But they were also breathless, as though they were the product of deep inner tensions.

ATLANTA, Feb. 6 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina charged today that, because Negro politicians in recent years have wielded the balance of power in elections in big cities of the North, the national Democratic party had rejected the State's Rights doctrine expoused by the South and had treated that region as a "stepchild."

Three mere were convicted and one man was acquitted early yesterday morning by a Federal Court jury of diverting 3,500,000 pounds of rationed sugar into the black market in 1946 for a reported profit of $150,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- The State Tax Commission warned thousands of delinquent truckers today that they faced revocation of their motor vehicle registrations unless they immediately filed the monthly returns required under the state's controversial truck mileage tax and paid the tax "in full."

The unexpected death of King George VI of Great Britain came as a severe shock to Wall Street. With arrangements for his funeral still undecided, no action has been taken by the New York Stock Exchange to mark the occasion. But if precedent is followed, the burial will be observed by a closing of the institution for a short period.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Schiaparelli introduces new details in cut, adding them to basic lines that remain natural, the natural waist and moulded hips. The bust is accented by a wide-open, heart-shaped neckline, often daringly low. Summer frocks, cocktail and evening gowns and the blouses within suits have this neckline.

The new Queen of England, Elizabeth II, has spent her entire life under the adoring eye of the millions of subjects of the British crown. Ever since she could toddle she has been the darling of the Empire.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Legislation to make unclaimed stock dividends held by brokerage houses and corporations payable to the state's abandoned property fund is scheduled for enactment at this session of the Legislature, it was learned today.
BOSTON, Feb. 6 -- A spokesman for Representative Christian A. Herter, Republican of Massachusetts, said today that Mr. Herter would decide about Feb. 20 whether to run for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Two Interstate Commerce Commission examiners today recommended that their agency should protect the present differential between all rail class rates between points in Texas and Louisiana and points on the Eastern seaboard, and the lower rates when there is a joint haul by railroads and one of the three water carriers serving the Gulf Coast and the East Coast area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Mrs. Hiram Cole Houghton, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, announced today that the federation's executive board had voted to undertake the registration of all club women for volunteer work in civil defense.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- Cornell University said today it would send regrets to neighboring Colgate that it could not pay a $131.50 bill for damages to two Colgate buildings.

For those who dream of a traditional wedding complete with satin or lace or have a hankering for the new and novel, Rosette Pennington presented a bridal collection yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Gov. Fuller Warren's press secretary, repeating his assertions that The Miami Herald had lied about the Governor, threatened today to cut off the newspaper and its capitol reporter from further information.
