LONDON, Feb. 6 -- In the early hours of this morning George VI died peacefully in his sleep at the royal estate at Sandringham. As night fell upon this mourning capital of a still great family of nations, his elder daughter was proclaimed Queen of this realm and its dependencies, head of the British Commonwealth and the Defender of the Faith, with the title of Elizabeth II.

While New Yorkers mourned yesterday for the death of King George VI, holding memorial services, displaying flags at half staff and paying tribute in formal and informal statements, the Duke of Windsor prepared to go home alone for the funeral.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The synthetic production in pure form of Vitamin B6, used in cancer research and previously not available for experimental use, was made public today by Dr. J. R. Heller, director of the National Cancer Institute of the Public Health Service.
The King's death and her sister's ascension to the throne do not affect the title of Princess Margaret Rose.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- American astronomers have discovered a new comet, a mere point of light invisible to the naked eye, in the far reaches of the northern sky, the National Geographic Society announced today. It is named for its discoverers, the Harrington Wilson Comet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives refused today to recommend the unseating of Representative Hardie Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania.

Your recent editorial was critical of the usual arguments made against U. M. T. and urged its immediate passage by Congress because it is needed. My contention, however, is that a military training course of six months for all 18-year-olds as proposed is not needed at all and would be a wasteful expenditure and just another menace to our national economy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- This country's membership in the International Materials Conference has enabled its defense production agencies to get a greater share of the world's scarce materials than would have been obtained in the open market, Manly Fleischmann, head of the Defense Production Administration, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Representatives of ten North Atlantic Treaty nations discussed with Admiral Lynde D. McCormick, Supreme Allied Commander of the Atlantic, today the organization of a new headquarters in Norfolk, Va. about April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Ducking nimbly around and under scaffolding, President Truman today took a few correspondents on a conducted tour of the White House, which is being reconstructed. He said it was still his hope that the First Family would be able to move into it early in April after three and one-half years in Blair House.

The shortage of nurses in city hospitals has become so great that "the prospect before us is frightening," Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday. The competition among all hospitals for nurses is "something close to frenzy," he said, with city hospitals worse off than others because of lower pay scales.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Congressmen complained today the Government underwrote loans on some veterans' houses built in a watery old lake bed, and approved another dwelling where the bathtub was not connected to the sewer system.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 6 -- All three rinks representing the Utica Curling Club today reached the semi-finals in the first women's Northeastern District curling championship bonspiel for the Hovey Trophy at St. Andrews Golf Club. Each up-state quartet defeated units from the Country Club of Brookline, Mass.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Forty-seven countries, including Japan, Italy and West Germany, made pledges today that came close to the United Nations goal of $20,000,000 for its 1952 technical assistance program. The United States contribution will be roughly $12,000,000.

Events tonight: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, Mitropoulos, conductor, Myra Hess, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Margaret Bonds, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Hungarian String Quartet, McMillin Theatre, 8:30.

Among India's culinary traditions the art of making perfect condiments has been brought to a fabled degree of excellence, This is the proud boast of the Government of India Information Service here, which recently heralded the second anniversary of the birth of the Republic of India by calling attention to some of its most essteemed condiment recipes.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Bills permitting savings banks to declare special dividends as well as regular dividends were submitted to the Legislature today by Senator John Hughes of Syracuse and Assem blyman D. Mallory Stephens of Putnam, both Republicans.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 6 (UP) -- Federal Judge Allen Cox dismissed perjury indictments against five pro-Truman Democrats today and announced that he would decide tomorrow when to begin trials for four accused of selling Federal jobs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP) -- A former official of the Institute of Pacific Relations refused today to tell the Senate Internal Security Committee whether she ever had been a Communist on the ground that her answer might be incriminating.
The American League will take off on its 1952 campaign on Tuesday, April 15, with Washington, Philadelphia, Detroit and Cleveland drawing the home openings, the schedule just released reveals.

NEWARK, Feb. 6 -- The Board of Public Utility Commissioners tonight granted the Public Service transportation companies, operators of 236 bus lines within the state, a temporary 2-cent increase in basic bus fares to become effective on Feb. 17.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied an application by Electric Bond and Share Company today to be permitted to retain its stock holdings in the United Gas Corporation. The applicant sought approval to retain 3,165,781 shares (approximately 27 per cent) of United's common stock which it acquired in connection with the liquidation of Electric Power and Light Corporation, a former subsidiary, and on the subsequent exercise of stock purchase rights.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (UP) -- An official of the American Hospital Association said tonight that his organization had been working for five years to promote safety measures that would minimize the chances of static electricity explosions in hospitals.

Mayor Impellitteri expresses the sentiments of the people of New York City when he bestows a deserved "well done" on Arthur W. Wallander for his services as Director of Civil Defense for the last year and a half. The former Police Commissioner has served the city without pay, thanks to Consolidated Edison, to which he now returns.
We are all aware that loose terminology embitters public debate. On that score I object to the term "thought control" in the news accounts of the Poughkeepsie hospital case.

Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., ordered Waldman Waldman, attorneys for the union, yesterday to institute an immediate investigation of all I. L. A. locals in the port to correct any abuses or undemocratic activities that might exist.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh testified yesterday before a New York County grand jury that has been studying charges he was lax in his duty as Commissioner of Investigation under former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

Steel companies of the United States, now in the midst of the industry's greatest expansion program, spent an aggregate of $1,041,000,000, a record amount, for new equipment and construction during 1951, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Two books about Gilbert and Sullivan will be issued by the British Book Centre on Feb. 26. One will be a new and revised edition of a biography by Herbert Sullivan and Newman Flower, "Sir Arthur Sullivan: His Life, Letters and Diaries," which was first published in England in 1927.
Helen Keller, the deaf and blind author, was "reunited" yesterday morning with the treasured, specially designed watch that was lost when she left it and other belongings in a taxicab recently.

The appointment of Comdr. John H. Forney as operational training and mobilization planning officer on the staff of Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Third Coast Guard District and the Eastern Area, was announced here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- A University of Illinois professor said today he regretted his remarks on a national television broadcast that had been interpreted as comparing both President Truman and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, to a piece of cheese.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, said today he believes the liquor industry "contemplates the use of television and radio for advertising in the not too distant future." He made the statement at an Interstate Commerce hearing on a bill which he sponsors to prohibit liquor advertising by radio and TV.

Tuition rises up to 25 per cent will take effect in Columbia University's seventeen school and departments next fall. The trustees approved the increases, the third in a decade, at their regular monthly meeting Monday afternoon.
Mayor Impellitteri and other leaders of New York life paid tribute to King George VI yesterday.

Many of the young girls brought into courts today are first offenders with futures still full of hope. Instead of sentencing them to reformatories or prisons, the courts are now sending some of these young girls to the Salvation Army's Wayside Home.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 6 (UP) -- King George's death caught Australia and New Zealand in the midst of preparations for a royal tour and thus it came as a double blow to these Dominions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The director and assistant director of the Dallas office of the Production and Marketing Administration of the Department of Agriculture were discharged today by Secretary Charles F. Brannan for inefficiency and inadequacy in the performance of their duties.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- As Britons stood silently today outside the red brick mansion on the Mall where lives 84-year-old Dowager Queen Mother Mary, they saw the indomitable old lady rigidly adhere -- even in tragedy -to her own inflexible rule that for a Queen duty comes before devotion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman formally nominated George F. Kennan, a career diplomat and authority on Russia, to be Ambassador to Moscow and at the same time "reluctantly" accepted the resignation of Admiral Alan G. Kirk as United States envoy to Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The drive to bring General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower home to participate in the campaign for his nomination as Republican Presidential candidate gave evidence today of gaining in momentum.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Feb. 2 rose 5 per cent above those in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Rear Admiral Victor C. Barringer Jr., U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Barringer have come to the Ambassador from Washington.

Thousands of potential but up now thwarted television fans received good news yesterday. An electronic industry expert said defense production restrictions will not delay expansion of broadcasts into current non-television areas once the Federal Communications Commission lifts its "freeze" on new stations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 2, 1952, totaled 731,006 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's broadcast tonight on the death of King George VI and the ascension of Queen Elizabeth II:
Plans for the construction of a new pier at a cost of about $2,700,000 were announced yesterday by Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

Your recent editorial in answer to Max Tamir ended with an irrelevant paragraph which, however, raises the basic question of the transit fare issue -- shall the straphangers be taxed whenever the city finds itself in financial need? On the surface, the question as to what shall be substituted for revenues if we do not raise fares sounds reasonable.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Subject to Queen Elizabeth's approval the body of the King will reach London by train over the weeek-end following a brief family service at the little sixteenth century Sandringham church outside the estate.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,153, for Thursday's operations:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 -- The Government began today the presentation of its case against fifteen California Communist party functionaries, to a decorous but incessant obbligato of objections from their counsel.
The American Tobacco Company has under consideration the issuance of about $100,000,000 of new securities intended for public offering through investment bankers headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

CAIRO, Ill., Feb. 7 (UP) -- Nine members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were arrested today on charges of conspiring to force Negro children to attend Cairo's all-white schools.

CALGARY, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Alberta Appeal Court ruled yesterday that the Canadian Pacific Railway Company and Imperial Oil, Ltd., are entitled to extract all the petroleum from the 160-acre farm owned by Michael Borys in the Leduc Oil Field even if there is interference and wastage of Mr. Borys' natural gas.

Solutions of problems ranging from potential gasoline rationing in event of a national emergency to rehabilitation of deteriorated highways will be sought by the Eastern Conference of Motor Clubs, whose formation was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 -- "Martin and Lewis in Paris" will serve as the title for a comedy the team of Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis will make this summer in France. Hal Wallis, the producer, plans to turn the boys out in Technicolor in the picture and has signed Elwood Ullman to develop a story line and screen play from what now amounts only to an idea.

In another example of the long-term investment of institutional funds under the sale-and-lease-back system which has come into vogue in recent years in the business realty field, Prudential Insurance Company of America has become the owner of an outstanding store property in Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The New York Rangers broke a three-game losing streak tonight with a convincing 3-to-1 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks before 5,892 fans in the Chicago Stadium.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 7 -- Resurgent West Germany will demand democratic freedom for the Saarlanders in a settlement of the state's future and will not send German youth to fight under any North Atlantic pact command in which it has no voice, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The British Government in a note to Egypt today expressed its "strongest condemnation" of the attacks on and the killing of Britons in the Cairo riots of Jan. 26 and the destruction of British property there..

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 7 (AP) -- A string of birdies a yard long pushed little Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., into the lead in the $10,000 El Paso open today as he lashed a seven-under-par 64 in the opening eighteen-hole round which couldn't be finished because of darkness.

From European craftsmen as well as American manufacturers have come new gadgets now being offered by housewares sections of department stores here. A visit to a few of these establishments revealed the following new ideas, both domestic and imported, in equipment for the kitchen:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Brooks Brothers and the A. De Pinna Company, which have been affiliated since Julius Garfinckel Co., Inc., acquired control of De Pinna in 1950, announced today a proposed corporate consolidation of the two concerns. The proposal will be presented to the stockholders of Brooks and De Pinna at meetings to be held Feb. 28.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A United States B-29 bomber, loaded with bombs, crashed and burned on a hillside in the outskirts of Tokyo tonight, killing all the crew members and setting several houses ablaze.
A documentary motion picture that deals openly with the subject of syphilis will be shown generally for the first time in commercial theatres. It has received the sanction of censors.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, returning as director of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, presented among other features of the program the Eighth Symphony of Philip Greeley Clapp, given its first public performance on this occasion.

In a tumult of shouted objections by 200 men and women, many of whom appeared on the verge of hysteria, the Board of Education yesterday continued the suspensions of eight teachers who refused to answer questions about alleged Communist party affiliations, and appointed two of its members to conduct departmental trials.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Daniel P. O'Connell, chairman of the Albany County Democratic Committee, announced today the selection of Leo W. O'Brien, staff correspondent of The International News Service in Albany, as the Democratic candidate for Representative in Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of Representative William T. Byrne.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Governor Dewey today designated George E. Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, L. I., an investment banker, as chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority to succeed William H. Draper of Garden City, who resigned to accept an appointment from President Truman as an Ambassador at Large.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday and closing prices on active months were 4 points higher to 1 point lower than on Wednesday.

The Dobb Corporation has sold the fourteen - story-and-penthouse apartment buildings for thirty-five families on plot 100 by 105 feet at 1172 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Ninety-third Street, to Frederick Brown, who recently acquired apartment properties at 630 Park Avenue and 901 Madison Avenue.

The "interest of the depositor is sovereign," The New York Savings Bank agreed yesterday in announcing plans to increase its dividend rate from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent. A letter to depositors of the bank noted that the higher 2 1/2 per cent rate is now permissible under amended regulations of the State Banking Board.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States representative at the 1951 session of the United Nations General Assembly, believes the Soviet Union has swung over to the propaganda line that a third world war has already begun because "they can't monopolize the peace theme any more."

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Liberating the silhouette from excessively molded contours, Jacques Griffe designs simple, wearable clothes that have a new ease. The traveling waistline is the point of departure of this less-fitted line and the theme of the collection.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, has upheld the right of a private formula to determine the value of a company's stock for estate tax purposes. The ruling supports the lower court finding of Federal Judge Harold P. Burke.

The stock market experienced difficulty again yesterday in doing more than holding within a restricted area. Certain oil issue, particularly those with some interests in the new Williston Basin, of the United States and Canadian Northwest and stocks of non-producers with holdings in the area were pushed ahead sharply.

Two openings are scheduled for this evening -- "Collector's Item" at the Booth and "Pygmalion" at the De Witt Clinton Community Center, 100 West Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx. The former will be presented at 8 o'clock; the latter at 8:30.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, the Democratic Minority leaders, announced today that they would attempt next week to force a showdown on permanent personal registration.

BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, Feb. 7 -- P. B. Fletcher, Southern Rhodesian Minister of Native Affairs, addressing a meeting of farmers at Essexvale today, recalled an incident in the Matopo hills during the Royal visit to South Africa and Rhodesia in 1947.
Passage of the Customs Simplification bill by June was forecast yesterday at a meeting of the National Council of American Importers in the Astor Hotel.

The use of modern advertising methods in the last three years to induce increased attendance at religious services by Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews and to lead others to choose places of worship has been reflected in enlarged congregations, it was announced yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Religion in American Life movement.

The steel industry charged yesterday that union proposals to limit management rights would foster inefficiency and induce such frustration that some workers might be driven to "radicalism and communism."

The "agility of a jack-rabbit developed by New Yorkers in their struggle for self-preservation" was responsible in part for a 2.3 per cent decline in traffic accidents last year, the Citizens Traffic Safety Conference reported yesterday.

Cannon Mills will offer the balance of its February and March production of muslin and percale sheets at a discount, it was learned yesterday. Beginning today, a temporary 5 per cent trade discount will be given on the bleached 128 and 180 types and a 2 1/2 per cent discount will be made available on the colored sheets of these constructions.

The recent warm spell, referred to as Thaw No. 4 by Metropolitan skiers, has put a damper on the near-by skilands, and the best prospects for sport this week-end are in Vermont, New Hampshire and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada.

Fourteen persons, whose creative works are considered most likely to win a permanent place in American culture, have won election to the National Institute of Arts and Letters, Douglas Moore, institute president, announced yesterday.

John Buckmaster, who had appeared recently in the revival of George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan," was sent to Bellevue Hospital for psychiatric observation yesterday after he had been arraigned in Felony Court on charges of felonious assault and carrying concealed weapons.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- A somber little group from the Royal Family and both Houses of Parliament was at the airport when Elizabeth, who left London a week ago as Princess, returned here today as Queen. A few score airport employes were the other onlookers.

Emergency shipping under Federal auspices received its first retrenchment order yesterday as a result of lessening demand for foreign-aid cargos, while the retrenchment was slight, shipping leaders considered it noteworthy, for it marked the first reversal of the flow of ships out of the national defense reserve fleet since the National Shipping Authority was established a year ago.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Britain's new Queen, Elizabeth II, arrived here safely today after a plane flight of more than 4,000 miles from Kenya, one of her far-flung dominions.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Winner of the best of the races at Hialeah today was a horse that must have been named by a Yale man. The 6-year-old gelding Whiffenpoof, by Bull Dog, held the lead throughout the seven-furlong dash and scored with a length and a half to spare.
The American Baseball Academy turned out its first graduating class yesterday afternoon -- 300 of the town's small fry -- each with one ambition: "I want to be in the big leagues."

Craig Lawrence has been appointed general manager of WCBS-TV, succeeding G. Richard Swift, who has resigned. Mr. Lawrence, who assumes his new post on Feb. 18, has been associated with the Cowles Broadcasting Company for nineteen years, and since 1946 has managed station WCOP in Boston.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 7 -A two-mile-square, pine-covered tract three miles from the business section of Lakewood has been offered to Newark Airport as an emergency landing strip in bad weather in a move to prevent such tragedies as the recent plane crashes in Elizabeth.

Newbold Morris, named last Friday by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath to conduct an investigation into charges of Government corruption, has offered the post of chief counsel in his investigation to Virgil W. Peterson, operating director of the Chicago Crime Commission.

The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions demanded yesterday that the United Nations investigate charges that 3,000 Venezuelan workers had been jailed without due process of law and that all Venezuelan unions had been deprived of their funds and membership records.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 -- For more than three hours today Arthur H. Samish, lobbyist for the liquor industry in California, was closeted with members of the House Ways and Means subcommittee investigating tax scandals.

One hundred and fifty violations had to be removed from the nine-story apartment house for thirty-six families on plot 60 by 100 feet at 120 West 123d Street, between Seventh and Lenox Avenues, before the Estate Securities Company, operators, would sign a contract for purchase of the property for cash over a first mortgage of $66,388 held by the Manhattan Savings Bank.

Coffee closed 15 to 20 points higher on a negligible volume of 8,250 bags, but except for that gain on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and a little late strength in vegetable oils, the commodity markets here moved generally lower yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II assumed full responsibilities of the monarchy immediately upon her return to Britain today.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 7 -- Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Foreign Minister, warned today that West Germany would be in a position to block the European army's participation in any collective defense measures ordered by the Atlantic Alliance unless given a voice in the decision.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Townsend Foster and her Utica No. 2 rink, the Glengarries, today defeated the No. 3 unit of the host Westchester Wicks, skipped by Mrs. Charles M. Hovey, 13 -- 12, in thirteen ends at the St. Andrews Golf Club to become the first curling champions of the newly established Women's Northeastern District.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 7 -- New snow trimmed the campus in fresh white while the first of several thousand visitors poured into Hanover for the forty-second annual Dartmouth College winter carnival.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Senator Benton said today after a visit to the White House that he would invite Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to speak in his state. He added that Mr. Truman had agreed that this was a "good idea."

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Diva Flanagan Bittson of Great Neck, L. I., asked court help today in obtaining an accounting of the estate of her late father, a fabulous Texan who wore emerald and ruby shirt buttons. She valued the estate at $2,000,000, but in a letter to Judge Clem McClelland she said the estate was appraised at $639,357.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Senate approved today, by vote of 73 to 2, an expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty to bring in Greece and Turkey and thus to extend the Western defensive alliance nearly to the Caspian Sea.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday that he would go to Albany next Wednesday to make a personal plea for legislative approval of the city's request for an additional $63,800,000 of state aid in 1952-53.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Senate wants Government workers to have plenty of time for lunch -- but on their own, not Government time.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- A campaign by Chicago hoodlums to increase their political power was described today as the most likely motive behind the shotgun murder last night of Charles Gross, 56 years old, acting Republican committeeman of the Thirty-first Ward on the Northwest side.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company last year turned in a record $404,202,528 in sales, 20 per cent above the previous high of $337,186,034 for 1950, but earnings fell 26 per cent under the impact of higher taxes.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- Detroit's first war-fraud trial since the beginning of the Korean conflict opened and closed in short order here today as Kenneth C. Heavlin of Wayne, Mich., pleaded guilty to a charge of having misrepresented as new $500 worth of surplus tank parts that he resold to the Government for $43,500.

The history of our times could provide no more fitting symbol than the voice of Winston Churchill calling for all the world to hear: "God save the Queen!" His valedictory to George VI, which we all heard over the radio yesterday, his expression of friendly sorrow for the widow and mother of the dead King, his wishes for the new Queen, were words spoken in behalf of many millions in many lands.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Many crosscurrents of speculative activity were evident in the grain markets today, but it was noted that buying of futures on the Board of Trade became active enough on setbacks to absorb the selling and to cause substantial rallies.

High up on the list of any man's most agreeable days is that one on which he decides not to shave. Most of his days are somber things, veering sharply in the direction of studied routine, but not that one when he declares against shaving.

New York University, returning to the basketball wars after a three-week lay-off, showed little signs of court rustiness, other than occasional off-beam marksmanship, against Syracuse last night. In command after the first few minutes, Howard Cann's Violet quintet raced to a 95-78 triumph over the Orange.

Charles H. Tuttle, president of the National Republican Club, and Lowell Wadmond head the list of organization candidates for Congressional district delegates and alternates from New York County to the Republican National Convention, it was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Curran, county chairman, after conferences with Assembly district leaders.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Measures to reconcile the native Malayan and Chinese peoples in Malaya and to enlist them in a partnership against communism and for self-government were proposed by the British Government today in it directive to the new High Commissioner of the Federation of Malaya, Gen. Sir Gerald Templer.

NO sooner does a fly fisherman reach the conclusion that there is nothing new under the sun in the form of equipment to improve his delicate art than someone comes forth with an item that could have been produced long before, but was not -- such as the "platyl" knotless tapered leader.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 7 -- General Eisenhower's public information officials at Shape denied today recent press reports that the general had told a group of visiting labor leaders on Monday that so long as he was in command at Shape, Spain would not be permitted entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Joseph Aiuppa of Chicago received a six-month jail sentence and was fined $1,000 in Federal Court today on charges of contempt of the United States Senate.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Taxpayer groups today accelerated their campaign to force a further 5 per cent reduction in the state personal income tax by cutting in half the amount now earmarked for reduction of World War II bonus bonds.

Past contributions of relief supplies to the people of Korea and to other countries suffering the ravages of war have made the United States "known and esteemed" and have brought blessings upon those who have contributed, Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday.

A 33-year-old defense plant worker admitted yesterday he had fatally stabbed two women in a ground-floor apartment at 1589 Metropolitan Avenue, Parkchester, the Bronx, early Monday morning and then placed a knife near each body to make it appear the women had engaged in a duel, District Attorney George B. DeLuca of the Bronx announced.

Of the $15,039,000 approved for civil works projects in the North Atlantic Division of the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers during the fiscal year beginning July 1, $2,374,000 has been allotted for the improvement of New York Harbor, it was announced yesterday. The North Atlantic Division includes the districts of New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, and Norfolk.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The State Department expressed "regret'' today that it had been forced to close down three information centers in Iran, but said the United States did not plan to take any retaliatory action.

About 200 employes at three extrusion plants of the Aluminum Company of America have been laid off because of "curtailment of the amount of aluminum permitted by the National Production Authority to be manufactured into extruded shapes during the first quarter of 1952," the company reported yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Out in the Persian Gulf it seems there are two or three fellows who are confronted with a pretty problem: They have so much money they don't know what to do with it.

The Ellenbogen Mill at 114 Straight Street in Paterson, N. J., has been sold by Straight Street Properties, Inc., to Leslie Properties, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by George H. Stickney Jr. as broker. The five-story building, containing 70,000 square feet of space, erected originally as a shirt factory, is now occupied by six tenants.

SANDRINGHAM, England, Feb. 7 -- Sandringham House was getting ready tonight for the arrival of Queen Elizabeth II tomorrow. Having fulfilled her state duties in the capital, she will drive to this quiet corner of England where her father was born and died, to join her sorrowing mother and sister in family mourning.
In what is slated to be the most crucial test of the value of one-way operation, Seventh and Eighth Avenues will be restricted to south and northbound flow respectively, starting March 3.
Ever see an old, battered sofa turn into a "new" man? You might if you could follow the old

Students and former students of Manhattanville College are active in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Madama Butterfly" on the night of Feb. 16 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Manhattanville Scholarship Fund.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Defense Department sources today cleared up some of the mystery surrounding an Air Force announcement yesterday that, in three sentences, had told of a new plane on order.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- Premier Edgar Faure tonight obtained a vote of confidence from the National Assembly by the narrow margin of 292 to 275.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen denounced three Midwestern States' "semi-isolationist Republican hierarchy" tonight and warned that only a "colorful campaign" and a "liberal Republican platform" could assure a G. O. P. victory in November.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Leading the nation's homage to its King, Prime Minister Churchill paid a moving tribute to King George VI in a nation-wide radio address tonight. During the last months, the Prime Minister said, the King had walked fearlessly with death as if death were a companion.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 7 (UP) -- The Insular Legislature today set March 3 as the date for a plebiscite on Puerto Rico's new "home rule" constitution, approved Monday by a constitutional convention.

We commend the State Board of Social Welfare on sufficiently resolving its internal differences as to oppose the enactment at this time of any law opening relief rolls to public inspection. The Board has been studying the question for three months, and announces that "even after this period of examination the Board members have divergent views on the matter."

Defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust suit on trial in Federal Court here charged yesterday that Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Otis Co., bond underwriters, conspired illegally to take business away from the seventeen defendants in the Government's suit.
Billy Cox, top third baseman in the major leagues last season, signed his contract for the Dodgers yesterday.

Two Went Side dock workers, accused of having beaten two men with a baseball bat and club in a Fourteenth Street bar and grill last Jan. 13, have been indicted on first and second degree assault charges, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The operator of the Yankee Inn here announced today that by mutual agreement a contract for a one-week appearance of the Weavers, radio and television singers, had been canceled.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Prices generally held steady when business was resumed on the Stock Exchange today. The only sections that could report any real activity covered shipping and foreign bonds, which continued with good gains.

OSLO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Brilliant sunshine warmed southern Norway today, just one week before the opening of the sixth Winter Olympic Games. Above freezing temperatures turned snow to slush in Oslo, but most of the Olympic sites in the hills north of the city survived the abnormal weather.

It isn't every day that Wall Street can serve up to investors a first major helping of stock of the leader in a fast-growing new industry. Consequently, what happened yesterday in the open market to the new shares of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Company did not take anybody's breath away.

Sirloin steak and two cuts each of lamb and pork are cheaper this week-end. While consumers have balked at high beef and lamb prices, supplies have continued to mount. The result is another 5-cent drop in the cost of sirloin steak, bringing it to $1.10 a pound.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman indicated today that he was far from enthusiastic about bringing Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty.

The New York Banking Board has announced that from now on banks in this state may pay as much as 2 1/2 per cent on their savings deposits. This is the first change in the ceiling for such payments since it was set at 2 per cent in 1935. It is up to the individual bank to decide whether it will adapt its policy in whole or in part to the new maximum.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Miss Claire Doran of Cleveland gained the semi-finals of the Palm Beach Women's Golf Championship today with a 5-and-4 victory over the medalist, Miss Grace De Moss of Corvallis, Ore.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7 -- Brazilian officials met with representatives of American business men here for the first time today to study the position of American capital in Brazil and its right to send profits abroad. Finance Minister Horacio Lafer expressed the conviction that a just settlement would be found that would protect the legitimate interests of Brazil and those of foreign investors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -The trade magazine Aviation Age urged today that the railllroads and airlines "rise above the low level to which they have fallen in their promotion and advertising.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., campaign manager for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, said yesterday he did not have "the slightest idea" whether the general would return to this country prior to the Republican National Convention, which is scheduled to convene in Chicago on July 7.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Feb. 7 -The Ground Observer Corps of the Eastern Air Defense Force will be alerted in the future without advance notice, Brig. Gen. George F. Smith declared that the volunteer force, announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 -- Public indignation over evidence that Communists had infiltrated the Hollywood film industry greatly harmed the industry, Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association, testified today before a jury in the court of Federal Judge Ben Harrison.

Soviet Russia has vetoed Italy's admission to the United Nations for the fifth time and thereby reaffirmed its determination to bar from membership nine free nations unless five Soviet puppets are admitted at the same time. This is a form of blackmail which the International Court of Justice has already outlawed as contrary to the Charter.

Mrs. J. Baird Magnus will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 930 Fifth Avenue for members of the executive committee in charge of plans for the fourth annual spring frolic and tea dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York to be held on the afternoon of April 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -Youths inducted into the proposed Universal Military Training program would be required to attend lectures on citizenship, the family and sex, Senators were told today.
The bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System indicated yesterday that it was willing to compromise with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to keep the company from liquidation.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday over the objections of City Council President Rudolph Halley the expenditure of $6,502,900 for construction of a bridge across the east channel of the East River to link Welfare Island with Long Island City Queens.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- During the week ended Feb. 6, member bank reserves increased $135,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

David L. Judson, Walter A. Taussig, Catherine T. Wortman, in Riverview South, being completed by the N. K. Winston-Holzer Co on E 82d St, between East End Ave and the East River -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, agents.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- True to her bias cut Mad Carpenter presents a collection that appears simple to the superficial observer, but in reality is born of export dressmaker technique. The play of structural seaming about sloping shoulders and gently swelling pushed-up sleeves is the only trimming except for a baroque pearl shell-shaped button at the throat, closing the high pointed collar on street frocks, blouses and coats.

New York Stock Exchange circles have protested to members of the Legislature against the "triple taxation" inherent in the New York City transfer tax proposed in Albany on Monday by Mayor Vincent Impellitteri, it was learned yesterday.

A new home and country became a reality instead of a dream yesterday for the Us family, one of the largest families of displaced persons to be resettled here since the first International Refugee Organization transport arrived Oct. 30, 1948.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The Temporary Committee of the North Atlantic Council finished today the preliminary draft of the resolution it will propose to the Council in Lisbon, Portugal, where it is expected to meet Feb. 20, instead of on the originally fixed date of Feb. 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A bill which would require bank holding companies to stick strictly to the banking field and divest themselves of non-banking interests was introduced today by Representative Brent Spence, Democrat of Kentucky.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Under renewed attack over corruption in Government, President Truman today defended himself and two members of his Cabinet -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder and Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- A plan under which American citizens who hold United States defense bonds would become the ultimate stockholders in privately operated peacetime industries grown out of atomic plants, power installations and other emergency facilities was outlined here today by Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that the city had reviewed thus far thirty-three relief cases challenged by the State Welfare Department, and that each one involved persons in dire need.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Backers of General Eisenhower announce today the formation of an executive committee to direct the campaign in Illinois under the sponsorship of the state-wide Eisenhower-for-President organization.

The hard-working Greenwich Village little-theatre group, the Loft Players, which has been displaying its theatrical wares for the last year in the Circle in the Square Theatre, offered its third bill of the season last night. It is called "Yerma," a poetic tragedy by Federico Garcia Lorca, the Spanish poet who was killed by Franco's adherents in 1936 in the civil war.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 8 -- The United Nations Command indicated today that an answer would be given tomorrow to a Communist proposal for an international conference on Far Eastern issues within three months after the start of an armistice in the Korean War.

Rejecting a defense motion for a two-month postponement, Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan yesterday set March 18 for the retrial of Frank Costello for contempt. The judge had been told that two members of a well-known Wall Street corporation law firm had been retained as co-counsel for the defense.

HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Paul Williams, Special Prosecutor, said today that attempts had been made to influence prospective members of a special grand jury being empaneled to investigate vice and alleged official corruption in Columbia County.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- The blacks, navy blues and grays that dominate the spring and summer fashion collections of London's leading dressmakers will strike the keynote of every official function in Britain in the months of mourning ahead.

THE Arabs and their desolate country have captured the imagination of many Westerners, and a small group of gifted Englishmen have written distinguished books about them. In fact, the memory of Charles Doughty, Sir Richard Burton, T. E. Lawrence and Gertrude Bell provides an almost unfairly high standard of comparison by which to judge a new book about Arabia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A House investigator told today how American youths had slipped behind the Iron Curtain last summer to attend the Communist "Youth Festival" in the Russian zone of Berlin.

The barbarous action of the Czechoslovak Government in seizing and holding incommunicado William N. Oatis was reviewed a few days ago by Dr. Channing Tobias of the American delegation before a committee of the General Assembly. Although no new resolution was asked of the U. N., it was worth recalling to the civilized world some of the fantastic details of the imprisonment and "trial" of the former Associated Press correspondent in Prague.

Business loans from banks in this area registered their second increase of the year during the week ended on Wednesday, advancing $11,000,000 to a total of $7,802,000,000. The rise compares with one of $127,000,000 in the corresponding week last year, when the largest weekly expansion of 1951 was reported.

A thirty-family apartment house at 867 East 179th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Geisinger Rau, operators, to Nathan Kaminsky for cash above mortgages of $36,000. The property is assessed at $50,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Two events of the week encourage the belief that the end is approaching of an era in American foreign policy in which the Soviets successfully exploited the weakness of United States military intelligence and the idealism implicit in our national system, to become a threat to the security of this country and the free world.

In the Feb. 1 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES you published a letter from Harry Long, who opposed the Metcalf-Hatch bill. This bill would give access to experimental animals where required in medical research.

After hearing four speakers criticize the city's fiscal and transit policies, the State Chamber of Commerce adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution urging the State Legislature to reject Mayor Impellitteri's requests for increased taxing power and financial aid.

LYNN, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Harry C. Clarke, 73 years old, and his wife, Alice B., 36, were held in $500 bail each in District Court today on fugitive from justice charges stemming from New York Indictments on charges of illegal adoption.

Four of this country's leading coat and suit designers -- Vincent Monte Sano, Ben Zuckerman, George Carmel and Robert Knox of Ben Gershel -- created the fashion news of Saks Fifth Avenue showing of spring coats and suits yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Ellis G. Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, was named by President Truman today to succeed Michael V. DiSalle as head of the Office of Price Stabilization.
A liquor store clerk and an off-duty detective captured two hold-up suspects late last night after firing a total of seven shots in a chase through Greenwich Village streets.
A field of 120 of the nation's top-ranking bridge players started play yesterday afternoon at the McAlpin Hotel for the 1952 Life and Senior Masters Pairs Championship.

PANAMA, Feb. 7 -- Panama's political slate was wiped clean today by President Alcibiades Arosemena's approval of a law passed early this morning by the National Assembly granting amnesty to former President Arnulfo Arias and his followers who have been held in jail since May 10, 1951.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Member banks of the Federal Reserve system made net profits of $760,000,000 in 1951, a decline of $21,000,000 or 3 per cent from the previous year.

Carnation growers from Maine to Colorado have gathered in New York for the fifty-eighth annual convention of the American Carnation Society. A rotating schedule brings them to this city for the first time since 1939, and in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday afternoon a flower show opened their three-day convention.

A Town Hall debut piano recltal was played last night by Margaret Bonds, who offered music by C. P. E. Bach and Liszt, Beethoven's Sonata in C, Op. 2, No. 3, Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue and the first New York performance of Johanna Bordewijk-Roepman's Sonata (1943),

State and municipal financing reported during January totaled $564,715,511, compared with $180,040,293 for the same month last year, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. Revenue bond financing in January's total was $258,055,000.

Two months ago Louis Waldman, counsel to the International Longshoremen's Association (A. F. L.), submitted to the Board of Inquiry investigating the recent wildcat longshore strike a series of proposals designed to wipe out evils among dockworkers' locals that interfere with "democratic self-government.''
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -John M. Allison, a veteran of twenty-two years in the Foreign Service, was sworn in today as Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs.

A check-up of admission receipts at 4 P. M. yesterday by the management of the Rivoli Theatre indicated that "Viva Zapata!" was surpassing by $155, with a gross of $3,571, the opening day business of last year's "David and Bethsheba," which drew a total of $10,300 in paid admissions and holds the opening week record at the Rivoli with a gross of $87,000.

Former President Herbert Hoover announced yesterday that he had received many messages from military and diplomatic leaders endorsing proposals on foreign policy he made in a speech a week ago Sunday.
Neither the Republican nor the Democratic party must lead the United States into military, economic or diplomatic isolation, Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, warned last night.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- North Korean Premier Kim II Sung called on the Communist armies yesterday to "prepare for decisive fighting with the enemy."

NEW CITY, N. Y., Feb. 7 -Most everybody who is anybody knows everybody in Rockland County. And any lawyer who is anybody expects to get invited to the shindig when the local Supreme Court Justice throws the party.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The condolences of President Nikolai M. Shvernik and Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky on the death of King George were conveyed to the British Embassy here today. Mr. Vishinsky addressed the following message to Sir Alvary Gascoigne, the British Ambassador:

The requirements of applicants for admission to the Officer Candidate Schools and the Aviation Cadet Program have been relaxed owing to a critical shortage of officers, the First Army announced yesterday. Men with dependents but who are otherwise qualified may now apply for admission to the school. Heretofore dependencies were an eliminating factor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- An "oil-for-education" program received strong support from spokesmen of educational, agricultural, labor and other groups at a Senate hearing today, but prospects of favorable action were doubtful.

Mayor Impellitteri yesterday ridiculed and branded as "the product of the twin brushes of whitewash and mud" a report issued Monday by Stanley Kreutzer, honorary commissioner of borough works of Manhattan. The report recommended a code of standards and ethics for city employes "beginning with the Mayor."

Robert Tripp Ross, Republican candidate for Representative in the Fifth Congressional District, yesterday urged voters in Queens County to show by their votes in the special election on Feb. 19 that they are "fed up with the disgraceful mismanagement of their national government by the Truman Administration."

" Is Anybody Listening," by William Holley Whyte and the editors of Fortune, described as "a layman's report on certain communication troubles of the business world," will be published March 28 by Simon Schuster. Each of the book's chapters takes a look at some of the things American business is doing and saying and the results thereof.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail, dissatisfied with dates allotted by the Maryland racing Commission, said today he would recommend that his syndicate drop its plans to buy Bowie Race Track.

Marking the end of a long era, Printed Service, the "readyprint" or "patent insides" to which many weekly newspapers owe their origin will be discontinued on March 29 by the Western Newspaper Union. At present, 1,412 publishers use the service.

Wholesale and retail dealers of perishable foods who are facing an increased gross business tax as proposed by Mayor Impellitteri demanded yesterday that the tax be spread to include banking institutions. They met at the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Office of International Trade of the United States Department of Commerce announced today that beginning Feb. 15, controlled materials products will be licensed for export to Japan and the Ryukyu Islands, including Okinawa, only if they are approved for import by occupation authorities, or in the case of Japan, by a local government agency.

Recent dissolution of the International Refugee Organization resulted yesterday in the adoption by the Women's American O. R. T. (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) of a guardianship program for its trade school students in nine countries.

Morris and Sidney Weiderlight have sold the one-story taxpayer occuying the entire blockfront on the north side of Union Turnpike, between 189th and 190th Streets, in Flushing, Queens, to the Jabor Holding Corporation, represented by Jacob Rubin, attorney.

The Sunbeam Corporation, manufacturer of household electrical appliances, plans to declare a 100 per cent stock dividend, subject to approval by stockholders at the annual meeting on Feb. 27, according to the proxy statement which is being sent to shareholders along with the annual report.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- A series of bills to change the reserve requirements for credit unions, to liberalize lending limits and to permit credit unions to participate in group insurance and pension plans were introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Thomas C. Campbell, Republican of Schenectady, at the request of the New York State Credit Union League.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Attorney General Francis E. Kelly of Massachusetts was exonerated tonight of implication of bribery in his office in a finding by Chief Justice Stanley E. Qua of the State Supreme Judicial Court.

Young women headed by Miss Anne Marie Tracy have arranged an entertainment known as the Gotham cocktail dance to be held this afternoon at Sherry's for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. Miss Tracy and her aides have been holding meetings recently in the Tea Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria to discuss the benefit.
Before sailing for England to attend the funeral of King George VI, the Duke of Windsor told reporters last night that the voyage was "all the sadder for me because I am undertaking it alone."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will send a special delegation to Iran Saturday to discuss plans for the resumption of oil production in the Middle Eastern nation, it was announced today.

This is one of those success stories that make the show business the fascinating business that it is. It concerns a young lady whose initial imprint on the public mind was chiefly that of a languid Hollywood siren who affected an absurd hair-do.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Holy Cross' basketball Crusaders defeated Columbia, 85 -- 80, in overtime tonight for their thirteenth victory of the season despite a 39-point scoring spree by the Lions' Jack Molinas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Truman indicated today that the reorganized Reconstruction Finance Corporation would run itself without a formal administrator or deputy until the Senate took a showdown vote on his nomination of Harry A. McDonald, a Michigan Republican, as its new head.

FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 8 -- One hundred men who were clerks, factory hands or schoolboys only sixteen weeks ago captured Ridge 102 at noon today after jet planes had seared the hill with napalm and after artillery had torn and pocked the crest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Brannan told the House Agricultural Committee today he would rather fall short of his goal of 16,000,000 bales of cotton this year than to raise the cotton support price.

TRENTON, Feb. 7 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, a New York milk-marketing subordinate and ten major distributors were named defendants today in a $36,000,000 anti-trust suit by a group of New Jersey milk producers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Fifty-six Senators joined today in proposing a Constitutional Amendment to prevent the use of treaties and Presidential agreements "to undermine the sovereignty of the United States."

Lack of an adequate supply of stray dogs and cats for experimental purposes has seriously delayed or caused to be abandoned research work on cancer, heart diseases, the effect of atomic radiation, gynecology and veterinary studies as well as a broad field of teaching in this area, the New York State Society for Medical Research reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- A move was under way today to assure full expression of this area's opinions before the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers, a unit of which will meet in Washington on Monday to consider recommendations for deepening the Delaware River channel.
Business men are increasing their use of arbitration to settle commercial disputes, A. C. Croft, president of the American Arbitration Association, reported yesterday.

Voting unanimously to remain in their posts, the eighteen directors of Youth House, a shelter for delinquent boys at 331 East Twelfth Street, withdrew yesterday the resignations they had sent to Mayor Impellitteri on Dec. 27.

HANOI, Indo-China, Feb. 7 -More than 250,000 persons have been relieved of the painful effects of trachoma under a United States economic aid missions health program for North Vietnam. Mobile teams and local dispensaries, provided with United States drugs and equipment, now are treating thirty to forty thousand trachoma sufferers a month in French and Vietnamese-controlled areas of North Vietnam.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Edward C. Boyle, United States Attorney here, and a Federal Commissioner refused to issue a warrant today for the arrest of Aldo Icardi, former Army Lieutenant, whom Italy wants to try in the wartime slaying of another American officer.

MUNSAN, Korea, Feb. 7 -- A long simmering conflict between public information officials at advance headquarters of the United Nations Command and Allied correspondents covering the armistice talks at Panmunjom flared into the open today when "certain" reporters were accused of abusing their privileges by fraternizing and "trafficking with the enemy."

Cornell University is about to seek increased financial support from business and industry. In his first address to the alumni, Deane W. Malott, who took office last September as the sixth president of the university, told 600 graduates at a dinner meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that the new fund-raising effort would be developed through a recently organized "corporation committee."
ALBANY, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Two displaced persons sought more than $25,000 damages in Supreme Court today on a claim that they had been deprived of their liberty while working on a farm.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations is attempting to organize a teachers' local in this city, it became known yesterday. At present, less than one-fourth of the city's 37,000 teachers are members of trade unions.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Companion bills providing state grants to help local communities set up special recreation centers in public schools for persons over 60 years old were submitted to the Legislature today with the backing of the Joint Legislative Committee on the Problems of the Aging.

LONDON, Feb. 7 (UP) -- Fifty-six gun salutes, one round for each year in the life of the late King George VI, boomed out today throughout Britain and the Commonwealth, from the Tower of London to ships at sea.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 -- Hundreds of letters seeking national opposition to the forthcoming Los Angeles hearings of the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives have been mailed here. They began to go out about a week ago with a statement calling the hearings "public pillory" and asking recipients to wire collect their approval.

NOUASSEUR AIR BASE, Morocco, Feb. 7 -- In the event of a third world war, it would now be possible for the heaviest United States bombers to pulverize Soviet industrial centers from newly established bases in Greenland, the United kingdom and French Morocco.

PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The United Nations second technical assistance conference ended here today still short of its goal of a $20,000,000 fund for its 1952 program. United Nations officials were optimistic, nevertheless, as ten more countries had indicated they would contribute.

The ukase from the Traffic Commissioner's office making it mandatory to use headlights on the city streets may prevent some accidents, but we hope it won't cause others. Many of these headlights, which haven't been used for years, are out of adjustment and will undoubtedly glare into oncoming drivers' eyes.

RABAT, French Morocco, Feb. 8 -- In case a third world war should ever break out, United States heavy bombers could "go all over Russia" from their new bases in Morocco, according to Maj. Gen. Archie J. Old Jr., commanding general of the United States Fifth Air Division.

HYDEN, Ky., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Authoritative sources here said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had assigned many of its Kentucky agents to an investigation of a reported "reign of terror" against the United Mine Workers union in this area.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Bills that would require the involuntary detention for treatment of all narcotic addicts regardless of age were introduced into the Legislature today by Senator Joseph Zaretzki and Assemblyman Hulan Jack, both Democrats of Manhattan.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- The Temporary Committee of the North Atlantic Council adjourned its second Paris session today without obtaining a full agreement to the increased defense expenditure urged upon the governments in December by its executive board -- W. Averell Harriman of the United States, Sir Edwin Plowden of Britain and Jean Monnet of France.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie, taking a backward look at the United Nations General Assembly session in over, said today that no great political issues had been solved, but he found that there was "less fear of war", now than when the meeting began three months ago.

Directors of Mansfield Tire and Rubber Company have called a special shareholders' meeting on March 11 to vote on a three-for-one split of the no-par value common stock, of which 225,000 shares are now authorized. They would authorize 750,000 shares of $5 par value common in its place.
The State Athletic Commission has started a drive to rid boxing of the return bout arrangement in connection with ring championships held under its jurisdiction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -- The Screen Actors Guild today won by a 2-to-1 majority vote in a National Labor Relations Board election its claim to jurisdiction over all performers working in films for television produced on the West Coast by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use about the home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Budget Bureau recommended today a cut of $343,000,000 in a Senate bill to authorize $808,000,000 annually for the Federal highway program in the fiscal years ending June 30, 1954, and June 30, 1955.

MANILA, Feb. 8 -- Reversing his position on export policy, the subject of a heated controversy between his administration and the local sugar industry, President Elpidio Quirino today banned all sugar exports to Japan. At the same time, President Quirino ordered the prosecution for libel of a Filipino business man who he said had slandered him by implying his office was "interested" in a $1,500,000 sugar deal.

" Collector's Item," which opened at the Booth last evening, has only one basic fault. It is monumentally dull. By working together feverishly and unsparingly, the author and actors have created an evening of boredom. This is not as easy as you might imagine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The overmantle brought to this country last fall by Princess Elizabeth, now England's Queen Elizabeth II, as a gift to the White House from her father, the late King George VI, will be placed on the north wall of the State Dining Room of the rebuilt mansion.

Today's performance of Verdi's "Otello," the first at the Metropolitan in three years, reminds us that in art as in other things the long way round is often the shortest way home. Verdi, as we know, based his opera on Shakespeare's play, but Shakespeare got his idea originally from an Italian collector of tales, one Giovambattista Giraldi, surnamed Cinthio.
Residential properties formed the bulk of realty passing to new control in transactions reported yesterday.

One of the top offerings of a heavy college basketball program tonight will find Army's quintet opposing a Columbia team strengthened by the return of Jack Molinas, its high-scoring center, on the Lions' court.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 8 -- The West German Government will take quick advantage of the clause in the contractual agreement with the Western Allies permitting Bonn to establish civil airlines.
Work on the new 20,000-ton luxury liner Flandre is being rushed to permit entry of the vessel into North Atlantic passenger service next June, a full month ahead of schedule.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Scientists at Johns Hopkins Hospital have removed the vital pituitary gland from a 72-year-old cancer patient and have kept him in good health for nearly three months.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 8 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower won an informal Republican Presidential preference primary here today by an overwhelming margin, 3,109 votes to 1,183 for his nearest rival, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio. Eight others divided 171 votes.

The North Jersey District Water Supply Commission has exercised its option and taken title to 358 acres in Passaic County. The property, on the westerly side of the Wanaque Reservoir, and a short distance above Midvale, was acquired from John H. Aemiseggar in a transaction negotiated by Feist Feist as brokers. It will be used to protect the reservoir from erosion and falling rock.

A ranch-type house with three bedrooms, on a plot of three-quarters of an acre on North Street and Haviland's Lane, White Plains, N. Y., has been sold by the George A. Bellair Company, builders, to George Milton. The home is one of twelve being erected on the former Heming estate by the Bellair firm in association with Frank R. Mascia.

An 8-year-old "mother" and a 9-year-old "doctor" discussed the problems of loneliness for an only child one day this week at the Washington Heights play school, at Public Schoo 169, 168th Street and Audubon Avenue, and considered the advisability of having more babies in the family.
A coffee house that serves European, Turkish and American versions of the beverage in a pleasant atmosphere of candlelight, good music and fine arts, has opened at 46 West Fifty-sixth Street.

An application by the New York Yankees for a new parking area to accommodate 530 automobiles north of the stadium was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at a special meeting at the Municipal Building. The application now goes to the Board of Estimate.
GENEVA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Union still guarded the secret of the fate of hundreds of thousands of war prisoners as a United Nations commission closed a three-week meeting here today.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Florida Citrus Mutual has found northern merchants like its quota system for limiting shipments, but will relax the quotas substantially next week.

Prof. Paul D. Kaufman, a member of the law school faculty of New York University, fell or jumped to his death at 4:45 P. M. yesterday from a bathroom window of his sixth-floor apartment at 45 Hawthorne Street, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Within a decade of the founding of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, the calling of the metalsmith had been established in Boston.

Brian Sullivan, who came from the Broadway musical theatre to the Metropolitan Opera four years ago, added another leading role to his repertoire here last night. Playing Pinkerton in "Madama Butterfly," he looked young and handsome and athletic, as a United States Navy lieutenant should.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The National Production Authority took under advisement today recommendations that it revoke its ban of last November on the production of color television sets. The Agency warned representatives of the industry who conferred with officials today that even if the ban is lifted "no additional materials will be allotted to anyone" specifically for the manufacture of color television products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland industrialist, was ordered today to give Senate elections investigators complete records of his contributions to the 1950 Ohio campaign to unseat Senator Robert A. Taft.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 8 -- As things now stand 40,000 Mexican contract workers in the United States will have to be shipped back to Mexico on Tuesday. The current United States-Mexicar agreement covering them expires Monday and thus far there is no sign that it will be renewed on extended.

Former City Magistrate J. Roland Sala of Brooklyn, who was exonerated last December after a hearing on charges of misconduct in office, has filed with Controller Lazarus Joseph a claim for $25,000 to cover counsel fees and other expenses incurred in his own defense.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the pledge given today by Queen Elizabeth II after the proclamation of her accession to the throne had been read:

Maj. Gen. E. F. Bullene, Chief Army Chemical Officer, warned a meeting of several hundred chemists last night that the present tendency to underestimate the potentialities of gas warfare might lead to national disaster.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade had an irregular course today, prices seesawing back and forth in a moderate range, with no special feature except that buying through commission houses broadened or the recessions, but flattened out on the rallies.

In this city of plenty 5,200 new children annually stand in need, waiting their chance to live in homes like other children. They are victims of family tragedies such as divorce, desertion, death or illness. They range from infants to girls and boys in the teens.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam sailed from New York on a Havana-Nassau cruise at 6 P. M. yesterday with a new master in command -- a master as well known for his literary accomplishments and historical research as he is for his seamanship and navigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson sought and apparently received today the general backing of Congressional foreign policy leaders for the positions to be taken by the United States in two forthcoming international conferences.

In a last fling at trophies before plunging into the title scrambles of the Nationals and Intercollegiates on the next two Saturdays, the track and field clan will reassemble at Madison Square Garden tonight for the eighty-third anniversary games of the New York Athletic Club.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,154, for Friday's operations:

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 8 -- The second anniversary of the only full-time established child guidance clinic in New York State was observed today with the dedication of the clinic's spacious new quarters here.

The Boy Scouts have trained American youth in character leadership and individual responsibility since 1910, when the movement was begun in this country. The 19,000,000th Scout was sworn in a few days ago. A three-year nation-wide program has been started to make the benefits of Scouting available to more boys and to train Scout leaders better.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- A Special Wage Stabilization Board panel recommended today an average 14.4 cent-an-hour wage increase for 11,500 workers at the Wright Aeronautical plant at Wood-Ridge, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -Air Transport Associates, a nonscheduled airline, asserted today that the Civil Aeronautics Board should recover $8,382,434 in mail subsidies paid Northwest Airlines, a scheduled line, over a four-year period.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 9 -- The United Nations Command gave qualified acceptance today to a Communist proposal for a top level political meeting among the Governments concerned within three months after the start of an armistice to discuss problems of a permanent settlement in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Alger Hiss urged the Supreme Court today not to press disbarment proceedings against him until his appeal for a new trial had been settled.

If there was any doubt that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower has strong popular support for the Republican nomination for President, it was dispelled by the "Serenade to Ike" at Madison Square Garden last night and early today.

The management of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn department store, has decided on liquidation. It made known last night that it had abandoned attempts to sell the store as a going concern and, instead, had offered its 1,400 employes a half-interest in the proceeds of the inventory.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The State Department of Commerce today reported the following snow conditions at New York ski centers:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Unemployment among workers covered by state unemployment insurance laws rose in January to 1,420,000, the Federal Bureau of Employment Security reported today.

An exhibit reflecting the results of a survey of public taste in decorating will be opened tomorrow in the new Queens County Catholic War Veterans Prize Home of 1952. The fifth of such model houses. It is at Grand Central Parkway and Parsons Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Women's Bureau today issued a leaflet on the subject "Why Do Women Work?" giving a preliminary summary of a study made by questioning 8,300 women workers in 100 trade union locals.
HONG KONG, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Three German nuns expelled from Communist China have reached here after twelve days of travel with loudspeakers blaring at them, "All missionaries must leave China."

An annual Bible Week to begin on Septuagesima Sunday, which this year is tomorrow and is the third Sunday before Ash Wednesday, is to be instituted for Roman Catholics for the first time in the United States.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 8 -- The Bonn Parliament set six conditions to the rearmament of West Germany tonight after an exhaustive two-day debate. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer now has the Bundestag's mandate to continue negotiations for a West German place in the European Defense Community with the very important addition that he must seek that place under the conditions laid down by these resolutions.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 4 -- This French protectorate, shaken by violent nationalist agitation in the last month, is still in mid-evolution from an Old Testament pastoral-agrarian society to the twentieth century.

Merchant steel exporters charged yesterday that controls redtape is unnecessarily restricting their trade despite development of a surplus in some prime carbon and secondary steel items. Merchant steel exporters are non-producers of the metal.
Improved winter equipment, though too little of it, is a feature of Exercise Snow Fall, the Army-Air Force winter maneuver, which enters its final phase at Camp Drum, N. Y., today.

After a two-hour conference with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and his chief rackets bureau aide, Alfred J. Scotti, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet said yesterday that departmental charges would "definitely" be brought against some firemen as a result of the extortion trial of James J. Moran.

The American Export liner Independence sailed virtually on schedule yesterday afternoon for a fifty-six-day cruise, with few of her 503 passengers aware that nearly 300 policemen, firemen. Coast Guards and crew members had conducted a painstaking search aboard her for four supposed bombs.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Miss Claire Doran of Cleveland and Miss Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore won their semi-final matches today to move into the final of the twenty-eighth annual women's golf championship of Palm Beach.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- Internal Revenue Bureau officials in Washington had been aware for more than fifteen years of "unsatisfactory conditions" in the San Francisco Collector's office without doing anything about it, according to testimony given a House subcommittee today.

Chlorophyll, that mysterious element of nature, which enables green plants to convert carbon dioxide and water into food by using the energy of sunlight, has replaced the anti-histamines as the "hottest" thing in advertising.

The Steve Allen television show, presented Mondays through Fridays from 12:45 to 1:30 P. M., will be discontinued by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Feb. 22. Mr. Allen will continue to be the master of ceremonies for "Songs for Sale" on Saturday evenings.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Assemblyman Orlo M. Brees, Republican candidate for State Senator, said he was a member of the Ku Klux Klan in Rhode Island for a brief time in 1927, but soon decided he wanted "no part of that organization."

TRENDS in shooting usually are reflected in the new weapons offered by the arms companies. Remington has just added two models to its long list, a slide action high-power rifle (the only one in this action available) and a 28-gauge autoloading shotgun.

An appeal to broaden the support for the United Negro College Fund, which aids in the maintenance of thirty-two institutions in the South, was made yesterday by industrial executives at a committee meeting in preparation for the fund's ninth annual campaign here in April.

The accession of Queen Elizabeth II again calls attention to the interesting and unusual place of the monarchy in the Commonwealth structure. That place is the product of a long and often thoughtful evolution. It is a free place, and it is a flexible one.
