ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Santa Anita race track again claims international attention tomorrow on several counts, including the 1952 bow of Hill Prince in one stakes feature and a lively battle between the Irish colt, Windy City II, and Kentucky's Hill Gail in a race for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Republicans are hopeful that their three-man battle in New Hampshire's Presidential preferential primary on March 11 will draw Republican voters in such numbers as to overshadow the Democratic votes the same day in the less-spirited contest between President Truman and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.
The prevailing impression left by the violin playing of John Creighton Murray, who gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall, was the emphasis he placed on tonal values.

Personnel practices must be placed on a "horse-sense level," H. Terry Oliver, personnel director at Mount Sinai Hospital, said yesterday at an institute on personnel practices held by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies at the Young Women's Christian Association's Central Branch at 610 Lexington Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation accused a former bank president of Point Marion, Pa., today of embezzling $152,177, charging he used most of it to buy utility company stocks in his own name. Depositors will not suffer any loss, the F. B. I. said.

Six persons on two trains of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were slightly injured yesterday when stones, believed to have been thrown by boys, smashed car windows. Stones and an air rifle also broke car windows on three trains of the New York Central System.

New York is to have three-color traffic signals -- red, yellow and green -- in all future installations. This system has been adopted as a national standard for a number of years, and is widely employed in other cities. We think the Department of Traffic is performing a service to bring New York into line with a practice which has helped to minimize accidents broadly over the nation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -Medals of Honor were presented at a Pentagon ceremony today to widows of three marines who won the nation's highest decoration while giving their lives on Korean battlefields.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- United Nations war planes pushed their round-the-clock attacks on enemy targets yesterday Allied foot soldiers enjoyed milder weather on a quiet front.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- Educators were urged today to make use of every possible medium of communication, including television, radio and films, to help build a "common denominator of ideas and information" on critical problems of the day.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 8 -- With votes about two-thirds counted in the India's first national elections it has become apparent that the governing Congress party headed by Prime Minister Jawaharal Nehru has virtually lost two important states to the right-wing opposition.
Steel industry spokesmen told a Wage Stabilization Board panel yesterday that it would be an abuse of Government power to compel of steel workers to join a union.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The tanker Esso Suez is going back to sea again next week. Scars from a disastrous sea collision almost a year ago that claimed thirty-nine lives have been erased at a shipyard here.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Vice Admiral Charles Turner Joy, chief allied truce negotiator, on the Communist proposal for a high-level conference after a Korean armistice:

What a sorry plight the city employes have been in during the past twenty years! In 1932 New York City's finances were at a low ebb as a result of the depression and the mismanagement of the city government by a Tammany Mayor. In 1933 the employes received a payless furlough. In 1934 a reform party was victorious at the polls, and Fiorello La Guardia was installed as Mayor.
OLEAN, N. Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- St. Bonaventure University today reached the end of the road it had hoped would lead to big-time intercollegiate football and suspended the sport, at least for 1952.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane's Brookmeade Stable will seek to remedy a slight oversight at Hialeah tomorrow. Brookmeade has won all of Hialeah's major stakes except the McLennan Handicap. In the seventeenth running of the $25,000 added race, the stable will be represented by Greek Ship, who figures to be the 8-to-5 favorite in a fifteen-horse line-up.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday 4 to 22 points net lower than on Thursday.

Retail trade this week ran 11 per cent below dollar volume of a year ago, it was estimated yesterday by trade observers. Statistical comparisons with year-ago sales continue to be deceptive, because of the extra-buying rush and higher prices, which sent volume soaring in the early part of 1951.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A new railroad communications car for President Truman's use was delivered today, ready for service. It is designed to keep the President, while on train trips, in close contact with the White House, the Defense Department and the world generally.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 8 (AP) -- This ancient seaport with a heritage of courage accepted as one of its own today Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, hero of the unsuccessful struggle to bring the sinking freighter Flying Enterprise to port.

Judge Harold R. Medina said at the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday that he was not concerned with the charge of defense counsel that Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Otis Co., proponents of competitive bidding for securities issues, had violated the Sherman anti-trust act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Feb. 5 to 175.8 per cent of the 1926 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 4.1 per cent below the level of a year ago but 12 per cent above the pre-Korean average (May 24 -June 25, 1950).
OSLO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The first accident on the Winter Olympic Games' bobsled run today slightly injured two Americans and brought demands that the course be rebuilt.

HONG KONG, Feb. 8 -- For weeks now Chinese Communists have been dismissing backsliding party functionaries and putting Red China's private business men through the process of intensified political reindoctrination on charges of corruption, fraud and general economic waste.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- A campaign to induce all families in Westchester to assemble emergency food supplies for use if an atomic attack were made on New York was begun today by the County Office of Civil Defense.

MADRID, Feb. 8 -- Until recently the foreign policy of Franco Spain consisted largely of measures and statements designed to resist or make the best of the diplomatic isolation that followed the 1945 Potsdam agreement denying Spain membership in the United Nations and the 1946 action of the General Assembly asking the member states to withdraw their Ambassadors from Madrid.

MERRICK, L. I., Feb. 8 -- Two little blonde sisters who disappeared from their home here yesterday morning after leaving cryptic notes for their parents and causing widespread anxiety throughout this community calmly returned today while scores of policemen and neighbors were searching for them. The children had been gone for twenty-six hours.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 8 -- The Denver University ski team, the first Western contingent to win honors here a year ago, assumed the lead in Dartmouth's forty second winter carnival tonight.
Larry MacPhail was en route to Florida last night, considering a request of his New York associates that they go through with a plan to purchase the Bowie, Md., race track.

The Federal Trade Commission's ruling that fur-bearing animals must be called by their real names was welcomed yesterday by representatives of the industry, although there were some who thought it might serve to slow volume.
Customs receipts at the Port of New York continued to decline during the last month, aggregating only $21,405,034, a drop of $6,750,000 below the total for January, 1951.

Alfred G. and Elma Milotte, the husband and wife team of photographers who supervised the filming of three movies in Walt Disney's True-Life Adventure series, "Seal Island," "Beaver Valley" and "Nature's Half-Acre," are on the way from Hollywood to Africa to photograph the latest in the wild-life documentary offerings, tentatively titled "Elephant Country."

Heating of homes entirely by electricity is growing by leaps and bounds, a Westinghouse Electric Corporation official declared yesterday. He said there was no limit to the potential market for this type of home heating wherever electricity was available.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Stockholders of City National Bank and Trust Company voted today to split the capital stock on a 4-for-1 basis and sell 40,000 additional shares.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 8 (UP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes said today the granting of Government defense contracts to New England textile mills that are underbid by southern mills would "destroy the incentive to lower production costs."
Two more Giants signed their contracts yesterday, raising the total to thirty, and three Yankees accepted terms.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 8 (UP) -Harold E. Stassen urged today that the State Department be stripped of all authority over the Voice of America program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Senate Investigations Committee says it has stopped the Department of Commerce from requiring business men to furnish seventy-five copies of applications for authority to make overseas shipments.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- All of the European continent's reigning monarchs, of whom there are only six left, will come here next week for the funeral of their friend and cousin, King George VI.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron told visiting United States business men today they would have the full cooperation of his Government if they want to set up branches in Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that twenty Federal grand juries were now sitting and fourteen others had been called into session across the country to survey racketeering and organized crime.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -Federal Judge James R. Kirkland sentenced a former deputy United States marshal, a policeman and twelve others for operating a multi-million dollar numbers racket today and accused the policeman of "selling his gun as a common torpedo."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it will ask the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco to lift its stay against proceedings involving the sale of Washington Water Power Company common stock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -Drafts of a message to be sent to Capitol Hill next week by President Truman with the Administration's proposals for renewing price and wage controls were circulated among the heads of defense agencies today to give executives an opportunity for last-minute suggestions.

Four detectives were commended by Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday for "outstanding police work" in solving the fatal stabbing of two Bronx women early Monday morning at 1580 Metropolitan Avenue, Parkchester, the Bronx.

CAIRO, Feb. 8 -- Premier Ali Maher Pasha said today that Egypt would adopt a policy of planned foreign trade to increase the supply of necessities for the people and cut the import of luxuries and semi-luxuries.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Feb. 8 (AP) -Two more packers and two more state food inspectors were accused today in the state horse meat scandal.
TOKYO, Feb. 8 -- Japan is in the midst of a shipbuilding boom, with foreign orders increasing. Oil tankers of the supersized class have been in greatest demand.

Clair F. Bee, Director of Athletics and basketball coach at Long Island University, has been appointed university controller by the school's board of trustees, William M. Hudson, acting president of the university, announced yesterday. His athletic post, which he held for twenty years, will be filled by William T. (Buck) Lai, who was assistant to Mr. Bee for four years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, estimated today that Selective Service would have to continue in effect concurrently with Universal Military Training during a transition period of three years.

The thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building accommodating forty-one families at 39 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Hearn Plaza Corporation to a customer of M. C. O'Brien, Inc., which was cooperating broker with Lester A. Hearn in the transaction.

The Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., complained yesterday to the State Commission Against Discrimination against St. Francis Hospital of Poughkeepsie for demanding that seven staff physicians quit the Dutchess County chapter of the organization or resign from the hospital's medical staff.

VIENNA, Feb. 8 -- Soviet authorities in Austria have been making an intensive drive to insure Austrian participation in and support for the international economic conference that the Kremlin has scheduled in Moscow in April.

The New York contract bridge pair of Ralph Hirschberg and Edgar Kaplan finished just ahead of a sixty-pair field at the McAlpin Hotel yesterday afternoon to capture the 1952 Life and Senior Master Pair Championship. Trailing by a scant 2 1/2 points in second place were Mrs. Edith Seligman of New York and Alvin Roth of Washington.

With a spectacular display of punching fury, Chico Vejar, young Stamford, Conn., welterweight, last night gained his eighth straight victory by knocking out Johnny De Fazio of Bayonne, N. J., in the ninth round of what was to have been the ten-round feature in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -Representative Adolph J. Sabath, chairman of the powerful House Rules Committee, put his support behind a sweeping Congressional investigation of American sports today to rid them of "grafting, gambling and crooks."

Italian velveteen manufacturers can take advantage of only a fraction of the United States demand for the product, according to Della M. Grattan, merchandising counselor to one of the largest Italian producers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Taxpayers actually have until midnight March 17 to file income tax returns.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Mrs. Kathleen Barnes, former wife of Joseph Barnes, a newspaper man, refused today to say whether she ever was a Communist on the ground of possible self-incrimination.
SANDRINGHAM, England, Feb. 8 -- Pale and worn after the ordeal she has been through since her father's death, Queen Elizabeth II arrived at Sandringham this afternoon to join her mourning family.
Edward C. Cerny Jr. has been appointed commodity manager for asphalt roofings for the building products division of Johns-Manville Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers crushed the last-place Baltimore Bullets, 103 -- 83, in a National Basketball Association game at the Arena before 6,500 fans tonight.

Dr. Konrad Adenauer Jr., son of the Chancellor of West Germany, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last night from Frankfort. Dr. Adenauer, a director of a public utility company in Cologne, is here at the invitation of the State Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 8 -- A mission to Italian Somaliland has reported to the United Nations that democratic institutions of self-government must be organized in the African territory if it is to be ready for independence in 1960.

Fred F. Finklehoffe, co-producer with Richard Krakeur of the current "Affairs of State," has joined forces with James S. Elliott for the presentation this season of Howell M. Forgy's play, "The Sun Looks Down," suggested by "American Me," Beatrice Griffith's prize-winning novel about Mexican-Americans.

A wave of increases in train fares for commuters was set in motion yesterday when the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington approved rises of 15 to 20 per cent in rates that will affect at least 80,000 persons traveling daily between this city and points in New Jersey.

J. David Stern, former owner and publisher of The Philadelphia Record and The New York Post, has a first novel on Julian Messners list titled "Eidolon," which will be published March 20. It is a science-fantasy dealing with a newspaper publisher, his star reporter and the haploid prodigy of a scientist.

Cocoa suffered a sharp break in New York futures trading yesterday, every delivery but the spot month dropping the daily trading limit of 100 points. March, which had sold as low as 33 cents a pound, had a nominal mark-up of 3 points at the close and thus ended the day with a net loss of 97 points.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- As a slain politician was buried with military honors, Mayor Martin H. Kennelly and Police Commissioner Timothy O'Connor ordered every hoodlum in this city arrested on sight today.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 8 -Gen. Mark W. Clark said tonight that a growing consciousness of the cost of manpower was leading the Army to make the most effective use of its manpower resources.

A new scenic landmark has been added to fabulous Miami. First word of the Florida playground's latest attraction is carried in the current issue of Sales Record, internal sales magazine of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Under a picture of a huge company transformer is the following caption: "What to See in Miami -- In addition to the Alligator farm and the Seminole Village, you'll want to see this 20,000/26,667kva OA/FA outdoor regulating transformer."

With a production of Shaw's "Pygmalion," the Equity Community Theatre began its third series of plays at the DeWitt Clinton Community Center in the Bronx last evening. Performances of "Blithe Spirit," "Lady in the Dark" and "The Pursuit of Happiness" will complete the series in February and March.

Shareholders of Marchant Calculating Machine Company will vote on a resolution to increase authorized capital stock to 1,000,000 shares from the present 300,000 on April 3, Edgar B. Jessup, president, has announced in releasing the preliminary report for 1951.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Elizabeth II took the oath of accession to the British throne today and was proclaimed head of the British Commonwealth of Nations throughout her island realm and in all her dominions and territories.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 -- Political speculation that Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr., son of the late Republican foreign policy leader, would seek the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Blair Moody in the November election was quickened here today as former Gov. Harry F. Kelly announced that he would not be a candidate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A Federal Trade Commission hearing examiner ruled today that the maker of Dolcin, a patent medicine, must stop advertising its product is a cure or effective treatment for any arthritic and rheumatic condition.

The average American Protestant has increased his yearly church contribution by $1.82 to $32.33, according to the Rev. Thomas K. Thompson, an official of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in America. In making his annual report to the council the cleric, who is executive director of its Joint Debarment of Stewardship and Benevolence, said that the increase "has just about kept pace with the declining value of the dollar."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 -- Even in the current slack farm season, several thousand wetbacks are entering the United States illegally, by sneaking across the California. Arizona, New Mexico and Texas borders every day.

The stock market stiffened yesterday and recovered a good part of the losses sustained earlier in the week. The rebound was not accompanied by an appreciable increase in business although the brand of leadership on the ascent proved of a higher type than recently has been in evidence.

If Ray Ashworth can be induced to stop accepting requests to reorganize police departments he intends to settle down to the comparatively sedentary task of bossing the third largest police force in the New York metropolitan area, the 927-man complement maintained by the Port of New York Authority.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- With all the pomp that has come down the centuries since the time of Good Queen Bess, Elizabeth II began her reign today.

Today's events: "Otello" at 2 o'clock and "Cosi fan tutte" at 8:15, Metropolitan Opera; Young People's Concert, Little Orchestral Society, Hunter College Auditorium, 11; National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, Mischa Elman, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Helen Schafmeister, piano, Town Hall, 3; Chamber music concert, Staten Island Museum, 3.

The Acme Steel Company reported a record sales volume last year with $81,855,797, an increase of 18.5 per cent over the $68,730,632 for 1950, according to the preliminary statement issued to stockholders yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 8 -- Her Highness Munawwar Jehan Begum, 54-year-old senior wife of the exiled Nawab, or ruler, of Junagadh, was indicted here today for the murder of a 13-year-old servant girl.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The National Science Foundation today announced approval of twenty-eight research grants averaging more than $14,500 -- a total of $410,000.

Granted that S. Stanley Kreutzer, "honorary commissioner of borough works" for Manhattan Borough President Wagner, roved pretty far afield from his original assignment in his final report on fitness for public office, Mayor Impellitteri is on poor ground in his ridicule of Mr. Kreutzer and the report.

A total of $1,576,203,219, or $235,112,683 above the city's current record budget of $1,341,090,536, has been requested by the city's 111 departments and agencies for their 1952-53 budgets, according to figures made public yesterday by Assistant Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.

WASHINGTON, Feb. (AP) -- Richard Lee Huntt is a solemn, brown-haired 11-year-old from Fairfax, Va. A few days ago he joined the Boy Scouts. All he expected was a fairly quiet round of hiking, camping and similar Boy Scout activities.

Many a Turk and many an American would like to express admiration and gratitude for Eleanor Burns, who died last week here in New York. Her heart was in Istanbul, at the American College for Girls, which she loved so well and which she served devotedly for forty-two years.

Severely battered about the head, the unclad blood-covered body of Leo Hartunian, 27-year- old Capital Air Lines pilot, was discovered about 10 o'clock last night amid overturned furniture in his three-and-a-half-room apartment on the third floor of a six- story apartment building at 67-66 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.
Fresh-looking print curtains, designed for kitchens or dinettes, part of a new collection by the Shapiro Son Curtain Corporation, are available at Hearn's.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas in sales reported yesterday by brokers and title companies.

Dr. Samuel P. Franklin, dean of the School of Education of the University of Pittsburgh and president of the Religious Education Association, announced yesterday that the Rev. Herman E. Wornom had been elected general secretary of the association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Michael V. DiSalle, head of the Office of Price Stabilization, today struck back at Whitney Tharin, secretary of the National Potato Council, who has charged Mr. DiSalle with responsibility for continuing in force "an administrative monstrosity" in the form of the agency's price ceiling on white potatoes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 8 (UP) -General of the Army Douglas MacArthur asked supporters today to take him out of the state's Republican Presidential primary, but they said they would seek to enter a "favorite son" who would throw any delegate strength to him.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., agreed yesterday to meet with officials of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Systems on Monday in an effort to work out a compromise that might save the system from liquidation or from being taken over by the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A report from Mexico City today that some 40,000 contract Mexicans might be sent home at once because Congress had not completed action on additional enforcement curbs against illegal entries, took Congress by surprise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Assistant Air Secretary G. L. Gil-patric testified today the Air Force had been ordered to cut its costs by $5,000,000,000 and had had to trim its production goal from 1,250 to 950 planes a month by the end of 1953.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 8 -- A gradual wiping out of the foremost military families of France, many of whom have borne arms under French colors for six or more generations, appears to be inevitable if the war in Indo-China continues to take the same toll as it has in the past six years.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The stock markets continued quiet today but prices held reasonably firm except in foreign bonds, which weakened under considerable profit-taking. The Stock Exchange will be closed next Friday for King George's funeral.

The tendency of ever-increasing synthetics and drugs in foods started during the Second World War, partly because of shortages and rising costs. Excessive stockpiling and developing of processed foods and rapid increase in the use of preservatives were the result of the tremendous problem of supplying the armed forces, lend-lease and civilians with food.
PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Mink coats today became an issue in French politics, too.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP) -- Macy's was invited today to tell Congress what it won't tell Gimbels -- why it wants to cut prices.
There are trees that grow in Manhattan, too, and the children who will attend the new Public School 6 will not have to look far to find proof.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Representative Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, who as a delegate to the United Nations Assembly in Paris late last year slugged it out orally with Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, over the Mutual Security Act and the imprisonment of four American fliers in Hungary, entered the races for election to the Senate today.

Governments have had a hard time making financial ends meet for 800 years, particularly at times when changing techniques of warfare involved increasing expenses for armaments, Prof. Wallace K. Ferguson of New York University said yesterday in a symposium on the Rennaissance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Reflecting rising operating revenues, the net income of the New York Telephone Company last year increased to $53,073,799 from $46,501,955 in 1950. Keith S. McHugh, president, reported yesterday. Operating revenues totaled $552,987,600, compared with $496,414,189.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, the Memphis, Tenn., dentist with the gifted golf swing, posted a five-under-par 66 today to take a three-stroke lead at the halfway point in the $10,000 El Paso open.
Four current exhibitions can be recommended to those who wish to keep abreast of art's many present-day phases.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation offered for public sale today $54,543,601 in stock and other securities of 151 banks across the nation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Stanton Griffis, retiring United States Ambassador to Spain, said today he was "assured" that President Truman, despite his stated dislike of the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, "recognizes the wisdom and necesssity" of carrying on negotiations for establishment of air and naval facilities in Spain.

ST. PAUL, Neb., Feb. 9 -- The widow of baseball's famed Grover Cleveland Alexander suggests baseball scholarships as a possible use for money in a fund set up originally to buy a marker for Old Pete's grave.

DASHER, a spotted fawn, lost his mother when he was only a few hours old. The farm people who adopted him gave him food, shelter and the freedom of Round Meadow. When he was able to fend for himself, these wise and kindly people sent him out into the wild woodland life for which he was born.

What could better illustrate the truths of Justice Douglas' article, "The Black Silence of Fear" (Jan. 13), than the letter of John F. X. Browne, published among other letters concerning the article on Jan. 27.

FOR hundreds of millions of the earth's people the primary problem is to obtain enough food to keep from starving. Most of the inhabitants of Asia, Africa and many other parts of the world are preoccupied day and night with the matter of getting a little more rice -- or wheat, or corn -- for empty stomachs.

Some out-of-town buyers returned to the wholesale markets here last week as summer lines started to open, resident buying offices reported. Sales improved and reorders were received in many divisions. Merchandise continued plentiful and values were good.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The police and detectives for the State's Attorney centered their attention today on the tangled financial affairs of Charles Gross, slain Republican politician, and on the political line-ups in his Thirty-first Ward in an effort to trace the killers who shot him to death Wednesday night.

This may or may not be an opportune time for Senator Capehart to press for a Senate vote on the bill to abolish the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Many of us would rather see the Senate continue with the statehood bills for Alaska and Hawaii, already long overdue.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 9 -Displaying equal strength in the field and on the track, Army romped to an easy 74-35 victory over Princeton in the feature of a five-sport program at the Military Academy today.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 9 -- George W. Della, president of the Maryland Senate, said today he would ask the Legislature Monday for a nonpartisan investigation of the State Racing Commission because of the fight over assignment of racing dates.

It was a little more than thirty years ago that the late A. P. Giannini came to New York from California in quest of investors to finance his then mushrooming holding company, Transamerica Corporation. This man who built a financial dynasty on the West Coast sought out some of his old friends, mostly successful merchants of Italian birth.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise in his sermon yesterday morning at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, predicted the triumph of democracy over any other type of human government, despite the selfish ambitions of government administrators.

With the outcome of the Korean peace negotiations still in doubt, the Quartermaster will continue to buy textiles, clothing and equipment at a rate comparable to last year's volume, it was pointed out last week.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The following winter sports conditions were reported today to the New York State Commerce Department:

" INFORMATION PLEASE," a long time radio favorite, has taken unto itself a television sponsor. It will make its debut on either June 22 or June 29 as the summer replacement for the Fred Waring Show over the C. B. S. video network on Sunday nights from 9 to 9:30 o'clock.

THE decision last week by the Supreme Court to review the "Miracle" case and thereby to render some decision on the validity of the banning of that film has much more significance to the future of motion pictures than most people realize.

The playgoer who complained in last week's Drama Mailbag that she had been misled by the critics to spending ten days in a "loonybin" with "The Shrike" should beware of other plays on Broadway. "Stalag 17" is about boys in their underwear, "Caesar and Cleopatra" shows you how to jump in the lake, and "The Fourposter" reveals that Jessica Tandy changes her clothes three times in about forty years.

ROME, Feb. 5 -- A proposal of the West Italy North Atlantic Conference, which includes most of the steamship lines plying regularly between Italy and the United States, to increase freight rates by 10 per cent, has brought about an effort to create a non-conference cargo service between Italian and United States Atlantic ports.

WITH the death of Louis Jouvet, Jean-Louis Barrault has become the leading actor-director-manager of the French stage. This means that for many Barrault is one of the leading figures of the world theatre.

SANDRINGHAM, England, Feb. 9 -- In the tiny sixteenth century church that nestles under the trees in grounds of Sandingham House, the body of King George VI lay in state today as nearly 1,000 tenants of the royal estate and nearby residents filed slowly past his flag-draped coffin.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- Sixty-four seconds was the difference between victory and defeat tonight as the New York Rangers pumped a trio of goals into the Bruin net in that space of time to win, 4 -- 2, before 8,397 fans at the Boston Garden.

DUBLIN, Feb. 9 -- United States Ambassador Frank P. Matthews said here today he was hopeful a satisfactory arrangement might be reached between the United States and Ireland to continue certain aid, despite the Dublin Government's decision not to agree to the terms of the Mutual Security Act while Ireland was partitioned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Representatives Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican of Pennsylvania, asserted today that the Government had failed to prosecute "a number" of tax fraud cases developed by the Philadelphia collector's office.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Windy City II, Hill Prince and Jockey Eddie Arcaro captured ends of a double stakes program at Santa Anita today.

" Point Five" on the Panmunjom agenda is a good spot for pitfalls and booby traps. Under the heading of general recommendations that the negotiators might make to their respective Governments there could be included a considerable and possibly unsavory variety.

Sharp declines in trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the last three months -- when turnover was only 92,900,806 shares against 171,065,755 a year earlier -- have revived talk of higher commission charges.

Legislation by Congress to curb "favoritism, extravagance, irresponsibility and corruption" and to raise taxes and close loopholes in the present tax laws was called for yesterday in the national program of the Liberal party.

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER an absence of ten years, Herbert Kline returned last December to the same area in Mexico where he had filmed the documentary, "The Forgotten Village," and made the happy discovery that people remembered him and were glad to see him again.

Financial markets developed a cautious tone last week as they awaited some stimulating development. Congressional action on new legislation and the steel wage dispute hearings continued at a slow pace. As a result, the stock market for the second successive week was under selling pressure and prices sagged to new lows for the year to date, recovering late.
Anthony Anastasia, boss stevedore of six piers in South Brooklyn, began a "crusade against communism on the waterfront" in his territory yesterday.

Prices of hides and skins, during recent weeks, have registered one of the sharpest declines on record, leaving quotations only slightly above the post-war low, the Tanners Council of America reported yesterday. Manufacturers and retailers of shoes and leather goods who take advantage of the present situation will be in a position to offer attractive promotions and merchandising displays, the council stated.
EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 9 -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis shot a two-under-par 69 today to hold his lead in the $10,000 El Paso open golf tourney with a fifty-four hole score of 200, fighting off

The State Athletic Commission's income from license fees, taxes on boxing and wrestling bouts and other sources for the calendar year 1951 increased $48,102.87 over that of 1950, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Chairman Robert K. Christenberry.

TWO summers ago, in Prades, the entire Casals Festival was recorded by Columbia and was released in time to hit the Christmas trade. Last summer, at Perpignan, Columbia engineers were again busy recording the festival.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Skilled jewelers have been summoned to the Tower of London tomorrow to clean the Imperial State Crown before it is placed on King George's coffin when it arrives from Sandringham. It will rest on the coffin until burial at Windsor on Friday.

Dr. Curt Sachs, consultant to the Music Division of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will discuss tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. "Die Walkuere," the second opera of Wagner' "Ring" cycle. The lecture, with musical illustration, will be the fifth in a series on Wagner under library sponsorship.

FOR almost half a century R. L. Schuyler has studied and taught England's constitutional development and imperial power. Born in New York (his father was on the editorial staff of THE TIMES), he remained faithful to the city through his long connection with Columbia University.
Five men, who, at the peril of their lives, rescued Robert P. Patterson from an enemy trap in the Argonne in World War I, were remembered in the will of the late Secretary of War.

Antonin Dvorak is one of the most underestimated of composers. He was one of the best symphonists after Beethoven. He composed the prettiest piano quintet in the literature, possibly the finest 'cello concerto, and there are no better specimens of their genre than the "Slavonic Dances."

The oldest routes of travel are not paths through the forests or channels down the rivers or the ancient courses from departure to landfall historically followed by ships. They are rather the flightways of birds. The scarlet tanager is known to pass across the Caribbean from the northwest coast of South America to the northeast coast of the United States.

A marked improvement in the attitude of American business toward economic education has occurred since the Advertising Council began its campaign along this line three years ago. While the council does not claim entire credit for the change of attitude, it does believe that its campaign was helpful.

A bill to continue Government control of the synthetic rubber industry for two years and to provide for new expansion of Government capacity to make butyl or special-purpose rubber is being prepared for introduction in Congress, industry sources said last week.

THE long and bitter debate about whether the Chinese Communist party consisted merely of "agrarian reformers" or was "really" a Communist party has now been settled by the march of events. The errors of governmental policy based on the former misconception cannot be undone.

THIS is a fighting book and the author intended it to be just that, risks accepted. Applying Mackinder's celebrated theory of the Heartland, the book presents an informative panorama of strategic world areas and the logistics of America's power position vis-a-vis Soviet Russia.

THE history of the Southern Pacific as told by Neill C. Wilson and Frank J. Taylor is an American railroad epic, a sort of Paul Bunyan story that really happened. This is not inappropriate, for the S. P. is a railroad giant.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Preventive medicine, when compared with the crushing economic burdens imposed on the world by illness, not only is better but also is cheaper, Prof. C.-E. A. Winslow contends in a monograph released today by the World Health Organization.

Mutual "moral concern for interracial justice" is expressed in a statement of the executive committee of the Commission on Religious Organizations of the National Conference of Christians and Jews made public for today, which is "Race Relations Sunday."

A FEW months back one of our popular illustrated weeklies published a series of articles on sex which took the form of serious discussions between highly qualified educators and psychologists. After the series started, the correspondence columns of the paper were filled with a running commentary from approving or disapproving readers.

Charles H. Tuttle, president of the National Republican Club, announced yesterday complete plans for the club's observance of the birthday of Abraham Lincoln next Tuesday, which will start with ceremonies at the Lincoln statue in Union Square Park at noon.

A REAL flower garden or border sometimes does not fit into the home owner's allotted space or time. Still, a few perennials and bulbs are a decided asset, and these may be incorporated in the shrub borders, if kinds that will thrive in such places are selected.

THE New York City Ballet opens its five-week season at the City Center on Tuesday evening. The first novelty will be seen on Thursday when Jerome Robbins' "Ballade" will have its world premiere. It is set to Debussy's "Six Epigraphes Antiques," orchestrated by Ernest Ansermet, and will have scenery and costumes by Boris Aronson.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- In an effort to clear up obvious public confusion over the Metcalf-Hatch Animal Research Bill, the Legislature has authorized the printing of 1,000 more copies of the controversial measure to be distributed to opponents of the bill throughout the state.

The investment world is paying its respects to a new American industrial prodigy which has risen from the "matured economy" of the 'Thirties just as spectacularly as the phoenix bird of fabled antiquity rose from its own ashes.

ON these Mondays when the New York City Ballet has its night off, no more rewarding book could be recommended to curl up with than Agnes de Mille's "Dance to the Piper." Besides being great fun, it is packed with substance, is warmly human for all its wicked wit, and contains more than a little solid wisdom.
Is the critical situation in iron and steel scrap scarcity finally taking a turn for the better? The scrap trade says yes, but its major consumer, the steel industry, doesn't agree.

Tomatoes are an important commercial crop throughout the Northeast. Therefore, state experiment stations place considerable emphasis on developing improved varieties, and home gardeners are able to reap the rewards. Progress made by four states and their aims for the future are reported here.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 9 -- The leaders of the South's dissident Democrats, hostile to the renomination of President Truman and distrustful of any would-be successor who has espoused the domestic policies of the Fair Deal, are in a political stew.
At Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee in 1897, a commemorative stamp was issued bearing the legend: "We hold a greater Empire than has been."

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 9 -- Cornell battled on almost even terms for the first half of its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game with Yale tonight, then scored 20 points in the third period to take command and win, 71 -- 61, for its fifth straight Ivy triumph.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A special House investigating committee reported today that the veteran educational and training program, while beneficial on the whole, was plagued with graft, waste and inefficiency costing the taxpayers "hundreds of millions" of dollars.

Forty-five minutes after they had slammed into the tape together in 4:10.4, Fred Wilt was called the winner over Don Gehrmann in the Baxter Mile. This was a reversal of the decision as first announced to a crowd of 13,000 at Madison Square Garden for last night's New York Athletic Club Games.

The International Refugee Organization went out of business yesterday with the arrival of 1,272 displaced persons here aboard the transport Gen. W. G. Haan. The resettling of thousands of refugees still awaiting emigration permits has been assured by the establishment by sixteen nations of a one-year provisional committee.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 -- The additional aluminum allocation accounts for half the automobile industry's deficit in the second quarter of this year, which has been estimated at 2,000,000 pounds. Labor and management sources here agreed that the extra aluminum would not alleviate unemployment appreciably in the industry unless it was accompanied by a comparable increase in copper.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- President Truman today named an eleven-man commission to recommend "an orderly, businesslike development of the resources" of the Missouri Basin.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 9 -- Dartmouth's quintet won its second close game of the year from Harvard tonight, 59 -- 57. Fred Gieg and Zack Boyages were the big men in the Dartmouth offense against the Eastern Intercollegiate League cellar team, each scoring 18 points.

Early dynastic Chinese ceramics, Ming and K'ang Hsi porcelains and a large selection of jade and other semi-precious mineral carvings will be auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday in a sale of Oriental art at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

RABAT, French Morocco, Feb. 9 -- Although the United States, through its agreement with France making possible the construction of strategic air bases in Morocco, has obtained a great military asset in this protectorate, it simultaneously has acquired a morass of diplomatic problems.

THIS introductory biography emphasizes St. Francis' boyhood and the happier episodes of his later life. Told almost entirely in dialogue, the narrative follows Francis from his carefree, mischievous young days in Assisi, through his years as a soldier and wanderer, to his spiritual awakening and dedication to the service of all living things.

Because nine out of ten of its students will marry and become homemakers, Lindenwood College, St. Charles, Mo., offers its students a liberal arts program designed to prepare them for a career in homemaking and citizenship. This does not mean a course of study with emphasis in home economics and civics, says Dr. F. L. McCluer, president of the 15-year-old college for women.

IOWA CITY, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Iowa controlled the ball for the last five minutes to hand Illinois its first Big Ten basketball defeat and gain a tie for the conference lead tonight. The score was 73 -- 68.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Fred Tritschler's one-hand stab with 37 seconds remaining gave Princeton's basketball team a surprise 79-77 victory over Penn tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Villanova upset Boston College, 72 -- 67, in the opener of the Palestra double-header.
After reading Alfred Steinberg's "Rewarding Ideas" Jan. 27) I have the impression that the slot machine in the cartoon accompanying the article must be "rigged" in favor of the Government.

AT this season for the past dozen years there has occurred a musicians' migration down to the Municipal Building and up to its twenty-fifth floor, where Station WNYC has its studios. The occasion is the American Music Festival, which goes on the air between Lincoln's and Washington's Birthdays.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The Midwest Stock Exchange increased its number of listings by twenty-seven issues last year and on Nov. 30 the total was 476. While the exchange reported a decline in volume of trading, commissions earned by members increased $394,611 during the year to a total of $5,729,964.

THERE'S a "no-casting" sign prominently displayed these days on the reception desk in George Abbott's office. The play producer and director, who has been around Broadway for nearly forty years, has dropped the production reins for a bit of acting himself -- television acting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Waste in the armed forces engaged the attention of two Congressional units today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A series of political popularity contests that will be helpful but not decisive in selection of Presidential nominees for the Democratic and Republican parties gets under way a month from Monday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Sector Robert A. Taft of Ohio has furnished written assurances that he will support the completion of the European army project.

JUNE ALLYSON'S face will never launch a thousand ships, but neither the actress nor the men who sell her films are particularly worried at the moment. Nor need they be. For the nation's motion-picture exhibitors, being more concerned with launching and keeping new customers, recently named the actress their most important feminine commodity of the past year.

This season's Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series of the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, opened yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with Mischa Elman as soloist. The eminent artist was heard in the first of three programs devoted to violin concertos that he will present with the organization in the series.

KASHMIR and Shalimar are magical words. Their sound stirs the wanderlust and makes ordinary folk envy Carveth Wells, his wife Zetta, and their friend Sam, who journeyed together the long road to Shalimar.
Thus was officially recorded last Wednesday morning the death of Britain's King.

J. LEWIS (POPPA) HALL is a high jumper Who looks like a football player. In fact he is a football player, awhizbang operative for the University of Florida. But his thoughts are far from the gridiron these days. He dreams of Helsinki and an Olympic championship.

RICHMOND, Va. -- Starting today, motorists who are planning spring vacations in the South will be able to obtain complete information about the estates and gardens which are to be open to the public during Virginia's annual Historic Garden Week, scheduled for April 26-May 3.
Seventy-two contract bridge life masters resumed play yesterday afternoon at the McAlpin Hotel in the 1952 Life Masters Individual Championship.

A recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES quotes Roger L. Putnam, Economic Stabilization Administrator, as stating that the steel industry should pay its workers a "considerable" wage increase without raising prices.

THE pruning of apple trees, which most people consider a specialized and rather technical procedure, is more a matter of common sense than is generally realized. The immediate objectives of pruning vary somewhat with the age of the tree. Once these are understood, the rest is largely a matter of good judgment, which the amateur is quite as likely to possess as the professional Apple trees are pruned now when temperatures are above 45 degrees.
Capt. Kurt Carlsen, his passengers and crew were not the only survivors when the Flying Enterprise went down off the coast of England last month.

LEXINGTON, Va., Feb. 9 (AP) -George Barclay, the T-formation wizard who in three years put Washington and Lee on the football map, resigned today as head coach at W. L. to become an assistant to Carl Snavely at the University of North Carolina.

IT is only from a distance that the Solid South seems solid. Sectionalism, economic differences, social and political conflicts have kept life below the Potomac varied and complex. The late David D. Wallace of Wofford College in his "South Carolina: A Short History," tells the story of his state with such insight and detail that the paradoxes of Southern life and thought become understandable.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States was watching with restrained but mounting anxiety this week the return of French-German competition for military security and the coveted, coal-rich Saar.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Hoot Mon, a new and strange-looking 40-foot yawl, won the nineteenth Sir Thomas Lipton Cup race on corrected time today from twenty-one blue-water sailing beauties.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Elizabeth II of England was proclaimed Queen this week with an additional title never before borne by a British monarch, a title with a notably non-regal utilitarian ring: "Head of the Commonwealth."

Regulations of the Office of Price Stabilization for the "average" or "typical" mark-ups in the food trade cannot be made to work. This is the conclusion reached from a survey just made by Safeway Stores, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb., 9 -- Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, gave assurance today that not all the chuckles would go out of the Office of Price Stabilization when he officially leaves Feb. 15.

A special class for cerebral palsied children will be opened soon in Public School 85 at 2400 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, under the joint operation of the Board of Education and the Department of Health.

JOHN SLOAN, the subject of this excellent short study, pioneered during the early twentieth century in painting American urban life. His canvases have charm and power, perhaps real greatness. Yet loan, so Lloyd Goodrich writes, "was never a financial success."

NEW DELHI, Feb. 9 -- The Communists have emerged as the second strongest party in India's first national elections, somewhat to the surprise of Prime Minister Nehru's political organization, the Indian National Congress. This appears to indicate a dangerous drift to the Left in the largest nation remaining among the free democracies and the principal bastion of the anti-totalitarian West in Asia. But the full significance is not yet clear.

THE first problem a children's book about radio and television has to overcome is how to get the set turned off so that the kids can see the book. Richard Floethe's illustrations should prove a big help in the present case, for they are engaging and imaginative, and make everything seem astonishingly simple -- as simple as turning those little knobs.

FOR the restless lad with more salt in his hair than can ever be brushed out, here is a sober introduction to the men and the ships that supply the world with oil. The author weighs the drudgery against the camaraderie in the tanker service, the dangers against the opportunities.

The United States Information Centers in Germany, the so-called America Houses, have had all too little publicity in the American press. After having surveyed these institutions the past two summers I am dismayed to find how few Americans know anything about the America Houses.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 9 -More than 1,400 men and tons of equipment parachuted to rugged snow-covered terrain near here today in the largest airborne operation of Exercise Snowfall, the combined Army-Air Force winter maneuvers that have just entered their final phase.

THE quality of television drama is running to extremes which warrant the attention not only of producers but of sponsors and advertising agencies as well. These extremes are linked directly to the running time of the play -- whether it is thirty or sixty minutes -- and suggest that something is sadly amiss.

FOR THIS WEEK: Store new packages of seed until sowing time in tin cans or glass jars, so that they will not be exposed to extremes of temperature or become damp. . . . Ordering boxes, tubs and new equipment or painting and repairing the old is in order for terrace and roof top gardens in the city. . . . Prune grape vines any day when temperature is 45 degrees or higher.

NEWARK, Feb. 9 -- Senator Edward Martin, Pennsylvania Republican, predicted tonight in a Lincoln Day dinner address to 500 Essex County Republicans that Congress would reject President Truman's request for a $5,000,000,000 tax increase.
The wings of air power were casting their shadow once again over the global situation and the Washington budget last week.

MAN'S infinite ingenuity is never more impressive than when it is being used to devise newer and more complex instruments for the torture of man. Progress in the development and proliferation of these instruments is constant and rapid.

A WHOLE coconut, sent by mail from vacationing friends in Florida, presents a dilemma. Should the slogan found on some of the nuts, "Plant me and grow a new house plant," be heeded or should the husk be chopped loose, the shell cracked with a hammer and the meat of the nut take out for coconut cake?

Mayor Impellitteri says that the city will need in the fiscal year beginning July 1 about $200,000,000 more than the $1,336,400,575 appropriated in the 1951-52 budget. He insists that failure to obtain this additional revenue will mean that there can be no balanced budget for 1952-53 without curtailment of essential city services and the denial of sorely needed pay rises to city employes.

ERIC JOHNSTON has been moving quietly in many directions since resuming the office of president of the Motion Picture Association of America after a year's absence to serve as Economic Stabilization Director in Washington.

The greatest cosmic event ever witnessed by man, at least within the span of history, is the sight of an exploding giant star. New calculations indicate that a supernova may burst with the energy of ten billion billion billion atom bombs and flare for two years or so with the brilliance of one hundred million suns.

KATHY GARDNER (who tells the story) disarms us at once with her civilized, articulate account of English country life between the wars. There is no hint of melodrama in her marriage, which has settled down to a compromise between the relative imperfections of a romantic, imaginative woman and the perfect Absolute of a traditional English gentleman.

ISTANBUL -- During the past year the Turkish State Press, Broadcasting and Tourist Department has made considerable progress toward opening up a realm rich in historic and cultural interest to modern tourism. At the same time it is conceded that a good distance has yet to be traversed before many places outside this city, Ankara, the capital, and Izmir, on the coast of the Aegean Sea can offer other than rudimentary accommodations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States and Mexico have agreed on a three-month extension of an agreement, due to expire Monday, that regulates the migration of farm workers into this country.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 9 -- A Milwaukee business man who has half a million dollars coming from the city but has not sent a bill since 1946 was in seclusion today.

Two hundred and thirty-six students will receive degrees on Wednesday evening at the winter commencement exercises of Queens College. Dr. John J. Theobald, president of the college, will confer degrees on 191 bachelors of arts, twenty-seven bachelors of science and eighteen masters of arts.

The new look worn by the libraries of Brooklyn has dispelled early fears that television might make serious inroads into the borough reading habits. Library officials credit the Brooklyn Public Library's 29 per cent increase in book circulation in the last two years to the improved appearance and streamlined service of its branches.

The United States Bureau of Mines has a long history of experience with explosive gaseous mixtures. Most mine disasters have been traced to an accumulation of methane underground and an igniting electrical spark. Last week the bureau reported on a four-year study of hospital operating rooms.

THE failure of many states to initiate landowner-sportsman programs, despite the great increase in the ranks of anglers and hunters during the past few years, has led a number of small groups to create their own hunting and fishing "preserve," and some of these projects have been remarkably successful.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Miss Claire Doran of Cleveland beat Miss Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, 2 and 1, today to win the twenty-eighth annual women's golf tournament of Palm Beach.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Mutual Security Administration and the Army are split sharply on policy governing the awarding of contracts abroad for goods manufactured under the foreign aid program.

A new car series, designated Fire Dome Eight and powered by a 160-horsepower, V-8 engine, was presented yesterday by the DeSoto division of the Chrysler Corporation. The models will be displayed Wednesday at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue, and dealer showrooms throughout the New York metropolitan area.

MEXICO CITY -- Most Americans who come down this way return home laden with gifts and personal purchases strictly in the souvenir class. While buying straw dolls, cartwheel hats and colorful scarves, few realize that they also can do advantageous shopping for their non-masquerade wardrobes in this country, which goes in for its own version of high fashion in a big way.

THERE is a wealth of keyboard recordings available for discussion this morning, and the proper place to begin is with The Well-Tempered Clavier. Wanda Landowska, the high priestess of the harpsichord, has been recording both books of Johann Sebastian Bach's enduring work, and Preludes and Fugues Nos. 1 to 8 from Book II has just been released by Victor on a twelve-inch disk.

BUFFALO, Feb. 9 -- With star Center Bob Zawoluk sitting out most of the second half because of four personal fouls, St. John's of Brooklyn came from behind tonight to defeat Niagara, 59-55, for its sixteenth victory in eighteen games. Niagara, throwing a tight defense around Zawoluk, led the favored Redmen, 25-22, after a nip-and-tuck first half in which the lead changed hands eight times.

Ninety-three thousand Americans were killed accidentally last year, according to the National Safety Council. This is like "accidentally" obliterating a city larger than Stamford, Conn., say, or Raleigh, N. C., or Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Nine million others were injured in accidents, which is equivalent to "accidentally" maiming the entire population of a city larger than New York.

An exhibition of "Early American Jewish Portraiture" will open today at the Jewish Museum of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in conjunction with the fiftieth annual meeting of the American Jewish Historical Society.

City College's basketball team scored its highest point total of the season in romping to an 87-49 victory over Dickinson College of Carlisle, Pa., last night. The triumph was City's sixth against seven defeats, and Dickinson's eleventh loss without a victory.

A wealth of low-priced merchandise is to be dumped in the laps of housewives in Brooklyn and its vicinity when the sixty-four-year-old department store, Frederick Loeser Co. in downtown Brooklyn, sells out its $4,500,000 inventory.

The body of Nathan Nelson, a 37-year-old dress manufacturer and trucking concern operator, shot dead in his expensively furnished bachelor apartment at 360 West Fifty-fifth Street, was discovered late yesterday afternoon by his brother and a business associate.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,155, for Saturday's operations:

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- United States Marine "Wolf Raider" pilots smashed a big Communist supply center in Northeast Korea yesterday. Ten supply dumps and twenty-seven buildings were left in smoking ruins.

The Ramapo Polo Club, sparked by Al Parsells, routed Long Island, 11 -- 6, last night in the final of the Metropolitan League tournament that opened an indoor polo doubleheader at the Squadron A Armory.

" OLD Dodge City on the Arkansaw," as the song runs, was perhaps the most celebrated of all American railhead towns. The railroad reached it in 1872, and soon pushed on west to the Kansas-Colorado line, but Dodge City remained in effect a railhead town for years because the towns west of it were small and unimportant.

Ethical values in contemporary life will be examined by the faculty and student body at Sarah Lawrence College at a conference on Wednesday and Thursday. All classes will be canceled while students and teachers meet in groups to discuss various aspects of the subject.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 9 -- Duke defeated Navy by the score of 70 to 68 in an overtime basketball game today. The thrilling contest was witnessed by a crowd of 3,600 fans. The home forces led at half time by the comfortable margin of 37 to 29, but Duke cut this advantage and went into the lead which it held until just before the end of the regulation time.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Fordham Rams faltered in the second half tonight and a stubborn Siena College basketball team rallied to win, 54 -- 48.
In these words in Ottawa last month Winston Churchill, the King's First Minister, defined the meaning of the British Crown.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- Communist "cultural advisers" in the Soviet zone of Germany are nearing the completion of a purge in libraries, shops and schools of at least 5,000,000 volumes, according to evidence brought to West Berlin recently by hundreds of East German teachers, doctors, lawyers and others.
DETROIT, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Automobiles cannot be made without copper but they can be made with considerably less of the red metal than was used before the Korean outbreak.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Spanish Embassy has delivered a memorandum to the State Department on President Truman's recent remark that he is not very fond of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime in Spain.

With losses from passenger train operations having averaged around $500,000,000 a year since 1948, the railroads are expected to make a renewed effort in the next few months to eliminate part of such losses.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 -- With the price of "regular" gasoline declining today to a new low of 13.9 cents a gallon at least two service stations here, members of the New Jersey Gasoline Retailers Association, made plats for a 1,000-car motorcade to Trenton, on Monday to protest lack of action by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and the State Legislature.

LONDON. THE mass arrests, summary executions and deportations in satellite Europe have by now become familiar to the American public. But comparatively little is known of the Communist policy of oppression in the realm of culture and the arts.
The cotton futures market turned active but weak yesterday, losing 21 to 75 points, with old old crop months showing the least strength.

For the next five to seven years, industry's requirements for engineers and technically trained personnel will exceed by far the number of graduates produced by engineering schools in this country, according to a report on a recent conference of educators and engineering executives at New York University's College of Engineering.

EXACTLY 11,255 titles is the final tally in the Publishers' Weekly summary for 1951 -- 233 more books than were published in 1950. Trends: mysteries and straight novels climbed, science fiction rocketed; down were fine arts, general literature, poetry, sports books.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 -- A fortnight's debate in the Diet [Parliament] and the continuing negotiations between the Japanese Government and the United States mission, headed by Dean Rusk, special Presidential envoy, has now given this nation a fairly clear picture of what it will have to expect under the security agreement following ratification of the San Francisco peace treaty.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 9 -Robert Grant 3d of New York and Stanley Pearson of Philadelphia gained the final round of the Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament today. Grant has two legs on the trophy and will retire it if he defeats Pearson tomorrow.

New York's so-called Little Hoover Commission -- nine legislators and officials -- recommended yesterday that the three-member State Civil Service Commission be abolished in favor of a single administrator, aided by a part-time board with advisory and some disciplinary power.

Quantities of aluminum allocated for roofing and siding are improperly proportioned with other aluminum products, and farm production may be "seriously injured" as a consequence, it was charged yesterday by five producers.

ALPENA, Mich., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Canadian champion, Miss Doreen McLeod, beat the United States speed queen, Barbara Marchetti of Detroit twice today in the first major upsets of the North American outdoor speed skating championships.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins in a fashion showing of costumes designed by American couturieres, which will be a feature of the Mardi Gras Ball for the benefit of the Welfare Fund of the New York Junior League.

OVER 250,000,000 carnations were grown in America in 1951. The reason that they have such a wide market was readily evident at the exhibit staged by the American Carnation Society in New York City last week.

SMOOTH, not to say unctuous, talking has always been a B. B. C. specialty. Now, a new personality who uses vinegar instead of oil has soared into precarious popularity. He is a testy, moody bachelor named Gilbert Charles Harding.

THIS Wednesday the Theatre Guild presents Christopher Fry's "Venus Observed" at the Century, a premiere that prompts the departmental "brain" to reflect on the sad fate which has befallen the products of foreign playwrights this campaign.
Commercial banks, pressed for better earnings as costs and taxes mount, are taking a closer look at their trust department "profit" ledgers.

RESORTS and transportation companies continue to announce plans for the long Washington's Birthday week-end. Elaborate entertainment programs are being scheduled by many hotels in New York State and Jersey; special week-end rates are being offered, and shore spots are anticipating big crowds, with winter fishermen taking advantage of the year-round sports facilities at places like Atlantic City, Asbury Park, Ocean City, Wildwood, Cape May, Long Branch, Point Pleasant, Margate City, Bradley Beach and Belmar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Should the United States consider at least part of the so-could Yalta Agreement of 1945 to be null and void? The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said this week that it should, but the State Department takes a somewhat different view.
HANOI, Indo-China, Feb. 9 -- The Vietminh regime is tightening the barriers against a growing exodus of upper-class groups from Vietminh areas to the French and Vietnam-controlled part of Tongking.

SOMEWHAT groggy from investigations, resignations and reorganization plans, the Bureau of Internal Revenue is striving doggedly to keep on top of its annual blizzard of income tax returns. From now until March 15, tax mail will swirl into bureau offices all over the country.

New coals were heaped yesterday on the smoldering fires of dissension that have been burning for some time in the art world because of the disagreement between the modernist and classical points of view.

RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 9 -- Frank E. McKinney, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserted tonight that the "boldness and grandeur" of President Truman's leadership had strengthened this country and its free-world allies to the point that they could now hope to prevent a third world war or else be assured of winning one if it came.

NO complaint is heard more frequently in a democracy than the cry that leaders are needed -- and cannot be found. Yet when the supreme crisis arrives the leader often arrives too, not on horseback, not in an armored motor car, but out of the masses of the people.

A NOVEL about a group of Protestant missionaries in Japan from the turn of the century until after World War II, "The Bridge of Heaven," is more successful in its incidental achievements than in the development of its main theme.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, protested to the Army today for having discriminated against New York State in recruiting construction workers for military bases in Arab countries.

Chemistry is spilling out of the laboratories and pouring over the nation's crossroads. The chemical process industries are growing so fast that the effect not only sparks Wall Street but reaches way out to Main Street. The college student far-sighted enough to have concentrated in this field often has a job awaiting him before he is handed his sheepskin.

I MADE a slip in referring to Alexander Slidell Mackenzie when I meant Ranald Slidell Mackenzie, and another in saying Ranald was not mentioned in the book. But as he was mentioned only once, and then only as commanding subordinate under Gen. George Crook, I hardly think the latter slip was an injustice.

A NEW style in home furnishings was quite firmly established at the recent wholesale markets in the Middle West. It is a style that looks traditional and should appeal to those who prefer period pieces, but it cannot be labeled as such in the truest sense of the word, for this furniture adapts motifs from the old styles rather than reproducing them.

The carpet industry, alive and chipper after last year's near-knockout blows, will woo coy prospective customers in an intensive promotion drive from April 21 to 30. Last week mill officials indicated that the "courtship" will be expensive as well as intensive.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 9 -- Bergen and Passaic Counties will be visited Tuesday and Wednesday when the seven-member Congressional committee investigating complaints that builders have been permitted to sell defective housing under Government-insured mortgages begins its nationwide tour of inspection.

A GREAT many people will tell you at the drop of an airplane what safety on the airlines is and what it is not. Some of them know a great deal about it, but few know as much as the commercial airline pilot, who does not often discuss safety in public.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Industrial Union of Marine Shipbuilding Workers of America authorized a strike vote among the 32,000 members of the Bethlehem Steel Company's eight Eastern shipyards.

Brilliant shooting by 6-foot 6-inch Jack Molinas in his first home appearance of the season after having turned in two sparkling exhibitions on the road, enabled the Columbia University quintet to defeat Army, 65 -- 61, in the Lions' Morningside Heights gymnasium last night.
OTTAWA, Feb. 9 -- Canada this week reaffirmed her position as the only American monarchy by the proclamation of Queen Elizabeth II as "supreme liege lady in and over Canada."

Admiral McCormick's title of Supreme Allied Commander of the Atlantic and his jurisdiction from the North Pole to the Tropic of Cancer are the most impressive in modern naval annals, but they fall short of the original title and jurisdiction conferred in the Atlantic.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9 -- Communist leaders in Peiping have fixed Feb. 15 as the final deadline for the "corrupt elements" in Red China's central Government to come forward and confess their transgressions voluntarily under an expiring policy of "leniency."

ROBERT PARRISH, a young man with a blond crew cut and the look of having just stepped off an urban college campus, is startling Hollywood with a new type of professional ambidexterity. Having spent twenty-five of his thirty-five years in pictures, he has during the past year substituted one working meaning of the word "cut!" for another, totally different one.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (Reuters) -- Alec Forbes, crack right-half, today struck a double blow for Arsenal, slamming home the winning goal against its bitter London rival, Tottenham, and sending his team to second place in the first division of English soccer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Wayne Coy said today that a growing backlog of work before the Federal Communications Commission, which he heads, was seriously affecting the economy of the communications industries and the nation as a whole.

A GROUP of fourteen prints by a new photographer, James G. Lambrakis, a Greenwich Village business man, will probably become the most popular of a seven-man exhibition of prize winners that opened last week and will run through Feb. 28.

PERMIT me to rectify an error in Aline Louchheim's review of "Michelangelo Drawings" Mrs. Louchheim says that the famous Windsor drawing representing '"Three Labors of Hercules" was thought by me to be a forgery whereas Army Popp had declared it a copy.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 5 -- There are about 20,000 Jews in Berlin and West Germany. Once there were 600,000 Jews in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Since September, 1950, the McCarran Internal Security Act, one of the most controversial and least known in the history of the United States, has been the law of this country.

COLLECTORS who made remittances, some dating back several months, to the United Nations Postal Administration here for stamps which the world organization began issuing last October are advised by Bertil A. Renborg, the administration's chief, that all orders are being filled as rapidly as this can be accomplished and that the backlog jam will soon be eased.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Despite the expressions of optimism from those in official positions, most delegates at the 1951 session of the United Nations General Assembly had decided by the time it adjourned that it was one of the least constructive in the history of the world organization.

ONE of the greatest forces in the spiritual and intellectual awakening of the South was the teaching of Henry Horace Williams, Professor of Philosophy at the University of North Carolina during the first third of the present century.

NEW DELHI, India. WHERE else but in India, in the atomic age, would polished statesmen pay serious attention to a 90-pound ascetic clad only in loin cloth and sandals, who walks from village to village preaching simply that those who have much should give of their fortunes to those who have none?

THERE recently appeared in this column the "favorite hands" of two of the famous players, Richard Frey and Howard Schenken, along with the observation that the expert's favorite hand is usually an exercise in card-reading or deception, and not merely an exercise in technique.

OSLO, Feb. 9 -- With only five more days to go before the winter Olympic Games open, Norway's "battle of the snow" took a turn for the worse today as worried officials and perspiring workmen labored frantically to get the sites into shape for the start of competition on Thursday.

THE office used by Fleur Cowles in her capacity as an editor of the magazines Look and Quick wasn't at all fancy or overwhelming. Somehow, one expected it to be. It just wasn't. It was medium-size, compact and pretty shipshape, with a small list to starboard, about which more later.

HAVANA, Feb. 9 -- A Cuban chapter of the World Brotherhood Organization designed to develop better understanding among the peoples of the world was established today at a luncheon attended by outstanding leaders of the movement and representative Cuban figures.

NEARLY all of the short stories in this book are concerned either with life in other worlds, or with invasion of Earth from other worlds. The few exceptions include a story of suspended animation, a chair which throws its occupant back into the bodies of others who have used it and a sort of fertilizer which enormously increases the growth of plants.
SODA fountains in a leading drug store chain recently have been found featuring an ice-cream sundae topped with sauce made simply by melting a popular commercial candy bar.
CAMP DRUM, in New York State's "North Country," is the site this week of the climactic phase of Exercise Snowfall -- the largest winter maneuvers the Army and Air Force have held since World War II.

The Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads announced yesterday additional commuter rates that will soon be made effective under the recent ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission increasing fares 15 to 20 per cent.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 9 (AP) -The William and Mary Board of Visitors today signed J. M. (Suey) Eason, successful high school coach, to a ten-year contract as head football coach and athletic director.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 9 -- For this New Hampshire town, the forty-second Dartmouth carnival ended in exactly the right manner. The Hanoverians triumphed against nine challenging college teams for the eighteenth time and a curtain of snow fell just in time for the final phases today.

IT was in the eighteenth century that the modern concerto developed, and collections of cencertos by two pioneers in the form are available on recent recordings.
