In behalf of the special purchase fund for the Whitney Museum of American Art, a loan exhibition of twentieth century American paintings will be held at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, from Feb. 21 through March 22. A preview will be held on the night of Feb. 20.

WRITERS on W. B. Yeats have become hag-ridden with notions of influences: too much sleuthing can take away from the wholeness, the integrity of any poem. A mind of Yeats' developing power was forever taking on fresh influences and getting fresh stimuli from books or pictures, people or events, so that it would be impossible to discover all of them.

BUSINESS and industry face at least another year of economic controls when the Defense Production Act expires on June 30. President Truman, in his State of the Union message, had asked for a two-year extension as well as tighter controls generally.

The spectacular attempt to eradicate particular diseases indigenous to underdeveloped areas of the world through treatment with "one-shot" penicillin has now spread to five countries and directly touched 1,000,000 of their natives.
Army's swimming team captured seven of ten firsts to overcome Columbia, 49 -- 35, in an Eastern League meet in the University pool yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- To get a settlement of the Anglo-Egyptian treaty dispute the British Government is prepared to go to any lengths that will not prejudice or impair the defense of the West.

BOMBAY, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The United States last hopes in the world table tennis championships, Martin Reisman and Doug Cartland of New York, were eliminated in the doubles semi-finals today by a sharp-stroking tandem from Japan.
A baby girl was born in an ambulance in Queens early yesterday after the mother had been in an automobile accident on her way to a hospital.

Puerto Rican rum has made more than a comeback. Frank Johnson, director of the Puerto Rican Rum Promotion, said yesterday that the glut of inventories that plagued the trade in 1948 had been moved. He reported that while 1951 consumption of all distilled spirits had increased only from 3 to 5 per cent over 1950, shipments of Puerto Rican rum had increased 15 per cent to a high of 700,000 cases last year.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 9 (UP) -- A Pennsylvania Railroad engineer, Francis B. Yentzer of Harrisburg, was acquitted today of charges of involuntary manslaughter and negligence in a train wreck that killed nine persons last May 18.

ALTHOUGH it is presented in a time of restrictions and regulations on the automobile industry, the forty-fourth annual Chicago Automobile Show gives promise of being one of the most brilliant exhibitions of its kind ever presented in this country.

THE "prestige" writer, as Lenard Kaufman points out in his new novel of a middle-aged writer's dilemma, occupies a curiously unique position in America. Commercially unsuccessful -- living, comparatively, from hand to mouth -- he is the object of an almost fanatical veneration.

COOKING food for TV and cooking food for people to eat are two entirely different things. To begin with, cooking food on television usually means preparing everything in triplicate -- an original and two carbons, using three full sets of ingredients.

John R. Crews, Kings County Republican Chairman, made public yesterday the list of organization candidates for delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention from the nine Brooklyn Congressional districts. He made the announcement after conferences with the Assembly district leaders.

LOS ANGELES. THE renowned AK601 on which the rowdy action of "Mister Roberts" takes place now has made more than half of the ninety-odd ports of this year's dry-land cruise. By late spring, when it drops anchor in some Eastern city, it will have docked in twenty-nine states and three Canadian provinces.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party of Slovenia has issued instructions for "an all-out and systematic struggle" against the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Slovenia.

Weary of floods of crime-and-corruption news, troubled over the reports of Congressional and state investigations and defalcations, it has been an inexpressible relief and uplift to turn to praise and appreciation, modest and unexaggerated, bestowed by worthy public servants on another worthy public servant.

A 4-year-old black Scottish terrier from the Bronx was one of the main winners yesterday in the event of the Associated Terrier Clubs at the 212th A. A. A. Group Amory. The show was one in which eleven breed clubs, all devoted to terriers, of course, fired the opening salutes in the series of specialties leading to tomorrow's start of Westminster.

Gil Hodges, the Iron Man first baseman who early last year was rated over - optimistically as a threat to erase Babe Ruth's 1927 record of sixty home runs, yesterday turned in his signed contract to the Dodgers.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Queen Elizabeth II decreed today that the court should come out of mourning for her father, King George VI, on June 1. This order started speculation on the date for the coronation. It had been thought that the ceremony might not take place until the spring of 1953, but the shorter period of mourning suggests a possibility that it may be held next summer.

Supporters of education throughout the nation will approve your editorial on educational television. It is indeed important to all of us that the New York Board of Regents continue to lead the way in this field of educational pioneering, and that Governor Dewey and the Legislature cooperate with their leadership.
A NEW chapter in the modern art controversy flares in today's news columns. It concerns a letter from the National Sculpture Society to the Metropolitan Museum.

Charles Munch, music director of the Boston Symphony, yesterday announced his plans for the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass. As in previous years, concerts will be given in the Theatre-Concert Hall and in the Music Shed.

Mayor Impellitteri will confer with Governor Dewey and legislative leaders at Albany this week on the city's $285,900,000 fiscal program of additional state aid and new or increased local taxes, it was reported yesterday.

BONN, Feb. 9 -- The problem of Germany's relationship with the West, a problem which a great many important people in Washington believed had been settled, returned this week to shake the fabric of post-war Europe. The complicated and sensitive aspects of the problem as it has developed show that it is one that cannot be settled by optimistic speeches or makeshift solutions.

A PATTERN of procedure for students of contemporary photographic activities was outlined last week by Lloyd E. Varden, one of the best-read men in the field and owner of a 7,000-volume library of photographic literature.

WE are seized anew with the glory and effervescence of Mozart when Sir Thomas Beecham elects to discourse his music in a manner completely his own; when the afflatus of the music seizes him so that he is as one possessed, driven to odd gestures of coquetry, insouciance, imperious command and Rabelaisian joy!

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -The Government allocated an extra million pounds of aluminum today to the automobile industry for the April-June period to help build more cars and alleviate the industry's unemployment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- When the United States Supreme Court held that the off-shore coastal lands, with their oil and natural gas resources, belonged to all forty-eight states and not to California, Texas and Louisiana, as these states had claimed, a controversy was set off that is still seething.

Registration at City College, which began spring session classes last Thursday, has declined by 587 students since last fall, Robert L. Taylor, registrar, reported yesterday. Total enrollment now is 30,975, as against 31,562 last September.

DALLAS, Feb. 9 -- Jimmy Phelan who introduced the spread formation to professional football, was named coach of the Dallas Texans of the National League today. President Giles Miller of the Texans announced the appointment of Phelan after a two-day meeting of the directors of the club.

EXACTLY fifty years ago an extremely unknown poet in a shabby room in New York's Chelsea was correcting proofs of the first of his major poems. The poet was Edwin Arlington Robinson and the poem was "Captain Craig."

The tragic and untimely death of King George VI last Wednesday has focused the attention of the world on heart disease at a time when we in this nation are starting our annual American Heart Week, which begins today. The cause of his death was coronary thrombosis, a disease that took the lives of 200,4444 Americans last year.

Common Cause, Inc., national American citizen organization to combat communism, will be the beneficiary of the performances of "Antony and Cleopatra," and "Caesar and Cleopatra," with Sir Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh, on the nights of Feb. 27 and 28, respectively, at the Ziegfeld Theatre.
ROME, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The text of Italy's note to the Soviet Union on renunciation of the peace treaty follows:

Guido Cantelli, conductor of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra in its broadcast concert last evening from Carnegie Hall, selected two works for his program -- Wagner's "Faust" Overture and Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- Senator Taft and Harold E. Stassen entered the West Virginia primary today, setting up a fifth round test in their fight for the Republican Presidential nomination. The West Virginia vote May 13 is merely a "popularity" contest.

STOWE, Vt. -- With the melting of the first hesitant snowflake on New York's pavement, veteran skiers, restless in their city shoes, head single-mindedly for New England's crusty slopes. To an equally nonveteran skier, occasionally called upon to autograph a plaster cast, their enthusiasm pour le sport has been a source of constant bewilderment.

The city's wet wash may be hanging from housewives' windows next month if the Laundry Workers Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union, C. I. O., carries out its threat to call a strike of 20,000 laundry employes at midnight Feb. 29.
PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- Fifty years ago today this North Jersey industrial city experienced the most disastrous fire in its 100-year history.

MIAMI, Feb. 9 -- Not since Coaltown's days at Hialeah has there been a front-running exhibition of the quality shown by William G. Helis Jr.'s New Jersey-bred Spartan Valor in the $36,150 McLennan Handicap today.

Coast Guard headquarters in Washington reported yesterday that it had received for final processing only fifty applications from foreign merchant marine officers wishing to sail under the United States flag. The program was instituted on Jan. 17 to cope with a shortage of trained citizen officers that has delayed 100 ships or more in the last month.

TO anyone who was a playgoer, a critic, or a producer in the Nineteen Twenties it is great satisfaction to see two of Eugene O'Neill's plays, "Anna Christie" and "Desire Under the Elms," revived on Broadway.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9 -- The nation-wide shortage of skilled workers can be remedied by speeding up the education of superior students, according to Henry Chauncey, president of the Educational Testing Service.

Retail trade officials gave second thought last week to the desirability of selective price decontrol, and concluded that any extensive removal of economic curbs on dry goods might open the way for parallel decontrol of wages and manufacturer prices.

NOUASSEUR AIR BASE, Morocco, Feb. 9 -- The Middle East may soon in itself become as important in global strategic terms as the great inland sea it borders, the Mediterranean, has been since ancient days and still remains.

THE Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute, Farmingdale, N. Y., will present its thirty-third annual Country Life-Open House Program on Feb. 21, 22 and 23. Between the hours of 1 and 9 P. M. during the three days, exhibits and demonstrations in a wide variety of agricultural and horticultural fields will be offered on the Main Campus, Melville Road, Farmingdale.

BEGINNING her book with Russia in 1919, second year of the revolution. Tanya Matthews ends it in England in 1946 with the words -- "So we live happily ever after." What happens between those years, as written down by Tanya Matthews, born Tanya Svetlova, makes a fascinating documentary on life behind the scenes in the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO'S Great Fire occurred in 1871; by 1879 more than 10,000 permits for reconstruction had been issued. Carl W. Condit's book is a valuable documentation of the Chicago style of building which evolved out of this activity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Representatives of the wool industry agreed today to ask the Agriculture Department to set up a loan program for the marketing year beginning April 1.

Preparing employes for a useful and happy period of retirement when they finish their working careers has become an important feature of labor-management relations in recent years, but it is still in its infancy as a welfare measure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Federal agents, striking at important sources of narcotics in 1951, have halted an upward trend in teen-age drug addiction and have sent to prison some of the narcotic traffic's "worst mobsters," Harry J. Anslinger, Commissioner of the Bureau of Narcotics, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture has reported that scientists have found chemicals in turpentine that "show excellent promise" for use in preparation of synthetic rubber, plastics and other products.

One large, ultimate question has hung over the Korean truce discussions from the beginning. It is this: After a military armistice, is there to be political settlement in Korea and how broad should it be? In Panmunjom last week the full truce delegation did some preliminary work on this problem, which must eventually be turned over to the diplomats.

The dog show that carries more prestige than any other in the United States will occupy Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Tuesday. It is the seventy-sixth event of the Westminster Kennel Club, held continuously since it originated as a 1,177-dog competition in Gilmore's Garden in 1877.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- France, like West Germany, will attach conditions of approval of the European army plan for integrating German forces in the West's defense.

A charge that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, "has now added blackmail" to "deceit and falsehood" in attacking those who disagree with him was voiced yesterday by Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, in a speech before the alumni association of City College yesterday.

A man enthralled with the possibilities of driving a bus yielded yesterday to the extent of giving at least fifty-eight passengers a satisfactory if somewhat erratic and unauthorized ride over the Willis Avenue route, linking Manhattan and the Bronx via 125th Street.

The employment of a few "bright, young" American Negroes in United States embassies throughout the world was recommended yesterday by a prominent Harlem clergyman as the "smartest and cheapest" way to defeat Communism overseas.

" VOLPONE," the opera George Antheil has based on Ben Jonson's play, will have its premiere on Feb. 29 in Los Angeles. It will be presented by the opera department of the University of Southern California in its Bovard Auditorium.

ATLANTA, Feb. 9 -- Plant expansions in the Southeast to meet the defense effort calling for expenditure of nearly $8,000,000 have just been approved by the Defense Production Administration. Steel, iron ore, railway transportation, parachutes, naphthalene, research, air transportation, ordnance, aircraft parts, carbon bisulphide, scrap metals and synthetic mullite are included in the commodities to be produced or services rendered.

WHEN Senator Wayne Morse rose recently in righteous anger against the lie detector, the Defense Department promptly banned the use of that device in testing job applicants. Not long afterward, however, the controversial instrument was again in the news as a member of the House demanded its widespread use for weeding subversive people out of the Government.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The proclamation of Queen Elizabeth's sovereignty yesterday began a process of recognition of allegiance that will culminate in the acclamations in Westminster Abbey on Coronation Day.

THE bromeliads number among their clan many of the least demanding, and most showy house plants. Native to tropical America, they are related to the pineapple family. They are valued either for their spectacular bloom or brightly colored foliage, or, in some cases, both.

WHENEVER Margaret Truman appears on a stage -- radio, television or concert hall -- there is a murmuring comment: "How has she acquired such poise?" It is something over four years ago that she made her professional debut, self-conscious and nervous, and but a year since she started on the "big time" in radio.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, called upon the Republican, party tonight to answer "the cry of desperation from every part of the country" by nominating for President "a leader who inspires confidence."

ALBANY, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The chairman of the Senate Public Welfare Committee today challenged arguments advanced by the State Social Welfare Board in urging defeat of legislation to open relief rolls for public inspection.

SPIES are. such unbelievable and repugnant characters that Americans did not take them seriously until recent years. Even now the phrase "cloak and dagger" is used somewhat derisively about undercover operations in general.

Department store sales last week continued to run behind the comparable 1951 figures, and trade observers estimated the decline at 11 per cent. Scare buying and higher prices a year ago contributed to the disparity.

IN such regional stories as "Henner's Lydia" and "Petite Suzanne" Mrs. de Angeli proved her ability to capture the atmosphere of a place, just as in her Newbery Award winner "The Door in the Wall" she captured the feeling of the past.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A new kind of disaster aid to families of miners killed in mine accidents was announced today by the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J, Feb. 9 -- Lothar Zeidler of Berlin, a journalism student at Rutgers University, hopes eventually to use the training he is receiving to tell the people of Western democracies how the Communists operate.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- An estimated 1,000,000 soccer fans paid tribute to King George VI today.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- Federal Germany will eventually ask for recreation of a high command and general staff to direct and control its ground and air forces in the European defense community as part of the program of complete equality in rearmament, a responsible Allied source said today.

James J. Moran is a former stenographer who rose with the political star of William O'Dwyer. Moran was a clerk in Kings County Court when Mr. O'Dwyer became a judge there in 1938. They became friendly. Moran was successively personal stenographer to Judge O'Dwyer, chief clerk under Brooklyn District Attorney O'Dwyer, First Deputy Fire Commissioner and finally Water Supply Commissioner under Mayor O'Dwyer.
In our country there will always be an outstanding American, self-labeled as a "progressive," asking us not to be "orthodox," a witch-hunter or harsh with the Communists and their associates.

ROSELLE PARK, N. J., Feb. 9 -- That exotic plant Mrs. Peter Selner had been displaying in her home at 170 Webster Avenue East has been banished to the basement.

A good spring and summer season is in store for men's shirt manufacturers, but they must realize that it will require six months to do the business this year they did in two-and-one-half in 1951, industry spokesmen said last week. Initial orders have been light, but reorders were reported to be larger than usual and steady.

BABETTE ROSMOND, former editor of two pulp magazines, is still haunted by illicit love and the martini-before-lunch set. Both subjects appeared in her former books. "The Dewy, Dewy Eyes" and "A Party for Grownups." Her third novel deals with the Delaware family, headed by fluttery Mrs. Vernon Delaware, who delights in sarcastic nips at her two daughters-in-law.

TAKING some characters and a hint or two out of a Somerset Maugham story, S. N. Behrman has written a lively comedy of manners, "Jane," with which the Theatre Guild has brightened a lugubrious season. "Jane" is the sort of literate artifice the theatre has always had a genius for.

JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 29 (By Airmail) -- Because he feels "uncertain and politically frustrated," Alan Paton, author of the best-selling novel "Cry, the Beloved Country," will live for a year, or more, in a tuberculosis settlement for colored peoples twenty-five miles from Durban City.

A world health program that would enlist American public support in meeting some of the most urgent health needs in various areas abroad has been undertaken by the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Ins., Paul Comly French, executive director, announced last week.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Feb. 9 (UP) -- Senator Herman Welker, Republican of Idaho, told a party rally here today that the Federal Administration is marked with "greed, sloth, stupidity, malice and dishonesty of Pendergastism surrounding the highest office in America."

VIRTUALLY ignored for three years, "Juan Perez Jolote" by Ricardo Pozas, certainly one of the best examples of biography in Mexican literature, is just beginning to attract attention locally. The delay is not particularly surprising since Pozas is not a known writer but a young ethnologist of the Mexican National Museum of Anthropology and his work appeared in Acta Antropologica, a student publication of the National School of Anthropology and History.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (AP) -Metro-Goldwn-Mayer's production Chief, Dore Schary, has filed a $1,250,000 libel suit against the Wage Earners Committee.

Putting on a blistering third-period attack that quelled the visitors' ambitions in short order, Joe Lapchick's New York Knickerbockers extended their winning streak at home to thirteen straight by halting the Philadelphia Warriors, 96 to 86, in an Eastern division battle of the National Basketball Association at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

THIS is the story of a woman who is elected President of the United States. The time is the present, the town a mythical suburb and the story opens on election day. Miriam Hall Bradley is pondering what her future will hold when all the votes are counted.

THE house is in turmoil. Tears and sharp words mingle. Gnome, the pup, has just chewed up mother's new black suede purse. The purse was her favorite Christmas present, just as Gnome was the 5-year-old's dream come true.

SARASOTA, Fla. -- It is roughly 220 miles by car from Miami, the capital of Florida's east coast resorts, across the Everglades via the Tamiami Trail and up the coastal highway to Sarasota, the capital of the state's west coast resort centers.

Happily, however, "The Fairy Chessmen" gives us Padgett's imagination at its brilliant best.

MIAMI BEACH -- In the Alice-in-Wonderland kind of civilization that goes by the name of Miami Beach in season, it is February, not March, that is supposed to come in like a lion, with tourists roaring up and down the beach looking for a room to occupy for those few hours between the time the night clubs close and the race track opens.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- A group of Boston physicians made public today a letter that they had written to President Truman, urging him to order the "immediate expulsion" from the United State of Dr. Walter P. Schreiber, World War II Chief of Medical Science in the Supreme Command of the German Army.

Martin Van Buren, eighth President of the United States, once sat down, pen in hand, to instruct his son John, a lawyer, brilliant orator and, like his father, a Democrat, in the intricacies of attaining the highest office in the land.

CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 9 -- In a last-minute rush of filing, full slates of delegates for five men were listed today for the nation's first Presidential preference primary, which will be held in New Hampshire March 11.

A 12-year-old Queens boy was pronounced dead at 2:45 P. M. yesterday, apparently of drowning, after he had remained submerged for a short time in the swimming pool of the Presbyterian Church House, 921 Madison Avenue, the police reported.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Grains sought lower levels on the Board of Trade today as the United Nations agreed, with some exceptions, to a Communist proposal for a higher level political conference after settlement of a Korean armistice.

ALMOST certainly Daphne du Maurier has been haunted by the specter of her own "Rebecca." It would need a dedicated artist or a confirmed experimentalist to resist so fabulously successful a brainchild. Miss du Maurier is neither of these things, but a storyteller whose sole aim is to bewitch and beguile.

AN inscription on an Italian 25-lire gray-brown and green -"Celebrazione Vanvitelliane de Caserta" -- suggests why this stamp has been issued. Luigi Vanvitelli (1700-1773), Italian architect, designed for Charles III of Spain a palace which stands in Caserta, sixteen miles from Naples, and is today called the "Versailles of Naples."

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 9 (UP) -- A series of explosions shattered a huge oil barge in the Warrior River today and three crewmen were reported killed as flames shot from the wreckage. Two others were injured, including a tug owner who-tried to save the trapped workers although burned himself.

U. S. WHEELING, W. Va., Feb. 9 (UP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said tonight that he knew of "no other way" to bring communism to the United States than to follow the recommendations of President Truman's chief economic advisor, Leon Keyserling.

MITES have built up to such numbers that this year they rank with cankerworm, elm leaf beetle and Japanese beetle as major pests of shade and ornamental trees and shrubs. They have become so destructive that the use of a miticide for their control, either as a special spray or, when feasible, in combination with an insecticide is recommended.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Conspiracy charges against Rudolf Slansky and other Czech leaders in connection with reports that they would be accused of having plotted to murder President Klement Gottwald should be considered as a blind for a widespread Soviet-ordered purge, according to Hubert Ripka, former Czech Cabinet Minister and president of the Free Czech National Committee.

Syracuse, N. Y., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Deane W. Malott, president of Cornell University, asserted tonight that proposed universal military training was "merely a scheme for a gargantuan boot camp" and wuold not provide training necessary for all-out war.

ABOVE the Mason-Dixon line, hardly a ghost to speak of turns up in contemporary American writing. IN his play "R. U. R." Capek lustily gibed at an inventor who seemed to consider himself a "scientific substitute for God" by virtue of his re-creation of animal life in robot form. From speculations on the creation of robots in the image of man, Capek turned to consider the fate of man if he had the power to disintegrate matter totally.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 9 -A summer series of pop concerts seemed assured tonight when trustees of the Connecticut Symphony Orchestra named an operating committee of eleven members to guide the orchestra. Harold B. Down was appointed general chairman of the committee.
TOKYO, Feb. 9 -- The Communists tried out some grand strategy and some minor tactics this week in the all-out political war they are fighting parallel to the limited shooting in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Presumably, eagle-eyed experts at both ends of the Capitol are busily going over the defense budget estimates of some $52,100,000,000 to cut out all waste. This happens to all requests for funds, but it is more impressive at present because the military expenditures promise to be so big for another year.

The city's Department of Commerce announced yesterday that its liaison program with Federal agencies, carried on through a new city bureau in Washington, had brought New York $280,000,000 in Federal contracts in recent months.

CAIRO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha said tonight that the military training of Egyptian "volunteers" would be taken over by the War and Navy Ministry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Officials of the Art Institute of Chicago told today how it took a year of investigation and considerable sales talk on four continents to gather the most complete Cezanne collection ever acquired in this country. The collection includes more than 100 oil paintings, water-colors and drawings by the famous French artist.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 10 -- Communist delegates at Panmunjom insisted today on an international conference after the start of an armistice in the Korean war to deal with a wide range of "related" questions.

MEREDITH WILLSON is a 49-year-old orchestra leader and composer who is musical director of Tallulah Bankhead's "The Big Show." Three years ago he wrote a sort of autobiography called "And There I Stood With My Piccolo."

The power to take any steps, including strike action, to achieve a forty-hour work week on the city's nine private bus lines by March 1 was granted yesterday to officials of the 40,000-man Local 100, Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

ROME, Feb. 9 -- The Italian Government has informed the Soviet Ambassador here that Moscow violated the Italian peace treaty by again vetoing Italy's admission to the United Nations, and that, therefore, Italy no longer considers herself bound by the obligations to the Soviet Union that the treaty had laid upon her.
There is news in prints for the girl who is planning her own dressmaking this spring. In the shops are tie silk reps, shantungs and textured silks and rayons printed with modern motif designs.
WARRENTON, Va., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Alexander Hamilton Calvert, president of the Warrenton Horse Show Association, was killed near here yesterday when his automobile smashed into a culvert.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 10 -- President Anastasio Somoza proved his talents as a dancer and a poet at festivities here last week celebrating his fifty-sixth birthday and the 100th anniversary of this capital city, it was reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- "Plymouth Adventure," adapted from the novel "the Pilgrim," by Ernest Gebler, is shaping up as one of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's most ambitious projects for the year.
Containers made of bamboo are included in a collection of new wares, imported from various countries, now available at the Basket Bazaar, 133 West Third Street.
A Whiteside Tumbler pigeon had the best seat in the house yesterday afternoon at the Thirtieth Annual Pet Show of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Americans earned a record $251,100,000,000 in personal income last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A native American style is developing in home architecture in this country, in the opinion of two experts who recently have completed a survey on the subject. They are Katherine Morrow Ford, formerly architectural consultant to House and Garden, and Thomas Creighton, editor of Progressive Architecture, whose book, "The American House Today," contains examples of the kinds of homes that led them to this belief.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Leon H. Keyserling declared tonight that he and his wife were both "bitterly opposed" to communism.

The Rev. Jose Mota, a nephew of Charles Cardinal Mota, Archbishop of Sao Paulo, Brazil, celebrated the solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. One of a group of South Americans who studied for the priesthood at St. John's Seminary, Brighton, Mass., Father Mota was ordained in Boston a month ago.

Former Commissioner of Welfare Raymond H. Hilliard issued another statement yesterday attacking the recent report by the New York State Department of Social Welfare, which had criticized local relief practices.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- In a soft-shoe dance of a northwest breeze that was so gentle even canoes could have replaced the winter sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, Vic Romagna came through the winner with 216 points in his craft Jenny IV.

" American Inventory," the experimental adult educational television program carried by the N. B. C.-TV network at 1:30 P. M. on Sundays, has been extended for an additional thirty-nine weeks by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and the National Broadcasting Company. An appropriation of $140,000 has been made for the 1952 series.
The blood bank of the New York Red Cross has begun what it expects to be the largest operational year of its history.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 10 -- Fierce mountain tribesmen beheaded a local Governor and three other officials last night and battled with swords and knives today. More than fifty persons were killed by them and more than 200 injured.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Stanley W. Pearson Jr. of Philadelphia defeated Robert Grant 3d of New York, national racquets champion, in the final round of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquets tournament today before a gallery of New York, Philadelphia and Boston fans.

The New York State Society for Medical Research, 2 East Sixty-third Street, announced yesterday that religious leaders of all faiths supported the Metcalf-Hatch bill for research use of a small percentage of the 400,000 unwanted dogs and cats that are destroyed by the pounds annually.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Brooklyn, the Bronx and Richmond probably will be called upon to pay more than one-half of 1 per cent as a separate county real estate tax while Manhattan and Queens pay less under the legislation submitted by Mayor Impellitteri to meet New York's revenue needs for the new fiscal year.

News of a small-scale British parachute drop in northern Malaya and of the fighting of ground troops to reach the advance party should be read in its context. Disorder in Malaya has been in the pattern of Communist aggression and conquest, and recent events indicate that the tempo has been accelerated.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 10 -- City officials and industrial leaders from several South Jersey towns along the Delaware River will go to Washington tomorrow to protest a $93,000,000 project to deepen the Delaware channel from Philadelphia to Trenton.

THE TIMES recently reported a recommendation by E. E. Kearns, manager of the General Electric Company's urban traffic division, that railroad rapid transit should be provided in a center mall in expressway rights-of-way.
Those who fancy gazing at the moon had a rewarding opportunity last night.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 -- Pressure for decontrol of some steel items was continuing in the steel industry last week. So far only chromium stainless steel has been freed. Other items which steel interests think should "go on their own" are: tinplate, certain wire products, sheets and strip.

E. H. van Delden, Professor of Industrial Relations in the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University, has been appointed director of the New York office of Salary Stabilization, 1834 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.
A crowded week on the New York art scene includes a show opening on Thursday at the Museum of Modern Art devoted to the graphic art of Odilon-Redon and Picasso.

" Cosi fan tutte" received its final performance of the season Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera, and it will be missed. The gay Mozart revival had six highly successful appearances in as many weeks and probably could have run as many more.

John Haynes Holmes, who became minister of the Community Church of New York forty-five years ago and is now its minister emeritus, enumerated in an anniversary sermon yesterday morning seven devils he declared "are devouring us."

MANILA, Feb. 10 -- Philippine reparations negotiators, in a new set of proposals to the six-man Japanese reparations mission now in Manila, suggested today the postponement of the Philippine demand for $8,000,000,000 in cash and opened the door to possible settlement of the basis for a treaty with Japan.

Champion Barmere's Locket, fawn bitch, owned by the Barmere Kennels of Van Nuys, Calif., and handled by Harry Sangster, was named best of breed in the ninth annual specialty show of the American Boxer Club last night. Picked as best of opposite sex was Champion Clinaude's Count v.d. Karlo, the property of Dr. and Mrs. L. R. McNichols of Fremont, Iowa.

Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, urged last night the granting of Israel's application for grants-in-aid of $126,000,000. He asserted that the fledgling state could supply military, naval and air bases "to stem aggression from imperialist Russia."

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 10 -- Seven men were killed and nineteen others were injured today in three accidents as airborne and armored cavalry moved into action on the second day of the final phase of Exercise Snowfall, the Army-Air Force winter war games.

Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company is offering to common stockholders the right to subscribe for 64,000 shares of additional common stock at $20 a share at the rate of one share for each ten shares held Feb. 6, 1952.

ALPENA, Mich., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Miss Barbara Marchetti of Detroit flashed to three straight victories today in a great comeback that gained her a tie with Miss Doreen McLeod of Edmonton, Alberta, for the senior women's title at the North American outdoor speed skating championships.

The recent announcement by the Superintendent of the United States Military Academy about the retention of Col. Earl H. Blaik as head football coach and director of athletics comes as a blow to many in the Army who had hoped a "new deal" was in store at West Point.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 11 -- The United Nations delegation at Panmunjom refused yesterday to recommend the holding of an international conference to discuss "all the problems of Asia" as the price of a permanent settlement in Korea.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Trade in grain futures showed a considerable increase in volume last week, marked by a notable gain in oats purchases on the Board of Trade. Operations in oats were greater than either wheat or corn. Business for the week totaled much larger than a year ago.

" Eat more lettuce," pleads the United States Department of Agriculture on behalf of growers, who are faced with the problem of moving this season's huge yield. Heavy shipments of iceberg lettuce are arriving here daily from the salad bowl of the West, California's Imperial Valley, along with sizable quantities from the South.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A five-year development program for Iraq that would ransform the nation's economy and the way of life of its people was recommended in a report to that Government today from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

The "full gold standard," which was one of the main pillars of international commerce in the world in which many of us were reared, is, as nearly everyone knows, no longer operative. In some quarters it has been the fashion in recent years to dispose of the fate of this venerable system with the statement that "the gold standard has broken down."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee plans to hear more than sixty witnesses this week as it strives to meet a Feb. 21 deadline, set by law, for reporting a Universal Military Training bill.

God will always find a way to carry forward His work because He is an "undiscouraged God," the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner, pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational), 211 West Fifty-sixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday.

Dr. George W. Taylor, former chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, has been chosen by the Congress of Industrial Organizatios as chief magistrate to eliminate jurisdictional disputes between C. I. O. unions.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had asked the Wage Stabilization Board to permit immediate payment of the 1.08 per cent cost-of-living part of a pending 3.58 per cent wage increase application for 200,000 employes in twenty-four states.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 -- The draft and impending military service present youth with such unanswerable problems concerning the future that going to school may seem a waste of time, a New York educator tonight told delegates to the seventh annual convention of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, said today he hoped President Truman, if he planned to run for re-election, would enter more primaries so the voters could choose between him and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.
Bertram B. Richardson has been named to the post of division service manager in this city by the Hoover Company, maker of electric cleaners and other products.

For the second successive year, sales and earnings of the Continental Can Company established new high records, General Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the board, announced in the preliminary annual statement for 1951 mailed to stockholders today.

Convinced that "the trend to worldliness during our own lifetimes has brought with it a spiritual apathy and moral callousness that would have seemed incredible fifty years ago," Harvard University announces today a plan to create "an important center of religious learning."

DETROIT, Feb. 10 -- Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr. declared today that he would become a candidate for the United States Senate from Michigan "only if such a move is essential in promoting the Presidential candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower."

The New York Rovers' return to home ice yesterday afternoon was most satisfactory to Lloyd Ailsby's skaters and a crowd of 5,327 at Madison Square Garden. With Gerald Kirk, sharp-shooting center, caging four goals, the Red Shirts whipped the Boston Olympics, 9 -- 4, in an Eastern Hockey League battle.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Rarely has the City received such a shock and sense of numbness as that which followed the sudden and unexpected death of the King.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Scottish nationalists insisted today that Britain's new Queen should be known as Elizabeth I because her famous namesake never ruled north of the border.
All runways at Newark Airport were ordered closed at 3 A. M. today by the Port of New York Authority.

Matthew J. Shevlin undermines with considerable effectiveness the arguments offered by Dr. William Heard Kilpatrick against the proposed Regents' school prayer. After reading his letter it is not likely that anyone in the future will take seriously such claims as that the prayer is unconstitutional, divisive, or not in accord with our ancient American traditions.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- From the viewpoint of Europeans concerned with making and carrying out economic policy, the United States Senate has dealt the Western community a serious blow in refusing the prompt repeal of the special import restrictions on dairy products that were slipped into last year's Defense Production Act.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,156, for Sunday's operations:

BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 -- Most Germans would like to pay off claims for Hitler's ravaging of Jewish property and persons but few of them think the West German Government can afford it. While the announcement by the Federal Government that it wished to negotiate a settlement of the Jewish restitution problem has been approved, West German Government leaders insist the treasury has not the money to make good.

It would have been possible to get up a pretty fair dog show from the number of dogs that already were in Madison Square Garden's basement yesterday. They were there for the Westminster Kennel Club event that begins its two-day run this morning.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Monday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Following is the eyewitness account of the National Airlines DC-6 crash here this morning as told by the stewardess of the plane, Nancy Taylor:

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Legislation authorizing state loans of up to $50,000,000 to nonprofit corporations for the construction of housing specifically designed for the elderly will be introduced tomorrow under the sponsorship of the joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UP) -- A concentrated enemy atom bomb attack on United States cities would leave 7,000,000 persons homeless and might "break the spirit of the people" unless regular activities were restored quickly, the Federal Civil Defense Administration warned today.

The first Metropolitan Opera performance of Strauss' "Elektra" since 1938-39 will be given on Monday evening, Feb. 18, to open the fifteenth week of the season. Also during the week will be this year's initial "Trovatore" and the debut of the soprano, Walburga Wegner, as Chrysothemis in "Elektra."

Pause and close your eyes in a brown woodland during a February stroll if you would really savor the country sounds of peace and contentment amid the fresh, clean smell of winter. Near by are the carillon-like notes of a thaw-fed brook tumbling over great, smooth granite stones.

NASHUA, N. H., Feb. 10 -- Keeping an engagement scheduled before he announced his Presidential candidacy, Senator Estes Kefauver launched the New Hampshire phase of his campaign tonight at the annual dinner of the Nashua Chamber of Commerce.

The Canadian dollar showed quiet strength last week, recovering all of the ground lost recently. It moved steadily upward from 99.625 cents on Monday to 99.968 cents in midweek, with Friday's final of 99.937 cents reflecting a gain of 5/16 cent over the preceding week.

Profiting from a succession of breaks, the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. With a crowd of 13,050 on hand to cheer them on after their long road trip, the Blues out-played the Canadian sextet in all phases except scoring. In that department Toronto had just enough of a margin to win, 4 -- 3.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10 -- The Communists have begun their expected propaganda attack on the Mexican-United States negotiations for a military aid agreement. The main weapon is the talent and name of David Alfaro Siqueiros, Mexican painter.

Orchestral musicians often want to set out on their own, and last night members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony began an independent venture. Thirty of them have formed the Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble, which gave its first concert at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.

Gina Bachauer, Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony collaborated on a beautiful performance of Grieg's Piano Concerto at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. The concerto was the high spot of the second annual benefit concert for the Queen's Fund for Greek Orphans.

As an original sponsor of compulsory automobile insurance I wish to commend your recent editorial "The Uninsured Motorist" and the excellent report of the New York State Insurance Department on this subject. The Marx Foundation is making awards to college students who have done the best thinking on this subject in order to stimulate interest in bringing about this necessary social reform.

This being a Monday, and the month being February, it is possible that more people in the United States will catch colds today than at any other time of the year. Dr. Joseph Kler of New Brunswick, N. J., a few years ago made an intensive study of the common cold and concluded that more colds start on Monday than on any other day of the week.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (UP) -- The Canadiens continued their mastery of the Black Hawks today, scoring a 3-to-2 victory on goals by Rookie Dickie Moore, Paul Meger and Bernie Geoffrion, before 10,616.
Larry Jansen, the solid man of the Giants' pitching staff for five straight years, yesterday became the thirty-first of Manager Leo Durocher's men to turn in his signed contract.

Customs agents cracked down yesterday on a two-way international gold and diamond smuggling combine. The ring was said to have smuggled out gold bullion, sold it in European black markets, then used the currency to purchase diamonds that were smuggled into the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Feb. 2 to 8 are given in the appended tabulation:

SINGAPORE, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A British ground detachment moving in to help a paratroop force clean up a jungle Communist center near the Thailand border ran into a Red ambush today. The ground unit reported itself held up by Communist fire and a flood at a river crossing five miles from the paratroopers.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., attacked yesterday an engineering report compiled for the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey that suggested Board of Transportation economies of $15,500,000. The union opposed the proposal as "creating fat jobs for lean politicians" while recommending "lay-offs and speed-up" for the employes.
Prices slipped a little lower on the New York Cotton Exchange last week.
SANDRINGHAM, England, Feb. 10 -- Queen Elizabeth II joined the rest of Britain today in offering special prayers for her father, King George VI.

THE boys have done an excellent job of tidying up the house. The Hall of Fame at Cooperstown looks a heap sight neater since those two vacant niches have been filled by Harry Heilmann and Paul Waner. But the baseball writers still have an important task confronting them before the pantheon of diamond gods takes on a completely orderly appearance.

There are always cynics who hold -- with some justification -- that treaties are only valid so long as one party can impose terms on the other or so long as they are mutually acceptable, and such being the case, why have treaties? This is no criticism of Italy for driving another nail into the coffin being prepared for her mutilated peace treaty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The egg you ate for breakfast and the ham that went with it, or the wheatcakes, the oatmeal, or even your after-breakfast cigarette, were not paid for entirely out of your own pocket. A part of its cost came straight from the pockets of your fellow taxpayers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 10 -- Although the States Rights Democrat (Dixiecrat) forces have showed signs of ebbing strength in several instances when bidding for control of local party machinery, the top leadership has made evident recently a strong belief that the dissidents' political vitality is far from being impaired.

EL PASO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, playing it safe but sure, rolled in with a two-under-par 69 today to win the $2,000 first prize in the $10,000 El Paso open golf tournament -- his first victory of the year. His total was 269.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The franc declined on the Bourse last week even though Premier Edgar Faure announced to the National Assembly a series of drastic steps to overcome inflation.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 -- Although the annual invasion of the United States by more than 1,000,000 Mexican border-jumpers has been a subject of special consideration by Congress and other branches of the Federal Government for nearly a year, the "wetback" influx is not only unabated but augmented.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 10 (AP) -- An informant who said he was familiar with the border situation declared today that Chinese Nationalist irregulars on Burma's northeastern frontier were carrying "brand-new" United States arms.
The forty-second anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America was marked yesterday by special services in churches and synagogues throughout the city.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 10 -- Despite the great expansion of Allied ground forces in Europe during the last year -- an increase from two to six United States divisions is the best example -- Allied infantry and armored divisions could not count on close air support during the opening and perhaps critical phase of a land battle.
ROME, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Following is a translation of the text of Pope Pius' address today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Army introduced a new airtight uniform for protection against poison gas and germ warfare today.
The Maritime Administration's reserve fleet has reached the "bottom of the barrel."

ROME, Feb. 10 -- Pope Pius made an impassioned appeal today for a "return to Jesus Christ, the Church and the Christian way of life" as the only means of avoiding dangers, "much more widespread and grave than pestilence and the convulsions of nature," that are threatening a world that is started "on the road to ruin."

Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis," excerpts from Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" and the appearance of several instrumentalists for the first time with the orchestra will be among the features of the 1952-1953 subscription season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. The twenty-eight-week season will open on Oct. 16, 1952, and close on April 26, 1953.

NOREFJELL, Norway, Feb. 10 (UP) -- Winter Olympic officials said tonight they would not move the alpine skiing competition from this snow-bare course, but would limit practice on the runs until the games begin Thursday.

RAHWAY, N. J., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Merck Co., manufacturing chemists, has acquired a 640-acre plant site on the Flint River near Albany, Ga., where it will produce medicinal chemicals, it has been announced. The company said it chose the location after an extensive survey of many areas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Manpower needs during the next two years will be increased by an estimated 3,500,000, Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, announced today.

A world that is becoming progressively smaller demands that the Christian church relegate sectarian differences and man-made traditions to a secondary position, the Rev. Dr. Chester A. Pennington said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.
A chance conversation in a Queens drug store led yesterday to the arraignment in Brooklyn Felony Court of two men charged with the theft of six cash registers.

ZURICH, Feb. 10 -- Following immediately after the radical curtailment of imports by Great Britain, last month's total suspension of imports by France without previous consultation with other Office of European Economic Cooperation countries is described in Switzerland as a shattering blow to the confidence in the future of O. E. E. C.

General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's chances of gaining the Republican nomination for President certainly are not going to be enhanced if there are many more telecasts such as last Friday night's from Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Michael V. DiSalle, retiring Director of Price Stabilization, set up a seven-man committee today with orders to begin an immediate study of the advisability of ending price ceilings on some consumer goods such as shoes and clothing.

The New York Curb Exchange and its operating affiliates, New York Curb Exchange Realty Associates, Inc., and New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation, had a total consolidated income for 1951 of $2,179,593 in 1951, Edward T. McCormick, president, announced yesterday. This compares with a total income of $1,725,251 in the preceding year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Long liquidation in grains appeared to have dwindled to a moderate volume last week, but it was still difficult to hold bulges. There was some evidence of accumulation on the setbacks, but apparently buyers were inclined to confine their purchases to the small recessions and at no time was there any indication of aggressive bull support following the frequent rallies.

The Board of Education will spend $6,500,000 this year in modernizing twenty elementary and high school buildings that are more than thirty years old, Andrew G. Clauson Jr., president of the board, announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Yale undergraduates of the School of Fine Arts, in cooperation with some graduates and faculty members, will show their paintings and sculpture at a preview in Branford College on the Yale campus on Wednesday evening.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Monday, Feb. 11 -- A four-engine National Airlines plane, bound for Miami, Fla., with at least sixty-two persons aboard, crashed into a thickly populated residential area of this city at 12:21 o'clock this morning, setting a fifty-family apartment house afire.

Supreme Court Justice Maximilian Moss asserted yesterday that the Jewish community had the two-fold responsibility to create "enough Jewish education facilities to care for every Jewish child, and to instill within him the knowledge and the character traits which Judaism can offer and which we can contribute to American democracy."

Track and field's latest judging controversy, which wound up with Fred Wilt being named the winner over Don Gehrmann in the Baxter Mile in a photo-inspired reversal of the human-eye decision announced some forty minutes earlier, pointed up previously suspected inadequacies of a rule written into the books of the Amateur Athletic Union just a few months ago.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 -- W. Stuart Symington said today he would become a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator if President Truman asked him to do so.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 10 -- A paradoxical situation has developed in the Dutch monetary and economic position. While the monetary position continues to improve, economic developments are causing some concern.

The Philadelphia Nationals, champions of the American Soccer League, yesterday defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos, 5 -- 4, at Croke Park. In another circuit encounter, Brookhattan-Galicia toppled the Newark Portuguese team by 3 -- 2.

Ch. Sovereign's Escort belonging to Mrs. Dorothy F. Drury of Oakville, Ont., won the specialty of the Boston Terrier Club of New York last night and a dog from the classes, Karli Ben Ghazi, a 1 1/2-year-old cream-colored dog owned by Mrs. Ruth H. Thom and her mother, Mrs. J. E. Baird, from Southport, Conn., that of the Afghan Hound Club of America.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 10 -- A major development in the South's expanding industrialization is the use of industrial wastes to create enterprises and to minimize stream and air pollution, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.
Pierre Bernac and Francis Poulenc, the famous French musical team, gave their only local recital of their present tour last night in Town Hall.
Seven new films, including importations from England and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets tangled with more than 100 Soviet-type MIG-15 jets in five flashing battles Sunday over Northwest Korea's MIG Alley.

DAPHNE DU MAURIER is one of the most popular novelists in the English-speaking world. A natural storyteller, she is also something much rarer in our present era of literary solemnity and drab fiction: she is a romanticist who sees life in terms of gaudy melodrama and flamboyantly colorful characters. Maybe that's why she is so popular.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10 -- A plan to create an important center of interdenominational religious learning open to students "without regard to their religious background" was announced here today by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University.

A new type of contact lens to replace eyeglasses -- fitting only over the pupil and kept in place by the elastic force of the eye itself -- was described yesterday to the Brooklyn Optometrical Society.

You walk across the rug, scuffing, then touch someone. Sparks! That's static electricity. It's a problem with the newer synthetic fibers. To cut down this tendency to build static the Dexter Chemical Corporation has introduced a product called Lektrostat, a new type of chemical agent used to process fabrics made of the fibers.

It is inevitable that in the current observance of National Heart Week some considerable stress should be laid upon the malign importance of heart disease in our society. It is certainly true that heart disease has become steadily more prominent as a major killer. It is, many persons feel, possibly the most outstanding challenge to science and progress.

The Abraham Straus branch department store, which is scheduled to open late this month in Hempstead, L. I., will employ 652 persons, and have an annual payroll of about $1,400,000, it has been announced by James H. Kahlert, vice president in charge of personnel.

Zinka Milanov's concert last night in Carnegie Hall was less in the nature of a vocal recital than a vocal exhibition. That is, she has a large following, many of which come not to hear her interpretations (which never are particularly imaginative) or her choice of music (which generally is quite conventional) but simply to bask in the glory of her voice, which can be one of the most thrilling to be heard today.

Immanuel Velikovsky, author of "Worlds in Collision," has a new two-volume work on Doubleday's list. "Ages in Chaos" is a re-examination of ancient Egyptian history from Exodus to the coming of Alexander the Great. The first volume, covering from Exodus to the reign of King Akhnaton in Egypt, will be published on March 27 and the second, bringing the study up to Alexander, is planned for May 8.

HANOI, Indo-China, Feb. 10 -- The French High Command here estimated today the Vietminh rebel losses for all Indo-China in December and January at 45,000 killed and wounded. The losses among troops of the French Union and the Vietnam Indo-Chinese were put at 5,135 killed, wounded or missing.
A 22-year-old mother was held in $1,000 bail yesterday on charges that she had put her 3-year-old daughter's hands above flaming gas jets to punish the child for playing with lipstick.

World-wide air transport is growing so rapidly as almost to take one's breath away. The International Civil Aviation Association reports that the movement of air passengers in 1951 was almost double that of 1947 and cargo movement by air more than tripled in four years.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 10 -- A French proposal offering a tentative solution of the problem of how to include the armed forces of Greece and Turkey in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was adopted today by the Standing Group, which agreed to submit it for a final decision to the North Atlantic Military Committee holding its first session tomorrow.
Stefan Apostolescu, an inventor, has designed a convertiplane intended for vertical ascents and descents and forward speeds between 400 and 500 miles an hour. An unusual safety feature is included.
What causes the demand for consumer credit to go up and down?

Arriving at the Booth soon is Cornelia Otis Skinner, a deft writer and actress, with her most ambitious one-woman show, "Paris '90." The premiere will take place Tuesday night, March 4. Forty-fifth Street then will have two outstanding solo entertainers, the other one being Emlyn Williams with his masterly characterizations from the works of Charles Dickens at the Golden.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 11 -- Stunned residents of the Meltzer Apartments at 652-58 Salem Avenue fled to the streets in their nightclothes earl this morning after the National Airlines plane had sheared off the roof of the three-story building with a roaring impact and turned a part of its top floor into a mass of flame.

MADRID, Feb. 10 -- The relation between church and state is the most complex of all the complexities of Spain. It is the prime example of the interplay of outward collaboration and inner conflict which makes this country so fascinating to explore and so hard to understand.
Several pertinent things that needed to be said were passed over by your correspondent Hussein K. Selim when writing his letter, "Clashes in Egypt," published Jan. 31.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- With great subtlety, Balenciaga cuts a sweater bodice that has only the faintest suggestion of a middy. It is fitted into the waistline in front, but down the back, where it buttons, it has considerable ease. He shows this silhouette in black crepe with a wide flat fold about the hips.

Admiral Alan G. Kirk, whose retirement as Ambassador to Russia was accepted last week by President Truman, has been elected chairman of the American Committee for the Liberation of the Peoples of Russia, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Eugene Lyons, retiring chairman, who will continue as a director of the committee.

Jon Otnes, Norwegian tenor, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The 33-year-old artist, who made his debut in the Oslo National Opera at 19, has concertized widely in Europe and South America, but had not been heard before in this country.

With only one session remaining in the 1952 Life Masters Individual contract bridge championship, David Warner of Philadelphia, continued last night to hold a commanding lead over an all-expert field of seventy-two players.
The Seafarers International Union's Atlantic and Gulf District, A. F. L., will begin paying today $2,500,000 in vacation money to its members.

CAIRO, Feb. 10 -- A military decree was issued today forbidding vessels of any sort, including the smallest craft, to pass under or approach within 200 meters of bridges over the Nile at Cairo between 6 in the evening and 6 in the morning.

Leaders of thirty civic and business groups, in a petition addressed to Governor Dewey and leaders of the State Legislature, urged yesterday that no new municipal taxes be permitted until the city government was made efficient and economical.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Segments of labor and agriculture represented by four strong organizations vigorously opposed Universal Military Training in Senate hearings today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Conrad E. Snow, chairman of the State Departments Loyalty Security Board, accused Senator Joseph A. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, tonight of trying to "smear the department" by resorting "to rumor, invention, half truths or no truths at all."

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 12 -- Communist negotiators at Panmunjom announced today that they were preparing a revised proposal for an international conference on Far Eastern affairs after the start of an armistice in the Korean war.

Benjamin Britten's opera, "The Rape of Lucretia," which had a brief Broadway run three years ago, was presented last night at Carl Fischer Concert Hall by Opera Futures, an enterprising opera workshop just completing its first six-week session.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Customs agents trained to recognize atomic bombs are keeping watch for enemy attempts to smuggle "unconventional weapons" into the United States.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Cabinet crisis threatened today over the issue of United States military aid to Indonesia.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- A $616,000,000 highway expansion program for New Jersey, partly financed by a 1 per cent increase in the gasoline tax and partly from Thruway tolls, was proposed tonight to New Jersey legislative leaders.

Expansion of credit sales through increased promotion of this store service, with the same techniques used in merchandising goods, would expand total store volume proportionately, 300 delegates to the ninth annual Northeastern Midatlantic consumer credit and collection conference were told yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The debate in the French National Assembly on the European army plan may puzzle Americans unless they recall the singular circumstances that gave rise to it. The first point to note is that, under tremendous United States pressure, projects for European unity have advanced faster on paper than in the minds of Europeans.

OSLO, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The five man International Olympic Executive Committee tonight withdrew from one battle of the "cold war" when it tossed the problem of German representation in the summer Olympics back into the laps of the Germans themselves.

The Marine Corps held its second blood drive yesterday at its headquarters at 346 Broadway, where officers headed by Maj. Carl Hoffman and enlisted personnel donated seventy pints of blood. One hundred and thirty volunteer donors appeared.

The thirteen Explorer Scouts who in the last few days have visited Washington, Philadelphia, West Point and this city in connection with the forty-second "birthday" of the Boy Scouts of America wound up their activities yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Facing a hostile house, Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, told the National Assembly today that it must accept the European army plan or have a West German army created despite French opposition.
TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- Legislative action was completed today to provide a Presidential straw vote at the April 15 primary election in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, said today that he hoped Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr. would run against him for the Senate.
The Brooklyn Federal grand jury is studying the income tax returns of James B. E. Olson, former Federal alcohol tax-supervisor for the New York District.

An "amicable" meeting between representatives of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., was held yesterday to discuss compromise terms that may save the system from liquidation by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman next Monday.

Newark Airport, often described as one of the safest in the world, was a ghost field yesterday. Closed at the recommendation of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey "because we could not afford to await the action of Federal authorities," there was no indication when, if at all, the huge airport might reopen.
Men who worked with the late Thomas Alva Edison gathered here yesterday to honor his memory on the 105th anniversary of his birth.
Ezio Pinza, former star of "South Pacific," may return to the Broadway boards next season.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 11 -- Shock followed by bitterness was the reaction today of this battered city and adjoining communities to the third air disaster here in less than two months.

Mayor Impellitteri will go to Albany today to seek $285,900,000 in increased state aid and taxes, and he is prepared to remain in the state capital the rest of this week, if necessary, in the interests of pressing for approval of his fiscal program.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- Organized New Jersey gasoline dealers voted unanimously tonight to close their stations in a price-war protest, after the State Assembly had rejected their proposal for a price freeze during study of their problems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- John W. Mays, White House doorman for almost forty-three years, has returned to duty again at Blair House.

ON Nov. 7, 1944, in a Tokyo prison, Japanese officials superintended the hanging of two of the most successful espionage agents the world has ever known. Both were spies in the service of Soviet Russia. One was a German, Dr. Richard Sorge, organizer and leader of "the Sorge Spy Ring." The other was a Japanese traitor, Ozaki Hozuni, Sorge's principal accomplice.

The annual luncheon and card party in behalf of the Catholic Big Sisters, of which Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy is president, will be given on Feb. 26 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The occasion will mark the fiftieth anniversary of the beneficiary.
MADRID, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Spanish, Foreign Ministry denied tonight that there was no religious freedom in Spain and said it regretted President Truman's attitude toward Spain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's Message to Congress today asking a two-year extension of the Nation's economic controls law:

A total of 3,000,000 persons live in the shadow of the four airports operated by the Port of New York Authority in New York and New Jersey, which handle more than 1,000 flights a day. To many of these people -- such as those in Elizabeth, N. J. -- this air umbrella is a cause of apprehension.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Royalties from patented medical appliances and medicines soon may be helping finance the education of America's medical students.

CAIRO, Feb. 11 -- Premier Ali Maher Pasha's office issued a statement tonight saying that the Army had denied charges made in the press by Fuad Serag el-Din Pasha, former Interior Minister, that it was responsible for the Cairo rioting two weeks ago.

BELGRADE, Feb. 11 -- The Communist party of Yugoslavia has discovered to its dismay and indignation that the state enterprises it created after the war in the name of Marxism have turned out to be monstrous little monopolies and cartels that are gouging the poor consumer.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb, 11 -- The North Atlantic Military Committee met today and approved all items on its agenda except one concerning its views of the Temporary Council Committee report, which will be discussed tomorrow.

SAPULPA, Okla., Feb. 11 (UP) -- Charles Hartman, vice president of the Sapulpa Board of Education, said today that some books in the Sapulpa High School library had been burned by the school after being criticized by a women's civic group for the way they dealt with socialism and sex.
The nation's largest mutual savings bank has joined the list of New York banks announcing plans to raise annual interest-dividends to 2 1/2 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11 -- A merchant marine cannot be delegated to other nations, "especially to those who would destroy it," L. R. Sanford of New York, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, declared today.

NEWARK, Feb. 11 -- Spokesmen for more than 4,000 veteran-owners of New Jersey homes poured an all-day string of complaints about substandard home construction into the ears of a five-member House investigating subcommittee here today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 11 -- With the blackened scars of two unsolved aviation disasters still painfully evident nearby, Federal, state and local officials set to work today to investigate the third air tragedy to hit this city in eight weeks.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The State Judicial Council renewed tonight its recommendation that the blue-ribbon jury system be abolished in New York, Bronx, Kings and Queens Counties.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Irregular price movements again were noted on the Board of Trade here in the grain futures markets today. In all pits there was a carry-over of selling from Saturday, with initial prices all substantially lower, rye suffering the heaviest declines.

Two classics and one contemporary composition were performed on the third Musicians' Guild concert of the season last night in Town Hall. Virgil Thomson's Four Songs, to text by Thomas Campion, formed the evening's premiere.

" A History of the Union League Club of New York City," written by the late Will Irwin and completed by Earl Chapin May and Joseph Hotchkiss, will be published Feb. 25 by Dodd, Mead. The book traces the course of the club from its foundation in the Civil War through its four sojourns in various parts of New York to its presnt Park Avenue site.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- With the exception of a few evening gowns, Gres abandons bodices of flattened Greek drapery, as well as her circular bias skirts. Bodices, still on the bias, are supple about the shoulders, with pushed-up kimono sleeves, but are tightly molded to the midriff.

Economic realities are stubborn things. Even in Stalinist-dominated countries these realities sometimes become so pressing that they force actions and admissions which give us a view of what lies behind the fog of obscuring propaganda. Recent events in Rumania provide a case in point.

Operations of Kroger Company, grocery chain, in 1951 resulted in an over-all net income of $12,657,940, Joseph B. Hall, president, announced yesterday. This includes a nonrecurring income of $3,545,000 representing profit from the sale and leasing back of the company's Cincinnati factory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The United States has indicated to Britain that it would be willing to allow British officials to test their experimental bombs in this country.
Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Thursday for an issue of $5,000,000 of notes dated Feb. 19 and due on Nov. 3.

The one-story taxpayer occupying the blockfront on the north side of Union Turnpike between 189th and 190th Streets in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by Sidney Weiderlight, operator, to investors represented by Jacob Rubin, attorney.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Recurrent rumors that France would devalue the franc in view of its declining unofficial market value in relation to gold and foreign currencies today provoked denial from authorized sources.

Early yesterday morning Harry Fishbein, long a New York contract bridge star, was declared winner of the 1952 Life Masters Individual championship. He had staged a whirlwind finish in the fifth and final session played here at the McAlpin Hotel to outdistance a field of seventy-two top-ranking bridge experts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Truman renewed his campaign for stronger anti-inflationary controls today as he asked Congress in a special message to extend the Defense Production Act for two more years, or until the middle of 1954.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The open hearings are being held on a bill to establish a single supply catalogue system for the national military establishment.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 11 -- West Germany made it clear tonight that it was not prepared to reduce the national level of consumption or endanger social security to pay for rearmament.

A colorful collection of objects for the home, imported from Yugoslavia is now available here. They may be seen from 11 A. M. to 8 P. M. until Feb. 22 in room 1224 of the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

These few are the days, and this the time of year, when the best walking is to be done at night. For a winters night, when the moon is full, provides the walker with the complete measure of things barely hinted during other days of the year.

One of the largest new construction programs to be undertaken by a Florida public utility was announced yesterday by the Florida Power and Light Company. Officials of the $200,000,000 power company said that plant expansion over the next ten years will amount to $332,000,000 to keep pace with Florida's fast growing population.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 12 -- Maj. George A. Davis Jr., who bagged fourteen enemy planes over Korea to become the greatest jet ace in the United States, was shot down Sunday and is believed to have been killed, the Air Force announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- For the second time within a week a Senate investigation of the Administration of Puerto Rico's first elected Governor, Luis Munoz Marin, was demanded today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Retail food prices dropped 0.9 per cent between Jan. 15 and Jan. 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. This was an unusually sharp change, with the fresh fruit and vegetable group showing the largest decline, or 4.3 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 11 -- Scandinavia is much to the fore in the European nuclear research center sponsored by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that will be formally launched in Geneva tomorrow.
