OSLO, Tuesday, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The women's giant slalom, scheduled to open the Winter Olympic Games Thursday, will be postponed until Sunday unless there is a sudden improvement in snow conditions on the Norefjell course, an official source said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Senate tonight passed unanimously a bill that would empower local officials to remove officers and volunteer members of fire departments on the grounds of incompetence or misconduct after a hearing.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Two movies with somber themes, "A Place in the Sun" and "A Streetcar Named Desire," dominated nominations Announced tonight for the twenty-fourth Annual Academy Awards.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- French and United States negotiators are agreed in principle on a formula for the exemption of United States defense expenditures from most forms of French taxation. Spokesmen for both Governments said they were "hopeful" that a formal accord could be reached by the end of this week.

The presidents of two non-scheduled airlines were among those who lost their lives yesterday in the third Elizabeth air crash. Their attorney, who was scheduled to make the flight with them, escaped the accident by taking an earlier Plane.

The death toll in yesterday's National Airlines plane crash in Elizabeth, N. J. -- the third there in two months -- rose to thirty-one last night. All the accidents occurred within an area of one square mile. The latest disaster resulted in the official closing of Newark Airport "until further notice."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Melvin J. Maas, former House member from Minnesota who recently went blind as a result of a disease of the optic nerve, received the Armed Forces Reserve Medal today for service to the Marine Corps Reserve during the last decade.

Cosmetics manufacturers have more to worry about than dreaming up such exotic names for their products as "My Sin," "Temptation" and "Tabu." One of their problems is computing ceiling prices, taking into consideration the part played by "advertising and promotion allowances."

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- The enemy Aggressor Force -- its target the industrial heartland of New York State -- scored gains of five to seven miles today in an all-out attack along the twenty-six-mile front.
Few men of his period deserved more of literature and learning than my old friend Edward W. Titus, who passed away on the morning of Jan. 27 at the age of 82.

New records in gross revenues, net income and volume of gas sold were registered in 1951 by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, according to the utility's annual report, issued yesterday. Gross revenues for last year totaled $52,298,971, compared with $41,365,528 in 1950, a gain of 26.4 per cent.

Proposals that the New York Stock Exchange undertake a modernization or replacement program for its buildings and equipment were advanced yesterday by Keith Funston, president, in his annual report. Such a program, he said, cannot be postponed much longer.

Although the pro Knickerbockers will occupy the spotlight this afternoon when they seek their fourteenth straight home victory against Syracuse at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, the college version of the game received all the attention at the weekly luncheon of the basketball writers yesterday.

The Brazilian cancer research center, which will stand as a memorial to Dr. Napoleao Laureano in his birthplace, Joao Pessoa, capital of the state of Paraiba, will be started next month and it is hoped that it may open its doors by next Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Foreign Minister of Spain during the Republican regime and now foreign editor of The Nation, was detained when he arrived on the French liner Liberte last Friday and taken to Ellis Island with his wife, it became known yesterday.

John J. Mann, a former page on the trading floor of the New York Curb Exchange, was re-elected chairman of its board of governors yesterday. Three of the four new governors elected with him started their financial careers in similar positions.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Republican legislative leaders decided this afternoon at a four-hour conference with Governor Dewey to defer any decision on New York's request for power to impose a separate county real estate tax pending further study of the subject.

The air crash in Elizabeth, N. J., on Dec. 16 was the second worst disaster in commercial aviation in the United States. That crash of a C-46 operated by the Miami Airline, Inc., claimed fifty-six lives.

The wartime past returned to La Guardia Airport yesterday as the city's first great beehive became the alternate terminus for Newark Airport, the metropolitan area's second-string field closed because of recent disasters.

If my memory is correct, THE NEW YORK TIMES has editorially blessed the United Nations experiment in setting up Libya as an independent nation. However, it has editorially criticized the Tunisians for pressing their own demands too fast and too far.

Nine school publications in eight communities have been named as winners of a contest conducted by the State Committee on Tubercuosis and Public Health of the State Charities Aid Association. The contest was for the best treatment of the subjects, "How Youth Can Help Fight Tuberculosis" and "What Our Tuberculosis Association Does."

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- The United Nations Commission on Germany, established by the General Assembly last December to investigate the possibility of holding free elections in both Eastern and Western Germany, including the Soviet and Western sectors of Berlin, held its first meeting today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Project Cirrus, the Defense Department's five-year research project in rainmaking and the artificial modification of clouds, will end July 1.

The International Cargo Handling Co-ordination Association, organized in London last fall to shorten the turn-around time of ships in port by improving cargo-handling techniques, will hold its first international meeting in Rotterdam and Amsterdam, the Netherlands, on April 21-23.

The Bonn Parliament has endorsed the European army plan by a good majority and pledged German cooperation as an equal partner in the defense of freedom and democracy but it attached to this vote a number of demands the precise meaning of which must still be ascertained.

WASHINGTON, Feb., 11 -- Charles E. Wilson, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, assured an audience of Georgetown University students tonight that "there is no cutback in the realistic production schedules" designed to achieve the original goals of the defense program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Immigration Service ordered today the deportation of Serge M. Rubinstein, Russian-born New York financier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Representative John E. Rankin, Democrat of Mississippi, termed as "utterly unfounded" today a charge that he put an "iron curtain" around-legislation to reorganize the Veterans Administration.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 11 -- Oklahoma's Republican convention accepted today a compromise on four delegates at large to the national convention. The compromise was reached by backers of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower, and the convention action avoided an open fight in state ranks.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Prices declined in all sections of the stock market here today. However, the falls were not heavy and industrial leaders closed fairly firm.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Hialeah, which has a mile-and-an-eighth track, tried something today. It put on a mile-and-a-sixteenth race for 3-year-olds -- the first contest at the distance since the oval was expanded to its present size. The start was down past the finish line, with the gate hauled back to a spot that allowed a run of a hundred yards or so before the horses went into the turn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will support grower prices of this year's corn crop at a national average of at least $1.60 a bushel.
BERLIN, Feb. 11 (AP) -- West Berliners trudged through a driving snowstorm to bank exchanges today to dump their East marks and as a result the Russian zone currency took another sharp dip.

The brothers Taylor -- Ralph and Milton -- reached reverently for ancient gallipots, chemist's crocks and time-darkened pestles and mortars yesterday in their apothecary's shop in the Barclay Hotel, East Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- Creation of a Metropolitan Rapid Transit Authority to build a new direct rail link with mid-Manhattan to ease the growing pressure of North Jersey commuters was proposed today by the New Jersey Regional Planning Commission.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was the heaviest in months, and the market closed barely steady 62 to 90 points net lower.

The fact that white will be especially important this spring was indicated in the opening of the Nettie Rosenstein designs at a luncheon-fashion show given by Saks Fifth Avenue in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Loss or damage during shipment to consumers causes an annual waste of $250,000,000 worth of goods, Henry H. Pratt, general traffic manager of Crucible Steel Company of America, said last night.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Four highway safety bills were approved unanimously by the State Senate tonight and sent to the Assembly for concurrence before they go to Governor Dewey for his signature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today it is "painfully aware" of costly "mistakes and errors" in military buying policies and added that it was doing everything possible to avoid wasting taxpayers' dollars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- The Government today granted Chrysler Corporation retail ceiling price increases ranging from $64 to $235 on its 1952 Plymouth, Dodge, De Soto and Chrysler passenger automobiles.
Criticism of the recent decision to retain Col. Earl H. Blaik as athletic director and head football coach at West Point has been fairly widespread, both at the Point and within the Army.

REPORTS from several refugees from northern blasts indicate that both salt and fresh water fishing in Florida seem to be reaching some kind of peak. Even the sailfish are plentiful and hungry, for a new record has been rung up in the Silver Sailfish Derby of the Palm Beaches.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 -- The Federal trial of fifteen California Communists bogged down in its fifth day today in a polite battle of legal technicalities that led the prosecutor to hazard that unless things were speeded "we'll be here until Christmas."

A report recommending 14.4 cents an hour increase for 11,500 employes of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Wood Ridge, N. J., made public on Saturday by Prof. Harry Shulman, chairman of a five-man panel investigating a labor dispute, was attacked yesterday by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation as "inflationary" and jeopardizing the framework of the free-enterprise system.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 -- President Juan D. Peron was reported today to have told provincial governors that they could expect a further decline in their authority. The states are to be deprived of more of their traditional autonomous powers in favor of a still stronger central government.
OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Wilf Lepine, 31-year-old Quebec City driver who captured the 1950 international sled dog derby, won the first heat in the 1952 three-day classic today.

OCALA, Fla., Feb. 11 -- An attempt to use an Elmo Roper public opinion poll as the basis for shifting the scene of the second Groveland rape case trial failed here today when Circuit Court Judge Truman G. Futch ruled that the survey violated established legal procedure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP) -- Leonard Decaux, former Congress of Industrial Organizations publicity director, refused today on the ground of possible self-incrimination to say whether he ever was a Communist.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that British Commonwealth countries chose to be called realms rather than dominions.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Senate passed and sent to the Assembly for concurrence tonight bill requested by the City of New York that would assure the permanent location of the Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island in the East River.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, in a tape-recorded talk, told the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors tonight that press speculation about Korean war negotiations could be modified to the advantage of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Oliver Edmund Clubb, formerly head of the State Department's Office of Chinese Affairs, was cleared today by the agency's Loyally and Security Board of charges that led to his suspension by Secretary Dean Acheson last June 27.

Business organizations with conventional marketing and distribution methods no longer can scoff at house-to-house canvassing. Edward L. Sard, executive director of the National Association of House-to-House Installment Companies, reported yesterday that house-to-house volume at retail now exceeded $1,000,000,000 annually.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- The New Jersey Legislature set up a legislative committee of six members tonight to study the Cause of disastrous plane crashes near Newark airport. Action on an Assembly resolution to create the group came after the third air tragedy in Elizabeth early this morning.

FEZ, French Morocco, Feb. 11 -- When one drives through the Moroccan countryside on a magnificent springlike day the contrasts between modern French achievements and Oriental Moorish beauties are accentuated.

Bidding syndicates were being formed yesterday for new issues of mortgage bonds of southern utility companies. Alabama Power Company is planning to come to market in April to raise $12,000,000. Georgia Power Company is expected to borrow $20,000,000 in July.

A 46-year-old teller who disappeared last Tuesday after an $8,347 discrepancy was discovered in his accounts at the Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank, 530 Fifth Avenue, surrendered yesterday to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The body of King George VI lies tonight in Westminster Hall, a part of the Palace of Westminster, where the mother of all parliaments sits. It was brought to London from Sandringham in the afternoon and borne through the cold wet streets on a gun carriage with the Dukes of Gloucester and Edinburgh walking behind with bared heads amid silent throngs.

An error which can lead to considerable misunderstanding crept into your dispatch from Geneva by Michael L. Hoffman under date of Feb. 6. Therein it is stated that whereas under the Brussels migration program the United States would bear only one-third the costs, under the McCarran plan "Washington would bear the whole cost."

It is nearly eighty-seven years since John Wilkes Booth, firing a pistol pointblank into the back of a man's head in a box in Ford's Theatre, Washington, thought he had killed Abraham Lincoln. The mortal body had breath for a few hours longer. The immortal part of Lincoln is as alive today as on the morning of his fifty-sixth birthday, on Feb. 12, 1865.

A syndicate headed by Louis Saritsky, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the eight-story thirty-two-family apartment house at 514 West 114th Street from the Melburn Realty Corporation, of which Frank Slater is president. The property, on a plot 75 by 101 feet, is assessed at $180,000. Rubin and David B. Solove were the brokers in the transaction, in which title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

UTICA, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., minority leader of the House of Representatives, said tonight that the United States at the end of the World War II lost the opportunity to become the architect of a peaceful era because some men were blinded by the lure of communism.

Yankee outfielder Gene Woodling yesterday accepted terms for 1952. Roy Hamey, assistant to General Manager George Weiss, also confirmed that the club had received the signed contract of Mickey Mantle, who disclosed last Saturday in Miami, Okla., that he had agreed to terms.

Sales declines and leveling-off of business volume in the early months of 1952 will be counter-balanced by a rise in general activity in the last six months of the year, according to Eli Shapiro, Associate Professor of Finance of the University of Chicago's School of Business.

Dollar sales volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended Feb. 9 was 14 per cent below that of the comparable week of 1951, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SANDRINGHAM, England, Feb. 11 -- The little villages around Sandringham returned to their ordinary pursuits tonight as the last visitors to the peaceful countryside around King George's estate departed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Paper supplies made available by fifteen of the nation's major daily newspapers should enable more than 800 of the nation's 10,000 weekly newspapers to continue publication, the National Production Authority announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that class I rail systems had a rate of return on property investment for the full year 1951 of 3.70 per cent, compared with 4.23 per cent in 1950.

Another opportunity -- probably the best yet -- is being offered to settle the costly Anglo-Iranian oil dispute. A mission from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, headed by the American vice president, Robert L. Gardner, arrived in Teheran yesterday to make a crucial attempt at a settlement.

It took the exploring fraternity four hundred and seventeen years after the discovery of America to discover the North Pole. For this discovery Admiral Peary was widely and rightly cheered. The year was 1909.

The American diamond market has been crippled by the operations of an international gold and diamond smuggling ring, Assistant United States Attorney Louis I. Kaplan charged yesterday at the arraignment of three alleged members of the gang.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 7 (By Airmail) -- A combination of American design, Mexican materials and craftsmanship and ancient Indian art have been brought together in a new collection of furniture produced here and destined for the high quality United States market.

For some mysterious reason the breeze blowing in Albany seems less favorable to acceptance of Permanent Personal Registration since publication of Dr. Robert F. Ray's report to Governor Dewey than it was before. This is illogical, because, as we read it, this report comes as close to being endorsement of P. P. R. as any factual study could be.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Melbourne Cricket Club refused today to permit the 1956 Olympic Games to be conducted in its vast stadium, and there is a possibility that Australia will lose the big international sports event.

If the depression in the textile industry, which has been going on for almost a year, continues much longer, it will cost other major sectors of the economy millions of dollars, the industry was warned yesterday.

SPOKANE, Wash., Feb. 11 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, on his first visit to this "inland empire" of the Pacific Northwest since 1947, told an audience of 3,100 persons here tonight that it was "just as easy to get to socialism by increased taxes as it is by the Government taking over industry after industry as in Great Britain."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Paul Graetz, French film producer, has Marlon Brando's name on a one-picture contract and at the moment is accompanying the actor to France aboard the Queen Mary. Brando is listed on the passenger manifest under the name of Sven Kalkie.
Robert H. Helle has been appointed technical superintendent of the Acrilan plant of Chemstrand Corporation, Decatur, Ala. He will direct process control and development at the plant.

Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., 1951 Wimbledon and Australian champion, was among the sixty-three players drawn last night for competition in the national indoor championship. The tournament will start Saturday morning at the Seventh Regiment Armory, with Mrs. Nancy Chaffee Kiner of Ventura, Calif. heading the women's list of twenty-five players.

The stock market ran against the usual pre-holiday influences yesterday and especially in view of the proximity to the week-end. The net result was a drift to the lower side. While the declines generally were confined to fractions, there were some gains and losses well in excess of a point.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 11 -- A total of 6,000 subscriptions will have been sold by the end of this week's campaign seeking to help restore the popularity of Broadway productions "on the road," it was predicted here following a progress report at a luncheon.
Wanted: Old boilers, rusting automobiles, trolley rails, odds and ends of junk metal.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Another episode in the unending pageant of British history was enacted today in Westminster Hall, whose storied walls have been the backdrop for more incidents in the life of this nation than bards and chroniclers can ever record.

HANOI, Indo-China, Feb. 11 -- Northern and southern stretches of the Tongking delta have replaced the Hoabinh sector as the main centers of warfare in North Vietnam. The French and Vietnamese forces have stepped up their counter-attacks against Vietminh delta infiltrations and are preparing additional clean-up operations.

Westminster, 76-year-old queen of dog shows, began its two-day run in Madison Square Garden yesterday with breed judging that blighted the hopes of many in a quality-laden field of 2,451 dogs but not of Dr. and Mrs. R. C. Harris of Santa Ana, Calif.

THE Norwegians had acted very smug and superior about it right from the start. After all, you couldn't blame them. They had meteorological tables by the bushel to prove their point and support their claims.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Feb. 11 -- A merchant in this South Shore village who advertises a "going out of business" sale must go out of business, or be fined for violating an ordinance that went into effect here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The fears and hopes of a valley that some say is destined to become the "Ruhr of America" were laid before the United States Corps of Engineers today in a hearing on the project to deepen to forty feet the channel of the Delaware River from the Philadelphia Navy Yard to Newbold Island, five miles south of Trenton, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Salary Stabilization Board today issued General Salary Order No. 11 setting out in legal form the policy on health and welfare plans adopted by the board in a recent resolution.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. made public today samples of a revised version of the Old Testament, the third authorized Protestant revision in 341 years.

Major securities and commodities exchanges throughout the United States will suspend operations today in observance of the Lincoln Birthday holiday. The only domestic markets to remain open will be those dealing in livestock. Canadian and British markets of all types will operate as usual.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 12 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,156 for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

Sweethearts or anyone with a sweet tooth would be happy at Altman's this week. A candy fair on the store's main floor is making Valentine shopping fun as new confections have their debut and old favorites are reintroduced.

A long-pending primary fight by the DeSapio leadership of Tammany Hall against Robert B. Blaikie, insurgent leader of the Seventh Assembly District, on Manhattan's upper West Side, was formally started yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Wild tribal rioting over Iran's elections took nine lives at Zabol, near the Afghan border, Saturday, before troops clamped martial law on the area, an Army spokesman said today. The spokesman said thirty-five had been injured.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -- The United States Government renewed legal efforts today to retain ownership of American President Lines, a $68,000,000 shipping concern.
Long Island Rail Road commuters will be cheered to know that those coaches in which they spend so much of their time are due for a bit of brightening up.

Aggressive buying sent cocoa higher yesterday on the Cocoa Exchange. After a weak start trade covering, mostly technical, came in and then producer interests began buying in deferred months. Prices closed 17 to 35 points higher on futures volume of 402 lots.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Swiss authorities tonight predicted new avalanche disasters in the Alps as Europe's death toll from slides and record snow storms reached 69.

The New York Rangers will be seeking a tie for fourth place in the National Hockey League when they meet the Boston Bruins in Madison Square Garden tonight. A victory for the Blues will give them the necessary 2 points to deadlock the Hub contingent for the last play-off berth.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The Assembly today approved and sent to the Senate legislation extending for another year Governor Dewey's loyalty program for weeding subversive employes out of the state service. The vote was 125 to 18. All the negative ballots were cast by Democrats.

The day is past when an inferior product can achieve more than temporary success with a big advertising and merchandising appropriation, the country's leading marketing and advertising executives were warned yesterday.

LEE SAVOLD, the most ferocious fighter since Tarzan slew his first lion with his bare hands, will put Rocky Marciano to the supreme test in Philadelphia tonight for the benefit of the television customers. The once billowy bartender earned the right to meet the rock-fisted Rocky by getting himself knocked out by Joe Louis in the sixth round.
BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California told the Republican party tonight that it must move forward "in the spirit of evolution and progress" or be doomed permanently to minority status.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Abdul Fattah Amr Pasha, Egypt's Ambassador to London, who is coming here from Cairo to attend the funeral of King George VI, will meet Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden tomorrow to discuss the resumption of negotiations on the British-Egyptian treaty dispute.

MIAMI, Feb. 12 -- Woolford Farm took the money, Greentree Stable got a bit of encouragement and Belair Stud ran into a disappointment in a $4,000 purse for 3-year-olds that headed Hialeah's hacing program today. Hialeah always keeps an eye on the calendar; the purse was named the Emancipator.

Fashions for juniors, as usual, cover the wide range of school-girl clothes at low prices and sophisticated styles at all prices. More than ever, designers are telling the world, with their spring creations, that juniors are a size range, not an age group.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The American Federation of Labor has renewed its full support of the International Labor Organization and accused certain representatives of management in this country of misrepresenting the organization and of making "irresponsible charges against it."

The famous Oliver R. Barrett collection of Lincolniana, to be auctioned next Tuesday and Wednesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, went on public exhibition yesterday. All through the day and into the evening a steady stream of visitors filtered slowly through the galleries, pausing and eddying around the historic relics.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (UP) -- A heavyweight title fight may go to the winner of tomorrow night's Rocky Marciano-Lee Savold bout here, Promoter Herman Taylor indicated today after a telephone conversation with Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board virtually closed the door today to transatlantic air service by independent or non-scheduled airline operators.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Legislation was introduced today to clear the way for establishing the birthplace of Walt Whitman, the poet, as a state historic shrine. The bill, introduced by Senator S. Wentworth Horton, Republican of Suffolk, would authorize the state to accept the Whitman homestead on Long Island as a gift from the Walt Whitman Birthplace Association, which now has title to the property.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Army announced today the posthumous award of the Medal of Honor to Sgt. Cornelius H. Charlton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Charlton, 873 Marcy Place, the Bronx, N. Y. He is the second Negro and the forty-first soldier to have been awarded the Medal of Honor during the Korean conflict.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 13 -- United Nations delegates at Panmunjom today awaited presentation by the Communists of a new proposal for recommendations to be made after the armistice by the military commands to the governments concerned for an overall settlement of Korean problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- A church spokesman charged today that Universal Military Training was being planned in an atmosphere of "hysteria" and would lead the United States into "economic slavery."
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- American industry was urged today to adopt a "get-tough" policy with labor to win back equality at the collective bargaining table.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 12 -- A cooperative program to increase the number of qualified college graduates entering public school teaching was announced today by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University. Dr. Conant made the announcement on behalf of the Harvard Graduate School of Education and twenty-one cooperating Eastern colleges.

The four-story building at 5002 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, containing seven stores and fifteen apartments, has been sold by M. Jakobowski to an investing customer of Hussey Hoeh, brokers in the transaction. The property is assessed at $60,000.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- "Profit is a good word, a clean word, an American word," says Richard M. Crooks, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- With buyers cautiously fearful of the impending budget, small, scattered selling pressure had the effect of lowering most prices on the stock markets here today. Unfavorable trade reports hit textile issues particularly, while the bulk of leading industrials were lower where altered.

MANILA, Feb. 12 -- President Elpidio Quirino submitted a balanced national budget to the Philippine Congress today. It was made possible by new taxes imposed last year and by United States assistance in agricultural and economic reconstruction.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Stan Musial of the Cardinals today got his back pay for 1951 -- a check for $20,001.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 12 -- The Social Christian (Catholic) Cabinet was defeated today in the Chamber of Deputies, the lower house, on a motion of censure that, in effect, blamed the Government for King Baudouin's declared intention not to attend the funeral of King George VI. The vote was 91 to 84, with one abstention.

The New York City ballet last night opened what is technically its tenth season at the City Center since its beginnings there in 1948. Obviously these engagements come too close together to be considered as seasons in the conventional sense, and it is, accordingly, more accurate perhaps simply to say that the company is once again in residence.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 -- The Detroit Public Library wag exhibiting today a letter from Abraham Lincoln to Henry J. Raymond, founder of THE NEW YORK TIMES, purchased for the library's Lincoln collection at an auction Feb. 2 in the Parke-Bernet Galleries in New York.
Behind only once during the game, Manhattan College's basketball team turned back its intra-city rival, City College, 72 to 54, in their thirty-second meeting last night at the Fordham gymnasium.

TOKYO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway protested sharply today against the "unwarranted" Soviet seizure of nearly 200 Japanese fishing boats in the waters off Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, the Republican floor leader, accused the Truman administration today of prolonging in Korea "the most hopeless conflict in American history."

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development offered Iran a face-saving plan today to get her $1,500,000,000 oil industry rolling again. It appeared the hard-up Iranian Government might be willing to talk business.
BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following forecasts and lists of winter sports conditions:

OCALA, Fla., Feb. 12 -- The second Groveland rape case trial began here today before an all-white jury that heard a 19-year-old white farm wife identify Walter Lee Irvin as one of four Negroes who criminally assaulted her in 1949.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- A Socialist caucus in the National Assembly proposed tonight that all decisions regarding a European army be postponed until Jun 1, when the new Disarmament Commission of the United Nations is to report, and that a new appeal be made to Britain to join the projected European defense community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Dr. Calvin B. Spencer, chief quarantine officer for the Port of New York since 1948, today was appointed chief of the Division of Foreign Quarantine of the Federal Security Agency's Public Health Service.

Controller Lazarus Joseph, in a report to the Board of Estimate and the City Council, said yesterday he expected that the city's general fund revenues during the current fiscal year would be $802,000 more than he had estimated last spring but that the carry-over on June 30 would be the smallest since 1943.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 12 Trinity College disclosed today that the fund raised for its gravely injured football captain, Billy Goralski, had been far over-subscribed, and it thanked the 1,583 individuals and organizations contributing to it.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12 -- Brazil intends to send two observers to the international economic conference in Moscow in April on the ground that Russian markets are important to Brazil and that such a move implies no friendship for the Soviet Union.

The world-wide struggle between statism and freedom is a drama in which all persons are actors and there is no place for idle spectators, Charles H. Tuttle declared yesterday. The president of the National Republican Club spoke at ceremonies marking the 143d anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln. The Civil War President was honored by members of the club and other groups at his statue in Union Square Park.

The city's radio station WNYC received an award for "public service in music" yesterday afternoon as it opened its thirteenth American Music Festival, which will run until Washington's birthday and will include more than 100 programs.

The Defense Production Act is scheduled to expire by statutory limitation on June 30, and Congress will shortly be considering a measure for its extension. In anticipation of this President Truman has addressed to that body a message dealing with the requirements of such legislation.

ROME, Feb. 12 -- The Vatican has moved swiftly to implement the exhortation that Pope Pius addressed to the Catholics of Rome Sunday when he urged them to bring about a "mighty reawakening of Catholic thought and action."
Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland denounced corruption in the Truman Administration in a speech last night here and declared that "this is the last year of the mink dynasty in Washington."

With traffic and income of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority up to new highs for 1951, George E. Spargo, general manager, found it "easy and pleasant" yesterday to report a "successful year" to Robert Moses, chairman, and members of the Authority.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 -- Pilgrims from over the country visited Springfield today to observe the birthday anniversary of Abraham Lincoln who is buried beneath a white shaft north of the city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph M. Dawson, in his testimony today on Universal Military Training, said he appeared for 16,000,000 adult church members.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12 -- A new Latin-American labor confederation organized under Peronista leadership and designed for "joint action against capitalist imperialism" is being formed at a conference at Asuncion, Paraguay.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 12 (UP) -- The State Mental Hospital reported today that its ousted chief clinical psychologist, a brilliant "case" man who wrote textbooks, had also written his own credentials as a doctor.

The nation's steel mills turned out 9,120,000 net tons of raw steel during January, the highest ever achieved in any month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Last month's output topped the previous monthly peak, established in October 1951, by almost 4,000 tons.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- It is the firm policy of the British Government to work for an increase of two-way trade between Canada and the United Kingdom, according to Peter Thorneycroft, president of Britain's Board of Trade.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Holiday, the attraction that will re-open the house as a first-run motion-picture showcase is "Return of the Texan," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama featuring Dale Robertson, Walter Brennan and Joanne Dru.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 12 -- A Chinese Nationalist invasion of the mainland from Formosa was held out tonight by Senator Robert A. Taft as the only chance of stopping a Communist assault on Southeast Asia. Such an attack by the Communist forces, he said, was "on the horizon."
All three local baseball clubs came up with signers yesterday, the Dodgers leading with Edwin (Duke) Snider, their coveted center-fielder.

Watch for some advertising on shoes to break at the trade and retail levels. One industry trade group, perhaps hinting what's to come, is preparing a design contest for footwear. Most persons in the industry are convinced the time is ripe for heavy advertising.

The Squadron A trio, paced by Phil Brady, turned back Westbury, 14 to 3, as play started last night in the annual Sherman Memorial handicap polo tournament at the Squadron A Armory. Brady helped himself to six goals as his teammates, Joe Schwartz and George Haas, accounted for four each.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson flew to London tonight in an effort to salvage his policy of bringing the West Germans into the defense of Western Europe. He may go from there to Bonn to see the West German leaders before flying on to Lisbon, Portugal, for the meeting of the North Atlantic Council Feb. 20.

Comdr. George W. Stedman Jr., a master mariner who turned Coast Guard officer ten years ago, has taken over as captain of the rescue cutter Tamaroa, relieving Comdr. W. Keith Thompson, the service announced here yesterday. Commander Thompson has been named to attend the Armed Forces Staff College, Norfolk, Va.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- A state code of military justice applicable to those in the National Guard, Naval Militia and Air National Guard was proposed today by the Joint Legislative Committee on Military Law. Most provisions of the proposed code parallel those in the Federal Uniform Code of Military Justice adopted lats year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, said today he thought newspapers in the United States had "admirably discharged their enormous responsibility." He spoke at the closing session of the Inland Daily Press Association's sixty-eighth winter meeting.

OSLO, Feb. 12 (UP) -- The feuding factions of East and West Germany were ordered today to resolve their differences over representation in the 1952 Summer Olympic Games at Helsinki and select one team to march under one flag after competitive tryouts in Berlin Stadium.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- John A. Diemand, president of the North American Companies, reported today that assets, surplus and premium writing of the insurance companies soared to new highs in 1951.

CAIRO, Feb. 12 -- Deputies of the Wafd party, which holds an overwhelming majority in both houses of Parliament, met this afternoon in the midst of rumors of political crisis and voted to continue their support of the Government of Premier Aly Maher Pasha.
OSLO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Perspiring Norwegian soldiers put the Olympic ski courses in fair shape today and the winter games will be open on schedule Thursday despite the lack of good snow.

Sapulpa, Okla., a town of some 13,000 people, has had its library collection investigated and five or six books in its high school library burned because "they just weren't good reading for teen-age children." What the books were we have no way of knowing because no records were kept of the authors or titles.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12 -- The independent peasants of Serbia are once again in a state of ferment -- this time as a result of the confiscatory taxes imposed by the commissions that have been ruthlessly carrying out the Government's new agrarian policy.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,157, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

The New York Knickerbockers turned back the Syracuse Nationals, leaders of the Eastern division of the National Basketball Association, 78 -- 69, yesterday at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory before 4,000. The triumphs extended the Knicks' home victory streak to fourteen.

With 47 per cent of its assets invested in the United States, the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada reported yesterday total assets at the end of 1951 of $1,666,000,000, an increase of $68,000,000 during the year. New insurance sold during the year amounted to $461,000,000, while benefits paid to policyholders totaled $125,000,000.

Rejection by the United States of any attempt to defeat restitution by West Germany to Jews harmed by Germans was urged yesterday in a telegram sent by seven major Jewish organizations to Secretary of State Dean Acheson. The organizations were the American Jewish Committee, American Jewish Congress, American Joint Distribution Committee, B'nai B'rith, Jewish Agency for Palestine, Jewish Labor Committee and the World Jewish Congress.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Congress was told today that public and private power groups in the Southwest have tentatively agreed to a contract for an integrated power set up in that area.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Plans for what is hoped will be the final reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have been completed, and the choice of the man to head the international staff has narrowed to Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister for External Affairs, and Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador in Washington.

PARK RIDGE, N. J., Feb. 12 -- Directing a spirited campaign throughout Bergen County to obtain support for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's nomination as the Republican party's candidate for President is a former military aide of the general, attractive 41-year-old Mrs. Stewart Alexander of 108 Pascack Road, this town.

Individuals and organizations concerned with the education and welfare of pre-school children are meeting this week to decide their stands on a bill now under consideration in Albany that would require the registration and certification of private nursery schools and kindergartens.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Residents of Thomas Paine's home community here are beginning to appreciate him anew. Commuters, housewives and merchants are discovering that their homes, stores and streets are on Paine's old 300-acre farm, where he wrote, fought, imbibed and barely escaped assassination, and where, at the end, his body was kidnapped from his grave.

The Soviet Government is reported by General Ridgway to have seized nearly 200 Japanese fishing vessels plying their trade off the northern shores of Japan. Of these 114 have been released, but twenty-nine have been confiscated and thirty-three have disappeared without a trace.

Richard Savitt stepped from a United Airlines plane at La Guardia Field yesterday, glad to be back after the disappointments and controversies of his trip to Australia with the Davis Cup team. He was met by his mother and went to his home in Orange, N. J., where he will rest until the start of the national indoor tennis championships Saturday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12 -- An open break has occurred between Lieut. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, Chief of Army Engineers, and the Mississippi Valley Association, powerful twenty-three-state resource development organization, because of the association's opposition to the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company told the Federal Power Commission today it will raise the price of its natural gas on Feb. 20. Panhandle sought commission approval of the rate increase, estimated to bring in $24,000,000 a year additional revenue, in an application Sept. 20. Since the commission has not acted on the request during the five-month waiting period required by law, Panhandle now may put the increase into effect.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 -- Counsel for the fifteen Communists in the nation's second major Smith Act trial asked today that the Government's case thus far be stricken from the record as an irrelevant exploration into the dim and legally inadmissible past.
The 1952 Nash-Healey sports car, incorporating American engineering and European styling and construction, was announced yesterday by the Nash Motors division, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation.

The importance of maintaining the essential ethical basis of all religious belief was stressed yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, New York City Superintendent of Schools, in an address to 1,500 teachers attending the silver anniversary luncheon of the Jewish Teachers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, said last night that the nation had lost confidence in the Truman Administration.

ALONG the New Jersey coast from Sandy Hook to the tip of Cape May the word is passing from surfcaster to surfcaster that "Mackey rides again" to lead the sports fishermen in their effort to re-enact the "no netting law" for striped bass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, won prompt and unanimous endorsement today by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee for the post of Director of Price Stabilization, succeeding Michael V. DiSalle.
Mayor Impellitteri may be called before the Queens County Grand Jury to explain what plans he has to protect residents of that borough from the hazards of low-flying planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb 12 -- President Truman will send to the Senate this week the nomination of W. John Kenney to be Administrator of the Mutual Security Agency, which has charge of economic aid to friendly free nations resisting Communist aggression.

Consolidated net earnings of the American Cyanamid Company last year were $34,788,000, equal to $8.08 a common share, Kenneth C. Towe, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary financial statement. The net profit compares with $33,739,000, or $8.99 a share, for 1950.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Counterpoint, the "horse of the year" in 1951, today was declared out of racing for an indefinite period because of injuries received in the runnnig of the Santa Anita Maturity on Feb. 2.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Mourning for King George VI has been a blow to British entertainment business. Several American performers and a major American motion picture have been affected by the general disinclination to go pleasure-seeking before the King's funeral.

MERIDA, Spain, Feb. 12 -- For three days a cattle fair has drawn animated throngs of town and country folk into Merida's main street, the Calle Santa Eulalia, and filled the two pleasant squares at either end. Last night the crowd consisted mostly of young people.

Well-known persons in the diplomatic and political worlds, as well as members of society, are interested actively in plans for the entertainment, known as the Carioca Ball, which will be held on the night of Feb. 21 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event will raise funds for the establishment of a cancer hospital and research laboratory in Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Federal Judge James R. Kirkland today acquitted Steve Nelson, Pennsylvania Communist leader, of contempt of Congress but called him "either the most famous or the most infamous Communist that ever roamed" the United States.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 12 (UP) -- A former German Medical Corps general now working for the United States Air Force today demanded an investigation of what he called "Communist-inspired" charges that he had committed war crimes.

Phyllis Curtin, in her second New York recital last night at Town Hall, had three types of accompaniment. For her Bach arias she had a violinist and a harpsichordist, for her standard selections a pianist and for Villa-Lobos' Bachianas Brasileiras eight 'cellos.

Retail gasoline dealers in New Jersey began a state-wide strike yesterday in an effort to bring about price-fixing legislation they are seeking as a result of recent price wars, mostly in the northern counties.

The United States Maritime Administration will take under advisement at a meeting in Washington this morning a proposal of Hoboken, N. J., to turn over to that city six Government-owned piers that have been points of controversy for many years.

In a way it is good to know that the days are getting longer. The sun is setting an hour or so later than it did back in the middle of December, when in the metropolitan area it could be seen to drop below the horizon at the indecently early hour of 4:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

DAVID WALKER'S third novel, "The Pillar,"* is a story about English officers in German prison camps. Mr. Walker is a Scotsman and knows whereof he writes. He was a prisoner for nearly five years himself and participated in three unsuccessful efforts to escape. He is a writer of considerable skill who has made steady progress with each of his books.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Monte Irvin, Negro leftfielder for the New York Giants, said today that a Soviet statement that deceit and bribery of voters had cost him election to the New Jersey Legislature last November was "just a big laugh."

This is Negro History Week. It is the one week when everyone, regardless of race, should pause and reexamine the past history and present problems of Negroes in Africa, in the Americas and throughout the world.

Annually the California Fig Institute, a nonprofit grower organization, proclaims February as Fig Month. It is a "celebration" in which Eastern housewives might well participate, for this is the season when the dried fruit is in best supply in local markets.

Fenimore House and the Farmer's Museum in Cooperstown, N. Y., both operated by the New York State Historical Association, have provided the documentary material for the newest collection of rugs, fabrics and wall paper designs made by F. Schumacher Co. The copies are available through decorators at the concern's showroom, 60 West Fortieth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Flashing one of its top performances of the campaign, the Yale quintet rolled to an 81-57 triumph over Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate League clash on the Payne Whitney court tonight.

A tire industry leader called yesterday for removal of the Government ban on production of white sidewall tires, saying it was causing black markets and could no longer be justified by shortages of natural rubber.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 12 -- Reinforced teams of Civil Aeronautics Board investigators struggled today with the evidence, locked in twisted steel, that may explain the cause of Elizabeth's third air disaster. Townsfolk watched them at work, grimly determined that whatever the outcome, Newark Airport must remain closed.

Government and airline officials agreed last night to keep Newark Airport closed, pending Congressional and other investigations, and set up a joint fifteen-member committee under Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Airlines, to increase the safety of airline operations over cities.

TRENTON, Feb. 12 -- State Senator Malcolm Forbes and other active supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower have collected 30,000 signatures of New Jersey voters who want the General to be President. But now the Senator finds his Eisenhower-for-President Club will have to do the job over again, if the name of its candidate goes in the state Presidential preference primary.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Mayor Impellitteri, with City Controller Lazarus Joseph standing beside him, announced here tonight that New York intended to impose a new $5 and $10 automobile use tax and a 25 per cent surtax on state retail liquor license fees, starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Truman was quoted by a Democratic member of Congress today as having said that his personal inclination was not to seek re-election, but that he might "sacrifice" his health and run again if he felt his candidacy would serve the cause of world peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, proposed today that the right to cross-examine those who make charges be granted to individuals named in the House Judiciary subcommittee's investigation of the Justice Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Chancellor John P. Myers, a Plattsburg banker, was renominated by both houses of the Legislature today for a second term on the Board of Regents, which is the supervising authority for all education in the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The overlapping of Federal tax increase bills, already causing many unexpected headaches as individuals file their final returns on 1951 income, promises to produce even more anguish a year from now.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Feb. 12 -- The commercial explosives plant being constructed here by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will consist of fifty buildings spread over 400 acres of the 1,200-acre tract purchased by the company in the Falling Waters-Bedington section along the Potomac River.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (UP) -- The defending champions, Bea McWane of Birmingham, Ala., and Robert Sweeny of Palm Beach, coasted to an easy victory in the first round of the Everglades mixed foursome golf tournament today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 12 -- The Southern Regional Education Board announced today that it had received a $100,000 grant from the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching to promote graduate education through inter-institutional programs involving universities and the facilities of Government agencies and industry.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 12 -- The furious political debate and public clamor in West Germany arising originally out of the quarrel with France over the Saar has had one important effect. A number of questions whose importance transcends the Saar issue have been brought into the open and their significance both for Germany and for all of Europe has been re-emphasized.

ARDSLEY, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- Every crime except murder is committed by runaway boys from Children's Village in adjacent Dobbs Ferry, Police Chief Henry Raab of Ardsley charged today in asking for state and county investigations of the institution, which cares for 400 unadjusted boys l0 to 17 years old.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Several new steps toward de-control of business and commercial rents in New York City were approved tentatively today at a meeting of the Temporary State Rent Commission headed by Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, Putnam Republican.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Senator Joseph Zaretzki, Democrat of Manhattan, announced today that he had ordered the drafting of legislation to bring the selling of reservations for non-scheduled airplane flights under state regulation.

HEADQUARTERS, U. S. Fifth Air Force, Korea, Feb. 12 (AP) -- An Air Force spokesman today defended the policy of keeping all jet pilots -- including aces -- in Korea until they had finished their normal tour of 100 combat missions.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The long sweater bodice, always nipped into the waistline, is the theme of Lafaurie's collection of spring clothes. This theme, with or without a belt or drapery about the hips, suggests the lowered waistline. The sweater bodice of a slim two-piece in shepherd's check with large starched white lapels, the striped pique blouse outside the skirt of a blond tobacco linen suit recall the proportions of the "twenties."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A nationally known church leader today urged an unemotional study of problems resulting from relations between the state and the church.

The Hellenic Realty Corporation has sold the four-story apartment house accomodating thirty-five families at 22-26 Henry Street in Palisades Park, N. J., to the Henry Street Corporation. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Sidney Cohn for the seller and Harold L. Sanford for the buyer.

In a transfer begun at midnight, aides of the House subcommittee investigating tax frauds shipped four cartons of confidential files yesterday from their office in the United States Court house at Foley Square to their headquarters in the House Office Building in Washington.

The 100-year-old green-and-white clapboard cottage at 313 East Fifty-eighth Street housing the Humane Society of New York was the scene of a protest meeting yesterday over the Metcalf-Hatch Animal Research Bill.

It is heartening in the face of growing public resentment of relief recipients to find that one leading newspaper is concerned about the essential inhumanity of opening relief rolls to public inspection.
Leonard R. Tanner has been appointed treasurer of Railway Express Agency, succeeding the late W. H. Johnson. Mr. Tanner has been assistant treasurer since 1937.

Tossy Spivakovsky, remarkably in the vein last night, proved once more in his Carnegie Hall appearance that he belongs among the choicest of violinists before the public today. His playing through a balanced and differentiated program had the polish of a master of the craft.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 12 -- head of smoke that resembled the upswept hair-do of a prim old lady rather than the familiar "mushroom" rose in a cloudless sky here today in a successful test of a simulated atomic bomb.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) -- A defense official testifed today it had been impossible to develop a "satisfactory" centralized military buying system partly because defense orders were regarded as an answer to unemployment and "a lot of social problems."

Most of the New Jersey Turnpike was built by contractors who countenanced sweatshop wages and hours, Frank J. Muench, regional director of the wages and hours and public contracts division of the United States Department of Labor, said yesterday.

An anonymous gift of $150,000 to Barnard College was announced yesterday by Dean Millicent C. McIntosh in her sixth annual message on "The State of the College." The money will be used to renovate Milbank Hall, built in 1899 and badly in need of repairs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- A musical edition in Technicolor of the old stage hit "Rain" which brought the late Jeanne Eagles her greatest theatrical success in 1922, is being planned by the Wald-Krasna unit. "Miss Sadie Thompson" is the title for the projected film, which Jerry Wald will produce from a script yet to be written.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Richard J. Gray, president of the American Federation of Labor's Building and Construction Trades Department, suggested today a labor-management mutual assistance pact to resist what he called the encroachments of Government on private enterprise.

Following the popular trend to soluble coffee, ten of the smaller roasters throughout the country have formed a new corporation to make the "quick" beverage in a million dollar plant at Linden, N. J. Three of them are the old New York coffee houses of Albert Ehlers, Inc., Arnold Aborn, Inc., and Joseph Martinson Co., Inc., The new company is called Tenco, Inc.

At 28, John H. McMillin is positively the only young man in the world who was born in Basehor, Kans., which was named after his great-great-uncle; installed dental equipment and acquired a wife in Guam; is now in the second year of a retailing course here, and is relaying his studies by airmail to the wife, who plans to open a bigger and better version of their 4-year-old department store in Agana within two months.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced today record net earnings for the year ended Dec. 31, 1951.
The present is a very critical time for the Adirondack Forest Preserve for several reasons.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Escapade, 72-foot yawl owned by Wendell Anderson of Detroit, moved into the lead in the Miami-Nassau race tonight as the fleet of nineteen sailing craft approached Great Isaac Light.

Selection of a "blue chip" delegation to the Democratic National Convention from New York County was completed yesterday by Carmine G. DeSapio, Tammany leader. Designating petitions to carry through the formality of electing the delegation at the April primary will be put in circulation later this week.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Communist forces slammed twelve unsuccessful attacks against Allied troops yesterday and suffered at least 250 casualties, 220 in one action, the Eighth Army reported today.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 12 -- Irate Bergen County householders, at a seven-hour session here today, detailed their complaints of faulty construction of Federally aided private homes, attributing much of it to a lack of proper investigation by inspectors of the Veterans Administration and Federal Housing Authority.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 12 -- West Germany's capacity to pay for defense in the first fiscal year of the European defense force has been fixed at about 11,000,000,000 Deutsche marks ($2,619,100,000), an Allied official disclosed today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 10 -- Production of potash at the Dead Sea works is "on the eve of resumption," Levi Eshkol, Minister of Agriculture and Development, disclosed last night in a speech at Haifa. He said production would be "on a much larger scale than carried on by the old enterprise."

An encouraging development in television this season is wider use of the medium for essentially educational or informational purposes. More is being done than might be realized both by the networks and cooperating organizations.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Thousands of British people walked past the catafalque on which the body of their King lay in Westminster Hall today. At times the line, four abreast, stretched one mile. The queue outside Westminster Hall in the palace yard was already long when the double oak doors opened as Big Ben chimed 8 A. M.

Starting at 7:45 this evening at the Century, first nighters will scan "Venus Observed," Christopher Fry's modern play in blank verse, starring Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer. On subsequent nights, the curtain will rise at the normal time, 8:30.

Secretary Acheson took off for Europe yesterday on a critical mission. He will represent President Truman at King George's funeral and attend the Nato conference at Lisbon, but his chief task will be the delicate one of acting as a moderator in the Franco-German disputes.

NEWPORT, R. I., Feb. 12 -- Miss Rhoda Low of Washington and Bristol, R. I., and Col. Consuelo Andrew Seone, U. S. A., retired, of Washington were married here in historic Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church this morning. The Rev. James R. MacColl 3d, rector of the church, performed the ceremony in the presence of a few close friends.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President and Mrs. Truman led the nation today in traditional ceremonies honoring the memory of Abraham Lincoln on the 143d anniversary of his birth.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 12 -- The chiefs of staff of the member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization adjourned today until Monday with what military circles described as a "reasonable and feasible plan that places on a firm basis the rearmament program of the West."

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 12 -- The United States and Mexico, after their third meeting in negotiations for a military aid agreement, were reported today to be "within sight of an accord" that would enable Mexico to begin receiving aid under the Mutual Security Act.

Commercial airliners flew in and out of La Guardia Airport yesterday at the rate of one every three minutes. The closing of Newark Airport, after the third major accident in near-by Elizabeth in two months, has meant that La Guardia is having its heaviest traffic in several years, but the 12-year-old airport is not having any trouble with the added volume.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The doors of Westminster Hall, where King George VI lies in state, swung shut at 1:45 A. M. today (8:45 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern Standard Time) after 76,246 mourners had filed past.

The sharp light of national prominence fastened upon a 26-month-old Doberman pinscher last night in Madison Square Garden. He was Champion Rancho Dobe's Storm, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Len Carey of Greenwich, Conn. The choice of best in show that made him the dog of the year was the high moment of the seventy-sixth Westminster Kennel Club competition.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 13 -The Liberal and Socialist Opposition walked out of both houses of Parliament today, blaming the Social Christian (Catholic) Government for King Baudouin's decision to absent himself from the funeral of King George VI on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The United States sold $4,000,000,000 more in goods to foreign countries than it bought from them in 1951 and United States foreign trade in general broke all records.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, brought suit for a million dollars today over political stories appearing in The Charleston Gazette the last two days.

Organized protection for the American flamingo has been assured by the formation of a conservation group in the Bahamas, John H. Baker, president of the National Audubon Society, said yesterday. The bird, one of the most beautiful in the world, is a native of the Caribbean, being chiefly found in the Bahamas. Its feathers are predominantly rose-pink, with black tips visible in flight.
The National City Bank of New York became the first of the large commercial banks in this area to announce an increase in interest rates on thrift deposits yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- The pit operations in grain futures on the Board of Trade here today were again on the choppy, nervous order. Prices were higher in the early trading on buying by export interests in corn, and by both exporters and mills in wheat, with some general commission support on the announcement of higher support prices for the 1952 crops of corn, soybeans and rice.

Institutions for women and girls should have women as superintendents, according to a resolution the National Conference of Superintendents of Women's and Girls' Correctional Institutions adopted yesterday in closing its twenty-third annual meeting, held at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

The pages of an illustrated book have been brought to actuality in an exhibition that opens today at Bonnier's, 605 Madison Avenue. The book in question is the handsomely illustrated "Contemporary Swedish Design," edited by Sven Erik Skawonius, a designer, and Arthur Hald, art historian, and just published by Pellegrini Cudahy.
Governors of the New York Curb Exchange held their forty-second organization meeting yesterday and elected James R. Dyer to be vice chairman of the board, succeeding Charles J. Kershaw.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Department of Defense said today that 816 Army officers and enlisted men previously listed as missing in action were now on the Korean prisoner list. Their families have vouched for the authenticity of letters from enemy prison camps.

St. John's University and St. Bonaventure, rated among the outstanding quintets in the nation, will meet tonight in the feature of the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. In the second game New York University will oppose Niagara.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The United States and French Governments have reached virtual agreement on a new formula that may greatly speed up the lagging construction of air bases, communications lines and other military facilities needed by General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the defense of Western Europe.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Jockey Steve Brooks and the Calumet Farm racing stable parted company today at Santa Anita Park.
Princeton dealt a severe blow to Columbia's hopes of retaining the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League crown by beating the Lions, 70 to 63, at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 14 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,159, for Wednesday's operations:

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- A bill that would authorize a census among automobile owners to determine the extent to which automobiles are protected by liability insurance went halfway through the Legislature today. The Senate acted unanimously on the bill and sent it to the Assembly for concurrence.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Indonesia's biggest political party, the Masjumi (Mohammedan) party, today rejected acceptance of United States aid under the Mutual Security Act.

Telephone wires in New Jersey hummed with 7,000,000 calls a day during 1951, the annual report of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company showed yesterday. This record volume of telephone conversations was accompanied by a 17,000,000 rise in toll and long distance calls for the year.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 13 (AP) -- First shipments of damp grain from the western provinces to go to Duluth, Minn., for drying in bond and storage will move next week-end, A. F. Dollery, chief of the Board of Grain Commissioners, inspection braneh, said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- Rocky Marciano, unbeaten Brockton, Mass., contender for the world heavyweight title, scored his thirty-ninth ring victory and his thirty-fourth knockout when he battered game, battle-scarred Lee Savold of Paterson, N. J., into submission tonight in the seventh round of what was to have been a ten-round bout at Convention Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Technicians and decorators handling final details of installations and arrangement of furniture were the only remaining workers today in the Conference Building of the United Nations, which will be opened to the public for the first time on Feb. 27.

Rudolph Halley, City Council President and Acting Mayor during Mayor Impellitteri's fundraising expedition to Albany, called on the city's business men yesterday to take a greater part in politics and government and help put municipal activities on a businesslike basis.
In many apartment houses the milkman, having placed bottles before doors in the same corridor, collects 1 to 1 1/2 cents a quart less from one housewife than from her neighbors.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth and J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan, N. J., excelled in today's quarter-finals of the mixed foursomes golf tournament at the Everglades Club.
More than 200 Puerto Ricans, crammed into flimsy cubicles in an illegally remodeled tenement at 4 West 104th Street, were ordered yesterday to vacate the building within ten days.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The stock markets here remained quiet today with prices still tending to slip. Losses, however, were small except in the case of German bonds, in which prices fell heavily on forecasts of the claim the German delegation will put forward at the debt conference at the end of February.
The following booklet, published recently, is primarily for farm households, but it contains information to city and suburban families as well:

Fordham will continue athletics, including football, as long as its teams are properly supported, the Very Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of the university, told 1,000 members of the Alumni Association at their ninety-eighth annual dinner at the Biltmore Hotel last night.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 14 -- United Nations and Communist staff officers agreed during their meeting at Panmunjom yesterday to exchange their war prisoners within sixty days after an armistice in Korea and came closer to an acceptable designation of "ports of entry" where neutral representatives would stand guard against the importation of new weapons and supplies for a military build-up during the truce.

George A. Butts, president of Winslow Bros. Smith Company, Boston wool merchants, and Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, were elected trustees of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company and directors of the Centennial Insurance Company at the annual meeting of the Atlantic Companies held here yesterday.

The field of the statistician is limitless. Detailed figures on hijacking are offered in the current issue of the Business Report, a semimonthly magazine published by Business Reports, Inc. Truck thefts, the publication says, are running at the rate of $65,000,000 a year, compared with $45,000,000 in 1949 and $30,000,000 in 1947.

BIG-GAME anglers, once they have been incurably infected by the virus, are restricted in their quest for big fish only by the boundaries of their bank balances, and this season these pilgrims seem to be headed for a new angling shrine off the coast of Talara, Peru.

Because his seven Eskimo dogs and honey bear cub howled and snarled in Sutton Place Tuesday night, David Irwin of Milford, Pa., an animal exhibitor, has been ordered to appear today in Mid-Manhattan Court on a charge of cruelty to animals.

As departmental budget hearings for the next fiscal year closed yesterday Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson announced that the city was "over the hump" in making the necessary savings to balance its current 1951-52 budget.

Failure of the Civil Aeronautics Board to grant the Council on Student Travel authority to act as a temporary indirect trans-Atlantic passenger air carrier will pose a difficult problem for student groups plannning to go abroad in June and return in September.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A force of 190,000 Reserve officers and enlisted men, or 70,000 more than last year, will undergo two weeks of field training this summer, the Army said today.

The Schools Motion Pictures Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organzation composed of teachers and private elementary and high school, recommends as suitable 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation has authorized payment of the usual quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share on March 10, it was announced yesterday. An extra dividend and a quarterly dividend of $1.25 each were distributed in December, last.

One dark night nine years ago Matylda Maria Najder slipped into a rowboat on the river Wisla, just a whisper ahead of the Nazis. She was trying to escape from Warsaw and the Gestapo who, a year before, had killed her husband, her parents, her sister and her brother-in-law before her eyes.

An investor bought from the Life Realty Corporation the five-story apartment house for twenty-seven families on plot 30 by 100 feet at 111-13 Lee Avenue, Brooklyn, through Citadel Realty, Queens brokers. The building contains two stores and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $50,000. Murray S. Selby was the attorney for the buyer.

Stockholders of the New York Central Railroad Company at their annual meeting in May will be asked to approve the merger of seven wholly owned subsidiaries with the parent organization. The company said the action was being taken in order to bring about a further simplification of the Central's capital structure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration disclosed today that the agency was laying off 900 employes across the country and might have to allow seventy-five new navigational aids to remain idle because of a shortage of funds.

Carnegie Hall, during rehearsals of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, has always been barred to outsiders, except for a privileged invited few. The musical explorations toward perfection have been conducted, traditionally, in an atmosphere of ment was abandoned for the first time.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Escapade, a 72-foot yawl owned by Wendell Anderson of Detroit, pushed into Nassau Harbor tonight to be the first of nineteen yachts to finish the fourteenth annual Miami-to-Nassau race.

SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 13 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury ending an eighteen-month investigation of soldier training schools in Northeastern Pennsylvania today indicted five men on charges of conspiring to defraud the Veterans Administration.

The recent emergence of communities that have mushroomed as a result of national defense needs has intensified activities of the National Urban League, devoted since 1910 to furthering equal economic opportunity for Negroes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Truman appeared to be enjoying himself immensely today as he continued to muddy the waters for those seeking to learn his 1952 political plans.
TOKYO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Japan is laying plans for a friendly economic partnership to get raw materials from Southeast Asia which she once tried to take by force of arms.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The Duke of Windsor, who returned here today to participate in a state ceremonial for the first time since he abdicated from the throne in 1936, went tonight to the bier of the brother who succeeded him, King George VI.

HEADQUARTERS, Fifth Air Force, Korea, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The United States Fifth Air Force has lost nearly twice as many planes as it has shot down since the beginning of the Korea war, but the losses are "not high in comparison to what is being accomplished," Lieut. Gen. Frank F. Everest, commander of the force, said today.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Presidents of the eight Ivy Group colleges have voted 6 to 2 in favor of abolishing spring football practice, a reliable source reported here today.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- One hundred and fifty committeemen representing the fifty-seven posts of the American Legion in Westchester County approved unanimously a report of its Americanism Committee dealing with Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N. Y.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Legislation to permit savings banks to invest up to 5 per cent of their assets in preferred and common stocks and to authorize the organization by savings banks of investment companies was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Fred Preller, Republican of Queens.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 13 (UP) -- New snow avalanches thundered down Alpine mountainsides in Switzerland and the Austrian Tyrol today, boosting the winter's accident death toll to seventy-five. Fresh snows throughout the area threatened more avalanches.

In "Venus Observed," which opened at the Century last evening, Christopher Fry is in a pensive mood. He describes it as a play for autumn, as "The Lady's Not for Burning" was a play for spring. On the whole, spring is the more becoming season to a man who cascades words and phrases torrentially.
