The third stage of the reactionary movement by the stock market was brought into focus yesterday as prices cracked the previous low of last week and came within easy striking distance of the December rates.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Allegations that political persecution is rife in six Latin-American countries and that imprisonment and torture are being used to eliminate opposition there were made today by the International League for the Rights of Man, which submitted a protest to United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie, as well as a request for an inquiry.

The United States is still handicapped in its relations with other nations by "a hangover of isolationism," James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday at the opening of the eighth annual course for teachers given by THE TIMES in cooperation with the Board of Education.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Mayor Impellitteri derided today as "real estate propaganda" reports that New York's proposed county real estate tax would occasion hundreds of thousands of rent increases. He added that he would press for power to impose the levy regardless of its effect on rents because he regarded it as a "fair tax."

Congress is rapidly approaching a point where it will have to take a positive decision on one of the most important issues it has faced since the war. The principle of universal military training and service was endorsed by Congressional action last year, but the time has now come for acceptance of a specific program to put it into effect.

The reported split between the Army and the Mutual Security Administration on the terms of awarding contracts abroad for goods manufactured under the foreign-aid program may be extremely difficult to settle to either side's complete satisfaction. Acting under the Benton amendment, which would encourage "where suitable" the free-labor movement in foreign-aid countries, the Security Administration has made it clear that these contracts should not go to plants or industries in which the unionists are Communist-led.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council is ready to approve the announced terms of a proposed revision by Peru of a dollar debt settlement which Peru put into effect five years ago over the objections of the Bondholders Council.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Legislation to permit savings banks to invest up to 5 per cent of their assets in preferred and common stocks and to authorize the organization by savings banks of investment companies was introduced in the Legislature today by Assemblyman Fred Preller, Republican of Queens.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council is ready to approve the announced terms of a proposed revision by Peru of a dollar debt settlement which Peru put into effect five years ago over the objections of the Bondholders Council.
The Canadian Province of British Columbia is entering the American market today for a second substantial long-term borrowing of American dollars in seven months.
Alexander G. Evans has been appointed assistant national sales manager for the receiver sales division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc.

A 65-year-old widow, with $58,000 in the bank, went to jail yesterday rather than put up $1,000 in bail. She had been arrested on charges of trying to pilfer a woman's scarf, some frozen smelts and a package of cheese -- worth $2.45 in all -- from Macy's.

OSLO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The sixth winter Olympic games will open tomorrow with the women's giant slalom at Norefjell and the first two heats of the two-man bobsled event in the Frognerseteren Hills over Oslo.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange had another busy day yesterday, and prices at the close were 4 points lower to 30 points higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Italy, in a memorandum to the State Department, has warned the United States that recently imposed tariffs on European goods are canceling out the Administration's efforts to restore the economies of friendly European countries.

Sales of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company for 1951 increased 10 per cent over the previous year, but earnings declined under the impact of higher taxes, increased costs and price controls, according to the annual report, released for today.

The Treasury announced yesterday its decision to refund the $1,023,568,350 of 2 1/2 per cent bonds called for payment on March 15 into an issue of 2 3/8 per cent bonds maturing on March 15, 1959, and callable on March 15, 1957.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense acted today to stave off a threatened fuel-oil shortage along the Eastern seaboard north of Norfolk, Va. The agency announced it had made an agreement with twelve oil companies to get 3,000,000 additional barrels of heating oil into the area by March 31, to forestall a shortage.

A manpower study for a Senate subcommittee on labor-management relations estimates that by 1960 some 1,500,000 farm workers will be displaced by chemical and labor-saving devices. According to Dr. Francis Joseph Weiss, special consultant to the subcommittee, the number of farm workers, including operators, win fall from the 1950 level of 9,320,000 to 7,785,000 by 1960.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Miss Jane M. Hoey, Director of the Bureau of Public Assistance, decried today charges of "relief chiseling" in the program for aid to dependent children.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Representatives of five small manufacturing concerns testified today they have suffered heavy losses on defense contracts.

In its first two and one-half years, the rehabilitation program for excessive drinkers among employes of the Consolidated Edison Company has reclaimed 52 per cent of them, Dr. S. Charles Franco, associate medical director of the company, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Barring a sharp change in the international picture, cutbacks in the production of passenger automobiles, refrigerators and other consumer goods will not go below levels fixed for the second quarter of this year, Henry H. Fowler, head of the National Production Authority, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General H. G. Morison denounced "fair trade" laws today as a "cloak" for noncompetitive price fixing on brand-name products.

HONG KONG, Feb. 13 -- As Red China prepared to celebrate the second anniversary of the Chinese-Soviet alliance tomorrow, the Peiping radio reported tonight that Mao Tse-tung, head of the Communist regime, had hailed "the great, ever closer friendship" between the two Communist powers in an exchange of congratulatory telegrams with Premier Joseph Stalin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A plan that, if accepted, would give Hoboken, N. J., lessee rights to six Government-owned piers and bring about rehabilitation and use of the valuable property by the Port of New York Authority was outlined at the United States Maritime Administration here today.

An "award of merit" to the American motion-picture industry for its production of "outstanding" and "constructive" films during 1951 was presented yesterday on behalf of thirteen national organizations that maintain film previewing and estimating committees.

Rallying after a sluggish first period which saw them yield two goals, the New York Rangers subdued the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Bill Cook's athletes looked very much like a sharp outfit in the second and third frames, and had little trouble taming the New England crew by the score of 6 to 2.

Two new films writ arrive in town today, "Lady Possessed," a romantic melodrama featuring James Mason, June Havoc, Stephen Dunne, Fay Compton and Pamela Kellino, is at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux. William Spier and Roy Kellino directed and Mr. Mason produced the Republic release from a script by Miss Kellino and Mr. Mason and the novel, "Del Palma," by Miss Kellino.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 13 -- The Federal Government is watching closely the attempt of Otto Strasser, an early Nazi who broke with Adolph Hitler and fled Germany, to return secretly to this country.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 13 -- The Western Union Telegraph Company today was permanently enjoined from sending race horse or gambling information over its lines in Michigan. The company consented to the injunction, handed down by Ingham County Circuit Judge Marvin J. Salmon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, cautioned today that if there was any premature price decontrol of important cost-of-living items, the federation would be compelled to reconsider its participation in the wage stabilization program.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- A parade of teachers, business men, policemen, parents and state employes told the Legislature's fiscal leaders today what they thought of Governor Dewey's record-breaking $1,092,760,000 budget.
COLUMBUS, Ohio., Feb. 13 -- The church could make a major contribution to world peace by strengthening its own program of mutual aid to peoples everywhere, Dr. Emory Ross of New York said here today.

PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 14 -- After a debate that threatened to upset the Western European rearmament program a week before it was to be submitted to the North Atlantic Council in Lisbon, Premier Edgar Faure today staked his Government on the National Assembly's approval of the European army plan.

American investment in Israel is "urgently and vitally needed" for the development of the country and to help solve the economic crises in Israel, Aaron Weisberg, general representative in the United States and Canada for Solel Boneh, a large Middle East industrial and construction company, said here yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 7 -- Italy foresees that she will be hard hit by the cutting in half of the sums that British tourists may spend abroad and by the recent decision of the French Government to reduce imports drastically.

THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Feb. 4 "France Comes First" deserves to be pondered by all security-minded Americans, because it points up the fact that the Allies must not take for granted the surface indication that German political leadership is willing to cooperate sincerely with the West.
More than $4,000,000 in cash assistance was obtained illegally by welfare clients last year, Philip Sokol, counsel to the Welfare Department, disclosed yesterday.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Feb. 13 -- A Congressional subcommittee carried its investigation of defective and improper construction of veterans' homes into the Suffolk County area today. Shop was set up in the Bay Shore Memorial Building when quarters in the County Welfare Building proved too small to accommodate the throng of more than 250.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Small and medium-size chemical concerns are jeopardizing their chances of getting scarce materials by their failure to make known their 1952 requirements to the National Production Authority, officials of that agency said today.
The controversy surrounding the contract demands of the United Steelworkers is rapidly approaching the day of the final showdown.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- When and if sovereignty is bestowed upon West Germany through contractual agreement with the Western Allies, West Berlin, which will retain its occupation status, will be "neither fish, flesh nor fowl," one Allied observer remarked today. "But there seems little else we can do about it now," the official added.

THE novel of understatement is rare enough to make us look twice at a good example of it when one comes along. We have the chance in Thomas Hal Phillips' "Search for a Hero," a book with a quiet, uninsistent integrity, a compelling story that never exhorts us, never shouts -- though what it has to say is deeply concerned with war and other scarcely less lethal conflicts of man.

The State of Alabama announced yesterday that it will offer on Feb. 28 an issue of $25,000,000 of road and bridge bonds dated April 1, 1952, and due April 1, 1954 to 1969. The bonds are callable in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Truman pledged the United States today to continue work for a treaty for Austria that would enable her "to stand as a free and independent nation."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- Two movie companies now are developing pictures about different periods in the history of American railroads.

Three Lithuanian fishermen, who set out last July ostensibly on a fishing expedition and escaped from one of the strongest sectors of the Iron Curtain, arrived here yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

George Harmon Coxe, author of twenty-nine detective novels since his first appeared in 1935, was elected national president of Mystery Writers of America, Inc. The announcement was made yesterday by the organization, which has a membership of 350 that includes most of the best known mystery story writers of the country.

A new program for airline operations at LaGuardia and New York International (Idlewild) airports, which would bring planes in and out over Bowery and Jamaica bays as much as possible, will be put up to twelve major airlines by a six-member subcommittee tomorrow.

A new work by William L. Shirer, "Mid-Century Journey," will be published by Farrar, Straus Young on April 22. The author of "Berlin Diary" presents his reappraisal of the European scene, discussing what has happened to Western Europe in the quarter century since his first experience as an American foreign correspondent.

I was glad to read the letter from William Lescaze commenting upon a prior letter from Harvey Stevenson on the subject of sculpture and murals as part of a well-rounded building design. This subject was raised with the Department of Public Works of this city some time ago by the Municipal Art Society during my incumbency as president.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Cornell's basketball team defeated Harvard, 69 -- 44, in Barton Hall tonight to continue unbeaten in six Eastern Intercollegiate League games. It was Harvard's sixth straight loss in the Ivy circuit.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 -- In vestigation into alleged irregularties in the San Francisco office of the Bureau of Internal Revnue developed along five lines here today.
The Reserve Officers Association's annual award for distinguished services to the armed forces was won yesterday by the New York Regional Blood Program of the American Red Cross.

Universal Military Training -- one of the most controversial and least understood measures in our recent military history -- was once again the subject of discussion last week by both House and Senate Armed Services Committees.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson arrived in London today and started promptly to meet with the civilian chiefs of the United States' constantly growing political and economic operations in Europe, most of whom were also in London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, said today that the Federal Government was about ready to take new action to speed up copper production in Michigan. He said the Defense Minerals Procurement Agency had agreed to guarantee the Copper Range Company a premium price of 25 1/2 cents a pound for the output of its White Pine mine in Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Western Europe's arsenals, in which the United States has invested millions of dollars for mutual defense, are about to quadruple the value of their contributions, President Truman told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Federal Communications Commission has postponed until March 10 a hearing scheduled for Feb. 25 on the application of the motion picture industry for a closed channel in the ultra-high-frequency band of the radio spectrum to be used to carry televised entertainment to theatres.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 -- Economic and fiscal reforms covering a wide range of affairs were announced to the Knesset (Parliament) today by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion. The measures, adopted by the Cabinet Sunday after four weeks of discussions are designed to check inflation, stimulate the flow of foreign capital and goods to Israel, and increase productivity.

Ernest A Gross; Acting Chief of the United States Delegation to the United Nations, said today that the United States would have specific proposals to place before the United Nations Disarmament Commission, "including a program of disclosure of

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Dr. Bruce D. Forsyth, Chief Dental Officer of the Public Health Service, said today that fluoridation of drinking water to prevent dental decay was "the most remarkable public health preventive developed in this country."

The country's mortgage and credit market is now "dominated by Government," savings bankers were told yesterday. Speaking at the fourth annual savings bank conference on operations, audit and control at the Commodore Hotel, Gordon F. Christie, assistant vice president of the Bridgeport, Conn., Peoples Savings Bank, noted that there were about forty agencies in Government engaged in lending activities.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Mainly as a result of rising rearmament costs and generally higher price, Parliament was asked today to provide an additional u121,043,260 [nearly $339,000,000] for the British Government during the current fiscal year ending April 1. As usual, Parliament will grant the increase.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The National Farm Labor Union, A. F. L., asserted today that the United States had reneged on its pledge to the Mexican Government to stamp out the traffic in wetbacks and that a bill passed by the Sentae ten days ago was inadequate to redeem that pledge.

After Ambassador Stanton Griffis' visit to President Truman there appeared in the Feb. 9 issue of THE TIMES the following: "Envoy says President is aware of need for bases despite dislike of Franco regime."

At this time forty states allow the sale of colored margarine. A year and a half have passed without federal margarine taxes, licenses or restrictions; the price of margarine has gone down and down, and yet the demand for butter continues so that prices have gone up, and sales generally are high.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- The Pretender to the Russian Throne, Grand Duke Vladimir Kyrillovitch, appealed to the Western world today to unite with Russian and satellite exiles to overthrow communism by armed force.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- In its first formal note to all of the Big Four powers, Communist East Germany asked tonight that the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France sign a peace treaty with Germany to speed reunification.

Assistant Attorney General James M. McInerney said yesterday that the special Federal Grand Jury to be convened in Brooklyn next week would investigate not only the four former top tax officials already named but other present and past tax department officials as well as outsiders.

The 170-man wage policy committee of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., was instructed yesterday to meet in Pittsburgh next Thursday to decide how much time the union should give the Government to effect a peaceful settlement in the steel wage dispute.

Trade associations should provide facilities to study uses by their members of radioactive isotopes in manufacturing, Dr. Charles E. Crompton said yesterday. Formerly with the Atomic Energy Commission and now director of the radioactivity division of the United States Testing Company, he spoke at a luncheon of Trade Association Executives in New York at the Astor Hotel.

Newly painted traffic guide lines on city streets have been so badly smeared because they were inadequately protected that a large part of the work will have to be done over again. Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley, indignant at the "untidy mess," gave orders to workmen yesterday to sacrifice speed for neatness.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 13 -- Pressure was put on Senator Robert A. Taft by Oregonians at every opportunity today to persuade him to enter the Oregon Republican Presidential preferential primary of May 16.

Despite the opposition of Norman Thomas, Socialist party candidate for the Presidency in the last six campaigns, to the nomination of any party member for the post this year, the organization's national executive committee has tentatively named Darlington Hoopes, national chairman, as a candidate.

Soviet Russia is energetically promoting an "international economic conference" to be held in Moscow in April. The main talking point for this conference is that an expansion of East-West trade is not only "mutually advantageous" but is also the answer to the economic problems of the Western nations and may prove their salvation in case of an American economic depression which the Communists have long been. predicting and for which they are still waiting.

CAIRO, Feb. 13 -- The success of the present mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to Iran in getting the Iranian oil industry going again would mean serious trouble both politically and economically in the Arab world, in the opinion of oil experts and diplomats here.

More than 200 civilian defense workers, auxiliary police and firemen, operating in a 24-degree cold, staged a two-hour atom raid drill in the Inwood section of Manhattan last night as the weekly mandatory civilian defense exercise moved uptown.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 14 (AP) --United States Army censors today cleared twenty-three more photos taken inside a northern Korean prison camp by Associated Press Photographer Frank Noel, who is a captive of the Communists.

Mrs. William MacRossie gave a tea yesterday afternoon in her home at 850 Park Avenue for a group of women serving with her in behalf of the performance of the Easter show at Radio City Music Hall on the night of April 3 for the benefit of Woodycrest Children's Home here.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Commuters who have been pilfering nickels and dimes from the self-service newsstand in the New York Central Railroad station here were threatened with exposure today by George A. Williams, station agent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Salary Stabilization Board was told today that it should use "flexibility" in its dealings with baseball, and that bonuses paid to some young players should be exempt from pay ceilings.
TORONTO, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The first-place Detroit Red Wings defeated Toronto by 3 to 1 tonight to stretch their lead over the runner-up Maple Leafs to 12 points.

The House Ways and Means Committee is considering a bill on narcotics control so drastic in its scope that a ship or airline owner would be faced with confiscation of a vessel or plane if it were found to be carrying illegal narcotics.

As the controversy over vivisection continued in full swing yesterday, a group backing the Metcalf-Hatch Animal Research Bill was in the midst of an intensive drive to sign up pet owners to join the crusade.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 13 -- Israeli police and Ministry of Commerce inspectors have launched an all-out struggle against the black market, which now involves all the luxuries and most of the necessities of life.

Young Miss Monique de la Bruchollerie, a pupil of Isidore Philipp, now of this city, and a graduate with highest honors of the Paris Conservatoire, made a first appearance as pianist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the performance of Rachmaninoff's Third Concerto last night in Carnegie Hall, and reaped an immense triumph.

The Dodgers yesterday completed the signing of their roster of thirty-eight players when Captain Pee Wee Reese joined Pitchers Ralph Branca and Clyde King in returning his contract. All received boosts in pay.

General Eisenhower stood a few days ago in the Fountain Court in the Chateau of Fontainebleau and addressed prophetic words to 1,000 officers and men of six nations among the forces he commands in Europe.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 13 -- An explosion at 4:16 o'clock this afternoon demolished the Farmingdale Federal Savings and Loan Association Building, injuring ten persons, at least three of them critically.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- The armed services hope to put their final stamp of approval tomorrow on a money-saving plan to buy all their clothing through one central buying office.
On the editorial page of your Feb. 7 issue there appeared a letter signed by the Rev. Joseph N. Moody. The writer inferred that Christian Scientists were against the teaching of public health.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- According to reports from universities here, several British scientists have received offers many times higher than their present salaries to work in the United States. Although there is little evidence that the offers are being taken up at this stage, they are being considered carefully.

Young Miss Monique de la Bruchollerie, a pupil of Isidore Philipp, now of this city, and a graduate with highest honors of the Paris Conservatoire, made a first appearance as pianist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the performance of Rachmaninoff's Third Concerto last night in Carnegie Hall, and reaped an immense triumph.

The Dodgers yesterday completed the signing of their roster of thirty-eight players when Captain Pee Wee Reese joined Pitchers Ralph Branca and Clyde King in returning his contract. All received boosts in pay.

General Eisenhower stood a few days ago in the Fountain Court in the Chateau of Fontainebleau and addressed prophetic words to 1,000 officers and men of six nations among the forces he commands in Europe.

Lands bordering the Aegean and Mediterranean Seas, which in the past have produced objects rich in design, have inspired a new collection of hand-screened wallpapers. Fresh in theme and color, the group, called "Eastward Flight Wallpaper," was designed by Virginia Hamill for the C. W. Stockwell. Company of Los Angeles.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 -- Woodvale Farm's Boot All, a 4-year-old filly who has been promising to win a stakes race since the fall of 1950, finally followed through on the promise at Hialeah today. She won the $13,625 Columbiana Handicap for fillies and mares. She was the 6-to-1 fourth choice in a field of fifteen.
CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 13 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that President Truman was a "good man" but the "confidence of the American people" in the Federal Government must be restored.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- A treasure trove of birchbark letters and documents casting light on Russian life in periods as early as that of William the Conqueror (about 1027 to 1087) has been uncovered in excavations at Novgorod, once Russia's greatest city, according to reports of Soviet archaeologists.

In the hope of reducing the hazardous practice of "jumping the lights," the Traffic Department began yesterday its test of a new combined red-green light as a substitute for the yellow or caution signal commonplace elsewhere.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -- The Screen Actors Guild today won a signal victory in an agreement negotiated with the Independent Motion Picture Producers Association that recognizes the principle of additional payment for performers appearing in theatrical films later released for television exhibition.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 13 -- Aggressor enemy forces continued their powerful attacks, taking Gouverneur in the early dawn, as the joint Army-Air Force cold-weather maneuver, called Exercise Snowfall, reached a crucial phase today.

The automobile use tax proposed by Mayor Impellitteri was attacked as "obnoxious" by the Automobile Club of New York in a message yesterday to Governor Dewey and leaders of the Legislature. The club urged repeal of a law enacted in 1947 that permits cities in the state to impose such a tax and a retail sales tax on gasoline and motor fuel.

The Schulte Building, a six-story structure on plot 45 by 175 feet at 384-86 Broadway through the block to Cortlandt Alley, has been sold by D. A. Schulte, Inc., to Irving I. Rosenbaum and Samuel Levy in a deal negotiated by John J. Reynolds and the Charles F. Noyes Company, brokers.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 13 -- With the weather factor eliminated by the hospitality of Lawrenceville School in making available the matchless facilities of its new $2,000,000 Lavino field house, all manner of records were broken today in the fourteenth annual Polar Bear triangular track meet.

In the third and final Bach Aria Group concert in Town Hall last night, the program followed the general pattern set by the others. There were three soloists -- Eileen Farrell, soprano; Blanche Thebom, mezzo-soprano, and Mack Harrell, bass -- who appeared in two complete cantatas and a group of arias.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 13 -- New Jersey's strike of service station operators who locked their pumps Monday in protest against the refusal of state legislators to set a fixed price for motor fuel, ended suddenly tonight.
Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private transit industry, upheld yesterday the discharge by the Triboro Coach Company of Queens of five employes for stealing fares.

Five Ellis Island guards have been dismissed, one has resigned and twenty-six others face possible reprimand, suspension or dismissal, all on accusations of extorting fees from potential deportees for special privileges, including gambling and permission to use telephones off limits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Two armed forces associations clashed today over a proposal to allow Universal Military Training graduates to discharge their seven-and-a-half-year reserve obligation in three years by joining the Nations Guard or Organized Reserve.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 -- The defense in the Smith Act trial of fifteen California Communists aimed its first major counterattack today, seeking to undermine the testimony of the Government's first witness with insinuations of Federal corruption, taunts of bad memory and challenges to explain such Marxist concepts as dialectical materialism and surplus value.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 13 -- John D. Rockefeller 3d has given $250,000 to establish the Rockefeller Public Service Awards for outstanding service by civilians in the Federal government, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced today. Dr. Dodds will help supervise administration of the awards.

Fordham came back after two straight losses to down a scrappy Iona five, 64 -- 49, at the Ram gym last night. Sophomore Richie Guerin of the Gaels led the scorers with 21 points. Danny Lyons, freshman forward, was high for the Rams with 18.

OSLO, Feb. 13 -- Growing doubts on the part of Melbourne about its ability to play Olympic host in 1956 due to the lack of a suitable stadium appeared today to reopen competition for the honor. Chicago, Philadelphia and Los Angeles have all cabled their applications to the International Olympic Committee, now meeting here.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb, 13 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today lifted farther than ever before the curtain of secrecy surrounding some of its Oak Ridge installations. The commission conducted more than fifty newspaper and magazine writers and photographers and newsreel men on a tour of recently declassified areas of Oak Ridge National Laboratory, its chief nuclear research center.

After several months of rumors, the Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that Igor Stravinsky's new opera, "The Rake's Progress," will be presented there during the 1952-53 season. It will be the first new production mounted by General Manager Rudolf Bing, as well as the first contemporary opera that he has sponsored.

FOOTBALL fame is fleeting enough at best, particularly as regards linemen. They get lost in a tangle of arms and legs, rarely drifting out of the pile-up and into the headlines. But the fame of Wilbur (Fats) Henry of Washington and Jefferson has endured for some thirty-odd years and the prodigious feats of this gridiron superman still are mentioned with awe by old-timers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Another stormy chapter in the history of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation appeared in the offing today as W. Stuart Symington, stepping down as Administrator, delegated the job of running the agency to Leo Nielson, present R. F. C. secretary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Truman paid tribute tonight to Michael V. DiSalle, retiring Administrator of the Office of Price Stabilization, as one who had come to Washington in the defense program to prevent a third world war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- An editorial in this newspaper today, addressed to the Republican voters of New Hampshire, included the following paragraph:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Representative Teague, Democrat of Texas, indicated today the House Veterans Committee may try to do something about safeguarding veterans against buying shoddily built houses.
To the Swiss goes credit for three delicacies -- two types of superb cookies and tiny tinned mushrooms -- that are appearing for the first time on grocery shelves here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 6, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Cocoa provided a flurry of action yesterday in what was otherwise a quiet day in commodity futures markets. Prices rose the 100-point daily limit in the deferred deliveries and were only 2, 5 and 4 points below it for March, May and July. Volume was 257 lots.

The Museum of Modern Art Will open to the public today a double show of graphic art. Prints, posters and book illustrations present the immense diversity of Picasso's graphic output over fifty years. A comprehensive selection of the lithographs and drawings by Odilon Redon, the French symbolist and pre-surrealist artist from 1870 to the early Nineteen Hundreds, provides the material for the other half of this unusually interesting exhibition.
To the Swiss goes credit for three delicacies -- two types of superb cookies and tiny tinned mushrooms -- that are appearing for the first time on grocery shelves here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 6, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Cocoa provided a flurry of action yesterday in what was otherwise a quiet day in commodity futures markets. Prices rose the 100-point daily limit in the deferred deliveries and were only 2, 5 and 4 points below it for March, May and July. Volume was 257 lots.

The Museum of Modern Art Will open to the public today a double show of graphic art. Prints, posters and book illustrations present the immense diversity of Picasso's graphic output over fifty years. A comprehensive selection of the lithographs and drawings by Odilon Redon, the French symbolist and pre-surrealist artist from 1870 to the early Nineteen Hundreds, provides the material for the other half of this unusually interesting exhibition.

OCALA, Fla., Feb. 13 -- The defense in the second Groveland rape case trial presented today a private criminologist who, testifying as an expert witness, accused the state of having used planted evidence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A special investigation of an $80,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company showed today that "there was no fraud, collusion or illegality" involved in the 1947 transaction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A special investigation of an $80,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company showed today that "there was no fraud, collusion or illegality" involved in the 1947 transaction.

THE proposal that a six-day antlerless deer season be held next fall in part of the Adirondacks seems to have stirred up quite a controversy in several parts of the state, primarily from sportsmen who fear this may be a wedge leading to a general antlerless season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- The Screen Writers Guild will undertake to open immediate negotiations with the Independent Motion Picture Producers Association to discuss extra payment for scenarists in the case of theatrical movies released to television, Mary McCall Jr., president of the guild, today declared.

An immediate modification of the electrical wiring system controlling the reversible propellers of all four-engine DC-6's and twin-engine Convair-240's was ordered yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Administration as a result of the crash of a DC-6 in Elizabeth, N. J., last Monday.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Caribbee, 58-foot yawl owned by Carleton Mitchell of Annapolis, Md., won the slowest Miami-to-Nassau race in history on the basis of corrected time today.

Skiers will find improved conditions the next few days, thanks to the heavy snows that visited the major Eastern resorts the past week. Encouraging, too, is the prediction of continued cold weather. This means that the present covers will stand up on slopes and trails.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- It was "M. Jacques Ducreux," deputy from the Department of the Vosges to the French National Assembly who died in an automobile accident Feb. 1, but it is Jacques Jean Edmond Tacnet, still listed as an army deserter and suspected collaborationist, who will be buried.

CAIRO, Feb. 14 -- The United States Government's regional agencies dealing with the Middle East and the State Department's regional services are leaving Cairo. Most of them will go to Beirut, Lebanon, but one or two are expected to move to Athens.

H. K. Schnetter has been appointed administrative assistant to the manager of the Eastern district of the lamp division of Westingtonhouse Electric Corporation. C. N. Neumann has been named sales promotion representative.
Christmas giving is now behind us for a time but there is another kind of gift that most of us can still make without loss to self and with incalculable benefit to some other person or persons.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Mayor Impellitteri's $200,000,000 estimate of the city's need for additional revenues to balance next year's budget was under heavy pressure here today. Some representatives of the Republican state administration and the Republican legislative majority now believe it can be cut by as much as $100,000,000.

The steel industry wound up yesterday its case against union wage demands with a renewed forecast that granting the union program would touch off "another round of ruinous inflation which would hurt everyone."

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway has ordered a drastic cut-back in Army services and occupation privileges accorded foreign diplomatic missions, United Nations civil agencies, and other non-military groups in Japan, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Truman pointed today to the bipartisan character of his judicial appointments and said that he would not hesitate to appoint a Dixiecrat to a South Carolina vacancy if he thought the man would make a good judge.

LAICHAU, Indo-China, Feb. 13 -- Set in the bottom of a deep river gorge flanked by towering mountains, this primitive little village of Thai tribesmen is the focus for the net of resistance that so far has kept the whole vast hill country of northwest Tongking free of penetration by the Communist-led Vietminh forces.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The Metcalf- Hatch bill to permit the requisitioning of dogs and other animals for medical experimentation was attacked today as unconstitutional, socialistic and an attempt to dictate conscience.
An important traffic appliance manufacturer acted to meet price cutting yesterday and took positive action to stablize prices of its irons and toasters.

William F. Treiber, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has been appointed first vice president, it was announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, president. Mr. Treiber, whose appointment becomes effective March 1, will succeed Leslie R. Rounds, who is retiring.

Parents of emotionally disturbed children need not possess "a sense of doom and futility" about their children because disturbed children can be helped, although it may take quite a while before their behavior changes, Dr. Robert M. Gomberg, executive director of Jewish Family Service, declared last night.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- A large number of friends, both French and American, went today to the village of Blerancourt, near Soissons, to attend a religious ceremony in memory of Miss Anne Morgan, daughter of the late J. Pierpont Morgan and sister of the late J. P. Morgan, New York bankers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today shut the door on an opportunity to return to this country in advance of the Republican National Convention.
India's first dyestuff and pharmaceutical plant will begin operation next month at Bulsar, near Bombay, it was announced yesterday by American Cyanamid Company, partner in the venture.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Three defendants, including The Times of London, went on trial in the Old Bailey today, charged with corrupt practices in the British general election campaign last October. All three pleaded not guilty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Democratic foreign-policy leader of the Senate, Senator Tom Connally of Texas, asked that body today to demand a break in relations with Hungary and if necessary to refuse money for maintaining any United States mission there.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Grain futures on the Board of Trade today turned weak after being strong early, especially in the coarse grains which registered sharply higher prices at the start. On the recession wheat prices dropped to new lows for many weeks, and reflected a generally indifferent demand.
A policeman in Brooklyn's Canarsie area eyed curiously yesterday the large metal projectile that protruded from a dump truck in front of 1441 East Ninety-fourth Street.

In a rarely invoked legal procedure, a New York County grand jury that has been investigating Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh's four-year tenure as Commissioner of Investigation in the O'Dwyer Administration handed up in General Sessions yesterday a sealed preliminary report.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- There are 1,968,702 Republicans and 1,931,618 Democrats entitled to vote in the April 22 primary for the election of delegates to the national nominating conventions, according to an enumeration made public today by Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State.

Plans for a building to house the expansion program of the Imperial Cleaning Stores were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a plot of land of 80 by 115 feet at 204th Street and Jamaica Avenue, in Hollis, Queens, by Max N. Hurwitz to the A. S. W. Operating Company of Hollis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, has drawn up regulations setting forth the kind of work about 8,000 conscientious objectors must perform if they want to stay out of the armed forces.

Five boutique-like displays of spring accessories in the foyer of the Astor Hotel set the theme of the Fashion Group accessory luncheon yesterday. These prophetic displays included a group of green and white beach accessories, suit addenda in all the parchment tones, a correlated group in shades of pink to lilac and black and white; blue and white and red and white accessories.

Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, undertakes another step tonight in his campaign to force a return title bout with Champion Kid Gavilan, when he squares off against Jimmy Herring, Ozone Park middleweight, in the ten-round feature at Madison Square Garden.

The National Broadcasting Company has been doing valuable spade work in the area of television opera, and has been getting alternate slaps and caresses for its pains. Late last night it produced Puccini's "The Cloak," better known as "Il Tabarro," with considerable success.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- The "aggressor" enemy brought into play a new and lethal weapon today -- a simulated artillery shell with an atomic warhead -- and inflicted heavy damage on the 511th Airborne Regiment of the "United States forces" in maneuvers in the field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Army, Navy and Air Force have agreed to buy their uniforms, shoes, sheets and other textiles and clothing through a single buying agency in a move to save millions of dollars of the taxpayers' money.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 (UP) -- Five persons who helped create one of Hollywood's most lavish films tonight won a major share of the $25,000 Christopher Awards for 1952.

SNAPPER GARRISON was a jockey with a penchant for lagging behind until the homestretch before turning loose his gallant steed to nip the opposition right on the wire. His fame will never die because he enriched the English language by contributing to it that vibrant, descriptive phrase, "a Garrison finish."
MIAMI, Feb. 14 --There was applause for the 17-year-old Negro apprentice, Hozzie L. Richardson, when he rode into the unsaddling enclosure at Hialeah after today's $4,000 St. Valentine Purse.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 14 -- The government of East Pakistan last night banned publication of the Pakistan Observer of Dacca, East Pakistan's leading English language daily. The action followed publication of an editorial attack on Prime Minister Kwaja Nazi-muddin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A tighter policy in the granting of accelerated tax amortization certificates will be invoked by the Government on March 1, James F. King, deputy administrator of the Defense Production Administration, said today.

Major changes to meet objections to a life insurance industry proposal for the liberalization of compensation to soliciting agents and for limiting expenses for promoting new business were offered yesterday by James A. McLain, chairman of the committee that made the recommendations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Manufacturers in Western Europe will get United States defense contracts totaling between $500,000,000 and $600,000,000 between now and June 30, under plans of the Defense Department to use available European capacity to break rearmament bottlenecks here and abroad.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- To counter spreading rumors of the impending devaluation of the peso, Carlos Novoa, director of the Federal Bank, declared today that Mexico's currency was "completely stable" and disclosed that gold and dollar reserves had increased by $46,000,000 during the last six months of 1951.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Representative Louis B. Heller, Democrat of New York, proposed today a Federal law carrying a death sentence penalty for acts of vandalism inspired by racial or religious prejudice that result in bodily injury or death to anyone.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 14 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower versus Harold E. Stassen, former Minnesota Governor, appeared today to be the Republican line-up in this state's first Presidential preference primary on March 18, but there was considerable confusion over the primary law.
Towboat operators who engage in deep-sea salvage towing are concerned over a serious threat to future operations posed by a recent court decision in an admiralty suit.

In appreciation of her work on behalf of the New York Heart Association, officials of that group presented last evening to Mrs. Vincent R. Irnpellitteri, wife of the Mayor, a portrait bronze bust of her at a reception for 125 persons at Gracie Mansion.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Sir Frank Whittle, who designed the first British jet aircraft engine and flew the first experimental plane nearly eleven years ago, may take a job in the United States because he is dissatisfied with the present trend of jet development in Britain.

Thomas E. Paradine, National Vice Commander of the American Legion and a member of Schenley Post in the Bronx, will speak at the February dinner meeting of Peter Minuit Post, the legion realty post, and the Real Estate War Veterans Association to be held Feb. 21 at the Brass Rail Restaurant, 100 Park Avenue.

Mao Tse-tung and Joseph Stalin celebrated the second anniversary of the Peiping-Moscow treaty yesterday with the customary epistolary love feast. Mao expressed his "heartfelt gratitude" to the Soviet Union and Stalin offered congratulations to the Chinese Communists.

A training program for purser-pharmacists aboard East Coast cargo ships that would qualify the officers to clear their ships through quarantine instead of waiting for examination by United States Public Health officials, was urged yesterday by the Staff Officers Association of America.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The newspaper Soviet Sport today exposed a series of "rigged" sports events which it claimed took place in the 1950 national track and field championships.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 14 -- The new economic program announced by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion in the Knesset (Parliament) was welcomed in conservative business circles toda yas representing a leaf or at least half a leaf out of the private enterprise book.

Upon the just and the unjust alike some Sunday rain occasionally must fall. Starting before dawn, it beats against the windows, and by breakfast time makes unfordable rivers of the gutters at the side of the street.

In a new switch of the party line the Communist regime of Eastern Germany has called upon the United States, Britain, France and Soviet Russia to conclude a peace treaty with all Germany which would prevent the rebirth of German militarism and at the same time reunite, disarm and neutralize that country.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The dwindling ranks of royalty gathered here today for the funeral of King George VI, who had presided over one of the strongest monarchies left on earth.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 15 -- Japan begins today her first post-war conference on a wide range of international issues with one of her close Asian neighbors.

A soft gray blue, called Gendarme, provided the color theme of Russek's presentation of spring fashions yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. Seen first in coats and suits and particularly effective in crisp worsteds and flannels, this same color was viewed later in full skirted cocktail frocks of stiff silk.

Zeke Zawoluk and Jack McMahon teamed in brilliant fashion to lead St. John's to a stirring comeback triumph over St. Bonaventure last night before the season's largest basketball crowd at Madison Square Garden. There were 16,151 fans on hand to watch the twice-beaten Redmen hand the Bonnies their second defeat of the campaign, 59 -- 56.

Though harvesting has been over for months, apples remain one of the most attractive of fresh fruit offerings. They are, in fact, the only locally grown fresh fruit that will be available until the rhubarb season begins in May.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Lew Worsham, veteran from Oakmont, Pa., posted an eight-under-par 63 today to lead a strong Texas open golf field that ripped Brackenridge Park's short par-71 layout apart.

The New York Telephone Company filed plans yesterday for a five-story addition to its exchange at 221-27 East Thirty-seventh Street and 218-22 East Thirty-eighth Street. The annex, which will cost $1,000,000, will be built on the Thirty-eighth Street side from the plans by Voorhees, Walker, Foley Smith, architects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Dr. Ernesto Galarza, research and education director of the National Farm Labor Union, A. F. L., told a Senate hearing today that the State and Labor Departments, at the behest of corporate farm interests, had instituted a system of peonage by contract whereby imported workers from Mexico and the West Indies were used to cut the wages of domestic agricultural workers below the poverty level.

We are pleased to note that Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman for the private transit industry, is making up for lost opportunities of the past to give the Transport Workers Union some sound advice on strikes in violation of contract. Mr. Kheel has just upheld the Triboro Coach Company of Queens for discharge Jan. 4 of five employes "allegedly for mishandling fares."
TRENTON, Feb. 14 -- Misuse of civil defense armbands to gain access to disaster scenes was criticized today by Thomas S. Dignan, deputy state civil defense director.

At a special meeting of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., here yesterday, preferred stockholders approved creation and issue of not exceeding $30,000,000 aggregate principal amount of notes. The company, however, proposes to incur at this time only $25,000,000 of funded indebtedness and has arranged with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States to borrow that amount.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A leading manufacturer of mining machines claimed today to have perfected an oxygen-making device that permits industrial users to make their own oxygen at savings up to 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Feb. 9 dropped 8 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by cities follow, in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

Buildings will not of themselves make an organization or an idea immortal. The palace of the League of Nations at Geneva outlived the League, though now its lovely buildings are put to good and hopeful use. The buildings of the United Nations on the east side of mid-Manhattan might still be standing even if the United Nations itself were in ruins.

SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Communists last night broke the quiet of the Korean battle lines with a 1,100-man attack on the eastern front that was shattered by a storm of Allied fire. It was the largest Communist attack in four weeks or more.

Representative Cecil R. King, chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee studying the administration of the internal revenue laws, charged yesterday that top Treasury Department officials were seeking to stifle the committee's investigation into alleged tax frauds in Brooklyn.

Brazil's action early this year to curb the percentage of profits taken out of the country by foreign companies was condemned yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers as a serious setback for future investment of foreign capital there.

Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company announced yesterday that it is completing arrangements to buy the Brush Development Company, a Cleveland research and manufacturing concern in the fields of electronics and technical instruments.

NEWARK, Feb. 14 -- An 1877 New Jersey statute that allows a loser of a wager to bring civil suit for rocovery of the loss was successfully invoked in Superior Court today, when a jury returned a verdict of $9,740 against an alleged bookmaker in favor of a convicted embezzler.

The whole free world will be awaiting anxiously the result of the vote of confidence tomorrow in the French National Assembly. This is no mere problem of the endless merry-go-round of French internal politics. This time the issue at stake is of paramount importance to the West.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The National Commander of the American Legion endorsed Universal Military Training today, but said the cost of the program as outlined to Congress was "unreasonably excessive."

Despite the tentative restraining order of a Federal Trade Commission examiner, Dolcin will continue its national advertising as "an outstanding drug for relieving arthritic and rheumatic pains and discomfort."

OSLO, Feb. 14 -- The United States got off to a scintillating start in the sixth winter Olympics today when Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence of Rutland, Vt., won the women's giant slalom at Norefjell in supreme style, more than 2 seconds ahead of her nearest competitor.

Greece cannot maintain an army of 150,000 men and at the same time rebuild a shattered economy unless she receives greater economic aid. That was the contention voiced yesterday by Athanese Politis, Greek Ambasador to the United States, in a talk before 200 members of the city's school system at the first of a weekly series of fourteen lectures on "Culture and Civilization of Greece."

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 14 -- Two Indian princes and the former part ruler of a principality are under arrest as the planners of a conspiracy to hire a bandit, a frock-coated former chauffeur, to conduct terror raids to frighten peasants out of accepting land legally expropriated from big landlords.

The Idaho, aristocrat of the potato trade, was denounced yesterday by produce dealers here and in New Jersey as a black market villain. The Office of Price Stabilization sent agents to the wholesale markets to investigate charges of over-ceiling prices, tie-in sales, and selling by the potato instead of by weight.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Queen Elizabeth II seized a brief respite from the new duties crowding heavily upon her and spent a few minutes tonight in solemn contemplation in Westminster Hall where the body of her father King George VI is lying in state.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- Contract negotiations between the American Woolen Company and the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., were broken off today after a three-hour session. With no date set for a resumption of talks, the possibility of a strike on March 15, when the present contract expires, was intensified.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -The Senate today urged the people of the United States to offer prayers this Sunday "that God may guide and protect our nation and preserve the peace of the world."

Unless another change of plan develops, "Two on the Aisle" will close at the Hellinger on March 8. The revue, which stars Bert Lahr and Dolores Gray, was supposed to move into the Broadway on March 3. As things stand at the moment, the Jule Styne-Betty Comden-Adolph Green-Abe Burrows show will be sent on tour March 10. Its destination, however, was unknown yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steadier yesterday and closing prices were 28 to 41 points net higher than on Wednesday.

Despite official investigations of local water-front conditions, New York City dock workers are still "viciously exploited" by racketeers who pay public officials for protection, Malcolm Johnson, International News Service writer, declared yesterday.

A surprisingly successful staging of a battlefield scene in a television studio was largely wasted by the Pulitzer Prize Playhouse in its presentation of "Hill 346" Wendesday night over the A. B. C. network. Technically, the re-enactment of the attack on the hill was one of the production triumphs of the year, but in their concern over spectacular effects the producers regrettably overlooked the more vital factor, the play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, told the Senate today that an Indianapolis brewery had settled a $636,000 Federal tax claim for $4,500 after Joseph D. Nunan Jr., a former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, had obtained special permission to represent the company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A longtime observer at firsthand of the political folkways of New Hampshire informs this department that the weather, that classic alibi for losers, is not at all likely to affect the outcome of the Presidential preference primary in New Hampshire on March 11, the first of the national series of 1952.

CAIRO, Feb. 14 -- The Egyptian Government, in its formal reply published today to the Governments that protested the losses suffered in the rioting in Cairo on Jan. 26, stated officially and clearly for the first time that the murders and property destruction were intended to further a subversive plot. The note said:

Record sales of $684,180,297 were achieved last year by the F. W. Woolworth Company and its Canadian subsidiary, but earnings fell $5,889,239 below 1950 under the pressure of higher operating costs and taxes, A. L. Cornvell, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

Chrysler Corporation's financial statement for last year points up rather graphically the finely honed teeth contained in current tax laws. The automotive company paid taxes totaling $239,859,709 in 1951, equal to two-thirds of wages paid and nearly four times the dividends paid stockholders.
The proposed Universal Military Training plan, now under discussion in Congress, is believed by many leaders to be a definite handicap to national defense.
PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The attitude of the Socialists, who hold the key to the Government's fate in the confidence vote on a European army, will be determined by their executive committee Saturday.

S. DILLON RIPLEY, Assistant Professor of Zoology and Associate Curator of the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale, describes himself as "a harmless ornithologist." Probably only the birds he shoots in the line of professional duty on his collecting expeditions would disagree with this description. It is about his most recent bird collecting expedition that Mr. Ripley has written in his "Search for the Spiny Babbler: A Naturalist's Adventures in Nepal."*

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A symposium on "The Radiation Sterilization of Antibiotics" was held here today to outline a method for a possible reduction in the cost of manufacturing penicillin by sterilizing it with gamma rays.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- By his early death King George VI may have been spared "protracted suffering and anguish of mind and body," the Journal of the British Medical Association suggested today.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Feb. 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio sharpened today his earlier denunciations of President Truman's program for investigating corruption in the Government. He also explained the basis for his attack on the Joint Chiefs of Staff, spelled out his views on the use of Chinese Nationalist troops and opposed any idea of a Columbia Valley Authority.
An appeal for 220,000 hospital workers needed by the Medical Emergency Division of Civil Defense was made last night by Mayor Impellitteri. The recruiting drive will open Monday.

Defense counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial here may call as a witness Cyrus Eaton, major stockholder of the Cleveland investment banking house of Otis Co., in connection with defense charges that Eaton conspired with Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Robert Young, Allegheny Corporation industrialist, to take business away from the defendant firms.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 -- Experts from the United States studying the Brazilian economic situation have agreed to support Brazilian applications to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Export-Import Bank for loans of approxi

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 -- The defense in the trial of fifteen California Communist party functionaries ran the gamut of Marxist dialectic today in an effort to prove to a Federal District Court jury that the "force and violence" attributed to communism were no different from everyday manifestations of capitalism.

More than two months since he was found beaten unconscious outside his apartment, Franz Schoenberner, one-time editor of the German satirical weekly Simplicissimus, remained in serious condition in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital yesterday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Benjamin Farer, a former New York newsboy who became owner of one of Connecticut's biggest newspaper and magazine distributing agencies, left bequests to scores of employes, relatives, friends and charities in his will, admitted to probate here today.

The Aetna Casualty and Surety Company has announced that Edward C. Knapp, secretary, has been named vice president and Robert W. Conly was named assistant vice president. Mr. Knapp was also named a vice president of the Accident and Liability Department of the Aetna Life Insurance Company.

For fostering American principles of interfaith good will District Attorney Frank S. Hogan was cited yesterday at the fourth annual Brotherhood Party for 300 aged New Yorkers in the Home of Old Israel, 70 Jefferson Street. Mr. Hogan, who will serve as chairman of the New York Region Brotherhood Week, beginning Sunday, said, "Brotherhood must be practiced each day of the year."

Painted guide lines on streets help both motorist and pedestrian, and we have on several occasions urged more of them. But the Traffic Department has certainly made an incredible mess out of the painting it has been doing. We published some photographs yesterday showing the smeared paving on two streets, caused when an excess of zeal to get the job done quickly had not been accompanied by planning and good management.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The American Tobacco Company of New York filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for $50,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures, due on Feb. 1, 1977. In addition, the company asked permission to market 1,075,685 shares of $25 par common stock.
Boys House, a new residence for homeless and neglected youths, was opened yesterday after a dedication ceremony at the adjoining buildings at 208 and 210 East Eighteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, made public today a blueprint for slashing more than $8,600,000,000 from President Truman's recommended 1953 fiscal year expenditure budget.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Wilson Co. and the United Packinghouse Workers of America, C. I. O., reached a tentative agreement today granting 10,000 employes of seven company plants increases of six cents an hour.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 14 -- Reunification of Germany must come before a peace treaty, West German Government circles declared tonight in answer to Communist East Germany's request for a four-power peace conference.

To collect his fee for defending a former left-wing labor leader, O. John Rogge has filed a lawyer's lien for $15,000 of Civil Rights Congress funds now being held by the Federal Government and the state.

The Democratic County Committee of Richmond yesterday named Jeremiah A. Sullivan, county leader, and Thomas J. Shanahan of the Manhattan end of the Sixteenth Congressional District, as delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 14 -- The executive vice president of the Farmingdale Savings and Loan Association and a young woman clerk died today of burns suffered when the institution's office was demolished in a gas explosion yesterday afternoon.

The problem was how to remove the bedrock core of a sloping tunnel 150 feet long without disturbing a fifty-story skyscraper, a subway line, two underground pedestrian ramps or traffic on Forty-second Street -- all of which lay within ten feet of the projected tunnel walls.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Advocates and opponents of the controversial issue of suspending citrus shipping rules bombarded Federal officials with more arguments again today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 14 -- Mayor Shlomo Z. Shagai of Jerusalem will visit New York next month and will receive a City Hall reception on March 6. He said today he had received a cable from Mayor Impellitteri saying he wished to reciprocate the hospitality he had received from the Jerusalem municipality during his visit to Israel last year.

Net sales of the Chrysler Corporation rose 16.3 per cent last year to $2,546,678,799, establishing a record high for the third successive year, but net earnings dropped 43.7 per cent under the 1950 total to $71,973,469, K. T. Keller, chairman, reported yesterday.

Last year Italy imported from the United States six times as much, in money values, as she exported to the United States, ending up with a trade deficit of $350,000,000. Since Italy then had to turn around and get dollars from us in the form of loans and grants, this situation seemed foolish.
OSLO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The "undying" Olympic flame went out for thirty seconds today.

The never-say-die element in some 15,000 Brooklyn housewives broke out violently yesterday at the bargain sales in Loeser's department store in Fulton Street. The sales mark the requiem for the 83-year-old store.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The sale of The Cincinnati Enquirer to The Cincinnati Times-Star for $7,500,000, subject to court approval, was announced today by the American Security and Trust Company, trustee under the will of the late John R. McLean.

Modern color schemes form fresh backgrounds for traditional pieces of furniture shown in ten new model rooms designed for young homemakers and now on view at Altman's. The settings have been arranged by the display department staff of that store.

An increase last week of 3,002,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 138,896,000 barrels, compared with 135,894,000 a week earlier and 133,134,000 a year ago.

All major forms of Soviet land and water transportation set record highs for freight transportation last year, apparently keeping pace with increasing industrial output, according to data released by the Soviet Government.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The first large-scale overhauling of the Walker State Boxing Law since its enactment in 1920 was proposed today by Robert K. Christenberrey, chairman of the State Athletic Commission, to enable the commission to clean up boxing and wrestling and root out practices that have been the subject of wide complaints.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 9, 1952, totaled 733,724 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,718 cars, or 0.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, 160,515 cars, or 28.0 percent more than for the corresponding week last year and 164,908 cars, or 29.0 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

In otherwise lackadaisical commodity futures trading yesterday, opening prices on the Cocoa Exchange rose to a new high for the recovery movement. Shortly thereafter profit-taking developed and bids were found thin. Offerings forced the market to give way, and the close was at net losses of 48 to 83 points on the day. Volume was 229 contracts, sugar contracts.
I should be grateful if you could spare space for the comment of one newly arrived from Egypt on various points in Professor C. Bradford Welles' letter of Jan. 29.
A fashion show was held in the new bridal shop on the third floor of Gimbels last night for career girls who are taking the leap-in leap year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a special message President Truman sent to Congress today, asking subpoena authority for Newbold Morris, who has been appointed as special investigator of Government scandals:

DETROIT, Feb. 14 -- Using pure gold master blocks, engineers of General Motors and Chrysler Corporation have achieved a standard for uniform precision in surface roughness measurement accurate to one-millionth of an inch.

Widespread publicity devoted to automobile accidents and fatalities has tended to obscure the other sources of accidental death. According to a recent publication of the National Safety Council, the American home rates second only to the motor vehicle as the source of accidental deaths in this country.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Guatemala Government said today all outgoing and incoming press messages are subject to censorship.

HONG KONG, Feb. 14 -- Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of Communist China, charged in a speech at Peiping today that the United States was "shamelessly stalling" the Korean armistice talks to maintain the "tense situation" as a means of furthering the preparations for a "new aggressive war."

WINDSOR, England, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Slopes leading up to St. George's Chapel, where King George VI will be entombed, were being converted into a garden of colors tonight. There were flowers from the ends of the earth.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The State Commission Against Discrimination, in its annual report to the Governor and the Legislature, said today it found "a definite improvement in the employment pattern" in 85 per cent of the complaint cases involving charges of discrimination in employment because of creed, color or national origin reviewed during 1951.

A revolutionary method of construction will be the outstanding feature of a new collection of bedroom furniture scheduled to arrive here next month. There are four styles in the group, all of them in classic eighteenth century mahogany. Made by the Mengel Company, they will be introduced to the public for the first time by Abraham Straus on March 9.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UP) -President Truman criticized newspapers today for publishing the fact that aerial maps showing the location of United States atomic installations had been issued by the Government and were easily available to the public.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Eight-year-old Cappy Whittemore had a highly prized message from Queen Elizabeth to show to his fellow third-graders here today. But while the message was warm and sympathetic, and quite exciting, it left unsolved Cappy's problem about Meg, his nine-month old miniature wirehaired pet.

Two apartment buildings with stores at 329-31 Lexington Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street, have been purchased by Titania Tarwid for investment from the Bank of New York and Fifth Avenue Bank, as trustees for fifteen different owners.
Seven more security guards at Ellis Island have been suspended on charges of extorting fees from aliens subject to deportation, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Dull conditions persisted in all parts of the Stock Exchange here today except in the market for South African gold-mine shares. Business remained small for few buyers were preparing to enter into commitments before the long week-end -- the markets will be closed tomorrow for King George's funeral. Prices continued to lag until just before the end, when some of them rose slightly.

A mistrial was declared yesterday in Kings County Court by Judge Carmine J. Marasco after ten of twelve jurors admitted that they had learned of the defendant's criminal background from newspaper accounts of the trial.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The State Judicial Council announced today in its annual report filed with the Legislature that it had arranged to make a survey of New York City courts to ascertain whether improvements in administration were possible. The council is headed by Chief Judge John T. Loughran of the Court of Appeals.

MONTREAL, Feb. 14 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens smashed to within a point of the second-place Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League tonight by beating Toronto, 3 to 1, in a rugged game punctuated by fights in every period.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The president of the New York State County Highway Superintendents Association asked today for a reduction in the state's truck load limit from 22,400 pounds per axle to 18,000 pounds.

More than 1,000 pints of blood are expected to be donated in a two-day mass contribution beginning yesterday and continuing today at the New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn Army Base. Many of those donating gave the blood as "life-saving valentines" to relatives in the armed forces.
As the first of its five scheduled world premieres, the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins' "Ballade" last night at the City Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- An emergency board, reporting to President Truman, recommended today that the railroads make a national agreement with seventeen nonoperating unions provid ing for the union shop and check-off of union dues.

A modest effort in Baltimore two years ago to provide good music for school children has mushroomed to the point where other communities in the United States have adopted the idea and where a national organization known as Young Audiences, Inc., has been formed to direct the effort.

The military transport General Sturgis arrived yesterday at Pier 61, North River, with 1,317 displaced persons. The vessel is the first to bring in D. P.s under the auspices of the Provisional Inter - Governmental Committee for Movement of Migrants from Europe, successor to the International Refugee Organization.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 15 -- Communist staff officers at Panmunjom presented yesterday a new draft of a proposal for an exchange of prisoners and repatriation of displaced civilians during an armistice in the Korean war.

Plans for a move to obtain veterans' emergency housing for use by families receiving relief allotments were announced yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Henry L McCarthy. He said he would summon officials of other city departments to confer with him on his plan for acquiring emergency housing when it is taken out of use by its present operator, the New York City Housing Authority.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 14 -George A. Williams, station agent here for the New York Central Railroad, saw improvement today in the honesty of commuters taking newspapers from his self-service newsstand in the station. The "honor system" cash box at the stand was $2.40 short yesterday, but today the loss was only 60 cents.

WALDEN, N. Y., Feb. 14 -- The eight news dealers in this Hudson River Valley community have signed a pledge not to sell comic books glorifying crime. The ban goes into effect Sunday to coincide with the opening of National Crime Prevention Week.
OCALA, Fla., Feb. 14 -- A 24-year-old Negro farm hand was convicted and sentenced to death for the second time today in the retrial of the celebrated 1949 Groveland rape case.

ADEN, Feb. 14 (UP) -- Leaders of a United States archaeological expedition to the land of the Queen of Sheba told today how they had escaped under gunfire from the King of Yemen's guard across a desert inhabited by hostile tribes.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- At the request of Mayor Impellitteri, a bill was introduced today in the Legislature to permit John C. Riedel to retain his present $15,000-a-year job as chief engineer of the Board of Estimate until he reaches the age of 82.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Truman asked Congress today to give Newbold Morris broad and unusual subpoena powers over private persons and documents to enable him to carry out an "independent, thorough and efficient" investigation of corruption in government.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,160, for Thursday's operations: Enemy probing attacks once again were repulsed in Korea. Our ground forces engaged enemy patrols that operated along the battlefront and inflicted casualties on the enemy.
Sal Maglie, the only unsigned Giant player, yesterday became a real holdout, although under no compulsion to report for training at Phoenix, Ariz., until March 1.

Jonathan B. Bingham, acting administrator of the Technical Cooperation Administration of the State Department, emphasized yesterday that the "major job" of providing capital in building up the underdeveloped areas of the world must be done by private business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The International Monetary Fund advanced Brazil $37,500,000 today to help tide that country over a temporary foreign exchange shortage. The fund purchased the equivalent of 693,750,000 Brazilian cruzeiros to complete the transaction.

Saul Feinberg, 26-year-old former student at Harvard Law School, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to an attempted bribery charge -- a felony -- to a seven-count indictment in connection with a fixed basketball game at Madison Square Garden three years ago.
Defense financing requirements increased business borrowings from New York banks $40,000,000 last week.

The stock market took a further hammering yesterday, the third consecutive substantial drop suffered by the share list. Again quotations melted under moderate selling. A few spots of resistance appeared during the session but generally buyers were attracted only to stocks which fell into the so-called "bargain" division.
