" Split Second," a melodrama with a background of the Nevada atomic desert written by Chester Erskine and Irving Wallace, has been purchased and scheduled for production by R. K. O. Radio Pictures, it was announced yesterday by the company. Lewis J. Rachmil will produce the forthcoming offering and Mr. Wallace has been signed to write a scenario treatment of the story, which is scheduled to go before the cameras later this year.
For the ninety-seven partners in Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, 1951 was the second-best year in history. But those who shared in profits divided about $1,000,000 less than in 1950.
DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Tigers and the Browns today disclosed a seven-player deal, which both clubs said would strengthen their prospects for the 1952 season.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 14 (UP) -- An agreement settling a water-front strike that blockaded all Puerto Rican ports for twenty-five days was reached today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- During the week ended Feb. 13, member bank reserves decreased $54,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- Premier Edgar Faure, who is also Minister of Finance, told the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today that with a view to reducing her trade deficit France planned to cut her dollar imports for the first half of this year from $500,000,000 to $330,000,000.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- A group of bills was introduced in the Legislature today designed to benefit the health of older persons and improve their employment opportunities.

Manly Fleischmann, Defense Production Administrator, defended yesterday the basic metals agreement recently made with Great Britain on the grounds that "American self-sufficiency in raw materials is a myth."

A syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co., submitted the best bid yesterday for $5,100,000 of bonds of Amarillo, Tex., due from 1953 to 1972. The bid was 100.186 for 3 1/2s, 1 3/4s and 2 1/4s, an interest cost of 2.123 per cent. A syndicate headed by the National City Bank of New York here, bid an interest cost of 2.139 per cent.

A tract of thirty acres fronting about 2,300 feet on Barlow Lane, south of the Boston Post Road, and also having a frontage on Greenhaven Road in the Greenhaven section of Rye, N. Y., has been purchased from the estate of Samuel Lewisohn by Maurice Epstein, president of the Hat-Man Holding Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- In a Senate speech, Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, today denounced attacks on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He also struck at what he termed "the growing war clique in the United States" which, he said, wanted to risk "a war with Russia."

AS one who has taught in New York City institutions of learning for more than three decades, at all three levels, elementary, secondary and collegiate, with the longest period of time in the latter, I have been deeply interested in the current discussions relative to the "release hour" and the Board of Regents proposal for a daily prayer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Truman said today that the question of running for re-election confronted him with a "difficult decision," and that he was not ready yet to announce his political plans.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- British geologist, Prof. F. E. Zeuner, reported this week that he had discovered a new connection between Britain and the Barbary apes of Gibraltar. He said he had found evidence that such apes -- or, technically speaking, tailless monkeys -- once inhabited this country.

A new violin concerto by Ernst von Dohnanyi, now resident in Tallahassee, Fla., was played for the first time in this city by Frances Magnes with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos' leadership last night in Carnegie Hall.

The former American Packing Company plant at 681-691 Henderson Street, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Ampac Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New York, to Gratale Warehouse, Inc., of Hoboken. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

KALIMPONG, India, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia have entered the Tibetan wool market following the recent decision of American importers not to accept any shipment of Tibetan wool after Feb. 29.

There was no general period of mourning for King George VI in Wall Street yesterday but the New York Curb Exchange, the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange halted trading for two minutes of silent prayer at 11 o'clock.

With at least 1,100 machine and metal fabricating plants in the New York area seeking to utilize idle facilities in defense work, there is no logic to the plan of the Defense Department to place $600,000,000 worth of defense work in European plants between now and June 30, according to the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 15 -- Lisbon awaits the opening of the Nato conference in the let-down mood of a hostess who has swept and garnished her house for guests who are unconscionably late. Two postponements, the first because the key reports were not ready, the second because of the death of King George VI, have taken the edge off Portuguese enthusiasm in welcoming their first important international meeting.
Taking up a suggestion by their new commodore, Paul Campbell, members of the Storm Trysail Club yesterday considered a sailing race around Long Island over the Memorial Day week-end.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Real estate credit controls were relaxed by the Government today to encourage construction of housing for military and civilian personnel in New Jersey and Kentucky.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Truman established Leo Nielson, secretary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as the agency's acting head today and told him to stay at that post until the Senate approved a permanent administrator.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 -- An undercover operative for the Navy's Intelligence Section and the Federal Bureau of Investigation who masqueraded for five years as an ardent Communist was introduced by the Government today as its second witness in the trial of fifteen California Communist party functionaries.

The Griffenhagen career and salary plan for city employes, which in several hearings has come under heavy attack by employe groups, found varying degrees of support yesterday from the municipal affairs committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., the Citizens Budget Commission and the Women's City Club of New York.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Feb. 15 -- Senator Robert A. Taft charged here today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation for years had had enough information on alleged communists in the government to bring about a thorough house-cleaning, but that a "soft" attitude in the executive department toward communists had stayed action.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here today upheld an order or United States District Judge George H. Moore for the payment of $33,478,578 in interest on bonds of the bankrupt Missouri Pacific Railroad now undergoing reorganization.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 15 -- Dartmouth's basketball team beat Yale tonight, 59 -- 50, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. Fred Gieg led the Indians with 14 points as they revenged an 81-57 drubbing suffered at New Haven earlier this week.
A state-wide investigation of all gas companies to determine the extent of their safety factors was ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.
Thousands of New Yorkers paid final tribute yesterday to the late King George VI.

Higher automobile insurance rates in New York State for bodily injury coverage above the basic minimum of $5,000 for injuries to one person and $10,000 for injuries to two or more persons will be sought soon by the underwriters, it was learned yesterday.

" The High Wall," a new film on prejudice, intended as a discussion-starter for parents' associations and other community organizations, was shown in a special preview yesterday at the local headquarters of one of its sponsors, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, 20 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- A House subcommittee said today it had found "no evidence of undue political influence" in a since-abandoned plan to grant a $46,000,000 Government loan to the Harvey Machine Company of Los Angeles.

The great need for Western "miracle" drugs in heavily populated, low-health nations of the Far East was expounded yesterday by two officials of Chas. Pfizer Co. Inc., a major American pharmaceutical company, at a press conference in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Dedicated to the sanctity of the individual and pledged to promote the kinship of man under God, the 1952 observance of Brotherhood Week will begin tomorrow.

HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Cuba should fight to defend the Western Hemisphere against Communist aggression, but her troops should not be sent to other continents, Dr. Roberto Agramonte y Pichardo, presidential candidate of the opposition People's party, or the Ortodoxos, in the June elections, declared in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing today issued a statement that making public the names of relief recipients in Indiana and Illinois had had virtually no effect on the size of public-assistance caseloads.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Military officials accused a House subcommittee today of being unfair in its charges of wasteful buying practices by the armed services.

New York's, 130 mutual savings banks increased new deposits $29,519,000 last month. According to data issued yesterday by Earl B. Schwulst, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, the rise brought total deposits to $12,208,441,000, for a gain of $572,948,000 for the twelve-month period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- National Airlines today charged a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner with thirty-seven errors in recent recommendations, which, National said, will "increase and perpetuate monopolistic advantages" of its larger rivals, Eastern Airlines and Pan American Airways.

Billy Graham enjoyed the expected workout at the expense of Jimmy Herring of Ozone Park at Madison Square Garden last night. Rated the 1-4 favorite over his young foe, the East Side battler gained the unanimous decision of the officials at the end of their ten-round bout.

The national indoor tennis championships start this morning at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue with William Talbert of New York and Mrs. Nancy Chaffee Kiner of Ventura, Calif., defending their titles.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority for the last ten years, will celebrate tomorrow the twenty-fifth anniversary of his first employment by that bi-state agency, dedicated since 1921 to the development of common resources of New York and New Jersey.
GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) -- The newest betting scheme -- George Seman's messenger service direct to the track -- was closed down today after four days.
Tentative plans to revive the traditional lifeboat race for merchant seamen in New York harbor have been announced by John Noble, executive director of the American Seamen's Friend Society.

Fourteen contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund sent to this office have added $391 to the current campaign total and another four donations reported by that number of social agencies have further increased the fund by $47 to make the aggregate for 1951-52 thus far $350,707.93.

The forty-four-room Richmond Hill mansion at Broadway and Harriman Road in Irvington, N. Y., has been purchased by Philips Laboratories, Inc., which has occupied the property under lease since 1944. It was acquired from Mr. and Mrs. Gus Trent and Bertram Trent of Irvington and will be used for electronic research.

TOKYO, Feb. 15 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's headquarters refused this afternoon to permit release of the daily transcript of conversations between United Nations and Communist delegates in the Korean truce negotiations over such questions as exchange of prisoners, conditions for truce enforcement and plans for an international conference regarding permanent Korean peace.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- John Masefield, the poet laureate, today published his poem in commemoration of King George VI. It was his second since the death of the King Feb. 6.

Yesterday General Romulo presented his credentials to President Truman as the "new" Ambassador of the Philippines to the United States. The "new" is hardly apropos, since General Romulo has been, in other capacities, a gifted and persuasive Ambassador of his country for almost a decade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Inland Steel Company of Chicago today filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $25,000,000 worth of first mortgage bonds, series "I," due March 1, 1982. In addition the company asked permission to sell $24,496,500 worth of debentures due March 15, 1972.

The first "combat vessel" in "the cold war" was commissioned at Hoboken yesterday. She is a seagoing Voice of America radio station, designed to frustrate Soviet jamming by moving close to target audiences and bombarding them with the most powerful transmitters ever installed on a ship.

Eleven George Polk Memorial awards have been made in the fields of newspapers, magazines and radio. Eight individual newspaper men and women were cited, as well as two newspapers. One magazine and one radio commentator also won awards.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 15 -- A gang of auto thieves said to have confessed stealing cars in New York City in the last several months, driving them to Redding, Conn., and striping them for parts, was apparently broken up today by accident.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The State Welfare Department reported today that home relief cases declined 30.7 per cent over the one-year period ended last November but rose slightly in recent months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The State Department announced today that all members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had notified the United States of their acceptance of Greece and Turkey into full membership of the North Atlantic pact.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 15 -- Pressure on General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to return home and enter the Presidential campaign is rising not only in the United States but also in international headquarters of the allied Western powers here.

One of the oldest parkways that meets 1952 standards for safety, utility and beauty is Connecticut's thirty-eight-mile Merritt Parkway, the "Gateway to New England." Although built several years before the Second World War, its straight stretches, sweeping curves, excellent sight-line, acceleration and deceleration strips at access roads, and broad, landscaped center islands were planned with more foresight than was used on many parkways of even later vintage.

Emitting a shrill Iroquois war cry -- a muted echo of the one which, a little more than 200 years ago, sent Pier van Blumendorp scurrying to the sanctuary of a rock where Grand Central Palace now stands -- a feathered Injun in beaded buckskin will open another National Sportsmen's Show in that many-storied tepee today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Building contractors asked Congress today to provide for court review of disputes over Government contracts.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Bob Lemon came to terms today with the Cleveland Indians in a telephone talk from his home at Long Beach, Calif. He agreed to a "slight" salary cut.

The Metropolitan Opera Company will visit seventeen cities in twelve states this spring, it was announced yesterday. The annual tour will take two weeks longer than last year, filling the seven weeks between April 14 and May 31.

The American National Theatre and Academy has renewed its interest in "Four Saints in Three Acts" as the fourth production of the current Play Series. Financial details of the deal are being ironed out with Virgil Thomson, who provided the music for the opera, and with the estate of the late Gertrude Stein, who wrote the libretto.

Prominent women headed by Mrs. E. Roland Harriman and including Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr. and Mrs. E. Herrick Low are aiding in the plans for the Red Cross luncheon to be given on Tuesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Trustees of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System will ask Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman on Monday to postpone for two weeks a scheduled final hearing on liquidation of the company.

Jack Keerane, 20 years old, was found guilty of second-degree manslaughter yesterday in Queens County Court in connection with the death of 62-year-old Joseph Finger, a former United Nations interpreter, who was found dead at his home early in the morning of Jan. 20.

A male nurse who allegedly cheated hospital patients by using a pain-relieving drug on himself instead of on them was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court. He was charged with violating the Federal narcotic laws.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 30 Adele Wolk Morgenstern accuses me of racism in my desire to limit the birth rates and population growth in India.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Council of Churches has advised members of the Legislature that it has qualms about a proposal by Governor Dewey to require the teaching in high schools of the evil effects of alcohol and narcotics.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Alvin Bardin, president of the now-defunct Indianapolis Brewing Company, said today that he never had had any business dealings with Mr. Numan. He said he had met Mr. Numan only once, when a mutual friend had introduced them at lunch in Chicago.

Mario Del Monaco took over the name role in the season's second performance of Verdi's "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera last night. Largely because of his stamina and the drive with which he sings, he showed himself to be one of the few tenors who can carry the heavy part.
Tennessee Eastman Company has reduced prices of acetate staple fiber from 48 cents to 42 cents a pound to meet the unexpected cut made by Celanese Corporation of America, it was learned yesterday.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- George A. Williams, ticket agent of the New York Central Railroad station here, held a brief ceremony at the station furnace today to mark his return in part, at least, to faith in the honesty of commuters.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- The French Government has canceled the diplomatic passports of two Tunisian Ministers -- an action apparently designed to block their departure for the United States to press the appeal for Tunisian home rule before the United Nations Security Council.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- A brief hush came over London today as the funeral service began at Windsor. At 2 P. M. a two-minute silence generally was observed throughout Britain.
In regard to the Metcalf-Hatch dog seizure bill shortly to be brought before the State Legislature may I make two points which seem to me to be worthy of consideration.

The sight of a city detective who had been taken into custody only a few hours earlier as a member of a burglary band caused Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan to lose official restraint in the East Sixty-seventh Street police station yesterday afternoon.

The ferocity of the bargain battle at Loeser's department store abated yesterday to a calmer maneuver by Brooklyn housewives. Ten thousand persons streamed through the ninety-year-old store in an orderly fashion that left both people and property undamaged.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Attorneys argued today whether a Lake Charles newspaper man abused or used correctly the guaranty of free speech contained in the United States and state Constitutions.

It is only a short walk that Dr. James A. Pike is taking -- from Columbia University's handsome white-stone-redbrick buildings that cluster on Morningside Heights across Amsterdam Avenue to the great Gothic mass that is the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Many dinner parties will be given tonight in Sherry's Opera Restaurant at the Metropolitan Opera House before the performance of "Madams Butterfly," which has been taken over to augment the Manhattanville College Alumnae Scholarship Fund.

The stevedoring and terminal operating industry in the Port of New York is to set up a special office to survey waterfront safety conditions and seek methods of reducing the accident rate among longshore personnel.

MIAMI, Feb. 15 -- A stakes race for Florida-bred 2-year-olds had top billing at Hialeah today, but a little number that was run sixth was of much more interest to race-trackers at way stations between here and old Jamaica. Six of the seven 3-year-olds in it are candidates for the $50,000 Flamingo Stakes, which is to be run March 1.
OSLO, Feb. 15 -- A twenty-one gun salute heralded the official opening ceremonies of the sixth Olympic winter games at Bislett Stadium this morning.

Track and field's biggest show of the winter, the sixty-fourth annual National A. A. U. indoor championships, will transform Madison Square Garden into a beehive of varied activity tonight. In a colorful dress parade of Olympic talent, 260 athletes and forty-seven relay teams will scramble for fifteen American titles.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Sixty-five men and women officers of all branches of the armed services, now in training at Fort Slocum as information officers, filled the press gallery today in the new Security Council chamber in the Conference Building at United Nations headquarters.
Operations last year of the Household Finance Corporation resulted in a record net income of $12,538,986, according to the 1951 annual report of the concern.
A charge that one of the so-called "linen shops" on Fifth Avenue had failed to label merchandise properly was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Alexander DelGiorno in Lower Manhattan Court.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "Dream of a Cossack," a Soviet film in color based on the novel of the same title by S. Babayevsky is at the Stanley. Boris Chirkov and Semyon Bondarchuk are featured in the Mosfilm production, a story of contemporary life in the Kuban region of the Caucasus, which Artkino is distributing.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- Two hundred clerks and other employes of Macy's-White Plains were not at work when the store opened at 9:35 A. M. today. The store called it a walkout in violation of contract, but union leaders said it was a lockout stemming from a six-month dispute here, at the main store in New York and branches in Flatbush, Jamaica and Parkchester.
The Departments of Health and Markets have joined forces to make sure that horse meat is being kept out of local butcher shops and restaurants.

Ten of the major domestic scheduled airlines using La Guardia Airport and New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, approved a plan yesterday for diverting "materially" airline traffic from over densely populated areas of Queens.
WINDSOR, England, Feb. 15 -- Here in St. George's Chapel, the pantheon of the House of Windsor, King George VI was laid to rest today among his ancestors and his kin.

I have been requested by the Executive Board of the New Jersey Federation of Teachers to address this communication to you in the effort to set the record straight and to explain out approach on an action taken by the Englewood Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Corporations poured out a record $8,053,000,000 in reported cash dividends for 1951, the Department of Commerce said today. This was 2 per cent above 1950, the previous high.
SYDNEY, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Australia's wool check this season is running only about 53 per cent of last year's record high.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 15 -- Thousands of refugees from drought - stricken Northeastern Brazil, driven by hunger, are straggling toward more prosperous regions in search of work and food. The movement has reached the proportions of a mass migration and is creating a serious problem for the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A target date of early March has been fixed by the Decontrol Committee of the Office of Price Stabilization for its first report on industries where relaxation of price ceilings have been suggested. The committee, headed by Edward B. Phelps, acting director of the O. P. S., held its first meeting on Wednesday.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail, an old hand at whipping up a storm, started another big blow today by proposing the merger of Bowie and Pimlico race tracks.

John Ranck, in his Town Hall piano recital last night, broke custom by beginning with two premieres -- Frederick Werle's "Sonata Brevis, No. 2" and Peter Whitton's Suite for Piano. The Werle work, massive and assertive, contained a touch of impressionism allied to a more modern type of dissonance.

An economic charter is needed to give full effectiveness to earlier Inter-American agreement. Ambassador Ricardo Martinez Vargas of Bolivia told the Pan American Society of the United States yesterday on its fortieth anniversary. He was the chief speaker at the celebration marking the day, held in the great hall of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street, where the society was founded.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 15 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt began a four-and-a-half-day visit to Israel today after attending a memorial service for King George VI at Saint George's Anglican Cathedral, in the walled Old City of Arab Jerusalem. She also visited the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, the Mosque of Omar and the Wailing Wall before crossing the border into the Israeli New City.

CHICAGO, Feb, 15 -- Stockholders of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company at a special meeting today voted approval of a proposal for a 25 per cent stock dividend. Substantially more than the required two-thirds majority of the stock was voted in favor of the action, the bank said.
The New England Mutual Life Insurance Company sold $336,000,000 of new life insurance in 1951, O. Kelley Anderson, president, reported in the 108th annual statement to policyholders.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A Hungarian refugee has invented what is described as a revolutionary type pump for use in industry and aviation, the Drexel Institute of Technology here announced today.

NEW WESTMINSTER, B. C., Feb. 15 (UP) -- A new process for producing aluminum was disclosed here today which may eventually cut the electrical power requirements of the North American aluminum industry by a fourth.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- H. Frederick Willkie, brother of the late Wendell Willkie, 1940 Republican nominee for President, was voted out today as president of Kingan Co., meat packing concern. He was replaced by W. R. Sinclair, Kingan board chairman who had been president before Mr. Willkie took over the job in December, 1950.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 15 -- Downhill and slalom races on the first day of the Williams College 1952 winter carnival tonight found Middlebury College racers in first place, with Dartmouth close behind.

THE festival of the hooks and bullets, known to seekers of fish and game as the National Sportsmen's Show, is with us once again, and for the next nine days the urban and suburban outdoor enthusiasts will crowd the jammed aisles of Grand Central Palace with all the enthusiasm of youngsters at their first circus.

It was a fine night at the City Center last night, with the New York City Ballet dancing handsomely in a program of wide range. There were no novelties on the schedule, but "The Cage," "Tyl Ulenspiegel" and "Symphony in C" were given for the first time in the current engagement.

Whether certain major life insurance Companies are held by the Government to be co-conspirators in the investment banking antitrust suit was discussed at the trial before Judge Harold R. Medina in Federal Court here yesterday.

The assassin's gun has barked again in the turbulent Middle East. This time it has shot down a former Deputy Premier of Iran, Hossein Fatemi, Premier Mossadegh's right-hand man and a leader in the National Front that seeks to cling to power by exploiting religious and nationalistic fanaticism.
The sales of six dwellings in Scarsdale, N. Y., have been reported by the Robert E. Farley Organization, Scarsdale, brokers.
BOSTON, Feb. 15 -- Harold E. Stassen, Republican Presidential aspirant, in a television appearance beamed through the New England area, presented a program tonight to aid the textile industry.

The world champion Yankees cut into their unsigned player list yesterday when Roy Hamey, assistant general manager, received three contracts from two right-handed rookie pitchers and one rookie infielder.

Optimism about the possibility of uniting Soviet exiles for a common fight against the Stalinist regime has risen sharply as a result of Admiral Alan G. Kirk's acceptance of the leadership of efforts to achieve such unity.

Plans for a new home colony in Suffolk County were disclosed with the announcement that a tract of 2,000 acres adjoining Camp Upton has been sold by the Young Metzner Realty Company to the Neck Road Corporation, of which Seymour Malman is president.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 15 -- The Eisenhower faction of Louisiana Republicans today won a court victory in their suit to force promulgation of returns in the Jan. 15 primary in which they were victors.
Roughly 100 pictures are in six new art exhibitions, providing sufficient evidence for a belief in the constant liveliness of American, painting today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Civil Service Commission cracked down today on thirteen present and former Federal tax employes in Massachusetts for violating the Hatch "Clean Politics" Act.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout, veteran Tigers' pitcher, toured the Miami Springs Country Club course with a 4-under-par 66 today to win the qualifying medal in the baseball players' golf championship.

WALDEN, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The District Attorney of Orange County today lauded the action taken by this village's eight news dealers in deciding to impose a voluntary ban on the sale of comic books glorifying crime. The move was also hailed by Roman Catholic and Protestant clergymen, school authorities and parents.

The commissioners of the $500,000,000 Port of New York Authority went on record yesterday as "proud and happy" to congratulate Austin J. Tobin, executive director, on his twenty-fifth anniversary at the bi-state agency.

Two women addicts charged with peddling small quantities of heroin in the Times Square area led Federal agents yesterday to an upper East Side flat where they seized two men and heroin and cocaine said to be worth $700,000 in the illegal market.

Deputy Defense Secretary William C. Foster declared last night in an address here that many recent charges against the military establishment have turned out upon investigation to be distortions, half-truths and sometimes "complete canards."

ATHENS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A senior police officer, testifying at the court-martial trial of twenty-nine persons charged with aiding a Communist spy ring, said today that about 30,000 Greeks were getting military training in Soviet satellite countries. He said the aim was an attack on Greece.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Representative Robert L. Doughton, Democrat of North Carolina, who at the age of 88 still directs the House's tax-raising Ways and Means Committee, announced today that he would not stand for election to a twenty-second consecutive term in Congress.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Leading all the way, Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth and J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan, N. J., won the Palm Beach mixed foursomes golf tournament today with a 5-and-4 victory over Miss Bee McWane of Birmingham and Bob Sweeny of Palm Beach.

WHALES show a spectacular spirit of noblesse oblige toward Herman Melville. It may be that they appreciate what his great novel of the white whale, "Moby-Dick," has done to keep them in the swim of literary celebrity. As return gestures, they seem to do what they can, on appropriate occasions, to give his works attention and validity.

Three physicians and an intern were among seven men and women who pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to charges of conspiracy to perform illegal operations for a $500,000-a-year "abortion mill" that was raided ten months ago in Stuyvesant Town.
Thugs netted loot totaling $40,000 in four burglaries and a hold-up yesterday and late Thursday in the Bronx.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Christopher T. Chenery's Hill Prince was named today to race in the $25,000 San Antonio Handicap tomorrow, a move that brought delight to most fans and the management of Santa Anita Park, and consternation to the immediate rivals of the handsome Virginia horse.

After several unsuccessful attempts Argentine dictator Peron, through his controlled labor federation, seems to have succeeded in forming a Latin-American Confederation of Labor at a meeting in Asuncion, Paraguay. There will now be three such confederations -- the peronista - dominated organization, the C. T. A. L., led by pro-Soviet Vicente Lombardo Toledano, and the O. R. I. T. (Regional Organization of Inter-American Workers) allied to the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

A new book, "The Forgotten Ones and Other True Tales of the South Seas," by James Norman Hall, will be issued by Atlantic- Little, Brown on Monday. The volume contains six stories describing the author's experiences on the island of Tahiti, where he went in 1921 seeking peace and refuge in which to write after four years of war.
Negotiations covering 32,000 workers in eight Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards on the East Coast took a more serious turn yesterday as the union interrupted contract talks to order a strike vote.

Nearly 1,000,000 more tons of newsprint will be available from Canada by 1960 under a program planned by newsprint producers there. Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, says that the program calls for increasing production in the next eight years by 914,000 tons, which will bring capacity to 6,161,000 tons.

Like the present-day suburban gardener, the Father of his Country was agreeably subject to the helpful proddings of writers on gardening. This fact is emphasized in an exhibit opened yesterday at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- The United States District Court was told today that a Philadelphia syndicate of "six prominent persons" had purchased the American and Foreign Warehousing Company, lessee of the old Cramps Shipyard.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Police and Tunisian Nationalists clashed here today in the square in front of the French Resident General's palace. Several persons, including two policemen, were injured by grenades from the mob and returning police gunfire before the violence ended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Government today approved increases in basic retail prices for 1952 Studebaker cars, ranging from $46.51 to $93. The Office of Price Stabilization said the company would apply flat increases to all models in each series of its automobiles as follows:

Savings banks newly liable to Federal taxation might switch in to tax-exempt-interest investments to the maximum extent of about $500,000,000, but the shift would not take place for a number of years and would not reach any such volume if savings banks in New York are authorized to invest in equities as proposed in legislation now pending in Albany.

Government restriction on critical materials, combined with an extremely soft market, exacted a heavy toll last year on factory sales of major electrical appliances. The extent was revealed yesterday by the first official report for 1951 issued by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
OSLO, Feb. 15 -- The United States winter Olympic team held a half-point lead after the second round of competition today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Viveca Lindfors has been signed by Universal-International to co-star with Richard Conte in "The Riding Kid," a story to be filmed in Technicolor about the California gold rush in 1849. Polly James is the author of the screen play.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- With Big Ben slowly tolling the fifty-six years of his life and guns thudding in salute, this sorrowing capital said its last farewell to King George VI today before he was laid to rest among his ancestors at Windsor.

A "sensational" spurt in trans-Atlantic passenger reservations in all classes during the last few weeks indicates the possibility of a record post-war travel year, steamship agents and booking officials reported yesterday.

A precision radio transmitter-receiver about the size of a long loaf of bread, weighing only 6 1/2 pounds, including a 3 1/2-pound battery, is rolling off the production line at the Raytheon Manufacturing Company's special products plant in Boston, one every five minutes, with forty inspections from start to finish.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use about the home:
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Alarms from the Continent have not yet shaken the United States' determination to back a European army as the keystone of Western European defense.

Consolidation of International Dairy Supply Company and International Dairy Engineering Company with Foremost Dairies, Inc., was announced yesterday by Paul E. Reinhold, president of Foremost, and Grover D. Turnbow, president of the International companies, which, next to the United States Government, are the largest shippers of dairy products to Japan.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,161, for Friday's operations:

Entertainment by celebrated Broadway performers at the twenty-third annual Press Photographers Ball at the Astor Hotel was canceled abruptly early this morning after the American Guild of Variety Artists had insisted that the entertainers be paid.

The question, "What does art mean to youth?" drew as, many varying responses yesterday from teen-age students as normally it might exact from their elders. They eschewed flowery phrases, however, and at no point in a forty-five-minute discussion was there even a mention of aesthetic appeal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Treasury Department disclosed today that it had granted Joseph D. Nunan Jr. special permission to represent nine clients in Government tax cases after he had resigned as Internal Revenue Commissioner in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Feb. 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This, the second consecutive weekly decline, brought the index, at 175.2 per cent of the 1926 average, to a point 4.7 per cent below the level of a year ago.
Hempstead, L. I. Union Free School District No. 27 announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on Feb. 27 an issue of $3,000,000 of bonds dated March 1, 1952, and due March 1, 1953 to 1982.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Golfers on the winter tour got an enforced rest today when heavy rain brought postponement of the second round of the $10,000 Texas open.

CAIRO, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Government of Egypt announced tonight the arrest of "subversive elements" responsible for the riots in which central Cairo was burned out Jan. 26 and in which a score or more persons were killed.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Peron government ordered Argentine manufacturers and wholesalers today to sell their wares directly to consumers as a means of lowering costs by eliminating middlemen.

The United Nations and an East Side barber shop owner are having a difference of opinion. So far the matter is one of protocol, not law, but it seems that Federal legislation may eventually be needed to resolve the issue.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 3 to 31 points yesterday, with old-crop months showing the most weakness.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The National Arts Foundation of New York announced here tonight a program to urge civic leaders throughout the country to name streets, avenues and parks after famous artists.
TORONTO, Feb. 15 -- After fifty years of talking, Canadians are ready to tackle their boldest irrigation project, convinced that 600,000 acres of prairie dust bowl can be made really fertile again.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb 15 (AP) -- An investigation came to light today into suspected examination cheating by about 200 University of Florida students, including some football players.

Howard David Seed, a young American business man in Indonesia, who was reported missing at sea since last Sunday, has been returned to his home in Jakarta alive and well, his parents here said yesterday.

In his first large deal since he recently entered the realty business as an investor and operator, Leo Kossove, former president of Holly Stores, Inc., has purchased the store and apartment building at 1082 Madison Avenue and 2426 East Eighty-second Street from David Green. L. V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers.

The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and subsidiary reported yesterday net income of $11,405,995, equal to $3.68 a common share, for the year ended Dec. 31, 1951. In the preceding twelve months, earnings amounted to $10,622,035, or $3.40 a share.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 15 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, was entered in Minnesota's Democratic Presidential primary today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Truman and his family joined representatives of the British Commonwealth today at a moving commemorative service for King George VI.

The stock market encountered a late splurge of selling yesterday which cut down an earlier recovery effort. The morning period gave some promise that the three-day recession in prices might be halted, but the absence of bids brought an easing from the highs of the session near the close and left only scant gains.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 16 -- Communist negotiators at Panmunjom proposed today -- and the United Nations delegation immediately rejected the suggestion -- that the Soviet Union be designated as one of the "neutral" nations, whose representatives would make inspections behind the lines during a truce in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it had started court action against two more private warehouse firms charged with misuse of more than $1,300,000 worth of Government-owned grain.

Arthur H. Vandenberg Jr., son of the late Republican Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, said yesterday that he preferred to work for the election of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as President, rather than run as a candidate for the Senate against Senator Blair Moody in Michigan.
In your recent editorial addressed to the Republican voters of New Hampshire there appeared overtones of the now familiar theme that "Senator Taft cannot win."

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A United Nations raid by scores of tanks into the central-front town of Kumsong killed nearly 100 Reds, wounded 88 more and blew up 50 Red bunkers, officers reported today.

All the seasons of the year seem to be gathered under the roof of a city florist shop in winter. Tulips, daffodils and flowering branches announce spring: roses, gladiolus and snapdragon are reminders of summer. There is often a tropical note, too, contributed by such flowers as the tongue-shaped anthurium and fragrant gardenias.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- New-bold Morris' chances of obtaining statutory power to grant immunity from prosecution to some witnesses in his investigation of corruption in government were placed in the "doubtful" category today by influential members of the House Judiciary Committee.

Robert B. Blaikie, West Side political leader, was successful yesterday in Supreme Court in his fight to prevent the William J. Sheldrick group from calling itself the "Regular Democratic Organization" in the Seventh Assembly District when the latter organization agreed to discontinue using the designation.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., accused the steel industry yesterday of seeking to provoke a strike to pry "completely unjustified" price increases out of the Government.
PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Bias cut and the folding of handsome plain fabrics without adornment add up to couture simplicity in Madeleine Vramant's summer ensembles.

A World Day of Prayer will be held at the call of the Metropolitan Student Christian Council tomorrow at 8 P. M. at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. The speaker will be the Rev. John Deschner, general secretary of the United Student Christian Council in the U. S. A.

WASHINGTON, Feb 15 -- Five large cities, including New York, Detroit and Providence, will be certified next week as surplus labor areas, an action designed to channel some defense procurement contracts to them even if they cannot offer the lowest price.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Higher interest rates on Federal Housing Administration insured mortgages and Veterans Administration guaranteed loans were urged today by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America at its midwinter mortgage conference.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Memorial services to King George VI were held around the world today at the same time as the monarch was being carried to his grave in brilliant pageantry in London and Windsor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The National Grange told Congress today it is opposed to "fair trade" price laws and said farmers resented high middlemen's profits.

Plums. pears, nectarines and peaches brought from Chile by the Santa Cecilia were sold at the colorful New York Fruit Auction this week and are on sale now in New York stores. The luscious fruit that was carried through the Panama Canal to tempt winter-jaded palates was the largest shipment of foreign fruit to arrive here this year.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday that beginning Monday at 2:30 P. M. he would hold hearings in Traffic Court for 333 taxicab drivers who in the last year had accumulated 422 summonses for traffic violations other than parking.

A Presidential emergency board has recommended that the nation's railroads and seventeen non-operating unions enter into a national agreement for the union shop and the voluntary check-off of union dues under assignment by employes. Approximately one million employes would be affected, of whom some 80 per cent are already union members.

Sales of leading mail order and chain stores for January were 4 per cent lower than for the like month of last year, according to a compilation of figures for forty- five companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. It Was the first comparative decline for any month since last July, when over-all volume was 6.3 per cent lower than for the month in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- A former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency testified today that John P. Davies Jr., State department official, once urged the agency to get "consultation and guidance" from three persons since identified as communists.
DES MOINES, Feb. 15 -- Growing world food needs can be met through continued application of science and farmer know-how in agricultural production, the National Farm Institute was told today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 15 -- Hossein Fatemi, Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's fiery Nationalist aide, was shot and seriously wounded today by a fanatical Moslem youth. Mr. Fatemi, 38 years old, was rushed to a hospital, where physicians said that his chances of survival would not be known for several hours. They said the bullet had punctured his intestines.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Wheat futures displayed considerable strength after early recessions, but neither wheat nor the corn and oats markets were able to enlist much support on the upturns, and there was another recession later in the day.

A healthy sign in the Pacific area is the series of conferences in which Japan and her former foes are trying to reach some agreements. Talks on reparations have been conducted between the Japanese and the Indonesians and the Japanese and the Filipinos.

Fifteen agents of the Office of Price Stabilization staged surprise visits yesterday on fifty fruit and vegetable jobbers in Newark and other localities in northern New Jersey in a move to curb black marketing of Idaho potatoes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Donald R. Richberg, who helped write the Railway Labor Act of 1926 as a lawyer for the unions, attacked sharply today a Presidential board's recommendation that the railroads make a joint national agreement granting the union shop to seventeen unions.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 15 -- The United States "defender forces" dropped a simulated atomic bomb into a large concentration of "aggressor" enemy forces this morning, insuring certain victory and bringing the winter war games of Exercise Snowfall to a close here at 1:08 P. M.

Young business men were requested by an official of the State Department here yesterday to help achieve a better informed public on international affairs in this country and to combat communism by carrying the message of democracy abroad.

Kenneth Chantler of Montreal and Jack Johnson, professional at the home club, reached the final round of the Pell Cup open racquets tournament yesterday. They will meet at 1:30 o'clock today at the Racquet and Tennis Club for the trophy won in 1950 by Robert Grant 3d, who did not defend.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Army will start in March to release from active duty several months ahead of schedule the first of the 220,000 members in the reserve and National Guard serving overseas and in this country.
The city's proposal to impose a separate county tax on real estate was assailed yesterday by the Five Counties Taxpayers Defense. Inc., an organization of civic groups in the five boroughs.

Many tests in medical research can be made only on large animals, such as dogs, Dr. Virginia K. Frantz of the research staff at Columbia - Presbyterian Hospital declared yesterday in endorsing the Metcalf-Hatch bill now pending before the State Legislature.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 15 -- The Communist party of Yugoslavia has begun to issue warnings to writers, musicians, artists, civil servants and the rank and file of party members throughout the country that the current political and economic reform program is aimed at creating a Socialist democracy and not a Western style democracy.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Republican of Manhattan, announced today that legislation had been drafted by the Joint Legislative Committee on Housing and Multiple Dwelling to make possible the construction of less expensive apartment house accommodations in New York City.
The steel industry's shipments of its finished products to consumers last year reached the record level of 78,928,950 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The congregation of the Jan Hus Czech Brethren Presbyterian Church of New York, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, will celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow and at a reconsecration service at 8 P. M. Monday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UP) -- The Navy today projected the possibility of an armed "bird-man" flying through the air with only a motor and wings strapped to his back.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney proposed today the creation of a bipartisan fair elections commission to ride herd on the campaign tactics of candidates for Federal office.

LONDON -- Little publicized, and probably unknown to the majority of American visitors, are a number of London organizations specializing in different aspects of tourist aid. They are scattered around the city and its suburbs, and range from the travel agencies organizing tours of historical houses and castles to information bureaus giving advice on antiques and the export of tweeds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Wage Stabilization Board recommended today a wage increase of 10 per cent plus 9 cents an hour, as well as other revisions of wages and working conditions, for about 10,000 workers of the Douglas Aircraft Company on the West Coast.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 -- For purposes of drawing political conclusions, India's first national elections may now be said to have ended. Some results from remote districts will continue to come in over the next week or so, but they will be relatively inconsequential.

ALTHOUGH one might be tempted to quarrel with A. C. Ward when he observes that a play surviving fifty years may be assigned a reasonable chance of "outlasting centuries,'' it is nevertheless feasible, it seems, to go along with him in the case of his subject.

In Albany last Wednesday the Assembly chamber of the State Capitol was the scene of a forum on New York City finances. The Assembly was in recess. At a vacant desk in the amphitheatre sat Vincent R. Impellitteri, Mayor of New York. In the well of the house were members of the Legislature's finance committees.

READERS of any of Aubrey Menen's earlier novels -- say "The Prevalence of Witches" or "The Backward Bride" -- will know about what to expect of this half-Irish, half-Indian Englishman. His prose is witty, charming, startling and altogether readable.

A sharp and unexpected decline in the demand for dry storage space in the port, coupled with a consistent outward movement of goods from local warehouses during the last few weeks, has aroused considerable concern among warehousemen.

DENVER, Colo., Feb. 16 -- With one of his greatest displays of enthusiasm during a week of campaigning in the Far West, Senator Robert A. Taft declared today in three words -- "I certainly do" -- that he accepted a "dare" from President Truman to oppose him in a campaign on foreign policy.
BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Mix radioactive isotopes with a little ingenuity and you are apt to find yourself doing a $4,500,000 yearly business.

ATHENS -- This year for the first time tourists coming to Greece may be assured of decent accommodations without the necessity of making previous bookings. This is mainly because the Greek Government, realizing the dollar-earning potential of an organized tourist trade, has made appreciable strides during the past twelve months toward its development under the able direction of Dimitrius Papaefsratiou, borrowed from the American Express Company's Athens branch to show the way.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16 (UP) -- Yale University's swimming team broke two world's records and three American records today in a brilliant day-long exhibition of a race against time.

King George VI has been laid to rest at Windsor. He has joined some of his illustrious ancestors in ceremonies that had, once more, the full panoply of royalty. These elaborate forms are the testimony to the high estate that he held and to the honor in which it is cherished.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Bill Spivey, the Kentucky basketball center who wants his eligibility restored, agreed today with directors of the school's athletic association that he would appear before the New York grand jury.

FIELD MARSHAL ERWIN ROMMEL has been served up with still another sauce. First we had Winston Churchill, the master chef, rising in the House of Commons during World War II and drawing criticism upon himself by a hearty presentation of Rommel, subsequently repeated in "The Grand Alliance."

GENEVA -- Long before the winter customers have packed up their skis for the last time this season Switzerland's cities and villages and her world-renowned hotel industry will be dusting off the sun chairs and planning the program for the summer season.

The sun has been shining in Florida lately. As a result, the citrus crop is running heavy and prices have slumped. Oranges are sold at auction in New York at 55 to 60 per cent of 1951 prices and grapefruit is selling at 60 to 70 per cent of the 1951 levels.

THE HAGUE -- Holland this year has scheduled an unusually large number of events for its warm-weather visitors -- some of the type that occur only once in a lifetime, others of the regular seasonal variety.

VISITORS motoring through North Carolina this spring or planning a stop-over in the state will find a succession of floral tours and shows, starting with the fifth annual Azalea Festival at Wilmington from March 27 to 30. The Airlie Gardens and the Orton Plantation are among the well-known show places near Wilmington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The State Department has under study three limited but potentially important steps that might be taken to meet demands for a more affirmative policy toward Communist China and the Chinese Nationalist Government on Formosa.

FOR the last five years there has been a steady increase in the number of Americans annually touring Europe in their own or rented cars. Economy, greater convenience and freedom from the rigid schedule imposed by timetables are the chief factors in this trend.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 -- President Juan Peron ostensibly came to grips last week with a force that was judged capable of unseating his Government within the foreseeable future -- uncontrolled inflation. After waiting six weeks for an economic commission composed of industry and trade union representatives to come up with an answer to Argentina's gravest internal problems, the President found himself saddled with the task of finding a solution.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- For the tourist the countries of the eastern Mediterranean -- Lebanon, Syria, Hashemite Jordan and Arab Palestine -- have undeniable historic appeal. Their civilization dates back not just a few hundred years but to at least 3,000 B. C.

STRASBURG, Va. -- Campfires flame a little higher and stars are brighter when one goes camping on a clear winter week-end. A Short return to nature when the trees are bare is not just a scheme for the foolhardy few. Snakes -- and bears, if it makes any difference to anyone -- are hibernating, but there is no reason for campers to follow their example.

THIS Presidential election has produced the usual crop of popular political assumptions. One of these is that "nobody can get the Republican nomination unless he is willing to fight for it." Another is that "the Republicans would wreck the present American foreign policy if they won."

The role of Vitamin E in human nutrition or in the treatment of disease has not been established. Vitamin E, discovered in 1922, has been called the "fertility vitamin," for animal tests indicate a deficiency of the vitamin may cause sterility and muscular weakness. However, there is no proof that this applies to the human being.

In the formal proclamation of the new reign the British Government has taken the greatest pains not to offend the sensibilities of its former colonies and dependencies. Elizabeth is not called Queen of the "British Dominions Beyond the Seas," which is the legal formula. "Dominion" is Out of favor.

" THE BIG EYE," Max Ehrlich's first book, was a science-fiction novel which created quite a stir. In this second book his theme is more usual (what happens when the victim of a blackmailer reaches the limit of his endurance), but freshness of approach and milieu, plus ingenuity of plotting, make it seem anything but routine.
Some jokes current abroad today are merely a laugh for a laugh's sake, but most are political. Some are old stories dressed up. Here is a roundup from Times European correspondents.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Coast Guard ships and planes seeking two overdue New Bedford fishing boats with eleven men aboard today discovered several pieces of wreckage floating 150 miles south-southeast of Nantucket Island. One of the vessels that had been reported missing, however, was reported en route to New Bedford.

One hundred and twenty-five thousand persons in the midtown area will get a new postal zone number tomorrow when the Times Square Station at 340-46 West Forty-second Street is dedicated. The new zone -- No. 36 -- runs from Forty-first Street to Forty-eighth Street and from the west side of Fifth Avenue to the Hudson River.

LONDON -- The death of the King eleven days ago brought a shock of grief to the nation and the entire commonwealth. The period of official mourning will mean curtailment of many official functions, a sharp cut in the court calendar, and the virtual elimination of appearances by the Royal Family at public events. But it will not affect activities in public places on the part of the average citizen or visitor.

The concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Ernest Ansermet yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall was the occasion of the New York debut of Arthur Grumiaux. The Belgian violinist had chosen the Mozart Concerto in G major as his vehicle, a comparatively simple work of its kind, but nevertheless well calculated to make known many facets of an artist's musical equipment.
IT is not true, of course, that experts can see through the backs of the cards; and their clairvoyance or intuition, while such does apparently exist, is over-rated.

BECAUSE petunias are so popular and widely grown, it is hard to believe that there are hazards in starting this annual flower. Most people prefer to leave the seed stage to their florist or nurseryman. Some, however, like to try their luck and sow their own.

STOCKHOLM -- The summer tourist season looks good on paper for Sweden. This capital is the main gateway to Finland, where the Olympic Games will be held this summer, and the Swedes expect to benefit from the transit traffic.

BELGRADE -- The Yugoslav Government is planning a daily room-and-board rate of $5 per person in order to attract more tourists to the Dalmatian Coast this summer. It is understood that this amount multiplied by the number of days the tourist intends to spend in a hotel is to be prepaid before arrival in Yugoslavia.

THE successful operetta "The Great Waltz" made many Americans aware that Johann Strauss had a father who was also a composer of popular waltzes. What is not so well known, however, is that the "waltz king" also had a brother who was a talented composer. His name was Josef.

A CHARACTER in John Hersey's "The Wall" is named Bronek Janta. A man in Buffalo, N. Y., is also named Bronek Janta. Janta (the character) was depicted as a Polish smuggler working for his own interests.
SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 16 (AP) -- A former Chinese Nationalist intelligence officer today gambled on American democracy and lost.

THE finest production at last summer's Baireuth Festival was that of Parsifal. In the major roles the cast was without weakness and there was competence all along the line of the lesser parts. The chorus and orchestra did their work in first-rate fashion.

Twenty-nine persons are before a court-martial in Greece, charged with being part of a Communist spy ring. One of them, a member of the Politburo of the Greek Communist party, is already under a death sentence for having entered Greece on a faked passport at the behest of his Communist masters.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16 -- The personal papers of Henry L. Stimson, who served under five Presidents, and whose public career started before the era of flight and lasted into the atomic age, have been given to Yale University, his alma mater.

IN the lower Florida Keys, on the way to President Truman's Key West vacation cottage, a determined effort is being made to save a tiny herd of unique North American wildlife. They are the Key Deer, pygmy descendants of the larger white-tailed deer marooned on the islands aeons ago by the ebb and flow of the ice age.

To the compelling -- and, I believe, unanswerable -- arguments that have been advanced in favor of a state-wide program of educational broadcasting on television there must be added a political consideration of the first magnitude.

SPRING training, the most enviable phase of a ball player's existence, is just around the corner. A few already have turned the corenr, but not officially. The rules say that life underneath the sheltering palms cannot begin formally until March 1, a device locked into the code by the diamond peons themselves as protection against the likes of Larry MacPhail.

PARIS -- The Folies-Bergere is presenting a new show as of March 1! Only a long-time resident can appreciate what this means. Year after year when his visiting friends arrive from abroad -- and in this case the man from New York or North Africa and the matron from Iceland or Queensland can be grouped in a pack -- they all make the same request: "Please take us to the Folies-Bergere."

MADRID, Feb. 16 -- The members of the Spanish ruling class are by now quite used to the fact that many nations, including the United States, do not like their Government. Despite that knowledge, however, they were surprised, confused and angered by President Truman's recent statements that he did not like the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

WHETHER or not the idea of the 7 o'clock Monday curtain, otherwise known as "Commuters' Night," will become a fixture in the Broadway theatre continues to reside in the domain of doubt. At the Majestic, home of "South Pacific," the experiment has progressed through three successive Mondays with satisfactory enough results.

More than 90 per cent of the Puerto Ricans in New York have become adjusted to life here and are employed gainfully, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy declared yesterday. He added that "they have made faster progress than any other immigrant group."
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,162, for Saturday's operations:

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- A doubling of gifts to the cerebral palsy drive in 1951 over 1950 also doubled the ratio of victims who could obtain treatment, delegates from all over the nation were told tonight at the President's Dinner of United Cerebral Palsy at the Palmer House.

TO the unsophisticated, Conrad is a teller of sea stories somewhat more exacting than those of William McFee. To the sophisticated, he is the author of "Lord Jim" and "Victory," a muddy philosopher, a master of point of view and of imagery. To the intelligentsia who know F. R. Leavis' "The Great Tradition,'' he is the masterful novelist who wrote "Nostromo" and "The Secret Agent."
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 16 -- Lord Macaulay once asked the rhetorical question: "What army commanded by a debating club ever escaped discomfiture and disgrace?"

WHEN Tim's doctor recommended a hearing aid relatives and friends felt it was a shame for such a little boy to wear one. Tim's parents didn't agree and soon he began to enjoy sounds he had never heard before. He said it made surprises happen every minute.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 16 -- Wisconsin forces backing General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower agreed here today to join Gov. Earl Warren's supporters and enter a delegate slate pledged to the Governor in the April 1 Presidential primary.

THE closing of Newark Airport early last Monday morning thrust a sudden and unusual burden of traffic on La Guardia Airport, to which a large majority of the Newark flights were transferred. But passengers arriving and departing via the twelve-year-old Queens airport found traffic being handled with a minimum of confusion and delay considering the gigantic task being undertaken there.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 16 -- Breaking a 37 -- all tie in the third quarter, Adelphi College defeated Queens College, 58 -- 49, in a Greater New York Basketball Conference game on the Adelphi court tonight. It was the fourth triumph against no losses in league play for the circuit leaders.

Moving with a precision that had the visitors off balance throughout the second half, the New York Knickerbockers certainly made their presence felt in the race for the Eastern Division honors in the National Basketball Association by whipping the Baltimore Bullets, 102 to 82, before 3,500 fans at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- President Truman said today he intended to recommend to Congress "additional measures" to make more efficient the operations of the Government's Executive Branch.

The City College basketball team continued its dominance over Brooklyn College last night. Leading from the outset, the Beavers trimmed the Kingsmen for the seventeenth straight time in their series, 64 -- 46, before 1,220 fans at the Beavers' uptown gym.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The odds on an armistice in Korea are still estimated here at a little better than 50-50, but the more our officials have studied the possibilities of negotiating a general political settlement in Korea and the Far East, the more gloomy they have become.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UP) -- A 12-point outburst in the third period enabled the University of Pennsylvania's basketball team to defeat Navy, 70 -- 65, tonight in the second half of a Palestra twin bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Federal customs agents in the fiscal year of 1951, seized diamonds valued at more than the combined total of the two previous years, it was disclosed today.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Feb. 16 -- The National Customs will take over the handling of cargo for this chief port of Ecuador from Puna Island, at the mouth of the Guayas River, according to the newspaper El Telegrafo, which said that 60,000,000 sucres [$4,000,000] had been included in the Government budget for that purpose.

THERE are two things about Thomas Sugrue's review of my book, "A Partisan History of Judaism," that, in my opinion, depart from what might have been a legitimate disagreement on his part with the thesis of the book.

MADRID -- One of the pleasures of a Spanish vacation this spring and summer will be watching how far a dollar will go when translated into pesetas. Spain needs dollars and until and if she receives them through United States Mutual Security Act channels, the majority of them must come from the purses of American tourists in Spain.
DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation said today that the Government's recent action in canceling a $69,000,000 machine tool order was "entirely satisfactory" to the company.

The elimination of all overseas flights to and from La Guardia Airport and the reduction of domestic flights from the present peak load of 680 were announced last night by Edward V. Rickenbacker, chairman of the recently formed National Air Transport Coordinating Committee. The decision was made at a five-hour meeting of the committee.
" MR. WYNDHAM LEWIS has produced a novel of 625 large pages, with a colored dust-cover and several black-and-white designs by himself, which weighs just over five pounds and costs three guineas.

A trick license plate is a minor prize much sought after by a commuter. Every year (except when Albany decrees keeping the old plate and adding a tag to it) the commuter tries to get a plate with his initials or his street address. If he doesn't, he has no real commuter blood.

An Austrian writer now living in England, Alfred Marnau has set himself an ambitious task. Telling the events in the lives of five friends, four men and one girl during the first years of Hitler's rise to power, he has tried not only to create real characters, but to endow them with the powers of symbols, to make them martyrs of the spirit surviving the dark kingdom of the Godless.

WITH "Pal Joey" established as one of the season's triumphs, co-producer Jule Styne can take pardonable pride not only in his own unflagging faith in the musical but also in the fact that he has achieved something close to a phenomenon in theatre economy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 16 -- Bob Reiss demonstrated why he is rated one of the best two-way players in the Ivy League by leading Columbia to an 83-57 triumph over Harvard tonight at the Harvard indoor building.

UNTIL recent years it seemed almost a necessity of the detective story that every sleuth should have his Watson, a baffled but admiring chronicler whose intelligence was just perceptibly below that of the reader.

Department store sales continued last week to trail the 1951 figures. Trade observers estimated the lag at about 10 per cent in terms of dollars, and remarked that the crowds attempting to buy goods at Frederick Loeser Co., Brooklyn store liquidating its stock, were adding to unit volume but not to over-all dollar sales.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- Developments in the New England textile industry over the last week have not been encouraging. The American Woolen Company's annual report stated bluntly that the company would increase its operations in the South, and unless costs in its Northern mills meet competitive levels of Southern producers it will move its entire operation from New England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Joseph D. Nunan Jr. and two other New Yorkers, all former tax officials, have been subpoenaed by a House Ways and Means (King) subcommittee to testify here in an investigation of Federal tax collection operations, in New York City.

An outstanding auction event of recent years, the sale of the famous Oliver R. Barrett Lincoln collection will take place on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons and evenings at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

IN a recent "Speaking of Books" column by J. Donald Adams there was the following sentence: "When a man loses humility he loses also all power of growth and becomes vulnerable to evils which destroy his worth; the history of our time provides more than its share of examples; let Hitler, Mussolini Roosevelt, Truman and Stalin suffice."
" You don't 'keep store' any more -- you have to have a supermarket."

TOKYO, Feb. 16 -- Japan proposed today a treaty of amity with the South Korean Republic and a series of parallel agreements covering a wide range of relations with a former subject nation divorced from Japanese control by the Pacific war.

A FEW weeks ago King Farouk of Egypt called on some old friends in Cairo, a foreign business man and his wife who have lived there for years. The King remarked that he had not seen much of them recently and the wife replied that they were living a quiet life, dining out occasionally with friends but avoiding affairs and public places.
GENOA -- For the traveler in Italy who does not want spoon-feeding, this great port offers many more opportunities for exploration and discovery than the better known cities.

FOR THIS WEEK: When flowers fade on amaryllis, cut off the stem, but continue to water the plant regularly so leaves will develop, and to fertilize once a month for flowers next winter. . . . Anchor winter coverings that have been loosened by wind, and water occasionally outdoor window boxes planted for winter. . . Blossoms of Johnny-jump-ups open on any mild sunny day.

Washington Square is due for a large measure of reconstruction under a $150,000 project slated to get under way late this spring under the direction of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan and Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

HELSINKI -- The nations of the world had a date in Finland for the summer of 1940, but the appointment was postponed indefinitely by World War II. In the course of that war Finland was overrun by various German and Soviet armies, and much of it was laid waste in 1944 by the retreating Germans.

As a decision on the steel wage dispute approaches and the deadline for a strike in the industry nears, financial markets found these factors sufficient reason for marking time last week. Holiday influences and a slightly more hopeful outlook for the Korean truce negotiations contributed to the indecisiveness of the markets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- "He's wavering," said the political quidnuncs to one another on Thursday when the President told his press conference that whether to run or not was "a very difficult decision for me to make." "He is going to do it," they said next day, when Mr. Truman told Representative Doughton of North Carolina, who is retiring at the end of this Congress, that "you will be missed by me."

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Many of the main attractions of this year's Edinburgh International Festival of Music and Drama, to be held from Aug. 17 to Sept. 6, have been selected. One of these is the New York City Ballet, which will give eight performances during the second week. The company has not yet chosen its repertoire.
PANAMA -- Tourists to Central America this spring and summer will have to travel by airplane, but fares are reasonable and departures from the United States are frequent.

Regarding Hugh Gaitskell's "Why Britain Faces a Dollar Dilemma" (Jan. 27), the problem could be nearly solved by increased coal production and an exchange of coal for Swedish iron ore instead of using valuable shipping space on the longer haul from the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Truman plan to let Newbold Morris grant immunity to witnesses in his Government house cleaning investigation is "fraught with the greatest danger," Senator Herbert O'Conor, Democrat of Maryland, declared today.

AS everyone knows, the function of a doll is not solely decorative. It is a manifestation of something a good deal more fundamental than the instinct for self-expression. The child who loves and cherishes a doll reaffirms the possibility of the continuance of the human race.

DUBLIN -- In terms of dollars few countries in Europe offer an American on vacation better all-round value for his money than Ireland this year. It has no food problems, there are immensely improved internal transport services and tours, and accommodations can be secured in the best hotels, even in the peak months of July, August and September, if visitors will make their reservations through their travel agents in good time.

PARIS. The latest whim of the Paris milliners is to make half hats, that is the front half. Some are mere bands posed on the front of the head. Even the full-sized give this impression because of their diminutive form. Trimming is applied with a light touch to accent side width or an upward tilt at the back.

PARIS, Sunday, Feb. 17 -- The French National Assembly's endorsement of the European army plan was assured when adjournment was taken at 5 o'clock this morning after the Socialists had lined up with the Government in voting priority to a compromise resolution, which carried by 327 to 276.

THE Independent Motion Picture Producers Association, which is the low budget film makers' counterpart of the Motion Picture Association of America, set a precedent by agreeing last week to make additional payments to performers out of revenue derived from television for the showing of pictures originally made for theatre exhibition.

Since it is my occupation to use the polygraph in the industrial field, I was much interested in Anthony Leviero's article "The 'Truth' Machine" (Feb. 10). One point of great importance might well be added to the facts presented -- namely, how questions and answers are synchronized with the lie-detector graph which records the various reactions of the subject to questions asked.

The Saar question is being made unnecessarily complicated. On Sept. 6, 1946, Secretary of State James F. Byrnes made a speech in the Opera House in Stuttgart. He was flanked by Senators Tom Connally and Vandenberg. The representatives of most European Governments and the German administrative divisions were present.

BRUSSELS -- From a tourist point of view, Belgium can be divided into three parts: Forty-five miles of seacoast in the northwest; the forests and hills of the Ardennes in the southeast; and the cities and towns rich in art, history and industry scattered in all areas.

THE Yale University Library1 in New Haven, Conn., established last week the Rosetta E. Clarkson Memorial of old herbals and other books. The collection comprises a priceless group of ancient gardening books and rare old herbals, presented to the library by Ralph P. Clarkson.
