W. McNeil Lowry, chief Washington correspondent for the Cox newspaper chain, has been appointed associate director of the International Press Institute, Lester Markel, chairman of the institute's executive board and Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 17 -- United Nations delegates accepted today, with some qualifications, a Communist proposal for an international conference after the start of an armistice to make a lasting settlement of Korean problems.

Between the Kefauver and other crime investigation, trials, trials for one sort of skulduggery or another, musical comedies with a heavy overly of Broadway in their plots and a Supreme Court suit in which a witness identified himself sorrowfully as a "schlup" or dope.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Champion Rancho Dobe's Storm, the Westminster-winning black and tan Doberman Pinscher owned by Mr. and Mrs. Len Carey of Greenwich, Conn., made his first ring appearance since the momentous Garden victory another triumphant one tonight.

BONN -- Travel in Germany this season is likely to prove more interesting than relaxing. A visit here is recommended chiefly for its "broadening qualities" rather than the pleasurable stimulations of the still exquisite vacationlands along the Rhine, in the Black Forest and in the Bavarian Alps.

For some years the nation's school system has been handicapped by a serious teacher shortage. Good teachers are needed today as never before. Growing enrollments, the indifference of superior students to teaching as a career, and the competition from Government and high-paying jobs -- all have combined to deplete the ranks of potential teachers in virtually every section of the country.
OSLO, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Only three of the five compulsory figures in women's figure skating were run off today with the remainder postponed until tomorrow because of the size of the field.

A RECORD year for North Atlantic travel appears to be in the making. Advance bookings for Europe and Mediterranean ports are now being made so rapidly that travel experts are confident that the figures recorded in the top post-war season of 1950 will be beaten by the trans-Atlantic liners.

IT is easy at this time of year to force branches of spring-flowering shrubs and trees into bloom, but it is difficult to arrange them after they come into flower. The usual method of forcing is to give them a good soaking when they are first cut, and then to place them in a deep container of water in a cool, sunny window and syringe them frequently until flowers appear.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 16 -- Leaders of industry, labor and Government joined here tonight in a civic tribute to the Studebaker Corporation on the occasion of its hundredth birthday.

SPIRITS as a cookery ingredient, though not as familiar as wine, do contribute distinctive flavor to certain dishes. One of the few examples native to this country is whisky cake, a Southern specialty.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The forty-fourth annual Chicago Auto Show opened here today after Mayor Martin H. Kennelly had arranged a truce in the labor dispute between the International Teamsters Union, A. F. L., and the Chicago Automobile Trades Association, sponsor of the show.

MR. CURDLE was speaking a little floridly when he interred the drama a century ago. But the fact that by and large "the drama is gone -- perfectly gone" in the winter of 1952 probably has some bearing on the fact that Emlyn Williams is a major event on Broadway in his evening of Dickens readings.

IT was a drowsy summer afternoon in 1950. From my library on the second floor of our home in Denver, Colo., I could hear the clang of the garden gate as five small boys of the ages of 12 and 13 entered wearing T-shirts, blue jeans and arrogance.

Michael James' "Kashmir -- Report On a Coveted Valley" (Feb. 3) was interesting and fair, but one paragraph annoyed me. He wrote, "* * * the Britisher * * * taught the Kashmiris the secrets of British cooking.

A program of college caliber for the student who does not plan to go to college has been established by the Midtown Business Center of the City College of New York. Its main feature is an innovation in business training. This is a "bridge to business" course covering both social and business skills. It can be completed in one part-time day semester with classes each morning, or in two part-time evening semesters.

Bizet's "Carmen," in the production staged by Tyrone Guthrie, with settings by Rolf Gerard, and Fritz Reiner conducting, was repeated yesterday in the Metropolitan Opera House with Paolo Silveri taking the role of the Toreador for the first time this season.

Hearings in Albany on a bill which would enable the state and city health commissioners to requisition dogs and cats from public-aided pounds for use in research laboratories ended last week with predictions that the bill would pass the Legislature.

A light vote is indicated for the special election in Queens on Tuesday in the Fifth Congressional District, where four candidates are vying for the right to succeed T. Vincent Quinn, Democrat, who resigned to become District Attorney. Mr. Quinn was elected to the latter post in November.

DURING the past two or three years many theatregoers from all parts of the country have been introduced to their first arena theatre production. Theatres-in-the-round have sprung up in tents, barns, ball-rooms and for the most part have contributed to the most exciting and vitalizing thing that has happened to the theatre in years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Alexis Kyrou of Greece, president of the United Nations Security Council for the month of February, expressed doubt on his return to the United States today that the next session of the Council would take place before Feb. 25, despite developments in the dispute between France and Tunisia.

HOWARD DIETZ, Broadway song writer, who did the libretto for the Metropolitan Opera's "Fledermaus," has made an English version of "La Boheme" which the Metropolitan will probably present next season.

VITTORIO DE SICA, the Italian director, who is currently represented here by the prize-winning comic fantasy "Miracle in Milan" and known previously for such fine dramas as "The Bicycle Thief," may shoot his next film here under the auspices of a major company.
SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Seven Allied raiding parties slashed into Communist positions on the western Korean front behind a heavy artillery barrage yesterday and then withdrew.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Yale increased its consecutive string of indoor dual track meet victories to nineteen today by defeating Harvard, 69 2/3 to 39 1/3, in the Coxe Memorial Cage.

Dr. Curt Sachs, music historian, who is conducting a ten-lecture free series on Richard Wagner's "Ring" cycle at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will speak on "Siegfried" tomorrow at 8:30 P. M.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 16 -- New Jersey's gasoline price war, which was supposed to have ended last Wednesday when retail dealers declared a "truce," flared up again today.

FRIEDRICH VON HUGEL'S importance springs not primarily from birth, position or external achievement. His family connections -- good German-Scotch descent and marriage to a sister of the thirteenth Earl of Pembroke -- were more satisfying than important. For public office or a professional career he had insufficient health.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 -- In what many diplomatic observers here believe to be a Cominforn-inspired move, Mexico's Communist leaders have offered to form a coalition with Gen. Miguel Henriquez Guzman to fight the July Presidential election with "one revolutionary candidate."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- W. John Kenney, President Truman's choice for Mutual Security Administrator, is a fast-moving corporation lawyer who looks like a well-dressed construction foreman on his way to teach a Sunday school class, a class for which he is already ten minutes late.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Workers for the Bureau of Internal Revenue generally are barred from representing taxpayers in claims before the bureau for two years after they leave Government service. But under certain circumstances former employes receive permission to represent clients.

In June, 1867, the Quaker City, an oceangoing sidewheeler, steamed out of New York Bay for an "Excursion to the Holy Land, Egypt, the Crimea, Greece and intermediate points of interest." Fortunately for subsequent tourists, Mark Twain was one of the pilgrims who paid $1,250 for passage on the Quaker City.

The introduction into the Decaogue of the Fourth Commandment, "Remember the Sabbath Day, to keep it holy," placed something new among ethical laws known among ancient peoples before Moses received the stone tablets, Rabbi Bernard J. Bamberger said in his sermon yesterday morning at West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street.

COPENHAGEN -- Denmark, which attracted about one out of every ten Americans who visited the Continent last year, is looking for a larger percentage in 1952. The Olympic Games in Finland are expected to draw many visitors north to Scandinavia from their accustomed circuits of European cities and resorts.

Since stock markets first appeared the operator who sold short has been the favorite bogeyman of the people who never want prices to go down -- of those who, in the words of the late Jacob Schiff, "think the tree grows right up to the sky." The bear has been cursed by politicians with a flair for language, regulated by administrators with more enthusiasm than statistics.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 16 -- Brazil's many money-changers are preparing to close down, and tourists ariving for the carnival face an unpleasant shock. The new law on "crimes against the economy of the people" does away with the free money market, beginning Feb. 24, the first day of the carnival.

THIS year many tours abroad are being tailored to suit the individual. While the standard trip to Europe -- the one first-timers usually select -- includes London, Paris, Rome, Geneva, Brussels and Amsterdam, innovations on this circuit are increasing. Motor-coach extensions to the standard tours have been found practical and popular. They are now available in most countries, thus affording travelers a glimpse of the hinterland without the expense of hiring a private limousine.

ONE moonlit night early in 1943 a PT boat drifted in close to a tiny German-held island off the North African coast and waited while two Navy signalmen climbed into a rubber craft and began to row shoreward. Their mission: to set up an observation post and signal what they saw back to their ship.

CHESS players who fancy themselves military strategists will find a certain support for their whimsy if they read the official history of the Army Air Forces. The period covered by Volume III is characterized by a series of daring gambits offered the German Air Force.

The Erie Mining Company announced yesterday that it has under consideration a $300,000,000 project on the Mesabi iron range in Minnesota for producing up to 10,500,000 tons a year of iron ore pellets from taconite, low-grade and heretofore virtually unused ore.

The Moore-McCormack Lines has chosen not to enter a defense against a charge of polluting New York Harbor waters, brought by Capt. Jefferson D. Beard, Navy Supervisor of the Port, in Eastern District Federal Court, Brooklyn.

In "Rewarding Ideas" (Jan. 27), Alfred Steinberg states, "Employe suggestion systems got under way in the Federal Government in 1918 when the Navy first began making awards to 'blue collar' workers in Government shipyards."

The new 120-inch reflecting telescope of the University of California's Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton will be ready for operation during 1954, Science Service reports. When the new instrument is finished, California will have the three largest telescopes in the world. The 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar and the 100-inch instrument on near-by Mount Wilson have been in operation for some time.

Only seven years have passed since the German Wehrmacht was driven back into its homeland and there crushed. In Europe last week the memory of German power -- and what it cost to break it -- reasserted itself with sharp impact.

GEORGE WASHINGTON was fifty years old when he performed what was perhaps the most vital of all his services to his country. For it was then that the man who had done most to win the war which gave his country independence used boldly and wisely his war-won prestige to save the nation in the peace that followed.

I WAS shocked when I read of the impending closing of WFDR. When this station leaves the air New York will lose its only progressive radio voice. The city will be left with just two independent commercial outlets on the FM band.

Grace Castagnetta's long piano program yesterday afternoon in Town Hall consisted of the Bach-Busoni Chaconne. Mozart's Sonata in D (K. 576), Chopin's B minor Sonata, three "American Ballads" by Roy Harris, Liszt's "Forest Murmurs" and Scriabin's B minor Fantasy. Miss Castagnetta concluded her recital, as is her custom, with a group of improvisations on themes suggested by the audience.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 31 to 39 points lower than on Friday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 16 -- After having declared that "no way is left for agreement," Premier Mohammed Mossadegh yielded to the demands of alarmed Iranian Senators today in agreeing to try for a last-ditch effort to negotiate an oil settlement with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Grains recovered from an early sell-off on the Board of Trade today, wiping out losses and in some cases substituting fair-size gains.

A ruling just made by the National Labor Relations Board in a new area of controversy illustrates once more how far Congress intended to go when in the Taft-Hartley Act it provided that an employe may be fired upon a union's request (where a union shop contract prevails) only for failure to tender dues.

AT the age of 22 Eugene Goossens made his successful debut as conductor of opera, replacing at short notice Thomas Beecham (not then Sir Thomas). He had had several years' experience as an orchestral musician and member of a string quartet, and he was already composing.

The Treasury-Federal Reserve System accord on public debt and credit management is nearly a year old. And instead of the delicate infant feared by many market skeptics, the accord looks like a sturdy baby sure to survive its second winter and likely to ride out, too, the proverbial storm and stress of a Presidential year.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Bill Mlkvy snapped out of his scoring slump tonight, but Temple University dropped a 77-60 basketball decision to Manhattan at Convention Hall.

WITH a big entry list and number of voluble delegates present from the Soviet Union and other Iron Curtain countries, India's first International Film Festival has been marked by an overdose of pro-Communist propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The committee said tonight that in the pronouncements of the Methodist Federation for Social Action "will be found the oft-repeated denunciation of fascism, (but) only one denunciation of communism has been noted."

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Nine of Army's ten varsity teams swung into action here today during the busiest athletic program of the cadet winter sports season. The tenth squad wasn't idle either, as the members of the traveling squash racquets team were competing against the Tigers at Princeton.

Jackie Jensen, who has said he expects to beat out Mickey Mantle as the center field replacement for Joe DiMaggio, turned in his signed contract yesterday to Roy Hamey, assistant general manager of the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested ten former members of the North Carolina Ku Klux Klan in a series of raids around Fair Bluff, N. C., this morning on charges of kidnapping and flogging a 27-year-old white woman and a white man. The F. B. I. agents were assisted by the Sheriff and deputies of Columbus County, N. C.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, knocking a stroke off men's par for the Normandy Shores course, took the lead today after the first eighteen-hole round of the $17,000 Weathervane coast to coast golf tournament.

ALASKA is now again being considered for statehood by Congress. This would certainly astonish a lot of Congressmen of the year 1867. Eighty-five years ago its purchase by the United States for $7,200,000 was widely derided as just about the most inept deal in real estate history.

IN 1950 the brilliant, aseptic Welsh poet Dylan Thomas (Dylan rhymes with penicillin) visited us for the first time. He is back a second time now -- to read his own and other poets' verses at the Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A., the Modern Museum and scores of colleges and universities -- as much by popular demand as by his own wish.

Broadening its policy of combining practical experience with classroom instruction, the Ohio University School of Journalism will inaugurate a Journalism Internship Plan this summer in cooperation with several daily newspapers throughout the state. Under the new program, comparable in many respects to the medical interne program conducted in most hospitals, high-ranking journalism students will get the opportunity of obtaining valuable newspaper experience during the summer period.

HERE is a clever suspense novel set in the Middle East oil country. It tells how a group of men and women -- Americans, English, an Arab and an Indian -- react to sudden imprisonment by a Russian interrogation team whose object is to discover just how soft "the enemy" would be in the next Big Show.
I wish that all my fellow-countrymen in Britain and the Commonwealth could have shared with my husband and myself the experience that has been ours since we arrived in this country ten days ago.

Retail sales volume continues well below that of a year ago, but manages to stay above the figures for 1950, regarded by merchants as the more normal comparative period because of abnormal scare buying in the first two months of 1951.

BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 16 -- Silas Dunklee, 28-year-old Brattleboro (Vt.) ace, today turned in the best performance of his cross-country career in capturing the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's Class A championship.

By dint of long argument and frequent United Nations concession some slow progress toward an armistice agreement in Korea is being made. At one point there is no meeting of minds in sight. It is the Communist contention that all prisoners of war must be returned, forcibly if necessary.

THIS is the season tourist officials, travel agents and even the tourists themselves have been waiting for. Give us, they have been saying, low-cost air transportation across the Atlantic, plenty of good shipping space, and the continuing spread between the value of the dollar at home and abroad, and there will be between 500,000 and a million American tourists wandering through Europe every single year.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Paced by Fred Tritschler's 24 points Princeton handed Cornell its first Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League defeat, 68 -- 54, at Dillon gymnasium tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Many of the kings and queens, foreign princes and heads of state who came to London to attend the funeral of George VI left the capital today on their homeward journey.

ATHENS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A Greek Army officer testified at the Communist spy trial today that the Government had been listening in for nearly two years to underground radio transmitters here sending military information to Red Rumania.
The letter of Chadbourne Dunham in THE TIMES of Feb. 10 was informative in pointing out the official American position regarding the status of the America Houses in Western Germany.

THE serenade is a simple and moving story of the war in the air. The big bird was a Flying Fort. She had a crew of ten men and all but one of them were 20 to 24 years old. Bert Stiles was the co-pilot. He had been in college before he joined and had ability as a writer.

NOW that the novel of actual combat seems at least temporarily to have run its course. we have many novels of bivouac. of home-front life in wartime. of non-combatant naval service and of imprisonment and escape.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Danbury's first "one-man" underwritten referendum will take place Monday from 3 to 9 P. M. in City Hall Auditorium to decide a long controversy over the proposed Small Claims Court.

A COLUMN of this kind owes much to its readers. Hardly a week goes by without my being reminded of that fact, sometimes pleasantly, sometimes to my embarrassment. Nothing in my working life has given me as much stimulation as I have derived from the interchange of ideas made possible by the reaction of readers to what appears in this space.

Five days a week, David M. Neuberger -- only living member of the class o '82 of New York University's School of Law -- joins the morning rush-hour throngs at the I. R. T. subway station at Seventy-ninth Street and Broadway, journeys to his law offices at 152 Nassau Street and puts in a full day either in office or in a court of law.

MEMBERS of the "Pal Joey" club, who for the past eleven years have been championing their favorite show with a zeal that puts to shame the survivors of the blizzard of '88, probably will admit to having had a few moments of trepidation when they learned that a revival was in the offing and they would be called to account.

PALISADES, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Edgar Snow denied emphatically today that he was a Communist or ever had been one and said he was completely unaware of the proposal that a committee of six persons be formed to help the Central Intelligence Agency, as told yesterday by a former agency operative in testimony before a Senate group investigating subversive influences.

When a lessor of property receives a deposit as security for performance by the tenant under the terms of a lease the amount of such deposit may or may not be taxable as income at the time of its receipt.

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 16 -- Amherst defeated Wesleyan, 64 -- 54, tonight for its second Little Three basketball victory of the season. The visiting Cardinals outscored the Jeffs in each of the last three stanzas but could not overcome a large early deficit.

PONDICHERRY, French India, Jan. 10 (By Airmail) -- Both Indian and French officials like to say that the four last French-held towns in India -- Pondicherry, Karikal, Mahe and Yanam -- are still living in the nineteenth century. This, the capital of the French Establishments in India, certainly appears to be living fifty years ago, and enjoying it.

Windsor Castle stands on an eminence above Windsor town, commanding a view -- the loveliest view in the world, said Pepys -- of the boated Thames, the playing fields of Eton, the gentle folds of Buckinghamshire, the oaks of the old royal forest.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Lou Kretlow, fire-balling White Sox pitcher, knocked out the defending champion, Al Dark of the Giants, today as the field moved into the semi-finals of the baseball players' golf championship.

CAMP DRUM, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- A caution against accepting atomic weapons as final and absolute in warfare was expressed today by Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commanding general of the First Army and director of Exercise Snowfall, Army-Air Force winter war games just concluded.

FOR Graham Greene the modern world has mechanized its creatures. The anxious, dissatisfied temperaments he describes are similar to those described by Pascal in the seventeenth century and by the Jansenist theologians. He is a chronicler of a period in time when the world is extraordinarily sad.

LISBON -- Every year Portugal becomes known to more tourists as word spreads of its curious charm. The fact that the Nato Conference is taking place in Lisbon will make a large new public aware of the tourist and holiday possibilities of the country.
William Talbert began the defense of his National indoor tennis championship yesterday with a convincing 6-2, 6-1 victory over Charles Hunt, formerly of California.

Jersey Joe Walcott beat the deadline yesterday. The heavy-weight champion of the world, who had until tomorrow to accept terms for a title bout or risk suspension in this state, came to an agreement with James Norris to defend his crown against Ezzard Charles in June.

THE tall tales which Davy Crockett inspired -- and spun -- are among the most picturesque in American folklore. In "Chanticleer of Wilderness Road" Meridel Le Sueur has woven many of the old favorites together with some biographical fasts and extracts from his writings into a continuous narrative.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- On becoming Queen, Elizabeth II assumed control over an immense establishment that is, in fact, a community of its own.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Russian peasants have been "plundering" land belonging to state-controlled collective farms in many regions, Pravda indicated today in an editorial quoted by the Moscow radio.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 16 -- John Foster Dulles described military containment of Russia as "a self-defeating policy" tonight and said it could be written off as a foreign policy.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- Honus Wagner, rated among the great shortstops of the game, put away his spikes and uniform for the last time today after more than forty years of baseball.

SINCE Biblical times, at least, man has been interested and stirred by the annual migrations of birds. In recent years careful observation and research, aided immensely by banding and the recovery records of ringed birds, have added much to our knowledge of the dispersal of migratory fowl in various parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The old adage that it takes two to make a fight is due for a rugged work-out next month when Congress takes up the question of renewing the present Defense Production Act with its controls over wages and prices.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 16 -- A plan for the development of United States education up to 1960, designed to meet an expanding school population, has been offered by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University.

WALTER O'MEARA was reared on the Minnesota-Ontario border and now lives in extreme southern Arizona. Of the four short stories in this volume, four are of the north country, one of southern Arizona, one of colonial New Mexico, and the last of Charleston, S. C.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Mediation Service announced early today that settlement had been reached on all issues involved in the 78-day strike of Prudential Insurance Company agents.
TOKYO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Japan, faced with surplus pound sterling credits, today announced a new trade policy of more buying and less selling in the sterling area.

HONG KONG, Feb. 16 -- Red China's vast agricultural domain, which the Peiping regime is socializing step by step along a planned road leading from "cooperatives" to Soviet-style collectives, is now marked by what the Communists call "four co-existing economies."

Colorful and portable bits and pieces of the wilderness, picked at random from New Jersey to Alaska, were crowded into Grand Central Palace in readiness for the opening of the National Sportsmen's Show, and a crowd that was described officially as "large, but orderly" waited impatiently for the opening of the doors at 11 A. M. yesterday.

THE first such course to be given in a commercial photography school, a short "Introduction to Photography" class is announced by The Germain School of Photography, 225 Broadway. Planned for persons who want a working knowledge of basic photography "quickly and inexpensively," the course consists of five three-and-one-half-hour sessions, one a week.

IN the Marxist vocabulary used by Fritz Sternberg, capitalism and socialism were on trial during the recent British election. The narrow Conservative victory over the socialist Labor party illustrates, at any rate, that there are two world trends, and that in Britain they command almost equal strength.

Stimulated by the competitive opportunity of larger interest-dividend payments, savings banks are giving renewed attention to the merchandising advantages of their special services. In addition to offering a means of obtaining new business, such facilities as teller's cheeks, money orders and banking-by-mail, it is now recognized, also provide the basis for an effective public relations program.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 16 -- In an attempt to break the deadlock over Western New Guinea, Indonesia has asked whether the Netherlands would be willing to consider a joint administration of the territory.

Benjamin Fine in his article, "No More Homework? The Pros and Cons" (Jan. 13) says that pupils carrying four subjects "normally spend three hours a night in home study." Theoretically, our pupils would also do this -- if it were not for their two forty-five-minute study periods.

Larger shipments of export grain are expected to flow through the Port of New York as the result of a recent court decision establishing parity in railroad freight rates for that commodity among North Atlantic ports.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 (UP) -- False, an 8-1 shot owned by Mrs. Nellie M. Mikel, broke American racing's longest current victory streak today when he defeated Claud Tanner's Light Broom by two lengths in the $10,000 added Lecompte Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

THE author of "Essay in Physics," Herbert L. Samuel, has played a leading part in Great Britain's political life. He has occupied high positions in the domestic and foreign services of his country and has been the leader of the Liberal party.

TELEVISION has brought to Peggy Wood a sidewalk identification she never experienced during a legitimate theatre career that began in the chorus of "Naughty Marietta" in 1910. As a triple-threat artist in musical comedy, operetta and stage drama, nothing ever had quite the meaning for her as a truck driver on East Sixty-fourth Street who greeted her warmly: "Aren't you Mama on television? Why, sure, you're Peggy Wood."
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission said today it might start a "baby" toll road extension to the Delaware River this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Two movie studios faced the prospect today of paying as much as $90,000 in back wages to two screen writers whose contracts were canceled because they refused to tell the House committee in 1947 if they were Communists.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Today's livestock prices reported by the Department of Agriculture follow
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The executive committee of the American Council on Education tonight unanimously approved a plan which would clamp strict controls on college sports.

Paul G. Hoffman's substitution of the word "investment" for "aid" in his article, " 'World Investment,' Not 'Foreign Aid'" (Feb. 3) is a mature but not a popular expression of our foreign policy. Unfortunately for our relations with other nations, too many inapplicable parallels have been drawn in the past and are repeated in the present.

The Rev. Dr. Herbert King, pastor of Grace Congregational Church, 310 West 139th Street, was named yesterday as chairman of an organizing committee for a New York division of "Christian Action," which is concerned with social projects.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16 -- The Republican party leadership in Connecticut has abandoned its traditional position of remaining uncommitted prior to a national convention by throwing its strength behind the Presidential candidacy of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

HONOLULU -- While Hawaii remains the Pacific tourist capital, there is growing interest in travel opportunities in the entire Pacific basin, sparked by the recent formation here of a Pacific Interim Travel Association to coordinate information and promote tourism in this vast area.

A SUN porch with its abundance of light, sunshine and fresh air is a useful place to get an early start with annual flowers and vegetables. Even perennials may be sown in the flats or pots and will make good growth there. If there is no sun porch, the next best place is a window sill with southern exposure.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- Economic experts here believe that East Germany's ambitious five-year plan, now in its second year, may be wrecked by the shortage of "technical intelligentsia" who have become the Soviet zone Government's most solicitous concern.

THIS history of the University Players bears a fully reasonable title, because two decades after its dissolution that group has taken on the properties of a completely grown theatrical legend. This is owing to the fact that if a stone be hurled of an evening at the marquee of almost any theatre housing a hit, it will extinguish lights spelling out the name of some former University Player.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Bermuda this month is swinging into her busy winter season. Until well after Easter, hoteliers and carriers expect no appreciable slackening. Signal for the change is a rise from the off-season charges that have applied for the past month or two, but comparison with tariffs of the previous two winters discloses no significant change in the rate pattern.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- French officials who are counting on a United States program of contracts to French firms for defense goods as part of the American aid to France are worried now about the effects of the restriction placed by the Mutual Security Agency that such plants must not have Communist-controlled labor forces.

MEXICO CITY -- The hundreds of miles of white tropical beaches along Mexico's Pacific coast are becoming one of the country's most popular tourist atractions. This long shoreline, which includes both sides of the Lower California peninsula and extends from the California to the Guatemalan borders, contains a number of fine beaches, many of them known to few people other than the local villagers and fishermen.

THE abstract front of this weeks' exhibitions is by no means a united one. On some sectors are performed acts of purest non-representationalism, while on others natural appearances are camouflaged under avant garde cloaks.

OSLO, Feb. 16 -- The Star-Spangled Banner was played in Bislett Stadium this afternoon in honor of Kenneth Henry of the United States who won the Olympic gold medal in the 500-meter speed-skating event.

SOME time this year, probably in the summer or the fall, Charlie Chaplin's new motion picture, "Limelight," which he calls a comedy-drama, and which, like all Chaplin creations, is the product of a slow, nervous and self-conscious germination, will be shown to the nation's moviegoers.

CARL ZEISS, INC., 485 Fifth Avenue, importer of the Contax and Ikonta cameras, signalizes its entry into the inexpensive camera field with the introduction of the Box Tengor camera, a $17 unit of the "deluxe box" type. Equipped with a two-element coated and color corrected f/9 lens, the camera uses 120 film for a yield of eight pictures, size 2 1/4 x 3 1/4 inches.

The frivolous instructs of teen-agers have no place in the Soviet Union's iron view of Communist youth. Now the Russians are taking to task a group of transgressing teen-agers -- girls who stay away from their factory jobs to worship male opera singers. A parable in a recent issue of the Komsomolskaya Pravda, newspaper of the Young Communist League, described the actions of the stage-door hangers-on as "worthy of hysterical bourgeois youth."
A combination of developments has made the supply picture in major metals a little rosier for consumers.

Trade barriers again are going up throughout the world. The accelerating rate at which they are appearing, as well as the continued muddle of international conditions that breed them, is arousing concern among American foreign traders.
TRIESTE -- To understand Trieste, a local aphorism says, the stranger must "look at this noble city not only with his eyes."

After an armistice in Korea, what? This question has been in the background of the truce discussions since they began. Last week the question was thrust into the foreground. It came up because the negotiators in the army tent at Panmunjom were discussing Item No. 5 on the truce agenda.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Because visitors have overtaxed the facilities of this Army installation, camp officials have instituted a new pass system and hours for visiting recruits in the Reception Center. The new visiting hours are from 1 to 5 P. M. on Sundays and holidays and from 6 to 8 P. M. on week-days
For several months the 3,900 students at Walton High School, an all-girl school at Jerome Avenue and West 195th Street, the Bronx, put aside the records of their favorite crooners.
A special panel of the Wage Stabilization Board completed hearings yesterday on the steel wage dispute and prepared to write a report that would serve as a basis for settlement.
TORONTO, Feb. 16 (UP) -- The last-place Chicago Black Hawks fought the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-2 tie tonight in a National Hockey League game.

LUXEMBOURG -- This tiny country has so many charms, particularly for Americans, that any effort by visitors to pick out one special attraction and label it No. 1 is likely to bring confusion. Some choose the general fairy-tale atmosphere -- of medieval castles rising straight up out of wooded hills, of bright uniforms and feudal pomp, of a sturdy peasantry tending vineyards on the sunny side of the Moselle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, charged in a Senate speech this week that Mr. Nunan enjoyed some spectacular success representing clients in tax cases. Senator Williams mentioned the Indianapolis Brewing Company, which Mr. Nunan has denied he ever represented.

TWO ballets by George Balanchine will have their world premieres by the New York City Ballet this week. On Tuesday his "Divertissement Classique" will be presented with Maria Tallchief, Tanaquil LeClercq, Melissa Hayden, Diana Adams, Patricia Wilde, Andre Eglevsky, Jerome Robbins and Nicholas Magallanes in the leading roles.

TAKEN together these two books resemble one of Miss Brown's familiar counterpoints: there is a great big book and there is a very little book -- or, at least, comfortably little. And like many of her other books these both deal with the world of small creatures illuminated with a pleasant kind of nonsense.

Rhododendron and andromeda plantings have lately showed widespread discoloration of foliage. In the article that follows, two experts give their opinion as to the cause of each condition and their remedy.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 16 -- The $10,000 Texas open turned into a free-for-all today as four players tied for the lead at thirty-six holes with cards of 132. While Lew Worsham of Oakmont, Pa., the first-round leader, faltered somewhat, Tony Holguin of San Antonio, Jay Hebert of Great Neck, L. I.; Walter Romans of Baltimore and Jack Burke of Houston, Tex., advanced to a deadlock at the top.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Manchester United today strengthened its grip at the top in English soccer with a 3-0 victory over Derby County.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A formal plea to Congress to enact a law to punish by execution or life sentence espionage against the United States in peacetime as well as in war was filed today with the House of Representatives by its Committee on Un-American Activities.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Feb. 16 -- Serving at this sprawling military installation are twelve amputees and other disabled military personnel who are among the 1,500 "handicaps" the Army has returned to duty since 1946.
TRENTON, Feb. 16 -- A Taft-Eisenhower popularity contest appeared to be shaping in New Jersey today with Republican leaders taking sides.

Leonard Ferguson, a 3-year-old member of the Hopalong Cassidy's numerous posse, had some difficulty sitting on his pony last night after an interview with his parents concerning a little horsing around in the afternoon.

The past week has seen the formal opening of this year's Olympic Games at Oslo. The torch has again been carried into the arena and the world has once more been reminded of the high idealism that is expected to be an integral part of this international event.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The sympathetic attitude of Secretary Dean Acheson and Foreign Minister Anthony Eden toward giving an American and British guarantee of the proposed European Army treaty appeared likely this week to facilitate French adhesion to the treaty which was the subject of prolonged debate in he National Assembly.

Paul G. Hoffman sagely observes: "It is we who are the crusaders for freedom and progress, not the men in the Kremlin." Just as we here at home are cognizant of that fact, so, I suspect, are the members of the Politburo, however much they seek to convey an entirely contrary impression.

WARSAW, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Polish Parliament, in a blow aimed at black marketing and reluctant farmers, adopted a law yesterday compelling livestock producers to deliver large quotas of meat to the Government.
Samuel S. Koenig, 80 years old, for forty-nine years Republican leader of the Sixth Assembly District on the lower East Side, was honored at a dinner last night in the Astor Hotel.

Women's and children's outer apparel manufacturers will keep pace with the new developments in synthetic fibers and utilize them to the fullest extent of consumer acceptance, it was pointed out in the trade last week. A new era is opening in fabric diversification which will bring into widespread use many new types of cloth containing the "wonder" chemical fibers by themselves or in blends with wool, cotton and silk.

For the first time since commercial airlines came of age a major airport in a large metropolitan area was closed down tight last week because of the protests of angry and frightened city dwellers living near the end of its runways.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 -- Pilaster, a horse from Maryland who usually does his stakes-winning when the pumpkins are frosted, won the $18,925 Miami Beach Handicap today at Hialeah in brow-mopping weather. It was the fourteenth stakes success for Mrs. H. L. Straus' 8-year-old gelding, and his first in Florida.

WHEN young Andy McIver, bound for Mr. Astor's new fur trading post in the Oregon Territory, impulsively joined the crew of the schooner Tonquin he was prepared for adventure. He got it. At Astoria he was shanghaied and sailed north, barely escaped the Tonquin's tragic fate in Nootka Sound, was rescued by a taciturn Indian and paddled the long way back to Astoria.

Because the suspicions of a parole officer had been aroused by a delay in gaining admittance to the home of a parolee, a 52-year-old East Harlem man was arrested yesterday on charges of possessing narcotics and counterfeiting.

CAIRO, Feb. 16 -- The Kingdom of Jordan, whose armed forces are subsidized and armed by Britain and part of whose officers are British, signed the Arab collective security pact today after a long delay following signature of the pact by the other Arab states.

Women of society, including Mrs. Juan T. Trippe and Mrs. George Emlen Roosevelt, are aiding plans for the performance of "Jane," with Basil Rathbone and Edna Best in the leading roles, on the night of April 17 at the Coronet Theatre for the benefit of the Foster Home Department of the Children's Aid Society.
Prices, prices! What are the official prices?

REVOLUTION is a subject from which the well-bred of today's generation -- American film -- especially might understandably shy. Social upheavals and rebellions are so current and disquieting in the world that the frank contemplation of their aspects might be felt indiscreet as screen fare.

Five hospitals, one in each of the boroughs, will participate in simultaneous air raid drills at 11:30 A. M. tomorrow to dramatize the city's need for 300,000 medical emergency volunteers for civil defense.
Changing his tactics along with his distance, Don Gehrmann last night gave the Madison Square Garden railbirds their first glimpse of his blinding speed.

AN experiment in mass air transportation that some scheduled airlines have welcomed for years and others have been more or less reluctant to accept will be started on May 1 with the inauguration of coach plane service across the North Atlantic.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- United States sources in London saw no insuperable difficulty tonight in meeting French demands for British-American "guarantees" against a defection by Germany or any other country from the proposed European army. It is understood the British take the same view.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Although Monday is the deadline for filing nominating petitions in this key state, only one candidate for the Presidential nomination, as of tonight, has personally announced that he would be in the Pennsylvania preference primary on April 22.

The basket of peaches which Albert M. Kahn peddled at the age of nine on the streets of Brooklyn was the foundation of a business which has expanded into a string of department stores, manufacturing enterprises and sales companies.

Spring volume improved last week and reorders began to pick up in the wholesale marker here, resident buying offices reported. Better merchandise continued to be in demand and response to promotional merchandise was especially good. Out-of-town buyers continued to shop lines in the ready-to-wear field.

THE Chancellor of the Exchequer's pledge not to tamper with the government's regulations on dollar expenditures for American films until the existing agreement with the United States comes up for renewal in September has given the film industry politicians plenty of time for cumulative resistance.
The Very Rev. Dr. James Albert Pike, former chaplain of Columbia University and a one-time practicing attorney, was formally installed yesterday as fifth dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 16 -- Colgate's basketball team checked high-scoring Syracuse with a zone defense to win, 71 -- 58, tonight in the ninety-eighth renewal of the traditional rivalry.

HOLLYWOOD. IN making "The Plymouth Adventure," Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer will go behind "the veil of legendry" and take a candid look at the Pilgrims who stepped ashore Nov. 11, 1620, on what is now Provincetown harbor, after a rough voyage of two months and five days aboard the Mayflower.

THE best things in Paris are free -- even if today it may cost more to be in a position to enjoy them. Although inflationary spirals have raised the cost of visiting in Paris just as in other parts of the world, only to see Paris is to enjoy Paris, to be beguiled by her.

THREE of last season's more enjoyable programs -- "The Goldbergs," "Mr. I. Magination" and Sam Levenson's own half-hour -- have returned to television after enforced lay-offs for varying reasons. It is good to have them all back, even if each does seem to have its own problems.

This is one of those decisive weekends, so dramatically different from the drowsy Saturdays and Sundays of old-time diplomacy, when history seems on the point of taking a new turn. In London yesterday Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, France and Germany were preparing for discussions which might clear up the situation caused by the tension and suspicion between France and West Germany.
SOMETIMES, it would seem, television's left hand doesn't know what its right hand is doing. This situation can have its serious side and, more frequently perhaps, its humorous aspects, too.
THIS is a story involving the promotion of that form of musical expression known as Opera, than which -- please stop me if I'm wrong -- there is no quicker or surer way of achieving losses.

UNDER the uninformative title. "Search for the Spiny Babbler," Dillon Ripley tells an interesting story of his travels in the hinterlands of Nepal, a country that is practically all hinterland. The Spiney Babbler comes in because this was one of the bird species that Mr. Ripley, an ornithologist, was seeking on his expedition for Yale, the Smithsonian Institution and the National Geographic Society.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 -- With the war surplus planes obtained from the United States for Indian civil airlines approaching the twilight of their usefulness, replacements have come down to a choice between the British Vickers Viscount and the American Convair 340.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The Democratic legislative leaders announced today that they would sponsor a broad program of bills affecting unemployment insurance, workmen's compensation and disability benefits.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- The Philadelphia Inquirer filed suit today to compel the Barnes Foundation to admit art students and the general public to the museum of modern art established by the late Dr. Albert Coombes Barnes.

BARRED last year from the walls of the Baltimore Museum of Art, the Baltimore International Salon of Photography, which had been an annual event until then, has won a reprieve this year -- on the condition, reached after some discussion, that the jury of selection consist of three prominent artists chosen by the museum board.

IN this tale of the seventieth century Paul French ingeniously combines mystery with science fiction. His inventiveness and his use of picturesque details remind one of Robert Heinlein's books and, though his characters are not so fully developed as are Heinlein's, they are for the most part more individualized than in the usual story of this kind.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- A missing chapter of ancient history was written last month for modern-day scholars when a 4,000-year-old temple for Inanna, the goddess of love and war, was unearthed at Nippur, Iraq, by archeologists of the University of Chicago and the University of Pennsylvania.

Announcement was made last evening of the purchase by the Philadelphia Museum of Art of "Prometheus Strangling the Vulture," one of the major works of the sculptor, Jacques Lipchitz, whose studio in New York was destroyed by fire on Jan. 5 with the attendant loss of a great part of his life's work.

THE Sixth Annual National Photographic Show, which starts Thursday and will run through Saturday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, will again, as last year, attempt to emphasize the educational aspects of the photographic medium.

When a visitor leaves the President's office in the White House, he generally walks out through the adjoining lobby. There the White House correspondents move in on him. For many months, the standard lobby question asked of every visitor who has anything to do with politics has been: "Do you think Mr. Truman is going to run again?" These are some of the conflicting answers the press has been given recently:

IN May, 1854, Colonel Suttle of Virginia came to Boston to recover a fugitive slave, Anthony Burns. The Vigilance Committee, in which the principal figure was the Reverend Theodore Parker and under which was organized the antislavery and abolitionist sentiment of Massachusetts, swung into action; hasty plans were thrown together for an attack on the Courthouse to liberate Burns by force and in calculated defiance of the Fugitive Slave Law.

IN 1911, when Charles Russell exhibited twenty-five canvases at the Folsom Galleries in New York, the show was titled "The West That Has Passed." The West, which he so carefully and lovingly recorded down to the last hoof, was really the West of the decades before the "bob" wire, the railroads and "skunk wagons," as he called automobiles.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 16 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has agreed in theory that, if Western Germany is rearmed within a European defense community, an attack upon the territory of the Bonn Federal Republic shall be regarded as an attack against the territory of any member of the alliance itself.

The response that the people of New York City have given to the observance of Brotherhood Week each year has been heartwarming and demonstrates that members of all faiths and races have come to understand the true significance of the occasion. The need was never greater than the present for our citizens to be joined together in the bonds of a common understanding.

THE central figure of this powerful and marvelously articulated story is the aging father of a mentally defective youth. Clyde Cassen is a good man, and if there have been ambiguities in his love for his bulking, infantile son, Henry, they have never issued in action or symbol.

THE hero is always one who saves: his passengers from the sea, his men from ambush, his friends from his foes. His adventures are always valid, whether they be those of "Ulysses too, that other war" or of the sixteenth - century Father John Gerard, returned to England after ordination on the Continent "to bring back souls to the knowledge and love of their Creator."

HONG KONG, Feb. 16 -- Whether or not the United States decides to "take the wraps off" the Chinese Nationalist Army, that army is not now ready to undertake a large-scale amphibious operation against the China mainland.

AFTER Emily Kimbrough returned from her post-collegiate trip to Europe, she had expected to spend her time like other girls of her generation and background -- hanging around the house until a suitable husband turned up.

MARK VAN DOREN'S "In That Far Land" is one of the first volumes to appear in the new series of Poetry Pamphlets published by the Prairie Press in Iowa City. Mr. Van Doren's book is, appropriately, a collection of reminiscences and celebrations of the Middle West, written with his characteristic lyric simplicity, quiet humor mad dignity.

TEL AVIV -- Another increase in volume of tourism is expected this year. According to estimates, 50,000 visitors will come between March and October, compared with 40,000 in the corresponding period last year. These eight months comprise Israel's season.

THE WNYC American Music Festival, which lasts from Lincoln's to Washington's Birthday and is now in its thirteenth flourishing season, may not be the biggest and best music festival America ever had, but it is certainly one of the most original.

ONE of the happiest opening day visitors at this outdoor extravaganza was one Albert Dienes of Lakewood, Ohio, who will return home today with the New Official Gun Book prize, a Model 70 Winchester rifle.

ROBERT MERRILL is in on a couple of new gimmicks on records this week. The first is Stephen Foster in Song and Story (Victor, ten-inch), in which the baritone is teamed with Clifton Fadiman, who handles the "story" angle. The story is a sad one -- the tragic life of America's great song writer -- quietly told between the eight selections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A good many politically wise persons in this politically minded city are taking a second look at the mushrooming campaign of Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee to capture the Democratic nomination at Chicago in July and agreeing that it has more go-power than they were willing to concede it two or three weeks ago.

Bursitis is one of the most common, most discomforting and least understood of ordinary human afflictions. Yet Dr. V. Charles Ancona of St. Clare's Hospital warned last week, in a lecture sponsored by the New York County Medical Society, that careless treatment or neglect of a bursitis can lead to a chronic disability that may take years to overcome.

An indication that Detective James J. Fox and three thugs arrested with him Friday after an abortive burglary attempt might have been involved in other recent midtown burglaries was given yesterday at the arraignment of the four men in Felony Court.

MONTREAL, Feb. 16 -- Dickie Moore and Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, a pair of rookies, tonight took care of all the Montreal scoring as the Canadiens rolled to a 5-1 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers.

A youngster not listed in the program accounted for the major surprise of the National interscholastic track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday. He was Don Philpott, unheralded Montclair High senior, who won the high school mile in the record time of 4:23.5.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 16 -- Phil D., coming through with a stirring stretch drive, captured the $29,800 San Antonio Handicap today, the final big test for the $100,000 San Anita Handicap.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 16 -- Middlebury College skiers defeated Dartmouth today to win the Williams College winter carnival ski meet.

At 22 years of age, Dominick Cirillo of 415 East 117th Street had achieved a gross business of $15,000 to $20,000 a day, Detective Kathryn B. Barry estimated yesterday. The business, she said, was narcotics

THE rhythmic hilarity of Carnival in Rio de Janeiro next week will touch off the spring travel season in South America. The Good Neighbor continent has manifold attractions which fortunately will survive the Last undulation of the samba-happy Carnival crowd in the Brazilian capital.

TOKYO, Feb. 16 -- In a "laboratory of democracy" in the only substantial slice of territory ever to be liberated for a long time from Iron Curtain control, the Yangyang triangle in North Korea, the majority of the populace has taken enthusiastically to free elections and education, and democratic self-government, according to findings of a special diplomatic committee of inquiry.

You can cross Scotland from Edinburgh to Glasgow in ninety minutes on from Inverness, on the Moray Firth, to the western sea loch of Loch Linnhe at Fort William in under three hours.

A Korean Roman Catholic priest, who in World War II had been forced to yield a pint of blood to the invading Japanese, donated blood voluntarily yesterday for American fighting men.

THERE'S a popular theory that only the lazy Americans do their sight-seeing and mountain-climbing with the aid of machines, while the rest of the world scales the heights by means of strength, patience, and a stout rope.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified today sixty-seven additional battle casualties in Korea, including 12 killed, 50 wounded, 3 missing and 2 injured. It also listed seven dead who previously had been reported missing. The following new casualties were listed from New York and New Jersey (none from Connecticut):

THE Cornish coast and the rocky moors of Devonshire furnish the natural makings of adventure in this bracing yarn of the eighteenth century. Knave-Go-By is the Dartmoor village where a boy who had lost his memory and his name clung to a danger-filled existence while he tried to establish his identity.

As chairman of the Senate subcommittee whose recent report on Communist propaganda activities in the United States was the subject of your editorial of Feb. 10, entitled "Communist Propaganda," I feel obliged to point out what I deem to be a misinterpretation of the position of the subcommittee.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 -- A country judge and World War II veteran who refuses to give up his fight to wrest statewide office from the powerful Long family political machine in Louisiana will again submit his cause to the electorate on Tuesday in a bid for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The ten-month-old Indonesian Government appeared doomed today as the Nationalist party joined the powerful Moslem Masjumi party in condemning Foreign Minister Achmed Subardjo's acceptance of United States aid under the Mutual Security Act.

The staff of United States Attorney Frank J. Parker will begin an over-all investigation into alleged corruption, racketeering, bribery and tax frauds when an extraordinary grand jury is impaneled tomorrow in Brooklyn Federal Court.

IT could be said that the one original contribution that American ingenuity has made to the arts of interior decoration is the development of the cocktail table -- that low-slung catch-all that is planted in front of the sofa in virtually every living room in this country today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) --Representative F. Edward Hebert berated the Defense Department today with the declaration that House of Representatives investigators were "working for the taxpayer" in exposing "wasteful" military buying.

HAVANA, Feb. 4 -- Havana's reputation as the "noisest city of the world," according to the local press, seems likely to remain unchallenged. Civic associations, physicians, psychiatrists and educators have protested for many years concerning the excessive racket, but little has been done about it.

LONDON -- Motor coach travel has developed with amazing rapidity in Britain during the post-war years and more particularly during the past twelve months. It is now possible to go all over the British Isles in luxurious coaches not only at less than half rail cost but with seats guaranteed.

Spring will be here on March 21, at 5:26 A.M. Anyone who wishes to see it arrive can do so by sitting up until, or getting up at, that hour. But spring will not appear with a salute of twenty-one guns, or even an audible click. Spring, like a Broadway show, is a product of preparations and rehearsals. Like Broadway shows, it opens out of town.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 16 -- The inhabitants of this community will start their own miniature Point Four program by raising funds to buy a tractor, seeder and thresher for the residents of Nuri, Sicily.

VIENNA -- Austria had her best tourist season since the war last year and this year she expects to do as well. Although no longer the cheapest travel country in Europe, Austria is still one of the cheapest, and there has been no rise in prices since the latter part of 1951.

Richard Savitt made his first tournament appearance since his return from Australia yesterday and a big gallery saw him defeat Gilbert Bogley, 6 -- 3, 6 - 4, in the national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

New York Catholic Charities provided some form of assistance in 1951 to 483,396 men, women and children of every race and creed, Msgr. James J. Lynch, director, said yesterday in a statement opening the thirty-third annual fund-raising appeal of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The attention of 700 delegates to a Leadership Conference on Civil Rights was focused today on demands that the United States Senate change its rules on debate in the interest of so-called civil rights legislation.

OSLO, Feb. 17 -- The traditional winter sports nations shared the spotlight in today's Olympic competitions. Especially did Norway shine. Three Norwegians topped the Holmenkollen ski-jumping list in the so-called combined event to be decided by a cross-country race later.

In a wild third period that produced seven goals, the New York Rovers defeated the New Haven Tomahawks, 5 -- 3, in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. When the same clubs met in New Haven last night, however the Tomahawks reversed the result by the same score.

The Associated Merchandising Corporation has appointed Miss Mel Palm merchandise representative for infants', children's, girls' and teens' wear, knit and woven lingerie and corsets in the upstairs and downstairs departments in the Chicago office, Louis J. Villar has joined the company as representative for merchandise standards and specification development.

Strong selling pressure in the early and latter part of last week caused a further sharp decline in cotton prices. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the period with net declines of 69 to 110 points, or $3.45 to $5.50 a bale, following net losses of 95 to 154 points, or $4.75 to $7.70 a bale, in the preceding week.

The Red Bank Board of Education voted yesterday to cancel the appearance of Dr. Theodore Brameld, Professor of Educational Philosophy at New York University, who had been scheduled to address the New Jersey community's school teachers next Thursday on the town's annual "Professional Day."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Labor, management and Government officials have a wide variety of views -- some sharply conflicting -- on how to handle "the problem of Communist-dominated unions," a Congressional survey disclosed tonight.

A series of recommendations for improving the care of homeless children in the city will be presented today to Mayor Impellitteri by the New York City Commission for the Foster Care of Children.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Jack Burke Jr., 29-year-old ex-Marine from Houston, played virtually flawless golf today to win the Texas Open tournament with a 24-under-par 260 for a new Professional Golfers Association record.

A Brooklyn College student who was shot in a liquor-store hold-up Saturday night in the Bronx was a prisoner yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center charged with assault and robbery. Two other youths were arrested with him and a fourth was picked up later.

Production of men's clothing during 1951 declined sharply from that of the previous year because manufacturers reduced factory operations to eliminate excess stocks when the consumer demand fell off, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. announced in a bulletin released today.

Figures released over the weekend by the Investment Association of New York, a group of 220 men below the age of 35 in the securities business, reveal that their advancement by age has been rapid. If the expectations of the members bear fruit, it will be even more so in the future.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The Rev. Dr. John A. O'Brien, lecturer and author at the University of Notre Dame, urged here tonight the enactment of a law requiring all couples contemplating marriage to complete a pre-marital course consisting of twelve lectures as a prerequisite for the purchase of a marriage license.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- A group of experts of Salzburg and Upper Asstrian Provincial Governments returned to Salzburg yesterday from Leghorn, where they had been studying the problem of providing shelter for the United States Army of occupation.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 17 (AP) -- North Carolina's civil defense director charged today that Communists were trying to sabotage civil defense by mailing thousands of letters ridiculing the air raid warden service.

Details on how to play the new game of Coupon are available in retail grocery stores. According to instructions obtained at one store the other day, here is how it goes: You buy six bottles of Pepsi-Cola. With the carton is a coupon entitling you to buy a pound of coffee, any brand, for 5 cents below the marked price.

Earl J. Byrne has been appointed to succeed the late Charles A. Wald as general manager for the inward freight services of the United States Lines, V. J. Freeze, vice president in charge of freight traffic, announced yesterday.

Benjamin Britten's "Billy Budd," Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" and Virgil Thomson's "Four Saints in Three Acts" are the operas to be presented by visiting companies during the Congress for Cultural Freedom to be held in Paris from April 30 to June 1.

A young noncommissioned officer was called back into service from the reserve, and his wife and children could no longer pay the rent. Another soldier's wife had to move back, with her children, into the home of her domineering mother and was literally going crazy. A Marine's widowed mother suffered a serious collapse because he was erroneously reported killed in Korea.
Bob Richards yesterday received the twenty-second James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy, voted to him last December as this nation's outstanding amateur athlete of 1951.

HONG KONG, Feb. 17 -- While the Communists are concentrating primarily on organizing the Chinese peasantry into pre-collective "mutual aid" groups, the Soviet type of state farm already has emerged in Red China as a basic model of "Socialist enterprise."

A number of unusual exhibitions are included in this week's art program, notably the attraction at Wildenstein's -- a loan exhibition of American twentieth century paintings selected by New York art critics. Organized for the benefit of the Whitney Museum Purchase Fund, this show will open Wednesday evening with a gala preview to which admission will be $5. The fee later will be 30 cents.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- Hope of finding the missing New Bedford fishing schooner Paolina dwindled today as Coast Guard searchers picked up more gear from the overdue vessel floating approximately forty miles southeast of the Nantucket lightship.

Old Persian motifs and large floral patterns, the latter reminiscent of those executed in a contemporary French manner, are but two types of designs included in the new Waverly collection of decorator fabrics of F. Schumacher Co. All of these will be available by Wednesday in stores here.

Reminiscing old timers drew verbal pictures last night of life and times in the old Chelsea section more than a half century ago as they recounted the origin and development of the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House, 436 West Twenty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- It has been an unsettled and unsatisfactory week for business and the financial markets generally. The shadow of national mourning for the late King has fallen over the whole picture, while the general trend of other events has not been favorable particularly for the stock markets.

Sidney Holland, Prime Minister and Finance Minister of New Zealand, brought news on his arrival in New York yesterday from London that his country was developing 900,000 acres of forests to produce soft wood pulp for the manufacture of paper. Mr. Holland will discuss the project at a dinner of the America-Australian Association at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Dewey's record-setting $1,093,000,000 state budget probably will be approved in the Senate this week without any major change either through increased appropriations or reduced taxes, Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Republican majority leader, said today.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Allied troops smashed a strong Communist attack on the west- central front in Korea yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Agreement was reached early today on a new contract which would bring average wage increases of $5.36 weekly, plus a $150 lump sum, to Prudential Insurance company agents.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities, reporting again on its own activities, may be listened to more respectfully than it used to be. We have grown Communist-conscious, and with reason. This fact does not, of course, prove that all those accused by the committee of being Communists actually are such nor does it vindicate some of the committee's haphazardly unfair procedure.
The week-end at the City Center saw the season's first performance of "Sylvia: Pas de Deux," "A la Francaix," "Bourree Fantasque" and "Age of Anxiety" by the New York City Ballet.

Tributes to the accomplishments of the Jan Hus Bohemian Brethren Presbyterian Church, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, were paid yesterday at a special service, dinner and afternoon program that marked the beginning of a yearlong celebration of the church's seventy-fifth anniversary.

On a wind-swept corner at York Avenue and Ninety-first Street, twenty-year-old Candlewood Farms of Brookfield, Conn., has opened a New York outlet to provide old and new customers with fresh eggs, butter and poultry, hickory-smoked ham and bacon.

It is now about a year since the City Planning Commission made public the comprehensive Harrison, Ballard Allen plan for a complete rezoning of New York City. Drafted at a cost of more than $300,000, the plan was designed to provide the framework for a modern zoning system that would replace the existing Zoning Resolution, or zoning law, that took effect in 1916.

PALERMO, Sicily, Feb. 17 -- A twin-engine British Viking airliner with thirty-one persons aboard smashed into 4,600-foot Mount Rose in the Sicilian mountains last night. Search planes spotted the wreckage today and one pilot saw three persons -- survivors or native peasants -- waving and a body lying in the open.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- In a message, Britain's Queen Mother commended her daughter Queen Elizabeth II to the nation tonight and said "in the great and lonely station to which she has been called she will need your protection and your love."

Two composers' groups gave programs over the week-end that were integrated into the WNYC American Music Festival because they fell within the time-span of the festival, which runs from Lincoln's birthday to Washington's.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 17 -- A large United States air base, capable of handling B-36 bombers, will be constructed soon on this British-ruled island as part of the strategic defense plan in the Middle East, a reliable American source reported here today. The source added that American personnel at the base would total about 3,000 men.

Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, predicted yesterday that Israel and the surrounding Arab nations ultimately would cooperate in peace and understanding that would result in widespread economic progress in the entire Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The Government certified New York and twenty-two other city areas today as labor-surplus regions eligible for special consideration in the award of defense contracts.
Cutbacks in new housing this year may force 25,000 furniture and bedding workers into unemployment, Morris Pizer, president of the United Furniture Workers of America, C. I. O., declared yesterday.

Lydia Karine, a French mezzo-soprano, made her American debut on Saturday evening in Town Hall, singing music by Melani, Schubert, Duparc, Faure, Debussy, de Falla, Granados and Nin. There also were first New York performances of five songs by Marcel Delannoy, three African chants harmonized by Barat-Pepper, and several Armenian folksongs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The latest score on business activity in 1951 showed today that the country's output of goods and services rose to $328,000,000,000, compared with $283,000,000,000 in 1950.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 17 -- Italy was understood today to have suggested the appointment of an Italian admiral as deputy Commander in Chief of the Allied forces in southern Europe in an effort to overcome the opposition of Turkey and Greece to the placing of their armies under Lieut. Gen. Maurizio Lazzaro de Castiglione of Italy as commander of Allied land forces in southern Europe.

KOHAT PASS, Pakistan, Jan. 11 (By Airmail) -- Every day is market day here, and business seems to be fine. The market takes up the whole of the only street of this little fortified village. Its wares ? Small arms and ammunition.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company last year realized net earnings of $15,476,754, equal to $3.01 a share on record sales of $176,164,620, according to the report of John D. Biggers, president. With taxes taking $34,000,000 or $6.61 a share, 1951 earnings were sharply reduced from the $24,752,425 or $4.82 a share earned in 1950 when sales totaled $170,056,311, the executive noted.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Nervous, choppy markets were the rule on the Board of Trade last week, with the trend irregularly downward in all grains. Bulls have made some efforts to rally support, but while there has been evidence of considerable accumulation on dips, buying in general was inclined to be listless.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 18 -- Communist negotiators pressed again yesterday for the inclusion of the Soviet Union as one of the neutral nations to police an armistice in the Korean war. The proposal, previously turned down by the United Nations Command, was rejected once more by the Allied delegation in the truce meetings at Panmunjom.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The French cotton milling industry is in the midst of a severe slump which has resulted in the closing of a number of factories and has caused others to reduce hours of work. In certain cases workers are employed not more than thirty-two hours a week instead of forty-five to forty-eight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Following is the text of the report issued today on the Yale University Advisory Committee's survey of "The Intellectual and Spiritual Welfare of the University, Its Students, and Its Faculty."

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The United States, British and French foreign ministers agreed today to bar West Germany from entering the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a full member -- for the time being.

Stuart Miller Crocker, chairman of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., one of the nation's largest natural gas producing and distributing systems, declared yesterday that "higher gas rates are inevitable."

Brenda Lewis, American soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera's touring company of "Fledermaus," will make her debut with the home company on Tuesday, Feb. 26, when she sings Musetta in the season's ninth performance of Puccini's "La Boheme."
More than 2,000 persons crowded into the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday to pay final tribute to King George VI.

Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe, duo-pianists, were the soloists on the Saturday night and Sunday afternoon Philharmonic-Symphony concerts in Carnegie Hall. They played Vaughan Williams' Concerto for Two Pianos in its first New York performances.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Rookie Real Chevrefils tallied his first major league goals in seventeen games today to spark the Bruins to a 5-to-2 triumph over the Black Hawks before 6,206 matinee fans at the Stadium.

When the new ruling of the Department of Traffic requiring the use of low-beam headlights rather than parking lights for driving in the city streets was promulgated it seemed clearly to be a step in the interest of safety. We still think the order is a good one, in so far as one-way streets and the dark side streets are concerned.

All locals of the International Longshoremen's Association A. F. L., in this port have been ordered to produce their books and records at the office of Waldman Waldman union attorneys, for examination and inspection. The order was given in a letter signed by Joseph P. Ryan, union president, copies of which were sent to each local on Thursday.

The United Nations negotiators in Korea are reported to have rejected without any conspicuous delay the Communist proposal that the Soviet Union be chosen as one of the "neutral" nations to contribute to the observation of a truce. The reason, it was announced, was "obvious," and it would certainly seem so to most persons in the free world.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 (UP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias faltered on the final four holes but still had enough to win the first 36-hole lap of the $17,000 Weathervane coast-to-coast golf tournament today.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Platinum gray, natural, oyster white, mink and beige follow the pale color trend of the season in Athena's new spring and summer suit collection, shown here this week. Navy is another important color, especially in combinations with polka dots or white inserts, binding and other detail.
SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights.

PARIS Feb. 17 -- Analysis of the vote in the National Assembly early today on giving priority to the French Government's resolution regarding the terms for setting up a European army, showed that opposition to the present army plan cut through all party lines.

IN this country Graham Greene's reputation depends almost exclusively on his fiction, his melodramatic novels of crime and espionage, which he calls "entertainments," and his serious novels about adultery and religion.
