Mr. Greene is unquestionably a brilliant writer, but he is not always a convincing one. Few modern writers have been so extravagantly overpraised.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The American Red Cross today reported a heavy demand for measles serum to fight the disease that had reached "epidemic proportions in a number of states."

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- A soap manufacturer's deathbed order that his firm contribute to charity "forever" $2 out of every $3 of net profits has brought $30,000,000 to hospitals, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and other institutions during the last thirty years, it was revealed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Marked by Hal Wallis for late summer or early fall production is "Key West," a suspense story written in screen play form by John Lucas. Charlton Heston and Lizabeth Scott will be co-starred in the picture, which, according to present plans, will be made on location in the Florida keys.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 -- Last week the steel ingot operating rate dropped half a point to 100 per cent of rated capacity. The trade considered this minor fluctuation to be insignificant and not indicating any definite downward trend. In fact, there was evidence that the industry would more than surpass an extra million tons of ingots over last year's record during the first quarter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, accused the House Committee on Un-American activities today of making a "misleading and unfair" report on Communist influence in Hollywood.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- The National Zionist Administrative Council of the Zionist Organization of America approved today plans for building trade schools and an American business college in Israel.

A project that may lead to a modified decentralization of the city's huge school system was made public yesterday with the disclosure that a citizens' committee in the northeast Bronx would function soon as an elected "board of education" to help administer eleven schools in that area.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Sir Thomas Beecham, 72-year-old symphony conductor, was resting comfortably today after a "very painful" attack of sciatica, which caused cancellation of last night's San Francisco Symphony concert.

Installation of equipment for the oft-delayed alternate-side-of-the-street parking plan on the upper West Side will start tomorrow, with the prohibitions slated to become effective by April 15, Acting Traffic Commission T. T. Wiley said yesterday.

In your issue of Feb. 8 you published a letter from Louis P. Goldberg in which he maintains that New York rapid transit is a necessary special service whose deficits should be paid by those who can afford it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The State Department said today that the Communist use what they describe as land reforms to exploit rural discontent in the interests of the Reds' seizure of power.

Cuba, Nicaragua and Panama have been rated highest in the forty-seventh semi-annual survey conducted by he Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau on commercial credit and collection condition in Latin-American markets during the last half of 1951, it was announced over the weekend by Philip J. Gray, bureau manager.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- The successful treatment of lumbago, rheumatism, sciatica and similar diseases as well as mild forms of arthritis by sound vibrations beyond the range of human hearing has been reported here by medical authorities.

OSLO, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, the 19-year-old Rutland, Vt., competitor who went hurtling after her second gold medal, lost her balance during the women's downhill ski race today when she made a daring jump and skidded into soft snow.

The fourth concert in the Choral Masterwork Series that Robert Shaw is presenting in Carnegie Hall with his Collegiate Chorale had Beethoven's Mass in D -- the "Missa Solemnis" -- on last night's program.

Fred Thomas, one of last year's winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. He showed again that he is a serious and straightforward young artist with a fine natural voice.

MAXWELL AIR FORCE BASE, Montgomery, Ala., Feb. 17 -- New courses and additional responsibilities planned for the Air University soon will expand the scope and administrative authority of one of the nation's largest educational enterprises.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Changes in the membership of the Wage Stabilization Board expected to be announced soon include the appointment of Arthur M. Ross, chairman of the San Francisco regional wage board, as a public member. He will take the place of William Hepburn of Georgia, until the latter, who is ill, returns to his post.

Victor Dyrgall, the national marathon champion who is hoping for a berth on the American Olympic team, yesterday won the senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 15-kilometer run which started and ended at the Yankee Stadium.

Airline officials began work yesterday on new schedules to trim La Guardia Airport traffic by a third in accordance with a plan announced Saturday night by the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee of Government and private aviation leaders headed by Edward V. Rickenbacker.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Yale University, which completed its first 250 years last October, has no Communist on its faculty, has no faculty member seeking to undermine democracy, has not engaged in "intimidation" that might affect academic freedom and currently has a religious life "deeper and richer" than it has had in years, an alumni committee reported today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Jack Russell, 46-year-old big league pitcher of the 1926-40 era, won the baseball players' golf championship today by defeating Dick Bartell, Detroit Tigers coach, 3 and 2, in the 18-hole final at the Miami Springs Country Club.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 17 -- Officials of the United States High Commissioner's office in Germany have advised the State Department against the creation of a national German army under the command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should a German contribution to a European army fail to materialize.
Seven new films, including importations from England, France and Italy are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Development by the Army and its civilian research agencies of a simple paper dressing to treat persons burned in an atomic attack was reported today in an interview by Maj. Gen. George E. Armstrong, Army Surgeon General.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 17 -- Police emergency crews used a rope lift early this morning to rescue a man who had been injured when his automobile plunged off a bridge sixty feet over the Long Island Rail Road tracks at Cutter Mill Road.

With an emergency goal-tender playing for them, the New York Rangers defeated the Canadiens of Montreal last night in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden, 3 to 2. The battle was witnessed by a crowd of 12,118, and the fans followed the tense action to the final second.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- The body of Pius X, "the Pope of Peace," who died shortly after the outbreak of World War I, was moved with solemn rites to its final resting place today in the Chapel of the Presentation in St. Peter's Basilica. Pius X was beatified last June and it is hoped that the "cause" of his beatification will be completed in time to permit his being raised to sainthood in 1953.

CAIRO, Feb. 17 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha, broadcasting to the United States, stated today that Egypt was prepared to cooperate fully and wholeheartedly in the maintenance of world peace through a strong and remodeled regional organization functioning within the framework of the United Nations Charter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- A wave of indignation arose today over the exclusion by secret ballot, of the Sing Sheng family from the Southwood residential district of South San Francisco, an industrial suburb.

A program of contemporary music that certainly should have been included on the WNYC American Music Festival was offered in Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon. Stuart Fastofsky was the selfless and able violin soloist. Around him were gathered two young composers, a pianist, a chamber orchestra and an audience that applauded after every movement.

ZURICH, Feb. 17 -- Restrictions on trade imposed abruptly this month by Britain and France in their efforts to escape the mischief of further monetary devaluation have led to such serious economic dislocation that many authorities in Switzerland fear that the European Payments Union might be forced to cease operations when the two-year trial period terminates at the end of June.

Last week's foreign exchange market was one of the dullest in months. Turnover was small and fluctuations narrow. The Tuesday holiday here, and the closing of the banks in Canada on Friday on the occasion of the funeral of King George, were responsible for the reduced interest.

There is a great deal of sleeve news in spring fashions. Patterns of The Times offers three styles in one pattern this week. An ingenious dress designed by Advance can have the bouffant cape sleeve, the balloon or lantern, or the long slim tapered sleeve.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17 -- A priceless collection of Mexican art is being assembled in New York, Paris and Mexico City for showing in Paris, Stockholm and, possibly, some other European capitals later this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The Treasury will offer a $1,024,000,000 bond issue tomorrow marking a partial departure from its much-criticized postwar "cheap" money policy.
On page 11 of your Feb. 8 edition it is prominently and erroneously stated that Queen Elizabeth becomes head of the Church of Scotland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate investigations subcommittee will seek to learn in public hearings beginning tomorrow the full extent of profits reaped by individuals and of tax losses suffered by the government on transactions involving war surplus ships.

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today that he believed the Asian friends of the United States should be permitted to "build and use" their own armies in the fight for peace and freedom.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The second annual conference on United States responsibility for World leadership opened here today under the auspices of the American Association for the United Nations.

" Don Gehrmann ran in Madison Square Garden for the first time." So observed a bemused bystander Saturday night after the Wisconsin Whippet, in a fiercely prideful expression of his suspected but previously undemonstrated greatness, stepped out on his own to shatter all records for 1,000 yards.

The much discussed "General Motors" wage contract, first introduced in 1948, attracted widespread attention at the time because of its two basic "escalation" clauses. It called for (1) cost of living adjustments every three months, and (2) a flat increase of 4 cents an hour annually, which was technically referred to as the "annual improvement factor."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A draft of legislation to establish a national water resources and related land conservation policy has been forwarded to the White House by the President's Water Resources Policy Commission.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 17 -- Tension caused by recent floggings in this section abated today following the arrest of ten former Ku Klux Klansmen on charges of kidnapping and violating civil rights.

" Back Door to War: Roosevelt Foreign Policy, 1933-1941," by Charles Callan Tansill, an argument against the belief that the United States was forced into World War II, will be published in May by Henry Regnery. The author, Professor of Diplomatic History at Georgetown University, has based his book on the confidential files of the State Department and the manuscript collections in the National Archives and the Library of Congress.

VIENTIANE, Indo-China, Feb. 17 -- Laos is making steady progress in cleaning up insurrectionary forces within her borders. This country is now regarded as the most peaceful of the three Indo-China states and if the Communistled Vietminh insurgent forces and their allies could be defeated elsewhere in Indo-China, Laotian and French authorities here believe Laos could achieve complete pacification in the next twelve to eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) -- Dorothy Maynor, noted Negro soprano, sang in Constitution Hall today -- the first Negro artist to perform commercially in the D. A. R. headquarters since before 1939. She opened her concert with Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's aria extolling human brotherhood and understanding.

There is genuine drama in the announcement that our recently resigned Ambassador to Moscow, Admiral Alan G. Kirk, has been elected chairman of the American Committee for Liberation of the Peoples of Russia. In accepting this new post Admiral Kirk made a statement which all of us would do well to remember:

Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue, Vicar-General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, blessed and broke ground yesterday afternoon for a new edifice for the Church of the Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary on 240th Street near Broadway, the Bronx.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 17 -- President Getulio Vargas has taken emergency steps for immediate work on projects totaling $10,000,000 during the first half of this year as a small step in the program to put Brazil's seaports into better condition. Improvement of shipping facilities is one of the most vital steps in the country's general development, since at present seaports represent so many bottlenecks hampering distribution.

As a visitor from Malaya I am grateful to you for your recent editorial "Red Pattern in Malaya." It is about time someone gave a true picture of the situation in Malaya. During my stay here for the past seven months I have noted that certain magazines have written about the Communist terrorism in Malaya, which they identified as a "liberation movement." I refer, of course, to the Leftist and "liberal" magazines.

Any idea that Lithuania moved of its own free will to join the Soviet system was rejected yesterday at a meeting to celebrate the thirty-fourth anniversary of the Baltic nation's independence -- an independence that has been only theoretical since June, 1940.
AMSTERDAM, Feb. 17 -- After a long period of hesitancy stock market prices suddenly relapsed with losses between two and five points due to less favorable domestic, industrial and trade news.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 18 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1, 163, for Sunday's operations:

BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 17 -- Sigurd Sorensen, 25-year-old Norseman from Brooklyn, today won the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's Class A jumping championship despite a blinding snowstorm which hampered flights off the tricky 80-meter hill.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Britain has an atomic weapon -- or soon will have. That fact, long a subject of surmise in this country and the United States, was confirmed officially tonight in an announcement from Prime Minister Churchill's office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A New York lawyer denounced as "a hoax on the public" today a Reconstruction Finance Corporation report denying that fraud and collusion were involved in an $80,000,000 R. F. C. loan to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company.

Jascha Heifetz, violinist, will inaugurate a "Meet the Master" filmed video program over N. B. C.-TV next Sunday at 5:30 P. M. The series will be presented on alternate Sunday afternoons thereafter, with other noted musicians participating.

Attracted to "Seventh Heaven," undoubtedly, because of his French antecedents, Arthur Lesser has acquired the rights to the Austin Strong play. John Golden, producer-director of the hit, which opened here in 1922 with Helen Menken and George Gaul and ran for 704 performances, confirmed the purchase yesterday.
A Beethoven-Purcell program was presented late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by the New Friends of Music.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Unlimited hydroplanes -- the Gold Cup boats -- raced in Miami Beach waters today for the first time since 1929 as the thirty-ninth annual Biscayne Bay regatta got under way. High winds delayed the start one day.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 17 -- Economic and military leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today to recommend an increase in authority for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to the alliance's Council of Ministers.

OTTAWA, Feb. 18 -- Cigarette smuggling across the Canadian border from the United States has got completely out of hand as the result of excessive taxation in this country Finance Minister Douglas Abbott was told today by Canadian tobacco growers.

CAIRO, Feb. 18 -- The parliamentary majority, made up of the Wafd party of former Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha, whose cabinet fell after the Cairo riots of Jan. 26, put up today, for the first time, definite opposition to a Government measure for a 5,000,000 Egyptian ($14,400,000) grant for the reconstruction business establishments burned out in the riots.

An eight-point program governing football, including the abolition of spring practice and post-season games, was announced simultaneously yesterday by the presidents of eight Ivy League colleges--Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Princeton and Yale.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Feb. 18 (Reuters) -- Japanese doctors, basing their claims on case histories of Hiroshima victims, said yesterday that atomic radiation did not cause women to become permanently sterile or to produce monstrous children.

Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan commended yesterday six members of the narcotics squad and four detectives attached to the West Thirtieth Street Station for excellent police work in the solution of recent crimes.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 18 -- An Estonian harmlessly exploded two crudely fashioned grenades in the United States Embassy here this afternoon after a visa had been denied to him to rejoin his wife in Miami, Fla. He then leaped to his death from a seventh-floor window.

The deluge of damage suits that threatened to wash out $2,000,000 from the treasury of the city as a result of its rain-making efforts in the 1950 drought was stemmed yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter, because of a technicality in the drawing of the papers, dismissed more than 100 suits brought by upstaters for alleged damages.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A bill that would strip the United States Trotting Association of all control over harness racing in New York State was submitted to the Legislature tonight with the backing of a special commitee headed by Senate Majority leader Arther H. Wicks. The committee has been conducting a study of racing for the past year.

Justice Hubert T. Delany of the Domestic Relations Court charged yesterday that there were judges here who drank to the point that "they aren't on the bench half the time" but the bar associations endorsed them, nevertheless, year after year, and the church did nothing about it.

William Francis Sutton, the country's most notorious bank robber, was arrested by two uniformed patrolmen yesterday within four blocks of Police Headquarters in Brooklyn. He had lived in the neighborhood for almost two years in miserly obscurity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A critical shortage of newsprint in the United States has temporarily eased, but the world demand will exceed the supply for years to come, a Government official said today.

At least 1,000 underprivileged children of pre-school age continue to be deprived of vitally needed free medical care in the Melrose Housing Project area in the Bronx, because a new city child health center, fully equipped, cannot open its doors.

The new Times Square Station of the Post Office went briskly into operation shortly before 1 P. M. yesterday at 340-46 West Forty-second Street, near Ninth Avenue. The opening followed dedicatory ceremonies conducted by Postmaster Albert Goldman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Trumuan today asked every American to contribute as generously as possible to help the American Red Cross meet its maximum national goal of $85,000,000 this year.
Directors of the United Fruit Company authorized payment of an extra dividend of 50 cents yesterday and a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, on April 15.

Richard Strauss' "Elektra," last given at the Metropolitan in the season of 1938-39, returned to that opera house last night with overwhelming success. The performance was followed by a demonstration of a shouting, cheering audience that lasted a good quarter of an hour.

Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries in the three months ended on Dec. 1 increased net profit to $2,605,000 from $1,813,000 a year ago, according to the report released for publication today.

Less than eight months ago a new Socialist International was born in Frankfurt, Germany, consisting of Socialist parties and exiled groups from thirty-one countries and dedicated to the struggle against communism. But the mere founding of a new International has been unable to overcome the doctrinaire rigidity which has so often vitiated the effectiveness of Socialist parties in the past.

What makes men and women withdraw from the life around them to dwell in obscurity, often in apparent poverty, when they may have at their disposal enough wealth to permit them to live, if not luxuriously, at least more comfortably than many of the people whose company they shun?

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Warner, the attraction is "Retreat, Hell!" a Korean war drama produced by United States Pictures and released by Warner Brothers. Frank Lovejoy, Richard Carlson, Anita Louise and Rusty Tamblyn head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Joseph H. Lewis and produced by Milton Sperling from a screen play by Mr. Sperling and Ted Sherdeman.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 5 points lower to 12 points higher.

The British are about to invade the United States frozen food market in a serious way. Under the brand name "Frood," a choice line of English strawberries, quick frozen in their own puree, is already on the shelves of Gimbel Brothers, Abraham Straus and the delicacy stores of Long Island and New Jersey.

Officials of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., voted yesterday to prepare for a strike on March 15 in the woolen and worsted industry. This action followed their rejection of a proposal by the American Woolen Company that separate contracts be written for each of its twenty-one mills to replace the over-all contract that has been in existence for fourteen years.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- The Communist party's thesis today is that there can be no talk of a "withering away" of the Soviet state at this time, but that on the contrary every means must be taken to strengthen the state's power, and particularly its army and intelligence service because of the "growing threat of a new anti-Soviet war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A minimum industry return of 10 per cent of net worth was introduced today by the Office of Price Stabilization as a consideration in establishing earnings standards for those seeking industry-wide price increases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- An itemized federal budget for the coming fiscal year, proposed by Senator Byrd of Virginia and providing for expenditures at least $8.6 billions less than those contemplated by the Administration, as usual has fallen soundlessly into a gulf of general indifference.

A plea for the city to reduce its present annual tax levies of nearly $3,000,000 on the Long Island Rail Road was voiced yesterday by William Wyer, the road's trustee, before a luncheon of 140 members of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce at 24-16 Bridge Plaza South, Long Island City.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A United States F-86 Sabre jet today destroyed a Soviet-made MIG-15 in a swirling air battle high over Sinanju, in northwest Korea. The fight pitted twenty-seven Sabres against elements of a 100-plane Communist formation.
SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights.

Ernest Anthony, a student at Haaren High School who represents the Catholic Youth Organization, outpointed Joseph Davis of the Police Athletic League in one of the hardest-fought tests in the New York City Golden Gloves finals at Madison Square Garden last night.
TOKYO, Tuesday Feb. 19 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,164, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday, Eastern standard time):

The Authors League of America, which sought intervention by the Federal Communications Commission in the "alleged practice of blacklisting" of radio and television writers, has been informed that such matters "are not properly the subject of a general hearing by the commission."

OSLO, Feb. 18 -- Norway swept the boards in the Olympic events contested today, taking all three first-place Gold Medals, one for the 18-kilometer cross-country ski race, one for the best of the participants who had also scored in yesterday's ski-jumping at Holmenkollen, and another for the 1,500-meter speed skating competition.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- A bill that would make the unlawful growing, possession or sale of marijuana a felony instead of a misdemeanor received unanimous approval in the Assembly tonight. It now goes to the Senate for concurrence.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 18 -- Danbury voted today by 678 to 190 to establish a small claims division of the City Court. Less than 6 per cent of the city's 17,000 eligible voters took part in the special referendum.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- There was some excited and ungenteel conversation in Hialeah's jockey room after the running of today's top race. Greentree Stable's Row Row Row, the favorite, finished last, and Jockey Christopher J. Rogers was more than a bit disturbed by what had happened to the 3-year-old colt as he headed around the bend.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 19 -- The Communist and United Nations truce delegations seemed to have reached a general agreement today on a proposal for an international conference after the start of an armistice in the Korean war to discuss a lasting settlement on the divided peninsula.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The loss of liberty would be greater calamity than another world war, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today told a conference of the American Association for the United Nations meeting in a three-day session here.

McCann-Erickson, Inc., advertising agency, has leased the eighth floor in the De Pinna Building, 650 Fifth Avenue, for its accounting department. The floor was leased from the A. De Pinna Company through Culver, Hollyday Co., and Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

The stock market struck a new low note since early December yesterday. Attempts to rally shares appeared in several sections but all were ineffective. The combined averages index of THE NEW YORK TIMES showed a drop of 0.92 point at the close.

The Wimbledon champions of 1951 and 1931 met in the national indoor tennis tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night and Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., the current titleholder, was the winner, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- It was taken for granted here tonight that the resolution before the French Assembly conditionally approving the European Army plan would be adopted tomorrow, less than twenty-four hours before the North Atlantic Council is to meet at Lisbon to consider it.

The Investment Bankers Association of America had "a perfect right" in 1941 to write to Louis H. Pink, then New York Superintendent of Insurance, to ascertain whether three insurance companies had violated the insurance law by joining together to purchase a $90,000,000 debenture issue of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Senate was asked today to urge a break in diplomatic relations with Communist Czechoslovakia because of her imprisonment of the United States correspondent William N. Oatis.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 18 (UP) -- Mrs. Mary Jean Parsons was in jail today while authorities pieced together the story of why she shot her husband after quarreling over financial aid they were receiving from her wealthy parents.

TOKYO, Feb. 18 -- North Koreans fed up with communism have formed guerrilla bands with South Korean irregulars and have been carrying out a hit-and-run war behind the Communist lines in North Korea for the last twelve months.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Two bills to enable violators of local traffic ordinances to plead guilty and pay their fines by mail, rather than having to face court arraignment, were passed unanimously by the Senate and sent to the Assembly tonight.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 18 -- Millard Romaine Jr. of Cincinatti, a 19-year-old Williams College sophomore, was found shot dead this morning in an unused attic room of his fraternity house less than twenty-four hours after the end of the college's annual Winter Carnival.

GRAND HAVEN, Mich., Feb. 18--A crew of movers with heavy hauling equipment started today the job of relocating the main buildings of the 100-year-old town of Agnew on United States Highway No. 31 seven miles south of here.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) -- Financial experts studying investment, development and long-term borrowing projects within the British Commonwealth have ended their private talks here, a reliable source said today.

Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Philadelphia Orchestra, Alexander Hilsberg, conductor, Claudio Arrau, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Jerome Rappaport, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Eileen Schauler, soprano, and Allen Rogers, piano, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 3; Rebe Colman and Helen Rice, sopranos, Stephen E. Henderson, tenor, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 9.

The bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which has been on the verge of liquidation a dozen times in the last year, informed Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday that it was finally breaking even on bus lines that carry more than 1,000,000 riders a day in Manhattan and the Bronx.
The letter which was published in your paper of Jan. 26 from Rudolf Lodgman von Auen has filled me with horror and apprehension.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Stricter conditions for granting American financial aid to foreign countries were urged today by Representative Edna F. Kelly of Brooklyn at the first legislative conference of the women's division of the Democratic State Committee.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders debated Mayor Impellitteri's requests for state help in solving New York City's financial problems for nearly six hours this afternoon without reaching any final decisions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Representative Walter E. Brehm, Republican of Ohio, asked the United States Court of Appeals today to reverse his conviction on charges of taking illegal salary kickbacks from an office clerk to help finance his election campaigns.

Recent reports in the press as to investigations now being conducted by the New York State Insurance Department raise again a question as to the adequacy of the laws regulating the life insurance companies enacted by the Legislature in 1906 as a result of the sweeping investigations made by the late Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation advised Mayor Impellitteri yesterday that conversion of Seventh Avenue to one-way operation would be "a direct violation" of its bus line franchise and called on the Mayor to direct Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to call off the project.

A program for increasing safety and reducing noise at La Guardia Airport and the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, has won approval of all parties concerned, the Queens Committee on Community Aviation Problems announced after a four-hour meeting at Queens Borough Hall yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18 -- In the first important move taken to stem the rising tide of Argentine inflation, President Juan Peron tonight announced a major revision in the Government's agricultural policies. Argentine farmers who have long felt themselves to be the whipping post of the country's economy, received a promise of an increase in payments of approximately 33 per cent for their crops this year.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Senate approved tonight a bill to close a loophole in the personal property law that permits the investment of 57.75 per cent of trust funds in equity securities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Former President Herbert Hoover declared tonight that "the flood of exposures of less than sacred honor or real patriotism" in government imparts a "special urgency" to the drive for reform and reorganization of the Civil Service Commission and the whole Federal personnel system.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Arthur S. Flemming, assistant to the Director of Defense Mobilization, warned personnel managers of American industry today to put into effect sound training programs based on the long-term needs of their companies and of the nation. This action is needed, he said, to keep the handling of manpower problems on a voluntary basis.
A new approach to the whole problem of planning the bathroom has been announced by the Crane Company, in whose opinion this particular part of the home has been sadly neglected in recent years.

Acquisition by the General Realty and Utilities Corporation of New York of a large realty holding on Euclid Avenue in Cleveland, Ohio, was announced here yesterday by Donald B. Callender, vice president of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., brokers in the deal, in conjunction with Heaton Pennington, Inc.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Olga Hajek, chairman, and Miss Elise Heck, co-chairman, are assisting Mrs. Lee S. Hartman and her aides on the executive committee in plans for the Thrift Gift Drive in behalf of the Play Schools Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Wage Stabilization Board completed action today on a pay-rise policy for commission employes without making any change in their commission rates.

It was most discouraging to read in THE TIMES that legislative leaders report that their mail runs about four to one against the Metcalf-Hatch Animal Research Bill, when we know that only a tiny percentage of the electorate are opposed to this legislation. This is no political phenomenon; a highly articulate minority has delayed progress before, but in this particular matter may I suggest a means of hearing from more of the majority.

Jobs will be few and plant capacity for manufacture of structural steel will go unused by early in the summer unless the Government releases approved orders for construction -- in volume and in a hurry.

Progress in Israel has been "phenomenal in the light of the terrible handicaps and obstacles" that have faced the Government, Rabbi Izchak Meyer Lewin, Minister of Welfare of Israel, said yesterday on his arrival at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for a four-week tour of Jewish communities in American cities.

HONG KONG, Feb. 18 -- Seven private contractors were sentenced to death and forty-seven others to jail terms on charges of defrauding the state in construction work on the Tienshui-Lanchow Railway in Northwest China. A Communist dispatch disclosed today they were tried before a mass meeting of 10,000 persons at Tienshui, Kansu Province, Jan. 21.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Government departments and agencies opposed further railroad freight rate increases at hearings today before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A witness at a Senate Internal Security subcommittee hearing refused to answer a question today on the ground that she was forbidden to do so by United Nations regulations.

A special Federal grand jury will be impaneled today to inquire into government corruption and racketeering in the Southern District of New York, United States Attorney Myles J. Lane announced yesterday. The scope of the inquiry will be national and international.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Truman asked Congress today to appropriate $360,248,306 more to pay the wage increases it voted for Federal employes last October.

I hope every owner of real estate in New York City is busy writing to the Mayor and to the Governor protesting this unfair "county tax" and urging some of that economy which Mayor Impellitteri promised so fervently before he was elected.

Intercoastal shipping, which has been in the doldrums since World War II and which survived a crisis last fall by raising freight rates, is still said to be operating on a slender margin of profit, wth business continuing its downward grade.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 18 -- Norway and Denmark have advised their Atlantic Pact allies of their intention to increase their minimal term of national military service to eighteen months, thus bringing to a year and a half the smallest period of conscription among any of the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- The Screen Writers Guild today announced the names of the scenarists who, in the opinion of their colleagues, contributed the most outstanding work to the screen last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- President Truman today endorsed as "reasonable" a proposal by Senator Blair Moody, Democrat of Michigan, to increase Federal aid for unemployment insurance in states where defense contracts had caused joblessness in civilian industries.

CHATHAM, Mass., Feb. 18 -- Two tankers, believed to have eighty-four crewmen aboard, were torn apart today off Cape Cod by giant waves driven by this winter's worse storm. At least nine men on one ship, including the captain, were believed dead.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Wheat and other grains reacted from early tops this morning, but developed a stronger tone again in the late trade, moving up sharply from the setbacks. In wheat there was a little early mill buying against domestic flour sales, but after this buying subsided there was indifferent support until prices had declined 1 cent or more, when commission absorption again broadened.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- A directed verdict of not guilty was given today in the case against The Times of London and two other defendants charged with corrupt practices in the 1951 general election.

More than 200 of the 2,300 field employes in the local offices of the Bureau of Internal Revenue have been asked to file statements of their net worth with the House Ways and Means subcommittee studying tax frauds, and 100 of them are "definitely under investigation."

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- Friction engendered among Massachusetts Republicans by the struggle for Presidential convention delegates burst into flame today with the release of letters exchanged by Daniel Tyler Jr., State Republican Chairman, and Basil Brewer of New Bedford, manager of Senator Robert A. Taft's campaign here.

Patients and personnel in five hospitals representing the city's five boroughs simulated conditions and counter-measures of an atomic attack yesterday morning in an air raid drill staged to dramatize the need for 220,000 volunteers for the hospital facilities section of the Office of Civil Defense.

The American Women's Association and the Girls' Service League will be joint beneficiaries of the performance of "Venus Observed," with Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer, on the night of March 12 at the Century Theatre. Mrs. Fraser M. Horn is chairman for the Girls' Service League and Miss Elizabeth Arden for the American Women's Association.
ROME, Feb. 18 -- The Monks of St. Bernard have been obliged by Chinese Communist authorities to close their hospice and refuge in the Himalaya Mountains, the Vatican radio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The abolition of the filibuster and the adoption of civil rights laws "must be made the most important political and moral issue in the coming election campaign," Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., told the National Leadership Conference on Civil Rights tonight.

The double-barreled shotgun with which Mrs. Mary Silas beat a burglary suspect to death early yesterday boomeranged against her. She accidentally shot herself in the stomach while subduing the intruder in her ground-floor flat at 51 West 139th Street.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- Cornell University announced today the creation of a central university archives to collect and preserve its historical records. Deane W. Malott, university president, said the unit would function as a division of the university library and would be directed by Mrs. Edith M. Fox.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Various aspects of the transactions involving eight surplus war tankers through which an original $101,000 private investment was run in three years into a $3,250, 000 profit have been referred to the Department of Justice "for study," the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee was told today by Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, Maritime Administrator.

It was encouraging to hear Premier Aly Maher Pasha talk reasonably in a broadcast to the United States on Sunday about a regional Middle Eastern pact for collective security. This is what we in the West are all hoping for, and it is a welcome change to hear the subject discussed without passion and on its merits.

Even before the New York Legislature convened on Jan. 9, in this Presidential-election year, it was obvious that Republican majority leaders had put up a "Do Not Disturb" sign. On Jan. 5 our correspondent at Albany, Leo Egan, reported the existence of "an effort to avoid any new occasions for internal party rifts."

" Get out and use 'shanks' mare'" may in the near future become more than just a popular admonition by sales executives in their efforts to get more out of their men. The reason is strong possibility of a shortage of automobiles, so necessary to millions of outside salesmen for carrying out their duties.

An investment banking group headed by the First National Bank of Chicago submitted the best bid yesterday for seven issues of bonds totaling $19,350,000 offered by the City and County of San Francisco, Calif.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, one of the larger operating units in the Bell System, announced yesterday plans for a $70,000,000 new financing program, the proceeds of which will be used for new construction purposes. Application for approval of the program was filed yesterday with the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners at Trenton.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (UP) -- State-wide support of a drive to make a national shrine of the Brooklyn burial places of 256 Maryland soldiers killed in the Revolutionary War was asked here today by the 29th Division Association.

A new Chinese restaurant must indeed be outstanding to gain attention in this city, where so many establishments specialize in delicacies of the East. The Oriental House that 24-year-old Teddy Wong has just opened at 39 West Fifty-second Street should succeed, for it possesses the essentials -- good food, a clean, pleasant atmosphere and a genial host.

OSLO, Feb. 18 (UP) -- A fighting Marine from Minnesota scored four goals in leading the unbeaten United States ice hockey team to an easy 8-to-2 victory over Finland today. It was the Americans' third success in the Olympic round-robin tournament.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 -- The Government's representations against fifteen California Communists during the first ten days of their trial in United States district court were subjected to critical scrutiny today by the presiding judge, William C. Mathes.

The preliminary report for 1951 of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and subsidiaries issued yesterday shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $26,500,128. This was equal to $1.93 a share on the utility's outstanding capital stock and compares with a net of $29,129,284, or $2.12 a share, in the preceding year.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- The winter's worst storm battered New England today with up to thirty-one inches of snow, caused at least thirty deaths, stranded several thousand motorists and tore apart two ships at sea.
Since the $64,000 robbery of the Sunnyside, Queens, branch bank of the Manufacturers Trust Company, in March, 1950, Willie Sutton had been one of the nation's most widely sought criminals.

The spring collection of suits and dresses by Maurice Rentner at Saks Fifth Avenue was placed on exhibition today on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The collection touches the highlights of the day's fashions in a conservative manner, for this great stylist never goes overboard on novelties.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- The Republican legislative leaders approved today for inclusion in the supplemental budget a $30,000 appropriation to help finance a tri-state study of smoke and air pollution control by the Interstate Sanitation Commission.

It is pleasing to note that Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association (A. F. L.), has ordered all locals in this port to produce their books at the offices of Waldman Waldman, the union's attorneys. This is a welcome follow-up of his recent request that the law firm make a survey aimed at correcting "any abuses or undemocratic activities that might exist."

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Democratic leaders asked the legislature tonight to endorse the Board of Regents proposal to establish a state-wide system of eleven television stations for educational purposes. They said it offered an unparalleled oportunity to improve educational methods.

RAJKOT, India, Feb. 18 -- A 34-year-old bandit, who is said to have murdered seventy-two persons in the last three years and always marked the scene of his crime with a taunting letter to the police written on blue note paper decorated with forget-me-nots, is terrorizing this 24,000 square-mile state of Saurashtra and has become a national concern with heavy political overtones.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Greyhound Corporation of Chicago asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for approval of the purchase of all the outstanding securities of American Buslines, Inc., also of Chicago, and its subsidiaries, and a redistribution of their transcontinental bus routes.

SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 18 -- By a unanimous vote of its five members the City Council of South San Francisco tonight "deplored and disavowed" the opposition to the occupancy of a house in its Southwood residential district by the family of Sing Sheng, a Chinese.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission estimated today that additional revenues amounting to slightly more than $1,000,000 would result from new charges it is authorized to make under the proposed Independent Office Appropriations Act of 1952.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, accused the Truman Administration today of "inexcusable and terrible negligence" in not providing enough air support for United States troops in Europe.

As a follow-up to his surprising announcement last week that two basketball triple-headers would be staged in the opening rounds of the National Invitation tournament, which starts at Madison Square Garden on March 8, Asa S. Bushnell, chairman of the tourney committee, reported another unusual twist yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 18 -- A husky minister, who turned down a professional football offer to become a pastor, told the police here today how he had thwarted and captured a burglar in his church with a tackle and combination hammer-lock and choke-hold.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Libya's Government indicated today it was ready to handle demonstrations that some officials fear may mar the new nation's first national elections tomorrow.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- The United States dollar is currently worth about 98 cents in Canadian money at a number of places across the border.

Any discussion of issues that are to be raised in connection with a general Far Eastern "peace" settlement must again swing the spotlight to the question of the future of Formosa. The United States will be obliged to defend its policy against attacks from quite differing quarters and it will be essential that Americans know what that policy is and why it was reached.

The Office of Price Stabilization was urged yesterday by the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., to decontrol fabrics made of rayon, acetate, silk and man-made fibers. Such action, the federation held, was in line with the recent decision of O. P. S. to eliminate ceilings where price pressure was non-existent.

Volume of trading in the New York commodity futures markets dropped to the lowest levels of recent months yesterday. There were only 11 deals in coffee, 201 in cocoa, 224 in cottonseed oil, 328 in the combined sugar contracts and 18 in soybean oil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senate friends of the long-pending legislation designed to grant full statehood to the Territories of Alaska and Hawaii met in "strategy session" today. They decided to press for an early voting showdown this week.

The New York City Housing Authority's sixty-eigh t projects with 265,000 tenants were hit yesterday by a "demonstration" work stoppage that took three-fourth of the buildings' maintenance workers off their jobs.

Ever since 1945, up to the present, the Treasury has adhered to a policy of refunding its comparatively high-interest long-term debt with five-year notes or with certificates running about a year. Because of their short maturities these replacement obligations have carried a low rate of interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- Pennsylvania's primary gained in national significance this afternoon when the names of Generals of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas A. MacArthur and that of Harold E. Stassen were entered in the Republican preferential balloting April 22.
In observance of Brotherhood Week, Mayor Impellitteri called yesterday upon his fellow-citizens to honor and respect the convictions and beliefs of their neighbors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 18 -- An on-the-spot inquiry in the Suez Canal zone has brought out hat Egyptian accusations against British authorities of forced labor practices are "not substantiated," the International Labor Organization reported today.

Probably no exhibition staged by the Sculptors Guild in its relatively short but dynamic history has had so many elements of appeal as the 1952 show that opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Defense today disclosed plans for a new series of atomic tests to be held at Eniwetok Atoll in the mid-Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau announced today that it had dismissed John A. Malone, assistant chief of the Income Tax Division of its San Francisco office. Mr. Malone was indicted last week on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States.

Two veteran performers, both former National Leaguers, Pitcher Johnny Sain and utility man Johnny Hopp, yesterday signed their 1952 Yankee contracts. Roy Hamey, assistant to General Manager George Weiss, said they were the twenty-ninth and thirtieth players to agree to terms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives today formally recommended Universal Military Training of all men at the age of 18 as a means of saving $13,000,000,000 a year in the military budget, once the plan is in full operation.

CAIRO, Feb. 18 -- The Government published four decrees today to remove legal minimum price rules which had maintained the price of cotton, Egypt's principal article of commerce, at artificial panels. The decrees at the same time provided a brake to prevent a too sudden fall.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- With small turnover, a dull tendency was evident in nearly all sections of the stock market here today. In general, however, price declines were not heavy.

Unacceptable excuses from defendants and caustic remarks from the bench characterized the proceeding yesterday in Traffic Court where Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh began four days of special hearings for 333 taxicab drivers who had failed to answer traffic summonses accumulated in the last eighteen months.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- Marie Besnard, 56-year-old French farm woman, will go on trial Wednesday in Poitiers charged with the murder of two husbands and ten other relatives and friends in the last twenty-five years by arsenic poisoning.

A deal has been worked out whereby "Call Me Madam," starring Ethel Merman, will curtail its successful New York run sooner than scheduled so that it can reopen the National Theatre in Washington, D. C., as a legitimate playhouse.

Little did Charles Goodyear realize when he invented the vulcanization of rubber in 1844, that the company bearing his name, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, would be the first rubber manufacturer to cross the $1,000,000,000-sales mark.

The nature of pebbles, glass, nails and other such items being what it is, an automobile's rubber tires do not have an easy time of it. Now the atom is helping to ease the strain. Strontium 90, a byproduct of the Oak Ridge atomic plant, is being used by B. F. Goodrich engineers to make the rubber coating of tire fabrics smoother and help the tires live longer.

Most of us hardly needed to be assured that Yale University was not a hotbed of communism or a center for a crusade against religion. The report of a special alumni committee, made public yesterday, was reassuring in another respect -- namely, in its brave insistence that "the business of a university is to educate, not to indoctrinate, its students."

PARIS, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Despite bland denials from those involved, rumors are flying that many Paris fashion houses are swaying perilously in a cold, financial wind. Hight taxes, higher to come, and increased costs are the problems. The designers admit these are headaches, but the official word from the haute couture syndicate is "Business is better than ever."
Fifty-eight other exhibitors were represented at Columbia University's fifth annual faculty art show yesterday, but, judging by the reception accorded to 11-year-old Judy Mitchell, it was her show.

The Fund for Adult Education has voted grants totaling $355,000 for the new community development program of the Foreign Policy Association, now under way. The fund is an independent organization established by the Ford Foundation.

The first special Congressional election of the year will be held today in northeastern Queens, where four candidates are seeking to succeed T. Vincent Quinn, Democrat, as Representative from the Fifth Congressional district.

ALBANY, Feb. 18--The Public Health Committee of the Assembly tonight reported out favorably the controversial Metcalf-Hatch bill to permit the requisitioning of dogs for medical research from publicly aided pounds.

OTTAWA, Feb. 18 (Canadian Press)--The Government has sent investigators into the United States for a first-hand inquiry into claims that United States-made women's wear was being dumped on the Canadian market at distress prices, it was learned today.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- A Victoria Cross, Britain's highest military award, will be among the 100 decorations and knighthoods presented at Queen Elizabeth's first investiture, at Buckingham Palace on Feb. 27. Her father approved these awards before his death.

THE tropics, says Marston Bates, are "a pleasant place to live and work, full of interesting plants, interesting animals, interesting people." Mr. Bates has earned his right to this opinion, for he has studied the tropics for many years in Honduras, Guatemala, Colombia, the West Indies and Egypt. As a naturalist and biologist working for the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation he spent eight years in Colombia studying mosquitos and yellow fever.

Two five-story store and apartment buildings at 1076 Lexington Avenue and 134 East Seventy-sixth Street, forming an "L" around the southwest corner, have been purchased by David H. Green, investor, from a client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, in a deal negotiated by Charles H. Hayes and George F. Meyer Co., brokers.

A woman, who said she was a model and dancer, and her companion, a 46-year-old ex-convict, were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court as promoters of a $2,000-a-day narcotics business operated from an "out of order" telephone booth in the Times Square area.

Sol Levy, 41-year-old basketball referee, was named yesterday in a seven - count criminal information charging he had conspired with Salvatore Tarto Sollazzo, convicted briber, to fix three National Basketball Association games.

The American Civil Liberties Union in a report issued here yesterday urged formation of standards for the issuance and denial of passports, the creation of administrative machinery for hearing and review, and legislation making issuance of a passport mandatory except for specific reasons.
OSLO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Formal presentation of the winter olympic games medals was made tonight in Bislett Stadium to winners of eight events while national anthems were played.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Western Germany was asked today by Britain, France and the United States to accept speedily the obligation to contribute 11,250,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $2,700,000,000) to Western defense.

A special grand jury charged with investigating corruption, racketeering, bribery and tax frauds was impaneled yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court. Twelve men and eleven women were selected for service.

" There is not one chance in a thousand that Israel and the United States will be at odds," Senator Paul H. Douglas declared yesterday at the opening 1952 fund-raising rally of the women's division of the United Jewish Appeal of New York.

Mrs. Margaret Farrand Thorp, author of "Female Persuasion," "America at the Movies" and "Charles Kingsley," has signed a contract with Oxford University Press to write a biography of the late William Allan Neilson, one of America's foremost educators and president of Smith College from 1917 to 1939.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The nation's grocers today asked for immediate suspension of price controls on all food and food products at the retail and wholesale levels.

An unusually large turnout of blood donors is expected today when a bloodmobile arrives at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street. Civil service employes who work there are scheduled to participate in a one-day mass donation.

John Foster Dulles, State Department adviser, in an address here yesterday to a meeting that included the Prime Minister of New Zealand, described as "a dangerous thing" the differences between the United States and certain British Commonwealth nations concerning policies for the Far East.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18 -- The Giants' bid for a second successive pennant in the National League started rolling today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The council of the Australian Lawn Tennis Association confirmed today that Adelaide, capital of South Australia, would be the site of the 1952 Davis Cup challenge round, defended a gift of $12,600 to Frank Sedgman, and announced the team to play at Wimbledon this summer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A Presidential emergency board today recommended pay increases for mechanical and other personnel of Pan American World Airways. Its report sharply condemned "quickie" work stoppages by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and also reprimanded management.

Madeline Foley and Fredell Lack, who both served in the ranks of the Little Orchestra Society, shared the spotlight as its soloists last night at its seventh concert of the season at Town Hall. They appeared jointly in the Telemann Concerto and later each had a concerto to herself.

A total of $74,565 has been subscribed to date in the 1952 fund-raising campaign of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, it was announced yesterday at the organization's first city-wide report meeting in Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street. The campaign, with a goal of $305,393, began Jan. 24.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina renewed yesterday his attack on partisan deals on nominations for judgeships.

Underwriting syndicates plan to distribute today about $13,000,000 of new common stock of two industrial enterprises, the Koppers Company, Inc., and the Dayton Rubber Company. Proceeds of the stock sales will be used to finance expansion operations and to increase working capital.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Indo-China, Feb. 18 -- The encouraging military outlook in Laos stems to a large extent from the generally satisfactory political situation.
Dr. Helen M. Wallace has been named director of the Department of Health's newly organized Bureau for Handicapped Children, Dr. John F. Mahoney, Commission of Health, announced yesterday.
DENVER, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Tevis F. Morrow, Los Angeles oil man, announced here today he was buying the Bonanza Oil Company of Wyoming for $18,598,560.

The campaign of the American Red Cross for $85,000,000, which begins March 1, should be oversubscribed as a reserve against the danger of a full-scale war this year, Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer asserted yesterday.
The pressure of "penalizing taxation" and the urgent need for new capital make it imperative for commercial banks to consider the issuance of preferred stock, bankers were told yesterday.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, Brotherhood Week chairman for the New York region, called yesterday upon the citizens of the city to join in a "practical opportunity to demonstrate what brotherhood means" by becoming part of this week's Blood for a Brother Gampaign" and donating blood for members of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman asked Congress today to extend for the duration of the national emergency, and six months thereafter, sixty of his wartime emergency powers, including authority to take over and run the nation's railroads.

In your issue of Feb. 4 Prof. Thomas I. Emerson of Yale Law School referred to my representation of John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, in a petition for rehearing before the Supreme Court in the Dennis case.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The continued existence of the historic Brooklyn Academy of Music as a cultural and civic center for New York's most populous borough virtually was assured today as the Senate passed unanimously a bill to permit the city to assume its financial support.

Proposed expenditure for expansion of mine production in the United States and Canada through 1955 amounts to more than $3,600,000,000, speakers reported yesterday at the annual convention of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurigcal Engineers in the Statler Hotel.

After trailing in the opening quarter and being all even 48 -- 48 at the half, the New York Knickerbockers turned back the Minneapolis Lakers at Madison Square Garden, 98 to 96, before 9,207 basketball fans last night. It was the sixteenth straight home victory for the New York five.

The independent voters on the Columbia University regular teaching staffs, would favor President Truman or Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois by a narrow margin over General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Presidency, according to a straw poll conducted by The Columbia Daily Spectator, student newspaper.

The stock market underwent its worst reversal in four months yesterday. Again it was a case of prices melting under limited selling with no support from buyers. Losses at some time during the session ranged to 3 points and the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index fell 2.49 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The first official word of White House reopening plans -- a series of informal afternoon receptions for high officials in May -- was given today by Mrs. James M. Helm, White House social secretary.

A new rinse concentrate that is said to banish generation of static electricity in most synthetic fibers such as nylon, Dacron, Orion and dynel has been developed by the Electro-Chemical Products Corporation, East Orange, N. J. Marketed under the name, "NUL," the product is believed to be the first for the household to offer relief from the discomforts of static electricity in clothing.

The Herb Shriner television show, presented Thursday evenings over the American Broadcasting Company network, is being canceled after the April 3 performance. The sponsor desired to reduce its overhead by presenting the program on alternate weeks, but Mr. Shriner elected to withdraw rather than not be seen on a weekly basis.
City Council President Rudolph Halley last night painted a humorous but grotesque picture of New York's municipal administration.

A novel exhibition for the benefit of a special purchase fund for the Whitney Museum will open with a preview reception this evening at the Wildenstein Galleries. The exhibition consists of seventy American pictures painted since 1900, selected by critics of the Art Digest, Art News, Life, the Magazine of Art, The New York Herald Tribune, Time and THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives turned down today a Republican demand on the Administration to disclose any secret commitments made by President Truman to Prime Minister Church of Britain.

The performance of the Prelude to the third act of "Lohengrin" by the Philadelphia Orchestra, led by Alexander Hilsberg, guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was the first-class curtain raiser of a long and variegated program. A brilliant and masterly performance!

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- Insurgent Republican district leaders, claiming a majority within the city committee, bolted the leadership of Chairman Raymond T. Moniz last night. The group walked out of a meeting when Mr. Moniz refused to recognize a proxy and decided not to attend any future committee sessions at which he presided.
L. F. Manneschmidt has been appointed factory branch manager in Philadelphia for Trailmobile, Inc., Cincinnati, manufacturer of commercial truck-trailers, a subsidiary of Pullman, Inc.

Dimitri Mitropoulos will lead the American premiere of Darius Milhaud's opera "Christophe Colomb," next November, it was announced yesterday. It will be a concert version in Carnegie Hall, with the Philharmonic-Symphony and soloists Eileen Farrell, Mack Harrell, David Lloyd, Norman Scott, John Brownlee, Adolph Anderson and the Schola Cantorum.

A new attempt to obtain a taxicab fare rise was made yesterday by 5,000 owner-drivers when spokesmen for the group delivered petitions calling for a 27 per cent increase to Mayor Impellitteri and City Council President Rudolph Halley.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Governor Dewey signed into law today two drastic bills aimed at reducing narcotics trade and addiction by establishing rigorous penalties for persons repeatedly convicted of violating the state's narcotic drug acts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee overrode its chairman, Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, today and directed him to conduct quick hearings on the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project.
Public and private financing demands will increase this year, the Bankers Trust Company declares in a review of "United States Government Securities and the Money Market," to be issued today.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 19 -- Time has not been standing still since the Rome meeting of the Atlantic Council. The conference which opens here tomorrow will wrestle with the same problems that were left unsolved three months ago. With few exceptions the Ministers who assemble here are the same who met in Rome.

CAIRO, Feb. 19 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha told representatives of the Higher Students Union today, in the presence of four of his Ministers, that he would enter into the earliest negotiations with Britain on the basis of immediate evacuation of the British Suez Canal garrison and unity of the Nile Valley.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Air Force said today that it had revised its policy on the taking of pictures of its plane crashes by newspaper photographers.

The City of Hoboken passed an ordinance yesterday establishing specific rates that may be charged by taxicab drivers for the transfer of steamship passengers from Hoboken piers to points in Manhattan, Brooklyn and other metropolitan areas.

CAIRO, Feb. 19 -- The previous Egyptian Cabinet's lack of courage in maintaining the legal minimum price for Egyptian cotton -- which is by far Egypt's principal economic asset -- after the world price dropped well below the Egyptian price, is now creating serious difficulties for the Ali Maher Cabinet.
Arriving by plane from Paris in the morning, Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen defeated William Lurie of New York in his first appearance in the National indoor tennis championship last night.

Robert Tripp Ross, Republican, was elected to Congress yesterday at a special election held in the Fifth Queens District, in the northeastern section of the county, to fill a vacancy caused by the election of T. Vincent Quinn, the previous Democratic incumbent, to the post of District Attorney of Queens.

This country's paper and pulp industry will set new production records this year, according to a prediction made yesterday at annual "Paper Week" conventions in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Exclusive of pulp, the industry turned out last year a record production of 26,100,000 tons of paper and paperboard, more than half the total world output.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- At least some aspects of the present controversy over rearming West Germany may be clarified by recalling the time and manner in which this question was raised by the United States Government.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of a communique issued by the Western Big Three foreign ministers and of a separate statement issued by them in conjunction with the Western German Chancellor:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to make available $125,000,000 in direct loans to war veterans for home purchases over the next sixteen months. The vote was 341 to 0.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- B. A. Lindberg, Associate Professor of Business Administration at Harvard University, reported today that "compulsory or mandatory retirement at age 65 is meeting with a lot of resistance."
Industrial Surveys Co, market research, floor in the Chanin Building, 122 E 42d St -- Cross Brown Co, brokers.

Well-known women headed by Mrs. Hugh Jackson Reber, chairman, and Mrs. William Barton Marsh, co-chairman, are furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of "Venus Observed," with Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer in the leading roles, on the night of March 10 at the Century Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Child Education Foundation. Already an encouraging subscription has been reported.

In a bid for commuter good will, the Long Island Rail Road apologized yesterday for delays suffered by 7,500 passengers last Friday night when a steam locomotive stalled on the road's main line just west of the station at New Hyde Park, L. I.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The American Association for the United Nations closed its three-day conference on United States responsibility for world leadership today with the adoption of a series of resolutions calling for more intensive United States support of the world organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- In a denunciation of isolationist sentiment. Governor Dewey declared tonight that "this country must make up its mind, and make it up very quickly, whether it wants to defend freedom in Oregon and California, or 8,000 mites from our shores."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Hungary took another major step toward complete state ownership today by nationalizing privately owned apartment houses and a large category of homes.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 20 -- Negotiations at Panmunjom for a Korean armistice went back to the staff officer groups today after yesterday's session of the main delegations had ended in an agreement to recommend an international conference within three months after a truce to discuss a lasting settlement of Korean problems.

Again a group of city employes has walked off the job, and again we are confronted with the necessity of saying, first, that it is illegal in New York State for such employes to strike and, second, that when the pay is so poor and the grievance machinery so inadequate it is small wonder that these things happen.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and a mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development issued a joint communique tonight saying that partial settlement of the Iranian oil crisis has been agreed on.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation was called today to investigate threatening letters warning the sponsors of the controversial animal research bill to withdraw the measure or face "the suffering and brutality" proposed for "defenseless dogs."

Home furnishings manufacturers and dealers were told the "economic facts of life" last night by a retailer prominent in the furniture field. Albert M. Kahn, president of Spear Co., told the trade segments they must realize the consumer now knows what he wants to buy and must be supplied with desired merchandise "at the proper price."
One of the longest and largest strikes of white-collar workers in the country's history -- the eighty-one-day-old walkout of 10,000 Prudential insurance agents -- ended last night.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 19 -- Chinese Nationalist and Japanese delegates presented their credentials today at a preliminary meeting designed to pave the way for the opening of full dress negotiations here on a bi-lateral Chinese-Japanese peace treaty. The conference is scheduled to begin officially tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- By a vote of 7 to 3, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee recommended to the full Senate today that Harry A. McDonald be confirmed as Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Mrs. Dorothy Schiff, publisher of The New York Post, and Lloyd K. Garrison, former chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, were designated yesterday as candidates for the Democratic State Committee. They were put up by the Lexington Democratic Club, an insurgent group in the Ninth Assembly district, which includes most of the Park Avenue section.

A special Federal rackets grand jury that was sworn in yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard heard four witnesses in its investigation of corruption and racketeering in the Southern District of New York. The panel will meet again Thursday.
Weakness in the stock market brought generally lower prices for New York commodity futures yesterday, but cottonseed oil was influenced by the strength in raw cotton.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- The Chinese Communists are organizing and training a marine amphibious force as a spearhead group under the command of Gen. Lin Piao for a possible invasion of Formosa, according to unofficial reports issued here today.

COLD SPRING - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- A "life-begins-at-40" experiment in creative education for Vassar alumnae and their husbands is being established here at Sunk Mine Farm, an estate owned by Mrs. William S. Ladd.

Mrs. George K. Livermore and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell are co-chairmen of the committee in charge of the plans for the benefit performance of "Don Juan in Hell" on the night of April 2 at the Plymouth Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Volunteer Associates of the New York Botanical Garden.

With five out-of-town airports bidding for some of the 226 daily airplane flights to be shifted away from La Guardia Airport, the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee set up a subcommittee yesterday to gather technical data on their available facilities.
Your editorial of Feb. 17 "A Basic Problem in Korea" underscored a most important phase of the current truce negotiations in Korea.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 19 -- The manifold difficulties confronting the new state of Laos dictate an uncertain future for this landlocked kingdom on the banks of the Mekong River. Laos must cope not only with a continuing internal rebellion, bolstered by aggression from Communist-led Vietminh forces, but it must deal also with economic, financial and social problems of great magnitude.
Government shipping authorities are expecting a steady reduction in the employment of federally owned shipping tonnage engaged in carrying emergency cargo.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The present weaknesses and the future strength of Western Germany were taken into account today when the foreign ministers of France, Britain and the United States approved the report of the "Three Wise Men," who found that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Federal Republic could afford to spend a little more than it wanted to for the collective security against aggression and a little less than was hoped.

New help for the homemaker who chooses to be her own decorator may be found in an unusual wallpaper sample book developed by United Wallpaper, Inc. The book, "Your Home and How to Decorate It," presents Talisman wallpapers as well as suggestions for their use. It may be examined at Thibaut, 44 East Fifty-third Street, where the papers are available for $3 and under a single roll.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Gov. Earl Warren announced today that he would enter the Republican Presidential primary in Wisconsin and would spend "a good many days" campaigning for the state's thirty delegates to the national convention before the April 1 election there.

William Francis Sutton, the bank robber, pleaded not guilty in Queens County Court yesterday to charges that he planned and executed the $63,942 robbery at the Manufacturers Trust Company on Queens Boulevard, Sunnyside, on March 9, 1950.

NEWARK, Feb. 19 -- Members of the New Jersey Parents Group for Retarded Children, Inc., have named six specialists in the field of medicine, psychiatry, psychology and education to the group's special advisory board, Howard Smith of Bloomfield, the group's president, announced today.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 (AP) -- James Andrew Wright, the "Scottsboro Boy," was cleared today of a charge that he raped a 13-year-old Negro girl. An Albany County Court jury returned the verdict after deliberating an hour and 20 minutes.

" Golden Ages of the Great Cities: The Flowering of Western Culture," a compilation of essays by thirteen European scholars and writers depicting the social life in cities of Europe and the United States that have played the most important part in the development of Western culture, will be published March 11 by Thames Hudson.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The City of New York has ample resources to finance, without state help, a $50,000,000-a-year school construction and modernization program for the next four years, a special commission headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore reported to the Legislature today.
A new exhibit to show the progress of evolution in the invertebrate creatures was opened here yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Wheat futures had a firm undertone most of the session today, reflecting persistent commission buying on small setbacks and some local support. Just before the close buying by export houses caused a rally. While no new export business was reported, there was increasing concern regarding weather conditions in the Southwest, the promised rains in that section having failed to materialize, while reports indicate that the need for rains is becoming urgent.
