The Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday the election of Charles W. Lyon Jr., as a director. Mr. Lyon is president of the Empire State Building Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The State Department announced today that British and French officials have arrived to confer with United States experts on a new coordinated program of economic aid to Yugoslavia.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 19 -- An inquest was ordered tonight into the death of Millard Romaine Jr., honor student at Williams College.

OSLO, Feb. 19 -- Empty bottles and orange and banana peels rained down on the Jordal ice hockey arena tonight as fans registered their indignation over the behavior of a United States player, Joseph Czarnota, who, in his team's 8-2 victory over the Swiss, deliberately floored one of his opponents with a well-aimed right.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Plans for a $30,000,000 research laboratory, designed to explore "hitherto untouched areas in the fields of turbojet and turboprop development," were disclosed here today by the General Electric Company. The laboratory is to be built at the company's present jet engine plant in Lockland, Ohio, and is expected to employ 600 to 800 research personnel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected a complaint against the practice of separating Negroes and whites in Southern Railway dining cars.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- A little known facet of British diplomacy that made life easier for Allied aviators forced down in a remote jungle area of India during World War II will be explored by Twentieth Century-Fox in a picture to be called "Naga Headhunters."

The Senate Labor subcommittee which is seeking light on an effective legislative approach to the problem of Communist-dominated unions is apparently making progress. Having explored the method by which the Atomic Energy Commission cut off recognition from Communist-controlled unions in atomic energy installations, the committee has now made public its latest report, which embodies the views of labor and industrial leaders, their attorneys, and recognized specialists in labor relations.
ATLANTA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Piedmont College trustees voted today to continue to accept grants from the Texas Education Association, financed by an avowedly anti-Jewish, anti-Negro millionaire.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Weakness of tin, copper and rubber shares were a feature of stock market trading here today. Sharp falls reflected fears about the future of commodity prices. By contrast, most South African gold mining issues were firmer.

OSLO, Feb. 19 -- Norway's drive on the winter Olympic awards continued successfully today. The harvest was one first-prize gold medal for the 10,000-meter speed skating and second-place silver and third-place bronze medals in the men's slalom, which was won by an Austrian.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, declared last night that the pending McCarran-Walter omnibus immigration bills would draw an Iron Curtain around the country's boundaries and keep out all but narrow categories of immigrants.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 19 -- The Yugoslav Communist party has shifted its line radically to the left After a one-year experiment that has demonstrated that without constant supervision and continuous injection of strong doses of propaganda Communists tend to lose their momentum and revolutionary spirit.

LISBON, Feb. 19 -- The military and economic leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty nations closed their preliminary discussions today by agreeing to stress the immediate requirements of defense planning in 1952. Longer range plans are not yet in condition to be crystallized.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- Armed with a large pile of Marxist literature, which it presented in evidence, the prosecution in the trial of fifteen California Communists endeavored today to show a Federal District Court jury that communism disdained conventional political and economic reform in favor of anti-Government activity admitted to be illegal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee debated today whether to defer its report on the Universal Military Training bill until after the House of Representatives had acted. A vote in the House is expected in the early days of March.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Diet (Parliament) today that a commission might be established to settle difficulties that might arise between Japanese authorities and garrison troops remaining here after ratification of the San Francisco treaty brought formal occupation to an end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee voted unanimously today to withhold from Newbold Morris the power to grant immunity to witnesses in his investigation into corruption in the Federal Government.

New Issues of more than $44,000,000 of tax-exempt-interest bonds, representing borrowings by the State of Oregon, the city of Philadelphia and other local governments were purchased by investment banking syndicates at competitive sale yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Measures to provide state regulation of the comic book industry and to facilitate the prosecution of persons publishing or handling comics likely to cause juvenile delinquency were introduced today under the sponsorship of the Joint Legislative Committee, which has been studying the comic-book problem since 1949.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 -- Among the hundreds of different campaign posters plastered over Mexico for the coming elections there is one that reads "Religion of the people Is Sacred." It is signed by Adolfo Ruiz Cortines who is the Government party's candidate for President, a man confident of victory.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Pravda charged today that the United States was planning to split Austria into eastern and western portions and carry out an "anschluss" by which western Austria would be merged with West Germany.

Diversity in design, color combinations and texture, which might be expected in a collection of eighty fabrics, is displayed in the new Greeff group of decorating materials, available through decorators, in the Greeff showrooms, 4 East Fifty-third Street.

Undismayed by increasing evidences, both here and in Albany, of a gathering storm of objections by property owners to the proposed county real estate tax, Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that he was still hopeful of winning state approval of much of his $285,900,000 fiscal aid program.

The restrained and temperate character of your editorial of Feb. 12 on the subject of the recent tragic crashes in Elizabeth is an example of the only type of approach to the problems raised by these disasters that affords an opportunity for taking whatever steps may be necessary to insure that such accidents do not occur in the future.

A documentary history of Abraham Lincoln and his times, pieced together through more than half a century of ardent collecting by the late Oliver R. Barrett of Chicago went under the hammer yesterday in the first stage of dissolution of the collection.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 19 -- A Communist purge of Jews and "bourgeois objectivists" from scientific and other cultural fields in Czechoslovakia is expected to begin soon, according to reliably informed experts on Czechoslovak affairs.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, continuing his inquiry into the widespread college basketball scandal, announced yesterday that a second former University of Kentucky player would appear this morning as a grand jury witness.

Ever since George chopped down that legendary tree, his birthday has been culinarily observed by serving tempting cherry desserts and other dishes. Cooking with cherries, of course, isn't limited to February any more than it is to the fresh cherry season, for annually a major portion of the crop is canned for use throughout the year. Although the 1951 pack was not quite up to the previous year's, stocks of all varieties are ample.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Governor Dewey's record $1,092,760,887 state budget for next year was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee and the Assembly Ways and Means Committee with minor amendments that added $141,885 to the total. All the amendments related to appropriations for the Senate and the judiciary.

Plans for the erection of several hundred homes to be sold at moderate prices were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by a builder of 234 acres of land in the Brentwood section of Islip, L. I., from Cooper and Mary Schieffelin in a deal negotiated by Watler Samuels, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The State Department's Loyalty and Security Board today "completely cleared" John Carter Vincent, a veteran foreign service officer, and the department returned him with its "full confidence and best wishes" to his post as diplomatic agent and Minister in Tangier.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Defending champion Jane Austin of Philadelphia and six other seeded players, three of them British, today gained the women's national squash racquets singles quarterfinals at the Harvard Club.

Although Carrie Munn looked in many directions, ranging from "Arizona matadors" to North Africa, for the inspiration of her spring and summer custom collection, it bore first and foremost the unmistakable stamp of her own gay, youthful design. Shown yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue, it was filled with the feminine frills and flowers, quilted touches, bright ribbons and braid she favors.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Bills to create four additional City Court justices in Manhattan were introduced today in the Legislature as part of a bipartisan deal by which two of the judgeships would go to Republicans and two to Democrats. City Court justices receive $20,000 a year.

SEOUL, Wednesday, Feb 20 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets, flying cover for bomber missions yesterday, destroyed three of an estimated 150 enemy MIG-15 jets that tried to intercept them over Northwest Korea.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped to their lowest levels since May, 1950, today as buyers continued to shy from marketed supplies. The country had shaved 1,000 head off the expected supply of 15,000, but it was not enough to prevent declines of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Failure "to appreciate the high purpose of the East-West game" was charged today against presidents of Ivy League colleges for their action in banning that group's coaches and players from future participation.

MIAMI, Feb. 19 -- There were challenges all along the line for Abe Levinson's 9-to-5 High Bracket in Hialeah's best horse race today, and after the 6-year-old gelding had scored by a nose, there was a final challenge from the stewards.

The problems of where to place automatic laundry units and how to wash fabrics that are specially finished or synthetic were discussed by two speakers yesterday afternoon at the second meeting of the 1952 Workshop for Electrical Living in the General Electric Auditorium, 570 Lexington Avenue.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Manager Chuck Dressen, who flew in today from California ready to start directing the conditioning of the 1952 Dodgers tomorrow morning, listed two immediate objectives:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 -- Food ministers from fourteen states met here today to review the food situation in India and to evolve a coordinated plan to meet a threatening food crisis which, according to official forecasts, will be as severe as that of last year.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 19 -- With only part of his squad assembled for training, Manager Leo Durocher today revealed that he feels exactly the same toward his 1952 club as he did a year ago in St. Petersburg, Fla. The skipper is convinced that the Giants will again boast power, speed and good pitching.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Joseph E. Casey, former House member and chief engineer of transactions in surplus Government ships that turned a $101,000 initial investment into a $3,250,000 profit in three years, swore to the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee today that the deals, from top to bottom, constituted only honest, free American enterprise at work.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Ten of the twenty Bishops of the Protestant Church in West Germany have expressed the view that the church should stay out of the West German defense debate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Truman will name Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle to head a special White House committee on air safety. The appointment probably will be made tomorrow.

Now that the second half of February is here, it is reasonably safe to say that the winter is over. What if the groundhog did see his shadow that other day, setting up the gloomy inference that before the crocus flowers there must be a further forty days of cold?

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A series of amendments to the rent control laws affecting business and commercial property in New York City designed to enable owners to recover possession of rented space more easily were submitted to the legislature today by the temporary rent committee headed by Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, Putnam Republican.
The Yankees yesterday signed Joe Ostrowski, Tom Morgan and Bill Miller, all pitchers, to bring their list of players under contract to thirty-three.

Merck Co., Inc., largest producer of cortisone, chalked up record sales and earnings last year from its diversified line of chemicals and drugs. One thousand of its items are used chiefly for medicinal, nutritional, industrial, laboratory, photographic and electronic purposes.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 -- Mrs. Eleanor Wernimont, wife of the agricultural attache at the United States Embassy here, was killed and her mother and sister seriously injured today in a freakish accident.

Duquesne, the country's only major unbeaten team this season with a record of eighteen triumphs; St. John's University of Brooklyn and St. Bonaventure have accepted bids to compete in the annual National Invitation Basketball Tournament starting March 8 at Madison Square Garden, Asa Bushnell, N. I. T. selection chairman, reported yesterday.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A fifty-five man House of Representatives was chosen for the new kingdom of Libya today in voting marked by scattered violence. The results, a possible barometer of Western prestige in the Arab world, are expected to become known Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A political trial balloon for W. Averell Harriman, possibly for Vice President or Senator from New York, was inflated on the steps of the White House today.

In the corners of restaurants, in concert halls and movie houses, at the ball game and on fishing parties -- and in the wards of local hospitals -- groups of wounded veterans are frequently seen, escorted by cheerful men and women. These "civilians" generally are members of the 52 Association, that altruistic group of New York business and professional people dedicated to the principle that "The Wounded Shall Never Be Forgotten."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19 -- How a former Arkansas cotton-grower introduced the hoe to Afghanistani was recounted here today by officials of the United Nations Technical Assistance Agency.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Yemen Legation in London said tonight that United States archeologist Wendell Phillips had made "false allegations" in a statement about his ouster from the tiny Arab kingdom last week.
The appearance of Bill Bangert, a three-time National Amateur Athletic Union shot-put champion, was the highlight of the track writers' luncheon at Leone's yesterday.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (UP) -- The newspaper Soviet Sport devoted three columns today to the coverage of the Winter Olympic Games, giving the principal results plus a description of the Oslo atmosphere.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- The State of California, through Gov. Earl Warren, offered wishes for happiness today to Sing Sheng, Chinese airplane mechanic whose attempted purchase of a home in a "white" district of south San Francisco had been voted down by his potential neighbors.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 19 -- A man described as a giant walked out of the night on the highway about ten miles northwest of here early today, saw a driver trapped in the cab of his smouldering truck-trailer and ripped the cab apart to save him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, questioned today whether it would not be better for the Federal Government to get jobs for the unemployed in Michigan, New York and elsewhere rather than increase unemployment compensation.
Complete programs for the two-week engagement of the Sadler's Wells Theatre Ballet, which opens at the Warner Theatre on March 25, have been announced by the company's American manager, S. Hurok.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- After three days of meetings, the United States, British and French foreign ministers and the West German Chancellor announced today that they had succeeded in removing the obstacles that had delayed the establishment of a European army and a new contractual relationship between the Western powers and the Bonn Republic.

IT started merely as some casual conversation during one of the Madison Square Garden track meets. Jack Mara, the president of the Football Giants, turned to his companion in the box, Gen John Reed Kilpatrick, the president of the Garden.

In an appeal for more civil defense volunteers Arthur W. Wallander, Civil Defense Director, said yesterday that only 136,314 volunteers, most of them civil defense workers, had completed the Red Cross first aid course.

Two gunmen, using a laundry employe as a shield, scooped up $7,000 in payroll cash, bound a policeman, the employe and three other persons and escaped yesterday from the Blue Diamond Laundry, Inc., 3616 Park Avenue, near 169th Street, the Bronx.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 -- Princeton's revitalized team moved into a first-place tie in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by virtue of a 58-44 triumph over Yale in Dillon gym.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 19 -- Agreements to exempt United States military purchases and construction from principal local taxes, now being negotiated with West European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, are well advanced in several countries. They will save American taxpayers millions of dollars.

Many victims of multiple sclerosis can be trained to care for themselves and return to work, Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine of the Bellevue Medical Center, said yesterday at a meeting of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society in the home of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 19 -- You could buy 1 (Israel) for 90 piasters in small change in Lilienblum Street today. [There are 100 piasters in an Israeli pound.]

The Soviet Union will probably impress an equal number of East Germans for forced labor in Russia if West Germans are mustered for a European army, Pastor Martin Niemoeller, German Evangelical Church leader, said upon his arrival here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb 18 (UP) -- The six TV "bests" of 1951 received the gold "Emmys" of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences tonight, with Senator Estes Kefauver carrying off a special "achievement" award.
ALBANY, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Assemblyman John R. Brook, Manhattan Republican, proposed today licensing "public loaders" on New York City's docks in an effort to end "mobster rule."

All stock exchanges and commodity exchanges in this country will be closed on Friday in commemoration of Washington's birthday. Some livestock markets, however, will remain open, as will all markets in Canada and in Europe.

The Democratic leaders of the Legislature in Albany have taken a constructive step in endorsing the plan of the New York State Board of Regents for a network of non-commercial, educational television stations, but much greater support will be needed if this worthwhile project is to survive the practical politics of a Presidential-election year.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The National Assembly adopted today the compromise resolution drafted Saturday giving qualified approval of a European army. The vote was 327 to 287. Twenty Socialists in a total of 107 violated the party's orders by voting against the resolution. Among them was Jules Moch, who was Minister of Defense when a European army was proposed by the French Government.

J. Warren Kinsman, vice president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., last night called upon the country's business men to undertake, "a great campaign of back-talk" in answer to those who have been misleading the public about "the enormous benefits" provided by American business structure.

Three new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "The African Queen," an adventure drama filmed in Technicolor in Africa and starring Katharine Hepburn and Humphrey Bogart, is at the Capitol John Huston directed and S. P. Eagle produced from the novel by C. S. Forester and a script written by James Agee and Mr. Huston.

Graham Greene, British author, whose novels are concerned with the conflict of good and evil and humanity's need of the love of God, expressed apprehension yesterday at this country's acceptance of "the informer."

The armistice delegates in Korea have reached what looks like agreement on the fifth and last point of their agenda. They have agreed, subject to their respective interpretations, to recommend, a high-level political conference, between the Governments concerned on both sides, to be held within three months after the armistice goes into effect, to decide the following issues: "Withdrawal of all foreign forces from .Korea, a peaceful settlement of the Korean question, etc."

CHATHAM, Mass., Feb. 19 -- With twenty-one crewmen rescued this afternoon by the Coast Guard from the stern section of the tanker Fort Mercer, thirteen others elected to remain on the wallowing half-ship until it could be towed to Boston across 150 miles of raging Atlantic Ocean.

Morgan Stanley Co. and Robert W. Baird Co., Inc., are offering today to investors a new issue of $4,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Chain Belt Company, Worcester, Mass., manufacturer of sprocket chains and construction and conveyor equipment.

TORONTO, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Toronto Maple Leafs and the New York Rangers battled through two periods of hockey and one period of mayhem tonight and wound up in a 3-3 tie that decided possession of second and fourth place in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The general index of basic commodities based on the August, 1939, level decreased from 317.1 on Feb. 8 to 314.3 on Feb. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The following tables list daily index numbers and spot market prices:

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein affirmed yesterday arbitration awards in favor of The Daily News, THE NEW YORK TIMES, The Herald Tribune, The Journal-American and The Mirror against the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 19 -- The Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will start its critical ninth session here tomorrow encouraged by this week's diplomatic agreements in principle of the need to rearm Western Germany.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 19 -- Satisfaction bordering on elation was the initial reaction in Government circles tonight to the results of the London meeting between the United States, British and French foreign ministers and West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

Stockholders of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., at their annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., approved the plan under which 1,152,215 shares of common stock held by the corporation will be retired. Shareholders were told that the company is carrying out as far as possible the terms of a consent agreement requiring it to dispose of fifty-four theatres within two years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Nathaniel Weyl, a free lance Washington writer, testified today that he and Alger Hiss, former high State Department official now serving a five-year sentence for perjury, were members of the same Communist cell here in 1934.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The National Labor Relations Board held today that a department store's rule barring union organizers from talking to employes in store restaurants reserved for employes violated the employes' statutory rights.

Helen Hayes, head of the American National Theatre and Academy as well as the American Theatre Wing, organizations dedicated to the welfare of the stage, will appear in behalf of the former. Starting at 8 o'clock this evening, the star will be seen at the Martin Beck in "Mrs. McThing," the second of Anta's five-play series, of which Robert Whitehead is the managing director.
SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights:

ROME, Feb. 19 (Reuters) -- A new category for classifying films has been added to the four already in use by the Catholic Cinematographic Center for stamping its approval or disapproval on movies shown in Italy.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and active months rose 1 to 6 points.
Directors of Rayonier, Inc., declared a 100 per cent stock dividend yesterday payable to common stockholders on April 1.

Six hundred physically handicapped children, most of whom had never before witnessed a Broadway performance, attended a preview showing yesterday afternoon at the Martin Beck Theatre of "Mrs. McThing," starring Helen Hayes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UP) High Government officials paid belated homage today to Constantino Brumidi, the Italian artist who poured out his soul in colorful frescoees and paintings on the walls of the United States Capitol.
NEW ORLEANS, Wednesday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Judge Robert Kennon of the State Court of Appeals won election as Governor of Louisiana today, overthrowing the political power of Gov. Earl Long.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,165 for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

Two thousand "absent" employes of the City Housing Authority ended their two-day work stoppage last night. They voted to return to their jobs in sixty-eight municipal housing projects after union leaders had said that was the quickest way to obtain mediation of a demand for a 50-cent increase in hourly wages.
Sumner Welles, former Under Secretary of State, has been elected president of Freedom House by its directors. Mr. Welles succeeded the late Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War.

The city is operating its housing projects in an economical and satisfactory manner, according to Walter H. Nelson, an assistant vice president in the mortgage and real estate department of the East River Savings Bank, who spoke yesterday at a meeting of the Economic Survey Committee of the Real Estate Board of New York.

ONE of Phyllis McGinley's most delightful poems expresses her understandable distaste for novels about the amatory affairs of unpleasant adults seen through the eyes of sensitive children. I wish that she would write another expressing an equal impatience with novels about the amatory affairs of sensitive adolescents. Love, since it is the most interesting of human emo tions, will always remain the most popular theme for fiction.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 19 -- Although much remains to be achieved in New York's fight against the use of narcotics by its youth, "perhaps half the battle is won," Gabriel R. Mason, principal of the Abraham Lincoln High School, Brooklyn, told the convention of the National Association of Secondary School Principals here today.

An increase of 17.4 per cent in sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company in 1951 made its total volume of $637,722,241 the largest in the 81-year history of the rubber company, according to the annual report yesterday. The previous peak in 1950 was $543,312,294.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Sam Snead, the West Virginia Slammer, and Betty MacKinnon, his Texas partner, fired a seven-under-par 64 to capture medalist honors in the eleventh annual international mixed two-ball open golf tournament today.

George Balanchine's new ballet, "Caracole," had its world premiere last night at the City Center at the hands of the New York City Ballet, and everybody was (or should have been) very happy. It is set to Mozart's Divertimento No. 15 in B flat major (K. V. 287), and it is as gay and sprightly, as elegant and formal, as that enchanting bit of music.

The Nato conference which opens in Lisbon today takes place at a critical time in the affairs of the Atlantic Community and it must deal with problems of extreme complexity and delicacy. It is well to recognize these facts at the beginning and to entertain no false hopes, even though the meeting begins in a much better atmosphere than seemed possible a week ago.

A syndicate of investors, represented by Frederick W. Scholem, bought the thirteen-story business building on plot 100 by 100 feet at 145-51 East Thirty-second Street from a group of operators headed by Myron Hechler and Joseph Durst, operators.

A civilian who tried to help a policeman capture a purse thief was shot and critically wounded yesterday afternoon when the patrolman's revolver was accidentally discharged during a scuffle with the thug.

Mayor Impellitteri's proposal for a separate county tax on real estate, sent to Albany with the approval of the Board of Estimate, was scathingly and vociferously opposed yesterday at a public hearing before the City Council's Committee on State Legislation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Giants and the Dodgers have appealed to the Government for special relief from salary controls to permit them to boost their payrolls, it was disclosed today.

Members of various committees aiding in the arrangements for the block party and evening of entertainment on May 23 for the benefit of the House of the Holy Comforter, met last night in the Parish House of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, to further plans for the event.
Prices of active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 8 to 27 points yesterday.

Pleas of not guilty were entered yesterday by eight suspended public school teachers who face departmental trials on charges of insubordination and unbecoming conduct because they refused to answer questions about alleged Communist party membership.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 20 -- The North Atlantic Council began its ninth formal session today by stressing its determination to deter or resist aggression but again reassuring the Soviet Union and the world that it did not "desire military forces great enough to launch a preventive war."

Dan Lyons' jump shot in the final three seconds gave Fordham's basketball team a 48-46 victory over Wagner College at Grymes Hill, S. I., last night. The triumph was the Rams' sixteenth in twenty-one games. Wagner's record is now fourteen victories and ten defeats.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- A revolutionary process for desalting sea water, promising to open vast new reservoirs of fresh water for use in agriculture, industry and the home wherever water is now scarce, was demonstrated here today at the national meeting of the American Research and Development Corporation.
Workers in the eight East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company have voted more than 50 to 1 to authorize strike action if no agreement is reached by March 1.

" Dear Barbarians," a first play by Lexford Richards, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Royale Theatre. The cast comprises Cloris Leachman, Violet Heming, Betsy Von Furstenberg, Donald Murphy and Nicholas Joy.

Rear Admiral John M. Will, commander of the Atlantic Division of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, welcomed the 180-foot Redbud, a multi-purpose freighter, as the latest addition to his fleet at the change of command ceremonies held yesterday morning at Pier 1, Brooklyn Army Base.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Opponents opened a drive in the Senate today to send the Alaska statehood bill back to committee for public hearings, and a vote on that question was set for next Wednesday.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- A revision of the law governing school elections has been proposed by a special committee headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore. It would permit all those eligible to vote in general elections to vote in school elections in cities under 125,000 population.
A leading producer of household utensils plans to help European women realize their dreams of owning American-style kitchens, and hopes to make a tidy profit in the process.

An additional $550,000,000 is to be added to the capital structure of the $12,500,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, according to an executive decision of the concern to be submitted to stockholders at the annual meeting on April 16.

SKIEN, Norway, Feb. 20 (UP) -Ken Henry of Chicago, winner oft the Olympic 500-meter speed skat-t ing championship, repeated his vic-I tory at the same distance in an in-] ternational meet today, but Hjal-/ mar _andersen, lqorway's triple-I crowl% speed king, was beaten in aI 3,000-meter race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The United States now has under serious consideration a policy of building up the armed forces of South Korea much faster than in the past.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for the period Dec. 30 to Feb. 2 averaged 37,655 bales for each working day. This compared with 42,746 bales for the corresponding period a year ago.

Many persons versed in the engineering and expansion programs of the nation's $22,000,000,000 electric power and light industry believe that by 1960 the country's power output rate will be more than double that at the end of World War II.

Cleared by the State Department's Loyalty and Security Board, John Carter Vincent embarked on the American Export Line Constitution yesterday to return to his post as United States Minister to Tangier.

Mother's Day business this year is expected by Irving K. Edwards, executive director of the National Committee on the Observance of Mother's Day, to break all records. Reasons: Merchandise is plentiful, prices are low, and retailers have a full four weeks to build up gift buying activity because Easter falls on April 13 and Mother's Day on May 11.

The 10-year-old United States Air Force Band gave its first Carnegie Hall concert late yesterday afternoon. The event, which ran from 5:30 to 7 o'clock, was one of the public programs in the thirteenth annual American Music Festival being sponsored by WNYC.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Answering questions in the House of Commons today, Prime Minister Churchill conceded that Laborite Aneurin Bevan had been right when he predicted that Britain would not be able to fulfill the Labor Government's plan to spend 4,700,000,000 [$13,160,000,000] on rearmament in the next three years.

The Julliard Opera Theatre has chosen nothing less than Verdi's "Falstaff" for its big production effort this year. Since this comic opera written by Verdi as he was approaching 80 is a unique masterpiece, it is good to have it back in town even if only for a few performances.

In a new and steadily intensifying Communist campaign against Austria the Moscow Pravda accuses the United States of planning, in collaboration with the Austrian Foreign Minister, to partition that country and attach it to Western Germany as an advance base against Soviet Russia.

At end of their graduating session yesterday enthusiastic and diligent young members of the first sewing class for 7 to 12 year old boys at the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty - ninth Street, displayed proudly their first sewing accomplishment -- neat, sturdy laundry bags, individually initialed.

ATHENS, Feb. 20 -- A reference to the murder of George W. Polk, 35-year-old American correspondent, in May, 1948, is contained in testimony before an Athens military court at a hearing of the case of twenty-nine alleged Communist spies.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 20 -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived by air this afternoon for a seven-day Visit to Pakistan. She will be the guest of the All-Pakistan Women's Association, a group which, under the leadership of the Begun Liaquat Ali Kahn, widow of the Prime Minister, has been struggling to better the standing of Pakistan's relatively downtrodden women.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -The Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals took under advisement last night a petition by the Securities and Exchange Commission to vacate a temporary restraining order, issued on Jan. 25, which prevents the commission from holding hearings on a proposed sale of the Washington Water Power Company.

LONDON, Feb, 20 -- That Churchillian promise that Britain's action would be "prompt, resolute and effective" if the Chinese Communists broke a Korean truce, although largely deflated since his return from the United States, continues to agitate the Opposition in the House of Commons.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 20 -John Clune's 24-point output sparked Navy to a 65 -- 53 victory over Columbia today. It was the first time the Middies had defeated the Lions in basketball since the 1946-47 season.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 20 -- The endurance contest between the Giants and Sal Maglie is approaching settlement. This was revealed by President Horace C. Stoneham today as he watched Manager Leo Durocher put his National League champions through a brisk training drill at Municipal Stadium.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Prime Minister Churchill said today that when he visited the United States and Canada in January, he traveled free on the railroads. He also confirmed that he had paid nothing for the suite of cabins and offices -- 10 Downing Street afloat -- that he occupied on the liner Queen Mary.
Sugar and coffee futures prices were lower yesterday. Wool was stronger. Cocoa and vegetable oils were mixed. Only in sugar was volume of trading normal.

" How to Co-Exist Without Playing the Kremlin's Game," a new book by James P. Warburg, will be published by Beacon Press of Boston on Feb. 29. Mr. Warburg, author of a number of books on American foreign policy, discusses six points of "a policy of liberation" which he believes will halt the "totalitarian tide" without war.

Leafing through recent letters from readers, this department has selected several notes that pose culinary questions likely to be of general interest. They are presented here together with the answers given by Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, THE NEW YORK TIMES' home economist:

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- The tanker Pendleton, which broke in two off Chatham, Mass., Monday during a northeast storm suffered "a bad jolt" when she ran aground in the Hudson River near Albany last July, a Coast Guard board of investigation was told today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The use of copper and aluminum for manufacturing consumer goods will be cut to 30 per cent of pre-Korean-war levels during the second quarter of this year, Henry H. Fowler, head of the National Production Authority, announced today. The figure compares with 35 per cent allowed in the current quarter.
Lisbon, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State Dean Acheson to the North Atlantic Council at the opening meeting of its ninth session today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -A proposal by the [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government to transfer the Selective Service System to the Department of Labor was rejected today by the Senate Committee on Executive Expenditures.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (UP) -Oscar Beregi, 76, once one of Europe's outstanding actors, faced deportation to Communist Hungary with courage today and said he had "come to expect such things."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -- A dispute over working shifts for six men on the picturesque Powell Street cable cars flared today into a full-scale transit strike that halted every street-car and bus and stranded 250,000 daily riders.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The State Department of Commerce today listed the following ski conditions at New York resorts:

In one of the most spectacular matches the national indoor tennis championship has produced in years, Kurt Nielsen of Denmark defeated Grant Golden of Wilmette, Ill., last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The score was 6 -- 2, 14 -- 16, 6 -- 4.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 -- Indian shipping tonnage has trebled since prewar years from 125,000 tons in 1939 to 391,000 tons at the beginning of 1952, K. Santhanam, Minister of Transport, told Parliament today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -- Paramount is more than moderately interested in making a film based on the life of Jimmy Durante. In fact, the comedian, his agent, Abe Lastfogel, and Don Hartman, production supervisor at the studio, have had several talks about the contemplated biography, which of course would involve the purchase of the Gene Fowler book, "Schnozzola, the Story of Jimmy Durante"

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- A conflict within the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles over the administration bill to require compulsory inspection of automobiles and trucks was disclosed today with the introduction of a new inspection bill by Assemblyman Lawrence W. Van Cleef, vice chairman of the joint committee.

The customer's whim will be Tailored Woman's command in the selection of spring shoes this year. From a large color chart of leathers, the customer may designate her preference as to color, color combinations and type of leather.

An increase last week of 2,025,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 140,921,000 barrels, compared with 138,896,000 a week earlier and 134,598,000 a year ago.

The hormone ACTH has been used to alleviate the symptoms of withdrawal of morphine in a narcotics addict under medical treatment, according to a report in the current issue of The New York State Journal of Medicine.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Senator William F. Condon, Westchester Republican, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates, announced today that the committee has sponsored a bill to liberalize the limits which life insurance companies can expend for commissions and other expenses incident to the conduct of their business.
I would like to reply to the letter in THE TIMES of Feb. 15 entitled "School Prayer Opposed."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted, 12 to 0, today to recommend legislation under which Universal Military Training would be automatically coupled with reduction in the country's standing armed forces.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The Senate today approved a proposed constitutional amendment that would increase the terms of Senators and Assemblymen from two to four years beginning with those elected in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -The Defense Department today reported a new total of 105,841 United States battle casualties in Korea, an increase of 333 over last week.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -- There is at least one vacancy for a starting pitcher on the Dodger staff and there may be two open spots, it was indicated after today's first workout.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- If this country does not continue to keep a firm hold on its economy until it has passed the peak of its defense buildup, "we won't be able to have much of a defense program and we won't have much of an economy either," Roger L. Putnam, administrator of the Economic Stabilization Agency, told the midwinter personnel conference of the American Management Association here today.

The stock market had another severe sinking spell yesterday. While the losses as measured by the composite rate of THE NEW YORK TIMES index did not quite reach the proportions of those of Tuesday, the decline was broader, sending fifty-nine stocks to new 1951-52 lows and clipping quotations from 1 to 3 points in the prime sections.

A United Nations of children spent a happy afternoon yesterday exchanging gifts, dancing and singing together at Public School 151, First Avenue and Ninety-first Street. Amity prevailed, as there were no disputes beyond an occasional scuffle for a good place to sit, and the only competition involved who could shout the loudest.

The first four large housing projects proposed by the Committee on Slum Clearance Plans for construction by private capital with Federal and local aid were approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday. Robert Moses is chairman of the slum clearance committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $50,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, Series H, due March 1, 1982, to be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The State Department of Public Works reported today that preliminary studies showed a bridge across the Hudson River in the Newburgh-Beacon area was justified as to structure and traffic flow.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 -- A soft-spoken San Diego photographer who spied on the Communist party for five years for the Government, under cross-examination at the Federal Court trial of fifteen Communists today, turned suddenly from a shy, obsequious witness into a formidable dialectical antagonist who frequently confounded questioning defense attorneys.

OSLO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- America's 19-year-old ski queen, Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, picked herself out of the snow after a jarring tumble in the Olympic slalom today and staged a remarkable comeback to win her second gold medal of the winter games.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -The Ways and Means subcommittee of the House of Representatives investigating the Internal Revenue Bureau ended two and a half weeks of public hearings here today with a sharp attack on the "top echelon" 'of the bureau both in this district and in Washington.
The work force employed on the waterfront of the Port of New York in the last year increased to 48,758 men, the largest number in three years, it was disclosed last night.
City Council President Rudolph Halley attacked racial and religious discrimination last night and declared that bigotry in our own country was a firm ally of Communist-style tyranny.
Carl Resnikoff has been appointed vice president in charge of sales of the Mastic Tile Corporation of America, Newburgh, N. Y. Joseph G. Baumann has been named sales manager of the Eastern division.

TRENTON, Feb. 20 -- The State Superior Court today ordered reinstatement of Jamesburg's Police Chief and single full-time policeman, Harry L. Hubbs. He had been dismissed when he failed to report for night as well as day duty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee called upon the State Department today to furnish it with the original or a full copy of the penciled notes Alger Hiss kept at the 1945 Yalta Conference of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill of England and Premier Stalin of Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Houston H. Wasson, a law partner of Newbold Morris, the Republican now in charge of the Administration's investigation into corruption in Government, planned and effected deals that brought $450,000 in fast profits to a number of persons on an investment of $1,000 in options on three surplus tankers, the Senate Permanent Investigating Subcommittee was told today.

CHANCE brings us this morning, on the same publication day, two extraordinarily different satiric novels about modern man -- hell-bent on developing and destroying his own Utopias. One is Mary McCarthy's "The Groves of Academe."* The other is Louis Kronenberger's "Grand Right and Left." They sparkle with wit and insight, the first as a morality, you might say, the second as an entertainment.

St. John's University will seek its eleventh straight basketball triumph tonight when the Redmen engage the University of Cincinnati in the second game of the collegiate double-header at Madison Square Garden. In the first contest, New York University will face Manhattan College at 7:45 P. M.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on Feb. 15 was 2,478,431 shares, up 32,205 shares from the figure for Jan. 15, which has been revised to 2,446,226 shares. Neither total includes short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

Bobby Thomson, whose home run beat the Dodgers for the National League pennant last year, said yesterday that he preferred his old center field position to third base, a station to which he was shifted midway during the 1951 season. The Staten Islander departed from La Guardia Airport aboard an American Airlines plane yesterday morning bound for the Giants' spring training base at Phoenix, Ariz.

OSLO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Nearly all the Olympic ski champions may compete in the United States championships at Stowe, Vt., next month. Members of the United States team said that Neil Starr, American insurance man, had offered to fly the Olympic winners to Stowe for the meet.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 20 -The full use of the productive resources of all countries in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is necessary to create an adequate defense, W. Averell Harriman, United States Mutual Security Director and chairman of Nato's Temporary Council Committee, said today in presenting his committee's report to the Council.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Truman Administration was heavily and unexpectedly defeated today on a foreign policy issue in the House of Representatives and suffered a setback in the Senate as well.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes called off at the last minute this morning a threatened strike against ten television film producing companies represented by the Alliance of Television Film Producers.

What is free enterprise? Is it something that works only when it pleases certain people? Is it something to ask for when you want to relieve industry of unnecessary Government controls, but something to oppose when it comes time to relieve the housewife of unfair controls?

Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore earned $19,713,887 or $8.65 a share on its common stock last year, against $19,853,511 or $8.64 a share in 1950, E. C. Wareheim, president, reported yesterday. The apparent disparity in figures was caused by the retirement of a preferred issue in 1951.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 20 -- A tall, smiling jurist has toppled the administration of Gov. Earl Long out of power in Louisiana politics by winning the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in the run-off primary. Nomination on the Democratic ticket is tantamount to election in Louisiana.

Frederick Ashton's "Illuminations" had its first presentation in the current season of the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night. Since Mr. Ashton was on hand to rehearse it himself for the first time since its premiere two years ago, it was in many ways a notable perofrmance.

Newbold Morris and his law partners submitted bills-totaling $108,750 for more than three years' legal work for American tanker and Chinese Nationalist trading interests currently being scrutinized by a Senate subcommittee. They estimate last year's fees may add $50,000 to $60,000 more.

Because the quiet austerity of the tea ceremony has dominated the arts and crafts of Japan for centuries by orienting these people toward appreciation of beautiful, simple man-made objects, a tea house dominates an exhibition of Japanese crafts opening today at the Brooklyn Museum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Truman announced today the creation of a President's Airport Commission. It will study the location and use of airports with a view to providing for the "safety, welfare and peace of mind" of persons living near commercial air installations.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Republicans in control of the State Administration and Legislature are making a serious effort to find some alternative for the proposed new county tax as a means of enabling New York City to balance its budget for the next fiscal year.

Titanium, the Cinderella of metals, still has a long road to traverse before it overcomes its one major drawback, its scarcity, but progress toward that end is being made steadily. A leading authority on this lightweight champion of metals predicted yesterday a big increase in titanium production this year.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Stock market prices remained nervous and sensitive today and showed numerous further declines. Most interest was again in commodity shares but falls were severe only in the case of some metal issues, notably copper.

CAIRO, Feb. 20 -- The Government tonight issued a decree under its martial law authority providing for six months to five years imprisonment and a fine of 50 to 500 Egyptian pounds ($17.35 to $173,50) for propagating false rumors that excite the people, for threatening public security or for damaging the public interest.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 20 -The hope expressed in the United States that the prestige of Admiral Alan G. Kirk, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, might help to unify the emigre and exile groups fighting the Soviet regime is not shared in this city, which often is regarded as a sort of forward echelon in the struggle.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- The Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation has donated $1,250,000 toward the completion of a new home and school for mentally retarded boys, Cardinal Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago, announced today.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- The Soviet Union tonight in effect called for a peace treaty with Germany to be negotiated by the four occupying powers. A letter handed to Premier Otto Grotewohl by Gregory Pushkin, the Soviet Ambassador to East Germany, endorsed the East German bid for a peace treaty, submitted last Wednesday, and expressed expectation that the Western Allies would back the proposal.

Five years of experimentation have brought underground gasification of coal nearer to practical application, Dr. Milton H. Fies, manager of coal mining operations for the Alabama Power Company, reported yesterday in a paper presented at the annual convention of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Statler Hotel.

JOHN GALBREATH is a wealthy man. He is the president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, owns a racing stable and has manifold business interests in Ohio. Not the least of his interests is Ohio State University, though the Buckeyes represent merely an avocation with him. Vic Janowicz, whom he financed through college, is one football player who doesn't have to worry about the future.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -With mixed results, the San Francisco Bay Area today experienced its first all-out air raid test. Both in this city and Oakland, compliance of citizens to "take cover" orders at the sound of sirens was good in the central city districts but poor in areas where the siren network did not function well.
SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights:

Burlington, Vt., borrowed $4,000,000 in the public market yesterday by a sale of electric bonds, due Feb. 1, 1957 to 1981, to a syndicate of banking houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The winning bid was 104.513 for fixed interest of 2 per cent. Blyth Co., Inc., bid 104.39 for the same rate.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 20 -- A New Jersey Joint Legislative Committee opened a series of public hearings into the state's airport problems here tonight as the plane crash of Feb. 11 claimed its thirtythird victim.
The collection presented by De Pinna yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel deserves the adjective "hand picked." It reflected the most important of spring fashions.

CAIRO, Feb. 20 -- Prices on the Egyptian cotton market were frozen today by order of the Cotton Exchange Commission in Alexandria and trading ceased while a delegation called upon the Finance Ministry in Cairo to seek a solution to a commercial puzzle that is of vital significance to Egypt. Cotton is the backbone of the Egyptian economy.

HARTFORD, Feb. 20 -- Homer S. Cummings, former United States Attorney General who has been a delegate to Democratic National Conventions since 1900, Chester Bowles and two national committee members from Connecticut will not be on the state's convention delegate slate this year.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- A constitutional amendment that, if adopted, would permit the Legislature to provide for the trial of most types of negligence suits without a jury or before special courts has been proposed by Assemblyman Edmund R. Lupton, Republican of Suffolk.
CHATHAM, Mass., Feb. 20 -The broken stern half of the tanker Fort Mercer, with thirteen men aboard, rode unsteadily tonight at the end of a towline behind two tugs headed for Block Island.

President Truman's appointment yesterday of a special commission headed by the respected Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle to study problems of safety in air travel should serve, in the end, to restore lost perspective as to our airports in the New York City area.

Last spring Eric Johnston, who was then Economic Stabilization Chief, introduced the so-called "profits test" as an adjunct to the program for establishing price ceilings. Ceilings were to be considered "fair and equitable," declared Mr. Johnston in a letter to Price Stabilizer Michael V. DiSalle, if an industry's dollar profit was running at 85 per cent of the best three years of the four-year span 1946-49.

OSLO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The winter Olympics had their first full-scale rhubarb today and as is so often the case the two athletes involved remained friends, grinned at each other and posed for photographers with their arms around each other's shoulders.

Mary Chase, who wrote "Harvey," has written another play that is equally original. It is called "Mrs. McThing." Helen Hayes and an excellent company acted it at the Martin Beck last evening. In the program it is learnedly described as "a comic fantasy." But it might simplify things to suggest that "Mrs. McThing" is a fairy-story that manages to combine "Alice-in-Wonderland" with Superman and Hopalong Cassidy.

Future growth of the paper industry in this country can be accelerated and assured through application of atomic research discoveries to increase the yield of wood pulp resources, the American Pulpwood Association was told yesterday at a meeting here.

While appreciating your recognition of the wrongs suffered by Italy and of her right to justice, allow us to state that we are sorry to disagree with that point of your editorial of Feb. 11 in which you remarked that you could not clearly see what Italy would gain by its energetic note to the Soviet Union.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion's Government won a 54-44 vote of confidence today at the end of a three-day debate in the Knesset (Parliament) on economic measures to check runaway inflation, stabilize Israeli currency and stimulate the flow of foreign capital to the country.

Alterations on five buildings at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn at a total cost of $1,891,200 were among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Plans for the hospital alterations were filed by DeYoung, Moscowitz Rosenberg, architects.

One of the by-products that derive from election years in our harassed nation is the opportunity to put career diplomats in the biggest posts. This is happening now with the transfer of Ambassador James Clement Dunn from Rome to Paris. As it happens, Mr. Dunn succeeds another career official who has done a first-rate job -- David K. E. Bruce, who now goes to Washington as Under Secretary of State.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 20 -- Chinese Nationalist handed the Japanese their draft of a full-fledged peace treaty for study today as both sides opened formal negotiations here on a bilateral agreement whose basic nature is thus far at issue.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Republican majority leader of the Senate, informed a delegation of Yonkers citizens today that there was no prospect that the Legislature would authorize Yonkers to impose a local tax on pari-mutuel betting at the Yonkers Raceway.

The West German diamond-cutting industry is growing despite efforts of the Belgian industry to curtail it, Harry Torczyner, attorney for several United States diamond concerns, reported here yesterday on his return from a business trip to Belgium and France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -President Truman formally ruled today that the nation's conscientious objectors must take jobs essential to the national welfare for two years if they want to avoid the draft.

The Maritime Department of Metropolitan Vocational High School introduced yesterday at a buffet luncheon aboard the schoolship John W. Brown, the new chairman, and members of its Maritime Educational Commission.

The ideals of brotherhood should be a living faith practiced fifty-two weeks a year, not just during Brotherhood Week, a panel of six junior high school students agreed yesterday on the New York Times Youth Forum.

Signal equipment at Times Square intersections was shifted yesterday as the Traffic Department program to install signs to guide pedestrians safely across the streets formally started. The long, narrow signs that will flash "Walk" and "Don't Walk" instructions will not be set up before Wednesday.
The Bank of Passaic and Trust Company, Passaic, N. J., announced yesterday plans to issue $1,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Wheat futures maintained a strong tone today, until late in the session, when there was a downturn in all pits after a slump developed in March soybeans. In the earlier trade, export sales, including four cargoes to France overnight, stimulated buying of wheat and this also brought some buying support to the coarse grains, which recently had been inclined to follow wheat.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 20 -- One of West Germany's most prominent neo-Nazis is turning out to be a genuine original.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 (AP) -Larry MacPhail, who began dabbling in horses only four years ago, took a big plunge today by swinging a $2,000,000 deal for the purchase of Bowie race track.
BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- From bustling ports along 140 miles of the Baltic Sea coast toughened former German naval commanders are putting to sea once more with recently trained crews.

The argument that permanent personal registration would pave the way for widespread election frauds was stressed yesterday in a memorandum addressed to Governor Dewey. The signers of the memorandum included several hundred New York City Republican figures, headed by William M. Chadbourne, and the memorandum appeared designed to offset the drive by women's groups to procure enactment of a P. P. R. law at the current session of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Truman received today greetings of "very best love" from Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio. In return Mr. Taft received Mr. Truman's assurance that he, Mr. Taft, was a "good man" but that he was on the wrong side of the political fence.

An exhibition of "Japan: Illustrated Books and Prints," a survey of Japanese art through thirteen centuries, was opened yesterday at the second-floor gallery of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

A novel court action charging the state with negligence for failure to "physically" bar a suspended motorist from driving brought the disclosure yesterday that at least 5,000 car operators a month were on the roads illegally in the metropolitan area.

Net incomes of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1951 amounted to $5,967,990, equal to $4.85 a share, according to the annual report yesterday. The net compared with $8,935,845, or $7.26 a share, in 1950.

It was a case of Terry Sawchuk against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. When it was all over matters were exactly even, at 1 to 1, in the Blue's National Hockey League contest against the Detroit Red Wings.

What promises to be the most effective agent in the eradication of tuberculosis, one of mankind's worst scourges, has been developed by a team of scientists working in cooperation with the city's Department of Hospitals, it was learned yesterday.
Three clergymen of Protestant, Jewish and Catholic faiths spearheaded this week's "Blood for a Brother Campaign" when they donated blood yesterday at the Red Cross center, 70 West Fortieth Street.
Total revenues and net profit of American Airlines, Inc., last year established company records, C. R. Smith, president, reported yesterday.

A 24-year-old clothing salesman was credited yesterday with having provided the information that led to the arrest of William Francis Sutton on a street in Brooklyn on Monday. Belated recog nition was given to boyish-looking Arnold Schuster of 941 Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, for having identified the bank robber to the policemen who arrested him.

Community recreation centers as well as specially fitted apartments for the aged are to be included in rate-aided public housing here-after, Herman T. Stichman, State housing Commissioner, announced yesterday.

New York will celebrate tomorrow the 220th anniversary of the birth of George Washington with patriotic and religious services. Beginning this afternoon and ending Monday morning, heavy holiday traffic by air, rail, bus and private automobile is expected.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- The trial of Marie Besnard, a French farm woman accused of poisoning two husbands and ten other relatives and friends over a period of twenty-five years, today opened at Poitiers with an anti-climax -- her conviction on the lesser charge of forgery.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 20 -- The Government of West Germany will introduce in the Bundestag anti-trust legislation continuing the Allied decartelization program when the Federal Republic achieves political independence on the signing of the contractual agreement, an authoritative source said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 13:

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina said yesterday in Federal Court here that he has formed no judicial opinion of issues in the investment banking anti-trust case before him and that the courtroom comments he has made from time to time were intended only to clarify the issues, restrict the scope of the case, and put the issues in the right background.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 21 -- United States planes, flying in large numbers across the Manchurian border and profiting by the delay in the Korean armistice talks, recently staged three more strafing-bombing attacks causing three casualties, the Peiping radio charged this morning.

Books of advice on how to be an ideal mother in the present age list all the requirements except one. Nowhere is there ever any mention of one function that is vital when many families have a widened geographical base -- the job of driving a taxicab.

The Avenue of the Americas Association has just held its annual meeting to take inventory of progress and to look into the future, a process which has been going on since 1921, when a group of business men and property owners organized to advance the interests of this central thoroughfare in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Truman stressed today the influence of religion on the cause of peace. In brief messages to two religious groups visiting the White House, the President dwelt on this country's striving for "real brotherhood" and the part religious groups could play in attaining it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Majority rule, except when deliberately blocked or delayed by the Constitution of the United States or by regulations the national charter permits -- such as the procedural by-laws of the Senate -- is still the dominant political tenet in this country.
They could not get wary members of Brooklyn's teen-age gangs to come to the social workers, so the social workers went to the gangs. And the gangs like it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -The General Accounting Office charged today that almost every type of college and training school raided the Treasury under the educational provisions of the World War II G.I. Bill of Rights.

Take a New England town meeting, that vanishing Americanism the cracker barrel, a number of civic-minded citizens and a chamber of commerce that does not insist the community is perfect -- and the result is the Bronx "Community Clinic."

Opposition developed yesterday at City College to a resolution adopted last Friday by the Student Council opposing "all investigations into students' loyalty on any American college campus by the college administration" because such inquiries aided in destroying "academic freedom and the students' reason for learning."

The American Woolen Company announced yesterday that "because of present conditions in the industry the directors were of the opinion that no dividend should be paid on the common stock at this time." Last year shareholders received $1 each in March, June, September and $3 at the year-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Truman today assumed full responsibility for including the granting of immunity among the powers he had asked Congress to give to Newbold Morris, the New York Republican selected with Presidential approval to head the campaign to root out corruption from the Federal Government.

The eighty-fifth annual exhibition by members of the American Water Color Society will open to the public today in the Galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Fifteen prizes and two honorable mentions are announced in connection with the exhibition.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 -- A treaty establishing the European Defense Community, consisting of France, Italy, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, is expected to be ready for signature in six weeks, according to an authoritative French source.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton of Chicago, former National Boxing Association welterweight champion, tonight gained a split decision over rugged Vic Cardell of Hartford, Conn., in a nationally televised ten-round bout in the Chicago Stadium.

The Cairo dispatch of Albion Ross to THE TIMES on Feb. 13 reports that the success of the International Bank mission to Teheran in getting the Iranian oil industry going again "would mean serious trouble both politically and economically in the Arab world, in the opinion of oil experts and diplomats here."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Defense production officials today certified $71,540,000 worth of projects for the expansion of domestic newsprint production as eligible for tax assistance from the Government.

Your editorial "Emergency Powers" appearing in THE TIMES of Feb. 11 is indeed timely. Quite cogently you say that "the practice of vesting unusual powers in the Executive because of the pressure of circumstances is a potential violation of good democratic process."

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20 -- A new effort to learn something of the source of volcanic heat -- a problem on which scientists never have agreed -- has been started by a University of Wisconsin team that is using the world's youngest volcano, Paricutin, as a natural laboratory.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,166, for Wednesday's operations:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission has announced that a proposed natural gas rate increase of $5,700,000 a year by Hope Natural Gas Company of Clarksburg, W. Va., will become effective as of Feb. 1, upon posting of a $500,000 bond and subject to refund of any amounts later disallowed by the agency.

Joseph D. Nunan Jr., former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, who has been under Congressional fire because of his activity in settling Government tax cases, has resigned as a member of Wenchel, Schulman, Manning Nunan, a Washington, D. C., firm of lawyers and tax consultants. Richard J. Burke, Mr. Nunan's New York attorney, announced last night.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -Mrs. Babe Zaharias and Al Besselink excelled in the international mixed two-ball open golf tournament today, carding a record 29 on the front nine and scoring an easy first-round victory.

The two-day auction sale of the great Lincoln collection assembled by the late Oliver R. Barrett, Chicago lawyer, ended last night with total sales of $273,610, Anthony N. Bade, auctioneer for most of the sessions, reported after his last "call."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- The United States is ready to begin the first round of diplomatic conferences here on the intricate job of preparing a plan for a world census of all armed forces and weapons.

The largest single group of aliens deported from this country in recent years by the Immigration and Naturalization Service will be aboard the Italian liner Vulcania when she sails Saturday for Lisbon and other European ports.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- The bloodchilling mating call of Tarzan of the Apes is echoing from the sound screens of about twenty first-run Moscow motion-picture houses this week, providing movie-goers with an exotic change of pace.
New records in sales, earnings, payrolls and taxes were made last year by the United States Rubber Company, according to the sixtieth annual report to stockholders, for publication today.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 20 -More than 300 military students from some twenty-five different nations are included in the 9,000 students who are studying here at the infantry school. One hundred and forty-eight Republic of Korea officers, who learn their lessons through fourteen interpreters, are numbered among the foreign students.

" The Trial" ("Der Prozess"), an Austrian-made film directed by G. W. Pabst and written by Rudolf Brunngraber, Kurt Hauser and Emmeric Roboz, has been scheduled to have its American premiere on Friday, March 7, at the Thalia Theatre.

Another phase in the long march of the universal military training program from theory to practice ends today, deadline for the Armed Services Committees of both House and Senate to report a U. M. T. bill to Congress. The two committees have now done their part.

Undeniable facts should teach the United States not to underestimate arms production in the U. S. S. R. in spite of Soviet industrial backwardness, Harry Schwartz, Russian specialist of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

MIAMI, Feb. 20 -- James Fitzsimmons, the 77-year-old horse trainer from Sheepshead Bay, and Keith Douglas Stuart, the 18-yearold jockey from Bermuda, haven't been making expenses at Hialeah. At 4:59 P. M. today things began to look up a bit for both.

Earnings of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., for the quarter ended on Jan. 31 were between $350,000 and $400,000, or equal to 35 to 40 cents a share, E. F. Fisher, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Detroit. In the corresponding period of 1950, the company sustained a loss of $161,000.

The official opening of the Greater New York Scholastic Art Awards exhibit took place yesterday afternoon on the sixth floor of Gimbels, where it will remain through March 8. The 852-piece show included paintings, ceramics, sculpture, photography, fashion illustration and other crafts submitted by students from sixty-eight junior and senior high schools.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United Nations Commander, today told Americans who question "why we are in Korea" that everything Americans cherished was at stake ultimately in the grim and wearisome Korean conflict.
Art exhibitions here indicate that the mid-winter season is in full swing.
All stock and commodity exchanges -- but not all livestock markets -- will be closed in the United States today in commemoration of the birthday of George Washington. Markets abroad will be open.

WEST WINFIELD, N. Y., Friday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A state trooper was killed early today when a police posse captured three armed fugitives who had broken out of the Herkimer County jail a few hours before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The adoption of a ten-point safety program for independent airlines and an endorsement of President Truman's appointment of a special airport commission were among the matters concluded here today as the Aircoach Transport Association ended a four-day emergency meeting.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association announced yesterday its opposition to Senate Bill 2444, which would prohibit the advertising of alcoholic beverages on television or radio broadcasts.
Dr. Theodore Brameld of New York University said yesterday he had declined an invitation to deliver by radio an address that had been banned from a school platform in Red Bank, N. J.

George Pentis, 20-year-old Marine, was sentenced to six months in a penitentiary yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court for escaping from two deputy United States marshals outside of the Brooklyn Federal Building on Dec. 19 last. He had pleaded guilty to the charge.

Controversy in the art world, engendered by criticisms contained in a letter sent early this month by the National Sculpture Society to the director and trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, appeared yesterday to be far from settlement. At least two other art groups have sprung to the defense of the museum, and twenty-two members of the Sculpture Society, including four past presidents, have signed a letter opposing the society's statement.

A bill pending in the Legislature which would give all employes of cities having more than 1,000,000 population eleven holidays each year was disapproved by a City Council committee yesterday after it was noted that the bill contained no provision for alternative time or pay.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Johnny Rutherford, a "right-handed Preacher Roe," who couldn't work out yesterday because he was a hold-out, signed today and became the center of attention for all the Dodger brass.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Freeport Bank, of Freeport, L. I., 23-25 South Main Street, Freeport, has received approval for a certificate of increase of capital stock from $325,000, consisting of 50,000 shares of preferred stock of $1.50 par value and 25,000 shares of common stock of $10 par value, to $425,000, consisting of 50,000 shares of preferred at $1.50 and 35,000 shares of $10 common.
OSLO, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Dick Button, America's incomparable figure skater, retained his Olympic championship tonight with one of the most glittering performances of his career.

A consulting engineer hired by Westchester County to oppose commutation fare increases for the New York Central Railroad held yesterday that a rise in rates "will be another long step in abolishing commutation rates as such."

Led by Dave Ellis, Princeton's captain, New Jersey rode into the semi-final round of the annual Sherman Memorial indoor polo tournament last night by beating the Fairfield (Conn.) Polo Club, 15 -- 7, at the Squadron A Armory. Also reaching the next-to-last round were the Squadron A Troopers, who halted the Squadron A Turtles, 11 -- 7.

Wholesale butter prices here hit the highest peak this week since the spring of 1948. Retail prices, though unchanged since last Friday, also are higher than at any time since that period. The current rate of 95 cents a pound for butter is 14 cents more than it was a year ago at this time, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 21 -- The state Public, Utility Commission approved today a temporary 10-cent fare for intrastate passengers of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, pending further consideration on application. The fare applies to travel between Jersey City and Hoboken.
