PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., decided tonight to postpone a strike one month to give the Wage Stabilization Board time to work out a peaceful settlement of the union's pay dispute with the steel industry.

Sausages, which were no news to Confucius, apparently still are good news to Americans. Production of sausages, one of the earliest prepared foods, has increased steadily in recent years till now it represents 7.5 per cent of the annual meat supply of this country. Last year's stocks totaled 1,699,300,000 pounds.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Stock-markets here were unsettled today by yesterday's fresh setback on Wall Street. Although selling remained light prices continued to fall. Oil shares and some industrial issues improved in the afternoon but the recovery was only slight and at the close prices showed another long list of small falls.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- A British admiral, Sir Arthur John Power, has been named Allied Commander in Chief for the English Channel area, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Headquarters in London announced today.

The wonderful music of Claudio Monteverdi's first opera, "Orfeo," which had its premiere in 1607 at the Gonzaga Palace in Mantua, was performed by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall for the first time here in the Respighi version.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 21 -- The Middlebury College women's ski team won the downhill race today in the first event of the twenty-first annual Middlebury winter carnival at the Middlebury Snow Bowl.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 21 -- The Federal Government of Germany has voluntarily agreed to continue to pay the full costs of United States, British and French troops stationed on its soil for a year after the occupation ends and after it becomes simultaneously a full member of the European Defense Community.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 21 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and his Chief of Staff, Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, will visit Turkey and Greece early next month to discuss with political and military leaders of Nato's two newest members the organization of a final command structure in the Mediterranean area.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Clarence A. Bickel, chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, announced today that the association will register a strong protest with the Securities and Exchange Commission against the plan to assess new fees in the securities business.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 22 -- The staff officers conference at Panmunjom over an armistice in the Korean war moved into a new deadlock yesterday, after the Communists declined to accept a United Nations explanation of its objection to the Soviet Union as one of the neutral nations to police the cease-fire.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 22 -- Communists staged a nation-wide series of riots yesterday -- the biggest and most violent since the occupation -- and the police cracked back today in pre-dawn raids on suspected Red hide-outs around Tokyo.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- A crewman of the storm-split tanker Fort Mercer testified at a Coast Guard inquiry today that he had warned the captain hours before the tanker broke in two off Cape Cod Monday that a plate was off and the ship "holed."
An "arrest on sight" order was requested yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh for 158 taxicab drivers who failed to appear in Traffic Court to answer traffic summonses.

The identity of the "wonder drugs" that have given new life to nearly 200 victims of advanced tuberculosis, as well as other facts hitherto kept secret, were revealed yesterday at a special press interview called by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, in his offices at 125 Worth Street.

Austin, Tex., sold yesterday $6,300,000 of bonds due from 1953 to 1977 to a banking syndicate headed by the First National Bank of Chicago at a bid of 100.038 for interest of 2 3/4 per cent and 1 3/4 per cent, an interest cost of 1.768 per cent.

Judge Harold R. Medina said in Federal Court here yesterday that the investment banking anti-trust trial that he is hearing is a worse judicial burden than was the trial of the eleven 'Communist leaders on conspiracy charges. The ordeal, he said, is not caused by the behavior of the lawyers, as in the Communist trial, but by the "oppressiveness" of the Government's case.

Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, demanded to know last night if it were true that Attorney General J. Howard McGrath had become a millionaire during the years that coincided with his political career.

Grass-cloth and marble texture patterns, often displayed in wallpapers of the designer type, are two of the new additions to the Trimz Super-Washable Plastic Wallpaper line. A product of the United Wallpaper, Inc., these relatively inexpensive papers are designed for homemakers who wish to hang their own, and, unlike another Trimz collection, the plastic papers do not have paste on the back of them.

CAIRO, Feb. 21 -- The owners of Shepheard's Hotel, having rescued from the fire that destroyed it during the riots of Jan. 26 the most famous barkeep in the Orient, Joe of the Long Bar, have given him the task of perpetuating the tradition of the historic hostelry until a new Shepheard's can be built.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- The 70-year-old Broad Street Station, an eyesore here for years and scene of one of the city's most spectacular general-alarm fires, will be razed this spring to make possible a land development project "larger than New York's Rockefeller Center."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that it had ordered a second atomic power plant that eventually could be developed for propulsion of submarines. Work on the prototype of a nuclear reactor different from that already under construction will be undertaken by the General Electric Company at the commission's 4,000-acre site at West Milton, N. Y., near Schenectady.

CAIRO, Feb. 21 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha announced this evening that the Egyptian Ambassador in London, Abdel Fattah Amr Pasha, who returned here today after two conferences with British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, had brought a letter from the British but no proposals.

Newsprint now has a buyer's market, the Wall Street Journal said yesterday in an article on the reactions of its consumers to Canadian proposals for an increase in the price by about $20 a ton. The financial paper quoted one consumer as declaring that he now had to "fight his way through paper salesmen" he hadn't seen in his office since before the Korean war.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias and Al Besselink had a close call before eliminating Miss Peggy Kirk and Carl Dann, 1 up, in the second round of the international mixed-ball golf tournament today.
The time has come when we must finally determine whether we will participate with Canada in the building of the great St. Lawrence Seaway and Power project.
MONTREAL, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored twice in the last four and a half minutes tonight to tie the Boston Bruins, 3 to 3, before a crowd of 14,301 at the Forum.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 22 -- Communist-led Korean civilians interned on the prison island of Koje, off the southern coast of Korea, rioted last Monday, killing one American soldier, wounding another and inflicting minor injuries on twenty-two, it was announced today by headquarters of the Second Logistical Command in Pusan.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Robert L. Garner, Vice President of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, who came to London today to discuss with British officials his efforts to arrange a resumption of oil operations in Iran, was cautious about the prospects of success.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The National Production Authority gave blanket approval today to all of the 645 applications for the construction of $200,000,000 worth of religious, municipal and community building projects received from all over the country.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, and the Schola Cantorum soloists, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Concert by members of the Columbia University music department, McMillin Theatre, 2:30; Young people's concert, Staten Island Symphony, Walter C. Piasecki, conductor, Curtis High School, 3; Chamber and choral music concert, Carl Fischer Hall, 4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- The Michigan Manufacturers Association told Congress today that special legislation, aimed at relieving Michigan's unemployment, was not needed or justified and threatened new Federal controls over the states.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Truman gave another cryptic hint today that he might be a candidate for re-election.
OSLO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Here is a list of champions crowned in the sixth winter Olympics:
Influenced by expanded credit requirements of defense and defense-supporting industries, business loans from banks in this area rose $23,000,000 last week.
SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The defense of Alaska, "mandatory" for the security of the United States, would be strengthened by the pending statehood measure, the Senate was told today in a message from the Defense Department.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 -- At the conclusion of a meeting of the board of the Glenn L. Martin Company here today, Mr. Martin, its veteran chairman, announced the election of George M. Bunker as president, general manager and director and of J. B. Wharton Jr. as vice president-finance.
One of the best periods of skiing in the history of the sport in the East awaits the expected record turnout of recreational and competitive enthusiasts over the Washington's Birthday holiday period.

OSLO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Prime Minister Oscar Torp of Norway, a pretty good soccer player in his day, rose to the defense of American and Canadian ice hockey tactics today, calling the blow-up over rough stuff in Tuesday night's game the result of "ignorance."

The United Tanker Corporation, which either directly or through subsidiaries has operated six of the surplus tankers involved in a Senate investigation in Washington, has submitted an application to the Department of Justice in effect denying any irregularity in the complex financial history of the little fleet.

Reports were current yesterday that managers of the Eisenhower-for-President campaign were exerting renewed efforts to have the general return to the United States well in advance of the Republican convention, which opens July 7 in Chicago.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 -- The Johns Hopkins Hospital and University have received subscriptions of $4,155,000 to their "assurance fund" during its first year of operation, D. Luke Hopkins, president of the Johns Hopkins Fund, announced today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 21 -- The status of women in Pakistan was explained, in part, here today to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. She was told that under Moslem law women already enjoyed many privileges sought by their sisters in other lands. Mrs. Roosevelt is the guest here of the All-Pakistan Women's Association.

Manhattan College upset New York University's quintet, 74 -- 66, at Madison Square Garden last night. A five-minute overtime period decided the intracity battle, opening contest of a double-header watched by 8,128 spectators. The teams were tied, 65-all, at the end of regulation playing time.

Looking haughtily at "Dear Barbarians," which opened at the Royale last evening, one of the first-night savants remarked: "This is like the stuff they did in Greenwich Village twenty-five years ago." That is an exaggeration. Greenwich Village was never so young.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 21 -- The Chinese Nationalist press reacted angrily today to Tokyo reports quoting Premier Shigeru Yoshida as having told the Diet (Parliament) that the Japanese delegation now here negotiating a bilateral treaty with the Taipei regime would recognize the latter's sovereignty only over territory it actually controls.

It was sound thinking on the part of Secretary Acheson to stress the defensive character of Nato in his opening address to the Lisbon conference. Americans should keep reminding themselves that there is a considerable body of opinion which believes that United States policies are leading more or less deliberately toward war.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 21 -- Gen. Gonzales de King announced today that five Vietminh battalions were beaten and dispersed in a six-day operation in the Tongking delta, northeast of Thaibinh that ended yesterday. He declared that 1,000 Vietminh combatants had been killed, wounded or captured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Average weekly earnings of production workers declined 57 cents between December and January but, at $66.79 in January, were $3.03 higher than a year earlier. The Bureau of Labor Statistics also reported today that the manufacturing work week declined a half hour during the same period. It called that an average decrease for the season.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur announced last night that he did not support General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's "candidacy for political office" and that he had "no personal feelings whatsoever with reference" to President Truman.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Having arrived by car, plane, train and bus, the early contingent of Yankees was assembled tonight, awaiting the call to the grim business of fat-rendering tomorrow at Miller Huggins Field.
MIAMI, Feb. 21 -- Eugene Rodriguez is a Cuban jockey. In the Hialeah race program the management persists in spelling his surname with a "q" instead of a "g."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- (AP) Merchant witnesses hit today at efforts to restore the effectiveness of "fair trade" laws permitting the establishments of minimum resale prices.
Donald McNeill of Searingtown, L. I., former national champion both outdoors and indoors, was eliminated from the United States indoor tennis championship last night.
Carl A. Salmonsen has been appointed general manager of the new industry control department of General Electric Company, Schenectady.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 -- Testimony that overthrow of the Government by force was mentioned at a Marxist class at San Diego in 1945 was presented today at the Federal District Court trial of fifteen California Communists.
SEOUL, Korea, Feb. 21 (AP) -- An Eighth Army spokesman said today that a report that old and obsolete artillery is being used in Korea "is just not true."
RENOVA, Pa., Feb. 21 -- A crew of experts, working amidst explosive fumes, succeeded today in capping a new gas well, ending a six-day battle with the gusher.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- The two Right Wing parties of the West German Government coalition asked today for something more than a provisional solution for the German conditions to rearmament and sought the restoration of Germany under the frontiers of 1937.

Circulars urging bus passengers to support union and company opposition to the plan to convert Seventh and Eighth Avenue to one-way flow were distributed yesterday to riders of all twenty-one routes of the New York City City Omnibus Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- The Government was reported to 1/2 day to have dropped the idea of limiting new houses to 1 1/2 bathrooms each.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Department store sales in the United States fell 6 per cent below those in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the Board's weekly report on sales by cities follow, in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1951:

" Truth in Masquerade: A Study of Fashions in Fact," by Esme Wingfield-Stratford, has been scheduled for April 7 publication by Roy. Through a selection of instances, ranging from ancient Egypt to the present, Mr. Wingfield-Stratford attempts to prove that historical fact is often only subconscious bias or conscious propaganda.

With demands for domestic and industrial gas growing continuously, natural gas soon may have to be augmented by supplies of synthetic gas made from seam coal and jumped through pipelines to consumers, C. R. Breck, of the Southern Natural Gas Company, declared yesterday.

On record net sales of $154,012,245, the Cone Mills Corporation and its subsidiaries last year had a net profit of $11,333,327, according to the annual report yesterday of this large domestic manufacturer of textile fabrics.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Grain futures were under some liquidating pressure at times today, but there was enough commission absorption to keep the market within narrow limits, except for March wheat which was down better than 1 cent at times. Trade volume was extremely light much of the day with the general news not outstanding enough to stimulate much activity on either side.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 21 -- A 52-year-old Lincoln woman, balked in efforts to enter a "favorite son" candidate in Nebraska's Republican Presidential preference primary, entered herself today as a "favorite daughter" pledged to support General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 21 (AP) -- An informant who returned from the Burmese-Chinese border area tonight said an air field recently was completed by Nationalist Chinese forces at Monghsat under the supervision of United States engineers.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Feb. 21 (AP) -- H. Frederick Willkie, hired at $60,000 a year by the meatpacking company of Kingan Co. to inject new ideas into the century-old business, was ousted from the company completely today.
The jumbled jig-saw behind the long-time operations of William Francis Sutton, the bank robber, who was captured in Brooklyn last Monday, began to fall neatly into place yesterday.

IN Gallodoro, an Italian town on the Mediterranean coast indistinguishable from Amalfi, everyone is poor and idle and in love with noise, any kind of noise, but the louder the better. The Gallodorian "genius for doing nothing" is famous and so is their fearsome local dialect. Equally worthy of fame is the Duke of Gallodoro, "the duke upstairs," as he is called by the quaint native characters of whom the entire population consists.

A portion of Mayor Impellitteri's $284,900,000 fiscal aid program received impetus yesterday when the City Council, under the Home Rule Act, requested the State Legislature to approve a bill currently before it empowering the city to levy a $60 a year charge for overnight parking in the streets.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 21 -- William Henry Belk, founder and president of the Belk Brothers Company, operators of a chain of 308 department stores; prominent Presbyterian layman and benefactor of churches, hospitals and schools, died in a Charlotte hospital this afternoon, after a brief illness. His age was 89.
Since natural gas has been used in the New York area, there has been a substantial increase in the number of gas meters running fast and overcharging customers.

A unanimous resolution attacking the recent reported findings on communism in Hollywood by the House Committee on Un-American Activities for an "indictment of an entire industry for the past activities of a misguided or vicious few" and declaring that the Council of Motion Picture Organizations would "give the widest possible publicity to the facts" was passed at a council meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

A group of the displaced who had lived in the easternmost rookeries on the Baruch city housing site by the East River, shivered in the raw wind at Rivington Street and Baruch Place last night, proof of the saying that misery loves company.
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 21 (Reuters) -- An Australian defense program costing ultimately about $1,900,000,000 was foreshadowed today by Defense Minister Philip McBride.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- A new attempt to reconcile French interests in Tunisia with the home-rule demands of the Nationalists there will begin tomorrow when Jean De Hauteclocque, Resident General of the protectorate, returns to Tunis with new instructions from the French Government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- During the week ended Feb. 20, member bank reserves decreased $87,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

OSLO, Feb. 21 -- Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., won a fourth gold medal for the United States, as generally expected, in the men's figure skating decided tonight at Bislett Stadium, but otherwise this eighth day of the sixth winter Olympics was not favorable for America.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 21 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Allies agreed today that they must remain "firm and vigilant" for a "very long period," during which they must by prudence and firmness discourage the Soviet Union from any contemplation of an aggressive war.

The music of a brass band and the rasp of loudspeakers echoed from the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets yesterday, drawing noon-hour financial district idlers to a day-in-advance celebration of George Washington's 220th birthday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A three-judge Federal Court today upheld an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission permitting the Boston Maine Railroad to put into effect a plan of security modification which would reduce the number of classes of its stock, authorize the issuance of new stock and cancel dividend arrearages on certain classes of stock.
DENVER, Feb. 21 -- A combination of C. I. O., A. F. L. and unaffiliated oil workers prepared today for a strike March 3 that threatened to halt refinery production in most areas.

A detailed program for reducing the number of airline flights into and out of La Guardia Airport was drawn up yesterday by scheduling experts from thirteen airlines and submitted to the National Air Transport Coordinating Committee.

Information on laundering that often-reached-for item, the towel; advice on using various types of bluing and a new pamphlet on laundering were some of the subjects discussed yesterday at a meeting in the General Foods Home Laundry Center, 383 Madison Avenue.

BABYLON, L. I., Feb. 21 -- A bitter controversy that has lasted more than two years will be brought to a climax here Saturday when the residents of this town and four neighboring communities vote on whether to establish a central school district.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Dewey said at a news conference today that he would be "greatly surprised" if thirty New York delegates to the Republican National convention supported Senator Robert A. Taft for the Presidential nomination. The Ohio Senator's managers have been claiming that many New York delegates.

Few national heroes in all history have stood the test of time better than the one whose birth two hundred and twenty years ago we celebrate today. Washington was a man of such selfless character and such vast abilities that he almost seems unreal; and yet the most critical examination of his motives and of his accomplishments serves only to enhance his stature.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- As arms production begins to gain momentum in Britain this year, more young men will be drafted for military service. A Government White Paper, giving a glimpse of what the nation's rearmament program will produce in the way of weapons, men and machines in 1952-53, announced today that there would be five registrations for national service during the year instead of the usual four.

A variety of spring silhouettes and fabrics were included in the selection of coats and suits presented to the press yesterday in the third-floor Grey Room at Ohrbach's. Coats were predominately full and suits emphasized both fullness and the slim, trim look.

Sgt. Arthur Gescheidle of the Wakefield Police Station arrested Mrs. Ethel Cawley of 4055 Carpenter Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday because, he charged, she "used loud and abusive language" and punched him when he told her to stand back from the scene of an auto crash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 16 totaled 737,609 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,885 cars, or 0.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 2,948 cars, or 0.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 177,541 cars, or 31.7 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

It is only a complete misanthrope who completely hates a party, and from this fact there can be made certain deductions about the warmer side of human nature. Since there unquestionably are a great many parties, it follows that there cannot be as many misanthropes as a casual glance around might suggest.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21 -- Sal Maglie agreed to terms today, by telephone from Niagara Falls, N. Y., removing the only holdout problem of the Giants.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Assemblyman Lawrence W. Van Cleef, vice chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems, said today that his introduction of a bill to provide for a compulsory automobile inspection system to be operated by private garages did not mean that he favored such a bill.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company further solidified its position last year as the second largest corporate enterprise in the world. At the end of 1951, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday, total assets had climbed to $10,900,906,184, an increase of $562,000,000 over the previous year.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "Five Fingers," a Twentieth Century-Fox, melodrama, featuring James Mason, Danielle Darrieux, Michael Rennie and Walter Hampden, is at the Roxy. Joseph L. Mankiewicz directed and Otto Lang produced from a screen play by Michael Wilson and a novel by L. C. Moyzisch.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Charged with violating export control regulations, the Express Aero Freight Terminal, a New York freight-forwarding concern, was ordered denied all privileges of participating in United States exports for the two-week period March 10 through March 24.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Asian and African members of the United Nations held a strategy conference today to plan a joint protest to the Security Council against French rule in Tunisia.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Feb. 21 -- Just like some individuals, the City of Asbury Park is experiencing a rough time with its landlord.

Contract talks between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., were recessed yesterday afternoon until Tuesday, as no progress toward a settlement was reported.

Eight pounds of smoking opium, that would have brought between $20,000 and $40,000 on the illicit market, was seized yesterday in the luggage of an alien tourist passenger, who arrived on the Italian liner Vulcania at Pier 84, Hudson River.

The Griller Quartet has existed with the same personnel since its birth, twenty-three years ago. This makes it the oldest such organization still in one piece, and -- as one might expect -- gives it uncommonly strong cohesiveness and maturity of ensemble spirit.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The State Defense Council approved today New York City's proposal for the construction of subway bomb shelters in congested areas and adopted a resolution urging Congress to appropriate funds to make Federal aid available for bomb shelter construction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Truman today nominated Ellsworth Bunker to be Ambassador to Italy and Cavendish W. Cannon, a veteran diplomat now Minister to Syria, to be Ambassador to Portugal. He filled two major posts opened in a recent shift of top diplomats here and abroad.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21 -- The spirit of democracy will burn brightly in a film being planned about the life of Cpl. Alexander Stewart, the former French war waif adopted by G. I.'s in North Africa, who was killed in action in Korea last Dec. 28 at the age of 22.
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 21 -- The United States has decided to give increased priority to France in its military and economic aid programs.

The Long dynasty in Louisiana has taken a larruping with the gubernatorial nomination of Judge Robert Kennon in a run-off contest with Carlos G. Spaht, who had been selected by Gov. Earl Long, brother of the late Huey Long, as the next incumbent of the big mansion at Baton Rouge.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- William Reid, who served as Deputy Mayor under former Mayor William O'Dwyer, assumed the role of chief negotiator for New York today in the city's campaign to get state financial help in balancing its budget for the next fiscal year.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21 -- President Getulio Vargas signed a decree today establishing export controls on all strategic materials. It creates the Strategic Materials Export Commission headed by Foreign Minister Joas Neves da Fontoura and including representatives of the General Staff, of the Ministries of Finance and Agriculture, of the National Research Council and of the Bank of Brazil's Export and Import Branch.

The operation of bus lines by the Westchester Street Transportation Company, an affiliate of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation, at the present fare would result in a loss of $156,600 this year, according to testimony given yesterday by company officials at a hearing before the Public Service Commission, at 233 Broadway.

ATHENS, Feb. 21 -- The political party calling itself the Democratic Union of the Left, which polled 178,325 votes and was fourth in numerical strength in the elections last Sept. 9, was characterized today as a legal front of international communism by the Director General of Athens Police, John Panopoulos, testifying in the military trial of alleged Communist spies.

Directors of Irving Trust Company have authorized payment of a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on April 1, it was announced yesterday. The banking institution distributed quarterly dividends of 20 cents a share last year, plus an extra dividend of 20 cents a share last December.
PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Rumors of financial tension for the government in France today resulted in a wave of speculation in hard currencies and gold.

Anthony Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront figure, was acquitted last night by a jury in Kings County Court of two charges resulting from an alleged attack upon a State Liquor Authority investigator. He had been on trial for three days on an indictment charging second-degree assault, which is a felony, and resisting a public officer, a misdemeanor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Training programs for occupations, both civilian and military, that depend primarily on women should take biological trends into account, Maj. Ruth E. Church of the Army Medical Corps said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Frederick P. Wall, secretary of Representative William L. Dawson, Democrat of Illinois, and three other persons on charges of peddling influence to obtain post office jobs.
TORONTO, Feb. 21 -- Under the watchful eye of Edward Johnson, former general manager of New York's Metropolitan Opera, the curtain rose tonight on Canada's third annual opera festival.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 21 -- The West German Bundestag today deliberated on what it would do about a neo-Nazi deputy who has confessed he was a first edition believer as well.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Styles Bridges, Senate Republican leader, criticized President Truman today for not submitting more government reorganization plans to Congress and said the Administration only had sought changes when necessary to quiet "public clamors."

A telephone warning that a bomb had been planted in the eleven-story Brooklyn Technical High School, DeKalb Avenue and Fort Greene Place, caused 600 students to leave the building last night while thirty police and firemen searched the premises for an hour and a half.

BUFFALO, Feb. 21 -- A Continent-wide movement began here today to convince Protestant churchgoers that their responsibility as Christians entailed a seven-day week that began on Sunday and only reached its fruition as they practiced their religious precepts in their daily tasks.

Your editorial in the Feb. 13 TIMES "On Burning Books" was interesting but quite misleading. You state, "book-burning is an activity too closely identified with totalitarian methods to be welcomed in the United States." It appears this requires explanation.

Students from sixty-six secondary schools in the Eastern United States were warned yesterday at the opening of the fourth annual Columbia College Forum on Democracy that political indifference was the greatest threat to American democracy.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 21 -- A young deserter from the Soviet Army said today that if the time ever comes, the forces that fight the struggle for liberation from the Communist regime in Moscow will find that Siberia is the soft underbelly of the Soviet Union.

Mayor Impellitteri slammed the brakes hard yesterday on a move by City Council President Rudolph Halley to get the Board of Estimate to hold a public hearing on proposed state legislation which would give the New York City Parking Authority sufficient strength to support its bond issue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- An extension from Feb. 1 to April 1 in the effective date of the retail packaged liquor price regulation drawn up by the Office of Price Stabilization, was granted today at the request of representatives of the retail liquor package store owners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, charged today that Joseph D. Nunan Jr., former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, had figured in four more tax cases in which "not one dime" had been collected although Government claims came to a sum of nearly $2,000,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Governor Dewey declared today that he favored the controversial Metcalf-Hatch bill to permit the requisition of dogs and cats for medical research from publicly aided collecting agencies.

Dissenting sharply from those who in recent months have begun to criticize the Korean war as "unnecessary" or "futile," General Ridgway has raised his voice in defense of the validity and the purposes of our intervention. He declares that to have failed to meet his challenge would have been to repudiate every principle we had previously professed.
On Feb. 15 thirty years had passed since the day when the Latvian Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution of the Republic of Latvia (of 1922), which provides that:
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- A little more of the lost freedom of the individual was restored in Britain today. Identity cards were abolished.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- An administrative spokesman warned today that most American youths for years to come could figure on serving a term in the armed forces.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 -- The Army Ordnance Corps today announced the award to Michigan concerns of defense contracts totaling $206,488,292, including a $135,000,000 award to the General Motors Corporation for continued production of GMC two-and-one-half-ton military trucks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Wage Stabilization Board expects to begin consideration of the steel wage dispute in a week or ten days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Wayne Coy resigned today as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission to take a position in private industry. In his letter accepting the resignation, President Truman said "yours is the ironic story of so many key civil servants whose abilities and special skills must be lost to Government because of the inadequacy of Government salaries."

Because of the low pay their principal wage-earner receives as a city employe, fifty-one families are getting supplementary assistance from the Department of Welfare, Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.

Good news for newsprint users: Newsprint Service Bureau reports that North American production in January set a record for that month and was 21,694 tons above the similar month of 1951. Last month's figure was 567,672 tons.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Three bills designed to curtail the political activities of labor unions and forbid the use of union money except from special funds whose collection would be strictly regulated were introduced in the Legislature today under bipartisan sponsorship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- Authorities at most of the nation's Army, Navy and Air Force bases believe that housing for service families at such installations should be transferred from private to military ownership, a report to the Senate Banking Committee said today.

A remarkably absorbing, half hour of television, successfully refuting many of the preconceived notions of what constitutes model programming, is being presented by the Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, at 8 o'clock Tuesday evenings over the DuMont Network and WABD.
SALEM, Ore., Feb. 21 -- Petitions were filed here today placing the name of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower on the May 16 Oregon primary ballot.
MIDDLETON, Tenn., Feb. 21 (AP) -- A furious gunfight erupted in this little Southwest Tennessee town today when a gunman tried to hold up the bank. The mass fire of angry citizens cut him down.

POITIERS, France, Feb. 21 (UP) -- A prim 58-year-old French farm-woman, accused of poisoning eleven relatives and friends for profit, denied in court today that she had put arsenic in her second husband's soup, because by killing him "I would have killed all my happiness."

Taxpayer opposition, here and in Albany, to first one new tax proposal and then another to rescue New York City from its budgetary dilemma is beginning to have unfortunate results. We begin to hear talk not of sound budget - balancing taxation but of strange, mysterious devices and "gimmicks" which would not purport to solve the city's problems but merely defer the evil day when the bills of city government must be paid.

Operating what he contends is one of the best-groomed legitimate theatres on Broadway, Billy Rose doesn't seem to have any trouble finding a tenant for the Ziegfeld. The degree of production activity, of course, has some bearing on that observation.

A $12,000,000 anti-trust suit against thirteen major league baseball clubs, the presidents of the National and American Leagues and Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick has been filed in Chicago by the Liberty Broadcasting System.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotten Exchange closed steady yesterday and final prices were 57 points higher to 2 points lower on active months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The action of the House of Representatives yesterday, "directing" the Secretary of State fully to inform it whether the President made any secret commitment to Prime Minister Churchill in Washington recently touching the dispatch of more American troops to foreign areas, was the consequence of four principal causes -- one embedded in the Constitution, two in acts of the Truman Administration, and one supplied by Prime Minister Churchill.

Current and planned activities for rehabilitation of war veterans on an internationally cooperative basis were discussed yesterday by Kurt Jansson, director of rehabilitation for the World Veterans Federation.

Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, called last night for the defeat of the Fair Deal in the forthcoming Presidential elections as the one means by which voters could demand the balancing of the Federal budget and an end to mounting deficits.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Achmed Soebardjo resigned today under a storm of protest against his endorsement of United States aid under the terms of the Mutual Security Act.

Three Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions won doubled welfare and pension contributions and other benefits in wage-review negotiations with East and Gulf Coast ship operators that wound up yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- The Mexican Government announced tonight that talks with the United States on a military aid agreement had broken down. The announcement by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the negotiations might be resumed, but, according to United States sources, the differences were basic and there was no likelihood of an agreement in the foreseeable future.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,167, for Thursday's operations:

YONKERS, Feb. 21 -- The Americanism Committee of the Westchester County American Legion was accused today by the Yonkers Council of Churches of using a technique similar to that of "McCarthyism" in criticizing Sarah Lawrence College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A warning of danger from psittacosis or "parrot fever" from birds obtained in Southern Florida was issued today by Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele of the Public Health Service.

A fairly strong recovery was made yesterday by the stock market but support faded late in the afternoon and the best gains were reduced in many instances. The rebound came after three days of selling pressure during which the market came perilously close to the November lows of last year.

Divertissements patterned after those of the traditional carnival ball given in Rio de Janeiro every year before the beginning of the Lenten season were features of the Carioca Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the establishment of a cancer hospital and research laboratory in Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today that Government price supports for cotton in 1952 will be at the same percentage level that has prevailed for several years.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Leaders of the American bar today condemned the televising or broadcasting of hearings by Congressional investigating committees and of judicial proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) -- American farmers took in more money last year than ever before in history, but because of higher costs their profit was below the record reached in 1947, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 21 (UP) -- Jerry Barber of Pasadena, Calif., and Earl Stewart of Dallas fought off gusty winds and a smattering of rain today as well as Memorial Park's difficult par to take a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Houston open.
At least 1,000 sisters of Roman Catholic religious orders of the New York Diocese will meet at St. Vincent's Hospital, 158 West Twelfth Street, today to donate blood for the armed forces.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 -- Inaugurating the New Delhi session of the International Film Festival today, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru urged producers, script writers and actors to pay greater attention "to bring about mutual understanding and friendly relations" among nations.

Representative F. Edward Hebert, chairman of the House Armed Services subcommittee, who denounced during open hearings in Washington last week waste in national defense expenditures, praised yesterday the operation of the Armed Services Medical Procurement Agency at 84 Sands Street, Brooklyn.

Audience reaction to an argument last night on a television program between Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican Presidential aspirant, and Tex McCrary, a supporter of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as President, almost stopped the show.

VERNON DIXON was not too hopeful before the race. He wasn't scared, mind you. But a 19-year-old boy couldn't help but be a trifle awed by the opposition he was facing. One of his rivals was George Rhoden, the holder of the world 400-meter record of 0:45.8. Another was Herb McKenley, the holder of the world 440-yard record of 46 seconds flat.

Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin and Alexei N. Kosygin are now full members of the Politburo, ruling body of the Soviet Union, rather than merely candidate members, as previously believed, diplomatic observers in this country have concluded after examining evidence that has recently become available.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The staff of a Senate subcommittee has been instructed to make a special inquiry as to whether Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, has been attempting "economic coercion" of press and radio critics.

The rubles are rolling merrily into Moscow movie box offices these days as Muscovites throng to watch Tarzan's jungle adventures, gasping as he swings through the treetops or battles with the villainous beasts and humans of his forest habitat. These moviegoers can apparently expect more thrills in the future, for the film now playing is being billed as the first of a series of such "exotic" pictures.

George Balanchine nodded a bit on his latest ballet, "Bayou," which had its world premiere last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center. For what must be the first time in his creative life, his choreography constituted the weakest element in a theatrical collaboration.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 21 -- A curfew was declared tonight in Tripoli after disturbances following upon the first general election in the new kingdom of Libya.
Recovery on the Stock Exchange yesterday was accompanied by a similar trend in the commodity futures markets. Some commodities recorded losses, but these were small and the tone was improved.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Sworn testimony of confusion and deliberately substandard work on a $300,000,000 air base construction program in North Africa was given at a Senate hearing today.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The weight of opinion among representative London critics is that "The Red Letter Day," by Andrew Rosenthal, is written by a good craftsman, is well acted and directed, but is not substantial enough.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 21 -- Two members of the Mapam party in Israel's Knesset (Parliament) resigned today from the party, which, they said, had become indistinguishable from the Communists. The dissidents, Mrs. Hanna Lamdan, Deputy Speaker of the Knesset, and David Livshitz decided to form a new political group.
(Thursday, Feb. 21, Observations) Only those areas which reported snow are listed.

A bright look keynotes most of the new smoking accessories. Brightness is found in color, whimsy of pattern or in originality of shape. Also of interest is the infinite variety of materials of which they are made, ranging from marble to perforated metal.
There was an absolutely topdrawer performance by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- A Federal court jury convicted tonight a leading Syracuse real estate broker and a former Syracuse Trust Company bookkeeper of a $1,600,000 fraud against the bank.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- Gopalaswami Ayyangar, Minister for Railways and Transport, presenting the annual railway budget to Parliament today, said that the biggest Government-owned industry would close the year ending March with a surplus equivalent to $44,000,000.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 22 (UP) -- The son of Gen. Claire Chennault of Flying Tiger fame charged today that he was dismissed as a state trooper because he had refused to donate $50 to the campaign fund of a gubernatorial candidate in the recent Louisiana elections.

Assuming for the moment that the story of small George Washington and the cherry tree is not a fable, George could have done a quicker and better job, with far less effort, if he had had some of the equipment available nowadays. George was only 5 then, according to the Parson Weems version of the story, and presumably the effort of chopping down the tree was tiring.

For its second presentation of the season, the DeWitt Clinton Community Center is housing the Equity Library Theatre production of Noel Coward's gay charade, 'Blithe Spirit." It was offered last night at the Bronx auditorium and will be done there again tonight.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 22 -- The arrival in camp today of Larry Jansen, twenty-three-game winner in the 1951 pennant charge, and Eldred Broadway, a left-handed rookie pitcher who has been assigned to Sioux City, Iowa, boosted the Giants' personnel in training to twenty-six, including players, coaches and manager Leo Durocher.
ATLANTA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Zack Cravey, State Insurance Commissioner, today waved a new legislative act at the Bankers Life and Casualty Company of Chicago, whose license he has refused to renew.

Philanthropies furthered by the Daughters of the American Revolution and the Sons of the American Revolution were the beneficiaries of the Colonial Ball held last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre under the joint auspices of the organizations.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 22 -- As several hundred Jewish leaders gathered here tonight on the eve of the opening of the United Jewish Appeal's 1952 campaign for $151,500,000, Edward M. M. Warburg, the appeal's general chairman, called the drive as the "most crucial in the 14-year-old history of the U. J. A."
From the abstract to the realist to the romantic -- such is the stylistic gamut run in most contemporary New York art exhibitions. Five of these, currently on view, follow this set pattern.
The following bits of advice, which may be of use to homemakers, have been received from various sources.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A uniform set of relaxed Lenten rules has been suggested to Roman Catholic Bishops throughout the United States to use if they see fit.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 22 -- John Foster Dulles, State Department adviser, today called for the same kind of "dynamism" in our present international relations as marked this country's emergence as a free nation.

Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State and chairman of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, urged last night a reassessment of our foreign policy, less timidity in dealing with the Soviet Union and a return to morality in government.

VIENNA, Feb. 22 -- Soviet authorities have been bringing strong pressure to bear on People's party officials in the Russian zones of Austria and Vienna to urge the removal from office of Foreign Minister Karl Gruber because of his recent speech warning Russia not to partition Austria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company of San Francisco applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for permission to market $55,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, series U, due Dec. 1, 1985, at public bidding.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Larry MacPhail, who vigorously argues that Baltimore horse racing would be better off with two major tracks instead of three, will get a chance to prove it at a joint Laurel - Bowie meet beginning March 22.
The police were still investigating last night the fatal stabbing Thursday night of a 13-year-old boy near his Brooklyn home. They believed, however, that the slaying was a case of mistaken identity.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 22 -- News of the first Dacca incident filtered through to Karachi late yesterday. In a press note received early in the morning the Government of East Pakistan acknowledged that one person had been killed on spot and that two others had died of injuries following a club and revolver charge on 7,000 persons, mostly students.

The thirteen-story office building at 151 East Thirty-second Street has been sold by a syndicate headed by Hechler Durst, operators, to an investing group represented by the Rowely Realty Corporation, broker in the transaction. The buyers, who paid cash above mortgages of $795,000, took title in the name of the 151 East Thirty-second Realty Corporation.

After two qualifying sessions played here last night at the Pierre Hotel, thirty-two contract bridge teams of four started knockout matches in the 1952 Vanderbilt Cup team of four national championship.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 22 -- Libyan police arrested Beshir Bey Sadawi, leader of the anti-Western opposition Congress party, early today, together with his brother, nephew and immediate followers. They were taken to Castel Benito Airfield and put on a plane en route for Egypt.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Feb. 22 -- Citizens of the twin communities of Biddeford and Saco, whose economy depends largely on the textile industry, trooped today through a large new plant opened by the Saco-Lowell Shops, manufacturer of textile machinery.

Members of the American paper industry heard optimistic forecasts yesterday on prospects for another year of record consumption, but were told that continued heavy demand still would be difficult to meet. Speeches attempting to point the direction of future development put the stress on progress as the American Paper and Pulp Association closed its seventy-fifth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ATHENS, Feb. 22 -- Today, the seventh day on which twenty-nine alleged Communist spies have been on trial before a military court here, the presiding judge read into the record about 300 messages said to have been exchanged between Greek Communist headquarters behind the Iron Curtain and Communist operatives within Greece.

Recent discussions in Washington and the training of a cadre of Korean officers at Fort Benning have again put emphasis on some of the longer- range problems involved in the building of Asia's defenses. It is agreed that points of peril must be made strong. It is not always agreed or understood how this is to take place.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -The trend in Hollywood for 19521953 appears to be down to the sea in ships. Historical and contemporary stories about epic sea adventures, ranging from the voyage of the Mayflower to the recent exploits of Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen aboard the ill-fated Flying Enterprise, are on the schedule of practically every studio.

" Man On the Run," an Associated British production starring Derek Farr and Joan Hopkins, has been scheduled to have its local premiere on Tuesday, Feb. 26, at the Trans-Lux Seventy-second Street Theatre, it was announced yesterday by the theatre circuit.

In your editorial of Feb. 6 "At America's Gateways" you sound a highly justified warning against the dangers inherent in the new McCarran Immigration Bill. In commenting on the bill, however, you further suggest that it contains some good points -- "including the abolition of racial discrimination as such."

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The 3-year-old division of thoroughbred racing launches its big money campaign tomorrow, with the favored Windy City II from Ireland and thirteen American colts competing in the Santa Anita Derby for a $140,000 purse.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Another sharp decline of the franc on the unofficial market coupled with the steady run upon hard currencies and gold maintained the panicky feeling on the Paris market today and encouraged talk of political repercussions felt to be impending in France.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 22 -- Dissatisfaction with President Juan D. Peron's "austerity plan" was manifested today by the Radical party in its unofficial newspaper, Adelante. In a leading article the paper guardedly charged the President had advanced the date of the general elections from this February to last November because he knew he could not be re-elected under the present circumstances.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported these snow conditions at New York ski centers:

In brisk and sunny weather, ideal for parades and other outdoor displays, the 220th anniversary of the birth of George Washington was celebrated here yesterday. Besides patriotic demonstrations, the day was solemnized with religious observances.
NEWPORT, R. I., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Because thirteen merchant seamen refused to abandon even half of their wrecked ship, the tanker Fort Mercer's stern was snugly anchored in Narragansett Bay tonight.

When it enters service this summer, the new superliner United States will be the largest completely air-conditioned ship afloat. A network of sixty-five individual air-conditioning systems are being installed by the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.
BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- Harvard University officials confirmed tonight that a six-foot cross was set aflame outside the rooms of nine Negro students at midnight Feb. 5.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Protesting against a pending Government decision to increase British steel prices, Steven J. L. Hardie resigned today as chairman of the Iron and Steel Corporation, which controls the nationalized steel industry.

Seventy thousand members of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., will meet and demonstrate at fifty General Electric plants on March 4 in protest against Federal stabilization policies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The 220th anniversary of George Washington's birth finds his famous Eighteenth Century homestead more than ever like it was when he and Martha Washington lived there.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 22 -- Forty thousand farms owned by private peasants in the rich Voivodina plain will be incorporated into the collective farm systemin the spring and summer as part of the Government's plan to accelerate implementation of its new agrarian policy.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- President Rajendra Prasad accepted today the resignation of the Maharajah of Bhavnagar as Governor of Madras, coincident with reports that the former ruler's younger brother, Prince Nirmal, had been charged with dacoity (banditry) in Saurashtra State.

Manhattan's deep and balanced squad is a solid favorite to retain its team title tonight in the thirty- first annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden. The form chart gives George Eastment's Jaspers 33 points.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 22 -- The Bergen County Bar Association announced today that it had obtained a contempt order against the New Jersey Crime Prevtion Council, Inc., on charges that in erecting a large sign opposite the County Courthouse here the council is attempting to inflame and influence grand jurors and trial jurors.

Only two books are published today. One is "Home to Tennessee: A Tale of Soldiers Returning," by Alfred Leland Crabb, a novel about the Army of Tennessee and the Battle of Nashville. The book, which Bobbs-Merrill is issuing at $3, is the author's eighth novel about the Civil War and his fifth with Nashville as the setting.
Arraigned on charges of assault and robbery before Magistrate Louis A. Pagnucco in Felony Court, four youths were held yesterday in $2,500 bail each for a hearing next Wednesday.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Feb. 22 -- Chicks chipping through their eggshells and an electronic control of industrial machinery are among the seventy exhibits at the thirty-third annual County Life-Open House Program, which opened here yesterday at the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Yale University has received a gift of $5,000,000 from the Old Dominion Foundation. Apart from aiding the liberal arts study program, the money will provide for the restoration of Connecticut Hall, a national as well as a university landmark, where Nathan Hale roomed before the Declaration of Independence.

From his Sugarbush Farm in Woodstock, Vt., Jack Ayres came to town this week with a sample of the new cheese now available by mail. The cheese is a seasoned, natural cheddar with a pronounced pungency that derives from long smoking over maple and hickory logs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Princeton remained deadlocked with Cornell for first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by defeating Yale, 65 -- 59, on the Payne Whitney court tonight. The victory was the Tigers' seventh against one loss in loop competition.
Personnel managers know they are necessities, not luxuries, in any efficient business operaiton, but the trick is to convince many in top management that this is the case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- John W. Anderson, president of the American Fair Trade Council, said today most housewives "prefer to have the manufacturers set and lawfully enforce the retail prices of their favorite trademarked products."

With the declaration that "the key to world peace is understanding," Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, urged yesterday that newpapers devote themselves more fully to the job of informing the public of the crucial issues of the day.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Ten Allied warplanes were lost behind Communist lines in the week ended yesterday, the Fifth Air Force said today. Five of the planes were shot down by Communist ground fire, and five failed to return for "unknown" reasons, the Air Force said.

It has been decided to end the long tenancy of "Affairs of State" at the Music Box on Saturday, March 8. Until yesterday, the producers, Richard W. Krakeur and Fred F. Finklehoffe, were not certain about the future of the comedy after the arrival at the Music Box of "Flight Into Egypt" on March 13.

Even if the "wonder drugs" that have actually cured animals of tuberculosis and proved to be remarkably effective in about 150 human cases do not fulfill early expectations they are not likely to be written off as lost hopes. To stop a disease in its tracks, even when it is far advanced, so that the body's defense mechanism can perform its beneficent work is too striking an achievement to be ignored.

Newsweek magazine said yesterday it had given General of the Army Douglas MacArthur an opportunity to read and comment on a story about him in advance of publication, and had "confidence that it reflected his present attitudes accurately."

H. R. 5693 would give the California canners and fishermen virtual monopoly on tuna canning by imposing a duty of three cents a pound on imported fresh and frozen tuna. This bill, already jammed through the House and now before the Senate, is an example of how a special-interest group with political power can reach into the consumer's pocketbook and the taxpayer's Treasury.

ESSEN, Germany, Feb. 22 -- To keep itself in the field in what is perhaps the most critical of all deological battlegrounds, the United States opened today its first specially built information center overseas.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 22 -- Formal negotiations between the Governments of Israel and the United States began here today for agreement on the way in which United States economic aid to Israel will be administered and controlled.

IT was standing room only at the Sportsmen's Show yesterday, both inside and outside the Grand Central Palace, for the Fire Department ordered the doors closed a few minutes before 3 o'clock, and then allowed the waiting customers to enter only at intervals during the afternoon.
An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure. But a preventive war is not an ounce but a ton of prevention. And no one has ever claimed that a ton of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

The Maritime Administration has decided to keep surplus ships on "stand-by" status, instead of returning them to the so-called "mothball" fleet, against the possibility of an "abrupt" change in tonnage needs, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A Congressional investigation of the Wage Stabilization Board for a "flagrant disregard" of the intent of Congress on the union shop was demanded today by Representative Leo E. Allen, Republican of Illinois.

BUFFALO, Feb. 22 -- A labor leader and a spokesman for management agreed here today that a sincere application of Christian ethics to the daily chores of mankind would go far toward eliminating friction and group tensions.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,168, for Friday's operations:

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Maurice Tabet, a permanent delegate to the United Nations from Beirut, Lebanon, caused quite a stir today when he won both major events in the annual George L. Lyon Memorial trapshoot at the New York Athletic Club's Tarvers Island range.

OSLO, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Winter sports stars from Germany, competing for the first time since World War II, won two gold medals in the Olympic Games today. Andreas Ostler completed a sweep of bobsled events and a sparkling duo won the pairs figure skating crown.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Members of Congress listened today to George Washington's Farewell Address. The address is read every year in both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 22 -- This was a truly sensational day in the annals of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Eden's report on the proposed contractual agreements with the German Federal Republic was received for what it is -- the final terms for the end of Allied occupation.

The report of the American Chicle Company for 1951 shows a net income after all expenses, taxes and other charges, of $4,163,637. This was equal to $3.21 a share on the gum-manufacturing concern's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $4,803,037, or $3.70, in the preceding year.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk and 17-year-old Don Bisplinghoff eliminated Sam Snead and Betty Mackinnon in the international mixed two-ball golf tournament here today.

LIBSON, Portugal, Feb. 22 -- The United States has agreed to submit its military budget to an annual review by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization along with the military budgets of the other Atlantic powers. The purpose of this joint review is to agree on priorities for defense expenditures so that first things can be done first.

Vessel construction in this country's shipyards continued its improvement last month, reaching a total of ninety-eight ships of 1,000 gross tons and over, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday. This was the second consecutive month that improvement, though slight, was noted in the council's statistics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- House investigators charged today that at least $2,000,000 worth of materials had been stolen during the building of United States air bases in North Africa and that as much as $50,000,000 had been "poured down the drain."

Students of Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths wielded mops, paint brushes and floor scrapers yesterday to prepare a new Interfaith Center on New York University's Bronx campus for opening next week.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- Boston's counterpart of the Westminster show, the thirty-ninth event of the Eastern Dog Club, began in Mechanics Building today with 1,305 dogs, a swirling crowd of holiday visitors and a number of results that were the same as in New York earlier this month.

The city will reap an immediate profit of $80,591 from the sale of 9,745 trolley car poles in Brooklyn and Queens, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. This will also save the city the estimated $250,000 that would be required to remove them.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The big handicap of the Florida racing season, the $50,000 added Widener, will be up for decision tomorrow at Hialeah. Thirteen are in it, and the short-priced favorite is William G. Helis Jr.'s Sparton Valor, who cracked the track record for nine furlongs in the McLennan Handicap two Saturdays ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The United States and Indonesia were described today as being close to an agreement for resuming shipments of Indonesian tin to this country.

The two-story office and warehouse building at 27-16 Forty-first Avenue in the Queens Plaza section of Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Eye Gate Realty Corporation from Robert D. McLellan through Queens Industrials, broker.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 22 -- On behalf of the occupying powers that now have forces in West Germany, British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the North Atlantic Council this afternoon that the new contractual relationships between the Federal Republic at Bonn and the Western Big Three Governments would "assure recognition of the validity of acts taken by the Allies by virtue of the occupation regime."

BARRE, Vt., Feb. 22 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio rolled up his political sleeves tonight and warned the Republican party that it could not afford to modify its principles to win the support of "mugwumps" in the 1952 election. Punching also at the Truman Administration's foreign policy, he asserted that it lacked a "passion for peace."

STAATSBURG, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Three persons, including a Vassar College student and a young New York attorney, were killed early today when their car skidded on an icy highway and plowed into a coal-laden trailer truck on Route 9 near this village, ten miles north of Poughkeepsie.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22 -- A youthful candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in Connecticut -- John M. Lupton of Weston -- submitted to Republican women in this state today his "receipe" to make the "mess of pottage" in Washington more palatable.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Colo., Feb. 22 -- Five hundred elementary and high school students here and in near-by Victor are trying to raise $300,000 for new school facilities by selling souvenir gold ore specimens taken from mines in this vicinity.

Week-end plans in untold homes these days are somewhat unhinged. Once, with youngsters away at college -- or, indeed, at home -- the elders could obey an impulse, accept the sudden telephoned invitation out of town, or just start out on their own.

An automoble driven by a member of the New York National Guard crashed into a group of three Brooklyn College students at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, killing one of them and critically injuring another. The third student escaped with minor injuries.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 22 -- Efforts of dissident Caodaist forces to win further defections among Caodaist troops still loyal to the Bao Dai Government in Vietnam have resulted in clashes in a Caodaist-held area northwest of Saigon.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 22 -- Today's North Atlantic Council vote approving unanimously the European Defense Force project means that the way is cleared for the creation by July 1, 1954, of the first German army and air force since the war -- an army of eight infantry and four armored divisions, backed by a tactical air force of 1,746 jet fighters.
WASHINGTON CROSSING, Pa., Feb. 22 -- The painting "Washington Crossing the Delaware," was placed on public view today close to the historic site it depicts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -Representative Monroe M. Redden, Democrat of North Carolina, said today that he and his brother each had received $25,000 "i. o. u.'s" for arranging the sale of a North Carolina company that obtained a $460,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and later went into receivership.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Feb. 18 -- Versatile furnishings for cramped households and equally cramped budgets dominated the first Dutch Furniture Fair, held on the grounds of the Netherlands Industries Fair here, with 175 exhibitors showing their wares over an area of more than 60,000 square feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee that is investigating the Department of Justice called on Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today to give it within thirty days case-by-case records on an estimated thousands of complaints sent to the department by other Government agencies during the last six years.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 22 -- The fourteen North Atlantic Treaty powers agreed today that "a militarily effective European Defense Force including a German contribution" should be established "at the earliest possible date."

A new civilian record for one-day group blood donations was set yesterday when 564 sisters of Roman Catholic orders in the New York Archdiocese contributed a pint of blood each at St. Vincent's Hospital. The previous record had been held by the Mergenthaler Linotype Company of Brooklyn, with 479 pints.

Robert Villemain of Paris, France, outpointed Danny Nardico, Tampa, Fla. light heavyweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The battle was savagely fought and entertained a crowd of 6,492 fans.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- Sigurd Sorenson, recently of Norway but now of Brooklyn, won the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds annual Washington's Birthday ski jumping competition today. The 25-year-old Norwegian triumphed on form over a field that included many of the top jumpers of the Eastern United States and Canada and several Western entries.

OSLO, Feb. 22 (UP) -- The United States ice hockey team won another Olympic game and a fistfight tonight as it maintained its slim hopes by defeating Poland, 5 -- 2. Favored Canada scored a 3-2 victory over Sweden in a battle of unbeaten teams and took a long stride toward the title.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The National Hospital Foundation, Inc., opened a drive today for funds to construct hospitals in 116 cities where the Negro population is at least 10,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 22 -- "Little Mac," a five-foot woman who is one of the oldest law-enforcement workers in the country, will celebrate her eightieth birthday tomorrow, but she said today she had no intention of retiring. A deputy sheriff of Westchester County since 1913, she formerly was assigned to the county jail but now is on the staff in Supreme Court.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Feb. 22 (UP) -- Thousands of marines, spearheaded by helicopter-borne shock troops, hit the beaches swiftly today in a joint Navy-Marine amphibious exercise.

Unfettered by scientific caution, a large number of adult male and female tuberculosis patients at Sea View Hospital on Staten Island joyfully hailed as "a miracle" last night the new drug combination that, it was disclosed three days ago, is being administered to patients in the $5,000,000 city institution housing 1,500 patients.

OTTAWA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The gross value of Canada's 1951 principal field crops was estimated by the Bureau of Statistics yesterday at a record $1,977,105,000 -- an increase of more than $100,000,000 over the preliminary estimate of $1,856,000,000.

PRESSMEN'S HOME, Tenn., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The electors of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union, A. F. L., will meet here March 3 to canvass returns in the union election, William McHugh, secretary, said today.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 22 -- Aided by excellent conditions, the men's ski teams began competition today in the twenty-first annual Middlebury Winter Carnival.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that when a veteran sells a home on which there is a 4 per cent G. I. mortgage and lets the purchaser assume the loan, the veteran remains personally responsible for its payment.

Down through the years there has been plenty of talk about overemphasis of football in American colleges but very little concerted action. The athletic scandals that have been exploding in the academic world during the past few months have, however, finally forced the problem beyond the hand-wringing stage.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Ohio Bell Telephone Company released yesterday an annual report that was studded with records everywhere except in net profit.

The third and, the police now say, last member of Willie (The Actor) Sutton's gang accused in the robbery of $64,000 from the Manufacturers Trust Company in Sunnyside, Queens, on March 9, 1950, was reported yesterday to have made a confession, but the authorities would not say what he said.
LISBON, Portugual, Feb. 22 -- Greek Foreign Minister Sophocles Venizelos implied today that Yugoslavia could count on Western support in the event of Soviet aggression.

That plain pipe rack is gradually being extended all over the country. Over the next four weeks Robert Hall Clothes, an organization which since 1940 has parlayed a stripped-down merchandising operation into 130 stores, will add eighteen more of its super market salesrooms.

Tex McCrary denied yesterday that he had called Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican Presidential aspirant, a "liar" during a heated debate Thursday night on the "Author Meets the Critics" television show over Station WABD of the Dumont network.

With the State Assembly expected to pass enabling legislation next week, the city will soon acquire the Brooklyn Academy of Music, an opera house that has played an important part in the musical, literary, political and cultural life of the city for forty-four years.

KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa., Feb. 22 -- A stern warning backed by a deer rifle brought Edward R. Mack a temporary victory today in his fight to save his service station restaurant from a road -widening project. Stare officials planned to confer tomorrow to determine what action, if any, would be taken against Mr. Mack, who contends no offers have been made to him for his property.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 23 -- The Communists negotiating at Panmunjom for an armistice in the Korean war pounced today upon the Allied announcement of bloody rioting among civilians interned by the United Nations in a stockade on Koje Island off the southern Korean coast, as the basis for a charge of "massacre and brutal inhumanity" against the prisoners.

OSLO, Feb. 22 -- West Germany won both of the Olympic events that were decided today, the four-man bobsled and pairs figure skating. At Bislett Stadium this evening the West German anthem hence was played twice, and 20,000 Norwegians in the stands cheered the German winners sportingly as they mounted the platform to receive their gold medals.

DENVER, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Bonanza Oil Company and its president, Dr. Victor Ziegler, were named in a $3,000,000 damage and accounting suit filed in district court here yesterday. The plaintiff is Leggio Connor, Denver promoter.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22 -- The winners of the third annual Freedoms Foundation Awards, consisting of 596 honor medals and $100,000 in cash and prizes, were announced today and Washington's Birthday ceremony.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Friends and foes of a bill to increase unemployment benefits through payments from the Federal Treasury exchanged bitter words today.

JAKARTA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Subardjo resigned yesterday after a majority of Indonesia's political parties had attacked his tentative acceptance on Jan. 5 of United States aid. The Cabinet also disapproved of the way he had handled the matter.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Expressions of hostility toward the economic policies of the United States were voiced in the House of Commons today during a debate on how to strengthen the sterling area and develop the resources of the Commonwealth.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The Board of Trustees of Rollins College tomorrow will consider a request of the institution's acting president, Hugh F. McKean, and two other top administrators to be relieved from their official duties at an early date.

No one knows just how many handicapped children there are in the City of New York, Dr. Helen M. Wallace said yesterday, but two things seem sure: Many such youngsters do not yet benefit from the help available to them, and many others need services that, as yet, the city does not provide.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- There was a superficial improvement among industrial shares in the stock markets here today but no real change in conditions, which basically remained dull.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Today's agreement at Lisbon on formation of a European defense army clears the way for General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to come home prior to the Republican convention in July, according to some Eisenhower-for-President strategists.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 22 -- With the increase of Allied troops in Germany there has been an increase in number of brawls and incidents between soldiers and Germany civilians. This has provoked a tide of indignation, often unjustified, against United States men in uniform, particularly.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Gen. S. M. Shtemanko, Soviet Army Chief of Staff, said today that the Soviet Union rejected the concept of an "atomic blitzkrieg."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A two-day conference of members of Congress, Iron Curtain refugees, educators, diplomats and former Communists began here today in an effort to establish newer psychological warfare techniques to be used against the Soviet Union and its satellites in the "cold war."
