BESSEMER, Ala., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Two groups of mine workers fought a gun battle in a Bessemer suburb today, wounding at least one man and peppering a house with bullets.

HOUSTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -- Young Jackie Burke Jr. played muddy Memorial Park's long, par-72 layout as if it were a sun-baked pitch and putt course today to fire a five-under-par 34, 33 -- 67 and take a two-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 -- Cornell's basketball team shook loose from Harvard in the second half to post a 71 -- 50 Eastern League victory at the indoor athletic building tonight.

The Board of Estimate has taken informally the first important step toward clearing the way for constructing the proposed third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, to be built under the Hudson River by the Port of New York Authority. The issue that had blocked action was how to connect the tube with the city street system.

The sixty-fifth annual World Day of Prayer, to be conducted by women in 105 countries from sunrise to sunset next Friday, will be marked with prayers and offerings by "millions who seek comfort through faith in Christ."

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- The Board of Governors of the American Bar Association recommended today that the House of Delegates, the 200-member policy-making body, take these steps at its meeting here Monday and Tuesday:
Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen finally met his master on indoor courts yesterday.

Twenty-three employes of the New York Central Railroad, waiters and cooks on trains, were accused yesterday of defrauding the Government of $15,000 in unemployment insurance benefits while regularly employed.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -- Police were completing arrangements today for the carnival that is expected to be the rowdiest in many years.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Pierre Merillon, long-time French diplomat and adviser to the French Chamber of Commerce, has added the insignia of a new title to his awards collection at Rancho El Retiro, his retirement home.

A tract of two and one-third acres on Bloomfield Avenue, off Route S-3, in Clifton, N. J., has been purchased by A. Horowitz Son, bookbinders, from John Hudak through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The new owners plan to improve the parcel with a one-story building containing 16,000 square feet of space for their own occupancy.

The case of the motorist who is charging New York State with negligence for failing to keep a suspended driver off the road has revealed the depressing fact that at least 5,000 motorists a month are driving around the metropolitan area with suspended licenses. It spotlights the weakness which seems to creep into the administration of safety laws.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Legislature was urged today by the county highway superintendents of the state to pass a pending bill that would reduce from 22,400 to 18,000 pounds the maximum axle weight of trucks using state roads.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Back once again amid the tranquility of old St. Pete, long the base of their training operations with the exception of last year's venture in Phoenix, the Yankees today launched their 1952 training campaign. A fourth straight pennant and world championship are the goals.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Billy Loes, the 22-year-old right- hander from Long Island City, stepped into the limelight today for the first time since Branch Rickey gave him $23,000 to sign as a Dodger bonus player three years ago.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The first direct talks on German reparations to Israel between representatives of the West German and Israeli Governments are tentatively scheduled to begin March 17, according to the current issue of the Jewish Chronicle, leading Jewish weekly in Britain. The Germans will conduct parallel negotiations with non-Israeli Jews.

LIKE an aging tragedienne thrust into the role of a bobby-soxer, the old and leisurely city of Bonn is making a brave effort to act as the capital of a nation of 50,000,000 Germans. The performance does not quite come off; there is a feeling of unreality and impermanence in the air.

DENVER -- With three months of fine sport still ahead of them, Colorado skiers are already beginning to discuss the past three months in the hushed and reverent tones which are reserved for the perfect things of life.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens walloped the Chicago Black Hawks, 7 to 0, tonight as Dick Moore scored three goals and Elmer Lach established a National Hockey League points record of 550.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- The current international situation demands that the Soviet defense forces "daily augment their war preparedness," in the opinion of the leaders of the nation's military apparatus.

The increased tempo at retail was reflected in orders in the wholesale market here last week, resident buying offices reported. Exceptional values available in many lines helped stimulate activity. Wholesale production, however, continued well ahead of the ability of stores to consume, with prices generally soft.

HERE is a colorful pageant of the nation's most famous bands, from the early days of our history down to modern times. The headings of military, concert, municipal, industrial, circus, the Salvation Army, college, and high school bands indicate the broad scope of this account of a musical form which has always enjoyed widespread popularity.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 23 -- Indonesia's domestic and international problems are exemplified in the controversy over acceptance of American aid under the new Mutual Security Agency -- the issue that brought about the resignation of Premier Sukiman's Cabinet today.

DAVID'S problem was one that most children -- and a good many grown-ups -- wish they had: how to spend a hundred dollars. This wealth had come to the 9-year-old boy as a gift from the railroad after he had prevented an accident.

THE summer of 1952 will mark the tenth anniversary session of the Berkshire Music Center. No one will find it strange, I suppose, if those of us who have been with the school from the start feel that this is a moment for rejoicing.

INDIAN film money, which is plentiful, and Hollywood know-how, which is scarce in the industry here, are now being combined for the first time in an attempt to open global markets to Indian studios, which are second in output in the world but have had an audience limited to this country and a few Indian colonies abroad.

A DECADE ago the term "early music" was apt to strike most people as meaning anything earlier than Bach. But in the last few years musicologists, an increasing number of performers and the gramophone industry particularly have been pushing the threshold back.

Fred Wilt, back at the distance that suits him best, last night received sweet balm for all the wounds he has suffered in the mile. In a stirring post-graduate sidelight to the undergraduate heroics of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, the gallant F. B. I. man ran two miles in 8 minutes 50.7 seconds.

TELEVISION producers and program sponsors are performing a serious disservice both to the medium as a whole and to their audiences in ruthlessly distorting accepted works of literature merely to accommodate their own opportunistic and trite notions of dramatic art.

ONE of the most ambitious projects yet attempted by television will be a series of six drama-documentary type programs on "Man" being prepared by the National Broadcasting Company in cooperation with the American Museum of Natural History.

THROUGH the ages the fox has fascinated story-tellers, challenged hunters and enraged farmers. It is easy to understand why when one reads David Stephen's tale of a great, gray fox of the Scottish hills who personifies all the wiliness and the courage of his kind.

The police reported yesterday that clothing, jewelry and luggage, believed to have been stolen from travelers in Pennsylvania Station and valued at $5,000, had been found in the room of a former convict, Jerry Paul Quinn, 51 years old, at 309 West Forty-eighth Street.

ALTHOUGH Christmas was scarcely over, 10-year-old Jennifer could hardly wait for spring. Still, as it turned out, the winter was filled with country fun -- there were skating and sleighriding, a Valentine box at school. Then when Jennifer wrote a prize essay and won an obstreperous heifer life became even more interesting. And Easter, when it finally came, seemed to be the fulfillment of her dreams.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Government will step in quickly if the threatened wage contract strike of oil workers throughout the nation takes place on schedule March 3, it was revealed today.

THE list of books by foreign diplomats and others who have visited Moscow and written about it is so long that one naturally approaches a new entry with jaundiced eye. Happily, such suspicion is unjustified in the present case.

Two women acquaintances of Thomas Kling, ex-convict henchman of Willie (the Actor) Sutton, bank robber, were questioned for several hours yesterday at the Long Island City, Queens, police station as the investigation into the activtes of the Sutton gang contnued.

Former Federal Judge J. Waties Waring has severed his life-long ties with Charleston, S. C., where his outspoken championship of Negro rights while he was on and off the bench brought him and his wife complete social ostracism, and has come to this city to live.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Joe Black, big Negro right-handed pitcher, displayed his skill for Manager Chuck Dressen today for the first time, with results that were a bit startling.

TODAY'S piece really began when I flung a copy of the current issue of The Hopkins Review across the room. In some respects, though not in all, by any means, I think I can be described as a patient man; if pressed, I could buttress that assumption with a few facts, but this is hardly the place or the occasion.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- The 1952 wage pattern for millions of American workers will be fashioned in the next sixty days. A half-dozen major unions, with steel, coal and oil in the vanguard, expect to write new contracts in March and April.

The Republican National Convention is still nineteen weeks away. The Democratic National Convention is still twenty-one weeks away. The Presidential election on Nov. 4 is more than thirty-six weeks away. Last week, despite the remoteness of the convention, the political pots were boiling as furiously as if the candidates were to be named next week.

Landlords who rent cellar clubs should be held accountable for crimes committed there, Magistrate John F. X. Masterson said Yesterday in Brooklyn Week-End Court after a raid Friday night that turned up two decks of heroin in a Brownsville basement.

NEW EGYPT, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Arthur Denhoed, 48 years old, who brought his wife and eleven children here from the Netherlands three years ago, reported today that his cousin's family of ten was on the way to the United States. The two families need lots of room, Mr. Denhoed said.

IT WAS the day after the opening of "The Shrike." The notices were wonderful -- simply wonderful. The phone began ringing early in the morning. "Saw THE TIMES -- Congratulations!" "Read the Trib -- You've got a hit!" "Thank you -- thank you," I said to everyone who called.

THIS is the third volume in Miss Tensen's excellent series of picture books for beginners to read on their own. The new book takes the reader who began with "Come to the Zoo" and progressed to "Come to the Farm" still another step forward along the road to easy reading.

These charges of godlessness and the teaching of socialism at Yale rather amuse some of us elderly Yalensians. When we were undergraduates in the Eighteen Nineties our parents were electrified by Mrs. Poteat's widely publicized exclamation that she would rather send her son to hell than to Yale College.

HAVING been typed in the acting profession as a temptress above all else, Ilona Massey still relishes the playing of such roles. "A woman is a woman," she says. "Playing the part of a siren just comes naturally. It's no strain at all."

THE review of my novel, "The Abbot Sisters," contained the following sentence: "One suspects that this is an early manuscript, published on the strength of Miss Roberts' successful pieces in The New Yorker."

THE Revere Camera Company of Chicago last week made public the formulas, previously a closely guarded trade secret, for processing the Belgian-made Diaversal enlarging paper, of which Revere is the sole American distributor.

The Third Street Music School Settlement will be the beneficiary of a musicale to be held on Tuesday evening in the home of Dr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lieb, 1 West Seventy-second Street. Miss Katherine Philbrick, the pianist and a member of the school's board of directors, will play.

Mme. Monique de la Bruchollerie, who had a brilliant success when she appeared as soloist in the Rachmaninoff Third Concerto with the Boston Symphony Orchestra last Wednesday, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

* * * From my own experience, having sons, aged 18 and 19, I agree with Justice Douglas in his analysis of the attitude of youth today. ("The Black Silence of Fear," Jan. 13). This is a misfortune, but a natural result of the circumstances in which youth finds itself.

Uncertainty regarding business and the labor outlook were reflected last week in the worst sinking spell in the securities market this year. The decline also was influenced by the recent unsettlement in commodity prices both here and abroad, the approach of a decision in the steel strike threat and by the Korean truce negotiations.

In spite of the entirely proper words of caution, there has been a flood of optimistic enthusiasm about the reports on the effectiveness of new specifics for tuberculosis. It is well to be on guard, of course, but it is impossible to ignore the large vistas that are opened up by this development. Here at hand is the strong possibility of having a good new weapon in a good fight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 23 -- The proposed $30,000,000 trunk sewer, designed to end pollution of the Raritan River, received unqualified support of organized labor this week when union leaders in all sections of the Raritan Valley forwarded to the Middlesex County Sewerage Authority resolutions favoring the project.

Young women headed by Mrs. Frederic Flach and Miss Frederica Kane are serving on the junior committee assisting Mrs. Kimball G. Colby and members of the executive committee in furthering the success of the luncheon and card party to be given on Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Catholic Big Sisters.

BONN, Feb. 23 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the last few days has been acting like a man who went into a poker hand with a pair of fours and wound up with the pot, but there really does not seem to be much reason for the smug confidence with which the Federal Government views future progress toward a settlement of the European army question and the achievement of German political independence.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 23 -- The North Atlantic alliance agreed today to try to raise a defensive army of about fifty divisions in Western Europe by the end of this year and to extend the authority of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower above all in the realm of logistics and the communications zones supporting his forces.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 23 -- A "cutting wind" produced by a knife blade moving faster than sound is being used to cut thin slices of many materials -- from asbestos to zinc -- in the General Electric Company's research laboratory here. The supersonic wind was developed by E. F. Fullam, one of the company's scientists, it was announced today.
Clendenin Ryan, former secretary to the late Mayor F. H. LaGuardia, has sold the private home at 31 East Sixty-ninth Street to the Austrian Government.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Siena Indians, still hopeful of a bid to the National invitation tourney, defeated St. Francis of Brooklyn tonight, 52 -- 43.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- A notable step toward insuring sufficient electric power for Italian industry, even in drought years, was taken today with the opening of a 120,000-kilowatt thermoelectric generating station in Genoa.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 24. (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,169, for Saturday's operations:

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- If the United States were to ratify the United Nations convention on news gathering, the conviction of William Oatis, American foreign correspondent, by Communist Czechoslovakia would be legalized and the State Department would not even have the right of protest, a committee of the American Bar Association declared today.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., state chairman of the Liberal party and a former Assistant Secretary of State, called yesterday for the pledge of American aid to "tewart Soviet intentions" in Iran, Suez, Egypt and North Africa.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -- Duquesne, the nation's last major unbeaten basketball team, had its 18-game winning streak snapped tonight, 64 -- 62, by Villanova in an overtime period. The Dukes failed to extend a stirring rally that carried them to a 60-60 tie in regulation time. Villanova's Ben Stewart scored the decisive goal on a driving lay-up with 3:32 remaining in the five-minute overtime.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Miss Mary Lena Faulk and 17-year-old Don Bisplinghoff, a team of sharpshooting youngsters who previously scored two major upsets, lost in the semi-finals of the international mixed two-ball open golf tournament today.

HAVANA -- Carnival began yesterday, and for five weeks its infectious spirit will be abroad in Cuba. In addition to stepping up generally the gay pace of this capital, Carnival time means a series of parades, exotic Afro-Cuban dances called comparsas, public concerts, dances and other special events.

A new science course designed to give laymen a better understanding of what science is about, with emphasis on scientific development as a living process rather than on the dogmatic conclusions of research, will be inaugurated at Dartmouth College in February, 1953.

The volume of scholarly research on the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in United States universities and colleges is now at an all-time high, according to a State Department survey and compilation of these studies.

" RED HARVEST," one of Dashiell Hammett's earlier novels and a work which helped establish his reputation in the tough, murder-mystery school, may turn up on Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's production schedule, if Richard Brooks can sell the idea to company executives.

IN 1930 Dr. A. J. Cronin's first novel, "Hatter's Castle," was published and, he tells us -- not at all vaingloriously but merely as stating fact -- that it "was acclaimed by critics, chosen by the Book Society, translated into twenty-one languages, serialized, dramatized and filmed.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge John Grimshaw Jr. granted a temporary restraining order yesterday to prevent the International Long-shoremens Association from allegedly interfering with oil transportation in the New York Harbor area.

SHRUB roses can do anything other shrubs can do. They can be used as background or for screening, as pillars, hedges and specimens, as a collection of bedding roses or to perk up an out-of-bloom shrub border. As a result many types suggest themselves for landscaping.

WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 23 -- Brandeis University today announced that work will begin immediately on the construction of the Adolph Ullman Amphitheatre on the campus. The amphitheatre will contain full facilities for spring and summer musical, dramatic and other cultural activities, and will be the first unit in the projected Creative Arts Center at the university.

NEITHER a very moving nor engrossing novel, "The Lighted Cities," at moments, is a reasonable facsimile of both. The characters are sensitively felt and the writing is facile and perceptive, but it lacks vitality.

JOSEF PIEPER, a German Catholic philosopher, is unknown to the American layman, and the career of his small but profound book in this country will teach us something about our capacity to receive criticism from a point of view to which most of us are hostile.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Kentucky's Hill Gail knocked the wind out of Windy City II today, whipping the Irish colt by four lengths for a smashing victory in the rich Santa Anita Derby.

NEXT time you're in Southern California and looking for movie stars -- which, despite the atomic age, the cold war, and the hot war, still lurks as the No. 1 thrill for half the tourists in America -- don't bother to hang around the Beverly Hills Hotel, drive past Romanoff's, and ignore the Brown Derby.

IT matters little whether you go vagabonding at sea, as w. I. B. Crealock did, or sail as a foc'sle hand, which was holger Thesleff's role, the problems you face are always the same. You fight wind, wave, weather get the feel of your ship, and learn how to make the best of her faults arid virtues.

NO one can say that Mozart is a neglected composer, especially in the record catalogues. Every phase of his vast output has been examined for recording, but as far as this reviewer knows, his Six Quartets Dedicated to Haydn have not been assembled before into a single album.

Nearly three years ago -- on April 1949 -- in a ceremony in the Departmental Auditorium in Washington, the foreign ministers of twelve powers signed in turn a fifteen-page document bound in blue goatskin and decorated with a red, white and blue ribbon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A resolution asking the United Nations to declare the Soviet Union an aggressor nation because of the Korean war and asking also that the Soviet and its satellites be expelled from the United Nations in the event of further aggression was adopted by the Conference on Psychological Warfare, which ended its two-day session here today.

I am somewhat of an expert in totalitarian methods of meting out "justice," having spent considerable time in Hungarian Fascist and Nazi jails, German Nazi prisons and camps, and some time in a Russian dungeon, only because I had worked for Reuters and The Associated Press.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 23 (UP) -- A 37-year-old jailer, charged with beating and torturing prisoners, was convicted today but got off with a $100 fine and a compliment from the judge, who said he ran "the best jail in the state."

THE team of Dee Brown and Martin Schmitt has done it again. "Trail Driving Days" is as notable a contribution to Western Americana as the magnificent "Fighting Indians of the West," which they gave us in 1948.

IN this cheerful little book John K. Galbraith, Professor of Economics at Harvard, has proved, among other things, that American economics can be written with style. We need no longer bewail the absence of an American D. H. Robertson.

The giant of them all, the $12,700,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, is about to set another record. Its 1,100,000 stockholders are being asked to approve at their annual meeting on April 16 the largest financing program ever undertaken by an American enterprise. The amount: $550,000,000. The reason: overwhelming demand for telephone service.

American college students are learning more about America. So reports Dr. Robert Whitney Bolwell, chairman of the George Washington University's Graduate Council, who in 1936 originated the American Thought and Civilization major now being offered by a number of leading universities throughout the country.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The United Jewish Appeal opened its nation-wide campaign for $151,500,000 today with the announcement that in the last six weeks eighteen cities alone had adopted goals amounting to more than $67,000,000.

WITH this book Barry Ulanov becomes the lengthiest apologist of the recent jazz dialects known as "be-bop" and "cool" music. The most prominent figures in be-bop are the saxophonist Charles "Yardbird" Parker and the trumpeter "Dizzy" Gillespie, while the outstanding cool musician is perhaps the pianist Lennie Tristano.

HOUSTON is unveiled here as a young giant with one foot in the Gulf, the other advanced toward the Yankees of Dallas with arms sweeping the oil-rich land from New Orleans to Mexico. The wealthiest citizens of this "most air-conditioned" city seem to be classified locally as ranging, say, from millionaire minnows to financial Tritons, and these are the protagonists of the book, the author's chief concern.
Rabbi Samuel M. Segal of Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning called for an adventure in "acting brotherhood."

Prices of cotton turned generally firmer last week following sharp net declines in the three preceding weeks. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net gains of 23 to 75 points, contrasted with net losses of 69 to 116 points during the preceding week.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H. -- Heavy snows last week not only brought New England winter resorts the finest skiing in years for the Washington's Birthday week-end but also held the promise of a prolonged season lasting well into the spring.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- There was a complete turnabout today in the second session of the triple over-the-holiday regattas at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

DURING the course of the Sportsmens Show, which closes its nine-day run at the Grand Central Palace tonight, we talked with several of the tackle manufacturers, and apparently only reels will be in danger of short supply in the near future, for the plastic materials now employed in many rods seem to have solved this problem.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Feb. 23 -- Mrs. Georgianna Hawkins was looking forward today to her next natal milestone on Thursday when she will be 104 years old.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 23 -- Isao Kawada, Japanese envoy, conferred "informally" today with George Yeh, Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, and took exception to the Nationalist draft of a Chinese-Japanese "treaty of peace."

DES MOINES, Feb. 23 -- The American Friend Ship campaign to gather money, equipment and livestock for a farm to be operated near Tokyo by the Japanese International Christian University was started here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A group of California Democrats announced tonight plans to enter a full slate of seventy delegates pledged to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in the state Democratic Presidential primary to be held June 3.

CAIRO, Feb. 23 -- The pashas instead of the people seem to have got hold of the sweep of parkland in the heart of Cairo -- equivalent to Central Park in New York -- that was nationalized last autumn as a patriotic and anti-British measure.

MUNSAN, Korea, Sunday, Feb. 24 -- Communist truce negotiators told the Allies at a fruitless two-hour session today they would hold out forever if necessary against the United Nations proposal for voluntary repatriation of prisoners of war.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, New York City Commissioner of Hospitals, and the two drug houses of E. R. Squibb Sons and Hoffman-LaRoche disclosed last week the remarkable results achieved in the treatment of advanced cases of tuberculosis with recently discovered drugs.

A TOTAL stranger to twentieth century art could not be blamed if, on a visit to the fifty-six paintings, drawings, sculpture and ceramics by Picasso at the Curt Valentin Gallery he refused point-blank to believe in their execution by one and the same hand.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 (UP) -- False, who had broken Light Broom's seven-race winning streak at the Fair Grounds last Saturday, proved today that the triumph was no fluke when the 4-1 shot handed Claud Tanner's colt another defeat in the $10,000 A. B. Letellier Memorial Handicap.

THE Exact 66, an enlarger, incorporating a built-in range-finder for accurately focusing the projected image on the easel, has been imported from Germany by Burleigh Brooks Company, 10 West Forty-sixth Street. Made by the Veigel factory in Stuttgart, the new enlarger is designed to take 2 1/4x2 1/4-inch negatives and smaller.

OSLO, Feb. 23 (UP) -- A four-goal burst in the second period gave the United States a 6-3 victory over Czechoslovakia tonight in the Olympic hockey tournament -- but Canada was all but assured of the championship anyway. The Canadians routed Norway, 11 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A special meeting of a House Judiciary subcommittee was called today for next Tuesday to consider Harold E. Stassen's demands for an investigation of reports that Attorney General J. Howard McGrath had become a millionaire while holding public office.

AMONG the natural and unnatural annual phenomena of the polar year, such as mosquitos and the caribou migration, one must now include the annual publication of at least one book on the Eskimo. While most of these volumes tend to partake in some degree of the gentle fatalism and tranquillity of these admirable people, the present book presents a sharp contrast.

ANY gardener can grow tuberous rooted begonias to rival the rarest orchid or camellia. The exquisite blossoms, with brisk petals and a satin-like substance, are emphasized by a background of almost equally attractive foliage. Colors range from purest white through deepest reds, which are effective in the garden or as cut flowers.

ON July 24, 1951, an old Packard convertible collided with a trailer-truck six miles from Phoenixville, Pa. A man, with rather Hardingesque looks, and a black-and-white mongrel dog were thrown from the car.

The old saw about distant shores being touched by ever-widening ripples is particularly apt for the Panama Canal, which is exposed on both sides to the transmissions of oceans. As one of the world's indispensable lifelines, it is exceedingly sensitive to a trouble stone cast anywhere.

A special demonstration of the New York Public Library's project, "Exploring the American Idea," which has been introduced into seventeen branches, will be given Tuesday at 8 P. M. at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The discussion, on the Declaration of Independence and other writings, will be led by Mrs. William Sayless, a housewife, and Gerritt Fielstra, a librarian. Dr. Horace Kallen, philosopher and author, will speak.

Once a "big" game on the local basketball scene, the Fordham-C. C. N. Y. encounter last night in the Fordham gymnasium, where the Rams rallied to down the Beavers, 55 -- 52, was played before approximately 1,000 persons. The home side, because of its superiority in height, experience and bench depth, was a strong choice, but the Lavender quintet did not fade until the final period.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- The substance and showmanship inherent in a great dog, won for the 26-month-old black and tan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, the main award tonight in the annual Eastern Dog Club event.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower does not plan to come home very soon, an official spokesman at the general's military headquarters near Paris said today.

OF all the vocal disks that recently have made their appearance, one of the most attractive contains Eleven Songs by Schubert sung for London by Heinrich Schlusnus. Schlusnus, it will be remembered, is the great German baritone who made so many wonderful pre-war Lieder records.
Sixteen surviving contract bridge teams resumed play yesterday afternoon at the Pierre Hotel for the 1952 Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four national championship.

THIS entry belongs in the category of promising novels whose reach exceeds their author's grasp, and in which the author's warmth of spirit does not quite compensate for a lack of depth and selectivity.

BRAIN, n. An apparatus with which we think that we think. That which distinguishes the man who is content to be something from the man who wishes to do something. A man of great wealth, or one who has been pitchforked into high station, has commonly such a headful of brain that his neighbors cannot keep their hats on.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Most grains crept upward throughout the session on the Board of Trade today, scoring gains running to around a cent. Corn was an exception. It sank more than a cent early, but came back to reduce its losses before the final gong.

TOKYO, Feb. 23 -- Small-scale Communist riots that took place Thursday in a half-dozen Japanese cities have been seized upon by conservative elements here as justification for a plan to return to the pre-war police system.

CAIRO, Feb. 23 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha announced today that he and his assistants would start conversations before Friday with Sir Ralph Stevenson, the British Ambassador, in an effort to solve the British-Egyptian conflict over Egyptian demands for evacuation of the Suez Canal base and for placing the Sudan under King Farouk.

While the Nato partners in Lisbon struggled last week with the problems raised by the threat of Communist aggression in Europe, half the world away many of the same Allies were enmeshed in the problems raised by the fact of Communist aggression in Asia.

Charles Dickens' own annotated copy of "The Cricket on the Hearth," from which he gave his public readings, will be among the first editions and autographed manuscripts of British authors, from the library of Walter P. Chrysler Jr. to be auctioned on Tuesday and Wednesday.

IN a clipping forwarded by a thoughtful friend we discover an article which appeared in this column twenty years ago in which we ask what the public, and what we ourselves, will think of Strauss' "Elektra" in 1952!

The modern and vastly improved version of the storage cellar on the farm, the deep freeze food unit, is making an unexpectedly successful invasion of the New York market. Units averaging twelve cubic feet capacity are selling at the rate of about 800 a month, even where apartment rental per square foot is so high that the housewife has been buying only two pounds of lamb chops at a time at the neighborhood butcher.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 23 -- Dartmouth's ski team demonstrated its all-around ability again today by winning the twenty-first Middlebury carnival.

THERE were few signs of new inflationary pressure last week so far as major indices were concerned. On the contrary, both commodity and stock prices moved lower than had been expected in relation to current demand, and profit margins in industrial fields are tending to narrow.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Feb. 23 -- By combining movies, a quiz program, skits, a panel discussion and a mock radio broadcast in the orientation of overseas-bound military personnel, officers here have established a program so popular that it is "standing room only" at Post Theatre No. 5.

Tomorrow the moon will swim between the earth and the sun, and millions will witness a total eclipse of the sun. Citizens of this country will see nothing of the most awe-inspiring of astronomical spectacles.

THE voluntary reduction of flights into and out of La Guardia Airport by the scheduled airlines will in no sense cripple the lines, aviation authorities agreed last week. But how much it will hurt them, in terms of revenue, cannot now even be estimated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The State Department was completing today a system of travel restrictions to be imposed soon on Soviet diplomats in this country.

PARIS, Feb. 23 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle tonight assailed a succession of post-war French Governments on the ground that they had submerged the national interests of France in the North Atlantic Pact and submitted to the domination of the nation's allies.

THE first class of the Nato Defense College, the school established by General Eisenhower to amalgamate the diverse elements of his command, is halfway toward graduation in May. In that wing of the eighteenth century Ecole Militaire where Napoleon learned about artillery, forty-one military men and six foreign service experts gather for their daily studies.

IN his new book, "Son of a Tinker," the popular and prolific Irish writer of romantic fiction, Maurice Walsh, has gathered nine tales, most of them with Irish and Scotch backgrounds. The title story is rooted in the small, hard, tight economy of rural Ireland.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 23 (UP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, criticized former President Herbert Hoover and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, tonight when he accused Republicans of making "staggering falsehoods." in an effort to win the election.

Dave Ellis and Mike Mahoney scored six goals apiece for the Princeton University polo team last night as the Tigers defeated Cornell, 14 -- 7, in a first-round match of the national intercollegiate championship tournament at the Squadron A Armory.

OSLO, Feb. 23 -- American Olympic officials laid plans today to end bickering and agree on a single United States city as a candidate for staging the 1956 Olympic Games in the event Melbourne backs out.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 -- Manning the defense plants is causing many headaches among employment managers. It is also causing worries in other lines which need additional help, including office boys and skilled workers. Thompson Products, Inc., manufacturer of jets and other equipment for defense, will soon be employing 14,000 in its various Cleveland plants.

Yale University last week spelled out the role that higher education must play in today's troubled world. A prominent committee of educators and laymen, headed by President-Emeritus Henry Sloane Coffin of Union Theological Seminary, commented on such matters as "disloyalty," religion and teaching of unpopular beliefs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Civil Defense Administration announced today development of a portable laboratory chest with which the states could save thousands of lives in event of an atomic bombing raid.

SOME time this spring, 100 years after his death, the body of Louis Braille will be moved to the French Pantheon. Though French newspapers have been full of centennial articles the celebrations are being held up for the great day.

Suzanne Bloch, assisted by ten fellow-enthusiasts for early music, presented her annual program late yesterday afternoon. This year, she gave it at Town Hall for the first time, for Times Hall, the scene of the first six in the series, is no longer available for public recitals.

Production of cotton textiles is leveling off at about 12 to 15 per cent under that of a year ago, it was pointed out last week by Worth Street commission men. With reduced prices and smaller unit output, it was estimated that cotton textile manufacturers this year will find their dollar volume shrinking on an average of 25 per cent.

HOUSTON, Feb. 23 -- Jack Burke Jr. continued to weave his spell of magic over sodden Memorial Park's par-72 layout today to step into a five-stroke lead at the 54-hole mark of the $10,000 Houston open golf tournament.

IN line with the trend toward low-cost European travel and the reduced tourist air fares is a new package tour offering ten days of sight-seeing in Europe for $100. Recently put out by a special department of the House of Travel, 47 East Forty-seventh Street, the package tour will be sold through more than 2,000 travel agents in the United States and Canada.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 24 -- United Nations and Communist delegates reached agreement at Panmunjom yesterday on rotation of troops during an armistice in the Korean war.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 -- As the small but select group of Yankee batterymen went through their second session of training today, several new developments involving the world champions came to light.

The mounting tempo of the flight of business as well as residents to the suburbs soon may drive many New York corporation officials into emotional upsets.

This picture is true only in part.

FRANZ POLGAR, the son of a poor, Hungarian schoolmaster, made a mark as a brilliant student. His education, however, was interrupted by the first World War. In the fighting he suffered wounds and was nearly buried alive.

SINCE the seventeenth century, when Descartes set the vogue, it is estimated that about 500 constructed languages have been proposed for international use. The best-known among them are Volapuk, Esperanto and Basic English, as well as the newly coined Interlingua. Yet a solution of the world's communications problem through a deliberately planned tongue remains not only unaccepted, but largely undiscussed.

Greater interest in profit-sharing plans as a means to provide retirement benefits for employes is expected this year as a result of the high corporation taxes now prevailing. Such planning showed a marked increase in 1951.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- As preparations proceed for a test in Australia this year of Britain's first atomic weapon, the general impression among scientists here is that the weapon is a specimen plutonium bomb.

Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, whose vivid lithographs captured some of the spirit of the era, particularly on the raffish side, lives again in a colorful biography and his work is increasingly admired.

Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, defended here last night the expansive power of the American economy, but contended that such expansion was contingent upon the attainment of a durable peace.

Mayneord, physicist of London's Royal Cancer Hospital, finds that after irradiation a few grains of thulium oxide will produce clear X-ray pictures of the teeth embedded in a skull and of the bones of the hand. Of about 5,000 merchant vessels built by the United States in World War II the Government still holds title to some 3,000. Although Thursday will be the anniversary of the granting of the road's charter by the State of Maryland, actual construction work did not begin until July 4, 1828.

IN 1945 the ketch Erma, a thirty-seven foot craft more than fifty years old, set sail from Smedslatten, Sweden, to America. On board were sixteen Estonians, seven men, five women, and four small children. They had been ordered to return to Soviet-controlled Estonia: faced with that ominous future, they decided that crossing the Atlantic in the gale-swept winter was a far less rugged alternative.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Staffs of two Congressional committees said today a proposed 25 per cent peacetime ceiling on Federal income taxes would "tend to shift the individual tax burden from the rich to the poor."

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Nick Kladis and Don Hanrahan combined for 49 points tonight to lead Loyola of Chicago to a 76-73 upset basketball victory over Seton Hall. The loss was the Easterners' second in 24 starts and snapped a 10-game winning streak.

ARABIA, the great peninsula of burning sand and stone, is also a near-desert in the geography of human knowledge. Although the long silences which hover over it have now and then been punctuated by the world-shaking events of its history, it has, on the whole, lost little or nothing of its traditional impenetrability.

WHILE we all cannot explore the seas or the streams or the ponds around us, still we can cut from nature segment and place it on top of a bookshelf, to contemplate the dart of one kind of fish, the shimmy and wiggle of another.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Nick Kladis and Don Hanrahan combined for 49 points tonight to lead Loyola of Chicago to a 76-73 upset basketball victory over Seton Hall. The loss was the Easterners' second in 24 starts and snapped a 10-game winning streak.

ALL winter long Frank Frisch had been moaning in his good-humored, tongue-in-cheek fashion: "I'm outa work. I'm among the unemployed. I gotta get me a job." Practically no one paid the slightest bit of attention to him. Ye Olde Flash looked much too robust to be starving to death. But as spring training kept getting closer and closer, Frisch kept getting more and more restless.

A SERIES of articles published in this space last fall covered conventions of bidding and play. Some standard conventions were disregarded in that series, because they are so time-honored and universal that they transcend what a bridge player calls "conventions"; they might more properly be called bridge players' habits.
HANOVER, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- Cornell took sole possession of the lead in Ivy League basketball tonight with a 57-41 victory over Dartmouth.

A HINDU journalist, a historian and military affairs expert, Nirad Chaudhuri has written his autobiography as a parallel to his times; using his own experiences as evidence, he has tried to describe the ruin and degeneracy that he finds progressively overtaking modern India.

" NO sir, I am not surprised. If I were still alive, I might claim to false modesty and pretend to be amazed, but having been the late Charles Dickens for some eighty-two summers, I am even more prone to speaking my mind now than when I was among you.

An experiment designed to ease congestion around the Chelsea piers will be started at 8 A. M. tomorrow, when Eleventh Avenue will become an exclusively southbound thoroughfare between Twenty-second and Thirteenth Streets.
The James Weldon Johnson Community Center will be the beneficiary of the matinee and evening performances of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on April 18 at Madison Square Garden.

LISBON, Feb. 23 -- The nations of the West, as Secretary Acheson told the North Atlantic Council this week, have "come a long way" since 1949. They have demonstrated what he terms "the creative capacity of democracy," shown a will to safeguard their freedom and bespoken a political maturity which allows them to gain strength without sacrificing freedom.

IN mid-July, 1861, Lincoln watched the regiments of many nationalities march smartly through Washington and cross the long bridge into Virginia to fight the native American upholders of slavery in the first great battle of the Civil War. Scotch Highlanders from New York stepped along in kilts with bagpipes skirling.

WITH the of production of "Venus Observed" by the Theatre Guild, Christopher Fry sets us all a problem. He has written a gaily bedizened verse play that few people understand. Since Mr. Fry is a magician with words, which he uses with taste and facility, people who revere the English language naturally have a hospitable interest in everything he does.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Former Prime Minister Clement Attlee asserted tonight that Prime Minister Churchill, in addressing Congress last month, seemed to be encouraging those "dangerous elements" in the United States "that advocate spreading the war with Communist China."

The splitting of two tankers in stormy New England seas last week emphasized the need for continued study of the relation of modern maritime welding to sea disasters, in the opinion of shipping leaders and ship construction experts. It is a problem that affects the entire merchant marine, as ship welding now far surpasses the old-fashioned riveting as a means of putting sea-going vessels together.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems charged today that New York's traffic laws were illogical, ambiguous and an "outdated jungle of confusion," and recommended an extensive revision to conform with the codes in other states.

At Lancaster House, London, representatives of thirty-one nations will gather this week for discussions on one of the most complex problems ever to be submitted to international scrutiny -- the repayment of more than $5,000,000,000 which Germany owes in non-German money to the outside world.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 23 -- The Army quintet, playing its last tune-up game before its important game with Navy here next Saturday, found Harvard an obstinate foe today. In their fifteenth meeting since 1904, the cadets defeated the Crimson, 65 -- 59, but had to stage a last-quarter rally to turn the trick.

Harold E. Stassen, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said last night that revelations concerning transactions by the New York law firm in which Newbold Morris is a partner "should disqualify" Mr. Morris for the job of investigating corruption in the Federal Government.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The board of trustees of Rollins College here met in all-day session today to consider a request by the institution's three top administrative officers to resign their duties, but adjourned until tomorrow night without taking any action.

NEW YORK'S experiment with a seven o'clock curtain for theatres is old to Shaftesbury Avenue. Of the forty-eight productions now playing in and around the West End of London, only six open later than 7:30 in the evening; two of those are twice nightly variety shows playing at 6:15 and 8:45.

" UNAMBO!" says the devil, characterized as a wheezy, sweet - smelling, but rather intrusive fat man in this novel by the biographer and friend of Franz Kafka. "Unambo! Uno -- one; ambo -- both!" And then he goes on to explain that his infernally patented little Unambo machine is able to give its possessor and operator the privilege of not choosing between courses of action.
KENTLAND, Ind., Feb. 23 -- Twelve Midwestern college soil experts met in this northern Indiana town to learn about krilium, the new soil conditioner produced by the Monsanto Chemical Company.
Three disease scourges of tropical countries, which disfigure, cripple and even mutilate millions of victims may be virtually wiped out by penicillin, Science Service. asserts.

MIAMI, Feb. 23 -- With Seminole Indians in the infield, 28,383 customers in the park and the mutuel department in a happy tizzy because of record-cracking business at the ticket windows, Hialeah today was the scene of the fifteenth running of the $50,000 added Widener, the No. 1 handicap of the Florida racing season.

KOJE ISLAND, Korea, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The commander of the United States troops who quelled Monday's Communist riot at this prison camp declared today that his men had fired only as a last resort at the attacking mob that screamed "Kill the Americans!"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The State Department has about decided to reject a proposal that the United States import thousands of South Koreans to meet a farm labor shortage in California, it was revealed today.

SEED catalogues need not be the gardener's only reading matter at this time of year. There is a vast amount of helpful garden literature available from state and Federal sources. Much of it contains the accumulated knowledge of decades, as compiled by agricultural experts, and is literally to be had for the asking.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 -- In their fight against communism, the Allies have lost the support of many decent Germans because of the West's support of some rightist groups, including Nazi line intellectuals, Rabbi Peter Levinson of the United States said today.

IN the first-page article, "The Struggle to Make the Past Alive," Mr. Allan Nevins makes a statement which must make the metallurgical statistician grieve. He says, "* * * but a historian rises to point out that all the gold and silver produced throughout the world since 1492 have been worth only about 16 billions of dollars."
Industrial orders and production are continuing to turn downward.

OSLO, Feb. 23 -- Little Finland's durable distance skiers won everything in sight in the sixth Winter Olympic Games program today, but Norway virtually clinched the team championship with only two more events remaining tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 23 -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, this afternoon urged Republican adherents of Senator Robert A. Taft and General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower to conduct their campaigns for the Presidential favorite with good taste and without deprecation of either man.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The House Unamerican Activities Committee, which was in the news this week with its report on Communist infiltration, has undergone substantial changes both in tactics and in personnel since the days of Martin Dies and J. Parnell Thomas.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 23 -- An appearance of boom prosperity prevails in Saigon and most of the other areas of Indo-China controlled by the French Union governments of the three Indo-China states.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 -- All sections of Mexican political opinion, from the far left to the far right, joined today in applauding the Government's decision to reject United States terms for a military aid agreement between the two countries.

" GARDENING for Everyone" will be the theme of the thirty-sixth International Flower Show. From Sunday, March 16, to Saturday, March 22, the results of another year's planning and planting by the experts of the horticultural world will give visitors to Grand Central Palace a preview of spring.

ARRANGED as a benefit for a special purchase fund of the Whitney Museum, a novel exhibition has opened at the Wildenstein Galleries. The art critics on seven publications were asked to select their favorite American paintings since 1900, ten to be chosen by the writers on each publication.

HAVING presented three new ballets by its two artistic directors, George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins, the New York City Ballet this week presents two others by guest choreographers, Antony Tudor and Frederick Ashton.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23 -- Communist propagandists are making frenzied efforts to discredit the United States and the Brazilian Government as the first steps in economic and military cooperation for mutual defense of the two countries near completion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Truman has a new hideaway -- a solarium with walls of blue-green glass perched atop the White House with a penthouse view of the Potomac River.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 23 -- Pakistan Army units have been called out to support police in quelling the continuing violence in Dacca, capital of East Pakistan.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- The International and Comparative Law Committee of the American Bar Association completed work tonight on its resolution to be presented tomorrow before the association's House of Delegates and disclosed it had made an about-face o nthe controversial United Nations news gathering convention.

GENEVA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe predicted today that the achievement of Western Europe's industrial development plans -- including increased arms production -- would be hindered by an ever-growing shortage of coal.

Costs of construction in the metropolitan area of New York and New Jersey during the past year have become stabilized for the first time since 1938 through 1940, according to the results of a survey made by Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.
Franco Autori, associate conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony, led his first Carnegie Hall concert of the season with that organization on Saturday night.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law will recommend tomorrow that state-wide bans on some Sunday sports and recreations be abolished and that localities receive the power to decide what activities they wish to restrict.

The Western Union Telegraph Company asserted yesterday that it could not stay in business as a private enterprise if it granted union demands for higher wages and other concessions. The company estimated the total cost of the demands at $50,000,000 a year and said they would necessitate a rise of 30 per cent in telegraph rates.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A startled Dayton team pulled its sixteenth straight basketball victory out of the fire in the closing seconds tonight as the Flyers subdued green but gallant Xavier of Cincinnati, 82 -- 80.

News is beginning to come out of Peiping that Communist China won't be able to ship that million tons of rice to hungry India after all. The Food Ministry in New Delhi says that the Communists "seem to be stockpiling their rice and we are not expecting to get any."
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 24 -- A new device "about the size and shape of a kernel of corn" may soon make possible a whole series of electrical wonders.

Springfield has the "Indian" sign on the New York Rovers. Yesterday afternoon, the Springfield Indians defeated the Red Shirts, 6-4, in the Eastern Hockey League feature at Madison Square Garden before 4,023.

The first two volumes of the three-volume pictorial record sub-series of the narrative history "U. S. Army in World War II" have been scheduled for March 18 publication by the Department of the Army. The volumes are "The War Against Germany and Italy: Mediterranean and Adjacent Areas," which will have 495 photographs; and "The War Against Germany: Europe and Adjacent Areas," with 567 photographs.
Mrs. Hugh A. Drum presented two altar vessels, a chalice and ciborium, to the Roman Catholic Chapel at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday in memory of her husband, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum.

CEDAR KEY, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Search boats groping through fog and rain today rescued a small middle-aged woman who had spent thirty-six terrifying hours drifting alone on a houseboat that strayed into the stormy Gulf of Mexico.

Mounting Olympic-year frenzy is establishing this as an indoor track season to be remembered. The heroics of Fred Wilt and Reggie Pearman, in special races, and of Manhattan's well-stocked squad in varsity competition at the Inter-collegiates, set the stage for a rousing finale to local banked-track operations in Saturday's Knights of Columbus games.

WYANDANCH, L. I., Feb. 24 -- Two small children perished and their 15-year-old brother was critically burned in a fire of undetermined origin that destroyed their two-story frame home here early this morning.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Evidence that there are primitive forms of animal life in the remote Antarctic and that the polar regions once may have been warm has been brought back here by British, Norwegian and Swedish scientists who took part in a recent two-year survey of Queen Maud Land.

You don't need to own a car to drive it. Out of that plain fact has grown the Hertz Driv-Ur-Self System, Inc., and its various allied companies. They do the owning of the cars and let the customer do the driving, for a fee based on mileage and time.

LESS than two miles from my house as you go up Ferris Hill and past the Country Club lives one of the most popular novelists in the world. When he moved into our town a few years ago his arrival aroused considerable interest. After all, what literate adult has not read at least some of the novels of A. J. Cronin? What kind of a fabulous creature would the celebrity be?

Once again the Korean negotiations have come to a full deadlock on the issue of the involuntary repatriation of prisoners. The Communists again insist, without qualification, that every person held in United Nations custody must be returned regardless of his own wish.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France expect to announce here within the next forty-eight hours conclusion of a full and final agreement with West Germany on the ending of the occupation status and the emergence of the German nation once more as a free member of the international community.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The break in the price of rubber and a sharp sympathetic tumble in rubber shares has proved an infectious complaint for the stock markets.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 -- A major reorganization of the United States Government's methods of distributing military aid to its European allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization already is being prepared as a result of the North Atlantic Council's approval here of the projected European Defense Force.

In no part of our city right now are its of growing pains better to be observed by the curious in such matters than in the reach along the East River front from Twenty-third Street to Forty-eighth -- that is, from where the tall red brick piles of Peter Cooper Village are set among green spaces past the point where the United Nations building operations are still proceeding.

Nearly 10,000 trained and uniformed volunteers -- who are also housewives, business and professional women, or taxi drivers, corporation executives, musicians and clerks -- gave 1,006,538 hours of skilled labor last year to the five New York chapters of the American Red Cross.

BUFFALO, Feb. 24 -- Three hundred Protestant laymen representing business, labor, agriculture, and the professions pledged themselves here today to work unselfishly for the betterment of mankind "regardless of cost."

ATHENS, Feb. 24 -- In a manner suggesting the rout of an invading force, today's press headlines the "Defeat of Tuberculosis" as a result of the new antituberculosis drug discovered in the United States.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Feb. 24 -- An all-time record of 998 polio patients were treated for 56,243 hospital hours at the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation, according to a report submitted today by Basil O'Connor, foundation president, for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.
The New York Rangers disposed of a dangerous enemy last night. Bill Cook's skaters, staging a strong third-period rally, subdued the Boston Bruins in an exciting contest, 5 to 2.
Elmer Rice, Pulitzer Prize playwright, has rejoined the Celanese Theatre after reaching an agreement with the sponsor's agency on terms under which his plays will be cast for the television program.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- During one of the best sailing afternoons of the season the dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club held the final of its three-day holiday regattas.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- The United Nations Commission for Germany, now functioning in Geneva, has invited East and West German represntatives to meet with the commission March 17 to begin discussions on the possibility of free elections to reunify Germany.

Rising unemployment increased this city's public relief rolls by 2,899 persons last month, reversing the slow decline in public assistance that began twenty months ago, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Tampa's Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias made an eighteen-foot putt on the thirty-sixth and final hole of the international mixed two-ball open golf tournament today to give her and Al Besselink of Chicago a winning 1-up over Miss Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., and Dick Chapman of Pinehurst.

A stockholders' committee of the International Railways of Central America announced yesterday that it has prepared a slate of directors to be voted upon at the next annual meeting in opposition to the present management, which it claims is influenced by the United Fruit Company, owner of 42.68 per cent of the voting stock of the railroad company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Under the Government's new policy of taking work to the jobless worker, some surplus labor cities can expect special help in the next few months, but others, particularly New England's textile centers and New York, cannot count on it.

For her debut recital in Town Hall last night, the Canadian contralto Mary Baron devoted her program to a single song cycle -- the fifteen lieder that make up Brahms' "Die Schoene Magelone," Op. 33. Reginald Boardman was at the piano.

LAKE WALES, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The Yankees' complicated preliminary spring training campaign began to unravel itself today when New York scribes, who had been watching a select group of hurlers practice at the regular base in St. Petersburg, finally tracked down Casey Stengel.

A second city-wide air raid drill for civil defense personnel, based on supposed explosions of atomic bombs underwater south of Governors Island and in mid-air above the Bronx, was scheduled for the evening of April 3 by Civil Defense Director Arthur W. Wallander yesterday.

Emotional religion and a ritualistic worship of God cannot be separated from an objective, Christ-like love of our fellow men without that religion's becoming a "discordant, harsh thing," Canon Edward N. West, sacrist of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday at the morning service in the cathedral.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Western Maryland Railway began its centennial celebration yesterday with ceremonies honoring the nine Rhodes brothers -- every one an engineer on the road.

OSLO, Feb. 24 -- The major competition of the Winter Games of the Sixth Olympic ended today in a brilliant victory for Norway. The host country's ski jumping team captured the first two places at Holmenkollen and was wildly applauded by a record crowd, variously estimated between 120,000 and 140,000 spectators headed by King Haakon, his family and Swedish and Belgian royalty. The victory gave the Norsemen the title with 125 1/2 points.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 -- Steel production was rolling along last week at 100.5 per cent of rated capacity, up 1/2 point from the week before. There was more evidence that steel in most of its forms will -- in a few months -- be hardly in the "tight" category.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- The worsening of French domestic and foreign financial situation has become a subject of concern to authorities of the European Economic Cooperation Administration and the managing board of the European Payments Union.

Tex McCrary is rapidly becoming television's trying little boy. While video as a whole has done a good job in bringing the Presidential-year politics into the home, the National Broadcasting Company's self-appointed leader of the cause of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower seems determined to turn the medium's political usefulness into an undignified side show.
The output of our manufacturing plants was surveyed yesterday to ascertain whether we are making more or less.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 -- North Atlantic Treaty Organization military authorities have received a promise of all but 10 per cent of the funds needed for the urgent program of construction of airfields and other permanent installations for the joint use of Western defense forces.
Men and women "of character and principle" were declared yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken in his sermon at Riverside Church to be "the supreme need today."

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The text of the official summary of the report drafted by the Temporary Council Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the effort required to build North Atlantic defenses:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Ellis Arnall, Director of Price Stabilization and former Governor of Georgia, said today he did not believe any Republican -- including General of the Army Dwight. D. Eisenhower -- could carry any Southern state in the Presidential election.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate Democratic leadership will call for a showdown vote tomorrow on confirmation of Harry A. McDonald as Administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Suitable for a contemporary room are some new black perforated metal accessories designed by Dick Galef. These accessories, from a four-inch-high cigarette cup to a two-foot-long cradle for magazines, are all simple in structure and inexpensive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Feb. 16 to 22 are given in the appended tabulation.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 24 -- Nearly 4,000 persons watched Sigurd Sorensen of the Norway Ski-Club of New York City sail 197 and 210 feet to capture the annual invitation ski jump of the Brattleboro Outing Club today. Sorenson's style, gained him 221 points.
The last surviving seeded contract bridge team in the Vanderbilt Cup knockout team-of-four national championship last night seemed headed for defeat.
Rabbi Itzchak Meyer Lewin, Israeli Minister of Welfare, declared last night that the Arab countries were preparing for a war of revenge against Israel.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24-- Walter O'Malley, president of the Dodgers, opened his first training camp press conference today by casting a full vote of confidence for Manager Charley Dressen.

The immediate expenditure of at least $1,350,000 to accelerate the emergency expansion of New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to compensate for the closing of Newark Airport has been decided upon by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Defense officials said today that draft calls this summer and fall would have to be big enough to provide "substantial" replacements for draftees and National Guardsmen released from active duty.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- A record sum of $11,341,000 in pledged contributions was announced here today at the closing sessions of the United Jewish Appeal's two-day inaugural conference. The meeting marked the forms opening of the appeal's 1952 nation-wide drive for $151,500,000 for aid to Israel, distressed Jews overseas and refugees entering the United States.

Assemblyman John R. Brook's bill to license "public loaders" on the city's piers in an effort to end "mobster rule" focuses attention on a long-standing evil which is one of the cardinal causes of waterfront crime. The "public loader" is a man who lifts the cargo from a pier to a truck for a fee.

ZURICH, Feb. 24 -- Publication of the last annual business reports of the great commercial banks of Switzerland confirms predictions that 1951 would prove the most conspicuously successful year in the history of Swiss banking.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 -- Ernst Jorgensen, a Danish rehabilitation expert who has been blind since the age of 10, has just completed a study for the United Nations that he hopes will help bring benefits to other sightless persons.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Another last minute legislative log-jam appeared in the making tonight as leaders adhered to their program of bringing the present session to an end in three weeks. Except for the measures embodying Governor Dewey's recommendations for curbing the spread of narcotic addiction, virtually no measures of major consequence have yet been acted upon in either house.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Britain's shipping industry has reason to be anxious about the future despite its present prosperity, according to the annual report of the Chamber of Shipping, published today. Steadily mounting costs in almost every phase of ship operation, the report said, are factors likely to remain "long after the present level of freights has subsided."

NEWARK, Feb. 24 -- Thieves broke into a building in the heart of the business district here early this morning and then chased themselves out of it by accidentally setting it afire. The fire did only negligible damage and the police have not yet determined how much loot the burglars managed to haul away before they crossed themselves up.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 24 -- An all-out fight by the nation's coal, oil and rail industries against proposed tariff free importation of Canadian natural gas to the Pacific Northwest was pledged here this week-end as the Western States Fuel Policy Council began a vigorous campaign to inform the region and the nation of the "economic death threat" allegedly inherent in cross-border pipeline proposals.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 -- The big decisions of the Atlantic Council were made with unexpected dispatch and comparative ease. In two days the fourteen nations represented here unanimously approved the agreements reached by the Big Three in London on the plan for the European army, on its relation to NATO, on the terms of the peace contract with West Germany and the amount of her contribution to the common defense.

Gerard Souzay, French baritone, who made his local debut last season, gave his second New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The gifted singer, whatever his vocal and interpretive faults or his merits, possess, to degree uncommon among vocalists of the younger generation the sort of showmanship that holds the attention tightly gripped, in itself a most valuable asset.

A "realistic" view of the necessity of penance in the spiritual life was urged yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, synodol judge of the ecclesiastical tribunal of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- The Interior Department said today that racial segregation on railroad cars was "a cancerous and corroding influence on our national unity" that sapped "the vitality of our democratic ideals."
It is the toys of America that have most interested a young Milanese architect visiting in this country for the first time.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 -- Trans World Airlines officials said today they hoped doubting passengers hereafter would take their word that emergency doors on their planes worked just fine.

It's not a minute too soon to start thinking about what you will be wearing in the Easter Parade, especially if you're going to make it yourself. So what shall it be? A coat or a jacket to top your new spring suit?

The United Steelworkers, in formulating their demands for higher wages in the current dispute with the steel industry, have contended that output per worker rose by 12.8 per cent in the three-year period ended with the middle of 1951.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- The Government's second major test of the application of the anti-subversive Smith Act to the Communist party will enter its fourth calendar week Tuesday, with seemingly equal prospects of clarifying the Communist question and of complicating it further.

A new method of successfully controlling shrinkage in cotton knitted fabrics was announced over the week-end by Arthur Reis Jr., president of Robert Reis Co. The process, called Reis Permasized, will be offered in March in the company's athletic and "T" shirts.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 24 (UP) -- Jack Burke Jr. of Houston coasted to his second straight golf tournament victory, touring Memorial Park's 7,200-yard, par 72 course in regulation figures today to win the $10,000 Houston Open with a 277.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The question Shakespeare posed some time ago about what's in a name is a very leading question.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- Take the homecoming celebration at a Midwestern university, add a touch of New Orleans Mardi Gras and a dash of Derby day at Louisville, mix the whole to last for three days and you have a fair sample of the collective madness that has gripped the entire Rhineland.

IT isn't the robin which is the first harbinger of spring to the baseball writer. It's the arrival of the Red Book, the official press brochure for the American League. Earl Hilligan crams it full of facts and figures to a fascinating degree while hovering in the background are visions of flamingoes, pelicans, palm trees and Moon over Miami.

REVELSTOKE, B. C., Feb. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Arnfinn Bergmann, who won the Olympic ski jump today, wanted to compete for Canada instead of his native Norway, but, his mother-in-law said tonight, that his application for Canadian citizenship was not made in time to make him eligible for the Canadian team.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 -- Repeated evidence of strong Communist infiltration into the Brazilian armed forces and civil administration has aroused grave concern here.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- A program for increasing pensions of retired public employes by a maximum of $300 a year in furtherance of the constitutional amendment approved last year has been advanced tentatively by a special committee headed by J. Raymond McGouran, State Controller.
Moscow fashions will come to Fifth Avenue Wednesday when Bonwit Teller will unveil window displays of what the well-dressed Soviet woman is wearing -- if she can afford it.
The validity of the hackneyed "where there's a will" has once again been demonstrated by the current enforcement of the double-parking law.

While the Canadian dollar and British sterling continued firm, chief interest in last week's foreign exchange market centered in the Uruguayan peso which closed at 38.59 cents, a loss of 3 3/4 cents from the preceding week, and lowest since October, 1950.
Not all the facts about the Metcalf-Hatch Pound Seizure Bill have been canvassed in your columns and not all the facts are generally known. I therefore hope that you will give space to this letter.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Price trends in the grain market were irregular last week on the Chicago Board of Trade, and there was some pressure of liquidation in the March deliveries at times, but for the period price changes were not particularly significant.

FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 24 -- Thousands of Florentines rushed into the streets today with the lust of battle in their eyes in answer to an urgent appeal to "defend your city" that appeared during the last few days in the press and on posters.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The year 1951 was a record sales year for Monsanto Chemical Company, reaching a total of $272,845,034, 20 per cent more than the previous high of 1950.

John Tyers, a member of the Metropolitan Opera's touring company of "Fledermaus," has been engaged by the parent company. He will make his debut at the Opera House on March 8 singing his touring role of Dr. Falke in the season's ninth and final performance of the opera.

A navigational "forecasting" screen that is expected to lessen greatly the hazards of ship collisions has been developed by the Raytheon Manufacturing Company for attachment to marine radar equipment.

MILTON, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Whiting Field, near here, where every naval aviator first experiences the dangerous excitement of flight, had its first fatality in several months of intensive operations on Jan. 31.
The Juilliard Quartet played second compositions for the four strings by three contemporary composers last night.

The first of the Government-built Mariner class of national defense cargo ships -- the Keystone Mariner -- will be launched on Friday afternoon. The vessel is being constructed by the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Chester, Pa.

OSLO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Katy Rodolph, pink-cheeked beauty of the American Olympic ski squad, disclosed today her secret marriage to team-mate Paul Wegeman and denied flatly any romance with Stein Eriksen, Norwegian skiing ace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee probably will put off action on a request for subpoena powers for Newbold Morris in his investigation of corruption in government until Senate investigators clear up his role in a surplus tanker deal, committee sources said today.
The Roxy Theatre at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street will open Broadway's first blood bank for movie patrons tonight.

The nonpartisan nature of the Election Reform Committee, Inc., which is pressing for enactment of permanent personal registration and other election law changes, was stressed yesterday by Bruce Bromley, chairman of the committee.

Although gross operating revenues increased 16 per cent last year, earnings for the common stock of the Florida Power Corporation declined 15 per cent from the previous year, according to the utility's annual report for 1951 being sent to stockholders today.
Westchester has become the second county in the seventeen-county metropolitan region around New York to be fully protected by zoning regulations, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Ten Western European nations have joined the United States in a move designed to insure that strategic goods are not transshipped to Communist-controlled countries.

BABYLON, L. I., Feb. 24 -- Voters in five school districts yesterday turned down by a margin of 179 votes a proposition to create a single centralized district. The official tally showed that 5,721 ballots were cast, with 2,949 voting against the proposition and 2,770 voting in favor.
