WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Government predicts the construction industry will have 400,000 fewer jobs to offer this year than last year because of controls and materials shortages.

Harold Lang, co-star of "Pal Joey," appeared last night as guest artist with the New York City Ballet at the City Center, dancing in the third movement of the Balanchine-Bizet "Symphony in C" with Janet Reed. Mr. Lang, formerly a member of the ballet company, has returned on several occasions in other seasons to make guest appearances.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Feb. 24 -- Suffolk County Republican Club members appeared today to favor settlement of their pending suit against former Representative W. Kingsland Macy for $50,000 as proposed by their former leader through his attorney, Guy O. Walser.
The Western Big Three foreign ministers expect to announce by tomorrow full, final agreement with Bonn on ending West German occupation. [1:8.]

Wayne Coy, who resigned on Thursday after four years and two months as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, will become a consultant to Time, Inc., which publishes the magazines Time, Life and Fortune, it was announced yesterday in the name of Roy E. Larsen, the president.
How to keep a new steel labor crisis from developing in a few months is one of the problems with which the Wage Stabilization Board is wrestling in its efforts to ward off a national strike March 23.

Today's column is concerned with a few of the many new cook books that have come off the press in recent weeks. They indicate the diversity of the subject of cookery. One is a compilation of recipes for dishes that the busy career girl can do in a hurry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, told Congress today that labor unions were the nation's best "salesmen" of democracy.

PARIS, Monday, Feb. 25 -- Premier Edgar Faure said today France would have to raise taxes 15 per cent, instead of the 10 per cent previously indicated, to meet her rearming obligations under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreement reached last week.
Three new films, including English and Italian-made importations, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The defeat, ninth in eleven games with Detroit this year for the Hawks, could have been much worse except for some standout goal tending by Harry Lumley. He had forty-four saves, nineteen in the second period.

An audience charged with high octane sentiment demonstrated its affection for Judy Garland by refusing to allow the singer to leave the stage at her final performance -- the 184th -- last night at the Palace Theatre.

In connection with the nationwide effort toward merger of the American Baptist Convention and the Disciples of Christ, the Rev. Theodore E. Miller of Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn, preached yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples) at Eighty-fifth Street, in a pulpit exchange with the Rev. Ira W. Langston.

The NATO conference in Lisbon is due to wind up today in something resembling a blaze of glory. No one could have hoped in advance that the meeting would accomplish so much. One gets the impression that the strength of the ideals which are driving the fourteen member nations forward is greater than the contrary cross-currents of national rivalries, historic fears and internal partisan politics.

MOORESTOWN, N. J., Feb. 24 -- Two small privately owned monoplanes plummeted to earth after a mid-air collision over nearby Mount Laurel at 3:55 P. M. today, killing all three men in the two craft. One of the planes exploded and burst into flames.
Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, declared yesterday that he believed the Korean war had lessened the possibility of there being a third World War.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 24 -- A redefinition of Formosa's protected status within the over-all framework of the United States defense structure in the Pacific is reported to have been under study here and in Washington in the light of a possible armistice in Korea and the altered position of the Supreme Command, Allied Powers, in Japan.

The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, who returned last week from a five-month tour for the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., reported yesterday on political, economic and religious conditions in the Orient.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,170, for Sunday's operations:
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- William Goodloe, who lost in semi-finals last year, today won the national championship of golf club champions with a landslide score of 10 and 9.

This week's art program is slightly less crowded than those of preceding weeks, but it contains many exhibitions of interest. Especially so is the display of work by the Duchamp family, Marcel, Jacques Villon, Duchamp-Villon and Suzanne Duchamp at the Rose Fried Gallery.

The first Kurt Weill Memorial Concert given last year made so marked an impression that it bore two repetitions. A second program, similar to that previously presented, also attracted a large audience Saturday night at Town Hall, again attesting to the public's continued interest in the music of the gifted composer.
Arrangements are virtually concluded for members of the armed forces in Japan and the Far East to see free performances of Moliere's "The School for Wives" and Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night."

Record gross operating revenues of $3,639,462,365 in 1951 produced a net income of $364,874,176 in 1951 for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries, his consolidated net income, was equal to $11.76 a share on the parent company's average outstanding capital stock during the year and compares with a net of $346,962,051, or $12.58 a share on fewer average shares, in the previous year.

Sometimes it seems as if the world was divided into two camps -- the forces that want life more complex (the tax people, the politicians, the diplomats) and those who try to make it simpler (the gadget-makers, the marketing men and the home economists).

Consolidated net earnings of C. I. T. Financial Corporation for 1951 were $22,165,060 or $7.31 a common share, against $30,787,608 or $8.04 a share in 1950, Arthur O. Dietz, president, reported yesterday. Earnings before taxes were $63,037,060 against $63,623,608 but taxes made the difference.

The city-wide requirement of 300,000 volunteers for the medical emergency division of the civil defense program has been only one-third filled, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals and civil defense coordinator, reported yesterday. In an artcile in the civil defense news bulletin he declared New York was "up to its ears in apathy" about the current recruiting drive.
Three leading contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination will appear on the same dais at the annual fund-raising dinner of the party's state committee to be held here on April 17.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that the tax loopholes cost the Federal Government more than $4,500,000,000 a year and benefited almost entirely those with annual incomes of more than $10,000.

Lessons in effective union organization and shop level ideas on increasing productivity will be among this country's exports to Europe a year hence when 2,000 European workers, most of them rank and file unionists, begin their homeward journeys.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 25 -- The United Nations Command came up today with a new compromise proposal in the Korean truce negotiations, calling for four instead of six-nation armistice teams to police the cease-fire.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -- Substantial wage increases, improvements in working conditions and preference of employment for professional actors hired by the day were the principal points won by the Screen Actors Guild in a new basic contract negotiated with the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

Columbia University's planning for its bicentennial celebration in 1954 is progressing, and appointment of Richard R. Powell, Dwight Professor of Law, to be director of the celebration is announced this morning. Professor Powell has been among those shaping up the preliminaries for some time.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- In the negotiations with Egypt that will open in Cairo this week the British Government is believed to be willing to consider terminating the British occupation of the Suez Canal zone but only on one immutable condition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) -- An attorney for Philleo Nash said today he had decided Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was protected against damage suits when he repeated outside Congress his previous Senate charges linking the White House aide with communism.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- With new national champion Peggy Howe of Boston pacing them, the U. S. women's squash racquets team today regained the international Wolfe-Noel Challenge Cup by defeating a star-studded British team, four matches to one, at the Harvard Club.
Arthur W. Foster has been named to the new position of field merchandising manager for the Parker Pen Company. He joined the company in 1931.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 -- Morocco, where the United States is constructing a $500,000,000 network of strategic airbases, and Tunisia, another French North African possession, have been associated with the North Atlantic Treaty by a decision of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council meeting here.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A British executive is on his way to the United States today to investigate United States methods and know-how in an unusual field, recruiting for the ministry.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 24 -- Senator Estes Kefauver's announcement in Chicago yesterday that he would enter the Wisconsin Presidential preference primary presents Wisconsin Democratic leaders with some headaches similar to those the state Republican chiefs have with their four-way Presidential primary race.

Near the bustling metropolitan oasis of Khartum, capital of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, in Northeast Africa, some of man's most ingenious conceptions of the nature of the physical universe were being put to the test this morning. The test is nature's own device, a total eclipse of the sun.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday that it had asked for time to appear in opposition to the St. Lawrence Seaway proposal at hearings that will begin today in Washington before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Half a ship was towed into port last night and tied up at a windswept open wharf in Brooklyn. This was the final chapter in the second major storm saga of the North Atlantic this season.

RENO, Feb. 24 (UP) -- The University of Denver ski team, led by versatile Marvin Crawford, won the slalom and jumping competition today to sweep all major events in the three-day University of Nevada winter-carnival.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 24 -- French and Vietnamese forces have evacuated Hoabinh and the mountainous western end of the highway linking Hoabinh with Hanoi.

The Manhattan Opera Guild made its debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall with a concert performance of Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin." The guild is dedicated to the proposition that young talent needs opportunity, and it has announced that further productions will be given.

The Teachers Union made public yesterday a request for particulars of the charges against eight teachers suspended on Jan. 31. The eight had refused to say whether they were Communist party members and Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, filed charges of "insubordination and conduct unbecoming a teacher" against each of them.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 -- Insurance against Willie Mays' departure for military service arrived in the Giants' training camp today in the person of Charles (Chuck) Diering, former St. Louis Cardinal star. He reported along with Clint Hartung and Ronald Samford, the rookie infielder from Sioux City with a .296 hitting average.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 24 -- Mrs. Golda Myerson, Minister of Labor, departed by air for the United States tonight to tell Americans that in spite of current economic difficulties Israel is moving steadily toward economic independence.

Defeated by Navy on a Saturday that saw some of the nation's ranking quintets abso b unexpected drubbings, Notre Dame will attempt to make its Eastern trip at least a partial success tonight when it faces New York University in the nineteenth game between the schools at Madison Square Garden.

Richard Savitt's first quest for the national indoor tennis championship was crowned with success yesterday. With the same masterful tennis that overpowered Budge Patty, the rangy Wimbledon champion from Orange, N. J., ended the reign of William Talbert of New York, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 --4 in the final round of the tournament.

The appointment of Richard R. Powell, Dwight Professor of Law at Columbia University, as director of the university's bicentennial celebration and a further outline of plans for the anniversary year were made known yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 21 -- Premier Willem Drees in the upper chamber last week said that the guilder had been saved from further depreciation and that the payments balance could now be brought into equilibrium.

The Manhattan Opera Guild made its debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall with a concert performance of Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin." The guild is dedicated to the proposition that young talent needs opportunity, and it has announced that further productions will be given.
MILL VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Cleveland outfielder Sam Chapman made it clear today that he is all through with playing the kind of baseball that means "moving the family all around."
Willie Sutton, the ostensibly successful bank robber and prison breaker who has spent twenty of the last twenty-six years behind bars, asserted yesterday that "crime is a sucker's racket."

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Benjamin Fine, education editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES told a gathering here at ceremonies marking the 157th anniversary of Union College that "this country boasts the best agricultural colleges in the world."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Prospects for favorable Senate action on the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project improved markedly today with the announcement by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, that he favored its construction by the United States and Canada.
OSLO, Feb. 25 -- Twenty-eight thousand people stood with bared heads at Bislett Stadium tonight as the Olympic flame was slowly extinguished, marking the end of the Sixth Winter Olympic Games.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- Democratic and Republican members of a House subcommittee on Un-American Activities wrangled through most of the morning here today over the question of permitting Detroit television stations to cover the Congressional group's investigation of Communist influence in the labor movement here.

Corinne Griffith, the motion-picture star and author of "My Life With the Redskins," has another autobiographical work on Houghton Mifflin's list for March 6 publication Entitled "Papa's Delicate Condition," the book describes some of her father's doings down in Texas when the author was 6 years old.

Mrs. Hugh Jackson Reber will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 1239 Madison Avenue for the executive committee and student committee aiding in plans for the March 10 performance of "Venus Observed," with Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer, at the Century Theatre for the benefit of the Child Education Foundation.
The Westinghouse Electric Corportation was struck hard by taxes last year, in company with many other industrial giants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Administration leaders prepared plans today to bring the Universal Military Training bill before a House of Representatives that appeared to be about equally divided on the issue. Debate will begin tomorrow in the House and will last the remainder of this week, the first test were being deferred until next week.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Dewey cleared the way today for a survey by the State Department of Mental Hygiene of the extent and care of mental deficiency. He approved for the supplemental budget a $25,000 appropriation to finance the survey.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The coronation of Queen Elizabeth II will take place in 1953. It almost certainly will be arranged for the spring or summer.

Respect for religion is the "keystone in the arch of human freedom," the Rev. John LaFarge, associate editor of America, Jesuit weekly magazine, told 750 lay and religious leaders of all faiths at a testimonial in his honor last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Cities throughout the country are experiencing a shortage of teachers for the handicapped, a report by the Board of Higher Education said yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law recommended tonight that virtually all sports events except horse racing, boxing and wrestling be permitted on Sunday unless a locality saw fit to ban them.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- A small group of fifteen to twenty lawyers comprise the "masterminds" controlling the Communist party in the United States, the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association was old today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The railroad industry today renewed an urgent plea for "the opportunity to earn a fair return" while business activity is at a high level throughout the country.

Sales of the Eaton Manufacturing Company and its subsidiaries rose to a new high of $186,771,067 last year from the $148,302,045 volume for 1950, but earnings declined under the pressure of greater taxes, the annual report said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- State adjutants general of the National Guard from all sections of the country were told today that the future of their organizations depended upon their "insisting" on legislation that would provide the Guard with a sure supply of manpower.
Eight thousand drivers and mechanics on the city's privately owned bus lines will get a cost-of-living wage increase of 6 cents an hour today.

NAPLES, Feb. 25 -- More than two hundred American, British, French and Italian warships will move at dawn tomorrow from Gibraltar and Malta and from French, Italian and North African Mediterranean ports to their appointed stations in the greatest combined naval training exercises ever held.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Blue ribbon juries in New York City would be outlawed under provisions of a bill passed by the Senate tonight in line with a recommendation of the State Judicial Council. The bill now goes to the Assembly for concurrence.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Snow and rain fell yesterday on most of Korea, cutting ground and air action to a minimum.
The United States Weather Bureau yesterday issued the following forecasts and reports of winter sports conditions in New England.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 -- The National Labor Relations Board today issued an order that ended the practice of some building trades unions in requiring a worker to join the union, as a condition of employment, without ever having qualified legally to do so.

New York City has borrowed $40,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due on April 23 and April 29 at an interest rate of 1 1/2 per cent, City Controller Lazarus Joseph said yesterday. The notes were sold to twenty-three banks and trust companies on an allotment basis, as follows:
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 25 -- Alvin Dark was designated by Manager Leo Durocher today as "the take charge guy" in the Giants' infield, and immediately proceeded to act like that.

The rapid growth of the advertising specialties business was brought out yesterday at the regional spring convention of Brown Bigelow, St. Paul, one of the oldest and largest of such concerns. Last year the company did a $42,000,000 business, compared with only $3,000,000 in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Truman's request that Newbold Morris, his investigator of corruption in the Federal Government, receive power to grant to witnesses immunity from prosecution was disapproved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Ten New York and New Jersey piers, over which move frequent and large amounts of hazardous military and Military Defense Assistance Program cargoes, will be declared restricted areas as of Saturday, the Coast Guard announced yesterday.

Phil Harris will make guest appearances on various National Broadcasting Company television shows under the terms of new contract arrangements with the network. The agreement also calls for the continuation of the Phil Harris-Alice Faye radio program.
Classification of a part of a bank's deposits as "borrowed capital" in computing taxes on earnings was suggested yesterday by Harold H. Helm, president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- The name of General MacArthur was stricken from the Pennsylvania preferential primary ballot today, leaving only those of General Eisenhower and Mr. Stassen.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, declared today that the head of a government "has no right to wait for corruption to take the form of scandal before he does something about it."
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Battling Edith Summerskill came out of her corner swinging today.

LISBON, Feb. 25 -- Greek sources said here tonight that W. Averell Harriman, United States Mutual Security Administrator, had expressed his own informal and personal views on the United States Presidential campaign during recent private talks with members of the Athens delegation here.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Most every spring training camp has what the boys in the trade call a "sleeper." He is that fellow picked up during the preceding winter through some obscure trade or draft claim who suddenly reveals talents no one ever suspected.

CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- The Ministry of Public Works announced here today a four-year Egyptian plan to increase the amount of irrigation water available from the Nile, and Arab news agency reports from Baghdad said that the Iraqi Government had announced adoption of a $450,000,000 International Bank for Reconstruction and Development five-year plan for Mesopotamia.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 (UP) -- Mr. and Mrs. R. H. McDaniel's Great Dream wore down the front-running Fleet Rings today to score a length victory in the $5,000 allowance feature at Santa Anita.

" God, Petrie! The dacoits!" How it all comes back -- Nayland Smith, so good, so brave, so damnably, don't y'know, eager; Flinders Petrie, so loyal, so little help; Dr. Fu (ugh!) Manchu, so luminous-eyed, so magnificently evil; Karamaneh, his beautiful daughter, and her little marmoset; and the dacoits!

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Feb. 25 (UP) -- Supreme Court Justice Leo J. Hagerty said today the grand jury investigation of corruption in Saratoga Springs would continue despite another justice's ruling that the jury was packed in favor of the prosecution.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Over the opposition of Conservatives and the Radical party, the French National Assembly passed a bill tonight providing an escalator system for increasing wages automatically in the event of a 10 per cent rise in living costs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Truman reminded the world today that the Communists had seized control of Czechoslovakia's free government just four years ago. He said it was this event that finally taught other free nations that they must be prepared in advance to combat a system that meant conquest, oppression and slavery.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 25 (UP) -- Dr. Walter Schreiber, former German general, will be off the United States Air Force's payroll in twenty-four hours unless a last-minute change in orders renews his contract, Brig. Gen. Otis O. Benson Jr. said today.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- American methods of factory training soon may be used in Britain in an effort to overcome this country's critical manpower shortage and find places in industry for middle-aged people.

ABRAHAM LINCOLN, a small-town lawyer whose only military experience had been a few days' service in an almost comic-opera Indian war, was a better strategist than any of his generals. This is the opinion of T. Harry Williams, Professor of History at Louisiana State University and author of "Lincoln and His Generals."* To demonstrate the grounds for this opinion is the purpose of his lively book.

TORONTO, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Two mining companies announced today that they have agreed to purchase $500,000 worth of shares each in Anglo-American Exploration, Ltd., which controls thousands of acres of possible oil-rich land in southern Saskatchewan and Manitoba.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn prevented the televising and radio broadcast of a hearing by a subgroup of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities in Detroit today. Further, he said here that there would be no more television or radio reporting of committee hearings as long as he was Speaker of the House and its rules remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced a $12,000,000 defense loan today to the Glenn L. Martin Company to guarantee continuation of the company's "vital" production of guided missiles and airplanes.

THE "proper" administration of New York's state forests has been a matter of considerable controversy, some of it heated, during recent weeks. But the introduction of a bill to create a temporary stage commission to study this important problem seems to meet with the approval of those interested in safeguarding these forests.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -"Fair trade" laws permit private price fixing which "always results in price-raising," a spokesman for R. H. Macy Co. told Congress today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 25 -- An uneasy peace came to East Pakistan over the week-end after three days of violence that the Government here hints was "stirred up" by foreign elements, by which is meant Indian.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- A National Labor, Relations Board ruling in Washington today, ordering collective bargaining elections among West Coast shipyard workers, was received here with mixed feelings by labor leaders.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Legal experts tonight requested a transcript of the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing in Washington at which Mrs. Keeney, a former United Nations employe, was accused of contempt.

Senator Humphrey of Minnesota, with an assist from the Institute of Public Affairs, has issued a statement attacking what he elects to describe as "loopholes" in the tax laws. We use this phraseology advisedly because Senator Humphrey uses the term "loophole" in a very special sense.

More than 500 students were dismissed from classes at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the 106-year-old Food Trades Vocational High School Annex at 60 West Thirteenth Street after a teacher reported a slight buckling in a wooden pillar in the auditorium

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The Government flashed a green light today for completion of almost all commercial and industrial buildings on which work was started and then halted to save materials for defense.
KHARTUM, Sudan, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The moon eclipsed the sun today and the nearly perfect weather gave scientists a rare glimpse of what goes on in space close to the sun.

A three-year study by a chemical manufacturing industry committee produced yesterday a report holding that air pollution was "not a serious or critical menace to public health," but that Government control was necessary because some plants were making no effort to curb the nuisance.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 25 -- High school facilities for teaching Negro pupils in Prince Edward County were criticized and defended today as a hearing opened before a three-judge Federal court on a petition making the first direct attack on the state's segregated school system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The following sentence in Senator Taft's "A Foreign Policy for Americans" (Doubleday, 1951) was so hotly challenged on a television show in New York City last week as a breach both of accuracy and good faith that the Senator said the critic had called him a "liar":

Objections to the probate of the will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of J. Pierpont Morgan, will be heard tomorrow morning by Surrogate William T. Collins and a jury. The will bequeathed most of her estate of more than $200,000 to Sol A. Rosenblatt, attorney, and cut off her sister, Mrs. Mabel S. Ingalls.

Willie Sutton has been nabbed. The last of the $10,000 in currency that went flying up a Farmingdale street after the recent bank explosion in that Long Island town, has been recovered. Now banks can get down to less flamboyant activities such as more enlightened employe relations.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Parliament had an old-fashioned party fight tonight, a political knock-down-and-drag-out affair, over the resignation of Steven J. L. Hardie as chairman of Britain's nationalized steel industry. The Conservatives won on points -- 250 votes to 203.

In his letter of Feb. 14 Clifford C. Johnston, a spokesman for the Christian Science Church, leads your readers to believe that the Regents examination in biology has not been modified in any way. Mr. Johnston succeeded in conveying this impression by failing to quote the last paragraph of an official New York City Board of Education circular. This reads:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate, by a vote of 46 to 23, confirmed today the nomination of Harry A. McDonald, Michigan Republican now chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be the new $17,500-a-year director of the long-investigated Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson used to have a rougher time with the home-grown politicians than any other foreign secretary in the world, but in the current controversy over the rearmament of West Germany, Congress has treated him like a member of the club.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Michael V. DiSalle, former price controller, opened his campaign for the Senate today with an attack on Republican foreign policy and Senator John W. Bricker, Republican, who is seeking re-election.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 25 -- While the evacuation of Hoabinh, French base southwest of Hanoi, gave further evidence that the Indo-China war in the main Tongking theatre was deadlocked for the present, a high French official said today he did not believe a decisive military victory was possible.

Five Marine Corps master sergeants, all veterans of World War II, were sworn in as second lieutenants at a ceremony yesterday at the corps' recruiting headquarters, 346 Broadway. The five were selected under a program for the promotion of desirable senior noncommissioned officers to the commissioned ranks.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Men are staying away from clothing stores by millions, and the proportion of money spent out of every dollar for men's clothes is continually declining.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- In today's top race at Hialeah, the $5,000 Flamingo Prep, were eight 3-year-olds that are candidates for Saturday's $50,000 Flamingo Stakes. One of the colts considered least likely to succeed was Gustave E. Smith's Handsome Teddy.

In his letter published Feb. 19 Richard H. Wels clearly depicts the evils inherent in the voting procedure of our mutual life insurance companies and offers new legislation as the remedy through which disfranchisement and self-perpetuation are to be ended and "democracy" is to be established.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 -United States leaders attending the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council meeting here are convinced they have a persuasive case to make to Congress for another year's program of aid to the European partners in the joint defense effort.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 -- Dr. Alcide de Gasperi, Premier of Italy, indicated today his Government would refuse to consider the inclusion of Yugoslavia in a regional defense system with Greece, Turkey and Italy as long as the Trieste question remained unsolved.

Net sales of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company rose 24 per cent last year to $135,150,517, highest in the history of the sixty-six-year-old automatic controls manufacturer, Harold W. Sweatt, president, reported yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A 15-foot, one-handed shot by subtitute Harry Brooks in the last six seconds lifted Seton Hall to an 83-to-81 basketball victory over the University of Louisville tonight. Brooks had just entered the game when he swept down the middle for the winning basket.

Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, said here last night that he was alarmed by "the evolvement of a revolution in this country wherein the American and Americanism are idolized."

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Council concluded its important ninth session today by agreeing on a $426,000,000 infrastructure program for military installations abroad, and establishing a new permanent headquarters in the vicinity of Paris.

" Man on the Run," a British-made melodrama, which arrives at the Seventy-second Street Trans-Lux, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Derek Farr and Joan Hopkins head the cast of the import, which was written and directed by Lawrence Huntington.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 25 -- The High Commissions of the United States, Britain and France delivered to Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, chairman of the Soviet Control Commission in East Germany, today a copy of the law drafted by the West German Government for the establishment of a free, democratic and united Germany.

Indeterminate reformatory sentences were imposed yesterday on two former New York University students who had been described as "key figures" in a $100,000 swindle from the Washington Square N. Y. T. bookstore.
The United States Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed yesterday the espionage convictions of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for transmitting vital atom bomb secrets to Russia.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 25 -- The names of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Republican, and Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, were taken out of the Minnesota Presidential primary today by state officials. J. A. A. Burnquist, Attorney General, held invalid a section of the primary law preventing persons from withdrawing their names as candidates unless they signed an affidavit that they would not accept the Presidential nomination if it were offered to them.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Samuel Reshevsky of New York, former chess champion of the United States, today defeated Larry Evans of City College, who succeeded him as titleholder, in their game adjourned from last night's first-round session of the international tournament here.
Reports that New York was unlikely to benefit from its designation as a surplus labor area, entitled to special consideration on defense contracts, drew sharp protests from city officials yesterday.

Part of the slight recovery in the stock market last week fell prey to renewed selling yesterday. The composite rate slid back only 0.12 point, but several of the recent favorites, including Squibb and Northern Pacific, had losses well beyond a point.

Brig. Gen. Frank Leo Howley, retired, who faced the Russians as commandant of Berlin in the critical days of the airlift, has been named vice chancellor for university development of New York University.

The news of the French withdrawal from Hoabinh in Indo-China is calculated to give any informed reader a pang of anxiety. At the very least it is psychologically bad to have to retreat. There is a French saying, "Reculer pour mieux sauter" (Draw back in order to jump better), but it looks more like getting set for the heavy Vietminh assault on Hanoi that has been rumored.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, for the second time has called on the Justice Department to consider whether "action" should be taken against John P. Davies Jr., State Department official who in the past was connected with policy on China.

Three major airlines will soon move their flight operations from La Guardia Airport to New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, officials of the lines announced yesterday. Large-scale expansion of the facilities at Idlewild, which should make it the busiest airport in the world, are now under way.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Saul Wallen, Boston arbitrator, will serve as chairman of three panels being set up by the Wage Stabilization Board to hear disputes in the aluminum industry.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Wheat showed little capacity for holding rallies on the Board of Trade today, and there was considerable selling due to snowfall reported over most of the dry Southwest areas. However, the selling was not aggressive and the market held in a moderate range. Absence of any new export buying was a check on buying support.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 25 -- The need for medical students to understand more about the psychological and emotional aspects of the care of children, regardless of the type of illness, was emphasized today at the opening of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the American Orthopsychiatric Association.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Feb. 25 -- The Dutch-Indonesian conference, which is winding up here this week, is expected to avoid an outright deadlock on the West New Guinea question. This would be achieved by a compromise providing for the appointment of a bilateral study commission that would examine possible solutions between now and the Dutch elections next June.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 25 -- Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, today told a House subcommittee investigating the recent air crashes here that Newark Airport was safe, efficiently run and vital to the nation's economy and defense.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,171, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M. Monday) Eastern standard time:

Borrowing from the English this department suggests pancakes today for the Shrove Tuesday "feast" to precede Lenten fasting that begins tomorrow, Ash Wednesday. The custom of making hot cakes to dispose of the fat and eggs prohibited during the forty days of Lent dates from centuries back in England.

Employes of banking houses in the financial district from presidents to office boys donated 350 pints of blood yesterday to a mobile unit set up by the Greater New York Red Cross Blood Program in the great hall of the State Chamber of Commerce, 65 Liberty Street.

A total of $18,000 bail was set yesterday on Elezer Perle, 40 years old, of 381 Central Park West, owner of four tenements on West 104th Street in which it is charged there are forty-one violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law and City Building Code.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has taken over control of Glenn McCarthy's oil, gas and hotel holdings. Mr. McCarthy owes Equitable $34,100,000. The Shamrock Hotel in Houston, Tex., one of the nation's better known hostelries, also is involved in the financial transaction.

WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio, Feb. 25 -- In stretching out the aircraft program to fit the new budget pattern laid down by President Truman, the Air Force has pared peak production rates by one-third, on the average. Deeper cuts, involving such secondary sources as the automobile industry, range up to more than two-thirds.
The new one-way pattern in the Chelsea dock area started at 8 A. M. yesterday with one of the worst traffic snarls ever experienced in that normally congested sector.

A new collection of decorative accessories imported from France, suitable for use in the currently popular French Provincial interiors, is now available at Brunovan, Inc., 383 Madison Avenue. All are reproductions of traditional French pieces.

A sophomore substitute's one-handed jump-shot, nine seconds before the end of a thrill-packed overtime struggle lifted Notre Dame to a 75-74 victory over New York University before 7,111 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UP) -- President Truman nominated Frederick L. Anderson, a retired Army major general and business men, today to assist in the dispensing of United States aid in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Ellis G. Arnall took over his duties as head of the Office of Price Stabilization today.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 -- The defensive strength -- and if the need should arise the offensive strength -- of The fourteen-nation Atlantic alliance will be immeasurably increased in the not too distant future by the presence on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean of the latest and previously unused weapons of the United States.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- An otherwise dull market was enlivened here today by the activity in South African gold-mining shares.
The Treasury is planning to crack down on commercial banks that seek to circumvent the purpose of tax anticipation bills by buying them from their customers.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Feb. 25 -- The typewriter brigade is going full blast at Warner Brothers, where forty scenarists are preparing thirty-five properties for the cameras. Victor Herbert's operetta, "Mlle. Modiste," is being worked into screen play form by Harold Erickson and Irmgard von Cube, while Mr. Herbert's song, "Kiss Me Again," is serving as the basis for a musical story that is being written by Sig Herzig.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 25 -- The three major branches of the American rabbinate which constitute the National Jewish Welfare Board's Division of Religious Activities have undertaken to provide 147 full-time Jewish military chaplains in 1952, Rabbi Max D. Davidson of Perth Amboy, N. J., chairman of the division, announced here tonight.
OSLO, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Dr. Karl Evang, director general of public health in Norway, today demanded strong and united counter-action against "the use of dope in the amateur sports world."

BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Holy Cross registered a 75-70 upset victory tonight over St. John's of Brooklyn, a much higher ranking intercollegiate basketball power. Tufts squeezed out a 75-73 triumph over St. Michael's in the all-New England opener at the Boston Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Following is a summary by the Federal Reserve Board of percentage changes from last year in department store sales by cities for the weeks indicated:

Spring suits being modeled informally today through Friday on the third floor at Lord Taylor's were designed by some of the top names in fashion. Several used black linen, worsted or silk for their offerings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Because of an outbreak of hoof and mouth disease in Saskatchewan, the Department of Agriculture halted today all imports of livestock and fresh meats from Canada. Department experts said that it probably would be about a year before the ban could be lifted.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Government charged a Baltimore automobile company with overcharges on more than 200 sales today and indicated it is preparing a crackdown on car dealers across the nation.

Dean Albert D. Kirwan of the University of Kentucky and William (Bill) Spivey, voluntarily retired member of the school's basketball team, arrived in New York yesterday. The athlete m scheduled to appear this morning at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to be questioned in connection with the basketball fix inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Southern California Gas Company of Los Angeles filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the sale of $30,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series A, due April 1, 1982. The bonds are to be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

Four former firemen who turned state's evidence and helped to convict former First Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran as the manipulator of a $500,000-a-year fuel-oil shakedown racket received one - year penitentiary terms in General Sessions yesterday after prison terms as high as twenty-three years had been suspended.

The matron of the Isabella Home for the Aged for forty-five years Mrs. Anna yon Boetticher, now must become one of the "little old people" she's been mothering all these years. Now 81, Mrs. von Boetticher will attend her forty-sixth founder's birthday celebration tonight at the rambling old brick home at 190th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The British Navy is investigating all possible means of submarine propulsion, including nuclear energy. This was disclosed today as the three armed services published their latest figures on how increased defense appropriations are to be spent.

Women headed by Mrs. Frederick Lewis Chapman and Mrs. Charles Hurd, and including Mrs. Alfred B. Cornell, have been holding meetings recently in the Tea Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria to advance plans for the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Bargain Box to be held on April 1 in the Starlight Roof of the hotel.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Assembly killed tonight a bill that would have permitted newspapers to make "fair and true" reports of nonpublic judicial or legislative proceedings without being subject to libel actions.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Andy Pafko celebrated his thirty-first birthday and his first training trip to Florida by reporting to the Dodger camp today. With Duke Snider arriving late last night and Carl Furillo already on hand Manager Chuck Dressen now has his 1952 outfield ready for training.
A few days ago upstate several seemingly unconnected events occurred. A man went off to Schenectady to work in defense industry. A farmer sold thirty cows for what he could get.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -The National Production Authority will extend until April 1 its deadline for the junking of old cars in the hands of wreckers, the Agency announced today.

James J. Moran's perjury conviction in Federal Court was upheld unanimously yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. The one-time city official and political protege of former Mayor William O'Dwyer was found guilty of testifying falsely last March before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -Gil Turner's everrlailing fists brought the unbeaten Philadelphia welterweight star his twenty-ninth straight victory tonight, a unanimous 10-round decision over fastmoving but hopelessly outpunched Del Flanagan of St, Paul. Turner weighecl 147 and Flanagan 145 pounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- For the second time within five weeks, the Port of Philadelphia from Trenton, N. J., to Wilmington, Del., was tied up today by a dispute over extra pay for unloading damaged cargo.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Dr. L. E. C. Hughes, chairman of the Institute of Atomic Information, a nonofficial body, said tonight he did not think the United States would be able to make a hydrogen bomb, but that if one was exploded on a big scale it probably would be the end of the world.

For the seventh consecutive year the M. A. Hanna Company made a new high record with 1951 net profit totaling $14,081,108, equal to $13.30 a share on the old common and $4.43 a share on the present stock. Net profit the year before was $13, 073,515, or $12.32, a share.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 26 -- The Communists rejected this morning a new United Nations Command proposal for establishment of a neutral supervisory commission of only four nations instead of six to police the Korean armistice. They made a sharp protest that the Allied suggestion was an attempt to bar the Soviet Union from the commission without "tenable reasons."

The Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, largest passenger ship afloat, returned to New York last week after a six-weeks absence. In the interim the vessel had been dry-docked for fifty-four tides for her annual overhaul, and the results were readily apparent.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Senate tonight approved Governor Dewey's record $1,092,902,772 budget for the new fiscal year that starts April 1 without a single dissenting vote as Democrats warned the Republican majority that adequate provision must be made to enable New York City to balance its budget before the present session adjourns.

THE Green Book is the National League's counterpart to the American League's Red Book, each designed to acquaint the Gentlemen of the Press with all the facts and all the statistics before they depart for spring training. Dave Grote, the new editor, has added some flourishes which make this the best brochure the older circuit has published.
A new bill of two-a-day vaudeville, headed by Lauritz Melchior, the operatic and concert tenor, will open this afternoon at the Palace Theatre.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady, yesterday and closing prices were 9 to 46 points net higher than on Saturday, with old crop months showing the most strength.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Two leaders of the House of Representatives interrupted a debate on other subjects today to warn that Guatemala, situated on the strategic flanks of the United States and its South American neighbors, had become a "beachhead" of communism.
The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, put two new symphonies and a soloist who was formerly a member of this orchestra on its program last night in Carnegie Hall.

For the third successive year, the world championship bridge team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee, all of New York, together with John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, is making its bid for the Vanderbilt Cup team-of-four national championship.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Assembly approved unanimously and sent to Governor Dewey tonight a bill enabling the City of New York to take title to the Brooklyn Academy of Music and establish a permanent civic and cultural center there.

While Congress-baiting may be one of the favorite indoor sports of the American people the truth is that Congress is as good or as bad as we, the people, choose to make it. Congress is literally the living embodiment of the American democracy; and if we value our democracy as much as we think we do, and as much as we say we do, we must constantly be alert to the quality of the Congress.

Crude rubber futures trading, most important in the Commodity Exchange, which was suspended March 31, 1951, will be resumed next Monday. Active months will be September and December, 1952, and March and May, 1953. The Commodity Exchange contract calls for delivery of ten tons of No. 1 standard quality ribbed smoked sheets.
The membership of the Medical Society of the County of New York last night rejected by a voice vote a resolution requesting that Federal social security benefits be extended to physicians.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Even with March 15 creeping closer, many taxpayers are finding they can smile contentedly when they view a hundred new economies being put into effect at Fort Slocum's eighty-eight acres of buildings and grounds on an island here in Long Island Sound.
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The text of a final communique of the ninth North Atlantic Council meeting and of a declaration of aims follows:

OTTAWA, Feb. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's thriving $2,000,000,000 livestock industry was struck a crippling blow today with the announcement of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Saskatchewan.
LeGrand L. Thurber has been appointed assistant sales manager of the electric typewriter division of International Business Machines Corporation. He previously was manager at Detroit.

The season of Lent will open tomorrow, Ash Wednesday, with services of contemplation in most of the evangelical and liturgical churches in this community. Daily services, often with visiting ministers occupying the pulpit, joint neighborhood services and special study groups have been scheduled to continue through the Lenten period ending on Easter Sunday, April 13.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Possible recall of H. Merle Cochran as United States Ambassador to Indonesia was under discussion at the State Department today following resignation of the Indonesian coalition Cabinet in protest against a secretly negotiated military aid agreement with the United States.

Television and appliance advertising has improved in quality since the Better Business Bureau of New York City announced its voluntary standards for such advertising two weeks ago. Under the plan the bureau writes a registered letter to those advertisers violating any provision of the standards, and a copy is sent to the publication involved.

Several authorities on tuberculosis sounded a warning yesterday at a conference at the New York Academy of Medicine against premature conclusions about the value of the new anti-tuberculosis drug reported last week. The conference was held under the auspices of the Medical Society of the County of New York, and preceded a regularly scheduled round-table in the evening on the modern treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis.

It usually' seems a shame to put a new, modern work at the end of a concert, as the Mannes-Gimpel-Sylva Trio did last night in Town Hall. The audience is tired, if the earlier part of the program has been substantial, and not receptive to the concentrated expression of contemporary music.
OSLO, Feb. 25 (UP) -- The 1952 Winter Olympics formally ended tonight in a blaze of pageantry and a chilly snub of the unpopular United States hockey team.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. charged tonight that Governor Dewey had "cold shouldered" permanent personal registration of voters to "buy off" Senator Robert A. Taft's supporters and aid General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower as a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination.

CAIRO, Feb. 25 -- Premier Aly Maher Pasha announced to the Egyptian nation today the beginning of negotiations with Britain for the solution of the Anglo-Egyptian conflict over the British garrison in the Suez Canal zone and the future of the Sudan. He revealed that the first of these conversations, with British Ambassador Sir Ralph Stevenson, will take place Saturday.
LOCUST, N. J., Feb. 25 (AP) -For a long half-hour today, a 39-year-old mother, who jumped into a ten-foot well after her 4-year-old son, calmly recited nursery rhymes until help came.

OSLO, Feb. 25 (UP) -- An American Olympic skier who secretly married a team-mate planned to return home with the prospect that he would wear a deckhand's dungarees. The Navy indicated in Washington that Alvin Paul Wegeman would be discharge from the Naval Aviation Cadet program because his marriage violated his enlistment oath.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -The Bell System Telephone Company received today Federal approval to spend $60,000,000 in 1952 on new intercity connections for telephone and telegraph service and television relay. The authority was issued by the Federal Communications Commission.

ATHENS, Feb. 25 -- Nicholas Beloyannis, 34 years old, admitted today to a military court before which he and twenty-eight others are on trial for treason, that he was a Communist and proud of being one. He said he had re-entered Greece for the express purpose of organizing a subversive movement the purpose of which was to bring his country under Soviet domination.
The following book, published today, will be of interest to the antique collector:

George J. Smythe, 26-year-old former Marine who was wounded on Iwo Jima in World War II, headed a line of 175 blood donors yesterday at the Western Union Company headquarters, 60 Hudson Street. It was the third time Western Union personnel have made mass donations in the American Red Cross blood program.

A few unhappy families reluctantly left their homes in 25 West 104th Street yesterday, in compliance with an order issued by the Department of Housing and Buildings finding the place "unfit for human habitation and dangerous to life and health."
The annual entertainment, known as the spring frolic and tea dance, will be held on the afternoon of April 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York.

Oscar, a whale so small that Jonah could have swallowed him like a college sophomore swallowing goldfish, will smile out of his jar of alcohol at visitors to the Museum of Natural History beginning today.

Mrs. Sadye S. Reiss, president of the Community Council of School Districts 18, 19 and 20, the Bronx, urged yesterday that steel be released to construct the new West Farms branch of the Public Library on Honeywell Avenue near East 180th Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore of Johns Hopkins University accused the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today of suppression and distortion of evidence and of welcoming "stacked" testimony that was destroying innocent men and jeopardizing this country.

In the largest exercise of its kind since World War II, the Navy will begin operations today on Convex III, aimed at protecting merchant shipping under "wartime conditions" from New York to Key West, Fla.
A proclamation issued at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri called on civic, welfare and business groups, the press, radio and television to cooperate in the observance of Harlem Day tomorrow.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The discussion of financial projects, including a 15 per cent tax increase resulting from the North Atlantic Treaty arms talks in Lisbon, had an unfavorable start tonight when the French National Assembly broke off a debate that had been scheduled to continue through the night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan named a five-man committee today to select a Federal employe to receive the 1952 William A. Jump Memorial Award for outstanding Government service.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 26 -- The Minnesota Supreme Court today ordered hearings Thursday on legal actions to take General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's name off the Republican ballot in the State Presidential primary election March 18 and to reinstate the name of Senator Estes Kefauver on the Democratic ballot.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- May the Post Office Department issue on Thursday a 3-cent stamp commemorating the 125th anniversary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, urged the House of Representatives today to pass the Administration bill to permit early initiation of Universal Military Training on the ground that "its enactment may shape the destiny of this nation and possibly the peace of the world for the rest of this century."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Telemeter, a new development in subscription television for the home, in which Paramount Pictures Corporation holds 50 per cent ownership, was demonstrated here today for more than four hours over open and closed circuits through the facilities of KCLA, the Paramount-owned television station in Los Angeles.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Prime Minister Churchill asserted in the House of Commons today that in promising that Britain's reaction to any breach of a truce in Korea would be "prompt, resolute and effective," he was merely giving voice in public to secret commitments made to the United States by former Prime Minister Clement Attlee and Herbert Morrison, former Foreign Secretary, during the life of the Labor Government.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The State Department of Commerce today listed the following winter sports conditions at New York resorts:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Truman Administration is "assuming" in its spending program that the Korean fighting will end by the middle of this year and that there will be no further war involving the United States for at least a year thereafter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, blamed Texas laws today for some of the Government's multi-million-dollar grain storage losses and urged the state to plug legal loopholes.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 26 -- In the first uncertain light of dawn today the largest armada to be assembled in these waters since the end of World War II was on the move from a score of Mediterranean ports to participate in "Exercise Grand Slam."

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- The United States should issue a warning that it will not tolerate armed intervention in the states of Central and Eastern Europe and thus encourage dissident elements there to throw off Soviet domination, a United States labor spokesman declared today.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- With three votes to spare, the Senate approved and sent to the Governor today a bill to permit the continuance of work relief projects in New York City after next July 1. The vote was 32 to 20.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 26 -- George Yeh, the Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, and Isao Kawada, the Japanese plenipotentiary, met for one and one-half hours today to seek a compromise formula that would break the logjam on the slow-moving Chinese-Japanese "peace treaty" talks here.

A proposed amendment to the zoning law which would compel existing large buildings used for retail, wholesale, manufacturing and storage purposes to install off-street loading berths for trucks by Jan. 1, 1957, came under the fire of representatives of civic and business associations and department stores yesterday at a public hearing in City Hall.
The Palace, where Judy Garland and two-a-day vaudeville made their simultaneous comebacks recently, began presenting its second bill yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Federal Mediation Service here announced late today that shipping and union representatives had agreed to meet at 11 A. M., Eastern standard time, tomorrow to discuss possible settlement of a tie-up along the Philadelphia waterfront that has lasted two days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia indicated a plainly receptive attitude today to efforts in his home state to "draft" him for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Amid widespread signs among leaders from Georgia that he would be called, he pointedly did not exclude an acceptance.

Distribution of debt securities within the present framework of the Securities Act of 1933 could be improved substantially by simplifying the registration requirements for investment grade securities, James Coggeshall Jr., president of the First Boston Corporation, said yesterday in a report to the investment banking concern's 8,000 stockholders.

Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, sharply criticized yesterday the owners of an apartment house at 300 Park Avenue near Forty-ninth Street for disregarding the law by renting space to commercial tenants before obtaining city permission.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 -- The Strong Manufacturing Company of Sebring, Ohio, has decided to sell out because, it says, it could not settle a strike. The concern manufactures porcelain enamelware.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California tonight called for Government programs to bolster agricultural economy and safeguard farm prices from collapse.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (UP) Gay New Orleans heralded the midnight advent of Lent today with wild and riotous Mardi Gras pageantry that produced scores of sore heads from coconuts and hangovers and lost children by the dozens.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 -- The United States, British and French Governments announced tonight that they had reached full agreement with West Germany on the German financial contribution to mutual Western defense until at least July 1, 1953. That contribution was approximately $202,000,000 a month until that time.

It doesn't look as if there'll be a subway circuit season to entertain the neighborhood trade at rock-bottom prices during the summer. Not unless George Brandt, who has been operating the Windsor (Bronx) and Flatbush (Brooklyn), changes his present stand.

Certain earthy characteristics inherent in the Belgian people apparently make socialism or even excessive Government economic controls impossible in Belgium. Louis Camu said this yesterday in a talk before the Belgian Chamber of Commerce in the United States at the St. Regis Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- There is no more tragic aspect of the prolonged armistice negotiations in Korea than the plight of the prisoners of war, and yet there is perhaps no issue in the armistice talks that is so misunderstood here at home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The State Department expressed "full confidence" today in H. Merle Cochran, its Ambassador to Indonesia, and said he had acted "in accordance with the department's instructions" in negotiating a secret military aid agreement with the fledgling republic.

At no time during the recent panel hearings on the steel wage dispute have we attempted to pass on the merits of the issues as they concerned the steel union vis-a-vis the industry. Instead, we have emphasized two basic, if fairly obvious, underlying facts of the situation.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 26 -- Fears were expressed today by a highly placed official of the German Evangelical Church that statements currently being made in the United States by the Rev. Martin Niemoeller might persuade the public in the United States that the church opposed rearmament.

The New York City Ballet last night presented the premiere of Antony Tudor's "La Gloire" at the City Center, and with all the goodwill in the world it is impossible to report very happily upon it this morning.

The confused situation confronting the Boston Maine Railroad as a result of the litigation concerning the road's stock modification plan prompted directors yesterday to take no dividend action at this time, according to E. S. French, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee is trying to devise an automatic plan to suspend price controls on items selling below ceilings and restore the controls if prices shoot up again.

Representative Francis E. Walter of Pennsylvania, chairman of the House subcommittee on immigration and naturalization, has challenged statements by Dr. Israel Goldstein about the Walter immigration pending in the House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Dr. Walter P. Schreiber, a former officer in the German Medical Corps who has been accused by a group of Boston doctors of having been an "accessory" to German atrocities in World War II, was dropped today from the payroll of the Air Force on direct word from Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 26 -- Twenty-three Protestant churches with white congregations said in a report issued today they would not accept members of other races as visitors at their services.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "This Woman Is Dangerous," a Warner Brothers romantic drama starring Joan Crawford and Dennis Morgan, is at the Paramount. Felix Feist directed and Robert Sisk produced from a script by Geoffrey Homes and George Washington Yates and a story by Bernard Girard.

James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., demanded yesterday that General Electric and Westinghouse pay interest to their workers on $15,000,000 in wage increases stalled by delays in Wage Stabilization Board approval.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26 -- The Communist party of Yugoslavia had decided to purge politically unreliable public school teachers and key personnel in industry and trade as one of the first measures designed to implement the recent shift of the party line to the left

GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 26 -- An electronically operated ultrahigh - speed printer, capable of printing the entire text of "Gone With the Wind" in two hours from magnetic tape, was demonstrated here today with the first production unit of the machine.

Mortgage institutions and lending agencies hold the key position in determining the future trend of growth in our cities, through their wise or unwise policies in approving building financing, according to Robert Dowling, president of the City Investing Company.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,172, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Wednesday (4 P. M., Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

The impact of increased taxation was reflected in the net earnings of the United Fruit Company, which declined last year to $50,893,898, or $5.79 a share, from $66,159,375, or $7.53 a share earned in 1950, according to the fifty-second annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., announced yesterday it would head the group that will construct an $11,000,000 dam on the Sakarya River in northwest Turkey. It is the first step of the $35,000,000 Sariyar hydroelectric project financed by Economic Cooperation Administration funds through the Eti Bank of the Turkish Government.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- The grain-price structure crumbled today under a wave of liquidating sales, which found no adequate opposition. Recent investment buyers turned sellers as they registered disappointment over the unsatisfactory action of the market.

A faulty altimeter and a fog pocket distorting visibility were advanced as possible causes of the crash of a Northeast Airlines plane into Flushing Bay just short of La Guardia Airport on Jan. 14 by witnesses testifying here yesterday before a Civil Aeronautics Board inquiry panel.
Fort Worth, Tex., sold yesterday issues of revenue and general obligation bonds totaling $7,750,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb.26 (UP) -- President Truman elevated Donald Cook today from vice chairman to chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, succeeding Harry A. McDonald, who took over as chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- Instead of the usual six, there were nine sets of pay-off figures on the result board after the running of today's feature race at Hialeah. Three horses finished in a dead heat for place, so that the calculators in the mutuel room had to figure out four returns for place and four for show.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The Coronation Stone, the Stone of Scone, dramatically stolen by Scottish nationalists more than a year ago, was quietly restored to its traditional place this afternoon in the Coronation Chair in Westminster Abbey.

Politics of a Presidential election year is laying a heavy hand on the legislative process at Albany. The session did not begin until Jan. 9, the latest constitutional date, but Republican leaders are standing by their intention to clear all business before March 15.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 26 -- Political independence seemed within West Germany's grasp tonight as a result of far-reaching decisions announced here and in Lisbon, Portugal, on the Federal Republic's defense contribution.

Three hours after taking off by air at 12:17 A. M. yesterday for a month's vacation, Miss Harriet E. Basch, a retired city school teacher, was pronounced dead at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from where she had departed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 26 -- The way a prospective mother feels about pregnancy and motherhood is likely to be "significantly related" to her emotional and physical adjustment in the prenatal period and to her later relationship to the child.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 26 -- Under Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's lead, the victorious Congress party has decided to attempt to form governments in all states, including those where Congress ministries might be upset by opposition coalitions led by the Communists.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 26 -- The French - Vietnamese troops that were evacuated last week-end from the Hoabinh sector have already been deployed in new assignments in the Tongking Delta according to reports reaching here today from Hanoi.

ATHENS, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Findings of the Greek military court now investigating charges of espionage against twenty-nine persons connected with the outlawed Greek Communist party will be referred to the United Nations, well-informed Greek circles said today.

The Belgian Government will raise in April a loan equivalent to $20,000,000 for the use of other countries in the European Payments Union, Louis Camu, vice chairman of the Banque de Bruxelles, declared here yesterday.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 -- The North Atlantic Council has accepted new and broader responsibilities for the expansion and liberalization of trade and for solving the problem of the maldistribution of manpower in Europe.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 -- George W. Perkins, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, who attended the North Atlantic Treaty Organization parley, will fly tomorrow to Madrid for a brief visit, during which he will discuss with Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo a wide range of subjects affecting Spanish-United States relations.

Directors of United Air Lines voted yesterday to offer the company's common shareholders about 224,000 shares of cumulative convertible $100 par value preferred stock at the rate of one share of preferred for each eleven shares of common.
A spring fashion story of line, fabric and color was told yesterday at Martin's in Brooklyn.

THE letter arrived yesterday from Baton Rouge, La. The letter writer stated that he was bidding farewell to sports after eighteen years and offered a word of thanks for the many nice things that had been said about him in this space, an unprecedented gesture. It was signed by Ed McKeever.

WEST NYACK, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Rockland County railroad commuters learned today that monthly commutation rates would be increased 11 to more than 30 per cent effective Saturday except on the three Erie lines, where commuters may purchase tickets for March through Wednesday at the old rate.

Investment banking syndicates competed at public sealed bidding yesterday for the award of new issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $12,675,000 in par value. In another public bidding transaction, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation sold to bankers $8,700,605 of outstanding 4 1/2 per cent income bonds of the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Superior Court dismissed today two $50,000,000 libel suits growing out of articles published about the Tucker Corporation, which was formed to build a rear-engine automobile.

The New York Rangers, unbeaten in their last four games, suffered a blow yesterday when it was learned that Jack Stoddard, rookie right winger, fractured his right wrist in a practice session and will be lost to the club for the remainder of the season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council will open its tenth session tomorrow at 11 A. M. It will meet for the first time in the newly completed Trusteeship Council chamber. The multi-colored room was designed by the Danish Government.

With the city in the midst of a measles epidemic, the Department of Health announced yesterday that it had published leaflets for public distribution advising parents what to do to protect their children in the present emergency.

More merchant tonnage went down the ways of world shipyards in 1951 than in any other non-war year since 1921 and the volume launched in Great Britain and Northern Ireland alone was larger than in any year since 1930, including the war years.

" Freedom is more endangered now than it has been for centuries," Dr. Henry Steele Commager, Professor of History at Columbia University, and Edgar Ansel Mowrer, former foreign correspondent, declared yesterday. They discussed "What Do We Mean By Freedom?" at a luncheon arranged by Freedom House and the Town Hall Club at the latter's center.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The United States and Japan ironed out their last differences yesterday and agreed on the operation of a security pact binding the two countries after the peace treaty is ratified.

General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein observed yesterday that the "crime of perjury is much too prevalent in the courts and before official investigating bodies," as he sentenced Henry D. McEvoy, 63-year-old former member of the Board of Smoke Control, to a six-month penitentiary term.

The second annual National Transport Vehicle Show and Fleet Maintenance Exposition opened last night with a display of more than 400 exhibits at the 212th Regiment Armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue. The show includes exhibits ranging from oil filters to air-operated riveting machines.

CAIRO, Feb. 26 -- Syria is adopting new methods to turn into constructive channels destructive energies of Arab students which find an outlet in demonstrations and political riots that are a constant menace to public order.

The Radio Corporation of America paid twice as much in taxes last year as it earned for stockholders, according to its annual report, issued yesterday. Despite record sales of $598, 955,000 in 1951, net profit declined to $31,193,000 from $46,250,000 the year before. The company's tax bill for the year amounted to $62,389,000.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- Five of witnesses called before a House Un-American Activities subcommittee here today refused to answer questions bearing on their relations with or attitude toward the Communist party. All five based their refusal on the Constitution guarantee against self-incrimination.

The prisoner-of-war question in Korea presents a challenge to our morality which we must not fail to face. To repatriate those prisoners of war who have openly and sincerely expressed their aversion to the Communist regime would be tantamount to delivering our friends to death at the hand of our common enemy.

MANY salmon anglers of limited means who canceled fishing trips to New Brunswick last season because of the regulation requiring non-resident anglers to employ a guide may return this season without worrying about the regulation, unless they plan fishing from a boat.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Britain has developed her own atomic bomb and has the plant to insure its regular production, Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today. He sug gested that, as a result, the United States was more amenable than formerly to the idea of an exchange of information about the progress of research into nuclear fission.
New shades, keyed to color combinations popular in contemporary room decoration, have been used in some of the new collection of about 500 Navajo wool rugs now on view at Altman's.

Brenda Lewis, American soprano, sang at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time last night and proved at once that she was a good artist. Her role was Musetta in "Boheme," and she gave the part a likable, spirited quality, which is just what Puccini and his librettists intended and which is more difficult to do than some people may think.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The newspaper El Mercurio quotes an authoritative source as saying Chile will renounce an agreement with American mining companies under which it sells a portion of its copper production on the world market.

A new Bureau of Labor Statistics wholesale price index, the measure of how much and how rapidly basic prices rise and fall, will appear this week. Ewan Clague, commissioner of labor statistics for the Department of Commerce, announced yesterday that a new figure, for Dec. 31, 1951, and the factor linking the old index with the new, will be published on Friday.
Capt. Robert C. Jones was installed yesterday as director of Church Army, an evangelistic and missionary agency within the Protestant Episcopal Church.

A 37-year-old armed bank robber was seized early yesterday morning by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents when he stepped from a West Coast plane at La Guardia Airport, fifteen hours after he is said to have robbed a Los Angeles bank of $19,628.
