ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Mrs. John P. Adam's Argentine horse, Miche, emerged from a slump today to win the $7,500 feature race at Santa Anita Park and the stable probably will take a chance with him in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap Saturday.
Tuition fees at New York University are to be raised by 14 to 30 per cent, Chancellor Henry T. Heald announced yesterday.

The American Bar Association has decided not to approve at this time what seemed two or three years ago a promising attempt to encourage the international movement of news. This is the so-called Covenant on the International Transmission of News and the Right of Correction, adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on May 14, 1949.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 26 -- Yesterday, the last day of the NATO conference, a group of American correspondents was briefed on the financial aspects of the Mutual Security Program by Ambassadors David Bruce, who is just leaving his post in Paris to be Under Secretary of State, and William Draper, who is just assuming the job of director of the Mutual Security Agency in Europe.

Spurning the entreaties of four policemen and a passing priest who pleaded with him for twenty-five minutes to return to safety, a man tentatively identified as Clerence Sims, 25 years old, of 222 West 114th Street, in the lower Harlem district of Manhattan, dropped 240 feet into the Hudson River from a point in the middle of the George Washington Bridge at 12:50 A. M. today. His body was being sought early this morning.

The stock market came under renewed selling pressure yesterday, magnified by absence of support. In the smallest volume since the first session of the year, prices melted in all of the principal divisions, the combined averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES index slumping an even point.

Against a sturdier foe, Columbia might have been in trouble last night on its home floor, but Yale's zone defense and retreating offense were not strong enough to harass Lu Rossini's Lions, who captured the Eastern Basketball League contest, 69 -- 62.
YOKOHAMA, Japan, Wednesday, Feb. 27 -- Four United States destroyers, veterans of the Korean war, slipped away from their berths at dawn this morning for a trip around the world "to show the flag."

PHOENIX, Feb. 26 -- Bigger than ever physically and better from a mental standpoint, with a mind eased of past worries, Sal Maglie today launched the preparatory grind for what he confidently expects will be his third straight "big" year as a Giant pitcher, with at least twenty victories as his goal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Efforts to set aside Speaker Sam Rayburn's ruling against televising or broadcasting House committee proceedings got under way today with little prospect of success.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Twelve of the eighteen Republican National Convention delegates selected yesterday by the state party's executive committee said today that they favored Senator Robert A. Taft for President.

OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canada faced a national crisis tonight as an international meat and livestock embargo that resulted from an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease was extended to trade between provinces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's administration in New York, putting the state on record for the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project for the tenth time in twenty years, asked Congress today for protection against a Federal power grab.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 26 -- Segregation is discrimination and fosters feelings of inferiority, three witnesses from New York told a three-judge Federal Court here today. They testified during the second day of a hearing in which the legality of Virginia's provision for separate schools for white and Negro students was being challenged directly for the first time.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- F. Eugene Ackerman of New York, president of The Wool Bureau, Inc., told the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers today that "the men's wear market is probably one of the most undersold in the country."

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, who indicated last week that he might be willing to run for Mayor with a "cleaned up" Democratic party, yesterday avoided saying whether he had definite aspirations for the Mayoralty.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 39 to 76 points lower. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange was closed for the Mardi Gras holiday.

The strike threat that hovered over the eight East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company was eased yesterday when the shipyard workers' union agreed to continue the present contract extension through March 30, contingent upon the company's continuance of "good faith" bargaining.

The American scientist, Frederick Gardner Cottrell, who died in 1948, is the subject of a biography by Frank Cameron, which Doubleday will publish March 6 under the title, "Cottrell: Samaritan of Science." It is a story of the man who conceived new techniques for making cheap fertilizers, soaps, vitamins and building materials, for producing helium and for rocket propulsion.

The Mutual Security Agency's plan for giving European workers a year's shop experience combined with collateral adult educational advantages in the United States has far-reaching possibilities. Already some three hundred to four hundred workers have been settled in a number of cities where joint committees comprising spokesmen for labor, management and sponsoring educational institutions, with M. S. A. cooperation, have provided jobs and housing.

" Convertibles" received a round of applause at the custom-made collection presented yesterday by Oldric Royce, 16 East Fifty-second Street. These were coat-type dresses, which, for more formal occasions, folded back to show panels of fabric.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The President's Airport Commission took up today its assignment to study the complex safety problems confronting the country's air terminals and to recommend immediate and long range solutions.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (AP) -- 3o Stafford, adio singer, was1 marr/ed today to Paul Weston,[ composer and her musical arrang-] er for the last six years. Father! Joseph Kearney performed the1 ceremony in St. Gregory's Roman{ Catholic church. The couple] planned to leave immediately for1 a wedding trip in Europe. It isI th second marriage for Miss Staf- ford.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 27 -- United Nations and Communist staff officers at Panmunjom met for fifteen minutes today and then adjourned, still tightly deadlocked over the enemy's refusal to accept a compromise proposal that would have banned the Soviet Union as one of the "neutral" nations to be designated to police a cease-fire in Korea.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 (UP) -- A scientist was charged today in a Federal grand jury indictment with perjury when he denied he and James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue, tried to get William M. Boyle Jr., former Democratic National Chairman, a $1,000,000 fee for handling an income tax case.

Many parties were given at the Mardi Gras Ball, held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the New York Junior League's welfare fund. Mrs. Thomas D. Luckenbill, chairman of the committee for the fete, headed the reception committee.

Several occurrences of late have been noted with interest by an untold number of thousands of people. Most poignant, perhaps, was the departure from this metropolis of a group of pathetic individuals whose way of life has forced them to substitute the enervating climate, at this time of year, of such places as Arizona and Florida for the robust splendors of a New York February.

Negotiations for the sale of the gas properties of the New England Electric System for $22,780,000 to a group of New York investment bankers have reached an impasse, it was learned yesterday. A hearing scheduled to be held before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the proposed sale was adjourned, subject to recall by a trial examiner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee formally urged the Senate today to give its consent to early ratification of the Japanese peace treaty and the three associated security pacts to create a democratic defensive alliance in the Pacific.

W. R. Grace Co. yesterday carried its long pending fight with Pan American World Airways over their jointly owned Pan American-Grace Airways to both the New York State courts and the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington. In both proceedings Grace seeks to compel the airline to arbitrate their differences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The National Production Authority today broadened the scope of its construction restrictions to permit the completion of another $186,000,000 worth of commercial building throughout the country. The action makes it possible to finish some 186 structures on which less than 20 per cent of the work had been completed when building curbs were imposed and is a reflection of the general easing in the structural steel supply situation.
DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 26 -- If Dallas were shiftless enough to depend on Broadway for its theatre culture, the citizenry would have to spend its evenings at home.

Mrs. Carmen Rodriguez, petite and pretty home economist, probably could hold the interest of any audience when. she lectures on nutrition. But the Puerto Rican housewives who will gather this afternoon at Public School 54 in the Bronx to hear her talk on "Better Food for Less Money," will be particularly captivated.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Jackie Jensen, the husky Californian who figures to play a prominent part in Casey Stengel's revamped 1952 outfield, attended his first Yankee workout today and his appearance was the signal for a barrage of extraordinary explanations, which, as Yogi Berra might express it, "left nobody feelin' hurt at nobody."
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Assembly approved unanimously today and sent to Governor Dewey a bill enabling Nassau County to set up a system under which traffic violation fines could be paid by mail.

The Knights of Columbus meet, to be held Saturday night, usually closes the Madison Square Garden track and field season. But this year Don Gehrmann, Fred Wilt and other national stars will have another chance on the Eighth Avenue arena boards.
I have followed your editorials with admiration and deep respect, particularly those purporting to arouse interest in better citizenship and better leadership.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A measure designed to help cities ease traffic congestion by restricting heavy vehicles to designated truck routes was approved without dissent in the Assembly today. It now goes to the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A one-handed stab by Dick Harter with a minute and 28 seconds remaining gave the Penn Quakers a thrilling 67-66 basketball victory over the Irish of Notre Dame tonight in the second game of a Palestra double-header before 4,337.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Robert Ardrey's novel, "The Brotherhood of Fear," published early this year, has been purchased for Twentieth Century-Fox by Julian Blaustein, executive producer. He also has engaged the services of the author to write the screen play, and Mr. Ardrey is scheduled to check into the studio in June to commence this work.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The announcement that the Agricultural Mortgage Corporation again was raising interest rates for loans to farmers, from 4 3/4 per cent to 5 1/2 per cent, revived dearer money fears on the stock exchange today. The announcement was taken as a signal for resumption of selling of British Government securities which fell ten shillings ($1.40) or more.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- After rising steadily since last August, the Government's new consumer price index stood still from mid-December to mid-January, but the old index, to which most wage escalator clauses are tied, went up one-tenth of 1 per cent, or two-tenths of an index point, from 190 to 190.2.
Realty operators were active over a wide area in Manhattan in transactions reported yesterday.
Consider the qualifications most desirable for a President. First he must have the confidence of the people in his character; without that he cannot lead, whatever his other qualities may be.

The Tammany members of the City Council demanded yesterday a flat guarantee from the Republican-controlled State Legislature that it would pass the proposed county real estate tax bill before the city authorities were put in the position of formally asking for the measure.

ALBANY, Feb, 26 -- Governor Dewey's record executive budget, as increased from $1,092,760,887 to $1,092,902,772 by Senate amendments, received final legislative approval in the Assembly today. Except for four Democrats from upstate districts who were recorded only as present, the vote on the appropriation bills involved was unanimous.

The International Business Machines Corporation earned last year $77,292,089 before taxes, an increase of $16,190,781 over the pre-tax income of $61,101,308 in 1950. After deducting $49,400,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, the 1951 net income declined to $27,892,089 from $33,301,308 the year before, when the tax bill was $21,600,000 less.
Speaker Sam Rayburn's sudden ban on television and radio coverage of the hearings of House committees brings to the fore a basic question that cannot be evaded.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 -- Dr. Willard E. Goslin, center of an educational storm on the West Coast in 1950, received tonight the American Education Award for 1952 of the associated exhibitors of the National Education Association. The presentation was at a regional meeting of the American Association of School Administrators.

Unusual antiques, including twenty-two trunks of women's clothes dating to the turn of the century, will be offered for sale at a special booth, to be maintained for the benefit of the East Side House Settlement and the Stepney Camp Committee at the annual National Antiques Show from March 10 to 16 at Madison Square Garden.

To have or not to have an atomic bomb makes a lot of difference in our tense era. Prime Minister Churchill's revelation in the House of Commons yesterday that Great Britain has not only had the bomb but also the plant to produce a regular line of them is a power factor of considerable importance.

Dr. Willard F. Libby, University of Chicago scientist who in 1949 evolved a method for determining the age of archaeological items by dating their radiocarbon content, exhibited some of the 250 samples he has measured last night. Dr. Libby showed a satchelful of old shoes, mummy cloths, rope and assorted wood slivers wrapped in modern pliofilm to 150 scientists and their wives gathered to honor him at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LE HAVRE, France, Feb. 26 -- (Reuters) -- An imaginative middle-aged Frenchman, tired of life in Europe, bluffed his way through a free transatlantic roundtrip to New York by wearing a steward's jacket when he got on and off a luxury liner, it was disclosed in court here today.
Plant diseases and other non-industrial factors sometimes cause crop damage for which blame is wrongly put on air pollution by industry, the Manufacturing Chemists Association was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The House of Representatives, by a standing vote of 162 -- 10, passed and returned to the Senate today the anti-wetback bill, designed to curb or shut off wholesale illegal entry of aliens into the United States.
Galen M. Sollenberger has been appointed manager of defense sales for the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, Toledo, Ohio, and George E. Hill Jr. has been named industrial safety glass manager.
That distinguished virtuoso and musician Robert Casadesus elected to play a program consisting mainly of familiar masterpieces of piano music last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The House Judiciary subcommittee that will investigate the Department of Justice is divided as to when it should question Attorney General J. Howard McGrath on the conduct of his department and angry over a "roadblock" that it feels has prevented it from obtaining space for its operations.

Scoring in streaks, St. Francis College defeated Brooklyn College, 61 -- 51, last night at the Flatbush Court. Brooklyn made a determined effort for three periods before the Terriers' last spurt put the basketball game out of the Kingsmen's reach.

ATHENS, Feb. 26 -- Dimitrius Batsis, one of the twenty-nine persons standing trial for espionage before an Athens military court admitted today he had received money from the Communist party organization behind the iron curtain and had distributed it among Communist operatives within Greece.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 -- John Lautner, Hungarian-born New Yorker who recently testified in Washington regarding inner workings of the Communist party, took the witness stand today as the Government's third witness against fifteen California Communist leaders charged with conspiring to teach and advocate forceful overthrow of the Government.

Step-up of defense measures and increased exports to close the dollar gap spell out another austerity program for consumers in Great Britain. This was the consensus of a team of British retailers here for a six-week tour of principal cities to study American methods.

CAIRO, Feb. 26 -- Egyptian political circles appeared today to be squarely behind Premier Aly Maher Pasha, who said yesterday he would insist that the British discuss the ways and means of evacuating their troops from the Suez Canal area and unity of the Nile Valley instead of merely the principle of evacuation.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 26 -- A dispute among officials here over $100 uniform allowance for the police and firemen is threatening to scuttle this city's $7,000,000 municipal government operation.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 26 -- Moving along with a number of its Brooklyn customers who have found new homes on Long Island, Abraham Straus gave a private showing today of its new suburban unit on Fulton Avenue here. The great glass doors of A. S. Nassau will not be opened to the public until Thursday.

Sixty nations have now signed agreements with the United States for military or economic aid under the Mutual Security Act. However, because of some unnecessarily rigid provisions of that act, trouble has arisen in the case of ten nations which are also in need of aid but which for one reason or another have felt themselves unable to comply with all the conditions laid down for it.
Except for domestic sugar, commodity prices moved lower yesterday, with the heaviest relative losses in vegetable oils, wool and cocoa.

KEENE, N. H., Feb. 26 -- Senator James H. Duff of Pennsylvania asserted tonight that scurrilous publications bordering on "Hitlerian technique" were being used against all Republican candidates for President except Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Senate public health committee approved today the Metcalf bill to permit the requisitioning of animals from publicly-aided pounds for medical research, thus clearing the way for legislative action on the controversial bill in both houses of the Legislature.

The 105-year-old Food Trades Vocational High School Annex, which was vacated by 500 students Monday after a teacher reported the slight buckling of a wooden pillar in the auditorium, was declared to be safe for occupancy yesterday.

Summer and bachelors may have had something to do this. Pacific Mills reports production of contour sheets last year failed to keep pace with demand. These are the sheets which have tailored corners and fit over mattresses without tucking, thus doing away with a chore that has baffled many a man otherwise handy around the house.

Five teen-age high school students of the metropolitan area agreed yesterday that the first line of defense in any country against fascism and communism was a well-informed public. The students made their comments at a New York Times Youth Forum in Forest Hills High School in Queens.

Patronage shakedowns, perjury and illegal use of official powers were charged against four former Staten Island political leaders and office holders in two indictments and a presentment handed up yesterday by a special grand jury that has been investigating crime and official corruption on the island.

Svetozar Gligoric, who captained the victorious team of Yugoslavia in the international team tournament, was leading at the close of play in the invitation chess masters tournament at the Casino Espanol yesterday, according to reports from Havana.

Early yesterday morning at the close of a slowly played fifty-six board final match at the Pierre Hotel, the all-Bronx contract bridge team of Ned Drucker, Sidney Mandell, Jesse Sloan, Milton Moss and Irving Kass was declared the winner of the 1952 Vanderbilt Cup Team-of-Four National Championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- John B. Dunlap, Commissioner of Federal Revenue, asserted today that "special attention" would be given this year to "excessive and unreasonable expenditures claimed as deductions in tax returns."

Air conditioning, which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary this year, achieved the status of a billion dollar industry for the first time in 1951, Cloud Wampler, president of the Carrier Corporation, declared at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Lincoln Newfield, Alabama bass, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. He proved himself the possessor of a likable personality, an attractive stage presence and a voice that is pleasant and resonant when used at the full.
OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 26 (UP) -- The lives of forty persons were imperiled today aboard an air coach flying at 12,000 feet when a passenger went berserk and fought the pilot and stewardess.
A "watchdog" unit that would audit assistance grants on a current basis in the centers of the New York City Department of Welfare was proposed yesterday by the New York State Board of Social Welfare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In an effort to clear up confusion among producers as to the fringe labor costs that cotton textile manufacturers may include in their price calculations, the Office of Price Stabilization amended today its ceiling price Regulation 37.
The Brooklyn police told a frenzied tale yesterday of a gadget-minded family that suddenly received a "free" hand with the stock of a Sears Roebuck Co. store.

WEST of Hudson Bay, south of the Arctic Circle and north of the timber line lie the great Barrens of the Keewatin District of Canada's Northwest Territories. In that vast expanse of lakes and rivers and gently rolling slopes covered with moss and lichens no trees grow, only a few dwarf willow scrubs, which provide the only fuel for the inland Eskimos who dwell there.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association went on record today in favor of an amendment to the United States Constitution to prevent any treaty entered into by this country from superseding any Federal or State law.

PARIS, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., is a heavy favorite to retain his world figure-skating championships in the competition starting tomorrow at the Palais des Sports with eighty-three competitors from thirteen countries.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- George Shuba, the only real portside pull-hitting outfielder the Dodgers have had on their roster in several years, arrived today and even before entering the clubhouse he came up with an unusual statement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- A top production official said today there was a "good chance" the Government would not go through with its plan to cut automobile production back to 930,000 units in the spring quarter.

Two men believed to be key members of a gang that had looted many East Side apartments over many months were in police custoday yesterday. Their capture resulted from an incidental tip picked up by detectives listening in on a wiretap in a vice case.

Expressing "grave" concern over a recent estimate that 250,000 New Yorkers were out of work, Mayor Impellitteri asked the Welfare Council of New York City yesterday to undertake a preliminary survey of the rising unemployment situation here.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Right-winger Gordie Howe, playing perhaps his best game in years, notched the winning goal with less than two minutes to play tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.

The scheduled Senate vote today on recommitting the Alaska statehood bill is in effect a vote on admission of Alaska to the Union at this session of Congress. If the measure is sent back to committee it is a safe bet that it will be a dead duck for the rest of this election year.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The main objective of many Antarctic expeditions, including Byrd's operations from Little America in 1947, has been geographical exploration.

Basketball players from a second out-of-town college pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to shave points in games at Madison Square Garden when three former stars at the University of Kentucky admitted they had plotted fixes with crooked New York gamblers.

The Coast Guard announced yesterday that it would make no changes on the ten piers declared as restricted areas under the Port Security program that would interfere with steamship passengers, their guests and legitimate visitors.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Hatch-Metcalf animal research bill passed the Assembly today, 103 -- 40.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A possible claim by the Government to more than one-half of the $2,800,000 of profits from an original investment of $100,000 in five surplus ships by a group headed by former Representative Joseph E. Casey of Massachusetts was indicated today as the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee pursued its inquiry into the deals.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Grain prices crumbled again today under early trade. At various times during the session weak spots were disclosed in other grains, and corn prices dropped sharply under the wave of long selling and local pressure, combined with some hedge sales.

Approximately 5,000 defense and other contracts with the Government will be renegotiated -- under the new renegotiation law this year, according to Frank L. Roberts, a member of the Renegotiation Board. He estimated that in 1953 upward of 10,000 contracts would be subject to renegotiation under the Renegotiation Act of 1951.

In his special message to the Legislature yesterday urging approval of two bills regulating advertising on the Thruway, Governor Dewey described the measures as "very minimum legislation." This is an understatement, for the "regulatory" features are so full of loopholes and exceptions that one almost wonders whether this kind of legislation is better than nothing at all.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 28 -- A defense agreement that spells out the details under which United States forces will remain in Japan after the peace treaty comes into effect was signed at a formal ceremony at noon today. Officials of both countries hailed the pact as a means of thwarting threats to peace in this part of the world.
VIENNA, Feb. 27 -- The rumor that Col. Gen. Jaroslav Prochazka, Czechoslovak Army Chief of Staff, had been purged was confirmed today when Maj. Gen. Vaclav Kratochvil was named as his successor.

Mrs. Gerald De Courcy May, 65 years old, for many years prominent in social circles here and in Southampton, L. I., died yesterday in a fall from her apartment in the Weylin Hotel, 40 East Fifty-fourth Street.

There are still a few good ways to make money in this country and some of them are right down on the farm. Take wool raising, for instance. The average price for the more than 225,500,000 pounds of shorn wool grown in 1951 was 99 1/2 cents a pound, highest on record.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee today approved without change the bill suggested by Robert K. Christenberry, State Athletic Commission chairman, for reorganizing the commission and strenegthening its powers for dealing with evils that have developed in boxing and wrestling over the past thirty years.

When special investigators started digging into crime and corruption in Staten Island last fall, none found the hunt so exciting and instructive as Beauford James George Jr., a tall, dark, heavy-lidded ex-G. I. and choir-singer from Ann Arbor, Mich., who is working as a $1-a-year man.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Savings of 235,000,000 (approximately $655,000,000) in spending by the Civil and Revenue departments will be diverted to strengthening Britain's defenses in the coming fiscal year, it was disclosed today when the Civil Estimates were laid before the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, foresaw today "clear-cut" Republican majorities in Congress next year if that pary named General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower its Presidential nominee.
New offices for Clinton Street and garden apartments on Eighty-third Street are planned as the result of transactions reported yesterday in Brooklyn.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 27 -- George Yeh, the Chinese Nationalist Foreign Minister, and Isao Kawada, the Japanese plenipotentiary, were reported to have made progress today in trying to iron out the disputed points that have delayed formal negotiations on a Chinese - Japanese peace treaty here.

Tweeds and linens, woven in Ireland and manufactured in this country into coats, suits, dresses and separates, were a feature at Franklin Simon recently in a showing given in conjunction with the Irish Government. Since Irish linens are already so widely known, the tweeds were of particular interest with their sheer worsted-like weight and handsome blendings of colors.
An increase last week of 844,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

The two-story private garage with three-room chauffeur's apartment at 22 East Eighty-fourth Street, near the southwest corner of Madison Avenue, was sold by Mrs. Frances H. Le Bouvier of London, England, to Frederick Brown in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Russian charges of a deal between the Canadian and United States hockey teams to play a tie game so the United States could take second place in the Olympic hockey competition were called "silly" today.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 27 -- The General Confederation of Labor, in a second request to United Fruit banana workers to act to withdraw the Labor Court edict under which the company's Tiquisate plantations had been ordered sold at auction next Wednesday, warned their union today that its representatives may be removed and others selected who will follow instructions of the parent union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 20, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Western surgeons set in motion today a program to combat one of the hazards of surgery -- the leaving of sponges or instruments in patients following operations.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Conservation groups clashed today with the State Grange and two commerce associations over a proposal pending in the Legislature to end the state's power to build water control projects in the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

Robert Roland Corp. in 10 E 46th St; United Service Organizations, in 11 W 42d St; Concord Watch Co. in 625 Madison Ave; Max Greenberg, lawyer, in 141 Broadway; Amesway Typewriter Laundry Service, in 122 Chambers St; Sunset Service Corp, store in 165-01 Hillside Avenue. Jamaica, Queens -- Abbott Adams, Inc, brokers.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The steadily increasing deficits incurred by the New York transit system, which, by the end of the next fiscal year, may total $40,800,000 more than the city had estimated, became a key issue today in negotiations looking toward a solution of New York's financial problems.

The Rangers got a bad one out of their system last night. Opposing the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden, the local skaters were humbled by the score of 3 to 1, in the presence of 10,063 fans.

ATHENS, Feb. 27 -- Col. Kolinos Athanassoulis, prosecutor for the Department of Military Justice, asked the Athens Military Court today for the death penalty for twelve of the twenty-nine defendants charged with espionage in behalf of international communism. One of the twelve is Elli Joannides, 61-year-old woman Red, already under sentence of death for subversive activities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An Army auditor has given Congress an estimate that waste, "kickbacks" and price-boosting through "conspiracy" have cost $50,000,000 in air base construction in North Africa.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Armco Steel Corporation has announced record sales for the twelve months ended Dec. 31 but a decline in earnings from the 1950 level. Net income totaled $35,004,487, equal to $6.69 on 5,213,530 shares of common stock outstanding on Dec. 31.
There are many reasons why some of America's 45,000,000 automobile and truck owners want to get rid of their vehicles. And there are many ways to dispose of an unwanted car.

Two of the nation's six regional accrediting agencies yesterday rejected as "not practicable" the American Council of Education's proposal that they be charged with enforcing the athletic code drafted for the A. C. E. by a committee of college presidents.
Fish, often neglected by the housewife in her menu-planning, comes into its rightful prominence during the forty-day Lenten period, which began yesterday.

Your recent excellent article on the Economic Conference to be held in Moscow in April assuredly did a good job in throwing more light upon a by no means negligible Soviet initiative. For the time being, at least, the idea seems to have been one of the shrewdest put forward by Cominform propaganda on both sides of the European Iron Curtain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Clark Gable, who went off salary at his own request last November, reported back to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer this morning. After he conferred with Dore Schary, studio boss, it was announced that Gable would go to work shortly in "Never Let Me Go."
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A young Dayton man who has Chinese blood but is a naturalized American citizen said today he was not going to live in his dream house after all.
The Federal Minister for Traffic has been informed of a letter from Louis Halpern in your issue of Dec. 31, 1951, under the caption, "Traveling in Germany."
St. John's will meet New York University and Manhattan will oppose La Salle tonight in the last regularly scheduled double-header of Madison Square Garden's eighteenth season of college basketball.

The East Side House Settlement and its affiliates, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery and the Stepney Camp, will be the beneficiaries of the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on the night of April 1 at the Warner Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- By a margin of one vote, the Senate returned the Alaska statehood bill to committee today and immediately became involved in a fight over whether to take up the companion Hawaii bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Charged with "irregularities" in the granting of export licenses, Henry George Bennett, chief licensing officer of the Department of Commerce's Office of International Trade, has been dismissed by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.

Commodities had a firm tone yesterday and most markets closed higher on the day. Even world sugar on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange staged a recovery in the final hour that took it above its low for the day and the season.

A $2,100,000 treble-damage antitrust suit was fried yesterday in Federal Court against eleven large electrical appliance, radio and television distributors by Monarch-Saphin Company, Inc., of 56 West Forty-fifth Street, which is attempting to reorganize under the bankruptcy laws.

The Federal Maritime Board, completing a long study of ship construction subsidies, has slashed Government aid to the American Export Lines on the company's two $25,000,000 luxury liners, the Independence and the Constitution.
The value of the Christian faith in a disturbed world was stressed in sermons at Ash Wednesday devotions here for Protestants yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 27 -- In this university town, where Negroes first settled as the slaves of Southern students and now find employment mainly in domestic service, an interracial art center is holding its fifth annual show.

A reminder that January was a strong month in the stock market came yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange released figures showing the market value of its listed stocks had gained $2,096,812,368 in that month and their average value had risen 63 cents a share.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 -- The Public Lands Committee of the National Association of Soil Conservation Districts declined to take action today on what the United States Forest Service and other conservation groups labeled as another attempt by Western stock men to "grab" public grazing lands in seventeen Western states.

The question as to whom the Messrs. Clifford Hayman and Frederick O'Neal recently yielded their project, "The Gentle Folks," was resolved yesterday. It is John Golden, Forty-fourth Street's prominent citizen, who acquired the drama written by Frank Alexander and E. A. Krumschmidt. Mr. Golden already is making suggestions for revisions on the third act and if all details are ironed out in time, the play will be done this spring.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, one of America's two international grand masters at chess, moved into first place last night in the international tournament sponsored by the Capablanca Chess Club, according to reports from Havana.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Pennsylvania opened a drive against rabid foxes today in a nineteen-county eastern area extending from the Maryland to the New York borders.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Gov. Earl Warren announced today that he would commute back and forth from California to Wisconsin to campaign for the state's April 1 Presidential primary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn today authorized the Judiciary subcommittee of the House of Representatives that will investigate the Department of Justice to rent office space in the George Washington Inn, a Privately owned building.

Kurt Nielsen, the young Danish player who won the French international indoor championship recently, will appear in the benefit tennis matches between France and the United States tomorrow night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of the elder J. Pierpont Morgan, was of sound mind and free of any pressure when she signed a will disposing of her estate of more than $400,000, according to three witnesses who testified yesterday as Surrogate William T. Collins opened hearings on whether the will should be admitted to probate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett declared today that a considerable increase in United States air power had been pledged to buttressing the collective force for the defense of Western Europe but that no further assignment of American ground troops other than replacements was in sight short of war.

Events tonight: "Manon," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, conductor, Szell, Margaret Harshaw, contralto, Set Branholm, tenor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Boris Maximovich, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; George Osmolovsky, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Carib Singers, McMillin Theatre, 8:30.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 27 (UP) -- A Wisconsin Democrat today asked a Senate subcommittee to make a "full and final report" on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's fitness for office and not "bury" Senator William Benton's charges against him.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, attacked yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposal to collect fees from the brokerage community "for services rendered to special beneficiaries." A man forced to register with the commission in the public interest, the said, gets no special service and should not be obliged to pay for what he does not get.

Tanaquil LeClercq went through one of the traditional ordeals of the great ritual of the ballet by dancing her first "Swan Lake" last night with the New York City Ballet at the City Center. Over the years the role of the Swan Queen has become a kind of initiation ceremony by which the young dancer achieves officially the status of ballerina.

An American edition of "The Struggle for Europe," by Chester Wilmot, recently issued in England, will be published by Harper on March 26. It is a one-volume history of the war in Europe based on all available evidence from the Allies and the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Despite the cuts in critical materials for civilian goods in the first quarter of the year, employment in metal working industries has been increasing steadily since December and employers expect the rise to continue through March.
In a letter by Roger Barton Prehn published Feb. 16 I find three statements to which I take exception.

Sigmund Janas, former president of Colonial Airlines, Inc., filed in the United States District Court yesterday an answer to the suit by the present management against him and other former officers. He indicated he would fight to the limit the proposal to merge Colonial with National Airlines that is pending before the Civil Aeronautics Board.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Senate approved today measures to impose heavy penalties upon insurance companies for filing false reports with the State Insurance Department and to broaden the coverage that could be offered by insurance companies under personal injury liability policies. Both bills were sent to the Assembly.
Four boatloads of Columbia oarsmen took a brief spin on the Harlem River yesterday as thirty-six heavyweight candidates reported for the Lions' first outdoor workout of the season.

Kurt Nielsen, the young Danish player who won the French international indoor championship recently, will appear in the benefit tennis matches between France and the United States tomorrow night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of the elder J. Pierpont Morgan, was of sound mind and free of any pressure when she signed a will disposing of her estate of more than $400,000, according to three witnesses who testified yesterday as Surrogate William T. Collins opened hearings on whether the will should be admitted to probate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett declared today that a considerable increase in United States air power had been pledged to buttressing the collective force for the defense of Western Europe but that no further assignment of American ground troops other than replacements was in sight short of war.

Events tonight: "Manon," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, conductor, Szell, Margaret Harshaw, contralto, Set Branholm, tenor, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Boris Maximovich, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; George Osmolovsky, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Carib Singers, McMillin Theatre, 8:30.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 (UP) -- Dark Count, out of the money in last Saturday's Santa Anita Derby, had an easier time today knocking off a field of California-bred 3-year-olds in the $15,000 added San Luis Rey Stakes.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 28 -- The United Nations armistice delegates at Panmunjom bluntly rejected yesterday the Communists' protest that last week's riots among Korean civilian internees on Koje Island constituted a "massacre" of their war prisoners.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 27 -- Dr. Donald F. Gibson, who was freed on a manslaughter charge last December in the death of his spinster benefactress, Elizabeth M. Ayres, stood accused today of having caused or hastened the death in 1948 of a patient whose widow the doctor later married.

New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was closed for sixty-one minutes near noon yesterday while search planes looked for two Navy torpedo bombers that were lost in thick weather after they took off from Floyd Bennett Field to participate in the Navy's operation Convex III.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is developing new iron-ore sources in Chile, Canada and Morgantown, Pa., in addition to expanding its Venezuelan operations, and has contracted to buy Labrador ore, E. G. Grace, chairman, disclosed yesterday in annual reports to stockholders and employes.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion read to the Knesset (Parliament) today the text of a note sent to the Soviet Union, assuring the Kremlin that Israel would not join any aggressive pact against the Soviet Union and asking the Russians to permit Soviet Jews to migrate to Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Following is the 45-to-44 Senate vote that sent back to committee the Alaskan statehood bill:

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Premier Edgar Faure asked the National Assembly tonight for no fewer than twenty formal votes of confidence on the principal features of his appropriation bill, which aims to cover French arming costs by a 15 per cent rise in taxes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service officials met for four hours this afternoon with union and management representatives without settling the three-day tie-up of dry cargo facilities in the Philadelphia port.
Miss Jessie Rosenfeld and Hunter College celebrated their eighty-second birthdays together yesterday at the annual birthday assembly in the college auditorium.

THE TIMES deserves commendation for its delayed and moderate editorial captioned "Airport Common Sense." We sufferers who own property in the vicinity of great airports are sick of being described as surrendering to "mob hysteria."

The New York Board of Trade has sent a letter to each member of the State Legislature in which it declares as "absolutely wrong" Mayor Impellitteri's contention that the city needs about $200,000,000 in additional revenue. The letters were signed by M. D. Griffith, executive vice president of the board.
Today is expected to be a field day for the city's bargain-hungry housewives and some male shoppers.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Two bills providing limited relief from the state personal income tax were approved unanimously by the Senate tonight and sent to the Assembly.
Parke, Davis Co., 85-year-old pharmaceutical concern that makes more than 1,000 different products, chalked up new peaks in sales and earnings last year despite an 89.5 per cent increase in taxes.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- A Detroit newspaper artist, accused before the House Committee on Un-American Activities of having been Michigan membership director for the Communist party, was discharged from his job today. At least three other persons faced the loss of their livelihood in the train of consequences propelled by the Detroit hearings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Office of Price Stabilization announced today the opening of a country-wide suryey to check the compliance of car dealers with the agency's regulations. The survey is intended to cover the invoice and posting requirements on new cars and the invoicing and tagging of used cars.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived here today for a tour of India in which she will gather material for a book of "impressions of the economic possibilities" of this country for the American "man in the street."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The British are always complaining that it is difficult to work with the United States because (1) we let domestic politics interfere with our foreign policy; (2) we are careless with secret information, and (3) we are constantly making statements that affect the interests of other countries without letting those countries know in advance.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Chicago and Southern Airlines, Inc., reported record-breaking profits and operating revenues during 1951.

With 300 teachers attending, the Board of Education began yesterday the nation's first course for instructors on the use of radioisotopes in the classroom. As a result of the course, high school students next fall will have an opportunity to learn about the atomic by-products in their biology, chemistry and physics classes.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- There is a "strong possibility" that the Dodgers will do their 1954 spring training in Arizona, Walter O'Malley, the Brooks' president, revealed today.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- West Germany will be permitted to manufacture propellants for shells and other missiles and to produce gun tubes ranging in size up to and including 105 millimeters under the direction and control of the European Defense Community.

A bitter foreign policy debate in the House of Commons, in which the Labor party sought to censure Prime Minister Churchill for his promise to the American Congress of "prompt, resolute and effective action" in case of a breakdown of an armistice in Korea, has ended with a personal triumph for the Prime Minister.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Rival pennant contenders in the American League, who for three successive years have been chasing the Yankees across the finish line, doubtless have been doing some wishful thinking that this could be the year Casey Stengel's Bombers finally bog down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The Treasury Department decorated four agents today for "exceptional" work and "outstanding courage" in exposing two major sources of narcotics and in trapping airborne gold smugglers.

The College of Mount Saint Vincent Development Fund will be augmented by the proceeds from the card party and fashion show to be held Saturday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the college.
PHOENIX, Feb. 27 -- The left-handed hitting outfielder for whom the Giants have been looking as a pinch hitter may be right here in camp, according to Manager Leo Durocher.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Frank Cohen testified today that the Empire Tractor Company was "solvent" and its stock "worth one million dollars" when Frank McKinney, now Democratic National Chairman, made a quick $68-to-$1 profit in a stock sale.

Some time ago you published an editorial commenting upon the refusal of the C. I. O. to accept an invitation to visit Government-controlled unions in Spain. You also commented on the fact that the truly representative unions of Spain are the non-Communist unions in exile.

THE law known among New Jersey sportsmen as "The Great Shad Subterfuge," which permits the commercial netting of striped bass by means of shad nets, seems to be stirring the sportsmen of that state to a zeal that threatens to have some repercussions on the members of the Fish and Game Council.

Love of freedom is a national characteristic of Ecuador. Edward G. Miller Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Ecuadorean American Association.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 27 -- "Good design was the theme of the eighteenth century gardener," said Alden Hopkins, resident landscape architect for colonial Williamsburg, speaking yesterday on landscape lessons of the eighteenth century before more than 100 garden enthusiasts at the sixth annual Williamsburg Garden Symposium.

A one-year penitentiary term was imposed yesterday on a former interne, and suspended sentences were given to three doctors and three women on their pleas of guilty to charges of conspiracy to operate a $500,000-a-year "abortion ring."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27 -- Rio de Janeiro returned to work today after a three-day carnival that is regarded as triumph for Chief of Police Gen. Ciro de Rezende, who kept his promise to see that the carnival was orderly despite the sale of alcohol.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Queen Elizabeth II held the first investiture of her reign today in the white and gold state ballroom at Buckingham Palace.
TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 28 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,173, for Wednesday's operations:
CAIRO, Feb. 27 -- Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, said here tonight that the time had come to put the unity of the Moslem world into terms of practical politics.

Exceeding the $21,000,000,000 mark for the first time, deposits in the nation's 529 mutual savings banks increased by $126,000,000 last month. The advance, which brought deposits to a total of $21,027,000,000, compares with a gain of $22,000,000 in January, 1951.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Archie Moore, veteran light-heavyweight challenger, won a unanimous decision over Jimmy Slade of New York tonight.

Companies doing defense work may use either a product or institutional type of advertising without qualms in their efforts to maintain their competitive position as far as the Renegotiation Board is concerned. There is no difference between the two types of advertising as they apply to over-all company costs, the board holds.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Konni Zilliacus returned to the fold of the British Labor party today and promptly joined up again with the Left Wing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A 50-year-old Cleveland labor organizer and Communist party member disclosed today that he had been counter-spying on Red activities in this country for the last eight years as a Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Judge John P. Donohoe directed in County Court here today that Joseph E. Venuti, Democratic chairman of East Chester, be arrested at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville to assure his appearance in court next Monday for continuation of his trial on a charge of conspiring to violate the gambling laws.

FRED WILT and Don Gehrmann, inseparable companions of the finish line, will have a reunion in Madison Square Garden on Saturday at the Knights of Columbus games. It has been three weeks since they've been together, three weeks since each thrilled to the announcement that he had won the Baxter Mile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Karl R. Bendetsen, Assistant Secretary of the Army, admitted today efforts to unify military buying are hampered by a lack of authority to "bang together heads" of the Army, Navy and Air Force.

Twenty-two local housing authorities sold yesterday $54,467,000 of loan notes for projects backed by the Public Housing Administration at interest costs ranging from 1.08 per cent to 1.12 per cent. Of the total, $28,175,000 will come due on Nov. 28, $25,442,000 on Sept. 19 and $850,000 on Sept. 12.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Blyth Co. will place on the market today a block of 225,000 shares of common stock of Rheem Manufacturing Company at $31 a share. Of the offering, 200,000 shares represent new financing by the company, and 25,000 shares the holdings of certain stockholders.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 27 -- French - Vietnamese forces today completed a week-long mop-up of Communist-led Vietminh troop installations in a vast area seventy-five miles west of Saigon. Ten thousand French Union and Vietnamese National Army troops were thrown into the operation which permitted establishment of new garrison posts and an important extension of French-Vietnamese-controlled territory in Cochin China.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 27 -- By an exchange of notes at the Israeli Foreign Ministry today the United States and Israel agreed on the terms under which $50,000,000 of United States aid for refugees' relief and resettlement will be administered.

For the first time this week the stock market showed some recuperative power yesterday. The recession was stemmed late in the session by some buying in the railroad issues, but interest failed to spread to other important sections. On balance, the list rose 0.13 point which gave a true indication of the general change in prices.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 27 -- The Adelphi College basketball team, Greater New York Conference champion, stopped the New York Aggies, Metropolitan Junior College titleholders, 82 -- 67, on the Adelphi court tonight. The victory broke a fifteen-game streak of the Aggies and was Adelphi's seventeenth triumph against six losses.
TORONTO, Feb. 27 -- This is V. O. N. Week in Canada and the nation is hearing more about this home nursing service than it has in all the fifty-four years since the order was founded.

Scoring 13 points in the five-minute overtime period after making only 12 during the second half, Fordham's basketball team halted Rutgers, 70 to 59, at the Fordham gymnasium last night. At the end of the regular playing time the score was tied at 57-all.

" My Son John," a Paramount drama marking the first screen appearance of Helen Hayes since 1935 and also starring Robert Walker, Van Heflin and Dean Jagger, is scheduled to follow the current engagement of "The African Queen" at the Capitol Theatre, it was announced by the film company yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The Illinois Bell Telephone Company announced today a $93,000,000 financing plan for expansion and service improvement.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Poised and collected, 9-year-old Elizabeth Bean stepped off an airliner this afternoon after her leisurely, unescorted around-the-globe flight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Richard B. Russell is expected to tell a delegation of Georgia and other Southern Democrats tomorrow that he will permit his name to be proposed for the Presidential nomination at the Democratic national convention of 1952.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Assembly approved today by a 103-to-40 vote the controversial Metcalf-Hatch animal research bill after a heated two-hour debate in which the measure was attacked as socialistic and lauded as essential to continued progress in medical science.
PARIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The United States placed third and fourth today in the opening phase of the world championship for ice-skating dancers as two British couples took the lead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Opposition in the Senate to President Truman's plan for reorganizing the Bureau of Internal Revenue took form today with the introduction by two powerful committee leaders of measures aimed at killing it.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
The city bowed yesterday to union and bus company pressure and abandoned plans to convert Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way streets.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Feb. 27 -- Central Pennsylvania shirt factories are going out of business under the joint impact of a slump in civilian orders and an inability to compete with low-wage Southern shops for military clothing contracts.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- Pravda reported today that a series of grave mistakes of ideological character, particularly regarding the role of the Soviet Union in Central Asia, had occurred in party and professional circles in the mid-Asiatic Republic of Uzbekistan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The National Petroleum Council reported today that "available supplies of oil and gas in the United States and the world are greater than ever before and are still increasing rapidly."

Capt. Henrik Kurt Carlsen, master of the ill-fated cargo ship Flying Enterprise, will get his new command within the next five weeks. The Isbrandtsen Line, owner of the sunken craft, is acquiring two C-2 type ships, one of which will be renamed Flying Enterprise II and placed under the courageous skipper's command.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 27 -- A government-sponsored film entitled "We Live Free," designed to show the Dutch people the suppression of freedom in Communist states and the need for a strong Atlantic defense, has run afoul of the censors.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 -- West Berlin still has a very arduous task ahead in its drive for economic recovery, but with economic activity at its highest level since the war, the basic outlook for 1952 is one of cautious optimism, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, said in his ninth quarterly report today.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 -- The Republican State Committee unwittingly barred Mrs. Eleanor Todd, president of the New Jersey Republican Woman's Club and the only woman among the ten designees for delegates at large to the Republican National Convention, from a meeting here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered six major domestic airlines today to halt their low-fare coach services March 31.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- The Defense Department announced 151 more United States battle casualties in Korea today, bringing the total since the fighting started to 105,992.

A "thorough discussion" of the demands of 32,000 workers in eight Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards on the East Coast highlighted yesterday's contract talks as negotiations were resumed between the company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., with the threat of an immediate walkout removed.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 27 -- The appointment of four specialists to assist in the supervision of the medical and surgical staff at Danbury Hospital was announced today by Bernard J. Dolan, president of the hospital's board of managers.

The only major remaining step for United Corporation to complete compliance with the Public Utility Holding Company Act is the sale of its holdings in the South Jersey Gas Company. William M. Hickey, president of the holding company, said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The trade association of the advertising specialty industry and its membership of 250 manufacturers and jobbers were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with conspiring to restrict and restrain competition.

Herman Methfessel superseded as District Attorney in Richmond County last fall, and Irving Rivkin, one of his assistants, declared yesterday that they did not fear disciplinary actions against them as recommended on Tuesday by the special grand jury inquiring into crime and official corruption on Staten Island.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 27 -- There is evidence that retarded intellectual development in children may be an expression of deep-seated personality problems, even though in some cases the mothers prefer to attribute retardation to physical rather than emotional causes.

TRENTON, Feb. 27 -- Temporary measures to speed the flow of traffic on the newly opened 118-mile New Jersey Turnpike and to eliminate severe congestion reminiscent of pre-turnpike days were announced here tonight.

Easter has arrived at the beginning of Lent in the America House gallery this year in the form of an exhibit of Easter eggs. Arranged by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council, the display will open today and continue through March 22 at the gallery, 32 East Fifty-second Street:

Police officials were puzzled yesterday over the problem of storing forty-nine fur coats and other fur pieces seized on Tuesday in a raid on a loft at 230 West Twenty-seventh Street. The furs were part of a collection of stolen property including jewelry, cameras and other items, with a total value estimated at $150,000.

EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Feb. 27 -- A determined attempt to overtake the Soviet lead in aircraft armament and to insure an orderly program of aviation armaments development has started here with the establishment of the Air Force Armaments Center.

It is worth noting again how normally and naturally France played her role at the Lisbon NATO conference despite the political weakness at home. Ten days ago it seemed possible that Socialist interference would upset the Faure Government on the issue of Germany's role in the European Army and thereby wreck the hopes of the NATO meeting.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh has presented a convincing argument for enlarging the budget of the magistrates' courts. While any request for increased funds by any city agency must be examined now with pitiless realism, the magistrates' budget is comparatively small, the court is self-supporting through fines, and the present treatment of these courts and their personnel is a glaring example of injustice which cannot be defended.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Dewey appealed today for generous support of the American Red Cross drive to raise $85,000,000 to finance its programs both within the United States and in foreign lands during the coming year.

A new convention and exposition hall is needed in New York to attract big meetings now by-passing the city for the lack of adequate facilities, according to the annual report of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore called his accuser, Louis F. Budenz, a willful perjurer today and challenged his Senate investigators to put the Lattimore-Budenz stories before the Department of Justice, "lead where it may."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Office of Price Stabilization hopes soon to be able to compare the margins it has fixed for wholesalers and retailers of grocery products with those which prevailed in both divisions of the food industry before Korea, it was reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Visitors attending the opening meeting of the Trusteeship Council's tenth session were admitted this morning, for the first time, to the new $11,000,000 conference building. The five-floor edifice flanks the towering Secretariat skyscraper at the eastern side of the world capital site.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The Assembly Ways and Means Committee approved today the Administration's bill to regulate billboards and other advertising devices along the Thruway after Governor Dewey, in a special message to the Legislature, had denounced "selfish interests" for opposing the measure.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A top military official testified today that an experiment in buying medical supplies for Korea might set a pattern for more economical military supply practices.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- Virtually the entire "Democracy fund" established by the United States in 1950 to restore West Germany's educational and social services has been expended.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Fine, former President Herbert Hoover and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur were reported tonight to have held a secret meeting in New York to discuss backing the Presidential candidacy of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

A special committee of the Board of Education proposed yesterday a new plan under which the city's teachers for the first time would be able to "seek official redress from grievances and also participate in making school policy."

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a fairly wide range yesterday and active months closed 1 point lower to 17 points higher than on Tuesday. The market opened unchanged to 21 points lower, and then sold off to losses of 21 to 41 points.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- In a new setting but according to an old formula, the United Nations Trusteeship Council opened its tenth session today in the recently finished conference building, with a defeat for the Soviet Union in a renewed attempt to seat Communist China.
Musical education can begin with the 4-day-old infant, Leopold Stokowski asserted yesterday.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Eighteen-year-old Miss Mary Freeman of George Washington University bettered the American long-course record in winning the women's 100-yard back-stroke event in 1:10.1 at the thirteenth annual Trenton Times A. A. swimming meet tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Two Republican Representatives proposed a change in House rules today that would overthrow a ruling by Speaker Sam Rayburn and permit radio, television and newsreel coverage of House committee hearings.
World War III has been fought and won on the deserts of Nevada where new tactical atomic weapons have been developed, William L. Laurence, science reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday.

With the help of the 3-year-old Collins quadruplets and their 5-year - old brother, Stephen, the Board of Education started the construction yesterday of new Public School 24 in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

Total assets of the Atlas Corporation, one of the country's largest "special situation" or closed-end investment trusts, increased $4,987,000 to $67,460,000 by the end of 1951 from $62,473,000 a year earlier, according to its annual report released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Federal Communications Commission disclosed today that it was renewing its concern over radio and televison stations that "emphasize" broadcasts of home race results in the afternoon hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The House Commerce Committee today approved a bill to restore to full effectiveness the "Fair Trade" laws of forty-five states. The Truman Administration split ranks on the issue.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Prospects for ending the sixty-five-year ban on the sale of pre-colored yellow oleomargarine in this state spiraled today as the Assembly Ways and Means Committee approved, 11 to 8, a repeal measure introduced by Assemblywoman Genesta M. Strong, Republican of Nassau.
SOMERSET, Ky., Feb. 27 (AP) -- John Sherman Cooper today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Association of American Railroads maintained today that the "clinching argument" against United States participation in the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway was Canada's willingness to proceed alone if necessary.

GRAND JUNCTION, Col, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Independent uranium miners, who produce nearly 75 per cent of the nation's supplies of the vital ore, intend to continue efforts to have a stronger voice in price-setting policies of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio and candidate for his party's nomination for the Presidency, said today he could not vote to start Universal Military Training at present "as long as the draft now is taking most young men for two years' active duty."

In these last days of February two melancholy anniversaries occasioned by Stalinist aggression require remembrance. President Truman has reminded us of the more recent of these two tragedies: the armed coup four years ago by which Czechoslovakia's Stalinists seized power and prepared the way for that nation's present slavery.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 27 (AP) -- President Sukarno and Vice President Mohammed Hatta have spent three days conferring with Indonesia's party leaders, but no early solution to the Government crisis is yet in sight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Government today took steps to open new defense housing near three Atomic Energy Commission plants to defense workers in other plants, military personnel and families forced from their homes by the plants' construction.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador in Washington, has formally declined to become secretary general of the reorganized North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Pope Pius XII spoke to 3,000,000 Roman Catholic students in the United States by radio yesterday afternoon and urged them to contribute to a fund to aid needy European children.

George (Muscles) Futterman, six-foot ex-convict and a Brooklyn union business agent, was indicted yesterday on charges he had paid $100 to a prosecution witness to perjure himself during the first-degree murder trial of Benedict Macri.

Four civil anti-trust suits were filed yesterday by the Government in Federal Court to enjoin two financiers from holding interlocking directorships in competing organizations having capital, surplus and undivided profits of more than $1,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27 (UP) -- A United States citizen has been held by the Argentine police since Feb. 14 on suspicion of mixing in local politics, authoritative sources reported today.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Feb. 28 (AP) -- United States Sabre jets shot down one Communist MIG and damaged another yesterday as the Red planes made an appearance in force over North Korea for the first time in four days.

The Public Service Commission authorized the Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday to convert its system to natural gas. The conversion, scheduled to begin next Thursday, will be the largest ever made. It will affect 925,000 consumers in Brooklyn and Queens, who use 2,000,000 gas-burning appliances.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Senator John H. Hughes, Republican of Syracuse, accused a Manhattan legislator today of sponsoring legislation "hatched up by the Communists."

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 27 -- The defense began presentation of its case in the school segregation hearings here today by outlining plans for a new $850,000 high school for Negroes in Prince Edward County. The case is being heard in Federal Court.

The annual spring festival of the St. James Protestant Episcopal Church will be held April 24 and 25 in the Parish House of the church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. Mrs. Charles I. Morton heads the executive committee for the event, proceeds from which will be donated to the needs of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Uncertainties over the coming national budget continued to restrict business in most markets on the stock exchange here today, when dealings began for the bookkeeping account that ends on budget day, March 11.

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 27 -- Two convoys from Malta have successfully negotiated the straits between Sicily and Tunisia and have entered the western Mediterranean after being under constant "attack" since dawn yesterday by air, submarine and surface craft participating in the Allied naval games.

The whereabouts of Martin G. Olsen, 36-year-old bank teller who left for lunch on Jan. 29 with $38,224 from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, 50 Court Street, Brooklyn, was still a mystery yesterday.

The statement by Matthew J. Shevlin that prayer in the schools will not create religious division is, unfortunately, not true. An incident in our own school convinced a majority of the parents present that the Regents' proposal for daily prayer in the public schools is a dangerous "apple of discord."

J. V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, reports that the work force employed on the waterfront was 48,758 in 1950-51 and that only 20,000 of these are generally considered "steady" men who apparently earn their principal livelihood from the industry, working 800 or more hours each year.

HONG KONG, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Three Canadian nuns arrived in Hong Kong today after eleven months in a Communist prison in China. A Catholic spokesman said they had been treated fairly well since the trial.

Fashion and fabrics go hand in hand when it comes to style. This is being demonstrated by Macy's, whose Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street windows offer a superb display of fabrics of many kinds and from many of the leading manufacturers of the country.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- James R. MacDuff, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, today ordered the suspension of all chauffeur's license renewals pending the development of procedures to prevent license forgeries such as those that came to light with the arrest of the Willie (the Actor) Sutton gang in Brooklyn.

Thomas J. Patterson, whose retirement as city budget director after forty-six years' service will take effect on Saturday, was honored by more than 800 persons last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Five weeks after the Army announced development of a new type of armored jacket for field soldiers the Marine Corps today demonstrated its version of a vest-like protector for its ground troops.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Government today accused the Sunbeam Corporation, electrical appliance manufacturer, of conspiracy to fix and control retail prices of its wares.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Soviet agriculture now has available a tractor pool 50 per cent more powerful than that of 1940, the last full prewar year the Soviet press said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- One hundred longshoremen, the first of 4,000 dock workers to be employed since stevedoring companies stopped hiring on Monday, went back to work today to load Army cargo.

Loans for defense and so-called "defense supporting" projects accounted for about half of the expansion in business loans from New York City banks last week, bringing the net gain to $25,000,000. The rise continued the uptrend for the fourth successive week and lifted the February gain to $99,000,000, compared with $312,000,000 in the same month last year.

A hot and heavy arbitration dispute involving Sidney Kingsley, Arthur Koestler and their "Darkness at Noon," dramatized by Mr. Kingsley from Mr. Koestler's book of the same name, finally has been terminated in favor of Mr. Kingsley, it became known yesterday.

In the Open Spaces Out in the wide open and lonely spaces, where singing cowboys ride and songwriters armed with tape recorders are supposed to ride right after them, nightfall has always brought a deep sense of peace.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The Senate approved unanimously today and sent to the Assembly for concurrence a bill to increase the membership of the State Board of Regents from thirteen to fifteen. The two new members would be elected by the Legislature next year.

" All God's chillun may get shoes some day, but they will not all get refrigerators, automobiles and TV sets," is the way Dr. George H. T. Kimble, director of the American Geographical Society, drove home the other day to an audience in Birmingham, Ala., the situation that we must face if the world's metal production were to rise to the per capita level of the United States.
The supposedly pro-Eisenhower Republican organization in New York County showed signs of being infiltrated by "Taftites" last night, at the first meeting in many months of the county committee.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks, outclassed for the first two periods, stormed back tonight to score two goals in the last period to tie the New York Rangers, 2 to 2

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The formal entrance of Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia today into the contest for the Democratic nomination for President this year increased to three the number of Democrats of predominant Southern ancestry from among whom the eventual choice may be made.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman today elevated Paul A. Walker of Oklahoma City to the chairmanship of the Federal Communications Commission and nominated Robert T. Bartley of Texas to the vacancy on the commission created by the resignation of Wayne Coy last week.

Frederic Ashton's ballet, "Picnic at Tintagel," had its world premiere last night at the City Center as the final novelty in the New York City Ballet's season. Set to Sir Arnold Bax' "Garden of Fand," and with scenery and costumes by Cecil Beaton, it was an all-British work, and had in its audience the British Ambassador, Sir Gladwyn Jebb, and Lady Jebb and other dignitaries.
