Sixteen acres zoned for residential development on Homans Avenue on the western slope of the Palisades in Closter, N. J., have been purchased by Home Building Associates of Tenafly from Mrs. Frances Adams of New York. George Meadows of Demarest was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Very few machine tools suitable for use in this country are, available in Japan despite reports to the contrary, Noble B. Clark, chief of foreign activities of the metalworking equipment division of the National Production Authority, said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Governor Dewey is being urged by several advisers to veto a bill giving New York City employes increased retirement allowances. It is contended that the measure, which won unanimous approval of both branches of the Legislature earlier this week, is inconsistent with the city's apparent needs for additional revenue.
OTTAWA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Canadian agricultural authorities disclosed today that the country's livestock industry had been hit by a new disease -- trypanosomiasis anaplasomis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, charged today that another client of Joseph D. Nunan's law firm, after sidestepping criminal prosecution, had paid nothing after four years on a $792,094 Federal tax claim.
A tight delivery situation is likely to develop before Easter in the women's coat and suit industry, according to Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc.
The renewed interest here in Fauve painting has naturally led to a reconsideration of the art of Vlaminck, a selection of whose canvases, from about 1906 to 1930, is on view at the Niveau Gallery.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday, and closed 19 points higher to 15 points lower than on Wednesday, with the near months showing the most strength.

ROME, Feb. 28 -- Two large merchant convoys, one from Oran, Algeria, and the other from Gibraltar sailed into the "enemy infested" waters of the Mediterranean early today as part of exercise "Grand Slam" in which more than 200 United States, British, French and Italian warships and hundreds of planes have been engaged in simulated war since dawn Tuesday.

GUATEMALA Feb. 28 -- The semi-official paper Nuestro Diario replied this evening to statements made on Feb. 25 by John W. McCormack and Joseph W. Martin Jr., leaders in the House of Representatives in Washington, that Guatemala appeared to be a Red beachhead.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman opened the American Red Cross subscription drive for $85,000,000 tonight in a radio address urging all Americans "to answer this compelling call of humanity."

Events today Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:45 o'clock; "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; Allen Rogers, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Elinor Warren, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Children's Concert, Mannes Music School, 8:30; Mendelssohn's "Elijah," Park Avenue Christian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, 8.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Dr. Henry Kronenberg, dean of the College of Education at the University of Arkansas, accused the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education today of "criticizing an honest effort by the people of Arkansas to devise an improved, plan of teacher education."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today that the Federal Reserve Board should exercise greater caution in controling inflationary bank credit so as to avoid "dangerous consequences for the Government securities market and the economy as a whole."

Leo Zemel, a 59-year-old textile jobber, of 1267 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury on a charge of cheating the Federal Government out of $98,350 in income taxes for 1945, 1946 and 1947.

The stock market continued yesterday on the recovery side but with no force behind the advance. The disappearance of selling allowed stocks to rally with ease, the composite rate as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES index rising 0.91 point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The conviction of Oscar Collazo, Puerto Rican Nationalist, for murder of a White House guard during an attempt to assassinate President Truman was upheld unanimously by the United States Court of Appeals today. Collazo may now appeal to the Supreme Court or seek clemency from the President to escape the electric chair.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 28 -- West German leaders and Allied and German representatives held conferences today on ways to implement the decisions made at the North Atlantic Council session in Lisbon, Portugal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

O. A. Byrne has been appointed assistant to the general manager of Colonial Airlines. Miss Rita V. Copelman has been named office manager at the general headquarters and Miss Irene Replogle is interline and public relations representative.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The development of about a dozen radioactive sugars for use as "tracers" in research on complex chemical reactions in living organisms was announced today by the National Bureau of Standards.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States, Britain and France announced jointly today that they were "urgently examining" a series of new proposals for achieving agreements with the Soviet Union on a treaty for Austria.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The speculative atmosphere appears to have been cleared by heavy recent liquidation, and while the grain markets were choppy today there was more confident buying on the setbacks, resulting in sharp rallies. Free selling of corn was again in evidence against purchases in the country, but short sellers had no easy time of it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- House investigators of tax collection scandals said today that John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, had protested removal of their files from New York after the Justice Department opened a grand jury inquiry of the New York Internal Revenue set-up.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Welterweight champion Kid Gavilan required a terrific final round to score a split decision over Don Williams, former choir singer from Worcester, in their non-title ten-round bout tonight at the Boston Garden.

Calumet Hecla Copper The fabricating activities of the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company currently are restricted to 70 per cent of capacity by governmental allocations and controls, Endicott R. Lovell, president, stated yesterday in Boston following the declaration of a 15-cent dividend on the common stock.
OTTAWA, Feb. 28 -- Vincent Massey was sworn in as Governor General of Canada today at a ceremony in the Canadian Senate Chamber.
BROOKSVILLE, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Sheriff Sim L. Lowman released today a Negro held in Hernando County Jail here a year and a half after he had been acquitted of a murder charge.

IN addition to arms, tackle and assorted equipment for all climates, fish, game and situations, American sportsmen with itching feet who want to make a personal check on the color of the grass across the fence, can now go prepared for conversation with native guides and porters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen accused the State Department tonight of cowardice in the Communist arrest of Angus Ward, United States consul general at Mukden, Manchuria, three years ago.

The Graham-Paige Corporation has come to the conclusion that it's a lot more profitable to operate outside of the automobile business. Last year, the company, now a "special situation" closed-end investment concern, earned the largest consolidated net income since its formation forty-two years ago.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 29 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,174, for Thursday's operations:
The seventh Leap Year Assembly will be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Edward Everett Watts Jr. is chairman of the committee for the event, which was established in 1924.
A $50,000,000 plant for the production of critically needed artificial fertilizers will be opened formally on Sunday by the Government of India at Sindri, Bihar.

" Meet the Masters," a series of films showing major musical figures in scenes from concerts and in moments of relaxation, had its debut last Sunday on N. B. C. (5:30 P. M.) with only partly successful results.

The letter from Willard G. Van Name on the subject of the Adirondack Forest Preserve, which was published in THE TIMES on Feb. 13, carries certain implications with regard to the competence and integrity of the forestry profession which should not be allowed to go unchallenged.

Two former convicts arrested on Wednesday in Brooklyn after they had committed a $4,000 burglary, were linked yesterday by the police to James J. Fox, the suspended detective who allegedly took part in several East Side burglaries with three other men.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Pakistan will ask the United Nations Security Council to examine the French cancellation of the passports of two Tunisian ministers and take steps to insure their presence in New York when the Council considers home rule demands of the French North African protectorate, according to Tunisian spokesmen here.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Joseph E. Venuti, Democratic chairman of Eastchester, wept when he was arrested in bed at the Lawrence Hospital here today by deputy sheriffs. The arrest had been ordered to assure his appearance at the continuation next Monday of his trial at White Plains on a misdemeanor charge.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- One of the most interesting phases of the current spring training campaign promises to be second-year development of the three rookie hurlers Greater New York's trio of major league clubs unveiled last summer.

HONUS WAGNER hung up his spikes the other day, formally retiring from baseball to take a deserved life of ease on a pension. Actually he had come and gone pretty much as he pleased in his role as Pirate coach. In effect, he already was on a pension, merely going through the motions of coaching whenever he felt like it and rarely deigning to take an out-of-town trip with the ball club.

CAIRO, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Egypt has pledged political, economic and social cooperation with the United States, and the United States has promised to expand technical aid to Egypt, a Government spokesman disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- During the week ended Feb. 27, member bank reserves decreased $297,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The alleged leader of a forgery gang whose activities are said to have cost Eastern banks $100,000 in the last two years was arrested yesterday by forgery squad detectives and postal inspectors. The capture was made near the Marine Midland Trust Company's midtown branch at 250 Park Avenue, at Forty-sixth Street.

The largest convoy exercises held by the Navy since World War II, now being conducted by Atlantic Fleet forces together with units of the Royal Canadian Air Force, are proving a genuine test of sea frontier defenses, Vice Admiral Oscar C. Badger, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, announced yesterday from his headquarters here.

The full, stunning magnitude of the financial emergency faced by New York City because of unsound transit management is at last beginning to be recognized. Mayor Impellitteri discovers that he understated the expected deficit on city-owned transit for the fiscal year 1952-53, starting next July 1, by many millions of dollars.

In these days of high meat costs, green peppers stuffed with sausage and rice, form the economical but delicious main course suggested for the Sunday dinner menu. Grapefruit, now in abundant supply, is suggested for the salad. Total cost of the meal for four is $2.75 or about 69 cents a person.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Not since the Revolutionary War era has the old breastwork at the end of Church Street here attracted so much attention as today, when Matteo Notorangelo demanded that it be leveled to improve his panoramic view of the Tappan Zee.
PHOENIX, Feb. 28 -- The emphasis in the Giants' training camp today was on the important gap in the infield left by the departure of Eddie Stanky.

Boilers for the Keystone Mariner, which is scheduled to be launched today at Chester, Pa., and is the first of thirty-five similar vessels under construction for the Government, will operate at 40 per cent greater steam pressures and appreciably higher temperatures than boilers used in the Victory ships of World War II.

Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee was described yesterday as having changed her will to favor Sol A. Rosenblatt, her attorney, when she became angry over anti-Semitic remarks that she attributed to her sister, Mrs. Mabel S. Ingalls of 860 Fifth Avenue.

Results of adjourned games brought about a shift among the leaders in the international chess masters' tournament at Havana yesterday, but Samuel Reshevsky of New York remained in the lead with a score of 3 -- 1 after a draw in his fourth-round game with Roman Toran, champion of Spain, lasting thirty-eight moves.

NORTON, Va., Feb. 28 (UP) -- A former field worker for the United Mine Workers filed a $350,000 damage suit against the union today charging that the union had dismissed him after he had refused to slay two mine owners.

In the past few months Moscow has been untiring in its efforts to inflame extremist nationalist sentiment among the Moslem peoples of Iran, Egypt and neighboring countries. The Kremlin's radio and press, and its puppet Communist movements, have spared no energy in denouncing as "imperialist aggression" every effort made to accommodate the interests of these independent nations with those of the West.
Charles J. McCue has been elected chairman of Indiana Limestone Company. He is vice president of the Philadelphia investment firm of Sheridan Bogan Paul Co., Inc.

A series of sixteen chamber-music concerts will be given next season, starting Nov. 2, by the New Friends of Music. It will be the organization's seventeenth consecutive season and will be devoted to Mozart; Italian music of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and three modern composers -- Igor Stravinsky, Paul Hindemith and Darius Milhaud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended Feb. 23, dropped 12 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A Federal department of transportation to develop and administer national transportation policy was advocated last night by Col. Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the New York City Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, charged today that the fight against the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project "ought to be called the American railroads vs. the American people."

In covering the world as widely and honestly as your newspaper does occasions arise perhaps inevitably when editorials and news are in conflict. It is thus on Feb. 25, when your leading editorial is "Freedom's Voice at Lisbon." NATO and E. D. C. steps at Lisbon are not only unprecedented.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman indicated today his agreement with Speak Sam Rayburn's ban on television and radio broadcasting of House committee meetings, but insisted that he had taken no part in the decision although it originally had been made from his White House office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Many generous comments have been made about Secretary of State Dean Acheson's achievements at the recent meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Lisbon, but Chairman James P. Richards of the House Foreign Affairs Committee compressed them all today into one memorable Goldwynism.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The Europe-bound soldier wants to know why he is on his way to garrison Western Europe, and what it is like there, and the answers are being painlessly inserted into his consciousness between layers of broad and "corny" fun.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Argentina's defending champion, Roberto de Vicenzo, and South Africa's Bobby Locke shared honors today as the seventh Mexican open golf tourney got under way.

The way to speedy ratification of the Japanese peace treaty and the accompanying American-Japanese security pact has been cleared with the signing in Tokyo of an administrative agreement fixing the conditions under which American troops will remain in Japan after the treaty goes into effect and the occupation ends.
Harlem's reputed "crime overload" and three henchmen were found guilty yesterday of conspiracy and sale of narcotics by a Federal court jury that deliberated only forty-five minutes.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 28 -- Negroes are making progress under a segregated school system, and most Virginians would not vote public funds for a mixed system, a Federal Court hearing was told here today.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 (AP) -- United States consular officials said today they were "doing everything possible" to obtain the release of Saul S. Saulson, 23, of Detroit, arrested two weeks ago by the Argentine police.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Medalist Vonnie Colby, Saulte Ste. Marie, Mich., eliminated Miss Liz Ridge, Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) entrant, 3 and 2, today in the first round of the women's South Atlantic golf tournament.
A delight to see, with its full evidence of this French designer's great talent and chic, was the Saks Fifth Avenue showing yesterday of Christian Dior's New York ready-to-wear spring fashions.

The sacrifice of Czechoslovakia to Hitler and later to Stalin "was not in vain," Prof. Hans Kohn of the City College Department of History declared yesterday. "It served," he said, "to awaken the democracies to the fact that you can't do business with either of them."

Despite the new budget estimates of a $54,000,000 rapid transit deficit for 1952-53 instead of the lower $34,000,000 previously forecast, Mayor Impellitteri yesterday reiterated his opposition to any increase in the existing 10-cent fare.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- West Germany will do its utmost to pay its pre-war debts but cannot succeed without a genuine foreign trade surplus, Hermann J. Abs, one of Germany's leading bankers said here today.

Ferdinand Charles Schwedtman, late vice president of the National City Bank and chairman of its Educational Trust, left one-half of his estate, valued at $400,000 to the National City Foundation, a training group for personnel that he founded in 1929.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Clement Attlee confirmed today Prime Minister Churchill's allegation in the House of Commons yesterday that the Labor Government last May had given its consent to carrying the Korean war beyond the Yalu River later if United Nations troops in Korea were subjected to heavy bombing by aircraft based in China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Union leaders agreed tonight to a week's postponement of a threatened strike in the oil industry. A walkout at most of the country's refineries had been set for next Sunday night.

GEORGETOWN, S. C., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The bodies of two persons identified as Mr. and Mrs. Le Grand Bouton Cannon, both listed in the New York Social Register, were found last night and early today in ashes of their plantation home near here. The bodies were charred beyond recognition.

An intricate check-kiting scheme, allegedly carried on by two Brooklyn bookmakers who ran original bank deposits of $37 into operations totaling more than $300,000, was exposed yesterday when a forty-five-count indictment charged the pair with grand larceny, forgery and conspiracy.

Boris Maximovich, the Ukrainian pianist who made his Town Hall debut last May, returned there last night to play a difficult program consisting of the Schumann Toccata, Chopin's G minor Ballade, B minor Scherzo, three Mazurkas and the D flat Nocturne, Liszt's Polonaise in E and Stravinsky's "Petruchka."

Magistrate Augustine B. Casey dismissed yesterday a perjury charge by former District Attorney Herman Methfessel of Staten Island against Mrs. Anna Wentworth, 34-year-old Richmond housewife, which has been pending in Felony Court at Stapleton, S. I., for the last five months.
George Osmolovsky, a young and talented violinist, gave the first of a pair of recitals last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. It was his first appearance here since his debut in 1949.

Baking with buttermilk and soda imparts to cakes and breads a delightful flavor and texture impossible to achieve with sweet milk and baking powder. Although it is a culinary technique that dates to grandma's kitchen, currently abundant buttermilk supplies make it an especially timely device for modern home cooks to master.
Dr. Carlton J. H. Hayes, former United States Ambassador to Spain, denounced United States foreign policy last night as "peculiarly indecisive" and inconsistent.

Announcement yesterday that the Commodity Exchange will resume futures trading in hides on March 10 heralded the return of that market to its former importance in the nation's business. Rubber futures trading will be resumed on March 3. In post-war years before trading was restricted rubber and hides accounted for about 70 per cent of the aggregate business of the Exchange.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- Many horse players -- particularly horse players of the $2-window variety -- begin their calculations by tossing out the favorite. Some of them had a high old time at Hialeah today, for all nine favorites took a larruping.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Jack Burke fired a 4-under-par 68 to take the lead today in the first round of the $10,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- An undercover member of a Communist cell in a Cleveland plant said today that the party was bent on destroying the capitalistic system in America, and would use "depressions or strikes or anything else" to accomplish this.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America (C. I. O.) has charged "the Pentagon" with discriminating against New York City and other clothing markets and asserts that it is materially responsible "for the dislocation and unemployment in the clothing and textile industries."

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Allied fighters and light bombers blasted new holes in the Communist supply lines in North Korea yesterday. Minor patrol contact marked the ground action. There was some artillery and mortar fire.
PARIS, Friday, Feb. 29 -- The Cabinet of Premier Edgar Faure resigned early today after it had been placed in the minority on a confidence vote in the National Assembly.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 28 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's name was ordered off the March 18 Minnesota Presidential primary ballot today by the State Supreme Court, which upheld arguments that Republican petitions filed in his behalf were technically defective.

Commodity futures in the New York market moved in both directions yesterday but the general tone was higher. Cocoa rose 45 to 65 points on moderate volume and coffee advanced 23 to 30 points on light volume. Wool and wool tops made impressive gains.

For the third year bills have been introduced into the New York State Legislature to amend the Education Law in such a way as to permit the increase of unnecessary blindness and to nullify at least in part efforts of national and state organizations to save sight.

PARIS, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Peerless Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., virtually clinched his fifth straight world figure skating championship today and Olympic champions Ria and Paul Falk of Germany won the pairs title by beating Peter and Karol Kennedy of Seattle.

A new housing colony is planned for Suffolk County where a fifty-three-acre tract at Pulaski Boulevard and Central Avenue, Greenlawn, has been purchased by Louis Wachtel of Roslyn from Nathan Singer and Ray Dressner. J. Edward Breuer, broker in the transaction, will act as sales agent for the houses, which will be in the $15,000 price class.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Government announced today the conclusion of an agreement under which it will purchase 50,000,000 pounds of nickel from Canadian mines over the next nine years. The contract was signed by the Defense Materials Procurement latency with Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., of Toronto.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 28 -- Brown University announced today President's Fellowships awards to Miss Margaret L. Coit, author of the Pulitzer Prize biography, "John C. Calhoun"; Prof. John H. Franklin of the history department at Howard University, and Prof. Maurice H. Heins of the Brown mathematics department.

A Bronx Red Cross Blood Donor Center, the third in the city, was opened yesterday at a ceremony on the fourth floor of St. Barnabas Hospital, 183d Street and Third Avenue, where the new station will operate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- New-bold Morris said tonight that he intended to investigate all the sensitive areas of the Government in his search for corruption and would pursue all leads as far as his authority permits him. He added he would conduct a completely unfettered, independent inquiry and ignore any possible political effects.

A new booklet of particular interest to owners of electric ranges has just been prepared by Mrs. Julia Kiene, director of the Home Economics Institute of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. It presents details on how to use and how to care for this kitchen equipment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Texas Power and Light Company, of Dallas filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the sale of $14,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due April 1, 1982, and $5,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due April 1, 1977.

Lieut. Comdr. Elihu Rickel, a naval chaplain, criticized American civilians yesterday for their failure to support more enthusiastically the fighting service men in Korea. The naval officer, a rabbi attached to the Naval Hospital, St. Albans, Queens, spoke at the opening rally for funds of the Brooklyn Chapter, American Red Cross, at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Feb. 23, 1952, totaled 683,368 cars, the American Association of Railroads announced today.

Production of steam-turbine generators by General Electric Company, Schenectady, reached the equivalent of 4,000,000 kilowatts last year for the first time in the company's history, it was announced yesterday. Power-making units shipped by the turbine division in 1951 had a total rating of 4,098,000 kilowatts.

In a recent press release by William (The Actor) Sutton, the bank robber, this notorious criminal has offered to sell his life story to the highest bidder. This offer is made, allegedly, in the hope his past will deter others from wrongdoing and to point out the pitfalls in a life of crime to potential criminals.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 28 -- A slate of thirty delegates, many of them former La Follette Progressives, was filed in the Wisconsin Republican Presidential preference primary this afternoon by Gov. Earl Warren of California.
The Board of Education dropped eight books from its approved textbook list yesterday on the ground that they contained derogatory statements about minority racial and religious groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman quietly took a hand in the Alaska statehood fight today, raising the hopes of proponents that the Senate would reverse yesterday's decision to send the bill back to committee for hearings.

The critical need for teachers of the handicapped and the gifted, and the importance of providing adequate school programs for these children were emphasized yesterday at the closing session of the four-day Hunter College Conference on the Education of the Exceptional Child.

SYDNEY, Nova Scotia, Feb. 28 -- Eighteen United States Air Force men, shepherded by the only one of them who had ever jumped before, parachuted safely from a twin-engined transport iced up in a blizzard as the last of its gasoline gave out early today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- United Nations forces have definite air superiority in Korea despite reports of the successes of Soviet MIG-15's, Howard Boyer, Assistant Administrator of the Defense Production Administration and Chairman of the Aircraft Production Board, asserted today.

Encouraged by successful union efforts to block conversion of Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way streets, Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., announced yesterday that he would recommend a similar union campaign to end one-way traffic on avenues already converted.
Willie Sutton, the bank robber, made a deal yesterday in Kings County Court. The agreement, however is unlikely to have any influence on Sutton's future.

The little "navy" that enforces the Federal pollution laws in the Port of New York and its approaches will dip its colors in farewell today to Capt. Jefferson D. Beard, United States Navy, Supervisor of New York Harbor.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Federal Judge Leon R. Yankwich ruled today that corporate income could not be taxed on a personal basis, opening the door for suits against the Internal Revenue Bureau for possibly more than a billion dollars.
John Reilly, an ex-boilermaker who breakfasts on beef stew, has been coming to McSorley's Old Ale House long enough to be considered a regular customer. He started 70 years ago. Last

A "vast growing debt," beyond constitutional limits, is accruing to the city as a result of drastic relaxation in its pay-as-you-go policy for capital improvements during the last twelve years, the Citizens Budget Commission reported yesterday.
DANIELSON, Conn., Feb. 28 -- An "honor prisoner," who traveled 3,000 miles so the state police could arrest him, was called a "real gentleman" by authorities who met him today.

CAIRO, Feb. 28 -- Egypt's new Minister of Municipal Affairs, Mohamed Ali Rushdy Bey, whose two chief cares are Cairo, with a population of 2,000,000, and Alexandria, with a population of 1,000,000, has got himself into a classic Islamic difficulty over the affairs of the "stolen auto buses."

A syndicate represented by Lorimer Denner, attorney, made an offer of $1,400,000 net for the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 1200 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of Eighty-seventh Street, at a court sale held yesterday before Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr., in Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

The City Affairs Committee of the City Council adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution urging the Board of Transportation to reconsider its decision to reduce service on the Third Avenue Elevated Line between 149th Street, the Bronx, and the City Hall station, Manhattan.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, giving to the House of Commons a full and encouraging report on the recent North Atlantic Council meetings in Lisbon, Portugal, showed himself well satisfied today with the accomplishments of the conference.
A Federal grand jury soon will be impaneled in the city to conduct an industry-wide investigation of the radio and television manufacturing field.

Sixteen secondary Communist leaders scheduled to go to trial Monday for conspiracy to teach and advocate the violent overthrow of the Government filed four motions yesterday, one of which seeks a thirty-day trial delay. Argument on the motions will be held Monday in Federal Court.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- The Dodgers will not trade or sell any of their eight regulars, Walter O'Malley, club president, said today.

Legislation to ban the sale of switch-blade knives in the state was asked yesterday by Justices Nathaniel J. Kaplan and James V. Mulholland of Brooklyn Children's Court. In a joint statement, the justices declared the knives to be "deadly weapons, not just toys; just as deadly as a revolver or pistol."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Truman expressed today his keen satisfaction with the recent North Atlantic Treaty conference in Lisbon and his view was echoed within two hours by the chairman of a Congressional committee that had received a full report on the meeting by Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- An Armed Services subcommittee of the House of Representatives learned for the first time today about the existence of an informal committee that sets procurement policies for the military forces.

No one doubted that the tried and true sportsmen who recurrently journey to the Aqueduct, Belmont and Jamaica racetracks would mind paying the Long Island Rail Road another cent on each single fare, the same as everyone else.

ATHENS, Feb. 28 -- Seven lawyers spoke in defense of twenty-nine persons accused of criminal espionage in Athens military court today. Others will be heard tomorrow. It is believed the verdicts will be announced Saturday. The prosecutor has asked for death sentences for twelve of the defendants.

Two new cars in the 1952 Henry J. series, the Corsair, powered by a four-cylinder engine and Corsair de luxe with a six-cylinder engine were presented yesterday by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation. Both models go on display today in dealer showrooms in the New York metropolitan area.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 -- President Truman's Administration and not General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower will be the chief issue in the New Hampshire primary, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Expanding steel production capacity has enabled the National Production Authority to make 250,000 tons of sheet and strip steel available to producers of consumer goods, Henry H. Fowler, administrator, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today a bill designed to tear down a "little iron curtain" erected against English-language books published abroad.

The International Jewelry Workers Union, A. F. L., appointed a special trustee yesterday to take over the affairs of the Brooklyn local whose ex-convict business agent was indicted Wednesday on charges of bribing a witness in a murder trial.
The guaranteed annual wage, one of the newest union goals in collective bargaining, has been won by 1,100 sugar workers here, it became known yesterday.

VIENNA, Feb. 28 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl and Dr. Karl Gruber, Foreign Minister, outlined Austrian foreign policy in Parliament today in answer to Communist party questions regarding a much-discussed dispatch by this correspondent (published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Feb. 1) about Austria's intention to meet any Soviet attempt at partition with counter-measures.

PORT LAVACA, Tex. Feb. 28 -- A new smelting unit, which will increase production at the Aluminum Company of America's Point, Comfort plant near here to 135,000,000 pounds a year, began operating today.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported yesterday for 1951 a consolidated net income of $148,697,356 after charges and taxes, equal to $9.71 each on the 15,320,249 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $123,581,477, or $8.09 in 1950. Total income increased to $1,559,046,979 from $1,318,183,136.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Two persons were killed and two others were injured, one critically, when an automobile jumped a fourteen-foot safety island on the New Jersey Turnpike at 11 A. M. today, and collided with a car traveling in the opposite direction.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- Officials of the United Textile Workers Union of America, A. F. L., and the American Woolen Company were reported today to be near an agreement on a new contract covering some 3,500 workers in three mills.

The State of Alabama borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of road and bridge bonds due April 1, 1954 to 1969 to a banking syndicate headed by First National Bank of New York at an interest cost of 1.636 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Treasury today reported a successful sale of its first medium-term marketable bond issue since World War II. Bonds paying 2 3/8 per cent interest were offered in exchange for $1,023,568,350 in bonds issued in 1941 and called for redemption March 15. The old bonds carried 2 1/2 per cent interest.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -- Relations between India and the United States "are getting on very well indeed" Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared at a news conference today. He differed with the attitudes taken by the Governments of Indonesia and Burma in their questioning of United States motives in offering financial and technical assistance to those countries under the Mutual Security Act.

Brisk Lenten season demand for fish coupled with only moderate receipts swung prices upward a nickel a pound on several popular species this week-end. Large retail outlets, however, cut price tags on a wide variety of fish and other Lenten foods.

" Elizabeth the Queen: The story of Britain's New Sovereign," by Marion (Crawfie) Crawford, has been scheduled for March 17 publication by Prentice-Hall. The new book which brings the life of Elizabeth II up to the present, has a complete section on former Queens of England and a chronological record of all the Kings of England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Opponents of Universal Military Training suggested to the House of Representatives today a number of substitutes for the Administration bill that would permit an early start on training men for six months at 18 and keeping them in the Ready Reserve for another 7 1/2 years.

Guatemala today offers another unhappy example of communism sowing the wind and reaping the whirlwind. Last September a hurricane leveled ten thousand acres of bananas cultivated by the United Fruit Company, temporarily throwing nearly four thousand workers out of jobs.

MORRISVILLE, Pa., Feb. 28 -- The multi-faceted boom predicted for this small town and other communities of the Delaware Valley as a result of the advent of a big steel mill is well under way and gaining momentum rapidly.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- Two members of the House Committee on Un-American Activities announced here today that they would urge Federal prosecution of a Detroit trade union official for having made false statements in a passport application.

Impersonal methods of distribution and marketing will grow in in the next twenty years because of anticipated increase in production facilities, coupled with the broadening base of purchase power, according to Marion Harper Jr., president of McCann-Erickson, Inc.

RAJKOT, India, Feb. 20 (By Air Mail) -- Democracy taking over from complete feudalism overnight has found one of its severest tests in the state of Saurashtra in Western India. Here, approximately 24,000 square miles of not particularly productive plains and barten low hills were, until four years ago, divided into 222 separate autonomous princely domains, where each maharajah and petty chief was his own law.

WEST POINT, N. Y. Feb. 28 -- Members of the Reserve Officers Training Corps from fifty-five northeastern colleges arrived at the United States Military Academy today for a four-day visit. The visitors, consisting of 110 senior R. O. T. C. trainees, will live with the corps of cadets during their stay.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28 -- Communist party plans for a New York State underground organization if the party were outlawed were detailed today at the trial of fifteen California Communists in Federal District Court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The House Monopoly Subcommittee approved a Fair Trade" bill today giving supporters of retail price-fixing a two-way lead over their opponents.

A business that started a quarter of a century ago because of a snore might conceivably provide business men with standard equipment for attending conventions and business dinners with ultra-inspirational speakers. The Flent Products Company has been manufacturing "anti-noise ear stopples" since its president, C. H. Low invented a device in Paris twenty-five years ago for the relief of his father made sleepless by his mother's snoring.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Prof. William John Fellner of the University of California, a member of one of the leading industrial families of Hungary before the Hitler conquests, will join the Yale faculty on July 1 as Professor of Economics, Edgar S. Furniss, provost of the university, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore declared today that Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, was a participant in a China lobby that was trying to "deliver the foreign policy of the United States into the hands of Chiang Kai-shek."
CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 -- Farm and city newspaper reporters gave Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio a big chuckle today.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Feb. 28 -- Mrs. Georgianna Hawkins retired two hours earlier than usual tonight after a busy day in which she greeted scores of well-wishers on her 104th birthday. And she seemed to enjoy every minute of it. The day had been proclaimed "Mrs. Georgianna Hawkins Day" by both the Patchogue Village Board and the Brookhaven Town Board.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 29 -- United Nations and Communist staff officers wound up yesterday their discussions of an exchange of prisoners during an armistice in the Korean war with general agreement on a draft recommendation prepared for submission today to a militry subcommittee of the truce delegations.

The New York State Crime Commission and Governor Dewey's office joined yesterday in denying reports that the commission had forwarded to the Governor a detailed report linking various nefarious practices to the court system in New York City.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Business shrank still further today on the stock exchange. Main exception was the foreign market where Japanese bonds were active and strong on hopes of a debt settlement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Alan Ladd and Paramount have brought their contract negotiations to a happy ending by tearing up his current agreement, which had until November to run, and writing a new one, to take effect on Saturday, whereby he will make one picture next year and a second film in 1954.
A virtually snowless winter has saved the cities in metropolitan New York millions of dollars.
The Second unit of the new $25,000,000 New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has now been started and will consist of a $7,500,000 Medical Science Building.

One of the most interesting experiences accorded the pres at a Mainbocher preview, is the privilege of reading the statement! written by the great designer on his own collection. It always reflects his approach to fashion for the particular season.

Remedies to avert a possible crisis in highway systems throughout the country were sought at a meeting held yesterday by the National Highway Users Conference at the University Club, 1 East Fifty-fourth Street. Representatives of more than forty organizations, the membership of which include about 18,000,000 motor vehicle owner, took part in the program.

New York University, La Salle, Louisville and Western Kentucky yesterday were added to the field for the National Invitation basketball tournament. Only one berth remains to be filled in the twelve-team event, which will get under way at Madison Square Garden with a triple-header on March 8.

St. John's ran out of gas, but time ran out on New York University and the Violets' stirring closin grally went for naught as the Redmen won by 78 -- 75 last night at Madison Square Garden. St. John's, a solid choice, recorded its twenty-first victory of the campaign after having frittered away most of an earlier 15-point lead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The State Department described today the administrative agreement signed yesterday in Tokyo between the United States and Japan as "an important step" toward peace and security in the Pacific area and toward a system of collective security for all democratic nations.

GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- Canada is preparing a program of sharp and extensive restrictions on imports of farm products from the United States in retaliation for the refusal by the United States Congress to rescind Section 104 of the Defense Production Act which imposes import quotas on cheese and other dairy products.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The Senate approved three bills today to increase the state's income from thoroughbred and harness racing. The way was cleared also for action next week on a fourth bill which would transfer to the State Harness Racing Commission the licensing powers now exercised by the United States Trotting Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Bargains in surplus Government ships during post-war years did not extend to the cost of legal and other advice in the buying of them, the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee heard today.

NEWARK, Feb. 28 -- Leo F. Link of Teaneck, who is under indictment as one of the major bookmakers in the metropolitan area, was convicted today by a Federal court jury on a four-count indictment charging evasion of income taxes totaling $135,543.
That group of furniture known as the "dinette set" seems to have come out of the kitchen area, for which it was originally designed, and into the living room.

Mayor Impellitteri warned yesterday that the city would be unable to appoint any more new policemen, though the force is now 1,287 short of its quota, "unless we get help in Albany." The Mayor is seeking legislative action to give him new state aid and let him impose new taxes totaling $200,000,000 above the current $1,330,000,000 budget for the city's operating costs next year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Detroit, Providence, Scranton and Wilkes-Barre today were certified to Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson as areas eligible for special consideration in the awarding of defense contracts because of unemployment conditions in those cities.

Many supper parties were given at the Bachelor Club's Leap Year costume ball last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The executive committee for the event included Sandy M. Pitofsky, founder of the club; John Jelke 3d and John Alden Talbot Jr. There were divertissements by professional entertainers.

The only books issued today are ten reprint editions of works of fiction and non-fiction. Signet Books is offering one novel, Rosamond Marshall's "Laird's Choice," at 25 cents. The other nine are from Pocket Books, of which four are in the concern's Cardinal Editions at 35 cents.
LONDON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Petroleum production is soaring in the Soviet Union and may reach 60,000,000 tons a year by 1955, the Petroleum Press Service said today.

While Manhattan was having its expected romp in the Metropolitan intercollegiates, Army, Yale and Princeton battled down to the wire in a thrilling finish to the jointly conducted Heptagonal indoor track and field championships at the Third Engineers Armory last night.
Following is THE NEW YORK TIMES transcription of the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's broadcast on European defenses from Washington last night:

Elinor Warren, soprano -- slender, pretty, with blonde ringlets -- sang in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Her program concentrated on pre-classical and romantic songs, with one operatic selection, the "Salce, Salce" and "Ave Maria" from "Otello," and she modulated her voice to the intimate demands of her selections.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- The Board of Regents today approved changes in the lighting standards for public schools that are expected to result in substantial savings in the cost of school construction and maintenance.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 29 -- The name of General McArthur, a 42-year-old Chicago packing house worker, was entered in the Wisconsin Presidential primary ten minutes before the filing deadline today.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Bennett E. Meyers, former Air Force general, was released from the Federal penitentiary here yesterday after serving an income tax evasion sentence of one year and a day, with time off for good behavior. He also served thirty additional days for failure to pay a $15,000 fine.

Fire Lieut. John G. Frey, the key witness in the conviction last month of James J. Moran as a shakedown racketeer, pleaded guilty yesterday to three departmental charges arising from his acceptance of "gratuities" as an inspector of refrigeration installations. He was fined thirty days' pay, the maximum penalty short of dismissal.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was on a smaller scale than in the preceding month and in February, 1951. However, the turnover was above the million-share mark in every full day's session, the largest of which was 1,968,300 on Feb. 20.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 29 -- An American-owned oil company has been ordered by a Venezuelan court to stop operating the rich Bajo Oil Field in eastern Venezuela. Under Venezuelan law there is no possible appeal against the court's decision.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems has pointed the way for reforms in the traffic law and ordinances that long have been overdue. Its comprehensive report calling for revisions of "outdated" traffic laws recommends adoption of statutes so that the law in this state will conform with the codes in other states.
The Soviet Government is considering a new move to combat the "private property feelings" of collective farmers, the magazine Bolshevik, theoretical organ of the Communist party, reveals.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of use in the home.

THE TIMES reported on Feb. 26 that the New York Joint Legislative Committee on the Sabbath Law has issued its report, in which it recommends the liberalization of the Blue Laws to allow public sports and shows on Sunday in those cities and towns which are willing to permit it.

In an effort to get car owners to check the filters in their vehicles at the same time they change the oil, Purolator Products, Inc., Rahway, N. J., will launch a "Filter Check Time" in April. Carlos D. Kelly, vice president in charge of sales, says the campaign will be spearheaded by a heavy schedule of national consumer advertising in national magazines as well as with point-of-sale material.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -- Egypt's cotton industry -- producer of the country's "white gold" -- is in the throes of a critical situation.

An all-day forum under auspices of the Christian Frontiers Committee of the Women's Society of Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, on the general theme "Mid-Century Challenge to Christian Missions," will be conducted Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has granted a plea of minority stockholders that it hold up its order approving financial reorganization of the Boston and Main Railroad pending further hearing.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Feb. 29 -- Carlton M. Owen, 23 years old, who refused a court verdict of innocent, today was sentenced to three years in prison as a draft law violator.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 29 -- Haj Amin el Husseini, former Mufti of Jerusalem, has been told by Cairo that he may not return to Egypt. The religious leader, who is in Karachi, has asked Pakistan for asylum.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 29 (AP) -- The University of Notre Dame said today it was a misunderstanding -- not a cut in milk rations -- that caused students to smash milk glasses in a dining hall.

Minimum wage rates for Puerto Rican migratory workers in eight Eastern states were made public yesterday by the Puerto Rican Department of Labor, which oversees the employment and transportation of island farm laborers.

CAIRO, Feb. 29 -- Ahmed Mortada el Maraghi, Egyptian Minister of the Interior, in a statement appearing in the weekly newspaper, Al Mussawar, stated that the riots in Cairo on Jan. 26 had been part of a premeditated revolt. The case against those arrested in the roating is expected to be disclosed tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Soviet Embassy, in a curt note to the State Department, denounced today as "an insult to the Soviet Union" an invitation by a special House Committee for Soviet officials to tell their version of a massacre twelve and one-half years ago in the Katyn Forest of about 10,000 Polish army officers.

The Government should reappraise the aluminum supply situation in view of a "definite softening of the market in several directions," Donovan Wilmot, vice president of the Aluminum Company of America, asserted yesterday.

Fourteen pints of blood, donated by personnel from Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station, Brooklyn, were carried by helicopter yesterday from the field to Pier 36, East River, where the American Red Cross waited to speed the blood to wounded in Korea.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 29 -- Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, announced today that he would challenge Gov. Earl Warren for California's seventy delegates to the Republican National Convention.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 15 points yesterday, in quiet trading.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Saturday, March 1 (AP) -- Shortwave radio reports received by the Red Cross here early today said two persons were killed and more than 150 injured in a tornado that tore out the heart of Fayetteville in south central Tennessee late yesterday.

When Jacob Garsh described himself yesterday in Flatbush Court as a nice, quiet tenant whom almost any landlord would find soothing to have around, he was uneprepared to hear his own voice contradict the story.

Business corporations were urged yesterday to support private enterprise in the social field by speakers at the final report meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association's centennial fund campaign at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, whose expiring appointment as Chief of Staff of the Air Force and whose chances of reappointment have dominated Pentagon discussion in recent weeks, is likely to be reappointed for a two-year term.

Action was taken by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to restore order in the curious price situation that has been built up in the old and "when issued" new common stocks of the American and Foreign Power Company. The Exchange ruled that new shares may be delivered on Tuesday in settlement of contracts for the old shares.
The Federal Government will "relieve" the Long Island Rail Road of the financial burden of carrying parcel post on April 1, officials of the Long Island said yesterday.

THE bird shooters who are convinced they have a champion pointer or setter taking life easy in the kennel will have an opportunity to test their pride this month, for the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club will open its spring trials on March 26.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 29 (UP) -- Columbus County's sheriff, H. Hugh Nance, today arrested the thirty-second man in a crackdown on the Ku Klux Klan in North Carolina and promised to round up more.

Madison Square Garden's final full-scale Olympic year track and field rendezvous, the thirty-third annual games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, will bring out all the top stars of the indoor circuit tonight. The meet will not be televised.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, told Senators today that permitting Canada to proceed alone with construction of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway would be "an unprecedented policy for a major power in an uncertain world."

While Mrs. Solomon J. Cohen was in the beauty parlor yesterday getting her hair set in preparation for the celebration of her ninth leap-year birthday last night, two hoodlums, one of them armed, entered her home at 1856 East Twenty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, and escaped with $10,000 in furs and jewelry and $300 in cash.
Elmer Reibold has been appointed sales manager of Hickok Manufacturing Company, Rochester, N. Y., maker of belts and men's jewelry.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 29 -- Bobby Locke of South Africa took a three-stroke lead in the $8,000 Mexican Open golf championship today by touring the Churubusco Country Club course in 67, for a thirty-six hole total of 135.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, opposed today a proposal that Government price supports on 1952 crop cotton be set above 90 per cent of parity, or about 31 cents a pound.

" Something To Live For," a Paramount drama co - starring Joan Fontaine, Ray Milland and Teresa Wright, has been scheduled for a local opening on Thursday, March 7, at the Normandie Theatre, it was announced yesterday by the film company. George Stevens directed and produced from a screen play written by Dwight Taylor. Included in the supporting cast are Richard Derr, Douglas Dick, Herbert Heyes, Harry Bellaver, Paul Valentine, Frank Orth and Bob Cornthwaite.
DENVER, Col., Feb. 29 -- Two nationally known authorities on tuberculosis treatment regard reports of new wonder drugs as "premature" and "ill-advised."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Representative F. Edward Hebert Democrat of Louisiana, said today that a "hush-hush Pentagon fight" between John Small, chairman of the Munitions Board and heads of the three military services has been carried to Secretary of Defense Robert A. Lovett.

Ever since it began its inquiries Senator McCarran's Internal Security subcommittee has been a sounding-board for the familiar allegation that treasonable or subversive influences were responsible for the failures of American policy in the Far East. Witnesses have made grave charges of communism; and some of those accused, either directly or by implication, have been allowed to testify in their own behalf only after long intervals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared tonight that the free nations had made such strides toward strength and unity in the fast two weeks that the period represented "a time of historic decision for the forces of peace in the world."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The United States, Britain and France agreed today to advance $45,000,000 more in economic aid to Yugoslavia, which would raise to $120,000,000 assistance given to Premier Marshal Tito for the fiscal year ending June 30. The previous tripartite agreement had tentatively allocated $125,000,000 to Yugoslavia for the period.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Two Texas sharpshooters became the Lone Stars in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament by taking a commanding lead in second-round play today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today the general level of farm product prices declined nearly 4 per cent between mid-January and mid-February. This was the second consecutive month that prices had declined.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- From morning until early evening today, about a thousand men and women of many faiths filed past a small sign that said "Meditation Room," entered a simply decorated chamber and prayed for peace and the success of the United Nations.
As reported in THE TIMES, a bill designed to regulate and control the practice of chiropractic has been introduced in both houses.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 29 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts dismissed tonight as "inconclusive" the preferential phase of the New Hampshire primary March 11 in respect to the chances of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

A five-year program of religious services designed this year to celebrate the 495th anniversary of the founding of the Unitas Fratrum or Moravian Church and at its end in 1957, the 500th anniversary, will begin tomorrow at 150 Moravian churches in the United States.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in February dropped to the smallest total since October and to the lowest figure for any February since 1949. The total of $26,114,000 compared with $54,856,000 in the preceding month and $27,739,000 in February, 1951.
With bank profits and growth increasingly dependent upon mass selling, special "sales departments" along industrial lines are likely to be developed soon, bankers were told yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 29 -- The Communist party's overt political campaigning in New York had objectives other than the conventional one of realizing party principles, it was suggested in testimony at the Smith Act trial of fifteen California Communists in Federal District Court today.

Upsets marked the play in the fifth round of the international chess masters tournament at the Casino Espanol yesterday, according to a report from Havana. The two leading players from the United States suffered defeat.

March is coming in like a lion, as far as the weight of underwriting commitments of securities' distributors is concerned. Negotiated offerings of industrial debt securities will figure prominently in a heavy schedule of public flotations slated for next week.
New worlds are opening for blind men and women who once could look forward only to spending their lives in institutions instead of among members of a family that becomes almost as their own.

It is common knowledge that lawyers, as a class, are conservative, and prone to oppose changes, not only in the mechanics of the law but otherwise. This may be due to the influence exerted upon their minds by our system of case law, which requires obedience to established precedents, very frequently hoary with age, and not infrequently out of step with the conditions of the present.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 29 -- Jackie Robinson, the Dodgers' leading hitter and the National League's top second baseman, got into his uniform today and, after a brisk workout, expressed confidence that he would be able to pick up where he left off last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing, head of the Federal Security Agency, told Congress today both he and President Truman were "unequivocally * * * opposed to socialized medicine."
CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 29 -- The Keystone Mariner, first of a class of thirty-five cargo ships, was launched this afternoon at the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

TORONTO, Feb. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Added protection for prospective buyers of new issues of speculative stock is provided in a bill before the Ontario Legislature. The bill amends the Securities Act to provide that a summary of the prospectus of any new company selling stock must be sent to the prospective buyer with the first circular, pamphlet or letter announcing the stock.
OTTAWA, Feb. 29 -- Canada will not resort to measures of commercial retaliation, Commerce Minister C. D. Howe told the House of Commons this afternoon.
Newbold Morris, the Truman Administration's special investigator of corruption in Government, said yesterday that he was still unsuccessful in his efforts to get a staff together.
Your editorial of Feb. 22 with respect to insurance coverage for automobile owners prompts the writer to make the following suggestions:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29 -- It was Homecoming Day for the Yankees today as Bombers began to arrive for the official launching of the 1952 training campaign tomorrow. However, there was one slight off-note. Phil Rizzuto really means it and may become an official holdout within the next twenty-four hours. He wants his $50,000.

The United States electorate was urged last night by John Foster Dulles, State Department adviser, to heed the words of George Washington who warned in his Farewell Address against permitting partisan feeling to burst into a flame that, instead of "warming," might "consume."

Even while Asa Bushnell and his national invitation basketball tournament committee continued to deliberate yesterday over the twelfth team, they proceeded to outline the pairings and schedule for the fifteenth annual competition. Regardless of the identity of "Team X," the missing link, which might be any one of a half-dozen eligibles, the tourney will get under way next Saturday night with a triple-header at Madison Square Garden.
The final report for the fortieth renewal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund showed yesterday total contributions of $351,412.61 in 1951-52, compared with $319,981.22 in 1950-51.

Sniffs of several new Spice Islands seasoning blends now at Charles Co., 340 Madison Avenue, can be perfume to the home cook. Most interesting, perhaps, is the pale green spaghetti sauce seasoning powder, three ounces for seventy cents.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 29 (AP) -- United States officials talked today with Saul S. Saulson, 23, Detroit tourist, for the first time since his arrest by Argentine police eleven days ago on undisclosed charges.
United States Attorney Myles J. Lane announced yesterday that he had worked out a reciprocal agreement with eight upstate county prosecutors for the exchange of information on organized crime.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The State Retirement System was directed by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein today to refuse a pension to John H. Wells, former Ogdensburg city court judge who refused to waive immunity before a special grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The House of Representatives completed general debate today on the Administration bill to permit the start of Universal Military Training, with opponents privately predicting that they could defeat the proposal by a margin of fifty to 100 votes.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 (UP) -- A night clerk in the Clinton Hotel found a fire smouldering in a basement linen closet early today in time to rouse the 125 guests before flames swept the hotel.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 29 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court decision left anti-Truman Democrats free today to run for Presidential elector in Alabama without taking the new pledge of loyalty to the national party.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Commuters are filching coins again from the self-service newsstand in the New York Central Railroad station here, George A. Williams, the station agent, said dejectedly today. Reporting a loss of $12.35 in the last week, he began converting an old sewing machine drawer into a trap-type coin box for use on the stand next Monday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 29 -- The negotiations between the Yugoslav and Italian Governments for settlement of the Trieste question have broken down completely and it is understood the possibility of reaching agreement now is more remote than ever.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 1 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,175, for Friday's operations:
MIAMI, Feb. 29 -- The Flamingo Stakes for 3-year-olds will be run as a double-header at Hialeah tomorrow. Instead of one $50,000 added race, there'll be two.

PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio opened his Illinois preferential primary campaign against Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, today by warning two audiences in this industrial center against "taking the Truman road to socialism."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to grant increases in pay and allowances to the armed forces, but to cut them to a little more than half the amount voted by the House.

A careful study of the Metcalf-Hatch bill shows nothing in the text to justify the distorted interpretation which Prof. Ruth Temple offers in her letter published Feb. 25. She has evidently persuaded herself that unwanted stray animals are the "private property" of local humane societies. There is no law nor any license or charter that could be interpreted as granting this exclusive title to such institutions.

The City Council went on record yesterday as being opposed to a reduction in service on the Third Avenue Elevated Line between 149th Street, the Bronx, and the City Hall station. By unanimous vote, the Council adopted a resolution proposed by its City Affairs Committee urging the Board of Transportation to reconsider a decision to cut service on the line beginning March 14.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 29 -- A balanced budget and increasing industrial production, both of which are being subsidized by United States economic assistance, have helped the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa to check the inflationary trend that had continued to harass them last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Civilian industry may get more metal in April, May and June than in the first three months of this year, marking the turning of the tide of cutbacks in consumer goods, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Word that the United States will invoke the rejection features of rubber buying contracts in the future has caused so much criticism in the Far East that the General Services Administration today attempted to clarify its position.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, who twice sought but missed election to the United States Senate from New Mexico, today won the top spot on the Republicans' Senate ballot in the May 6 primary election.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 29 (UP) -- The average school teacher in this country earned more than $3,000 for the first time in history during the 1949-50 school year, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 -- The Office of Price Stabilization today accused the Pennsylvania Railroad of illegally increasing its restroom prices in New York's Pennsylvania Station and in thirty-three other cities in eight states.

A recital by Artur Rubinstein is one of the few remaining relics of the days long ago when the piano virtuoso in the grand style was a king of the musical world. There is electricity in the air -- not only in the playing but also in the audience. There is an eagerness on the part of the paying customer to be stirred, and this responsiveness is reflected in the stirring quality of the performances.

DETROIT, Feb. 29 -- A Detroit grandmother, who for nine years served the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a spy within Communist ranks, gave a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities a cell-by-cell roll-call today of more than 100 persons whom she described as leading or active members of the party in Michigan.

Mayor Impellitteri announced yesterday at City Hall that he had opened discussions with Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, on detailed plans for new housing projects in the city.
PARIS, Feb. 29 -- There are attractive ideas for every room at the twenty-first household goods show that opened today at the Grand Palais.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan told Senators today that farmers have received about one-fifth of the increase in retail cost of food which has taken place in the past year. He said the rest went to grocers, wholesalers and processors.

Two furnished model homes priced at $11,490 and $11,990, the first of 800 planned, will be opened to the public today in Mayfair Park, a new colony started by Robert Grundt and Jack Greenman in the Plainedge-Wantagh area of Nassau County, L. I.

Paul Dukas completed his big Sonata in E flat minor in 1900. It caused great excitement when it was introduced. Some French musicians hailed it as a successor to the late Beethoven sonatas; "monumental" was the least of the adjectives used in describing it.
GENEVA, N. Y., Feb. 29 (AP) Democratic leaders of thirty-one upstate counties have formed an organization to battle New York City leaders for "a say" in party affairs in the state.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Naitonal Labor Relations Board condemned as illegal today the union hiring hall provisions of the Seattle waterfront agreement. The board ordered the employers and the union to make up the pay losses of two individuals who were discriminated against and who instituted the board action.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- A man who is alleged to have run a boarding home for children without a license and to have packed thirty-seven boys and girls into six rooms was arraigned here today before Children's Court Judge George W. Smith on a charge of contributing to the neglect of children.

A power shovel is used for breaking down a solid pile of sulphur for shipment from the Freeport Sulphur Company's Grande Ecaille, La., mine. This procedure is necessary because, as the sulphur is pumped from wells driven deep into underground salt dome deposits, the mineral pours into huge storage bins in a dark red stream, then solidifies, turning bright yellow in color.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 -- Edward G. Budd Jr., president of the Budd Company, reported today that the company made more sales in 1951 than in 1950, but earned less because of increased taxation and higher costs of labor and materials.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- The delegation of Yemen publicly appealed to the United States today to give its support to the Tunisian nationalist government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics released today a new weekly wholesale price index. The weekly index, which begins with this release, has been revised to correspond to the revision of the official monthly comprehensive wholesale price index.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- President Truman today renewed his request to Congress for a $12,000,000 contribution to the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund during the fiscal year ending June 30. He also proposed authorization of a $12,000,000 fund for the following year.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 29 -- Since Houston is a city of 594,321 souls, not everyone is occupied exclusively with making theatre or going to the theatre. There are rumors that oil also has been discovered in this vicinity, but to a Gotham playgoer who is limited to a visit of four days, the theatre activities of Houston appear to be the main industry, closely followed by the symphony orchestra, ballet and the Shamrock Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 29 -- The five-day strike that tied up dry cargo facilities at the port of Philadelphia was settled tonight. About 4,000 longshoremen along the Delaware River from Wilmington, Del., to Trenton, N. J., are expected back at work tomorrow morning.
GENEVA, Feb. 29 -- The Lisbon meeting of the North Atlantic Council settled many economic issues, but nearly all these settlements are by nature temporary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore today acknowledged two inaccuracies in his past testimony and reaffirmed he had been inaccurate in a third instance. As Senate investigators beat heavily at his earlier and his current evidence, Professor Lattimore, a member of the faculty of the Johns Hopkins University, testified for the fourth straight day before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee. He conceded after having been confronted with documentary data:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Representative Edna F. Kelly, Democrat of New York, is sponsoring a bill to allow widows and widowers] to deduct from-their income tax within limitations the amount they must pay to have their children cared for while they themselves work.

New financing in February showed a marked contraction from the preceding month, with the total of new bonds the smallest for any month since January, 1951, and the least for a February since 1947. The decline might have been larger but for a sharp rise in stock financing to the highest figure for any February since 1929.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberal of New York, said yesterday that he was "not at all sure" that he could support the universal military training bill now before Congress, although he favored the program "in principle."

F. M. Flynn, president of television station WPIX, which is owned by The New York Daily News, announced yesterday the immediate suspension of broadcasts of racing results pending consultation with the Federal Communications Commission. At the same time Mr. Flynn said WPIX "does not concede the commission's authority to force such information off the air altogether."

The statistical measurement of economic magnitudes and changes has made great strides in recent years; and largely because of this progress statistics have tended more and more to become "news." While it may have been unusual, therefore, it was by no means unprecedented to find two important news stories emanating from one Government bureau, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

The New York Telephone Company will undertake one of the costliest expansion and service improvement programs in its history this year, Keith S. McHugh, president, declares in the annual report to be mailed to stockholders today. The $180,000,000 program calls for adding another 323,000 telephones.

Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, whose will is being contested in Surrogate's Court, never handled any money, not even for lunches or entertainments, Mrs. Amelia Davis, her long-time friend and one-time paid companion, testified yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UP) -- The Army handed Congress "documentary evidence" today to support its claim that Hawaii officials had been consulted about the use of flat stone markers in Honolulu's new Memorial Cemetery.

Budge Patty of Los Angeles, playing for France, defeated Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., national indoor and Wimbledon champion, in the opening contest of the Franco-American team match at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night. The score was 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 29 (UP) -- The possibility of an off track and rumors that Hill Prince may not be at his best resulted today in eighteen horses being entered for the fifteenth running of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap tomorrow.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 29 (AP) -- District Attorney Stephen A. Moynahan tonight ordered an inquest March 26 in the death of Millard Romaine Jr., 19 years old, of Cincinnati, Williams College sophomore whose blood-covered body was found Feb. 18 in a fraternity house room. The order followed receipt of an autopsy report.

The stock market staged an inconclusive performance yesterday with prices lower at the close. Prices throughout the session moved over a narrow range in the slowest business since last July. Transfers on the Stock Exchange were limited to 1,000,000 shares, compared with 1,150,000 shares on Thursday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Saturday, March 1 -- A photograph of the body of a well-dressed young woman found in an old steamer trunk on the estate here of a New York surgeon was identified early today in Milwaukee by Gerald Scott, 20 years old, as that of Joanne Barbara Scott, his 16-year-old wife and the mother of their 16-month-old child.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- Admiral Lynde D McCormick, U. S. N., the Supreme Allied Commander of North Atlantic, arrived in London today for conferences with Prime Minister Churchill and Field Marshal Viscount Alexander, Minister of Defense. He will leave here Tuesday for Denmark for further talks with officials regarding the allocation of ships and men under his command.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 1 -- The long drawn out armistice talks in Korea were on the verge of a breakdown yesterday when the United Nations delegates at Panmunjom told the Communists that their rejection of the Soviet Union as one of the neutral nations to police the cease-fire was "firm, final and irrevocable."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 29 The fresh air and open spaces of Westchester County are fine for children's bodies but, in the opinion of at least one local mother, the youngsters' minds could do with a bit more out-of-school stimulation. The opening tomorrow of a nine-week Saturday morning movie-lecture series planned for the young represents the culmination of that mother's one-woman campaign to provide a combined entertainment-education program.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- The corn futures market showed relative strength today, while there was considerable pressure on the wheat market. Fluctuations in all pits, however, were again on the choppy order, and while there was support on small recession there was still reluctance in following the upturns.
Cocoa and wool gained yesterday but other commodity futures prices moved little or irregularly in trading here.
