Chico Vejar, willing young boxer from Stamford, Conn., made a gallant recovery in his ten - round fight with Fitzie Pruden at Madison Square Garden last night. Floored for a count of 5 when the bell rang to end the first round, the Connecticut battler came on to gain the decision over his seasoned foe from St. Catherine's, Ont.

PARIS, Feb. 29 -- In response to a resolution adopted by the North Atlantic Council in Lisbon, Portugal, last week, the European Marshall Plan council is expected soon to draw up a report showing how its future activities could be coordinated with the economic aims of the Atlantic alliance.
PARIS, Feb. 29 -- Paul Reynaud, World War II Premier and leader of the moderate Independents, was called back today from Oxford, England, where he had gone to make a speech, to be

The two-story factory at 422 Alden Street in Orange, N. J., has been sold by the S. J. Realty Corporation, holding company for Tops Plastic Corporation, to the LaScola Corporation. The latter, which is in the screw machine business, will occupy the building in an expansion move.

Home buyers in New Jersey who obtained mortgage loans guaranteed by the Veterans Administration may sign a responsibility agreement with the builder starting today. The supplementary agreement is not required but its use has been endorsed by the Home Builders Association of Northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Indian tribes are subject to 800 special laws and 2,200 regulations "just because they are Indians," a spokesman told a House committee today. This, said Felix S. Cohen, attorney for the American Association of Indian Affairs, is "an unprecedented invasion of American principles."

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, March 1 (AP) -- United Nations tanks broke through Communist positions in sudden thrusts on the central and western Korean fronts yesterday and poured a stream of gunfire into enemy dugouts and ridges before withdrawing.
PHOENIX, Feb. 29 -- Davey Williams hit a home run today that may have clinched for the Dallas infielder the eighth hitting slot in the Giants' line-up for 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 29 -- India's general budget for the fiscal year ending March 31, 1952, will close with a substantial surplus of the rupee equivalent of $86,000,000, against an expected surplus of $52,000,000. Presenting the new budget to Parliament today, Finance Minister Chintaman Deshmukh declared that except for a serious food situation that was continuing to cause anxiety, there was all-around improvement in the nation's economy.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 29 -- Princeton's smooth-passing basketball team moved into a first-place tie in the Ivy League tonight by defeating Harvard, 65 -- 55, in Dillon Gym.

From Brattleboro, Vt., headquarters of the Holstein-Friesian Association of America, comes word that Pistertje Inka Korndyke Molly, 7-year-old pet of Mrs. Amalie Trunz of Millerton, N. Y., has joined the bovine immortals with production of 1,057 pounds of butterfat and 25,208 pounds of 4.2 per cent milk on three milkings a day for 365 days.

March was proclaimed "Red Cross Month" yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri, who appealed to New Yorkers to oversubscribe the city's quota of $6,700,000. The American Red Cross is opening its national campaign today for $85,000,000.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 29 -- The Israel Association of Manufacturers, at its annual general meeting that closed here today voted to cooperate in implementing the Government's economic reform program, but advocated some amendments.
Three dwellings in upper Westchester County were sold recently through Alys Moehlenpah, Chappaqua broker.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Maritime Board approved today a 15 per cent increase in freight rates of Alaska Steamship Company and Coastwise Line.
Four art exhibitions here are sufficiently varied in character to make a wide appeal.

ROME, Feb. 29 -- One small merchant convoy sailed into Gibraltar today after having crossed the whole of the Western Mediterranean undetected by hundreds of ships, planes and submarines that were scouring the area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Rapid progress made in the building of new or expanded plants for defense needs have eased demands for structural steel for the second quarter, officials of the National Production Authority said today. They offered this explanation for the drop of more than 85,000 tons in the structural steel industrial expansion.

WILMINGTON, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- St. Lawrence University, the host school, showed surprising strength today to capture two individual titles and finish a close runner-up to Middlebury in the team race in the first half of the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association senior championships.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 29 -- The United States submarine Flying Fish logged her 5,000th dive before noon today to set a world record. The Secretary of the Navy, Dan A. Kimball, handled the bow-plane controls for four minutes during the dive in Long Island Sound and made the log entry with firm, bold hand.

Some New Yorkers were probably surprised and shocked when they read that their public school system was still using, for classes, a building on West Thirteenth Street that is 105 years old. It was closed temporarily when a teacher found a slight buckling of a wooden pillar.

MARCH comes in like a liar today, ready to give us a month of broken promises of spring, so the thing to do is to ignore the local scene's climatic prevarications and go out to Arizona with Joseph Wood Krutch and enjoy "The Desert Year."* A philosopher on a holiday, Mr. Krutch has been rediscovering the pleasures of the Southwest's open spaces, and he finds them great.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Lewis A. Alliger, 77 years old, of Cherry Street, Katonah, a partner of Whitehead Alliger Co., wholesale paper dealer at 11 Thomas Street, New York, died here last night at the Northern Westchester Hospital of injuries received in a fall from a second-floor window of the building.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 29 -- The constitutionality of Virginia's school-segregation system was disputed and defended today, as final arguments were presented in the Federal court hearing that began Monday.

The consumer has not stocked up on shoes during the past year but has purchased at the normal rate of three pair per capita. Overproduction of the industry at the beginning of the year did not result in over-purchasing by the public, the Tanners Council of America, Inc., reported yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The stock markets ended the week on a slightly firmer basis today although volume of business was still small.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force, apparently believing the day of small-size atomic bombs is near, has organized and trained two units for atomic warfare on the battlefield.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 29 -- Australians have been interested to learn of Speaker Sam Rayburn's ban this week on the televising, broadcasting and photographing for newsreels of committee hearings of the House of Representatives.

The Department of Traffic installed four "Walk" and "Don't Walk" neon signs yesterday at Forty-fourth Street and Broadway in Times Square. T. T. Wiley, acting commissioner of the department, said they would make the intersection "much safer" for pedestrians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A review and sufficient cutting back of military programs to permit a $10,000,000,000 reduction in the President's $85,400,000,000 budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 was proposed today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, chairman of the Senate subcommittee in charge of armed services appropriations.

OBERSTDORF, Germany, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Hans Bjoernstad, Norway's 1950 world ski jumping champion, m took the lead with a 416-foot jump today in the three-day international meet on Oberstdorf hill. Contestants are graded on distance only.
Children's early experiences with music -- even the most "serious" music -- can be remarkably vivid ones, if the conditions are right.

ROME, Feb. 29 -- Sophocles Venizelos, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister of Greece, returning home from the Lisbon conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, stopped off in Rome this evening for a four-day official visit during which he will discuss with responsible Italian statesmen the principal problems outstanding between the two countries.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The British Centurion tank has proved its superiority in action in some of the worst tank country in the world, Korea, according to the commander of a British tank battalion who recently returned from thirteen months service in Korea.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 29 -- Aside from its signal accomplishments as a conference the Lisbon meeting brought the world to Portugal, and Portugal to the attention of the world. This easy-going, seaward-looking nation was not visibly excited by the visitation, but to most of the NATO delegates the trip here was a voyage of discovery.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Kropp Forge Company announced here today that it had succeeded in making bar forgings of titanium after fourteen months of research. The forgings with good surface finishes are being turned out in quantity both for armament and civilian use.

New York Stock Exchange figures were released yesterday revealing that listed bonds in January rose 58 cents for each $100 of par value and that aggregate market value gained $634,427,515 in the month, rising from $95,634,349,961 at the end of December to $96,268,777,476 on Jan. 31.

Events today: "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, 2; Jeanne Marie Schneck, mezzo-so-prano, Town Hall, 3; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Il Trovatore," Salmaggi Opera, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, conductor, Mitropoulos, 'cello soloist, Leonard Rose, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The travels of Soviet, Bulgarian and Rumanian diplomats in Britain are expected to be circumscribed in retaliation for restrictions placed in those countries upon British diplomats.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- The present approach to divorce was criticized today at a conference sponsored by the University of Chicago Law School, attended by about 500 sociologists, attorneys, social service workers and clergymen.
ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- Governor Dewey signed without comment today the bill to continue the personal income tax at 90 per cent of the normal rates.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, who declared a week ago that he was not a member of the Liberal party, asserted yesterday that he would be "most disinclined" to run for office again without the backing of that party.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 29 -- A second film dealing with the exploits of the Army Medical Corps in Korea is being planned by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 29 -- Historians rose in unanimous protest today against the demand of Matteo Notorangelo for permission to level the Revolutionary War breastwork at the end of Church Street so he would have a better view of the Hudson River.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Communist-led rebels hurled violent attacks at pro-French outposts thirty miles northwest of Saigon yesterday, but were thrown back with severe losses, French military headquarters announced today.

New York University, undefeated in dual competition during the regular campaign, scored 71 points to win the metropolitan college swimming championships in the Violets' John J. Quigley Memorial Pool at University Heights last night. It was the victors' third title and gave them permanent possession of the Radford McCormack Trophy. Fordham's defending titleholders finished second and City College was third.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A sharp drop in food prices at wholesale and retail was reported today, making a decline in the consumers' price index next month almost certain. The index directly influences the wage level of the country.

No contracts have been signed, but an understanding is said to exist whereby Andrew Rosenthal's latest play, "Red Letter Day," which opened last week to a set of highly favorable notices from the London critics, will be unveiled on Broadway early next season under the banner of John Golden.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 29 -- Louisiana's supporters of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican nomination for President virtually clinched their legal battle for certification as winners of a primary Jan. 15 when the First District Circuit Court of Appeals this afternoon upheld a lower court ruling requiring the Republican Central Committee to promulgate returns of that primary.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 29 -- West Coast ship owners today faced the prospect of new wage demands from the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L.

Union spokesmen for the city's civil service employes often make the assertion that many of these employes are so poorly paid that they have to get help from the Welfare Department. We put this question to Welfare Commissioner. McCarthy recently. He confirms that there are families of city employes who are receiving supplementary assistance, fifty-one of them in fact, out of roughly 200,000 city employes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- President Truman today predicted a hundred years of peace ahead at a meeting with forty finalists of the Westinghouse Science Talent Search.
PARIS, Feb. 29 (UP) -- Dick Button of Englewood, N. J., glided through a series of intricate maneuvers of his own design tonight to win his fifth straight world figure skating championship.
A World War I pilot who served under the late Mayor, then Capt. F. H. La Guardia, watched his 21-year-old son sworn into the Air Force yesterday as an aviation cadet.

THE joint presentation last month of a book and an exhibit at Bonniers devoted to contemporary Swedish design pointed up the fact that the art of good creative design still continues in that and other Scandinavian countries -- despite the current emphasis on the influences of Italy.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Feed grains made modest advances on the Board of Trade today in a continuation of the preceding session's rally. Brokers thought the upturn, both today and yesterday, was based largely on the fact corn and oats had been pretty thoroughly liquidated.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- Witherbee, N. Y., an iron mining town not far from Lake Placid, has been on the map for some time, but a lot of people never heard of it.
The Air Force announced yesterday that flying training for Air Force reservists, which was suspended last year because of aircraft requirements in Korea, would be resumed in the summer.

PARIS, March 1 -- The French Government has failed thus far in its attempt to present the decisions taken at the Lisbon conference of the North Atlantic Treaty Council as a series of unqualified successes from the French point of view.
CAIRO, March 1 (AP) -- A proposal for creation of an Egyptian-German bank has been forwarded to Dr. Albert Buehler, director of the Bank Deutscher Laender.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 -- A Republican Presidential primary campaign of some bitterness in California was foreseen this weekend as critics of Gov. Earl Warren opened a fight aimed at sending an uninstructed delegation to the party's national convention in Chicago in July.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 -- Questions put to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt by Indian newspapermen at a Delhi press association luncheon for the President's widow today underscored the significant wide and growing acceptance here that a new era of cordiality and understanding between India and the United States has arrived.

Twelve of the village's fifteen voters in Lonsdale, Ark., ran for public office in a recent local election. The other three voters were relatives of the candidates, and therefore ineligible to act as judges of the election.

THIS is the diary of a young Englishman in government service who, unable to stand the climate of tropical Africa, got a job with the famous Hudson's Bay Company at its Cape Dorset Post in Foxe Land -- the extreme southwestern point of Baffin Land.

Early this month New York will have an opportunity of hearing the works of a distinguished and unusual French musician, Dr. Leon Algazi, gifted composer and choral conductor, critic, and director of music for the Union of Hebrew Congregations of France.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Federal experts put a cloud today on any dream of wholesale tax refunds in Hollywood.

LONDON, March 1 -- When Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden rose in the House of Commons on Thursday to deliver his report on the Lisbon meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty powers he was a tired man. Out of weariness he twice referred to Clement Attlee, the leader of the Opposition, as "Prime Minister."

IT was very wise of Mr. Prescott to write this discursive book on the fiction of the last decade -- American. British and Irish (but not French or Scandinavian). Readers of his contributions four times a week to Books of The Times might have gone on for the proverbial "forever" without making out exactly what he stood for as a critic of fiction.

NEWARK, March 1 -- The first Snowfall in months was the least of the conversational topics today among residents of the Center Terrace garden apartments. The big news was that 11-year-old Raphaela Fasano, whose family lives at No. 108, was going back to school on Monday.

THE Frisians, proud and independent people who live in northwest Holland, have blood in their eyes. They speak a language of their own, resembling Scottish English, but cannot induce the Netherlands Government to grant it the same legal standing as Dutch.

HEARTENED, apparently, by public acceptance of programs with a religious theme, WABD and the DuMont network are planning a full hour program devoted entirely to news of religious activity throughout the world and hopes to get the project started within the next few weeks in a late Sunday afternoon time period.

ROCHESTER -- Measured by volume, the sixteenth Rochester International Salon of Photography, one of the principal annual displays of pictorialism in the country, is the most successful in its history. Selected recently by twelve judges in the various categories, the show will be placed on exhibition Friday at the Memorial Art Gallery, here, and continue through March 28.

THE next few weeks will see the opening of spring flower shows from Massachusetts to Florida. For residents of the metropolitan area, one of the highlights of the garden year will be the International Flower Show, which will be held from March 16 to 22 at Grand Central Palace, Forty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, said today that he did not favor a $10,000,000,000 reduction in the military budget alone, as some accounts indicated yesterday, but in the over-all Federal budget.

IN diaries, letters and memoirs, the War of American Independence was one of the most fruitful of our wars. From general to private, the American soldier was given to recording his experiences and, especially in the case of the enlisted man, his opinion of his superior officers.

The people of Lebanon, N. H., are developing a community scholarship fund which will give financial assistance for college education to the most deserving graduates of the town's two high schools. The aim is to help up to eight college students each year in the form of long-term loans at a low interest rate. The loans would be repaid at convenient periods after the students become wage-earners.

EACH year the annual exhibition by members of the American Abstract Artists displays a wider range of statement. Each year there is less of the sensational, less of the arbitrary in the work displayed. Each year there is evidence of greater concern with the artist's primary problem of space, approached through more or less common idioms but from quite personal angles.

Don Gehrmann's attempted "double" developed into an utter fiasco last night as the thirty-third annual New York Chapter Knights of Columbus Games rang down the curtain on the 1952 track season at Madison Square Garden.
In the computation of Federal income tax, payments to veterans for benefits administered by the Veterans Administration are tax- free, veterans were reminded yesterday.

Barry (Bernie) Robinson, 29-year-old seaman of 1070 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, was booked last night at the West 123d Street Station on a charge of homicide in the death of Mrs. Joanne Barbara Scott, 16-year-old mother, whose body was found Friday in a trunk on an estate at Greenwich, Conn.

March this year arrived one day later than usual. For this we can thank that happy institution known as Leap Year. The effect may be to raise by a slight percentage the month's mean temperature, at the same time postponing by one day the calendar's announcement of spring.

In sixty years the Hebrew Free Loan Society, organized on a nonsectarian and interracial basis, has made loans totaling $39,189,429 to 725,464 persons, Joseph Durst, president, announced yesterday in making public the society's fiscal audit for 1951.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1 -- The great experiment is but a short week away for Manager Leo Durocher and his Giants. Thirteen practice workouts went into history with today's brief drill, held on a muddy field.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Bobby Riggs and Pancho Segura today turned down the doubles title of the National Professional Clay Courts Tennis tourney, after winning it on a default.

Twenty-seven thousand five hundred members and guests of the Institute of Radio Engineers, representing nearly every country outside the Iron Curtain, are expected here tomorrow to celebrate forty years of existence of what is perhaps the world's most influential organization devoted wholly to radio and allied sciences.

THE European music festival schedule is now so complete that between April 30 and Sept. 6 there is only one stretch that is not festival-filled -- the time from the closing of the Holland Festival on July 4 to the opening of the Salzburg on July 23. But the Munich Opera Festival usually occurs in July, which will take care of that.

TO see a scholar setting limits to his own discipline is always a refreshing experience. It is one which awaits the reader of this series of essays on historiography and philosophy of history by the distinguished professor of modern history at Cambridge.

In accordance with the expansion of the passenger department of American Export Lines, John E. Bailey has been named to the newly created post of assistant general passenger manager. Mr. Bailey has been with the company since 1930, serving in the passenger department except for his first year in the organization.

DETROIT, March 1 (AP) -- Governmental agencies controlling automobile production volume and -- to a large extent -- automobile sales are under severe pressure these days. The manufacturers want higher production quotas; the retailers want an easing of credit restrictions.

THE author of this interesting and unusual book is the curator of a museum devoted to the history of fire fighting -- the H. V Smith Museum of the Home Insurance Company in New York City. "As You Pass By" is an informal history of New York's volunteer fire department and a descriptive account of the changing metropolis that was familiar to "those who, in their times, knew their city best -- the volunteer firemen."

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (UP) -- Ernie Beck, Eastern League scoring leader, tallied 31 points tonight to lead Pennsylvania to a 92-52 rout of Harvard before 1,933 fans in the second game of a basketball double-header at the Palestra.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas accused Texas, California and Louisiana today of trying to take away the rich offshore oil fields -- "a $40,000,000,000 treasure chest" -- at the expense of the forty-five other states.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 1 -- The annual battle on the Princeton campus to place every sophomore in an upperclass eating club ended in an unexpectedly early success this week. The seventeen clubs, comparable to fraternities at other colleges, had extended bids to more than 700 sophomores.

A NUT too hard to crack, but which is already worth millions of dollars to Brazil's economy and may be worth many millions more, is the subject of a Point Four inquiry into the commercial possibilities of one of the most curious resources of the entire South American continent, the babassu palm nut.
Representatives of seventy-five anti - Communist trade unions formed a national Negro labor committee yesterday to improve the lot of individual Negroes and achieve the objectives of organized labor.

IN the lexicon of the critic there is a nice, polite, well rounded word that imparts a fine air of distinction when it is casually dropped into a review. This writer does not often use it, but we cannot refrain today, on account of it fits so snugly the films we have to propose.
TRENTON, March 1 -- The New Jersey Presidential preference primary, to be held April 15, is becoming a gentlemanly battle designed to leave no permanent political bitterness.

SAIGON, March 1 -- The indeterminate, seemingly endless nature of the war in Indo-China was re-emphasized last week-end by French withdrawal from the little mountain valley town of Hoabinh, forty miles west of Hanoi, and the highway that links Hoabinh with the Tongking Delta.

With the railroads virtually the only major industry failing to share in the general postwar prosperity, there is expected to be a rather determined movement to revise the present Federal regulatory program at this session of Congress in an effort to create a sounder national transportation system.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft will visit Connecticut Wednesday to seek some of its twenty-two delegates to the Republican National Convention.

To advance from chef in the Majestic Hotel in Paris to one of this country's top-flight copywriters and agency executives seems a bit incongruous but that is exactly what David Ogilvy has accomplished.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- In a bleak-looking room here that once echoed the sounds of men and machines setting type and sending newspaper pages to the pressroom, there are now 100 desks awaiting occupants.

A WELCOME reissue. "Bird of Paradise," is the second novel by a once-famous Edwardian to be published here. In England, too, Mrs. Leverson's novels (there are six of them) are reappearing in quick succession.
EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., March 1 -- The planes of tomorrow, so full of electronic and automatic controls that the pilot merely "goes for a ride," are under test here at the Air Proving Ground.

ALFRED BULLTOP STORMALONG was to the New England sailor what Paul Bunyan was to lumberjacks and Pecos Bill to cowboys. Cradled in a dory, he cut his teeth on whalebone, learned his letters from Bowditch's "Practical Navigator" and grew up to be the greatest -- and the biggest -- mariner of them all.

MEXICO CITY, March 1 -- The crowd's favorite, Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., was the only man to break 70 in the third round of the $8,000 Mexican open golf championship today, but at the end of the day's play he was still three strokes behind the leader, steady Bobby Locke of South Africa.

ATHENS, March 1 -- A military court here sentenced eight persons, including a woman, to death and four others to life imprisonment today on charges of espionage involving high treason. Two of those who received life sentences were women.

THE European amateur photographer has less sophistication than the American but is more straightforward and sincere, Dr. Fritz Neugass told the Riverdale Camera Club last week. The European amateur never uses professional models, as is the practice with American clubs, never glamorizes, is "more concerned with mood than with prettiness and composition," and relies on his own impressions.

" THE ROAD" has been given an experimental prod in its rattling ribs recently and shows tentative signs of rejuvenation. The determined nudgers are the Council of the Living Theatre, set up last year to commemorate 200 years of drama in America, and the Theatre Guild, which has a protracted and sinewy tradition of its own in stage annals.

Bernard Sobel recently inquired in your columns why we didn't print a short synopsis of the operas in our programs instead of, as he put it, "forcing patrons to buy librettos." I sympathize with Mr. Sobel's feelings and would like to offer the following explanation of the situation.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, Air Force Chief of Staff, was tapped by President Truman today for another fourteen-month term.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Racing urged in a 108-page report today that a broad legislative study be undertaken immediately of the controversial subject of off-track betting on horse races.

THROUGHOUT the Government's 105 years of stamp-issuing there has been no legal case like the one last week when a private company sought to prevent the Postoffice Department from issuing a postage stamp.

" Don't count wool out as a textile fiber!" Progressive companies in the wool industry are determined to keep their product from a total or even partial eclipse caused by the rapid rise of manmade fibers.

IF you have a sharp eye for a deal, the right contacts and a well-insulated sense of propriety, you can parlay a modest stake of working capital in Washington into a respectable fortune almost as fast as you can spell Reconstruction Finance Corporation backward. In fact, you can sometimes get by without the capital.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- In line with the apparent Soviet purpose to keep Communist forces in Korea supplied with guns and ammunition and to insure a steady stream of similar tools of unrest for troubled areas of the Middle East, land-locked Czechoslovakia is starting a merchant marine of her own.

Robert A. Vogeler, American business man who was imprisoned in Hungary for seventeen months, expressed the opinion last night that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower could serve his country best in Western Europe while Senator Robert A. Taft ran for President on the Republican ticket.

LAKE WALES, Fla. -- On the roads outside this central Florida city there are signs pointing to something modestly called The Great Masterpiece. The signs lead to a fifteen-acre tract of palmetto scrub where buzzards wheel overhead and workmen have just finished hoisting into place a 24x12-foot mosaic reproduction of da Vinci's "The Last Supper."

PERHAPS in no sphere of English life is the English gift for combining divergent forces so well exhibited as in the Established Church, where Protestant and Catholic elements, freedom and authority, individualism and tradition are blended.
BONN Germany, March 1 -- A wage bonus plan, introduced in the Ruhr coal mines at the behest of United States "authorities, is bringing important results. Production has increased beyond expectations.

A tall, rugged Norseman stood at attention here last week as the Norwegian consul general pinned on his lapel the 1951 gold medal of the Norwegian Shipowners Association. His piercing blue eyes were misty and an embarassed smile crept over his broad face.

THERE is a peculiarity inherent in staging television drama which will cause a meticulous director to beat his head against the wall quicker than a director in the theatre or movies. It is the matter of allowing an actor all the freedom of movement required to point up his characterization while following him with a TV camera that knows nothing of broken field running.
A new life began last week for a 12-year-old Puerto Rican boy who thought he was a child nobody wanted.

TWO roles, among the longest ever written for child actors, are currently being played on Broadway by children who have not reached their tenth birthday. They are Brandon de Wilde, 9, and Lydia Reed, 8, who perform with Helen Hayes in the recently opened "Mrs. McThing," by Mary Chase, author also of the fabulous "Harvey."

MADRID, March 1 -- Assistant Secretary of State George W. Perkins today flew to Paris after a series of conversations with Minister of Foreign Affairs Alberto Martin Artajo and other high Spanish officials during which he was understood to have given assurances that the United States Government had decided to embark on a policy of military and economic collaboration with Spain.

TO anyone conjuring up a surface picture of Paris in the Nineties the obvious elegances of the Right Bank present themselves -- Maxim's, the Jockey Club, red-plush boulevard cafes, the beau monde enjoying elaborate leisure along the leaf-patterned paths of the Champs-Elysees or the swank avenues of the Bois.

CINCINNATI, March 1 (AP) -- The National League said today it had appointed two new umpires and would try them out in spring exhibition games in Florida. If they do all right, they probably will be named permanent league umpires, officials added.

In a spine-tingling finish that had the onlookers out of their seats, Johnny Bach's Fordham basketball team upset its old rival, New York University, 59 to 57, in the thirty-second battle between the intracity foes at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon.

THERE is no richer personality in the American labor movement than David Dubinsky, and none whose career offers more fruitful opportunity for biographical analysis. Unfortunately this slim volume supplies no real answer to those bent on learning what the president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union is really like.

SINCE fairy stories are perilous merchandise, no one can blame Broadway managements for having regarded Mary Chase's "Mrs. McThing" as a hazardous project. There is no such thing as a pretty good fairy story on the stage, as there is no such thing as alchemy that almost works.
The stock market turned, firm and active in the final half-hour of yesterdays short session and closed irregularly higher. Price changes were limited generally to small fractions.

UNDER the auspices of the Junior Council, five illustrious writers filed out on the platform of the Museum of Modern Art's auditorium one night last week. They settled themselves like characters in a minstrel show, with the museum's Monroe Wheeler as interlocutor and novelist Glen-way Wescott, directing an almost professionally boyish charm at the audience, as end man.

Twenty months ago when war broke out in Korea it was clear that Soviet imperialism represented a real and present threat to democracies everywhere. It was imperative that we increase our fighting strength as rapidly as possible. Our prompt move to join in collective security against aggression had the whole-hearted support of the vast majority of the American people.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 1 -- Navy's basketball team scuttled Army, 60 to 55, today in the traditional clash that brought the season to a close for the service rivals. A snowstorm snarled traffic and delayed the arrival of the officials. The midshipmen finally found smooth sailing late in the fourth period to the dismay of a partisan gathering of 5,000 in the field-house.
Four airlines will become new tenants of the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, today when they shift their operations from La Guardia Airport to that terminal.

ROME, March 1 -- The continued vulnerability of surface craft to underwater attack despite the improvement in methods of detecting and "killing" submarines is one of the lessons that are emerging from Exercise Grand Slam, which has kept United States, British, French and Italian naval forces engaged for the last five days in simulated warfare throughout the western Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The North Atlantic Treaty has been all over the front pages this week, but it still rates with sex and atomic energy as something everybody talks about but doesn't quite understand. Accordingly, it may be useful to review the remarkable story of this organization, which has now reached an important milestone.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 1 (AP) -- Puerto Ricans will decide Monday whether they want more power for their Government, alternately criticized as a "dictatorship" and defended as democratic and progressive.

Under the direction of Dr. Nicholas Rashevsky the University of Chicago is applying mathematics to the size of crowds, the way rumors spread, and the retention of dust and soot in the lungs. In fact, every human and animal activity falls within the purview of the mathematicians. That is how it happens that Dr. H. D. Landahl, a member of the committee, is devoting his attention to gambling.

New Yorkers pay four times as much to support the Federal Government as they do to maintain their own increasingly costly municipal government, Dr. Neal Bowman of the National Association of Manufacturers reported last night.

Mrs. Gilbert Miller and Mrs. William Woodward are among a group of well-known women serving on the arrangements committee for the April in Paris Ball, to be held on April 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the French Hospital and various Franco-American philanthropies.

IF the word has not yet been invented, it is high time: Gandhiolatry -- the worship of Gandhi. A cult started in India before Gandhi's flesh was burned to ashes and he is now worshiped there as a deity. That was inevitable, but the interesting and perhaps significant development is the adoration that has spread to other countries.
At the age of 74, Dr. Alexander Marx, director of libraries, and Jacob H. Schiff, Professor of History at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, will make his first trip to Israel.

JUST for once let us not enter into any discussion whether opera ought to be sung in English. Just for once let us assume that opera in English has been accepted as one of the facts of life, just as a German "Carmen" is accepted in Vienna and a French "Rigoletto" in Paris.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- The Florida winter tourist season, once reckoned as reaching its peak between Jan. 15 and March 15, has been gradually stretching out over longer periods, but the most marked change has come this year, with the peak coming two to three weeks later than usual.
In Barbara Ward's "The Secret of the British Monarchy" (Feb. 17), I was interested in the statement that Edmund Burke was an English philosopher.

" Dentistry is on the verge of a new and exciting chapter in its quest for an ideal restorative material," says the Journal of the American Dental Association editorially. Its enthusiasm is inspired by eight scientific reports on dental fillings made of self-curing resins.

Have you been hearing any good books lately? For some time now Charles Laughton has been dashing about the country, reading the Gettysburg Address and fragments of famous novels and plays. With three equally distinguished colleagues -- Charles Boyer, Cedric Hardwicke and Agnes Moorehead -- he has been reading, or pretending to read, Shaw's "Don Juan in Hell."

Members of the Brown Alumnae Club of New York have taken over the performance of "Venus Observed," with Rex Harrison and Lilli Palmer in the leading roles, on the night of March 11 at the Century Theatre to augment the club's Scholarship Fund.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Col. V. S. Hsiang, former Chinese Nationalist Air Force officer, has confirmed reports that his wife and two sons, who left Washington quietly about a month ago, have probably entered Communist China, a spokesman for Colonel Hsiang's attorney said today.

THE Bolshevik Revolution of 1917 was largely a revolt against the concept of a class society. Yet thirty-five years later, the Soviet Union is as markedly stratified as the Imperial Russia it replaced. Soviet theoreticians, far from denying this, make a point of the fact that the U. S. S. R. is not a classless utopia.

CONCORD, N. H., March 1 -- While New Hampshire delegates will not swing much weight in next summers nominating conventions -- may even have trouble landing hotel reservations when they reach Chicago -- the Presidential primary here on March 11 will have a psychological impact on the future hopes of at least five major Presidential possibilities.
With adjourned games holding up the completion of five rounds in the international chess masters tournament at the Club Capablanca in Havana yesterday, pairings were announced for the sixth round.

A QUIET novel with a serene surface and some murky depths, "The Works of Love" deals with the small adventures and dim aspirations of a man named Will Brady. He is presented just a bit as if he were an Everyman, the twentieth-century American variety.

The ready-to-wear market was only moderately active last week and there were scattered reorders for summer merchandise here, resident buying offices reported. Wholesale prices generally continued soft, offering exceptional promotion values which have been receiving good consumer response.
THE author of "The Blue Ice" and other well-documented tales of entrapment and pursuit laid in exotic places has now written one laid in England and Germany at the time of the Berlin airlift.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Washington officials are revising their predictions about the long-heralded "civilian pinch."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- A five-year tropical wood testing program at the Yale School of Forestry has disclosed a tropical hardwood almost five times stronger than white oak, North America's most commonly used hardwood.

Your article in last Sunday's TIMES in the column "Through the Mill" is excellent. I agree with every word you wrote. Surely, there is a great obligation not to distort our literary masterpieces. By faithful portrayal in this glorious new medium our classical gems can be made to thrill and delight countless millions that the printed page has not reached.

WITHOUT underestimating the value of education, it is still possible to believe that the most important project of the newly organized dance department of the Juilliard School of Music under the direction of Martha Hill is its plan for making the school, with its admirable facilities, something of a production center.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 1 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury has indicted three grain elevator operators on charges that they illegally disposed of more than half a million bushels of Government-owned corn and wheat. The indictments, announced last night, also charged the three men with making false statements in contracting with the Commodity Credit Corporation for storage of the grain.

" JUST look at my hands!" a young mother of our acquaintance remarked the other day in a tone of mixed sorrow and resentment. "Here we sit surrounded by a sea of mud." (The family had just moved into a new house in a new, as yet unsodded, development.) "

Intelligent, musical singing was presented by Jean Marie Schneck, mezzo-soprano, who made her Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon. Her musicality was attested by the solid nature of her program -- Scarlatti, Schubert, Brahms, French composers -- with few of the frills and senseless salon pieces so often encountered.

A NEW project in the entertainment of the armed forces of the United States in Europe, which will bring American professional theatre to their barracks doors, will be launched in Salzburg Wednesday. "Broadway Playhouse," a stock company of professional actors, will present Norman Krasna's 1947 Broadway hit, "John Loves Mary," and then go on tour with it through Austria, Germany, Italy, Greece, North Africa and Trieste.

WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohio, March 1 -- Samuel R. Guard, editor of the Breeder's Gazette in Louisville and president of the Sheep Farmers of America, Inc., urged here today the doubling of the sheep population of America, particularly on the farms east of the Missouri River.

Snow made an eerie fairyland of Fort Tyron Park yesterday but could not obliterate the hopes of those who run the medieval museum called the Cloisters for acquiring an espaliered tree, the seeds of the mandrake and the seeds of the poison hemlock.

THE wildfowlers of this country have become rather weary of promises that are always "going to be" fulfilled but seem to get sidetracked somewhere in the Department of the Interior, with the result that it has become necessary to introduce legislation in Congress to bring about changes that were legalized two years ago.

WITH all five of its season's novelties duly accomplished, the New York City Ballet will settle down for its last two weeks at the City Center for a peaceful period of concentrating on performance alone. An interesting novelty will be Hugh Laing's first appearance in "Tyl Ulenspiegel" next Sunday afternoon.
ANDOVER, Mass., March 1 -- The Exeter basketball team defeated Andover today by a 65-58 score. Ahead three times during the game, Andover made a late rally which failed when Exeter froze the ball.

" BY a long, immense and reasoned derangement of all the senses," the young Arthur Rimbaud proclaimed eighty years ago, "the poet makes himself a seer." By seeking in himself "all forms of love, pain and madness," by turning himself into "the great sick man, the great criminal, the great accursed," the poet "reaches the unknown; and if, maddened, he should end by losing understanding of his visions, at least he has seen them."
The trans-Atlantic coal market last week closely followed the pattern thus far in 1952, with little activity observed and few vessel "fixtures," or contracts for shipments being made final.

Forty members of the New York County Council of Jewish War Veterans donated yesterday to its second blood bank drive. Bad weather reduced the number of donations at the Red Cross center, 70 West Fortieth Street.

FOR THIS WEEK: All house plants do better if there are containers with water about the room to add humidity. This helps even geraniums whose soil should dry out between waterings. . . . Don't start tomato seed too early. March 20 to April 1 is soon enough if seedlings are transplanted outdoors about May 10. . . .

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 -- An American citizen held by Argentine authorities since Feb. 14 on suspicion that he might be involved in an anti-Government plot was released into the custody of the United States Embassy early this morning, Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker announced today.
TOKYO, Sunday, March 2 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,176, for Saturday's operations:

MIAMI BEACH -- Vacationists will find March and April the two best months of the year at south Florida's Gold Coast resorts and present indications are that tardy tourists will outnumber the early arrivals before the current season ends.

RICHMOND, Va. ONE out of four persons in this country is a Red Cross member. One out of ninety is a Red Cross volunteer. Thus it is clear that the American Red Cross, which opens its annual fund drive this month, is far more than a service organization; it is people -- neighbors helping neighbors, humanity turning decent thoughts into decent deeds.

RENO, Nev., March 1 (UP) -- Laverne V. Redfield, who was robbed of almost $2,500,000 in what is believed to be the nation's biggest burglary, said today he had been "pretty stupid" to have kept such wealth in his home.

Shlomo Z. Shragai, the first elected Mayor of Jerusalem, will arrive next Wednesday morning at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, and will be greeted by Grover Whalen in behalf of Mayor Impelletteri. On Thursday, a public reception will be given for Mayor Shragai in front of City Hall by Mayor Impelletteri.

Their objective being second place in the Eastern division of the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbockers took a step in that direction last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, where they overwhelmed the Boston Celtics, 105 -- 86.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Hopes for revival of the Alaska statehood bill received a lift today when Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, told the bill's sponsors that he would leave his sickbed to file a motion Monday for Senate reconsideration of the measure.

DO book clubs make a best seller out of a book? Or do they simply monopolize books that are potential best sellers? You can draw your own conclusions from a departmental survey of the fiction list this week. Nine of the sixteen novels thereon have been distributed to the captive audiences of three different clubs -- six to the B-O-M, two to the Dollar Book Club and one to the Literary Guild.*

The investment world is bracing itself for the biggest demands for new money to be made by corporate business on the public market since yields on basic Government securities were unpegged by the Federal Reserve System last year.

AS a variation on the headlong and exhausting push for Miami which a lot of New York drivers, off on spring vacations, will attempt in the next few weeks, there is an easier and more rewarding way of doing it. That is, simply, to remember that the coastal routes between New Jersey and Florida offer some of the finest touring country in the world for anyone who will take the time.

Six more liberal arts colleges have joined with the Columbia University School of Engineering in a combined plan providing students with a five-year course of study leading to both the bachelor of arts and engineering degrees. The inclusion of these colleges brings the total number of liberal arts schools participating in the plan to twenty.

THIS is a book of personal memoirs by a much-traveled young Japanese woman, Yoko Matsuoka (no relation to war criminal Yosuke Matsuoka), who was born into a family of distinguished journalists and educators.

Egypt's Prime Minister, Aly Maher Pasha, chose what seemed to be an inopportune moment yesterday to hand in his resignation. During his incumbency of a little over a month he had appeared to be working toward an agreement with the British for an amicable settlement of the Suez controversy and, indeed, was to have been conferring yesterday with the British Ambassador, Sir Ralph Stevenson.

THE mechanics of pay-as-you-see television appear to have been satisfactorily worked out by the International Telemeter Corporation through the development of a coin box easily attachable to any receiving set which automatically decodes a scrambled picture signal when the required amount of nickels, dimes, quarters or half dollars are deposited.

MILWAUKEE, March 1 -- H. J. Heinz 2d of Pittsburgh, president of the H. J. Heinz Company, was elected president of the Community Chests and Councils of America, Inc., as the organization ended its thirty-third national conference today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 -- A charge that West Coast shipyards would be returned to a "ghost status" as a result of a bargaining election among shipyard carpenters and machinists, ordered this week by the National Labor Relations Board, was made yesterday by the Bay Cities Metal Trades Council.

When the Federal income tax law was amended to provide that a stock dividend is taxable to the extent that it constitutes income under the Sixteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution, it was thought that this branch of the law would be fairly settled. Exceptions, however, continue to arise.

Asia: Two Stalemates Korea and Indo-China jut out into the sea on either end of the Chinese mainland like a bull's horns. Last week, the western powers held a firm grip on each of these horns, but the bull's latent power still was a large threat.
WASHINGTON March 1 (UP) -- While the Federal Government digs deeper and deeper into the taxpayer's pockets, a big group of states is doing just the opposite, a country-wide survey showed today.
The stand of the Defense Department as reported by Anthony Leviero ("The 'Truth' Machine," Feb. 10) in prohibiting the use of lie detectors is perfectly correct.

IN this heart-warning story of Inyo, an Indian boy, the author has given us a memorable record of the last stand of the Paiute tribe when the white man invaded and settled the Indian's hunting grounds. It was one of the laws of this tribe that in time of famine the old and helpless would be sent out from the tepees with one last pack-basket full of food, never to return.

Gertrude Samuels' article entitled "Court of First Resort for the Family" appeared last Jan. 6. For many years I urged upon the judges of the City Court of Buffalo the establishment of such an institution, but without success.

The New York State non-occupational disability benefit program has worked so well in its first eighteen months that it has disproved the fears of the "prophets of gloom" who predicted its collapse within six months, the Workmen's Compensation Board said yesterday in its report to Governor Dewey.

HONG KONG, March 1 -- Fourteen persons, including two Americans, were injured in Chinese riots that broke out today in Kowloon after British authorities had refused to permit a "comfort mission" to enter this colony from Red China.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- Today's prices of livestock reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

PARIS, March 1 -- The downfall of the Cabinet of Edgar Faure this week by a vote in the National Assembly should be traced as much to its political as to its economic causes. This will make formation of a new coalition doubly hard.

Pressed to find new capital in order to serve the expanding credit needs of the defense economy, commercial banks are taking a new look at the desirability of preferred shares. In nearby New Jersey one bank management has already adopted a proposal to offer $1,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock, and the plan will be submitted to stockholders at a special meeting this week.

MARCH is a fairly busy time for the fruit grower, whether he has only a few trees in the back yard or a full-fledged orchard. Among the several chores, fertilizing is perhaps the most important. Pruning and dormant spraying are also on the agenda.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 -- Gushing Oil, a handsome chestnut colt owned by Sam E. Wilson Jr., overcame a poor start to win the $20,000 added Louisiana Derby by a length today. The heavily backed and heavily weighted Oh Leo finished last in the twenty-fifth running of the Fair Grounds race.

CRITICISM of present camera design and photographic materials was voiced last week by Berenice Abbott in a talk to an overflow audience at the Village Camera Club. "What we need of equipment is this," she said: "Let it possess as good a structure as the real-life content which surrounds us.

THE praiseworthy object of the exhibition at the Rose Fried Gallery, "Duchamp Freres Soeur," is to remind us, if need there still be, of one of France's most spirited artist-families, whose achievements brilliantly, and idiosyncratically, illuminate art's last half century.

THE reasons behind the resignation of Wayne Coy as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission stress with special vividness one of the critical problems in contemporary government: inadequate pay for important Federal jobs.

CAIRO, Ill., March 1 (UP) -- Twenty-one Negro children here have been transferred to schools normally reserved for white pupils despite the arrest of eight persons on charges of conspiring to send Negroes to the schools.

Guido Cantelli completed his season with the N. B. C. Symphony yesterday when he conducted his eighth concert with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall. The event was heard on a coast-to-coast network and was broadcast from 6:30 to 7:30

THE science editor of the London News Chronicle, Ritchie Calder, reports here on a recent glimpse into the possibilities of a better life for the peoples who live in the broad marginal areas of North Africa and Western Asia.

March hurled down a 4.9-inch snow carpet for a leonine entry yesterday, the city's heaviest snowfall in three years. Traffic skidded into scores of accidents; power lines tumbled, darkening many New Jersey homes; and the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, and La Guardia Airport were closed for a time.

NOW that Leslie Baily has written "The Gilbert and Sullivan Book," no one need perform this pleasant labor again. Although the general story of the inspired but uneasy theatre partnership is known, Mr. Baily has assembled the pertinent facts in one place and discovered some more that have never been published.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Phil Rizzuto affixed his signature today to a 1952 contract to play for the Yankees. He and General Manager George M. Weiss had conferred until midnight last night. When Li'l Phil awoke this morning he decided to accept Weiss' last compromise offer.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 1 -- Nearly every North Korean division contains troops captured from South Korean forces and compelled to take up arms against their former comrades. Between 30,000 and 40,000 South Koreans taken as prisoners of war are in the Soviet-modeled uniform of the North Korean Army against their will.

LONDON, March 1 -- Seldom in Parliamentary history has an opposition motion enabled a Prime Minister to turn the tables on his critics so effectively as Mr. Churchill did this week when he showed that the former Labor Government had given the United States the same sort of pledge that its leaders were now criticizing him for making.

In an expansion move that will be carried out without use of Federation funds or solicitation of contributions, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will erect a large building for itself and affiliated agencies at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, on the south west corner diagonally opposite to Bloomingdale's.

Dr. John F. Fulton of Yale's School of Medicine maintains that because of the recent air crashes stronger safety belts are needed and that passenger seats should face the tail end of a plane to lessen the possibility of injury.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The United States and the rest of the free world should not rearm at a pace too rapid, lest they become economically crippled, the United States Chamber of Commerce declared today.

Further evidence of an easier trend in some lines and a brighter outlook for relaxed controls in certain industries became evident as February came to a close. Financial markets reflected the changing conditions by a more cautious attitude.

RICHMOND, March 1 -- Spring merchandising is making its appearance in Fifth District department stores in greater volume as clearance sales make room for incoming stocks. Trade remains brisk and February is expected to make a better comparison with the 1951 month than did January.

BONN, March 1 -- Federal Germany's place in the European Defense Community and the Germans' willingness to help defend that community have progressed remarkably as a result of the decisions taken at Lisbon.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 1 -- Princeton's hockey team routed Dartmouth, 6 -- 2, today in a penalty-filled Pentagonal League contest that threatened to break out into open warfare at Baker Rink.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The executive council of the State Federation of Labor denounced today as "class legislation of the rankest order" the Erwin-Travia bills, now before the Legislature, that would severely restrict labor unions financial participation in election campaigns.

THE only thing that can save one of the rarest mammals in the United States --- of which at most sixty specimens are still alive -- is Congressional action on H. R. 2897, a measure still locked up in the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.

Three more units of the United States Power Squadrons are on the threshold of admission. They will be the Sarasota (Fla.) Power Squadron, the Santa Barbara (Calif.) Power Squadron, and the Mansfield (Ohio) Power Squadron. Their recent applications have been approved by the committee on rules headed by F. Ritter Shumway of Rochester, a former national chief commander.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- House leaders were hinting tonight that they would accept further amendments to "soften up" the impact of the controversial Universal Military Training Bill. The changes were viewed as efforts to get badly needed doubtful votes for the legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore conceded today that in 1940, after extensive editing by himself, he had published for the Institute of Pacific Relations an article submitted as "a straight Marxist analysis."

BATON ROUGE, La., March 1 -- Temperamental Tommy Bolt fired clubs and angry words and below-par golf to take a two-stroke lead in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open tournament today. His fifty-four hole total was 208. Jack Burke, winner of the San Antonio and Houston open events, was even par in third-round play, to remain second with 210.

Fine English furniture and many varied accessories of quality will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The property in the sale, one of three to be held this week, is from Mrs. James H. Walker of Bethlehem Pa., and other owners.

IN "Legacy for Our Sons," Garth Hale has turned out a novelistic portrayal of the change in this country since the inception of the New Deal. For a starter, he pictures "the American Way" as one wherein the rugged individualist of private enterprise works hard, wins success, and enjoys "the fruit of his own labors."

OF Schumann's four symphonies, his Second is least often played. Many consider it his best, however; and surely Schumann never surpassed, in its intensity and mournful melodic beauty, the slow movement.

IN the upper strata of the bridge world, the bid that is most admired is the one that makes the opponents guess; the play that is most admired is the one that leads the opponents into error. The highest art is the art of deception.

As a Hungarian political exile I would welcome with deepest and sincerest emotions the complete termination of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Hungarian Communist Government. It's high time to sever all ties with that Muscovite puppet regime which has infringed the Yalta agreement and which illegitimately rules Hungary.

MIAMI, March 1 -- A tourist, winging his way to the sunny south, finds his only interest in the scenery is that it keeps its distance some 20,000 feet below. So he turns introspective and lets his mind wander as he approaches Florida for a look at the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah today and a more careful exploration of ten major league ball clubs later on.

MEXICO CITY, March 1 -- Communists' in an effort to enlist widespread Latin-American support for the international economic conference to be held in Moscow April 3 to 10, are saying that the meeting will be entirely private, without direct interference of the Soviet Union or any other government.
RE Mrs. Mary Colum's review of T. R. Henn's "The Lonely Tower: Studies in the Poetry of W. B. Yeats":
PARIS, March 1 (UP) -- Mlle. Jacqueline du Bief of France won the world figure skating championship tonight after her chief competition, Miss Tenley Albright of Newton, Mass., suddenly withdrew.

SOME reviews end with the smart device of a "sting in the tail"; I shall reverse the process and make at the outset what reservations I have about a book which is, upon the whole, fascinating. Maisie Ward of course always writes well, but all her books show that her conscientiousness sometimes outweighs her discrimination: she says just a little too much.

USUALLY little, if any, garden room can be spared for growing herbs. As a result, some gardeners limit this group to a few plants of parsley and chives outside the kitchen door. Growers not so easily discouraged, however, will find a border of flowering herbs a most satisfactory arrangement -- and one that will be enjoyable all summer long.

EASY-GOING is the word for the American public, but there are signs that the citizens will not stay that way long. A shift in thinking is apparent, and a deeper patriotism underlies it. When the pocketbook nerve is touched or a headline shouts of a Government servant caught dipping into the till Mr. Citizen becomes vocal and indignant.

THE beginning of tourist-class airline travel across the North Atlantic is still two months away but already some of the lines that were less than enthusiastic about it a few months ago are starting to wonder why it was not launched sooner. It is not only that advance bookings on the tourist class planes are running heavy for almost all of the lines.

AS ever, Alfred Leland Crabb writes a comparatively simple story, of uncomplex people, emotions unprobed by psychiatry and such; and also as ever, he remains close to his factual ingredients. In this "Tale of Soldiers Returning," he achieves effects equal to those of the best of his earlier works and, perhaps, a greater maturity than he has yet shown his readers.

ROME, March 1 -- Official circles in Rome today noted a willingness to negotiate a solution of the Trieste problem was implicit in the statements made by Marshal Tito yesterday, but considered his proposals completely unacceptable. It is thought that no official reply will be made because Premier Tito's latest suggestions were rejected by Premier Alcide De Gasperi in a press conference he held in Lisbon on Feb. 25.

PARIS (By Wireless). DURING the recent debate in the National Assembly the remark was often heard that if the Government did not fall from the crisis over the European army it might fall from the financial crisis.

THE boxwood moved into the restored Williamsburg, Va., is a flourishing testimonial to the fact that this glossy, highly prized "herb" will adapt itself to new surroundings whatever its age. The oldest bushes brought into the town are estimated to be about two hundred years old and they have made themselves at home without losing any of the thick, wide growth of tiny evergreen leaves.
The fashions for spring 1952 are a happy meeting of designs which take their inspiration from past eras and fabrics which have been created by modern science.

CONCORD, N. H., March 1 -- Three Presidential aspirants who consider the New Hampshire primary March 11 anything but "eyewash" will stump the state next week in one of the most hectic campaign wind-ups this region has ever seen.
ORANGEBURG, N. Y., March 1 -- The 1,450 veterans and their families in the Shanks Village housing project here were told officially today that the development would be demolished on Dec. 1, 1953.

PARIS, March 1 -- Obliged by the hostility of the Socialists and De Gaullists to abandon the idea of forming a national union among all French parties except the Communist, Paul Reynaud, wartime Premier was engaged tonight in seeking some kind of Cabinet combination that would have a majority in the Assembly.

Despite the sporadic criticism against the public schools for neglecting the "tool subjects" -- reading, writing and arithmetic -- evidence has accumulated in recent months that the schools are doing a pretty good job in this area.

Mervyn Shorr's rebounding and scoring paced City College's basketball team to a 59-to-48 victory over the New York Athletic Club in the Beaver's gymnasium last night. The triumph was the Lavender's eighth in eighteen games and brought the N. Y. A. C.'s record to 9 -- 11.

THROUGHOUT the northeastern United States and eastern Canada excellent snow conditions last week - end brought record numbers of skiers to winter resorts. In Vermont overnight accommodations that had to be pressed into service included farms, private homes, schoolhouses and even a funeral parlor.

CAIRO, March 1 -- Naguib al Hilaili Pasha, known as the "conscience of the Wafd," who was expelled from the Wafd party last autumn by its present leadership, formed a Cabinet tonight following the resignation early this afternoon of Aly Maher Pasha.

Normal living young mice have been obtained from ova (eggs) transplanted into the spleen for as long as sixty days before retransplantation into the ovary of a foster mother, says Dr. Clarence C. Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory at Bar Harbor, Me., and his colleagues Dr. Katherine P. Hummel, Mary Eddy and Barbara Rupple in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
PERHAPS the most flagrant example of the way TV producers have mistreated classics is "The Moonstone." I cite it in further evidence of your excellent article on this point in last Sunday's TIMES.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 1 (AP) -- Top-seeded Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of La Jolla, Calif., and Miss Althea Gibson of New York scored victories today in the St. Andrew invitation lawn tennis tournament.
ALBANY, Mar. 1 (UP) -- The following snow conditions at New York ski centers were reported today to the State Commerce Department:

BERLIN, March 1 -- With hardly the fanfare generated by the Soviet sector of Berlin, and with $100,000,000 from the United States already spent, West Berlin is running well ahead in the race between the two sectors to rebuild this war-torn city.
The wages of the American worker bought more meat at the end of 1951 than they did in June last year, according to tables prepared by the American Meat Institute.

THIS is a modest story which hovers between adventure and social commentary. The setting is the steaming back country of Guatemala where modern Calibans labor for whisky and similar semi-necessities of life. The white flotsam drifting from one dubious job to another feel themselves superior only in color, and their goal is to strike it rich and get out.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 1 -- Army scored a sweep in three events against Navy today as the cadets defeated the midshipmen in swimming, gymnastics and squash racquets.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- The five-day dispute that tied up dry cargo shipments in the port of Philadelphia was over today, but a snow storm that left docks and decks slippery prevented some 4,000 longshoremen from returning to work.

SUMMIT, N. J., March 1 -- Ignoring Federal aid, this city's Substandard Housing Board has announced the creation of a nonprofit organization to privately rebuild or renovate homes for families living in dwellings considered substandard or beyond repair.

MIAMI -- During mid-April a special series of concerts and plays will supplement the regular entertainment calendar in the Miami area. From April 14 to 20 the city of Miami and the Inter-American Music Council will be joint sponsors of a program of North and South American music and dancing as part of the local observance of Pan-American Week.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- With spring in the air and a slingshot on his desk, Fritz Heimann, attorney in the Office of Price Stabilization, yielded to temptation at lunchtime yesterday.

The steamship industry is actively opposing the reopening of the Merchant Ship Sales Act of 1946 to permit the sale of eight Government-owned, war-built vessels to citizens of the Republic of the Philippines.

EXETER, N. H., March 1 -- A brilliant exhibition by Phillips Exeter Academy's swimming captain, Bob Browning, gave the team its second straight victory over arch-rival Andover today by a score of 40 -- 35. It was the Exeter team's seventeenth straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Coast Guard has reversed a verdict of misconduct against twenty-three United States seamen for refusing to put to sea in the Isbrandtsen Lines' Flying Arrow in the Far East in 1949.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau said today it classifies most "merchandise clubs" -- pools designed to give customers a chance at big bargains -- as lotteries.

JOSE FERRER, the man of the month, last month, and probably next month, characteristically enough, arrived at the Cort Theatre the other night with just about sufficient time to get out of street clothes and into those he is wearing in his latest hit, "The Shrike."

Mrs. Alexander Dolowitz of 718 Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn, has been named chairman of a national steering committee to mobilize American women in setting up the first medical school in this country under Jewish auspices, Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of Yeshiva University, announced yesterday.
DANBURY, Conn., March 1 -- Many firemen in Fairfield County found their problems mounting this week.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Employment and unemployment are largely economic matters, but sometimes politics figures. Take Detroit, for example.

CALL Louis de Rochemont a man vitally interested in the national welfare. His latest production, "Walk East on Beacon," a drama in which the F. B. I. justifiably is given proper credit, is practically ready for the theatres. However, the producer already is delving into another subject of similar import.
The greatest expansion program in the history of medical education, to cost $250,000,000, is now under way in this country.

BOHUSLAV MARTINU, the prolific Czech composer now living here, almost always attracts the admiration of his listeners, although he sometimes fails to warm their hearts. A work which has both virtues is at hand this week on a ten-inch Urania disk, the Sonatina for Two Violins and Piano, (1931).

Religion in the future will be secure though its expression may assume outward forms different from those in the past, Rabbi Israel Goldstein predicted in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.

Rumanian Jews have suffered severe economic, cultural and political losses during the last five years under that country's Communist regime, the World Jewish Congress charged in a documented study released today.

DALLAS, March 1 -- Consumer buying in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District through January and the first half of February maintained a steady pace in contrast to marked fluctuations last year. Consumer soft goods generally are showing better sales record than durables, the bank reported in its monthly summary of district conditions.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Ted Williams, the Boston Red Sox' $100,000-year-slugger called to active duty as a Marine flier, signed a one-year contract today shortly after hitting training camp.

Prominent political figures of the city, state and nation took a ribbing last night when the Inner Circle presented its annual lampooning show, called "$ave Our $kins." The audience of 1,100 at the Astor Hotel included Mayor Impellitteri, most members of the Board of Estimate and many jurists.

LOUISVILLE, March 1 (UP) -- A driving lay-up shot by Lou Tsioropoulos with less than two minutes to play gave Kentucky a hair-raising 44-43 victory over Louisiana State tonight and its thirteenth Southeastern Conference basketball tournament title.

YOUR obituary of Alfred Einstein paid eloquent tribute to the passing of a great scholar. Great as was his contribution to our knowledge of music, the published works alone do not account for the unique influence this gentle and unassuming man exerted on his colleagues all over the world.

DANISH pastry, which has been adopted whole-heartedly by Americans, is served as regularly in coffee shops and lunch counters as doughnuts, corn-meal muffins and other breakfast breads considered native to this country.

THIS is the seemingly endless saga of a Schwabenland pig-herd who made a million packing meat in Chicago. "I say where there's a rill there's a way. A poor man don't always stay poor," should lend a notion both of Adolph Konrad and the dialogue Mr. Morris has fashioned to record his progress.

The state lent to the City Housing Authority yesterday $59,180,000 for construction of two low-income housing projects in Manhattan and Brooklyn. They will house 3,800 families in apartments for which the rent will be $9 a room, including utilities.

Last week's total eclipse of the sun was a one day's wonder. It was far away -- in Africa, the Middle East, Siberia. For the astronomers one solar eclipse is like another; for the people in its path it means many different things. In Africa last Monday witch doctors were using incantations to drive an evil spirit away from the sun.
PARIS, March 1 -- The real value of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's accomplishments at Lisbon will be measured by two reactions which cannot be gauged in advance.

AGAIN the landscape is the tattered field of Italy. Like the battles they describe, the war novels are slowly moving up the Italian boot "Victory Also Ends" takes us to the Po Valley and almost to the brink of victory.

Almost forty years in the construction industry has brought a full head of gray hair to Ralph E. DeSimone but it hasn't trimmed his appetite for bigger and better tunnels, bridges, docks or pipelines, to say nothing about a variety of other projects which run the range from ocean salvage to residential and hospital developments.

THE New Jersey Turnpike Authority moved quickly last week to implement the program outlined by Authority Chairman Paul L. Troast in this column last Sunday to remove the bottlenecks that have developed as use of the 118-mile toll road continued to exceed all official estimates.

IT would call for more than the Dark Continent, of course, to subdue Humphrey Bogart. Indeed, judging by the generally acclaimed "The African Queen" at the Capitol, quite the reverse appears to have occurred for Mr. Bogart and his colleagues, Katharine Hepburn, Director John Huston and Producer Sam Spiegel.

TOKYO, Sunday, March 2 -- No prospect exists for an early truce agreement in Korea and an exchange of prisoners captured in the nineteen-month war, Rear Admiral Ruthven E. Libby, United Nations delegate, said yesterday.
ITHACA, March 1 -- Cornell's basketball team set a new team scoring record in defeating Bucknell, 87-67, before 2,500 in Barton Hall tonight. The previous high was 82.

IN the forthcoming revival of Gluck's "Alcestis" at the Metropolitan Mme. Flagstad will take the title part for the first time in her career for her last appearance on the operatic stags It is a remarkable role for a retiring prima donna to undertake as the culmination of her development as all artist.

AS one of the original members of the "Brain Trust," Raymond Moley wrote part of President Roosevelt's acceptance speech in 1936. Mr. Roosevelt, revising the speech, "incorporated passages that seemed to be designed to inflame class feeling and bitter antagonisms."

More than 100 women headed by Mrs. Walter Maynard and including Mrs. Arthur Gray Jr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Peabody are serving on the women's committee aiding in the drive for funds for the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America.
The bitter continuing fight for determination of the final legal status of "fair trade" took on many of the aspects of a three-ring circus last week.

In Lisbon and in Paris The North Atlantic Allies last Monday in Lisbon concluded the most productive conference they have ever held. Four days later in Paris the Government of France, a key member of the alliance, fell. The two events were related.

Mayor Impellitteri has proclaimed March 12 as O. R. T. Day "in recognition of the noble and constructive work performed by Women's American O. R. T. in the economic rehabilitation of uprooted and underprivileged Jewish people throughout the world."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 -- The Yugoslav Government is awaiting with anxiety the second phase of the United States-British-French conference, now taking place in Washington, on the problem of economic aid to Yugoslavia.

Back in 1947 Prof. Jozef Cohen of the University of Illinois was recuperating from an automobile accident which kept him in a hospital for a year. One day, as he was shaving with a spherical or magnifying mirror, he noticed how it focused a beam of light. Then and there he conceived a way of bringing colors together from their purest source, a spectrum.
