A REVIEWER for THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 15 discusses "Birthright" as "the first commercially shown film dealing solely with the subject of syphilis." It is apparently a sincere but cinematographically homespun effort at a documentary drama from a county health department down in Georgia.

Stringing out its attack in fine style, New Jersey captured the annual George C. Sherman Memorial indoor polo tournament last night by beating the Squadron A Reserves, 14 -- 7, at the Squadron A Armory.

THERE'S not another field like the mystery novel for inspiring everybody with a desire to get into the act. There have been whodunits by operatic divas (both Wagnerian and Puceinian), Biblical scholars (both Protestant and Catholic), tennis aces, film stars, Broadway playwrights and an endless succession of lawyers, doctors and assorted university professors.

After conferring for five hours in the Municipal Building, city and state officials agreed yesterday that they were making progress in their discussion of Mayor Impellitteri's request to the state for additional financial aid and taxing power but they declined to be more specific.

WRITING in the carefree mood of summer vacation, Mr. Beim tells a light, easy story about two families and their season's acquaintances at an Atlantic Ocean resort. Bayberry Beach is a familiar kind of place with small cot tages, boardwalk, amusement park and a commercialized atmosphere.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- Two rare Assyrian tablets, 2,800 years old and said to be the only ones of their kind in this country, have been presented to the Yale University Babylonian Collection by Mrs. Julia Kahn of New York in memory of her mother, Mrs. Rebekah Kohut.

Roscoe R. Braham Jr., senior meteorologist of the university's Chicago Midway Laboratory, recently told the American Meteorological Society that most of the moisture and energy in a thunderstorm is dissipated without falling as rain or appearing as lightning.

LENNIE TRISTANO is one of the most astonishing of that astonishing race of "advanced" jazzmen. Records of his piano improvisations have attracted serious musicians as well as the bop crowd. He has a school where he coaches like-minded instrumentalists.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Mrs. Golda Myerson, Israel's Minister of Labor, said tonight her nation's economic difficulties were the result of a "self-imposed transition period of hardship" in order to achieve a highly industrial and productive framework within the nezt few years.

IT is some months since this reviewer paid any attention to records for children. With the arrival of a new batch, it seemed a good idea to have a look at some of the most recent products to see what, if any, progress has been made in this field.

Three years ago the Association of American Universities set up a commission to study the financial aspects of American colleges and universities. Aided by a $450,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation and Carnegie Corporation, the Commission on Financing Higher Education attracted some of the nation's foremost educators.

MIAMI, March 1 -- Blue Man, with a loop-the-field run from last place in the backstretch, and Charlie McAdam, with a front-of-the-pack charge in which he turned back repeated challenges, were the winners of the double-header running of the $50,000 added Flamingo Stakes for 3-year-olds before 32,209 brow-mopping customers at Hialeah today.

A BOY like Tom was destined for something exciting. It Just didn't seem fair to have him stuck by the window with a cold in his head when his whole class was going to the zoo. So it doesn't seem a bit surprising to the reader that, when he looked up from his book, there was a monkey on the window sill.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- All the predictions made last fall that Florida's west-coast resorts would have a good winter have come true. The 1951-52 season has set a record and tourists are still crowding into the area. Sarasota's Chamber of Commerce has just opened a "replacement bureau" with a person stationed at the telephone from 2 in the afternoon until 11 at night to check possible vacancies for desperate motorists seeking a night's shelter.

FRENCH playwrights fared badly on Broadway this season. In Paris they have not been doing much better. Anouilh, Roussin, Cocteau, Claudel, Ayme, Deval -- giants of the French stage -- they have been cut down, one by one, to human size by their own country's critics the better to roast them.

MONTREAL, March 1 -- The veteran Floyd Curry, a steady, unspectacular workman, scored twice tonight as the Montreal Canadiens swept to a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the hard driving New York Rangers before a capacity crowd of 14,443 at the Forum.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- Yale's hockey team strengthened its first-place position in the Pentagonal Hockey League by defeating Harvard, 4 -- 3, at the Arena tonight before a capacity junior prom crowd.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The New York State Citizens' Health Council ended its two-day organizational meeting today with the election of Dr. Robert Polson of the Cornell University Department of Rural Sociology, as its first temporary president.

One of the two pharmaceutical houses to which we owe the development of the chemicals that have produced remarkable results in the treatment of tuberculosis spent about a million and a quarter over the years and tested some five thousand compounds. Probably the other house had the same experience, one that is common enough in these days of systematic, organized industrial research.

Louis Slobodkin, sculptor and illustrator, will discuss "Illustrating Children's Books" at 6:15 P.M. Tuesday in the second lecture of the free spring series on art at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

IN the last half century Protestant Christianity in America has sought to become intellectually honest by overcoming religious obscurantism without destroying the valid insights of biblical theology. It has also sought to become widely effective by continuing the missionary movement and beginning the ecumenical movement of cooperation among denominations, and to become socially relevant by careful study of economic and political problems with prophetic concern for the downtrodden and oppressed.

THIS is a study of Protestantism's "common cause" -- the world-wide missionary movement of the last century and a half. Attention is focused upon the momentous missionary conferences which met at Edinburgh (1910), Jerusalem (1928), Madras (1938) and Whitby, Canada (1947).

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 1 -- India's eagerness to solve her own problems is a principal factor in her resistance to the lure of communism, Franklyn C. Rogers, Professor of Civil Engineering at Rutgers University, declared this week upon his return from the new republic.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Republican tax investigators threatened today to "yell like hell" over any attempt to soft pedal a pending inquiry into the New York Internal Revenue Office.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- The petroleum industry took sharp issue today with recent charges by Senator Hubert Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, that oil companies were evading $750,000,000 a year in taxes through tax law loopholes.

The first convoy to reach port safely in the Navy's Atlantic Fleet exercise Convex III, which is concerned with the protection of merchant shipping, arrived in Charleston, S. C., late Friday. This was announced here yesterday by the Eastern Sea Frontier headquarters.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 1 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower welcomed Greece and Turkey into his Atlantic defense camp today.

With the new wholesale price index which was introduced on Friday, the United States will be measuring its price movements with a yardstick more than twice as long as it has needed for most of its history.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Truman will appeal to the American people next Thursday night for support of a foreign military and economic program totaling $7,900,000,000.

TAKE a couple of intrepid young deep-sea divers, put them down in the waters off a deserted South Sea atoll, introduce as ruthless a villain as Long John Silver ever hoped to be, and you have the makings of a two-fisted mystery-adventure story.

SALISIBURY, Conn., March 1 -- Howard Jansen of the Norge Ski Club, Chicago, leaped 137 and 150 feet for 186.3 points to win the senior title of the national ski jumping championships today. Marty Wingsneff, a clubmate, was second with 180.3 points on jumps of 130 and 146 feet.

A second grant of $28,810 to the University of Illinois for its experimental pre-school for retarded children has been made by the National Institute for Mental Health of the United States Public Health Service. This grant will carry the program through Sept. 1, 1952.

Spring night-light glamour expresses itself in an airy manner. Fabrics sheer as butterfly wings float in full-skirted elegance. The short dress takes the lead over the long. There's a new in-between length favored by Jane Derby and called by her the "awkward" length.

THE chances are that Leonard Dubkin and I have been on cordial terms with the same sort of bat, though his association has been by far the more intimate and rewarding. He observedfor two years the behavior of a whole colony on the outskirts of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The armed forces are accepting, without comment or attempt to explain, the rejection by relatives of servicemen of medals awarded to heroes of the fighting in Korea.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Forty physicians from all over the state met here today to organize the State Blood Bank Association, a nonprofit group sponsored by the State Medical Society and designed to increase the amount of blood donations and the number of blood centers in the state.

THERE are certain writers, as different as Dickens from Kipling, who never shake off the burden of their childhood. The abandonment to the blacking factory in Dickens' case and in Kipling's to the cruel Aunt Rosa living in the sandy suburban road were never forgotten.

In his typical workmanlike fashion, Secretary of State Acheson Friday night outlined the perspectives before us in the light of decisions taken at London and Lisbon these last two weeks -- "a time of historic decision for the forces of peace." He pointed out that these meetings had resulted in five major accomplishments toward such goals as creating a stronger North Atlantic defense force and reintegrating Western Germany into the European community.

IT is unfortunate that the many volumes of the Jewish Talmud are so little known and appreciated by Christians. Today the work is available in several languages, including English, and there are various commentaries by modern Jewish, Catholic and Protestant scholars.

South and '52 The eleven states in the Solid South -- Virginia, North and South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Tennessee, Arkansas and Texas -- cast 128 of the 531 electoral votes for the Presidency. At the Democratic convention, they have 290 of the 1,230 delegates. At the Philadelphia convention in July, 1948, the South put forth its own candidate.

WASHINGTON. SEVERAL years ago, an Englishman named Stephen Potter wrote a book called "The Theory and Practice of Gamesmanship or the Art of Winning Games Without Actually Cheating." Essentially, the purpose of his book was to demonstrate how to rattle an opponent, or put him off his game and thus how to win games without really being able to play them.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The United States Government is following the political crisis in Egypt with unusual interest.

In a thrilling climax Bishop Loughlin Memorial dethroned Cardinal Hayes as the City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion yesterday. The Purple gained its twenty-second victory in the meet's twenty-five year history by tallying 34 1/2 points to 33 for the Cardinals.

ST. PETERSBBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Yankee stars gauged up on General Manager George Weiss in a "grab" for Joe DiMaggio's $100,000 but they nicked George for only a small portion of it, Shortstop Phil Rizzuto revealed today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Faced by a serious shortage of nurses, the Health Resources Advisory Committee of the Office of Defense Mobilization announced today the appointment of a special subcommittee to study how to make the best possible use of the available number of hospital workers.
BANGOR, Me., March 1 (UP) -- Bennett H. Fishler, New Jersey newspaper publisher, has purchased an interest in The Bangor Evening and Sunday Commercial.

A MUTED cacophony of anguished sounds which recently twanged the Southern California welkin was not, as some suspected, a periodic regional stirring of the earth's crust, nor yet atomic palpitations in adjacent Nevada, but merely the labor pains of a leopard changing his spots.

With the aluminum supply situation taking a definite turn for the better, the segment of the Government which has been advocating further expansion of aluminum-production capacity may have to recast its thinking.

HYBRID vegetables and flowers are becoming more and more widely grown since the time some thirty years ago when hybrid corn first revolutionized a whole industry. Crossing two varieties of flowers has become common enough so that amateurs create new kinds.

Just one more word about Cleopatra. Prof. Richard M. Haywood's "The Real Cleopatra, Caesar and Antony" (Feb. 3) was very good in pointing out how far removed the real person is from the "Ouled-Nails" that we see on stage and screen impersonating the famed queen.

FORT ATKINSON, Wis., March 1 -- One of the first acts of a Republican Administration, if elected in November, should be "a re-examination of our military structure," Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio told Wisconsin audiences today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- A last-ditch attempt to get a permanent personal registration bill onto the floor of the Legislature will be made Tuesday when its sponsor, Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican of Manhattan, offers a group of "safeguard" amendments to the Assembly Judiciary Committee.

IN the northern tip of the Philippines lies the wild, mountainous country of the Igorot tribes -- a colorful people noted for their "head-hunting pastimes." Kate Bigelow Montague, who lived in Igorot country during the Thirties with her gold - mining husband, shows genuine respect for these simple and passionate people whose customs were old and brutally forthright, but who nevertheless possessed integrity, bravery and skill.

OBERSTDORF, Germany, March 1 (AP) -- Keith Wegeman of Denver, member of the United States Olympic ski team, jumped 414 feet 3 inches today in the international "ski-flying" tournament, but could do no better than fourth place.

TOKYO, March 1 -- As the marathon truce negotiations entered their eighth month with no end in sight, the question began to loom larger whether the Chinese and the North Korean Communists, with Moscow at their backs, really want a truce.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Speaker Rayburn's ban on televising and broadcasting of House committee hearings carried profound political implications, as perhaps no one recognized better than the venerable Texas politician himself.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Mrs. David W. Wallace, 89-year-old mother of Mrs. Harry Truman, rallied today from an illness that became so serious last night that President Truman summoned her three sons to her bedside at Blair House.

THE visitor to the Mediterranean who laments that he hears only American spoken on the Riviera beaches during the season and complains that he did not cross the Atlantic to meet the boys from home at the Nigresco in Nice can quickly escape to an utterly "foreign" atmosphere by going to Corsica.

CANTON, N. Y., March 1 -- Middlebury's determined Panthers held stubbornly to its lead today to turn aside a resurgent Dartmouth team in the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association senior championship held in conjunction with St. Lawrence University's seventeenth annual winter carnival.

DURING the next two months the spring floral displays in private and public gardens and along municipally planned blossom trails will be a major tourist attraction throughout the Deep South. Heralding the season are the azaleas, camellias, gardenias and sub-tropical plants in Florida's Cypress Gardens near Winter Haven.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur has urged his followers in New Hampshire to support Senator Robert A. Taft in the state's Presidential primary March 11.

HAMAR, Norway, March 1 -- Unconcerned by one false start, Ken Henry of Chicago streaked to the world 500-meter speed-skating championship and Norway's brilliant Hjalmar Andersen set a new meet record in winning the 5,000-meter title today. These were the same men who scored victories in the Winter Olympics at Oslo last week, and Andersen was favored to take tomorrow's 1,500 and 10,000 meter races as he did in the Olympics.

GRANDMA MOSES touches an Achilles heel of sentiment in nearly every urban American. The self-taught artist of Eagle Bridge, N. Y., who thought of her first pictures as "no more than of doing fancy work," paints at a tip-up table which she prefers to an easel.

Although unit sales in most departments held up well, lower prices brought about an 8 per cent decline in New York and Brooklyn department stores last week. An exact estimate of sales was difficult to ascertain owing to the liquidation activity at Loeser's.

THE Belgian - born French writer Henri Michaux was admired by such European intellectuals as Gide. His writings were originally culled into the present form to make an anthology in France; this American edition is bilingual, with facing pages in French and English.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft is supported by a majority of the 52 delegates to the Republican Presidential nominating convention chosen so far in six states.

SOUTH African fiction (of which we are seeing more and more these days) seems to fall naturally into two types -- the exotic, love-on-the-veld kind, as practiced by writers like Stuart Cloete and Daphne Rooke, and the novel of social protest, as exemplified in Alan Paton's "Cry, the Beloved Country."

PRINCETON, N. J., March 1 -- Princeton moved into sole possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight with an easy victory over Dartmouth, 74 -- 46, before 2,500 fans in Dillon Gymnasium.

There has been much discussion recently about John Durang, the alleged first native American professional actor, born in 1768 and appearing on the stage for the first time in or about 1785. Undoubtedly someone has been misinformed.
A survey to determine the needs of servicemen and women stationed at camps and bases throughout the country will be made by the United Service Organizations, it was announced yesterday.

A machine has been developed that measures the thickness of industrial products -- plastics, paper, rubber, tape, steel, cardboard -- by means of nuclear energy with an accuracy hitherto unattainable. The device, which represents an important application of what the scientists, spurred by war necessity, discovered at Oak Ridge, was studied in operation last week in a desolate section of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, hard by Greenpoint and Maspeth, Queens.

Fifteen hundred passengers on eight B. M. T. subway trains were delayed more than an hour yesterday afternoon when a Brooklyn-bound Brighton Beach express was halted on the Manhattan Bridge by a fire on the third rail. Four hundred persons on the Brighton train were escorted by way of a catwalk to a bus on the bridge and taken to the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn.
The scheduled airlines of the world, except those in Russia and China, did a gross business of $1,700,000,000 in 1951.
An American shoe manufacturer and an English producer have made reciprocal arrangements that are believed to be unique in the industry.
A TALENTED novelist and playwright, Kate O'Brien, has assumed a task of whose difficulties she is aware. She writes:

AS in "Adopted Jane" and "Country Cousin," Miss Daringer here explores the problems of a child meeting a new family situation, this time in a household dominated by a stepmother and her three children.

IF you are sentimental about Paris -- and who can fail to be? -- a new Vox disk in a handsomely designed album should arouse nostalgic sighs. It is called This Is Paris, and it contains a busy and ecstatic montage of voices and sounds hymning the excitement, romance and traditions of freedom of this storied capital.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The annual wrangle over renewing the Defense Production Act with the controls it authorizes over all parts of the national economy opens next week in Congress. The Senate's Banking and Currency Committee begins hearings on the measure Tuesday with the expectation that final action by Congress will be taken well in advance of June 30, when the present act expires.
MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- A College boy from Philadelphia and a fireman from West Palm Beach, Fla., advanced into the final round of the Dixie amateur golf tournament today.

A pair of discarded salad bowls inspired the design for a protected bird feeder. Because of the shape of the bowls, squirrels are unable to get a toehold. Bullying bluejays, too, are foiled, since the space between the two bowls is not sufficiently large to accommodate them. Yet it is adequate to welcome birds who are now beginning to return from the South. And, most of all, this feeder provides protection for birds and seed.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 1 -- Mrs. John Payson Adams' Miche, who finished second in the $141,200 Santa Anita Handicap today, was declared the winner by the stewards, who ruled he had been fouled by Intent in the run down the stretch.

The conclusions of the recent National Conference on Retirement of Older Workers that there must be some better way of determining an individual's ability to continue to be a productive worker than basing it solely on the turn of a calendar page were brought home forcibly to this writer a few months ago after a discussion seminar of Armed Forces officers on manpower problems in mobilization.

IF you are sentimental about Paris -- and who can fail to be? -- a new Vox disk in a handsomely designed album should arouse nostalgic sighs. It is called This Is Paris, and it contains a busy and ecstatic montage of voices and sounds hymning the excitement, romance and traditions of freedom of this storied capital.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The annual wrangle over renewing the Defense Production Act with the controls it authorizes over all parts of the national economy opens next week in Congress. The Senate's Banking and Currency Committee begins hearings on the measure Tuesday with the expectation that final action by Congress will be taken well in advance of June 30, when the present act expires.
MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- A College boy from Philadelphia and a fireman from West Palm Beach, Fla., advanced into the final round of the Dixie amateur golf tournament today.
An American shoe manufacturer and an English producer have made reciprocal arrangements that are believed to be unique in the industry.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 2 -- A draft agreement that would grant to the Dutch a "most favored nation" status in Indonesia but not "national treatment" is one of the principal fruits of six weeks of negotiations here to prepare a set of treaties to replace the twenty - sixth - month - old Netherlands-Indonesia union.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri, expressed the fear today that in televised Congressional hearings "even the most well-intentioned members of Congress would have one eye on the camera."

One of the underlying ideas in the Point Four program is that assistance to "underdeveloped" areas should be something more than economic aid. The export of skills is no less important than the shipment of materials and money. The skills lie in human beings, and the program therefore means that individual persons who are adequately equipped should go into action to make their abilities available in a wide field.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its opposition to bills pending in Albany that would increase the number of judges in several courts in this city. It declared that the legislation stemmed from bipartisan deals to provide "rich gravy for both major parties."

NEWBURGH, N. Y., March 2 (AP) -- More than 80,000 civilian vol-i unteers reported to observationl !posts and filter centers today in a surprise twelve-state exercise called by the Eastern Air .Defense tforce. It was the first time the I ivolunteers had been called into action without advance warning.

ALBANY, March 2 (AP) --The temporary State Commission on Revision of the Civil Service Law today postponed for another year submission to the Legislature of recommendations for wholesale changes in what it called the "complex, confusing and unworkable" present Civil Service statute.

ALBANY, March 2 -- One possible solution for New York's financial crisis that is being explored semi-officially, even though it lacks any official sponsorship at the moment, is the transfer of the city's publicly owned transit system from the Board of Transportation to an autonomous, self-financing authority.

GUATEMALA, March 2 -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman denied in a message to Congress yesterday that his Government had decided to expel the United Fruit Company from Guatemala or expropriate its properties.

The can opener, unrightfully considered as dull a topic as the toothbrush, has been subjected to close attention such as it never had before, thanks to the Can Manufacturers Institute. Result: The organization, whose members produce 95 per cent of the nation's tin cans, has awarded, after three years' study, a seal of approval to nine can openers, both hand-type and wall-type.

Over much of the world, particularly in Asia, a major segment of Communist propaganda is directed toward the peasantry, who comprise the bulk of the population in underdeveloped countries. If they will embrace Stalinism, these peasants are told, their poverty will be ended; they will be given land; they will be freed of the heavy exactions of landlords and rural loan sharks.
Today's story deals with an all-American fashion, that of the cotton shirtwaist. Cotton is essentially an American fabric, the shirtwaist an important part of the American woman's wardrobe.
TORONTO, March 2 -- Ontario is pushing ahead with its most ambitious hydroelectric project, involving the development of 1,200,000 horsepower from the Niagara River.
The American Geographical Society, in its 100th year, faces a financial crisis it hopes to resolve with the first fund-raising efforts in its history.

Pan American World Airways will file a brief with the Civil Aeronautics Board today asking that it renew without change the competitive route structure for American-flag air carriers flying the North Atlantic between the United States and Europe. Some of the trans-Atlantic route certificates expire next July.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -- Horace Stoneham, Giants president, was in a sunshiny mood today though a cold wind in the wake of overnight rains made it impossible for Manager Leo Durocher to go through with a scrub game he had scheduled for the squad.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Area of the Methodist Church, in his sermon yesterday as guest preacher at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared that man was "beyond the reach of any human dictator" in matters affecting his eternal welfare.

The Communists are cooperating with the totalitarian regimes of Latin America. In Argentina, Communist criticism of the Peron Government has subsided to a whisper. In Peru, one of the principal leaders of the Communist party, Juan P. Luna, was elected to Congress with the support of dictator Manuel Odria.

A new novel by Paul Gallico, "Trial by Terror," to be published by Knopf on April 21, has been chosen for May distribution by the Literary Guild. In his sixth novel Mr. Gallico tells of an American newspaper man who sets out to investigate the "voluntary" confessions extorted by the Communists behind the Iron Curtain.
The following reports from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in all parts of the country show that the nurse shortage is serious and is getting worse.
The Canadian dollar crossed par and reached a premium of 1/32 of one per cent in terms of the American dollar, last Friday, for the first time since 1939, and then again in 1938.

Mr. Leslie Gould, financial editor of The New York Journal-American, devoted two of his daily columns in that newspaper last week to a discussion of the new wholesale price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, whose details had just been released.

New York, having increased its park recreational facilities five-fold in the last eighteen years, is failing to protect park users from assaults by hoodlums, Park Commissioner Robert Moses charged yesterday.
The transportation and utilities section of the Red Cross fund campaign announced yesterday that the section's quota was $680,000. The total amount sought in the city is $6,700,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- A motion picture without dialogue, in which the camera and natural sound effects will tell the story, is the bold plan that Clarence Greene and Russel Rouse will undertake in their next film, "The Thief."

The package is supposed to sell the product, and keep it sold. That is its theory and its reason for existence, more imporatnt even than protection for the contents. From Toronto comes the anecdote of the bacon that consisted chiefly of stripes on the package and fat inside.
In New York City we have had the Dimout, Blackout, Brownout and now, with the coming of each day, we have the Glareout.

After almost a decade of immense labor the Soviet Union has completed, or almost completed, a series of strategic railroad lines revolutionizing the transport pattern of much of Siberia and Central Asia.

NASHUA, N. H., March 2 (UP) -- Supporters of Senator Robert A. Taft were jubilant today over what they considered to be General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's first open endorsement of the Ohio Republican for President.

A Commissioner of the United States Court of Claims is taking testimony on an unusual case in which a Government-owned steamship line is suing the Government for recovery of $609,110 allegedly paid for the maintenance of passengers erroneously detained by the Immigration Service.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Senate investigators said today that the Navy had allowed "43,000 pounds of frozen smoked ham, valued at $23,000, to spoil in a supply depot at San Diego, Calif."
BOSTON, March 2 (AP) -- An underhanded toss by Harry Gallatin with six seconds remaining gave the New York Knickerbockers an 89-87 victory over Boston today in a National Basketball Association game.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Congress, which undertook to slim itself through a 1946 Reorganization Act, is bulging right out of the Capitol.

Black Hills Power and Light Company is offering to stockholders rights to subscribe to 33,730 additional shares of common stock at $17.75 a share at the rate of one share for each six held. The offering is underwritten by a banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc.

LONDON, March 2 -- Postponement of the budget for one week has given rise to considerable guessing as to the real reason for the action which has considerably increased the depression in the stock markets.

An authoritative line on United States Olympic track and field prospects will not be available until outdoor competition gets going full blast two months hence. However, indoor developments provide cause for optimism that the Stars and Stripes will be strongly represented at Helsinki this summer.
DAVOS, Switzerland, March 2 (AP) -- Martin Strolz of Austria won the Parsenn Derby race today in a field of more than 100 skiers from ten nations.

An unusual occurrence took place in the final period when Freddy Glover, sentenced to two consecutive penalties, slipped out at the expiration of the first banishment. Lew Hogg, the penalty timekeeper, admitted the lapse, and promised it would not happen again.

MARITTA WOLFF'S new novel, "Back of Town,"* is a love story without any love in it -- only sex and passion and jealousy and spite and the persistent self-destructive folly of misguided mortals. It isn't convincing enough in its motivation to be the major novel which Miss Wolff seems certain to write one day, but it is quite good, nevertheless. All Miss Wolff's novels are good.
CAIRO, March 2 -- Premier Ahmed Naguib al Hilaili Pasha, after the first meeting of his new Cabinet, announced tonight that decrees had been issued suspending Parliament for a month.

Changes in cast were widely in force with the New York City Ballet at the City Center over the week-end, since Maria Tallchief was out on a brief trip to Hollywood and Janet Reed will be out for the remainder of the season with an injured foot.
MIAMI, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Practically everybody who had anything to do with serving drinks sponsored a cocktail-mixing contest today.

The International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., still split into rival camps as a result of the dock strike last fall, was threatened yesterday with further dissension as Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president, sought to curb the activities of Anthony Anastasia, heretofore one of the stanchest Ryan supporters.

Congress should call upon President Truman to submit a new budget that would stay within the estimated $71,000,000,000 Federal revenues for the year starting July 1 and thus avoid either a $14,500,000,000 deficit or new taxes, the seven-member committee on taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York said yesterday.

One hundred and fifty persons gathered yesterday at the Louis Kossuth monument in Riverside Park at 113th Street and Riverside Drive to pay tribute to the Hungarian patriot and liberator. In a program arranged by the Grand Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons of New York, to commemorate the stateman's 100th Masonic anniversary, Kossuth was praised as representative of the finest qualities in Hungarian and Masonic traditions and aspirations.

Man is a deplorable being -- not only the lower, jury-convicted man, or the average man, but just man. Nor is it necessary to seek support of this thesis from woman, for she is, after all, just a different side of the same rib species and is quite as deplorable.

A row of apartment houses in the Bronx that had been held in one ownership for more than thirty years passed to new control when Florence Batonick, executrix of the estate of Kopel Brumer, sold the four five-story buildings on plot 150 by 100 feet at 776 and 782 Prospect Avenue, near Longwood Avenue, to the Trans-New York Corporation, operators.

ROME, March 2 -- A merchant convoy of forty United States British, French and Italian cargo ships entered the approaches to Gibraltar tonight in face of a simulated onslaught of "enemy submarines and planes after crossing the Western Mediterranean from Malta as part of exercise Grand Slam in which the fleet of four nations are now engaged.
MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Tampa, Fla., March 2 -- A "new deal" is here for the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A bipartisan group of twenty-five Senators will move Tuesday for action on a bill to create a temporary "nonpartisan, Hoover-type survey commission" that would study the relations of the United States with its North Atlantic Allies.

In his amiable discourse of Feb. 15 on the farm and city votes in New Hampshire, Arthur Krock gives us the word of an expert in such matters that the weather is not likely to affect the outcome of the primary elections in that state on March 11.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, told a television audience today that Senator Richard B. Russell would receive support from "much of the South" as a Democratic candidate for President.

An audience of 1,550, which included all the standees the law would allow, jammed Town Hall last night for Andres Segovia's annual New York recital. And despite the size of the crowd, the famous Spanish guitarist held it in the utmost silence by the wizardry of his art.

Healthy Christian living requires a "regular examination of conscience," the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 118th Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

Cesare Siepi, one of the leading bassos of the Metropolitan Opera, was in excellent voice for his Hunter College appearance last night. There was ample measure of vocal security, breath control, soaring fortissimo, full-voice phrases. The texture of the voice was uncommonly rich, and Mr. Siepi used his vocal resources intelligently.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Miss Marlene Bauer won her first golf tournament as a professional today with an eight-under-par 71 that set a women's record for the Sarasota Bay Country Club' course. Miss Bauer, who was 18 years old on Feb. 16, earned $350 in the eighteen - hole one - day Sarasota women's open.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- The United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information will open a new effort here tomorrow to complete an international code of ethics for journalists.

BONN, Germany, March 2 (AP) -- West Germany sent a demand to the European Assembly today for restoration of "democratic conditions" in the coal-rich Saar -- center of a bitter French-German dispute since World War I.
PARIS, March 2 -- A further decline in the standing of France in the European Payments Union occurred during February. Total indebtedness, according to figures now available, exceeded $400,000,000.

MIAMI, March 2 -- The pink flamingoes with their strange, grotesque beauty were routed from the palm tree island in Hialeah's infield lake yesterday and herded onto dry land. It was part of the ceremony which goes with the annual running of the Flamingo Stakes, top 3-year-old event of the Florida racing season. The Seminole Indians parade first, then the flamingoes.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The State Blood Bank Association concluded its two-day organizational meeting here today by electing officers who will serve until the annual meeting of the State Medical Society, which sponsored the group, in New York City May 12 to 16.

The four four-story loft buildings at 736 Ninth Avenue and 360-66 West Fiftieth Street forming an "L" around the southeast corner have been sold by the Milford Operating Corporation to the Franklin Moving Storage Company through Samuel Kurcias, broker.

Involved in a bitter row with the scenic artists union over the importation of foreign scenery (designed by Mary Purvis), "Women of Twilight," a facsimile of a London hit, will be presented at 8 o'clock this evening at the Plymouth.

A plan to end the four-year-old free transfers among the three city-operated subway systems and to abolish the cut-rate combination fares allowed for some buses and subways is being explored in the city's quest for more funds. It would mean a flat ten-cent fare on each line, effective July 1 -- if approved.

HAMAR, Norway, March 2 (AP) -- Hjalmar Andersen, Norway's speed-skating star who won three Olympic gold medals, captured his third consecutive world championship today with a meet-record time in the climactic 10,000-meter race.

" We, the People," which has been on the air since the early days of video, is still the wallflower of television. Of all the major programs, it would be hard to find another so obviously afraid of doing the wrong thing in public or running the risk of letting a person just be himself.

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -- Main topic of conversation in the steel trade last week was the plight of the small nonintegrated steel mill. Most of these plants, because of higher costs, charge higher prices than larger units. With over-all demand dropping for steel products in easier supply it means that order books of small steelmakers are not as heavy as they were a few months ago.

The storm-tossed North Atlantic claimed more victims yesterday as mountainous waves and gale winds raked the Eastern seaboard from South Carolina to Nova Scotia. By nightfall the sea had subsided somewhat, but five ships had sent out distress signals and the wreckage of one had already been located.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, March 3 (AP) -- Allied tanks, artillery and infantry battered Chinese troops at several points yesterday on the increasingly active western Korean front.

Public comment and criticism on the principles underlying the city's proposed rezoning plan will be invited at a series of five public hearings beginning on March 25, the City Planning Commission said yesterday.
Seven films, including importations from Germany and China, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
John C. Helies of Bridgeport, Conn., has been named general manager of the newly-established appliance control department of the General Electric Company at Morrison, Ill.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 2 -- Sixteen prominent laymen of the Congregational Christian Churches called on denomination officials today "to cease trying to put the church into power politics."

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -- Representative Kenneth Keating, Republican of New York, disclosed today that House investigators have uncovered cases where the Justice Department has "whitewashed" criminal charges brought against "influential or politically powerful figures?"
I have read Mr. Hoover's speech, made recently, but my reaction is far different from that ascribed in the press to a very imposing list of names, some of whom are friends or acquaintances of mine.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The outcome of a series of major votes in the Senate and House of Representatives this week may determine whether Congress can finish "must" business before the national political conventions in July and thus free members for a summer and fall of campaigning.
Members of the Barnard College Club of New York have presented $29,377, raised in the last two years, to Barnard College.

Miguel Najdorf and Erich Eliskases, both from Argentina, went ahead of Israel A. Horowitz in the international chess masters tournament at the Club Capablanca yesterday when the New Yorker took his turn for a day off, according to a report from Havana.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Casey Stengel wrote down at random today some two dozen names which may not mean a thing. Actually they arranged the order in which two squads were to go to the plate in the afternoon's batting drill.

MILWAUKEE, March 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republican aspirant for the Presidential nomination, devoted his attention today to conversations with clergymen and political supporters in Milwaukee.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., March 2 -- A 3 1/2-year-old Orange Belton English setter, Ch. Rock Falls Racket, became the best-in-show winner tonight in the sixth annual event of the Twin Brooks Kennel Club.

A forgotten opera of Handel, "Il Pastor Fido," was given in concert form yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by the New Friends of Music. In all probability, this was the first American performance of the work.

PARIS, March 2 -- Wartime Premier Paul Reynaud, who is head of the French Independent party, abandoned today his attempt to form a national union Cabinet. He declared the French Constitution must be changed before a stable government was possible.

SALISBURY, Conn., March 2 -- Merrill (Mezzy) Barber, 33-year-old research engineer from Brattleboro, Vt., today won the National Open ski jumping title before 8,000. The Vermont star soared flawlessly 190 and 188 feet for 236.1 points.

More than eight months have passed since Jacob A. Malik, speaking on a United Nations radio program, proposed "a peaceful settlement of the Korean question." Nearly eight months have gone by since the armistice negotiations in Korea actually began. Sometimes there has seemed to be progress.

Organizations concerned with the welfare of children are urging members of their groups and the general public to "marshal vocal and vigorous support" for various key bills affecting children now pending in the State Legislature.

TOKYO, Monday, March 3 -- Communist truce negotiators conceded today that the United Nations had the right to object to the Soviet Union's participation as one of the neutral nations to police an armistice in the Korean war. But the enemy demanded that the Allied delegation give "logical reasons" for Russia's exclusion.

TOKYO, March 2 -- Debate in Parliament and the press following the administrative agreement between Japan and the United States signed last Thursday setting the terms for the retention of United States bases here after the peace treaty now appears to have revealed the general Japanese reaction.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 -- India's most spectacular achievement toward solving her self-sufficiency problem and building a new national life, the $48,300,000 chemical fertilizer factory constructed with United States and British private industrial assistance at Sindri in Bihar State, was formally opened by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today.
ROME, March 2 -- Vatican scholars believed today that two of the Roman Catholic Popes whose likenesses hang in the stately Basilica of St. Paul's Outside the Walls were actually the same person.

AMSTERDAM, March 2 -- After a short burst of liveliness the stock market turned dull with small net losses by the end of last week. The premium on dollar securities fell to an all-time low of just over 4 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 -- Pacific Greyhound Lines buses were absent from the highways of the West today as a strike called one minute after midnight shut down operations in California and six other Western states.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Agriculture Committee of the National Planning Association declared today that "broadly conceived" agricultural reform must supplement investment and technical assistance programs of the United States if such programs were to succeed in raising the standards of living in Asia and elsewhere in the world.

Prices of cotton moved over a fairly wide trading range last week but closed the five-day trading session with only moderate net changes. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 8 to down 31 points, compared with advances ranging from 23 to 75 points in the previous week.

Trial of a Federal indictment charging criminal conspiracy against sixteen functionaries of the Communist party for teaching and advocating overthrow of the Government by force and violence is scheduled to begin at 10:30 A. M. today before Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock in the United States Courthouse in Foley Square.
The number of workers seeking unemployment insurance in this city and state has declined 20 per cent since the beginning of the year.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- The American College of Surgeons announced today that 112 hospitals in New York City had been named in its list of fully approved hospitals for 1951. Two hospitals in the city received provisional approval.

If one-way traffic on Manhattan's North-South avenues is an inevitable feature of any broad solution of our street-congestion problems, then the "victory" of the New York City Omnibus Corporation in the case of Seventh and Eighth Avenues is only temporary -- one battle disposed of, but not a whole campaign lost.
Four firemen gingerly approaching a manhole in Brooklyn last night were burned when the cover blew off and flames shot into the air. All were hospitalized, one in critical condition.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The emergency Economic Conference on Israel pledged today a minimum sale of $200,000,000 in State of Israel bonds by the end of this year to aid Israel's industrial and economic development and bring the nation closer to economic self-sufficiency.

ROME, March 2 -- Pope Pius celebrated his seventy-sixth birthday today and the thirteenth anniversary of his elevation to the Pontificate. Rome took official cognizance of the occasion for the first time by raising the Italian flag over Government buildings while the Pontifical yellow and white colors were flown all over the tiny state of Vatican City.

LONDON, March 2 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Chancellor of the Exchequer in the last Labor Government, declared today that the measures taken thus far by the Conservative Government had not yet halted the decline in the gold reserves of the sterling area.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 2 -- "Snow Ducks" fluttered out on the wing today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Their flight was the sailing dinghy regatta there.

When will France wake up? This is the simple, homely question that outsiders have asked in one form or another since the war. In fact, it was being asked with equal insistence during the interwar years -- but there was no answer. The tragic divisions continued, bringing the alternate shame and glory of Vichyite collaboration and the Resistance.

Thomas Richner, pianist, who presented an all-Mozart program at Town Hall last season, gave another devoted to keyboard music of that composer yesterday afternoon in the same auditorium. His playing again was serious, sincere and refined, with careful attention to details, including ornamentation.

The Military Sea Transportation Service, faced with increasing commitments but a shortage of trained personnel, has started instruction designed to insure an adequate number of specialists to man the expanding fleet. The ships form the backbone of the supply lines to this country's armed forces overseas.

Old money in new surroundings was put on public display last week for the first time at the new home of the Chase National Bank's Collection of Moneys of the World at 37 Wall Street. The collection had been exhibited twenty-two years at the main office of the bank at 18 Pine Street.

Newbold Morris, who was appointed assistant attorney general to investigate corruption in the National Government, declared yesterday that he would ask President Truman to dismiss any Federal employe who refused to answer a questionnaire on his activities, 25,000 of which he has already dispatched.

RENO, Nev., March 2 (UP) -- A woman and four ex-convicts were arrested near Butte, Mont., today and Lorenz R. Greeson, Reno chief of police, said he wanted them held for questioning in Friday's $2,500,000 burglary at the home of Laverne V. Redfield here.
ZURICH, March 2 -- From the highest official sources, it was learned that the tactics of the Swiss delegation at the London Conference will be those indicated in the following story.

The Social Security System fund, and similar trust accounts administered or sponsored by the United States Government, own about $1 of every $6 of the public debt and are adding to their holdings at the rate of $8,800,000,000 a year, according to a report by the Institute of Life Insurance.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- Press photographers were greeted with loud "boos" and some were manhandled last night when they tried to take pictures at a rally sponsored by the Philadelphia Freedom of the Press Association where Communists spoke.

MEXICO CITY, March 2 -- Bobby Locke withstood the pressure today, fired a steady one-under-par-71 and won the Mexican open golf championship with a 72-hole total of 276, twelve strokes below par for the Churubusco Country Club course. He beat Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., by two strokes.

The modern world must be "rebuilt from its foundations" if it is to be preserved from the consequences of its own wholesale infringement of the moral law, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday in the first in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Our Association of Municipal Chemists wishes to record its grateful appreciation for your editorial comment on the salary plight of the city's employes on several occasions. We take special note of your cogent remarks in the issue of Feb. 20, "When City Employes Strike."
MEXICO CITY, March 2 -- A fine old row has been stirred up among Mexican bullfight fans by a young man who not so long ago was one of their greatest idols, the 28-year-old matador Luis Procuna.
Sandra Post Shop, sportswear, store, second floor and basement in 521 Madison Ave, at 53d St, from Joseph H. and Milton Schwartz, represented by David L. Charal, attorney.

Our Association of Municipal Chemists wishes to record its grateful appreciation for your editorial comment on the salary plight of the city's employes on several occasions. We take special note of your cogent remarks in the issue of Feb. 20, "When City Employes Strike."
MEXICO CITY, March 2 -- A fine old row has been stirred up among Mexican bullfight fans by a young man who not so long ago was one of their greatest idols, the 28-year-old matador Luis Procuna.
Sandra Post Shop, sportswear, store, second floor and basement in 521 Madison Ave, at 53d St, from Joseph H. and Milton Schwartz, represented by David L. Charal, attorney.

Only the grace of God can rid the world of the fear and despair that have gripped it, the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Leber, executive secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian in the U. S. A., said yesterday morning in a sermon at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Broadway and Seventy-third Street.
CHICAGO, March 2 -- Several days of crumbling prices featured the trade in grains last week, with low points for the crop year registered in all pits as longs unloaded their holdings.

An estate of thirty-six acres with a fourteen-room house, guest house, barns, swimming pool and lake in Ridgefield, Conn., was purchased by James Picker of the Picker X-Ray Corporation from Richard Blum in a deal negotiated by S. B. Tapalow, head of the farm department of Joseph P. Day, Inc.

BOSTON, March 2 (UP) -- Boston's fighting Bruins, bidding desperately for a play-off berth, rallied tonight to deadlock the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 2, and pick up a point on fourth-place New York before 5,096 National Hockey League fans at the Arena.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 2 (UP) -- Bill Nary turned in a sensational 6-under-par 66 today to gain a tie at 281 in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament with Tommy Bolt and Jack Burke Jr., for 72-holes on the moss-draped country club course.

The Rev. Allen S. Hedgecock, minister of the First Moravian Episcopal Church, Lexington Avenue and Thirtieth Street, conducted yesterday morning a celebration of the 495th anniversary of the founding in Bohemia of the Unitas Fratrum, or Moravian Church, known as the Brethren's Unity.

The adventurous music department of the Lexington Avenue Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. gave a full-scale program of the music of the late Kurt Weill yesterday afternoon. The composer would have been 53 years old on that date.

A light snowfall, turning to rain, was predicted for this morning by the Weather Bureau in the wake of the 4.9 inches of snow that fell in Saturday's baby blizzard. Fresh southeasterly winds were expected today, with the rain continuing into tomorrow.

The rejection this week by the Congress of Honduras of the proposed amendment giving women the right to vote is a discouragement to all those who are working for universal democracy. How can a country claim to be democratic when one-half of its citizens are prevented from having any voice in government?

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., March 2 (Canadian Press) -- Art Tommy, 18-year-old Ottawa skier, today captured honors in the annual Kandahar. His combined totals for yesterday's downhill and today's slalom decided for the young star.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) -- Two members of the Senate Appropriations Committee asked today that General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower report personally to Congress on the prospects and progress of European defense before the committee votes on a new $7,900,000,000 foreign aid bill.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- If the advance information is of any interest to Manager Tommy Holmes of the Boston Braves, this will let him know the Brooklyn pitchers who will face his club next Saturday and Sunday at Miami.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 2(AP) -- Bill Spivey, Kentucky's seven-foot All-America center, was permanently barred from athletics today at the University of Kentucky.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 2 -- A special ten-week course to alert the public school teachers of this state to the dangers of communism and to be conducted jointly by the Rhode Island State Department of Education and Brown University, was announced here today. Each of the ten lectures will be given by an expert on one phase of the Soviet system or on the machinations of native Communists.

It was made patent in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night that the Detroit Red Wings are just a one-line team. That line, however, is the Sid Abel-Ted Lindsay-Gordie Howe outfit, a combination that seemingly can go out and score any time it seems so inclined.

LINCROFT, N. J., March 2 -- Mrs. Geraldine L. Thompson, founder of the Monmouth County Organization for Social Service and its president for forty years, was surprised by several hundred well-wishers who drove from many sections of the state yesterday to help her observe her eightieth birthday anniversary at her Brookdale Farm home here.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 2 (AP) -- The French high command announced tonight that it had smashed an attempt by elements of two Communist-led Vietminh divisions to gain a foothold in the Red River delta thirty miles southeast of Hanoi.
TOKYO, Monday, March 3 (AP) -- General headquarters communique 1,177, for Sunday's operations:

Displaying a brand of hockey that was far from effective, the New York Rovers remained in the cellar in the Eastern Hockey League by dropping a 5-3 verdict to the Atlantic City Sea Gulls at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

SAIGON, Indo-China, March 2 (AP) -- The French high command announced tonight that it had smashed an attempt by elements of two Communist-led Vietminh divisions to gain a foothold in the Red River delta thirty miles southeast of Hanoi.

The large number of this week's art exhibitions is proof that the season is at its height. Of special interest is the Art News national annual exhibition of work by amateur painters, opening today at the Riverside Museum.

PUSAN, Korea, Monday, March 3 (AP) -- A shipment of 21,139 CARE food and textile packages has arrived in Korea as a gift from the General Federation of Women's Clubs of the United States. The shipment, valued at more than $200,000, was the largest of CARE supplies to have arrived in Korea.

Operations of the Gillette Safety Razor Company and its subsidiaries last year resulted in consolidated earnings of $15,738,656, or $3.58 a common share, before special charges, according to the fiftieth annual report issued for publication today.

It is not a pleasant task to register even a partial dissent from the views about nursery school regulation expressed in THE TIMES of Feb. 27 by Miss Estelle H. Farber. The matter, however, is less simple than she thinks. With regulations on the subject of sanitation and fire hazards no one could find fault.

The imminent acquisition of the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the city will come as welcome news to many. In approving a measure enabling New York City to take title to the historic opera house the state Legislature has guaranteed the continued existence of a building that has played an important role in the cultural and political life of this community for more than forty years.

Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," which has missed a season at the Metropolitan Opera, will be revived during the company's eighteenth week, which begins next Monday. Hans Hopf will make his debut in the role of Walther.
More nurses are working today than ever before in the nation's history, yet a critical shortage of nursing service exists in almost every city and rural area.

The National Association of Wool Manufacturers has requested decontrol of wool textiles, it was learned over the week-end. In a letter to Charles E. Wilson, chief of the Office of Defense Mobilization and Price Stabilizer Ellis G. Arnall, the association's executive committee enclosed a schedule of wool textile prices to prove its contention that there is no valid reason to continue price control.
TOKYO, Monday, March 3 (AP) -- General headquarters communique 1,177, for Sunday's operations:
More nurses are working today than ever before in the nation's history, yet a critical shortage of nursing service exists in almost every city and rural area.

The National Association of Wool Manufacturers has requested decontrol of wool textiles, it was learned over the week-end. In a letter to Charles E. Wilson, chief of the Office of Defense Mobilization and Price Stabilizer Ellis G. Arnall, the association's executive committee enclosed a schedule of wool textile prices to prove its contention that there is no valid reason to continue price control.

Max Zaslofsky will be honored between games of the professional basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The popular point-producer of the New York Knickerbockers will receive, among other gifts, an automobile from his friends and fans, after which he will lead the Knicks against the champion Rochester Royals.

The state's failure to support the city's day care program was criticized by Mayor Impellitteri yesterday as he officially proclaimed Day Care Week and dedicated the city's newest center at Lexington Houses, 115 East Ninety-eighth Street.

President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson will observe the tenth anniversary of the Voice of America in a radio broadcast to be presented by WNBC this afternoon from 1:30 to 2 o'clock. They will speak from the new transmitter ship Courier, now anchored in the Potomac River at Washington, which will sail soon to beam Voice of America programs behind the Iron Curtain.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 3 -- Gov. John S. Fine led thtousands of public employes tonight in taking an oath of loyalty to their State Government.

The proposals to abolish free transfers and cut-rate combination rides on the city's transportation lines were assailed yesterday by Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, as acts that would constitute a general fare increase. As such, he declared, he was against them.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Chief bottleneck in the increase of frozen food retail sales are reluctance of store operators to install sufficient display cabinet space, leaders in the frozen food industry said today at the sixth annual National Frozen Foods Convention.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- The Yankee ball players are just beginning to round into shape, but Charles Dillion Stengel already is in midseason form. The manager of the champions was standing behind the batting cage at Miller Huggins Field today when a little boy sneaked under the fence and raced over for an autograph.

There was only one slim-skirt silhouette shown in the Joseph Halpert collection of Jacques Fath designs modeled yesterday at Lord Taylor's. This was in a cap-sleeved navy dress with white cardigan closing extending onto the front of the slim skirt and white banding the cap sleeves.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Congress was threatened with a Presidential veto today if it passes proposed fair trade legislation designed to permit minimum picefixing on "name-brand" products.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Tuesday, March 4 -- An automobile plunged into the Hudson River at 12:25 A. M. today after breaking through the gate of a ferryboat docked at the West Shore ferry terminal here.

Are material shortages letting up? Many manufacturers do not think so, but the Whirlpool Corporation, St. Joseph, Mich., manufacturer of home laundry equipment, believes they are. In fact, Whirlpool plans to re-enter by mid-summer the consumer markets it was obliged to withdraw from twelve months ago due to material shortages.
The trial of sixteen secondary Communist leaders was adjourned yesterday until March 31 over the protests of United States Attorney Myles J. Lane.

MONTREAL, March 3 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, was disqualified in a fight at the Forum tonight and his handlers became so incensed that three carloads of police were called to restore order as numerous brawls broke out among the spectators.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Governor Dewey and spokesmen for the Republican majority in the Legislature were reported tonight to have reached agreement on a program that will enable Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate to balance New York's budget for the next fiscal year.

On record net sales of $215,704,848, the Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries achieved the highest earnings in its history with the 1951 net of $15,837,846, despite taxes which took $32,288,822, according to the report yesterday of R. S. Reynolds Jr., president.

GENEVA, March 3 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe opened its seventh session here today without its vice president, Arnost Tauber, who was believed in Western circles to have been a victim of the current Czechoslovak Government purge.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The most powerful foreign policy leader in Congress, Senator Tom Connally, angrily warned France today that she must "do her duty" toward her own defense if she expected more United States economic help.

" The experts" have by no means "all the answers" to the countless questions that trouble parents of growing children, two speakers at the annual conference of the Child Study Association of America emphasized yesterday and added that parents shouldn't expect them to.

Ready-to-wear spring fashions with distinctive details that lent a pleasing individual feeling were presented yesterday in Jay Thorpe's originals. Never prettier nor more wearable, the designs ran the gamut through sheer daytime wools, suits with charming companion blouses, silk coats, cocktail and evening fashions.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court today let stand a decision that Negroes might be restricted in the use of a city-operated golf course.

PARIS, March 3 -- Antoine Pinay, Minister of Public Works and Transports in the Cabinet of Premier Edgar Faure, which fell last week, and in the Pleven Cabinet, announced tonight that he would try to form a new French ministry composed mainly of technicians without regard to their political connections.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 (AP) -- Prof. Hugh C. Willett predicted today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's special committee would find nothing wrong with controlled post-season bowl games in its survey, and Dr. Fred D. Fagg, president of the University of Southern California, followed with a strong endorsement of the big bowl contests.
NICE, France, March 3 -- A four-engine Air France plane crashed into an olive grove today and killed thirty-seven persons, including a ballet dancer from Brooklyn.

Reports from Albany indicate that Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders are giving serious consideration to the idea of putting New York City's passenger transportation under public Authority as part of a plan to ease the city's financial burdens.

PARIS, March 3 -- United States diplomats from posts in Eastern Europe met here today with State Department representatives to discuss all aspects of the United States policy inside the Soviet sphere, including the question whether some diplomatic missions behind the Iron Curtain should be closed.
The Kings County District Attorney's office gained yesterday a major legal point in its efforts to inquire into the financial affairs of present and former members of the Police Department.

CHAMPLAIN, Ill., March 3 (AP) -- Illinois, the nation's No. 2 basketball team, clinched the Big Ten championship tonight by walloping Northwestern, 95 -- 74, for its twelfth Conference victory in thirteen starts. It was the biggest score rolled up by the Illini this season.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Senate approved unanimously and sent to the Assembly tonight a bill to carry out Governor Dewey's recommendation for increased state aid for alcoholic clinics and provide for a study of alcoholism by the State Mental Health Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The State Department announced today that steps had been taken to organize an "independent and private" committee to represent the interests of United States holders of German corporate dollar bonds at a conference now in progress in London.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Following are texts of the majority and minority opinions handed down today by the United States Supreme Court the case of New York's Finberg Law.

In only three days' active campaigning, the commerce and industry section of the Brooklyn Red Cross Fund drive has collected 30 per cent of its $301,500 quota in the city-wide appeal for $6,700,000, section chairman Rodney C. Ward told business men at a luncheon in the Hotel St. George yesterday.

For the second time in six months New York courts have ruled that market valuation is the best appraisal that dissenting shareholders can obtain when they choose not to go along with the decisions of their company. The first such decision was made in a suit brought against R. H. Macy Co., which has stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

TRENTON, March 3 -- Mr. Alexander has been under pressure to run for several months by the New Jersey Democratic leadership, which in the last three years has replaced former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in organization management. New Jersey party leaders hailed Mr. Alexander's announcement with predictions of success in the election. They termed him a "strong" candidate to top the ballot.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, persuaded the Senate Expenditures Committee today to call Edward H. Foley Jr., Under Secretary of the Treasury, for questioning on any personal interest he had taken in pending tax cases.

Prime Minister Nehru is justified in feeling pride and elation over the completion of the vast chemical fertilizer factory at Sindri. This means a great deal from every point of view. India needs a considerable degree of industrialization, but in the normal course of events she must and should for a very long time be a predominantly agricultural country.

DETROIT, March 3 (UP) -- Detroit's second line powered the Red Wings to a 3-to-2 victory over Chicago tonight, moving the Wings within 2 points of their fourth straight National Hockey League championship.
MIAMI, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Hialeah ended the most profitable season in Florida turf history today with both attendance and betting figures setting new records.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Jacob S. Potofsky, chairman of the international committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, protested today against the death sentences imposed on nine members of non-Communist unions in Spain.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Ralph Coghlan, former editor of the editorial page of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, today was appointed public relations director on the staff of Newbold Morris, Special Assistant Attorney General in charge of the campaign to clean up corruption in the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Charles W. Fox offered today some exhibits of his own to put alongside those assembled by the House Armed Services Committee for its "chamber of horrors" on military buying.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Twentieth Century-Fox is about to reactivate "On to Oregon," a historical drama it has thought about making on and off since 1943 under such titles as "The Sager Trek" and "The Valiant Seven." Rory Calhoun will be starred in the picture, to be produced by Samuel G. Engel.

Five suspended officers of Local 222, Brooklyn unit of the International Jewelry Workers Union, A. F. L., were restored to their posts yesterday. The action came after a hearing by top union officials showed that the men had no knowledge of the outside activities of a business agent who had been indicted last week for bribing a witness.

CAIRO, March 3 -- Ahmed Naguib al Hilaili Pasha, Egypt's new Premier, said today that any meeting of Parliament, such as the one called for this afternoon, would not be permitted. Decrees had been issued yesterday suspending Parliament for one month.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 3 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived in Turkey's capital today. He came to seal with his presence the membership of this country -- geographically belonging mostly to Asia and partly to Europe -- in the concert of Western Powers, of which he is Supreme Commander.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- New Jersey laws requiring the daily reading of five verses of the Old Testament in public schools and permitting the recitation of the Lord's Prayer, were left undisturbed by the Supreme Court today.

Manufacturers of men's and boys' work clothing and slacks are taking a cautious approach to the task of placing orders for their fall fabric requirements, a survey of the suppliers' exhibit in the New Yorker Hotel showed yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 3 -- Twenty-nine home owners, who assert their living conditions are intolerable because of a pall of smoke, soot, cinders and gas from the Harlem Division yards of the New York Central Railroad at White Plains North, brought their woes into Supreme Court today in a plea for, more tlan $290,000 damages against the railroad.

ACCORDING to Bart Allen, a hound enthusiast, any one who buys a foxhound through the mail needs to be lucky or influential: lucky enough to get a good dog, or influential enough to make the man take a bad dog back and refund the money.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, March 4 (AP) -- United States Sabre jet planes destroyed two Communist MIG-15 jets and damaged five more in four air battles over North Korea yesterday. Ground fighting was limited to scouting thrusts by small patrols.

Since the original company of "Women of Twilight" is busy in London, the management has rushed a second company across the Atlantic to look after the trade in this country. Although the motive is kind, the gesture is unnecessary.

Trimmed or untrimmed, little hats for spring have big fashion importance. Aranka, Inc., 410 Park Avenue, showed a recently imported collection of French hats yesterday. For different occasions, different moods, and made with decidedly different treatments, all the hats shown were consistently small.

" Bugles in the Afternoon," a Western drama in Technicolor featuring Ray Milland, Helena Carter, Hugh Marlowe and Forrest Tucker, which arrives at the Warner, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Roy Rowland directed the William Cagney production for Warner Brothers release.

BUENOS AIRES, March 3 -- The chain of peronista newspapers over the week-end began a concerted rebuttal to an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 24 by asserting that that paper had allied itself with the other enemies of Argentina, including the "pig," Spruille Braden, former United States Ambassador.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 3 (UP) -- Hill Prince, a champion every year he raced, will be retired to stud at the close of the Santa Anita meeting next Saturday, owner Christopher T. Chenery announced today.

LONDON, March 3 -- A valuable and long-forgotten crate of mummified cats from ancient Egypt has been unearthed from the labyrinthine vaults of the British Natural History Museum enabling a zoologist to make an exact scientific classification of the pets of the pharaohs.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 -- The Communist party in New York State planned to establish a secret "underground" section to operate along with its overt section even if no legal sanctions came into force against the party, it was testified in Federal District Court today.

The suggestion offered in your columns by Rev. G. L. Parker, advising teachers to acquaint their pupils with modern lives of exemplary character, points to a highly important moral resource. Here are some such biographies which the Ethical Culture Schools have found useful, along with lives of long ago.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- With the entire industrial base of the country expanding under the defense effort, the United States will emerge from the mobilization period "far more powerful than we ever were before," Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, declared tonight.

ST. LOUIS, March 3 -- James P. Finnegan, former Internal Revenue Collector, while in office approached Government officials in Washington in connection with a hotel concern's claim against the Coast Guard, a witness testified in Federal Court here today.

BALBOA, C. Z., March 3 -- The Panama Canal Company has discharged a 28-year-old Panamanian chauffeur for his connection with the new anti-United States Peronista organization, the Latin-American Confederation of Labor, it became known today.
PATERSON, N. J., March 3 -- The suit brought by Mrs. Klein and Mr. Doremus was first heard in Passaic County Superior Court here by Judge Robert H. Davidson in February, 1950.

Land in Yonkers near the Westchester County system of parkways and the proposed New York to Buffalo Thruway has been selected as the site of a building to house the sales and service offices of the National Cash Register Company in the county.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Democratic Congressional leaders told President Truman today that the Universal Military Training bill would have a rough road to follow in the House of Representatives, starting tomorrow.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- Walter F. O'Malley, president of the Dodgers, reported today a tie-up among television, the motion picture industry and baseball.
WESTPORT, Mass., March 3 -- Alvano C. Goddard of Drift Road, former New Bedford insurance broker, and well - known Quaker minister and teacher, died today. He was 88 years old.

Members of a junior committee, including the Misses Eleanor Rutteage and Elizabeth Buchheister, are aiding in the sale of tickets for the performances of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on March 27 at the Warner Theatre and "Don Juan in Hell" on April 1 at the Plymouth Theatre, which have been taken over to raise funds for the Vocational Advisory Service.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 3 -- The New York Shipbuilding Corporation announced today that it had received an award for two additional Navy oilers. This will make five recently ordered by the Navy Department's Bureau of Ships.

PARIS, March 3 -- It was characteristic of the French National Assembly, nearly always preoccupied with domestic politics, to reject a tax increase at the very moment when the French Government was asking more aid from the United States and when the Washington Administration was preparing a kind of publicity campaign to get from Congress a generous foreign aid allotment for the coming year.

All speculation over the identity of "Team X" in the forthcoming national invitation college basketball tournament ended yesterday, with the naming of Seattle University by Chairman Asa Bushnell. The far western Chieftains will bring a 29-and-7 record into Madison Square Garden Monday night, when they face Holy Cross (20 -- 2) in an opening round contest.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3 -- The Communist party's current campaign to extirpate Western ideas, which had begun to flourish inside and outside the party, is now being directed against the judiciary, the press and the universities.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- The Yankees had six aspiring candidates working out at first base yesterday. But today there was room for only one.
