In the House of Representatives voting will begin today on a matter that has nothing to do with party affiliation and that has a great deal to do with the future security of the people of the United States. This is the bill to put into effect a system of universal military training in accordance with the general principles approved by Congress last year.

The League of Composers gave the second of its season's concerts last night in Carl Fischer Hall in conjunction with a music publisher, this time the Valley Music Press. New music by eight composers was performed.

The two five-story apartment houses with eleven stores at 101 West Seventieth Street and 100 West Seventy-first Street, occupying the entire westerly blockfront on Columbus Avenue, have been sold by Richard P. Limburg, representing the estate of Samuel J. Richford, to an investing client of Walter Scott Co. L. J. Phillips Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Reuben Lesser for the buyer and Siegelman Schwartz for the seller.
The Sunbeam Corporation will fight the Department of Justice as vigorously as it has squared off in the past with retailers who have cut prices of its "fair traded" small appliances.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Archibald S. Alexander, 46-year-old Under Secretary of the Army, resigned today to seek the Democratic nomination for Senator in New Jersey. He seeks to oppose Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican, who has served in the Senate since Dec. 7, 1944, and who is a candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The extension of military production time schedules and an improvement in imports have combined to ease the supply in some critical metals and chemicals, but there is little improvement in other materials groups, the Defense Production Administration announced today.

Directors of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation at their meeting in San Diego, Calif., yesterday elected Gen. Joseph T. McNarney (retired) as president. He succeeds LaMotte T. Cohu, who becomes vice chairman of the board. Both will assume their new offices on April 1.
It's Kentucky again as the No. 1 college basketball team in the nation for 1952, just as it was in 1949 and 1951.

There is a cheese famine and prices are high in the New York market and elsewhere for foreign types of cheese, whether made at home or abroad. Local importers attribute the situation to the so-called Andresen amendment, section 104 of the Defense Production Act, passed last July.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 3 -- The Israeli Government is carefully looking into the beaks of an unexpected number of Egyptian doves of peace. The birds were released by Sir Mohommed Zafrullah Khan, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, in the form of statements in Cairo and again in Baghdad and in Karachi, that a peaceful settlement of the Israeli-Arab conflict was desirable and a prerequisite to any Middle East defense plans.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- The National League's best third baseman, Billy Cox, finally appeared today, apparently in the best of health and spirits, and went through his first workout with the Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today dismissed an appeal that had contested the validity of Georgia's county unit election system.
A jurisdictional dispute between New York and New Jersey members of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., last night forced the closing of two Army-controlled piers in Jersey City.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 4 -- A massive earthquake deep under the Pacific Ocean floor killed at least twenty-eight persons today, opened gaping fissures on Hokkaido Island, crumbled buildings, overturned trains and kicked up tidal waves that washed away 400 buildings in one Japanese seacoast village.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Railroads of the country are divided on their response to the union shop recommendations of a presidential emergency board.
SYRACUSE, March 3 (UP) -- Plans were underway to erect a grandstand seating at least 6,400 persons for the Intercollegiate Rowing Regatta to be held on Onondaga Lake, June 21.
The dollar sales volume of twelve department stores here last month was 8.5 per cent below that of February last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Because Arnold Eidus is both an accomplished violinist and an artist of refinement, his recital at Carnegie Hall last night had grace and distinction. Thanks to two of the works he introduced, it also had novelty.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of debentures and preferred stock having a par value of $45,000,000. Proceeds will be used to finance expansion of an oil pipe line company and a public utility company and to increase the working and capital funds of a food manufacturing enterprise.

The second semester of school began, as the first had ended, quietly. Indeed, the first semester had been a little too quiet. Day followed day, week after week passed without a serious crisis, an insoluble problem.

Reflecting a sharp increase in equipment obligations, the long-term debt of the Reading Company last year increased $11,347,724 to $121,332,893 at the year-end, according to the road's fifty-fourth annual report released for publication today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 3 -- Lee and J. J. Shubert of New York will present musical shows in the County Center here for twelve weeks every summer for the next five years under terms of a contract approved today by the Westchester Board of Acquisition and Contract.

Free enterprise is becoming a mere figure of speech. It is bad enough that the Government has decided it must put ceilings on prices to prevent inflation, but now it is planned to prevent storekeepers from reducing prices.

The Bronx County District Attorney's thirteen-month-old inquiry into attempted fixes of Manhattan College games in the 1949-50 and 1950-51 seasons entered its final stage yesterday as two brothers pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges to cover a bribery and conspiracy indictment.

The Metcalf-Hatch bill, which was framed with the intention of turning over to research laboratories impounded domestic animals that would ordinarily be killed, aroused the expected opposition of anti-vivisectionists. Bitter as this opposition was, it was redeemed by the more sensible attitude adopted by humane societies organized for the prevention of cruelty to animals.

j A new development in tooth-j [brushing, to aid children wearing] :braces and also to lessen receding1 [of' -gums in adults was described ;yesterday to the lortheastern So-! ;ciety of Orthodontists at the an-I nual convention in the Commodore: Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The top prize of a $2,800 scholarship in the eleventh Westinghouse talent search went tonight to 17-year-old Karl H. Muench of Evanston, Ill., for his work in endocrinology.

ALBANY, March 3 -- A bill permitting the State Correction Department to transfer female prisoners described as "dull normal and borderline" intelligence case from Westfield State Farm at Bedford Hills to the Albion State Training School has been approved by the Senate and is awaiting action in an Assembly committee.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., March 3 -- With the help of an 11-year-old boy and a new variety of cash box, George A. Williams, station agent here for the New York Central Railroad, kept all the commuters of the 7:43 A. M. New York express honest today when they bought newspapers at his self-service stand in the station.

A letter entitled "Saving Our Trees," appearing in your Feb. 13 issue, by Willard Van Name and a reply from E. W. Littlefield in your Feb. 29 issue, entitled "Forestry Operations," are both informative but fail to make known to your readers an extremely important fact; New York State owns two types of forest governed by separate laws and managed for distinctly different purposes -- preservation forests and production forests.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The head of the Government's refugee program denounced the present immigration law today as an "un-American," Nazi-Communist-type measure that set up a United States "Iron Curtain" against people from other lands.

ROME, March 3 -- After a long conversation this morning with Dr. Alcide De Gasperi, the Italian Premier and Foreign Minister, the Vice Premier and Foreign Minister of Greece, Sophocles Venizelos, told the press that good progress had been made toward realizing his proposal of closer defense collaboration among Greece, Italy and Turkey.

After almost eleven months, rubber futures trading was resumed yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Closing prices for the day were less than half their level on March 30, 1951. Trade was not brisk, only fifty contracts or 500 tons of No. 1 standard quality smoked sheets.
Liberty Music Shops touched off a price war in phonograph records yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- General rain or snow in the dry Southwest, while not heavy, was sufficient to take the edge off the wheat demand today, prices working off after being fairly steady early. Commission buying did not broaden much until prices had declined as much as 1 cent, when a moderate demand developed and steadied the market.

Cornelia Otis Skinner will offer her new full-length solo production, "Paris '90," at the Booth Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. Produced and directed by Alden S. Blodget, the entertainment has a score by Kay Swift, with orchestrations by Robert Russell Bennett, conducted by Nathaniel Shilkret.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- International Harvester Company announced today sales in the fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 reached the highest for any first quarter in company history.

The Institute of International Finance of New York University declared yesterday that commercial banks were being forced into mergers to relieve the disproportions between capital resources and risk assets as a result of the growing dependence of business and industry on banks for working capital in the post-war period.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party has won 390 of 429 Assembly seats in Uttar Pradesh, India's largest state by population and the last to complete returns in the marathon elections. The Prime Minister himself had been elected from an Uttar Pradesh constituency in his home city, Allahabad.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore acknowledged today that while the Hitler-Stalin pact still was in force he had disclosed to the Soviet Ambassador here a then confidential Lattimore assignment to a mission to Nationalist China.

A tall, broad-shouldered man with a bronzed face stood on the bridge of the luxury liner Ryndam yesterday as she approached her Hoboken pier. An impressive figure, he was Jan Pieter Boshoff, newly appointed skipper, completing his first Atlantic crossing as commander of the ship.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 3 -- Cornell University agricultural experts announced today the development of a new type of "navy" bean after nine years of breeding processes. The new development means plenty of beans for the Navy and the Army.

A crank letter and an anonymous phone call resulted yesterday in bomb scares in Queens and the Bronx. The letter was addressed to the Tax Bureau in Borough Hall, Kew Gardens, and the phone call was made to the Cardinal Hayes High School, the Bronx.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y:, March 3 -- An $8,000,000 project involving construction of 300 $22,000-to-$35,000 homes on a ninety-four-acre Mamaroneck Avenue tract here was announced today by Robert E. L. Howe Jr., broker in the purchase of the property at approximately $175,000 by Louis Berlanti of Harrison.
LONDON, March 3 -- With the new National Budget only eight days off, trading was at a minimum on the stock markets here today. Prices were barely tested, but small declines outnumbered gains.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 4 -- The United Nations expects that more than 50,000 South Koreans captured by the Communists, many of whom are now enrolled in the North Korean Army, will be included in the prisoner-of-war exchange after a cease-fire, Allied delegates at Panmunjom told Chinese and North Korean negotiators yesterday.

Business "embarrassments" in a selected list of merchandise suppliers, manufacturers and wholesalers last year showed a decline of 30 per cent in number but an increase of 30 per cent in dollar volume over the previous year, according to a compilation released yesterday by the National Credit Office.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- By a vote of 8 to 1 the Supreme Court today sustained a Missiuri law requiring employers to give workers four hours off duty, with pay, on election days. Justice William O. Douglas wrote the majority ruling, to which Justice Robert H. Jackson sarcastically dissented.
Three of the major hydroelectric and irrigation projects now being built in the Soviet Union have encountered serious difficulties and are lagging behind schedule, recent issues of Pravda report.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States District Court here entered a $7,000,000 default judgment today against Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow, former Chinese Air Force officer, in favor of the Republic of China.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- An attempt by the Soviet delegation to expand the discussions of the United Nations Trustee Council to include representatives of social, cultural and educational organizations in the trust territories was met with strong opposition from France, Belgium and El Salvador this afternoon.

CONCORD, N. H., March 3 -- Harold E. Stassen, Republican Presidential aspirant, asserted today that the development of a pre-convention deadlock between General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio steadily was strengthening his own position as second choice at Chicago in July.

Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee, granddaughter of the late J. P. Morgan, was afraid her husband would take her to France and "incarcerate her as an incompetent," Mrs. Evelyn Chandler, former wife of Supreme Court Justice Norman S. Dike, testified in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

BRADFORD, Mass. -- The appointment of Randall J. LeBoeuf, senior partner of LeBoeuf and Lamb, New York law firm, as one of three new trustees of Bradford Junior College was announced today by Robert Wood Coe, president of the board.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 3 -- Plans for development of a small park beside the Revolutionary War breastwork at the end of Church Street here blossomed today when preservation of the tiny fortification, on a promontory overlooking the Tappan Zee, became virtually certain.

ROME, March 3 -- Eighty-year-old Marshal Pietro Badoglio, who after conquering Ethiopia for Mussolini "liquidated" fascism in 1943, was jostled today by a crowd of women who shouted "traitor" and other abusive epithets at him. The women, fifteen of whom were arrested and held for questioning, were believed to be fascistically inclined mothers and widows of men who lost their lives in World War II.

Over-the-counter dealers have gone on record against the part of the proposed amendment to the New York State Banking Law that would limit the investments of savings banks in common stocks to those registered on national securities exchanges.

William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, told Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday that he might buy more than fifty passensger cars after he had completed his own study of the need for additional equipment to provide safe and adequate service.

Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co., Chicago investment banking firm, who is a major Government witness in the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking firms, described in Federal Court yesterday his unsuccessful efforts over a period of years to bid for railroad financing.

HONG KONG, March 3 -- Twenty-four Chinese, including five students, five members of a left-wing weavers' union and fourteen laborers were arraigned today on "breach of peace" charges arising from Saturday's riot at Kowloon.

General Ridgway's criticism of those who ask "Why are we in Korea?" may be natural enough, for he is in a very difficult position. But natural, too, is the question itself, and discredit can hardly be attached to those who ask it, for it comes as a direct result of the way in which the whole Korean business has been and is being conducted.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Tim Holland, University of Miami student from Rockville Centre, L. I., and David A. Perkins of Ormond Beach, Fla., tied for medal honors in the annual South Florida golf tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. They fired one-under-par 69's to pace a qualifying field of sixty-six.

CINCINNATI, March 3 -- New methods permitting more efficient concentration of a 2,000,000-volt X-ray beam against advanced cancers otherwise inaccessible to treatment were described here today at the National Cancer Conference.
Edwin E. Howard has been appointed regional personnel manager in the personnel administration department of General Foods Corporation.

One of the most attractive novelties that the adventurous Thomas Scherman and his Little Orchestra Society have introduced to New York appeared on the program of last night's eighth and closing concert of the season's regular series at Town Hall.

A new electronic device, in which vacuum tubes are almost completely replaced by "transistors" -- bits of laboratory magic half as large as the average match --received its first public showing yesterday. The demonstration was given at the opening of the Institute of Radio Engineers' fortieth anniversary convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Apartment buildings figured in Bronx realty transactions reported yesterday.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The State Automobile Dealers Association charged today that the Dewey Administration's bill setting up a state-operated system of compulsory inspection of motor vehicles contained "serious and incurable defects."

Amateur humorists who persist in retailing talking dog stories just haven't kept pace with progress. The General Electric Company has a new and improved refrigerator that not only talks but walks. The company is sending the unit, electronically controlled and animated, on the road for its fifth year as a sales promotion stunt.

The notion that "Taft can't win" and that the "independent" voters will vote only for Eisenhower is being widely disseminated. Q. E. D., Eisenhower must be named for the Presidency by the Republican convention.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 22 to 38 points net lower on active months than on Friday.

Winter greens, plentiful now for summer hungry tastes, are high in vitamins and minerals and low in cost. Whether served in salad or as a cooked vegetable, spinach, lettuce, escarole, kale, endive and chicory are in a good position to compete with leafy canned or frozen counterparts.

Miguel Najdorf of Argentina retained first place with a score of 6 -- 1 in the international chess masters tournament at the Club Capablanca yesterday. His seventhround match with Erich Eliskases, Argentine rival, was drawn in forty moves, according to a report from Havana.

William Wyler, the Paramount director-producer, w/ll spend most of the summer in Italy' making "Roman Holiday," according to present plans. William Holden and Audrey Hepburn, who made a hit on Broadway recently, will be costarred in this comedy by Ian Hunter about a European princess who tosses aside family traditions and falls in love with an Amerlcanl newspaper reporter.

HONOLULU, March 3 -- One of Hawaii's two Federal grand juries was ordered into action today by Judge J. Frank McLaughlin as a dispute between the jurist and Hawaii's other Federal Judge, Delbert E. Metzger, over the validity of the jury lists continued.

In an effort to aid both builders and land owners in the development of large housing tracts, B. J. Bergton of Teaneck, N. J., has devised an option plan whereby the builder buys only the amount of land for his immediate needs. He takes an option on the remainder of the tract for future development if conditions are favorable.
Kentucky and Illinois kept rolling along atop The United Press basketball rankings, but a big battle shaped up yesterday for third place.

The Supreme Court's decision will have "no immediate effect" on the proceedings in this city, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday. Eight public school teachers have been dismissed and eight others face departmental trials for refusing to say whether they were members of the Communist party.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 3 (AP) -- Puerto Ricans voted overwhelmingly today to ratify their new Constitution.

PHOENIX, March 3 -- Leo Durocher put his squad through more than two hours of practice today on the muddy field of Municipal Stadium. But the sun blazed down warmly and despite the treacherous footing, the players had a good day.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- An attack upon the new Federal gambling tax was rejected today by the Supreme Court, which did not pass upon the Constitutionality of the levy. Through a formal order, the high court sustained the action of a lower tribunal on the basis that an injunction had been sought to protect a criminal business.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- A United Nations body of experts on journalism agreed today to give high priority to the consideration of ways of removing the obstacles to the free flow of information.

The first four housing projects -- totaling in cost $83,992,000 -- proposed by Robert Moses' Committee on Slum Clearance Plans for construction by private capital with federal and local aid have now been approved by the City Planning Commission. This is the first major step under a new program for the redevelopment of substandard housing areas to accommodate middle-income families at rentals within their income range.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 4 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,178, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M. Tuesday (4 P. M., Monday, Eastern standard time):

BONN, Germany, March 3 -- The organized non-Communist agitation against rearmament has attained such proportions in West Germany that the Government's ability to win a majority for a defense contribution in the Bundestag is being questioned by some Allied officials.

Trans World Airlines filed a brief with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday asking that its international route certificate be made permanent. The company asserted that balanced competition would he assured between this nation's air transport carriers serving the important routes to Europe, Africa, and the East.

DETROIT, March 3 -- Two stewards for the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., named as Communists at a hearing of the House Un-American Activities Committee here last week, were dismissed today from their jobs at Dodge plants. They were Miss Edith Van Horn, a chief steward at the Dodge main plant in suburban Hamtramck, and Paul Henley, at the Dodge engine plant.

New proof that lighting today's home is one subject on which no two designers appear to think alike may be seen in some new fixtures at Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street. Two groups are represented, each quite different from the other.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court decided today that the Secretary of Agriculture lacked the power to order payments to milk cooperatives for disposing of milk during seasons of high production.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 (AP) -- The Peiping radio said today that Gen. Kim Il Sung, chairman of the Military Council and Premier of North Korea, had issued a decree placing the country in a virtual state of emergency to combat bubonic plague.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate shunted the Hawaii statehood bill into the background today as it decided to consider instead Administration-opposed legislation to give to the states involved the profits from oil and other deposits lying beneath their offshore seas.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Supreme Court upheld in a 6-to-3 decision today the constitutionality of New York's Feinberg Law.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 3 (UP) -- Jack Burke Jr. calmly rolled in a 20-foot putt for a birdie 3 today to win the $10,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament's "sudden-death" play-off and his third consecutive major tourney victory.
Net earnings of the Pure Oil Company in 1951 rose to $33,593,727 or $7.88 a common share, second-highest in its thirty-eight-year history from the $30,329,084 or $7.06 a common share earned in 1950.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Governor Dewey urged the Legislature tonight to reappropriate $25,000,000 for a state-wide bomb shelter program and to memorialize Congress to pay one-half the cost of any shelter activity undertaken by the state or its localities.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 -- A trickle of foreign capital has returned to the Mexican oil industry. But there is no indication under present circumstances, which are unlikely to change, that the country can attract the kind of investment needed to regain its place as a factor in the world oil situation.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Port and grain interests of Baltimore and Philadelphia asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to make a comparative study of the cost of handling grain for export at the ports of New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore.

BERLIN, N. H., March 3 (AP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, said tonight that when General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower completed his job in Europe, the general would be "a fighting campaigner who will make every Truman bureaucrat and demagogue take out for the high hills."

The stock market gained slightly yesterday but the absence of business and the slight alterations in prices, except in scattered instances, produced no definite result. It was one of the most inconclusive sessions of the year. Traders showed no indication that they would do more than stand pat on present holdings pending an indication that funds might return to the market after the tax payment date.

Following the successful agreements reached by the statesmen of the Western World at Lisbon the struggle to convert the Atlantic community from a paper organization into a living reality has now been transferred to the Parliaments of the member nations which must ratify these agreements and raise the funds for putting them into effect.
RACINE, Wis., March 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft challenged the Democratic party tonight to make a campaign issue of the Taft-Hartley law in the forthcoming elections.
The nation-wide shortage of nurses has hit New York harder than any other large city in the country.

All parking in Times Square will be prohibited effective Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Acting Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. The new ban will be on a twenty-four-hour, seven-day-a-week basis and will take in both sides of the square between Forty-second and Forty-seventh Streets.

The drive by Joseph P. Ryan, lifetime president of the International Longshoremen's Association, A. F. L., to close the anti-Communist club set up last month by Anthony Anastasia gained momentum yesterday as Mr. Ryan met with union officials in Brooklyn.
The storm-battered Liberty ship Rachel Jackson is expected to dock this afternon at Pier 37, Hudson River, still in command of her valiant, painfully injured master, Capt. William R. Thomas.

Blood collections for the American Red Cross here in February totaled 27,213 pints, slightly short of the 30,000-pint quota for the New York region. Dr. William M. Markel, regional administrator of the blood program, attributed the shortage to the short month and two holidays.

Federal intervention is being sought to settle the controversy involving the importation of foreign scenery. Awaiting the decision from Ralph Wright, assistant Secretary of Labor, are the United Scenic Artists, Local 829, of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, A. F. L., and the League of New York Theatres, the group of producers and theatre operators.

Of 121 New York Central Railroad commuters interviewed by members of the Citizens' Commuters Committee, which is opposing a 30 per cent rate rise sought by the line, ninety-seven would change their commuting habits if the increase is granted, the Public Service Commission was told yesterday.

Every salesman is selling to an individual and every buyer is purchasing a performance, and not a product. H. B. Sharer, sales training specialist for the United States Rubber Company, told the Sales Executive Club of New York at a meeting yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

THOSE who have in the past charged the New York Conservation Department with failure to "take a firm stand" in fish and game matters can relax, for the department now seems up to its ears in two matters that are definitely "firm," the management of the Forest Preserve and the proposed antlerless deer bill.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The House of Representatives refused today to authorize the Administration to start a program of Universal Military Training for men at 18 years of age, followed by seven and a half years of Reserve obligation.
GENEVA, March 4 -- Western Europe is in one of its moods of feeling economically inadequate, almost hopelessly inadequate, to the tasks before it.

The board of directors of the Queens County Chamber of Commerce went on record yesterday as favoring the continued operation of La Guardia Airport and of the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, under air traffic reforms protecting the residents of the area.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Charles E. Wilson, Defense Mobilization Director, called today for a two-year extension of price, wage and other economic controls needed to insure the nation's attainment of goals of military strength sought by the end of 1954.

Frank Erickson, nationally known gambler, was indicted yesterday on charges of income tax evasion by the special Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury, which is investigating bribery, corruption and tax frauds.
ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate approved by a vote of 34 to 18 today the Metcalf-Hatch Bill to permit the requisitioning of animals from publicly-aided pounds for medical research.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The Wage Stabilization Board approved a pension plan today for 18,000 West Coast longshoremen employed by shipping companies in the Pacific Maritime Association.

There was no assurance yesterday that Mayor Impellitteri would have enough support from his Democratic colleagues in the Board of Estimate, the City Council or the State Legislature to put into effect the higher subway fare and 3 per cent sales tax package that reports from Albany indicated was in the cards being dealt by the Republican-controlled state administration.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Truman expressed "keen interest" today in the establishment of a suitable cemetery and memorial for 256 Marylanders who were killed in a heroic rear-guard action that saved Washington's army in the battle of Brooklyn, often known as the Battle of Long Island.

GENEVA, March 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Karin Kock, head of the Swedish Government's Bureau of Statistics, was today unanimously elected Chairman of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe for the third year.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The United States accused Communist Czechoslovakia today of having seized and jailed a United States Army corporal more than a year ago, held him incommunicado and then turned him over to Poland last month.

Many a father who is busy getting established fails to realize that "half of what he is here for on earth is to enjoy his children and teach them how to enjoy life and be useful," Dr. O. Spurgeon English, Professor of Psychiatry at Temple University's Medical School, said here last night.

PARIS, March 4 -- While putting off his reply tonight, Antoine Pinay, former Minister of Public Works, was expected to agree tomorrow to ask the French National Assembly Thursday to endorse him as Premier.

The 1952 International Ice Patrol will begin today, when a converted B-17 observation plane will take off from Argentia, Nfld., to range the expanse of the North Atlantic in search of icebergs and ice fields dangerous to navigation.
Prices on the cotton futures market here closed irregular yesterday 15 points higher to 4 points lower than on Monday

I regret that I must take exception to your editorial article of March 2 in relation to one-way traffic on Seventh and Eighth Avenues. In it you implied that the New York City Omnibus Corporation was alone in its opposition to the plan of Acting Commissioner Wiley to do away with two-way traffic on these two thorough-fares. The facts of the case do not bear out any such assumption.

Although Government can keep interest rates artificially low for a time, recent developments show that it cannot "control" rates, George B. Roberts, vice president of the National City Bank of New York, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to allow the 15-year-old granddaughter of James C. Dunn to retain her American citizenship while continuing to live abroad with him.

The Feinberg Law was pushed through the New York Legislature toward the end of the session in March, 1949. It implements provisions of the State Civil Service Law that forbid employment of teachers who advocate or who belong to organizations that advocate forcible overthrow of the Government.

Tommy Ryan, suspended fight manager, obtained an order yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen requiring the State Athletic Commission to show cause Thursday why its ruling revoking Ryan's license should not be rescinded.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 4 -- The "independent oil crowd" was accused today by Gov. Earl Warren of pouring money into the California Republican Presidential primary campaign in an attempt to defeat him.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 4 -- Carroll Binder, editorial editor of The Minneapolis Tribune, told a United Nations committee of twelve news experts today that there was growing opposition in the United States to the treatment of freedom of information matters within the United Nations.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 5 (AP) -- General Headquarters communique 1,179, for twenty-four hours ended 6 A. M., Wednesday (4 P. M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 5 -- The Korean truce negotiations reached a complete deadlock yesterday on all disputed points when Communist and United Nations negotiators failed to find an answer to the impasse over the voluntary repatriation of prisoners, inclusion of the Soviet Union as one of the "neutral" armistice controllers and designation of ports of entry at which impartial inspectors should be stationed after a cease-fire.
The United States Plywood Corporation moved yesterday to place prices of its products on an even keel in a market that has gone up and down like a roller coaster in the last year.

Despite limitations on foreign exchange and supplies of materials, expanding industrial development in Latin America and elsewhere makes it essential that this country maintain a steady flow of foreign investment to assure future export sales as well as imports of essential materials.

PARIS, March 4 -- Senator Tom Connally's remark that France would not deserve United States aid if she did not do all she could to defend herself was published conspicuously in leading Paris newspapers today.

Powerful, low slung cars, capable of zooming around the Indianapolis Speedway at 180 miles an hour, were among the $675,000 worth of automotive exhibits at the International Auto Sport Show that opened yesterday at the 104th Field Artillery Battalion Armory, Jamaica, Queens.

Subpoenas for officials of the New York and Brooklyn offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau were issued yesterday by Magistrate Phillip B. Thurston in Traffic Court after two certificates submitted by motorists had been declared to be of suspicious origin.

In honor of "Paris '90," which opened at the Booth last evening, Cornelia Otis Skinner has created her most elaborate one-woman show. It begins with a vivid poster curtain made by Donald Oenslager out of French lithographs of the period; and it comes to life in the gay overture Kay Swift has composed.

Consolidated net sales of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., for the first quarter ended on Jan. 26 increased to $87,336,961 from the $76,637,330 volume for the corresponding period a year earlier, Robert T. Stevens, board chairman of the textile company, reported at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

BERLIN, March 4 -- The two suburban districts of Rudow and Buckow, in the United States sector of Berlin, were blacked out suddenly at 7 o'clock tonight as East Berlin authorities cut electrical power that they have been supplying to West Berlin by interzonal agreement.

Minneapolis, Minn., sold yesterday $3,320,000 of various purpose bonds due April 1, 1953 to 1982, to Phelps, Fenn Co. and associates at a bid of 100.66 for interest of 1.90 per cent. The bankers bought also $996,962 of the city's street improvement bonds due April 1, 1953 to 1972, at a bid of 100.06 for 1 3/4 s.

In a special message on Feb. 11 President Truman asked Congress for a two-year extension of the Defense Production Act, placing major emphasis on stiffening its anti-inflation provisions. He called particularly for repeal of the Capehart, Herlong and Butler- Hope Amendments, which were added last summer when the bill was first extended

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 4 -- A new effort to organize Republican state chairmen into a country-wire organization and the presentation of a new idea to help capture the farm vote in the 1952 Presidential election will be made at a meeting of the twenty-state Midwest and Rocky Mountain Conference of Republican State Chairmen at Phoenix, Ariz., on Friday and Saturday.

Dairy farmers in the five-state milkshed serving metropolitan New York said yesterday they would bring court action, if necessary, to compel Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan to discontinue in this area the type of payments to milk cooperatives that were outlawed by the United States Supreme Court on Monday in a case brought by farmers in the Boston milkshed.

The price war in phonograph records continued with added vigor yesterday as more and more stores jumped into the act. By the end of the day Macy's, Gimbels, Abraham Straus and other stores were selling many selections at or below wholesale prices.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Prof. Owen Lattimore rejected today as "absolutely implausible," or unworthy of belief, a suggestion that the Soviet Union once had used the Institute of Pacific Relations as a "cover shop" for spying.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 4 -- One of the worst train disasters in Brazil's history occurred near the capital this morning, killing at least 102 persons and injuring 200, of whom fifty were on the danger list. Accurate figures still were impossible to get this evening because of the scale of the catastrophe and the consequent confusion, but the death toll was expected to mount above the present total.

The plan of the New York State Board of Regents to establish a network of non-commercial television stations for educational purposes continues to hang precariously in the balance in Albany. Although the need for prompt action was made clear some weeks ago, the Republican leadership of the Legislature has failed to rise to an opportunity which may not present itself again for many years.
CINCINNATI, March 4 -- Transformation of a plant cancer into normal healthy tissue has been achieved for the first time at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, New York.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 4 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of New York, president of the World Council of Churches, attacked tonight what he called "a new breed of self - appointed un - American vigilantes" as a threat to the nation's freedom.

Synthetic fibers, which have replaced wool in some industries, have entered a new field, heretofore thought impregnable. They are now being used to make papermakers' felts -- the wide continuous belts which run through the papermaking machine, carrying the pulp during its gradual conversion into Paper.

The idea of trying to do "Peer Gynt" in three weekly half-hour installments, with each installment divided into two parts by a middle commercial, might seem theatrical audacity carried to a questionable extreme. As a matter of fact, it probably is, but Albert McCleery, producer of the Cameo Theatre, certainly is giving the dramatic stunt an earnest and interesting try.
GUATEMALA, March 4 -- Today's action adds to the troubles of United Fruit here. The company faces the sale of its Tiquisate plantations at a public auction tomorrow.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Eight antique automobiles, led by a 1913 Stanley Steamer, struggled through a blizzard here today from the Drake Hotel to the main post office in commemorating the first half-century of the American Automobile Association.
ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate approved and sent to the Assembly today the bill that would strip the United States Trotting Association of its licensing powers over harness racing officials.
JACKSON, Miss., March 4 (UP) -- A Negro corporal furloughed from Korea to be a Government witness testified today that a former Sheriff had him flogged in an attempt to force a false confession.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 4 (AP) -- Oregon Democrats, "after conversations with Washington," decided today not to file President Truman as a candidate in the state's May 16 Democratic primary.

MILWAUKEE, March 4 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, completed today a pre-primary bid in the First and Second Congressional Districts of Wisconsin for the support of the state's thirty delegates.
The United States has undergone a social revolution in the last four decades, and particularly since the late Thirties.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- The defending champion, a former winner, and a co-medalist were beaten today in the first round of match play in the South Florida amateur golf championship.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- A historic, friendly chapter in the somewhat strained relationship between television and motion pictures will be written into the record on March 16 when the C. B. S. Television network will go behind the scenes in the Samuel Goldwyn studio to show how a motion picture is made.

LONDON, March 4 -- Although volume of business on the stock markets dwindled today there was slight improvement, caused largely by professional balancing of books in advance of next Tuesday's budget. Some British funds went a little lower in the closing stages.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Carl Furillo, the Dodgers' lead-off man in ninety-one games last year, was dropped to the eighth spot when Manager Chuck Dressen announced tomorrow's line-up of regulars after today's workout.
Yesterday's cold and unpleasant drizzle turned into a freakish rainstorm shortly after 9 o'clock last night. There was thunder and lightning and in parts of New Jersey hail fell.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Grain futures developed a stronger tone after declines in the early pit operations today. Overnight-selling orders caused dips in all grains at the start, with March oats down 2 1/2 cents. However, early setbacks were short-lived and there was a gradually tightening market later.

The 1952 custom - made spring collection of Bergdorf Goodman is a well-rounded one in which two knowing and experienced designers -- Mary Gleason and Leslie Morris -- have created smart and youthful clothes for the dignified woman, and young and dainty ones for the sophisticate.

A 21-year-old youth, who charged that on New Year's Day in 1951 he had been beaten by a policeman in the West Forty-seventh Street police station, testified yesterday at the trial of a suspended patrolman, William A. Tierney, that Tierney had ordered him "to run across the room, I want some target practice."

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today the public was being used as "guinea pigs" by a few "careless, indifferent or unscrupulous" cosmetics makers and asked authority to pre-test new cosmetics.

Price roll-backs in men's suits, some as high as $7, will become effective tomorrow with the showing of the spring line of Ripley Clothes, it was announced yesterday by S. O. Newman, president. Ripley operates twenty-six retail stores selling popular priced men's clothing.

A new hydrophobic resin finish for rayon textiles was announced yesterday by the Sun Chemical Company of Long Island City, Queens. Ernest Nathan, vice president, said the finish constituted a new type of compound that would impart, in one operation, durable water repellency, spot and stain resistance, crush resistance and shrink resistance.

LONDON, March 4 -- Former Prime Minister Clement Attlee and his moderate leadership of the Labor party won a striking victory over Aneurin Bevan, left-wing leader, whose political fortunes have been rising lately, at a private meeting today of the Labor members of Parliament.

EVER since Xenophon wrote "The March of the Ten Thousand" defeat and retreat have been the themes of a surprising percentage of the good books about men at war. There's something about courage in the face of overwhelming disaster that has a different and perhaps stronger appeal to the imagination than victory itself.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration said today it had tightened the terms under which it guaranteed private loans for World War II veterans to purchase business automobiles.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Allocations of scarce materials for the production of consumer goods in the coming quarter were announced by the National Production Authority today but were already out of date before the totals were made public.

I believe that Americans should know why the Red Army celebrates its "birthday" throughout the world every year on Feb. 23. That day in Berlin a "sumptuous reception for thousands of guests including John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner of Germany," was held by the Soviet authorities.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- All-America Dick Kazmaier said today that curtailment of spring football practice "is not beneficial" to the college game.

A prison sentence of fifteen and one-half to twenty-eight years was imposed yesterday in General Sessions on James J. Moran, former First Deputy Fire Commissioner, convicted as "guiding genius" of a $500,000-a-year fuel oil shakedown racket.

NAPLES, Italy, March 4 -- An intensive bombardment of the Sardinian coast by a combined United States, British, French and Italian naval force of eight cruisers and ten destroyers was the high-light today of Exercise Grand Slam, which for the last eight days and nights has seen the fleets and planes of the four Mediterranean allies locked in realistically simulated combat.

Operations of Glenn L. Martin Company, aircraft manufacturer, resulted in 1951 in a net loss of $22,178,000, according to the preliminary proxy statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- Eddie Stanky wears his new managerial toga as gracefully and as naturally as if he'd been born to the purple like John McGraw. There's a world of wisdom in his young head and there's the ring of authority in his voice. He is a leader of men and the pity of it is that the Cardinals haven't given him more gifted performers to lead.
Going over the heads of their Governments, President Truman yesterday broadcast directly to the peoples of Soviet Russia and Red China a message of peace, hope and friendship.

M. J. Martin and D. S. Starring have been elected directors of Penick Ford, Ltd. Mr. Martin, who joined the company in 1920, was elected vice president in charge of packaged goods sales in 1947. Mr. Starring is president of Starring Co., Inc., manufacturers of electrical devices, and a director of the Bridgeport Brass Company, Premium Oil and Gas Company and Sandar Corporation.

NEW DELHI, March 4 -- Apparently continuing its cultural and economic propaganda assault upon India on a non-stop basis, the Soviet Union is opening an art exhibition in New Delhi tomorrow while coincidentally approaching Indian representatives to attend the International Economic Conference in Moscow next month.

BOSTON, March 4 (UP) -- For the first time in seven important games the Boston Bruins staged a "blue-chip" performance tonight, beating New York, 4 -- 1, and moving into a fourth-place tie with the Rangers before 5,697 fans at Boston Garden.

Proposals for augmenting the nation's aluminum supply through a seven-year purchase contract with Canada for 3,500,000,000 pounds of that country's metal in ingot form and through additional domestic expansion of productive facilities have been drafted by Samuel W. Anderson, deputy administrator for aluminum of the Defense Production Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The military in some cases has thrown Government investigators into the brig for trying to fund out what happened to public funds at military posts, one of them has testified.

The airy shapes and colorful patterns produced by craftsmen in the Venini glass factory in Murano, Italy, go on display here today at Georg Jensen beside the more solid and somberly colored designs made in Sweden by Orrefors.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Miss Marjorie Lindsay, Curtis Cup golfer from Decatur, Ill., fired 37, 36 -- 73, one over men's par for the 6,367-yard Ponce De Leon course today to capture the medal in the twenty-fourth Florida East Coast women's golf tournament.

Let's hope the national criminal network never gets its hands on a perfected model of a device to aid clerical routine which is now in the experimental stage. The Eastman Kodak Company is working on a contraption for making inexpensive copies of documents in less than a minute.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The continued existence of Champlain College, the four-year liberal arts college established by the State University in Plattsburg, was threatened today by a request from the Federal Government that its site be converted to an Air Force base.

Ralph L. Van Name, secretary of the New York City Employes Retirement System, notified Mayor Impellitteri yesterday of his retirement, effective next June 2. At the same time, he resigned from the State Pension Commission in a letter to Governor Dewey criticizing the Governor for allegedly trying to gain control of the commission.

Count Ferdinando Sarmi of Italy was the creater of the spring custom order collection for Elizabeth Arden shown yesterday at 691 Fifth Avenue. His quick understanding of the American woman's demand for chic plus wearability was readily seen in the clothes.

The musicians of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony were seen at work yesterday in paintings done by students of the Art Students League who were invited a few weeks ago to "do" the orchestra at rehearsal. The results of their work were put on display in the Carnegie Hall Art Gallery, which also is Carnegie Hall's refreshment room.

BONN, Germany, March 4 -- West Germany received an allocation of $30,000,000 today under the United States Mutual Security Aid program and may be getting a good deal more money shortly, depending upon the extent to which the United States may have to go to the aid of France and other participants in the Western defense.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The air approaches to the United States now are guarded by about 300 all-weather jet fighter planes kept on constant alert. The number is increasing.

TRENTON, March 4 -- Political activity in New Jersey brought the prospect today that Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat, might enter the Presidential preference primary on April 15 and that voters might be asked to write in the name of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Republican.
Although the need for blood for the armed forces is still great, the Red Cross announced yesterday that the quota for March in the New York region has been set at 27,000 pints.

It is common knowledge that there is a great deal of resentment in Europe against the United States. I, as a citizen of the United States, living with my family and working in Europe on the problem of intergroup relations, am especially sensitive to this irritation and bitterness.

There seems to be a moment in the lives of eleven-year-olds when they become feverish correspondents. It may be impossible to get them to write a note to Uncle Frank thanking him for the gift of a genuine Indian headdress from Atlantic City; but one sort of writing they will do without end, even to the envelope-addressing, so long as a parent will furnish the stamps.
GUATEMALA, March 4 (AP) -- The United States-owned United Fruit Company won a partial victory today in a labor dispute that had been represented as threatening the company's survival in this country.
PHOENIX, March 4 -- Encouraging signs of his pitching strength came to Leo Durocher today and the Giant skipper made no effort to conceal his satisfaction.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 4 -- World tinplate production dropped to 5,640,000 tons in 1951 from the 1950 figure of 5,753,000 tons, the International Tin Study Group reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Senate, off to a slow start on what promised to be prolonged debate over Federal-vs.-state control of offshore oil resources, found itself confronted by an unusual mid-session traffic jam today.
In a far-reaching realignment of its executive staff, McCann-Erickson, Inc., adverttising agency, has promoted seven of its key men.

LONDON, March 4 -- Warnings of "racial conflict" and "disaster" were given in the House of Commons today by critics of the Conservative Government's plan to hold a conference next month to consider a constitution for a Central African Federation.

A high - frequency electronic "sandwich," representing a new principle that soon may be essential in the planning of tomorrow's "inexpensive but efficient" nationwide television networks, was shown here yesterday for the first time at the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Truman became the Voice of America today and sent a message of hope and peace around the world.
At the moment the Grand CenI I tral Palace is a galaxy of eonfusion--a maze of whirling disks and sparks and vacuum tubes.
LONDON, March 4 (Reuters) -- The sterling area's dollar deficit dropped sharply in February for the first time in months, it was learned today.
In commodity futures trading in New York yesterday there were small gains, small losses and a generally irregular pattern.
Eastman Kodak Company increased sales last year by 18 1/2 per cent to a record $542,284,510 from the $457,778,775 volume for 1950, but the pressure of taxes reduced earnings sharply.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate approved unanimously today two bills that would continue cost-of-living pay increases granted to 70,000 state employes last year and give them an additional 6 per cent increase for the year beginning April 1.

A Doberman pinscher with chills, a canary with an appetite like a bird and a guinea pig that has been feeling rather poorly lately all received routine physical checkups yesterday in the Ellen Prince Speyer hospital's Petmobile. Pets of the children of Manhattanville Day Nursery, 71 Old Broadway, were brought to the clinic as part of the nursery's observance of Day Care Week officially proclaimed by the Mayor.

MONTREAL, March 4 (AP) -- The Montreal Athletic Commission fined Sandy Saddler, world featherweight champion, $500 today and said he was lucky he was not suspended for his conduct in his bout last night with Armand Savoie of Montreal.

CLAREMONT, N. H., March 4 (UP) -- Senator Leverett Saltonstall, Republican of Massachusetts, appealed tonight to New Hampshire voters to make General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower the "broom" to sweep out the "dangerous corruption" of the Democratic Administration.
It was moving day yesterday for the North Shore chapter of the American Red Cross in Flushing, but right through the noisy confusion Miss Jane E. King worked on her card file.

Scandinavian regard for the interesting qualities of wood is apparent in a new collection of Danish furniture just arrived at Swedish Modern, 675 Fifth Avenue and available there through decorators. For these pieces, a variety of woods -- teak, beech, walnut and mahogany -- have been treated with a dull, rubbed finish that gives full play to the grain.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 4 (UP) --Howard Tate, 22, of Canton, Ohio, scored a three-round decision over Jesse Brown of Toledo to win the first Jack Dempsey international novice heavyweight tournament at the Sports Arena tonight.

ST. LOUIS, March 4 -- The Government today was forced to cross-examine one of its own key witnesses as an "adverse and hostile witness" in the prosecution of James P. Finnegan, former Collector of Internal Revenue.
An alert policeman on school-crossing post captured two men early yesterday who were allegedly fleeing after an attempted hold-up of a grocery store at 785 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx.

CINCINNATI, March 4 -- Religion and organized labor were described here today by Allan S. Haywood, executive vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as co-defenders of the democratic way of life and "logical partners" in combating the twin dictatorships of communism and fascism.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 4 (AP) -- The Dominican Republic's Secretary of War said today his country would complain to the United Nations Security Council that Russian submarines had violated Dominican territorial waters.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The sale of thirty-three surplus ships, among hundreds the Government campaigned to get rid of after World War II, brought fees and stock profits estimated at $1,267,200 to a small group of lawyers who stepped in, the Senate Permanent Investigating subcommittee heard today.
